title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Hotel Complex Is Planned
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority yesterday hired an Englewood Cliffs company, Kajima International, to develop a $250 million hotel and entertainment complex between Giants Stadium and the Continental Airlines Arena. The complex would be built on a 55-acre site now bisected by Route 120, which would have to be rerouted east of the arena, said Robert Mulcahy, the president of the sports authority.

title: TV WEEKEND;Alan Alda Returns to Neil Simon's Midlife Crisis
description: Neil Simon's adaptation, indeed rewrite, of his Broadway play "Jake's Women" can be seen Sunday on CBS. Alan Alda repeats his stage role as Jake with his customary skill. The supporting cast is strong: Anne Archer as Jake's second wife, Maggie; Mira Sorvino as his first wife, Julie, killed in a car accident; Julie Kavner as his sister, Karen; Joyce Van Patten as his analyst, Edith, and Lolita Davidovich as his exasperated girlfriend, Sheila.

title: Fetal Tissue Research Has Scientific Support
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;White Gives Thanks
description: Tears of thanks welled up in REGGIE WHITE's eyes when the Green Bay Packers defensive star accepted a $143,261 check from donations to rebuild the Tennessee church where he serves as an associate pastor.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Feb. 18 about the tennis player Chanda Rubin and her rise in the women's rankings misstated the number of siblings she has. She is the second of three children, not the elder of two.

title: TV SPORTS;Tribute on Ice Filled With Deep Emotions
description: It has become easy to grow fatigued by the glut of televised figure skating, but a tribute tonight to the late Sergei Grinkov on CBS from 9 to 11 o'clock has a curative effect. To watch the grief-and-rebirth program executed by Yekaterina Gordeyeva, Grinkov's widow and pairs partner, was stunning, as she shook her fists in rage, looked around the arena in disbelief, fell to her knees in mourning and willed tears into her eyes.

title: Police Arrest Man In Beating of Boy, 13
description: A 13-year-old Queens boy was hospitalized in critical condition yesterday after his parents allowed one of their friends to discipline him by beating him with a metal pipe, the police said.

title: David Rosenthal, 77, Genetics Researcher
description: Dr. David Rosenthal, an expert on schizophrenia and the role that genetics play in the disorder, died on Monday at a nursing home in Rising Sun, Md. He was 77, and had previously lived in Bethesda.

title: Inside Art
description: Estates for Galleries

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Vitamin to Protect Fetuses Will Be Required in Foods
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday that it would require all enriched foods to be fortified with folic acid, a vitamin that can prevent a common and devastating type of birth defect.

title: Episcopal Bishop in Heresy Trial Violated No Church Law
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Reader's Digest Layoffs
description: The Reader's Digest Association (Canada) Ltd. said today that it would lay off 90 workers, or 24 percent of its staff, in the next six months as part of a restructuring. The announcement comes a month after Joe Beaudoin took over as president and chief executive of the Canadian company, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of Reader's Digest Association Inc. of Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Help Wanted: Critic

title: Boy, 11, Is Arrested In Armed Robberies
description: An 11-year-old boy went on a shooting and robbery rampage on Tuesday before wounding a security guard who then held the boy for the police, the authorities said.

title: Former Bankers Trust Trader Settles Charges in Derivatives Case
description: A former Bankers Trust trader agreed today to pay $50,000 to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he misled Gibson Greetings Inc. on the value of derivatives the company had bought from Bankers Trust.

title: Do Rights or Economic Growth Come First? Asia and Europe Clash
description: I can think of at least 10 issues to seriously embarrass the Europeans," the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, said as the leaders of 25 Asian and European nations converged here for a meeting on trade and economics that opens on Friday.

title: Abroad at Home;First, Do Less Harm
description: Dr. Fred Ruder was a dentist in Panama City, Fla. He agreed to put some money in a business of his dental assistant's husband -- who turned out to be running marijuana.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Shaq Enjoys Feast on Continental Arena Cuisine
description: Before last night's contest, Shaquille O'Neal was asked how he would approach the game. O'Neal rubbed his hands together, opened his mouth, and acted as if he were taking a bite out of a sandwich.

title: POLITICS: NEW YORK;Buchanan's New York Drive: Low in Money, High in Zeal
description: From his home in Hempstead, L.I., Gary R. Grella frantically works the phone, distributes fliers and otherwise runs his slice of Patrick J. Buchanan's New York campaign with more than a little passion for what he calls "a populist uprising."

title: Pemex Reports Costs and Seeks Tax Break
description: Mexico's state oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, disclosed today how much it spends to get a barrel of crude oil equivalent out of the ground: an average $2.52 a barrel in 1995.

title: Beethoven, Now and Forever
description: Here are some favorite Beethoven recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 for a single CD to $48 for a triple-set.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MARUBENI TO ACQUIRE 29% STAKE IN SITHE ENERGIES
description: Sithe Energies Inc., an independent power producer, said yesterday that the Marubeni Corporation, a Japanese trading company, would acquire a 29 percent stake in Sithe by purchasing its outstanding shares for $15 each. Marubeni will pay about $250 million for its stake. It will also contribute $42 million to the company this year and $24 million on April 1, 1997. That $66 million will finance Sithe's investments in projects in the United States and elsewhere, Sithe's vice chairman, Barry F. Sullivan, said. Shares of Sithe more than doubled yesterday, to $14.50 from $5.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SOHEIR KHASHOGGI, a sister of Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi Arabian arms dealer, is another woman who has drawn partly from her own experiences to write a book. In her case it is a novel, "Mirage," a tale of romance, polygamy and sibling relationships in a fictitous Middle Eastern country. The book, which she said has been banned in Saudi Arabia, was published this week by Forge.

title: Beethoven, Now and Forever
description: Here are some favorite Beethoven recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 for a single CD to $48 for a triple-set.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart in Business Day on Feb. 22 about executive compensation misstated the 1994 revenues for Investment Technology Group Inc. The company's revenues totaled $56.7 million in 1994; they were $72 million in 1995.

title: Power Shopping in Los Angelas;Bloomingdale's Pushes Into a Crowd
description: Standing in the middle of the designer sportswear department at Nordstrom, Lisa Razin ticked off the differences between the department stores in the Southern California bazaar. Bullock's is her place to buy cutting-edge fashion, while Nordstrom is where she goes for cosmetics and party dresses. Robinsons-May has no clear-cut image at all.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Panel in Japan Proposing Phone Company Breakup
description: In what could presage a major overhaul of Japan's telecommunications market, a Government advisory committee called today for the breakup of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's main telephone service provider and the world's largest telephone company.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FRUEHAUF POSTS ANOTHER LOSS AND SEEKS A MERGER
description: As the Fruehauf Trailer Corporation posted a fourth-quarter loss of $4.46 million, or 11 cents a share, the company said yesterday that it had hired Oppenheimer & Company to help it find a merger partner. Fruehauf, which has posted losses in three of its last five quarters, said it expected a wave of mergers in the truck-and-trailer industry. Thomas B. Roller, Fruehauf's chief executive and president, said the company had been negotiating a merger or sale of assets with several parties for five months. The fourth-quarter results included a charge of $1.83 million, or 5 cents a share, for the early payment of debt, the company said. Fruehauf's shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $1, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DU PONT TO TRIM 1,500 JOBS AT TWO OF ITS UNITS
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that two of its major businesses would cut about 1,500 employee and contractor jobs to increase competitiveness. Du Pont said it expected to take a first-quarter charge of about $27.8 million, or 5 cents a share, to cover the cost of the cuts at Du Pont Nylon North America and Du Pont Dacron. The chemical and energy company, based in Wilmington, Del., said the cuts would include 1,200 employee positions and 300 contractor jobs. Du Pont said some of the employees would be transferred but about 800 were expected to be laid off. The company's shares fell $1.25 yesterday, to $76.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Exploring Asia, Americana and Form
description: Eliot Feld's restless intelligence was a hallmark of the program presented by Feld Ballets/NY on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. In the evening's three revivals, Mr. Feld shifts from a pure-dance exploration of form in "The Grand Canon" to mysterious and perfumed exoticism in "Asia," with a stop along the way for a bit of Americana, neatly skewed, in "Santa Fe Saga." He takes a keen-eyed look at another kind of Americana in "Doo Dah Day," turning cherished tradition upside down literally, figuratively and unsettlingly.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Deere to Open Plant in Mexico
description: Reflecting the continuing impact of the North American Free Trade Agreement on corporate investment, Deere & Company said today that it would build a new diesel engine factory for $100 million in Torreon, Mexico.

title: Baby's Move Ends a Battle Over Her Fate
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, yesterday helped arrange for the transfer of a brain-dead infant from a Queens hospital that was unwilling to continue caring for her to a Catholic hospital in Manhattan, which will presumably let her remain on a mechanical ventilator until her heart stops beating.

title: A Battle Royal Looms on Divorce
description: A day after Diana, the Princess of Wales, said she had reluctantly agreed to divorce her estranged husband, Prince Charles, it became increasingly clear that her ringing threat last year to "not go quietly" had been deadly serious.

title: Milken Must Remain on Probation During S.E.C. Inquiry
description: A Federal judge extended the probation of Michael R. Milken yesterday while the Securities and Exchange Commission completes an investigation into his recent business dealings, including advice he gave Ted Turner on his company's sale to Time Warner Inc.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;A copywriter-turned-producer is bringing the lighter side of Madison Ave. to the tube.
description: TELEVISION'S take on advertising has careened from the broad burlesques of "Bewitched" to the traumatic dramatics of "Thirtysomething" to the soap-opera antics of "Melrose Place." Now a one-time copywriter at New York agencies will try bringing Madison Avenue to Middle America in the form of a workplace comedy.

title: Israel's Bumper-Sticker Wars: Counterattack From the Right
description: There's a new bumper sticker on the traffic-choked streets of Jerusalem these days, a right-wing response to memorial stickers distributed after the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

title: Tax Error By Vanguard
description: The Vanguard Group mailed incorrect tax-preparation materials to its more than five million fund shareholders that could result in people having to amend their tax returns to the Internal Revenue Service, Vanguard said today.

title: DESIGN REVIEW;God of Style Was in the Details
description: At a time when fashion is all about "cool" and dressing down in the simplest, most unadorned clothing, it's exhilarating to see an exhibition of elegant clothes with exquisite details from a time when dressing up in finery was the ideal.

title: BASEBALL;For Boggs, A Big Goal And Talent To Reach It
description: Wade Boggs will not reach 3,000 hits this season he is 459 hits away -- but the Yankee third baseman intends to stick around until he does reach that milestone.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Charged in Bank Fraud
description: An Edison woman was accused in a Federal indictment yesterday of using a fake name, a nonexistent employer and phony Social Security numbers to persuade a judge to approve a fraudulent bankruptcy plan. Marlene Linton was also charged with bank fraud for supplying false information when she applied for a home mortgage, said Michael A. Guadagno of the United States Attorney's Office. She was among 123 people nationwide who have been charged in a crackdown on bankruptcy fraud that was announced yesterday by the United States Attorney General, Janet Reno.

title: On My Mind;Five Days to Answer
description: This is a question, addressed with urgency, to Senator Robert Dole and Steve Forbes. They have only five days, at most, to answer.

title: Restaurants
description: The crisp, airy flatbreads are swooping in and out of the dips. They hesitate over the smooth baba gannouj with its mingled flavors of sesame, smoke and eggplant and hover over the briney taramosalata, rich with roe. They fly through pine nuts and a slick of olive oil to touch down in the hummus and then splash off into tzatziki, that tangy yogurt and cucumber concoction.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bill on State Inmates Passes
description: Over Democrats' objections, a bill that would extend the state's authority to house its prisoners in county jails was approved yesterday by the Assembly. Joseph V. Doria Jr., the Assembly minority leader, said the bill is unfair to counties because the state does not pay the full cost of incarcerating its inmates.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Division III

title: Germany and U.S. Are Closer To Easing Limits on Air Travel
description: The United States and Germany agreed yesterday to drop restrictions on air travel between the two countries, though at least one important hurdle remains before the agreement can go into effect.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTUIT'S PROFITS RISE, BUT ITS STOCK SLIPS
description: Intuit Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 50 percent, but its stock fell after the company projected only modest revenue growth from its Quicken personal finance software this year. Intuit earned $21.9 million, or 46 cents a share in the quarter, which ended on Jan. 31, compared with $14.6 million, or 33 cents, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenues rose 32 percent, to $221.7 million. Revenues are expected to grow 30 percent in the second half of the year, but profits are expected to remain flat because of lower-margin sales of Quicken, higher expenses for its electronic banking service and difficulties in Germany, the company said. "While Quicken's total unit volumes are growing well, we expect only modest Quicken revenue growth" for 1996, the company's chairman, Scott D. Cook, said. The announcement came after the stock market closed, but the company's shares tumbled $4 in after-hours trading, to $62.75. Earlier, the shares rose $2 in Nasdaq trading.

title: BASEBALL;Series Tirade Will Cost Indians' Belle $50,000 Fine
description: Faced with the alternative of a 10-game suspension, Albert Belle of the Cleveland Indians accepted a $50,000 fine today for his dugout tirade against a television reporter before the third game of last year's World Series.

title: Market Place;Help Arrives For Pickens, But the Cost Is Very High
description: Even among the titans of the 1980's takeover era, T. Boone Pickens stood out for having the vision, the money and the gall to make derelict corporate chiefs with sagging stock prices quake.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Blue-Chip Losing Streak Extended on Debt Worries Blue-chip stocks extended their losing streak into a fourth session as traders reacted to testimony by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin that the United States could default on its debt by March 21 unless Congress raised the $4.9 trillion debt ceiling.

title: U.N. Mission To Haiti Is Reprieved
description: A last-minute offer by Canada to pay for hundreds of peacekeeping troops broke through a Chinese roadblock today and saved a mission in Haiti hours before it was set to expire.

title: GOLF;Janzen Seizes the Lead by Shooting an Artistic 63
description: The hints have been there since the season first began. A 65 in the second round of the Mercedes Championships at La Costa, a 66 in the third round at Tucson the next week. Ever since his back-to-back top-10 finishes to open the year, Lee Janzen has been threatening to go very deep under par, to shoot one of those absurdly low rounds.

title: Stroh to Buy Heileman in Big Brewery Deal
description: The Stroh Brewery Company said today that it planned to buy the G. Heileman Brewing Company in a complex deal estimated at $275 million to $300 million.

title: BASKETBALL;Manhattan's Hoover Is Out
description: Manhattan, which has spent the bulk of its basketball season recovering from the loss of its starting backcourt and injuries to two other players, was dealt another major setback yesterday when Jason Hoover was lost for this weekend's Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament at the Knickerbocker Arena in Albany.

title: 123 Reported Dead In Peru Plane Crash
description: A Faucett Airlines plane carrying 117 passengers and 6 crew members crashed last night in a canyon in southern Peru.

title: HOCKEY;Wing Eruption Crushes Isles
description: Nicklas Lidstrom and Dino Ciccarelli both had a goal and an assist in a four-goal second-period flurry tonight that carried the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-1 victory over the Islanders.

title: TV Executives Promise Clinton a Violence Ratings System by '97
description: Showcasing the persuasive powers of the Presidency, President Clinton today summoned the leaders of the entertainment industry to the White House and was rewarded with an industry pledge to produce a voluntary television ratings system by next January.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Nur Die, Rheine, Germany, a unit of the Vatter G.m.b.H. unit of the Sara Lee Corp., to TBWA Frankfurt, a unit of Omnicom Group, to handle its hosiery account, previously at Springer & Jacoby, Hamburg, Germany. The billings were estimated at $8 million. TBWA handles other Sara Lee brands like Hanes casual wear and Wonderbra. * Kenjo, New York, to the Levinson Group, New York, as the first agency to advertise the Kenjo Watches retail chain. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Moscow's $10 Billion Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund has taken a calculated gamble by promising Russia $10 billion if it sticks to a strict regimen of market reforms over the next three years. The Government of President Boris Yeltsin and Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin has been erratic and often ineffective. But it has kept federal spending in check and brought inflation down from astronomical levels to about 4 percent a month. Markets are not well in Russia, but they are alive. With additional help from the West, they might survive.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ABN Amro Posts Rise Of 14.4% in 1995 Profit
description: ABN Amro Holding N.V., the largest banking company in the Netherlands, said yesterday that its profit rose 14.4 percent in 1995, largely because of increased commission income from its international network. The company posted profit of 2.62 billion guilders, about $1.61 billion, compared with 2.29 billion guilders a year earlier.

title: 9-Year-Old Chokes to Death On Hot Dog Served in School
description: A 9-year-old girl apparently choked on a hot dog in the lunch room of her East Harlem elementary school yesterday and died shortly afterward. It was the second time such an incident has happened in a New York school in the last five years.

title: POLITICS;Despite Voters' Unhappiness, New Entries Seem Unlikely
description: Despite the inconclusive outcome of the early primaries and caucuses, the chance that a new candidate will enter the field for the Republican Presidential nomination is almost nil, students of Republican politics say.

title: Teledyne Rejects New WHX Offer
description: Teledyne Inc. said last night that it was rejecting the WHX Corporation's latest merger offer, even though it had been sweetened to $1.78 billion, from $1.67 billion on Monday.

title: Allied Signal to Sell Unit To Bosch for $1.5 Billion
description: Leaving a business that was losing money on an operating basis, Allied Signal Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its light-vehicle hydraulic and anti-lock brake business to Robert Bosch G.m.b.H., a German conglomerate, for $1.5 billion in cash.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal to postpone elections for local school boards in New York City referred incorrectly in some editions to the date of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's suspension of school boards in the Bronx. It was on Feb. 12, not in January.

title: Diner's Journal
description: I sure hope this is going to last in this neighborhood," said a friend I met waiting in line at Cosi Sandwich Bar. "We need someplace good to eat."

title: Administration Warns of an Early Shortfall in a Medicare Fund
description: The Clinton Administration said today that if Congress took no action, the trust fund that pays Medicare's hospital bills would probably run out of money in the middle of 2001, rather than at the end of 2002 as previously projected.

title: Richard Rainwater's Empire Adds Mesa
description: When T. Boone Pickens decided three weeks ago to strike a deal with Richard E. Rainwater to cede control of Mesa Inc., Mr. Rainwater did not go to see Mr. Pickens.

title: Sports Of The Times;O'Donnell Comes Into The Billfold
description: HE walked across the small stage to the podium with the facing green helmets, and his first message for the starving fans of the worst team in professional football was a promise to present himself in a manner befitting a team whose coach lines players up in numerical order for the national anthem.

title: Economic Yeast for a Stale Industry;New York Tries to Stem Loss of City Bakeries
description: The time passed long ago when the ovens of hulking bread factories like Silvercup and Taystee Bread in Queens filled pockets of the city's landscape with the robust aroma of fresh-baked bread. The Silvercup factory, hard by the East River in Long Island City, is now a television studio. Taystee's huge logo in Flushing beckoned to a web of highways before Stroehmann Bakeries closed its plant in 1992 and converted it into a Home Depot.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Chinese Aircraft Maker Said to Visit Fokker
description: A Chinese aircraft builder is looking into taking over the ailing aircraft maker Fokker N.V., a Dutch newspaper reported yesterday. The paper, De Telegraaf, said that a delegation from the China-based Aviation Industry General Corporation arrived in the Netherlands a few days ago to review Fokker's books. A Fokker spokesman refused to confirm the report. An Avic spokesman said he "didn't have any idea" about the visit.

title: 25 and Under
description: French to a T

title: INSIDE
description: A Talk With the I.R.A.

title: Major U.S. Recycler to Buy Large New York Trash Company
description: In the latest move by a large corporation into New York City's troubled garbage hauling industry, Waste Management Inc., the nation's biggest recycling company, said yesterday that it had agreed to a $200 million deal to buy one of the city's largest recycling and trash-collection companies.

title: Clinton Under Attack by Both Sides in a Renewed Logging Fight
description: When President Clinton paid a visit to Seattle last weekend, more than a thousand demonstrators protested legislation he had signed that exempts timber companies from having to comply with the nation's environmental laws while cutting old-growth trees on Forest Service land.

title: Keeping the Courts Independent
description: Gov. George Pataki of New York made the right decision when he referred the case of Judge Lorin Duckman to the Commission on Judicial Conduct instead of calling for an impeachment vote in the State Legislature, as he had first threatened. A hasty and politicized vote would contaminate the judicial process, making judges fearful of -- and vulnerable to -- retaliation from partisan politicians who might disagree with their rulings.

title: Irish Nationalists Starting to Agree Among Themselves
description: Gerry Adams and John Hume, the two most influential Roman Catholic political leaders in Northern Ireland, said today that they had met with Irish Republican Army officials on Wednesday and had come away with the impression that the group would restore the cease-fire it ended on Feb. 9.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIG O TIRES DISCUSSES A $54 MILLION SALE TO TBC
description: Big O Tires Inc., a chain of auto service stores, said yesterday that it was negotiating to sell the company to the TBC Corporation, an automotive replacement parts distributor, for about $54 million. Big O said TBC had offered a cash price of $16.50 a share for Big O, which has about 3.3 million shares outstanding. The shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to $14.50, in Nasdaq trading; the shares of TBC, based in Memphis, rose 25 cents, to $7.125. Big O, based in Englewood, Colo., said a previously announced merger agreement between Big O and a group of the company's managers and dealers was still in effect but could be terminated by either side.

title: GYMNASTICS;The U.S. Athletes Take Top 4 Spots
description: Men's preliminaries at the 21st annual American Cup tonight proved to be a scorefest for the home team, with United States athletes taking the top four spots.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Brothers McMullen 1995. Fox. $100.71. Laser disk, $39.98. 98 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMPDENT CORP., Atlanta, a dental practice management company, agreed to buy Dental Care Plus Management Corp., a managed dental-care provider in Illinois, for $27 million in cash and the assumption of $11 million in debt.

title: What to Hear, Where and When
description: Here is a sampling of forthcoming Beethoven events in Manhattan:

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Little Change In Treasury Prices in Day
description: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday in trading buffetted by mixed signals from economic reports and by comments from Federal Reserve officials that suggested the central bank might not be prepared to cut interest rates soon.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Nightmarish Ending For a Hollywood Dream
description: From the Journals of Jean Seberg" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 11. The film opens today at the Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: War Games Aren't Just Play Stuff
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Protesting Law on Prison Care
description: Advocates for people with AIDS demonstrated on the State House steps yesterday against a new law that could force inmates to pay for health care they receive while in custody, the A.P. reported.

title: Neediest Cases Drive Has Second-Best Total
description: with its second-highest total ever: $4,635,538. The 1995-96 drive had a surge in donations this week because of several large gifts, including several generous contributions from Wall Street firms, the proceeds from a New York Times employee book sale and a $10,000 donation from an advertising company.

title: Art In Review;Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: Home Video
description: Squeeze Play?

title: Inside Art
description: Estates for Galleries

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daiwa Bank Shares Rise
description: The shares of Daiwa Bank Ltd. rose yesterday after the bank agreed to pay $340 million in fines to settle fraud charges in the United States, bringing the bank's New York bond-trading scandal to a close. Traders called the fine a bargain since the bank had faced a maximum penalty of $1.3 billion. Daiwa shares rose as high as 734 yen before closing at 710 yen, up 18 yen, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: FILM REVIEW;A Mystical View of the South
description: "The Neon Bible" was shown as part of the 1995 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2. The film opens today at the Quad Cinema, 13th Street, west of Fifth Avenue, in Greenwich Village.

title: All 123 on Peruvian Jetliner Reportedly Killed in Crash
description: A Peruvian commercial jet crashed tonight in an Andean canyon in southern Peru, killing all 123 people aboard, an airport official said.

title: The Winners of the 1996 Grammy Awards
description: Here are the winners of the Grammy Awards, presented Wednesday night in Los Angeles.

title: Beethoven, Now and Forever
description: Here are some favorite Beethoven recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 for a single CD to $48 for a triple-set.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Mortgage rates rose this week as strong economic news and lingering uncertainty about a balanced-budget agreement pushed up bond rates, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.41 percent in the week ending Friday, up from 7.32 percent last week.

title: ART REVIEW;Edward Kienholz's Great Big Assault
description: The first big museum show of Edward Kienholz's garrulous, hectoring work, full of caustic indictments of American life, has finally come to New York, spreading 90 works through two big floors of the Whitney Museum of American Art. It's been nearly 35 years since "Roxys," a life-size environment depicting a Nevada whorehouse, replete with gruesomely distorted girls and a madam with a boar's skull for a head, established Kienholz as one of Los Angeles's premier artists. Indicting male lust and female complicity with equal ire, "Roxys" introduced an artist who mixed strands of Expressionism, Surrealism, Pop, Happenings and Conceptualism with the often fetid detritus of everyday life, no holds barred.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Surge in Gifts Lifts Fund To Second-Highest Total
description: having collected $4,635,538 so far, its second-highest total ever. The fund's record high is $5.08 million in 1991-92.

title: Gap Chief Gets $64.6 Million in Stock Sale
description: The chief executive of Gap Inc., Millard S. Drexler, made $64.6 million recently on a sale of 1.3 million shares of stock in the clothing retailer.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Scott and O'Neal Foil Nets' Best-Laid Plans
description: Butch Beard's game plan was to double down on Shaquille O'Neal and hope the Orlando Magic would not beat his team from the outside.

title: Agency Won't Sue Hillary Clinton's Former Law Firm
description: Officials of the Federal agency charged with investigating fraud in the savings and loan industry said today that they believe there were no grounds for a civil lawsuit against Hillary Rodham Clinton's former law firm in Arkansas for work done on behalf of a savings and loan owned by the Clintons' former business partner in the Whitewater land venture.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Angels in Miami Beach, Visiting a Transvestite
description: For a play devoted to the premise that life is a dance, Nilo Cruz's "Dancing on Her Knees," which opened last night at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, is remarkably unable to find its feet.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Virgin-Bechtel Group Picked for Rail Project
description: The British Government chose a group yesterday led by Virgin Group, headed by the entrepreneur Richard Branson, and Bechtel Inc., one of the world's largest civil engineering companies, to build and run a rail link between London and the Channel Tunnel. The Government will give the group a L1.4 billion subsidy to build the high-speed link, which is estimated to cost L3 billion, or $4.6 billion, and is scheduled to open in 2003. For Virgin, operating the 68-mile link fits Mr. Branson's plan to set up a pan-European rail and air network.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REVLON SHARES TRADE HIGHER AFTER PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Shares of Revlon Inc. traded higher yesterday after the company's initial public offering. Revlon, the New York-based cosmetics maker, sold 7.5 million shares -- 15 percent of its class A common stock -- at $24 each. The shares opened yesterday at $27.25 on the New York Stock Exchange, reached a high of $29.625 and closed at $27.625. Revlon, which is closely held by the financier Ronald O. Perelman's MacAndrews & Forbes Holding Inc., said it planned to use net proceeds from the offering to repay debt. The company said in November that it had about $2.2 billion in debt, much of it taken on when Mr. Perelman acquired the company in 1986 for $1.8 billion.

title: Beethoven, Now and Forever
description: Here are some favorite Beethoven recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 for a single CD to $48 for a triple-set.

title: Jobless Claims Fall in a Shorter Workweek
description: The number of Americans filing new claims for state unemployment benefits tumbled last week, but economists said today that the sharp drop did not signal any drastic improvement in the labor market.

title: House Approves Biggest Change In Farm Policy Since New Deal
description: The House today approved a major overhaul of American farm programs, voting to end 1930's policies that pay farmers not to plant certain crops and to replace many subsidies with fixed payments that would end after seven years.

title: JUDGE'S DECISION BOLSTERS GINGRICH
description: A Federal judge today threw out a major accusation involving Speaker Newt Gingrich, ruling that the political action committee Mr. Gingrich headed did not make illegal campaign contributions to him and other Republicans, as the Federal Election Commission had charged.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PAXSON AGREES TO BUY TWO RADIO STATIONS IN FLORIDA
description: The Paxson Communications Corporation of West Palm Beach, Fla., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two Florida radio stations for about $115 million. Paxson said it would acquire WXDJ-FM in Homestead and WRMA-FM in Fort Lauderdale from New Age Broadcasting Inc. and the Seventies Broadcasting Corporation. Paxson owns and operates radio and television stations. Its shares fell $1.25 yesterday, to $20, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. TO SHEPHERD PROTEST OFF CUBA BY AN EXILE GROUP
description: In a move aimed at heading off another confrontation between Cuba and anti-Castro activists, President Clinton today ordered the Coast Guard to escort Cuban-American protesters who plan to send boats and small airplanes into the Caribbean on Saturday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Slacker Who Will Do Anything (Anything!) to Avoid Work
description: A WHITE MERC WITH FINS By James Hawes 289 pages. Pantheon Books. $22.

title: News Analysis;Network Heads Agree and Disagree on Ratings Plan
description: Seldom have so many people who have so much direct power over what Americans find on their television screens been gathered together in one room, let alone agreed together on one policy. The policy is to develop a ratings system for television programs that will give viewers an indication of content not suitable for children. And although the network leaders repeatedly described the action as voluntary, it got a swift kick from the telecommunications legislation passed earlier this year.

title: Arts Endowment Doesn't Neglect Audiences
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF CHIP MAKER LSI LOGIC FALL FOR A SECOND DAY
description: The stock of the LSI Logic Corporation fell again yesterday, a day after it joined other computer chip makers in warning of disappointing profits. The shares fell $3.875, to $27.625, in trading of more than 17 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock dropped $4 a share on Wednesday. LSI, based in Milpitas, Calif., said on Wednesday that it expected revenues for the first quarter, which ends on March 31, to lag behind Wall Street estimates by 10 percent and that it expected earnings of 32 to 35 cents a share. Analysts had predicted first-quarter revenues of $350 million, unchanged from the fourth quarter of 1995, and earnings of 46 cents a share.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Francois Truffaut: Stolen Portraits 1994. Fox Lorber/Orion. $89.98. 93 minutes. In French, with English subtitles. No rating.

title: ART REVIEW;Colonial Latin America: Sleeping Beauty Awakes
description: AS hard as it is to believe, nearly all the 250 objects that pulsate and shine through the galleries of the Brooklyn Museum in "Converging Cultures: Art and Identity in Spanish America," the dazzling show of colonial-period art that opens today, have been slumbering in the museum's storage bins for 40 years.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets Open Vault Wider Than Ever for O'Donnell
description: The Jets, demonstrating how a lowly football team can immediately gain respect in the world of free agency, awarded the largest contract in their history today and landed quarterback Neil O'Donnell from the Super Bowl runner-up Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Giuliani Plans to Cut Off Financing to Some Groups That HelpImmigrants
description: The Giuliani administration plans to stop financing for several groups that now get city funds to provide services to immigrants, including an agency that has been helping Dominicans, the city's largest immigrant group.

title: Microsoft Backs Ratings System For the Internet
description: The Microsoft Corporation, contending that individuals rather than governments should control what people see on the Internet, has endorsed a new voluntary ratings system for information distributed via the World Wide Web. The company also said it would build a complete information filtering system into the next version of its Internet Explorer software.

title: POLITICS;Keyes Planning A Hunger Strike
description: Alan Keyes, who is seeking the Republican nomination, said he was starting a hunger strike to protest his exclusion from the Presidential debate today.

title: Gonzlez Rival Vows Tougher Anti-Terror Moves
description: MADRID  Jose Maria Aznar, the center-right challenger to become Spanish prime minister in elections Sunday, promises he will introduce tougher measures to deal with Basque terrorism.

title: Art in Review
description: Moyra Davey American Fine Arts 22 Wooster Street (near Grand Street) SoHo Through March 9

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Tracy's Tire Worries
description: PAUL TRACY, of the Penske Racing Indy-car team, is one of the favorites as the 1996 CART season starts this weekend in Homestead, Fla. But his tires have him worried, he said yesterday in a teleconference. Early indications are that Firestone's tires are faster than Goodyear's, which Tracy's team uses. He would like to see Goodyear create sets of tires tailored to the specific driving styles of the fastest racers (like himself), instead of producing one type of tire meant to satisfy everyone. That might upset some of the less-favored Goodyear teams, Tracy said, "but by being less diplomatic, maybe the overall results will be better."

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Plan to Mix Oil With Oil In Europe
description: In an effort to cut costs in Europe where demand for gasoline has been declining while refining capacity has been increasing, the Mobil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company said yesterday that they would combine their refining and marketing of fuels and lubricants.

title: Speed Record: One Trillion Bits a Second
description: Making a dramatic leap in the speed of communications, three separate groups of researchers have succeeded for the first time in transmitting information at a rate of one trillion bits a second through an optical fiber.

title: BASKETBALL;Former Convict Is Found Guilty In Jordan Case
description: A former convict was found guilty of murder today for shooting Michael Jordan's father during a holdup as he awoke from a nap along a dark highway in his $40,000 luxury car. The defendant, Daniel Green, 21, could be sentenced to death in the 1993 slaying of James R. Jordan, 57.

title: Virus Linked to a Cancer in AIDS Patients Is Identified
description: A virus that is believed to cause Kaposi's sarcoma, the most common cancer affecting gay men with AIDS, has been grown in the laboratory and photographed for the first time, scientists in California reported today.

title: Officials to Sell Netscape Stock
description: Several executives of the Netscape Communications Corporation, the Internet software maker, have told regulators they intend to sell millions of dollars worth of stock.

title: Doctors' Group Recommends Reducing Cholesterol Checks
description: A major doctors' group today recommended that fewer people have their cholesterol levels measured than is currently advocated, setting off a debate among medical authorities over the value of screening many Americans for this risk factor of heart disease.

title: Art in Review
description: Paul Ramirez Jonas Postmasters Gallery 80 Greene Street, near Spring Street SoHo Through March 9

title: CHRONICLE
description: DANIELLE MITTERRAND, the widow of President Francois Mitterrand, was aware that her husband had a daughter by another woman and accepted the situation, according to an interview published this week in a French magazine.

title: For Children
description: 'A Poppy Seed Purim' Merkin Concert Hall 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan (212) 501-3330 Ages 3 to 10 Sunday

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Agency Switch For Keds Account
description: The Stride Rite Corporation has unexpectedly ended its relationship with Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York on the account of its Keds brand of casual footwear after almost two years. The account was shifted without a review to Toth Design and Advertising in Concord, Mass., which handles promotions for Keds and advertising for Stride Rite children's shoes.

title: POLITICS: RAISING FUNDS;When Big Money Fails To Win Some Delegates
description: Two or three times each week, more than 250 Republican fund-raisers reach for their telephones to join a nationwide conference with Lamar Alexander and his financial architects to plot ways to raise new cash. The fund-raisers are given a few days to come up with donations of more than $5,000 each, and are told to send the contributions by Federal Express to campaign headquarters in Nashville so that the money arrives in time for the next wave of crucial contests.

title: POLITICS: MICHIGAN;Buchanan Strikes a Chord in Workers
description: Patrick J. Buchanan's message has been striking a chord here in this lunch-bucket city with workers like Kelly Bright, a stocky, bearded 37-year-old who was laid off at a Buick plant in the 1980's, when American cars were losing ground to foreign models.

title: The Spoken Word
description: "THE ART OF SCREENWRITING," American Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. A weekend of screenings and discussions with screenwriters before and after the screenings. Tomorrow at 2 P.M., "Get Shorty," with the film's screenwriter, Scott Frank. Tomorrow at 5 P.M., "A Little Princess," with the film's screenwriter, Richard La Gravenese. On Sunday at 2 P.M., "Georgia," with appearances by the screenwriter, Barbara Turner, as well as by the director, Ulu Grosbard, and the actresses Mare Winningham and Jennifer Jason Leigh. Admission: $5; $4 for the elderly; $2.50 for children and students. Information: (718) 784-0077.

title: COMPANY NEWS;METROCALL AGREES TO ACQUIRE 2 MORE PAGING SERVICES
description: Metrocall Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the assets of Satellite Paging and the Message Network for $28 million in cash. The deal was announced two days after Metrocall said it would buy Parkway Paging Inc. for $28 million. Satellite Paging has about 60,000 subscribers in New York and New Jersey; Message Network has about 50,000 subscribers in Florida, and Parkway Paging has about 140,000 subscribers in Texas. Metrocall, which is based in Alexandria, Va., has more than 940,000 subscribers in the United States. Its shares rose 50 cents, to $20, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Episcopal Bishop in Heresy Trial Violated No Church Law
description: To the Editor:

title: New Scrutiny In Child Care Is Proposed
description: Saying that children may be at risk, a legislative committee today proposed licensing people who receive state money to care for the children of relatives or friends on welfare.

title: Meter Glitch: Cabs Jump Gun On New Fares
description: Blame it on leap year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RISCORP SHARES SURGE ON FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The shares of Riscorp Inc. surged in a heavy first day of trading yesterday, a sign of intense interest in managed care stocks. Riscorp, Florida's largest workers' compensation insurer, sold 10 million shares at $19 each. The shares closed yesterday at $21.50 in Nasdaq trading. Riscorp, based in Sarasota, has added a new twist to workers' compensation by offering managed care services like a 24-hour injury hot line, an in-house medical director to set up treatment programs and a referral network.

title: Indian Opposition Leader Faces Arrest
description: A judge today ordered the arrest of 10 politicians charged in an $18-million bribery scandal, including four former Cabinet ministers and the leader of India's largest opposition party.

title: At the Top of TV News, A Star Is Made, Not Born
description: IN "Up Close and Personal," Michelle Pfeiffer morphs gorgeously from tacky would-be television-news talent at a local Miami station to sleek, glamorous network swan. Her transformation is overseen by Robert Redford, who might as well be saying "Here's looking at you, kid," with every appreciative gaze. These two stars, well matched and vastly charming, also happen to be playing actual grown-ups, with knowing dialogue supplied by Joan Didion and John Gregory Dunne.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Hampton's Financial Gain Could Be Riesenberg's Loss
description: The Giants were still waiting late yesterday for an official offer sheet from the San Francisco 49ers for running back Rodney Hampton. That offer, expected to be about $16.5 million over six years with a signing bonus of between $3.5 million and $4 million, should come within 24 hours.

title: U.S. Fixation on Castro May Do Us No Good;An Illegal Action?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pay and Performance
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: 'Handmade Readymades' Bertha and Karl Leubsdorf Art Gallery Hunter College of the City University of New York Lexington Avenue at 68th Street Through March 16

title: No Pay Increase for Stride Rite's Chairman
description: The chairman and chief executive of the Stride Rite Corporation, Robert Siegel, did not receive a pay increase this year or a bonus last year because the company failed to make money.

title: County Passes Ban on Smoking in Restaurants
description: The Westchester County Board of Health today passed one of the region's strictest anti-smoking measures, banning smoking in all county restaurants, regardless of size.

title: Art in Review
description: Matthew Antezzo Basilico Fine Arts 26 Wooster Street SoHo Through March 16

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Feb. 21 about the planned acquisition of Span Instruments Inc. by Tylan General Inc. described Span incompletely. Its main business is instrumentation for process monitoring and control; software represents a smaller part of its business.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Auto Nation USA Picks Hill, Holliday
description: Auto Nation USA in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., which plans to open so-called used-car mega-stores around the country, said yesterday that it had named Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston to handle its integrated marketing and communications account. The billings were estimated at $75 million over three years.

title: No Headline
description: With a woman, you become a couple and you often get stuck playing roles, with all those needy mechanisms tied up with sentiments. It's not like my mother. She needs me. She doesn't ask for any guarantees. It is a more freely given love."

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Losing in West, Knicks Sink in the East
description: John Starks was sprawled across several chairs at the Delta Center, his right ankle swollen and aching. Patrick Ewing was scheduled for a massage to knead out the soreness from Wednesday night.

title: Don't Corner Arafat
description: Outraged by the bombings that killed 27 people on Sunday, the Israeli Government is threatening to hit back at Islamic militants. Prime Minister Shimon Peres is reconsidering the planned withdrawal of Israeli troops from Hebron, the last Palestinian city under occupation. The Internal Security Minister, Moshe Shahal, has talked about erecting fences between the West Bank and Israel. And Mr. Peres has demanded that Yasir Arafat crush his main political foe, the militant Islamic movement Hamas.

title: The Republican Doldrums
description: Whatever its outcome, the South Carolina Republican primary leaves a visitor with the powerful image of a political party treading water. This condition is, presumably, reversible before the August convention in San Diego. But between the Iowa primary and South Carolina's, the four major candidates have failed to give their prepackaged platforms the sort of programmatic jolt that might make one or the other a credible alternative to Bill Clinton. Maybe that is why a different G.O.P. winner pops up in each primary.

title: POLITICS: STEVE FORBES;Forbes Learns How to Take Off the Gloves
description: Steve Forbes, the self-financed immovable force that bedevils his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination, is learning how to mix it up with his opponents.

title: Federal Rail Agency Eases New Go-Slow Rule for Trains
description: Responding to objections from New Jersey Transit, the Federal Railroad Administration today relaxed a new rule instituted in the wake of two collisions last month, including the one in Secaucus, N.J.

title: BASEBALL;It's Showtime for Wilson and His Fastball
description: Paul Wilson sees a message in the Mets' decision to start him in the exhibition opener against the Braves in West Palm Beach on Friday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Ban on Teen-Age Smoking
description: The first ordinance in New Jersey prohibiting smoking by people under 18 will go into effect here today. The man behind the measure, Mayor Austin Kutscher, who also happens to be a cardiologist, said yesterday that no extra police officers would be deployed to enforce the ban.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about efforts to revamp Russia's coal industry omitted a passage in some copies. The affected section follows:

title: James Barbagallo, U.S. Pianist, 43, Who Won Prizes
description: James Barbagallo, an American pianist who won the bronze medal at the Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow in 1982 and who performed for several years as a member of the Amadeus Trio, died on Monday at his parents' home in San Leandro, Calif. He was 43 and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Disney, Thorn EMI Select Firms
description: Two entertainment marketers have made decisions on their accounts.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Chargers in Major Moves
description: The San Diego Chargers signed Miami Dolphins defensive end Marco Coleman to an offer sheet today, and in a stunning related move they released running back Natrone Means to help clear room under the salary cap.

title: Mayor Sues Over State Law On Police Contract Disputes
description: Refusing to concede defeat in a fierce dispute with the police union, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani filed a lawsuit yesterday aimed at overturning a state law that might lead to higher pay for New York City police officers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;Foschi Case Reviewed
description: Swimming's world governing body will review U.S. Swimming's decision to reinstate JESSICA FOSCHI, the 15-year-old freestyler from Long Island who tested positive for steroids.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Phillips Unretires
description: TONY PHILLIPS, who abruptly announced his retirement from baseball earlier this week, has changed his mind and will return to the Chicago White Sox.

title: In America;Daytime TV's Child Porn
description: The shows cost next to nothing to produce, and there are still plenty of parents willing to usher their children onstage for a nationally televised dose of sexual exploitation and humiliation. So it is unlikely anyone will pull the plug on the degrading shoutfests that are known euphemistically as talk shows.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stock prices were higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 43.26 points, or 0.21 percent, at 20,168.63. On Thursday, the Nikkei advanced 205.40 points.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Hudson's Bond Rating Drops
description: Citing Hudson County's declining property tax base, a Wall Street rating service announced yesterday that it was downgrading the county's bond rating. Moody's Investors Service also chastised the county for relying increasingly on one-time measures to close its budget deficit, The Associated Press reported. The rating was lowered from Baa1 to Baa.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Amnesty for Tax Delinquents
description: Minutes after the State Assembly approved a bill that grants amnesty to delinquent taxpayers, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed the measure into law.

title: HOCKEY;Kypreos Traded for Momesso in Four-Player Deal
description: To enhance their size and toughness for the Stanley Cup playoffs, the Rangers obtained Sergio Momesso and Bill Berg last night in a trade with the Toronto Maple Leafs. In return, they sent Nick Kypreos and Wayne Presley to Toronto.

title: As Ever Beethoven: For a Month, for the Ages
description: A SUDDEN spate of interesting books about Beethoven shows that fresh revelations on this much-worried subject are still possible. (Scott Burnham's "Beethoven Hero," for one, recently appeared, and David B. Dennis's "Beethoven in German Politics, 1870-1989" is about to.) More illumination undoubtedly awaits in the Beethoven month that is about to descend on New York.

title: Rome Journal;At 30-Something, Leave Home? Mamma Mia, No!
description: It usually takes a lot marriage at least -- for a young Italian man to leave Mamma. So, with more Italians marrying later in life, more young men are staying home longer and, it seems, enjoying it more.

title: POLITICS: THE ISSUE;Abortion Issue Resurfaces in G.O.P. Debate
description: For the first time since the Iowa caucuses more than two weeks ago, cultural issues, particularly abortion, were back on the table today as the Republican Presidential race moved South.

title: Fossil Collecting Is by Permit Only
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS;Lamar Alexander Out on the Stump: 'I Can See a Rising, Shining America'
description: Following is an excerpt from a speech given by Lamar Alexander at a rally in Marietta, Ga., on Monday, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times. It provides an example of the message Mr. Alexander delivers in his standard campaign speech.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 19 about the new Phillips Ambulatory Care Center opened by Beth Israel Hospital misstated the number of exam rooms in the new clinic and in the hospital's old clinic. The figure of 23 rooms in the new clinic and 6 in the old one referred only to the pediatric area, not to the entire clinic.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: I Am Cuba 1964. Milestone. $79.95. 141 minutes. In Spanish, Russian and English, with English subtitles. No rating.

title: Richard A. Riley, 79, Ex-Chief Of the Firestone Tire Company
description: Richard A. Riley, former chairman, chief executive and president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, died on Wednesday at the Manor Care Nursing Home in Akron, Ohio. He was 79.

title: FILM REVIEW;Down Below the Waves, Singing 'Louie Louie'
description: Down Periscope," a desperately wacky comedy in which Kelsey Grammer makes his major motion picture debut, suggests the cinematic equivalent of the obsolete submarine on which most of the movie's action takes place. The Stingray, deployed to play war games with America's nuclear-powered fleet for reasons best left unexplored, is a rusted tub that makes the most alarming sounds when submerged. The deeper it plunges, the louder the protesting chorus of metallic clanks, groans and shudders it sends up. When the vessel reaches a certain depth, the picture on the screen begins to jiggle ominously.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW;If Not Utopia, What Is It? The World by Kiley
description: Since most people now accept that the Utopia envisioned by modern architects was a miserable flop, the wonderful Daniel Urban Kiley show at the Urban Center may cause some visitors to rub their eyes in disbelief. What is this if not Utopia, this dappled, sunlit world of trees, lawns, fountains and flowers? Isn't this the garden city modern architects promised to cultivate along with their crisp Machine Age buildings?

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that are to close soon:

title: Beethoven, Now and Forever
description: Here are some favorite Beethoven recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 for a single CD to $48 for a triple-set.

title: U.S. Fixation on Castro May Do Us No Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts Endowment Doesn't Neglect Audiences
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Inflation Falls
description: The European Union's annual inflation rate fell to 2.8 percent in January, the lowest level since 1987, according to figures released today. The figures show a fall of two-tenths of a percentage point from December.

title: David Durand Is Dead at 83; Was Statistics Pioneer at M.I.T.
description: David Durand, a former professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who was a pioneer in applying statistical tools to problems in financial markets, died on Monday at the M.I.T. Infirmary in Cambridge, Mass. He was 83 and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: Litton Is Owed Millions by Honeywell, Jury Says
description: A jury hearing Litton Industries Inc.'s antitrust lawsuit against Honeywell Inc. returned a partial verdict, saying Litton deserved damages of $234 million.

title: Tribute to Louis Malle, a Shy, Complex Director
description: His movies are known for the depth and range of the emotions they evoked. But to those who knew and loved him best, Louis Malle, the French film maker who died last November at 63, was such a shy, diffident man that he found it almost impossible to express or even acknowledge his own private feelings.

title: POLITICS: LOOKING ABROAD;Forbes Offers View of His Foreign Policy Stands
description: If Steve Forbes could change the world, he would give Taiwan a seat in the United Nations, split Rwanda into two countries with Hutus on one side and Tutsis on the other, and see to it that the President of Serbia was indicted as a war criminal.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: WEIGHT LIFTING;Steroid Appeal Denied
description: A Dresden, Germany, state court yesterday rejected an appeal by a former East German weight lifter who is seeking damages from the state for side effects suffered from performance-enhancing drugs.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;A Hard Look at the American West
description: The image of the American West as a place of wide-open spaces and untrammeled dreams still grips the national imagination, long after the reality has become complex and compromised. Robert Adams, whose quietly beautiful photographs of the West taken over the past 30 years are on view at the Howard Greenberg Gallery, is a leader among a group of contemporary photographers who try to record the present-day contradictions of the area that was once both physically and psychologically the frontier.

title: Castro's Moles Dig Deep (Not Just Among Exiles)
description: No one should have been shocked when a trusted pilot for Brothers to the Rescue, the anti-Castro organization whose planes were shot down last week, showed up on Cuban television denouncing the group as a tool of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Real Estate;Brokers are reporting a surge in demand for midpriced apartments in Manhattan.
description: WHILE the biggest, most desirable prewar apartments on Fifth and Park Avenues have been rising in price for more than a year, real estate brokers in Manhattan are now reporting a surge in sales of midpriced apartments elsewhere.

title: Political Memo;Mayor, as Maverick, Finds Buchanan an Easy Target
description: He has never been to a national political convention and is in no imminent danger of being invited to one. But for a brief moment on Wednesday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who tumbles freely through the political cosmos, actually seemed at home here at a gathering of the state's tiny Independence Party.

title: Arson at German Mosque
description: Assailants firebombed a partly constructed mosque here in southern Germany, the police said today. No one was injured in the attack, which took place late Wednesday, and damage was light.

title: Bond Rater Faults Mayor Over Budget
description: One of New York City's major bond raters yesterday strongly criticized Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's preliminary budget proposal for the coming fiscal year, warning that it would lower the city's credit rating further if the Mayor failed to address risky assumptions in his proposal.

title: A Fighter For Rights Is Treated For Cancer
description: His voice was raspy and tired, but Kwame Toure, better known to most Americans as Stokely Carmichael, answered the phone from his hospital bed with the phrase he had used for over 20 years: "Ready for the revolution."

title: POLITICS: THE DEBATE;As Rivals Take the Stage, Sniping Abounds
description: The four major Republican Presidential contenders competed today to deliver the starkest appeals to Southern conservatives in a fast-paced debate that was marked by testy exchanges.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SmithKline Beecham To Shut 5 Europe Plants
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. announced a "major restructuring" of its worldwide supply manufacturing operations in Europe yesterday, saying it would close five plants and cut 400 jobs. SmithKline, Britain's second-largest drug maker, said the move was aimed at providing the company "with a capable and responsive supply network in Europe into the next decade."

title: Episcopal Bishop in Heresy Trial Violated No Church Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Pull Plug on Senate Panel, for Now
description: Senate Democrats used a procedural tactic today to force at least a temporary halt to the Senate's Whitewater inquiry, which they denounced as a political witch hunt.

title: Commission Recommends Streamlined Spy Agencies
description: A Presidential commission on the future of United States spy services has recommended shrinking the nation's intelligence agencies but leaving their structure fundamentally unchanged, according to Government officials who have read its report.

title: NYC;Helping Hand In the Quest For Refuge
description: LATELY, Dr. Allen Keller said, a growing number of his patients have come from Bosnia, some of them survivors of torture in Serbian detention camps, others wracked by assorted traumas from the long Balkan war. "I have one patient, every time a car backfires, he hits the ground," said Dr. Keller, who runs a clinic at Bellevue Hospital and New York University Medical Center for foreign victims of human-rights abuses.

title: FILM REVIEW;Finding Companionship Through Kidnapping
description: Dorota Kedzierzawska's "Crows" is a small, exquisitely photographed Polish allegory about a neglected child. This girl is only 9 years old, but her face bespeaks an adult's troubles -- or perhaps a whole nation's. As played with scrappy ferocity by Karolina Ostrozna, this nameless young heroine searches throughout the film for some sense of connection and responsibility. The only way she can find it is by stealing someone to love.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Aerospace Profit Almost Doubled in 1995
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said yesterday that its profit nearly doubled in 1995 as it started to see results of a three-year-old reorganization plan and widening margins in its military business. The company, which makes Tornado fighters, Seawolf missiles and Avro jets, said its pretax profit before the one-time cost of streamlining its business rose 95 percent, to L330 million, or $505 million, from L169 million in 1994.

title: Art in Review
description: Jutta Koether Pat Hearn Gallery 530 West 22d Street Chelsea Through March 10

title: 3 Held in Carjacking That Hurt Teen-Ager
description: Using a witness's recollection of three letters from a license plate, detectives in Queens tracked down and arrested three men yesterday who they said had stolen a truck from an auto dealership and then run down a 17-year-old Brooklyn woman during a flight from the police.

title: Art in Review
description: Leon Golub Ronald Feldman Fine Arts 31 Mercer Street SoHo Through April 6

title: As Sarajevo Declares Siege Over, Serbs Still Pack
description: In the early hours of this day when Muslim-Croat Federation police entered this town and the Bosnian Government formally declared the siege of Sarajevo over, Joka Gajic prepared for one last visit to her heart doctor.

title: Chip Thieves Are Arrested After a Sting In California
description: The armed robbers of Silicon Valley were striking high-tech companies every 10 days or so, making off with computer chips and other components worth more than their weight in gold. With workers terrorized and losses in the millions, the F.B.I. and the San Jose police began an undercover operation 18 months ago.

title: BASKETBALL;Doctor Tells Coleman To Sit Out the Season
description: Derrick Coleman has been advised by a doctor to skip the 28 remaining games of the Philadelphia 76ers' season, but he will be re-examined by a team doctor.

title: Buchanan Is as Wrong as Father Coughlin Was
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Britain to Investigate Unichem's Proposal
description: British authorities said yesterday that they would investigate Unichem P.L.C.'s proposed purchase of Lloyds Chemists P.L.C., a drug wholesaler and pharmacy chain. Britain's Department of Trade and Industry said it would ask the Monopolies and Mergers Commission to investigate the antitrust implications of a merger between Unichem and Lloyds. It also asked that the European Commission, which has jurisdiction over cross-border mergers, refer a proposed merger between Gehe of Germany and Lloyds Chemists to British authorities.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers, Already Riddled With Injuries, Lose Verbeek
description: The Rangers stopped their home losing streak last night with a 3-3 tie in overtime against the Buffalo Sabres. But they paid dearly for it when they lost another key player to injury.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Weekend yesterday with the Inside Art column misidentified the owner of Leger's 1920 painting "Sleeping Women." It is one of 40 artworks from the Oscar Kolin estate being sold by the Pace Wildenstein gallery; it is not from the Oveta Culp Hobby estate.

title: Children Shouldn't Be Grist for the Talk Shows' Mill
description: To the Editor:

title: For Drug Abuse: New Metaphor and New Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Should Press For Action on Libya
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRINOVA'S UNIT SELLING YOKOHAMA AEROQUIP STAKE
description: The Trinova Corporation said yesterday that its Aeroquip Corporation unit had agreed to sell its 35 percent interest in Yokohama Aeroquip K.K. to the Yokohama Rubber Company of Japan for $34 million. Trinova said Yokohama Rubber would terminate use of the Aeroquip trade names and rename the company. The joint venture, founded in 1973, manufactures and sells fittings, couplings and hose and tube assemblies for industrial and automotive markets. Trinova said its other operations in Japan -- Aeroquip Automotive in Nagoya and Vickers Industrial in Tokyo -- would be unaffected by this transaction. Trinova is based in Maumee, Ohio.

title: About New York;Endless Laps, And Dreaming, In a Bronx Pool
description: A BRONX health club, Scott Joplin and a Roman Catholic parish are unusual sponsors for an Olympic swimmer. But John Dagbovi Senakwami is an unlikely Olympian.

title: Judge Duckman's Case
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS;In Their Own Words
description: BOB DOLE Speaking at a rally yesterday at the statehouse in Hartford, Conn.:

title: HORSE RACING;Mecke Could Be Force at Gulfstream Park
description: Manny Tortora has this chestnut in his barn at nearby Calder Race Course who may be the tamest, nicest and fastest 4-year-old in the business.

title: Barnard Health Plan Apportions the Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Prison Is Delayed For F. Lee Bailey
description: An appeals court has granted the defense lawyer F. Lee Bailey a reprieve hours before he was to report to Federal prison for failing to turn over millions in cash and stock from a drug-dealer client.

title: Inmate Is Executed After 13 Reprieves
description: A man who had avoided execution 13 times in his 14 years on death row was executed by injection early today for killing an elderly man in a 1979 robbery.

title: Breakaway Space Satellite Finally Dies Out
description: The runaway satellite-on-a-rope fell silent and became just another piece of space junk today when its batteries finally died, five days after it had broken away from the shuttle Columbia.

title: Rare Testing on a 737 Seeks Elusive Answers to a Crash
description: Air safety investigators have begun highly unusual tests on a parked Boeing 737, forcing parts askew with hydraulic arms and clipping vital control cables, in an effort to determine why another 737 owned by USAir fell out of the sky near Pittsburgh in September 1994.

title: Ivax Acquires Drug Concerns
description: The Ivax Corporation has bought three affiliated South American drug companies in exchange for about $41.75 million of Ivax common stock, the company said today. Ivax said revenues for the companies totaled $35 million last year.

title: BASEBALL;Strong Debut by Wilson Springs Mets Into Action
description: Paul Wilson wasn't as impressed with his pitches today as he was with his composure. Facing the World Series champions in his first big-league game could have made him queasy, exhibition or not.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Guilty in Union Bribery Case
description: An Arizona insurance salesman, Donald W. Purk, pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to paying $9,000 in bribes to Charles V. Giordano, the former president of Teamster Local 125 in Passaic County, for the purchase of $300,000 in pension-plan annuities, The Associated Press said. In 1994, Mr. Giordano pleaded guilty to embezzlement and is awaiting sentencing. Local 125, which represents about 1,000 beer and soda truck drivers and warehouse workers, is now supervised by a union trustee. A criminal investigation into the local is continuing, the Federal authorities said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AGREEMENT TO BUY MRS. SMITH'S FROZEN PIE BUSINESS
description: Conagra Inc. reached a tentative agreement yesterday to buy the Mrs. Smith's frozen pie business from the J. M. Smucker Company of Orrville, Ohio. Terms of the letter of intent were not disclosed, but Smucker said the transaction would result in a small loss on its investment in Mrs. Smith's. The Omaha-based Conagra is a diversified international food company. Its frozen food division's brands include Healthy Choice, Marie Callender's, Morton, Chun King and La Choy. Smucker makes fruit spreads, ice cream toppings, peanut butter and fruit juice beverages.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;With O'Donnell Signed, Jets Refigure Finances
description: The tremors from the Jets' mega-signing Thursday continue to reverberate. Every day now, the Jets will be skirting the salary-cap maximum of about $40 million in the wake of the five-year, $25 million contract given to quarterback Neil O'Donnell.

title: Buchanan Is as Wrong as Father Coughlin Was
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles E. Palm, 84, Professor Of Entomology and Agriculture
description: Dr. Charles Edmund Palm, an authority on insect life and plant pathology who built the department of entomology at Cornell University into one of the finest in the country, died last Sunday at Cayuga Medical Center in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 84 and lived in Ithaca.

title: Drug Agency Acts Quickly On New Therapy for AIDS
description: Acting unusually quickly, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a new drug to treat AIDS, the second one of a promising new class of drugs.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery numbers yesterday gave an incorrect number in some editions for the New Jersey Pick-6 Lotto of Thursday. The winning numbers were 1, 6, 10, 15, 24 and 30, with the bonus number 74628; the sequence did not include 16.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: MUJSIC REVIEW;Post-Tonal Winner in a Composing Contest
description: Last year Speculum Musicae held a composition contest in the hope of finding works that might not otherwise have come the group's way. About 120 composers from all over the world entered, and on Tuesday evening at the Miller Theater the ensemble played the winning work, "Philomel's Refrain" (1993), by Frederick Speck, a composer from Louisville, Ky.

title: Wife Remembers a Spy With Love and Disbelief
description: Despite his Richard Gere looks, it was not love at first sight. A newcomer from Cuba with no job or familiarity with American ways, Juan Pablo Roque seemed too much of a burden to the young single mother of two children who had left Cuba 30 years earlier.

title: No Headline
description: Whatever happens, Benin will be a determining factor in the intellectual discussion that is already under way about whether democracy can survive in Africa.

title: When Death Is Not the End
description: The headlines shout our confusion: "Court to Decide Brain-Dead Baby's Fate"; "Medical Certainty, Legal Limbo"; "Hospital Ordered to Keep Brain-Dead Baby Alive."

title: Religion Journal;Old Issues Arise in a Hearing on a Heresy Charge
description: When nine Episcopal bishops convened last Tuesday as a rare ecclesiastical court, they met at an almost disarmingly attractive site, the Cathedral of St. John in Wilmington, Del., a gray granite building with wood-paneled hallways and a peaceful meditation garden.

title: Editor! Editor! Taking the Bows for Anonymous
description: The ironies of it all haven't escaped Daniel Menaker. He is, after all, a literary sort, attuned to such things.

title: POLITICS: THE ELECTORATE;Specialists Pay $50 a Pop To Listen to the Vox Pop
description: One of the vox poppers was amused at the $50 he received for his two hours of focus-group opining. "Hey, this is $10 more than Steve Forbes spent on every Arizona vote," noted the Maryland voter, ready for Tuesday's primary and freshly milked of preciously recorded opinions that would soon be vetted by waiting political specialists.

title: Milken Says He Has Abided by Agreement
description: Michael Milken insisted today that no wrongdoing would turn up in the new investigation that led to his being put on probation for an additional three months in Wall Street's biggest securities fraud scandal.

title: G.I.'s in Bosnia Shun Hunt for War-Crime Suspects
description: The mountainous, snow-swept Bosnian town of Han Pijesak is surrounded by American troops. It is inside the American peacekeeping zone in eastern Bosnia, and soldiers assigned to the regional headquarters of the United States Army's First Armored Division could reach the outskirts of Han Pijesak in a leisurely hike.

title: Jury Imposes Death Penalty In '92 Murder
description: A man convicted of the kidnapping, rape and murder of an artist from Bucks County, Pa., was sentenced today to die by lethal injection.

title: POLITICS: THE WEEKS AHEAD;Race in Fast-Forward
description: The rules of the game will soon change. The score may or may not.

title: True North and Publicis Agree To Keep Working on Dispute
description: After more than a year and a half of sometimes fractious arguments over a jointly owned European venture, two giant international advertising agencies have finally agreed on something: They will keep trying to resolve their dispute but are unlikely to do so.

title: New York's Partial Primary
description: Despite the Pataki-D'Amato effort to prevent a Western-style election in New York, the state's Republicans are going to have a partially contested primary after all. Indeed, the March 7 primary that the Governor and the Senator tried to rig for Bob Dole is turning into a perversely important test for the staggering front-runner.

title: Kmart Finishes A Last-Minute Deal on Debt
description: The Kmart Corporation's most troublesome debt provision was eliminated last night, just hours before the company would have been pushed into a violation of loan agreements that could have forced it to seek bankruptcy protection.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Rutgers Keeps Wenzel
description: Rutgers ended speculation about its men's basketball coach yesterday by announcing that it had extended BOB WENZEL's contract. Specific terms were not disclosed, but an athletic department news release called it a multiple-year contract.

title: A Confrontation Over Hog Growers in North Carolina
