description: After five waste lagoons at large hog farms in southeast North Carolina broke last summer, spilling millions of gallons of waste into state waterways, environmental groups here decided it was time for what they called a "Hog Summit."

title: Republican Leaders Seek Debt Bill
description: Republican Congressional leaders want to extend the limit on Federal borrowing until only the end of March, high-ranking aides said today, while they continue to seek a way to pass a longer extension that would satisfy their own fiscal conservatives without provoking a veto.

title: Bogota Leader Assails U.S. And May End Cooperation
description: In a televised address tonight, President Ernesto Samper called the United States decision to decertify Colombia as an ally in the fight against drug trafficking "deplorable," and vowed that Colombia would "re-examine and re-evaluate the terms of bilateral cooperation in the anti-drug fight."

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: And The Winner Is ...
description: Citizens dismayed at the prospect of attending to a seemingly endless slog of primaries in the months ahead need no longer despair. Sure, we have South Carolina's primary today, and Georgia, Colorado, Rhode Island, Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, Vermont and Maryland this Tuesday. And then New York on Thursday, more contenders the following week, and on and on. By April, we stand to be almost comatose with the sheer suspense of it all.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Puts Restrictions On Futures Speculation
description: The Chinese Government said yesterday that it had banned state enterprises from engaging in futures speculation in an attempt to further regulate the once-chaotic futures market. State enterprises and Government departments will be allowed to trade futures securities only for protecting against financial risk, the order from the Securities Commission said.

title: Solon B. Cousins, 70, Former Chief of Y.M.C.A.
description: Solon B. Cousins, who from 1980 to 1990 was national executive director of the Y.M.C.A. of the U.S.A., the national office of the Y.M.C.A movement in the United States, died on Tuesday at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 70 and lived in Winnetka, Ill.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Disgrace in a Profusion of Detail
description: Prison camps are horrific by their nature, even when conditions are humane. And there were particular, inhumane horrors attached to the Confederate camp called Andersonville. "A disgrace to civilization" is the way a Confederate inspector (played by William H. Macy) describes the camp, and in the course of TNT's four-hour mini-series tomorrow and Monday night, a profusion of historically accurate details backs him up. The filthy, brutal conditions included lack of food, makeshift tents that served as shelter, and a polluted stream that ran through the grounds, downstream from where Confederate soldiers dumped sewage. Built to house 8,000 Union prisoners, Andersonville came to hold 45,000. In 1864 and 1865, more than 12,000 of them died.

title: FOOTBALL;Giants Offer $10 Million To a Backup For Cowboys
description: Guard Lance Smith has openly talked about retiring. Giants coaches love tackle Doug Riesenberg, but think he is overpaid. It's possible one or both players may not be with the team this season. That's why the Giants yesterday offered a large amount of money to a Dallas player who couldn't crack the starting lineup.

title: G.O.P. Is Reviving Plans To Reduce Regulations
description: Months after Republican proposals to roll back Government regulations stalled in the Senate, the party's leaders have revived the issue and plan to bring another measure to the House floor next week.

title: Prudential Shores Up Its Capital Reserve
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America added $1.9 billion to its capital base last year, after a drop in 1994 that matched the steepest decline in the financial conglomerate's history.

title: Threat Seen to Military's AIDS Research
description: Prominent AIDS researchers and military doctors say a new law requiring the military to discharge all troops infected with the AIDS virus will force them to shut down some of the nation's most important research on the disease.

title: Baby Superstore's Shares Plunge Again
description: The stock of Baby Superstore Inc., which has been on a roller-coaster ride this week, plunged again today after the company posted fourth-quarter earnings that were below expectations and restated its third-quarter net income at a sharply lower level.

title: HOCKEY;Housley Does Not Disappoint in Debut With the Devils
description: The superior passing skills the Devils were seeking from Phil Housley when they obtained the defenseman in a trade this week came to the surface in his debut with the Devils tonight. Looking every bit the offensive defenseman he has been for years, Housley set up the goal that tied the game and then assisted on the one that put New Jersey up for good, helping the Devils to a 6-2 victory over the Islanders at Continental Arena.

title: OPERA REVIEW;A Verdi Epic of Honor and Vengeance
description: In "La Forza del Destino," form wages a losing battle against content. Verdi's early late-period melodrama of honor avenged and virtue misconstrued may be too rich for its own good. Whatever ideals of tight proportion and storytelling logic it began with are crowded and misshaped by the wealth of music. The first scene, with its swift movement and economy of gesture, is the most soundly built, an island of cogency with hints of "Otello" and "Falstaff" to come.

title: BASKETBALL;After Streak, Nets Face Reality
description: Little more than a week after they won their fifth consecutive game, the Nets have not so much arrived, as they have arrived at another crossroads.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Australian Violinist And Rising Pianist
description: That the Australian violinist Jane Peters won the Bronze Medal in the International Tchaikovsky Competition 10 years ago was encouraging and surprising. Competitions tend to reward performers with flashy techniques and crowd-pleasing styles. But Ms. Peters is a substantive musician and a refined violinist. Her performance on Wednesday night at Weill Recital Hall, sponsored by Pro Musicis, was most distinguished.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Dutch to Extend Credit for Fokker
description: The Dutch Government agreed yesterday to extend Fokker N.V. enough emergency credit to keep it operating for two weeks while the plane manufacturer talks with South Korean and Chinese aircraft companies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WARNER-LAMBERT TO SELL GENERIC UNIT TO NALE
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that it would sell its Warner Chilcott Laboratories generic pharmaceutical business to Nale Laboratories P.L.C. Terms of the contract were not disclosed. Warner Chilcott had 1995 sales of $125 million from the marketing of about 70 generic pharmaceuticals. Warner-Lambert has entered into a manufacturing and service agreement with Nale and will retain rights to a minority equity interest in it. Nale is a closely held Irish developer of generic medicines.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DEAL TO ACQUIRE CORTIZONE AND HEMORID BRANDS
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that its consumer health care group had agreed to acquire the Cortizone and Hemorid brands from the Thompson Medical Company. Terms were not disclosed. Cortizone is an over-the-counter hydrocortisone product used to relieve itching related to skin irritations, rashes and insect bites. Hemorid is a hemorrhoid treatment for women. Thompson Medical, a privately held concern in West Palm Beach, Fla., is a pharmaceutical products company. Pfizer is a diversified health care company based in New York.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Mayor Barred From Selling Water System
description: A state judge has blocked Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to sell New York City's vast water and sewer system to a quasi-independent state agency, derailing a fiscal maneuver that the Mayor had proposed as a way to raise money for school repairs and other construction projects.

title: A Judge Questions Settlements By the S.E.C. in Orange County
description: A Federal judge has ordered an unusual hearing on the settlements between the Securities and Exchange Commission and two former officials of Orange County, Calif., to consider why the commission did not seek "additional remedies."

title: Empire Blue Cross Is Fined $1.1 Million, Setting Record
description: In the largest penalty ever assessed against a health insurance company in New York, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield was fined $1.1 million for violations of state insurance law, the State Insurance Department announced today.

title: INSIDE
description: Dealing With the Debt

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Money Laundering Is Denied
description: A former Atlantic City casino executive, Stephen McClintock, pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of laundering $124,000 to circumvent laws requiring reporting of individual cash transactions exceeding $10,000. The charges stem from a 1994 sting operation in which an undercover agent from the Internal Revenue Service said he induced Mr. McClintock, then the sales manager for table games at Tropworld casino, into laundering the cash by purchasing and redeeming chips in transactions at eight casinos. His trial is scheduled to begin May 6.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHERWIN-WILLIAMS WILL ADD GROW GROUP UNIT
description: The Sherwin-Williams Company will purchase the household and consumer products business of Grow Group Inc., which was recently acquired by British-based Imperial Chemicals Industries P.L.C., the companies said yesterday. The business manufactures specialty aerosol, household and professional cleaning products, with sales of about $80 million. Financial terms were not disclosed. I.C.I. bought Grow, a paint maker, after it outbid Sherwin-Williams with a $350 million offer. I.C.I. said then that it would be looking at possible divestments.

title: Albert Harris, 51, Theater Director
description: Albert Harris, a theater director and head of Theater Off Park, died yesterday at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 51.

title: New Jersey Considers Privatizing Its Child Welfare
description: A proposal to use a private business operating like a managed care network to handle state child welfare cases has put New Jersey at the forefront of a national debate over how best to overhaul the care of abused and neglected children.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks' Worst Trip in 10 Years Ends With a Thud
description: After a while, it was all a blur. Anthony Mason was hit with a technical foul for complaining late in the game. The basket the Knicks were shooting at seemed the size of a peephole, and another double-digit lead on the road disintegrated before a loud crowd in a visiting arena.

title: Wes Farrell, 56, Pop Songwriter Who Created 60's and 70's Hits
description: Wes Farrell, a music executive and songwriter whose four-decade career included the hit pop song "Hang On Sloopy" and the music for the television series "The Partridge Family," died on Thursday at a resort on Fisher Island, Fla. He was 56 and lived in Coconut Grove, Fla..

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Sports of The Times;Ernie D Has Found A New Game
description: FINALLY, we come to the cream of the college basketball season. March Madness, that annual monthlong celebration of upsets, defeats, surprises and Cinderellas.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Mercedes Factory
description: Mercedes-Benz A.G. said yesterday that it was planning to invest around 1 billion marks ($680 million) to build a new motor factory near Stuttgart, Germany. In addition to 750 million marks to replace an existing factory, Mercedes will spend about 250 million marks to move some production elsewhere and remove obsolete fixtures, a company spokesman said. Mercedes-Benz is the largest division in the Daimler-Benz A.G. group. Mercedes-Benz, with far-flung truck operations, also owns the Freightliner Corporation. (AP)

title: North Dakota, With German Roots, Adopts Spanish as Second Language
description: In a high school and a city named for the Iron Chancellor of Imperial Germany, the grandchildren of German immigrants pore over their lessons in the school's most popular foreign language: Spanish.

title: Technology Issues Follow Compaq's Fall
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation stunned industry analysts yesterday and sent technology stocks into a tailspin after it announced that earnings for the first quarter would be below expectations because of sluggish sales in February.

title: BEHIND THE BADGE: A special report.;A Portrait of the Detective in the 'O. J. Whirlpool'
description: Robert Deutsch, a lawyer, watched the evening news with mounting disbelief. It was the preliminary hearing in O. J. Simpson's murder trial, and a tall, confident detective was recounting how he had discovered an incriminating glove behind Mr. Simpson's house.

title: Thanks, Reminiscences And Tunes, Lots of Tunes
description: As the band played the blues, Johnny (Guitar) Watson sang to accept his Pioneer Award from the Rhythm and Blues Foundation on Thursday night. "I have been nominated for a few Grammys," he intoned above a rolling vamp. "But the R&B award is the real deal." Bobby Womack, accepting his, was even more to the point. "Where's the check?" he asked, and was handed one.

title: China Thaw Will Carry High Price For Taiwan
description: HONG KONG  In optimists' forecasts, the stormy political weather currently blowing into Taiwan from China should lift by the end of March.

title: Speedometer Misled Pilots of Jet
description: The Boeing 757 that crashed off the Dominican Republic on Feb. 6 had a faulty airspeed indicator, and the crew wrongly believed it had sufficient speed to maintain its altitude, according to Dominican officials.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Russia Proposes Tariff Rise, Despite Pledge to I.M.F. Russia's Finance Ministry has proposed raising tariffs on a broad array of imports by an average of 20 percent, despite Moscow's assurances to the I.M.F. only a week ago, as a condition for a $10.2 billion loan, that the country would continue reforming markets and reducing trade barriers.

title: POLITICS: THE IMAGE;For Buchanan, It's a Costume Change Every Day
description: Thank you, men of The Citadel!" shouted Patrick J. Buchanan, leaning heavily on the first noun before plunging from the podium, in shirt-sleeves, to clasp the hands reaching for him through the wrought-iron gates of the Military College of South Carolina here today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Frazier Still in Hospital
description: The former Nebraska quarterback TOMMIE FRAZIER remained in the cardiovascular unit of a Lincoln, Neb., hospital yesterday, five days after he was admitted for a sinus infection.

title: State Is Ruled Accountable Over Calls on Child Abuse
description: A state appeals court ruled today that New York could be held liable for a child's death if officials failed to respond properly to reports they received about the child on the state's child-abuse emergency phone line.

title: SKIING;Street Sews Up Downhill Title
description: The Russian-American summit atop a hill in Norway's far north produced two smiling winners today: Varvara Zelenskaja made history for Russia, and Picabo Street did the same for the United States.

title: POP REVIEW;Saying Farewell? Not Really
description: For a year, the Ramones, who helped give birth to punk-rock at the Manhattan club CBGB two decades ago, have been announcing that they will disband after their current tour. Larger audiences than usual have been attending their recent performances in hopes of witnessing the band's historic final concert. But their show at the Academy on Thursday night was not the Ramones' first farewell show in New York, nor will it be the last: The band is in negotiations to perform on the Lollapalooza tour this summer and a spokeswoman said that they would most likely be playing in Manhattan again.

title: Giuliani Finances Child-Abuse Fight
description: Ending what had been an intensely awkward standoff, the Giuliani administration said yesterday that it had come up with $1.2 million to keep 16 child-abuse-prevention programs in the city's Beacon schools from closing.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Italy's Economy Slips
description: Italy's gross domestic product contracted in the fourth quarter from the previous quarter and yearly growth fell to 2.4 percent from 3.4 percent, the Government said yesterday. Analysts, who had expected a decline, said Italy's economy was not slowing as fast as suggested in this report, which they said was distorted by the different number of working days in each quarter and by shifting inventories. The report was preliminary and did not include a breakdown of demand by sectors of the economy. Full numbers will be reported on April 16. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: POLITICS: THE ADS;Experts Saying Negative Ads Will Be Around for a While
description: Steve Forbes spent a lot of money on negative advertising in Iowa and New Hampshire and came in fourth in both states. Conceding that his strategy had been a "mistake," he switched to a more positive advertising campaign in Arizona and came in first.

title: Clinton to Issue Visa to Leader Of the I.R.A.'s Political Wing
description: President Clinton will grant a visa to Gerry Adams, the leader of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, but will not allow him any official White House meetings, the Administration said today.

title: No Caps on Damages for Railroads
description: The recent rash of train accidents makes this a most inappropriate time for Congress to set limits on the damages railroads must pay to victims of proven negligence. Yet the Senate will soon consider a bill that may include caps on punitive damages, and the House has already approved a measure capping both "pain and suffering" and punitive damage awards. Congress should eliminate these damages provisions before passing the broader Amtrak bill of which they are a part.

title: Debt-Collection Bill Could Reduce Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: African Anomaly: An Election Up for Grabs
description: COTONOU, Benin, March 1

title: A Federal Judge Allows Cameras at Court Hearing
description: Citing what he called the social and political significance of a lawsuit seeking a court takeover of New York City's troubled child welfare system, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that television cameras could broadcast the first hearing in the class-action case.

title: Peter Forbath, 65, an Author, Journalist and Producer, Dies
description: Peter Forbath, who lived the swashbuckling life of a foreign correspondent, produced an award-winning television documentary and wrote five books, died on Thursday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 65 and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cable TV Wires Are Cut
description: The police yesterday were investigating the cutting of wires near a cable television system's satellite reception site. Service to about 100,000 customers was affected Thursday, the day TKR Cable Company took over the system after purchasing it from Sammons Communications. About 100 of the 150 Sammons employees were laid off in the ownership transfer. Bill Murray, a spokesman for TKR, said yesterday that company security has been increased. "We have no idea about the cable problem," said Robert Connelly, a spokesman for Local 827 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, which represents about 130 of the former Sammons employees.

title: Chip Factory for Taiwan
description: Texas Instruments-Acer Inc. will spend as much as $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion to build its third memory chip factory in Taiwan, a company executive said today. The latest project will be in a Government-backed technology park in southern Taiwan. Construction will begin at the end of the year. The company, a joint venture of Texas Instruments Inc. and Acer Inc. of Taiwan, recently broke ground on its second factory. That plant is to begin production of 16-megabit chips early next year and eventually shift to 64-megabit chips.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Bankers Trust Dispute Settled
description: PT Dharmala Sakti Sejahtera of Indonesia has settled a dispute over $69 million in losses on derivatives it bought from the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.

title: BASKETBALL;Tournament Teams Know UConn Awaits
description: Notre Dame, Villanova and any other women's basketball team with aspirations of a Big East championship know that all roads lead through Storrs, Conn. The Irish, the Wildcats and 10 other visitors begin their quests today at UConn's Gampel Pavilion knowing that the Huskies, the defending national champions and the tournament's No. 1-seeded team at 27-3 over all and 17-1 in conference play, lurk, luxuriating in a bye until Sunday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hubcap Business Thriving
description: The Palisades Parkway just awful," Joe DeMarco said yesterday when asked where the deadliest potholes are in North Jersey. Awful, that is, for drivers whose hubcaps bounce away when a pothole is hit. But business is booming for businessmen like Mr. DeMarco, who owns Hubcap Joe's in Oradell, which stocks about 5,000 spare hubcaps. Mr. DeMarco said the best spot for hubcap scavenging is the George Washington Bridge -- "except that you risk getting killed if you stop there to pick one up."

title: Jury Leaves Litton's Award Unchanged
description: A Federal jury hearing the antitrust lawsuit by Litton Industries against Honeywell Inc. ended its deliberations yesterday, after deciding not to increase a $234 million verdict against Honeywell.

title: Rescuers at Peru Crash Site Find Bodies as Crowd Watches
description: Hundreds of somber onlookers watched today as firefighters lined up bodies on an Andean hillside where a fiery plane crash killed 123 people. The plane, a Faucett Airlines Boeing 737, went down on Thursday night five miles outside Arequipa, Peru's second largest city.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAGAZINE REPORT LIFTS SHARE PRICE OF REEBOK
description: The shares of Reebok International Ltd. rose yesterday after Business Week magazine reported that the company, a shoe and apparel maker, might receive a takeover offer from an unidentified German conglomerate. Shares of the company, based in Stoughton, Mass., rose $2.625, to $29, in trading of 1.6 million shares. Business Week, in its latest issue, quoted an unidentified New York money manager as saying that the German conglomerate is preparing an offer for Reebok in the mid-$40-a-share range. The money manager obtained the information from unidentified Swiss sources, the magazine said. A spokeswoman for Reebok, the second-largest United States maker of athletic shoes behind Nike Inc., declined to comment.

title: Kevorkian, Exploiting Exemption in Suicide Law, Testifies on the Pain That His Efforts End
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian took the witness stand today at his assisted-suicide trial and testified that he never wants to see any of his patients die but that he accepts -- as the cost of relieving pain, and "with great internal mental and emotional anguish" -- the death of those who choose to kill themselves.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Boone Stays With Reds
description: The Cincinnati Reds have reached agreement with second baseman BRET BOONE on a $725,000 contract for this season.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RENAL TREATMENT CENTERS INC., Berwyn, Pa. which provides dialysis treatment, purchased 11 dialysis centers in Oklahoma City for $16.2 million in stock.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: Fire in Garment District Cripples Part of Midtown
description: A fire in the kitchen of a Chinese restaurant started a major blaze in the garment district yesterday, destroying a six-story office building, snarling rush-hour traffic, disrupting West Side subway service and sending plumes of smoke over 20 square blocks of Chelsea, Hell's Kitchen and other parts of midtown Manhattan.

title: Clinton Grants Visa To Sinn Fein Leader
description: President Clinton will grant a visa to Gerry Adams, the leader of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, but will not allow him any official White House meetings, the Administration said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about homosexuals in the military misstated the Air Force's policy on keeping track of the number of people discharged for homosexuality. The Air Force does tabulate the number, but a change in record keeping makes it impossible to compare the figures for the fiscal year 1995 and the previous year.

title: An Academy Concept Interests Desegregation Planners
description: The latest chapter in the stormy 10-year fight over desegregating Dwight Morrow High School here centers on a state-sponsored effort to change it into a six-year academy offering four years of specialized high school courses and two years of college education.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Saturday about the soprano Dorothy Maynor credited her with one recording incorrectly. She did not record the role of Leonore in "Fidelio" with Toscanini.

title: POLITICS: THE ADVOCATES;Rivals United In Cultivating Religious Right
description: For all their ideological differences, the Republicans on the eve of the first Southern primary were united on one thing: their drive to win favor with religious conservatives, a particularly potent voting bloc in South Carolina.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Saturday about an increase in European film production misidentified the German company that recently agreed to buy American films from Hearst Entertainment. It was ZDF, the German television network, not the Kirch Group.

title: Bernice Bernstein, 87, U.S. Chief Of New York Health Programs
description: Bernice Lotwin Bernstein, a former New York regional director of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, died on Wednesday at the Group Health Hospital in Seattle. She was 87 and had moved to Seattle from the Upper East Side of Manhattan eight months ago.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STORAGE USA SELLING STAKE TO SECURITY CAPITAL
description: Storage USA Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 28 percent stake to Security Capital U.S. Realty for $220 million, providing cash to continue its rapid expansion in the highly profitable self-storage industry. Self-storage facilities have grown in popularity in recent years as more consumers find them a cheap and easy extension of their closets, basements and garages. The stock of Storage USA closed up $2 on the New York Stock Exchange at $33.75, an all-time high. Under the agreement, Storage USA, based in Columbia, Md., will sell 7.03 million shares to Security Capital at $31.30 each. After the sale, it will have about 25.2 million shares outstanding.

title: Editors' Note
description: Because of an error in computerized page design, a label was misplaced in some copies yesterday beneath a front-page picture of a meeting of television network executives with President Clinton and Vice President Gore. The reference to the President should have said simply "President Bill Clinton." The "Disney" label was for Michael S. Ovitz. The Times regrets the error.

title: GOLF;Ozaki Has The Lead By a Stroke At Doral
description: This is a city that views itself in international terms, a sultry place where a variety of cultures meld into an eclectic and electric whole. It is fitting, then, that the city's signature golf event, the Doral-Ryder Open, should have a leader board right out of the United Nations.

title: 2 in Armored-Car Case Get 10-Year Jail Terms
description: Robert and Susanna Scaretta, who were convicted 16 months ago of using their armored car company to steal $35 million from some of the nation's largest banks, were each sentenced today to 10 years in prison.

title: The Internet's Private Side
description: During a jaunt through the World Wide Web, I came across a seemingly innocuous invitation: "This is a HOT link." I clicked on the glowing words, which connected me with another computer that generated a picture of a nude woman with the tag line "Slut for Rent" imposed over her in big yellow letters. The Web site had similar pictures of "Candy," "Amber" and "Farah," as well as the predictable audio tracks.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Steep Drop in Oil Leads Retreat In Prices of Most Commodities
description: Crude oil led commodity prices sharply lower yesterday, dragged down by signs that Iraq planned to accept a United Nations proposal to allow limited oil sales.

title: A Bad Bill on Cuba
description: The Clinton Administration has done many things right and one thing terribly wrong in response to Cuba's shootdown of two unarmed planes flown by Miami-based exiles.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FREDDIE MAC BOARD RAISES ITS DIVIDEND
description: The board of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation raised the dividend that the concern pays to shareholders by 16.6 percent and authorized the buyback of as much as $1 billion of its common stock. Federal Home Loan, known as Freddie Mac, is a quasi-governmental concern that buys mortgages and repackages them into securities. It will be able to buy more than 11.5 million common shares at current prices. The repurchases will be conducted in the open market over the next several years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOARD CONDITIONALLY AUTHORIZES STOCK SPLIT
description: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that its board had conditionally authorized a 4-for-1 split in its common stock. UAL, which is majority owned by employees, said stockholders would be asked to approve an increase in the authorized common stock at the company's April 24 annual meeting to accomplish the split. UAL's stock rose $5.50, to $184.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. If stockholder approval is obtained, the stock split is scheduled to occur at the close of business May 6. The Chicago-based United is the nation's largest majority employee-owned company.

title: Why Mention Race?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;INFLO HOLDINGS TO CLOSE KEEBLER BAKERY IN ATLANTA
description: Inflo Holdings said yesterday that it would close its Atlanta bakery, the smallest of its six Keebler Company plants, and dismiss the 450 workers there. Inflo, a joint venture between Flowers Industries of Thomasville, Ga., and a Luxembourg investment fund, said it did not expect to shut any of the other plants it acquired when it bought Keebler on Jan. 27. The company said it would move the plant's equipment to other locations, sell the Atlanta plant and increase employment at some of the remaining Keebler operations.

title: 50 Years of Wishing You Were Here;Photographer Chronicles Adirondack Postcard Kitsch
description: Even Richard K. Dean, whose life's work has been postcards, admits that postcards aren't usually taken seriously. He wasn't thinking of history, he said, when he photographed the dude ranches, the wax museum and other kitschy attractions that entertained generations of vacationing New Yorkers up here in the Adirondacks.

title: Don't Build Rural Prisons for Urban Criminals
description: To the Editor:

title: Wrong Again
description: If bookies and stockbrokers were as wrong as often as political analysts and commentators have been lately, they would be broke. Only major league baseball managers can fail so consistently and still find work. Consider all the speculation about winners and losers leading up to the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire and Arizona primaries.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL REPORT
description: P.S.A.L. Quarterfinals

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;ITT to Buy London Hotel
description: The ITT Corporation said this week that its ITT Sheraton unit had offered to buy the Park Lane Hotel in London for about $68 million. Boston-based ITT Sheraton, which owns and franchises more than 400 hotels, expects to buy the 308-room hotel in April.

title: Bridge
description: Thousands of players arriving for the start of the Spring National Championships here today are learning, belatedly, about a result that is long overdue. The Barry Crane Top 500 winner, the player with the most master points in a year, is normally known by Dec. 31, and often earlier.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Keeping Corporate Score;In South Africa It's Even Hard to Find the Players
description: The South Afri can economy is Teddy Roosevelt's nightmare what America might look like if the trusts had never been busted, John D. Rockefeller had won the Standard Oil case and the unions still had to deal with Andrew Carnegie, the autocratic steel magnate.

title: Mrs. Fields Cookies in 'Low Fat' Settlement
description: Mrs. Fields Cookies trumpeted its Chocolite and Semi-Sweet Classic brands as low-fat, but the Federal Trade Commission says they actually contain almost twice the fat that low-fat cookies are allowed.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Work Affects PATH Service
description: PATH service between Harrison and Journal Square will be suspended from 1 A.M. to 1 P.M. tomorrow (and the following two Sundays) to repair wiring, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Riders can board shuttle buses linking the two stations in either direction, said Joy Faber, a Port Authority spokeswoman. JOE SHARKEY

title: Vehicle Sales Unexpectedly Strong Last Month
description: Most auto makers reported strong February sales today, an early indication that the economy may be shrugging off a slow fourth quarter of 1995 and the effects of January's snowstorms.

title: Stocks Surge as Rates Fall, But Technology Shares Sag
description: Stock prices surged yesterday as a drop in interest rates snapped a four-day losing streak. But technology stocks sold off.

title: On Eve of Spanish Vote, Premier Seems to Fade
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez loves bonsai trees and has spent long hours tending his collection, alone in the recesses of the official residence.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Giving Newcomers A Chance
description: The trombonist and arranger Slide Hampton was in a particularly generous mood on Tuesday night at the Iridium, giving two young writers the opportunity to show off their arrangements. The trumpeter Mike Mossman, who is part of Mr. Hampton's small big band, and the pianist Danilo Perez, who isn't, turned in two complicated, clever arrangements, full of quiet dissonance and color.

title: Clinton Declares That Colombia Has Failed to Curb Drug Trade
description: President Clinton declared today that Colombia, the world's largest cocaine producer, had failed to cooperate in the fight against illegal drugs, a determination that not only stigmatizes it but also makes the country ineligible for most American economic aid.

title: Journal;East Village Story
description: In an age when almost every show-biz event is predigested and presold by the media long before the public can decide for itself, the truly spontaneous pop-culture phenomenon is almost extinct. Almost but not quite. Two weeks ago, at a 150-seat theater in the East Village, a rock opera called "Rent," written and performed by unknowns, came out of nowhere to earn the most ecstatic raves of any American musical in the two decades since "A Chorus Line." And now the world is rushing to catch up: "Rent" will quickly move to Broadway to accommodate the insatiable demand for tickets, even as Hollywood titans fight to bring it to the screen.

title: GYMNASTICS;Veteran Gymnasts Fare Best
description: Experience counts for a lot, as the younger gymnasts learned at the American Cup today. The veterans Kerri Strug, Oksana Chusovitina and Svetlana Boginskaya showed poise and power to take the top spots after the women's preliminaries.

title: Chief Executive of HarperCollins Resigns Unexpectedly
description: In a surprise move, George Craig, president and chief executive of HarperCollins, told senior executives at the book publishing company in a memo yesterday that he was stepping down.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Corporate Confidence Gains Slowly in Japan
description: After four years of recession, corporate confidence in Japan is improving but more slowly than analysts had expected, according to a Bank of Japan survey released yesterday. The central bank's quarterly survey showed that the percentage of major manufacturers saying business conditions were bad fell to 23 percent in February from 26 percent last November. Eleven percent said conditions were good, down from 12 percent, with 66 percent saying business was somewhere between good and bad, up from 62 percent.

title: Gorbachev Says He May Enter Presidential Race
description: In a quest for political resurrection, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, said he will be a candidate in the presidential elections in June if democrats fail to unite behind a single candidate.

title: Kodak Names President of Imaging Unit
description: The Eastman Kodak Company named a former exectuive at the International Business Machines Corporation, Robert M. Unterberger, to the post of president of its Digital and Applied Imaging unit.

title: A Bosnian Serb Is Indicted by Tribunal
description: The International Tribunal for Former Yugoslavia indicted a Bosnian Serb general today on charges of war crimes that include the shelling of Sarajevo, making him the second indicted suspect in custody at The Hague and by far the highest ranking.

title: RUSSIAN AIDE CALLS FOR HIGHER TARIFF, RENEGING ON VOW
description: Contradicting assurances made to the International Monetary Fund only a week ago, Russia's Finance Minister has proposed a broad increase in import tariffs.

title: Alice E. Weil, 70; U.N. Groundbreaker In Posts for Women
description: Alice Ehrenfeld Weil, the first American woman to hold the rank of Assistant Secretary General at the United Nations, died on Wednesday at her home in New York. She was 70 years old and lived for most of her life on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: After 6 Months, Schools Know Their Enrollments
description: Of all the descriptions that capture the vastness of the New York City public school system, perhaps none is as telling as this: It took officials until noon yesterday, a full six months after the opening of school, to complete the count of every student enrolled for the year. It is 1,056,251, an increase of 23,109 over the previous school year.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICANS;Citadel of Moderate, Monied G.O.P. Looks at Primary, and Sighs
description: Commuters can be a grumpy lot, especially at 7 A.M., and so Edward Dadakis was not surprised by the lukewarm response this morning as he handed out fliers for Senator Bob Dole on the Metro-North platform here. Everything had already been said in other states, he sensed. "I see our role as reminding people there is a primary," he said.

title: Rig Count Rises by 2
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States jumped by 2 this week, to 707, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 684 rigs operating nationwide during the comparable week a year earlier. Of the rigs running this week, 436 were exploring for natural gas and 265 for oil. Six rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: Golf Course Plan Approved for Johnson Estate
description: Having voiced a wish to help preserve open space in this increasingly crowded corner of Mercer County, one of America's wealthiest women has received permission to turn her estate into a golf course.

title: Treasury Prices Surge on Purchasers' Report
description: Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday after the nation's purchasing managers reported tough business conditions in February and investors saw yet another reason for the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates next month.

title: Helene Koon, 71, Expert in Drama
description: Dr. Helene Wickham Koon, an author, scholar of 18th-century dramatic literature and former professor of English at California State University in San Bernardino, died on Feb. 13 at her home in Hollywood. She was 71.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tuberculosis Tests at School
description: Skin tests for tuberculosis will be given to 120 teachers and other staff members and 200 students at Neptune High School in the next two weeks, after one staff member was diagnosed with the disease this week, the Monmouth County Health Department said. Among students, the initial round of tests will be confined to those who had close contact with the staff member, who is no longer working at the school. Afterward, others among the 1,100 students will be tested if they request it. An information session will be held at the school Thursday night to discuss the transmission, diagnosis and treatment of tuberculosis.

title: L.I. Couple Sentenced In Huge Theft Scheme
description: Robert and Susanna Scaretta, who were convicted of using their Long Island armored car company to steal $35 million from some of the nation's largest banks, were sentenced to 10 years in prison. The judge said they showed no remorse and noted that they had spent lavishly on their home, cars, a private plane and gambling vacations.

title: Apple to Close Its On-Line Unit
description: Apple Computer Inc. has decided to discontinue its once-heralded on-line service, eWorld, on March 31.

title: Fares Go Up: Cabbies Line Up to Have Meters Tuned Up
description: As surely as Deanna Thompson knows that Madison Square Garden is on Seventh Avenue, she knows the price of a taxi ride from the corner of her Upper West Side apartment to her law office in Lower Manhattan.

title: BASEBALL;Cone and the Yankees Get Down to Business
description: After the Yankees stretched the definition a little in introducing a group of borderline "legends," after Bob Sheppard gave the event a Bronx flavor by introducing the current Yankees, after Phil Rizzuto tossed out the first pitch and after the hot dog, peanut and popcorn mascots found their dancing spots throughout the stands, David Cone finally threw the first pitch of the first exhibition game at Legends Field today.

title: Children Shouldn't Be Grist for the Talk Shows' Mill
description: To the Editor: Re "Double Exploitation," Bob Herbert's Feb. 26 column: I, too, find reprehensible the incessant efforts of talk show hosts to use the misery and confusion of troubled children as grist for the "infotainment" mill.

title: Buenos Aires Journal;The Rock, Unyielding, Of the Plaza De Mayo
description: It was a scene that Argentina will not soon forget: blood oozing from the white headscarf of Hebe de Bonafini, the 67-year-old leader of the Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, who was beaten by the police last week as she tried to intervene in a student protest that turned violent.

title: The Year of the Whopper
description: Infinite Jest By David Foster Wallace. 1,079 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $29.95.

title: PLAYWRIGHTS AND TV;Theater Is Irrelevant?
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX;Evalisse's Pearls
description: ON the desk in my office I have a statue of Jemaja, the Santeria religion's goddess of the sea. Her neck has been broken and reglued. A hand is missing from one outstretched arm; the other hand cradles a cluster of pearls from the sea. What can you expect for a dollar from the Salvation Army in Paterson?

title: The View From: Larchmont;A Church That Takes an Unconventional View Toward Lent
description: IT is Lent, and the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church here is marking the 40-day period before Easter with worship services, Bible-discussion groups -- and lessons in ballroom dancing, aerobics classes and showings of movies like "Apollo 13" and "Babette's Feast."

title: Classical Briefs
description: SCHUBERT: 'DIE WINTERREISE' Wolfgang Holzmair, baritone; Imogen Cooper, pianist. Philips Classics 446 407-2; CD.

title: Is Secret Sign Needed To Get Low-Fee Banking?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kou Qiu, Jordan! Slam Dunk! Pee-ow Liang!
description: PEE-OW Liang!"

title: ON THE STREET;Spring Sandwich
description: Fashion on the streets of Manhattan is an up-to-the-minute mirror of nature's whimsy. Two Sundays ago, for instance, the Lake in Central Park was frozen, allowing the public a rare chance to walk under the Bow Bridge, above. In ensuing days, nature performed one of its somersaults and temperatures took a vernal turn. By last Sunday, a pair of gliding swans had replaced the people on the Lake and fashionable women removed their coats, providing a spring preview: a revival of the miniskirt, and a stretch of leg as graceful as the swans. But by week's end, New York was wrapped once more in an icy cloak, and its denizens in their fake furs. From such caprices of weather and fashion comes the city's snap.

title: WHERE MAVENS SHOP;TOKYO
description: ALONG with the rising skyline and enlarged thoroughfares, a major evidence of the rapid changes in Tokyo's shitamachi, or old commercial center, is the disappearance of many small, family-owned shops.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Copley Exhibitions Converge in Houston
description: The remarkable dual career of the 18th-century painter John Singleton Copley is examined in two exhibitions on view at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, through April 28. Comprising nearly 100 works, "John Singleton Copley in America" and "John Singleton Copley in England" provide a comprehensive overview of the artist's work on both sides of the Atlantic. The shows originated at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the National Gallery in Washington, respectively, but only in Houston will they be seen at the same time.

title: THE NIGHT;Classics Rewritten And Retold
description: IN a red bow tie so bright it was nearly safety orange, Garrison Keillor was only half-hidden behind a big column at a reception room at the Essex House hotel last Monday. As the host of the Authors Guild Foundation benefit, he probably should have been mingling with the literati crowding the cocktail hour. But he seemed to prefer narrating to participating.

title: SOAPBOX;Christopher and Me
description: One of the unexpected joys of moving back to Queens from Greenwich Village three years ago to care for my ailing mother was the friendship of a little East Indian boy who lives next door. Christopher, 4, has shiny black hair in a Beatles cut, enormous brown eyes and a keen sense of humor.

title: Board Resigns At U.S. Fund For Czechs And Slovaks
description: The entire board of a troubled investment fund set up to help the Czech and Slovak republics has resigned. Now President Clinton is to appoint an interim board to help determine if the fund should be shut or merged with another fund, a spokesman for the Agency for International Development said today.

title: Mothers Whose Drug Habit Kills Their Babies
description: THE moment she first held tiny Saleem Groom in her arms, Linda Bohan, a maternity room nurse, became worried. "I knew something was off," she said last week, explaining that the infant was jittery, a signal to medical workers that his mother might have been using drugs while she was pregnant. "It's terrible seeing some of these babies born and wondering what kind of life they will have."

title: In the Region/Long Island;In the 'Unhampton Hamptons,' the Price Is Right
description: WHEN Thomas and Kathleen Baldassare began looking on the East End for a weekend house, they first started searching in West Hampton Beach and in Quogue.

title: INVESTING IT;The Talk of Cyberspace: Is Iomega Losing Its Zip?
description: EVERY investor dreams of getting in on the meteoric rise of a hot stock like that of the Iomega Corporation, a maker of high-capacity disk drives for computers. The stock could be picked up for about $1 a share early last year, and last week, it traded as high as $20.

title: Management Fees Aren't Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property/Don't Tread on Me;Developers Try Brokerage, Angering the Brokers
description: BEAR, STEARNS wants a new headquarters, and its real estate representative is the developer Fred Wilpon?

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Stablemate Runs Out Of Cigar's Shadow
description: Wekiva Springs, who ran second to his stablemate Cigar in the Donn Handicap three weeks ago, ran first in the Gulfstream Park Handicap today when he caught Star Standard in the homestretch on a sloppy track and outran him to the wire by a length and three-quarters.

title: INVESTING IT;Pushing Goodyear To Focus Abroad
description: CAN Samir Gibara keep the good news rolling at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company?

title: FUNDS WATCH;Bear Markets: Fierce, Yes, But Fleeting
description: Even though investors keep piling into stocks, many are fretting about the next bear market.

title: THEATER;Out of This World Visitor at Yale Rep
description: AT the same time each year the Yale Repertory Theater gives over its main stage to the Yale School of Drama's actors and designers, and to a professional director from the outside world.

title: WAY UPSTATE NEW YORK
description: SPRAWLED OUT BETWEEN LAKE Champlain and the St. Lawrence River, just over the border from Quebec, the upper fringe of New York State's northern tier contains some of the most austerely handsome rural terrain east of the Rocky Mountains. An enclave of big woods, tiny Yankee and French-American villages and semiabandoned farmland, it has a rip-roaring tradition of local revolts and uprisings, outspoken individualism and 200 years of smuggling.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Dakar
description: For anyone who has traveled around West Africa, the strongest impression upon returning to Dakar, the capital of Senegal, is likely to be that nowhere has the marriage between Europe and Africa been as thoroughly consummated.

title: INSIDE
description: Limiting Federal Housing

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volvo 850 R;A Wolf in Swedish Clothing
description: THE commercial is so quick that it's almost subliminal. Very MTV, very grainy, all of it in black and white. That's a wolf there in the cage. And sand -- or is it snow? And the speeding car is -- what is that car?

title: Der Rosenkavalier' Has Yet to Yield Up Most of Its Secrets
description: THE OPERAS OF Richard Strauss have figured more prominently in the New York City Opera's repertory than might be expected, given their typical grand scale and extreme vocal demands. What the company has done is pick its spots. When it presented "Der Rosenkavalier" in 1972, it enabled New Yorkers to hear that special artist Elisabeth Grummer, at the end of her career, as the Marschallin. Now, on Saturday evening, the company offers that opera again, in a production by Jonathan Miller.

title: Snow Can't Keep the Golfer Home
description: WITH six inches of fresh snow on the ground and the temperature in the teens, it did not seem like a good day for a round of golf. But at 7:30 A.M. on a recent Sunday morning, Bob Bottomley tossed his golf bag into his car trunk and set out to play 18 holes at Pebble Beach.

title: Feb. 25-March 2;China Takes a Slap at Haiti
description: In one of the most intense standoffs the United Nations Security Council has experienced lately, China tried to block the continuation of an international peacekeeping force in Haiti because the small Caribbean nation had the temerity to recognize Taiwan and invite its leaders to attend important functions in Port-au-Prince, most recently the inauguration on Feb. 7 of President Rene Preval.

title: GOOD EATING;The Sunny South On the East Side
description: BAR ANISE+ (212) 355-1112; 1022 Third Avenue, near 61st Street; $(c) all major credit cards

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: ATTORNEY FOR THE DAMNED A Lawyer's Life With the Criminally Insane. By Denis Woychuk. Free Press, $23.

title: WHERE MAVENS SHOP;RIO DE JANIERO
description: PASSING the leafy, heavily trafficked corner of the Rua Toneleiros and the Rua Santa Clara in Rio's Copacabana, you might think the Bazar Soba was just another tropical hardware store, with walking sticks and chewing tobacco on display and bird cages hanging from the ceiling alongside cast-iron pots and bongo drums.

title: A First-Time Buyer's Primer and Road Map
description: IT won't be too long before pachysandra emerges from hibernation, azalea buds ripen, trees sprout new leaves and a fresh crop of "For Sale" signs appears on lawns across the land.

title: MUSIC;Thinking Big About a Little Instrument
description: WHOEVER takes the children to the family concert in the revived Community Theater of Morristown next Sunday will find that the children are not the only ones having a good time. In the middle of a short concert of carefully chosen classical standards by the New Philharmonic of New Jersey, Robert Bonfiglio, who has been called the Pied Piper of the harmonica, will work his charisma on music of Stephen Foster, John Philip Sousa and others.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE CARRIAGE STONE By Sigbjorn Holmebakk. Dufour, cloth, $25; paper, $13.95.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: SHOWS;Birthday for Boomers
description: In a Parisian version of the free birthday meal at Denny's, the Lido de Paris cabaret is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year by offering patrons who visit on their 50th birthdays a free show and dinner. Proof of birthdate is required, and the person celebrating must be accompanied by a paying guest (of any age). Admission to dinner and the 10 P.M. show is $145 to $199 a person. Call (800) 227-4884 or (33 1) 40.76.56.32.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST;A Libretto From Bensonhurst: Hey, Let's Put On an Opera!
description: The strains of Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci" can be heard on the B4 bus these days after the last passengers have disembarked near the end of its route on Bay Ridge Parkway. It's the driver, Richard Haber, practicing his role as a tenor in the chorus of the Regina Opera, a small company in Bensonhurst that puts on fully staged, fully costumed operas with a full orchestra.

title: WHERE MAVENS SHOP;CAIRO
description: IT is no bigger than a bedroom, and its stone floors wear the grime that permeates Old Cairo. But on a street where craftsmen have been sewing sturdy cotton tents for centuries, the shop of Ibrahim Sayed Ahmed & Sons has an honored place.

title: Setting Standards For Public Spaces
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET WATCH;Telling The Truth About Derivatives
description: Mark to market.

title: IN BRIEF;The State Creates a Mascot In Its War Against Potholes
description: Pity the poor potholes, now that Pothole Pat is looking for them.

title: POLITICS: NEW ENGLAND;Economy Poses Risks and Rewards
description: New England's economy has a way of making its mark on the nation's politics. In 1988, the region's high-tech boom and the confidence it spawned gave rise to the Presidential candidacy of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who promised to carry the "Massachusetts miracle" to the nation.

title: Tales Out of Africa
description: ZENZELE A Letter for My Daughter. By J. Nozipo Maraire. 194 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $20.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Port Richmond, S.I.;Eclectic Housing, Traditional Diversity
description: PORT RICHMOND is but a country village now . . . A trolley runs along the shore and one runs up [Port] Richmond Ave. . . . Standing in front of this building there are 18 houses in sight."

title: WHERE MAVENS SHOP;LONDON
description: THE namesake of George's of Chelsea usually greets clients from his bed. As the door to his cream and British racing-green domain opens, he may deign to raise an eyelid or even wag his tail at the more fetching customers. Yes, George is a dog, a Jack Russell-Corgi cross adopted from a London shelter. The shop that bears his name, on London's Chelsea Green, overflows with useful and amusing canine accessories.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Death of a Parrot Salesman
description: Archy McNally is a raffish combination of Dashiell Hammett's Nick Charles and P. G. Wodehouse's Bertie Wooster: a charmingly spoiled, overgrown adolescent with a taste for booze, an eye for the ladies and a nose for trouble, not to mention a highfalutin vocabulary and a gift for the wisecrack. In McNALLY'S PUZZLE (Putnam, $24.95), Lawrence Sanders's sixth book of "discreet inquiries" starring McNally -- who "works" for his father's stuffy law firm -- the somewhat ridiculous sleuth must dig into the gruesome death of a millionaire parrot-shop owner named Hiram Gottschalk in an attempt to unravel the circumstances of his passing and the tangled mess of the family he leaves behind. As usual, Mr. Sanders's thin story line takes a back seat to the verbal and social antics of McNally and his cronies: what is on the menu at the "exclusive" Pelican Club is more important than any particular clue, and serious sleuthing can be at least temporarily diverted by a well-made gimlet. The real focus is on Archy's prancing and preening and so-called life of the mind as he tools around south Florida entertaining the millionaire's twin daughters, fencing with his housekeeper and tracking the bizarre activities -- parrot smuggling is one, perhaps -- of Gottschalk's troubled stepson. Helping McNally with his rounds is his lovable if brainless sidekick, Binky Watrous, who falls in love this time with a tambourine-banging Irishwoman, and a scrappy mutt named Hobo, whose star turn includes soothing McNally's frayed nerves and providing more than one well-timed rescue. Erik Burns

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Sunday

title: COVER STORY;Andersonville, A Symbol of Wartime Suffering and Brutality
description: FOR sheer inhumanity, it would be difficult to match Andersonville. The hell hole of Civil War prisons, it was a name, said one 19th-century author, "which has been stamped so deeply by cruelty into the pages of American history." Lack of food and medical supplies, pollution, drastic overcrowding and the disregard of officials and guards turned his Confederate prison into an abattoir of misery and death. All of this is evident in John Frankenheimer's mini-series "Andersonville" (shown in two parts tonight and Monday night at 8 on TNT).

title: Herself a Multitude
description: Unlocking the Air And Other Stories. By Ursula K. Le Guin. 207 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $22.

title: UPPER EAST SIDE;Author! Author! Choosing Sides in a Debate at Chapin
description: If real life were more like fiction, the clash between Tom Wolfe, author of one of New York's defining novels, "The Bonfire of the Vanities," and Susan Cheever, the writer and daughter of John Cheever, the late chronicler of haute WASP angst, would have been more mano a mano.

title: ENCOUNTERS;A Composer Who Finds Lasting Inspiration in 'Alice in Wonderland'
description: IN a small cottage in Sag Harbor's North Haven, David Del Tredici sits playing the piano as he meets the man who has come to take his picture. He is playing with just one hand -- almost unconsciously, with a feeling of both anxiety and release -- as he turns to pose.

title: HOME CLINIC;Toward Understanding Tool Quality
description: THERE are tools in every home. Most homeowners have at least one hammer, a screwdriver and a saw. Not all tools are found in the workshop or toolbox, though.

title: Pop Culture: Extremes but Little Reality
description: On the sitcom "News Radio" recently, the owner of a New York radio station decided to sell out to a large company. His small, loyal staff begged him to change hismond.Because they live in a television fantasy, he did. He didn't need any more money, he decided; the friendship of his employees mattered more.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about art dealers who exhibit and sell works from their homes referred incorrectly to Contemporary African Art, a gallery in a brownstone on West 108th Street. It is not the city's only commercial gallery of contemporary African art. Skoto Gallery in SoHo, at 25 Prince Street, sells contemporary African art and African-American works.

title: Holy Hypochondria, Batman!
description: REMOTE

title: Trying to Put Children in Drug Facility
description: LOUISE and Wayne Hoppner have been waiting for two months for a spot at Outreach House for their 17-year-old-son, Joe.

title: ON THE MAP;In Englewood, No Business Except Show Business
description: When Erik Kessler, a retired musician, first came to the Actors' Fund Nursing Home in Englewood, he was convinced his life was over. Now, four years later, Mr. Kessler sits in the theatrical library that he helped put together for -- a collection of scripts, playbills and books by and for the stage-struck. "I can do anything, and it's all because of this place," said Mr. Kessler, 72. "It's a harmonious place. I owe them my life, and I will always be grateful."

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL;A Means to Learn New Ways
description: Their hands, some hardened by the years of confining housework they did in the dry Yemeni countryside, are decorated with henna inks that take hours to apply but are a standard beautifier.

title: POLITICS: ONE PRIMARY;Connecticut Is Platform For Believer In Buchanan
description: Five years ago, Tom Scott organized a rally to protest Connecticut's new income tax and drew an angry crowd of 40,000 to the Capitol. Two years ago, he ran for Governor as an independent and won 11 percent of the vote.

title: Australia
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Amy Auster's article on Kosciusko National Park, "A Park of History and Poetry" (Jan. 14). The isolation of the park, however, makes it a difficult day trip. Visitors to the Melbourne area might try Fraser National Park, only 90 miles from town. The park features Lake Eildon, a manmade lake used mainly by picnickers and boaters.

title: A Family Stumbles Over Its Flaws
description: Say this city has ten million souls, Some are living in mansions, some are living in holes: Yet there's no place for us, my dear, yet there's no place for us.

title: Forget Jose. There's an America Of Kevins and Ashleys Aborning
description: THE first gift that parents give a child is life. The second is a name.

title: Perspective/Boxing: 25 Years Haven't Softened The Blows;More Than Just a Fight: A Metaphor for an Era
description: It was called, simply, The Fight, because that first match between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier, 25 years ago this week, contained too many metaphors to cram into one jingly ad line.

title: HARLEM;Bank Rebuilds, To Street's Benefit, After a Major Fire
description: Three years ago, an electrical fire destroyed the headquarters of the Carver Federal Savings Bank on 125th Street. But for Carver, the only black-owned savings bank in New York, it was only a glancing blow. "After the fire," said Carver's president, Thomas L. Clark, "people waited to be shuttled to our branch in Chelsea rather than change banks."

title: Now-Orphaned Park Once Thrilled Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: HOTELS;Peace on Park Avenue
description: Tranquillity is not a word that springs to mind when describing life in Manhattan. But the Kitano Hotel, which reopened in September after a four-year reconstruction, thinks it can bring the serenity of ancient Japan to New York with a package that combines a night in its Tatami suite and a dinner in its Nadaman Hakubai restaurant. The Tatami suite includes a tea ceremony room in the centuries-old sukiya-zukuri style, noted for its delicacy and use of natural materials.

title: CUTTINGS;Walls of Leaves: A Meditative Interior, Outdoors
description: About 15 years ago, Ngaere Macray bought 40 acres of old potato fields in Sagaponack, L.I., and started to build a house and garden.

title: MIDTOWN;Keeping a Museum Afloat
description: At first, all sides proclaimed victory in the Battle of the Guadalcanal, the fight that ended with the city agreeing to change course and abandon its plan to anchor the aircraft carrier Guadalcanal next to the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum in the Hudson River and use it as a heliport, mainly for sightseeing flights.

title: IN BRIEF;Airport Rail Link Moves A Step Closer to Reality
description: In five years, traveling from Newark International Airport to Penn Station in Manhattan in just 20 minutes may no longer be a fantasy. Last week, the Federal Aviation Administration approved a crucial set of plans to extend the airport's monorail about a mile to a new station on New Jersey Transit's Northeast Corridor line.

title: FROM THE DESK OF: AMY WU;Scrimping on College Has Its Own Price
description: I AM one of a growing number of young people who are condensing their college education from four years to three. My decision to graduate a year early has much less to do with ambition, however, than with saving a good deal of money.

title: Preparing for a Campaign Against Drugs, Officials Seek More Jail Spacefor Dealers
description: In a move to drive cocaine and heroin dealers out of crime-infested sections of Queens and Brooklyn, New York City police plan a six-month campaign to arrest more than 7,700 suspected narcotics sellers and buyers -- so many that it is forcing correction officials to look for additional jail space.

title: Feb. 25-March 2;Now Talk Is Cheap
description: ABC, CBS and NBC each spend between $300 and $400 million a year on their news divisions. Fox spends about one-tenth that. So executives of the big three got a bit huffy last week when Rupert Murdoch, chairman of Fox's parent News Corporation, offered a free hour of prime time to each Presidential candidate in November.

title: COPING;H.I.V.-Positive: Inside the Mind Game
description: Barbara Williams prepared a particularly sumptuous feast last Thanksgiving Day -- turkey and roast beef, three kinds of pie -- and invited her five sisters from Brooklyn and their children. There were more than 15 people around the table in her South Bronx apartment, and she waited until they were full and feeling good before she quietly led her own four kids, who ranged in age from 4 to 25, into her bedroom.

title: EARNING IT;The Virtual Office Bumps Into Some Very Real Limits
description: FOR seven years, Judith S. Lederman worked out of her home and employed six other consultants who worked from their homes, too. But whatever its benefits, this virtual office frequently left her frustrated. "I was getting a level of work that was unprofessional, and I was unable to monitor it," she said. "The projects were floundering."

title: Facing the Extreme'
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL;System Is More Than Anyone Bargained For
description: The essence of winning free agency in the National Football League has evolved into this. Devise and employ a richly developed plan that defines:

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Johnson Misses His Record, But Demolishes Opponents
description: The Summer Olympics are four months away, but already there is an air of resignation about the men's 400 meters. The other Americans are positioning themselves for the future, because Michael Johnson retains a stranglehold on the present.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: MEGATRENDS ASIA Eight Asian Megatrends That Are Reshaping Our World. By John Naisbitt. Simon & Schuster, $24.

title: PARK SLOPE;At Newsstand, Notes Mourn Its Slain Owner
description: A handwritten message explains the circumstances behind the shuttered gate of a Park Slope newsstand: "Do not deliver newspaper until further notice due to death in the family."

title: Crime
description: Here it is, only three weeks since Mario Balzic was forced to retire as police chief (a traumatic event that K. C. Constantine presented with dry-eyed dignity in "Cranks and Shadows"), and already things are falling apart in Rocksburg, Pa. This worn-out working-class town is used to its corrupt and venal Mayor and the sorry state of its Police Department, but in GOOD SONS (Mysterious Press/Warner, $21.95), everyone is alarmed by the vicious beating and rape of a woman whose family owns a local cement company. What Rocksburg needs is a new police chief, and it looks as if it's going to be Detective Sgt. Ruggiero (Rugs) Carlucci.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Carolina Restaurateur Takes SoHo Farther South
description: Alexander Smalls, an opera singer turned restaurateur, is on a mission: to raise New Yorkers' appreciation of Southern cooking. Two years ago he opened Cafe Beulah, at 39 East 19th Street, a bistro specializing in Southern fare. Tomorrow , he is opening Sweet Ophelia's in SoHo, at Broome and Crosby Streets, a Southern grill and takeout bakery. "Southern food is our premiere American cuisine and not always represented in the best light," said Mr. Smalls, who was reared in South Carolina.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Nostalgic Trips From Singapore to Malacca
description: With the help of Malaysia's last working steam locomotive, the Peninsular Line railway service is initiating nostalgic daily excursions between Singapore and Malacca this month.

title: In the Region/Westchester;Broker and Homeowners Sue Upscale Developer
description: BURTON GARRET of Mount Kisco, a developer of high-end homes in northern Westchester County, has until Friday to answer a $1 million suit filed by the Houlihan/Lawrence brokerage concern charging that fradulent practices deprived it of earned commissions and damaged its reputation.

title: BASEBALL;Rainout Does Not Dampen Gooden's Spirits
description: Dwight Gooden disguised a sheepish smile today after Manager Joe Torre informed him that his long-awaited return to baseball with the Yankees would be put off for one day because of relentless rain at the Reds' spring training home in Plant City, Fla.

title: POP VIEW;Disco's Born-Again Bad Girl
description: BEFORE MADONNA, THERE WAS DONNA, THE sultry, 70's siren who didn't so much sing about sex as ooze it into the grooves. On the 1975 hit "Love to Love You Baby," a 17-minute opus of pounding rhythms and orgasmic moans, Donna Summer and the producer Giorgio Moroder changed the complexion of disco from romantic to erotic. Though the song barely plumbed the depths of Ms. Summer's huge, soulful voice, its provocative sensuality brought her instant notoriety in a genre dominated by one-hit wonders.

title: HEADLESS BODY';Wrong Head
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Briefs
description: STRAVINSKY: 'FIREBIRD' SUITE; 'JEU DE CARTES'; 'AGON' Zurich Tonhalle Orchestra conducted by Michael Stern. Denon CD-98972; CD.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 3, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: WEDDINGS;Sharon Fischman, Michael Lazar
description: Sharon B. Fischman, a daughter of Dr. Marian W. Fischman and Dr. Donald A. Fischman, both of New York, was married last evening to Michael I. Lazar, a son of Marilyn Kraemer of Succasunna, N.J., and Lawrence Lazar of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Henry Weiner performed the ceremony at Il Tulipano, a restaurant in Cedar Grove, N.J.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: PUSSY, KING OF THE PIRATES By Kathy Acker. Grove, $21.

title: EDUCATION;Uncertainty Appears to Ease at an Imperiled Special School
description: It has been a chaotic winter at the A. Harry Moore School in Jersey City. In January, Governor Whitman announced a plan to cut $750,000 in state aid to the school, which serves severely disabled children in pre-kindergarten through 12th grade. Then the school's principal, Dennis Paporello, sent a letter to parents warning that it might close if the funds were not restored. Most recently, the teachers were notified that they would lose their jobs in August if the budget gap was not closed.

title: Sunday March 3, 1996: PAINT REMOVERS;A Chip of the Old Block
description: Back when Art Nouveau splendor was a welcome invitation to Times Square, an outdoor billboard at the New Amsterdam Theater heralded its latest productions. In the process of renovating the 94-year-old theater, a group of experts used a paint chip from the billboard to chronicle that rich stage history. The team from Building Conservation Associates, examining the chip under a stereobinocular microscope, discovered 121 layers and was able to assign each color to a different event. "When I saw the magnification of the chip, I thought, This is it, the perfect way to visualize the theater's varied history," says Raymond Pepi, the company's president.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;Shelter Ruling Irks Neighbors
description: For the homeless men living in the shelter at the Flushing Armory, the ruling last month that ordered it to open around the clock was welcome. It meant they would no longer have to be roused at the crack of dawn and taken to Manhattan.

title: MUSIC;James Galway Leading a Crowded Week
description: SOLO, duo, chamber and orchestral performances by more than a dozen artists make this one of the most crowded musical weeks of the year thus far in Connecticut.

title: For the Return of Electric Cars, The Reality Is Virtually Present
description: THE first electric car that Fred Whitridge ever drove had cut-glass windows and a tiller rather than a steering wheel. That was 15 years ago, when his wife's 85-year-old grandmother let the couple take a spin in her 1914 Rauch and Lang town car, after giving Mr. Whitridge about a minute's worth of instruction.

title: Corporate America Is Courting Agricultural Biotech
description: WALL STREET has been bitten by this bug before.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Yuk, Yuk, Congressionally

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column last Sunday about the newly renovated Opera Garnier in Paris misstated its telephone number. It is 40.01.17.89.

title: SPENDING IT;Should You Invest? Kick the Tires First
description: EVEN before they open for business, some chains of used-car stores are dreaming of going public.

title: A ROYAL HAVEN IN PARIS
description: Midnight on the Rue de la Bas tille. At the table next to ours outside the glass-domed Bofinger brasserie, two tanned blond lovers are fork-feeding each other oysters. Inside, amid lace and stained glass, sinuous Art Nouveau wood and zinc-topped counters, opera-goers in opera finery are polishing off the piles of crustaceans and the charcuterie served to them by orange-aproned waiters; outside, lean figures on motorized skateboards race by.

title: Portraits in Words' Chosen For Museum Lecture Series
description: EVERY two years the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College offers thematically twinned programs that bring acclaimed speakers to the county. This year, the Yaseen Lecture Series, as the programs are called, will address the topic "Portraits in Words and Images." The painter Chuck Close will speak today at 2 P.M., and the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Doris Kearns Goodwin will speak next Sunday at 2 P.M.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Happy Feet
description: THEY are up and moving in a room that, despite the dim lights, the cocktail waitresses, the rotating mirrored ball, the singer in an evening dress and the 17-piece orchestra on a raised stage, has the look of a high school social.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE DEATH OF COMMON SENSE: How Law Is Suffocating America By Philip K. Howard. Warner, $10.99.

title: Feb. 25-March 2;Farm Subsidies Bite the Dust
description: Since the 1930's, most of America's 1.5 million farmers could count on the Federal government to subsidize their crops if market prices fell too low. Those days may soon be gone.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Westchester Q&A: Dr. Ronald D. Valenti;The Juggling Act of Paying for Schools
description: ANOTHER year, another round of cuts in state aid for school districts. This year, Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget cuts general state aid and calls for school districts to pay millions more to educate and transport special-education preschoolers, services that had mainly been paid for by the state and county governments.

title: Sisters, Lovers, Tarts and Friends
description: Janet Malcolm's last book was The Silent Woman: Sylvia Plath and Ted Hughes."

title: DINING OUT;Charm in a Bistro-Like Setting in Rye
description: A DINING spot for many years, this sweet little building now accommodates Sorrel. The place has always radiated a great deal of charm, the kind one finds in the cozy, just-around-the-corner bistros in Europe, and the few improvements the present occupant has made do nothing to alter this mood.

title: FABLED ROAD TO THE FAR EAST
description: FOR SOME 1,500 YEARS, UNTIL ITS decline in the 15th century, the ancient trade route known as the Silk Road was a principal artery for goods and ideas passing from China to Europe. Finery, spices and porcelain were exchanged for such Western delicacies as walnuts and figs and, more importantly, gold.

title: So Many States, So Little Time
description: It seems like only yesterday that the Republican Presidential campaign meandered along at a bucolic pace, with leisurely forays by the candidates around the country. Now the contest rockets past at warp speed. As a succession of primary elections crashes down on the voters every three or four days, a sensation that too much is happening too quickly has set in. Whatever was the intention of political strategists in establishing a compressed schedule of primaries at the beginning of the campaign season, it has not served the interest of democracy and rational choice.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JACKSON HEIGHTS;Immigration Bill Stirs Fears
description: Dilip Jani has dished up tea and tandoori at the Jackson Diner on 74th Street for the last 11 years, and since 1992, when he applied to sponsor his wife and children, they have waited in Bombay for the visa backlog to clear. Pramoda Rai, a waitress at the diner, is seeking legal papers for her elderly mother, who came to stay with her since her father died. And across the street at Melodyland, a video and music shop, Seema Vermani has also been thinking about sponsoring her mother.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;The Hoyas Make the Most Of a Weakened Villanova
description: When Rutgers lost its freshman star, Susan Blauser, to a knee injury in the opening minutes against Boston College, the Scarlet Knights' hold on their perch in the Big East tournament seemed slippery, at best.

title: Arm Wrestler Scrapes for Return to Table
description: BRICKLAYERS and stonemasons rely heavily on cement mixers. When they break down, the results can be disastrous, except when Glenn Terracciano is on the job. He just mixes cement by hand.

title: Karadzic and Hussein, Survivors;Bosnia and Iraq: The West Repeats Itself
description: ON the ground in Bosnia, NATO commanders are slowly learning a lesson that might have been driven home to them in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war: Sometimes, it is not enough to humiliate a dictator before his people. If you want him out of office, you may have to do the job yourself.

title: ART VIEW;A Master of Discreet Bourgeoisie Charms
description: YOU CAN PASS BY SOME works of art many times before they catch your eye, but then they take on a special significance because they were overlooked.
