I imagine people have had this experience with the works of the French painter Louis-Leopold Boilly (1761-1845), whose nearly pitch-perfect show is at the National Gallery of Art.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;A Composer Finds Favor Without Courting Fashion
description: James MacMillan has been hailed by members of the British press as the greatest composer of his generation. In his native Scotland, he has become a symbol of regional cultural pride. And his first opera, "Ines de Castro," which will receive its premiere at the Edinburgh Festival this summer, is eagerly anticipated.

title: WRIGHT'S OLD NEIGHBORHOOD
description: OAK PARK, ILL., SEEMS LIKE AN ordinary suburb. If you drive through it quickly you see an average Midwestern small town: solid, leafy trees; broad, straight streets lined with banks and shops; lots of churches, and block after block of good old American houses of every architectural style.

title: Of a Young Hopeful's Views And His Flag Etiquette
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhood Under Pressure
description: Speak My Name Black Men on Masculinity and the American Dream. Edited by Don Belton. 272 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $24.

title: L.I. VINES
description: Chardonnay Duck Walk Vineyards, Water Mill, 1994. About $13 (1.5 liters) and $7 (standard bottle).

title: Along Thai Border, Malaria Outpaces New Drugs
description: The ragged mountains and thick jungles along the Thai-Burmese border, rife with ethnic insurgencies, wandering refugees and smugglers of gems and teakwood, are the world's epicenter of drug-resistant malaria.

title: TELEVISION;Disaffected? Click On a People's Choice
description: MIKE EVANS IS PASSIONATE ABOUT his Republican Presidential candidate. Passionate enough to travel to the New Hampshire primary from his home in Virginia. Passionate enough to wear campaign buttons and pass out T-shirts. Passionate enough to get arrested during a protest outside the G.O.P. debate and spend six hours in jail.

title: HORSE RACING;Mr Purple Goes From Santa Anita Long Shot to Big Shot
description: Cigar could not make it from Florida, Serena's Song could not make it the final quarter-mile, and the race favorite, Helmsman, could not offer any punch down the stretch. Instead of a showcase for the stars of the sport, today's $1 million Santa Anita Handicap turned into a parade for inscrutable long shots, as 18-1 Mr Purple beat 64-1 Luthier Fever and 14-1 Just Java across the line in the premier race of the meet at Santa Anita.

title: NATO Looks to Peacekeeping by Europeans on Their Own
description: The United States and its NATO allies have agreed on new procedures to allow European countries to undertake future peacekeeping missions like the American-led operation in Bosnia on their own if necessary, allied officials said today.

title: GOLF;And Now Playing In Miami: Jaws III
description: Darkness halted play in the third round of the Doral-Ryder Open today, but there was one thing that was easily visible through the gloaming that enveloped the Blue Monster course at the Doral Resort and Spa.

title: Feb. 25-March 2;The Real Killing Fields
description: When Dr. Haing S. Ngor, the Cambodian surgeon who won an Academy award for his debut acting performance in the 1984 film "The Killing Fields," was shot to death outside his home in Los Angeles last Sunday night, police investigators declined to identify possible suspects or offer a possible motive. But Government officials in Phom Penh were not so reticent. Samdech Hun Sen, the Cambodian co-premier, called Dr. Ngor's shooting "a pure political act."

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;Day Full of Fighting Words for Buchanan
description: Instead of the mantle of the heroes of the American Revolution, Patrick J. Buchanan found himself covered in snow and epithets from hundreds of protesters as he tried to carry his campaign for the Republican nomination to the village green here this afternoon.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE ANIMALS' WALTZ By Cary Fagan. St. Martin's, $21.95.

title: ESSAY;A Crop of Winter Books
description: I'M often asked what books a gardener should read, especially in late winter, and it's a question that stumps me. No books would be one answer. Just get ready to plant a seed and some trees and keep your eyes open. Learn from the insects that have devoured your roses and from your version of my Cousin Janice, who will always show up to tell you what you're doing wrong.

title: Rough Sea Cuts Short Service for Cuban Pilots
description: Memorial services by air and sea for the four men killed a week ago when their two planes were shot down by Cuba ran into rough weather today, forcing a flotilla of boats to turn back before reaching their destination in international waters north of Cuba.

title: Fur Coats vs. Others
description: To the Styles Editor:

title: 'Infinite Jest'
description: Reading David Foster Wallace's latest novel, ''Infinite Jest,'' I couldn't help thinking at times about 7-year-old Seymour Glass's book-length ''letter'' home from camp, published in The New Yorker in 1965 as ''Hapworth 16, 1924.'' I felt a similar feeling of admiration alloyed with impatience veering toward strained credulity. (Do you suppose Seymour's parents actually read the whole thing?) I had previously been a great admirer of Mr. Wallace's collection of stories, ''Girl With Curious Hair,'' and, to a lesser extent, of the loose, baggy monster that was his debut novel, ''The Broom of the System,'' which I confess to not finishing. If Mr. Wallace were less talented, you would be inclined to shoot him -- or possibly yourself -- somewhere right around page 480 of ''Infinite Jest.'' In fact, you might anyway.

title: After Prosecutor's Error, Woman Convicted of Murder Is Freed
description: Two years ago, a jury in this border town sentenced the wife of a prominent doctor to life in prison after convicting her on murder charges. Prosecutors said she had given a fortune teller $3,000 to arrange the murder of a high school honor student she blamed for jilting her youngest daughter.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Too British for Yankee Ears?
description: WHEN PULP appeared on the British music show "Top of the Pops" last fall to promote "Different Class," its No. 1 album there, the host asked the band's frontman, Jarvis Cocker, what he liked most about success. "The birds," Mr. Cocker replied with a seductive smile. It was a pithy and very English answer ("birds," of course, being the British equivalent of the word "chicks").

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: ALAN JAY LERNER A Biography. By Edward Jablonski. Holt, $35.

title: INVESTING IT;Some Stocks That Waft On the Summer Breezes
description: EVERYONE knows you get a deal on Christmas cards the week after. And a heart-shaped box of chocolates bears a tempting price tag come the second half of February.

title: In Wilton, It's Time Again for Antiques to Go
description: SPRING is still some weeks away on the calendar, but at the Wilton Historical Society 29th Annual Antiques Show this weekend, masses of golden forsythia will greet the winter-weary, providing a coaxing setting for the spending public.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: VILLAGES, EAST AND WEST;Foes Say 'Basta' to a Shelter Plan
description: A decade ago it was a block that locals went out of their way to avoid. Thousands of homeless men still used the old Men's Shelter at 8 East Third Street, an overcrowded center where even employees were arrested for selling drugs, and robberies and brawls were not uncommon.

title: Growth When Resources Are Slim
description: MICHAEL AND DALE SMYTH didn't let a bad economy prevent them from fulfilling their dream. After years of dairy farming, Mr. and Mrs. Smyth have established an independent dairy. They own and operate Trinity Farm in Enfield, one of only seven farms in the state that process, bottle and sell their own milk.

title: Will Cars Ride to the Rescue When Houses Lose Power?
description: IF your home was among the tens of thousands that lost power this winter in severe storms, you may have wished for a backup generator to keep your home's basic electrical systems running. If a new technology proves itself, the solution may be sitting in your garage.

title: FILM;An English Director Stirs Up A Tale of a Sorry Youth
description: IN THE 1960'S AND 70'S A suburban English schoolboy named Graham Young became famous as a mass murderer, first poisoning his stepmother and, after a stay in a psychiatric hospital, eight of his co-workers. He did his "science experiments" in his parents' basement, and his specialty was death by teacup.

title: JERSEY;A Leaner Army Leaves a Town Behind
description: TWO miles up the road is a sprawling military base with a budget of more than $1 billion, where 4,750 people come to work every day. But you don't see much indication of this on the main streets of Dover, a blue-collar town left behind in an increasingly white-collar military economy.

title: An Adjutant With Attitude;Betsy McCaughey Ross Pursues Her Own Agenda
description: Lieut. Gov. Elizabeth McCaughey Ross was hurtling through the hallways of the Free Academy High School in this Hudson River mill town early this month when a bell-bottomed teen-ager innocently asked a loaded question.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Suspense permeates four classics -- two spooky, one a modern crime puzzle and one a western -- on the film roster on television this week. And for contrast, there's early Elvis Presley.

title: PERSEPCTIVES;The New Approach on Tax-Delinquent Property
description: FROM his office in Bordentown, N.J., J. Douglas Breen runs a tax collection operation. He collects delinquent taxes from Jersey City property owners, but not as a public employee. He's a principal in the Breen Capital Group, a servicing company for the First Boston Corporation, the winning bidder in 1993 when Jersey City farmed out the task of collecting $43.7 million in unpaid property taxes. The city was paid $25 million for the privilege, and hopes to get more eventually. Meanwhile, the collections rate since 1993 has risen.

title: The World;What Castro Still Needs Is a Good Fight
description: UNTIL last weekend, it was tempting to think that Fidel Castro mattered less to the United States than at any time since his seizure of power 37 years ago. Ever since Bill Clinton took office, Washington has viewed Mr. Castro as a noxious irritant, to be sure, but mostly it has tried to ignore him. Yet somehow Mr. Castro -- and the exiles in Miami who so despise him -- manage periodically to keep drawing America's attention back to their family feud.

title: POSTINGS: A Memorial to 3 Firemen Who Died in the Line of Duty;Building a Monument to Bravery
description: When I am called to duty God, whenever flames may rage, give me strength to save some life, whatever be its age. . . .

title: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;High-Tech Milk in Schools Worrying Some Parents
description: Pauletta Brooks's 6-year-old son, Tye, drinks at least six cups of milk a day. It is the milk he drinks at Public School 11 that worries Ms. Brooks, an artist. .

title: Charles Goodman, A Publisher, 55
description: Charles H. Goodman, a publisher of magazines, a philanthropist and a volunteer for rights organizations, died on Feb. 23 at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 55 and lived in Manhattan.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A Beaux-Arts Building for Louisiana Lore
description: Visitors to Louisiana seeking an in-depth portrait of the state will find it at the Williams Research Center, housed in a handsome, recently restored Beaux-Arts building at 410 Chartres Street in the French Quarter of New Orleans. The14,500-square-foot center, which contains 80 tons of archival material, was opened in late January by the Historic New Orleans Collection, one of the city's most popular small museums, which had outgrown its quarters at 533 Royal Street.

title: Out of the Lab, A Revolution On the Farm
description: THIS spring, Joe Tusek and many of his fellow farmers here in western Illinois will plant soybean seeds fortified with a biological weapon borrowed from the petunia. The genetic alteration will enable the farmers to cut costs by dousing their crops with Roundup, a cheap but powerful Monsanto herbicide that would kill normal soybean plants along with the weeds.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MAPLE SUGARING

title: Oprah Buffa
description: HOT AIR All Talk, All the Time. By Howard Kurtz. 407 pp. New York: Times Books/Random House. $25.

title: GARDENING;Hail the Speedy Radish, in All Its Forms
description: This, according to the National Garden Bureau, a promotional arm of the seed trade, is the year of the radish.

title: Sunday March 3, 1996: SIGN LANGUAGE;An Urban Sideshow
description: You wouldn't know it after a nonchalant glance, but the Samsung Consumer Electronics billboards on the Avenue of the Americas between 24th and 26th Streets aren't billboards at all. They are huge tapestries, photomurals really, made of nylon-mesh parachute cloth cut to fit the buildings like new siding, window cutouts included. This reusable approach to advertising is the work of Peter Arnell, who handles Samsung's marketing. In the largest printing job of this kind ever, the photographs (taken by Arnell) and graphics were transferred to 16-foot-wide cloth panels using a wide-board printer.

title: Feb. 25-March 2;Just Plain Words
description: If Bill Clinton had said it, he would have sounded un-Presidential. If Secretary of State Warren Christopher had said it, he would have seemed uncomfortable. But it seemed perfectly natural when Madeleine K. Albright, the 59-year-old grandmother who represents the United States at the United Nations, condemned Cuba's shootdown of two small civilian planes and uttered an expletive in the process. "Frankly, this is not cojones; this is cowardice," she said, echoing the very word the fighter pilots used as they boasted about their attack.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 3, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: Book Notes;The Story of 'Longitude,' a Surprise Best Seller
description: A YEAR ago, had anyone asked Dava Sobel what she thought would happen to a book on longitude that she was writing, she might have replied, "Very little."

title: E.P.A. Tells Landfills to Curb Gas Emissions
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency will require that the nation's largest landfills -- a list topped by the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island -- significantly curb the volume of noxious gases that steam up from rotting mountains of garbage.

title: AT LEISURE;A Sport That Offers Equal Opportunity, if Not Fresh Air
description: It's Tuesday night, a league night at the Courtside, and the president of the North Jersey Darts Federation -- with a pint of Pete's Wicked Ale in one hand and a Marlboro Menthol in the other -- is explaining why his beloved sport doesn't get the respect it deserves.

title: The Nation;Congress Shall Be Nothing if Not Contentious
description: IN his book "To Renew America," Speaker Newt Gingrich recommends the study of early American history "as a form of self-improvement," to reverse the "decay of our civilization."

title: Let Tigers Dance
description: I WANT to go to Princeton," says Amory Blaine, the young hero of F. Scott Fitzgerald's "This Side of Paradise."

title: Word for Word: Military Gay Policy;When 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' Means Do Ask and Do Tell All
description: WHEN the Clinton Administration announced a policy of "don't ask, don't tell" for homosexuals in the military, the rules seemed clear enough: Gay soldiers could serve so long as they kept quiet about their sexuality. Commanders would no longer be allowed to ask about a soldier's sexual orientation.

title: Ideas That Work for Appliance Repairer
description: THESE days, entrepreneurship is the name of the game. But back in 1960, when Anthony Attanasio left a good job as a Sears technician to go out on his own, not everyone applauded his enterprise.

title: Restaurant Was Never Inspected
description: The restaurant where a six-alarm fire began in the garment district Friday was never inspected by city fire or building inspectors, fire officials said yesterday. The reason, they added, was that the property had not been registered with the city and had been illegally occupied for at least six years.

title: Dante and Turrets and DDT: Princeton, as They've Lived It
description: New Jerseyans tend to experience Princeton University as something not quite New Jersey, an island of ivy in a sea of shopping malls, casinos and turnpike exits. But what is Princeton like to those who actually spend four years there? The following observations were compiled from interviews by James Barron '77, Andy Newman '86 and Alexandra Nyberg '97.

title: A Trip to the Edge of Nowhere
description: TOURING the arid, icy cold highlands of southwestern Bolivia is like taking a trip back in time -- all the way back to the earth's formative years. At more than 12,000 feet above sea level, the region bordering Chile and Argentina south and west of Lake Poopo is a bleak moonscape of immense salt flats, treeless hills and lakes stained a rainbow of colors. Volcanoes billow steam like gigantic smokestacks. Mud pots burp and gurgle sulfurous fumes.

title: Morality Play
description: In this scenario, the devil is in the details.

title: EDUCATION;For State Colleges, a 4-Year Contract but Not a Lot to Crow About
description: The longstanding threat of a strike at New Jersey's state colleges dissolved last week when negotiators finally agreed on a new contract for unionized faculty members. But the settlement left both sides glum, with union representatives bemoaning a wage freeze and college administrators wishing they could have pushed through a new system of raises based on job performance.

title: Q and A
description: Studying Art in France

title: From Low- to High-Tech at Philips Labs
description: IT was the winter of 1946 when Marguerite Norgren arrived at Philips Research Laboratories for an interview for a position as a file clerk.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;A Man Without a Position Prepares for Them All
description: Pardon Butch Huskey if his equipment bag is a little heavier than those belonging to other players. With three different gloves to pack along with his bats, Huskey could use his own personal baggage handler, if one were available.

title: WHERE MAVENS SHOP;ROME
description: THE white skullcap in Gammarelli's window discreetly signals the shop's status: tailor for two centuries to the popes and princes of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bosnia Sends Soldiers to Iran for Infantry Training
description: The Bosnian Government has sent soldiers to Iran for training as part of an effort to revamp its military, senior Western and Bosnian Government officials say.

title: ON THE JOB;When Your Resume Was a Blank Page
description: A first job is sometimes painful, sometimes joyful. But it is always unforgettable, a mine of lessons or a well of laughter that lasts a lifetime. Here are some readers' memories of this rite of passage.

title: Our Towns A Dog Shelter Rides the Wave Of a Big Rescue
description: SUDDENLY, everyone loves the Mohawk and Hudson River Humane Society. People burst in, breathless and excited, and the phone rings all day.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Quilt-Making Or Bookbinding?
description: YOU know the idea of learning vacations is gaining ground when it gets the Disney stamp of approval. The Disney Institute, which opened last month as a Walt Disney World resort in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., is a theme park for adults who want to dabble in a variety of areas from culinary arts to animation techniques. The institute offers two- and three-hour programs including how to shoot better home videos, collect antiques or talk like Mickey Mouse. Until May 18, three-night packages, including lodging but not meals, cost $349 a person; after May 18, the packages cost from $518 to $630 a person; (800) 282-9282, fax (407) 939-4898.

title: Revenge of the Nerd
description: QUENTIN TARANTINO The Man and His Movies. By Jami Bernard. Illustrated. 245 pp. New York: Harper Perennial. Paper, $13. QUENTIN TARANTINO Shooting From the Hip. By Wensley Clarkson. Illustrated. 312 pp. New York: The Overlook Press. Paper, $15.95.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Miles of Barricades

title: The View From: Willimantic;A Food Co-op, Stressing the Organic, Stands the Test of Time
description: AT the Willimantic Food Co-op, staff members greeted shoppers ("Hi! How y'doing?"), unloaded oranges and poured oat bran into a bin. Linda Carlson was shopping with her 9-year-old daughter, Emma Weiss. They live in Chaplin, and Ms. Carlson said they came to the co-op "because of the wholesome foods and the great people." Emma said, "I like Alice and her horse."

title: POLITICS: GEORGIA;Avid Following Buoys Buchanan
description: In a 36-hour period this week, three candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination held rallies in suburban Cobb County, ground zero for the explosion in the growth of Georgia Republicanism and for the state's Presidential primary next Tuesday.

title: CHATTER;An Inmate Who Wants to Die
description: John M. Martini, a death row inmate, says he wants to be executed. Should the Public Defender continue to file appeals against his wishes?

title: A Lapsed Man
description: HEARING VOICES By A. N. Wilson. 214 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $22.50. THE novelist A. N. Wilson is a member of that vanishing species, the English man of letters: urbane, ironic, fluent, precise, felicitously erudite and, above all, pleasurably readable. The volumes of his Lampitt Papers series are narrated by Julian Ramsay, a failed novelist who has made a lifelong career as a character actor in a lowbrow radio soap opera. They cover the period from just before World War II to the present -- or, rather, a little beyond the present, since Julian's now is revealed in this fourth volume to be just over the threshold of the new millennium. "Hearing Voices," however, is largely concerned with events in his life during the 1960's.

title: Sunday March 3, 1996: PATCHING THINGS UP;Balancing Act
description: Testosterone deficiency, bad jokes aside, is a serious medical condition whose symptoms include loss of sexual desire, fatigue, depression and osteoporosis. Most men aren't even aware that they suffer from a hormone shortage: researchers estimate that between four and five million are afflicted seriously enough to warrant treatment, although only 5 percent actually receive it.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 2 Greg Drew, rock 'n' roll voice trainer, teaches the art of clean living.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Market and Pharmacy Specialize in Vermont
description: Locally produced maple syrup, maple candy and cheddar cheese are staples in many Vermont markets. And they are the staples of the first business venture among four friends who decided that there was a market for them in Brooklyn.

title: Republican Primary A Rarity for Voters
description: FOR the first time in recent history there is a Republican Presidential primary in the state this year -- this Thursday -- but voters expecting it to bear much resemblance to what went on in New Hampshire last month will be disappointed.

title: Little Storm That Could Sets Record
description: Deep into a hard white winter that old-timers may brag about someday with neck-high gestures, an unpretentious snowstorm swirled up the Atlantic seaboard yesterday, reburying the landscape from Virginia to Massachusetts under 3 to 8 inches. In New York City, it quietly transformed the winter of 1995-96 into the snowiest in the 127 years that accurate weather records have been kept.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 18 about a video revival of films by the director John Cassavetes misidentified the actress who played the wife in "Faces." She was Lynn Carlin, not Gena Rowlands.

title: WEDDINGS;Teri Karush, Stuart Rogers
description: Teri Lynn Karush, a reporter for The American Lawyer in New York, and Stuart Charles Rogers, an associate at the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, are to be married today. Rabbi Charles G. Agin is to officiate at the Metropolitan, a catering concern in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Bus From Casinos Overturns, Killing 1 and Injuring 34
description: A Grayline tour bus bound for Manhattan, carrying dozens of sleeping passengers home from the Atlantic City casinos, overturned on the Garden State Parkway in central New Jersey early yesterday, killing one person and injuring 34, the police said.

title: CHELSEA;'Tunneling': Uptown Set Is Being Wooed
description: For a partier who frequents only nightspots on the Upper East Side, a visit to the Tunnel may seem like a trip through the Twilight Zone. Along the way are stops at the "hip-hop room," a dark lounge with exposed pipes and peeling paint; an immense dance hall (more exposed pipes), and a huge unisex bathroom with half-naked dancers bumping and grinding on the bar.

title: A Great Corporation Is Not a Country Club
description: To the Editor:

title: Acquisitions, the Inside Story
description: ACQUIRING Art in the 90's: The Inside Story" is first of all a lesson on how to stage a blockbuster without leaving home. The exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford is designed to provide a glimpse of how a museum adds to its holdings.

title: IN PERSON;What to Do, And When
description: From Turbi Smilow, an independent guidance counselor in North Brunswick, some words of advice on how and when to do what when applying to colleges:

title: State Would Ditch History Just to Save a Few Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial and Errors
description: Reasonable Doubts The O. J. Simpson Case and the Criminal Justice System. By Alan M. Dershowitz. Illustrated. 238 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $20.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: MADISON SQUARE;Van Gogh's Passion, in Van Gogh's Words
description: DOWNSTAGE left are an easel and paints. To the right, a chair. In this minimal setting, Vincent van Gogh, portrayed by Ger Campbell, an Irish actor, tells his troubled story in words the artist actually used.

title: SIGNOFF;Defending the Land of Mainframe
description: Big-eyed and blue-faced Bob and green-faced Dot are the heroes in "Reboot," the computer-animated cartoon show that takes place in a computer. (Dot's full name: Dot Matrix, as in printer, get it?)

title: RIVERDALE;A White House for Russians
description: These days, the murmur on Mosholu Avenue is enough to give any Secret Service agent night sweats. Word has it the Russians want to raze the White House.

title: Irrational Medicine
description: DEMOCRACY AND DAN

title: IN BRIEF;Juvenile Justice Commission Has a Leader and Advisers
description: After a bit of a rough start, Paul Donnelly, the man who moved from Austin, Tex., to New Jersey to head the Governor's new Juvenile Justice Commission without being formally assured he had the job, was sworn in last week, and the first three members of the commission's advisory council have been appointed.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;In Short Trip, Dole Predicts Big New York Victory
description: Bob Dole touched down on Long Island today for about half an hour and declared that New York would take him a "big, big way" toward cinching the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Crime Against Tourists Down in Rio, Police Say
description: Touring Rio de Janeiro was less dangerous last year than in 1994, according to the Specialized Police Branch (Divisao Especializada de Atendimento ao Turista), created in 1992 to help foreign tourists who are victims of crime. Thefts and robberies involving tourists dropped 21 percent in 1995: 1,223, down from 1,547 in 1994. Last year 790,000 foreign tourists visited Rio, an increase of 438,000 over 1990, according to the Brazilian Association of Travel Agents.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;A Co-op Regains the Road to Financial Recovery
description: ONE fall day in 1990 Rebecca Doggett and her husband, Joseph Thomasberger, bought their co-op at Crescent Park, a 266-apartment building in East Orange modeled on the grand Art Deco style of the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach.

title: EVENING HOURS;Of Pens and the Police
description: A party for a book, a party for book people and a party for police officers who stand out.

title: FILM VIEW;Go Ahead. Laugh. Babe Is Used to Ridicule
description: NO SOONER HAD THE Academy Award nominations been announced than the jokes began: all those catty references to sow's ears and bacon, headline variations on the phrase "pigs fly," cartoons showing quadrupeds before batteries of microphones. Entertainment Weekly featured a drawing of porcine hindquarters stepping into a Rolls, with the caption "You know the pickings are slim when you see Babe the pig shopping for a tux."

title: Brothers in a Movie World of Their Own
description: THE WINTRY LANDSCAPE IS FLAT AND bleak, a whiteout broken only by a strip of two-lane blacktop, a muddy police cruiser on the shoulder, a blossom of blood in the snow. A couple of local officers have come out from town to investigate. See, there's a car upside down in a farmer's field and three bodies have been found shot. Pretty darn mysterious. It's not every day they get a triple homicide in these parts, you know. One bumpkin of an officer is completely baffled. Jeez, he says.

title: The Longest War In the World
description: THE BORDER REGION BETWEEN Kenya and south Sudan is a harsh, dry, fly-ridden semidesert inhabited by nomadic cattle herders. The Kenyan village of Lokichokio sprouts up incongruously, a surreal boom town where growling cargo planes lift off from a world-class landing strip and sunburned Europeans and Americans populate a steadily expanding metropolis of safarilike huts and trailers. Lokichokio is the staging ground of Operation Lifeline Sudan, the United Nations' long-running, $2-million-a-week relief program that year after year brings precious little relief to the famished victims of Sudan's civil war, the longest war in the world.

title: POLITICS: ON CAMPUS;'Where's the Party?' Refers to Republicans
description: The spring-break tans at Washington and Lee University are not quite so common this year. Budding politicos preparing for this weekend's Mock Convention skipped the beaches, staying in town to phone hundreds of county Republican leaders in states large and small.

title: A Man Who Dreams of Bubbles to Mars
description: ASK most people what they think of bubbles and they'll recall the sweet summer days of youth, running through the grass, plastic bottle of soap solution in hand, dipping, then lifting the wand to the lips to blow, watching and giggling as one by one the shiny spheres floated, then burst with a splash. For most people, that's pretty much the end of bubbles.

title: FOOD;Threads of Expensive Saffron Wend Way Into Classic Dishes
description: SAFFRON is perhaps the most expensive ingredient of all. By the pound it costs thousands of dollars. Fortunately, it is used by the pinch.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Dan Woog;Taking Gay Issues Into the Schools
description: UNTIL two years ago very, very few people in Dan Woog's life knew that the award-winning high school soccer coach was gay.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
description: HARD COVER

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;Rem Koolhaas Sizes Up the Future
description: BY A HAPPY COINCIDENCE, Rem Koolhaas's new book, "S, M, L, XL," arrived just as the magnificent Mondrian show was ending its run at the Museum of Modern Art. One couldn't ask for a better symbol of the passing of modern art's baton than the fortuitous dovetailing of these two events. Mondrian, the pioneer abstract painter, ended his career with "Broadway Boogie-Woogie." Koolhaas, the flying Dutchman of contemporary architecture, began his career with "Delirious New York," a 1978 book that paid a comparably ecstatic tribute to Manhattan's fascinating rhythms. For a brief moment this winter, it seemed that the Dutch still held sway over this tiny, as yet untamed New World island.

title: THE SENATOR CANNOT HELP BEING HIMSELF
description: IN THE LAST DAY OF JANUARY AT 7 P.M., Alfonse D'Amato popped out of the side door of his office on the fifth floor of the Hart Senate Office Building and moved swiftly down the hallway with two aides and a reporter in pursuit. The Senator was upset.

title: More Groups Are Feeding the Hungry With What Others Leave
description: Gleaning, the ancient practice of providing leftover food to needy people, is spreading in the United States, from the larger farms where it first cropped up years ago to small organic farms, supermarkets and cafeterias.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;In Dublin, a Golden Run
description: THE powerful bomb that went off on Feb. 9 on London's Canary Wharf did not make a big noise on the floor of the Dublin stock exchange.

title: UZBEKISTAN'S GOLDEN CITY
description: THE SPARKLING CENTERPIECE of those jeweled cities strung on the swagged necklace of the ancient Silk Road, a remote oasis in the immensity of Central Asia, Samarkand has excited the imagination of conquerors and con men alike. Alexander the Great took the city in 329 B.C. and soon thereafter proclaimed himself a god. Marco Polo's travels may not have brought him to Samarkand, but he embellished its legend and thus his own. By the eighth century A.D., Islamic invaders swept in to convert the Zoroastrian populace (although secret fire worship continued to flourish). In 1220, Genghis Khan cut off the water supply, strangling the population, and reduced the city to rubble.

title: WEDDINGS;Lori Riker and David Begleiter
description: Lori Beth Riker, a daughter of Carol and Martin Riker of Armonk, N.Y., was married last evening to David Ian Begleiter, a son of Alvin Begleiter of White Plains and the late Muriel Begleiter. Rabbi David H. Lincoln performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: Spy Pablum
description: When a voluminous assessment of United States intelligence agencies devotes only two pages to criticisms of the Central Intelligence Agency, it is not hard to divine that the authors ducked some difficult issues. Unhappily, that is just what the Presidential commission on the future of American intelligence agencies has done. After a year of study and high public expectations, the commission has produced an anodyne report that offers no bold ideas for overhauling the Government's espionage empire, a creaky and expensive relic of the cold war.

title: PUFFINS GALORE
description: WHEN THE DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC programs at Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology asked us to sign on as "leaders" of a combined birding, archeological and remote-places expedition called " 'Round Britain," we figured it was as much challenge as invitation. Could two city-born and city-bred writers who didn't own a pair of hiking boots between them and knew almost nothing about birds, rocks, or neolithic society hold their own on an journey that seemed designed exclusively for those with a passion for identifying birds and tramping over long-abandoned, wind-whipped islands? This expedition wasn't bound for Wordsworth's Lake District, the Cotswolds, or any such bucolic area but instead for Milton's "stormy Hebrides," surf-beaten islands and rocky pillars rising out of the North Atlantic.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 11 about new uses for former city halls referred incompletely to renovation costs of the former Greenwich town hall. The cost to the town was about $420,000; $125,000 was the Greenwich Arts Council's cost for completing its space in the building.

title: William Wood, 68, Benefactor of Arts
description: William P. Wood, a Philadelphia lawyer, civic leader and benefactor of the arts and conservation, died on Feb. 24 at the Southern Chester County Community Medical Center in Pennsylvania. He was 68 and lived in Chatham, Pa.

title: Finances Are a Big Hurdle At Animal Medical Center
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: THEATER;Curtain Calls With No Help From Uncle Sam
description: WE ARE THE SUCCESsors to the pocket theaters of Paris," says Aaron Beall, executive director of Todo Con Nada, a tiny, 60-seat theater on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. "Beckett wrote for all these little theaters. He was charmed by their intimacy."

title: Shoes Step Up and Talk Ugly
description: IT'S not that clothes are out, but the buying public has a new credo: feet first.

title: Arid Corner Of Chile Preserves History
description: THE view from the window of the bus taking me the 60 miles from Calama to San Pedro de Atacama showed nothing but stones and sky. Vast stretches of reddish-brown or gray gravel rose toward rocky hills and distant volcanoes; although I could see for miles, there wasn't a shred of green. Mars, I thought, must look like this. Still, the barren landscape had a majesty that softer places couldn't match. And the long ride through the desert made the dusty trees and fields around the little town of San Pedro appear downright inviting when the village came into view.

title: World News Briefs;U.S. and Brazil Reach Accord on Nuclear Issue
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher, on a five-country tour of Latin America, has initialed an agreement opening the way for Brazil to purchase nuclear technology from American companies.

title: WEDDINGS;Megan Mulry, Jeffrey Huisinga
description: Margaret Power Mulry, a daughter of Margaret and Thomas Mulry of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Michael Huisinga, a son of Judith and E. Lindell Huisinga of Monticello, Ill. Norman Goodman, the New York County Clerk, performed the ceremony at the Inn at Irving Place in Manhattan.

title: ART;A Visionary Artist's Output During a Time of Mental Illness
description: Blakelock: Visionary in Context Heckscher Museum, Prime Avenue, Huntington. Through Apr. 7. 351-3250.

title: SHELTER;A Time Limit on Motel Stays Hits Welfare Families Hard
description: For the past five months, Warren and Julie M. have reluctantly made their home in the Capri Inn on Route 46, furnishing their champagne-colored, glass-mirrored room with a toaster oven, a cooler, some books and some baby food for their 6-month-old son, Rasheem.

title: YOUR HOME;Winter Flooding Problems
description: AFTER a winter like this one, the best thing that can be said about snow is that it eventually melts. But it has not necessarily gone away for good. In fact, it just could cause some trouble come spring.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 25 about traveling art shows and how they are planned misstated the opening date for a Cezanne retrospective at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. It is May 30, not May 18; the show is to close on Aug. 18.

title: To the Middle East
description: To the Editor: The Travel section article on Petra ("Through the Gorge to Petra," Feb. 11) gave alluring attention to this most popular attraction in Jordan, but the story was unduly limiting in referring to excursions to Petra only from Israel.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JAMAICA;Borngod Allah, Surviving
description: On Feb. 11, The City profiled the scene at a Jamaica, Queens, pawnshop run by a man known as Goldfinger, who helps out aspiring rappers. Here's a look at one of his proteges, Borngod Allah, who has just had a child.

title: SPENDING IT;When Frequent Fliers Could Use a Compass
description: IN growing numbers over the last 15 years, companies from airlines to credit issuers to hotel chains have offered frequent-flier miles as incentives to vacation-hungry Americans.

title: Regulating Travel
description: To the Editor: I found the Practical Traveler column "To Regulate Agents or Not" (Jan. 21) somewhat disturbing. I entirely disagree with the prominence it provided to comments from travel industry lobbyists. Their premise that state legislation in this domain has been overly hasty is self-serving. It helps only to perpetuate the fragmented state of regulation, which nurtured the Milestone Educational Institute debacle in 1993. The abrupt default of Milestone, a Massachusetts student tour operator, caused 4,462 students and teachers to lose $7.8 million. according to the State Attorney General.

title: LIVES;Bar, None
description: The Spring Lounge, one of the last two neighborhood bars in Little Italy (aside from private social clubs), is up for sale, which makes me scared. For years I've used the place as a rendezvous-resting place and portable office; it was also a virtual residence for a character in my first novel. The Spring Lounge isn't the only neighborhood bar I've used to shelter both myself and people who populate my books, but lately it seems as if they've all been going down like birds shot off a wire.

title: DANCE IN FILMS;Who Really Makes Those Moves?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Last Accounting of the Great Snows of Yesteryear
description: No banshee howl of blizzard wind or wild white dance of winter madness attended the funeral yesterday of a record.

title: POLITICS: CHANGING DIRECTION;DOLE EASILY BEATS BUCHANAN TO WIN IN SOUTH CAROLINA
description: Senator Bob Dole won a commanding victory today in the South Carolina primary, a crucial Southern test that led him to reclaim the title of front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: WEDDINGS;Heather Simpson, Benjamin Hanson
description: Heather Simpson, a hydrogeologist, and Dr. Benjamin Zane Hanson, a geochemist at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, were married yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y. Eileen Pilla, the Mayor of Tarrytown, officiated at Tappan Hill.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;49ers Sign Hampton To an Offer Sheet
description: The San Francisco 49ers have pursued running back Rodney Hampton the way a tiger eyes its prey. They have acted with great passion and hunger in their hunt of the Giants' running back and they have been prepared to do whatever it takes to get him.

title: Escape to the Azores
description: AS ALWAYS, IT IS THE GETTING THERE THAT COUNTS. THE MORE RUGGED the journey, the more secure the memory of it against the ravages of time -- and the deeper the awareness of where you have arrived. That is why I was determined to make the voyage from Sao Miguel, the largest of the Azores, to Santa Maria, the southernmost island, by boat.

title: Ideas & Trends;Coal Tries for a Comeback
description: STANDING against the side of a soot-streaked mountain, the cluster of rickety wooden buildings that comprise the Blaschak family coal company look as if time passed them by decades ago.

title: Compromising Positions;I Promised Me a Rose Garden
description: TIRED of professional politicians? Let's have a citizens' Congress that meets only half the year, at half today's pay, and stays home the rest of the time.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 3/ The stock of the Iomega Corporation, which makes the popular Zip drives for computers, has skyrocketed, but short-sellers control a huge amount of the shares. By Edward Wyatt.

title: IN PERSON;She'll Get You In
description: IN a year and a half, if all goes well, Lauren Carifa, now 17, will be unpacking T-shirts, computer disks, cookie tins and her Ridgewood High School diploma in her dormitory room at college, the right college, the college where she will be pushed but not panicked, with students who will challenge but not viciously compete.

title: WEDDINGS;Shirley Hannah, John Rosenbaum
description: Shirley Elaine Hannah, a daughter of Ethel and Harold Hannah of Abingdon, Va., is to be married today to John Edward Rosenbaum, the son of Joan and Joseph Rosenbaum of South Orange, N.J. Rabbi David Davis officiated at the Claremont Country Club in Oakland, Calif.

title: Marijuana for Pain Isn't Good Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Shaman or Showman?
description: ON a recent Sunday morning, before stores on Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, pulled up their steel shutters for business, the office of El Indio Amazonico near 86th Street was already filled with about 20 men whose heavy hearts were expressed by their knotted brows and compressed lips.

title: VILLAGES, EAST AND WEST;'One Way' Just Became The Other
description: Some people were surprised on Monday to find that West 11th Street had changed directions between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. The move was long talked about to improve safety at Mulry Square, but some locals -- including P.S. 41's principal, Frank DeStefano, and St. Vincent's Hospital -- did not learn it was happening until the day the one-way signs were reversed, to eastbound from westbound. The transportation department told a Community Board 2 committee meeting last month that the change was slated for the end of February. "We apologize for any inconvenience," a spokesman said, "but the project as a whole was very upfront from the beginning."

title: VILLAGES, EAST AND WEST;At P.S. 41, the Medium Is the Window
description: It pays to advertise. When Public School 41, the Greenwich Village School, needs supplies, it takes its message to the streets. And gets results. The medium: hand-printed fliers in its windows on West 11th Street.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Spiders With 500 Legs, for 2-Legged Investors
description: LAST year was a great time to be in a stock mutual fund, but it was an even better year to be in an index fund.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;Remembrance of War: A Personal Side of Dole
description: It is the essence of the Bob Dole story, and now, after nearly a year of campaigning for President for the third time, the Senator is starting to tell it in some detail.

title: WEDDINGS;Sarah E. Pigman, Roger Tellefsen
description: Sarah Edith Pigman, an information systems consultant in Berwyn, Pa., was married yesterday to F. Roger Tellefsen, an associate at Weichert Realtors in West Chester, Pa. The Rev. Mark John Ainsworth performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Peter's Church in the Great Valley in Paoli, Pa.

title: Long Island Q&A: James R. Powell;When High Tech Can Help Low Tech Like Roads and Trains
description: DR. JAMES R. POWELL of Shoreham is a co-founder of a consortium formed to demonstrate how new technology can help rebuild the nation's deteriorated infrastructure at half the price.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;Gambling With the Thermometer in Bermuda
description: AT a latitude of 32 degrees, Bermuda has winters that are mild rather than tropical, and though the archipelago is warmed by the Gulf Stream, from January to March it is only people from places like Saskatoon who dare to swim off a Bermudian pink sand beach.

title: Expatriate Games
description: IN the early 1970's I lived in Cambridge, Mass., in theory attending graduate school but actually trying to write a novel. Each day I went to a morning class; then I came home, started my novel and within minutes went back to bed and watched television until bedtime. I don't recall whether life was imitating art or vice versa, but I dimly remember that the book I was attempting to write involved a group of young people living in the Boston area and barely staying awake.

title: Managed Care Is Less Care At Creedmoor's Clinics
description: To the Editor:

title: SPENDING IT;For Used Cars, New Pitches
description: FOR Barry Gitteman, the road to buying a 1994 Jeep Grand Cherokee took a sudden turn three weeks ago at a car dealership in Annapolis, Md. To afford the Jeep, Mr. Gitteman, a teacher at the Naval Academy, needed to get top dollar for his 1992 Ford Taurus.

title: MUSIC;Offering Younger Listeners An Introduction to a Concert
description: PARENTS hoping to insure that their children are exposed at any early age to the joys of classical music have several options this week.

title: Shootings at Schools Prompt New Concerns About Violence
description: Two years after school districts around the nation scrambled to adopt tough provisions to keep guns out of schools, fatal shootings of students and teachers are again on the rise, renewing concerns about crime and violence in schools.

title: A Job Well Done
description: To the Styles Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Margaret Tracey, Russell Kaiser
description: Margaret Tracey and Russell Joseph Kaiser, dancers at the New York City Ballet, were married on Tuesday at the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew in New York. The Rev. Edward Horne performed the United Methodist ceremony.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH STOPPARD By Mel Gussow. Limelight, $18.

title: New in High School: Lessons in Trust
description: IN a traditional high school physical education class, climbing the walls of the gymnasium would not be tolerated. Neither would jumping off bleachers or jumping off telephone poles. Most teachers would not allow boys and girls to hold hands or hug each other in class, either.

title: India Acts in Scandal
description: The Supreme Court has ordered the federal police to stop taking orders from the Government and report only to the court in its investigation into an $18 million bribery scandal.

title: ON CAMPUS;Distinguished Alumni Help Rutgers Inaugurate Its New Arts Center
description: In the late 1950's, George Segal was already an aspiring artist, but he was trying to make a living as a chicken farmer in South Brunswick. He and Allan Kaprow, an artist who was teaching art history at Rutgers University, developed a friendship based on their avid interest in the New York School of Abstract Expressionism. Mr. Kaprow invited Mr. Segal to teach a drawing course and -- when chicken farming turned out to be as unremunerative as art-making -- to pursue a master's degree at Rutgers to improve his academic prospects. Their hunger for a more direct reflection of "the look of the tangible world" in art touched off what Mr. Segal jokingly calls "the New Brunswick school," whose aim was to incorporate fragments of everyday life.

title: OFF THE SHELF;Primers of Persuasion: How to Win With Words
description: A FRIEND of mine, a lawyer doing business in the former Soviet sphere, once told me about a contract he negotiated for some American businessmen investing in a Russian enterprise during the old perestroika days.

title: 'Infinite Jest'
description: Reading David Foster Wallace's latest novel, ''Infinite Jest,'' I couldn't help thinking at times about 7-year-old Seymour Glass's book-length ''letter'' home from camp, published in The New Yorker in 1965 as ''Hapworth 16, 1924.'' I felt a similar feeling of admiration alloyed with impatience veering toward strained credulity. (Do you suppose Seymour's parents actually read the whole thing?) I had previously been a great admirer of Mr. Wallace's collection of stories, ''Girl With Curious Hair,'' and, to a lesser extent, of the loose, baggy monster that was his debut novel, ''The Broom of the System,'' which I confess to not finishing. If Mr. Wallace were less talented, you would be inclined to shoot him -- or possibly yourself -- somewhere right around page 480 of ''Infinite Jest.'' In fact, you might anyway.

title: Pirro Assailed Over News Breaks
description: ON Dec. 31, 1993, just hours before Jeanine Pirro was to take office as Westchester County District Attorney, the newspaper heiress Anne Scripps Douglas was slain in Bronxville. As David Hebert tells it, Ms. Pirro had not even unpacked her files before she was deluged with requests from the television show "America's Most Wanted" and the news program "Dateline NBC."

title: PLAYWRIGHTS AND TV;Fluidity Is The Key
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Chroniclers of the 90's Push Their Book Onto the Web
description: STEVEN DALY and Nathaniel Wice wanted to chronicle 90's youth culture, and they wanted to do it without one unsatirical mention of the moniker Generation X.

title: Giuliani Backs Crew's Bid to Postpone School Board Elections
description: In his bid to postpone the May 7 community school board elections for at least a year while officials investigate patronage and corruption, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, has won the support of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and, it appears, a majority of the members of the Board of Education.

title: Anti-Drug Effort Turns To Elementary Schools
description: IT is fairly common knowledge that many high school and even junior high school students experiment with drugs, but what about youngsters still in elementary grades? To stop them from becoming involved with marijuana and alcohol, the yearly all-elementary schools meeting of the Mamaroneck Public Schools will, for the first time, focus on drugs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 4 about Antarctica misidentified the zone where the waters of the Southern Ocean meet the warmer seas of the Atlantic and Pacific. It is the Antarctic Convergence, not Conversion. The article also misstated the century in which Europeans were drawn to Antarctic waters. It was the 19th, not the 16th.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Grudge Match With Hollywood
description: ONCE, there were stars like Jean Arthur and Robert Taylor. And movies had laughs, romance and poignancy. Nobody talked about "character-driven" stories with "thematic underpinnings." The business was manipulation, and the product was cheap sentiment. But it made people happy.

title: L.I. a Key to Future Of 3-State Region
description: LONG ISLAND'S fate is inseparably wedded to the future of a three-state metropolitan region that faces irreversible economic, environmental and social decline over the next 25 years, the Regional Plan Association is forecasting.

title: Perspective/Boxing: 25 Years Haven't Softened The Blows;Frazier Finally Earned Respect Inside the Ring
description: The fight goes on. The opponent is always the same. Not the hoarse, shuffling Muhammad Ali of 1996, but the brash, crafty Muhammad Ali of 1971.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THE SWORD OF IMAGINATION Memoirs of a Half-Century of Literary Conflict. By Russell Kirk. Eerdmans, $34.99.

title: Hoop Is Thicker Than Water
description: AT MCNICHOLS ARENA IN DENVER, IT'S the second quarter of a sloppy game between two losing teams, the Denver Nuggets and the Golden State Warriors. Rick Barry, the 51-year-old basketball Hall of Famer, is watching more intensely than most of the players are playing. "Come on!" he says.

title: WEDDINGS;Judith Gelernter And Jon Jaroker
description: Judith Gelernter, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Gelernter of Setauket, L.I., is to be married today to Jon Jaroker, the son of Elena and Michael Jaroker of Great Kills, S.I. The bride's grandfather Rabbi Theodore N. Lewis is to perform the ceremony at the Three Village Inn in Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions;Renaissance Ballroom, and Luxury on Upper Fifth
description: 22 East 35th Street

title: WEDDINGS;Robin Sheingold, Sydney J. Mehl
description: Robin Sheingold, a sales executive, and Dr. Sydney J. Mehl, a cardiologist, are to be married today at Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to perform the ceremony.

title: Feb. 25-March 2;Irish Peace Talks On Again
description: More than two weeks after the I.R.A. ended its 17-month cease-fire with a scattering of bombs in London, the leaders of Britain and Ireland last week tried to put the battered Northern Ireland peace process back on track. On Wednesday, Prime Ministers John Major of Britain and John Bruton of Ireland said talks between all the warring sides -- once an elusive prospect -- would take place without fail on June 10.

title: DANCE VIEW;In Pace With Its Time: Fast, Complex, Like a Computer
description: AT A TIME WHEN YOUNG people prefer E-mail to the human voice on the telephone, it is not surprising that choreographers and dancers are communing with the public in new ways. This past season the New York City Ballet dancers, surpassing their customary brilliance, dazzled with fresh daring and bold technique. Speed and complexity, synonymous with the computer age, were especially visible in both the company's performances and its new choreography. No other comparable troupe has so consistently mirrored its time, beginning in the late 1940's with George Balanchine's futuristic works to modern music and Jerome Robbins's studies in urban alienation.

title: A LA CARTE;Make Way for a Promising Russian Restaurant in Oceanside
description: RUSSIAN restaurants have always ben rare on Long Island. In recent years, two of these, Fyodoroff in Carle Place and La Petite Maison Russe in Woodmere, have tried and failed to find a home here. But the sparkling, new 40-seat storefront Cafe Samovar, opened by a warm, hospitable Russian family, at 2245 Long Beach Road in Oceanside (764-7676), has the potential to be around for quite a while.

title: On the Battlefields of Business, Millions of Casualties
description: Drive along the asphalt river of Interstate 95 across the Rhode Island border and into the pristine confines of Connecticut. Stop at that first tourist information center with its sheaves of brochures promising lazy delights. What could anyone possibly guess of Steven A. Holthausen, the portly man behind the counter who dispenses the answers?

title: Feb. 25-March 2;The First Farewell
description: The Ramones, the New York group that helped create punk-rock in the 70's, bid farewell to their fans on Thursday night.

title: WHERE MAVENS SHOP;NEW YORK
description: WHAT do vacuum cleaners, chandeliers and taxicab domes have in common? They all need light bulbs. The bulbs may come in very different shapes and sizes, but they belong to the bulb family nonetheless, and therefore they all huddle together at a New York store called, not surprisingly, Just Bulbs.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Sears, With 750 Jobs, Is Replacing Alexander's
description: After sitting vacant for three years, the 200,000-square-foot building that had housed Alexander's department store in Rego Park, Queens, is getting a new tenant: Sears, Roebuck & Company. The retailer, based in Illinois, plans to open there on March 16.

title: POSTINGS: Tourneau and Swatch on 57th Street;Where Time Is of the Essence
description: It's a long way from Times Square, capital 'T,' but 57th Street between Fifth and Madison will soon be a mini times square too.

title: In the Middle East: Terror or Retaliation?
description: To the Editor:

title: VOWS;Elizabeth King and Paul Farrell
description: ELIZABETH KING, 36, can make topiaries, vinegars or petits fours that look like Wedgwood china as easily as others make instant coffee.

title: Habitats/From Central Park West to Park Slope;Back to a Big House
description: WHEN Louise Orkin, 60, a sculptor, and her husband, Leonard, 63, a lawyer in Manhattan, decided to leave their seven-room Central Park West apartment and buy a big house in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, she said her friends were more than incredulous.

title: DINING OUT;Faithfully Spanish Menu, Vibrant Cuisine
description: GREAT NECK boasts everything from kosher Persian to nuevo Puerto Rican food. Now the Spanish have made their move to Middle Neck Road. Spanish restaurants are rare on Long Island. Most straddle two continents with a Spanish-Mexican menu, a mismatch of vastly different cuisines.

title: The Wild, Wild Lower East Side;Democracy Is Messy. Does That Mean It Doesn't Work? A Look at Community Board 3.
description: A PHALANX of police officers nervously watched over last November's meeting of Community Board 3 on the Lower East Side, where even the prosaic task of taking attendance is highly charged. As the name of each member was read aloud, shouts of "guilty" resounded from the audience of hecklers, squatters and anarchists. It was business as usual for the beleaguered board -- cat feces, smoke bombs and raw eggs have flown at past meetings. On this night, however, a different weapon was to be unveiled.

title: ART;Over Their Shoulders, an Iron Hand
description: IT HAS BEEN TWO decades since the first historical survey of Hitler's official art raised such an outcry that the Frankfurter Kunstverein, which mounted the exhibition, found it necessary to publish a book of the outraged reactions.

title: Kvetching Through Russia
description: MOSCOW DAYS Life and Hard Times in the New Russia. By Galina Dutkina. Translated by Catherine A. Fitzpatrick. 238 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $23. IN "Moscow Days: Life and Hard Times in the New Russia," Galina Dutkina tries very hard to persuade her readers that life in post-Communist Russia is horrible. And while hers is a premise that most people in the West would readily accept, Ms. Dutkina does a surprisingly bad job of demonstrating it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GYMNASTICS Strug Wins at American Cup

title: Meteorologist Finds His Moment in the Snow
description: When Ignatius Camporeale sat down to eat his omelet dinner on Friday night in Hoboken, N.J., he had a feeling it was going to be, as he put it, a "momentous day," undoubtedly the pinnacle of his career.

title: The Downstairs That Kept the Upstairs Going
description: THE vivid portrayal of a butler and housekeeper in the Merchant-Ivory movie "Remains of the Day" shed sympathetic light on the vanished world of the English country house servant. Fortunately for those whose curiosity was piqued, the vestiges of that shadowy realm of maids, cooks and gardeners have been painstakingly preserved by Britain's National Trust, which marked its centennial last year.

title: HARLEM;A Legend Reviews His Housing Legacies
description: For the last 14 years, the Rev. Dr. M. Moran Weston has been retired. But that description is little more than a technicality. The only hint of a leisurely pace for Dr. Weston, 85, a theologian, banker, developer of affordable housing, human-rights advocate and Harlem mainstay, is that he spends more time at his Florida home where, as he puts it, "there are no stairs to climb."

title: CLASSICAL BRIEF
description: BRITTEN: 'THE HOLY SONNETS OF JOHN DONNE,' SONGS Ian Bostridge, tenor; Graham Johnson, pianist. Hyperion CDA66823; CD.

title: ART REVIEW;Africa and Ecuador: What 3 Artists Saw
description: ATTRACTIONS at Aljira: A Center for Contemporary Art here begin with the black-and-white prints of Olusegun Fayemi, a photographer who is currently represented in "African Images/American Portraits," at the Newark Public Library. They are followed by Hugo X. Bastidas's grisaille paintings and, for dessert, the opalescent watercolors of Joe Overstreet, whose retrospective is on view at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton. It is a cross section involving contrasts, the most obvious of which are chromatic and the most profound are temperamental.

title: POSTINGS: American Landmark and Brown, Harris, Stevens;2 Building Managers Ally
description: Only a month ago, American Landmark Management, a midsize manager of buildings, was struggling to compete; Oskar Brecher, its president, was holding talks around town, searching for a merger or a consolidation with another midsize company.

title: A.T.M. Problems
description: To the Editor: In her Jan. 21 essay ("Global Village? Not Really"), Pamela Petro speaks of having her Mastercard rejected at several A.T.M.'s, for reasons no one could explain. My daughter had a similar problem in Israel recently. We finally discovered that the A.T.M.'s in Israel use four-digit PIN numbers. My daughter's number had six digits.

title: Longer Perspectives on the Moses Epoch
description: USING drawings, models, photographs and original artifacts, many of them never displayed, an exhibition at the Museums of Stony Brook, "Robert Moses and the Shaping of New York," chronicles the life and work of the man who had a profound influence on Long Island life.

title: A Thousand and One Japanese Nights
description: The Pillow Boy of the Lady Onogoro By Alison Fell. 247 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace & Company. $22.

title: PATH Isn't the Problem; Raising Fare Isn't a Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: The Continuing Fallout Of Business Downsizing
description: FORECASTS for Connecticut's economy have been as chilly as a gale in winter, with economists anticipating that most areas will be suffering for another year. And economic indicators are only part of the picture. A recent study reveals worsening social problems in the state and a gloomy attitude about the future.

title: Backyard Horses? Try a Support Group
description: CONNECTICUT'S newest horse club is not for fancy folk. It's for the backyard horseowners who cannot afford stable fees or simply don't want to have their horses elsewhere.

title: DIARY
description: THE LAST FRONTIER Feet First Aggressively pursuing the market for connecting people to the Internet, AT&T; announced ambitious programs that include unlimited Internet access, electronic mail and nationwide directory service for under $20 a month. It also said its telephone customers could have five hours of free Internet access each month. The plan puts strong pressure on all other players and would-be competitors -- and on AT&T; to keep its lines and technical support unclogged.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Serbs May Sever Some NATO Contacts
description: NATO officials said today that the Bosnian Serbs had indicated that they might sever some ties with the peacekeeping force after the indictment of one of their generals by the war crimes tribunal at The Hague.

title: THEATER REVIEW;The Life and Art Of Clint Holmes
description: Clint Holmes has a story. So who doesn't?

title: Richard V. Benson, Advertiser, 74
description: Richard V. Benson, a magazine-circulation consultant and a pioneer in the field of direct-mail advertising, died on Feb. 22 at his home in Fernandina Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 74.

title: TECHNOLOGY VIEW;How to Cure Those TV Blues (and Reds and Greens)
description: THE OLD BILL NYE QUIP that "Wagner's music is better than it sounds" might be applied, with slight image adjustment, to the television set. Chances are, your picture can be a lot better than it looks, even if it looks pretty good.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE AGE OF WIRE AND STRING Stories. By Ben Marcus. Knopf, $21.

title: Boards: Vital Link or Just Red Tape?
description: DO community boards work?

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks Find the Bluest Highways
description: It began with Don Nelson and John Starks going through conniptions in Phoenix a week ago, and ended with their boss, Madison Square Garden President Dave Checketts, eyeing a spent locker room at the Delta Center here Friday night.

title: WINE;The Right Mate With Steak May Not Always Be a Red
description: MATCHING wine to steak need not be a complex process, but for the pairing to please the palate optimally requires more than the casual selection of just any red.

title: Who's Fighting Whom?
description: To the Styles Editor:

title: To the Middle East
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from the area, my wife and I were most interested to read the coverage of Sharm el Sheik and its surroundings ("Undersea Wonders Off Sinai's Sands," Feb. 11). Your readers may be interested to know that, due no doubt to lessened political tensions in the area, the sights may be conveniently visited on a Red Sea cruise.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;A Creator Of Gardens In Sound, He Looked Only Ahead
description: WITH THE DEATH of the eminent Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu on Feb. 20, the world of contemporary music lost one of its most creative and versatile practitioners. In a career spanning more than 40 years, Takemitsu wrote not only orchestral and other instrumental works but also nearly 100 film scores integral to the art of New Wave cinema in Japan. Bridging Eastern and Western styles, he sought to merge ancient court music and traditional Japanese instruments with modern forms.

title: VIEWPOINT;Cracking the Cookie Cutter
description: WHAT was your biggest failure in your previous job?"

title: Frozen Ghosts in a Famous Garden
description: On the subject of winter, the artist Andrew Wyeth once observed that something waits beneath it; not all is revealed. So it was recently in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art, where the familiar was transformed into the cryptic by a mantle of snow. The frozen landscape revealed a half-told tale, one in which nature's hand briefly altered the complexion of art. Sculptures by Picasso, Calder, Moore, Miro and Maillol were transformed by their borrowed coats: old friends hunkered inside ghosts of their true selves. But these souls will soon reappear, for in March we're reminded that winter is water soluble. ANNETTE GRANT

title: HELP;Giving The Gift Of Time
description: The following is a list of some organizations around the five boroughs that can use your help.

title: Housing Authorities Find New Strategies
description: THE Danbury Housing Authority has won so many regional and national awards that its executive director, Bernard Fitzpatrick, says his peers elsewhere seem jealous.

title: Adventures of Alexander Supertramp
description: INTO THE WILD By Jon Krakauer. 207 pp. New York: Villard Books. $22.

title: BOOKEND;The Singer of Tales: On Joseph Brodsky
description: Those who knew Joseph Brodsky were well aware that his heart disease was serious and that it would probably be the death of him, but because he always existed in his friends' minds not just as a person but as some kind of principle of indestructibility, it was difficult for them to admit that he was in danger. The intensity and boldness of his genius plus the sheer exhilaration of being in his company kept you from thinking about the threat to his health; he had such valor and style, and lived at such a deliberate distance from self-pity and personal complaint, you were inclined to forget that he was as mortal as the next one. So his death in January at the age of 55 was all the more shocking and distressing. Having to speak of him in the past tense feels like an affront to grammar itself.

title: Riverhead Battling Steep Decline
description: LOIS DeWALL remembers a time during the 1940's when there were three thriving sweet shops on Main Street in downtown Riverhead.

title: PATH Isn't the Problem; Raising Fare Isn't a Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM;A Multinational Consortium All in One Actor
description: IT'S A WEDNESDAY, LATE afternoon, and Alfred Molina has only a brief time between shows. This doesn't seem to matter one whit to him. No "do not disturb" signs for this actor. No deep-breathing exercises. Not even 40 winks.

title: Dams for Water Supply Are Altering Earth's Orbit, Expert Says
description: The insatiable thirst of the world's burgeoning billions has caused a spurt of dam building in temperate regions in the last 40 years, and a scientist with the space agency has found that the reservoirs are affecting Earth's orbital rotation.

title: Rose Memories
description: To the Styles Editor:

title: PLAYWRIGHTS AND TV;Interactive Art Form
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;When Dickens Came Via the Installment Plan
description: THE VICTORIANS read the novels of Dickens and Thackeray serialized monthly in the form of paperback books in much the same way that television audiences today watch weekly episodes of "Melrose Place." As masters of melodrama, 19th-century writers pushed all the buttons to keep fans coming back for more thrills in each installment.

title: Asian and European Nations Pledge Partnership
description: European and Asian leaders ended their first economic summit meeting today by promising a "strong partnership" in trade and investment but leaving contentious human rights issues unresolved.

title: MILAN, BEYOND CHIC
description: Y HUSBAND, BOB, AND I HAVE ENTERED THE flow of Italian history: we are fleeing the hordes. We head from the hills to the Lombardy plain in an attempt to salvage the remaining four days of a vacation buffeted by crowds. Where, we had asked each other, could we go that tourists, people like us, don't? What place is never mentioned in the same breath or breathlessness as Venice, Florence or Rome?

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Aging Hardware Means Increased Airline Delays
description: The weather may be fine for flying and the plane may be ready and waiting, or even most of the way to its destination. But the flight may still be delayed because the country's air traffic control system has broken down.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Feb. 18, about new airlines serving New York airports, misstated a telephone number for Kiwi International reservations in New Jersey. It is (201) 622-3232. Passengers may also call (800) 538-5494, the other number given in the column.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Fractured Fairy Tales
description: Julie Taymor is one of the most remarkable theater artists of the last two decades, though she unfortunately remains known to only a relatively small group of cognoscenti. Like the works she creates, Ms. Taymor is not easily classifiable; she is a director, a designer, a mask and puppet maker, a choreographer, film maker and fabulist. She creates worlds of visual splendor and an almost childlike fantasy that, like good fairy tales, reveal grotesquerie and even horror just barely beneath the surface. Her work as a designer and director reflects her literal and artistic journeys through Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Bali, Japan and Paris and her apprenticeships with Joseph Chaikin, Herbert Blau and the Bread and Puppet Theater. This background has resulted in productions of Shakespeare, opera and original works in which the visual, the narrative and the symbolic are inseparable. Ms. Taymor integrates techniques and esthetics from a wide variety of theatrical cultures. But unlike some contemporary directors who seem to plunder other cultures for inspiration only to come up with mere superficial borrowings, she creates a unique yet somehow familiar vocabulary that, as Eileen Blumenthal, a professor of theater arts at Rutgers University, says in her highly readable JULIE TAYMOR, PLAYING WITH FIRE: Theater, Opera, Film (Abrams, $49.50), is a "new theatrical organism." Ms. Taymor, who collaborated on the book with Ms. Blumenthal, describes each of the 15 productions she has designed or directed since her work in Bali in the mid-1970's. This book will be of interest to anyone who wonders where the magic, spirit and theatricality of the theater have gone in recent times, or to anyone who values the visual and creative imagination. Arnold Aronson

title: Interlude At Lake George
description: OUR winter weekend at Lake George and Gore Mountain came about almost by accident. At a silent auction for the benefit of our local nature center, my husband, Rolf, had placed a bid for a long-weekend stay at a snow-covered cottage that had been seductively photographed in sight of a frozen Lake George. Among the area's attractions were cited nearness to a ski area new to us -- Gore Mountain -- and several fine country inns. Our bid captured the prize.

title: Sunday March 3, 1996: NO-FAULT PHOTOS;Picture Perfect Divorce
description: The divorce is long final, but the marriage's early promise is still enshrined in the wedding album. Now, thanks to an enterprising businessman in Vancouver, British Columbia, current marital reality and past photo op can be reconciled. Keith Guelpa's computer-aided photographic service, Divorce X, allows embittered customers to preserve the precious memories (usually pictures of themselves) and edit out the bitter ones (their used-to-be's).

title: U.S. Consulates
description: To the Editor: The article "First U.S. Consulate Will Close Its Doors" (Travel Advisory, Jan. 28), about the consulate in Bordeaux, reminded me of my experience. I had the dubious honor and distinct displeasure of closing another of our long-term consulates -- in Izmir, Turkey -- in 1993, when I was consul general there.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MIDWOOD Haitian Voodoo Beat, Traditional and Modern

title: IN BRIEF;Light-Rail Proposal Wins Award for Design
description: The Federal Department of Transportation and the National Endowment for the Arts have given Wallace Roberts & Todd, a Philadelphia urban design firm, an Honor Award for its Urban Design Guidelines Handbook for New Jersey Transit's proposed Hudson-Bergen Light Rail Transit System.

title: QUICK SIP;Casino City Comes Up With Another Winner
description: The Atlantic City Municipal Utilities Authority, the waterworks of Monopoly board fame, has done it again. For the third time since 1992, it has won a Toast of the Tap Award, competing this year against 33 other municipalities including New York and Philadelphia.

title: TELEVISION;Room Enough to Stretch the Imagination
description: MARLO THOMAS HAD A LOT to answer for in the late 1960's. Young single women streamed into Manhattan, demanding that real estate agents find them decent apartments they could afford. After all, if Ann Marie, the chronically unemployed actress played by Ms. Thomas in the ABC series "That Girl," could afford a pretty little one-bedroom that was clearly on a town-house block in the East 70's, why couldn't they? Ann was apparently paying the rent with her earnings from waitressing and handing out product samples at department stores.

title: Susie M. Sharp, 88, Trail-Blazing Judge
description: Susie Marshall Sharp, the first woman to be popularly elected to the post of chief justice of a state supreme court in the United States, died on Friday at her home. She was 88.

title: BENEFITS
description: Theater Tribute

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: DEVIL'S FOOD By Janice Weber. Warner, $22.95.

title: Home Improvement;A 2,000-Mile Fence? First, Get Estimates.
description: IF he is elected President of the United States, Patrick J. Buchanan vows, "I will stop this massive illegal immigration cold. Period. Paragraph."

title: Kaiser Drops Its Hostile Offer for Alumax
description: The Kaiser Aluminum Corporation said today that it had decided to withdraw its hostile offer to acquire Alumax Inc., a rival aluminum producer.

title: Angkor Wat
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned from a tourist visit to Cambodia and, thanks to the saving habits of my wife, having found the piece by Barbara Crossette on Angkor Wat ("Angkor Emerges From the Jungle," Jan. 28), I hasten to compliment her on a perceptive report of her visit there toward the end of 1995. My own visit there confirms all she said, although I did not stay at Angkor Village and therefore cannot comment on her experience there.

title: Why Virtue Is in Short Supply
description: THIS is the season of the virtues. William J. Bennett began the trend by writing a book of them. Francis Fukuyama followed with a book about trust. Prince Charles has said that when he becomes King he wishes to be known as "the Defender of Faith." No Stephen L. Carter, the William Nelson Cromwell Professor of Law at Yale University and author of "The Culture of Disbelief," enters the lists with "Integrity."

title: UPPER WEST SIDE;Thalia Going Legit for a Bit
