description: The marquee of the Thalia theater, the popular Upper West Side showcase for classic films, has been dark for nearly a year. Next month, it will be lit once again, although only briefly. And the feature attraction will not be a movie, but a play, "Black Illusions," which one of its writers, Dacia Demetria Palmer, says, "gets to the truth of black love."

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WERTMULLER FILMS

title: No Water Money for City Schools
description: A State Supreme Court judge has ruled that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's misguided plan to sell the New York City water system is illegal. The ruling will be welcomed by New Yorkers who rightly worried that the sale might weaken the city's control over its upstate watershed. But it poses a serious financial problem for the Mayor, who had counted on money from the sale to rebuild schools.

title: District's Arts Support Puts 'Pippin' On Stage at High School
description: VOTERS in the Byram Hills School District approved a $10 million bond proposal in November, which includes renovations to the high school theater. But even without the new lighting and sound systems and seating improvements that are planned, the theater reflects the community's strong support for the arts.

title: WEDDINGS;Carol Schreiber, Lawrence Hanover
description: Carol Dale Schreiber, a daughter of Ellen Schreiber of Brooklyn and the late Al Schreiber, was married in Manhattan last evening to Lawrence Jonathan Hanover, a son of Amy-Beth and Norman Hanover of Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Potasnick performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: STYLE;Couture Lives!
description: Some random thoughts on the recent round of fashion shows in Paris:

title: Accusations Against Mrs. Clinton Are Baseless
description: To the Editor:

title: A State Primary: A Spotty Record
description: CONNECTICUT'S Presidential primary, which comes around again Tuesday for the Republicans, has a quirky history in which political leaders have sometimes endorsed candidates who did not win the nomination -- and voters have at times embraced people who never become President or even the nominee.

title: Rodney Rash, Horse Trainer, 36
description: The trainer Rodney Rash, who was to saddle last year's winner, Urgent Request, in the Santa Anita Handicap today, died on Friday. He was 36.

title: Pace Students Are Offering Their Help With Tax Forms
description: FOR those who find tax forms daunting -- and who have a hard time coming up with the fee to pay an accountant -- this can be a dreaded time of year. But there is free help available to anyone who needs it, thanks to members of Pace University's accounting department.

title: FOOD;A Little Lamb Eats Ivy
description: Mary and her little lamb are the perfect pastoral. Animal and shepherd wander the grassy knoll without destination or care, a romantic idyll of innocence and freedom.

title: PATH Isn't the Problem; Raising Fare Isn't a Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: ON POLITICS;Charity-Care Retread: The Jobless Fund, Again
description: The moribund proposal to raise the cigarette tax to help pay for hospital care for the poor might actually have been more politically palatable than the latest proposal making the rounds of the State House: continuing a regressive payroll tax on employees and higher unemployment insurance-tax rates for employers.

title: SOAPBOX;PHOTOGRAPHER'S JOURNAL
A Decade of Obsession
description: A TWILIGHT STRUGGLE American Power and Nicaragua, 1977-1990. By Robert Kagan. Illustrated. 903 pp. New York: The Free Press. $37.50.

title: MAKING IT WORK;One, Two, Three. . .Find the Emotion!
description: WHEN Greg Drew tells someone what he does for a living, the response is usually the same: you teach rock 'n' roll singers how to sing? Don't they know already?

title: DINING OUT;Spicy Dishes, Pecan Pie and Dancin'
description: THAT line from Gilbert and Sullivan, "Things are seldom what they seem," might apply to the menu at Violets Dinner Club, a recent arrival in downtown Stamford.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Snowboarding Champs To Vie in Vermont
description: The world's most accomplished snowboard riders will perform daredevil stunts at Stratton Mountain Resort in Vermont from March 21 to 24, during the 14th annual U.S. Open Snowboarding Championships. This event, the oldest contest in a young but fast-growing sport, draws 300 of the world's best riders and as many as 10,000 spectators, according to Myra Foster, public relations manager for Stratton Mountain. The $50,000 purse, she said, will be split equally between male and female competitors.

title: RESTAURANTS;Rustic Intimacy
description: MICHAEL CETRULO, the owner of Il Mondo Vecchio in Madison and now Scalini Fedeli, hopes to own the best Italian restaurant in New Jersey someday. If my first meal at his new venture is any indication, he already does.

title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Wrapping a Gift? Remember the String
description: Q. How can grandparents setting up Uniform Gift to Minors Act accounts for their grandchildren's education make sure the money won't be squandered by divorcing parents?

title: Owner of Pizzeria Is Killed in S.I. Shop
description: The owner of a popular Staten Island pizzeria was shot and killed as he was closing his shop Friday night, several weeks before he was scheduled to testify against two men accused of holding up the business last year, the police said yesterday.

title: WEDDINGS;Francine LeFrak and Eric Friedberg
description: Francine Ayn LeFrak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. LeFrak of New York, was married last evening at Temple Emanu-El in New York to Eric Brian Friedberg, the son of Mrs. William Friedberg of New York and the late Mr. Friedberg. Rabbi Amy Ehrlich performed the ceremony, in which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took part.

title: Feb. 25-March 2;Superdollar Suspense
description: Six years ago, nearly perfect counterfeit $100 bills began turning up in the Middle East. Despite an investigation by the Central Intelligence Agency and Treasury agents, officials say the origin of these "superdollars" is a mystery. Suspicions have focused on Iran, which owns the kind of presses the United States Government uses to print legitimate $100 bills. STEPHEN ENGELBERG

title: Of a Young Hopeful's Views And His Flag Etiquette
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Blaring Hastings Fire Alarm

title: Oklahoma Bombing Targeted the Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Dredging of Channels Urged
description: Longshoremen and truckers are scheduled to gather in Newark today to urge officials in Trenton and Albany to authorize the dredging of channels in the ports of Newark and New York. The ports employ 167,000 workers, most of them in New Jersey, but silt buildups have forced some freighters to dock in deeper ports like Baltimore and Norfolk, Va., said Al Cernadis, a spokesman for the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: Equity and Convertible-Debt Offerings Planned During the Week
description: The following equity and convertible-debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Stock Move by Alumax
description: Alumax Inc. took action today to prop up its stock price one day after the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation withdrew a takeover bid valued at up to $2.5 billion. Saying that its outlook was strong, Alumax canceled a shelf registration for an offering of up to 9.2 million shares of common stock. "In light of current business conditions and our strong projected cash flows, the company does not need to sell additional equity at this time and there are no plans to renew the proposed offering," the chief executive, Allen Born, said. Wall Street analysts said the action was an attempt to limit an expected tumble in the stock price on Monday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Observing Women's Day
description: For the first time this year, schools in all 21 counties in the state will take part in programs Friday celebrating International Women's Day. In New Jersey, the day was first commemorated in the Metuchen schools four years ago and is now part of the curriculum of all school districts in Middlesex County and some districts in each of the other counties.

title: HOCKEY;Gretzky Suffers Concussion in Second Game With Blues
description: Wayne Gretzky, playing just his second game with the St. Louis Blues, was elbowed in the head and sustained a minor concussion today, leaving the ice clinging to the shoulders of his new teammates.

title: N.Y.P.D. Was Quick to Look Into Melee
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER REVIEW;Carnival Above Ground, Tragedy Below
description: If earnestness alone were what made a musical great, "Floyd Collins" would be in the stratosphere of "Oklahoma!" and "Gypsy." Tina Landau and Adam Guettel's ambitious, tuneful lesson in American history, which opened last night at Playwrights Horizons, radiates good faith, moral seriousness and artistic discipline.

title: POLITICS: TELEVISION TACTICS;Candidates, and Surrogates, Angle for an Instant of Air Time
description: The candidates are visiting two, sometimes three states a day. Where they cannot be in person they have tried to appear by satellite, or have sent their wives and their daughters, or, when they have run out of family members, have deployed their surrogates.

title: Fighting Police Corruption;Use of New Strategies Provokes New Questions
description: The 911 call could hardly have been more routine. A man wearing a denim jacket and fatigue pants was reported to be selling drugs outside a housing project in southern Brooklyn.

title: Australia Pushes Compromise For Treaty to Ban Atom Tests
description: With only a month left to finish most of the drafting of a treaty banning nuclear testing worldwide, the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva has been given fresh momentum by Australia, which proposed a compromise text that tries to close gaps on several important issues.

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;Populist Candidate Has Sophisticated and Lucrative Political Apparatus
description: Patrick J. Buchanan has cast himself as the working-class insurgent whose grass-roots Presidential campaign has been fighting well-financed, highly organized political powerhouses.

title: New York Gets $8 Billion In Mortgages
description: In a broad plan intended to raise the historically low level of home ownership in New York City, Fannie Mae, the nation's largest provider of mortgage loans, is making $8 billion available and changing its rules so that more New Yorkers of all incomes qualify for loans.

title: POLITICS: THE TALK IN THE CHURCH;Fundamentalists Have a Word For Pat Buchanan -- Amen!
description: We really have been too timid," Patrick J. Buchanan preached to the congregants of Northside Independent Methodist Church this morning. "We've had a certain milquetoast Christianity in America."

title: POLITICS: LAMAR ALEXANDER;Still Waiting for a Victory But Determined to Go On
description: By 8 P.M. on Saturday, an hour after the polls had closed in South Carolina, Lamar Alexander was in his hotel suite here, down for a night of room service and a few quiet hours of political reflection. As recently as a week ago, this was supposed to have been a big night of victory speeches and hotel ballrooms, celebrating the results of the first contest in the South and the start of a string of hoped-for victories in the corner of the country that Mr. Alexander calls home.

title: A Code Of Honor Troubles Princeton
description: Every year, Princeton University's freshmen are convened before setting foot in a classroom to be told a story that goes something like this:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Acura Dealers Conduct Reviews
description: Acura dealer groups in metropolitan New York and Philadelphia are proceeding with reviews for their accounts after the Acura division of the American Honda Motor Corporation permitted local dealer associations to hire agencies separate from the national Acura agency, the Ketchum Advertising Los Angeles unit of Ketchum Communications.

title: H. L. Steinbach, 77, A Medical Educator
description: Dr. Howard L. Steinbach, a San Francisco radiologist and educator, died last Monday at the Jewish Home for the Aged in San Francisco. He was 77 and lived in suburban Hillsborough.

title: Survey on Sex Crimes Finds Young at Risk
description: Two-thirds of the sex offenders in state prisons say their victims were children, and a third of those victims were offspring or stepchildren of their attackers, the Justice Department reported today.

title: Tokens Worth $15,000 Stolen in Subway
description: Two men with a silver gun surprised two subway token clerks as they changed shifts early yesterday, making off with three boxes of subway tokens worth a total of $15,000, the police said.

title: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;Can Twinkies think, and other ruminations on the Web as a garbage depository.
description: HELLO, I am Stuart Roberts," reads a Web page I recently tripped over. "I have big feet."

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;How to Focus A Sales Pitch In Cyberspace
description: In an Internet equivalent of zoned advertising by the print media, Hotwired, the on-line publication that is the cyberspace sibling of Wired magazine, is offering advertisers a way to aim their sales pitches more narrowly.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: SPECIAL PLEADERS: A periodic look at lobbying.;Lawyers and Lobbyists Help Guide Effort By Republicans to Speed Drug Approvals
description: Within days after the Republicans won control of Congress in 1994, some gay rights groups saw an opportunity to win speedier access to new, unapproved treatments for AIDS by rewriting Federal drug laws. They knew just whom to call for help in drafting the legislation: Peter Barton Hutt, a Washington lawyer who is one of the nation's leading experts on food and drug laws.

title: Campaigns Need Total Public Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: BASKETBALL;As Knicks Win, Starks Scores And Seethes
description: A much-needed victory helped the Knicks yesterday, but it did not help the frosty relationship between John Starks and Don Nelson.

title: Stocks Off a Bit in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks were trading modestly lower here today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down one-quarter of 1 percent, or 50.23 points, to stand at 20,118.40. On Friday, the index gained 43.26 points.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Rockets Down Lakers Hakeem Olajuwon, outshining Magic Johnson, had 29 points and 13 rebounds yesterday to lead the Houston Rockets to a 111-107 victory over the host Los Angeles Lakers.

title: The 'Single Tax' Caught On in 2 States
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge's Troubles Echo Throughout Courtrooms
description: For weeks, the actions of Judge Lorin Duckman in New York City Criminal Court have reverberated to City Hall and as far as Albany, with political leaders charging that his handling of domestic violence cases indicates the judicial system is overly concerned with the rights of defendants.

title: Twists of Fate Take a Family From Grief to Joy
description: The tale has the elements of a classic mystery: a grieving widow; a misidentified body; a key, which, despite lottery-like odds, fits the wrong door, and a happy ending, as the husband and wife, having each learned the other is not dead, vow never again to take each other for granted.

title: Court Control of the City Jails
description: For nearly two decades, New York City has run its jails under a detailed Federal court consent decree, which sets standards on everything from guard staffing to the condiments available in the prison dining room. Now, the Giuliani administration has asked the court to loosen or lift some of the provisions.

title: A Little Known Conservative Topples Gonzalez in Spain
description: After 13 years in power, Felipe Gonzalez, the man who consolidated this country's transition from dictatorship to democracy, went down to defeat today to Jose Maria Aznar, a young conservative leader who is barely known outside Spain.

title: Bridge
description: The oldest major championship in bridge began today at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here. The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, which was first played in 1928, has attracted an entry of 99 teams, including all the top-ranked players in the country, and will continue through Saturday.

title: 2 Turkish Parties Agree on Freezing Out the Islamic Forces
description: Turkey's months-long political stalemate ended yesterday with an agreement by two rival conservative parties to form a coalition Government that will leave an Islamic party out in the cold.

title: U.S. Negotiates to Send Vietnamese Home, Quietly, From Asian Camps
description: White House aides have a nightmare: the last 36,000 Vietnamese boat people, after years in camps vainly waiting for resettlement in the West, are forcibly returned to Vietnam in ugly scenes, shown on television, that recapitulate the pain, anger and guilt of the war that President Clinton opposed.

title: Slaves Suffered at Confederate Gala Site
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Gorbachev's Ambition
description: In the years since he turned over the keys to the Kremlin to Boris Yeltsin, Mikhail Gorbachev has been restless in the shadow of his successor. Overtaken by a political revolution he initiated but could not control, Mr. Gorbachev retreated to the private sector, where he organized his own foundation, capitalized on his continuing popularity abroad and fumed over Mr. Yeltsin's leadership. Now, in a bout of pride, Mr. Gorbachev says he is prepared to run for president if democrats cannot unite behind another candidate.

title: Trial Forces New Look At Apartheid-Era Crime
description: After dark on Jan. 21, 1987, a half-dozen men with AK-47's burst into Victor Ntuli's small house in what is now the province of KwaZulu-Natal, spraying it with gunfire. Their goal was to kill Mr. Ntuli, an African National Congress leader.

title: Washington Post Purchase
description: The Washington Post Company said its Post-Newsweek Cable subsidiary had acquired the Columbus Television Cable Corporation of Mississippi for about $23 million in cash and stock. The company, which publishes The Washington Post and Newsweek magazine, said Columbus Television Cable served about 15,700 subscribers in Columbus, Miss. With the purchase, Post-Newsweek has about 554,700 subscribers in 16 states.

title: POLITICS: CONNECTICUT;Rowland and Whitman Back Dole at a Rally in Darien
description: Striving to drum up interest in the election with only two days to go before Connecticut's primary, Governors John G. Rowland and Christine Todd Whitman led a campaign rally here today to urge Fairfield County Republicans to help get out the vote for Senator Bob Dole.

title: Cigar Gets In Some Exercise
description: Cigar, the 1995 Horse of the Year, went to the race track to exercise this morning for the first time in 12 days, and his trainer, Bill Mott, reported that his patched right hoof seemed to be holding up.

title: In America;Trouble After School
description: Marisa Vural, a 16-year-old high school student, told the Police Commissioner last week that it is easier in many New York neighborhoods for a child to get a gun than a library card.

title: Ethlyne Clair, Film Actress, 91
description: Ethlyne Clair, who starred in silent comedies, westerns and serials, died on Tuesday at Tarzana Hospital here. She was 91.

title: Forbes Joins Buchanan As a Target of Giuliani
description: There are three candidates running in the Republican Presidential primary in New York, and Mayor Giuliani has found fault with two of them: Steve Forbes and Patrick J. Buchanan. While that moves the Mayor closer to backing Bob Dole, Mr. Giuliani still will not commit to endorsing him.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Paraplegic Reporter Making Himself Whole
description: During the years John Hockenberry was a correspondent for National Public Radio, few of his listeners were aware that he was a paraplegic, or, as he puts it, "a crip." He sometimes pushed himself crazily to excel as a reporter, first in this country, later in the Middle East and Africa. By wheelchair, car, truck, plane and donkey, he covered, among other stories, the famine in Somalia, the Persian Gulf war and the Kurdish refugees who had been disowned by Turkey and Iraq and, effectively, by the world.

title: John Cardinal Krol, Pivotal Catholic Figure, Dies at 85
description: John Cardinal Krol, who headed the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Philadelphia for 27 years and was a pivotal figure in the American church, died early yesterday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 85.

title: Rikers Smoking Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Thompson, 89, Publishing Executive
description: Paul Williams Thompson, a brigadier general who led a unit in the D-Day invasion of Normandy and a publishing executive who built up Reader's Digest in Europe, died on Feb. 9 at Mariner Health of Port Orange in Daytona Beach, Fla. A former resident of Chappaqua, N.Y., he was 89 and lived in Daytona Beach Shores.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: World News Briefs;Russians Shell Village After Chechnya Ambush
description: Heavy fighting erupted at dawn today near a village in western Chechnya when Russian troops were ambushed by separatist guerrillas, forcing civilians to flee after the town was shelled in retaliation.

title: BOMBING IN ISRAEL: HAMAS;Split in Hamas Seen as Bomb Follows Vow Of Brief Halt
description: In a sign of discord among the armed factions affiliated with Hamas, the militants who took responsiblity for today's suicide attack in Jerusalem broke a temporary halt in violence declared by the Islamic group after a similar bombing last week.

title: A Proper Home for 'Rent,' On Wrong Side of Tracks
description: After a long search, "Rent," the acclaimed rock opera about life on the Lower East Side, has found a Broadway home. The show will open on April 29 at the Nederlander Theater, a rarely used playhouse on West 41st Street, on the outskirts of the theater district.

title: China Faults Guidance System in Crash of Satellite
description: In its first full account of an explosion during a satellite launching last month, China's state-run media reported this weekend that defects in the rocket's guidance system caused the disaster. The incident was a blow to China's cut-rate commercial launching business.

title: France Ending Auctions Monopoly
description: Over the last 30 years, as London and New York gradually replaced Paris as the main international marketplaces for art, antiques and antiquities, French auctioneers at least remained masters of their own house. Their share of world trade in art continued to fall, but by law they alone could hold auctions in France.

title: BASEBALL;A Friendly Parting of the Ways for Bonilla and Mets
description: Bobby Bonilla is happy where he is, playing for a talent-laden Orioles team and batting behind Rafael Palmeiro and in front of Cal Ripken. "It doesn't get any better than that," Bonilla said, flashing his trademark smile.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Mix of Kids, Talent and Merriment
description: Dancers jumped for joy and made the audience want to jump along with them on Saturday afternoon at the Joyce Theater. What caused the contagious merriment was a Kids Dance program by Feld Ballets/NY. It was both for young people and to a large extent by young people.

title: Britain Grants Hong Kong Visa Concessions
description: Prime Minister John Major of Britain announced today a visa-free entry to Britain for Hong Kong passport holders after June 30, 1997.

title: GOLF;Norman Wins 3d Doral With a New Weapon
description: For much of his career, Greg Norman has won golf tournaments with macho golf, sometimes coming from behind with stunning final-round charges, other times going away with a dismissive flick of the putter. He even has, on the odd occasion, had tournaments handed to him by players who were intimidated by his large shadow.

title: Patents;A technique is said to ease attachment of tumors to mice, making them 'little cancer patients.'
description: ALTHOUGH the search for a way to mimic human cancers in laboratory animals has been under way for more than a century, scientists have been able to approximate the disease only crudely in mice and rats. The lack of a clinically relevant animal model is one reason that cures for cancer remain elusive.

title: Offer of New Bangladesh Election Fails to Solve Political Crisis
description: A bitter power struggle between the two main political parties in Bangladesh took a new turn today when Prime Minister Khaleda Zia, yielding to months of protests and strikes, offered to step down in favor of a "non-party" government that would conduct a new election.

title: After Disappointments, a New Chief for HarperCollins
description: Anthea Disney, who aggressively increased revenues when she was editor in chief of TV Guide and who is a longtime protegee of Rupert Murdoch, the man who controls the News Corporation, was named president and chief executive of the company's sputtering HarperCollins publishing unit yesterday.

title: BASKETBALL;Lady Jaspers Win M.A.A.C.
description: Manhattan, led by Wanda Camps's season-high 28 points, defeated Fairfield, 92-66, at Knickerbocker Arena today to capture the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament title.

title: At a Cajun Dance Hall, Race No Longer Rules
description: At a club here named La Poussiere on a recent Saturday night, an all-white crowd danced to a rhythmic Cajun two-step. It is a ritual tinged with racial overtones that is found in small clubs throughout the southern part of this state, where a fusion of French and English is the dialect.

title: DANCE REVIEW;It's Urban Anxiety, But Goofy
description: Eliot Feld is in many ways a subversive choreographer, choosing to work with a confined palette of movement that is recognizably rooted in ballet but abandons some of its central tenets. His are urban dances and as much a product of the abrupt and anxious atmosphere of their time as the work of George Balanchine was of an earlier, more noble-seeming urban environment.

title: Grammy Repositioning
description: Many executives in the record industry complain of excess product and slow sales. One path to larger market share is to repackage Grammy winners for crossover appeal.

title: Helen Bunce, 86, Poor Children's Mitten Lady
description: Helen Bunce, who knitted so many mittens she didn't know what to do unless she was knitting more mittens, died on Feb. 24 at a nursing home in Watertown, N.Y., where she was known as the Mitten Lady. She was 86 and had been knitting mittens until a few days before her death.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Once again, TAMMY FAYE MESSNER, the former wife of the fallen television evangelist Jim Bakker, faces the imprisonment of a spouse. Her second husband, ROE MESSNER, who married her in 1993 after she divorced Mr. Bakker, is scheduled to be sentenced on March 20 in Wichita, Kan. He was convicted there in November of bankruptcy fraud after he had concealed $400,000 in assets. He faces up to five years in prison.

title: Capitol Staffs Find Overtime Is Hard to Get
description: As Congress begins to apply standard labor laws to its own employees, senators and representatives have decided to make fewer than half of their personal staff members eligible for overtime pay, a survey indicates.

title: Management Lessons For Roosevelt Schools
description: Each afternoon, when classes are dismissed at the Junior-Senior High School here, Debra Cavanagh, a math teacher, gathers her things and her class list and heads into the streets of this village to the homes of students who have not been doing their homework. Last week, she vowed to hit two homes a day and persuaded a science teacher to do the same.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Murdoch Protegee For HarperCollins

title: Sports of The Times;Once, a Young Mullin Played in New York
description: HE took a 6 A.M. flight out of Chicago on Saturday, rushing here hours ahead of his team. New York is still home, for all the years on the West Coast, for all the changes, for better or worse.

title: Compromise Bills Due on Data Encryption
description: Legislation will be introduced in the House and the Senate tomorrow in an effort to break the deadlock between the computer industry and the Clinton Administration over the control and export of software and hardware used to scramble electronic data.

title: Hurtful Gay Club Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: WHX Urges a Teledyne Shareholder Vote
description: The WHX Corporation said yesterday that it wanted shareholders of Teledyne to vote on its $1.78 billion bid for the company, a Los Angeles-based maker of aviation and electronics products. The offer was rejected last week by Teledyne's board.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The producer ROBERT WHITEHEAD could hardly cast a show with more luminaries than will rise to pay him tribute tonight at a celebration of his 80th birthday and the 50th anniversary of his first Broadway show, "Medea."

title: Pushing Brazil, Christopher Urges Trade Zone by 2005
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher urged Brazil this weekend to help forge a free-trade zone spanning the Americas by the year 2005.

title: BOMBING IN ISRAEL;ISRAELI RAGE RISES AS BOMB KILLS 19, IMPERILING PEACE
description: The dull thud of another exploding bus echoed through Jerusalem early today, taking 19 lives and deepening the shadow over the future of the Israeli-Palestinian peace.

title: Open Market Hopes It'll Be Next Netscape
description: Since Netscape Communications rocketed out as 1995's hottest initial public offering in August, many companies with Internet-related products have become darlings of Wall Street. Open Market Inc., an 18-month-old software start-up, hopes it will soon be its turn at bat.

title: Testing Time for Mr. Dole;After So Many Years, He Must Define HImself
description: Pat Buchanan said the South Carolina primary held "the keys to the kingdom," but the keys wound up in Bob Dole's pocket. It is of course dangerous to predict the final outcome of the weekly lotto game known as the Republican primary campaign. But Mr. Dole's convincing victory here has temporarily restored his credentials as the party's front-runner. It has also been a profound disappointment for Mr. Buchanan, who failed to enlarge his base even in a state that, at least on paper, seemed to offer a receptive audience for his protectionist economics and regressive social values. It also showed that Lamar Alexander is having trouble getting anyone to listen to his earnest prescriptions, and it reminded Steve Forbes that expensive TV advertising and two quick visits will not cut it among voters who like their candidates up front and personal.

title: Bosnian Praises Iran's Aid
description: Prime Minister Hasan Muratovic of Bosnia arrived in Iran today and said his country would always remember Iranian aid in its fighting with Bosnian Serbs, the Iranian news agency IRNA said.

title: A Fighter for Children Widens the Battleground
description: A tiny Marcia Robinson Lowry will make her national Court TV debut today with a bruise on the bridge of her nose and her right hand in a cast for what doctors call a boxer's fracture. To allies and adversaries alike, it seems fitting: As an advocate for abused and neglected children, she has been slugging it out with New York City's child welfare system for more than 23 years.

title: Campaigns Need Total Public Financing;Myopic 'Positive' Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay;Free Advice for All
description: The makers of Advil are now suggesting that Tylenol may ruin your liver. I suspect Tylenol will soon blaze back with a campaign to hint that Advil rips out your stomach lining. That will give the boys at Bayer aspirin the chance to repeat both competitors' warnings, and to call for unity against the common enemy, headaches.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers and Devils: These Checks Won't Be Forged
description: Center Mark Messier, recovering from an injury to his right shoulder, practiced with the Rangers today and seemed in good spirits afterward.

title: Broadcasters Bet on Sports As First Step In New Markets
description: In India, where World Cup cricket captivates the sporting public the way the Super Bowl does in the United States, 10 million cable television households had access last week to 200 hours of televised matches through Star Sports, a joint venture of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and John C. Malone's Tele-Communications Inc.

title: World News Briefs;2 Boat Accidents Kill 117 on Lake Victoria
description: Ugandans are calling for tougher action against boat operators on Lake Victoria after 117 people died in two accidents in the last week.

title: Taiwan Belongs to No One
description: As if controlling its own press were not enough, China has been skillfully getting its point of view into the international media in recent months. Hong Kong, Japanese and American newspapers have been filled with intimidating reports, from unidentified sources, of China's plans for imminent invasions, blockades or bombings of Taiwan. In January, The New York Times carried an article citing unconfirmed reports that China was prepared to launch missile strikes every day for a month against Taiwan following the country's first presidential election, on March 23.

title: POP REVIEW;Understated Showcase For Sting's New Songs
description: Sting has a routine: when he puts out a new album, every few years, he starts his world tour with a club show in Manhattan. To preview his album "Mercury Falling" (A&M), which will be released on March 12, he performed at the Academy on Saturday night. His club shows are as much public dress rehearsals as concerts, and at them, Sting trades arena bravado for the modesty of a musician at work, still tinkering with songs on their way from the studio to the stage.

title: Sports of The Times;A Time for Family Values With the Nets' Bradley
description: Two hours before Saturday's game against the hot Seattle SuperSonics, Shawn Bradley, the Nets' center, stood before 100 fellow Mormons seated behind a basket in the Continental Arena.

title: MEDIA: TELEVISION;I a ratings reversal, ABC slips to the bottom of the networks' wheel of fortune.
description: LAST season's top-rated network, ABC, now finds itself in the position of another front-runner who took a humbling beating in the New Hampshire primary.

title: Dorothy Porter, Ziegfeld Dancer and Mayor, 89
description: Dorothy Porter, a Ziegfeld girl and the first woman to be a mayor in Nevada, died on Feb. 24 at a rehabilitation center. She was 89.

title: Critics Attack Pataki Formula for Helping Disabled Students
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's budget contains a few arcane provisions intended to solve a problem that has long confounded politicians and educators alike: runaway spending and abuse in the state program that pays to educate disabled children.

title: World News Briefs;British Military to Keep Its Ban on Homosexuals
description: After a comprehensive review, Britain has decided to keep its ban on homosexuals in the military, the Defense Minister, Michael Portillo, said today.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;As if You Didn't Know, A Policeman's Lot, etc.
description: What does Southern California need most? A prime-time cop show, that's what. Or at least that's what ABC is betting on with "High Incident," a new series from Dreamworks (the new high-powered Spielberg-Katzenberg-Geffen factory). The premiere is tonight. The outlook is cloudy.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lowe Gets Account From Time Warner
description: Time Warner Inc. and units of Nike Inc. and Pepsico Inc. have made decisions involving accounts.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Mafiosi and Killer in the Florida Sun
description: TROPICAL DEPRESSION By Laurence Shames 293 pages. Hyperion. $21.95.

title: POLITICS: THE MAYOR;No Endorsement, but Scorn for Flat Tax
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized Steve Forbes's flat-tax plan yesterday, saying it would prove especially damaging to New York City and the state.

title: Campaigns Need Total Public Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: Civic-Minded Pursuits Gain Ground at Newspapers
description: The Duluth News-Tribune ran an article across the top of its front page in September about 50 local men who got together at a nearby resort to discuss ways they could help curb the rising incidence of domestic abuse, murder and fighting in schools here in northern Minnesota.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Marguerite Duras, 81, Novelist and Screenwriter
description: Marguerite Duras, author of the best-selling novel "The Lover" and one of the most widely read French writers of the postwar era, died today in Paris. She was 81. Page D9.

title: BASKETBALL;N.C.A.A. Bid Is the Prize For Canisius or Fairfield
description: Iona's hopes of booking a long-awaited return trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament were canceled by Canisius this evening, 63-62, in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament semifinal at Knickerbocker Arena.

title: Pennsylvania Ave. 90210
description: Dear Presidential Candidate:

title: Abroad at Home;It's Up to Arafat
description: What looked inevitable two weeks ago is now a frail hope. The process that began in Oslo and saw Yitzhak Rabin shake Yasir Arafat's hand on the White House lawn may not lead to peace between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: BASEBALL;Maddux Battles Inflation One Batter at a Time
description: Ken Griffey Jr. or Frank Thomas could hit 62 home runs this year, and the number would not be as mind-boggling as one Greg Maddux has achieved the past four seasons. In an era of e.r.a. inflation, when earned run averages are soaring, Maddux has permitted 1.98 earned runs per nine innings compared with 4.00 for other National League pitchers.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Concerns on Gambling Bill
description: Some New Jersey lawmakers are worried that gambling legislation scheduled for debate in the United States House of Representatives on Tuesday could lead to higher taxes and stricter regulations for Atlantic City casinos.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Aid Weighed in Costly Snows
description: After 13 snowstorms, it is not surprising that New Jersey's towns and counties could use some help digging out from under a blizzard of bills. Legislation before the Assembly Transportation and Communications Committee today would provide $25 million from the Department of Transportation to defray the cost of removing snow and repairing roads.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden's 3 So-So Innings Are as Good as a Victory
description: Dwight Gooden was so eager to see a baseball game this morning that three hours before he made his own comeback after over 20 months away from major league hitters, he snuck off to the field where Jimmy Key was pitching in a B game. Gooden studied Key's comeback attempt because, he explained, he needed baseball. He missed the game.

title: BASKETBALL;Connecticut's Power Leaves Rutgers Reeling
description: Connecticut has a few weeks to try to prove its supremacy in women's college basketball, as it did last season.

title: Taking In the Sites;More Phone Directories Spring Up on the Web
description: In more than 5,000 United States telephone books, no one has a phone listed under the name Newt Gingrich. There are 13 listings of Bill Clinton. One Hillary Clinton is listed, but she's in California. Slightly more than 600 people have the last name Madonna, and one is Madonna Madonna.

title: BASKETBALL;St. John's Gets Shot Of Needed Confidence
description: At least three good things happened yesterday to the St. John's basketball team. It beat Pittsburgh, 74-68. It outrebounded the Panthers by 50-26 for the game and by 31-10 in the second half. And its regular season of horrors ended.

title: Prototypes of Virtual Shoppers
description: If the ultimate goal of computer networking is to create virtual societies that closely mimic the real ones we live in, most people would agree that cyberspace is still a poor imitation.

title: POLITICS: STEVE FORBES;Forbes Battles State Party Regulars in New York
description: After a third-place finish in South Carolina, Steve Forbes began campaigning in New York yesterday needing a strong showing in the state's Presidential primary on Thursday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Sugar Issue Sparks Debate
description: Representative Richard A. Zimmer, Republican of Delaware Township, has criticized Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the only member of the New Jersey delegation to the House to vote with the majority against eliminating sugar-price fixing, for receiving $45,000 in contributions and speaking fees from Florida sugar growers.

title: BASEBALL;A Richer Nomo Is Just as Sharp
description: Hideo Nomo, with a $4.3 million, three-year contract in his pocket, picked up where 1995 left off today by retiring 9 of 10 batters in his first appearance of the spring.

title: No Headline
description: We are at a decisive crossroads, either to continue the political process to achieve our national target of freedom and independence, or to fall with our cause and our people at the hands of our enemies, and those who make our cause into merchandise."

title: Rabin's Killer Fit for Trial
description: Israeli psychiatrists who examined Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's confessed assassin, Yigal Amir, have concluded that he is fit to stand trial, Mr. Amir's lawyer said today.

title: Meyer Schapiro, 91, Is Dead; His Work Wove Art and Life
description: Dr. Meyer Schapiro, University Professor Emeritus at Columbia University, multidisciplinary critic and historian, galvanic teacher, lifelong radical and for more than 50 years a pre-eminent figure in the intellectual life of New York, died yesterday at the Greenwich Village house that had been his home for more than 60 years. He was 91.

title: An Irony in Quoting Lawyer on Sex Shops
description: To the Editor:

title: Serbian Chief Moves to Suppress Opposition at Home
description: In the three months since signing the Dayton peace accords, President Slobodan Milosevic has been promoting himself internationally as a guarantor of peace in the Balkans. But inside Serbia, he has been working to suppress political opposition and reassert state control of the economy, diplomats and economists here say.

title: POLITICS: CLEARER FOCUS;Dole Fulfills His Promise in a Contest in the South
description: For weeks Bob Dole has sought a showdown with Pat Buchanan, head to head, man to man, without the distraction of a bunch of other candidates. Give me that, he has said, and I will win big.

title: INSIDE
description: Power Shifts in Spain

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;GINGRICH PRESSING DOLE'S OPPONENTS TO QUIT THE RACE
description: In the wake of Senator Bob Dole's decisive victory in the South Carolina primary, Speaker Newt Gingrich led other prominent Republicans today in pressuring the Senator's rivals to quit the race.

title: Campaigns Need Total Public Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: The Shell Game of Hollywood 'Net Profits';Dreamworks May Be Shaking Up Some Time-Honored Accounting Habits
description: When Walter Parkes wrote the screenplay for "War Games" with Lawrence Lasker, he, like many screenwriters, was promised a share of the movie's net profits. Although the 1983 movie was an enormous hit and earned Mr. Parkes an Academy Award nomination, he never shared in the film's financial success with MGM/UA. "I can promise you I never saw any net profits," he said.

title: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA: In the Workplace Musical chairs;The Company as Family, No More
description: It was an icy, pastel day and in the harried midmorning hours the sidewalks were clotted with workers parading into One Chase Manhattan Plaza, a sterile tower of ponderous coolness just off Broadway and hard by Wall Street. On the ground floor of the Chase banking headquarters sprawls a bustling branch that employees reverently know as the Mother Branch.

title: Metro Matters;A Quiet Plan To Transform Criminal Law
description: WRAPPED inside Gov. George E. Pataki's budget is a plan to make some of the most far-reaching changes in criminal sentencing that New York has ever seen. It would lengthen sentences for first-time violent felons, and eliminate their right to parole.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;A Runner Bears Ethiopia's Fragile Hopes
description: As the sun rose over the lip of the National Stadium, and wood smoke wrapped the high-rises and tin-roofed shanties of the capital in a gauzy cocoon, the world's greatest distance runner arrived for his morning workout. In a taxi.

title: Marguerite Duras, 81, Author Who Explored Love and Sex
description: Marguerite Duras, author of the best-selling novel "The Lover" and one of the most widely read French writers of the postwar era, died today at her home in Paris. She was 81.

title: Future Communications
description: Most of the recent rise in the Dow Jones industrial average has been fueled by interest in technoloby stocks, and investors have turned an even more vigilant eye to that sector of the economy after Congress passed the telecommunications bill last month. In the long run, that legislation allowd local phone operators to compete with long-distance operators and vice versa. And those companies could also compete with cable companies, who, in turn, are faced with increasing competition from some home satellite firms as well as microwave broadcast transmissions.

title: India and Pakistan Troops Clash in Kashmir
description: Indian and Pakistani troops clashed today across the dividing line of the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir, the Pakistani Defense Ministry said.

title: Manila Journal;Queen of the Quirky, Imelda Marcos Holds Court
description: A pale blue bird began to chirp loudly high above the table where Imelda Marcos was eating breakfast.

title: HORSE RACING;The Race to Churchill Downs Has Begun
description: When Hennessy won the Hopeful at Saratoga last summer for his fourth straight victory, he was anointed the early favorite for the 1996 Kentucky Derby. And, right then, he became the leading candidate to suffer one of the enduring curses in racing: Like so many other favorites in so many other years, he was probably doomed not to make it.

title: HOCKEY;King's Jaw Is Shattered As Isles Keep Suffering
description: It was the kind of game that landed an unsuspecting player in the hospital with a broken jaw and a concussion. Derek King sacrificed his jaw and, temporarily, his consciousness, to make a pass that created a 4-3 first-period lead for the Islanders.

title: Beninese Throng Polls in 2d Free Election
description: Polling stations were thronged today as people turned out in huge numbers to take part in this West African country's second free election since a transition to democracy in 1991.

title: Cardinal Krol Dies at 85; Led philadelphia's Catholics
description: John Cardinal Krol, the former leader of the Philadelphia Archdiocese who was a strict church disciplinarian and a pivotal figure in the American church, died yesterday. Page D9.

title: FOOTBALL;Hold On, Hampton: Giants Plan to Match
description: The Giants will keep one of their top offensive threats, running back Rodney Hampton, by matching the San Francisco 49ers' six-year, $16.45 million offer, the Giants' co-owner, Bob Tisch, said last night.

title: The 'Single Tax' Caught On in 2 States
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Gingrich to Visit Forest
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich will travel to Sterling Forest today to underscore his commitment to finding a means of maintaining it as public land, a spokesman for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday. Streams on the huge tract, 40 miles north of New York City, feed reservoirs that supply water to two million New Jersey residents, but the current owners want to develop the land for commercial and residential uses.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Agencies Promote Top Executives
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York and BBDO New York have promoted top executives to new positions.

title: This Week's Treasury Sales Are Limited to Regular Bill Auctions
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;An Equal Commitment To Blissful Moments And the Sorrows of Life
description: Some wires crossed in the brain on Thursday evening, when the Vienna Philharmonic played Mahler's "Resurrection" Symphony in the first of three concerts led by Seiji Ozawa at Carnegie Hall. At one point in the second movement of this, Mahler's Second Symphony, his Fourth crowded into consciousness.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Panel Considers Adoption Bill
description: A bill that would allow adopted children over the age of 18 to have access to their birth certificates (and learn the name of their biological mothers) will be considered today by the Assembly Community Services Committee. Also before the panel is a proposal that would establish a voluntary registry in the Department of Human Services for children and parents who want to locate each other.

title: Netscape Plans Additions to Software Line
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation plans to introduce updated and new software this week, its co-founder, Marc Andreessen, said.

title: Dispute Over Insanity Defense Is Revived in Murder Trial
description: The day before John C. Salvi 3d walked into two Brookline abortion clinics and shot two receptionists to death at point-blank range in December 1994, he practiced firing his rifle at a target held in his other hand, according to testimony in his trial this past week.

title: The Declaration by Peres: 'War in Every Sense of the Word'
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel at a news conference after a suicide bomber attack in Jerusalem:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Australian Utility Sold
description: The Australian state of Victoria said today that it had sold Yallourn Energy to a consortium led by Powergen P.L.C. of Britain for $2.43 billion (Australian), or $1.85 billion (United States). It is the first of five planned sales of power companies by the state, which is the second-most populous in Australia. Yallourn Energy consists of the 1,450-megawatt Yallourn brown-coal power station and related coal mining operations. The Powergen bidding group includes some Australian investors. (AP)

title: Dairy Lobby Won On House Farm Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE MAYOR;Giuliani Tepidly Backs Dole, but Only to Block Buchanan
description: It was considerably less than a full-throated endorsement, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani finally informed the city yesterday of his intention to vote for Senator Bob Dole in Thursday's New York primary, mildly suggesting that fellow Republicans consider doing likewise.

title: Russian Space Mementos Show Gagarin's Ride was a Rough One
description: THE launching of the first human into space by the Soviet Union -- a 108-minute dash around the globe by Lieut. Yuri A. Gagarin on April 12, 1961 -- stunned the world, particularly the United States, which at the time was struggling to catch up in the space race. Shortly after the Soviet success, President Kennedy, under enormous pressure to outdo the Communists, announced a bold plan to land Americans on the Moon by the end of the decade.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Gerstner Declares I.B.M. Is Poised for Leadership Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chairman of I.B.M., told Wall Street analysts and investors that the company's traditional strength as a global maker of sophisticated systems would make it a major power in the era of network computing, which is being fueled by the rapid growth of the Internet. The message was that I.B.M. would more than make up for its disastrous missteps adjusting to the era of the personal computer. [Page D4.]

title: Queens Teacher Accused of Slur Is Keeping Job
description: A white Queens teacher accused of using a racial epithet in referring to a black fifth grader was permitted to keep her job after school officials defeated an effort to oust her in a dispute that has bitterly divided the school community over the last week.

title: Jury Selection Begins in Trial of Clinton Partners
description: Jury selection began today in the fraud and conspiracy trial of President Clinton's partners in the Whitewater land deal and the man who succeeded him as Governor, with the President himself subpoenaed to testify.

title: HOCKEY;A Tie With Rangers Leaves the Devils Satisfied
description: If the Stanley Cup playoffs began today, the Rangers and the Devils could meet in the first round. Certainly this would be entertaining, but what a waste of a great local rivalry in an early bracket.

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;Dole's Rivals Stake Their Ground Before Biggest Primary Day Yet
description: From a carpet factory in LaGrange, Ga., to a boat house in Burlington, Vt., to a paper mill in Bangor, Me., the Republican Presidential candidates scattered up and down the East today for a final burst of campaigning on the eve of the biggest day of voting thus far.

title: Crew Seeks to Overhaul New York School Bureaucracy
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday proposed a reorganization of the much-maligned central headquarters of the New York City school system, offering a plan to have 110 Livingston Street focus on enforcing standards while scaling back its largely redundant role in writing curriculum and establishing guidelines to meet those goals.

title: Footnote to History: Gagarin's Close Call
description: Lieut. Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet astronaut who, on April 12, 1961, was the first human in space, did not have the seamless triumph that Moscow publicized for so many decades. In fact, man's first voyage beyond the planet was nearly a disaster.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Hill's Triple-Double Leads Pistons Grant Hill's sixth triple-double of the season paced the Detroit Pistons to a 99-93 victory over the visiting Atlanta Hawks last night. Hill finished with 17 points, 12 assists and 11 rebounds as Detroit won for the fifth time in six games.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. to Offer U.N. a Plan To Pay $1.5 Billion Debt
description: The Clinton Administration will propose a five-year plan for paying $1.2 billion in United States debts to the United Nations -- $1.5 billion if this year's assessment is included -- when it submits budget proposals to Congress on March 18, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief American delegate, said today.

title: Cigar Hopes High
description: Bill Mott, the trainer of Cigar, says he is optimistic the horse will run in the Dubai World Cup on March 27. Cigar, who is recovering from a bruised hoof, galloped once around the Gulfstream track today.

title: New Mexico Holdup Results in 5 Deaths
description: An elderly couple were found shot to death near their car today, a day after they apparently stumbled onto a holdup at a video store in which their grandson and two other people were slain.

title: POLITICS: NEW YORK;On New York's Primary Ballot, It's Who You Know That Counts
description: If Senator Bob Dole's opponents needed a lesson on what it means to confront the New York State Republican Party in Thursday's primary, there were two places they could look: The first was last night in Franklin Square, L.I., where Mr. Dole was flanked by Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, in front of nearly 1,000 people packed into a restaurant.

title: Hertz Plans to Again Sell Used Cars Driven by Renters
description: The Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest rental-car company, said today that it would open 39 used-car lots this year to sell cars driven by its customers for 7 to 12 months.

title: When Phone Companies Fight, Consumer Loses
description: To the Editor:

title: A Florida Congressman With a Fighting Spirit Will Retire
description: Representative Sam M. Gibbons, a 76-year-old Floridian who led efforts for civil rights and open government in the House in the 1960's and became Speaker Newt Gingrich's chief denouncer in the 1990's, announced his retirement today after 34 years in Congress.

title: Tracing a Genetic Disease To Bits of Traveling DNA
description: SIFTING through the chromosomes of people with an inherited nerve disease, researchers have made a strange discovery: woven neatly into the human genome lie stretches of DNA once thought to belong exclusively to insects.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHOENIX HOME LIFE MUTUAL INSURANCE CO., will acquire a 15 percent stake in Aberdeen Trust P.L.C., of Aberdeen, Scotland, an investment management company, as part of a joint venture agreement between the two companies. The mutual life insurer will pay $37.5 million for the Aberdeen stake.

title: No Headline
description: I knew there were hundreds and even thousands being laid off. I guess I thought I was special. Then the day came when they made a business decision to let me go. It was, 'Bye, and don't let the door hit you."'

title: In Performance;DANCE
description: An American Who Specializes In a Classic Form From India Kay Poursine Merce Cunningham Studio

title: PATAKI PROPOSES LETTING TEACHERS SUSPEND STUDENTS
description: Seeking to give New York's teachers greater control over their schools, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed legislation that would permit teachers for the first time to suspend disruptive children from their classrooms for up to 10 days.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cutting Historic-Site Visits
description: The Whitman administration has proposed reducing visiting days at seven historic sites from five to three a week as part of an effort to save $1.8 million, officials said yesterday. Six of the 20 employees at these sites would be laid off, and 5 unarmed and lower-paid guards would replace park rangers at state parks, said Amy Collings, a spokeswoman for the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Assessing Carnegie Hall Without the Concrete
description: Was it just a decade ago that everyone still took the magnificent sound of Carnegie Hall for granted? Yes, but a decade in which those fabled acoustics probably received more discussion than in all of the hall's previous 95 years.

title: Surprising Role Found for Breast Cancer Gene
description: WHEN scientists first began closing in on the gene behind many cases of hereditary breast cancer, they could not help but let their fantasies fly. Wouldn't it be nice, they said, if the discovery of the gene cast light not only on the origins of familial breast cancer, which is relatively rare, but on the colossal problem of breast cancer generally, the commonest malignancy among women?

title: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA;More Than Money, They Miss the Pride a Good Job Brought
description: The wedge-shaped B-2 Stealth bomber sliced through the brownish-blue California haze. Robert Muse lay back on the hood of the pickup and watched it fly, like a boy gauging the progress of his paper airplane.

title: Age of Universe Is Now Settled, Astronomer Says
description: ASTRONOMERS working with new measurements by the Hubble Space Telescope believe that they have finally settled a longstanding controversy over the age of the universe. Dr. Allan Sandage of the Carnegie Observatories in Pasadena, Calif., and his colleagues calculate that the universe is at least 15 billion years old, and they say that recent challenges to the standard theory of how the universe began and evolved stand refuted.

title: BOMBING IS ISRAEL: THE WIDOW;Leah Rabin Tells Israelis To Be Strong
description: Yitzhak Rabin's widow, Leah, compared the four suicide bombings since last Sunday to the Nazi Blitz of London during World War II and appealed to Israeli citizens to show the same stiff morale and resolution the British did a half century ago.

title: POLITICS: ADVERTISING;Forbes's Ad Purse Strings Open, but to What End?
description: Fulfilling his pledge to spend $1 million on advertising for the New York primary, Steve Forbes yesterday completed the purchase of enough television time to make him almost unavoidable to viewers over the next few days.

title: FOOTBALL;Giants Savor Rare Victory Over the 49ers
description: When it came to running back Rodney Hampton, the Giants said enough was enough. They drew a line in the sand and the man holding the stick was Robert Tisch. It was Tisch, one of the team's co-owners, who made sure the Giants' leading career rusher stayed a Giant.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A move to identify the most creative TV spots is bound to stir debate.
description: ONE way people in advertising enjoy spending their time -- apart from thinking lovely thoughts about clients, of course -- is in debating which television commercials might be the best ever made. A new effort to identify the most creative spots is sure to stir still more debate.

title: POLITICS: THE NEWCOMERS;Behind in Ohio Polls, Buchanan's Guerrillas Still Have Field Day
description: It is two weeks to the Presidential primary in Ohio, a very important state to win, and still there is nary a sign of activity by any Republican campaigns -- except Patrick J. Buchanan's all-volunteer squad.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: In Performance;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Three New Works of Americana And 'Appalachian Spring' Concordia Orchestra Alice Tully Hall

title: Marist Ousted By Monmouth
description: Mustafa Barksdale hit a 3-pointer with seven seconds left, then made a game-winning free throw to lift Monmouth to a 57-56 upset victory over Marist in a Northeast Conference semifinal game tonight.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BOSTON RED SOX -- Agreed to terms with Eric Gunderson and Brian Bark, pitchers. National League MONTREAL EXPOS -- Agreed to terms with Ozzie Canseco, first baseman-outfielder. Frontier League JOHNSTOWN STEAL -- Released Scott Beardsley, pitcher. KALAMAZOO KODIAKS -- Signed Dan Davis, pitcher, Corey Gafford, catcher, Jasone DeWitt, infielder, and Aries Leonard and Ryan Alkire, outfielders.

title: BASKETBALL;Canisius Turns Back The Clock
description: The last time Canisius made it to the big dance, bobby socks were in style.

title: POLITICS: THE FAITHFUL;Dole Sounds Enthusiastic About Ballot In New York
description: Bob Dole told an excited crowd at an airport hangar in this snow-covered state capital tonight that New York could cinch the Republican nomination for him on Thursday.

title: BASKETBALL;It's Nothing Personal, Nelson Says, but Starks Will Stay on the Bench
description: Don Nelson, a coach facing criticism from a key player, took a firm and philosophical approach after today's practice. Despite recent barbs thrown at him by John Starks, Nelson insisted his rift with Starks was strictly business, not personal. And Nelson remained committed to Hubert Davis as the starting shooting guard.

title: If My Daughter and I Had Been Shopping in Tel Aviv
description: Monday. "It happened again!" my daughter Hannah, 12, shouts from the den. "Come quickly! This time it's in Tel Aviv!"

title: Will Double-Hull Tankers Prevent Oil Spills;In U.S. Waters
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Devils Enroll In Crash Course
description: On a night when the Rangers tried to intimidate the Devils by using their own Crash Line -- Darren Langdon, Ian Laperriere and Joe Kocur -- New Jersey was missing two-thirds of its infamous Crash Line, its most effective combination during last season's Stanley Cup triumph.

title: I.B.M. Displays Its Muscles And Some Warts to Wall St.
description: Declaring that "the world is coming our way," Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chairman of I.B.M., said yesterday that the company's traditional strength as a global maker of sophisticated systems would make it a major power in the era of network computing, which is being fueled by the rapid growth of the Internet. Mr. Gerstner and two of his lieutenants gave an unusually lengthy three-hour exposition of I.B.M.'s strengths and weaknesses to a group of Wall Street analysts and major investors in New York. The overall message was that the company's leadership in network computing in the years ahead would more than make up for disastrous missteps in the last 15 years, during the era of personal computers.

title: NYC;G.O.P. Brawl Gets Cheers From Sidelines
description: NOW that the Federal courts have forced democracy on New York's Republicans, much the way parents used to pry open their children's mouths to get them to swallow castor oil, we are left to contemplate another strange phenomenon: New York Democrats, who come by brawling naturally, are to be found this primary week at the edges of the schoolyard, watching while the other boys and girls scrap.

title: 2 O-Ring Problems Reported on Shuttle
description: Hot rocket gas singed O-rings in the space shuttle Columbia's booster rockets during liftoff nearly two weeks ago but did not endanger the space shuttle or its seven astronauts, NASA said today.

title: Consumer Spending Drops As Income Growth Slows
description: The growth in personal income slowed in January after increasing in 1995 at the fastest pace in five years, and consumer spending fell for the first time in three years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Patterns
description: Fashionable Bridal Wear

title: POLITICS: NEW ENGLAND;Forbes Says That If Nominated, He'd Consider Keyes for Chairman of G.O.P.
description: On a day that Speaker Newt Gingrich put his chips on Senator Bob Dole's Presidential candidacy, Steve Forbes today tried to forge a long-distance alliance with Alan Keyes, another candidate who has received little support from party leaders.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RAYTHEON AGREES TO SELL XYPLEX TO WHITTAKER
description: The Raytheon Company has agreed to sell Xyplex Inc. to the Whittaker Corporation of Simi Valley, Calif., for $117.5 million in cash and stock, the companies said yesterday. Xyplex, which is based in Boxborough, Mass., has 500 employees and makes data communications products for computer networks. Raytheon bought Xyplex in October 1994 for about $171 million, which included about $35 million in Xyplex cash. Xyplex has about $100 million in annual sales. Whittaker has sales of $160 million. Under the agreement, Whittaker is to pay $67.5 million in cash and $50 million in Whittaker stock for the company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Microsoft Account Is Placed in Review
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it had placed in review its business-to-business direct marketing account, which had been at Anderson & Lembke in San Francisco for two years until the agency resigned last week. The billings were estimated at $15 million to $25 million.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;China Announces Tests Of Missiles Near Taiwan
description: China announced today that it will hold missile tests at sea March 8 to 15 in an area just off the island of Taiwan, apparently part of military exercises intended to intimidate the island before its presidential elections this month.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;News Corp. Ends Contract For Satellite
description: The Comsat Corporation said yesterday that the News Corporation had canceled its contract to transmit programming from a satellite that Comsat plans to launch this week.

title: No Need to Count Every Last Person
description: When the Census Bureau counts heads in the year 2000, it will stop trying to track down every household. Instead, after census-takers contact about 90 percent of the population, the bureau will use sampling techniques to round out the total.

title: Newspaper Publisher's Wife Kills Him, and Then Herself
description: The estranged wife of a newspaper publisher flew to New Jersey yesterday, went to her husband's office in Westfield and shot him to death, then took her own life moments later, the authorities said last night.

title: INSIDE
description: Property Seizure Backed

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Sets Target Of 8% Growth a Year
description: China plans annual economic growth of 8 percent until the end of the decade and has decided that curbing inflation will be its top priority, the Prime Minister, Li Peng, said in his report on the latest five-year plan for the nation. The growth goal is below last year's rise in gross domestic product of 10.2 percent, according to the report, which is to be officially presented today.

title: New Talks Begin in Belfast, But Adams Is Turned Away
description: A crucial phase in the accelerated Northern Ireland peace effort began today with Gerry Adams, the political leader of the Irish Republican Army, being turned away from the guarded gates of the British Government building where a new round of talks is being held.

title: SWIMMING;Fearless Teen-Ager Swims in Fast Lane
description: Perhaps it was the time the family Doberman grabbed her face with his jaws, as if fetching the morning paper, and she didn't cry.

title: On My Mind;Now It's Israel's Job
description: After three bombing massacres of Israelis, and secret warnings by Israel's intelligence that more were coming, Prime Minister Shimon Peres said Israel was at war with the Palestinian Hamas terrorists "in every sense of the word."

title: DANCE REVIEW;Of Dots, Dash and a Touch Of This, That and Etc.
description: You could accurately describe the work presented by Amy Sue Rosen and Derek Bernstein on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church as simple dances about rocks and dots. But Ms. Rosen and Mr. Bernstein, longtime choreographic collaborators, took those props and created sturdy yet whimsical imaginary worlds.

title: Reversing Field, Ford Will Aggressively Cut Costs
description: After months of dismissing concerns that its cars have become too expensive, the Ford Motor Company has reversed course and begun an aggressive cost-cutting campaign that includes the elimination of 6,000 product engineering jobs.

title: POLITICS: COLORADO;Western Attire, Not Western Issues
description: In the saga of how the Rocky Mountain West is being won in this spring's pell-mell round of Republican primaries and caucuses, the region's contentious old issues of land, water, timber and minerals have yet to come into play.

title: Owner of Second Avenue Deli Is Shot and Killed in Robbery
description: Abe Lebewohl, the blustery businessman who transformed a tiny 12-seat restaurant in the East Village into a New York institution called the Second Avenue Deli, was shot and killed in a robbery yesterday morning as he tried to deliver the day's deposits to a nearby bank.

title: Moscow Journal;'War and Peace,' the Sequel: Scholars See Scarlett
description: The most beloved heroine of Russian literature, Natasha Rostova, was feeling sexy. "Staring at herself in the mirror, Natasha admired the cleavage of her high breasts, shapely hips, and narrow shoulders. Beneath her dress, she detected the outline of her leg, slim ankles and high instep and lost her breath for a moment, aroused by her own femininity."

title: Noriega Motion Raises Question About Witness
description: The Cali drug trafficking organization paid $1.2 million to induce an important prosecution witness to testify against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in 1992, according to testimony today in Federal court from the man who delivered the money.

title: POLITICS: VERMONT;Lagging, Lugar Puts Big Hopes on Small State
description: With nothing better than a fifth-place finish in the seven Republican primaries so far, and no more than 1 percent of the ballots cast in the last six, Senator Richard G. Lugar seems to be drawing a line in the Vermont snow.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: Dole Gains From Party Unity Much has been made of the fact that Senator Bob Dole has gained the near undivided support of New York's Republican organization in Thursday's primary. The reality is that the contested primary race is turning out to be to Mr. Dole's benefit. Because of his unified party support, Mr. Dole has fielded a slate of delegate candidates that includes some of the best-known names in Republican politics. [Page A1.]

title: True Welfare Reform Requires Living Wage
description: To the Editor:

title: Minnie Pearl, 'Grand Ole Opry' Star for 50 Years, Dies at 83
description: Minnie Pearl, the raucously funny radio, television and stage personality who was known as the queen of country comedy, died yesterday at a hospital in Nashville. She was 83.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Banish Attack Ads? That Won't Help
description: Before some senator proposes an N-chip that would automatically block out negative campaign commercials, let's think positively. Although everybody claims to hate negativity, the peppiest moments of the Republican debates so far have been the personal exchanges over charges made in commercials. And for all the grouching about their insidious effects on American civilization, insults and accusations have always enlivened Presidential campaigns. They are as American as funny hats.

title: Bosnian Seeks Votes With a Call To All Sects
description: In a campaign that may profoundly affect the future of this country, Bosnia's former Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, is planning to run against President Alija Izetbegovic in elections this year on a platform of ethnic harmony and an end to religion-based politics.

title: Dow Registers Rise of 63.59; Passes 5,600
description: Stock prices lurched sharply higher yesterday, pushed by a number of large computer-driven buy orders and another good day in the long end of the bond market.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets Trade Brown
description: The Jets traded right tackle JAMES BROWN to the Dolphins for a 1997 fifth-round pick. In doing so, the team opened about $400,000 in salary-cap room for 1996. Brown played in 15 games last season, starting 12 of them.

title: BOMBING IS ISRAEL: THE OVERVIEW;4TH TERROR BLAST IN ISRAEL KILLS 14 AT MALL IN TEL AVIV; NINE-DAY TOLL GROWS TO  61
description: The fourth in a series of savage suicide bomb attacks in Israel struck in the heart of Tel Aviv today, bringing the nine-day death toll to 61.

title: PERIPHERALS;Now, Making a Game Out of 'Connections'
description: JAMES BURKE could not have imagined that his M.A. in English from Oxford would lead to television and science, but it did, and those who enjoyed "Connections," his 10-part series on PBS years ago, are grateful. His followup 20-part series, "Connections2 ," was written and produced for the Learning Channel, a network of Discovery Communications Inc.

title: BASEBALL;Injured Kelly May Not Start
description: Manager Joe Torre indicated tonight that Pat Kelly's status as the starting second baseman for the Yankees could change soon if his injured right shoulder does not heal and enable him to play consistently in spring training.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bright Lights Fail to Dazzle
description: Lights from the new golf range on Chelsea Piers in Manhattan are annoying residents across the river, ruining the view and damaging efforts to attract residential developers to Hoboken's neglected waterfront, Stephen Hudock, president of the Hoboken City Council, said yesterday. "You try to see the Empire State Building and you've got these piercing lights that are blinding to anyone looking over there," said Mr. Hudock, who has asked Councilman Thomas K. Duane of New York to intervene. But Jack Batman, a spokesman for Chelsea Piers Management, the owners, said he had not heard any objections to the 28 1,500-watt lights from either side of the Hudson.

title: With Layoffs Coming, Ontario Workers Strike Over Security
description: A cold wind battered Sheila Steaman's thickly bundled frame as she and a score of co-workers paced endlessly around the plaza in front of an Ontario government office building on Bay Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 13 about the role of Royal Dutch/Shell in Nigeria misstated actions of the Royal Geographical Society in London. While some of its members urged the society in January to sever its links to Shell as a corporate patron, the society has not broken ties or returned any Shell donations.

title: Gingrich Promises to Block Development of Sterling Forest
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich stood today beside the frozen Wanaque River, which feeds one of New Jersey's major reservoirs, and pledged "unequivocally" to pass a bill by the summer that would save Sterling Forest from future development.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Companies Form Ad Units
description: DDB Needham Worldwide and the Sony Corporation have formed special advertising units.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Women's World Cup

title: BOMBING IS ISRAEL: THE WHITE HOUSE;As Israeli Peace Team Flies Home, Clinton Calls a Special Meeting
description: President Clinton's top advisers will recommend that the United States provide Israel with more intelligence and antiterrorism technology and take further action to isolate Iran because of its history of sponsoring terrorism, American officials said tonight.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BankAmerica Buyback Plan
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would buy back as much as $2 billion of its common stock and $1 billion of its preferred stock by the end of 1997.

title: In Performance;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Jazzy American Rhythms And Chat Sessions Richard Stoltzman, clarinetist Weill Hall

title: William Morgan, 85, Part of Famed Child-Custody Case, Dies
description: William J. Morgan, a psychologist who fought the Germans and Japanese behind enemy lines in World War II, outfoxed Soviet spies during the cold war and later thwarted American courts by keeping his granddaughter away from a father whom her mother had accused of sexual abuse, died on Saturday in Bethesda, Md. He was 85.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FLAGSTAR BUYING 3 FAMILY RESTAURANT CHAINS
description: The Flagstar Companies agreed yesterday to buy three restaurant chains with 344 outlets from Family Restaurants Inc. for $306.5 million. The price for the Coco's, Carrows and Jojos chains will consist of cash, notes and the assumption of capital lease obligations. Coco's is a bakery restaurant chain with 170 restaurants primarily in California. Flagstar will also acquire licensing rights for more than 240 Coco's operating in Japan and Korea. Carrows, with 157 restaurants, mostly in California, is a family dining chain. Jojos is a 17-restaurant family dining chain in Texas and Indiana. Family Restaurants, based in Irvine, Calif., will continue to operate 319 restaurants under other names.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Agent Orange Manufacturers Cannot Sue U.S., Justices Say
