description: The Supreme Court ruled today that manufacturers of Agent Orange, the chemical defoliant that American troops sprayed over Vietnam, cannot sue the Federal Government to recover their costs of defending and settling lawsuits by veterans who trace various health problems to their exposure to dioxin, one of the defoliant's byproducts.

title: Executive Changes
description: CACI INTERNATIONAL INC., Arlington, Va., named James Allen chief financial officer, succeeding Samuel Strickland.

title: POLITICS;D'Amato Dips in Poll
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's job approval rating has dipped to 34 percent, down from 39 percent in November, an independent poll reported today. The statewide poll of New York voters, by Quinnipiac College in Hamden, Conn., had Mr. D'Amato losing a hypothetical United States Senate race to New York City's Public Advocate, Mark Green, 50 percent to 33 percent.

title: TV SPORTS;When Elmer Gantry Was a Color Man
description: In today's boxing telecasts, somebody talks nearly all the time. Sometimes it's good talk, sometimes it's bad. Usually it's too much. And sometimes HBO's George Foreman, pretending to be a doctor, shouts out his diagnoses.

title: Japanese Stocks Gain
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 119.99, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,183.87. On Monday, the index fell 104.75 points.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LESLIE FAY IS WARNED BY BANKRUPTCY JUDGE
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge Tina Brozman threatened yesterday to liquidate the Leslie Fay Companies if it did not file a revised bankruptcy plan by April 17. Judge Brozman said she would consider converting the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization case to a Chapter 7 liquidation or simply throw it out of bankruptcy court if the plan was not filed by the deadline. If the case is thrown out of court, creditors would then be free to divide the assets among themselves. The apparel company filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors in April 1993. Since then, Leslie Fay has struggled to reorganize. The most recent obstacle to its emergence from bankruptcy has been its inability to sell Sassco Fashions, its most profitable division.

title: John Kallos, 70, a Biologist With Interest in Environmental Issues
description: John Kallos, a molecular biologist who founded the Sustainable Development Initiative, a forum at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business for environmentalists, academics and business people, died on Feb. 25. Dr. Kallos, who lived on Morningside Heights, was 70.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Strickland Is Back
description: Eleven days after he vowed his days with the Portland Trail Blazers were over, ROD STRICKLAND rejoined the team yesterday. "I don't regret anything I've done," Strickland said. "It's just a matter of me deciding to come back and play."

title: Mideast Peace Process Cannot Go Forward
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple Computer Stock Declines
description: Apple Computer Inc.'s stock slid to a 52-week low today after the company canceled a teleconference with computer industry analysts at which it had been expected to discuss its Internet strategy.

title: Sports of The Times;For Carril, Is It the End Of the Agony?
description: PETE CARRIL never wanted a rocking chair.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Imperial Chemical Buys Latin Paint Company
description: Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. reinforced its position as the world's largest paint company yesterday by buying the South American company Bunge Paints Ltd. for $390 million. Imperial said the move would make it South America's leading paint and coatings concern and the first company in the world to sell more than 250 million gallons of paint annually.

title: POLITICS: THE TRAIL;Buchanan Is Slugging Away, Seeking a Georgia Comeback
description: Patrick J. Buchanan was talking about the might-have-beens.

title: Council Members Critical Of Tests in Stairwell Fires
description: Members of the City Council accused the city's Housing Authority yesterday of wasting several hundred thousand dollars in its efforts to combat deadly stairwell fires by hiring a consultant to perform tests that experts warned were flawed and too expensive.

title: BASKETBALL;Providence Seems Poised to Steal the Show
description: No matter who wins the Big East men's basketball tournament, the elite conference will send five or six teams to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 64-team championships next week. At the moment, that sixth team is Providence, and yesterday several coaches anointed the Friars as the dark horse in the Big East tournament, which runs tomorrow through Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Protein Culprit Acts To Cause Huntington's
description: A SIMPLE experiment has given researchers an important new clue to what causes Huntington's disease and brain disorders like it.

title: First, Let's Ask How Children Get Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: BOMBING IS ISRAEL;4 Israeli Soldiers Killed in Clash in Lebanon
description: Four Israeli soldiers were killed and nine were wounded in a clash with guerrillas in southern Lebanon, Israel Radio and the newspaper Davar Rishon reported today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LSI LOGIC PLANS TO BUY BACK AS MANY AS 4 MILLION SHARES
description: Taking advantage of the recent decline in the price of technology stocks, the LSI Logic Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy back as many as four million of its common shares for use in its employee stock plans. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of the company, a chip maker based in Milpitas, Calif., closed up 62.5 cents at $26.625, well below year's high of $62.50. The stock will be purchased on the open market, but the company did not disclose when it expected to complete the repurchase. As of last year, LSI had 144.7 million shares assuming the full conversion of all securities.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIELDCREST PLANS TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS AND CUT 500 JOBS
description: Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., the maker of bed and bath textile products, said yesterday that it would close its towel weaving plant in York, S.C., and a yarn manufacturing operation in Concord, N.C., cutting a total of 500 jobs. The company said the closings, part of its consolidation effort, were expected to save between $8 million and $9 million a year. Fieldcrest said it will take a charge of 31 cents to 35 cents a share in the first quarter to cover the cost of the shutdowns. The plant closings are set for mid-May or early June.

title: PC Makers Release Flood Of Products
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation and two of its rivals announced steep price cuts today, reflecting intense competition in a slowing personal computer market.

title: Generic Drug Companies Seek Loophole
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Double-Hull Tankers Prevent Oil Spills?
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Fight Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS;Voting Hours In Connecticut
description: Polls in Connecticut will be open today from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. for the Republican Presidential primary. Only registered Republicans are eligible to vote. Information on polling places is available from town clerks and registrars of voters.

title: Elusive Genetic Switch At Last Yields Image Of Its 3-D Structure
description: IN an arduous feat that involved luck as well as dogged persistence, researchers have worked out the three-dimensional structure of one of the most famous proteins in the history of molecular biology.

title: Tax Revolt Over West Point;School District Fights Cut in Aid to Offset Exemption
description: This Hudson River community used to have a deal with Washington: the Government would compensate it for the school taxes it lost because the huge West Point Military Academy here was tax exempt.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Bears Sign Conway
description: The Chicago Bears yesterday signed wide receiver CURTIS CONWAY, a restricted free agent, to a four-year, $10 million contract, including a $3 million signing bonus. Conway is coming off the best of his three professional seasons. (AP)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Medical Services Enhanced
description: Muhlenberg Regional Medical Center has signed an agreement that will give its patients access to such services as open-heart surgery and pediatric intensive care at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, the medical center announced yesterday. Four other hospitals and health care systems in Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth and Union Counties have also affiliated.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Mixed Data On Economy Cloud Bonds
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as the bond market wrestled with conflicting economic signals and changing perceptions on the economy's outlook. Many traders and investors believe the Federal Reserve still intends to cut interest rates, with the timing uncertain.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KAREN NUSSBAUM, who has been director of the Women's Bureau of the Labor Department since 1993, is joining the A.F.L.-C.I.O. as director of its new working women's department.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. ROBOTICS PURCHASES AMBER WAVE SYSTEMS
description: The United States Robotics Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Amber Wave Systems Inc., a maker of computer switching devices, for about $40 million in stock. U.S. Robotics said the acquisition of Amber Wave, based in Acton, Mass., would allow it to offer low-cost switching for corporate customers and expand its reach overseas. Amber Wave's products have been successful in Europe, Australia and the Pacific Rim. U.S. Robotics makes modems and other computer communication devices.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Boyfriend Sought in Murder
description: There was nothing remarkable about the behavior of a Paterson couple, William West and Barbara Davidson, at the party Friday night when she was last seen alive, prosecutors said yesterday. But on Sunday night, a family member found Ms. Davidson stabbed several times in the neck and left in a car parked at the Holiday Inn in Saddle Brook, said Frank Puccio, first assistant prosecutor for Bergen County. Yesterday, a murder warrant was issued for Mr. West, Mr. Puccio said.

title: Proposal Would Reorganize U.S. Intelligence Agencies
description: The chairman of the House intelligence committee today proposed reorganizing the nation's espionage services and splitting up the Central Intelligence Agency, including spinning off its clandestine services directorate.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Venezuela Again Opens to Foreign Oil Concerns
description: Venezuela, a petroleum-rich country that is currently starved for cash, is moving to vastly increase its crude oil production.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CITATION INSURANCE AGREES TO BUY PHYSICIANS INSURANCE
description: Citation Insurance Group agreed yesterday to buy the Physicians Insurance Company of Ohio in a stock transaction valued at as much as $30 a share, or $160 million. The transaction could be valued at as little as $131 million, or $25.20 a share. Physicians Insurance holders will receive between 5 and 6.12 shares of Citation for each of their shares, depending on the average closing price of Physicians' stock over a period of 20 trading days. At Friday's closing price of $27.125, each Physicians Insurance shareholder would get 5.39 Citation shares, valuing the transaction at $141 million. Shares of Citation rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $4.625, and shares of Physicians Insurance fell $1, to $26.25. Physicians is a unit of Guinness Peat Group P.L.C.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about an extension of the Senate hearings on Whitewater misidentified a committee member. At the far right, behind Senator Alfonse D'Amato, was Senator Richard Shelby, Republican of Alabama, not Senator Spencer Abraham, Republican of Michigan.

title: Plan to Trim Headquarters
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has proposed a reorganization of the Board of Education's headquarters that would focus on enforcing standards while scaling back the largely redundant role of writing curriculum and establishing guidelines to meet those goals. Page B2.

title: The Real Zyuganov
description: Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist Party leader who is the current favorite to win Russia's presidential elections in June, tries hard to sound like a reasonable man.

title: BASKETBALL;UConn and Notre Dame In Showdown for Title
description: The UConn Huskies are right where all of the Big East expected them to be: in line to win a third consecutive conference tournament and gain an automatic bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association 64-team tournament field.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Gretzky to Return Soon
description: WAYNE GRETZKY may be in street clothes tonight for his first home appearance with the St. Louis Blues, but it is likely to be just a temporary setback for the team that labored for months to acquire him. Gretzky sustained a concussion in Sunday's game at Edmonton, and the Blues said a decision on his availability will be made after he skates with the team this morning.

title: Lilly Industries Agrees to Buy Guardsman
description: Lilly Industries said today that it had agreed to buy Guardsman Products Inc., a maker of paints, varnishes and other products for the wood furniture industry, for $23 a share, or about $235 million.

title: BASEBALL;Brogna Plays Waiting Game Until His Back Pain Eases
description: Rico Brogna hopes he will be in the lineup Tuesday when the Mets play a split-squad exhibition game here against the Florida Marlins. If he is, it will be Brogna's first game action of the spring and the first chance to test his troublesome lower back, which has sidelined him for the first three games.

title: Slave Auction' Criticized
description: After criticism from black leaders and others, a television evangelist apologized today for inviting his parishioners to participate in a "slave auction" to raise money for high school students.

title: POP REVIEW;The Allman Brothers, Still Mixing the Genres
description: The Allman Brothers began a 17-night stand at the Beacon Theater on Friday night, but for the better part of the show, something was missing: an Allman brother.

title: Mideast Peace Process Cannot Go Forward
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Sending 5 Boat People Back to Cuba
description: The United States was sending five boat people back to Cuba today under last year's migration accords, which have not been affected by Cuba's downing of two small civilian aircraft, American officials said.

title: After Pledges at Asia Summit, Europe Faces Cost
description: PARIS  European leaders went into last weekend's Bangkok summit conference hoping they could tiptoe around human rights, promote exports to Asia and enhance their presence in the region.

title: POLITICS: CONNECTICUT;Forbes Goes On TV Show In Hartford For Primary
description: Steve Forbes was the only Presidential candidate in Connecticut today, making appearances that together with his television ads and a 30-minute show of his own assured that his face would be freshest in the minds of Republicans as they vote in Tuesday's primary.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;South Africa Ex-Minister Gets Murder Trial Delay
description: The trial of South Africa's former Defense Minister, Magnus Malan, and 19 other defendants accused of plotting political killings in the 1980's was delayed today when a judge gave Mr. Malan's lawyers more time to study his case.

title: Pharmacia & Upjohn to Close 40% of Drug-Making Plants
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said today that it would close 40 percent of its worldwide drug manufacturing plants, saving $300 million a year by 2000.

title: G.O.P. Seeks to Expand Access to Health Care, With a Catch
description: House Republican leaders said today that they would soon take up a bill intended to expand access to health insurance for millions of Americans, but they intend to add provisions that are likely to generate bitter, prolonged disputes in Congress.

title: Market Place;Campbell Appointment May Signal New Tack
description: After a year without a chief financial officer, the Campbell Soup Company is reaching out to the investor community, and raising the possibility of significant change ahead. Today it will name Basil L. Anderson chief financial officer and vice president of the company.

title: Q & A
description: Stars and Sand

title: War Criminals Not NATO Job, New Judge Says
description: The Canadian judge who will take over this fall as chief prosecutor of the international war crimes tribunals for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda said today that the prime responsibility for arresting those charged with offenses in Bosnia lies with Balkan leaders who signed the Dayton peace agreement, not with a NATO-led international force.

title: Chess
description: It took Garry Kasparov less than than two weeks to resume tournament play after his world championship match in New York with Viswanathan Anand ended on Oct. 11. It took Anand three months before he came out of hibernation.

title: In Performance;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Negotiating Both Vivaldi And Art-Rock Allusions John Williams, guitarist 92d Street Y

title: POLITICS: IN HIS OWN WORDS;LAMAR ALEXANDER
description: He spoke at a gathering of about 50 supporters in Burlington, Vt., in a boathouse on Lake Champlain:

title: Mideast Peace Process Cannot Go Forward
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepsi Strikes MTV Deal
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Viacom Inc. to be the exclusive soft-drink sponsor of certain programs on the MTV music television network. The value of the three-year deal was not disclosed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAXTER AND INHALE THERAPEUTIC SYSTEMS IN VENTURE
description: Baxter International Inc. will invest about $80 million in Inhale Therapeutic Systems as part of a drug collaboration between the two companies, Inhale Therapeutic said yesterday. Baxter will initially acquire about 12 percent of Inhale's stock for $20 million, said Robert B. Chess, chief executive of Inhale. Baxter will then provide another $60 million in research financing and milestone payments. It has options to invest an additional $55 million in the company. Shares of Inhale Therapeutic soared $4.50, or 37 percent, to $16.75, yesterday, and shares of Baxter rose $1.125, to $47.125. The pair will initially use Inhale's dry-powder inhaler technology to develop four drugs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is no amount of money large enough, it seems, to entice PAUL McCARTNEY, RINGO STARR and GEORGE HARRISON back together on stage to perform live again. Geoff Baker, the spokesman for "The Beatles Anthology" projects, confirmed yesterday that the former band members had turned down an offer of $225 million to do 22 concerts in Japan, Europe and the United States. The offer came from a consortium of German and American businessmen, but Mr. Baker said yesterday that he was not authorized to identify them more precisely.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kikkoman Account Is Under Review
description: Kikkoman International in San Francisco has placed in review its consumer soy sauce account, with billings estimated at $5 million to $6 million. The account has been handled for more than a decade by the San Francisco office of the Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;The Littlest Computer Thinks That It's a Giant
description: I AM typing this sentence, not without difficulty, on the smallest full-fledged I.B.M. personal computer around. How small? About the size of a paperback novel. At 6 1/4 inches by 4 1/2 inches by 1 1/4 inches, the I.B.M. Palm Top PC 110 is not quite as big as the Ivy edition of "Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All." At 1 pound, 6 ounces, it weighs almost exactly as much as the Signet Classics edition of "Les Miserables." Need I add that it can easily hold the entire text of both and more besides?

title: G.O.P. Plans For Capital Are on Hold
description: It was just about a year ago that Speaker Newt Gingrich vowed that the time had come to turn Washington from a crumbling city into his image of a glistening capital.

title: Film Stirs Argentines' Memories Of a Nazi
description: It was 36 years ago that Cecilio Guillermo Leal first learned that his quiet German neighbor, whom he knew as Ricardo Clement, was not the plain hydrologist he claimed to be.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Assault Citation
description: A former Nebraska football player, CHRISTIAN PETER, was cited for third-degree assault after he allegedly grabbed a woman by the neck in a Kearney, Neb., bar this weekend. AMY JACOBSEN, a Buffalo County deputy attorney, said she will review the report and decide this week whether formal charges will be filed.

title: Finding Profit in Aiding the Lost;A Civilian Industry Is Built on the Military's Locator Technology
description: It is a navigational system designed in the 1970's to guide troops and missiles, but in the 1990's it has come to be used far more often for helping truckers, boaters and hikers find their way.

title: Swimmer Denied '72 Gold
description: For the second time in three months, the International Olympic Committee today rejected a request by the American Rick DeMont for restitution of the swimming gold medal that was stripped from him in 1972 following a positive drug test.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: THEATER REVIEW;Drink And Fight Then Fight Some More
description: The Carneys of County Mayo are a close-knit clan that lives by its own set of family values: fighting and booze. Harry, the spiritual leader, counsels his brothers that in life's struggles, "a bottle is better than a fist; a broken bottle is better than two fists." Dada, a blowhard for whom truth is nebulous at best, exhorts his sons by quoting Gene Tunney: "A man must fight back."

title: A Misstep by AT&T and a Setback for Lotus
description: AT&T's decision to discontinue a venture that linked users of Lotus Notes software over AT&T phone lines was widely seen as a setback for Notes. And the news was one factor behind a sharp drop in the stock price of Lotus's parent, I.B.M., the last few days.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fund-Raiser Is Criticized
description: An antismoking group has criticized the Easter Seal Society of New Jersey for "profiting from a tobacco-glorification event" during which 225 guests smoked expensive cigars. Billed as the Garden State Cigar Party, the March 1 gathering at the Garden City Arts Center raised $21,000 for the charity, which provides services to disabled people, said Barbara Getze, its organizer. "Tobacco use and tobacco smoke pollution are particularly hazardous for disabled persons," said Regina Carlson, executive director of Group Against Smoking Pollution. TERRY PRISTIN

title: BASEBALL;With Orioles, a Coach Laughs
description: Rick Down had not even finished pulling on his black Orioles jersey today when reporters quickly descended upon him, causing his fellow Baltimore coaches to unleash a stream of playful abuse.

title: Lyle Talbot, 94, Charactor Actor And TV Neighbor
description: Lyle Talbot, a veteran character actor in movies and on television, died Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 94.

title: Dreamworks In New Alliance
description: Dreamworks SKG said today that it was acquiring a 40 percent stake in Pacific Data Images, a closely held computer animation company. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MIDCOM SHARES FALL 42% ON RESTATEMENT OF EARNINGS
description: The shares of Midcom Communications Inc. plunged 42 percent yesterday after the company said earnings in its 1995 third quarter were actually less than it had reported because of an accounting glitch. The Seattle-based telecommunications company said its third-quarter revenues were $2.7 million less than the $51.5 million it reported last November. Midcom said the restatement was caused by an overstatement of unbilled revenue during its conversion to a new billing system. Midcom said the problem caused it to fall out of compliance with its working capital credit line. The lender allowed the company to continue to borrow, but the company noted that this would reduce its borrowing capacity. Shares of Midcom fell $5.75, to $8, yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Electronic Toll Plan on Hold
description: Bills to authorize an electronic toll system on the state's three toll roads were put on hold yesterday so that an Assembly committee could gather more information on how much the change would cost and how well a similar system had worked for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority in New York. Michael G. Frommer, the president of the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers Local 194, which represents New Jersey Turnpike Authority employees, asked the Assembly Transportation and Communications Committee also to consider how many highway jobs might be lost in an electronic conversion.

title: The New York Primary
description: Senator Bob Dole says New York is "a big one." With 93 delegates to be selected on Thursday, it is the biggest state primary yet. But Mr. Dole's brief journey across the state yesterday was part of a subdued campaign reflecting his hope that victory will be served up by a powerful Republican organization that insiders like to call "Al D'Amato Inc."

title: By Design;The Surprise Is Khaki
description: Who would expect khaki to be a hot fashion? Even when a Gap advertising campaign in summer 1993 showed celebrities like Hemingway, Gene Kelly and Marilyn Monroe wearing khakis, the pants were still for casual wear. Then Calvin Klein brought out a line called Khaki, and Karl Lagerfeld showed cotton khaki pants with tweed jackets in his spring collection for Chanel.

title: The War in Israel
description: Four deadly suicide bombings by Palestinian terrorists in nine days have convulsed Israel. As the architects of these savage attacks no doubt hoped, the spasm of terror has nearly ruptured Israel's plans for peace with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Only courageous leadership and decisive action by Israel and the P.L.O. can keep the hope of peace alive.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;The Artist as a Freewheeling Heel
description: PAUL GAUGUIN A Life By David Sweetman Illustrated. 600 pages. Simon & Schuster. $35.

title: Clinton Urges Action on Bills to Create Jobs and Lift Incomes
description: President Clinton today responded to the anxieties about job security that are rippling through the Republican Presidential race by repackaging his legislative program as a "growth agenda" that will "keep creating jobs and raise incomes" to allow all Americans to compete in the new global economy.

title: Newbridge Reaches Pact With Siemens
description: The Newbridge Networks Corporation and the German telecommunications giant Siemens A.G.announced a sweeping technology alliance today.

title: Computer Problems Delay Student Aid Applications
description: The Federal Department of Education, which processes applications for more than $32 billion in student aid each year, has run into computer problems that have delayed nearly a million applications, which could force some students to postpone enrollment decisions.

title: Court Strengthens Government Rights in Forfeiture Cases
description: Bolstering government authority to seize property used to commit a crime, the Supreme Court ruled today that the property might be forfeited even if the owner was innocent of any wrongdoing.

title: CITY OPERA REVIEW;2 Staples Start Season
description: The spring season of the New York City Opera promises some unusual offerings, including the American premiere of Jost Meier's "Dreyfus Affair." But the season commenced with two staples: "La Traviata" on Friday and "Tosca" on Saturday afternoon. The news came from the singing, especially the debut of a Bronx-born tenor, Don Bernardini, who sang Alfredo in Renata Scotto's effectively traditional production of "Traviata."

title: POLITICS: GEORGIA;Atlanta Officials Abashed At Arrest of a Candidate
description: Mayor Bill Campbell, summoning Olympian powers of spin control, characterized it as "a whimsical night" in Atlanta.

title: Hicks, Muse Buys Ghirardelli Chocolate
description: The Ghirardelli Chocolate Company has been bought by a Dallas investment company. The deal, which was announced today, is the third time in the last 10 years that the company has changed owners.

title: COMPANY NEWS;3COM TO BUY AXON NETWORKS FOR $65 MILLION
description: The 3Com Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Axon Networks Inc. for $65 million, mostly in cash, to acquire computer network monitoring software and technology. 3Com, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $45 million to $50 million for the acquisition of Axon, based in Newton, Mass. Axon develops software and electronic devices that let computer managers keep track of the performance of sophisticated, company-wide networks from their work stations.

title: Burmese Harbor Drug Lord
description: The leader of a Burmese drug operation who is wanted in the United States on heroin trafficking charges is living in a lakeside villa in the most exclusive neighborhood of Yangon, Myanmar's capital, a diplomat said today.

title: Times Mirror to Cash In on Netscape's Rise
description: Only 11 months after making one of the best investments in its history, the Times Mirror Company is cashing in with a return of about 2,200 percent. And it is doing so on terms that will not require it to pay capital gains taxes for years to come.

title: Ecosystem's Productivity Rises With Diversity of Its Species
description: RESEARCHERS studying experimental prairies say they have confirmed what conservationists have long hoped would be true: having more species improves an ecosystem's productivity.

title: Jefferies Group Stock Split
description: Jefferies Group Inc., a Los Angeles-based brokerage firm, said today that its board had approved a 2-for-1 split on all outstanding shares. The split is payable March 29 to shareholders of record on March 15. The company said the board had approved continuation of the quarterly cash dividend rate of 5 cents a share on the approximately 12 million shares to be outstanding after the split.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bodega Owner Is Charged
description: The owner of an Irvington bodega was charged yesterday with the November 1994 murder of a Newark businessman to whom she owed $80,000, officials said yesterday. Maria Rafaella Cruz lured the businessman, Agripino Gomezinto, to her store, where she and an accomplice, Jose Vargas of Newark, beat him to death, said Clifford J. Minor, the Essex County Prosecutor.

title: N.J. Transit Begins to Observe New Train Safety Rules
description: As the 1109 Main-line train from Hoboken approached its final stop at the foothills of a barren mountain range here, the conductor drew a two-way radio from his hip belt and talked to the engineer.

title: Baumgartner Wins Sullivan Award
description: The Olympic wrestler Bruce Baumgartner, a finalist for the fifth time, won the Sullivan Award today as the nation's top amateur athlete of 1995.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Coca-Cola Expands An Agency's Role
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis by awarding that agency creative responsibilities for its Nestea Cool brand of iced tea, which had been handled in-house. The billings were not disclosed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Argosy Gaming Corp., St. Louis, to Bates U.S.A./Midwest, Indianapolis, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., as the first agency to handle advertising for a casino in Lawrenceburg, Ind. The billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. Twin Laboratories Inc., Ronkonkoma, L.I., to Slater Hanft Martin, New York, to handle advertising and sales promotion for its Nature's Herbs and Alvita Teas brands, previously handled by Greenstone Roberts Advertising, Melville, L.I. The billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Italy Opens Inquiry Into Jail Escape by Achille Lauro Gunman
description: The Justice Ministry said today that it was investigating the disappearance of a Palestinian terrorist convicted of killing an American Jew in a cruise ship hijacking in 1985.

title: Libel Case Against Writer and Magazine Is Dismissed
description: In a ruling that adopts a broad view of the right of writers and publishers to state opinions even if defamatory, a Federal judge has dismissed a libel lawsuit against the author John McPhee, The New Yorker magazine and Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Runs, Trills, Passage Work And Crescendo Into Tattoo
description: The mad idea of traversing all the Beethoven piano sonatas in one series of concerts originated with Artur Schnabel, who played the sequence in Berlin in 1927 and recorded it the following decade. Schnabel triumphed because he was a composer and pianist in equal measure. The 32 sonatas encompass spectacularly varied worlds, to which no single style serves as guide; Schnabel explored them with the recreative intensity that composers can bring to the keyboard. The downside of his achievement was the creation of a marathon mode of piano athletics.

title: Israelis' Crackdown And Support by U.S.
description: Israel mounted its war on terrorism, sending troops on a punitive raid to a West Bank refugee camp, home to two attackers who struck last week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a telephone transcription error, an article yesterday about Marcia Robinson Lowry, a lawyer and head of the Children's Rights Project who is arguing in a Federal lawsuit for a court takeover of New York City's child protection agency, included an erroneous description. The first sentence should have begun "Attorney Marcia Robinson Lowry," not "A tiny Marcia Robinson Lowry." (Ms. Lowry is 5 foot 7.)

title: Fashion/Review;In London, Blueblood Meets Hot Blood
description: The Gothic church that was the site for the Alexander McQueen show on Friday night, the close of the London fashion collections, has a vaulted foyer. Yet, it almost seemed that Isabella Blow, the stylist, would have to bend her head to get her far-ranging feathered Philip Treacy hat through it.

title: Lehman Division Is Fined in Maxwell Case
description: Lehman Brothers International said today that it had been fined L80,000, or $121,600, by the Securities and Futures Authority for keeping inadequate records and for maintaining lax procedures in dealings with the late Robert Maxwell.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the Monterey Bay Aquarium in California referred incorrectly to a window in the new Outer Bay Exhibit. It is among the largest windows in an aquarium; it is not the largest.

title: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA;Big Holes Where the Dignity Used to Be
description: To the beggars downtown that autumn day, every wing-tipped stride of James E. Sharlow seemed to resonate with prosperity. His suit was boardroom gray, his tie was red silk, his creases as crisp as fresh money. One ragged man sidled up to him with a sad story and an outstretched palm.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Trafalgar to Kvaerner In $1.4 Billion Deal
description: Kvaerner A.S. of Norway agreed yesterday to buy Trafalgar House P.L.C. for L904 million (about $1.4 billion). The merger will create one of the world's biggest construction companies involved in oil and gas projects. Kvaerner has long sought to expand internationally in oil and gas work. Its hostile bid last year for another British engineering and construction company, Amec, failed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bankruptcies Expected For Fokker Companies
description: Ben van Schaik, chairman of the troubled Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V., said yesterday that Fokker Holding N.V. and Fokker N.V. would be declared bankrupt even if the business units of the company were allowed to continue to operate. In an interview with Dutch television, Mr. van Schaik said he wanted banks, administrators and the Government to provide more clarity this week on the future of Fokker. Fokker's principal owner Daimler-Benz of Germany, recently said it was discontinuing financial help for Fokker.

title: Oklahoma Grandparents Turn Grief Into a Quest
description: It is income tax time, and Glenn Wilburn, 45, a certified public accountant, is wrestling with the season's usual mountain of papers and figures at the office. But it is the notes by his kitchen telephone that are his passion and have made him a lightning rod for the legions of unofficial investigators looking into the bombing of the Federal Building here.

title: New $100 Bills Due Soon
description: The newly designed $100 bills, the first major makeover of the United States currency since 1928, will become available on March 25, the Treasury announced today. The department said some 800 million of the new bills would be available by that week but emphasized the old-style bills would continue to be legal United States tender and would be phased out gradually as they were replaced by the new currency.

title: In Performance;POP MUSIC
description: Back to Teardrops And Heartaches Joni James, Town Hall If the adoring reception given to the 1950's pop singer Joni James on Saturday evening is any proof of the cliche, absence does make the heart grow fonder, at least in the realm of pop nostalgia. Ms. James's sold-out concert was her first New York appearance in 27 years. The mostly middle-aged audience greeted her with a standing ovation and flooded the stage with floral tributes.

title: Grace Rejects Plan to Merge With Hercules
description: Spurning yet another suitor for its businesses, W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it would not consider merging with Hercules Inc., a rival chemical manufacturer. Grace also said that Thomas L. Gossage, the chairman of Hercules who proposed the deal, had resigned from its board.

title: BOMBING IS ISRAEL: THE CRACKDOWN;Israeli Troops Raid Camp Where 2 Bombers Lived
description: Struggling against a wave of Palestinian suicide bombings, the Israeli Government mounted its declared war on terrorism today, sending troops on a punitive raid on this refugee camp, home to two attackers who struck last week.

title: British Chief Promises Hong Kong a Tight Check on China
description: Wading into a rising tide of anxiety over China's impending takeover of Hong Kong, Prime Minister John Major today sought to shore up morale and confidence here by promising Hong Kong citizens visa-free access to Britain and vigorous scrutiny of China's behavior in the territory after it regains sovereignty.

title: Turncoat Says an Accused Mobster Is Acting Insane to Avoid Prison
description: For more than five years, psychiatrists, physicians, defense lawyers and prosecutors have produced a torrent of medical reports and legal documents in a dispute over whether a man who walks around Greenwich Village in a bathrobe is capable of being a Mafia godfather.

title: A Bad Way to Fight the Drug Trade
description: Influencing the behavior of countries involved in the production or shipment of illicit drugs is no easy matter for the United States, but the problem is exacerbated by a clumsy law the President must exercise every year. It requires that the State Department annually compile a list of delinquent countries, and that the White House decide which deserve punishment and which can go unscathed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Kvaerner Puts Cunard On Block in Takeover
description: Cunard, the luxury-cruise-ship operator, is up for sale after its parent, Trafalgar House, agreed to a takeover by the Norwegian engineering giant Kvaerner. Kvaerner said yesterday that several prospective buyers had expressed interest, despite Cunard's aging fleet and financial losses.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Wells Fargo Said to Be Ousting Economists
description: Wells Fargo & Company will dismiss its entire economics research department upon completing its takeover of First Interstate Bancorp on April 1, individuals at the banks said today.

title: Spain's Election Victor Still Faces an Uphill Fight
description: Jose Maria Aznar may sound dull and nasal to many Spaniards, but in a crisis he knows how to keep his head. Last April, 40 pounds of explosives intended for the conservative leader blew up just yards short of his bulletproof car. Mr. Aznar climbed from the wreck largely unscathed, brushed off his clothes and walked to a nearby hospital.

title: Advances in Genetics Give Biology Curriculums a Thought-Provoking New Dimension
description: Remember high school biology? Most questions were about Mendel's sweet peas, animal family trees and that yucky frog floating in formaldehyde, awaiting dissection.

title: RJR Increases Dividend 23% In Latest Move In Proxy Battle
description: RJR Nabisco Holdings, in its escalating proxy battle with the investors Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn to win the hearts and votes of shareholders at its annual meeting this spring, announced yesterday that it would raise its annual dividend 23 percent, to $1.85 a share.

title: Patient Lost Two Months Is in Custody
description: A patient with a violent history who escaped from a New Jersey state psychiatric hospital two months ago was found today at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, officials said.

title: Start of Charter School Shows Flaws in Concept
description: The campus is 18 portable buildings in a muddy vacant field and the classrooms contain 1950's desks and chairs. There is no gymnasium, food service or library. The school almost closed in December when it ran out of money, and it was recently cited by the state for accounting procedures so lax it could be shut later on.

title: Croats Jump Gun on Takeover of Sarajevo Suburb
description: A squad of Croatian police officers entered the burning Sarajevo suburb of Hadzici on Tuesday evening, jumping the gun on a scheduled takeover by Bosnia's Muslim-Croat federation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japanese Banks Offer Vague Help in Bailout
description: In a faint bow to blistering public criticism over a proposed rescue of mortgage companies, Japanese banks agreed today to shoulder a bit more of the burden. But the banks' plan is so vague that it is not clear whether the banks will actually have to put up any more money.

title: Medicine Can Do Without Religion or State;Brain-Death Diagnosis
description: To the Editor:

title: ON HOCKEY;Unlike the Rangers, the Devils Act Like Winners
description: With the Stanley Cup playoffs six weeks away, the Devils and the Rangers seem like two planes at an airport rising and descending on parallel runways. Monday's 2-2 tie at Madison Square Garden was reflected on the faces of the opposing coaches and revealed much about their attitudes.

title: INSIDE
description: Beyond Mendel's Pea Pods

title: A Marriage Fit for a Queen
description: When Princess Diana told the world that she had agreed to divorce Prince Charles, she implied that it was not her doing or desire. She had loved Charles and would always love him. He was the father of her children. But it was time for the courts to make legal what had become established fact: The marriage had irretrievably broken down. Boringly, Buckingham Palace muttered about terms, conditions and money. The Princess, upstaging as ever, talked about feelings.

title: BASEBALL;Fernandez Reluctant To Fill In For Kelly
description: Pat Kelly has not been informed by Yankee Manager Joe Torre that his lingering right shoulder injury could cost him his starting job at second base, but he realizes it. Tony Fernandez has been told that Torre called him the front-runner to start in place of Kelly, but he does not believe it. The intriguing message sent by the manager on Monday casting doubt on Kelly's status had both players attempting to decipher it today.

title: Judge Agrees To Rehear Case On Drugs Seized By the Police
description: A Federal judge who was widely criticized for throwing out drug evidence agreed yesterday to listen to prosecutors' arguments that he should change his mind, saying that a rehearing is "in the interests of justice."

title: PRO BASKETBALL;If the Knicks Haven't Hit the Bottom, They're Close
description: He was looking over at celebrity row as the ball passed through the net, egging everyone on as if it were a Game 7. Each swish resembled a dagger. He made another. And then another. Each shot left his fingertips with precision and purpose.

title: HOCKEY;Palffy's Second Straight Hat Trick Turns Isles Around
description: Zigmund Palffy had three goals on Sunday but could not enjoy his first career hat trick because the Islanders lost the game to Winnipeg. Tonight, though, everyone wanted to take their hats off to Palffy, and he was happy to receive the adulation.

title: S.E.C. Panel Issues Proposals To Ease Corporate Offerings
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission took the first steps today to eliminate hundreds of rules and required forms in an attempt to simplify corporate offering procedures and make it easier for small companies to raise capital.

title: Auto Sales Rise by 5.6%, With Ford's Flat in Month
description: Auto sales rose 5.6 percent last month, assuaging industry and Wall Street fears that the industry was heading for a stiff downturn.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RALPHS GROCERY TO LAY OFF ABOUT 1,000 WORKERS
description: The Ralphs Grocery Company said it would lay off about 1,000 workers, most of them part-time clerks, cashiers and meat cutters, in the next 10 days at its supermarkets in Southern California. Ralphs, the region's biggest grocer, has 26,000 employees. The company said the job cuts were adjustments stemming from its merger with the Food 4 Less chain last year. Regulators ordered that 27 stores be sold for antitrust reasons after the merger and the company decided to close another 28. That cut part-time workers' hours from an average 31 hours a week to 25.5 a week, Ralphs said. But for those part-time workers who remain, the number of hours a week are expected to increase.

title: Queens Teen-Ager Is Shot in Head
description: A 13-year-old Queens youth was shot in the head yesterday when he and another 13-year-old youth were playing with a gun, the police said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fear Over Meningitis Deaths
description: Nervous New Jersey residents have been calling state health officials, worried about the recent sudden deaths of two high school boys from meningococcal disease, the A.P. reported. Officials said yesterday there is no need for students to be alarmed because meningitis is spread only through close contact.

title: POP REVIEW;Mismatched Latin Bands Still Sell Out
description: Rock en Espanol, a transnational movement of Spanish-speaking rock bands, has such a large following that two completely mismatched bands can still sell out the Palladium. On Monday night, Soda Stereo, an Argentine band that takes its cues from 80's MTV-fueled pop and rock, joined up with a ratty little Colombian alternative rock band called Aterciopelados to scare the security force with its rabid audience.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Filling In for Hermann Prey
description: A young California-born baritone, Christopheren Nomura, came to the rescue of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center when an indisposed Hermann Prey pulled out of last weekend's concerts. Mr. Nomura, a 1992 Young Concert Artists award winner, made a strong impression on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, though the concert, as a whole, did not.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACX BUYS GRAVURE PACKAGING FOR $30 MILLION
description: ACX Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the privately held Gravure Packaging Inc. for $30 million, which included $2.4 million in cash, 911,000 ACX common shares and the assumption of $12 million of debt. ACX plans to merge Gravure, which has about 200 employees, with its Graphic Packaging Corporation unit, expanding the folding-carton operations. ACX, based in Golden, Colo., makes ceramic products, packaging, and flat-rolled sheet aluminum products. The company had sales of $910.9 million in 1995.

title: Ben Franklin Cutbacks
description: Ben Franklin Retail Stores Inc., the chain of crafts stores, said today that it would close its distribution center in New Hope, Minn., resulting in the loss of 105 jobs. The company said the closing is expected to be completed by June 1. Ben Franklin owns 41 Ben Franklin Crafts Superstores and is a franchisor to more than 300 craft stores, as well as 540 variety stores.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Orton's Warped Wit, More Slapstick Than Verbal
description: Joe Orton is a good man to find in this season of Presidential primaries, when debate platforms ring with holy sentiments that no one takes at face value.

title: POLITICS: THE OUTLOOK;Finding the Formula
description: Through two campaigns and the start of a third, Bob Dole was the man who could hardly win a Presidential primary. Now, presto change-o, he has turned into the man who can hardly lose one.

title: A New York Era Dies With a Deli Man
description: The murder of Abe Lebewohl not only ended the life of a much-beloved figure in the life of the Lower East Side, but was also a grim reminder of the diminished Jewish presence in a neighborhood that served as a Plymouth Rock for newcomers from Eastern Europe.

title: Election on Line
description: Computer users may obtain late results of yesterday's Republican Presidential primaries from The New York Times's two services: The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes.com, and

title: New Drugs Are Precisely Timed To Match Body's Biological Clock
description: THEY once seemed like technological marvels: "600 tiny time pills" packed inside a cold tablet and programmed to release a set amount of medicine into the body for 12 hours. But last week a group of doctors meeting in New York proclaimed that the sun was setting on this shotgun approach to drug dosing and dawning on an age of drugs that are precisely timed to enter the bloodstream when they are needed most.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Scrod Smothered With Wine and Vegetables
description: This mixture of vegetables, olives and white wine works well with many kinds of fish, mild or strong. I prefer to use scrod, a firm-fleshed white fish readily available on the East Coast. Scrod is the name for a young cod. Flounder and boneless chicken breasts would make good substitutes, but the chicken would have to cook longer than the fish.

title: 2 Are Shot on Marine Base
description: A Marine officer was fatally shot and another was critically wounded this afternoon when a sergeant opened fire at Camp Pendleton, a Marine Corps base, the authorities said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Coca-Cola's Olympic campaign to focus on the armchair athlete.
description: BORROWING a marketing strategy from Norma Desmond, who in "Sunset Boulevard" plots her comeback to please "those wonderful people out there in the dark," the Coca-Cola Company will focus much of an extensive and expensive campaign for the 1996 Summer Olympics on the fans rather than the athletes.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;The Forbes Pitch for a Flat Tax
description: BODY This is a new 30-second advertisement that will be broadcast in various states, and that has already begun in New York on behalf of Steve Forbes.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;CS Profit Up 5%
description: CS Holding A.G., the Swiss financial services company, reported yesterday that it had a 5 percent profit increase in 1995, with a 40 percent pretax profit gain in its Credit Suisse banking unit. The company, which also has electrical power and industrial operations, said it earned 1.4 billion Swiss francs ($1.17 billion), up from 1.33 billion francs in 1994.

title: Health Advocates Assail Pataki Spending Cuts
description: In the last few years, New York State has tried to correct the problems created by years of discharging tens of thousands of patients from state mental hospitals into communities without first establishing treatment programs and housing. The state committed a lot of money, and the investment had begun to pay off as new clinics, vocational programs and housing opened.

title: John W. Wright, 83, Headed Money-Management Company
description: John Winthrop Wright, the founder and chairman of Wright Investors' Service, an investment management and advisory service company, died on Monday at Saint Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. Mr. Wright, a resident of Fairfield, Conn., was 83.

title: Cairo Journal;Above the City's Din, Always the Voice of Allah
description: From a worn-out tape player in the back of Saad Eddin Saleh's carpentry shop, a silvery voice read out the rhythmic verses that in this din-filled city form a kind of constant chorus.

title: POLITICS: In Their Own Words
description: BOB DOLE Speaking yesterday at the Association for a Better New York: "I've never met a perfect candidate for any office. Maybe there are a few in New York. I don't know of any. Maybe some here. But John Lindsay was close because he was my friend. I remember John going to Kansas with me one day, tall, good-looking guy. I was just happy to be along with a guy like that. And he was what we called a moderate-to-liberal Republican. Some would eliminate the word 'moderate.' People said, 'What are you bringing him to Kansas for?' And I said, 'Because I want people to know that we are a big party.' And John did a great job. You raised $12,000 that day, remember that? You got half and I got half, as I recall.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Drop on Weakened Rate-Cut Hope
description: Prices of Treasury securities slumped yesterday, as hopes for a quick cut in interest rates were weakened by a strong factory orders report and by comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.

title: Decoded Cables Depict Big Wartime Soviet Spy Ring in U.S.
description: Decoded fragments of cables from Soviet spies in New York and Washington during World War II indicate the Soviets had contacts throughout the United States, including within the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the military and the chief American intelligence agency, according to documents made public today.

title: Pratt & Whitney Deal
description: An aircraft leasing company has ordered 18 engines, worth $240 million, from Pratt & Whitney, the company said today. The International Lease Finance Corporation, a unit of the American International Group, has ordered 11 engines for Boeing 777's and seven engines for Airbus A330-200's. Pratt & Whitney, a unit of United Technologies, will begin delivering the engines in 1998 and 1999 and continue through 2005.

title: POLITICS: THE VICTOR;A Years-Long Quest Yields a Blockbuster
description: Tonight, Bob Dole held a victory party that felt at last like a real victory party.

title: Newsweek in Russian Magazine Venture
description: Under a licensing agreement with a Russian publisher, Newsweek will provide material from current issues of the magazine for a new Russian language newsweekly that will start up in May. Newsweek, which is owned by the Washington Post Company, will also provide commercial and editorial advice to the publication, which will carry Newsweek's logo on its cover. The agreement is to be announced formally in Moscow today.

title: No Headline
description: We still spend some time on pea plants but move very quickly into humans. Most kids wouldn't know a pea plant if they met one. But they do know and care about human traits." KEN BINGMAN, on how the teaching of high school biology has changed. [B9:2]

title: Republicans Make an Offer On the Elusive '96 Budget
description: With the temporary spending authority for scores of Federal agencies scheduled to expire next week, Republicans in Congress offered today to pass a budget for the rest of the 1996 fiscal year and to increase spending on social programs by $4.5 billion -- if the White House would agree to a deficit-cutting deal.

title: COMPANY NEWS;I.B.M. ANNOUNCES SOME STEEPER PRICE CUTS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had made additional price cuts of 4 percent to 9 percent in its line of commercial desktop personal computers. The price cuts were in addition to a 20 percent price cut announced two weeks ago and followed sharp price cuts announced on Monday by the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation. "We additionally fine-tuned prices to match those of our major competitors," an I.B.M. spokeswoman said. I.B.M. also said yesterday that it would invest $500 million to increase the manufacturing capacity of its storage technology unit.

title: World News Briefs;Mandela in Hospital For 3 Days of Tests
description: President Nelson Mandela underwent a battery of tests today that he says are intended to squelch reports that he is ill.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EXCEL INDUSTRIES TO BUY ANDERSON INDUSTRIES
description: Excel Industries signed a definitive agreement yesterday to buy the closely held Anderson Industries for an undisclosed amount. Anderson Industries is a holding company based in Rockford, Ill., whose main asset is Atwood Industries, a maker of equipment such as gas ranges, water heaters, furnaces, air-conditioners for recreational vehicles and housing. Excel, based in Elkhart, Ind., said Atwood's sales were expected to be about $375 million this year. Atwood has about 3,700 employees at 13 plants in the United States, one plant in Mexico and one in Italy. Excel makes window and door systems for manufacturers of cars, vans, trucks and buses.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Graf, Capriati to Play
description: JENNIFER CAPRIATI, who hasn't played in a United States event in 16 months, and STEFFI GRAF, who hasn't played in a tournament yet this year because of injuries, both confirmed yesterday that they have accepted wild cards into the State Farm Evert Cup, which begins Friday in Indian Wells, Calif. Capriati, who abruptly quit her sport after a first-round loss at the 1993 United States Open, launched her latest comeback last month in Essen, Germany, where she fell to an eventual finalist, JANA NOVOTNA, in the quarterfinals.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bailout of Shipyard In Denmark Collapses
description: The third bailout plan of Burmeister & Wain Holding collapsed yesterday after American creditors refused to accept the plan to save the Danish shipyard. Burmeister & Wain suspended payments with court permission in June 1995, and the three-month suspension has since been extended twice. It expires on March 27. A third extension was considered unlikely and analysts said the company could be heading toward liquidation.

title: TV NOTES;A New Job at NBC
description: Bridget Potter, who was "reorganized" out of a high-level job at HBO last summer, has landed very much on her feet. This week, NBC created a job for her, as senior vice president for entertainment, East Coast. She will be in charge of developing people and programs for the network and for the entertainment portions of the cable channel CNBC and NBC's Superchannel in Europe.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Packer Talks With Jackson
description: Billy Packer of CBS reiterated yesterday that racism had nothing to do with his referring to Georgetown's Allen Iverson as a "tough monkey" and said he had talked to the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who offered him guidance during a telephone conversation.

title: Over the Top in an Auction Catalogue
description: The cover is so self-consciously quiet it looks more like a wedding album than an auction-house catalogue. Yet the cool white cotton cover with discreet silver lettering that says only "The Estate of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis April 23-26, 1996," with Sotheby's name in small letters at the bottom, has captured the public's curiosity in a way no other auction catalogue ever has.

title: SLED-DOG RACING;Officials Force Swenson Out
description: The five-time Iditarod champion, Rick Swenson, was ejected from the trail sled-dog race because a dog on his team died in the first day of racing.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HILDY PARKS planted a garden in the rear of her midtown Manhattan apartment building and one at her home in Mougins, France. So, her husband, ALEXANDER H. COHEN, reasoned that another garden would be the perfect gift for her birthday next Tuesday. ("She's somewhere between Social Security and George Burns," he said.)

title: Peter B. Smith, 61, Banking Executive
description: Peter B. Smith, a senior executive at J. P. Morgan & Company, died on Saturday at the Sharon Hospital in Sharon, Conn. He was 61.

title: Prosecutor Cites Bomber's 'Fatal Flaws'
description: It was not a dangerous combination of drugs that drove Edward J. Leary to place firebombs in the New York City subway system, as his defense lawyers have suggested, a prosecutor said yesterday. It was, he said, a fatal flaw in Mr. Leary that led to the physical and psychic scars that will mar the victims of those acts for the rest of their lives.

title: The College That Churchill Made Famous Now Awaits Thatcher
description: It was 50 years ago today that Winston Churchill, at tiny Westminster College in Fulton, Mo., delivered the speech in which he coined the term Iron Curtain, defining the start of the cold war.

title: I.R.S. Offers Companies a Deal in Contract-Worker Disputes
description: The Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that it would offer discounts of up to 87.5 percent on the payroll taxes owed by employers who were found to have improperly paid employees as independent contractors.

title: Real Estate;With a plan to become a nine-story store, Warner Brothers will double its Manhattan retail space.
description: THE Warner Brothers Studio Store at 1 East 57th Street, a 15-floor building at Fifth Avenue, is growing from 30,000 square feet on three floors to 75,000 square feet on nine.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fenwick Inspires a Candidate
description: Michael Pappas, an insurance agent and Somerset County freeholder, chose the statue of Millicent Fenwick, the last resident of his county to serve in Congress, as the setting yesterday for announcing his candidacy for the seat being vacated by Richard A. Zimmer of Lawrenceville.

title: Journal;Mixed Media Message
description: As the nation's most powerful show-biz moguls posed for their V-chip photo op with President Clinton at the White House last Thursday, the opposite end of America's media food chain gathered at the Miyako Hotel in Japantown here. Some 650 representatives of the alternative print and electronic press, from Mother Jones to the Columbus (Ohio) Guardian to Dyke TV, had gathered for the first annual Media and Democracy Congress, and there wasn't a network suit in sight.

title: AT LUNCH WITH/John Updike;On Reading, Writing And Rabbit
description: HOW clever of Alfred A. Knopf to have put his publishing house not far from the spot where a gastronomic shrine would one day rise. Because of his foresight, John Updike, decades later, had to walk only a few steps to reach Lutece.

title: POLITICS: NEW YORK;At Last, New York Has Piece of Action In Republican Race
description: From Buffalo to midtown Manhattan, the three major Republican Presidential candidates raced their campaigns across New York yesterday, staging the kind of last-minute political displays that have historically intrigued voters here, from expressions of solidarity with Israel to a sharp round of internal party strife.

title: Business Advice From the Sidelines;It's Management By Game Theory
description: Can an N.B.A. coach offer an M.B.A. anything besides entertainment?

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Feeling, Flirtation and Voices
description: The International Hugo Wolf Academy, based in Stuttgart, Germany, and directed by the pianist Hartmut Holl, is devoted to the teaching and preservation of the vocal ensemble repertory. Mr. Holl -- along with Benita Valente, soprano; Katherine Ciesinski, mezzo-soprano; Markus Schafer, tenor, and Peter Lika, bass -- demonstrated that specialty in a program of Schumann's vocal and chamber works on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Sports of the Times;Garden Fans Yowl Like March Winds
description: NEVER realized how many Knicks fans went to St. John's until I heard the yowls in the Garden after last night's hideous 105-88 defeat by the Clippers. The boos reminded me of the outbursts against Brian Mahoney, although not quite as bitter, not quite as desperate.

title: Factory Orders Show Surprising Strength
description: Factory orders jumped unexpectedly in January and backlogs surged, the Commerce Department said today, offering evidence that manufacturing might be picking up after months of weakness.

title: BOMBING IN ISRAEL: THE WHITE HOUSE;U.S. Is Sending Technology To Help Intercept Bombers
description: President Clinton sent Israel sophisticated bomb-detection equipment today, a shipment that senior Administration officials said had been held up for several months in a dispute over who would pay for it.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: UConn Women Get a Crown and Men Hope They're Next;Wolters Is M.V.P. In Rout of the Irish
description: In its first year in the Big East, Notre Dame often proved to be an irresistible force.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Snapshots Fit for a Czar
description: Russia's Last Czar" leaves the impression that the ill-fated Nicholas II was a much better photographer than emperor. While his empire was going to ruin, he was snapping his wife, children and courtiers, who posed elegantly and disported playfully. The family's home photos enrich tonight's National Geographic special, which treats the fall of the Romanovs as a domestic tragedy.

title: Immigration History
description: To the Editor:

title: Mental Health System Is Ripe for Tragedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Teaching Man's Best Eyes to See
description: THE whispering is getting louder. "Mommy, I have to go to the bathroom!" a little boy repeats. Heads turn. His mother, mortified, grips his arm and points the only way out, down the middle aisle in front of everyone. "Don't touch the dogs," she warns.

title: BASEBALL;Bunning and Weaver Get Their Cooperstown Niches
description: Jim Bunning, a Republican Congressman from Kentucky who is one of the few members of his party not running for its Presidential nomination, won his own election today, and he wasn't even running in a primary.

title: House Panel Backs Alien Farm Workers
description: Bowing to big farming interests, the House Agriculture Committee approved an amendment to the House immigration bill yesterday that would grant temporary work visas to up to 250,000 foreign farm workers, even though many Republicans say the move would only encourage a flood of illegal immigrants.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MUTUAL OF OMAHA PLANS TO CUT MORE THAN 1,000 JOBS
description: The Mutual of Omaha Companies said yesterday that it would cut more than 1,000 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force, by the end of the year. The company said the job cuts were part of the shift from traditional health insurance to products that offer better opportunities for growth, such as life insurance, annuities and managed health care. About 800 jobs in Omaha and 250 outside Omaha are to be eliminated. The company cited an 8.5 percent decline in health-insurance revenue last year, saying that it had abandoned sales of major-medical and small-group insurance in eight states whose laws the company considered onerous. The states were California, Florida, Kentucky, Maine, New Jersey, New York, Vermont and Washington.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KMART PLANS TO SELL CZECH AND SLOVAK STORES
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the six Kmart stores in the Czech Republic and the seven in Slovakia to Tesco P.L.C. of Britain for about $117.5 million, to focus on its core operations in North America. . Kmart, the struggling discount retailer based in Troy, Mich., bought the 13 stores from the former Czechoslovak Government in 1992. The sale would cut Kmart's international outlets to 134 stores. Kmart, the nation's second-largest retailer, operates 2,168 Kmart stores and Super Kmart Centers, plus 167 Builders Square specialty outlets.

title: HOCKEY;Blues' Fans Give Gretzky a Wild Greeting
description: A record total of 20,725 fans jammed into the Kiel Center tonight, standing in unison, cheering at the top of their lungs, waving posters and generating enough electricity to rival the excitement of a Stanley Cup playoff game.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: World News Briefs;Security Council Urges Diplomacy in Burundi
description: With the call for a standby military force for Burundi muted by compromise, the Security Council unanimously passed a resolution today stressing diplomatic solutions to the violence between rival Tutsi and Hutu factions.

title: How Can U.S. Say Cuba Scorns Law?
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Paralysis in Albany
description: New York's State Legislature is in a bind. It cannot decide what to do about Gov. George Pataki's proposal to close a $4 billion budget deficit by relying on more than $2 billion in projected savings from Congressional actions that are not close to enactment and may never occur. Rather than face reality and find alternative ways to reduce the deficit, the legislators want to defer a decision by adopting a three-month temporary budget, with the hope that Washington will come to the rescue.

title: Minnie Pearl Is Dead at 83; Star of 'The Grand Ole Opry'
description: Minnie Pearl, the raucously funny radio, television and stage personality who was known as the queen of country comedy, died yesterday at a hospital in Nashville. She was 83.

title: Foreign Affairs;Who Are You?
description: The latest suicide bombings in Israel are so much more threatening than all those before because coming in rapid succession, at a time when Israelis least expected them, they have undermined the very logic of the peace process. Israelis see no positive connection anymore between the peace process and their daily lives. The peace process has never gone so far and yet the daily lives of Israelis have never been so terrifying. That's not how it was supposed to be, but creating that sort of absurd situation is exactly the goal of the terrorists.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN GREETINGS AGAIN BIDS FOR GIBSON
description: The American Greetings Corporation said today that it had made another offer to buy Gibson Greetings Inc., this time for $18 a share, or a total of $292.9 million. American Greetings, the nation's No. 2 maker of greeting cards, said Gibson, the No. 3 card maker, had declined to meet with it to discuss the offer. Hallmark Cards Inc. is No. 1. Gibson spurned an earlier offer last July, citing antitrust complications. The two companies together would have more than 50 percent of the United States market. In July, Gibson, which is based in Cincinnati, had said that it might put itself up for sale after it lost market share to American Greetings and Hallmark, posted its first annual loss since going public in 1982 and lost several key executives. The shares of Gibson closed yesterday at $14.50, down 12.5 cents. American Greetings stock rose 37.5 cents, to $28.25.

title: Companies to Get Amnesty if They Return Worker Savings
description: The Government will grant amnesty to employers who have dipped into their workers' 401(k) retirement savings, provided they put the money back before the end of summer, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich plans to announce this morning.

title: Saudi Dissident in Britain Wins Round in Fight Against Deportation
description: A leading Saudi dissident, regarded by the British Government as an irritant in its lucrative commercial and political relations with Riyadh, won a crucial round today in his battle to stave off deportation.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Prosecutors Tried to Protect Abused Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Not So Fast: Vegetables the Italian Way
description: FASTER and quicker are the reigning demands in contemporary American cooking. But when it comes to vegetable cookery, the results are sometimes warmed over. Crunchy green beans, almost-raw cauliflower and wooden carrots are now familiar in many homes and restaurants.

title: Frank Daniel, 69, Film Maker Who Fled Prague
description: Frank Daniel, the Czechoslovak-born film maker who inspired two generations of aspiring movie makers in Europe and the United States, where he headed five major film schools, died on Thursday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 69.

title: Psst! Hiding Spy Costs Goes Back to 1790
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Stocks Rise
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the bench mark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 57.31 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,241.18. On Tuesday, the Nikkei gained 119.99 points.

title: Braving a Growl for a Thick Cup of Soup
description: AL YEGANEH, the Soup Man of West 55th Street, makes a mean pot of soup, which may explain why customers are willing to run a gantlet to get it.

title: BOMBING IN ISRAEL: THE MOOD;Day's Routine Now a Test of Courage
description: Reeling from four devastating suicide bombings in little more than a week that dimmed their hopes for peace, Israelis tried to pull themselves together today, going about daily routines that have become tests of courage.

title: Empire Blue Cross Permitted To Form 2 For-Profit Units
description: The New York State Insurance Department yesterday approved a request by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to establish two wholly owned for-profit units that could eventually take over most of the troubled health insurer's business.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Tribute to Stokowski and His Many Tricks
description: Now that the early-music movement has won its battles and settled into sedate respectability, expect the inevitable counterrevolution. And when it comes, reserve the posts of patron saint and honorary generalissimo for Leopold Stokowski. While early-music people tell us that old music is best explained through old habits, Stokowski reinvented early music in his own image. He gave us the Baroque with a cinematic swagger, lighted up in Broadway lights. We loved it.

title: World News Briefs;Benin Presidential Vote Heads for a Runoff
description: With votes from Sunday's balloting roughly split between President Nicephore D. Soglo and the man he unseated in Benin's first democratic election five years ago, electoral officials said today that the two men would face a runoff later this month.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Teen-Age Son Held in Killing
description: The 16-year-old son of a woman shot eight times last week in the driveway of her estranged husband's home has been charged with her murder, the boy's father told The Associated Press yesterday. But the Acting Prosecutor for Somerset County, Melaine Campbell, refused to identify the juvenile.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about AT&T's plan to discontinue a venture that linked users of Lotus Notes software over telephone lines omitted the given name and affiliation of an executive who spoke about the appeal of such private networks. He was Mathew Wolf, founder and principal owner of Worldcom, a Notes-based network service.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for bean and tuna salad in The Living Section last Wednesday with an article about canned foods misstated the nutritional analysis. The analysis per serving is 385 calories, 20 grams fat, 9 milligrams cholesterol, 180 milligrams sodium (before salting), 25 grams protein and 30 grams carbohydrate.

title: BOMBING IN ISRAEL: THE OVERVIEW;Israeli Forces Seal Off Big Parts of West Bank
description: Israeli troops fanned out across the West Bank today, welding shut houses and barricading Palestinians in their towns and villages in retaliation for four attacks within nine days by suicide bombers.

title: TV NOTES;A Winner for a Change
description: What does it feel like to win a week for once? People at CBS found out yesterday, when Nielsen numbers showed that the network had finished first in the prime-time ratings race last week -- for the first time this season.

title: TV NOTES;Isn't That Special?
description: Like David Letterman, who had to leave Larry (Bud) Melman behind, Dana Carvey has been blocked from taking some comic characters he created while at NBC. Mr. Carvey, a "Saturday Night Live" alumnus, has been told that his Church Lady and other characters are NBC's intellectual property, and he can't use them on his new comedy show, which will make its debut on ABC next Tuesday at 9:30 P.M. L. M.

title: Business Travel;If you're headed to New York later in the year, there is hope for getting a hotel room.
description: NEW YORK hotels were so filled late last year that many business travelers were forced to stay in the suburbs and exurbs. At a hotel industry reception last November, the president of one large chain told of nine business travelers from the Washington-Baltimore area who flew to New York that morning for a company meeting and had to fly back home that night because they could not get hotel rooms -- then had to turn around and do it again the next day.

title: Food Notes;How Many Authors Does It Take to Write A Book on Chocolate?
description: THE Book of Chocolate," a completely fat-free indulgence but one that threatens to induce serious cravings, has been published by Flammarion ($50).

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew of New York City to reorganize the system's central headquarters misstated the saving estimated under the plan. It is $271,500, not $271.5 million.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: UConn Women Get a Crown and Men Hope They're Next;A Jumbo Agenda at Garden As 10 Play While 3 Wait
description: It's a bigger Big East. But is it better?

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB INCREASES BUYBACK PLAN
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it had increased its share repurchase program 50 percent, to 75 million shares from 50 million, to help raise shareholder value. In April 1993, the buyback program was raised to 50 million shares from 25 million and Bristol-Myers, the maker of Bufferin pain reliever and Clairol hair-care products, bought 46.3 million shares under that plan. The company had an average of 505 million shares outstanding in the fourth quarter. Bristol-Myers made the announcement after trading yesterday. Its shares rose 62.5 cents, to $87.75, on the Big Board.

title: U.S. Bans a Drug Used Abroad for Insomnia
description: The Government banned the importation of the sedative Rohypnol today, saying the pill is a growing threat to teen-agers and young adults and has no legitimate therapeutic use.

title: Medicine Can Do Without Religion or State
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Trade Surplus Shrinks in Japan
