description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus for the first 20 days of February shrank 80.9 percent from the comparable period in 1995, to $1.232 billion, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SALEM CORP., Pittsburgh, the industrial equipment maker that put itself up for sale last March, said it did not receive a firm bid for the company.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Dispute Over U.S. Exports Of Poultry to Russia Settled
description: A trade dispute between the United States and Russia was apparently settled today when Washington received formal assurances that American poultry shipments to Russia would continue without interruption.

title: Chiron Eye Implant Is Approved For Treating an AIDS Infection
description: The Chiron Corporation said today that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing a device that can be implanted in the eyes of AIDS patients to help them fight blindness.

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;Buchanan Won't Pledge To Back Dole
description: Patrick J. Buchanan today raised the possibility for the first time publicly that he would not endorse Senator Bob Dole for President if Mr. Dole wins the Republican nomination.

title: Parts Maker Is Charged With Export Fraud
description: A small New Jersey company that manufactures electronic parts for the military and two of its top executives were charged by the Government today with illegally sending plans for $2 million of equipment for weapons and communications systems to companies in Russia and Ukraine.

title: Denver Airport Nestles Into Its Lair
description: Depriving cartoonists and television talk show hosts of a staple food, Denver International Airport has emerged in its first year as the nation's most efficient cold-weather airport.

title: Food Notes
description: Natural-Food Supermarkets

title: Our Towns;After the Ebb, Walton Dries Itself Off
description: WHEN the waters that nearly drowned Delaware Street receded, and the politicians tsk-tsking the wreckage from helicopters vanished into the clouds, people like Milton Northrup were left to ponder a fundamental question: pack it in or start over?

title: Slain Delicatessen Owner Is Mourned at Synagogue
description: On a holiday intended to celebrate the joyous deliverance of the Jews, hundreds of people gathered at a synagogue on East Sixth Street to mourn for Abe Lebewohl, the delicatessen owner whose slaying stunned customers and neighbors on the Lower East Side.

title: Late Surge Sends Dow to 17th High of Year
description: Stocks surged in the last half-hour of trading yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to a new record for the 17th time this year.

title: Michelin Lops Off A Star
description: For 63 years, the red Michelin guide has conferred three stars on what it considers the finest restaurants in France, meaning cuisine so exceptional that it is worth a special trip. For all but one of those years, the Tour d'Argent has been on the special list.

title: Market Place;Wall St. Nudges Grace to Speak With Hercules
description: When it comes to unsolicited takeover offers, chief executives have learned to expect the unexpected. But an offer for W. R. Grace & Company has set a new standard, and Wall Street loves it.

title: Program Helps Arts In Schools
description: Yasser Nacel, a 10-year-old fifth grader at Public School 165 in Manhattan, was giving his assessment of Mexican art yesterday.

title: Hero' Sues Over Losing a Housing Job Offer
description: When Rafael Sencion, a 39-year-old bachelor, voluntarily left his job last May so that a co-worker with a family of four could keep his job, his act drew widespread praise in a city often maligned for being uncaring.

title: House Creates Panel To Study Gambling
description: The House of Representatives voted today to establish a national commission to study the pros and cons of gambling.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swedish Rates Cut Again
description: Sweden's central bank delivered a widely expected interest-rate cut yesterday, its fifth such move this year. The bank said it would trim the repurchase rate, the bank's main instrument for steering money market and short-term interest rates, to 7.85 percent from 8.05 percent. Most economists see cuts continuing throughout the spring and summer. (Reuters)

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;De Beers Profit Rises
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines, the diamond company, reported yesterday that it had higher earnings last year, largely as a result of better sales of gemstones on world markets. The company said net attributable earnings rose to $624 million last year from $560 million in 1994, excluding the retained earnings of associates. (Reuters)

title: A Founder Sells Microsoft Stock
description: A co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, Paul Allen, has sold 700,000 Microsoft shares worth about $70 million in the last two weeks.

title: Court Panel Throws Out Judge's Restraint on Business Week
description: In a closely followed First Amendment case, a Federal appeals court panel in Cincinnati threw out yesterday a lower court's ruling blocking Business Week magazine from publishing sealed court documents from a lawsuit brought by Procter & Gamble against the Bankers Trust Company.

title: BOXING;Route to a Tyson Bout Goes Through Garden
description: Don King made a promise yesterday: When Mike Tyson regains the unified heavyweight crown, "the champion of the world takes on all comers." That's good news for three former champions, who will formally announce tomorrow a tripleheader at Madison Square Garden on May 10 that could elevate any or all of them to the head of the line waiting to get into the ring with Tyson.

title: Susan K. Kamen, Military Engineer, 59
description: Susan K. Kamen, an engineer for the military and, in a second career, a vice president at the New York Life Insurance Company, died last Thursday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Mrs. Kamen, who also maintained a home in Wainscott, L.I., was 59.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in "This Week" in the Long Island Weekly on Sunday misstated the date of a concert at the "Salon des Arts" exhibition in Southold. It will be at 1 P.M. on Saturday at the Church of the Open Door; it was not last Sunday.

title: Lie-Detector Tests Are Banned on Victims Alleging Rape
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today that prohibits law enforcement officials from subjecting people who file rape complaints to polygraph tests.

title: New York Restaurants to Branch Out
description: A NUMBER of restaurants spawned in New York are going national. One of the first to announce multi-city expansion plans was Alan Stillman's New York Restaurant Group, which includes Smith & Wollensky and Manhattan Ocean Club.

title: POLITICS: RACES FOR CONGRESS;Utah Lawmaker Awash in Personal Troubles Abandons Run
description: Representative Enid Greene Waldholtz of Utah, once hailed as a rising young freshman Republican but more recently the object of withering criticism for the handling of her financial and family affairs, announced yesterday that she would not seek re-election this fall.

title: Gene Factor Tied to Severity of Lupus
description: ONE of the many puzzling aspects of the autoimmune disease lupus is the wide variation in severity among patients, particularly across racial lines: blacks, who are three times as likely as whites to develop lupus, are also more prone to suffer serious complications, especially kidney disease.

title: TRANSACTIONSAuto Racing TREADWAY RACING - Named Buddy Lindblom team manager. Baseball American League CHICAGO WHITE SOX - Signed Bobby Thigpen, pitcher, to a minor league contract. CLEVELAND INDIANS - Signed Herbert Perry, infielder, Jeromy Burnitz, outfielder, and Paul Shuey, pitcher. National League CINCINNATI REDS - Reassigned John Roper, Domingo Jean, and Brett Tomko, pitchers; Aaron Boone, Stephen Larkin, and Ruben Santana, infielders; and Keith  Mitchell, Pat Watkins, and Cleveland Ladell, outfielders, to their minor-league  camp. Northeast League NORTHEAST LEAGUE - Awarded a franchise to West Warwick, R.I. ALBANY-COLONIE DIAMOND DOGS - Signed Felix de Leon, infielder. Basketball LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS - Activated Malik Sealy, guard, from the injured list. Placed Keith Tower, center, on the injured list. Football National Football League INDIANAPOLIS COLTS - Named Chuck Bresnahan linebackers coach. SAN DIEGO CHARGERS - Signed Al Pupunu, tight end, to a three-year contract. Canadian Football League CALGARY STAMPEDERS - Named Roy Shivers assistant general manager. Signed Collin  Newman, safety, and Mark Clarke, wide receiver. Arena Football League ALBANY FIREBIRDS - Waived Shannon Cornelius, lineman. Signed Mario Perry, fullback-linebacker. CHARLOTTE RAGE - Signed Keith Ballard, lineman. CONNECTICUT COYOTES - Signed John Sacca, quarterback; Bruce Bourgoin, fullback-linebacker; Jim Ward, lineman; and Lee Harris, wide receiver-defensive  back. Waived Brian Boerboom, lineman. MEMPHIS PHARAOHS - Signed Artis Ford, lineman. MINNESOTA FIGHTING PIKE - Signed Harry Jackson, fullback-linebacker; Sheldon Haliburton, lineman; Zed Robinson, wide receiver-defensive back. SAN JOSE SABERCATS - Signed Leonard Nelson, fullback-linebacker. Waived Gary Williams, lineman. TAMPA BAY STORM - Signed Lamar Rogers, lineman. TEXAS TERROR - Signed Kevin Adams, fullback-lnebacker. Hockey National Hockey League TORONTO MAPLE LEAFS - Fired Pat Burns, coach. Named Nick Beverley interim coach.
Dalai Lama Finds China's Threats A Subject for Humor and Anxiety
description: Among the pilgrims who flock to the Dalai Lama's home-in-exile in these Himalayan hills, many regard him as a living god -- some of them Buddhist monks like the Dalai Lama himself, others refugees from faiths and places far removed from his native Tibet.

title: In Prague, Modern Art Meets Modern Problems
description: In 1978, eager to upstage the capitalist West, Czechoslovakia's Communist regime decided to found a museum of modern art in Prague that would be larger and more ambitious than the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris. The museum had a site in the cavernous Veletrzni Palace, which was built as a trade exhibition space in 1929 and was badly damaged by a fire in 1974. It also had the money: it could print it.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Dallas Was Rocking; The Nets Are Reeling
description: It was Jason Kidd poster night at Reunion Arena tonight. Dallas should have given out umbrellas, too, the way Kidd and the Mavericks rained 3-pointers on the Nets.

title: General Denounces AIDS Policy as Unfair
description: Discharging members of the military who have the AIDS virus is unfair and wastes money that has been spent on training, Gen. John Shalikashvili told lawmakers today.

title: How Can U.S. Say Cuba Scorns Law?;Don't Overreact
description: To the Editor:

title: SOCCER;Here Come the MetroStars
description: The MetroStars staged their first practice this morning inside the bubble outside Giants Stadium in preparation for the first season of Major League Soccer.

title: Robber of Priest Blesses Himself
description: A Roman Catholic priest who came to the Bronx from Michigan to say a funeral Mass for his uncle was robbed on Monday night by two thieves, one of whom blessed himself when he realized he was robbing a priest, the police said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Rams Sign Jones
description: The St. Louis Rams, who allowed the second-most points in the league last year (422), moved to bolster their defense yesterday by signing the former Cowboy middle linebacker ROBERT JONES to a five-year contract worth about $10 million, including a bonus of $3 million. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;RIVAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE BIONAIRE FOR $24 MILLION
description: The Rival Company, based in Kansas City, Mo., has agreed to acquire Bionaire Inc., a Canadian maker of air purifiers and humidifiers, for $24 million. Rival, a maker of small household and personal-care appliances, said it would pay about $1.65 a share for Montreal-based Bionaire, to increase its focus on home environmental products. Rival said it hopes to close the deal early next month.

title: A One-Sided Peace
description: The devastating terrorist attacks in Tel Aviv, Jerusalem and Ashkelon, which have killed 61 people over nine days, underscore the serious shortcomings of the Oslo peace accords, signed by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization in 1993.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Rises 42.27 Points To Year's 17th Record A renewed optimism in the stock market propelled the Dow Jones industrial average to its 17th record of the year. Surging in the last half-hour of trading, the Dow jumped 42.27 points, to 5,642.42, bringing its three-day gain to 156.80 points, or 2.8 percent.

title: THEATER REVIEW;So What's With Your Syntax, Portia?
description: Overtime," A. R. Gurney's modern sequel to "The Merchant of Venice," co-opts the comedy in the last scene as Shakespeare tidies up loose ends relating to Shylock's trial and the various masquerades involved. Portia, a blond, bossy, post-deb type, is at the center of the festive group that has gathered in her garden at Belmont, which suggests a Connecticut estate left over from the 1920's and now going to seed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ex-Ayer Executive Opens New Shop
description: Janet Kraus, a former managing partner and executive creative director at N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York, has opened a creatively focused agency in New York named Door #2.

title: Serb Lawyer Vows Not to Cooperate With War Crimes Tribunal
description: More than 20 criminal lawyers have been assembled to defend Bosnian Serb officers at the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague, and their chief task will be to insure that the defendants do not cooperate, the chief lawyer said Monday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Tense Pursuit on I-78
description: A trucker from Jersey City, occasionally holding a revolver to his head, rammed a police cruiser while being pursued on Interstate 78 early yesterday, and came to a stop only after he crashed into a concrete divider in Strauss town, Pa., the authorities said.

title: TV NOTES;Program Notes
description: Michelle Pfeiffer is the first guest-human on "Muppets Tonight!," Friday night at 8:30 on ABC. . . . Returning from hiatus: "The Bonnie Hunt Show," on CBS, Sundays at 8:30 P.M.; "Brotherly Love," on NBC, Mondays at 8:30 P.M., and "Sliders," on Fox, Fridays at 8 P.M.

title: U.S. Slap on the Hand Brings Colombia Out Punching
description: Fanning nationalist discontent over President Clinton's formal declaration that Colombia was not cooperating in the fight against drugs, this country's embattled President has moved to cool relations with the United States further, apparently as a means of relieving pressure on him to resign.

title: A Hometown Feels Less Like Home
description: To Wall Street and the world, it was the National Cash Register Company. Then, it was modernized, computerized, streamlined down to NCR. But in Dayton, the company was always just "the Cash."

title: Doc T. Nevaquaya, Comanche Artist, 63
description: Doc Tate Nevaquaya, a Comanche artist and flutist who was named an Oklahoma Treasure last fall, died on Tuesday in Comanche County Memorial Hospital in Lawton. He was 63.

title: Kevorkian Says He Aims to Ease Suffering, Not to Hasten Death
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian denied throughout two days of cross-examination ending today that he ever intended to help anybody die, even though he knew that breathing carbon monoxide would kill Dr. Ali Khalili and Merian Frederick, the two people he has been charged with illegally helping commit suicide in 1993.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief music review yesterday about a performance by the Concordia Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night referred incorrectly to the conductor. Marin Alsop is a woman.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Calhoun and Allen Honored
description: Connecticut, which won the Big East Conference regular season and is seeded No. 1 in the post-season tournament that begins today at Madison Square Garden, received two individual honors last night.

title: Kidd Has an Olympic Dream
description: With the Mavericks pretty much out of the playoff race, the discussion here has centered on whether Jason Kidd would be selected to play for Dream Team III at the Atlanta Olympics.

title: About New York;One Man's Version of Community Control: Take Over a School
description: MIGUEL GARCIA, a veteran of Bronx school board wars, had a novel idea for community control.

title: Fearing a Toehold for Gay Marriages, Conservatives Rush to Bar theDoor
description: Fearful that a court case will lead to the sanctioning of marriages of lesbian and gay couples in Hawaii by the end of 1997, conservatives are campaigning across the nation to insure that the recognition of same-sex marriages will not spread to other states.

title: Corrections
description: The dateline yesterday on an article about new safety rules in the wake of a train crash on New Jersey Transit referred incorrectly to Suffern, a stop on the railroad's Main Line. It is in New York, not New Jersey.

title: The Gooey Sells as Well as the Glittery at Cable TV's Mall
description: BOB and Lisa are going crazy over a pair of apples gooey, jumbo-size apples thickly coated with caramel and pecans.

title: BASEBALL;Brogna Is Injured Again, Might Miss More Drills
description: It just hasn't been a fun spring for Rico Brogna. The Mets' first baseman, sidelined for nearly a week with a sore back, twisted his right knee while running out a grounder in a split-squad game against the Florida Marlins here today and is likely to miss more training time.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jets Cut Prior
description: The Jets cut another player yesterday in retooling their salary cap and personnel. This time ANTHONY PRIOR, a top special-teams player and defensive back, was waived. He is the fifth key performer from last season's squad to leave, and the seventh over all. By waiving Prior, a ninth-round draft pick by the Giants in 1992, the Jets will be about $1.2 million under the salary cap.

title: BASEBALL;White Sox Won't Concede to Indians
description: In the immortal words of Ozzie Guillen, "You never know."

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;DOLE, SWEEPING 8 PRIMARIES, CALLS FOR PARTY TO UNITE; ALEXANDER READY TO QUIT
description: Senator Bob Dole won a clean sweep of eight primaries spanning New England, the Rockies and as far South as Georgia yesterday, leaping far ahead of his rivals in the biggest test thus far of the Republican Presidential primary season.

title: Gotti Plotted Huge Bribe, Witness Says
description: The courtroom saga over the sanity of the suspected mob boss Vincent Gigante took another bizarre turn yesterday: This time, the focus was on John Gotti, who was called so desperate to get out of prison that he considered bribing the President of the United States.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kodak Realigns Agency Roster
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had realigned its agency roster by consolidating its worldwide consumer advertising account at two sibling WPP Group agencies in New York, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and the J. Walter Thompson Company, and ending a 15-year relationship with Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York. Kodak spends an estimated $250 million to $300 million annually on advertising.

title: Move in Senate Aims at Cutting Corporate Aid
description: Acknowledging that Congress does not have the political will to do the job itself, a bipartisan group of senators pushed today for the formation of an independent commission to help drastically cut the subsidies and tax breaks for business that they called "corporate welfare."

title: Eating We
description: EVEN "foodies" who think prepared foods are unspeakable draw the line at mayonnaise. While they prefer to have it homemade, in a pinch they will reluctantly use Hellman's, which for most other Americans is the gold standard.

title: Panel Votes for Worker Visas for 250,000
description: Bowing to big farming interests in California, Florida and Texas, the House Agriculture Committee today approved an amendment to the House immigration bill that would grant temporary work visas to as many as 250,000 foreign farm workers, even though many senior Republicans say this will only encourage a new flood of illegal aliens.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three years ago, DANA CAPPIELLO, a maternity-wear manufacturer from San Francisco, lost her dearest friend, Anthony Torrieri, to AIDS. In the process, she said, she learned "that people had no compassion."

title: COMPANY NEWS;PREMIERE TECHNOLOGIES SELLS 6.5 MILLION SHARES
description: The stock of Premiere Technologies Inc. rose well above its offering price in its first day of trading on the Nasdaq stock market. Atlanta-based Premiere makes software that lets people use most telephones to also gain access to computers, fax machines and the Internet. The company sold 6.5 million shares to raise $117 million. Premiere's stock closed at $26.25, in trading of more than 6.5 million shares. The offering was priced at $16, or $4 higher than the low end of its original $12 to $14 price range, an indication of strong investor demand for the shares. The company plans to use proceeds from the offering to pay debts and to expand its software network.

title: Mr. Gingrich's Legal Victory
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich has maintained that his political action committee, Gopac, did not violate Federal election laws when it failed to register with the Federal Election Commission in 1989 and 1990 -- the early stages of Gopac's effort to engineer a Republican takeover of Congress. Last week a Federal judge agreed, tossing out the F.E.C.'s complaint and handing Mr. Gingrich an important legal victory.

title: Senate Approves Compromise Bill Tightening Curbs on Cuba
description: The Senate moved today to punish the Cuban Government for its downing of two American private aircraft last month, passing legislation that would tighten the embargo on American trade with Cuba and punish other countries that insisted on continuing trade on their own.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Spending on Students Varies
description: To the surprise of no one, figures released yesterday by the State Department of Education showed that spending on public schools varies widely throughout New Jersey, with some districts doling out more than twice as much for each student as other districts. The average is $7,451 per student, the A.P. said.

title: Foie Gras By Day, Hot Dogs By Night (Shh!)
description: AT first, Michel Richard did not want to come clean about his secret passions. "You'll write it in the newspaper and everyone will know," said the chef at the highly acclaimed Citrus in Los Angeles with assorted outposts around the country.

title: California Governor Sues U.S. For Cost of Imprisoning Aliens
description: Stepping up his battle with the Clinton Administration over the politically charged issue of illegal immigration, Gov. Pete Wilson of California today sued the Federal Government for failing to reimburse his state for the costs of incarcerating undocumented aliens who have been convicted of felonies.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Penn Forces One-Game Playoff
description: On the night that Princeton could have clinched its 11th, and possibly last, Ivy League championship under Coach Pete Carril, the Pennsylvania Quakers turned a hot, passionate evening in the Palestra into the penultimate game of the Ivy season.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Vermont

title: TV NOTES;Roseanne's Coming Back
description: ABC formally announced yesterday that it had a deal with Carsey-Werner Productions for a ninth year of "Roseanne," the biggest prime-time hit of the early 1990's.

title: The Street Cop In Pin Stripes
description: Lou Matarazzo takes off his gun, a snubnose .38 he is packing under his pin-stripe suit, and slips it into the drawer of his burnished horseshoe desk.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Digging Up Fort Dix
description: A multimillion-dollar, 10-year archeological survey of Fort Dix will begin next month, as researchers attempt to learn more about the rich history of the sprawling site, which became a military post in 1917. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Barnard Workers to Suspend Strike During Spring Break
description: Union officials said yesterday that 150 clerical workers at Barnard College would return to work today after voting Monday night to suspend their strike.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Beethoven as Idealist, Militarist, Rebel, Whatever
description: BEETHOVEN IN GERMAN POLITICS, 1870-1989 By David B. Dennis 251 pages. Yale University Press. Illustrated. $30.

title: That Vote in Benin
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Spielman Visits Giants
description: The Detroit Lions' unrestricted free agent linebacker, CHRIS SPIELMAN, visited the Giants' complex yesterday and though it appears the team will not make a formal offer soon, the Giants are interested.

title: Crackdown Is Intensified In Quality-of-Life Crimes
description: Intensifying Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's crackdown on so-called quality-of-life crimes, the Police Department has quietly begun increasing the number of arrests it makes for marijuana smoking, fare-beating and other misdemeanors, senior police officials said yesterday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Gambling Study Is Approved
description: The United States House of Representatives approved a bill yesterday to create a Federal commission to study gambling, the first step in what some Atlantic City casino executives see as a crusade to impose stricter regulations and higher taxes on casinos.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHAT do Gerard Jaboulet, John Munch, Rocky O'Callaghan and Sydney Back have in common? Syrah.

title: POLITICS: THE POLITICIANS;Dole Savors the Comfort of a Political Machine
description: After the early rebuffs and scares of open-season, non-machine primary politics, Senator Bob Dole beamed tonight as a police escort rushed him to the bosom of one of the most formidable political machines in the nation, the Nassau County Republican organization.

title: Automobile Workers Strike, Shutting 2 G.M. Parts Plants
description: Almost 3,200 members of the United Automobile Workers went on strike today, shutting down two General Motors factories that make brake parts in Dayton, Ohio. The work stoppage threatened to force the closing of other factories that need the parts.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;Evans is Critical Of Foschi Decision
description: The world record-holder JANET EVANS criticized United States Swimming yesterday for repealing the doping suspension of JESSICA FOSCHI. One day before Evans beginning her quest to qualify for her third Olympics at the United States Olympic swimming trials in Indianapolis, the triple world record-holder and four-time Olympic gold medalist lashed out at the sport's governing body, which reversed a decision to ban Foschi for two years.

title: Medicine Can Do Without Religion or State;Sound New York Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: CONNECTICUT;Dole Gains Easy Victory, But Doubts Are Cast, Too
description: In a state known for its moderate brand of Republicanism, Senator Bob Dole won the Presidential primary in Connecticut yesterday by an impressive margin.

title: House G.O.P. Chiefs Back Off On Stiff Antiregulatory Plan
description: House Republican leaders abruptly postponed debate today on a bill to roll back Government regulations, and asked the party's moderates and conservatives to work together on a less sweeping version of the legislation.

title: Personal Health
description: MARIE NATALE'S gynecological problems began 16 years ago. When she was 29, shortly after her son was born, she developed pelvic pain and excessive bleeding caused by advanced endometriosis, extensive growth of uterine tissue outside of the uterus that pressed on other organs and bled monthly into the pelvic cavity. She had surgery to remove the errant tissue and relieve the distress, but two years later, the pain returned.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;N.B.A. Fines Barkley
description: CHARLES BARKLEY was fined $7,500 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for criticizing the officiating after Phoenix's 121-114 victory over Dallas on Sunday. Barkley, who had 26 points in 27 minutes in the game, called the officiating terrible, and added: "DAVID WOOD can't guard me if the officials do their job, but they wanted the game to be close for NBC. The officials took all my aggression away." (AP)

title: GOLF;For Norman, A Return To Eerie Site
description: Like the mansion on a hill in a Stephen King novel, the colonial clubhouse at Eagle Trace is a chilling backdrop for a golf nightmare. It sits up high on the edge of the Everglades, circled by osprey and the occasional, ominous vultures, a silent reminder of the horror stories that have taken place on the greensward that stretches out below.

title: F. Lee Bailey Is Sent to Jail On a Charge Of Contempt
description: F. Lee Bailey, a star in the courtroom as a criminal defense lawyer, went to jail today after failing to comply with a judge's order that he turn over millions of dollars in assets that a former client, a drug trafficker, had agreed to forfeit to the Government.

title: POLITICS;State Senator to Retire
description: A Republican State Senator who has been in New York's Legislature since 1965 announced today that he would not seek re-election this fall.

title: Primary Damages
description: Bob Dole's sweep of eight primaries on Tuesday has knocked his mainstream competitors off the boards and brought endorsements from both of them, Lamar Alexander and Richard Lugar. If New York Republicans follow the script written by Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Mr. Dole can claim the largest delegate prize of the season with a victory there today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AS THREE-FIVE PREDICTS LOWER SALES, ITS SHARES FALL
description: The shares of Three-Five Systems Inc. plunged yesterday after the company, a maker of liquid crystal displays used in cellular phones, predicted lower sales and earnings because a major customer had cut its order. Three-Five Systems shares fell $5.875, to $12.75, a 52-week low on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, which is based in Phoenix, said it would report "unfavorable revenue and earnings comparisons" for the next several quarters because a major customer was winding down orders faster than expected. Three-Five declined to identify the customer. Motorola Inc. accounted for more than 80 percent of the company's revenue in 1994.

title: BASEBALL;An Infielder Comes in From the Cold
description: For the first few weeks of spring camp, Edgardo Alfonzo appeared to be the odd man out in an infield crowded with one too many starters.

title: Home Faxes Come In Two Flavors With Toppings
description: WHEN letters came only in envelopes, you couldn't choose what sort of mail carrier -- friendly or surly, vigilant or careless -- brought them to the door. Now that documents can travel by telephone to your living room, you can choose your carrier: thermal or plain, standard or fancy, with auto-dial, delay and broadcast.

title: Pop in Review
description: Teary Eyes One Minute, A Sly Wink the Next Dixie Carter Cafe Carlyle

title: COMPANY NEWS;PULLMAN SELLS ONE UNIT AND CONSIDERS SELLING OTHERS
description: A unit of Mark IV Industries has bought the Pullman Company's Imperial Eastman fluid-carrying-products division for about $75 million in cash plus certain liabilities, Pullman said yesterday. Pullman also said it was in talks with potential buyers for its remaining businesses: Clevite Elastomers, which manufactures vibration control components, and Conforma Clad, which makes specialty custom-engineered components. Pullman, a maker of automotive components and specialty industrial products that is based in Lebanon, N.J., said it would use the proceeds from the sale of Imperial Eastman to pay off debt. Mark IV, based in Amherst, N.Y., manufactures transportation, engineered and technical products.

title: Economic Scene;Freeing air routes to Japan will help travelers but won't be easy.
description: AFTER an exchange of hard words last week, Tokyo and Washington apparently inched closer toward agreement on an expansion of air cargo flights across the Pacific. But that is just the overture to the main act: opening tightly restricted passenger service. American, Delta, Continental and Trans World Airlines, along with tourism businesses, have organized a group called Access U.S.-Japan to lobby their cause when President Clinton meets Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto in Tokyo next month.

title: Plan Seeks to Bar Winners of 4 School Board Elections
description: State legislative leaders began discussing a proposal yesterday to allow the New York City Schools Chancellor to temporarily block the winners of school board elections in May from taking their seats on four boards that are now under suspension.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League TEXAS RANGERS -- Reassigned Jeff Davis, Kerry Lacy, Terry Burrows, Jonathan Johnson and Joey Vierra, pitchers, to their minor-league camp.

title: Lead Paint: New Rules Announced
description: Sixty-four million houses and apartments contain lead-based paint, the Department of Housing and Urban Development estimates, and that includes the great majority of those built before 1978. Researchers say many of the people who live in them have no idea of the hazards of sanding or stripping the paint, or even opening and closing doors and windows with surfaces that rub.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Harness Race Investigated
description: A Freehold Raceway harness driver has been accused of rigging a race last summer by holding his horse back, letting two others finish first and second.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;$30 Million Fraud Admitted
description: The former owner of two investment companies pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to defrauding clients of $30 million from 1991 to 1995 and agreed to cooperate with Federal authorities.

title: Lobbyists Did Not Write Proposal on F.D.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Mexican Official, Held in U.S., Gains Partial Freedom
description: Under heavy guard and intense secrecy, a former Mexican Deputy Attorney General who spent a year in American jails was whisked out of a New Jersey jail to partial freedom today while the Governments of Mexico and the United States struggled to find a way to send him back to Mexico to stand trial.

title: George S. Franklin Jr., 82, Foreign Policy Expert
description: George S. Franklin Jr., who studied American foreign policy for many years and urged better relations with the Soviet Union and China long before such talk was fashionable, died on Tuesday in Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 82.

title: Tutor Is Dismissed After Video Shows Abuse of Youths
description: For nearly 20 years, Larry Bottone worked with teen-agers here as a coach, teacher and finally president of his own after-school tutoring program for minority students. Now he has been dismissed after the program's board was shown a videotape in which, board members say, he recorded himself whipping and torturing three black teen-age boys.

title: 8 Tied to Chicago Drug Gang Are Convicted
description: Eight people tied to a Chicago street gang were convicted today of Federal drug conspiracy charges.

title: Marie-Helene de Rothschild, 65, Worldly Hostess Extraordinaire
description: Marie-Helene de Rothschild, one of Europe's most imaginative hostesses, whose activities were a major part of the Paris social season for many years, died on Friday at her home in Ferrieres, 20 miles northeast of Paris. She was 65 and had suffered for three decades from an incurable degenerative arthritic ailment.

title: China Cited for Abuses
description: The Clinton Administration issued its annual human rights report, finding China guilty of "widespread and well-documented" abuses. Page A10.

title: INSIDE
description: New Battle in Chechnya

title: POLITICS;In His Own Words
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN

title: Plea in a Racial Killing
description: Moments before his murder trial began on Monday, a white man switched his plea and pleaded guilty to fatally shooting a black man in a racially motivated attack outside a restaurant.

title: The Internet Goes to School;Bellwether or Bust? Educators Debate Value of Surfing
description: Before her third-grade class waded into the Internet, Mary Anne Denner, a teacher at the Maugham Elementary School here, selected the White House home page as an engaging first exhibit where they might be able to extract information for future reports.

title: Maputo Elephant Reserve Journal;Thinking Big ($800 Million) to Rescue Big Game
description: In this remote and beautiful corner of the world, representatives of a conservative Louisiana millionaire used to hand American cash to a rebel movement so cruel that it kidnapped children for its assassination squads.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. QUITS TORT REFORM PLAN
description: After months of resistance, House Republicans have dropped their plans for a sweeping overhaul of the nation's civil litigation system in favor of a narrower effort by Senate Republicans that would only limit lawsuits involving faulty products.

title: President of Campus Crusade Gets $1 Million Religion Prize
description: Bill Bright, founder and president of the international ministry Campus Crusade for Christ, was named the recipient of a $1 million religion prize yesterday, an annual award whose value is designed to be larger than the Nobel Prize's.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What's in a name? JULIUS RUDEL, the former general director and principal conductor of the New York City Opera, had an answer for that question yesterday at City Hall when Mayor RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI declared it to be Julius Rudel Day.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions And Talks
description: Line, Color and Form American Institute of Graphic Arts, 164 Fifth Avenue (22d Street); (212) 807-1990.

title: Rebels Burst Into Chechen Capital, Retaking Part of City
description: In a searing new humiliation for President Boris N. Yeltsin, hundreds of rebels rode into the capital of secessionist Chechnya on a captured freight train today and mounted the biggest battle the war-ravaged city has seen in more than a year.

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks Stop Being Pushovers, For a Night
description: As with most of his teammates, Derek Harper was fed up. Someone from the opposing franchise was baiting John Starks during a timeout late in the third quarter, and the Knicks' captain could take it no more. The losing. The bickering. The frustration. And now the taunting. It all came to a boil.

title: Police Say Armed Man Robbed 11 Gay Bars
description: The Police Department believes that one man is responsible for armed holdups of at least 10 gay bars in Manhattan and one in Queens since July, officials said yesterday.

title: Essay;If Not Arafat . . .
description: The idea behind the Peres approach to peace with the Palestinians was to subcontract the dirty business of suppressing Arab terrorism to Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted on Tuesday for a picture of the conductor Seiji Ozawa with an article about the acoustics of Carnegie Hall. The photographer was Steve J. Sherman.

title: Pop in Review
description: A Sold-Out Hip-Hop Merger Of Caribbean and American The Fugees Tramps

title: No Verdict Yet In Firebomb Trial
description: Jurors began deliberating yesterday in the case of Edward J. Leary, who is accused of setting off two firebombs in the subway, but the jurors retired for the night without reaching a verdict.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Counties Seek Disaster Aid
description: Officials of three counties ravaged by floods in January plan to meet next week with representatives of the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the hope of obtaining assistance in making repairs, the public safety director for Warren County said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CYRIX ENTERS DEAL TO EXPAND USE OF ITS CHIPS
description: The Cyrix Corporation, a designer of microprocessors, said yesterday that it would assemble personal computers in a joint venture with the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation. The arrangement will initially allow Cyrix to sell PC's containing its chips directly to customers of E.D.S., generally businesses that buy computers in large quantities. Cyrix executives said they hoped to capture enough attention to cause big PC makers to use more of their chips. Drew Peck, an analyst with Cowen & Company in Boston, said the strategy was similar to what Micron Technology Inc. has done to develop a market for its memory chips. Still, Cyrix's shares fell yesterday in a broad sell-off of semiconductor issues after Texas Instruments Inc. lowered industry growth forecasts. Cyrix fell $1.9375, to $21.3125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;Candidates Criticized for Sound-Bite Approach to Problem of Illegal Aliens
description: Bryan Fenley's eyes hardly left the video screen as he watched small groups of men darting through the hills and arroyos, trying to sneak into America.

title: Big Changes Down on the Farm
description: Reforming the nation's bloated farm subsidy programs is no overnight task. It has taken 60 years for an emergency relief program to mutate into what now amounts to a welfare system for the rural middle class. Nevertheless, Congress has moved an amazing distance toward ending support programs for wheat, corn, rice and cotton. It even took aim, although it missed, at peanuts, sugar and dairy support systems that milk consumers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Early Signs With Bills
description: The free-agent wide receiver QUINN EARLY agreed yesterday to a four-year contract with the Buffalo Bills. Terms of the deal were not released, but Early was known to have been seeking at least $2.3 million per season, including a signing bonus of $1.5 million to $2 million.

title: One Bad Turn Produces Another for a Swimmer at the U.S. Trials
description: On the first day of the Olympic swimming trials, the United States lost one of its medal candidates when Kristine Quance was disqualified for a rules violation that was the aquatic equivalent of a foot fault.

title: BASKETBALL;Xavier Bounces Fordham
description: Darnell Williams made two free throws with 26 seconds left and Lenny Brown scored 17 points to lead Xavier of Ohio to a 61-54 victory over Fordham today in the first round of the Atlantic 10 tournament in Philadelphia.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Federal appeals court panel throwing out a judge's restraint order against Business Week magazine misspelled the surname of the First Amendment lawyer in Manhattan who had filed a brief opposing the restraint order. He is Robert D. Sack.

title: Sports of The Times;A Tourney That Means Everything
description: WE have become conditioned, for obvious reasons, to think of these Big East tournaments as a fund-raising irrelevance, a made-for-TV jamboree. But don't tell that to Adrian Griffin, or Maurice (Mo) Brown.

title: DANCE REVIEW;From Spain And Lovely To Look At
description: George Balanchine once said that if you didn't like his ballets there was always the music to close your eyes and listen to. The National Ballet of Spain, which performed on Tuesday night in the second of its two programs at City Center, provides another kind of alternative. It is so filled with beautiful faces and handsomely arched upper bodies that it almost didn't matter what the dancers were doing. And that is just as well, for dance was the least interesting part of the evening.

title: 3 U.S. Servicemen Convicted Of Rape of Okinawa Girl
description: Three American servicemen were convicted by a Japanese court this morning in the abduction and rape of a 12-year-old Japanese girl, a crime that ignited a public outcry against the presence of American military bases in Japan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Time Warner And U S West Still at Odd
description: With a trial date only six days away, there is no sign that Time Warner Inc. and U S West are near a settlement of their dispute over Time Warner's planned acquisition of Turner Broadcasting System.

title: Today, It's New York's Turn
description: Republicans in New York State go to the polls today to choose delegates in their Presidential primary.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lowe Awarded Baseball's Account
description: Major League Baseball in New York said yesterday that it had awarded Lowe & Partners/SMS its account, which had been handled by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco. Advertising spending was estimated at $18 million, including spending by television stations that broadcast baseball games.

title: Stocks Fall in Japan
description: Stocks were trading sharply lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 284.03 points, or 1.4 percent, at 19957.15. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 57.31 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Israeli Crackdown Renews Anxieties of Palestinians
description: A dank chill pervaded the Abu Ein cooking-pot factory today, the slow drip of water the only sound in the building that the Palestinian owner had dreamed would be clanging with new workers churning out housewares in time to sell for Passover.

title: Taiwan and China
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bullets End Sonics' Winning Streak at 14

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/CLASSICAL CD'S;Schubert Scaled For Home
description: The old, funny "Saturday Night Live" had its Conductors' Club skit: five or six grown men inanely waving their arms while Beethoven's Fifth barked on the record player. However cruelly exaggerated, the sketch made a valid point about the illusions of home listening: there is something ridiculous in restaging grandiose orchestral music within the confines of a living room. For chamber music, at least, the scale is correct. Even those of us with extremely modest apartments could invite over a string quartet and make the music comfortable.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;TV Airwaves Becoming Issue In Budget Battle
description: The television airwaves are becoming part of the budget wars in Congress, with Senate Republicans taking a hard look at proposals to raise billions of dollars by auctioning off a part of the radio spectrum earmarked for advanced TV services.

title: The Pop Life;The Bands Of Summer: Old-Timers
description: This summer's pop-music concert season is shaping up to be one of waiting for next season. Though music fans were hoping for big tours by U2, Paul McCartney and Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, these have been pushed back until at least 1997. Instead, from June through August, when the concert industry traditionally does 70 percent of its business, amphitheaters and arenas will be filled with the same bands and package tours that go out almost every summer: from nostalgia acts like the Moody Blues to traveling circuses like Lollapalooza.

title: Lord Jay, 88, Laborite Gadfly Who Defied Leaders on Europe
description: Lord Jay, an iconoclastic British Labor politician and former Cabinet officer who was such a fierce opponent of economic ties with Europe that he railed against Britain's entry into the Common Market even as his own Prime Minister, Harold Wilson, was aggressively campaigning for membership, died yesterday at his home in Oxfordshire. He was 88. Known as Douglas Jay until he received a life peerage in 1987, Lord Jay was an Oxford-trained economist who worked for The Economist and other publications before entering politics.

title: BASEBALL;Torre Offers An Apology To Versatile Kamieniecki
description: Scott Kamieniecki was sipping apple juice and devouring a cookie in the Yankee clubhouse this morning when the serenity of the moment and of spring training was rudely interrupted by reporters.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;False Rape Report Is Charged
description: An Elizabeth woman who said she was raped by an inmate at the Union County Jail while being restrained by another inmate, and then changed her account of the events twice, was accused in an indictment yesterday of making false statements. The four-count indictment also charged the woman, Alveda Torrado, with failing to respond to a court order to appear yesterday before the grand jury.

title: Brooklyn Gas and Con Ed Weigh Plans for Piece of Lilco
description: Even as Gov. George E. Pataki forges ahead with his plan to dismantle the Long Island Lighting Company, Lilco and Brooklyn Union Gas have been pursuing their own plans to merge and run the Island's gas and electric service, public officials say.

title: Linkup With Computer Saves Space and Allows Add-Ons
description: ON the ever-crowded desktop, one of the most logical and space-saving developments is the multifunction peripheral.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., said the consortium of its GE Power Systems division and two Italian companies, Snamprogetti and Turbotecnica, had received a $600 million contract to build a power plant in Sardinia. GE Power also won a contract worth more than $130 million to build part of a new power plant in Takoradi, Ghana.

title: Boeing, in Rosy Forecast, Says Industry Is Recovering
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that a recovery is under way in the commercial airplane industry, as it issued a new 20-year forecast for the industry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Scott Franks, a partner at Earle Palmer Brown, Philadelphia, was promoted to the new post of general manager, assuming responsibilities from Lonny Strum, president, who left to consider opening or acquiring an agency. Laura Cherensky-McEwen was named vice president and publisher at Snow Country magazine, Trumbull, Conn., a publication of The New York Times Company Magazine Group, succeeding Peter Griffin, who was named vice president and advertising director at a sibling publication, Golf Digest. Ms. Cherensky-McEwen had been associate publisher at Harper's Bazaar magazine, New York, owned by Hearst Corp.

title: POLITICS: BALLOT RULES;Two Rulings Seen Affecting Many Contests
description: Officials from both the Democratic and Republican parties have begun to acknowledge that the Federal lawsuit that opened up New York's Republican primary to more candidates could also force the Legislature to loosen rules for entering most other races, ending a system that has long been criticized as a tool that political bosses use to control elections.

title: Wells Fargo Bid Wins Approval
description: Wells Fargo & Company, which dates back to the Gold Rush days, won final regulatory approval today to acquire First Interstate Bancorp in a merger that is expected to create the nation's seventh-largest bank.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Underbelly of the Presidency
description: So You Want to Be President?" starts out on a promisingly provocative trip. It begins with a visit to "opposition researchers," a k a the dirty tricks teams that dig into the doings of political candidates. Most of their findings, exhumed from public records, are pretty dry, but now and then these scholars earn their pay and make their employers' day with something juicy, like evidence of sexual hanky-panky.

title: Council to Bar Elimination of Alarm Boxes
description: The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said yesterday that the Council would block the Giuliani administration's plan to dismantle the city's fire-alarm box system because the proposal would leave thousands of New Yorkers with no way to report fires quickly.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MARRIOTT TO FRANCHISE NEW GROUP OF ALL-SUITE HOTELS
description: Marriott International Inc. said yesterday that it planned to franchise an all-suite limited service hotel line under its Fairfield Inn brand for business travelers. The new hotels, which will be called Fairfield Suites, will have rooms that are 25 percent larger than Fairfield Inn rooms. They will also have more amenities, including a pantry area, refrigerator, microwave and a second phone. Guests will pay $55 to $65 a night, compared with $45 to $50 at a Fairfield Inn.

title: House Panel Approves Bill Easing Rules On Insurance
description: A House committee today approved legislation that would make it easier for small employers to band together and buy health insurance, but the bill would allow such health plans to avoid all state insurance regulation.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Republican Presidential primary in Connecticut misidentified the winner of the 1968 Presidential election in that state in some copies. It was Hubert H. Humphrey, not Lyndon B. Johnson, who did not seek re-election.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF ATLAS AIR RISE AFTER IT AGREES TO LEASE PLANES
description: The stock of Atlas Air rose nearly 16 percent yesterday, a day after the company announced a deal to lease five Boeing 747-200 freighter aircraft from the Federal Express Corporation. Atlas will lease the bulk-cargo planes, which Federal Express acquired in its purchase of the Flying Tigers cargo carrier, until 1998. The agreement will give Atlas more than 10 percent of the world's large air-freighter capacity by year-end, the company said. Atlas, of Golden, Colo., provides airlines with Boeing 747 freighters, plus crews, maintenance and insurance, usually under three-year contracts. Its shares rose $4.875, to $35.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Mayor Runs for Governor
description: The Mayor of Seattle, Norm Rice, announced today that he would run for governor. His announcement came two weeks after Gov. Mike Lowry said he would not seek a second term. Mr. Rice, a 52-year-old Democrat who is in his second term, is president of the Conference of Mayors. If elected, he would be the first black to be governor of Washington and the second elected governor in the United States.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Panel to Hear Animal Issues
description: Animal rights will be the theme of a State Senate committee hearing today as lawmakers consider a number of bills intended to protect animals and those who try to help them. One measure would increase the penalties for selling stray animals in shelters for medical research, and another would require proper ventilation of vehicles used to transport animals. Another bill before the Citizens, Veterans' Affairs and Agriculture Committee would protect people from being sued when they try to rescue abused or neglected animals.

title: Scenes of Rebirth at the Mall;New Stores for Juniors Succeed by Moving Quickly
description: Resnick, an asset management firm in Beverly Hills, Calif. "If you've made a mistake, mark it down and get it out of there. Merry-Go-Round kept denying this strategy and building inventory, and it killed them." The company went out of business this year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Consolidation Continues at Kodak
description: A day after the Eastman Kodak Company consolidated its worldwide consumer advertising account at two agencies, the company consolidated its worldwide professional and printing business-to-business account at the Saatchi & Saatchi Business Communications unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in Rochester by naming that shop as its worldwide agency of record. Billings were not disclosed, but Kodak will spend an estimated $50 million to $70 million this year on marketing communications to promote its professional and printing services.

title: In the Class of '70, Wounded Winners
description: The faces of the Bucknell University class of 1970 gaze out from the yearbook with a wide-eyed hopefulness untarnished by time. Though their hairstyles and clothes may look ever more dated, the class members remain forever 22 years old and unbowed, captured by the camera at a singular, ascendant moment of their youth.

title: Inspectors Failed to See Brake Problem on Train That Derailed
description: The Federal Railroad Administrator told a House subcommittee today that a 48-car freight train that derailed in California on Feb. 1 had been checked by agency inspectors before it began its trip, but that they had not noticed that a braking device on board had broken.

title: Bridge
description: New York stars had mixed fortunes in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Tuesday.

title: BEIJING STEPS UP MILITARY PRESSURE ON TAIWAN LEADER
description: Fears of confrontation rose today after China's announcement that it would conduct a week of missile tests near two of Taiwan's leading seaports, threatening a partial blockade of the island's commercial shipping.

title: 2 Swiss Drug Giants In a Surprise Merger To Be 2d in World
description: In a announcement that took the $200 billion worldwide pharmaceuticals industry by surprise, two Swiss drug giants, Sandoz Ltd. and Ciba-Geigy Ltd., announced yesterday that they would merge, forming a biotechnology powerhouse that would be the world's second-largest pharmaceutical maker.

title: Warhol Star Is Back For 15 More Minutes
description: I SOLD my mother for $10,000," said Brigid Berlin with a mischievous grin, pointing to the wall where an oil portrait of Honey Berlin, her rail-thin, blond socialite mother, once hung. "Every time mother had a face lift she made the artist repaint her portrait so it would match. I sold the painting because I couldn't stand having to live up to all that perfection."

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTERCEL TO BUY WIRELESS LICENSE FOR ATLANTA AREA
description: Intercel Inc., based in West Point, Ga., agreed yesterday to buy a personal communications services license for the Atlanta area from GTE Mobilnet Inc. for $195 million. The Atlanta license area covers about seven million potential subscribers in most of Georgia and parts of Alabama, South Carolina and Tennessee. Intercel already owns licenses for three adjacent P.C.S. markets. GTE acquired the license in a Federal Communications Commission auction last year. Separately, the Scana Corporation, an energy holding company in Columbia, S.C., said it would invest another $75 million in Intercel. Scana currently holds about a 17 percent stake. Intercel shares rose $2.25 yesterday, to $18.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: BASKETBALL;Beard Decides He Won't Use Bully Pulpit
description: Butch Beard wanted to throw his hands up in frustration. Four consecutive losses and five in your last six games can do that to you.

title: Corrections
description: A sentence was rendered incorrectly in a letter published yesterday from Lisa C. Smith of the Brooklyn District Attorney's Office on the domestic abuse case of Galina Komar. The sentence should have read: "When Mr. Oliver was about to be released from jail, we had him rearrested and persuaded two other judges to increase his bail."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a hearing on whether Vincent Gigante, accused of leading the Genovese crime family, is competent to stand trial misstated the year when Paul Castellano, who headed the Gambino crime family, was murdered. It was in December 1985, not 1995.

title: Bonn Unemployment at 11.1% : German Jobless Total Surges to Postwar Peak
description: FRANKFURT  German unemployment rose to a postwar record in February, raising the possibility that Europe's economic engine is heading for recession.

title: New Chief Executive Is Named at Nextel
description: Nextel Communications Inc. has named Daniel Akerson, a longtime telecommunications executive, as its chairman and chief executive. The appointment was effective today.

title: CS First Boston Executive Quits
description: Robert E. Diamond, the head of CS First Boston Inc.'s 1,200-member global fixed-income unit, resigned yesterday amid turmoil over bonuses in his department.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BROADCASTING;Cerone Is WPIX's Man
description: RICK CERONE, a former Yankee catcher, will call the team's games for WPIX-TV/Channel 11 this season. Cerone, who announced several Yankee games last year, will join BOBBY MURCER. So far, PHIL RIZZUTO has not decided whether to come out of retirement for a limited schedule of games. PAUL OLDEN, the play-by-play voice for the team, might still be re-signed.

title: Ex-Vichy Aide Says He Is Scapegoat for French Guilt in Holocaust
description: Fighting a move to bring him to trial 13 years after his first indictment on charges he ordered the deportation of hundreds of Jews from France to a Nazi death camp during World War II, a former French Cabinet minister said in an interview published today that he was a scapegoat for French complicity in the Holocaust.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Monday's activity in the credit markets misstated the debt rating that Duff & Phelps Credit Rating gave to $900 million in senior notes sold by the Sprint Corporation's cellular unit, 360degrees Communications. The rating is BB+, not BBB+.

title: BASKETBALL;Marbury Riding High at Ga. Tech
description: About the same time the ballyhoo around Stephon Marbury subsided to a dull roar, a strange thing happened at Georgia Tech. Marbury, the heralded freshman guard from Coney Island, figured out that he didn't need to win every game for his team single-handedly, and the Yellow Jackets began a steady climb from a 6-8 record to the top of the Atlantic Coast Conference.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IP TIMBERLANDS IN $905 MILLION DEAL WITH R-H TIMBER
description: IP Timberlands Ltd. said yesterday that one of its subsidiaries had agreed to sell a general partnership interest to the R-H Timber Company for $905 million. IP Timberlands, a subsidiary of the International Paper Company, owns 300,000 acres of forest lands in Oregon and Washington. R-H Timber is a new company formed by the Roseburg Forest Products Company and the Hampton Company. Roseburg dropped out of negotiations to buy three wood-product factories and 600,000 acres of Oregon timberlands from the Weyerhaeuser Company last month. International Paper said it would record a gain of about $335 million, or $1.25 a share, on the sale.

title: Traditional Family Stabilized in the 90's, Study Suggests
description: After two decades of social pressures that caused many to fear that it might dissolve, the traditional American family is making a comeback in the 1990's, a Washington research group said today in issuing a profile of the country's population.

title: AT HOME WITH: SUSAN SOROS;A Private Life, A Public Passion
description: SUSAN SOROS, wife of the financier George Soros, the man who manages nearly $11 billion in assets, the man known for winning $2 billion by betting against the British pound, moves through Manhattan enveloped in a skein of mystery. When her car pulls to a curb, her chauffeur jumps out and carefully scans the landscape for danger.

title: U.S. Productivity Level Fell 0.5% in the Fourth Quarter
description: The productivity of American workers declined in the fourth quarter as the hours they spent on the job increased at a faster pace than their output of goods and services, the Government reported today.

title: Corrections
description: A caption accompanying a photograph yesterday of Republican members of the House Agriculture Committee just before a vote to grant temporary visas to farm workers misstated the given name of one of the members. He is Bill Barrett of Nebraska, not Thomas Barrett.

title: BASEBALL;Indians Plan to Sell Additional Tickets
description: Having sold out all its games at Jacobs Field months ago, the Cleveland Indians are preparing to sell more than 100,000 additional tickets for the 1996 season, the club said today.

title: U.S. Finds China Guilty of Wide Rights Abuses
description: The Clinton Administration issued its annual human rights report today, declaring China guilty of "widespread and well-documented human rights abuses," and announced that the United States would again co-sponsor a critical resolution on China at the coming meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOODY'S LOWERS ITS RATING ON WAL-MART DEBT
description: The credit rating on about $8.6 billion of long-term debt of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. was cut yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which said growth could slow for the world's largest retailer. The downgrade comes after Wal-Mart reported its first decline in quarterly earnings and said its same-store sales growth had slowed. The senior debt of Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., was cut one notch, to Aa2, the third-highest level.

title: FOOTBALL;When Lions Talk Nicely, The Giants Lose Brooks
description: Giants linebacker Michael Brooks was in Detroit yesterday visiting with Lions Coach Wayne Fontes and his defensive staff. They had a nice conversation, something that Brooks and the Giants will probably not be having in the near future. A relationship that was once great turned sour and, in a somewhat bizarre turn of events, came to an end.

title: Where Father Coughlin Broadcast His Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani's Spending Plan Is Approved Nearly Intact
description: In a prelude to the larger battle ahead over New York City's next budget, the City Council approved changes to the current spending plan yesterday that reversed a handful of cuts Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had proposed in recycling, youth programs and child-abuse prevention programs in the city's Beacon Schools.

title: A. D. Woudhuysen, 78, Trader On Wall St. Honored by Dutch
description: Andries D. Woudhuysen, a prominent international securities trader for the brokerage firm of Burnham & Company who was commended by the Netherlands Government for his work in the resistance to Nazi Germany, died on Sunday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 78 and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Metro Matters;Low Priority For the Judging Of the Judges
description: AFTER weeks of headlines and controversy, the case of Judge Lorin Duckman has landed in the hands of a state commission that has one half-time investigator in New York City, takes two years to resolve a serious case and operates in officially sanctioned secret.

title: SENIOR CLASS;Removing the Stigma From the O-Word
description: A FEW years ago, Prof. Joan G. Silberman, who teaches English at Rockland Community College in Suffern, N.Y., offered a summer course titled "The Literature of Old Age."

title: Review/Fashion;Gucci Reinvents Jet-Set Sophistication
description: It was as if Tom Ford, the designer of Gucci, had pumped happy gas into the room instead of the seductive soundtrack crooning "The Look of Love." Some of fashion's most famous poker faces were smiling, and many found their feet for the first time in the Milan season, which opened on Friday, to give him a standing ovation at the end.

title: Leadership Battle Divides Prominent Union
description: During John J. Sweeney's 15 years at the helm of the Service Employees International, the union was hailed as the brightest spot in labor's firmament because it was by far the most successful union in attracting new members.

title: Arrest Puts Israel Arabs Under Cloud
description: The disclosure today that an Israeli Arab has been arrested on suspicion of driving a Palestinian suicide bomber to Tel Aviv on Monday put Israel's Arabs on the defensive and highlighted the delicate problems they face as a minority in a Jewish state.

title: Liberties;Let Dole Be Dole
description: You can feel the excitement building.

title: Santa Fe Soul, Stamped in Tin
description: IF spare adobe walls and Navajo rugs are the yin of Santa Fe, Ford Ruthling's house is the yang.

title: Reversal of a Gag Order
description: The United States Court of Appeals in Ohio has finally overturned a district judge's unconstitutional injunction that blocked Business Week magazine from printing an article about sealed court documents for weeks on end last fall. The ruling, a resounding repudiation of the lower court's censoring action, will prove worth the wait if judges everywhere heed its message.

title: Gene Inserted in Crop Plant Is Shown to Spread to Wild
description: A field study has shown that a gene inserted into a crop plant can easily be transferred to a close relative, highlighting potentially unseen consequences of the genetic engineering of plants, scientists said today.

title: World News Briefs;U.S. Sends Jets to Jordan For Patrol Duty
description: The Pentagon is sending 34 Air Force jet fighters and tanker aircraft to Jordan, a move that officials said was unrelated to the recent terror campaign against Israel.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Ping-Pong A Piglet And Ritual
description: There are women as well as men in the troupe, and its dancing style has nothing to do with nightclubs or discos. Poppo and the Go-Go Boys is a serious company.

title: The Power to Suspend Students
description: Gov. George Pataki's proposal to give individual teachers the authority to suspend disruptive students -- a function currently reserved for principals and superintendents -- is a bad idea. While everyone sympathizes with the need to maintain order in the classroom, the New York Governor's proposal is a blunt response that is likely to do more harm than good. It could actually undermine a reasonably effective disciplinary process that already suspends 4 to 5 percent of the state's students each year.

title: Pop in Review
description: Banana, Nirvana, Manana And All Things Psychedelic Gong The Bottom Line

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Securities Fall Again
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the second straight day, as investor hopes of another rate cut by the Federal Reserve continued to fade on fears of more strong economic data that could lead to inflationary pressures.

title: Dow Declines by 12.65; Chip Shares Have a Selloff
description: Stock prices slumped yesterday, hurt by a decline in bonds and by a selloff in semiconductor issues.

title: Bernadette Castro Is Fined $22,000
description: New York State's Parks Commissioner, Bernadette Castro, has agreed to pay a $22,000 fine for failing to file timely finance reports for hundreds of thousands of dollars she lent to her own failed campaign to unseat Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: A Trial Without Witnesses
description: The International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague is being undermined by a lack of cooperation from most of the combatants in the former Yugoslavia -- the Serbs, Bosnian Serbs and Croats. Unless the United Nations and the Western powers use all their leverage to help the tribunal, the rule of international law and the legacy of the Nuremberg trials will be in danger.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 24 about a vow by Patrick J. Buchanan to end abortions mischaracterized the position of another Republican Presidential candidate, Senator Bob Dole. Mr. Dole has said that he supports a constitutional amendment to overturn the Supreme Court decision permitting abortions, but that he favors making exceptions in cases of rape or incest or when the pregnant woman's life is endangered.

title: POLITICS;Unyielding to Predictions, Forbes Persists
description: With a last-minute burst of television advertising, cross-state stumping and a hard-sought political endorsement yesterday, Steve Forbes focused his full attention on today's New York Republican Presidential primary, turning the state into a last stand for his beleaguered campaign.

title: Council Sues to Prevent Hospital Sales
description: Seeking to reclaim its share of City Hall turf, the City Council sued Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday to block the Mayor's proposed sale of city hospitals. Council leaders said public hospitals could not be sold or leased without their approval.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Still Speedy at 60
description: EDDIE HILL, who turned 60 yesterday, will celebrate this weekend at the Gatornationals drag races in Gainesville, Fla., at his usual pace: more than 300 miles an hour for less than 5 seconds. Hill, from Wichita Falls, Tex., was the 1993 National Hot Rod Association champion in the marquee Top Fuel division. "My youthfulness is 98 percent due to nitromethane," he said yesterday, referring to the volatile fuel that helps his car produce 6,000 horsepower. "Any kind of a ride like that has got to get your heart rate up," said Hill, "and it's got to keep your arteries blown out."

title: I.B.M. to Lift Output of Hard Disk Drives
description: Citing a "terrific opportunity" to meet rising demand, I.B.M. said yesterday that it would spend $500 million over the next two years to increase its production of sophisticated hard disk drives that store data in computers.

title: Texas Instruments Cites Surplus of Computer Memory Chips
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that an oversupply of memory chips was hurting prices as demand for personal computers slowed.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Echoes Of an Era Of Cool
description: Pucho and His Latin Soul Brothers played at S.O.B.'s on Tuesday night and revived an era where funk, jazz and Latin music were cross-fertilizing wildly. Veterans of the time, fans of the original band, were there in the audience, but so were younger dancers; Pucho, if not the coolest of the 60's revival groups, is certainly cool. And he has a new album, "Rip a Dip" (Milestone).

title: World News Briefs;U.N. Agency to End Aid To Vietnamese in Camps
description: The United Nations refugee agency said today that it would end aid to more than 35,000 Vietnamese boat people in camps in southeast Asia, leaving them with no choice but to return home.

title: AIDS Council Likely to Back Needle Programs
description: Seeking to reduce the transmission of the AIDS virus among intravenous drug users, the Governor's Advisory Council on AIDS is expected to recommend that New Jersey allow exchange programs for clean needles and the sale of syringes without prescriptions at pharmacies.

title: POLITICS;Today's Vote Elects 93 Delegates
description: Republicans in New York State hold their primary today to choose 93 delegates and 93 alternates to the party's national convention in San Diego in August.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Just in time for spring, hokum from a most traditional source.
description: SO outrageous is the hoopla, ballyhoo, bunkum -- and yes, secrecy -- of the $15 million advertising campaign for "Airiana the Arrow" that it could have been conceived by P. T. Barnum.

title: Colombian Police Kill a Top Drug Trafficker Near Medellin
description: The Colombian police killed a top drug trafficker who was on the run in a shootout late Tuesday night on a darkened highway outside Medellin.

title: S.& L.'s Set a Record for Profits Last Year
description: The savings and loan industry earned a record $5.4 billion in 1995, but regulators expressed concern today about underlying trends, including rising consumer and mortgage delinquencies.

title: In a Russian Proverb, Too Many Nurses
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: ENDORSEMENT;Kemp Supports Forbes in Bid to Salvage Flat-Tax Plan as an Issue in the Campaign
description: Never has the normally shy and retiring Steve Forbes come as close to gushing as he did here today when he stood shoulder-to-shoulder with Jack F. Kemp, the Republican Party luminary Mr. Forbes proudly described as "my guru-in-chief."

title: Reject Myths;Korea Security Threat?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Hans Kraus, 90, Originator Of Sports Medicine in U.S., Dies
description: Dr. Hans Kraus, a specialist in physical medicine and rehabilitation who has been called the father of sports medicine in the United States, died yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 90.

title: At Gucci, a fresh take on jet-set sophistication.
New Plan Would Block School Election Victors
description: State legislative leaders are discussing a proposal to allow the New York City Schools Chancellor to temporarily block the winners of school board elections in May from taking their seats on four boards that are now under suspension.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Bit of the Ridiculous In a Search for Her Roots 'La Gringa' Repertorio Espanol

title: World News Briefs;Several Die in Riot In Port-au-Prince Slum
description: A shootout today between the police and a street gang in the Cite Soleil slum left several people dead, witnesses said. Among those wounded were two policemen, one hit by a bullet and another struck by a bottle, the independent Radio Metropole reported.

title: World News Briefs;House Passes Bill To Punish Cuba
description: The House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed a bill today that seeks to discourage foreign investment in Cuba and to tighten the United States embargo on Cuba. President Clinton, who withdrew past objections to the bill after Cuba shot down two American civilian planes on Feb. 24, says he will sign the bill, which the Senate has approved.

title: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;Dole Appears to Spark Little Campaign Fire
description: Senator Bob Dole has the unqualified backing of the state Republican Party, a comfortable lead in the polls and an army of party workers to pull out his vote in today's Presidential primary.

title: Bid to Foil a Sarajevo Transfer Is Ended by a NATO Threat
description: About a dozen men tried to obstruct the handover of this Sarajevo suburb to the Muslim-Croat federation that is to govern the town, but the interlopers withdrew today after a threat of force by NATO. They were thought to be Bosnian Croat police officers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Murdoch in European Digital TV Venture
description: In the most significant venture to date aimed at tapping the potentially huge European pay-television market, Rupert Murdoch and his British Sky Broadcasting Group teamed up today with three of Europe's largest media groups to offer digital pay television throughout the Continent, in particular to German- and French-speaking countries.

title: Pop in Review
description: Forty Songs Sung 1-2-3 In Honor of Charles Strouse Linda Lavin Rainbow and Stars

title: Reject Myths;On Trade With Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times;For One Knick, Good Demeanor Extends Far Beyond 3-Point Range
description: AMID all the bickering and strife, the moaning and pouting -- the losing -- that has been the Knicks in the last few months, one player plays quietly, effectively, even elegantly. It is Hubert Davis Jr., who recently replaced the volatile and slumping John Starks in the starting lineup.

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;Dole Endorsed by Alexander and Lugar
description: Senator Bob Dole moved yesterday to assemble a harmonious front of Republican leaders to anoint him as the certain nominee and was emboldened by glowing endorsements from two former rivals -- Lamar Alexander and Senator Richard G. Lugar -- who just a day before had still been warning that he was not the best candidate.

title: Piper Jaffray Is Fined Over Data on Fund
