description: The National Association of Securities Dealers fined the Piper Jaffray Companies $1.25 million yesterday, saying that the firm had sold a mutual fund without fully informing investors that it contained volatile mortgage-backed derivatives.

title: Spy Agencies Don't Require a Major Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BASEBALL;Brogna to Get M.R.I. Test
description: Rico Brogna and the rest of the Mets are cautiously optimistic that the first baseman won't be sidelined very long with a strained right knee. But the extent of the injury won't be determined until a magnetic resonance imaging test is conducted Thursday at a hospital in Fort Pierce, Fla.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GLENAYRE'S OUTLOOK BRINGS A 23% DROP IN SHARES
description: The shares of Glenayre Technologies Inc. fell 23 percent yesterday after the company, a telecommunications equipment maker, said its first-quarter sales might be hurt by a regulatory ruling. Glenayre said on Tuesday that a recent decision by the Federal Communications Commission to freeze new applications for 900 megahertz paging licenses may mean that first-quarter sales will fall $10 million to $12 million below analysts' estimates. The company, based in Charlotte, N.C., did not disclose those estimates. Glenayre shares fell $10, to $32.25, in Nasdaq trading of 10.8 million shares.

title: Reorganization of Camden Police Is Urged
description: State Attorney General Deborah T. Poritz today recommended a reorganization and expansion of the Police Department in Camden, where a record 60 killings last year registered the highest per-capita murder rate of any major city in the state.

title: Pearl Lang Premiere
description: The Pearl Lang Dance Theater will present a premiere set to music by George Crumb and Ms. Lang's signature "Shira," danced by Rika Okamato, in performances on Saturday at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 4 P.M. at Kaye Playhouse, Hunter College, 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues. Tickets are $17; $10 for students and the elderly. Reservations: (212) 772-4448.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sandoz and Ciba Of Switzerland to Merge Sandoz and Ciba agreed to merge, subject to shareholder approval, forming a new company, Novartis, "based on the concept of a merger among equals."

title: No Headline
description: For the last year, I have been going across this country, describing my vision of America's future and asking this question: Is Senator Dole the man that Republicans want carrying our banner against Bill Clinton and leading us into the new century? And what I've discovered is that for most Republicans, the answer to that is yes."

title: Classical Music in Review
description: A Conductor's Rapport With His Ensemble National Arts Center Orchestra of Canada Avery Fisher Hall

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Buchanan Emerges From 8-Way Failure Unbowed and Pledging to Remain Vocal
description: Patrick J. Buchanan may be going down, but he is going down swinging a pitchfork.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;ITT May Acquire Control of Sportschannel
description: As a result of negotiations with the Cablevision Systems Corporation about the repayment of a loan, the ITT Corporation may gain control of Sportschannel New York, which televises the games of the Mets, Islanders, Devils and Nets.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: To Make Deer Frown

title: Theater in Review
description: The Third in a Trilogy Of Gospel Musicals 'Born to Sing! Mama 3' Paramount Theater

title: BASKETBALL;A Fitting End to the Season: St. John's Falls Short
description: The St. John's season ended last night as it began, with hints of promise and flashes of brilliance that led to one final disappointment. Playing for little more than self-respect and the hope for something better in the future, the Red Storm manufactured one last rally in a painful year, one good enough to take a lead over Providence and threaten the Friars' chances of a bid for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: What's Left Over For Bath Mats?
description: When Diana met Charles, she appeared to have simple tastes, favoring frilly modest-maiden dresses, a modified bowl-cut hair style and makeup that could not have been hard to maintain.

title: POLITICS: AT THE CAPITOL;Dole Hoping To Get Back To Legislating In Congress
description: The next major stop for Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign is the United States Capitol, where the majority leader hopes to burnish his reputation for getting things done with action on different legislative fronts -- from immigration to health insurance.

title: Gingrich Asks Judge's Ouster For Ruling Out Drug Evidence
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich and other House Republican leaders called on President Clinton today to ask for the resignation of the Federal judge in New York City who was criticized for throwing out drug evidence.

title: Electric Bus? An Old Idea Is New Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Poultry-Producer Shares Climb as Russia Ends Plan for a Ban
description: Shares of Tyson Foods Inc. and other poultry producers rose yesterday after Russia promised not to bar imports of chickens from the United States.

title: Officer Gets Long Term In Prison For Perjury
description: A Manhattan judge yesterday sentenced an officer from the scandal-scarred 30th Precinct to up to four and a half years in state prison for lying under oath about an arrest. It was the longest sentence yet in a perjury case stemming from the precinct's corruption scandal.

title: POLITICS;Dole's Troubled Horizon
description: Bob Dole is not quite there yet. He lost a pair of adversaries today, but two others hang on, notably Patrick J. Buchanan, who is apparently determined to harry him, the same way J. E. B. Stuart harried McClellan, all the way to the Republican convention in San Diego in August.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Alltel Corp., Little Rock, Ark., is selling $300 million of debentures due in 2016 through Stephens Inc. The debentures are rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN GREETINGS RULES OUT HOSTILE BID FOR GIBSON
description: The American Greetings Corporation, which was spurned in its second bid for Gibson Greetings Inc., said yesterday that it would not attempt a hostile takeover. But Morry Weiss, the chairman and chief executive of American Greetings, said the company might sweeten its bid "to get the attention of Gibson's management and board." Cleveland-based American Greetings said on Tuesday that it had offered to buy Cincinnati-based Gibson for $18 a share, or $292.9 million. Gibson shares rose $2.375 yesterday, to $16.875, in Nasdaq trading; shares of American Greetings rose 75 cents, to $29.

title: Casino Operator to Adopt Lake Como
description: Mirage Resorts Inc., whose glitzy hotels with volcanoes and pirate ships set the standard for Las Vegas extravagance, announced plans today for a $1.25 billion Italian-theme resort called Bellagio.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Johnson Leaves His Options Open
description: MAGIC JOHNSON and MICHAEL JORDAN finishing their National Basketball Association careers together? Johnson reunited in Miami with his former coach PAT RILEY? Johnson back home in Michigan, playing for the Pistons?

title: New Chief for London's National Theater
description: Trevor Nunn, the director who rose to fame in the 1960's as the Wunderkind of the Royal Shakespeare Company and then struck bountiful commercial success in the West End with a parade of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musicals, has been chosen as the new director of the National Theater. He will succeed Richard Eyre, the director since 1988, who will step down in September 1997. Mr. Nunn is scheduled to keep the job for five years.

title: Market Place;Money Keeps Pouring Into Market Funds
description: Despite the heavy volatility in the stock and bond markets in February, mutual fund investors remained unshaken, continuing to pour plenty of fresh cash into funds investing here and abroad, according to estimates released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;At Home With Paragons Of Terrestrial Success
description: THE EARTH DWELLERS Adventures in the Land of Ants By Erich Hoyt Illustrated. 319 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: Senate Must Ratify Chemical Weapons Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Music in Review
description: A Young Tenor Vs. a Large House 'Cosi Fan Tutte' Metropolitan Opera

title: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA;For Bucknell's Class of '96, Pressure to Focus, and Fast
description: Every generation has its pressure cooker. For the Bucknell class of 1970, it was Vietnam and the draft. Lives and goals were transformed as men sought escape from an increasingly unpopular war, or dealt with the prospect of fighting in it.

title: The Silent Republicans
description: It is time for pro-choice Republican officeholders to act for women across America.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Slot Machine Rule Lifted
description: The State Casino Control Commission voted unanimously yesterday to repeal a 16-year-old rule barring casino operators from buying more than half of their slot machines from a single manufacturer.

title: HOCKEY;Richer Has a Much-Needed Big Night
description: For the moment, you can close the case on two missing persons files.

title: Target Was Israeli Government, Says Arab Linked to 3 Bombings
description: A young Palestinian man accused of recruiting three of the latest suicide bombers said today that he was told the attacks were called to insure the defeat of the Israeli Government and thus undermine the political process toward peace.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hospital Alignment Planned
description: The Cancer Institute of New Jersey plans to announce a new partnership today with Morristown Memorial Hospital and affiliations with Overlook Hospital of Summit and Mountainside Hospital of Montclair, the A.P. reported. They are among nine New Jersey hospitals or research centers to announce new mergers or affiliations this week.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;In Germany, Downsizing Means 10.3% Jobless
description: Corporate Germany has been producing a drumbeat of layoffs, downsizings, bankruptcies and the flight of jobs abroad. Individually, none of these has been of the magnitude of AT&T's plan to slash 40,000 jobs, but taken together they are producing the grimmest employment prospects in Europe's largest economy since the end of World War II.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Image Campaign For Plank Road
description: The Miller Brewing Company unit of the Philip Morris Companies has expanded its relationship with BBDO Toronto by awarding the agency an assignment to create an image campaign to promote Plank Road Brewery as a division of Miller that markets smaller specialty beer brands like Icehouse and Red Dog. Billings were not disclosed.

title: BASKETBALL;Last-second Victory Gives Pirates Date With UConn
description: In Seton Hall's playbook, it's called "1-4 Dribble." The "1" is basketball's universal designation for the point guard, and the "4" refers to the four other players who move to the wing, clearing the way for the point guard.

title: SKIING;Snowboard Injuries Taking On New Look
description: As snowboarding melds with the mainstream of Alpine skiing, an idiosyncrasy about the newer sport is becoming all too obvious: snowboarders are incurring some of the injuries that skiers now avoid.

title: Court Voids A Law Barring Help in Suicide
description: In the first decision by a full Federal appeals court on the issue of doctor-assisted suicide, a Washington State law barring the practice was struck down here today as contrary to a constitutional "right to die."

title: In the E.R., Nonemergencies Get a Big Markup
description: Anyone who has gone to the emergency room for a sore throat or cold knows that the bill can be breathtaking. Now a study shows why: hospitals charge double what treatment for nonurgent visits actually costs.

title: Cuba, Citing Earlier Intrusions, Defends Downing of 2 Cessnas
description: Cuba told a special session of the General Assembly today that a long series of provocative and illegal overflights of Cuba by Cuban-Americans had led to the decision on Feb. 24 to shoot down two civilian aircraft, killing four people.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Like Gene Kelly, the man who made her a star, LESLIE CARON will receive the Lifetime Achievement Award of the School of American Ballet on Monday at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. Mr. Kelly, who died last month, received the award in 1992.

title: Executive Changes
description: AGRIBIOTECH INC., Las Vegas, Nev., a farming equipment company, named Henry Ingalls chief financial officer and vice president.

title: A Rarity in Hong Kong: Budget Is in Deficit
description: Hong Kong's new Financial Secretary announced a rare budget deficit today but said growth would pick up as the rich British colony headed toward Chinese rule in 1997. The deficit was the territory's first in 13 years.

title: Life and Death Reports From a Chicago Project
description: At 16, LeAlan Jones is full of ambition and dreams of playing college football and pulling his family out of the ghetto.

title: Still Loud and Unbowed
description: Senator Bob Dole's eight-primary sweep on Tuesday seemed to make Patrick J. Buchanan more determined to speak out. Page B10.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism is losing its first female dean. JOAN KONNER, 65, is stepping down from the position she has held since 1988 but will remain as publisher of the Columbia Journalism Review.

title: An Invitation Even the Biggest Stars Can't Refuse
description: Mel Gibson is coming. John Travolta arrives tonight. Arnold Schwarzenegger already showed up and sat side by side with Sandra Bullock, Tom Hanks, Keanu Reeves, Morgan Freeman, Warren Beatty, Winona Ryder, Sigourney Weaver, Kevin Costner and Sophia Loren.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Promises, Partly Kept, With Debussy and Stravinsky Philadelphia Orchestra Carnegie Hall

title: Serb Move Angers Europe
description: The European Union today sharply criticized a recent decision by Serbian authorities to take control of Belgrade's only independent television station, Studio B, and said further restraints on the news media would hurt future ties.

title: Diner's Journal
description: As you may know, lunchtime turns into a free wine tasting next week at five midtown restaurants: Smith & Wollensky, Park Avenue Cafe, Manhattan Ocean Club, the Post House and Cite.

title: World News Briefs;Jordan Confiscates Shipment for Iraq
description: Jordan announced today that it had seized aircraft spare parts and other supplies headed for Iraq in violation of United Nations sanctions.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACME-CLEVELAND STOCK SURGES ON DANAHER BID
description: The stock of the Acme-Cleveland Corporation, a maker of telecommunications products, soared yesterday after the Danaher Corporation offered to buy the company for $27 a share in cash, or more than $173 million. Acme-Cleveland's stock climbed past the offering price, rising $10.125, or about 50 percent, to $30.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Danaher's stock was unchanged at $34.625. Danaher, a maker of tools, environmental controls and transportation products that is based in Washington, D.C., had revenue of $1.49 billion last year. Acme-Cleveland, which is based in Cleveland, reported sales last year of $120.7 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Last Cahnce
description: Here is a sampling of shows in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Jobless Rates Change Little in New York Region
description: In a further indication of the local economy's continued sluggishness, monthly unemployment rates in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region were virtually unchanged over the same period last year, according to Labor Department figures released yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STERILE CONCEPTS REJECTS OFFER FROM MAXXIM MEDICAL
description: Sterile Concepts Holdings Inc. has rejected an unsolicited acquisition offer of $118 million from Maxxim Medical Inc. Maxxim last month proposed acquiring all the outstanding common stock of Sterile Concepts at $16 a share. Sterile Concepts, based in Richmond, provides surgical and clinical trays to hospitals and surgery centers. Maxxim, based in Sugar Land, Tex., is a maker and supplier of medical products. The shares of Sterile Concepts rose 37.5 cents, to $17.625, yesterday, and the stock of Maxxim was down 62.5 cents, at $18.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TV WEEKEND;A New Home in Malibu For a Familiar Formula
description: If the label says Spelling Television Inc., you can be sure the package includes gorgeous actors, seemingly getting younger all the time, in various stages of undress and romantic ardor. The Aaron Spelling list, often compiled with E. Duke Vincent, includes "Dynasty," "Beverly Hills, 90210," "Melrose Place" and the more recent "Savannah." Now, making its entrance on NBC tomorrow as a two-hour movie, there's "Malibu Shores." Spelling devotees won't be disappointed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANDRE AGASSI, the tennis star, has given BROOKE SHIELDS an engagement ring, but no date has been set for the wedding. "He gave her a ring, and they're extremely happy, Perry Rogers, Mr. Agassi's business manager, told the A.P. yesterday. He would not give any other details.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Tuesday about a special advertising unit formed by the New York office of DDB Needham Worldwide included erroneous information supplied by the agency about the status of an account recently won by the unit, for the Travel Channel, a cable television network. Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners had not been the agency of record for the account; it had handled the account for a year on a project basis.

title: Study Bolsters Theory on Early Humans
description: A new study supports the idea that the humans who first populated Asia, Europe and the Americas may have been descendants of a small group who first left Africa about 100,000 years ago.

title: On My Mind;Would We Do It Again?
description: For nations as for people, one question is always available to find out whether a past decision was right or a mistake. Would we do it again?

title: The Chargers Sign Coleman
description: The San Diego Chargers' big gamble paid off today when they acquired defensive end Marco Coleman from the Miami Dolphins, who failed to match an offer for $9.6 million over three years.

title: FILM REVIEW;If They Haven't Found Love by 30, They'll Jump. Well, O.K.
description: In Eric Schaeffer's "If Lucy Fell," Elle Macpherson swoons over Mr. Schaeffer and calls him "a cute, smart, sexy, good-looking guy," perhaps laboring under the misconception that Mr. Schaeffer is the next Woody Allen. True, Mr. Schaeffer has made a bittersweet romantic comedy with a New York setting, but that's as far as the resemblance goes.

title: Defunct Florida Bond Firm Settles Case Involving Campaign Aid
description: FAIC Securities, a defunct Miami brokerage firm that was owned by the Florida sugar-cane magnates Alfonso and Jose F. Fanjul, agreed yesterday to pay $439,000 to settle a case filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Megan's Law' Halted By a New York Judge
description: The New York law that allows communities to know if sex offenders are in their midst has been blocked by a judge pending a hearing into its constitutionality. The judge said he wanted to prevent the "irreparable harm" releasing such information would do until constitutional challenges could be heard.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Best for Entrepreneurs
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 198.72 points, or 1 percent, at 20,155.87. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 284.03 points.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a City Council suit against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the proposed sale of city hospitals misspelled the surname of a former Councilman who is representing the Council. He is Edward L. Sadowsky, not Sadowski.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Thief Poses as an Officer
description: A man wearing a baseball cap with a State Police emblem pulled over two cars in separate incidents last month in Denville and Maplewood and claimed he was an undercover officer searching for narcotics, the Morris County Prosecutor's office said yesterday. The man also stole $100 in cash from a Rockaway gas station, after he said he was investigating credit card fraud, Lieut. Christopher D. Linne said. Witnesses said the man was driving a Ford Thunderbird, but all the unmarked cars used by the state police are Chevrolet Caprices, Lieutenant Linne said.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Hubris at Chase
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Assassins 1995. Warner. $100.71. Laser disk, $39.98. 133 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Several New Reports Give A Mixed View of Economy
description: Several new statistics gave a mixed reading on the economy today, as economists awaited the Labor Department's employment report on Friday.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Retailers' Sales Rise, but Shares Take a Beating
description: A quirk in the calendar, some good weather and a nation of shoppers who decided they could not live another day without a new shirt or scarf combined to lift retail sales in February. But the rebound, after months of low numbers, does not necessarily indicate that the retail industry is back with a vengeance.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Accused Boy to Be Monitored
description: An 8-year-old boy who was charged with setting a Christmas Eve fire that resulted in a man's death will be monitored for six months and required to enroll in a fire-prevention program, Edward DeFazio, first assistant prosecutor for Hudson County, said yesterday.

title: U.S. Decision on Mexico Drugs Draws Opposition in Congress
description: Angered by President Clinton's decision to declare Mexico a cooperative partner in the war on drugs, lawmakers in the House and Senate are trying to overturn the decision on the ground that Mexico has done little to shut down the huge pipelines for cocaine and other illegal narcotics that stretch across the border into the United States.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NETSCAPE STOCK PLUMMETS IN BATTLE WITH MICROSOFT
description: The stock of the Netscape Communications Corporation, which has lost more than half its value in the last five weeks over worries that the Microsoft Corporation will beat it out in the war over software for use on the Internet, fell almost 14 percent yesterday. The shares were down $6.25, to $38.75, in Nasdaq trading. They stood at $83.50 on Jan. 31. Microsoft and Netscape are taking shots at each other's software and courting business partners. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Microsoft was trying to license its Internet software to America Online Inc. in a move to derail talks between America Online and Netscape. America Online has more than five million customers; gaining access to them would be a coup for Netscape or Microsoft.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Ace Ventura: When Nature Calls 1995. Warner. Laser disk, $34.98. 94 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Grosvenor 'Sculpture' Paula Cooper 155 Wooster Street, near Houston Street SoHo Through March 23

title: Inside Art
description: A Gauguin Must Be Sold

title: INSIDE
description: Entering Right-to-Die Fray

title: BASKETBALL;If the Knicks Keep Stumbling, Nelson May Fall
description: Saying he feels as if he has been "kicked in the teeth," Don Nelson acknowledged yesterday that he was an embattled coach and said that the Knicks' off-season changes might even include himself.

title: POLITICS: THE PARTY;D'Amato Apologizes for Effort To Shut Out Rivals of Dole
description: An exit poll already showed Bob Dole to be the overwhelming winner in New York, but Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato apologized late yesterday afternoon for his role -- mostly successful -- in shutting other candidates out of the Republican primary.

title: Congress Sends White House a Compromise Foreign Spending Bill
description: In a sharp retreat from Republican plans to eliminate three American agencies, lawmakers agreed today on final legislation to allow President Clinton to dismantle only one of the three.

title: Bellicose Beijing Makes Asians Uneasy
description: SINGAPORE  China's increasingly bellicose approach toward Taiwan is fanning concerns in Asia that Beijing may be pursuing a plan to recover "lost territory" that goes far beyond the return of Hong Kong in 1997, Macau in 1999 and "early" reunification with Taiwan.

title: BASEBALL;Stanley Helps Girardi Learn the Yankee Way
description: A discreet meeting transpired in right field this morning. Two Yankee catchers, one past and one present. Mike Stanley and Joe Girardi talked about life as a Yankee.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Bulletproof Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;3 Arrested in Girl's Shooting
description: Three Paterson men have been arrested in the Tuesday night shooting of a 13-year-old girl, who was apparently caught in a crossfire while she was sitting on her porch, the police said yesterday.

title: Belying Yeltsin Statement, Chechens Press Attack in Grozny
description: An increasingly desperate President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that, "as of this afternoon, everything in Grozny is calm," even as Chechen rebels rampaged again through the secessionist capital, destroying water lines, gas depots and heating supplies while taking control of as much as a third of the city.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;National Semiconductor Earnings Slide 59.6%
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that earnings tumbled 59.6 percent in its fiscal third quarter, hurt by lower-than-expected sales and higher costs.

title: 30-Year Mortgages Dip
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.38 percent this week, down from 7.41 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.4 percent this week, up from 5.38 percent a week earlier. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 6.87 percent, unchanged from last week.

title: Iran Tells the Europeans That It Doesn't Back Terror
description: The Government of Iran has opened a concerted effort to assure its Western trading partners that it is being wrongly tarred by the United States and Israel as being involved in the recent wave of suicide bombings in Israel.

title: Physicist and Former Diplomat Faces a Big Test: Running Queens College
description: Allen Lee Sessoms, the new president of Queens College, likes to quote Henry Kissinger, who once compared the politics of academia to that surrounding nuclear weapons.

title: Review/Fashion;Busy Bees at Prada; Versace Goes Courting
description: The image that most stayed in the mind after the Prada show, the first of today's Milan collections, was not on the runway. It was in the foyer where the show was held, where cotillions of the house's worker bees milled about. Everyone who wasn't a bee knew who was, because they were wearing a shirt, a skirt and a jacket in a hen-scratch print, in varying combinations of puce, mustard and burnt orange.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economic Statistics Give a Mixed Reading New statistics gave a mixed reading as economists awaited today's report on employment.

title: COMPANY NEWS;YAHOO INTERNET SERVICE PLAS A PUBLIC STOCK OFFERING
description: Yahoo, which operates one of the most popular directories on the World Wide Web of the Internet, announced yesterday that it would sell shares to the public for the first time. The initial public offering would be the latest in a flurry of sales by Internet-related companies over the last year. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Yahoo said that it would offer 2.6 million shares and that it expected the price to be $10 to $12 a share. Yahoo was incorporated only last April. Yahoo's directory makes Web browsing easier, and the service has more than 800,000 users a day.

title: Clinton Takes Drug Battle To a School In Maryland
description: Recalling the experiences of his own generation, and indeed his own brother, President Clinton warned a rapt audience of high school students today that illegal drugs were dangerous as well as wrong and that using them would mean forfeiting personal freedom and a promising future.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Not a New Trend
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;An Icon Who Outlived Her Work and Her Armor
description: NO INTERMISSIONS The Life of Agnes de Mille By Carol Easton Little, Brown & Company. 548 pages. $29.95.

title: NYC;State Courts Found Guilty By Jury of Peers
description: BY now, most New Yorkers except perhaps those who have been on extended vacations know that the Governor and the Mayor hold certain judges in disdain. That includes some sitting on the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals. But should you want a brief, if rough, summary of their views, try Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, who stands with them on this matter.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. OFFICE PRODUCTS AGREES TO $136 MILLION IN DEALS
description: The U.S. Office Products Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 17 companies for about $136 million in stock and cash, adding $340 million in annual revenue. U.S. Office Products, which is based in Washington, D.C., will pay for the acquisitions with 80 percent stock and 20 percent cash. The companies being acquired include several contract stationers: Radar Business Systems, which has operations in six Southeastern states; the J. Thayer Company in Portland, Ore.; Raleigh Office Supply in Raleigh, N.C.; the Carolina Office Equipment Company in Rocky Mount, N.C., and DBI Inc. in Lansing, Mich. U.S. Office Products will also buy School Specialty Inc., a distributor of school supplies that is based in Appleton, Wis., and Kentwood Office Furniture of Grand Rapids, Mich., a distributor of used, rented and remade furniture.

title: Likud Says Arafat Staged Interview to Bolster Peres
description: Accusing Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, of media manipulation, the opposition Likud party reacted angrily today to a televised interview in which an Islamic militant said recent suicide bombings were intended to help Likud defeat Mr. Peres in upcoming elections.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Pep Boys hires Cliff Freeman to enliven its image and sales.
description: THE agency that brought pizazz to peddling pizza and made buying office supplies seem like fun is facing perhaps its most challenging retail assignment: convincing consumers that shopping for automotive parts and repairs can be less painful than a root canal without anesthesia or a double feature of "Waterworld" and "Showgirls."

title: Cheering a Conviction, But Living With Scars
description: When the fireball engulfed her, Sheila Flynn barely felt the flames. It was only when she turned to a passer-by for help and saw the horror in the woman's eyes that she realized she had been burned beyond recognition. Since then, she has waited patiently for the subway bomber, Edward J. Leary, to be brought to justice.

title: Securities Bill Emerges in House As G.O.P. Drops Some Demands
description: An important House subcommittee unanimously approved a bill today to reduce regulation of the securities industry, but only after Republicans agreed to drop several of their most far-reaching proposals in the face of strong opposition from Democrats and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Braveheart 1995. Paramount. $102.32. 177 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Look to Ourselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecution of Ex-Charity Head Is Faulted
description: Lawyers for a longtime president of the United Way of America who was convicted of fraud argued in a Federal appeals court today that prosecutors relied improperly on lurid testimony about the former leader's trysts with a teen-ager to win their case.

title: U.N. Assesses Psychic Scars Left on Rwandan Children by Killings
description: For the children of Rwanda, the genocidal massacres of 1994 that left an estimated half million people dead were not horrors that happened in somebody's else house, but before their eyes, according to a report to be published on Friday.

title: Art in Review
description: Keith Haring Andre Emmerich Gallery 41 East 57th Street Through March 23

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Russian Shepherd of Mutual Funds
description: When Dmitri V. Vasiliev was a student of Marxist economics, he was taught that the stock market was a casino for the super-rich.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SEAFOOD SUPPLIER IS SOLD TO A UNIT OF CONAGRA
description: The Conagra Shrimp Companies, a unit of Conagra Inc., said yesterday that it had bought Meridian Products Inc., a seafood supplier, for undisclosed terms. Meridian, which is based in Santa Fe Springs, Calif., has annual sales of about $200 million. Along with two subsidiaries, Atlantic Meridian and Gulf Meridian, it supplies seafood worldwide. Conagra Shrimp, which is based in Tampa, Fla., packages and processes shrimp.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Musicals, Nearly Lost, Sing On

title: Strike at a G.M. Parts Plant Is Affecting Much of Company
description: General AMotors assembly plants began running out of brakes and shutting down today, as a three-day strike at two brake parts factories in Dayton, Ohio, threatened to cripple car and truck production from the world's largest auto maker.

title: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;Rare Picture of New York Republicans Shows Support for Moderate Stances
description: In the first clear snapshot of Republican primary voters in recent New York State history, a survey of people leaving polling places yesterday showed that Republicans here tend to oppose a constitutional ban on abortion, reject religious conservatism and view themselves as being near the political center.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the retirement of Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, referred incorrectly to a bill that he managed on the House floor as a freshman in 1964. It was the Economic Opportunity Act, not the Civil Rights Act.

title: Abroad at Home;The Fraying of Hope
description: Newspapers are an imperfect in strument. But at their best their rare best -- they can illuminate a profound problem that society has not perceived or understood. That is what The New York Times is doing this week in a series of extended articles called "The Downsizing of America."

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Wages of Greed
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;RTZ-CRA Profits Rose 8.3% in 1995
description: The RTZ Corporation and CRA Ltd., which combined into the world's largest mining company, reported yesterday that the merged concern had an 8.3 percent rise in after-tax profits in 1995, helped by higher aluminum prices. RTZ-CRA earned $1.29 billion, up from $1.19 billion in 1994. Sales rose 12 percent, to $8.90 billion.

title: Yale Offers Some Tradeoffs In Deadlocked Wage Talks
description: One day after clerical workers ended a monthlong strike, Yale University offered today to make some tradeoffs in its contract proposals in an effort to end a deadlock in negotiations with two of its labor unions.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;11 Indicted in Sports Betting
description: Eleven people associated with the Genovese crime family were charged in indictments with illegally operating a major sports betting ring and loansharking operation that made $1 million a year in profits, the State Attorney General's office said yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Young Guns Treat Maddux and Braves to a 2-0 Eye-Opener
description: Greg Maddux has heard the hype coming out of the Mets' spring camp some 40 miles north of here.

title: FILM REVIEW;'La Cage aux Folles,' but in South Beach
description: Shaking a layer of dust off its well-worn marabou, "La Cage aux Folles" returns to the screen as "The Birdcage," an American remake with plenty of new pizazz. This material still shows its age (as it did even in the 1979 French-language version), but it has been tarted up with giddy ingenuity.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Comedy by Almodovar Shows He's Cheered Up
description: The Flower of My Secret" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 13. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Executive Changes
description: CHATCOM INC., Chatsworth, Calif., named James B. Mariner president and chief executive, succeeding Gerald R. Sayer, who will continue to serve on Chatcom's board and executive committee. Mr. Mariner was most recently president of Turnaround Management Corp., Los Angeles, a consulting group specializing in turnarounds for technology companies.

title: Lonrho Founder Is Selling Stake
description: Roland W. Rowland, founder of the conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C., is selling his stake in the company to the German executive who ousted him last year, it was announced today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Three Compete For Four A's Award
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York, which is known as the Four A's, has named three finalists to compete for the 1996 John O'Toole Award, presented to marketers for consistently outstanding campaigns over a period of time.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Panel Backs Gas Detector Bill
description: Thanks to alarms set off by carbon monoxide detectors, an apartment complex in Fort Lee was safely evacuated twice in the last week. Yesterday, the Senate Community Affairs Committee unanimously approved a bill requiring new homes and apartments to be equipped with devices to detect the poisonous gas.

title: CHRONICLE
description: OLIVER STONE, RICHARD DONNER and LAUREN SHULER-DONNER, film makers who have all worked in New Mexico, have taken a stand in behalf of elderly buffalo in that state.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Little Change For Treasuries As Gains Melt
description: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, paring early gains made on a report showing a rise in weekly jobless claims.

title: MERGER OF GRUG GIANTS: THE SPECULATION;Value of Zeneca Soars, in Part Because It's Viewed as a Target
description: The American depository receipts for shares in Zeneca Group P.L.C. of Britain jumped 7.4 percent yesterday after two of Switzerland's three big drug makers, Sandoz A.G. and Ciba-Geigy A.G., agreed to merge.

title: SWIMMING;A Little Breather Was All He Needed
description: Tom Dolan is the world record-holder and world champion in swimming's 400-meter individual medley, so there was great concern in mid-January when his energy level plummeted and his standing heart rate shot up to 90 beats a minute.

title: 9-Year-Old Accused of Stalking Schoolmate
description: A 9-year-old boy who left a phone message for a 10-year-old girl, telling her, "I want to be your lover," has been accused of violating the state's anti-stalking law, his lawyer said today.

title: POLITICS: NASSAU COUNTY;Science Of Politics, L.I. Style, Prevails
description: He rested his cigar in an ashtray. He laid out the contents of his pockets on the huge mahogany desk: the loose change, the cellular telephone, the rosary beads. Then the leader of the Nassau County Republican Party eased himself into a chair.

title: Borrowing Authority of U.S. Is Extended for Two Weeks
description: Congress and the White House resumed their six-month struggle over the shape of the 1996 Federal budget today with a rare agreement: to avert a looming default on the Federal debt by extending the Government's borrowing authority for two weeks, through March 29.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Playboy Wins Restraining Order On Law Blocking Explicit Shows
description: A Federal judge blocked today part of a new telecommunications law requiring cable companies to block audio and video of sexually explicit programs.

title: Critic's Choice/Film;Chance, Fate and the Bible
description: It would be a mistake to think of "The Decalogue," Krzysztof Kieslowski's dramatic series of made-for-television films inspired by the Ten Commandments, as cinematic interpretations of biblical teaching. These 10 hourlong movies, which the Film Society of Lincoln Center is showing today through Thursday at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, are elliptical stories that draw no easy moral conclusions.

title: Fans in the Stands Are Boys Again
description: There are some things you know in life: that the sun will rise in the morning, the city will swelter in the summertime and for a few days every year, Ron Dicamillo and friends will put down their briefcases, play hooky from work and saunter to Madison Square Garden to drink, cheer and watch a marathon of slam dunks and fast breaks.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Economy Shrank in 4th Quarter
description: Germany's economy shrank in the fourth quarter of last year, the Government said yesterday. The economy shrank five-tenths of 1 percent from a quarter earlier, when growth was flat. Growth for all of 1995 was 1.9 percent, the Federal Statistics Office in Wiesbaden said.

title: A Correction: Most Overpaid Executives
description: A chart in Business Day on Feb. 22 with an article about the 1994 compensation of chief executives at small companies included an erroneous entry for the chief executive ranked in a compensation study as the most overpaid at a midsized company. The chief executive ranked as the most overpaid in that category was Herbert J. Siegel of Chris-Craft industries, not Robert Cohn of the Octel Communications Corporation. In addition, the original chart listed only the total compensation of the four chief executives in four categories, giving an incomplete picture of how they were paid. A corrected and expanded chart appears below.

title: The Marrying Kind
description: Same-sex marriage? The idea is, in one sense, breathtaking. Since the word "marriage" has always denoted a male-female pairing, can so fundamental an institution be redefined so radically, so quickly?

title: Planes Collide; 6 Are Dead
description: Two small planes collided in a fireball and crashed into the sea about a mile offshore today. The body of one man was found, and five other people were missing. Lieut. George Eldredge of the Coast Guard said both planes sank. A search was suspended until Friday morning because of the high waves and wind.

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;In Florida, Dole Plays Cuba Card
description: Mourning the deaths of four Cuban-American pilots who were shot down by Cuba last month, Senator Bob Dole today called for the Justice Department to indict the "murderers" who were responsible and try them in an American court.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Military Suffers, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling Sharpens Assisted-Suicide Debate
description: In striking down a Washington State law that made assisted suicide a felony -- and strongly upholding individuals' right to decide "how and when to die" -- a Federal appeals court has squarely taken sides in the nation's difficult, and increasingly divisive, debate over the right to die.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Banning Bomb-Making Guide
description: It is against the law to build a bomb, but teachers are not barred from showing students how to do it. The Senate Education Committee passed a bill yesterday that would outlaw bomb-building instruction. The measure was spurred by an incident last year in which a Vernon High School teacher allowed his students to watch a video showing fellow classmates building and detonating pipe bombs, the A.P. reported. Dennis O'Leary, the Sussex County Prosecutor, tried to charge the teacher, but discovered that what he did was legal.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Iran's Economic Plight Casts a Pall on Today's Vote
description: Outside a state-run department store here, a banner reminded customers of their "Islamic obligation" to vote on Friday. But as Malyam Fahrae lugged a bag of the rice whose price has tripled since last summer, she complained that Iran's Government had left her and other middle-class Teheran residents with other priorities.

title: Pinhas Alter, 69, Israel Orthodox Leader
description: Pinhas Menachem Alter, one of Israel's rigorously Orthodox rabbis, died today in Jerusalem. He was 69.

title: About Real Estate;Office Plan Scrapped for Elderly Project
description: What had been planned as an office development within the 2,200-acre Princeton Forrestal Center is being transformed into an $80 million continuing-care complex for people age 73 and older.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Management Shifts Bring Name Change
description: Kaprielian/O'Leary in New York is being renamed O'Leary Clarke & Partners to reflect a reorganization involving senior management.

title: E.P.A. Accuses A Company Of Distortion
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that the Ethyl Corporation, in newspaper advertisements, had distorted the E.P.A.'s position about a gasoline additive the company had introduced over the agency's objections.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Of a Pageant of Miracles And an Eye for Apples
description: Not that you've probably thought about it a lot, but what do you imagine a singing apple looks like?

title: The Quarterfinals In Bridge Tourney
description: Quarterfinal play in the Vanderbilt Knockout Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals began here today.

title: POLITICS: NEW YORK;DOLE IS VICTOR IN NEW YORK, CONTINUING PRIMARY SURGE; RIVALS VOW TO STAY IN RACE
description: Senator Bob Dole sailed to an overwhelming primary victory in New York State yesterday, surmounting a vigorous challenge by Steve Forbes and cementing his standing as the commanding favorite to win the Republican Party's Presidential nomination.

title: A Slimmer 110 Livingston Street
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew recognized during his first days in New York City that the Board of Education bureaucracy had become a symbol of dysfunction and that closing down its headquarters at 110 Livingston Street -- while shifting staff elsewhere -- would make for a potent emblem of change. Shutting down the office entirely may not be possible; some central functions will always be needed. But this week, Mr. Crew took his first cut at the bureaucratic underbrush. His plan, even though thin on specifics, moves in the right direction.

title: Hubble Provides First Glimpses of the Surface of Distant Pluto
description: Astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope have been able to get the first, tantalizing glimpses of far-away Pluto's icy surface.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;High-Tech Contracting
description: To the Editor:

title: BASKETBALL;UMass Maintains Control
description: The University of Massachusetts had a first-round bye in the Atlantic 10 tournament, so Carmelo Travieso, Rigoberto Nunez, Edgar and Giddel Padilla and Coach John Calipari spent part of Wednesday at the Roberto Clemente Middle School.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTEL LOSES APPEAL OF CASE AGAINST CYRIX
description: The Intel Corporation has lost a Federal court appeal in a case that challenged the right of a rival chip maker, the Cyrix Corporation, to have its products manufactured by I.B.M. and SGS-Thomson Microelectronics. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit this week rejected the argument by Intel that its licensing agreements with I.B.M. and SGS-Thomson barred them from using their production operations to make chips for Cyrix. The decision marks the latest in a series of setbacks for Intel in a long-running patent fight against Cyrix, which has tried to challenge Intel's dominance in the market for the microprocessors that control the operations of personal computers.

title: ART REVIEW;Too Jewish? Jewish Artists Ponder
description: One of the videos in the show "Too Jewish," opening on Sunday at the Jewish Museum, tells the story of the Jewish girl who asks her mother why Jews don't wear stars, the way her Christian friends wear crosses. Her mother responds, "Honey, why advertise?"

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Wessex Water to Bid For South West
description: Wessex Water P.L.C. said yesterday that it wanted to bid for a neighboring utility, South West Water P.L.C., in what would be the largest consolidation in the British water and sewage industry since the Government sold it piecemeal in 1989. A marriage of South West with Wessex would be the first among Britain's 10 major water and sewage companies. The two combined provide water to 2.6 million people and sewage services to 4 million in the southwest of England.

title: U.S. Says Envoy to Ireland Wrongly Punished 2 Colleagues
description: Jean Kennedy Smith, the United States Ambassador to Ireland, was reprimanded this week by Secretary of State Warren Christopher for retaliating against two subordinates who questioned her recommendation in 1994 to grant a visa to the I.R.A.'s political leader.

title: Tough Law On Sentences Is Criticized
description: Two years after California's tough "three strikes and you're out" law went into effect, twice as many defendants have been imprisoned under the law for marijuana possession as for murder, rape and kidnapping combined, according to a new study.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Multiple Pleasure' Tanya Bonakdar Gallery 130 Prince Street SoHo Through March 16

title: MERGER OF DRUG GIANTS;How Big Is Big?
description: The proposed merger of Sandoz Ltd. and Ciba-Geigy Ltd. is one of the biggest combinations in business history. But estimates of just how big the transaction is vary widely. Here is a look at how various parties value the deal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a motion for a new trial for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega mischaracterized what his lawyers said about efforts by the Cali drug-trafficking organization in Colombia to influence a witness at the general's first trial, in 1992. At a hearing, the lawyers said the Government should have known that the drug cartel would try to influence the witness to testify, not that the cartel would try to influence his testimony.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Muriel's Wedding 1994. Miramax. $100.97. Laser disk, $39.99. 105 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Progressive Caucus
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New Campaigns From Nonprofits
description: Two nonprofit organizations are making advertising plans.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Whither Education?
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM REVIEW;Deadly Plot by a Milquetoast Villain
description: JOEL and Ethan Coen's new film is called "Fargo" even though most of it is set in Minnesota. Apparently the title is about something beyond geography. Testing limits, breaking boundaries, going too far: the Coen brothers' eclectic films, ranging from the great ("Barton Fink") to the inscrutable ("The Hudsucker Proxy"), always manage to make that their guiding principle and secret weapon. They're road movies headed for the tricky unknown, and "Fargo" finds the Coens roaming exuberantly across their favorite terrain.

title: No Headline
description: It's a time to do male bonding. Get away from the old ladies, burp and drink."

title: 25 and Under
description: Many neighborhoods in New York City have a Latin restaurant, usually Cuban or Dominican, where the cafe con leche is half the price of the cappuccino across the street and the forcefully flavored food is served in portions so big you can barely walk after dinner. In many ways, Calidad Latina, which opened in Chelsea four months ago, is typical of the best of these restaurants, with the bonus of food that displays a subtlety rare in places that specialize in humble ingredients and full-bore flavors.

title: Sports of The Times;Sheffer Has Other Things On His Mind
description: THE games are the best time. The games block out what is happening back home in Israel. It has never been worse in the three years since Doron Sheffer came to the University of Connecticut to play basketball.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Feb. 22 with an article about the 1994 compensation of chief executives at small companies included an erroneous entry for the chief executive ranked in a compensation study as the most overpaid at a midsized company. The chief executive ranked as the most overpaid in that category was Herbert J. Siegel of Chris-Craft Industries, not Robert Cohn of the Octel Communications Corporation.

title: Home Video
description: Junior Critics

title: Man With AIDS Tested Negative, U.S. Says
description: Federal health officials yesterday reported a rare case of an individual with AIDS who persistently tested negative for the AIDS virus. The man, who lives in Utah, was a longtime blood plasma donor, but an investigation found no evidence that his plasma had infected anyone, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in its weekly report.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Senator STROM THURMOND, Republican of South Carolina, passes a milestone today: at the age of 93 years and 94 days, he breaks the record for the oldest person ever to serve in the Senate. The mark has until now been held by Theodore Green of Rhode Island, who retired from the Senate in 1961.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Boy Takes a Gun to Class
description: A 6-year-old boy brought a 9-millimeter handgun to class yesterday, and was trying to unload it when it discharged, the police said. No one in the classroom at Our Lady of Good Counsel School was injured. The police charged the boy with possession of a weapon and later released him into his grandmother's custody, Detective Daniel Collins, a police spokesman, said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Satellite Order By News Corp. For Direct TV
description: The MCI Communications Corporation and the News Corporation said today that in a move to begin direct television broadcasting, they had ordered two high-powered satellites from the Loral Corporation at a cost of more than $400 million.

title: BASKETBALL;The Wolfpack Strikes Quickly
description: Danny Strong scored 10 of North Carolina State's points during a 19-0 game-opening run in the first round of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament as the Wolfpack handled Florida State, 80-65, tonight.

title: BASKETBALL;St. John's Enters Off Season With an Uncertain Outlook
description: The subdued voices and the blank looks in the dressing room at the end of the corridor at Madison Square Garden said more than the members of the St. John's Red Storm could at the end of the season. As the players and coaches departed, they walked past a picture from another time, with Lou Carnesecca punching the Garden air while Brian Mahoney, his longtime assistant, stood behind him.

title: The Politics of Layoffs: In Search of a Message
description: Last fall, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, convened a meeting of about a dozen of the party's top political consultants to get some advice. Polls showed increasing disillusionment with the Republican Congress, but little evidence of increased support for Democrats. What positive message, Mr. Dodd wanted to know, could the party use to win over the growing numbers of disgruntled Americans?

title: POLITICS: STRATEGY;How the White House Sizes Up Dole
description: For the Clinton White House, the prospect of Bob Dole as the Republican Presidential nominee is both good news and bad.

title: Inverness Journal;Lost and Found: An African King in Scotland?
description: Scots were skeptical when Chief Nicholas Gcaleka arrived here in February from Butterworth, South Africa, proclaiming that a hurricane spirit had sent him to find the skull of a Xhosa king who, according to legend, had been decapitated by a Scot in the early 1800's.

title: U.S. Judge Blocks State's Plan to Release Names and Addresses of SexOffenders
description: A Federal judge yesterday blocked New York State's plans to release the names and addresses of convicted sex offenders through local police departments and a "900" telephone number that officials had planned to begin operating today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BUFFETT TO TAKE SHARES IN MERGED DISNEY-CAPITAL CITIES
description: In a vote of confidence for the newly merged company, the multibillionaire investor Warren E. Buffett said yesterday that he wanted shares of the Walt Disney Company in exchange for his investment company's $2.5 billion stake in Capital Cities/ABC Inc. Disney is buying the media company for $19 billion in cash and stock, but it gave shareholders some latitude on how they would be paid. Yesterday was the deadline for making the choices. The standard selection was a share in Disney stock and $65 in cash for each Capital Cities share. But shareholders could also request to be paid all in stock or all in cash, subject to certain limits. Mr. Buffett controlled 20 million shares, or 13 percent, of Capital Cities/ABC stock through the Omaha-based reinsurer and investment company Berkshire Hathaway Inc.

title: Mayor Is Said to Reject Bratton's Planned Personnel Shifts
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has rejected several top-level Police Department personnel moves proposed by Commissioner William J. Bratton, further straining their often tense relationship, senior police officials say.

title: David Gebhard, 68, an Expert On California Architecture, Dies
description: David Gebhard, an architectural historian who specialized in the architecture of California, died on Sunday while bicycling near his home. He was 68 and lived in Santa Barbara.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;The World of 1970
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Warwick Baker To Buy Back Stake
description: Warwick Baker & Fiore in New York has agreed to buy back from Lopex P.L.C. in London the 40 percent stake in the agency that Lopex has owned since 1979. Terms of the agreement between Warwick Baker and Lopex, which is an investment company with interests in communications, were not disclosed; it is subject to approval by Lopex shareholders by the end of April.

title: Organized Labor's Hope for a Comeback
description: When AT&T announced in January that it would lay off 40,000 employees, the company's biggest union, the Communications Workers of America, had not been given a clue. But when another telephone company, Nynex, wanted to sharply cut costs, the union agreed to use its influence with state regulators only after signing a contract that preserved the jobs of nearly all of Nynex's 40,000 blue-collar workers.

title: Forfeiting Fairness
description: When the nation's highest court displays indifference to unfair actions by government against people who have done nothing wrong, it invites cynicism about the institution and the justice system generally. That was the Supreme Court's dubious achievement when it ruled 5 to 4 this week against an unusually sympathetic plaintiff whose cause had attracted wide interest.

title: Market Surges Near Close, With Dow Climbing 11.92
description: As Wall Street awaited today's report on February unemployment, the stock market marked time for most of the session yesterday before surging near the close.

title: Power Talks for Long Island
description: Obedient to Gov. George Pataki's initiative, the Long Island Power Authority, a New York State agency, has voted to open negotiations with the Long Island Lighting Company over a state takeover that could give some relief to Islanders, burdened with the highest utility rates in the continental United States. The decision is an important step but one that leaves wide open all the complex questions about Lilco's future.

title: ART REVIEW;Dubuffet and the Abstraction He Found in Nature
description: It's hard to know if Jean Dubuffet was a sponge or a sieve, if he absorbed ideas from his contemporaries or had so many of his own that he continually leaked them into the surrounding atmosphere. Either way -- and it seems to have been a combination of the two -- he was an exceptionally busy artist, and no more than during the 1950's.

title: World News Briefs;Zairian Troops, Unpaid, Lift Camp Blockade
description: Zairian troops have withdrawn from around Rwandan refugee camps in eastern Zaire, officials said today.

title: FILM REVIEW;Three Pets' Second Excellent Adventure
description: When Chance, a pizza-loving bulldog from the suburbs of San Francisco, has his heart broken by a streetwise city stray named Delilah, he voices his misery in words that any child could understand. "It's like getting a bath, missing dinner and going to the vet all rolled into one!" he laments.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Feb. 20 about a review for the advertising account of the Naya brand of spring water marketed by Nora Beverages U.S.A. included an agency erroneously among those competing for the account, because of information supplied by Nora. The Progressive Image Group in New York did not participate in the review.

title: In America;A Job Myth Downsized
description: Like a hit tune played incessantly on top-40 radio, we keep hearing that technological advances, especially computers, are throwing wages out of whack and otherwise making life miserable for American workers. It's a sad song. It tells us that the job crunch and the growing inequality in wages are, to a great extent, the natural result of the demand in a high-tech economy for highly educated, highly skilled workers. The dopes who can't cope are necessarily left behind.

title: At the Clubs, Murmurs and Ambient Music
description: SHORTLY after midnight at a recent party in a midtown Manhattan loft, Howard Goldkrand sat slumped on a couch. Below his seat was a speaker, which rumbled and reverberated through the sofa cushions as a disk jockey known as Spooky mixed records full of swooshing electronics and heavy, heavy bass. "You know what this is?" Mr. Goldkrand asked, looking up happily. "This is vibrational medicine, man."

title: U.N. Prosecutor Asks Serbs to Hand Over War-Crimes Suspect
description: The United Nations prosecutor of war crimes in the former Yugoslavia asked Serbian officials today to hand over a soldier who is suspected of taking part in the massacre of thousands of Muslims last year in Srebrenica.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Works on Paper' Seventh Regiment Armory Park Avenue and 67th Street Today and tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Admission: $10; $20 for three-day ticket.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-12

title: For Children
description: 'Tale of Princess Kaguya' TriBeCa Performing Arts Center Borough of Manhattan Community College 199 Chambers Street (212) 346-8510 Ages 7 and up Tonight and tomorrow

title: A Freer Vietnam Brings Rise in Violent Crime
description: When Tran Ngoc Bich, a 19-year-old honor student, was found bludgeoned to death in her own bedroom, apparently the victim of a burglar, it was a brutal example of the rise in violent crime in Vietnam.

title: World News Briefs;Russia Backs Treaty Against Nuclear Tests
description: Russia today endorsed a global treaty to ban underground nuclear tests, but stopped short of supporting the West's goal of banning even the tiniest release of nuclear energy.

title: Art in Review
description: Bill Jacobson Julie Saul Gallery 560 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through March 23

title: POLITICS: TEXAS;Dole Stands Tall in State Where Prize Is Huge
description: As George Bush might say if he were running for President this year, the action should now be switching from the Big Apple to the Big Enchilada -- to Texas, with its 123 Republican delegates, the most of any state so far in the battle for the Republican nomination.

title: Spot Checks Are Set For Pension Plans
description: The Government will begin making spot checks to insure that companies are telling employees whether they have failed to put enough money in their pension plans.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;How Ansel Adams Put Nature in Focus
description: Ansel Adams could be a maniac about clarity. In "Focus: Memoirs of a Life in Photography," Beaumont Newhall, the first curator of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, tells a story about Adams, who was helping him with a photography exhibition at the museum. Adams was looking at one of Laszlo Moholy-Nagy's abstract photographs. "Ansel didn't like Moholy-Nagy's work at all and in particular didn't like this photograph," Newhall recalls. "He felt it was too poor a print to exhibit." So he got permission to make a clear print of it. The new print, Newhall says, "was full of details and textures not found in the original print -- but it was no longer an abstraction." Clarity obscured it.

title: Police Find the Gun Used to Kill Deli Owner
description: Detectives yesterday recovered the gun used to kill the owner of the Second Avenue Deli on Monday, the police said.

title: FILM REVIEW;Screens Tests for All, And for Only a Small Fee
description: Giuseppe Tornatore's "Star Maker" is an hommage to cinema and Sicily, both well worthy of such fond attention. Beyond that, it's not the coherent narrative it appears to be, since the screenplay by Mr. Tornatore ("Cinema Paradiso") and Fabio Rinaudo isn't much more than an occasion for stringing together anecdotes and gentle observations. The film tours Sicily in the service of a pleasant conceit and falters only when it rises to a histrionic pitch. Mr. Tornatore does a far better job of evoking his homeland than of persuading the audience that his characters have anything important at stake.

title: Market Place;Deere seems poised to ride positive trends in farming.
description: AFTER nearly a decade of the blues in the heartland, there's a lot of optimism rising along with the corn and wheat in the Midwest. Commodity prices are climbing, as is demand for American grain exports. Farm income is going up. And legislation making its way through Congress promises to bring more acreage under cultivation and more dollars into farmers' pockets.

title: Restaurants
description: Mario, Marco and Mauro Maccioni, sons of Sirio of Le Cirque, seem to know me. In my three undisguised visits to their lively new restaurant, Osteria del Circo (pronounced CHEER-co), they have been extremely solicitous, popping up every few minutes to make sure things were going smoothly. When I ordered a sold-out bottle of wine, one of the brothers instantly appeared with another, more expensive bottle. Another night, a brother approached as I sat near the raucous bar, waiting for my guests to arrive. "Are you sure you wouldn't like to go to your table now?" he asked anxiously. The table was waiting and Mr. Maccioni whisked my coat away.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SALE OF FUND AMERICAN UNIT TO MELLON HITS HURDLES
description: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. of Norwich, Vt., said yesterday that talks about the sale of its mortgage unit to Mellon Mortgage, a unit of the Mellon Bank Corporation, were going more slowly than expected. In December, Mellon had proposed in a letter of intent to buy all of Fund American's mortgage subsidiary, the Source One Mortgage Services Corporation. Mellon "has revised the scope and other terms of the transaction it is willing to discuss," Fund American said in a statement. It added: "Fund American is continuing discussions with Mellon and other parties. There can be no assurance any transaction will be negotiated or consummated."

title: Manor Care to Spin Off Choice Hotels Unit
description: Manor Care Inc., the nursing-home and hotel giant, said yesterday that it would spin off its hotel business into a separate corporation in which it would retain no ownership interest. Analysts said the lodging unit, Choice Hotels International, could be worth almost $1 billion.

title: Yet Another Storm Delays Rest for the Winter-Weary
description: A stinging mix of ice pellets and snow snarled commuting for residents of the New York metropolitan region yesterday, as layers of crusting ice sent cars spinning out of control, causing pileups and intermittently forcing the closing of several bridges and highways.

title: Downsizing: The Trashing of America's Soul;Do Dropouts Count?
description: To the Editor:

title: What the Dying Really Need
description: When the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled on Wednesday that terminally ill, mentally competent patients have a constitutional right to physician-assisted suicide, advocates of the right to die movement hailed it as a civil rights triumph. That is true, but the celebration must be tempered with respect, caution and careful planning.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bigger Prize for Swimmers
description: Last year, participants who attended the Atlantic City Ocean Marathon Swim complained that the purse was too meager and threatened to withdraw if the prize was not increased to $25,000. Last-minute sponsorship saved the 23-mile event. This year, the marathon, known as the Around the Island swim, will become the richest event of its kind, said Frank D'Alonzo, the executive director. The Aug. 3 purse will grow to $40,000, the A.P. reported. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Author of Immigration Measure in Senate Drops Most Provisions onForeign Workers
description: In a victory for business leaders, the author of the Senate immigration bill said today that he would drop almost all provisions on foreign workers, measures that American companies had said would hurt their ability to recruit skilled employees from abroad.

title: Man Convicted In Bombings On Subway
description: Edward J. Leary, a computer analyst from suburban New Jersey who lost his job and carried his rage into New York City's subway, was convicted yesterday of firebombing two trains, as a Manhattan jury rejected his claim that antidepressants had driven him insane.

title: BASKETBALL;Villanova Is Fueled By Return Of Kittles
description: Villanova's successful basketball season re-established a positive direction last night. Kerry Kittles, back from his self-imposed exile, was in a white and blue Wildcat uniform. As the Wildcats prepare themselves for tournament time, the connection has never seemed more important.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPRINT CORP., Westwood, Kan., the long-distance telephone company, completed the spinoff of 360degrees Communications Co., Chicago, formerly Sprint Cellular.

title: The Bludgeoning of Taiwan
description: China crosses a new and dangerous threshold today by firing unarmed missiles into the waters surrounding Taiwan's two principal ports. Bludgeoning Taiwan into compliance with Beijing's wishes may satisfy some craving among China's leaders for a show of strength, but it risks badly damaging China's relations with the United States and the rest of the world.

title: Stake in McDonald's May Be Buffett Boon
description: The multibillionaire investor Warren E. Buffett may have added more than another hundred million dollars to his portfolio if he still owns the stake of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the McDonald's Corporation that he held at the end of 1994.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION TO CUT UP TO 1,000 WORKERS
description: The Overnite Transportation Company, a trucking concern owned by the Union Pacific Corporation, plans to lay off up to 1,000 workers nationwide, beginning on Monday, because of declining traffic and depressed freight rates. The cuts are to occur at all levels of the company. Overnite, which is based in Richmond, employs 14,000 workers at more than 170 terminals nationwide. It is one of the largest haulers that consolidate loads from several customers aboard one truck. Such companies, known as less-than-truckload carriers, have been squeezed financially in the last year as some operators have driven down rates.

title: Plan Would Split Superstore Into Three
description: In what might be described as a kind of emperor's-new-clothes legal maneuver, the city's Department of Buildings is considering classifying the sprawling new Fairway supermarket in Harlem as not one but three stores, so it can operate legally under zoning laws.

title: Big Board's Profits Climb
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had income of $56.7 million last year, nearly 29 percent higher that the $44 million it earned the previous year. Revenues were $500.8 million, about 11 percent higher than the $452.3 million in 1994. For the fourth quarter, the exchange had profits of $13.5 million on revenues of $136.1 million, compared with earnings of $1.4 million on $114.7 million a year earlier.

title: Art in Review
description: Craigie Horsfield Barbara Gladstone Gallery 99 Greene Street, near Prince Street SoHo Through March 16

title: POP REVIEW;A Rare Glimpse of Yoko Ono, Reaching Far Beyond Words
description: Don't kill me! No, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no! Help me, help me, help me!" Yoko Ono was wailing and shrieking those words, and sounds that weren't words at all, while her band banged out a one-chord hard-rock crescendo. Such primal emotion, seized and sustained, was the core of Ms. Ono's concert at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night. She doesn't perform often, but as she stood in a spotlight surrounded by darkness, her body contorted and her voice moving from childlike peeps to tortured grunts and cries, she was spellbinding.

title: FILM REVIEW;Impish Tricks In Edgy Style
description: Chungking Express" was shown as part of the 1994 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 26, 1994. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: The Four Brontes: Myth vs. Reality
description: ONE of the more poignant curiosities of English literature has journeyed across the Atlantic to be put on display in Manhattan this season. Glowing ethereally within the protective sheathing of a glass case at the Pierpont Morgan Library is a pair of neatly stitched, lightly soiled, finely creased white gloves, which lie alongside each other like precious ivories rescued from a vanished civilization. The gloves are remarkable for their minuteness -- they are less than half as broad as a modern female hand, and their fingers are scarcely thicker than a pencil -- but much more so for their association: these few inches of kid once covered the hand that held the pen that wrote "Jane Eyre."

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Opel Statement Is Due Today
description: Adam Opel A.G. said today that it would make a major announcement on Friday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STERLING COMMERCE SHARES CLIMB IN FIRST TRADING DAY
description: The shares of Sterling Commerce Inc. jumped yesterday in their first day of trading as investors bet on the company's technology to provide secure transactions over computer networks. Sterling's shares closed at $29 in trading of 8.7 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, a former unit of Sterling Software Inc., sold 12 million shares at $24 to raise $288 million. Sterling Commerce writes software for Electronic Data Interchange, a set of technical standards that lets companies execute transactions and transfer documents electronically. Dallas Software, which writes software to manage computer networks, retains 84 percent of Sterling Commerce's 75 million shares outstanding after the sale.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: A Fight Over Baby's Dignity and Death
description: Although the tumor pressing on Brianne Rideout's brain stem had robbed her of all of her reflexes and plunged her into a coma, her parents still clutched a sliver of hope.

title: School Board Inquiry Over Press Aide Job
description: The chief investigator for the Board of Education said yesterday she was trying to determine whether Josh Plaut, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, had intervened to get his girlfriend a job in the board's press office.

title: Of Royal Lineage and Dripping Daggers
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: GOLF;A Calm Herron Expands Lead
description: This was supposed to be the day the rookie succumbed to the magnitude of it all, the day the nasty Eagle Trace winds came up off the Everglades and blew Tim Herron away like a helium balloon.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTEK IN PACT TO BUY COMMUNICATIONS BUSINESSES
description: The Intek Diversified Corporation agreed yesterday to buy certain wireless communications businesses from Simmonds Capital Ltd. and Securicor Group P.L.C. for stock valued at more than $237 million at Thursday's closing price plus an undisclosed amount of cash. The transactions will combine Intek's Roamer One air time services business with the United States land mobile radio business of Simmonds's Midland International Corporation unit, as well as the radio communications unit of Securicor Group. Intek, a Los Angeles-based company that is building a nationwide mobile radio network, will buy a license to use the Midland name for 2.5 million Intek shares.

title: Nelahozeves Journal;From Czech-American Roots to Riches
description: In the late 1980's, William Lobkowicz was just a well-educated young Bostonian from a comfortable home who had a promising career in real estate. His surname suggested a Slavic background, but nothing else hinted at the strange life that awaited him.

title: New! Original! Nonfat! Fat-Free!
description: Most consumers think of the supermarket as a place to buy food. That's true. But it is also a noisy political arena, a rough-and-tumble democracy in which the customer casts a vote and the packages on the shelves try to win it. Like real politicians, packages use words to persuade. And because they have as little as a second to make their pitch, they are masters of the tiny, tiny sound bite.

title: To Be 18 Years Old And Homeless
description: I spent the first 21 years of my life in foster care in New York City. After living with five foster families, I "graduated" from the system in 1991. Since then, I have also graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton and Columbia Law School, and have achieved the dream I nurtured since I was 10 years old. I am an advocate for children in foster care.

title: Forbes Loses Lone Delegate on Recheck
