description: For a few hours, Frances Gallonty was the $2 million delegate, the only one picked up by Steve Forbes in the New York Republican Presidential primary despite all the money he spent on the race.

title: Giuliani Says Police Moves Are Up to Him
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he routinely involved himself in top-level policy and personnel decisions concerning the Police Department, and had no qualms about overruling the Police Commissioner.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ICL of Britain to Quit PC Business After Loss
description: ICL P.L.C., the British computer unit of Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan, said yesterday that it was quitting the personal computer business after a 1995 loss, in a further setback for Europe's struggling PC industry. ICL, which is about 80 percent owned by Fujitsu, will "retain about a 20 percent stake in the PC business, but Fujitsu is taking over the operations," an ICL spokeswoman said.

title: BASKETBALL;A Battle of the Big East: It's UConn vs. Georgetown
description: They are still just erratic enough to make their coach frown. John Thompson tends to frown loudly, especially in March, when months of effort are suddenly defined forever. But there was far more satisfaction than criticism last night from the coach of the Georgetown Hoyas, when Victor Page had a wondrous coming-out party, Allen Iverson exhibited his controlled brilliance and their teammates did what had to be done.

title: Corrections
description: A movie review in Weekend yesterday about the Italian film "The Star Maker" referred incorrectly to the eligibility of two other Italian films for an Oscar nomination in the best foreign film category. "Lamerica" and "Il Postino" were eligible last year, not this year; "The Star Maker" is a nominee this year.

title: Pro-Chechen Hijacker of Turkish Jet Surrenders in Germany
description: A pro-Chechen gunman hijacked a Turkish Cypriot airliner to Munich late Friday, but released the 109 hostages early today. A Munich airport spokesman, Hans-Joachim Bues, said the 101 passengers and 8 crew members were safe.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Interest Rate Trimmed Again, to 6%
description: The Bank of England reduced its minimum lending rate yesterday to 6 percent from 6.25 percent, the third rate cut in four months. Commercial banks responded by lowering the interest rates they charge to home buyers and other borrowers.

title: Jean Kennedy Smith's Excessive Zeal
description: American diplomacy owes much of its energy as well as some of its mishaps to the service of non-professionals. Both effects are apparent in Dublin, where the United States is represented by Jean Kennedy Smith, sister of Senator Edward Kennedy. By all accounts, Mrs. Smith has brought enthusiasm, fresh ideas and political leverage to her post. But she has also run afoul of rules meant to protect the integrity of career diplomats.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and headline yesterday about the Clinton Adminstration's policy regarding Federal programs that set aside some contracts for companies owned by women or members of minorities misstated the extent of the policy change in some editions . The Administration is imposing a three-year moratorium on any new set-aside programs, not on existing programs.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;St. John's Unaware of Mahoney Plans
description: The president of St. John's University, responding to a report on ESPN, said last night that he was unaware of any plans by Brian Mahoney to resign as the school's head basketball coach. "I'm not aware of that, and that is not a 'No comment,' " the Rev. Donald Harrington said at Madison Square Garden, where he was attending the Big East tournament. He declined to discuss Mahoney's status further.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reed Elsevier Defers Sale of a Book Business
description: Reed Elsevier P.L.C. said yesterday that it would defer sale of its consumer books business because the offers it received were not enough. The company said it still planned to sell the unit, which publishes adult and children's books including "Winnie the Pooh" and "Thomas the Tank Engine."

title: SWIMMING;Late Kick Puts Evans On Team
description: Janet Evans let it be known that she had no plans to leave the Olympic swimming trials quickly or quietly.

title: Journal;Dole's Unpaid Debt
description: Now that Pat Buchanan has been reduced to waving a pitchfork from the sidelines, both the Republic and the Republican Party have been saved from his take-no-prisoners prosecution of the culture wars, right?

title: Express Track for Jobs;Transit Tech Updates Vocational High With Courses on Modern Trains
description: John Thomas, 18 years old, wearing a blue hard hat, stood atop a ladder with a circuit tester, prodding the wiring of an old red subway car, incongruously parked in an outsize classroom at the High School of Transit Technology. The problem: a train is stalled in a crowded subway station. The assignment: find the dead circuit.

title: POLITICS;Excerpts From Dole Speech on Faith and Family, the Budget and the Future
description: Following are excerpts from a speech Senator Bob Dole gave late last month before the Christian Coalition in Columbia, S.C., as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: BASKETBALL;Christ the King's Aim Is Title
description: Christ the King (24-0), the nation's second-ranked team, heads into tomorrow's Catholic High Schools Athletic Association intersectional quarterfinals as the overwhelming favorite to repeat as the Class A city champion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nuclear Agency Threatens To Close Connecticut Plants The Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave New England's largest utility 30 days to show that two reactors it operates in Connecticut are properly equipped for emergencies. If the company fails to prove their safety, the commission threatened to close them. The company, Northeast Utilities, is already under fire for safety problems at another reactor.

title: Of Royal Lineage and Dripping Daggers
description: To the Editor:

title: Breakthrough for Public Justice
description: In an act of judicial independence, Federal District Judge Robert Ward allowed television cameras from the Court TV cable network into his Manhattan courtroom on Monday to broadcast the opening hearing in a lawsuit seeking a court takeover of the city's child welfare agency. It was the first time that cameras have been allowed in a Federal courtroom since 1994, when the Judicial Conference of the United States, the main policy-making body for Federal courts, voted to bar cameras from Federal trial and appellate courts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about rail safety incorrectly summarized the Congressional testimony of the Federal Railroad Administrator on Wednesday about a train that derailed on Feb. 1 in Cajon Pass, Calif. The official, Jolene Molitoris, said her agency's inspectors were not told that a safety device on the trains frequently failed. She did not say that the inspectors had checked that particular train before it derailed.

title: An Illinois City, Once Down and Out, Finds Rebirth in RiverboatGambling
description: This once mean and wasted city is on a roll. Known just a few years ago mostly for its prison and cadavers of steel mills, Joliet is growing, building homes and adding jobs.

title: Israeli Troops Dynamite Family Home of Bomber
description: Israeli troops dynamited the rented family home of a Palestinian suicide bomber today, part of a series of punitive measures by the Israeli Government and the Palestinian Authority to underscore that they would meet violent opposition to their peace treaty with similar force.

title: Chinese Missile Testing Fails to Disrupt Life on Taiwan
description: The day after three unarmed Chinese missiles fell near Taiwan's shores, unsubtle weapons in a campaign of intimidation, leaders here made the expected calls for calm and vowed to repel any attacks.

title: House Republicans Offer an Ambitious Plan to Expand Health CareCoverage
description: House Republican leaders offered a package of health care proposals today that is significantly more ambitious than the bipartisan measure pending in the Senate, and they predicted that it would win quick passage in the House.

title: POP REVIEW;A Disco Queen Parades Her Greatest Hits
description: With wind blowing her hair back, steam rising from beneath her feet and more than a dozen different colored spotlights converging on her, Donna Summer strutted and sang on Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall as if her reign as crown diva of disco and pop had never come to an end.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Trump Says It's His Taj
description: Until just before the grand opening last night, Mohammad Rashid was calling his Indian restaurant Taj Mahal. But earlier this week, lawyers for Donald Trump, whose gargantuan Taj Mahal casino is across Pacific Avenue from the new 40-seat restaurant, got a court order barring Mr. Rashid's use of the name. A Trump lawsuit contended that around the world, people now associate the Taj Mahal name more with Mr. Trump's casino than with the famous monument in Agra, India.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CONSECO ANNOUNCES PLANS TO DOUBLE ITS DIVIDEND RATE
description: Conseco Inc., an insurance and financial services company, said yesterday that it would double its dividend rate. The company, which now pays a quarterly dividend of 2 cents a share, will raise its dividend to 4 cents a share before accounting for a 2-for-1 stock split. The company will pay the dividend on April 1, the same day it will issue two shares for every one share held. After the split, the quarterly dividend rate will be 2 cents a share, effectively doubled. The stock split and higher dividend will be for shareholders of record on March 20.

title: Bridge
description: Four world-class bridge teams began play this afternoon in the semifinal stage of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. The results by captain after 16 of 64 deals were these: Nick Nickell of Raleigh, N.C., trailed Jim Cayne of Manhattan by 2 imps, and Zia Mahmood of Manhattan trailed Grant Baze of La Jolla, Calif., by 18.

title: POLITICS: THE FRONT-RUNNER;Still Cautious, Dole Looks To November Nonetheless
description: While hesitant to act too confident that he would win the Republican Presidential nomination, Bob Dole today nonetheless began to steer his campaign toward November and a matchup against President Clinton.

title: Memphis Bank Buying Biggest Tennessee S.& L.
description: The Union Planters Corporation agreed to acquire the Leader Financial Corporation yesterday for stock valued at $486 million, creating Tennessee's largest banking company.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Officer Commits Suicide
description: A police sergeant committed suicide in his car outside police headquarters yesterday, shooting himself once in the head with his service weapon, the authorities said.

title: About New York;Paying A Price For Candor
description: THE Housing Authority isn't talking about Rafael Sencion. Nor is the Mayor's office. Their silence is understandable since Mr. Sencion is suing them for reneging on a job offer, and they prefer not to comment on such matters.

title: Networks Put Cap on Advil-Tylenol War
description: While they can do little about the negative political advertising battle of the Republican Presidential candidates, the television networks are stepping in to referee a similarly sharp dispute between Advil and Tylenol.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HARCOURT GENERAL INCREASING STOCK BUYBACK PROGRAM
description: Harcourt General Inc. said yesterday that it would raise its stock buyback program by one million shares. The publishing and retailing company may now repurchase from investors 3.5 million shares, up from 2.5 million shares previously. So far the company has bought back 1.8 million shares under the original program, which was approved in April 1995. Harcourt said it now had about 72.6 million shares outstanding. The company's shares were down $2, at $44.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TENNECO TO GET $815.7 MILLION FROM CASE STAKE
description: Tenneco Inc. will realize proceeds of $815.7 million from its sale of 15.2 million shares of the Case Corporation, whose public offering of 16.7 million shares was priced on Thursday at $53.75 a share. The stock of Case, which makes agricultural and construction equipment, was down 62.5 cents yesterday, to $53.125, in New York Stock Exchange trading of almost 43 million shares. The Tenneco stake amounted to 21 percent of Case's outstanding shares. Tenneco, a Houston-based conglomerate, announced last month it was selling its remaining stake in Case, whose headquarters are in Racine, Wis.

title: A Trade 'Loophole' Is Costly to Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Phone Auction Bidder Reports Aid From Big Cable Executive
description: John Dolan, who has bid nearly $1 billion for wireless telephone licenses that the Federal Government has reserved for small businesses, disclosed today that he was getting a lot of help from his uncle: Charles F. Dolan, the billionaire chairman of Cablevision Systems.

title: World News Briefs;Nearly 3,000 Are Dead In Epidemics in Nigeria
description: Almost 3,000 people, most of them children, have died in epidemics of meningitis, cholera and measles this year in northern Nigeria, the World Health Organization said today.

title: Market Takes Steepest Drop Since '91
description: Stocks and bonds took their worst pummeling in years yesterday in a selloff caused by a surprise report that more jobs were created in February than in any month since September 1983.

title: FILM REVIEW;Where Tempers And Heads Tend to Fly
description: Welcome to oblivion!" declares Paul Merchant (Bruce Ramsay), a 22d-century scientist, as he pushes the buttons that will do away with Pinhead (Doug Bradley) once and for all. Poof! A few blinding beams of light, laser patterns and bloodcurdling screams later, this visually striking stand-in for Satan is gone, presumably forever. That's because "Hellraiser: Bloodline," the fourth in the popular horror series that began in 1987, has been announced as the final episode. As cinematic Armageddons go, this one is a real bust.

title: Harry Ryba, Famed as Fudge King of Mackinac Island, Dies at 88.
description: Harry Ryba, the fudge king of Mackinac Island in Michigan, died on Monday at Detroit Macomb Hospital in Warren, Mich. Mr. Ryba, who divided his time between the island and Warren, was 88.

title: 4 Oil Companies to Drill Well 7,625 Feet Under Gulf of Mexico
description: Four major oil companies are planning to drill a well 7,625 feet beneath the Gulf of Mexico -- the deepest water that anyone has yet tried to explore for oil, people familiar with the venture said yesterday.

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Clinton Calls On Companies to Train Workers
description: Preaching the doctrine of corporate responsibility with the verve of evangelism and the gentle hand of voluntarism, President Clinton today urged American companies to build up their workers as well as their profits, "within the limits of their capacity."

title: Sports of The Times;A New Fight, Or Plain Old Surrender?
description: WATCHING the Knicks go through the motions last night against the 76ers here, I wondered whether the news of the day -- the dismissal of Coach Don Nelson -- meant resignation for the Knicks, or represented the first step of a resurgence.

title: Safety Deadline Set By Nuclear Agency For 2 Power Plants
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has given New England's largest utility 30 days to show that two of the nuclear power plants it operates in Connecticut are properly equipped for emergencies or face having to shut them down.

title: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA;On Wall Street: For Richer, for Poorer?
description: Is Wall Street really to blame?

title: No Headline
description: This is not for me but for the very essence of human existence, and let me give you a promise, what I do will always be for human welfare. I will not abuse it."

title: Lawyers Create a Panel To Assess Judges' Actions
description: Responding to bitter attacks on judicial rulings, lawyers' groups throughout New York State have formed a panel to assess independently the actions of judges who become targets of public criticism, and to counter what the lawyers deem unwarranted castigation of judicial decisions.

title: State Fines Sloan-Kettering For an Error in Brain Surgery
description: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City has been fined $12,000, the maximum allowed by state law, in a case in which a surgeon operated on the wrong side of a patient's brain, officials of the State Health Department and the center said yesterday.

title: POLITICS: THE SENATE;Open Virginia Primary Opposed
description: The chairman of the Virginia Republican Party today filed a lawsuit seeking to ban Democrats and independents from voting in the party's United States Senate primary in June.

title: Bomb Rocks London Street; No Inuries Reported
description: A bomb exploded in a trash bin on a busy West London road early today, and suspicion immediately fell on the Irish Republican Army.

title: Unexpected Strength in Jobs Unsettles Stocks and Bonds;705,000 New Jobs In February Cut Into Unemployment
description: In what appeared to be a stunningly strong rebound from the economic impact of January's blizzard, American employers added 705,000 new jobs last month while the unemployment rate fell three-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent, the Labor Department said today.

title: World News Briefs;Officials Say Vote in Iran Won't Bring Big Changes
description: As millions of Iranians went to the polls today to choose a new Parliament, Government officials declared in advance that the results of the election would not bring about major changes in the country's policies.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Change Direction and Dismiss Coach
description: Eight months ago, Don Nelson took over as coach of the Knicks with aspirations of healing his tarnished reputation and leading a group of playoff-hardened veterans back to prominence in the post-season.

title: Nation Was Founded on Religious Neutrality
description: To the Editor:

title: POP REVIEW;K. D. Lang's Grand Drama of the Lovelorn
description: Can a singer strut and swoon at the same time? Thrusting out her chest and throwing back her head in the throes of romantic delirium, K. D. Lang seems to do exactly that. While letting out her full-throttle wails, the 34-year-old Canadian singer fuses Patsy Cline's earthy torchiness with Peggy Lee's smoky intensity and Liza Minnelli's belting fervor. The result is something grandly and self-consciously dramatic in the best pop diva tradition.

title: POLITICS: FLORIDA;With a Major Primary Nearing, Little Havana Is Beginning to Look a Lot Like a Giant
description: Campaign stops at the Cuban cafes of Little Havana are traditional in the political season, just like hard-hat tours of Midwestern assembly lines and pickle-munching strolls through the Lower East Side. But Senator Bob Dole's visit to the Centro Vasco restaurant on Thursday had a purpose far beyond the usual photo opportunity: to brake the political momentum generated here by President Clinton after the Feb. 24 destruction of two civilian aircraft by Fidel Castro's Air Force.

title: INSIDE
description: Kevorkian Wins Again

title: World News Briefs;Standoff as U.N. Team Is Barred From Iraqi Site
description: A United Nations arms inspection team was blocked today from entering a site in Baghdad, provoking a standoff that continued through the night, United Nations officials said.

title: Militants Divided
description: A Palestinian in a New York jail who described himself as the political leader of Hamas said in an interview that while the Islamic group opposes violence, it cannot rein in the dozens of loosely allied militians in the West Bank and Gaza.

title: Keep College Open to the Poor
description: During the last 20 years, the incomes of college graduates have risen while workers with only high school educations have seen earnings and job opportunities evaporate. New York State, with its vast numbers of poor, cannot afford to worsen the trend. Given that imperative, one of the signal issues in Albany this spring is the dispute over funding for public colleges and universities -- the schools of choice for low-income New Yorkers seeking to better their lot.

title: Snow-Blind, But Unbowed. (Well, Maybe A Tad Bowed.)
description: Somewhere, a chrome yellow sun burns like a magnifying glass in a summer-blue sky, and palm trees sway over the white-sand beaches of a tropical isle. Somewhere, a gentle breeze up from a mirror sea caresses the cheek, and perfect days stretch away to the horizon. Somewhere . . .

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Seismic Waves Flow From Garden Again
description: When Patrick Ewing trotted onto the Spectrum floor in Philadelphia last night, his undistinguished teammates included Brad Lohaus and J. R. Reid, and his coach was a career assistant named Jeff Van Gundy. The names might as well have been Ken Bannister, Eddie Lee Wilkins and Bob Hill.

title: Hamas Political Chief Says Group Can't Curb Terrorists
description: A senior political leader of the militant Islamic group Hamas, speaking in the detention center in New York where he has been held since July for possible extradition to Israel, said yesterday that while the political wing of Hamas wants an end to violence, it exercises only limited authority over dozens of loosely allied militias in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Sweatshop Workers Share $1.1 Million
description: Thai and Hispanic garment workers who were forced to toil in a compound ringed with barbed wire for less than $1 an hour got back-pay checks today totaling $1.1 million.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about research that determined the three-dimensional structure of an important protein, the lactose repressor, misstated an affiliation of Dr. Jeffrey H. Miller, a researcher who has worked on the protein. He is on the faculty at the University of California at Los Angeles, not Berkeley.

title: Zyuganov: Not Red, Not White, Just Eurasian
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: AT THE ALAMODespite Poor Showing, Forbes Vows to Press On tothe Convention
description: With the Alamo as his backdrop, Steve Forbes said today that he had no intention of surrendering to Senator Bob Dole, vowing to press his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination through to the party's convention in San Diego.

title: OPERA REVIEW;A Chilling, Willful Salome
description: No opera in the repertory is more dominated by its title character than Richard Strauss's "Salome." So when the final slicing orchestra chords ended the performance on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera, it was appropriate for Catherine Malfitano, who sang Salome, to break the cast-bow-first protocol and take the stage by herself. Her reception was tumultuous and well deserved. Ms. Malfitano's portrayal was riveting, no easy feat given the excesses of the Nikolaus Lehnhoff production, which had not been seen at the Met since 1990.

title: I.B.M. Contends With a Scandal In Argentina
description: In Argentina, where payoffs, kickbacks and government corruption are considered part of everyday life, it came as little surprise last September when I.B.M. was accused of paying bribes to obtain a $250 million contract to modernize the computers of the state-owned Banco de la Nacion.

title: Netscape Tie To Compuserve
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation broadened the reach of its popular Navigator World Wide Web browser program today by entering into a distribution agreement with Compuserve Inc., the world's second-largest on-line computer service.

title: Serbs Said to Harass Both Serbs and Non-Serbs
description: Chaos and intimidation are increasing in the last Serbian areas of Sarajevo waiting to be brought under Bosnian Government control, international officials said today. Most Serbs will probably be gone from formerly Serb-held areas by March 20, the deadline for reunification of the city, undermining hopes of rebuilding a multi-ethnic Bosnia.

title: Judge Doubts Crew's Motive In School Case
description: A judge expressed skepticism yesterday over some of the reasons given by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew for suspending a Bronx school board.

title: In Okinawa, U.S. Bases Remain a Big Issue
description: Okinawans are somewhat uncomfortable with the idea that, as The Okinawa Times remarked in an editorial today, it took the "sacrifice of a schoolgirl" to make progress in the movement to scale back the American military bases that occupy 20 percent of the land on this Japanese island.

title: Surprise Job Report Ambushes Bond Investors
description: Bond investors were swept up in a wild scramble to sell off holdings yesterday after the Government reported a much stronger labor market than investors had imagined. Months of pricing in the climate of a weak economy and cuts in interest rates evaporated in a flash.

title: New York's Foreign-Born Population Increases
description: In the first half of the 1990's, new census figures show, enormous numbers of people left New York City for other parts of the United States, and were replaced mostly by people from abroad, trends that experts say mean vast changes for the region's culture and economy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: Tax Ruling Favors Columbia/HCA
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that a favorable ruling from the United States Tax Court meant it would not have to pay $614 million in taxes and interest.

title: BASEBALL;Key Displays Old Form With 3 Shutout Innings
description: The gusty winds reached 20 miles per hour at Osceola County Stadium so the 55-degree temperature felt chillier than normal. Hardly perfect conditions for any pitcher, especially a 34-year-old left-hander who is trying to rebound from major shoulder surgery. But Jimmy Key was close to perfect today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;A Few Changes for the Rangers
description: Reeling Knick-like through what could become a Backward March, the Rangers are making changes before visiting the Washington Capitals this afternoon.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants in the Hunt After Bills Get Spielman
description: Having lost out in the free-agent shuffle for linebacker Chris Spielman, the Giants will look for help at the position elsewhere -- in the free-agent market, in the draft or on their present roster, General Manager George Young said yesterday.

title: G.M. Files a Lawsuit Against VW and Some Executives
description: Still angry about the defection of eight managers to Volkswagen A. G. three years ago, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it had filed a civil complaint against Volkswagen, four Volkswagen executives and the former G.M. executives for the theft of company secrets.

title: Looking Past the Drop
description: In the face of yesterday's selloff of stocks and bonds, market analysts are counseling investors to remain focused on the long term, rather than on wild one-day swings.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: TERRIBLE HONESTY: Mongrel Manhattan in the 1920s By Ann Douglas. Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Torn Knee May Stop Brogna for at Least 3 Weeks
description: Rico Brogna, who established himself last year as the Mets' first baseman, will be sidelined for at least three weeks and may not play on opening day.

title: A Search for Answers To Avoid the Layoffs
description: Gerald Greenwald slipped into his limousine near O'Hare Airport, leaned back and pondered a daring deal.

title: McCall Joins In Criticizing Budget Plan By Giuliani
description: Echoing criticism from other fiscal monitors, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall assailed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's preliminary budget proposal for the coming fiscal year, saying today that it was based on hundreds of millions of dollars in questionable assumptions.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;'Madison County' Spoof From a Cartoon Duck
description: Addicted to spoofs, the animated series "Duckman: Private Eye/ Family Man" tonight takes aim at "The Bridges of Madison County." The episode is called "The Girls of Route Canal."

title: Always Busy, Seemingly by Accident
description: Onstage, Brian Murray communicates a certain verity and an authenticity, whether he is playing Falstaff or a shady character in a Joe Orton black comedy. This is, of course, both a key to his virtuosity and also a reason he is not more celebrated. It is not easy to define a Brian Murray role, which is why he can seem so infinite.

title: Black Lawmakers Attack Rowland's Court Choices
description: Despite angry criticism from black lawmakers, Gov. John G. Rowland today appointed a group of 10 judges to the state trial courts that did not include a single black member.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;H.I.V. Test for Boxers
description: Starting April 1, boxers fighting in New Jersey will have to test negative for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, before entering the ring, the state's Athletic Control Board said. The requirement matches one in effect in Nevada since 1988. Atlantic City and Las Vegas are the two locations for major boxing matches, the state boxing commissioner, Larry Hazzard, said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MANUFACTURERS LIFE TO SELL ENHANCE FINANCIAL STAKE
description: Enhance Financial Services Group Inc. said yesterday that the Manufacturers Life Insurance Company planned to sell its remaining 12.3 percent stake in the company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Enhance said that Toronto-based Manufacturers, a founding shareholder of the company, planned to sell up to 1.95 million shares in an underwritten offering and more than 211,000 more shares if demand was strong enough. On Feb 9, Manufacturers agreed to sell 400,000 shares at $24.48 each to the Swiss Reinsurance Company. Enhance is a New York reinsurer of financial guaranties issued by insurers of municipal bonds and other insurance products.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: YOGEN FRUZ WORLDWIDE INC., Toronto, acquired I Can't Believe It's Yogurt Ltd. and Brice Foods Inc., a frozen yogurt franchisor, for $14 million.

title: BASKETBALL;A Battle of the Big East's Best: It's UConn vs. Georgetown
description: For 27 of 40 minutes, Connecticut and Syracuse battled on even terms in their Big East semifinal last night at Madison Square Garden. Then top-seeded Connecticut pulled the trigger on its zone press, left the Orangemen gasping and raced to an 85-67 victory that put the Huskies in the final tonight against Georgetown.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEKTRONIX STOCK SLIDES AFTER EARNINGS REPORT
description: Shares of Tektronix Inc. plunged 24 percent yesterday after the company said late on Thursday that its third-quarter net income had fallen well below analysts' expectations. Tektronix, based in Wilsonville, Ore., a high-technology printing and imaging company, said net income for the quarter ended Feb. 24 was $22.4 million, or 67 cents a share, up from $21.4 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. But analysts had predicted Tektronix net would come in at about 86 cents a share. Tektronix's stock was down $10.50, at $33.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Late in the session the company said it would repurchase 1.5 million of its shares.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: ATLANTIC 10;UMass Avenges Only Loss
description: His game against George Washington in tonight's Atlantic 10 semifinals was not one for Massachusetts center Marcus Camby's scrapbook.

title: POLITICS: THE PLATFORM;Buchanan Courts Old Friends With a Warning
description: Tired of watching Senator Bob Dole raid the ranks of social and religious conservatives, Patrick J. Buchanan reversed himself today and said that, without more support, he might not be able to maintain the Republican Party's strict opposition to abortion.

title: PROM BASKETBALL;Robinson's 44 Points Overwhelm Bradley and the Nets
description: A clinic. That is about the only way to describe what David Robinson put on for Shawn Bradley tonight.

title: CBS and ABC Line Up Stars For New Fall Comedy Shows
description: Two networks trying to mount comebacks enlisted high-profile (and high-salaried) help yesterday: CBS announced a new comedy deal with Ted Danson, the longtime star of the NBC hit "Cheers," and ABC announced a new comedy deal with Michael J. Fox, the former star of the NBC hit "Family Ties."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia President Quits In Dispute on Costs
description: The president of the Italian state airline Alitalia angrily resigned yesterday, saying the carrier's owners were shying away from making heavy job cuts. The president, Renato Riverso, who was brought in two years ago to rescue the money-losing airline, said in a letter to the Milan financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore that he was stepping down after his relations with Alitalia's owner, the state holding company IRI, had broken down.

title: Unexpected Strength in Jobs Unsettles Stocks and Bonds;The Experts Stress A Wild Day Doesn't Always Set a Trend
description: As much tossing and turning as investors have done in recent weeks, the steady upward march by the markets has lulled most people to sleep.

title: Britons Losing Taste for 'the Royals'
description: The letter to the editor in The Independent last Tuesday attacked the Prince of Wales in no uncertain terms. It said the person "likely to be our next monarch" was a hypocrite: a man who "spoke his marriage vows before millions of people and shortly afterwards committed adultery." A man who professes worry about the environment yet drives "a large gas guzzling motor car." And who "claims concern about wildlife while killing animals for sport."

title: Nintendo Postpones New Game Machine
description: The Nintendo Company said today that it would postpone the introduction of its new 64-bit game machine in Japan until June 23.

title: Another Portrait Of Slaves at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE MONEY;Dole's Aides Are Counting Ways To Keep Campaign Cash Flowing
description: As Senator Bob Dole edges closer to the $37 million spending limit for the Presidential primaries, Republican strategists are exploring ways to maneuver around Federal election laws to keep his campaign afloat financially until the nominating convention in August.

title: Weapons and Bomb Ingredients Are Seized in a Barn in Oregon
description: Police officers investigating a burglary stumbled onto a cache of weapons and fertilizer bomb ingredients, though the amount was much less than what was used in the Oklahoma City bombing that killed 168, officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: The Art in Review column in Weekend yesterday misstated the exhibition history of Robert Grosvenor's sculpture "Tapanga." The work was exhibited in the mid-1960's, but there is no monumental version of it at the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y.

title: Donna Karan Seen as Seeking 2d Chance at Stock Offering
description: The designer Donna Karan, who failed at an attempt to bring her namesake company public in 1993, will try again this summer with Bear, Stearns as the lead underwriter, a person close to the deal said yesterday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;The Knicks Players Agree That Nelson Had to Go
description: Derek Harper noticed a change immediately. On the day the Knicks fired Don Nelson and promoted the assistant Jeff Van Gundy to the head coaching job, the veteran point guard taped his ankles before the team's rugged shoot-around practice at the Spectrum.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Price of Orange Juice Takes Off As Cold Snap Threatens Florida
description: Orange juice prices surged to their highest levels in nearly four years on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday as cold weather threatened Florida's crop.

title: Avoiding Anarchy in Burundi
description: A world grown accustomed to human disaster in the face of diplomatic failure has more to hope for in the coming days. Next Saturday, a meeting of African leaders in Tunis, brokered by former President Jimmy Carter, will test the proposition that breaking the cycle of mass violence in Central Africa may at last be possible. They need the international community's help.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Clemson Defies History And Dumps Carolina
description: There was little to suggest something out of the ordinary was about to occur tonight.

title: Beliefs
description: There has always been something wonderfully naive about the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, the $1 million-plus award given to Bill Bright this year, founder of the international evangelical ministry Campus Crusade for Christ.

title: C.I.A. WILL PRESS ARAFAT AND ISRAEL ON ANTI-TERRORISM
description: In advance of a summit meeting on terrorism, top Central Intelligence Agency officials will meet this weekend with the chiefs of the Palestinian and Israeli internal security forces to offer help and encourage the old enemies to cooperate against the suicide bombers of Hamas, American officials said today.

title: Dairy Legislation Takes Inclusive Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Doing Major Time For a Minor Crime
description: Every night around midnight, a dirty old van departs the Midtown South precinct and cruises lower Manhattan. This van will prowl through some of the nicest neighborhoods of the city and some of the worst. It will stay out all night, or until it is full.

title: Trump Cancels Plan For Davids Island
description: Donald J. Trump says he has dropped plans to buy Davids Island from New Rochelle, and he wants his $500,000 option payment back.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TWO NEW FAMILIES OF WORK STATIONS ARE DISPLAYED
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation displayed two new families of work stations and new graphics for its machines yesterday in a bid to improve its fifth-place market share. Digital Equipment, based in Maynard, Mass., said the new entry-level and midrange machines would offer more computing power for the money than its competitors. Work stations are powerful computers used by engineers, scientists and software programmers. Digital Equipment's new entry-level line, called the Alpha Station 255, consists of two models with prices starting at $7,399, the company said. The midlevel line, called Alpha Station 500, consists of three models, with prices starting at $15,863.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the stands taken by Presidential candidates on immigration referred incorrectly to the rise in the number of illegal immigrants in the United States. Immigration experts generally agree that the number of foreigners in the country illegally increases by about 300,000 to 400,000 annually, not that that number are entering the country illegally each year. Experts estimate that about half enter the country illegally; the rest are admitted legally but overstay their visas.

title: A Life Raft for Hong Kong
description: Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, took a welcome step beyond the decent minimum in a morale-boosting visit to Hong Kong this week. An almost audible sigh of relief greeted his promise of visa-free access to Britain for Hong Kong citizens after the colony is handed over to China in July 1997. This does not assure permanent abode to Hong Kong emigrants, but if the turnover to Beijing is followed by a repressive crackdown, those fleeing to Britain will have a chance to seek political asylum.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STORAGE TRUST REALTY IS ACQUIRING 25 FACILITIES
description: Storage Trust Realty said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 25 self-storage facilities from Balcor/Colonial Storage Income Fund-86 for $67.1 million. Storage Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Columbia, Mo., said the agreement was subject to certain conditions, including approval by the limited partners of Balcor/Colonial. Storage Trust operates 138 facilities in 16 states.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about chefs' secret eating habits misstated the location of Cafe Annie, owned by the chef Robert del Grande. It is in Houston, not Dallas.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Thumps and Thwacks To a Spiritual Ecstasy
description: This relentless winter has undoubtedly produced greater tragedies, but it was sad to see so many empty seats at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening. Those who were driven away by the sleet missed what may well stand as the most thrilling moment of the New York Philharmonic season, a stunning performance of James MacMillan's "Veni, Veni, Emmanuel," with Evelyn Glennie as percussion soloist and Leonard Slatkin conducting.

title: Kevorkian Again Not Guilty of Aiding Suicide
description: For the second time since Dr. Jack Kevorkian began his campaign for doctor-assisted suicide six years ago, a jury today acquitted him of violating a Michigan law banning assisted suicides, a measure written specifically to stop him.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Pay Phones Are Disconnected
description: On advice from the Police Department, Camden city officials issued an order to disconnect hundreds of public pay telephones because drug dealers use them, The Associated Press said yesterday. About 20 percent of the 2,000 to 3,000 outdoor pay telephones, mostly near housing projects, would be taken out. Businesses and New Jersey Pay Phone Association, which represents about 50 small companies with phones in Camden, have asked the city to reconsider the move.

title: Zyuganov: Not Red, Not White, Just Eurasian
description: To the Editor:

title: Pulp Mills Turn Over a New Leaf;Some Companies See Green as Just Good Business
description: OGLETHORPE, Ga.

title: The Endless Winter
description: Setting records for snowfall amounts wasn't enough: Yesterday, the winter that won't go away dropped a fresh dollop of snow, adding to the region's miseries with two weeks still left in the season.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EX-MAGELLAN FUND HEAD TO LEAVE W. R. GRACE BOARD
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that Peter Lynch, vice chairman of Fidelity Investments and former manager of Fidelity's Magellan Fund, will resign from the Grace board on May 10. A Grace spokeswoman said Mr. Lynch's departure was unrelated to Thomas Gossage's resignation from the board four days ago. Mr. Gossage, chairman of Hercules Inc., quit the board after his proposal to merge Grace with his company was rejected by Grace's board. The spokeswoman said Grace's chairman, Albert Costello, had indicated that Mr. Lynch supported the board's position on the offer. Mr. Lynch was not immediately available to comment.

title: Confidential Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrants Replace New York's Natives
description: In the first half of the 1990's, new census figures show, enormous numbers of people left New York City for other parts of the United States, and were replaced mostly by people from abroad, trends that experts say continue to further vast changes in the culture and the economy of the region.

title: POLITICS: NEW YORK STATE;A Region Not Likely to Be Heavily Contested in '96
description: Within two hours after the primary polls closed in New York Thursday night, Steve Forbes held a farewell rally at a Manhattan hotel, while Bob Dole, speaking by satellite from Texas, addressed his supporters gathered at a midtown Republican women's club. And that may well be the last New Yorkers see of the 1996 Presidential campaign.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;3 Sentenced in Sports Betting
description: Three young men were sentenced yesterday after pleading guilty last month to gambling charges in a sports betting ring at Nutley High School in March 1995. In Superior Court, Thomas Stigliano, 26, of Verona, was sentenced to nine months in county jail and two years' probation. Gerard Cimolo, 25, of Belleville, got a four-month jail term with two years' probation, and Herbert Hoffman, 20, of Nutley, was sentenced to 60 days in jail and a year's probation. A fourth man who pleaded guilty, Michael Luzzi, 20, of Nutley, will be sentenced next week. Prosecutors said the sports betting ring took in from $5,000 to $7,000 a week.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: POLITICS: A DEPARTURE;Morry Taylor, Tire Magnate, Stops His G.O.P. Campaign
description: Morry Taylor, the tire magnate, gave up his little-noted run for the Republican Presidential nomination today and endorsed Senator Bob Dole.

title: Rules of Ownership Changing for Media
description: Media companies will soon be permitted to own more television and radio stations nationally and more radio stations in each local market, Federal regulators said today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Gun's Serial Number Filed Off
description: The serial number on the 9-millimeter handgun that a 6-year-old boy accidentally fired in a classroom on Thursday was filed off and cannot be traced, said Newark Detective Irvin Taliaferro. None of the 12 first graders at Our Lady of Good Counsel School was injured when the gun went off while the boy was unloading it. The boy was charged with weapons violations and released to the custody of his father and grandmother. The bullet was lodged in a wall. "We're thankful a potential tragedy did not take place," said Michael F. Hurley, a spokesman for the Newark Archdiocese.

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Dole Sounds Conservative Themes in Oklahoma
description: Bob Dole, who has all but wrapped up his party's Presidential nomination, was still campaigning hard, with a strong conservative message.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Subway 'Bing-Bong'

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KENNEDY INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT;At Kennedy, An Emerging Wrap Artist
description: No one ever had to whisper the word "plastics" in the ear of Dennis Jiminez. Ever since his days supervising the loading and unloading of baggage for a Chilean airline at Kennedy International Airport, he has witnessed the mournful spectacle of suitcases' exploding their guts onto the ramp, the floor, the tarmac. There is a way, he thought, to prevent the sorry sight -- and make a fortune at the same time. Plastics. Plastic wrap, to be specific.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Subaru Legacy Outback, Mazda MPV All-Sport, Audi A6Quattro wagon; Substitutes for Sport Utilities
description: CLIMBING into a sport utility vehicle can be a challenge, particularly for a short woman in a tight skirt. A colleague, with whom I was having lunch, politely held open the door of his Ford Explorer as I hoisted myself into the passenger seat in a not-so-ladylike manner. Just how much, I wondered in mid-climb, did my hiked-up skirt leave exposed?

title: WELFARE REVAMP, HALTED IN CAPITAL, PROCEEDS ANYWAY
description: Although Congress and President Clinton remain deadlocked on landmark legislation overhauling the nation's welfare system, states around the country, with conservative governors and legislators in the lead, have already cut billions of dollars from welfare programs and have won waivers from Washington enabling them to experiment with ways of cutting billions more.

title: HOCKEY;In Overtime, Devils Pass Tough Test
description: They have gone through their midseason swoon and have inched their way up the Eastern Conference standing, into the final playoff spot, then seventh place, and now a tie for sixth. The Devils are playing with the confidence and verve required to get back to the Stanley Cup finals, and victories like today's, a 4-3 overtime triumph against the high-flying Pittsburgh Penguins at the Civic Arena, will only boost the chances of a team that is kicking into overdrive as the regular season heads into the final month.

title: Sex Convictions Vacated
description: An imprisoned couple serving their 11th year of life terms for child-molestation will get a new trial and could soon be free on bail.

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Leahy, Peter Hornick
description: Elizabeth Mary Leahy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Leahy of Princeton, N.J., was married last evening to Peter Jeremy Hornick, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Hornick of Melville, L.I. The Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Town Club in New York.

title: SPEAK SOFTLY, CARRY A VEILED THREAT
description: Beijing must be delighted with Fareed Zakaria's recommendation that the United States, in its policy toward China, forget about "the problems of neglected orphans, brave dissidents and cheap labor" ("Speak Softly, Carry a Veiled Threat," Feb. 18).

title: Giants in the Earth
description: UNDAUNTED COURAGE Meriwether Lewis, Thomas Jefferson, and the Opening of the American West. By Stephen E. Ambrose. Illustrated. 511 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $27.50.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;For Twins, A Grimm Odyssey In a Heavy Metal World
description: Patrons who have had too much to drink can be forgiven for thinking they're seeing double when they leave Coney Island High, the St. Marks Place rock club. Most nights find a pair of identical twins, Marissa and Victoria Stern, running the coat check in a closetlike room by the door.

title: HISTORICAL SHOWS;Out of the Public Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Protest on Peru
description: To the Editor: I am shocked by the publication of Calvin Sims's article "What's Doing in Lima" (Feb. 11). I find this totally outrageous! I'd like to remind you of The Times's excellent editorial of Jan. 16 commenting on the secret military court that sentenced my daughter, Lori Berenson, to life in prison.

title: Giuliani Embarks on a Visit To Support a Troubled Israel
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has embarked on a two-day visit to Israel that offers support to that nation in the face of terrorism and follows a New York political tradition.

title: World News Briefs;Iraqis, After a Standoff, Yield on Arms Inspection
description: After a tense all-night standoff, Iraq has admitted a team of United Nations arms experts to a building they suspect contains documents about Iraq's arms programs, a senior United Nations official said today.

title: WHITE SQUALL';Labor of Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: BANDIDO Oscar "Zeta" Acosta and the Chicano Experience. By Ilan Stavans. Icon Editions/HarperCollins, $20.

title: HIS ACCIDENT
description: Alison Craiglow Hockenberry stirred memories of my own intimate feelings concerning my spouse and his disability (Lives: "His Accident," Feb. 18).

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: LITTLE GIRLS IN CHURCH By Kathleen Norris. University of Pittsburgh, cloth, $24.95; paper, $10.95.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;How Talented Composers Become Useless
description: The nice thing about anism, someone once observed, is how quickly it becomes a wasm. Some musical wasms -- academic-wasm, for example, and its dependent varieties of modern-wasm and Serial-wasm -- continue to linger on artificial life support, though, and continue to threaten the increasingly fragile classical ecosystem. A pair of new Albany CD's of music by Donald Martino, now the Walter Bigelow Rosen Professor of Music Emeritus at Harvard, have recently come my way like a gust of musty air. They prompt me to throw open a window on the miseducation of musicians in America.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 18 about living in Astoria, Queens, misstated the number of public schools in the neighborhood. There are six elementary schools and three intermediate schools in Astoria. The article also misstated the street on the western border of the Astoria Houses. It is First Street, not Shore Boulevard.

title: Q. & A.
description: Elevators And Taxes In a Co-op

title: INVESTING IT;Israeli Stocks Hang On Despite Bomb Attacks
description: BOMBS scarcely seem to scare stock markets anymore. Investors appear to calmly go about their business as long as they remain confident that a country's economy will remain strong.

title: WEDDINGS;Sarah Schatz, Stephen Deschenes
description: Sarah North Schatz, a daughter of Elizabeth and David Schatz of Sarasota, Fla., was married last evening to Stephen Luke Deschenes, a son of Elizabeth Deschenes and Dr. Donald Deschenes of Centerville, Mass. The Rev. Vernon Nichols, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Pratt Mansion in New York.

title: How Far to Support Taiwan?
description: By firing ballistic missiles within Taiwan's territorial waters, China is sending political and military messages to both the United States and Taiwan. Unless the Clinton Administration delivers a demonstrably tough response -- both diplomatically and militarily -- the exercises could escalate dangerously and Beijing will be convinced it can act with impunity.

title: TV SPORTS;Rizzuto Unplugged? Maybe It Won't Last
description: Houston, we have a problem. We've lost the Scooter.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Extending the Reach Of Cellular Telephones
description: A new product from A.T.& T. Wireless makes it possible for international travelers to make calls to and receive calls from 35 countries beyond North America.

title: The Day the Albatross Went Down
description: CHRISTOPHER SHELDON is writing a book, a love story really, about himself and his wife -- how they met on Capt. Irving Johnson's last voyage around the globe, and how she died at sea.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: The Republican War Against Women An Insider's Report From Behind the Lines. By Tanya Melich. Bantam, $23.95.

title: Palestinians Must Speak Out Against Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Teachers Now Are the Experts in Sex Education Class
description: I REMEMBER the day in fifth grade when we had our first sex ed lesson," said Jessica Moramarco, a ninth grader at Northport High School. "They presented it to the girls and boys separately, and everyone was sitting there red-faced, like, 'O.K., I want to go back to class now!' But because we've been talking about it in school ever since, now it's no big deal."

title: The Original-Sin of Brussels-Sprout Cookery
description: MY STERN, BEAUTIFUL mother perfected "the Original-Sin School of Vegetable Cookery." Her favorite victim: the Brussels sprout. Born Presbyterian, she was not alone in boiling first, asking later. God also overcooks. (See global warming.) Mom was first on our street to serve separate salads, with separate forks. But when it came to the scourging of farm tubers, she proved to be just one more Clorox country-club lady of stringent 1953. Her face probably still appears on the walls of certain vegetable post offices.

title: The Morality of Fat
description: At the dawn of the New Age of Dietary Enlightenment, in about 1989, readers of The New York Times began clamoring for lean and stylish dishes. Vegetables, more vegetables. Fish. Fresh herbs. No fat, please, anything but fat. But flavor, give us flavor, and style.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Hootenanny
description: Thirty-five years ago, with anthems like "If I Had a Hammer" and "Leaving on a Jet Plane," three young musicans influence music's course, and a nation's youth. PETER, PAUL AND MARY: LIFELINES on Great Performances features the trio on stage with old friends like the signers Odetta, Richie Havens and Tom Paxton, Dave Van Ronk on guitar, and the harmonica virtuoso John Sebastian.

title: Atlanta Mayor Is Trying to Rein In Street Party
description: Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta, who for the last two years has been bedeviled by controversy surrounding the annual spring pilgrimage here by thousands of black college students, has appointed a critic of his handling of the event to lead a committee to coordinate the city's response this year.

title: IMMIGRANT VOTERS RESHAPE POLITICS
description: In one of a thousand small chain reactions of democracy, Pamela Brathwaite, of Barbados, was in Brooklyn Federal Court taking the oath of citizenship one recent morning so she would be able to vote, just as a friend had done before her and just as her mother, sisters, uncle and cousin would do after her. They were telling one another that one more vote would make a difference.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;A Capitalist Camp in Siberia
description: Given the international diversification of this company, its enviable record of increasing earnings and the quality of its products, we feel a premium multiple to that of the market makes some sense. But at a 22 multiple of current earnings and projected E.P.S. for 1995 of $2.25 a share, the current $53 price of International Flavors and Fragrances fully reflects its growth potential for the next few years. We recommend investors defer purchase at this time." (May 20, 1995) An analyst's presentation to a group of mutual fund managers? A research report culled from the pages of the Value Line Investment Survey? No, this is an evaluation by Max Bezyradin, a senior business major at Irkutsk State University in Irkutsk, Siberia, on his final examination in the finance course I taught there last spring.

title: For a Grucci, From Fireworks To Politics
description: DRIVING through a snowstorm last month on his way to Brookhaven Town Hall, Felix J. Grucci Jr. described his move from pyrotechnics to politics.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: GREENWICH VILLAGE;A Walk Into the Past Of a Countryside
description: BEFORE it became part of the city, Greenwich Village was a country settlement on the Hudson with a street pattern all its own. "When the streets start going off at crazy angles," says John Wilson, an urban historian, "you know you're in the old part of the Village."

title: A Rationed Coke
description: THE FORMAT WAS SIMPLICITY itself: porridge for breakfast, rice pudding for lunch and some ungodly mix of the remains for dinner. Malefactors were punished by being given more, and people who begged off were made to eat every last drop under the supervision of a tennis-shoe-wielding master. Plates, floors, even the pockets of our corduroy jackets were soon encrusted with a white glop that could have afforded archeologists a lifetime of exploration.

title: Sense And Edibility;The Food Taster
description: Michael Lynch, Haarmann & Reimer, Springfield, N.J. Lynch breaks tastes down into key flavor components. Q: How do you become an expert?

title: Retreat Center Named for Leukemia Victim
description: JEANNIE STAPLETON SMITH describes herself as a devout Catholic and "a woman of faith." Her religious beliefs are so strong, she said, that when her 17-year-old son, Timothy, died of leukemia, her grief was tempered by "the fact that I could say God meant my son to live 17 years and not a second longer."

title: Mob Hit?
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: BOOKEND; Selling 'Huck Finn' Down the River
description: In the January issue of Harper's Magazine, the novelist Jane Smiley writes that she's "stunned" by the notion that "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" "is a great novel . . . even a serious novel." She attributes its canonization to a propaganda initiative by a small group of literary critics, among them Lionel Trilling and T. S. Eliot, soon after World War II. She sees this as part of a longstanding cultism that assigns a dominant position to "white, Protestant, middle-class male authors" -- Emerson, Hawthorne and Melville, for example -- while relegating women authors, especially authors of best-selling novels, to the kitchen middens of Parnassus. Citing Ernest Hemingway's famously unhesitating assertion that "all modern American literature" comes from "Huckleberry Finn," Ms. Smiley argues that American literature would have been better off if it had grown instead out of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," one of the few novels that may be said to have had a pronounced effect on events.

title: Palestinians Must Speak Out Against Terrorism;World Can Take Action
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;Factory Now a 'Jewel' in the Zone's Crown
description: The abandoned Washburn Wire factory, which sprawls for three blocks along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in East Harlem, has become a hot property since the creation of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone.

title: Streetscapes/Central Park;A Reservoir Below Causes a Dust Bowl Above
description: THE Central Park Conservancy is spending $18.2 million because the reservoir holds water.

title: The World;Running After the Cold War
description: IT was only two months ago that President Clinton unveiled a concise election-year vision of a post-cold war foreign policy: the United States as "the world's very best peacemaker."

title: An Addendum On Lloyd Harbor
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;In Collapse of Chemistry, Nelson and Ewing Failed to Mix
description: On a mild day last October, Patrick Ewing walked into the office of his new coach, arranged his 7-foot frame comfortably on a sofa and began his first serious conversation with the man who would possibly oversee the remaining years of his stellar National Basketball Association career.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Tea, Coffee and Books On Personal Recovery

title: Peril Rides The School Bus
description: IT probably took 14-year-old Andrea Chen less than 30 seconds to become a gruesome statistic on school bus fatalities. An Irvington High School freshman, she was leaving her school bus on a Thursday afternoon last month when a drawstring on her jacket caught on the bus handrail.

title: The Prison Odyssey of Sol Wachtler
description: In September 1993, Sol Wachtler, then 64, after resigning in disgrace as New York State's Chief Judge, pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 15 months in Federal prison for harassing Joy Silverman, a woman with whom he had had an affair. This nationally prominent jurist was about to get an inmate's view of the American system of crime and punishment. Following are excerpts from his prison diary, which Mr. Wachtler intends to incorporate into a book. He kept the journal at the medium-security Federal Correctional Institution in Butner, N.C., and later at the Federal Medical Center in Rochester, Minn. At both prisons, Mr. Wachtler underwent treatment for manic depression, the disorder he was diagnosed as having at the time of his crime.

title: The Tales Angels Tell Under Fourth-Grade Desks
description: ROSEMARY DORRICO MADIA knows something about masterpieces, Monet and Michelangelo. But what she knows about most of all is motivation.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;At Last, N.Y.U. Captures Elusive Spot in Final Four
description: New York University's season did not end yesterday afternoon. It did not end because this was Mindy Sokalsky's last chance for glory, and she was not going to let it pass her by. And it did not end because Marsha Harris, the team's spiritual leader, managed to avoid getting a fifth foul down the stretch.

title: WEDDINGS;Jill Warren, Chad L. Karp
description: Jill Marcia Warren, the daughter of Carla and Peter Warren of Morganville, N.J., was married last evening to Chad Laurence Karp, the son of Judith and Leonard Karp of Dix Hills, L.I. Rabbi Stanley Ringler performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Power Plants Defended
description: Responding to sharp rebukes from Federal regulators, Northeast Utilities, New England's largest power producer, said that its four nuclear power plants in Connecticut were safe and that a dramatically reshaped management would insure that past errors were not repeated. But the company is just beginning to rebuild.

title: World News Briefs;20,000 Attend a Protest Against Serbian Leader
description: Some 20,000 people demonstrated in Belgrade against the Government of President Slobodan Milosevic today, the anniversary of opposition protests crushed by troops in 1991.

title: WEDDINGS;Allegra C. Costa and Scott H. Herman
description: Allegra C. Costa, the daughter of Piergiorgio Costa of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Silvia Costa, was married yesterday to Dr. Scott H. Herman, a son of Christine and Dr. Michael Herman of Southport, Conn. Msgr. James Connolly performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville.

title: IN BRIEF;Storms Leave Beaches Knee-Deep in Clams
description: The sea gulls are happy, even if the people who live near the beaches in Atlantic and Cape May Counties aren't. Winter storms that have hit the coast since the blizzard of Jan. 7 and 8 created a surf so rough that the incoming waves gouged out the sandy ocean bottom, depositing thousands and thousands of large, hard-shelled clams on the beaches.

title: TENNIS;Capriati, Williams Thrust Into Spotlight
description: Women's tennis, often criticized for its lack of intriguing early-round encounters, served up the ultimate in marquee razzle-dazzle today in the State Farm Evert Cup.

title: GOLF;Herron's Confidence Rises and Shots Sink
description: They came after Tim Herron today, firing at him from back in the field, throwing in putts and trying to throw a scare into the rookie from Minneapolis. It almost unnerved him. His lead in the Honda Classic and his confidence in himself were shrinking with each hole.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VENUS, THE PLAY

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;An Egyptian Museum Bites the Dust
description: Demolition workers have begun pulling down the concrete framework of an unfinished museum that was to be constructed only 200 meters from the famous Zoser Step Pyramid near the Great Pyramids of Giza in Egypt. The decision came several weeks ago when the Egyptian Culture Minister, Farouq Hosni, toured the site and decided that the project posed an esthetic threat to the landscape of the area, 15 miles south of central Cairo on the west bank of the Nile.

title: ARCHITECTURE;A City Poised on Glitter and Ashes
description: THE ROAD GETS ROUGHER. IT'S lonelier and tougher. Franklin D. Israel is the man who got away: the native New Yorker who went west and became Frank Israel, Star Architect, Hollywood Architect. Now at age 50, Israel is the subject of a vibrant retrospective at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, a show that is also a haunting portrait of Los Angeles at a critical moment in the city's history.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;An English Legoland
description: Scenes from Amsterdam, Edinburgh and Paris rendered in little plastic bricks will be one of the attractions of the Legoland theme park scheduled to open on March 29 near Windsor, about 20 miles west of London. The 150-acre park is based on the Legoland that opened in Denmark in 1968.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Arraignment in Seattle Fire
description: A Seattle man who went to Brazil after a fire at his parents' frozen-food warehouse killed four firefighters in 1995 was arraigned on Friday on charges of first-degree murder and arson. The man, Martin Pang, 40, was returned to Seattle last week.

title: IN PERSON;Many Laurels, but No Rest
description: TOWARD the end of a recent evening, Les Paul said, "I'm working on a new guitar now."

title: Ozark Mountain High
description: GIVE US A KISS A Country Noir. By Daniel Woodrell. 237 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $22.50.

title: The Geograpy of Taste
description: IT USED TO BE THTA THE FOOD YOU chose to put in your mouth revealed your roots as readily as the accent that came out of it. Now food preferences linked to region alone are beginning to fade. People move around. Food companies market nationally. Nonetheless, the quirks and wrinkles of particular tastes continue to faintly mark the culinary landscape. High sales of Nilla Wafers in the South, for example, or of chunky peanut butter in the West reflect endemic, though frequently inexplicable, affinities that have existed for generations. here are some of the things we like to eat, and where we like to eat them.

title: For Middle-Aged Singles, Social Scene Is Like Tundra
description: To the Editor:

title: State Shift Would Impinge on the Disabled
description: I applaud Assemblyman Thomas DiNapoli's statement on special education. He stated that by changing the fiscal responsibility from the state to the municipalities for special education services, it will be the children who will suffer the most.

title: FILM RATINGS;Cynics and Hypocrites
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Ornery Stove -- or Tenants?
description: Call it the Mortifying Saga of the Gas Stove That May or May Not Leak. It is part of a five-year struggle between tenant and landlord at one of the fanciest addresses on the Upper East Side over who gets custody of the major appliances. The neighbors are not amused.

title: The Nation;G.O.P. Congress Faces A Downsized Agenda
description: REPUBLICANS expect attention to shift back to Congress this week after the Super Tuesday primaries. If it does, the lesson will be what a difference a year makes.

title: Science Fiction
description: Genre labels like "science fiction" and "mystery" are perpetuated by the publishing industry for the convenience of publishers, booksellers and book buyers, in roughly that order. It is handy for all concerned to divide the unwieldy universe of fiction into discrete categories that translate into clearly marked shelf space in your local bookstore. But it's worth remembering that genres typically arise not from market imperatives but from the collective imagination of writers who find themselves drawn to similar themes and narrative strategies. Not surprisingly, despite the best efforts of the publishing industry, the borders between genres tend to be as permeable as a Balkan truce line.

title: Sunday March 10, 1996;A QUESTION FOR: Saul Bass
description: With his wife, Elaine, he has created innovative film titles, credit sequences and corporate logos. Tomorrow, the 75-year-old Bass will be honored in New York by the School of Visual Arts, where an exhibition of his work will be on display through April 5.

title: Word for Word/Television Commercials;It Isn't All Big Pink Bunnies and Marlboro Men
description: THE Leo Burnett Company, the world's seventh largest advertising agency, recently compiled a list of "the 100 best commercials of all time" from around the world, and it is already stirring debate among advertising executives. The commercials were grouped by category: celebrity endorsements, testimonials, parodies, etc. Here's an annotated sampling of four categories from the list. STUART ELLIOTT Blockbusters

title: TELEVISION VIEW;When Soul-Searching Is Just Part of the Job
description: RIVING FROM CRIME SCENE TO CRIME scene, detectives have a lot of time to chat. And on television, at least, they have an insatiable need to search their souls, philosophize about their jobs and dissect moral problems while they're on the road. On "Homicide" recently, a conversation between the ever-sensitive Tim Bayliss (Kyle Secor) and his intense partner, Frank Pembleton (Andre Braugher), took an unexpectedly witty turn.

title: March 3-9;For a Bomber, No Excuses
description: Edward J. Leary seemed an unlikely bomber. A family man earning $87,000 a year as a computer systems analyst, he owned a home in suburban New Jersey, apartments in Brooklyn and a summer house.

title: WEDDINGS;Stephanie Dance, Anthony Tancredi
description: Stephanie Clune Dance, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter D. Dance of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Anthony Laurence Tancredi, a son of Rosemary Yaecker Merry of Hampton, N.J., and Dr. Robert G. Tancredi of Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Lupton P. Abshire performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: War Games Off Taiwan To Expand, Beijing Says
description: Further stepping up its military pressure on Taiwan, China said tonight that it would close a huge swath of the Taiwan Strait on Tuesday to conduct "live fire" exercises with naval ships and warplanes as a series of missile tests neared completion.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE

title: THE INVISIBLE FAMILY
description: Has the Federal Government lost its mind? From Robert Sabbag's "Invisible Family" (Feb. 11), it appears that Jess Brewer, the witness in the drug investigation who was himself "never a target of the investigation," was paid to relocate with his family from Hawaii, was provided transportation, counseling, accommodation (with a per diem of $150), $8,000 to purchase new furniture, $7,000 to purchase a car and a monthly nontaxable stipend of $1,800, in return for which he provided testimony (which was not used) to secure the conviction of two drug dealers -- one of whom got five years in prison without parole and the other nine years without parole. Big deal.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;Empowerment Brings Tension Too
description: It did not take long after the politicians had signed on the dotted line, clearing the way for $300 million to flow into the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, for new tensions to surface between black and Hispanic community leaders.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: BIBLE STORIES FOR ADULTS By James Morrow. Harcourt Brace, cloth, $22; paper, $12.

title: Woodruff Jones English Lawyer, 86
description: Woodruff Jones English, a retired senior partner in the large Newark-based law firm of McCarter & English and a volunteer with medical, social service and rights organizations, died on March 3 at the Meadow Lakes retirement community in Hightstown, N.J. He was 86.

title: Correction
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about investing in Irish companies misstated the stock symbol and the March 1 price of the American depository receipts of the Jefferson Smurfit Group. The symbol is JS, not JJSC; the price on March 1 was $25, not $11.375. (The symbol and price shown were for the shares of the company's United States affiliate, the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation.)

title: WEDDINGS;Ginny Bumgardner, Mark W. Arnold
description: Dr. Ginny Li Bumgardner and Dr. Mark W. Arnold, both assistant professors of surgery at the College of Medicine of Ohio State University in Columbus, were married yesterday. The Rev. J. Franklin Luchsinger, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Columbus.

title: Cut Aid to Dependent Corporations Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus on an Antique Medium Called Paper
description: IN the renovated 150-year-old carriage house of the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion in Norwalk, artists work to a background of classical music, honing and developing skills by making paper, lithographs, etchings, silk screens and photographs.

title: WEDDINGS;Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Allison Stacey Cowles
description: Allison Stacey Cowles, the widow of William H. Cowles 3d, who was the publisher of The Spokesman-Review in Spokane, Wash., was married yesterday afternoon to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the chairman and chief executive of The New York Times Company.

title: No Headline
description: THE Copper Beech Inn in Ivoryton has long been a dining landmark. Yet with several ownership turnovers over the years, it has experienced peaks and valleys. The rambling old clapboard house, with its glassed-in conservatory-cocktail lounge, is as handsome and well-maintained as ever. There are three main dining rooms (plus a tiny one for overflow), each furnished differently in English or French country style.

title: ART;Interpreting That Deepest of Emotions, Love
description: Love" Arlene Bujese Gallery, 66 Newtown La., East Hampton. To Mar. 17. 324-2823.

title: BELLEVUE'S EMERGENCY
description: To read that Bellevue Hospital has beds upstairs that "are crowded with patients in need of apartments, jobs and psychiatric counseling," in an era when budget cuts have been extremely painful in areas like education and, ironically, public health, can turn a Democrat into a Republican in a New York minute. I assume that I am not alone in wondering where the patients who actually require medical care are admitted.

title: Learning How to Be a Full-Time Mother
description: LIZ FOREST of New Rochelle was an economist with an economics consulting firm. She hired a nanny and continued to work after her first child, Jocelyn, was born. During her second pregnancy, Ms. Forest panicked.

title: Still Lives With AIDS;3 Youths Face Shadows On Their Horizons
description: Growing up a half-step from a wayward bullet, it was easy for one young man from Bedford-Stuyvesant to figure that sex could never be as lethal as the crack dealers and street gangs stalking his neighborhood.

title: Sense And Edibility;The Menu Writer
description: Tanga Teasley, Darden Restaurants, Orlando, Fla. As manager of menu services, Teasley oversees the design and language of the menus for Red Lobster restaurants. Q: Do you write all the copy?

title: THE NIGHT;A Benefit Show in The Aviary
description: CELEBRITY birds of a feather flocked into the Ziegfeld Theater last Sunday for the premiere of "The Birdcage."

title: SPENDING IT;What's the Buzz? G.M.'s Electric Car Is Headed to Showrooms
description: ELECTRIC cars produced by a brand-name auto company, complete with warranty and dealer service, are just a few months away. But the EV1, the two-seater from the General Motors Corporation, will cost roughly $35,000, almost as much as a Corvette and a little more than two Saturns. At that price, who is going to want one?

title: RUNWAYS;Fashion's Military Fascination: Unsettling, Romantic Esthetic
description: THERE is something unsettling about the forward march of military style on designer runways in the opening weeks of the international fashion season. Uniforms, battle fatigues, camouflage patterns and Eisenhower jackets have all made appearances.

title: Westchester Q&A: Lawrence Otis Graham;The Persistence of Passive Bigotry
description: SOME people at the Greenwich Country Club may have sensed that Lawrence Otis Graham was not the kind of busboy they usually encountered. After all, they told him that he spoke like "an educated white man."

title: SIGNOFF;Not a 50's TV Mom in 90's Clothing
description: At a recent press conference for the ABC sitcom "Home Improvement" (Tuesday at 9 P.M.), Patricia Richardson was asked how she liked being America's perfect mom.

title: EVENING HOURS;And to All a Good Night
description: Whether East Side or West, the mood was celebratory.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JACKSON HEIGHTS;Board 3 Official Quits in Dispute
description: In her 18 years as district manager of Community Board 3, Mary Sarro sometimes bypassed the board to get things done when bureaucracy and politics got in the way. And this tendency may have cost her job.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;Political Mechanic Strives for Big Picture
description: For Bob Dole, winning the New York primary on Thursday night was like breaking the sound barrier. Finally, after two aborted missions for President, he had surpassed a place that long seemed beyond his reach, and he now seemed safely on his way toward capturing his party's nomination.
