title: BASEBALL;Yankees Can Feel The Power In Red Sox
description: The addition of Kevin Mitchell to the Boston Red Sox received mixed reviews today in the camp of the Yankees, one of the teams that will be most directly affected if Mitchell has remembered to bring his home run bat back from Japan.

title: POSTINGS: Eichner Begins $40 Million Conversion at Park Central;On 7th Ave., Half Hotel, Half Time-Share Condo
description: Construction began last week on a $40 million conversion of half the 26-story Park Central Hotel into New York City's first time-share condominium. Ian Bruce Eichner, the developer, said he plans to keep the eastern half of the building as a "lower-end hotel" with its entrance on Seventh Avenue. The western half will be a 360-unit time-share operation called the Manhattan Club, with a new entrance on 56th Street.

title: March 3-9;U.S. Servicemen Sentenced In Rape on Okinawa
description: The punishment was a bit heavy by Japanese standards, but many Okinawans thought the sentences were too light when a Japanese court sentenced two American servicemen last week to seven years in prison for the abduction and rape of a 12-year-old Okinawan girl. A third serviceman received a prison term of six and a half years.

title: Neighbors Voice Concern Cautiously
description: Although deeply concerned by the Chinese missile tests near Taiwan, Japan and other countries in the region are carefully avoiding any strong criticism for fear of offending China.

title: The View From: Port Chester;What About College? 'We'll Worry About It Later,' Father Says
description: EVERYTHING is coming in fours these days for Coco and Bruce Lefkowitz of Rye. They have four cribs, four highchairs, four infant car seats, four swing sets, four rocking toys shaped like kangaroos. And they have four tiny babies conceived in a glass laboratory dish eight months ago and born at United Hospital Medical Center here between 2:55 and 2:57 P.M. on Feb. 21.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: Ambrose Bierce's End
description: To the Editor:

title: State and Navy Settle On Toxic Spoils
description: Spoil Dumped in Sound May Be Tainted" [Feb. 4] contains a significant factual error. On behalf of the State Department of State, the agency responsible for evaluating Federal projects' consistency with our coastal-use policies, I filed a lawsuit against the Navy charging the Navy with violations of the Coastal Zone Management Act. Contrary to the statement in your article, this office did not "drop" the lawsuit against the Navy on the basis of any finding by the Governor. Rather we reached a settlement with the Navy, because the Navy made various important commitments that protect the state's long-term environmental interests. The commitments include these items:

title: On the Margins
description: YOU HAVE THE WRONG MAN Stories. By Maria Flook. 242 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $23.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Tuneful Gems From a Master of a Lost Art
description: WHEN Leroy Anderson studied music at Harvard in the late 1920's, his teachers had no idea what to make of him, least of all the exacting Walter Piston. Anderson's fugues didn't behave the way fugues were supposed to. His extended compositions were cumbersome. And he wasted his time, they thought, conducting the Harvard Band and playing accordion.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CENTRAL BROOKLYN;One Election Where Votes May Not Help
description: Even though Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew may not permit the winners to wield any power immediately, the school board race in Community School District 17 is awash with aspiring candidates for the May 7 elections, including a majority of the old board, which was suspended 15 months ago for political infighting and mismanagement.

title: Hamas Unit Says It Will Resume Suicide Bombings
description: The Qassam military wing of the Muslim fundamentalist group Hamas said today that it would resume suicide bombings because of crackdowns by Israel and the Palestinian Authority.

title: YOUR HOME;Charging Late Fees In a Co-op
description: OF all the duties that befall a co-op's board of directors -- from deciding when to redecorate the lobby to determining how to refinance the underlying mortgage -- one of the most frustrating is also the most mundane: making sure the maintenance gets collected.

title: School Chiefs Harder to Find
description: WANTED: Dedicated individual willing to work a minimum of 15-hour days; attend night meetings and events four to five times a week; have legislative lobbying capabilities; be responsible for maintenance of local property values and student educational performance, and be accountable to thousands of self-proclaimed bosses.

title: MUSIC;3 Times 2: Zwilich Paired With Beethoven
description: WHEN Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's husband died in 1979, she kept his surname, which roots her firmly at the end of almost any list starting with A. Her honors, however, are strictly A-list, studded with firsts: first woman to win the Pulitzer Prize (for her First Symphony), first composer in residence at Carnegie Hall, first woman to earn a doctorate in composition at Juilliard, first composer named to the Florida Artists Hall of Fame.

title: World News Briefs;As Cyprus Hijack Ends, Arms Prove to Be Fake
description: A Turkish waiter hoping to win sympathy for the Chechen revolt in Russia used fake weapons to hijack a Turkish Cypiot airliner to Germany but freed his hostages and gave himself up this morning.

title: Editorial Notebook;The Unmaking of a Primary
description: Senator Al D'Amato, that born-again political reformer, has come to a sudden realization that in a democracy, elections should involve more than one name on the ballot. "I think the process is served better when we have competition," he told voters after his candidate, Senator Bob Dole, handily won the Republican primary in New York.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Monterey Aquarium Gets a New Wing
description: Soupfin sharks, green sea turtles and a gallery filled with delicate jellyfish are a few of the attractions on display in the new $57 million wing of the Monterey Bay Aquarium in Monterey, Calif.

title: Another Side of the Desk
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: No Headline
description: My girlfriend begged me to come and do it. She told me if you become a citizen, you get to vote. I figure I can make a difference."

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Sunday March 10, 1996: 8 RMS, 4 BATHS, NO VU;House Hunters
description: Chip designers are like graffiti artists: they can't leave a blank space alone. When Karl Bohringer and Bruce Donald of Cornell's computer science department were building an array of tiny robot arms on a silicon chip, they were left with some undeveloped silicon in the corner. So Bohringer teamed up with a friend, Ken Goldberg of the University of California at Berkeley, to design a version of Fallingwater, Frank Lloyd Wright's famous house.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Ray Quixote: Allen Tilts at Hoop and UConn Wins
description: Unbelievable. Or even better. In a magnificent final of the Big East men's basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden, Georgetown took a 74-63 lead on Connecticut with 4 minutes 46 seconds left. Whereupon the Huskies scored the final 12 points of the game, the last 2 on Ray Allen's 13-foot, tilting one-handed jump shot with 13.6 seconds left. And the Huskies won, 75-74.

title: WEDDINGS;Jane F. Isay, Jonathan Dolger
description: Jane Franzblau Isay, the publisher of Grosset Books in New York, is to be married today to Jonathan Dolger, a literary agent. Rabbi Balfour Brickner is to perform the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: POSTINGS: Bronx's Beth Abraham Hospital Venturing Into Westchester;Former Warehouse to Become a Medical Facility
description: A former industrial warehouse in Greenburgh in Westchester County is being transformed into a medical facility to house two expanding medical programs offered by Beth Abraham Hospital in the Bronx.

title: Sports of The Times;Van Gundy: Like Father, Like Son, Like Son
description: THIS was back in November, before the Knicks were exposed as a team with terminal dry rot. The new coach, Don Nelson, was interviewed on PBS by Charlie Rose, who wanted to know where all the future head coaches were.

title: THEATER;A Postwar Message For the Millennium
description: IF economic terror and moral indifference were ever presaged by a playwright, the handwriting on the wall belonged to Arthur Miller.

title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Be Forewarned! This Fund May Be 'Loaded'
description: Q. Why would anyone pay an upfront commission to buy a mutual fund? LINDA WALLEN Rochester

title: Sunday March 10, 1996: HOW ABOUT 'TEDIUM'?;Name That Element
description: Speaking of names, which we do a fair amount of this Sunday, the German scientists who recently devised Element 112 have refused to entitle it because the international commission that rules on such nomenclature rejected the names they gave Elements 107, 108 and 109. In the meantime, some suggestions:

title: New Union Tactics
description: A five-day-old strike by 3,200 brake parts workers in Dayton, Ohio, has shut down a third of the General Motors Corporation North American assembly lines. Yet 300 of those workers are crossing picket lines with their union's approval to make brake parts at the same factories for the Chrysler Corporation and a Japanese auto maker.

title: NEW JERSEY & CO.;Why Strikers At Terminal Stay on Strike
description: For the last two months, commuters dashing in and out of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan have dashed past a cluster of strikers standing outside the building behind yellow metal barricades, bearing red and white signs and handing out leaflets.

title: VIEWS;Celebrating Women Who Have Changed Young Lives
description: Mom was first choice. Teachers and grandmothers made strong showings, as did Governor Whitman and other women who are New Jersey history makers.

title: CHINA ON THE EDGE ... OF WHAT?
description: Your articles on China (Feb. 18) were enlightening but missed one of the more extraordinary developments there.

title: Quiet Town On ET Road Using Lure Of U.F.O.'s
description: This speck of a town is little more than a trailer park, a gas station and a diner alongside State Route 375, a 100-mile stretch of secondary road through the scrub country of southern Nevada where there are often more cows on the blacktop than cars.

title: ON LANGUAGE;The Hunting of the Grouse
description: THE SEASON OF elections in Russia, Israel, the United States and probably Britain brings with it the language of complaint. As the punster at the O'Meara Camping Equipment Company in Dublin wrote in an advertisement for a sale at this time of year, "Now Is the Winter of Our Discount Tent."

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: The Patriot By Piers Paul Read. Random House, $23.

title: The Country Airs and Graces of Limoges
description: WHO knows Limoges? It is one of the great, historic cities of France, situated in the green foothills of its central, mountainous heart. It is the most important urban center between Orleans, on the Loire, and Toulouse in the south near the Pyrenees and is on the same direct railway line from Paris; yet country airs blow in its hilly old streets.

title: Sunday March 10, 1996: APOSTROPHE COPS;Don't Be So Possessive
description: Hard to believe, but throughout the land the Federal Government has sanctioned only four apostrophes to make place names possessive. The latest to be so entitled by the U.S. Board on Geographic Names, the first genitive it has bestowed in 32 years, is Carlos Elmer's Joshua View. This is a vista in Arizona from which the photographer Carlos Elmer took pictures of Joshua trees. Since 1890, the nine-member board, in Reston, Va., has remained hostile to possessives, stripping Harpers Ferry and Jamestown, among others, of their apostrophes.

title: Returnees Complain That Cuba Reneged
description: Ten months after 13 Cubans were forced to return to their country after trying to flee to the United States, they contend that neither the Cuban nor the American Government has lived up to an agreement that they would face no retribution when they returned.

title: SOAPBOX;700 Candid Words About Race
description: FOR a time, Colin Powell's potential candidacy sharply altered the public discourse about race and politics. In reflection, it was all quite extraordinary: much of the leadership of America's white party, a k a the Republicans, pined to be led by the son of black immigrants. When he decided not to run for President, the hope that he alone could bridge the racial divide was dashed. Now, the nation is left without a simplistic answer to its 375-year racial quandary. We are back to tough, slow, messy choices.

title: Women's Travel
description: To the Editor: From the perspective of an 850-member women's travel club, we were delighted at the attention given to the the women's market by Betsy Wade's "Adventures for Women" (Practical Traveler, Feb. 11). In fact, the adventure market for women is a mere fraction of the cultural touring market for women. It is estimated that women constitute 43 percent of all American adults who travel frequently and that women took 45 percent of all pleasure trips in 1993.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;A Golden Anniversary for the Ruler of Tables (and Siberia) at '21'
description: You don't have to have a firm wallet and smoke a fat cigar to get a good table at the "21" Club, but it helps to know Walter Weiss. For 50 years Mr. Weiss, the restaurant's headwaiter, has been a real-estate broker for dining power-brokers in a town where a certain crowd thinks you are only as important as the table where you lunch. He fixes the pecking order among the elite and the pretenders at "21," deciding who gets the preferred tables -- those at which Steinbeck, Benchley and Bogart were regulars -- and who is banished to "Siberia," on the east side of the downstairs dining room known as the Barroom.

title: FILM;Film-Making Twins With a Taste for the Dark Side
description: WHILE MANY identical twins try to set themselves apart from each other, Tim and Steven Quay seem to revel in their doubleness. The Brothers Quay, as they are jointly known, have worked together their entire lives, first as illustrators, then as animators celebrated for elaborately detailed puppet films shown in art houses and on MTV. On Wednesday, their first live-action feature, a black-and-white film called "Institute Benjimenta," has its premiere in the United States.

title: The Education Of an Insufferable Food Dilettante
description: The first dish that I ever prepared from start to finish, not counting eggs over easy, was navarin printanier (lamb stew with spring vegetables) from Julia Child's "Mastering the Art of French Cooking." I don't remember very well what it tasted like, but I do recall the thrill of reading a serious book about food. I had thought all recipes were written on index cards by my mother or her friends and stored in a little box in our kitchen.

title: For Bonds, Notes From the Silver-Lining Crowd
description: BOND fund investors wondering if any air remained in the bubble from last year's rally got their answer on Friday. Prices plunged, erasing six months of gains, and long-term yields topped 6.7 percent, their highest level since August.

title: Survival Instinct;Alone or Not, Israel Strikes Back
description: AFTER the fourth human bomb, this one in the heart of Tel Aviv, brought to 61 the toll in tattered victims, the anger and grief turned to despair. Many Israelis who had put their faith in the peace with Palestinians felt betrayed -- by Yasir Arafat, by Shimon Peres, by all the foreign leaders who had insisted that peace would bring them security. Once again, many seemed to feel, in their immediate anguish, that Israel was waging "total war" and was alone.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: TOUR with Dr. James M. Shuart the campus that he spent most of his life on, and the trip does not go quickly. One minute you are walking and talking. The next there is no one beside to you.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ARMADILLO RODEO Written and illustrated by Jan Brett. Unpaged. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Widow Sues C.I.A. in Guatemalan's Killing
description: An American lawyer whose hunger strikes led to the disclosure that a paid agent of the Central Intelligence Agency was implicated in the murder of her husband, a Guatemalan guerrilla leader, has sued the agency and United States officials, seeking millions of dollars in damages.

title: WEDDINGS;Emi Ishida, Herman Chui
description: Emi Ishida, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Takanobu Ishida of Setauket, L.I., was married yesterday to Herman C. Chui, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles K. Chui of College Station, Tex. The Rev. Dr. John D. Koeker performed the ceremony at the Valley Presbyterian Church in Portola Valley, Calif.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Unsigned In Chicago: Good Coach With Karma
description: Phil Jackson will stroll into Madison Square Garden today looking like a poker player holding all the cards.

title: At African Heart of Voodoo, Pride Over Heritage
description: There are no factory whistles to compete with the church bells or the muezzin's call to prayer in this sun-battered town that resembles so many other forgotten stops along the West African coast. So few cars move about that schoolchildren think nothing of strolling down the middle of its sandy streets.

title: DINING OUT;For the Devotees of Hearty Meat Entrees
description: A RESTAURANT that calls itself the Stockyard pulls no punches. Diners in search of big beef and husky meat entrees know that this is the place. The decor at the new Westbury steakhouse is just as straightforward. Outside, a large bank-style clock is emblazoned with the image of a longhorn steer. That same logo appears on a mirror over the bar and is etched in glass room dividers.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Merger's Effect Echoes Home
description: An estimated 448 New Jersey workers are likely to lose their jobs under worldwide downsizing projected as part of the $27 billion merger announced on Thursday by the pharmaceutical giants Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, a spokesman for both companies said yesterday. The companies plan to lay off about 10 percent of their 135,000 employees worldwide. Eric Jackson, a spokesman for Ciba-Geigy, said it has 2,400 workers in Summit, West Caldwell and Woodbridge. An additional 2,000 work at the Sandoz pharmaceuticals headquarters in East Hanover. The merger was announced, pending approval by stockholders and regulators in the United States and Europe.

title: Will Thieves Crack Your Automated Nest Egg?
description: PILOTS for Trans World Airlines can view their 401(k) retirement accounts on their home computers to make sure their last contributions went into the proper investment and to calculate their portfolio's performance. They cannot, however, use the computer to switch investment choices or to borrow from their accounts.

title: Stunt Man
description: MAKING THE ALPHABET DANCE Recreational Wordplay. By Ross Eckler. 279 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $23.95.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Car Seats for Babies Are Found Flawed
description: A group of 15,370 rear-facing car seats for infants have been found defective by Cosco, the manufacturer. The seats, labeled Dreamride Ultra Car Bed-Seat, Model 02-719, were manufactured between April 8, 1994, and June 15, 1995. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration crash tests revealed that the seat rotated farther from the vertical position than the 70 degrees the Federal standard allows. Owners are advised to get a free reinforcement kit from Cosco, 2525 State Street, Columbus, Ind. 47201; (800) 314-9327.

title: GOOD EATING;In Queens, Exotica Becomes the Norm
description: CHRISTOS HASAPO-TAVERNA ++ (718) 726-5195; 41-08 23d Avenue, at 41st Street, Astoria; (c) all major credit cards

title: ART VIEW;The Groundwork For Masterpieces
description: ONE OF THE MOST rewarding things in life is to look over the shoulder of a great artist and see exactly what is going on, second by second. That is why people are standing in line outside the Picasso Museum here to see "Sketchbook Drawings by Picasso."

title: Top Bridge Teams Reach Vanderbilt Finals
description: Two of the best bridge teams in the world clashed here today in the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Eric Smith mimics Michael Jackson and Stevie Wonder and makes himself a hit in Brighton Beach.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE;Stoops: Steeped in History
description: Like the wrought-iron balconies of New Orleans and the bow-front houses of Boston, the stoop had long been an architectural signature of New York.

title: Bruno Stein, 65, N.Y.U. Labor Economist
description: Bruno Stein, a professor of economics at New York University who wrote extensively on labor relations, mediation and pension systems, died last Sunday of pancreatic cancer at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 65.

title: Police Singled Out Black Drivers In Drug Crackdown, Judge Says
description: A New Jersey judge has found that state police troopers patrolling southern reaches of the New Jersey Turnpike on the lookout for drug suspects singled out and pulled over black motorists in widely inordinate numbers over a three-year period simply because of their race.

title: The Black Truffle
description: IF A BIOGRAPHY OF MY STOMACH WERE EVER TO BE written, the longest chapter would undoubtedly be a salute to the "divine tubercule" -- the lumpy, pungent, giddily expensive black truffle.

title: Licensing Dog Breeders
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Mental Gymnastics;Crawling Up the Celestial Staircase
description: LIKE celestial couch potatoes glued to a giant television screen, we gaze at the twinkling lights in the sky above us. Without having to leave the comfort of our earthly living room, we conjure up a world out there.

title: CHOICE TABLES;Philadelphia Captivates Food Lovers
description: WALNUT and 15th. Any little black book listing choice restaurants in Philadelphia is bound to include that address. In fact, it is possible to eat well for a week without venturing beyond Walnut Street between South 15th and South 16th Streets.

title: A Journal of the War Years
description: THE BOOK OF SECRETS By M. G. Vassanji. 337 pp. New York: Picador USA. $24. THE "book of our secrets" is the name the village elders use for the journal they see a young British administrator writing in so earnestly every evening. The book, they say, is full of captured spirits. The elders are Muslims, with their roots in India, and the village is in British East Africa, near the border of German territory. The time is the beginning of World War I. Before the war is over, the diary will be stolen and Alfred Corbin, the young administrator in his first foreign post, will be transferred away.

title: L.I. VINES
description: Cabernet Port Pindar Vineyards, Peconic, 1992. About $24 (regular bottle) and $13 (half bottle).

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Starving at the Banquet
description: Originally published in 1873 and until now not easily available in English translation, mile Zola's novel THE BELLY OF PARIS (Sun and Moon, paper, $14.95) recounts the sad story of Florent, a young schoolteacher sent to prison after being falsely accused of resisting Louis Napoleon's coup d'tat in 1851. At the novel's opening, seven years have passed; Florent has escaped and returned to Paris half dead of starvation only to find himself lost in the sprawling, Lucullan new markets of Les Halles, overwhelmed by "an avalanche of food." These markets provide the book's true focus, as Zola chronicles the vigorous, greedy intrigues of butchers, fishwives, poultry sellers and butter dealers, all of whom feel first irritated, then threatened by the sight of this morose, idealistic, skinny young man. To Florent, the markets "appeared symbolical of some glutted, digesting beast, of Paris, wallowing in its fat and silently upholding the Empire" that has treated him so cruelly. Clearly that's also how they appeared to Zola, who, in Ernest Alfred Vizetelly's translation, minutely describes this "colossal belly" -- from the damp, odorous fish stalls to the mountains of fleshy produce in the vegetable and fruit pavilions. As Florent becomes increasingly repelled by Louis Napoleon's mercantile Paris and begins to plot an ill-fated insurrection, these descriptions turn monstrous. Never before has cheese seemed so sinister: "A Livarot was swarming with life; and in a fragile box behind the scales a Grom flavored with aniseed diffused such a pestilential smell that all around it the very flies had fallen lifeless on the gray-veined slab of ruddy marble." The novel's appeal lies, of course, in Zola's descriptive brilliance, his ability to paint this brutal, teeming world of food with the confidence of a Dutch master. But the political conflict, personified by scrawny Florent and the overfed shopkeepers, is artfully rendered as well. This is not a book for dieters -- or those with delicate stomachs. Suzanne Berne

title: Jean Maxwell, 81, An Expert on Aging And Social Welfare
description: Professor Jean Margaret Maxwell, who helped establish the New York School of Social Work at New York University in the 1950's and the San Diego State University School of Social Work in the 1960's, died on Feb. 22 at the Casa de Manana retirement community in San Diego. She was 81.

title: L.I.R.R. Planning New Emergency Procedures
description: FOLLOWING a rash of accidents elsewhere, the Long Island Rail Road will soon conduct a campaign to tell passengers how to escape from railroad cars in emergencies.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: CONFESSIONS OF AN IVY LEAGUE BOOKIE A True Tale of Love and the Vig. By Peter Alson. Crown, $22.

title: Latest Anti-Semitic Sprayings Reveal a Growing Trend of Hate
description: SPRAY painting of anti-Semitic sentiments on houses in the Orienta Point section of this village led to several recent momentous events here: a march down the Post Road before a forum at Mamaroneck High School, which drew 2,000 people including an impressive dais of politicians, law enforcers, members of the clergy and educators who vehemently denounced the actions, and a manhunt that blanketed the quiet Orienta Point streets with police officers.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Those Limit Orders Have Their Limits
description: THOUGH record amounts of cash have been pouring into mutual funds, some people have been sitting nervously on the sidelines, wanting to get in but wanting to avoid doing it at a market top.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 10, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: Palestinians Must Speak Out Against Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFITS
description: Ballet Honors MONDAY -- The School of American Ballet will benefit from a black-tie dinner at the New York State Theater. Leslie Caron and John S. Chalsty, the president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, will receive awards. Cocktails at 6:15 P.M. Tickets, $500, from (212) 877-0600.

title: The Dispossessed
description: A MODERN HISTORY OF THE KURDS By David McDowall. 472 pp. New York: I. B. Tauris/ St. Martin's Press. $35.

title: Approaching the Artichoke
description: WHEN I WAS A TEEN-AGER LIVing in France with my family, I heard a story about artichokes that made a strong impression on me. My father met a woman whose well-to-do family had been forced, during World War II, to take in German soldiers. Naturally, her family had not been pleased at the prospect, and on the appointed day they planned their first move: a dish that would be a piece de resistance in the truest sense of the term. That night for dinner, they served artichokes, but -- under cover of food shortages -- they provided only enough for the soldiers. Non, non, il n'y a pas de quoi, they said. You go ahead and enjoy them. They are such a delicacy, n'est-ce pas? And then they sat back and watched in silence as the Nazis, utterly at a loss and with no one to imitate, choked and chewed through every leaf, thorn and bristle.

title: Who Is the Best Restaurateur in America?
description: Entering TriBakery, his first stop of the day, Drew Nieporent pauses to shift the wicker baskets of the biggest loaves of bread to the top shelf, where they're easier for the customers to grab. He asks the cashier to push a tray of lemon squares to the front of the display case (easier for the customers to see) and points out that the pastries are end to end in one part of the case, sparse in another. A few words with the manager, and then, snatching a croissant on the way out, he walks next door to TriBeCa Grill, his highest-volume restaurant, where he picks up a sheet of telephone messages. Although he is the head of a restaurant empire that does nearly $30 million a year in business, Nieporent has yet to hire a secretary. He checks calls (most are from friends or friends of friends, hoping for a table at one of his restaurants), then studies the reservations list. Celebrities, friends, regular customers, food professionals: all will require some acknowledgment -- a little schmooze from the owner himself, a little something from the kitchen or both.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Finis to Tourist Agency On Eve of the Olympics
description: EMPLOYEES of the United States Travel and Tourism Administration were notified four weeks ago that their 35-year-old agency would be formally abolished on April 15.

title: Trying to Find a Common Ground
description: In the political history of New York City, few relationships have been as sensitive and problematic as that between black and Hispanic politicians. But now, with Republicans holding power in Albany and City Hall, the two groups have been finding common ground in recent months and trying to diffuse their past tensions.

title: U.S. Barbs Are Biggest Blow to Colombia Ties, Its Leader Says
description: President Ernesto Samper, riding out Colombia's recent loss of backing from Washington as a full partner in the fight against drugs, says that recent statements by American officials criticizing his presidency are more damaging to the two countries' relations than decertification itself.

title: Primary Colors
description: To the Editor:

title: Silence! Mr. Puddings in the Pot
description: SATURDAY MORNINGS. The kitchen of a brownstone house in Brooklyn long decades ago. And my sister and I sitting in tense silence at the table, our prayerful gaze on the large pot on the stove. In it, simmering away, was Mr. Pudding, the most highly prized dish from my mother's native Barbados.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;With a Little Help From Her Friends
description: TYPING away in obscurity at a computer screen in a Park Slope apartment, the aspiring novelist could be forgiven for a twinge of envy at the scene: a book party for a novice fiction writer at which 400 guests sipped wine and took in the breathtaking views from a $20 million duplex, with its own swimming pool, near the top of Olympic Tower.

title: SWIMMING;Splashing Toward A Historic First
description: When Byron Davis lets his mind sprint along with his body, he dreams of the Summer Olympics in Atlanta, his arm raised high after a good swim, water rolling off his body, tears of release streaming down his face.

title: Shuttle Lands in Florida After Troubled Flight
description: The space shuttle Columbia and its seven-member crew returned to Earth today, ending a 16-day flight marred by a landing-system failure and the loss of a tethered science satellite.

title: Commercial Property/Times Square;Those Retail Feet Are Dancing North of 42d Street
description: TIMES SQUARE has been good to Arthur J. Cutler. His three West 44th Street restaurants -- Ollie's Noodle Shop, Carmine's and Virgil's -- are great successes. Not surprisingly, he is looking to open even more restaurants nearby.

title: New Room (With View) For Police At Stamford Station
description: FOR at least a decade, Metro-North Commuter Railroad and Amtrak passengers using the Stamford station have called the concrete passageway beneath the tracks the "tunnel of terror." Rather than use the tunnel, many riders would go from one side of the station to the other by walking under the railroad bridges on Washington Boulevard and Atlantic Street.

title: Hawaii's Queen
description: To the Editor: How can I express my appreciation for Susan F. Yim's lovely "Echoes of a Vanished Hawaii" (Jan. 21)? What excited me and my husband was the photo of Queen Emma's Summer Palace, since we had just returned from a month in Hawaii. My play, "Queen Emma, Blossom of Hawaii," was performed twice there in Emmalani Hall, making it the first production in this new showplace that is now part of the Summer Palace.

title: George Burns, Straight Man And Ageless Wit, Dies at 100
description: Correction Appended

title: WEDDINGS;Sharon Feit, Thomas Calaman
description: Sharon Feit, the daughter of Patricia and Richard Feit of Flushing, Queens, is to be married today to Thomas Anthony Calaman, the son of Toby and Donald Calaman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich is to officiate at Fox Hollow, a catering concern in Woodbury, L.I.

title: ON THE MAP;Towering Over Weehawken, a Form in Search of a Function
description: The red-brick tower is an anomaly, seemingly transplanted from Renaissance Italy and placed next to a shopping complex in the middle of Weehawken. It's also a reminder that some things, no matter how long they have outlived their usefulness, are too beautiful to destroy.

title: Amigo Cantisano's Organic Dream
description: IT'S EARLY JANUARY, AND TODAY, NEAR Auburn, Calif., in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, the sun is too warm to be seasonable, the blue sky washed by remnants of early-morning fog. Three weeks ago, after a dry autumn, a major winter storm blew across the north-central section of the state. As the storm moved eastward, its force began to wane, but not before it visited this small grove of olive trees 120 miles northeast of San Francisco, harvesting them with uncanny and unwelcome thoroughness. The ground here is purple with ripe olives unprofitably leaching their oil onto the roots of last year's olive seedlings.

title: OUT THERE: LOS ANGELES;Boulevard Chic: A Mix of Scotch And Hopscotch
description: THIS is perhaps the one town on earth where wheat-grass juice and $645 imported thigh-high boots can comfortably share a commercial strip.

title: WOMEN'S HISTORY MONTH;Exploring Women's Lives in Art, Song, Magic and More
description: Women's History Month is being observed in March (and in some cases beyond). Here's a sampling of scheduled events:

title: The Theory Of Supermarkets
description: Is it possible even to describe the otherworldly rush and animal wonder one feels on entering the modern supermarket? The journey is transforming, beginning with that blast of unnatural wind -- the chilly zephyr in summer, the dragon's breath in winter -- that conducts us through the automatic portals into this highly ordered yet voluptuous realm. It is, on some level, our greatest achievement. The painted cinder blocks of the average Food Lion are the true heirs to the walls of Jericho, built to protect the earliest stores of wheat and strike the first blow for post-nomadic culture.

title: March 3-9;For Stocks, Good News Is Bad
description: What's up? Doesn't the stock market want Americans to have jobs?

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Neighborly Patrols
description: SOMEBODY called 911 from a pay phone on Ohio Avenue, reported a disturbance and left the receiver dangling in a crisp midwinter wind.

title: Love Among the Ruins
description: ON Feb. 26, 1995, the day her husband helped bring down a venerable British investment bank, Lisa Leeson joined a rather exclusive sorority. Its members include Lori Milken (wife of Michael) and Seema Boesky (former wife of Ivan), part of an elite group whose husbands perpetrated spectacular feats of fraud and illegal financial manipulation.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UNION SQUARE;Park's New Problem: Success
description: Ten years ago, before Union Square became a poster child for urban revitalization, a coalition of business leaders, neighborhood advocates and city officials agreed that the 3.5-acre park should expand into Union Square West as part of an ambitious scheme to nearly double the park's size.

title: Search Ended in Bombay Building Collapse
description: Rescue teams ended a search today for bodies trapped in a collapsed apartment building in Bombay, the police said. The collapse on Thursday killed 27 people.

title: ON COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Allen Sinks the Shot That Matters
description: Ray Allen was talking about being afraid. Allen listened to a question about something he had once said, a memory of being scared at the start of his freshman season at Connecticut.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;San Francisco
description: Never modest about their city, San Franciscans now have more reasons to boast. Instead of yet another Super Bowl victory by the Forty-Niners, however, civic pride is focusing on the new and revitalized arts institutions and museums that assure the city a position in the cultural big leagues.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Playing Variations On Russian Themes
description: AMONG THE RUSSIAN CULTURAL treasures brought to light by the dismantling of the Iron Curtain is the St. Petersburg String Quartet. Although this youthful ensemble, which sprouted as a student venture at the Leningrad Conservatory in 1985, has come to international attention rather slowly, its reputation now rests on a solid foundation of collective musical savvy and interpretive vision, to judge from a small but impressive group of recordings on Sony Classical.

title: Job Cuts to Cause Token-Booth Delays
description: Subway riders who buy tokens at many of the city's larger stations can expect delays beginning tomorrow morning as a result of the elimination of 125 token-clerk jobs, Transit Authority officials said yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Hundley and Thompson Play
description: Catcher Todd Hundley and outfielder Ryan Thompson made their spring debuts today in a 6-2 B game loss to Baltimore at Fort Lauderdale Stadium.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Gardens Should Get a Life

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: SHELL GAME A True Story of Banking, Spies, Lies, Politics -- and the Arming of Saddam Hussein. By Peter Mantius. St. Martin's, $23.95.

title: A Lifetime in the News
description: EVENTS LEADING UP TO MY DEATH The Life of a Twentieth-Century Reporter. By Howard K. Smith. Illustrated. 419 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: On the Ferry in Winter: Poetry in Motion
description: DURING the summer months, the Bridgeport-Port Jefferson ferry is like a cruise ship. The two big white boats, Park City and Grand Republic, sail out of Port Jefferson with a colorful cargo of sunbathers, dressed for all the world as though they expected to land in Barbados instead of Bridgeport.

title: Utility Defends Safety Of Its Nuclear Plants
description: In response to a series of sharp rebukes recently from Federal regulators for problems at its four Connecticut nuclear power plants, Northeast Utilities said yesterday that the plants were safe and a newly reshaped management would insure that errors would not be repeated.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Millie Grenough;In Tune With English, Accent on Grammar
description: MILLIE GRENOUGH is a social worker in private practice, a professional singer and musician and a teacher of English as a Second Language. She has master's degrees in both teaching and social work and lives in New Haven. And her resume notes that she is from "a singing family" of seven children. Last year McGraw-Hill published her "Sing It! Learn English Through Song," a six-level text/workbook/cassette series.

title: EARNING IT;When Abuse Follows Women to Work
description: IN December, an angry assembly-line worker at a Chrysler Corporation plant in Sterling Heights, Mich., fatally shot Jacqueline Pritchett, a co-worker, before killing himself. The incident was another case of workplace violence, but it had a second side, too: Ms. Pritchett was killed by a boyfriend against whom she had recently filed an assault complaint.

title: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Of Flags and the Future
description: The Clinton-Gore '96 Primary Committee, President Clinton's re-election apparatus, began broadcasting a 30-second commercial on Friday that presents Mr. Clinton's positions on leading social issues. Campaign officials have declined to say where the advertisement will run; a Republican consultant who follows political advertising purchases told The Associated Press that it would be broadcast in Michigan, Illinois, Ohio, Wisconsin and California. ON THE SCREEN The commercial opens with a close-up of a waving American flag, the words "America's Future" superimposed upon it, then dissolves to a shot of Mr. Clinton delivering his State of the Union Message last January. It cuts to a montage of children, families, blue-collar workers, boarded-up homes and more scenes of Mr. Clinton's speech. It closes with a little girl, hand on chest, pledging allegiance to the flag.

title: Thatcher Urges Stronger Atlantic Alliance
description: Describing a world similar to the one Winston Churchill saw 50 years ago, Margaret Thatcher urged today that NATO be expanded and refocused militarily and that allies on both sides of the Atlantic form a political and trade partnership.

title: New Life at a Hapsburg Playground
description: THE most poignant sight in Schonbrunn, Vienna's homage to Versailles, is not the white-and-gold Mirror Hall in which the six-year-old Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart in 1762 played before Empress Maria Theresa, nor is it the short iron bed in which old Emperor Franz Joseph died in 1916. It is, at least for me, a little bird.

title: Writing for the Ages
description: To the Editor:

title: HISTORICAL SHOWS;Arrogance In High Places
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation;Mr. Forbes's Modest Plan
description: STEVE FORBES has ridiculed suggestions that he is spending millions on a campaign for President just because his proposed flat tax would cut his tax bill.

title: You Left Your Heart Where?
description: NOT long ago my friend Elsie Ruth asked me to accompany her on a drive from Chicago to Washington State, where she had some business.

title: In a Great Shark Debate, All Sorts of Tooth Marks
description: Hey, dude, there's a shark."

title: MARKET WATCH;Anybody Want To Buy A Bond?
description: Sometimes, it matters who has been doing the buying.

title: Schools Find New Roles for Computers
description: WHILE some of their classmates were reading from a picture book, several second-grade students at the Columbus Elementary School here were putting the finishing touches on volcano pictures. Instead of applying paintbrush strokes, the children painted with strokes on a computer keyboard, selecting and changing hues as quickly as their little hands could move.

title: The View From: West Haven;Young Hands Helping Abandoned Animals
description: THEY rush in, throw down their book bags, hang up their clothes, do their chores, then dash to their favorite pets. They're the Kennel Kids, who work with unwanted animals, helping out at the West Haven Animal Shelter: more particularly, the Judy E. Rettig Animal Care Facility.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: A CULINARY JOURNEY IN GASCONY Recipes and Stories From My French Canal Boat. By Kate Ratliffe. Ten Speed, paper, $16.95.

title: Sunday March 10, 1996: SISTERS UNDER THE SKIN;Dialing For Doctors
description: Working for something called the directorate of telemedicine has a bit of an Orwellian air about it, but U.S. soldiers abroad should be thankful that Cheryl and Linda Youngblood Sales, sisters, are keeping their eyes on them. Their electronic house calls save lives.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Megalopolis On the Slopes
description: The owners of the Sugarbush and Killington ski areas have announced plans to merge their operating companies to create the American Skiing Company, which they say will be the largest ski operating company in North America, based on annual skier visits, which are projected to reach 3.5 million by the end of this season. Les Otten, president and chief executive officer of L.B.O. Resort Enterprises -- whose holdings include Sugarbush, Sunday River in Maine and Attitash Bear Peak Cranmore in New Hampshire -- will become head of the new company. In addition to the above resorts, the new company will include the holdings of S-K-I Limited, which owns Killington, Mount Snow and Haystack in Vermont, Waterville Valley in New Hampshire and Sugarloaf/U.S.A. in Maine. The merger must be approved by stockholders of S-K-I Ltd.

title: BELLEVUE'S EMERGENCY
description: I was interested in two pieces of information that were inadvertently revealed in Katherine Eban Finkelstein's article "Bellevue's Emergency" (Feb. 11). First, that Michelle C., a welfare mother, could afford a car in New York City. And second, that Medicaid patients are now the most prized and sought-after population in voluntary hospitals.

title: CUTTINGS;It's Time to Prune, With Reverence and Abandon
description: Everyone who got all his or her pruning done this winter raise your hand. I don't see any hands.

title: Sir James Sutherland Dies at 95, Collected Stories About Writers
description: Sir James Runcieman Sutherland, a British connoisseur of literary anecdotes who taught at five American universities, died on Feb. 24 at the Oaken Holt Residential Home in Eynsham, near Oxford, England, The Guardian reported on Friday. He was 95.

title: North Carolina High Court Backs Tax Money to Aid Businesses
description: Conservative groups seeking to limit the role of government and curb the uses of public money were dealt a setback on Friday when North Carolina's highest court upheld the constitutionality of a host of tax-financed incentives that communities and the state could use to aid businesses.

title: Drive to Build Jewish Museum in Warsaw Meets Ambivalence
description: In the belief that Poles should understand more about the long history of Jews in their country than the abbreviated account of the Holocaust taught in schools, an effort is under way to build a Jewish museum here.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 25 about a museum show tracing the history of blacks in the Stony Brook area misstated the ancestry of Ted Green, historian of a family of early settlers, the Harts. Rachel Holland Hart was Mr. Green's grandmother on his mother's side, not his father's.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-12

title: VOWS;Toni Kotite and Adam Guild
description: MANY members of the class of 1981 at the Dalton School in Manhattan remember Toni Kotite, 32, very well. She would regularly walk into ninth-grade classes wearing one red stocking and one blue stocking, with a sweater, a miniskirt and a giant grin. "She was crazy, she was fun, she had terrific spirit, she had insane clothes," Angela Janklow Harrington, a classmate and friend, recalled.

title: GARDENING;Rejuvenation After the Biting Winter of '96
description: SNOWDROPS have bloomed. The witchhazels have burst. Crocus spears are showing. Even the daffodils are pushing up leaf tips. In short, the earth is coming alive again and none too soon. Although spring does not officially arrive until March 20, its preview performances are too emphatic to be denied.

title: ART REVIEW;Footnotes on Paper That Speak Volumes
description: A GOOD title is hard to find, and "Important Papers," though reminiscent of the "captured documents" that loomed so large in the Vietnam era, is one of the best. For the last few years, such papers have come in peace to the Walker Kornbluth Gallery here, bearing not words but images, painted, drawn and printed. This time around, there are nearly 70 of them representing 15 artists, most of them well-known in New Jersey and Rockland County, N.Y., and a few with international reputations.

title: BASEBALL;Davey Johnson Tries to Make Peace With the Past
description: A look at Davey Johnson's won-lost record as a major league manager would not lead to the conclusion that this is a man who cannot get or hold a job. A look at his employment record would indicate otherwise.

title: CUNY Investigation Clears Kingsborough College Chief
description: Leon M. Goldstein, whose chance to become New York City schools chancellor last fall was derailed by questions over his 24-year tenure as president of Kingsborough Community College, has been cleared of any significant wrongdoing by a City University of New York investigation, officials said yesterday.

title: IN BRIEF;Moving With the Seasons, Eastwind Changes Routes
description: Trenton-based Eastwind Airlines will substitute new routes to Providence and Richmond for its Florida flights beginning April 16. The change will give Eastwind, which also serves Boston and Greensboro, N.C., four flights daily on the East Coast.

title: INSIDE
description: China Announces New Tests

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Year-Old State Housing Plan Starts Up 2,600 Units
description: A YEAR ago New Jersey unveiled its first comprehensive housing plan -- a broad blueprint designed to funnel $700 million by the turn of the century into the production of low- and moderate-income residences while increasing home ownership in the state's cities and rental housing in its suburbs.

title: Classrooms Plug In, With Clinton's Help
description: President Clinton was in California yesterday for ceremonies intended to promote his goal of connecting every school in the nation to the Internet by the turn of the century. More than 20,000 volunteers across the state helped lay six million feet of cable that will give classrooms access to cyberspace. Technology companies sponsored the effort.

description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Sunday

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: FILM VIEW;Why Can't Hollywood Get Gay Life Right?
description: TWO YEARS AFTER Hollywood stepped gingerly into the territory of gay drama with "Philadelphia," the major studios have ventured to release another star vehicle with homosexual heroes. "The Birdcage," directed by Mike Nichols from a script by Elaine May, would seem ideally designed to overcome the public's presumed distaste for gay protagonists.

title: Sense And Edibility;The Cake Decorator
description: Colette Peters, Colette's Cakes, New York City JOB: Owner of Colette's Cakes; designer, baker and decorator of elaborate cakes; author of three books on cake decorating. WHERE TO FIND HER CREATIONS: Society weddings, celebrity birthdays and other events that require custom-made cakes. WORK EXPERIENCE: Formerly a designer for Tiffany & Company; 15 years as a professional cake decorator. JOB-RELATED EDUCATION: M.F.A. in painting; self-taught cake decorator. DAILY INGREDIENTS: 4 pounds of buttercream (3 cups of sugar, 3 pounds of butter and 1 1/2 cups of egg whites) for a typical wedding cake.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;Glad to Have Police, but Not in Parking Spaces
description: When the city reopened the Flushing Armory as a homeless shelter in December, businesses and residents were relieved to find that the Police Department's Queens North Task Force was also moving in.

title: Let Political Pundits Take Page From Bookies
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE STREET;Meeting Winter Head-On, With Zip
description: The jump suit has emerged this winter as a weekend alternative to the popular fashion of dressing in sportswear layers. It has always been a speedy one-step way of dressing for skiing and for cold snowy weather off the slopes.

title: Sunday March 10, 1996: PAT BOONE, REBORN AGAIN;Love Letters in the Slag
description: He's a guy so far away from the mainstream of pop music that he can be accepted by it." The he in question is Mr. White Bucks himself, Pat Boone, the Anti-Elvis of the 50's and 60's. The speaker, David Dorn of Rhino Entertainment, wasn't even born when Boone started recording blanched versions of R & B tunes four decades ago, but the L.A. recording executive knows "cool kitsch" when he hears it. And he knows the MTV kids, who adored the new video "Pat Boone: 40 Years of Hits." So Dorn and his colleagues are in the process of reinventing the 61-year-old Boone as a heavy-metal rocker. If all goes as planned, in the fall Rhino will release an album -- working title, "Pat Boone: No More Mr. Nice Guy" -- on which this exemplar of Christian virtue will put his own spin to hits by the likes of Guns 'n' Roses, Metallica, Jimi Hendrix and other artists from, you would have thought, the nether world of Boone's musical taste.

title: In Special Education, One Size Doesn't Fit All
description: To the Editor:

title: Cold Comfort
description: WILL YOU ALWAYS LOVE ME? And Other Stories. By Joyce Carol Oates. 326 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/Dutton. $23.95.

title: Bricks and Mortar
description: Studies in Tectonic Culture The Poetics of Construction in Nineteenth and Twentieth Century Architecture. By Kenneth Frampton. Edited by John Cava. Illustrated. 430 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $50.

title: Money From Sports Tickets Could Finish Chelsea Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: The Thames, the Sound And Toxic Dumping
description: Arthur J. Rocque Jr. of the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection was being overly kind in his assessment that some of the opponents to the United States Navy dredging of the Thames River were "extremely economical with the truth." ("Navy Facing Criticism in Toxic Dumping," Feb. 4). Sadly, the article appears afflicted with a similar parsimony.

title: Liberties;Love That Bob
description: Bob Dole is the candidate of not.

title: Myrtle Beach Satisfies Golf Gluttons
description: THE golf holiday, in its traditional middle-class male model, is an occasion to binge. Escaping the long drive to a course and the long wait to tee off, and saying goodbye to the family, the lawn and other demands on his leisure time, the golfer picks up his sticks and heads for a golf-vacation destination, where the courses are plentiful and playing 27 to 36 holes a day for six days is virtually hassle-free.

title: Fugitive Opts To Surrender, Four Decades After Flight
description: A Portland, Ore., man who spent almost four decades living quietly as a fugitive surrendered on Friday to the authorities in Washington State, his lawyer said.

title: Speaking English Properly Is No Cause for Derision
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY & CO.;Towns Battle Phone Towers, but the Towers Have the Edge
description: As the home of AT&T's Basking Ridge headquarters, this Somerset County community has long depended on the telephone industry. But in recent years, Bernards has joined a growing roster of municipalities resisting an increasingly important part of the business: cellular phone towers and antennas.

title: Center for Elderly Exposes Racial Tensions
description: Seventeen years ago, Marge and Dennis Jones, an interracial couple six months into their marriage, were searching for a tolerant suburb where the passel of children they envisioned having would feel at ease. They moved into a four-bedroom Cape Cod in Greenburgh, a racially mixed town 15 miles north of New York City, and had four children. Mrs. Jones said her family had never encountered racial hostility.

title: Catching a Man With Arroz con Leche
description: DON'T KNOW WHERE I GOT THE IDEA that this is the dessert by which a girl proves she is ready for marriage. I think Mami put this story into my head. Whenever she wanted to encourage my domestic arts, she'd sing me a little song called "Arroz con Leche, Rice Pudding":

title: TO AND FRO ON TWO WHEELS
description: IT wasn't until I set out by bike that I understood what a challenge South Carolina's Low Country must have been to its first European settlers, who arrived from Spain and France in the 1500's. A flat land gently fractured by a maze of rivers and millenniums of tidal flooding, the coast south of Charleston is all salt marshes and sea islands, and biking from point A to point B usually meant backtracking to a bridge to bypass the swamp or estuary between us and our destination. Since getting from A to B was not really our goal, we saw each dead end not as a frustration but as an opportunity to glimpse the subdued beauty of the landscape, with its muted grays and browns and patches of green, often hidden, literally, by aggressive jasmine and honeysuckle vines or by spidery live oaks festooned in Spanish moss. Home builders add to the general subtlety, favoring waterfront to roadfront, so that all a visitor might see is the ghostly white glow of a mansion tucked at the river-end of a long tree-filled lot.

title: Study Questions Monitoring of Fetus at Birth
description: A study has cast doubt on the effectiveness of fetal monitors in preventing brain damage during childbirth, finding that 99.8 percent of all signs of such injuries turn out to be false alarms.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: ART VIEW;In Love With the Myth of the 'Outsider'
description: PROBABLY NO ART SO CATERS TO THE public's hatred of the establishment as outsider art. The work of the uneducated, the insane, the criminal and the underprivileged, outsider art preserves a myth of esthetic purity for a culture tired of its experts. The outsider artist has not suffered the deforming influence of art school, and his art requires no esoteric explanation from critics. Motivated merely by the joy of making art, the outsider is totally unaware, or so the story goes, of the history of art or of the marketplace.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN As Naval Engagements Go, Not a Classic
description: Anne Frank Remembered Kenneth Branagh (narrator), Glenn Close (reading excerpts from "The Diary of Anne Frank"), Hanneli Goslar, Peter Pfeffer Directed by Jon Blair PG 122 minutes

title: One for Dinner
description: To the Editor: Two to three times a year I ride Amtrak's City of New Orleans round trip between New Orleans and Fulton, Ky. I have complained in the past to Amtrak about diner seating practices, and have been issued a letter of apology and a refund voucher. But the service remains unchanged.

title: The Survivor
description: HEAVEN'S COAST A Memoir. By Mark Doty. 305 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $24. RACKED by back pain, the poet Mark Doty decided to consult a New Age healer. "On my first visit," he tells us in the prologue of his new memoir, "as I lay on my stomach in a room full of ferns and charts marking the locations of chakras and pressure points, she touched one vertebra which throbbed, seemed almost to ring, painfully, like a struck tuning fork." When Mr. Doty told her this was the source of his misery, she replied that the damaged vertebra was the one that represented "faith in the future." Small wonder: a few months earlier, Mr. Doty had learned that his lover, Wally Roberts, was H.I.V. positive.

title: Pursuing a Theme, Clinton Helps Schools Go On-Line
description: With a length of electrical cable and a nod to the American traditions of barn-raisings, quilting-bees and victory gardens, President Clinton helped wire classrooms in a California high school to the Internet today in a first step toward his goal of connecting every school in the nation by the turn of the century.

title: March 3-9;The Agony of Victory
description: Suppose, for a moment, that Pat Buchanan won the Republican nomination, but so narrowly that he had to squash his pride and take as his running mate Al D'Amato, the very man he had blasted for backing Bob Dole. Think of the humiliation.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;The Upset Of Tourney Is the Lack Of Upsets
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference prides itself on the intensity and competitiveness of its post-season tournament, the nation's third oldest. But matters went very much according to form today in the semifinals, continuing a rather quiet weekend at the Greensboro Coliseum.

title: DIARY
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Robert Morton, Top Producer for Letterman, Leaves 'Late Show'
description: Robert Morton, the executive producer of "Late Show with David Letterman" and a close associate of Mr. Letterman for virtually all of the comedian's career in television, will leave that show immediately, staff members on the late night program said yesterday.

title: BELLEVUE'S EMERGENCY
description: Bellevue's influence extends far west of the Hudson River. In addition to serving as a bulwark for medical care for the underserved, it stands as a beacon for the principle that all humans are deserving of compassionate assistance in their time of need.

title: A Bosnian Education
description: LOVE THY NEIGHBOR A Story of War. By Peter Maass. 305 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25. THE war in Bosnia has elicited no civilized response from the West other than good books written by journalists who have witnessed the carnage. No one knows this better than the journalists themselves, so their books are sad, verging on heartbroken, and Peter Maass's "Love Thy Neighbor: A Story of War" is the one of the saddest and best that I have read.

title: Late Blast of Cold Coats East in Ice and Misery
description: Spring may be just around the corner, but a bone-chilling burst of arctic air shattered records all along the Eastern Seaboard yesterday as March blustered along more leonine than lamblike.

title: F.D.A.'s Policy Endorsed
description: Although critics of the Federal Food and Drug Administration are clamoring for the United States to copy Europe's system for approving medical devices, Congress should wait for more proof that such a change would be helpful, a Government report issued on Friday says.

title: Rene Thinks, Therefore He Is. You?
description: MOST people talk about themselves in the first person: "I am I, Don Quixote." "I'm puttin' on my top hat." "I am not a crook." "I" is normal. But if I said to my wife, "Richard Sandomir is throwing out the garbage," she would reply, "Griffin Miller is proud of you, you yutz."

title: Victor Crawford, 63; Opposed Smoking
description: Victor Crawford, a former tobacco lobbyist who became a crusader against smoking after his throat cancer was diagnosed, died on March 2 at Johns Hopkins Hospital here. He was 63 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: MUSIC;Choral Programs Hint at the Approach of Spring
description: CROCUSES may provide the first visual signs of spring, but the proliferation of choral concerts is also a good indication that winter days are numbered. Today at 4 P.M., the Taghkanic Chorale brings "Melodies and Dances From the Old Country" to Peekskill. The program at the Paramount Center for the Arts is devoted to traditional tunes filtered through the genius of Brahms ("Gypsy Songs"), Bartok ("Four Slavic Folk Songs") and Elgar ("Songs of the Bavarian Highlands"). The music director, Johannes Somary, will conduct, and tickets will be available at the door.

title: Following in the Frog's Footsteps
description: IT ISN'T EASY BEING GREEN," Kermit the Frog used to warble in one of his better-known ballads. Still, through perseverance and the appeal of his gently quirky Clifford personality, Kermit made himself a movie and television star.

title: 2 Men Killed In an Ambush In St. Thomas
description: Two South Carolina men who had come here to visit and liked it so much they stayed were ambushed, robbed and shot execution-style on Friday, the police said. It was the third attack on visitors from the mainland here this year.

title: The Generation Gap;What Kids Don't Get About Food
description: Boy - How can you eat something that smells and has mold all on it? Dad - It is form France. Boy - Oh.

title: Red, Hot and Chili
description: THE HOTTEST THING IN my childhood was my father's temper. Our kitchen was empty of spices -- only some banal chaff in dusty bottles. We ate instant mashed potatoes, canned spinach, overcooked hash; food drained of color, growing cold.

title: After the Prince Turns Into a Frog
description: AS Nicholas W. Leeson sits in a Singapore prison, Lisa Leeson has been loyally supporting him. But often, when a rogue trader or financier gets caught, the marriage cannot survive the strain.

title: March 3-9;China Sends Taiwan A Dangerous Signal
description: The psychological warfare that China is waging against Taiwan entered the danger zone last week when Beijing staged ballistic missile tests that amounted to assaults by Beijing on watery target zones a few dozen miles off Taiwan's main seaports.

title: EARNING IT;True or False: The Japanese Have Exams for Everything
description: DO the Japanese take lots of tests? You may not know the half of it.

title: Oaxaca
description: To the Editor: How fortunate we were to have read your article "In Oaxaca, Reveling in the Exchange Rate" (Jan. 7) just before visiting this area. It was surprising to us how few tourists were in an area that contains consistently ideal weather (warm, sunny days and cool, clear nights), friendly people and culinary delights. The coffee, hot chocolate and fresh juices can only be described as outstanding, as are the region's numerous other foods. And, finally, the highly favorable exchange rate made everything very reasonable. For example, we ate at a first-rate French restaurant (Las Chalotes, 116 Fiallo, near the zocalo) not mentioned in your article. An exquisite dinner, including appetizers, quail, rich desserts and wine came to under $30 for the two of us!

title: Anti-Smoking Code Faces Legal Hurdle
description: WESTCHESTER'S tough anti-smoking ordinance, adopted less than two weeks ago by the County Board of Health, is already facing a legal challenge from restaurateurs and tavern owners. And even if it clears that hurdle, the amendment to the Health Code -- considered one of the strictest in the state -- may be quickly superseded by a weaker bill out of Albany intended, in part, to ease the economic impact of no-smoking policies on the tourism and hospitality industries.

title: Center for Homeless Veterans Offers Balm for the Wounds Within
description: He was one of five from his infantry unit in Vietnam selected for search and destroy missions. "You go in one end, come out the other and leave nothing alive in between," said James Metts, who estimates that he killed thousands of Vietnamese before his yearlong tour ended in 1972. "Babies, old people, the whole nine yards."

title: New Technology Sells Schools on Weather
description: ON a recent afternoon after classes at Yorktown High School, two ninth graders, Noah Weber and Justin Longobardi, both 15, sat at a computer and checked on current weather conditions, which were being gathered by sensors on the school's roof. A nearby modem was ready to transmit the data to WNBC-TV Channel 4 in midtown Manhattan, where it is used during broadcast weather reports several times a week.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;A Top Principal Forsakes City For Suburbs
description: The madness starts at 7:30 A.M. Roberta Kirshbaum arrives at Public School 75 on West End Avenue at 96th Street to begin a 10-hour juggling act in which she dashes between classrooms and her office, playing nurse, secretary, teacher, counselor, hall monitor, grant-writer and ombudsman for 700 parents. She is P.S. 75's principal.

title: The World: Alien Expressions;Wretched Refuse Is Just the Start
description: BOB DOLE, in his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, talks about illegal immigration as a "flood." Patrick J. Buchanan calls it an "invasion." This meeting of the metaphors offers a quick summary of the images that Americans invoke in discussions of immigration. Other countries have their own metaphors.

title: JERSEY;Credit on Campus, but Not for Courses
description: THEY hand out all this free stuff just for filling out a credit card form," declared Alison Gertel, 18, a freshman on the Rutgers University campus in New Brunswick.

title: OUTDOORS;One Man Fishes While The Rest Of Us Freeze
description: What do long lines of people at the supermarket checkout counters and heavy bird-feeder activity portend? According to Christopher Letts of Peekskill, N.Y., they mean that it is time for him to go ice fishing.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: INVESTING IT;Is There a Matisse in Your Future? How to Invest in Aesthetics
description: WILLIAM M. B. BERGER -- like three generations of his family before him -- has done a lot of investing in his time. He began managing money in 1950, earned a reputation as an aggressive-growth investor, and for 20 years served as president of the $3 billion family of mutual funds that bear his name.

title: What's Behind The Bovine Sign?
description: For weeks, locals have asked one another what's behind the names Holy Cow and Udder Club, emblazoned in white on new dark-green awnings on an 86th Street building near Broadway. This being the Upper West Side, it was a safe bet that the awnings signaled the arrival of a bar or restaurant, rather than a dairy. Still, why those names? A co-owner of both, Bob Farley, explained that the signature line of Phil Rizzuto, the broadcast voice of the Yankees for 39 years, was the inspiration for Holy Cow, a steakhouse that is opening tomorrow. Among the parters are several New York sports figures, including Brian Leetch of the Rangers, Pat Kelly of the Yankees, the fighter Shannon Briggs and Howard Cross of the Giants. And the Udder Club, which will be for private parties only? The logic of the name is practically transparent, Mr. Farley reasoned. "You know, the udders are underneath the cow." JANET ALLON

title: Not Your Grandmother's Head Cheese
description: FIVE YEARS AFTER MY grandmother's death, I wake knowing that never again will I taste her head cheese. You know what head cheese is, of course. Or were you not raised as I was, eating parts of animals that other people unreasonably despise? Head cheese (at least my grandmother's own peculiar recipe) is made from the meat boiled off the head of a pig or cow, all the chopped bits suspended in a vinegary-salty gelled broth. My grandmother hardened her head cheese in clean half-gallon Oak Grove milk cartons, so it was always sandwich size, square, studded with graceful curlicues of cartilage, sliced from the block as you unpeeled the waxed cardboard. I miss my grandmother's head cheese the way Proust missed his lime-blossom-tea-soaked madeleine cakes. I miss it more, because unlike his cakes, this head cheese is unavailable anywhere else and will never be tasted again upon this earth.

title: Palestinians Must Speak Out Against Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Sugar, My Sugar
description: LIFE ISN'T GOOD ENOUGH FOR no cigarette," says Leonard Michaels. This is precisely how I've come to view my relationship to sugar. Today was a disaster, I tell myself at least twice a week, stopping on my way home from work at a cafe that makes the most perfect Rice Krispies Treats, but this tastes delicious. Quentin Tarantino, asked why he eats Cap'n Crunch, replied, "Because it tastes good and is easy to fix." Cap'n Crunch, Rice Krispies Treats: I'm addicted to refined sugar in its less refined forms -- breakfast cereal, cookies, ice cream, root beer, licorice, peanut brittle, et al., ad nauseam. Kid's stuff. When I'm happy, I consume sweets to celebrate. When I'm upset, I eat treats as consolation. Since I'm fairly manic-depressive, I never don't have a reason to be in the throes of sugar shock. I don't smoke. I don't do drugs. I do sugar -- in massive doses. So what? Who doesn't? What's the harm? Where's the interest? It's imperative that I be reading nonfiction prose when mainlining glucose. I stutter, and much of the glory of sugar is the way it seems like succor to my tired mouth muscles. Sugar consumption is, to me, a gorgeous allegory about intractable reality and very temporary transcendence. A bumper sticker, as always, gets it right: Eat dessert first; life is uncertain.

title: How Big a Threat Today Is the Factionalism Madison Foresaw?
description: To the Editor:

title: Younger Audiences, Younger Performers
description: PERFORMANCES by and for young people are much in evidence today, starting at 2 o'clock when Connecticut Ballet offers a free "Coppelia" ticket to each child accompanied by an adult. Delibes' popular work is a ballet with a story, so the performance at Rich Forum in Stamford offers children an easy-to-follow introduction to the dance.

title: POLITICS: STEVE FORBES;In Their Own Words
description: He spoke yesterday in Miami, reacting to former Vice President Dan Quayle's suggestion that he drop out of the Presidential race:

title: A LA CARTE;The All-You-Can Eat Barbecue Dinner, Portuguese-Style
description: RODIZIO, the Brazilian and Portuguese all-you-can-eat barbecue dinner, has come to Nassau County. And Manny Carvalho, the man who, along with his wife, Louisa, introduced it at their new 100-seat Churrasquiera Bairrada, at 144 Jericho Turnpike, in Mineola (739-3856), is at least as much of a story as the all-inclusive meat-centered meal.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Reflecting on a Decision to Leave
description: Naomi Hill was seduced by the suburbs. In 1991, after 11 years as principal of Public School 87, which gained national prominence during her tenure, she was dazzled at the discoveries just across the Hudson, in Tenafly, N.J.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Europe By Bus: New Dimensions
description: A new European bus service, Cityzap, is entering the market for budget travelers, joining Eurobus, which started a year ago and is doing well, according to its founder.

title: Political Memo;Giuliani And Bratton: The Ties That Chafe
description: William J. Bratton's term as New York City's Police Commissioner officially ended 18 days ago. His reappointment would normally be a formality, since commissioners have always served at the pleasure of their mayors, even though the City Charter specifies a five-year term.

title: THE TRIALS OF A PEACE SEEKER -- A special report.;Terrorism Forces Peres From Brink of Triumph
description: As the human bombs exploded one after another during the last two weeks, Shimon Peres could have been excused for wondering if destiny had not singled him out for cruel mockery.

title: SNAPSHOTS;Vying for Individuality, Parking and More Interesting Weekends
description: What can you expect to find at a New Jersey state college? These capsule assessments of the eight campuses (not including Thomas Edison, which has no campus) are by Bill Paul of Westfield, author of "Getting In: Inside the College Admissions Process" (Addison-Wesley, 1995).

title: MAKING IT WORK;Eric Smith, Disco Czar
description: ERIC SMITH'S slight smile lets you know that his dance moves are right tonight. He has just jumped from the stage to the dance floor for one of his most popular numbers, and it's Michael Jackson mimicry at its best.

title: Back to Vietnam
description: DRAGON ASCENDING Vietnam and the Vietnamese. By Henry Kamm. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $24.95. THIRTY-FIVE years ago we blustered into Vietnam full of blind certainty and can-do optimism, not only oblivious of thousands of years of history but downright uncaring about such trifles. What did all that matter? The fate of the Free World was at stake.

title: Applying to College? First, See the Guidance Counselor
description: To the Editor:

title: Unsung But Striving;9 State Colleges, Long Overlooked, Emerge From Their Modest Origins
description: IN the early days of her college search, Caitlin Ryan had visions of Vassar. She wanted to study literature, and she yearned for a campus with broad lawns and classrooms that smelled of books, dust and history.

title: Man, 37, Is Arrested In Ex-Wife's Killing
description: What began as a police investigation of a car accident ended in the arrest today of a 37-year-old Roselle Park man on charges that he murdered his former wife, the Union County Prosecutor's office said.

title: Seafood Adventure
description: IT'S just such a pleasure to get seafood," says the woman who told me about Sinclaire's. Normally, you're lucky to find one fish dish on a menu, she said. This menu offers dozens.

title: To the Defense Of Fair Haven
description: Your article ("The Battle of the Drug Trade in Fair Haven," Feb. 4) had all the drama of the plot from "The French Connection." However, as not infrequently happens in journalistic forays like this, fact is exaggerated to make for a more entertaining article.

title: U.S. to Take Over Agency
description: The executive director of the city's Housing Authority resigned on Friday and the housing commission voted 5 to 2 to turn over control of the agency to Federal officials.

title: WEDDINGS;Danielle Devine, Gregory Greene
description: Danielle Marie Devine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Devine of Rumson, N.J., was married there last evening to Gregory Richard Greene, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Greene of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Joseph W. Hughes performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: 70 Years After Scopes Trial, Creation Debate Lives
description: Seventy years after John Scopes was convicted of teaching evolution in Dayton, Tenn., the State Legislature here is considering permitting school boards to dismiss teachers who present evolution as fact rather than a theory of human origin.

title: SOAPBOX;My Neighbor, My Nuisance
description: I LIVE next door to a private school for girls. The school's Georgian building, designed by Delano & Aldrich, has wrought-iron arches, freshly painted window bays and lots of polished brass. On the sidewalk outside our building my neighbors sometimes collide with the chauffeurs and nannies of the girls who go to the school. Twice a day huge luxury coach buses pull up to the school belching fumes and blocking traffic; twice a day crowds of Mercedeses and Saabs double-park outside our door.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN As Naval Engagements Go, Not a Classic
description: Down Periscope Kelsey Grammer, Lauren Holly, Bruce Dern, Rob Schneider, Rip Torn Directed by David S. Ward PG-13 88 minutes

title: Eleven Artists Ponder Flesh's Possibilities
description: WALT WHITMAN might approve of the current exhibition at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield. In his vision, all of humanity blended into one force. There is a sameness about the work of "In the Flesh" that produces conflicting feelings. At the same time that a viewer's attention flags after seeing skin represented over and over, he or she might begin to feel a palpable, almost itchy sensation. It's as if Christo had wrapped the interior of the museum in flesh.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
