description: IOWA, the Old West, Norway and pre-talkie Hollywood provide the locales for some choice films on television this week.

title: Early Returns;First, the Winner; Now, the Voting
description: AFTER a buildup that lasted three years, the Republican Presidential campaign came and went in a four-week blur that had a shorter run than Colin Powell's book tour.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading with an article on Friday about a survey of voters in the New York Presidential primary mischaracterized voters' feelings about the tax system in some editions. The voters surveyed did not strongly back a progressive income tax system; they were split over the issue, with half supporting the flat tax.

title: Syosset Girl, 14, Gets to Shine in TV Role
description: FOR 14-year-old Paige Tiffany, the last few weeks of school have been far from typical.

title: FILM;Typecast As A Beatle No More
description: FOR A WHILE IT SEEMED THAT Ian Hart's film career might be limited to playing John Lennon. He first attracted notice in "The Hours and Times," a low-budget 1992 drama about a weekend that Lennon spent in Barcelona with his manager, Brian Epstein. Then, in the 1994 movie "Backbeat," a more lavish drama about the early days of the Beatles in Hamburg, Mr. Hart again played Lennon. And when the producers of "Forrest Gump" needed an actor to dub Lennon's voice, they came knocking on Mr. Hart's door.

title: State Shift Would Impinge on the Disabled
description: State Would Make School Boards Pay Some Costs for the Disabled" [Feb. 11], on the Governor's proposal to transfer special education costs to local school districts, fails to describe the most devastating impact the Governor's proposal would have on some of our most needy children. At risk are our most severely disabled children who are enrolled in the state-supported schools, because they require intensive therapy or constant medical intervention not only to learn and thrive, but also, in many instances, to survive.

title: POP MUSIC;Lord Sting, at Peace In His Fields of Gold
description: Surrounded by massive wooden furniture, thick Persian carpets and a dripping candelabra, Sting leans forward in the baronial sitting hall of his 16th-century manor house in this hamlet, a 90-minute drive southwest of London, and begins to tell a story. "I was climbing an Aztec pyramid in Mexico," he says. "And when I got to the top, there was this guy sitting in a lotus position, facing the view. Suddenly, without even turning his head, he announced, 'You will find peace within, Sting.' " Laughing at the memory, which even he concedes sounds farfetched, the singer adds, "He seemed to be expecting me."

title: THEATER;Of Mystery, Murder and Other Delights
description: FOR SOME PEOPLE, whodunits are like peanuts. Consume one or two and you're hooked. It's the game that fascinates: can the solution be ferreted out before the author reveals it? But what about whodunits on the stage. Are they any different? Stephen Sondheim, a collector and designer of puzzles and games, has written what he calls a comedy thriller with George Furth, his creative partner in the musical "Company." The play, "Getting Away With Murder," stars John Rubinstein, Terrence Mann and Christine Ebersole as members of a therapy group whose psychiatrist is unaccountably missing. Directed by Jack O'Brien, it opens on Broadway next Sunday at the Broadhurst Theater.

title: For Wind Symphony, A Benefit of Its Own
description: TO survive, a musical group needs loyal benefactors, a large paying public or a smart idea. The Hudson Valley Wind Symphony has, at the very least, a smart idea.

title: James Atwater, Journalist and Dean, 67
description: James David Atwater, an editor at Time and other magazines and who later became dean at the University of Missouri School of Journalism, died on March 1 at his home in Columbia, Mo. He was 67.

title: WEDDINGS;Pamela G. Cohen, William A. Torres
description: Pamela Gale Cohen, an associate at Goldman Sachs & Company, the New York investment bank, was married last evening to William Armand Torres, an associate at the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell. Rabbi Fred Davidow officiated at the Georgian Terrace in Atlanta. The Rev. Ron Gagne, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Another Side of the Desk
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns;Calls for Bans As Students Keep Puffing
description: AFTER school, the smokers head to the curb to light up. It's the same curb smokers at Elizabeth High School have used forever -- across the street from the Dunn Sports Center, in front of the corner grocery. "A habit, I guess," said one of the smokers, dragging long and hard on a Camel.

title: AT THE GATE;Getting a Grip on the Value Of a Glamorous New Act
description: WHEN Planet Hollywood International makes its appearance as an initial public offering this spring, it is likely to be one of the year's hottest performers. Crowds always gather when the company opens a new restaurant, and investors are expected to come for the same reason the crowds assemble: celebrity glitz.

title: Children's Books;Bookshelf
description: IN A CIRCLE LONG AGO: A Treasury of Native Lore From North America. By Nancy Van Laan. Illustrated by Lisa Desimini. Apple Soup/Knopf. $20. (Ages 8 and up) Here is a respectful, geographically organized and handsomely illustrated anthology of stories, songs and poems from more than 20 tribal traditions across the continent.

title: Habitats/Jersey City;Decorating on the Cheap
description: INSIDE Oskar Torres's 13- by 16-foot studio room, striped fabric hangs on the walls. Heavy red velvet tablecloths ("Red is my passion," Mr. Torres says), piles of lavishly illustrated decorating books and bouquets of yellow daffodils are reminiscent of a wealthy artist's Greenwich Village den.

title: Sports of The Times;Free Agency Becomes Giants' Latest Fumble
description: FOR the Giants, the awful truth of pro football free agency is that playing for this flagship franchise is now only as attractive (in any order) as its recent record, its coaching staff and its treasury.

title: What I've Learned From Toast
description: NOT LONG AGO I WAS GIVEN A TOASTER AS A gift. For years I lived without one. Toasting, it seemed to me, was a sham: in goes the pre-sliced slip of machine-molded white bread, and out pops a pretense of royalty, an imposter to the throne of cakes and jam and tea. The toaster -- invented, I'd always thought, expressly to facilitate this sorry masquerade -- was to blame.

title: Sense And Edibility;The Icing-and-Stripe Applicator
description: Javier Carriedo, Interstate Brands, Chicago JOB: Line operator. Monitors the application by machine of icing on Hostess cupcakes during first of two eight-hour shifts, insuring that the right quantity of frosting goes on each cupcake and that the trademark squiggled line is centered. WHERE TO FIND HIS CREATIONS: Supermarkets, school cafeterias, convenience stores, lunch boxes, vending machines and middle-American cupboards. WORK EXPERIENCE: 32 1/2 years at the company, mostly in this position. JOB-RELATED EDUCATION: One week of training. DAILY INGREDIENTS: More than 24,400 pounds of icing, including some 14,000 pounds of sugar, 2,500 pounds each of shortening and cocoa and more than 600 gallons of water. CUPCAKES COMPLETED IN A SHIFT: 400,000. HOURLY DECORATING PRODUCTION: 350,000 loops, with an average of 7 a cupcake. MOST ELABORATE CREATION: The Hostess cupcake. UNION WAGE: About $17 an hour.

title: Ideas & Trends;Guns: One Nation Bars, The Other Requires
description: Relaxing at a firing range where the thunder of a dozen submachine guns threatens to set off avalanches in the snow-capped Alps above, Frederic Oguey comes across as just another 13-year-old with sandy hair, a toothy grin and his own assault rifle.

title: South Africa Opens Doors On a Charter
description: It's another meeting of the authors of South Africa's Constitution.

title: HISTORICAL SHOWS;Showing All Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Buehl, Mr. Schwartzman
description: Anne Caroline Buehl, a director of RogersCasey, an investment consultant in Darien, Conn., was married last evening to Peter Albert Schwartzman, a vice president of Alliance Capital Management in New York. Acting Village Justice Gino Papa of East Hills, L.I., officiated at the North Shore Country Club in Glen Head, L.I.

title: DINING OUT;A Glow in Ardsley That Leads to Sushi
description: SET in a tiny cul-de-sac off the main road, Sushi Man glows invitingly through the glass expanse of its storefront window. Inside this small restaurant, a warm welcome and courteous service await diners who might sit at the sushi counter or at Western-style tables. And, in either location, impeccably fresh fish, generously and meticulously cut, provides the tasty basis for items turned out from the sushi counter and the kitchen.

title: Turning Whims Into Whimsical Little Books
description: WHOLE BOOKS HAVE been written on the subject of cigars. But to devote an entire book to cigar papers, those outrageously colorful labels and bands that adorn cigars and cigar boxes? To John McConnell, a 56-year-old British graphics designer, the idea seemed perfect for Pentagram Papers, the series of wry little books on arcane subjects that have appeared sporadically since 1978.

title: Let Political Pundits Take Page From Bookies
description: To the Editor:

title: Nepal's Jungle
description: To the Editor: As a follow-up to Susan Ram's highly favorable appraisal of Tiger Tops Jungle Lodge in Nepal (Oct. 15, 1995), I feel bound to share with you my experience of that jungle camp this January.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS;A Shoemaker's Opus: Footwear Fit for a Prima Donna
description: Yefim Slusker, known to his clientele as Jimmy, can't always remember the names of his "very, very famous" customers. But he can tell you their exact dimensions: the precise inches of Placido Domingo's considerable girth, for instance, or the shape and size of Jessye Norman's feet.

title: Dr. Brown's Cel-Ray Tonic
description: WHEN MY PARENTS took me to eat at Canter's delicatessen, I invariably ordered a Dr. Brown's Cel-Ray Tonic; it was the only soft drink my mother sanctioned, believing that its trace of vegetable matter (extract of celery seed was a mere footnote in the long list of ingredients) would fortify a growing boy. Medicinal or not, I loved the exhilarating sting of carbonation, the delicate hint of vanilla and the icy, mouth-dousing sweetness.

title: Living, and Buying, in the North End of Boston
description: THE North End is a residential and commercial waterfront neighborhood accustomed over the centuries to periodic reinvigoration by waves of immigrants. The latest wave is of domestic origin, however -- droves of Boston-area residents who find they can live in the North End while earning rental income from residential or commercial tenants that subsidize their own housing costs.

title: In the Region/Connecticut;At Stratford, Yet Another Plan Takes the Stage
description: WITH a history as tortured as Hamlet's and as long as Henry IV, Parts I and II, the former Shakespeare Theater in Stratford is up for redevelopment again. It has functioned only sporadically since it closed in 1976.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Russia's Imbalance of Power
description: ON June 16, Russia will hold its most important election of this century as its people vote to retain or replace President Boris N. Yeltsin. But this political puzzle, like all puzzles, has a clear, finished picture: No matter who is elected, Mr. Yeltsin will remain in power. The only question is what title he will hold -- or give himself.

title: Bruno Stein, 65, N.Y.U. Professor
description: Bruno Stein, a professor of economics at New York University who wrote extensively on labor relations, mediation and pension systems, died last Sunday of pancreatic cancer at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 65.

title: William G. Carr Is Dead at 95; Former Head of Teachers' Group
description: William G. Carr, an educator who brought a distinctly international outlook to his 15 years as executive secretary of the National Education Association, died on March 1 at a hospice in Denver. He was 95.

title: HOME CLINIC;Testing for the Presence of Radon
description: WITHIN the last decade a number of articles have appeared on radon. Radon is an invisible gas that seeps into homes and contaminates them with radiation. Where exactly does this gas come from? Why has it suddenly appeared, and how serious is the radon threat?

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Oakley Returns to Knicks For a Look at the New Look
description: Charles Oakley rubbed his eyes after practice today, like the kid who had fallen asleep and missed all the exciting and juicy parts of the movie. His Knick teammates, the ones he remembered before he nodded off, anyhow, filled him in on the details.

title: March 3-9;Yeltsin's Nightmare Recurs
description: It was supposed to be a two-day war. At least that is the impression Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, gave 15 months ago when he sent 40,000 troops into the successionist republic of Chechnya. Since then the Chechen city of Grozny has practically been razed, tens of thousands of people have died, and Mr. Yeltsin's political future has been put in absolute peril. But at least the Russians had taken Grozny. Or they had until dawn on Wednesday, when hundreds of separatist rebels stormed the city. For days the fighting raged, as fiercely as it ever has in this particularly brutal war. And Mr. Yeltsin, who is desperately seeking to extricate himself from the war while not looking weak, had to watch as his military commanders were again outclassed by gangs who rely almost totally on stolen weapons.

title: How Women Can Raise the Rafters
description: JENNIFER ANISKOVICH received a power miter saw as a gift at Christmas. A year ago, the Branford lawyer probably would not have known what to do with it. But, using the construction skills gained in serving as a project co-chairwoman with Habitat for Humanity of New Haven, she quickly set up the saw and built a workbench in her garage.

title: WEDDINGS;Elissa S. Shay, Daniel J. Ordan
description: Elissa Sara Shay, the daughter of Dr. Melvin D. Shay of Brooklyn and the late Lucy Bohm Shay, is to be married today to Daniel Jay Ordan, a son of Edith Ordan of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Ellis Ordan. Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt is to officiate at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE MIRROR OF MONSTERS AND PRODIGIES By Pamela Ditchoff. Coffee House, paper, $12.95.

title: Shoreham May Get New Role
description: STRIPPED of nuclear fuel and working parts, the remains of the $5.5 billion former Shoreham power plant and its surroundings may yet play a role in providing electricity for Long Island.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Fort Lee, N.J.;'Manhattan West' Atop the Palisades
description: ARGUABLY New Jersey's most strategically situated municipality, the two-and-a-half-square-mile Borough of Fort Lee sits at the western ramp of the George Washington Bridge where Routes 46, 1, 9 and 9W, Interstates 80 and 95 and the Palisades Interstate Parkway converge to funnel 100 million vehicles into and out of Manhattan each year.

title: WEDDINGS;Mindy Suh, Eugene Hong
description: Mindy Minkyung Suh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Won Suk Suh of Floral Park, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Eugene Sukpyo Hong, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Soonsung Hong of Seoul, South Korea. The Rev. Sukhyoung Kim, an Evangelical minister, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 27 about Queen Nefertari's tomb characterized the Getty Conservation Institute incorrectly. It it not part of the J. Paul Getty Museum; the institute and the museum are both part of the J. Paul Getty Trust.

title: WEDDINGS;Victoria Tennant, Kirk J. Stambler
description: Victoria Tennant, an actress in New York and Los Angeles, was married on Monday to Kirk Justin Stambler, an entertainment lawyer. Mayor Bruno Margras of Gustavia, St.-Barthelemy, officiated at the Town Hall there.

title: Foreign Affairs;Surely They Know
description: No."

title: Sating the Appetites of Older Students
description: MADELYN WOOD, Pat Hirtle and Jenefer Berall have all been out of school for some time, but each now carries around an oft-read, thick copy of Shakespeare's collected works.

title: BACKTALK;Between a Rock and an Olympic Place
description: As the Atlanta Games approach, the item that looms largest on the Olympic agenda is establishing a fair and consistent drug policy.

title: SEINFELD';Mickey Sans the Ears
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKEND/Justin Kaplan; Selling 'Huck Finn' Down the River
description: In the January issue of Harper's Magazine, the novelist Jane Smiley writes that she's "stunned" by the notion that "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" "is a great novel . . . even a serious novel." She attributes its canonization to a propaganda initiative by a small group of literary critics, among them Lionel Trilling and T. S. Eliot, soon after World War II. She sees this as part of a longstanding cultism that assigns a dominant position to "white, Protestant, middle-class male authors" -- Emerson, Hawthorne and Melville, for example -- while relegating women authors, especially authors of best-selling novels, to the kitchen middens of Parnassus. Citing Ernest Hemingway's famously unhesitating assertion that "all modern American literature" comes from "Huckleberry Finn," Ms. Smiley argues that American literature would have been better off if it had grown instead out of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," one of the few novels that may be said to have had a pronounced effect on events.

title: Dad Walks Into the Sunset, Leaving a Family on Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: COPING;Claudine Is Missing. Or Did She Run Away?
description: RICKY TAMBIL last saw her daughter, Claudine, at 3 P.M. on Friday, Feb. 23. The 19-year-old stopped at Look, her mother's hair salon on East 29th Street, on her way to answer a classified ad for a receptionist at a salon in SoHo. She was wearing beige linen pants and a white shirt. Everything else -- leather jacket, boots, knapsack -- was black. As usual, she looked good; Claudine is 5 feet 9 inches tall, with a pretty, round face framed by long, dark blonde hair. In the picture on the missing person flyer her parents made up, her gray-green eyes seem coolly confident under quizzically arched eyebrows.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report column on the Travel Advisory page on Feb. 18 about taxes at tourist destinations referred incorrectly to a tax in San Antonio and misstated the combined total of two taxes there. The city has a sales tax, which applies to restaurants; it does not have a restaurant tax as such. The sales and lodging taxes total 22.75 percent, not 24.7.

title: Paying for a Mistake
description: To the Editor:

title: A Life After I.B.M. Leads to Odd Sports Treasures
description: THE search for new materials has led Philip L. Glazer to unusual finds. A stack of old football programs revealed a legendary 1934 Stanford-Columbia University Rose Bowlgame, the program autographed by the entire Columbia team. A tattered 1942 war bond program with autographs of Honus Wagner, Connie Mack and George Sisler turned up at auction.

title: IN BRIEF;Long Branch Pier Owner Going Back to Court
description: The owner of the Long Branch Amusement Pier is to return to court next month in his attempts to prove that utility companies were responsible for the 1987 fire that destroyed the pier, precipitating the decline of the city's beach and boardwalk. That trial, tentatively set to start April 15, could determine what role the historic pier and its owner, Pat Cicalese, play in Long Branch's redevelopment.

title: HOCKEY;Kovalev Enjoys Surprise Reprieve
description: For a guy who was supposed to be under suspension, Aleksei Kovalev did pretty well today when the Rangers visited the Washington Capitals.

title: HISTORICAL SHOWS;Call It O.P.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 4/ Bombs scarcely rattled investors in Israeli stocks. By Paul Lewis.

title: FUNDS WATCH;Some Lessons From the 1930's
description: Investors looking for protection in today's volatile market might find refuge in the Dodge & Cox funds, says Susan Paluch, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago. Dodge & Cox began managing money in the Depression, and the lessons of that era were not lost on the firm.

title: WORD & IMAGE;Do Computers Eat Our Paychecks?
description: UNTIL JUST THE other day, I thought the computer had greatly enhanced my life and income and, despite some obvious dislocations, those of most other Americans as well. I'm no longer so sure. Computers may also be exacerbating our social problems by depressing most wages. I wish the politicians and the media would devote some of this year's election debate to examining that possibility.

title: INVESTING IT;The Year Is 2010. Do You Know Where Your Bull Is?
description: IS the high-flying stock market, buoyed by a seemingly limitless tide of pension money, heading for a fall? No, not on the order of last Friday's 171-point drop, but something potentially far more disturbing two or three decades down the road -- when the baby boomers retire and begin to trade in their securities for Winnebagos, visits to the periodontist and trips to Disney World with the grandchildren?

title: In the Region/Long Island;The 1783 Jones Family Farmhouse Put on the Market
description: IT is an unpretentious house down a private lane, out of sight of the road. The 18th-century Federal-style farmhouse known as Hill House is the ancestral home of the Jones family, which once owned thousands of acres stretching from the North to the South Shores between Oyster Bay and Jones Beach.

title: Oh, for Those Pearls
description: In the next couple of days, 15,000 people will receive "The Estate of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis" in the mail. More than 4,000 items that belonged to the former First Lady will be up for grabs at a Sotheby's auction on April 23. The catalogue is 584 pages long and has nearly 800 illustrations. I want those pearls.

title: FOOD;Irish Trout, Mackerel and Sorbet
description: AS anyone who has been to Ireland recently knows, the cooking there has undergone a revolution similar to ours. The following menu, devised for St. Patrick's Day by James O'Shea, the owner of Grappa Trattoria and West Street Grill restaurant in Litchfield, Conn., encompasses some of the trends.

title: ON POLITICS;Finding a Safe Way To Trim School Costs
description: Governor Whitman once observed that it would be political suicide, given the state's long tradition of home rule, to force particular school districts to merge to help reduce school spending costs.

title: Cigar's Trip to Dubai Still On
description: The trainer Bill Mott virtually assured a trip to Dubai next week for Cigar after watching the 1995 Horse of the Year gallop a mile and a half today at Gulfstream Park.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TRAIL LECTURE

title: March 3-9;Moscow, I Have A Problem
description: Children these days know more about the near disaster of Apollo 13 than the triumph of Apollo 11 and the successful landing of a dozen American astronauts on the Moon from 1969 to 1972. But maybe there's a space blockbuster to be made that can have enough drama to make money and still honor a goal that was achieved.

title: WEDDINGS;Janine Schultz, Michael M. Smith
description: Janine Schultz, a financial editor, and Michael Mark Smith, an investment banker, were married last evening. Rabbi Lawrence W. Raphael performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: Cold Spring Harbor Labs Moratorium May End
description: A TWO-YEAR moratorium on non-residential construction, aimed at limiting expansion of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories in Laurel Hollow, should be coming to an end tomorrow.

title: Who Will Win State Property?
description: SINCE 1905, the Norwich State Hospital on its 780-acre college-like campus overlooking the Thames River has been eastern Connecticut's primary mental health and substance abuse treatment center.

title: HIS ACCIDENT
description: When I was lying in an intensive care unit a few years ago at age 18, newly paralyzed from a car crash, I thought I'd be forever "romantically challenged," never mind physically challenged. Soon after rehabilitation, I discovered that fortunately, there are many women -- just like Hockenberry -- who realize that a man who uses a wheelchair can still be in a mutually supportive, satisfying, fun and loving relationship.

title: THEATER;Portraits of Nixon and Kissinger From Inside Out
description: WHEN HE WAS PREPARING TO DIRECT "Nixon's Nixon," a play that imagines the encounter between Henry A. Kissinger and Richard M. Nixon on the eve of Nixon's resignation as President in 1974, Jim Simpson made an artistic decision: no latex noses.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Birdcage Robin Williams, Nathan Lane, Dianne Wiest, Gene Hackman, Dan Futterman, Calista Flockhart Directed by Mike Nichols R 118 minutes

title: Toys 'R' Us Is Crying Westward Ho!
description: When Toys "R" Us decided in 1994 that it wanted to open a toy store on the Upper East Side -- the first Toys "R" Us in a residential neighborhood anywhere in the country -- the company ran into heavy opposition. Civic groups protested what they fear will be increased pedestrian and traffic congestion, as well as pollution at the site, 80th Street and Third Avenue. Banding together as Neighbors "R" Us, they persuaded the Giuliani administration to oppose the store's building permit in court. Toys "R" Us won the right to build, but the city is appealing.

title: Downsizing and Its Discontents
description: Modern capitalism has always dealt its cards unevenly, but over time prosperity and freedom have flowed to almost everyone living under the system. The United States, moreover, is the envy of other industrial democracies because of its recent success in creating jobs and subduing inflation. Why, then, are so many Americans anxious about the future? If you have any doubt that such anxiety exists, read the meticulously reported series of articles in The Times last week, with their portrayal of lives, families, workplaces and communities disrupted by the downsizing in corporate America.

title: Cocaine Daze;Deborah Cantie Knows Guns, Drugs and Rikers Island. Now She Is Seeking Help. Can a Life Change?
description: IT used to be that Deborah Cantie wouldn't know where she'd wake up. Life for a addict is like that, she said. Instead of a two-minute egg, she would start with a two-dollar bottle. But that was another day.

title: CHATTER;The Pros and Cons of Helmets
description: The state Senate voted recently to repeal a law requiring motorcycle riders to wear helmets. But Governor Whitman says riding bareheaded is "absolutely nuts." What do you think?

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: If Lucy Fell Sarah Jessica Parker, Eric Schaeffer, Ben Stiller, Elle MacPherson Directed by Eric Schaeffer R 93 minutes

title: DANCE;The Maturing Of an Investment In Ballet's Future
description: LEANING INTO THE FAINT GLOW from lamps on a monitor table at the back of the Joyce Theater, Eliot Feld is displaying several of his many talents. One of these is, as he puts it, "dissatisfaction well addressed."

title: WEDDINGS;Dawn Porter, John E. Eringis
description: Dawn Porter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Wynne Porter Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday to John Edward Eringis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Eringis of Port St. Lucie, Fla. The Rev. William H. Wood 3d will perform the Episcopal ceremony at St. Christopher's Church in Gladwyne, Pa.

title: Eat or Be Eaten
description: THE TOASTER The first electric toaster appeared in 1909. It toasted one side at a time and required constant vigilance: when the toast was done, you pulled the plug. The first automatic electric toaster was designed in 1919 by Charles Strite, a man sick and tired of burned toast. Americans were skeptical at first about investing in a single-function appliance, but prices dropped and - such is the allure of toasted bread - sales mushroomed. From 1922 to 1930 sales tripled, from 400,000 units to 1,200,000, thanks in part to the introduction of sliced bread by Wonder. Toasters now live in 88 percent of American homes; the tiny chrome hearth on the counter may well be the one object that pleases most of the people most of the time.

title: LIVES;Why I Disapprove of What I Do
description: You can't be a restaurant critic," M.F.K Fisher said to me 21 years ago, "unless you are one of those ambitious sorts, willing to walk on your grandmother's grave." I nodded meekly and agreed.

title: March 3-9;Clinton Outlines a Position On Affirmative Action
description: Like magma bubbling beneath the political surface, affirmative action will probably erupt into a major issue in the Presidential campaign this fall. That was all but assured when the Clinton Administration decided last week that it will declare a three-year moratorium on new Federal set-aside programs, but will maintain other policies that assure preferential treatment for minorities and women bidding on Federal contracts. At the same time, a bill sponsored by Senator Bob Dole to end all Federal racial and gender preferences cleared a House subcommittee on its inexorable journey toward Congressional passage and a Presidential veto.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Week in Review on March 3, with an article about the use of coal for home heating misstated the location of the Blaschak Coal Corporation. It is in St. Nicholas Village, Pennsylvania, not Nazareth.

title: March 3-9;Hello Ozzie and Harriet
description: The traditional American family is making a comeback. Last week the Population Reference Bureau, Inc. a private research group in Washington, reported that the number of two-parent households with children had increased by 700,000 from 1990 to 1995, reversing a 20-year trend, and the divorce rate had slowed from 23 divorces per 1,000 in 1980 to 20.5 divorces per 1,000 marriages in 1994. The author of the report, Carol J. De Vita, chalked it up to -- you guessed it -- the baby boomers entering middle age. She said that after putting off marriage or dissolving early marriages and remarrying, the boomers have settled down to raising families.

title: COVER STORY;A Proving Ground for Candidates
description: For a politician in trouble, a visit to Ted Koppel at ABC News's "Nightline" must feel like the proverbial trip to the dentist: discomfort lies ahead, but there's no better way to eradicate the pain.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAYSIDE;Envelope, Please. Makeup Whiz Has Designs on an Oscar.
description: For Bob Laden, a special-effects makeup artist, old age has its rewards.

title: Slow Paddling in the Low Country
description: IF there is one trait of the Low Country's salt marshes that lingers longest in a visitor's memory, it is the smell. Long after the other images of the day have dimmed -- of porpoises rolling through the murky water or orange-billed birds chattering from ancient oyster banks or sand of a deserted barrier island collapsing underfoot in the incoming waves -- the smell stays with you.

title: Manhattan Sales Help Other Boroughs
description: IT is a script to delight home sellers, buyers wobbling on the fence and, of course, brokers: The residential real-estate engine that is Manhattan will churn up a wave that ripples through the other boroughs.

title: Unaware, Over There
description: As he leaves Sydney, the businessman flashes the "V" for victory sign to his Australian partner. Then on to China, where he presents his local contact with a fine green wool hat from New York. Oops. This globe-trotting executive has stepped on foreign toes on two continents: In Australia, the "V" gesture signifies defeat, and in China, a green hat means that one is a cuckold. Do you have a tale of folly on a foreign business trip? Send it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send it by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include a phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Blue Jays Lose Again, Now by Subtraction
description: Gord Ash and Pat Gillick held a reunion of sorts the other day right out there on the field near the third-base dugout at Dunedin Stadium. Some observers wondered if Ash, the Blue Jays' general manager, might not grab a bat from the rack and end the reunion with his mentor with a whack.

title: Returned Refugees Say Cuba, Defying Pact, Retaliates
description: One day after Washington and Havana agreed last May that "boat people" fleeing Cuba would no longer be guaranteed political asylum in the United States, 13 men were picked up aboard two rafts adrift in the Caribbean. Assured by the American and Cuban Governments that there would be no retribution against them, they were forcibly returned to their homes here.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: PARKING;Lost at the Airport
description: The three major New York airports now offer free aid to motorists stranded in their parking lots with dead batteries or snowbound vehicles. Help is also available free for motorists at La Guardia and Kennedy airports who lock their keys in their cars or find their door locks frozen. Motorists summon aid by flagging down police, security or parking-lot personnel or using emergency phones in the lots. And at Newark and La Guardia, those who forget where they parked can ask lot attendants to check a computer log of license-plate numbers and locations. Motorists who forget their license-plate numbers are out of luck.

title: Keeping the Blues at Bay
description: THE BLUE DEVILS OF NADA A Contemporary American Approach to Aesthetic Statement. By Albert Murray. 238 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $23.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;The World Around the Corner
description: In the years following the Civil War, emancipated slaves poured into the nation's capital, often ending up in cramped and hidden alley neighborhoods. Overcrowding and lack of sanitation attracted reformers, and by the turn of the century a movement to eradicate these pestilential areas was under way. Reform legislation, urban planning schemes, two wars and documentary photographers like Lewis Hine came and went before the neighborhoods were finally razed in a redevelopment effort in the 1950's. In 1943, a social worker named Godfrey Frankel (1912-95) took his camera and rode a bicycle into one of these alleys, ready to expose the capital's squalid underside. To his surprise, what he discovered during repeated afternoon forays was something richer and more complex -- a community and its children, which are portrayed in IN THE ALLEYS: Kids in the Shadow of the Capitol (Smithsonian, cloth, $55; paper, $24.95), with text by Laura Goldstein, a freelance Washington journalist, and a foreword by the photographer Gordon Parks. Mr. Parks also visited the alleys in the early 1940's, and describes them as dirty, disgruntled and gloomy, but Frankel's images portray a more benign environment. The sun raking across the uneven brick passageways and peeling wooden steps where troops of small children gather suggest stability and warmth. When Frankel's subjects face his camera, their expressions range from grave to gleeful, their integrity never in doubt. Ragged clothes become symbols of pluck and resourcefulness rather than despair. Ms. Goldstein provides an affectionate biography of Frankel and a history of the Washington alleys. By including comments by middle-aged survivors of alley childhood, she adds depth to this record of an eradicated past. Rosemary Ranck

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;After Clinching Victory, Carril Says Goodbye
description: Princeton Coach Pete Carril called it the happiest day of his life. Princeton players wept, both in joy and sadness. For the Tigers had just won the Ivy League championship in a playoff game and then heard their contented and satisfied coach announce his retirement.

title: Blame a Fever, Not a Fall, For Death of 'Amiable Child'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sense And Edibility;The Flavorist
description: Marion Sudol, International Flavors and Fragrances, Dayton, N.J. Sudol analyzes and tries to recreate the elements of natural flavors for the company's stock or for manufacturers' requests. Q: How do you distinguish flavors?

title: After a Year, It's a 'Love Fest' For High-End Mall
description: SOME things do live up to expectations. A year after its opening, The Westchester, the $270 million fashion center here, has been "universally judged a resounding success by any standard," said Mayor S. J. Schulman of White Plains.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BEST ENEMIES FOREVER By Kathleen Leverich. Illustrated by Walter Lorraine. 136 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $14. (Ages 7 and up)

title: THE BIG CITY;A Fool and His Money
description: MY NIGHT OF GAMBLING BEGAN IN the basement of a brownstone on the Upper West Side. It was a comfortable studio apartment with a couch, a television set showing ESPN and, in the center of the room, a table covered with telephones, tape recorders and paperwork. Around the table were three young, clean-cut bookmakers; one of them, in tortoise-shell glasses and a white button-down shirt, could have modeled for a Brooks Brothers catalogue.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK;Awaiting Hong Kong Exodus
description: On a recent rain-rattled afternoon, Shiu Kam Leung was walking down busy Eighth Avenue in Sunset Park, passing the prickly durians that hang in market doorways. For Mr. Leung, the bad-smelling yet sweet-tasting fruit popular in Asia is a harbinger of what he believes will be an economic boom in the neighborhood.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Temple Gives Everything, But Cannot Beat the Best
description: It was a most disheartening experience for the Temple Owls. They stood toe to toe with Massachusetts, ranked No. 2 in the nation, in the Atlantic 10 tournament championship game at the Civic Center tonight, hit UMass with their best shot, and the Minutemen didn't flinch.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: PARADE;A Long Goodbye
description: After one more season, the lights go out for good -- literally -- on one of Disneyland's longest-running attractions. The Main Street Electrical Parade, which first rolled out at the Anaheim, Calif., theme park on June 17, 1972, will make its farewell appearances each evening this year from March 30 to Oct. 31. The original parade had a dozen floats, and after numerous revisions that number now exceeds 40, with more than half a million battery-powered bulbs.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Rally To Defeat Jets
description: Bryan McCabe scored the go-ahead goal in the second period today as the Islanders rallied to beat the Winnipeg Jets, 4-2.

title: March 3-9;Bailey Goes to Jail
description: F. Lee Bailey, the lawyer who defended Patricia Hearst and O. J. Simpson, could not escape jail himself this week after failing to come up with $3 million to satisfy a Federal judge. The money is part of more than $20 million in cash and stock a former client had agreed to forfeit to the Government but that prosecutors charge Mr. Bailey is now trying to steal. While the dispute over ownership is settled, Mr. Bailey could not meet a contempt order requiring him to turn over the assets to the court by Feb. 29.

title: GOVERNMENT;Wanted: More Money From Port Authority
description: In municipal government, when the going gets tough, the tough look for ways to boost their revenues.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN As Naval Engagements Go, Not a Classic
description: Up Close and Personal Robert Redford, Michelle Pfeiffer, Stockard Channing, Joe Mantegna, Kate Nelligan Directed by Jon Avnet PG-13 124 minutes

title: W. R. Grace Reported Ready to Sell a Unit
description: The directors of W. R. Grace & Company have approved the sale of its Grace Dearborn water-treatment unit for about $600 million, several large Grace shareholders say.

title: No Headline
description: The chicken promised for every pot is a very American bird. It is affable, amenable, eager to be of service for the larger good, though equally prepared to stand alone. Since the 1920's, in fact, chicken has been a veritable canvas for the reigning themes of the American diet. Whether it's scarcity or abundance, health or flavor that concern us, chicken is hope incarnate. This has as much to do with the character of chicken, a regular chameleon, as it does with the character of the American people. Consider the contemporary bird: affordable, convenient, the country's favorite low-fat dinner. But beneath these obvious virtues (which is what most Americans say they want in their food), chicken has the amazing capacity to respond to the ethnic flavor of the month -- these days, Asian and Latin American -- and the very real need for occasional indulgence.

title: POLITICS: A FAULT LINE;Anti-Abortion Passion in G.O.P. Threatens to Pull Dole Off-Center
description: As Senator Bob Dole turns his attention to unifying the Republican Party, few issues will be more sensitive than abortion, in the view of strategists on both sides of the issue. It could complicate his choice of a running mate, his construction of a party platform and his ability to handle Patrick J. Buchanan.

title: Jaspers and Friars in N.I.T.
description: Jerry Tarkanian did get his team into a post-season tournament, the National Invitation Tournament. And keeping him company will be three teams from the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference -- Iona, Manhattan and Fairfield. Tarkanian's Fresno State Bulldogs will be one of 32 teams in the N.I.T., which will be played at campus sites until the semifinals on March 26 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Once More A Legend Becomes An Angel
description: Once again, the words "David Merrick Presents . . ." will adorn a Broadway theater marquee.

title: THE MARKET'S STUMBLE: THE COST OF TRADING;Wide-Ranging Commissions Found at Brokerage Firms
description: A recent survey of brokerage firms found startling differences in the commissions paid by investors for the same services, with the Paine Webber Group charging seven times as much as the deep-discount brokerage firm, Wall Street Equities, on a comparable trade.

title: For Rather, Technology Has Drawbacks, Too
description: On March 9, 1981, the night Dan Rather replaced Walter Cronkite as the anchor of "CBS Evening News," the camera showed Mr. Rather from the waist up, with nothing behind him but a blank dove-gray backdrop.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Library Is Now 200
description: Two hundred years ago this week, the Legislature authorized the purchase of 35 books that formed the original collection of the New Jersey State Library, which will celebrate its bicentennial today with ceremonies in the Assembly chambers. The library has 500,000 books, but it did not buy any books in the last fiscal year. Instead, the library spent its $180,000 book-acquisition budget on computers, said Robert L. Bland, director of the State Government Information Services Bureau. Although the library resumed buying new books this year, next year's budget for acquiring books has been cut by $130,000.

title: Denver Embraces Oklahomans Traveling to Bombing Trial
description: When the Oklahoma City bombing trial starts here this fall, anyone who shows an Oklahoma driver's license at La Petite Cleaners will get 50 percent off on pressing and cleaning.

title: 2 Fires Rout 50 From Harlem Apartments
description: Two suspicious fires ravaged the top two floors of a city-owned apartment building in Harlem late Saturday and early yesterday, leaving an elderly woman hospitalized in critical condition with burns and smoke-related injuries, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: Town Tries to Keep Its Balance in Wake of White Flight
description: For most of its 141 years, this village of turn-of-the-century Victorian houses and just-built-yesterday subdivisions was overwhelmingly white and perfectly content with the way of the world.

title: PROFIT AND LOSS -- A special report.;Private Business, Public Schools: Why Hartford Experiment Failed
description: The concept seemed simple enough when Education Alternatives Inc. came here in 1994 to help manage Hartford's 32 public schools: use private-business expertise to wring more money for education out of the district's $200 million budget.

title: POLITICAL POWER LIKELY TO SHIELD SHIPS' SUBSIDIES
description: In 1993, a task force advising Vice President Al Gore on "reinventing government" recommended the elimination of subsidies for the fading maritime industry, which it described as "a cancer eating away" at the Federal Treasury.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Port Magazine Is to Close
description: Being in the publishing business is the last thing the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey needs, George J. Marlin, its executive director, said last week. Consequently, Via Port of New York and New Jersey, a free bimonthly trade magazine on port and air cargo matters with 25,000 subscribers, will cease publication after 47 years, the authority announced. The move will save $475,000 a year, said Gwen Williams, a spokeswoman for the authority.

title: Sports of The Times;Poetic Madness: On April 1, A Champion
description: TO understand why fans call the next three weeks March Madness, one had only to spend time with Georgetown's Allen Iverson last week.

title: Memorial to Black Soldiers Faces Deadline
description: Sponsors of a project to build the first monument on the Mall here dedicated to the achievements of African-Americans are running out of time to raise the $5 million they need to save the project.

title: HOCKEY;Graves Sends Message: No Cause for Concern
description: When his many admirers praise Adam Graves, it is as if they are reading from the Boy Scout Handbook. They call the Ranger forward trustworthy, loyal, helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean and reverent.

title: Tom McDermott, 83, an Actor Whose Life Was His Craft
description: Tom McDermott, who caught the acting bug as a high school student in Chicago and never shook it off during a 64-year career on and off Broadway, in regional theater, on television and in the movies, died on Wednesday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about the junior apparel industry misstated the current status of Paul Harris Stores Inc. in some editions. Paul Harris, which emerged from Federal bankruptcy court protection in 1992, continues to be in business; it did not cease operations.

title: In America;Bullet To the Heart
description: I woke up," said William Manchester, the eminent historian and biographer, "feeling like a Sherman tank had run over me, driven by General Patton."

title: At Lunch, Belfast Women Talk of a Hunger for Peace
description: The four Roman Catholic women from working-class areas of Belfast met on a recent afternoon for lunch downtown in the Europa Hotel, which claims with bitter pride that as a target of the Irish Republican Army it is the most-bombed hotel in Europe.

title: Editorial Notebook: Stalin's Shadow;The Pain and Pride Of Russian History
description: Though Josef Stalin died 43 years ago, he torments Russia to this day. As Russians prepare for a presidential election this June, a revived Communist Party is struggling with the still volatile issue of Stalin and his legacy. Gennadi Zyuganov, the party's presidential candidate, seems wary of condemning one of the founding architects of the Soviet state yet fearful of embracing him. Other Communists openly defend Stalin as a great leader.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Amoco Unit Shifts To Leo Burnett
description: Amoco Petroleum Products Marketing, a division of the Amoco Corporation, has abruptly left Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., after almost a year and, without a review, named as its primary agency the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago. The billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Taking In the Sites;Bull, Bear and Mouse on the Internet
description: One big advantage professional investors have over the little guy is access to information. To invest their billions, large portfolio managers spend tens of thousands of dollars a year on research reports, corporate documents, graphs and charts of historical patterns, and up-to-the-minute stock quotes.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Eight Drug Arrests At Two Nightclubs
description: In the latest effort to curtail illegal drug use in Manhattan dance clubs, investigators made eight arrests at two trendy nightspots early Saturday, the police said.

title: Students Looking to Unions for Careers in Social Change
description: With large-scale layoffs and falling wages creating many of the same anxieties felt in the 1930's, Lazar Treschan, like hundreds of other idealistic college students, is planning to do what many of the best and the brightest did after college in the Depression: become union organizers.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Lottery Award Is Disputed
description: A Hacksensack company that lost its bid for a $78 million New Jersey lottery contract has accused the winning company of concealing information about its former national sales director, who was indicted in 1994 on bribery charges. In contesting the decision to award the contract to the Rhode Island-based Gtech Holdings Corporation, the losing bidder, Automated Wagering International Inc., told the State Director of Purchase and Property Friday that Gtech had failed to disclose that J. David Smith, the former Gtech official, remained a consultant with the company. But Robert Rendine, a spokesman for Gtech, said Mr. Smith severed all connections with the company before his indictment.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Singing 60's Songs as a Family Might
description: Peter, Paul and Mary take over public television's "Great Performances" tonight for a show called "Lifelines," a celebration of folk music going back at least as far as their early days in Greenwich Village. For anyone who prowled the folk scene in the 1960's, this is a joyful remembrance of things past. Not too long ago, the trio and their accomplished friends might have seemed like nostalgic artifacts. With the current downsizing of America, however, their voices and messages have regained stunning relevance.

title: Hereford Journal;With City Lights Calling, Reluctant Cowgirls Ride
description: Willa Cather's books are on display, as are the platinum records of Patsy Cline. There is a display on Wilma Mankiller, the former head of the Cherokee Nation, and a bronze statuette of Sacajawea, the Shoshone interpreter for the Lewis and Clark expedition.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Emily Dickinson's Words Step Daintily From Page to Stage
description: Breath: The Passionate Life and Extraordinary Language of Emily Dickinson," presented by Lynn Wichern and David Wolfson on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church, is obviously a labor of great love.

title: Constitution Protects Same-Sex Marriages;AIDS Data Not in Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Guerrillas in Lebanon Renew Attacks on Israelis
description: Party of God guerrillas carried out a wave of bomb and rocket attacks on Israeli troops in southern Lebanon today, killing at least one soldier and wounding five others, security officials and the Israeli military said.

title: THE MARKETS' STUMBLE: THE WAIT;Fund Investors Hold Key To Health of Stock Market
description: Each time Wall Street has panicked in the last few years, investors on Main Street have stepped in and stemmed the tide of selling. Whether that continues today will depend on the hundreds of thousands of people who have invested in mutual funds in recent years.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Deceptive Containers Fought
description: A bill to ban the sale of nonalcoholic beverages in containers made to look like those in which alcoholic beverages are sold will be considered today by the Assembly Consumer Affairs and Regulated Professions Committee. The measure was introduced after juice and iced tea in liquor-like containers began appearing on store shelves in South Jersey, said the bill's sponsor, Assemblywoman Shirley K. Turner, Democrat of Ewing Township. Her bill would also bar candy cigarette sales.

title: Philadelphia' Screenplay Suit To Reach Court
description: A lawsuit contending that the makers of the movie "Philadelphia" misappropriated a story about a New York lawyer, who was dismissed after his employer discovered he had AIDS, is scheduled to go to trial tomorrow in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Saturday Night Live" has lost another member of its ensemble: this time DAVID SPADE, known for his impersonations of an unfriendly airline attendant and an entertainment critic, is quitting the beleaguered program.

title: Europe Will Contest U.S.-German Air Pact
description: In a move that could undermine a fledgling alliance between Lufthansa A.G. and United Airlines, the European Commission said last week that it would take legal action against Germany for signing an open skies agreement with the United States.

title: Trial of 2 Former Presidents Begins in Korea
description: In an unprecedented joint trial, two former Presidents who began as childhood friends and ruled South Korea in successive terms from 1980 to 1993 went on trial today in connection with their violent seizure of power.

title: Senate Panel Tells of Waste in Travel
description: The Government could save more than $1 billion in travel costs every year by cutting back on regulations and paper work, a Senate panel said on Friday.

title: Abroad at Home;How Terrorism Wins
description: Terrorism has a cost beyond its menace to life and peace. A democratic society, feeling threatened, may put aside legal norms and adopt authoritarian measures. It may fear freedom.

title: What's It All About?
description: Now that he has won 12 primaries and the pressure is off, we demand that Bob Dole tell us what it's really all about. Surely, "it" -- by which he seems to mean the campaign or the future of America or the existential plight of man as a creature of finite mind in an infinite universe -- cannot be all about all the things he has said "it" is all about. The man is toying with us, and it -- the toying, that is -- has to stop!

title: Interests Collide in Communications Ventures
description: Just as the digital age has made for strange bedfellows, it has also created a new category of dysfunctional relationships: companies that form alliances, only to find later that their interests have diverged.

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;Buchanan Keeps Campaigning, For the Issues, and the Fun of It
description: What does Pat want?

title: Constitution Protects Same-Sex Marriages
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Dreamer Ascending On Flowing Wings
description: One might have expected the old-fashioned virtues of craft and intelligence from Pearl Lang, whose company performed on Saturday night at the Kaye Playhouse. Ms. Lang danced with Martha Graham for 30 years and has been choreographing since the 1950's. What was surprising was the crackling energy and excitement of much of the work on the program, which was dedicated to the memory of Martha Hill, the pioneering modern-dance educator, who died in November.

title: POLITICS: OLDER VOTERS;Loyalty and Skepticism From Dole's Age Group
description: At age 76, four years older than Senator Bob Dole, Mary T. Andrejcak has been blessed with good health and vitality.

title: U.N. Agencies Feeling the Pain as the U.S. Lags on Payments
description: Congressional reluctance to provide money for international organizations combined with Clinton Administration delays in allocating the scarce funds that are available have begun to cut into a wide range of United Nations programs, many of which serve the world's poorest countries.

title: Cancun Tells Its Spring-Break Visitors to Behave Themselves
description: The ritual known as spring break has changed little over the years, with hundreds of thousands of college students continuing to flock to beach communities in Florida, Texas, Mexico and the Caribbean. But the estimated 250,000 American students who will visit Cancun, Mexico, this month are in for a shock.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Ageless Japanese Tales Of Sorcery and Love
description: Suzushi Hanayagi and Shiho Fujimura brought an austere beauty to "Jiuta-Mai: Classical Dance of Kyoto and Osaka," on Thursday night at the Japan Society. Every step they took during this program of solos seemed to arise from an eternal stillness and return to it.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;With soap operas now on the Web, what's next? J. R. Ewing logging on to lead chat groups?
description: THE soap opera, which as serialized entertainment dates to Charles Dickens, is rapidly gaining popularity on the Internet. In the last year, "Ferndale," financed by America Online; "Techno 3"; "The Spot," and "The Squat" have been introduced, while "475 Madison Avenue" and "The East Village" are making their debuts this month on the Microsoft Network and Time Warner's Pathfinder Web site.

title: Sports of The Times;The Kid Coach Makes All the Right Moves
description: THE new coach pulled a clear, plastic container from his pocket, flipped open the top and poured a handful of green mints called Tic Tacs into his mouth. Jeff Van Gundy was mouth-wateringly ready for a stunningly successful first X's and O's encounter with Phil Jackson.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Taking Aim at Hollywood
description: In the history of musical comedies, no site has been more accident prone than the intersection of Broadway and Hollywood. One need only mention the word movie in the same breath with titles like "Paint Your Wagon," "Camelot" and "A Chorus Line" to produce shudders of revulsion from that arcane and zealous breed for whom the Broadway musical is religion.

title: Shoplifting Suspect Takes Police Car
description: A handcuffed shoplifting suspect jumped into an idling patrol car on Friday and sped out of the parking lot at police headquarters here, but officers did not chase him because he was considered non-violent, a spokesman said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Somerset Growing Fastest
description: Somerset County is the fastest-growing county in New Jersey, with a 10.5 percent increase in population from 1990 to 1995, according to the latest figures from the United States Census Bureau. Somerset's population increased to 265,440 from 240,245, the bureau said in a report released last week. Essex County's population, by contrast, decreased by 2.5 percent over the same period, falling to 758,626 from 777,964. Bergen County remained the most-populous county, with 845,189. Salem County, with a population of 64,921, stayed the smallest.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the impact of new immigrant citizens on New York City politics described a Republican welfare plan incorrectly. Under the proposal, it would be up to states to decide whether to provide Medicaid, the health program for the poor, to immigrants who have not become citizens. The proposal would not strip legal immigrants of Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly.

title: SWIMMING;Davis Misses Olympic Team by Three-Tenths of a Second
description: As an 8-year-old in Cleveland, Byron Davis began swimming at a local Y.M.C.A., not because he was enamored of the sport but because the day he showed up, the bowling league was already filled.

title: TENNIS;On the Comeback Trail at 19, Capriati Returns to the Dominating Style of Her Youth
description: She was all anticipation and annihilation during her match, and, for the first time in too many years, all smiles and serenity afterward.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the coming Presidential campaign in New York misstated the state's rank in population. It is now third, behind California and Texas, not second; New York still has the second most electoral votes, which are based on the 1990 census.

title: Don't Bet on Parking Meters
description: Financial watchdogs from Wall Street to the City Comptroller are worried about the shaky revenue assumptions in Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's proposed budget. To understand why, consider the plan for parking meters.

title: Essay;The Great Disconnect
description: A company announces layoffs that will make its products cost less and its profits rise. This is greeted as good news by investors, and the stock goes up.

title: POLITICS;For Buchanan, Early Gains in Missouri
description: Patrick J. Buchanan showed early strength on Saturday as Republicans gathered throughout Missouri to begin a process that eventually will lead to selection of 36 delegates to the Republican National Convention.

title: Some New York Judges Relish Easy Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Nothing Up Their Sleeves?;Masters of the High-Tech Demo Spin Their Magic
description: They aren't pulpit-thumping preachers, they aren't used-car salesmen and they aren't even movie stars, but the world of high technology has spawned its own virtuosos who have raised the mundane product demonstration to an art form.

title: When a Police Officer Shoots Another
description: A year and a half ago, an off-duty New York City police officer, Peter Del-Debbio, shot an undercover transit police officer, Desmond Robinson, four times in the back in a Manhattan subway station in a moment of chaos and mistaken identity.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Sudan Holding Election That Some Call a Charade
description: The Islamic military Government in the Sudan is pressing ahead with an election this week, asserting that the polling will transform this country into a modern democracy.

title: Whit Bissell, Stage and Screen Actor, 86
description: Whitner (Whit) Bissell, a character actor who appeared on Broadway and in scores of films, died on Tuesday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 86.

title: At Some Schools, It's Hard to Curl Up With a Good Book
description: The library at Public School 139 in Rego Park, Queens, closed more than a decade ago. When students have research questions, their teachers fetch metal carts stacked with dictionaries and encyclopedias from the corridors and wheel them into class. The Parents Association bought the books and the carts last year.

title: Did Yeltsin Get a Sweetheart Deal on I.M.F. Loans?
description: Poor countries usually do a bit of groveling and a lot of kicking and screaming when they negotiate with the International Monetary Fund, needing the loans the organization provides but resenting the demands for austerity that accompany its help.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L. to Scrutinize Musical Franchises
description: Both National Football League franchises in Los Angeles moved last season, three more franchises (Cleveland, Seattle and Houston) hope to hop to new spots as early as next season and several others (including Tampa Bay, Arizona, Cincinnati and Detroit) have eyed new stadiums, new cities, new homes.

title: BASEBALL;Perez's Renaissance May Rotate Gooden Out
description: Melido Perez is still working on a no-hitter for spring training and that is working on the mind of Joe Torre as the manager ponders assembling a starting rotation. Suddenly, Dwight Gooden is no longer an untouchable in the rotation. Suddenly, there is quite a serious skirmish among the Yankee starters.

title: Clear Channel Adding Stations
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. agreed last week to buy U S Radio Inc. for $140 million.

title: POLITICS: THE PROBABLE OPPONENTS;In Many Ways, Probable Foes Are Peas in Pod
description: Nearly three years ago, President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole and their wives broke bread at a festive, bipartisan dinner at Duke Zeibert's, a favorite restaurant of the powerful that was five blocks from the White House.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Lubbock's Team Won't Disappear in Mirror
description: Lubbock, Tex., is not exactly synonymous with college basketball.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: No Panic Seen After Market Drop At mutual fund and brokerage firms around the country this weekend, the volume of calls from customers rose, but there was no sign of panic selling in the wake of Friday's 171-point dive in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: No Headline
description: I'm 85 and I'm still driving, so I can tell you I know the ropes. For me, I was able to do a lot of things at 72. But running a country is another thing altogether."

title: Harrison Smith, Banker, 76
description: Harrison Smith, a retired New York banker long active in community affairs, died last Monday in a car accident in Surry, Me. He was 76 and lived in nearby Brooklin, Me., where he moved from Manhattan in 1986.

title: Bridge
description: Seven months after an agonizing defeat, a loss by 7 imps in the final of the Spingold Knockout Teams in New Orleans, Zia Mahmood of Manhattan and his team have gained revenge on their great rivals. In the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams here Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, they defeated Nick Nickell of Raleigh, N.C., and his world champion squad by 37.

title: Constitution Protects Same-Sex Marriages
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents;Getting a grip on those teeny-weeny cups doctors love to give you to hold your urine sample.
description: IT'S probably safe to say that every woman at one time or another has been handed a little plastic cup by a doctor or nurse and sent off to provide a urine sample. The specimen cups seem always to be small and awkward to handle, making the process cumbersome and sometimes unsanitary.

title: The Jobs Immigrants Take
description: America is in the throes of another debate over legal immigration, and this time those that would close the country's doors seem to have the upper hand. While an unhealthy nativism lies behind today's backlash, there are real reasons to worry about immigration. The most important: its negative effects on low-skilled African-Americans.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Showing Flag Off Taiwan

title: A Carousel Of Visions;Artist Brings the Fantasies Of Children to Magical Life
description: Artistic acclaim came early to Milo Mottola. When he was 8, his drawing of menacing tooth film with the slogan "Plaque is mean, so keep teeth clean" was such a hit it won him a $50 savings bond from a dental group and was made into a poster. So what if he had to go to a banquet and wear the pink suit his mother picked out?

title: JAZZ REVIEW;A Patriarch Whose Riffs Are Ever New
description: The saxophonist and composer Benny Carter has such a central position in American music that his absence would have completely changed the musical landscape of the 20th century. Mr. Carter, who was celebrated at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night in a Jazz at Lincoln Center program, helped insure the success of Capitol Records with his early hit "Cow-Cow Boogie." His composing for television was so absorbed by the idiom that his writing now occasionally sounds as if he refers to television, instead of the other way around. And as a jazz musician -- improviser, composer and arranger -- he's one of the foundations of the music. Mr. Carter, 88, has been part of jazz recording nearly from its beginning.

title: World News Briefs;Swiss Vote to Shore Up Minority Language Use
description: Swiss voters approved an amendment today to keep the Romansch language from dying out as the country's fourth national language.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Deacons' Duncan Seizes The A.C.C.
description: The ball was in Stephon Marbury's hands, but the game and the moment belonged to Tim Duncan. And so, ultimately, did the championship in the 43d annual Atlantic Coast Conference Tournament, as Wake Forest outlasted Georgia Tech today, 75-74.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Put the Brakes on Their Downward Slide With a Convincing Victory
description: If there was ever a must-win situation for the Nets, it was tonight, regardless of Butch Beard's reluctance to say so.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Child-Cancer Study Planned
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency plans to conduct a study examining why children in Toms River have been stricken with cancer of the brain and the central nervous system at four times the rate that might have been expected, The Associated Press reported yesterday. From 1979 to 1991, eight children were diagnosed with one of those cancers. In a population the size of Toms River's -- 11,000 children under the age of 20 -- researchers would have expected to find no more than two cases, health officials said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When LORRAINE GORDON and her friends gather at Seventh Avenue South and Perry Street in Greenwich Village tomorrow to celebrate a new geographical designation, "Max Gordon Corner," it will mark the end of a long crusade.

title: Government Undercut Czech-Slovak Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Stonewall B. Stickney, Mental Health Commissioner, 72
description: Stonewall B. Stickney, who supervised a court-ordered overhaul of Alabama's mental health system as its first full-time Commissioner, died on Wednesday. He was 72.

title: Court Hears of a Warning on Rabin Attack
description: An Israeli police officer said in court today that the police were briefed on the evening of Yitzhak Rabin's assassination about the possibility of an attempt on the Prime Minister's life.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Finding New Drama in Stalin's Life
description: STALIN The First In-Depth Biography Based on Explosive New Documents From Russia's Secret Archives By Edvard Radzinsky Translated by H. T. Willetts Illustrated. 607 pages. Doubleday. $30.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Odd Shoe Exchange Fits the Hard-to-Fit
description: People with one amputated foot need not pay for a new pair of shoes, or those with feet of markedly different sizes pay for two pairs to get the correct fit for both feet.

title: Arafat Men Seize 3 in Hamas; Not Enough, Peres Says
description: Under mounting pressure to crush the militant Hamas movement, which is linked to recent suicide bombings in Israel, the Palestinian Authority said today that it had arrested three senior members of the movement's military wing.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Store Discounts for Elderly
description: Merchants and city officials are teaming up on a plan intended to encourage businesses to give discounts to residents over 60. The Merchants Council of Jersey City, in conjunction with the city, will publish a free guide this spring to stores offering discounts for the elderly and will provide window decals for participating retailers. Michael Yun, who heads the merchants' council, said only about 10 percent of the city's 3,000 merchants now give discounts to old people.

title: Metro Matters;Another Frill: Giving the Poor Good Lawyers
description: ONE day last winter, Mitchell D. was accused of robbing a midtown deli. He said he didn't do it, but his court-appointed lawyer said he had a bad case and advised him to plead guilty. He refused.

title: Parent Groups Seek 'Megan's Law' Role
description: Several parent-teacher associations say they should be told when a convicted sex offender settles here. They have applied to be notified under the community notification act known as "Megan's Law."

title: BASEBALL;Franco a Saving Grace For Mets' Young Arms
description: John Franco has a ready answer for those who suggest that, because he is 35, the Mets need to groom another bullpen stopper: "Read the back of my bubble-gum card."

title: Xerox Creating Company to Push Its New Flat-Panel Displays
description: The Xerox Corporation will announce the formation on Monday of Dpix, a wholly owned company created to help it enter the market for high-resolution flat-panel displays.

title: Winter Was the Deadliest for City Trees in 20 Years
description: To the list of urban casualties of the long, bitter winter -- water pipes, train service, the overtime budget for snow removal -- now add trees.

title: Donnelley Unit Offering
description: The R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company said last week that it planned to sell a majority stake in its Metromail Corporation direct-marketing information unit in a public offering, to focus more on its commercial printing business. Donnelley, the world's largest commercial printer, said it would retain a significant minority stake in Metromail. Metromail, based in Lombard, Ill., offers consumer information and reference services to companies involved in direct mail and telephone marketing.

title: Big Board Seat Is Sold
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold for $1.25 million on Friday, tying the record set a month ago. Owning a stock exchange seat confers membership and gives the holder the right to trade stocks and vote in exchange meetings. There are 1,366 seats on the stock exchange, a number fixed since 1953. The exchange does not disclose the names of buyers and sellers.

title: Peres Praises Arafat; Giuliani Not So Sure
description: The Palestinian Authority announced yesterday it had arrested three senior members of the military wing of Hamas, the Islamic movement linked to recent suicide bombings in Israel, and Yasir Arafat drew guarded praise from Shimon Peres, Israel's Prime Minister.

title: Black Activist Disparages Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Frieda Sandberg Lewis, 85, A Champion of Jewish Causes
description: Frieda Sandberg Lewis, a champion of Jewish causes and past national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, died on Feb. 29 in Deerfield Beach, Fla. She was 85, and a former resident of Great Neck, L.I., and Manhattan.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;The Mighty Bulls Have Worries Too
description: Even a team with a 54-7 record can have problems, and the Chicago Bulls have a few.

title: GOLF;Outshooting His Elders, Herron Wins the Honda
description: He wasn't supposed to be able to do this. Rookies don't win in their seventh PGA Tour start. Young fellows with the nickname of Lumpy don't shoot 62 in the first round and they don't shoot 69 in the last round and they don't beat veterans like Mark McCumber and Nick Price and Mark O'Meara and Payne Stewart.

title: Constitution Protects Same-Sex Marriages
description: To the Editor:

title: Fleeting Fame Sells in Asia For a Lot More Than a Song
description: For a people taught from childhood not to draw attention to themselves, the Japanese sure do love to sing in front of others. According to one estimate, about 16.5 million times a day, somebody in Japan -- in a bar, in a booth, in a sightseeing bus, in the quiet of home -- grabs a microphone and, accompanied by recorded music and usually by ample booze, warbles an off-key Japanese love ballad or a perky pop hit.

title: U.S. to Fight Magazine Ad Tax by Ottawa
description: The Clinton Administration is about to put its trade weaponry to work against Canada on behalf of American magazine publishers, and in particular, Sports Illustrated.

title: Will Kosovo Explode?
description: The Dayton peace accords might have brought peace, however temporary, to Bosnia. Yet another crisis is simmering in Kosovo, Serbia's southernmost province, that could explode into more ethnic violence in the Balkans.

title: World News Briefs;Surprise U.N. Inspections After a Standoff in Iraq
description: United Nations weapons experts made surprise inspections at two Iraqi sites today in a search of information on banned weapons of mass destruction.

title: James Atwater, Journalist and Dean, 67
description: James David Atwater, an editor at Time and other magazines and who later became dean at the University of Missouri School of Journalism, died on March 1 at his home in Columbia, Mo. He was 67.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Wheaton Joins Lowe & Partners
description: Jack Wheaton, who had most recently been president and managing director at Lois/USA in New York, has joined Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York in the new position of executive vice president and executive director. He will manage the American portion of Lowe's Coca-Cola Company account, which includes brands like Diet Coke and Sprite.

title: G.E. and Rolls Alliance Is Seen
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. and the General Electric Company are expected to announce on Monday the formation of an alliance seeking to supply the United States military with jet engines for a new generation of strike aircraft.

title: After Victory, A New Trial For a Weary Kevorkian
description: The day after he was again acquitted of breaking Michigan's now-expired assisted suicide law, a visibly weary Dr. Jack Kevorkian indicated he was out of patience with the legal system.

title: Nampheun Journal;Hellbent on Progress, Thais Sidestep Priesthood
description: Like his father and his grandfather before him, Kasem Wayamo set the world aside recently to enter the Buddhist monkhood in a coming-of-age ritual that lies at the heart of Thai tradition. He may be the last in his family to do so.

title: MEDIA: PRESS;In increasing numbers, critics get an early start in their analysis of campaign  reporting.
description: PEOPLE who complain that Presidential campaigns start earlier and earlier can at least take heart from this: the political news media, who are partly responsible for the endless campaign, are also coming under the critical scrutiny of foundations and academics earlier in the race than ever before.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;A Final Thought: UConn and UMass Taking High Road
description: At the end of a weekend that had already generated a Final Four level of breathtaking moments and passion plays, the 58th National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament began to take shape yesterday, reflecting a reality that the participants already knew too well. Beware the potholes on the road to Exit 16W.

title: Microsoft Issues Pink Slips To Most 3.5-Inch Floppies
description: You may want to stash a couple of floppy disks in your memorabilia collection, next to the vinyl LP's and eight-track tapes, to someday show your grandchildren the quaint storage devices once ubiquitous in computers. Demand for the 1.44-megabyte, 3.5-inch floppy is on the wane.

title: If Amtrak Pays Damages, We All Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Shrugging Off Indictment, Bosnian Serb General Skis
description: The Bosnian Serb military commander, who is wanted on charges of committing war crimes, was seen skiing near Sarajevo this weekend.

title: 3M Chases the Dream of Building a Better Disk
