description: The 3.5-inch floppy disk is now 12 years old. For the computer industry, which reckons time in something akin to dog years, that makes it at least an octogenarian, and there is no shortage of young pups barking for a chance to take its place.

title: U.S. Sending More Ships to Taiwan Area in Warning to China
description: Faced with rising tensions between China and Taiwan, the Clinton Administration has decided to step up American forces in the area, including sending a second carrier battle group there, officials said tonight.

title: If Amtrak Pays Damages, We All Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Can the Web be a time capsule if no one is saving the information for posterity?
description: NATHAN MYHRVOLD, one of the top executives at the Microsoft Corporation, handed a visitor a small, odd-shaped object from his office windowsill.

title: Paul Steiner, Who Popularized Coffee Table Books, Dies at 83
description: Paul Steiner, who helped reshape the publishing business in the United States and made the illustrated coffee table book an industry staple, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Polk Awards Are Announced For Excellence in Journalism
description: Reporters for The New York Times have won 2 of the 12 George Polk Awards for excellence in journalism in 1995, capturing the prizes for metropolitan reporting and business writing.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Santa Monica, Calif., to Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., as the first agency to handle national advertising for the hospital management company. Harry Drury handles advertising for the Tenet South Florida Health System unit, with billings estimated at $3 million. The total billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. Borden Inc., Columbus, Ohio, reassigned brands between two roster shops; the billings were not disclosed. Campbell Mithun Esty, Minneapolis, which is owned by top managers and the Interpublic Group of Cos., was awarded Realemon concentrated juice products in addition to its assignments for Borden's pasta brands. Realemon had been handled by Grey Advertising, New York, which was awarded the Cremora nondairy coffee creamer brand, previously at Campbell Mithun; Grey handles Borden brands like Eagle sweetened condensed milk.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Music Teacher Honored
description: A tuba player who has performed with the Spike Jones Band and the New Jersey Pops was one of 26 first-year teachers to receive a Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation Fellowship last week. The foundation is named for a Madison township philanthropist who died in 1974. David Grego, the tuba player, is finishing his first year of teaching music in the Livingston School District. The winners, many of whom teach as second careers, were chosen by the State Department of Education. TERRY PRISTIN

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Of Mamma, Hard Times, Wise Guys And Pasta
description: To judge from "Little Italy," the Italian word for roots is pasta. Tonight's warm look at the Italian-American experience, through the memories of children and grandchildren of immigrants, celebrates kitchen, table and, of course, mamma mia as the main ingredients of family life. "This is not fast food," somebody says of the eating ritual. "It's slow food."

title: I. G. Oppenheim, 83, Lindsay's Secretary
description: Irving G. Oppenheim, a familiar figure in New York City government for 43 years, including eight as Mayor John V. Lindsay's fleet-fingered night secretary, died on Feb. 29 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He was 83 and lived in the Bronx.

title: OPERA REVIEW;Casting Light On Heartfelt Essentials
description: The New York City Opera has so many reasons not to do "Der Rosenkavalier" that its new production by Jonathan Miller on Saturday was awaited with anticipation, curiosity and just a tinge of dread.

title: Unbowed by Setbacks, Randall Marches On
description: When he was approached about playing the part of the reporter E. K. Hornbeck in "Inherit the Wind," the latest revival by Tony Randall's National Actors Theater, Anthony Heald begged off. Not because he didn't want to play the part, but because it had been played 41 years ago on Broadway by an actor named Tony Randall.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the marriage of Allison Stacey Cowles to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the chairman and chief executive of The New York Times Company, referred incorrectly to the organization formed by the merger of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. It is the Newspaper Association of America, not the National Newspaper Association.

title: NATO to Move Against Anarchy in Serb-Held Suburbs
description: NATO commanders today ordered reinforcements to quell mounting lawlessness and arson in the two remaining Serb-held suburbs of Sarajevo, which are to be handed over to the Bosnian-Croatian federation within the next 10 days.

title: Behind Housing Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKET'S STUMBLE;Bond Futures Push a Bit Lower in Chicago
description: Government bond futures pushed lower in Chicago last night, as a new round of Japanese dealer-led selling hit the market. United States bonds also fell in trading in Asia earlier today, and most Pacific stock markets closed down as well.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;A Few Women's Teams Are Feeling Left Out
description: The four best college teams in the nation received the top seedings last night for the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament. The form sheet also held up for the four second-seeded teams. But at the bottom of the 64-team draw, there were teams on the bubble that made it and some good ones that did not, often with bitter or resigned reactions by their coaches.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Ilie Nastase, Bad Boy of Tennis, Runs Hard to Take Over Bucharest CityHall
description: Who would want to run a city where more than 100 homeless people froze to death on the streets this winter and there was no money to pay for the burials? Where rubbish piles tower over parked cars, and potholes have cratered into mini-canyons?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Q&A/Edward Said : Roots of the West's Fear of Islam
description: Born into a Palestinian Christian family in East Jerusalem in 1935, Edward Said, a professor of comparative literature at Columbia University, has written extensively on Middle East politics. He spoke recently with Ken Shulman in Percoto, Italy.

title: Leon Finley, Lawyer and University Benefactor, 88
description: Leon Finley, a Manhattan lawyer whose lifelong support of St. John's University put his name on Finley Hall at the School of Law, died on March 2 at New York Hospital. He was 88 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Job Cuts at G.E.
description: The General Electric Company plans to cut its salaried work force by about 100 employees, company officials have announced. The cuts, at G.E.'s Power Systems division in Schenectady, come just three months after the elimination of 390 jobs there.

title: Giuliani Wades Into the Aftermath of Jerusalem's Bombings
description: On the first day of a two-day trip to Israel, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani waded into the volatile waters of Mideast politics, cautioning Israelis about dealing with Yasir Arafat.

title: BALLET REVIEW;Clockwork And Pop In Range Of Rhythms
description: Les Ballets Jazz de Montreal points its toes and kicks up its heels in many directions. It defines ballet and jazz in the loosest of terms, and its creations show a multitude of musical and choreographic influences. Its dancers were often sleekly classical on Friday night at Gould Hall. Yet they could also easily step into the cast of a sassy Broadway musical. And they also romped to rock and sizzled to jazz.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Singing Beyond Words And Other Conventions
description: Unlike many singers specializing in contemporary music, Joan La Barbara has a genuinely beautiful voice. She is also a prolific composer, having pioneered a style of vocal writing in which live voice is superimposed on recorded tracks. She has inspired a large body of work, including outright masterpieces by Morton Feldman and Robert Ashley. On Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall, this mesmerizing, multi-faceted talent showed off five recent pieces created for her and a new work of her own.

title: Showcasing an Issue, Clinton Plans a Visit to a Bergen County DumpsiteToday
description: As a young boy, Frank Capriola played baseball in the muddy fields behind his parents' home in the tiny working-class borough of Wallington in Bergen County. He also remembers chopping down the long meadow brush to lay tracks for go-cart races with his friends.

title: HOCKEY;Devil's Sizzle in Overtime in a Possible Playoff Preview
description: The rapid rise of the Devils in the Eastern Conference standing in recent weeks has put them within hailing distance of the Flyers, setting up a possible first-round match in the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Kmart to Test Its Own Label Credit Card
description: In its latest effort to lure customers into its discounted aisles, the Kmart Corporation will issue a private-label credit card.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the comedian George Burns misstated the year of Gracie Allen's retirement in some copies. It was 1959, not 1958.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;First Jail, Then the Ultimate Makeover
description: The woman-in-peril plot is a staple of made-for-television movies, and "A Face to Die For" goes for the kind of danger that throws terror into the heart of any soap-opera heroine. It takes Yasmine Bleeth, the actress best known as a "Baywatch" babe, and gives her a really bad face. She plays a sensitive, poor, aspiring costume designer named Emily, whose face was scarred in a car accident when she was 6.

title: Roy A. Herbert, 66, Magazine Editor
description: Roy A. Herbert, a former managing editor of Reader's Digest who was credited with ending the magazine's support of the Vietnam War, died on Friday at his home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. He was 66.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;So Much for Karma. Knicks Stomp Bulls.
description: The intensity and passion of their veterans returned just as the intensity and passion in the building returned. Patrick Ewing put his head down, driving and dunking harder than he has in the last two months. Derek Harper hit much more net than iron. And finally, the awesome Chicago Bulls fell with an audible thud.

title: Music in Review;CABARET
description: Joys and Sorrows of Life, From Funny to Personal Julie Wilson Oak Room

title: COMPANY NEWS;TELLABS HAS PLANS TO ACQUIRE STEINBRECHER
description: Tellabs Inc. said yesterday that it intended to acquire the Steinbrecher Corporation, a privately held provider of wide-band wireless communications systems, for about $76 million. Steinbrecher, founded in 1973, employs 130 people at its headquarters in Burlington, Mass. It had sales of about $10.1 million last year. Tellabs, based in Lisle, Ill., makes telecommunications equipment and systems. Tellabs' stock rose $1.25 a share yesterday, to $45.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Eisleben Journal;After 450 Years, Is Martin Luther Now a T-Shirt?
description: At the House of Culture here, Gudrun Riedel flipped through her calendar of Martin Luther events and her list of Martin Luther exhibits and shrugged coyly at the ironies of her destiny.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Voila, the Muppet in the Machine
description: YOU click on an icon. The CD-ROM indicator lights up and the hard drive clacks away, reassuring you that the software is loading. The multimedia program displays its copyright notice, bursts into an upbeat song-and-dance video and . . . huh? What the . . . ?

title: Boy Lost in a Forest Is Saved by 2 Dogs
description: They led a boy to the brink of death, then saved his life. Now two dogs are going to get a new home.

title: HOCKEY;Housley Adds Some Punch To the Devils' Power Play
description: Phil Housley seemed like an odd fit for the Devils. Now in his 14th season in the National Hockey League, Housley, a defenseman, had specialized in soft passes, not hard checks.

title: Lucky Lab Accident Yields New Recipe For Diamond Coating
description: BY unintentionally substituting the wrong gas for one they intended to use for hardening tools, workers at a small metallurgical company have accidentally hit upon a potentially valuable method for coating objects with a hard diamond film.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Heating Oil Prices Keep Rising As Cold Weather Persists in East
description: Heating oil and natural gas drove commodity prices higher yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, as unseasonably cold weather in the Eastern United States suggested increased demand at a time of low inventories.

title: Second Carrier Is Sent by U.S. As 'Precaution' : Beijing Warns the U.S.On Taiwan Intervention
description: WASHINGTON  As the Chinese military launched increasingly robust exercises near Taiwan, U.S. officials confirmed Monday that a second aircraft carrier group would be sent to the area as a "precautionary measure."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: CYCLING;Rominger to Ride in America
description: TONY ROMINGER of Switzerland, the world's second-ranked cyclist, will compete with the sport's top-ranked team, Italian-based Mapei-GB, in this year's Tour DuPont.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REVAMPING OF PC MODEM INVENTOR CLEARED
description: Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. said yesterday that a United States Bankruptcy Court judge had confirmed its Chapter 11 reorganization plan, which would pay all creditors and give new investors 49 percent of the company in exchange for $35 million. The investors, Acma Ltd., and BCE's Northern Telecom Ltd., are buying equal stakes in Hayes and have also offered to put up $6.5 million each in convertible loans. The chief executive of Hayes, Dennis Hayes, and the employee stock plan would own 51 percent of the reorganized company. Hayes said the $35 million from the investing companies, a $70 million debt facility with CIT Group/Credit Finance and the proceeds from the sale of surplus land would be used to pay Hayes's creditors. Acma said Hayes was expected to make a pretax profit of $20.2 million on revenue of $329 million this year.

title: New Capital For Rodman
description: Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc. said today that its majority stockholder, the Mexican brokerage firm Abaco Casa de Bolsa, had agreed to invest $9.5 million more in the investment company in the next two months.

title: G.E. and Rolls Are Teaming Up to Work on New Engine
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. and the General Electric Company said today that they would work together to develop an engine to compete in a program to build a new military strike aircraft for both the United States and Britain. The engine contracts alone for the new jets could total $90 billion.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Colombian General Linked to Drugs Quits
description: Colombia's military commander, Gen. Camilo Zuniga, a close ally of President Ernesto Samper who is suspected by American officials of ties to drug traffickers, resigned today.

title: Review/Fashion;Unusual Fabrics Steal Spotlight
description: It is a good sign when a collection forces inquiry about the fabrics used. Some of the most interesting materials are to be found in the creations of developing designers, who, as lords of their own small houses, which started the Paris round of the fall shows today, are using fabric experimentation as a way to define their contribution to fashion.

title: Rod Stewart Cancels
description: A concert by the rock singer Rod Stewart scheduled for tonight at Madison Square Garden has been canceled because of illness. Mr. Stewart was also unable to appear last night. Both concerts have been rescheduled for May. Tickets for last night's show will be honored on May 22 only; tonight's tickets will be honored on May 23 only. Information: (212) 465-6741.

title: Uganda Opposition Seeks a Halt to Killings
description: Uganda's opposition parties urged the Government today to act swiftly to halt a series of attacks by a rebel religious group in which an estimated 180 people have been killed in the past week.

title: As West Booms, Suburbanites Ask If Wild Horses Make Good Neighbors
description: For longer than anyone can remember, wild horses have come down from the hills here every fall, grazing amid the sagebrush just outside this high desert city until they return to their summer range in the mountains.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The Cuervo republic will have a constitution, but no 18th Amendment.
description: IT may be true, as John Donne declared, that no man is an island, but an alcoholic beverage is trying to become one.

title: Ex-Presidents, on Trial in Seoul, Defend Coup and Crackdown
description: At the opening of a courtroom drama in Seoul that has enormous resonance throughout Asia, two former South Korean Presidents today defended their seizure of power in 1979.

title: Forget the Census; Let's Have Doughnuts
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Output Rises
description: German industrial output rose 1.3 percent in January from the year earlier, according to preliminary seasonally adjusted data released yesterday by the Economics Ministry. A 10.2 percent rise in production of capital goods offset declines in consumer goods and construction, the ministry said. December output, however, was revised to show a 1.1 decline from November and a 4.7 percent fall from the month a year earlier. The ministry said it could not rule out a downward revision of the January data. Germany is in a pronounced economic slump, with 10.3 percent unemployment nationwide. (Reuters)

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Coach Knows the Drill: It's Time for Upsets
description: On the morning after Wayne Szoke, the head coach of the Monmouth University men's basketball team, learned which school his team was to play in the first round of the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament -- the first time that either he as a head coach or Monmouth as a school had reached such giddy heights -- Szoke did exactly what he had planned to do this morning, exactly what he knew had to do. Wayne Szoke went to the dentist.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FMC CORP., Chicago, signed a letter of intent with ASB to acquire its Frigoscandia Equipment Holding unit, a Swedish maker of industrial freezers, which has annual sales of $235 million. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Motorist Is Hit by a Train
description: A woman whose car was hit by a New Jersey Transit train yesterday while she was apparently trying to cross the tracks suffered cuts and bruises but was not seriously injured, a spokesman for the transit agency said. Witnesses told the transit police that the woman, Nancy Vintimilla of Hackensack, tried to enter the crossing while the gates were coming down and a train was approaching, said the spokesman, Ken Miller. No one on the train was injured, and buses took commuters to their final destination in Hoboken.

title: Ex-Official In Suffolk Is Acquitted Of Bribery
description: In one of the largest frauds in American corporate history, John McNamara was able to persuade General Motors to lend him $6.2 billion for vans that did not exist.

title: Forget the Census; Let's Have Doughnuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the planned merger of Ciba-Geigy Ltd. and Sandoz Ltd., two Swiss drug companies, misstated the number of jobs that would be eliminated over the next few years as a result. The companies said they would cut their combined work force by 10,000 employees, not 13,500.

title: Review/Fashion;In Milan, All-Too-Human Armani
description: It is easy to forget, as fashion marches on, crushing its own past in a thuggish attempt to declare everything new, what fashion might be like without a Giorgio Armani.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Democrats Moving to Pascrell
description: Democrats are closing ranks behind William J. Pascrell Jr., the Mayor of Paterson and an Assembly member, who is trying to unseat United States Representative William J. Martini, a freshman Republican. The Essex and Passaic County Democratic organizations have endorsed Mr. Pascrell, and both Mary Lee Fitzgerald, a former State Education Commissioner, and Roger Jacobs, a West Orange lawyer, dropped out of the race last week.

title: Music in Review;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Bach With Mysticism And a Provocative Palette Vladimir Feltsman, Pianist 92d Street Y

title: Crew Aide Is Accused
description: The chief investigator for the New York City Board of Education has found that David Begel, the spokesman for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, violated conflict-of-interest rules by working as a consultant for a private educational organization during his first month at the board.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FUND AMERICAN TO BUY STAKE IN FOLKSAMERICA
description: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a 50 percent stake in the Folksamerica Holding Company for $79.4 million. Fund American, an insurance holding company in Norwich, Vt., will receive preferred stock of Folksamerica Holding and rights to buy as much as 6.9 million Folksamerica common shares for $11.47 each. Folksamerica plans to use proceeds from the transaction to complete its $88 million acquisition of the Christiania General Insurance Corporation of Tarrytown, N.Y., which is owned by the Oslo Reinsurance Company, based in Oslo.

title: Keep WNYC-TV's Ethnic Programming
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Uniform Maker Folds
description: President Clinton is a fan of school uniforms, as are administrators for Passaic's elementary schools. But six years after the school district's optional uniform program began, officials discovered a snag: the BES Company, of Emerson, which made the blue apparel, had gone out of business. Administrators are trying to persuade a Hackensack company to start making the uniforms so the program can continue, said David W. McLean, assistant superintendent of Passaic city schools.

title: On My Mind;Indicting China's Terrorism
description: By firing missiles into the waters off Taiwan, Communist China is committing open, deliberate international terrorism of enormous danger.

title: New Printers From Hewlett-Packard
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it would soon offer a new generation of color laser printers that can print a color page for the same cost as a similiar page on a black-and-white laser printer. The company said that the new printers were capable of producing near-photographic images.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fokker Plans to File Bankruptcy This Week
description: The Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. said yesterday that it expected to file for bankruptcy as soon as this week for Fokker Holding N.V. and its Fokker aircraft business. The company is nearing the end of its emergency funds from the Dutch Government and has been scrambling to find a foreign buyer. The company, whose principal owner, Daimler-Benz of Germany, said recently that it was discontinuing financial help, has been trying to raise money from the Government and from banks to continue operating.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRISTOL-MYERS BUYS ARGENTINE DRUG MAKER
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it had acquired Argentia S.A., an Argentine maker and marketer of pharmaceuticals. Argentia, whose 1995 sales were about $67 million, manufactures antibiotics and drugs to treat respiratory and gastrointestinal problems, Bristol-Myers said. Based near Buenos Aires, Argentia has about 600 employees. The purchase is Bristol-Myers's fourth foreign pharmaceutical-company acquisition in the last 24 months, the company said. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;Gingrich and Whitman Appeal to Forbes to Drop Out of Presidential Contest
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey today unsuccessfully urged Steve Forbes to quit the Presidential race, in separate entreaties seeking to unite Republicans on the eve of the biggest day of voting.

title: BASEBALL;Accepting Failure Helps Hundley Succeed
description: At 26, Todd Hundley has found some tranquillity in his life. The Mets catcher, who once was so headstrong that Manager Dallas Green wondered aloud about his unwillingness to accept instruction, believes he has finally hit upon the key to make the most of his baseball career.

title: PATH Names New Director For Rail Line
description: Michael DePallo, a top executive at California's Bay Area Rapid Transit District, was named director and general manager of the Port Authority Trans-Hudson rail line for New York and New Jersey today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Current Account Trade By Japan Shows Deficit
description: Japan had a current account trade deficit of 1.9 billion yen ($17.87 million) in January, the first in five years, the Finance Ministry reported yesterday. It said that the cumulative surplus in the nation's current account -- a broad measure of trade in goods and services -- was declining and would continue to do so, but that the deficit was temporary.

title: Microsoft and DirecTV Form an Alliance
description: The Microsoft Corporation and the satellite broadcast system DirecTV said yesterday that they would collaborate to deliver digital entertainment and information services to personal computers within the year.

title: Q & A
description: The Speed of Light

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.N. and Baghdad Scale A 3d Diplomatic Hurdle
description: After a 12-hour standoff, Iraqi soldiers today allowed United Nations weapons monitors to enter a training base used by the Republican Guard, which has close ties to President Saddam Hussein. It was the second confrontation in three days.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nelson Takes the Blame for the Knicks' Travails
description: Gone was the haggard look that had characterized his 59 games. Instead, a reflective and composed and sometimes remorseful Don Nelson gave his side of the story yesterday, three days after he was dismissed from a coaching job for the second time in 13 months.

title: Henry B. Fried, 89, an Expert On Watches, Clocks and Time
description: Henry B. Fried, an eminent watchmaker who filled his minutes and years with hard work, appreciation of culture and the joys of sport, died on Sunday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 89.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Regain About a Third From Selloff
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved sharply higher yesterday and recouped about a third of the selloff on Friday, as buyers, sensing an oversold condition, moved back into the market looking for value.

title: Union President Yields Race to Challenger
description: Facing the likelihood of defeat in the campaign to succeed John J. Sweeney as president of the Service Employees International, the union's interim president, Richard W. Cordtz, announced yesterday that he was withdrawing from the race.

title: Congresswoman Says Audit Faults Her Campaign
description: An audit of her past campaign finance reports found a jumble of illegal contributions, "ghost contributors" and embezzled money, Representative Enid Greene Waldholtz told Federal officials today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACME-CLEVELAND TAKES ANTI-TAKEOVER STEP
description: The Acme-Cleveland Corporation, the target of a $186 million takeover attempt by the Danaher Corporation, said yesterday that it had adopted a takeover defense and had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to help it analyze the bid. Danaher made the $27-a-share offer last week, and Acme-Cleveland urged its shareholders to wait for its recommendation. The offer expires on April 3. Danaher is a Washington-based maker of hand tools and other specialty tools. Acme-Cleveland, based in Pepper Pike, Ohio, makes electronics and telecommunication products. Acme-Cleveland also said it had agreed to acquire the Phoenix Data Communication Corporation and American Technology Labs Inc., two networking communications concerns that had combined annual sales of about $7 million, for a total of $8.7 million.

title: Spy Panel's Reforms Are No 'Pablum'
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Disclose Talks On Communications Tie
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said yesterday that it had been in merger talks with a rival, British Telecommunications P.L.C., to create the biggest telecommunications company in the world, but that the talks had ended. Cable and Wireless and British Telecom would have a combined market capitalization of L33 billion (about $50.7 billion).

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Robin Raj was named executive vice president and executive creative director at Ikonic Interactive Inc., San Francisco, succeeding Jim Granger, who left to open Eye TV, Larkspur, Calif., a design and production agency for television and interactive media. Mr. Raj had been senior vice president and group creative director at TN Technologies, San Francisco, a unit of True North Communications.

title: America Online in Alliances With AT&T and Netscape
description: America Online announced two major alliances yesterday, with AT&T and Netscape Communications, that were intended to help the world's largest on-line information service take fuller advantage of the Internet's growing popularity.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Knight-Ridder Tries To Sell Cable Stake
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. is negotiating to get out of cable television by selling its share in TKR Cable to its partner, Tele-Communications Inc.

title: Market Place;As the market rebounds, utilities just aren't bouncing.
description: NEVER mind.

title: Athena Wins U.S. Approval Of a New Drug
description: Athena Neuroscience Inc. announced today that it had received contingent approval from the Food and Drug Administration for its drug Zanaflex, a potential new treatment for spasticity resulting from spinal cord injury.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Looking to Cuba for an Issue
description: BODY This is a new 60-second radio advertisement for Steve Forbes that has been broadcast in Florida in the days leading up to today's primary there.

title: Two Gold Producers to Merge In a $1.5 Billion Stock Swap
description: The Battle Mountain Gold Company in Houston said today that it had agreed to merge with Hemlo Gold Mines of Toronto in a $1.5 billion stock swap that would create one of North America's largest gold producers.

title: No Headline
description: Ten years ago, you couldn't find a place to get a sandwich. You could not watch a movie here. If you saw two people, it was a crowd. That has changed entirely."

title: TENNIS;Two Worlds Are United Beyond the Grand Stage
description: While Steffi Graf battered away at yet another victim on the Stadium Court this morning, Guy Forget politely waited his turn and an uncomplaining Mats Wilander was relegated to the tiny Clubhouse Court. The first day of a controversial experiment in coed tennis at this desert resort produced no tantrums, but not all players were convinced that they needed to share courts to promote the sport.

title: G.O.P. Tries for Unity
description: On the eve of primary votes in seven states today, Speaker Newt Gingrich and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey urged Steve Forbes to quit the Presidential race in an effort to unite Republicans.

title: German Press Is Baring More About Politicians' Sex Lives
description: The press attention given to a state premier's divorce suggests that the code of silence that has long shrouded the private life of German politicians is slowly eroding.

title: They'd Rather Fight Than Switch
description: For Bob Dole, the writing may already be on the wall.

title: Wounded Officer Faulted In Subway Shooting Trial
description: An undercover officer shot by a fellow police officer was to blame for his own injuries because he was not wearing his badge or the colors of the day that would have identified him, a lawyer for the officer charged in the shooting told a Manhattan jury yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Whitman Drug Plan Is Stalled
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal to reduce the number of elderly people eligible for a subsidized prescription drug program will not be part of the new state budget, Donald T. DiFrancesco, president of the State Senate, said yesterday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Hope Victory Ends Skid
description: It is not easy to be patient when you have lost five games in a row. But Butch Beard saw a glimpse of hope, even after having watched his Nets give back all the progress they had made since the All-Star Game break in the last two weeks.

title: Bill Nicholson, Outfielder, 81
description: Bill Nicholson, an outfielder with the Chicago Cubs and the Philadelphia Phillies from 1939-53 who twice led the National League in home runs and runs batted in, died last Friday of a heart attack in his home. He was 81.

title: POLITICS: ON THE ROAD;Clinton Asks Tax Breaks For Toxic-Waste Cleanup
description: President Clinton challenged the Republican-controlled Congress today to approve a proposal to use $2 billion in tax breaks to spur the revitalization of mildly contaminated urban industrial sites, even as he accused the lawmakers of mounting "the most aggressive anti-environmental campaign in our history."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market Recovers Two-Thirds of Its Loss The stock market regained nearly two-thirds of the ground it lost on Friday in its worst drubbing in four years. Riding a wave of buying from mutual funds and other investment managers, who saw an opportunity to scoop up bargains, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 110.55 points, or 2 percent, to 5,581.00, its strongest gain in five years. [Page A1.]

title: COMPANY NEWS;CALDOR PLANS LAYOFFS, STORE CLOSINGS AND OPENINGS
description: The Caldor Corporation, the country's fourth-largest discount store chain, which filed for bankruptcy protection six months ago, said yesterday that it planned to close 12 underperforming stores that employ more than 1,000 people, and open six new stores. The plan must be approved by bankruptcy court in New York. Caldor plans to close eight stores around Rochester and Syracuse, two in Massachusetts, one in Connecticut and one on Long Island. The six new stores will be in Silver Spring, Md.; District Heights, Md.; Glen Oaks, Queens; Westbury, L.I.; Hunting Park, Pa., and Edgewater, N.J.

title: It's Not Over Till It's Over
description: It is true that this week promises, if not exactly balmy weather, at least bearable weather. It is also true that several recent Aprils in New York City have featured snowstorms. So this is no time to be talking about spring being just around the corner. Rather it is a time to wonder if winter, which has already cost New York big bucks and its residents big headaches, has got a few more licks left in it.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Cowboys Sign Linebacker
description: The Dallas Cowboys have signed the free-agent linebacker FRED STRICKLAND, formerly of the Green Bay Packers, to a two-year, $1.15 million contract. Strickland received a $350,000 signing bonus from the Cowboys, plus base salaries of $200,000 in the first year and $600,000 in the second. (AP)

title: Gaming on Wall Street
description: Today, the one sure tip in the stock market is to buy any company that is about to be added to the Standard & Poor's 500. The market is full of mutual and pension funds and bank trust departments that must buy stock in every company on that 500. Each time a company is chosen to replace one that has merged or gone bust, there is a sizeable demand for its stock, even if it has just published a lousy earnings report.

title: Swindler-Informer Is Convicted Of Having Accomplice Killed
description: A career swindler whose work as a Government informer played a prime role in exposing major municipal corruption in New York City and Chicago was convicted yesterday of masterminding the murder of an accomplice in what prosecutors said was his latest swindle.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Truck-Weight Site Is Fought
description: Residents of tiny, affluent Harding Township, where the average lot is three acres, were outraged when the State Department of Transportation floated the idea of building a truck-weighing station in their community. "It's inconceivable that the state would propose doing this in our residential area," said Rich Wiedmann, the township administrator.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NELLCOR BENNETT TO SWAP STOCK FOR INFRASONICS
description: Nellcor Puritan Bennett Inc. of Pleasanton, Calif., said yesterday that it planned to acquire Infrasonics Inc. in a $66 million stock swap. The deal would add infant and high-frequency ventilators to Nellcor's product line. Infrasonics stockholders would receive 0.095 share of Nellcor Puritan Bennett for each Infrasonics share, with a minimum stock value of $6.25 a share. Shares of Nellcor Puritan Bennett, which makes health care products including monitors and sensors, jumped $6.25, to $71.25, while Infrasonics shares rose $1, to 6.50. Infrasonics, based in San Diego, had revenue of $23 million in the year ended in June. It is the leading producer of infant ventilators and second in production of high-frequency ventilators.

title: Don't Let Immigrants Take Jobs From the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Washington Opera paid tribute on Sunday evening to PLACIDO DOMINGO, its new artistic director, at a Domingo Gala.

title: U.S. Seeking Tougher Sanctions To Press Nigeria for Democracy
description: The Clinton Administration has circulated a proposal for strong new economic sanctions intended to force the Nigerian military Government to move toward democracy. But the proposal has received a cool reception from several European countries, according to diplomats, officials and American business representatives watching the negotiations.

title: Audrey Cohen, 64, Innovative Educator, Dies
description: Audrey Cohen, an innovative educator for more than 30 years and president and founder of Audrey Cohen College, died on Sunday morning at her home in Manhattan. She was 64.

title: Shell Makes a Big Oil Discovery Off Nigeria
description: Royal Dutch/Shell, which has been criticized by human rights groups for its operations in Nigeria, has made a potentially significant discovery of oil in a deep-water area off the coast of the West African country, Shell officials confirmed today.

title: Don't Let Immigrants Take Jobs From the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Ex-Champs Within 90 Minutes
description: Fighting a week of sleep deprivation and shrinking dog teams, the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race leaders pulled out of this Norton Sound village at midday today, heading for a final eight-hour layover before the dash to Nome.

title: POLITICS: VOICES;Sitting Out the Dance of Politics
description: Hard by the highway mix of gambling casinos and tarpaper-shack poverty, Carla King, a waitress at the Blue and White diner, said she had finally heard someone mention that today was the eve of primary voting day.

title: Guatemala Kidnappings Follow Purge
description: The burly men who grabbed Vinicio Pacheco and stuffed him into a car with smoked windows ultimately decided not to kill him, though they tortured and toyed with him for hours.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MEDTRONIC TO BUY REMAINING SYNECTICS SHARES
description: Medtronic Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $59 million, or $41.74 a share, for the shares of Synectics Medical A.B. of Sweden that it does not already own. For the last three years, Medtronic has held about a 7.4 percent stake in Synectics. Its tender offer valued the Stockholm-based company at about $63.7 million. Synectics is a world leader in computerized systems that help diagnose urological and digestive problems and sleep apnea. Shares of Minneapolis-based Medtronic fell $1.25, to $55.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HOCKEY;Blinking Back the Tears, Montreal Closes Its Forum
description: On the night hockey said goodbye to the Montreal Forum, even The Rocket's eyes were misty.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Citizens Financial Picks Ingalls
description: The Citizens Financial Group, which is owned by the Royal Bank of Scotland, said yesterday that it had named Ingalls Advertising in Boston to handle marketing communications for its Citizens Bank unit, which has branches in Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island. The account, with billings estimated at $6 million to $8 million, had been handled for the last eight years by Duffy & Shanley Inc. in Providence, R.I., which resigned last month.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IMMULOGIC-HOECHST PARTNERSHIP DISSOLVED
description: Shares of the Immulogic Pharmaceutical Corporation of Waltham, Mass., fell 28 percent yesterday after Hoechst Marion Roussel Inc. dropped its partnership with the biotechnology company, surrendering the rights to the Allervax line of allergy products. Wall Street seemed uncertain whether the dissolution of the partnership was related to product performance or whether the venture was simply a casualty of Hoechst's reorganization after its merger with Marion Merrell Dow. Hoechst Marion Roussel is a division of the giant German drug maker Hoechst A.G., which said it planned to sell part or all of its 1.25 million shares of Immulogic, or about 6 percent of the company. Immulogic shares fell $3.75 to close at $13.25 on the Nasdaq.

title: China Warns U.S. to Stay Out of Taiwan Feud
description: With the United States bolstering its naval forces near Taiwan, China charged today that the Clinton Administration and Taiwan's leaders had touched off a crisis that has now reached an advanced state of intimidation and the threat of conflict.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;N.Y.U.'s Persistence Pays Off
description: For the seniors Kenya Jones and Mindy Sokalsky, this was their last chance for glory while playing basketball at New York University.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Canadian Nickel Producer Turns Aside an Offer by Inco
description: Diamond Fields Resources of Canada, which has agreed to be acquired by Falconbridge Ltd., disclosed today that it had rejected an offer from Inco Ltd. that appeared to be aimed at breaking up the Falconbridge deal.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz CD's;Statements Of Promise And Hope
description: Joe Lovano, 'Quartets'

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Fear of Fat as the Bane of Modernism
description: DEDICATION TO HUNGER The Anorexic Esthetic in Modern Culture. By Leslie Heywood 243 pages. University of California Press. $35.

title: Fidelity Shifts Management At 26 of Its Mutual Funds
description: In one of the largest management shifts in its history, Fidelity Investments, the country's largest mutual fund company, is reassigning 26 of its equity-portfolio managers in an effort to improve the performance of the funds.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAXXIM MEDICAL RAISES BID FOR STERILE CONCEPTS
description: Maxxim Medical Inc. said yesterday that it had raised its offer for Sterile Concepts Holdings Inc. to $17.75 a share after Sterile Concepts rejected a $16-a-share bid last week. Maxxim, a maker of medical-therapy products, has offered cash or stock, or a combination. The new offer values Sterile Concepts at about $128 million, which includes the assumption of $29 million in debt. Sterile Concepts is a Richmond-based maker of surgical trays. A Sterile Concepts representative was not immediately available for comment. Last week, Sterile Concepts cited "philosophical differences" between the two companies for rejecting the first offer and adopted an anti-takeover plan.

title: Music in Review;JAZZ
description: Visiting Drummer's Swing Adds Texture to the Party Highlights of Jazz Pace Downtown Theater

title: Acid Rain Leading to Moose Deaths
description: A STRANGE, debilitating malady has killed hundreds of moose in southwest Sweden over the last decade, and acid raid was the catalyst for a complex chain of events leading to the disease, a Swedish scientist says. This appears to be the first instance in which acidification has been linked to mortality in a warm-blooded wild animal.

title: Defiance and Disorder for Another Serb Exit
description: Bosnian Serb police officers, weaving their jeep through black smoke from burning buildings, fired rounds into the air, tossed grenades and waved a huge Serbian flag as they led a convoy of civilian cars today out of the gutted remains of the Serbian-held suburb of Ilidza.

title: Observer;Pluto in Peril
description: Pluto may not be a planet. Can you believe it? Is everything we learned in school a lie?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Kipketer Must Run for Kenya
description: WILSON KIPKETER, the world 800-meter champion, must compete for his native Kenya and not for his adopted home of Denmark at the Olympics, the National Olympic Committee of Kenya says. Kipketer wants to run for Denmark even though he is not a Danish citizen. He won a gold medal for Denmark at the world championships last year.

title: DOW LEAPS 110.55 AS STOCKS RECOUP MUCH OF SELLOFF
description: After taking a weekend to reflect on the worst percentage decline in the Dow Jones industrial average in four years, the stock market yesterday rode a wave of buying from mutual funds and other managers of large pools of investments to its strongest gain in almost two years, retracing nearly two-thirds of the ground it lost on Friday.

title: Right-to-Die Group Offers Broad Array of Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki's Budget Plan Takes Another Blow
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's most powerful ally in the State Legislature called on the Governor today to rewrite his budget for the 1997 fiscal year, saying it depends too heavily on Federal actions that seem increasingly unlikely to happen in the near future.

title: In Battle of Opera Houses, Paris Allows Each to Win
description: As if intent on underlining their different musical tastes, this city's rival opera houses chose to present their proudest moments of the season within days of each other this month, with the Theatre du Chatelet opting as ever to be daring and the Paris National Opera preferring a safer path more certain to win popular approval.

title: Sports of the Times;Pro Coaches Need a Chair And a Whip
description: IN a quiet moment nearly two years ago, shortly after Chuck Daly decided not to coach the Nets anymore, he was asked whether he thought he might ever return to the National Basketball Association as a designated genius.

title: Computer Recreates Call of Dinosaur Sound Organ
description: MOST of the screeches, honks and roars emitted by movie dinosaurs are based on little more than imagination, and paleontologists generally regard these cinematic noises as art rather than scientific replicas of the originals.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Mozart Made Modern, Yet With Humanity
description: It took the 1991 bicentennial in all its relentlessness to suck the life out of Mozart, and performances like Sunday afternoon's at Carnegie Hall to breathe it back in. What wonderful playing of the "Prague" Symphony by James Levine and the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra: such cushioned elegance of sound and gracefully balanced forward motion.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Leo Burnett Gets Big Board Account
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had named the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago to handle its account, which had been at Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York for the last five years. The billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Could Life on Loose Bit of Mars Survive a Short Cut to Earth?
description: SHOOTING stars are nothing new. For thousands of years, humans gazing up at dark skies have been fascinated by these streaks of light. What is new is an increasingly good understanding of their origins and those of rocky cousins that survive the fiery plunge through Earth's atmosphere to strike the ground below.

title: POLITICS: THE FRONT-RUNNER;With Nomination in Reach, Dole Plays a Cautious Game
description: Victory is so tantalizingly close now that he can almost touch it, but there have been so many frustrations, so many letdowns in the last decade and a half that Bob Dole, ever cautious, cannot quite bring himself to believe in it.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Class Conflicts That Stir Aaron Spelling's Worlds
description: It's been a sociology mantra for at least a decade: The rich are getting richer, the poor poorer. All of which intensifies the focus on America's most reluctantly acknowledged fact: class divisions.

title: 2 Global Pepsico Units Set For Snack Foods and Drinks
description: Less than one month after Roger A. Enrico was named the next chairman and chief executive of Pepsico Inc., the company announced yesterday that it was consolidating its beverage and snack-food businesses into two worldwide units.

title: State to Study Ocean County Over Cancer
description: State Health Department officials said today that they would begin a detailed examination of all childhood cancer cases in Ocean County to try to learn the causes of an elevated rate of cancer among children there.

title: Unusual Molecule Could Be Key To Cancer Patient's Weight Loss
description: EXTREME weight loss, known as wasting, long recognized and dreaded as a hallmark of cancer, has puzzled researchers for decades. Patients literally waste away, acquiring an almost skeletal look. Some actually die from the wasting rather than the cancer, researchers say. Even though wasting is considered a serious illness in and of itself, the mechanism has eluded scientists.

title: Music in Review;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Relaxed Interpretation Of Two Sibelius Symphonies Toronto Symphony Carnegie Hall

title: Officials Seek Wider Powers to Seize Children in Drug Homes
description: With New York officials working to toughen child protection laws, there is widespread sentiment in Albany to give welfare agencies more power to take babies who are born with drugs in their systems away from their mothers.

title: America Should Pay Its Debts to the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Strike's Effect Widely Felt In Auto Plants
description: The effects of a week-old brake-factory strike rippled across North America today, with the General Motors Corporation's closing of 14 assembly plants and 16 parts plants from Chihuahua, Mexico, to Oshawa, Canada.

title: DANCE REVIEW;From India, Delicate, Martial And Wild
description: One pleasant surprise followed another in "Music and Dance of Manipur," which the Ranganiketan Manipuri Cultural Arts Troupe presented on Sunday night at Symphony Space. All its offerings came from Manipur, a region in northeast India that is surrounded by mountain ranges, near the border with Myanmar. Manipur is isolated from the rest of India, but it is rich in dance.

title: Don't Let Immigrants Take Jobs From the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Read It First In Alternative Press
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Shutdown Grows

title: BOXING;Seething Bruno Counts the Days
description: Less than a week from a $6 million payday, Frank Bruno is unhappy. One might even say angry.

title: New City Buses Take a Long Road to New York
description: New York City needs new buses, as any rider of the Transit Authority's creaky fleet knows. But some passengers waiting to see gleaming new coaches will have to wait just a bit longer while the buses make a detour: to Atlanta.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Sweetness and Humor in a Willful Role
description: Larissa Lezhnina has quite a following among American balletomanes, and so a number of New York fans were in the audience today when the young Russian ballerina appeared as a guest artist with the Connecticut Ballet in "Coppelia." But as it turned out, Ms. Lezhnina was not the only highlight of the matinee. There was much to admire in the production itself, a version by Brett Raphael, the company's director, of the original by Arthur Saint-Leon.

title: Navigation Satellites Have Rival: the Sea Turtle
description: SEA TURTLES, those crusty old mariners that ply the oceans, may, like their human counterparts, use a kind of global positioning system to perform their navigational feats, scientists say. But unlike humans, who rely on signals beamed from satellites, turtles appear to sense the earth's magnetic field.

title: Go Slow on F.D.A. Reforms
description: Americans who remember the thalidomide disaster in England 35 years ago, when many mothers who had taken the drug had babies with serious birth defects, were grateful that the Food and Drug Administration kept it off the market in this country. But now the F.D.A. has come under fire for taking too long to approve drugs and medical devices. Congress is considering legislation that is designed to speed things up, but that may go too far in loosening regulatory safeguards.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Hong Kong Stocks Plunge 7.3%, Rattled by U.S. Bond Prices and China
description: As Hong Kong's stock market spiraled precipitously lower amid worries of war over Taiwan and over American interest rates, a mood of anxiety settled over this territory today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Backpack Dispute
description: An administrative law judge will hear arguments today about a school policy prohibiting students from wearing backpacks in corridors and classrooms. Last month, Leo F. Klagholz, the State Commissioner of Education, ordered Elyse Meredith, an eighth grader at William Annin Middle School, to comply with the rule while awaiting today's proceeding.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;12,927 Aid Neediest Cases, As $4.8 Million Is Raised
description: Bernadine T., a single mother of four children in Brooklyn, budgets her monthly $1,426 paycheck meticulously. Even so, there were days last year when she came up short. No money for diapers, or food, or both.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sharp and Alcatel Join on Phone Product
description: The Sharp Corporation of Japan and Alcatel Alsthom S.A. of France announced an alliance yesterday to develop new wireless equipment that combine cellular telephones with electronic organizers. Sharp will also distribute Alcatel equipment for digital cellular telephones.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Steers Clear of a Starter Dispute
description: One day after Manager Joe Torre turned Dwight Gooden's spring-training stroll in the starting rotation into an interesting tap dance for a job by injecting some doubt into his seemingly untouchable status, the pitcher barely reacted. To Gooden, it is not much of a challenge; it is not a problem.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Get Ball Back In Their Own Court
description: When Derek Harper walked over to Jeff Van Gundy on Sunday evening and presented him with the game ball after Van Gundy's first pro victory, the veteran point guard was not only showing a sign of respect and appreciation for his new coach. He was also returning a favor.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;As eWorld Sinks, Which Lifeboat?
description: APPLE COMPUTER INC.'s on-line information service, eWorld, is eVaporating, and by the end of the month will be eXtinct. Apple says it will shut down eWorld on March 31 and refocus its attention on the Internet's World Wide Web.

title: Board Members, Too, Are Getting Investor Scrutiny
description: In a move that could mark the beginning of a new phase in the shareholder-rights movement, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' pension fund is expected to release today a list of what it calls the 23 "least valuable directors" in corporate America.

title: Emergency Plan Set for Seizure Drug
description: A hard-to-get drug used to treat a severe seizure condition in infants will be made available by the manufacturer on a restricted basis until production is back to full capacity in several months, it was announced today.

title: Drilling on Phonics? Reading Twain? Goals Don't Say
description: Here are the national curriculum guidelines for teaching English, being issued today by the National Council of Teachers of English and the International Reading Association:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Investigative Unit Supported
description: Democratic legislators yesterday urged their colleagues to support their bill to assure the continuing independence of the State Commission of Investigation. A task force appointed by Governor Whitman recommended earlier this year that the commission report to the Attorney General's office. State Senator James E. McGreevey, Democrat of Woodbridge, said the commission should be made permanent rather than subject to dismantling every six years.

title: G.E. Chief's Compensation for 1995
description: John F. Welch Jr., chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Company, received $10.6 million in salary, bonus and stock-appreciation rights last year, placing him among the highest-paid chief executives in the United States.

title: In Jerusalem, Giuliani Takes a Feared Bus Route
description: No. 18 buses have been traveling across this tense city largely empty since two recent suicide bombers killed 45 people on the line. Today, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani expressed his solidarity with Israel by climbing aboard the 6:30 A.M. run trailed by staff members and a gaggle of television crews, the problem was finding space.

title: Opponents Nervous as a Democrat Tries Regulatory Overhaul
description: Another major proposal to give industry broad relief from costly Government rules is coming to the Senate soon, but this time not from the Republican leaders whose ambitious antiregulatory agenda has been stymied so far. Instead, its author is an influential Democrat, and his proposal has stirred deep unease among environmental, labor and consumer groups and in the Clinton Administration.

title: TV SPORTS;Up Goes the Volume, Down Goes the I.Q.
description: The overhyped buildup to the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament must be cauterizing brain cells. What other conclusion was there for Quinn Buckner sounding like a born-again Vitaleist, shouting, "It's that time!" and "Let the games begin!" at the end of CBS's selection show Sunday night? Next year, he may toss a chair or muss Pat O'Brien's hair.

title: Ex-Defense Chief on Trial in South Africa
description: The trial of an apartheid-era Defense Minister, Magnus Malan, began here today with prosecutors promising that their case would "cast a shaft of judicial light" into a dark corner of South Africa's history.

title: Read It First In Alternative Press
description: To the Editor:

title: SWIMMING;Bennett Wins the 800 Meters, With Evans Way Back in Second
description: As the eight finalists in the women's 800-meter freestyle arrived at poolside tonight, they were serenaded by Aretha Franklin's "Respect," which is what Brooke Bennett earned from Janet Evans.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L. Owners Bask, but Tagliabue Has Warning
description: When the National Football League owners opened their annual meeting here today, they heard good news. N.F.L. television ratings continue to soar, and so do league attendance and revenues. The sport remains the most popular among Americans.

title: Birdcage' Shows Growth In Older Audience's Power
description: Robin Williams, the star of "The Birdcage," voiced one reason for the resounding -- and unexpected -- success of the film, which opened last Friday. "It's basically very funny, and now, with all the primaries in the news, people want some kind of antidote," he offered. "You know, laughter as medication."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Jet Makers Preparing Bids For a Rich Pentagon Prize
description: Micky Blackwell, an executive at the Lockheed Martin Corporation, has spent much of his career building jet fighters for the American military. So he knows the superlatives to use in making the pitch for a new plane: biggest, fastest, stealthiest, deadliest.

title: Old Nemesis, DDT, Reaches Remote Midway Albatrosses
description: AS its name suggests, Midway atoll in the North Pacific is a long way from anywhere: 3,100 miles from Los Angeles, 2,400 miles from Tokyo and 1,150 miles from Honolulu at the other end of the Hawaiian Islands chain. But isolation has not protected oceanic birds nesting on Midway from environmental contaminants that originate in distant places. Researchers have found high levels of DDT compounds, PCB's and dioxin-like compounds in black-footed albatross adults, chicks and eggs.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Chechen Rebels Leaving Capital After Attack
description: Small groups of Chechen rebels battled Russian troops in Grozny today as the separatists continued their retreat from the city, but Russia's Interior Minister, Anatoly Kulikov, admitted that their assault had caught his troops off guard.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;1986 Giants Remember
description: Ten years after helping the Giants win their first Super Bowl, members of the 1986 team are participating in a yearlong series of events to commemorate the accomplishment. "As captain of that team, I found it to be the most dedicated group of individuals that I've ever been a part of," said HARRY CARSON, who played linebacker, at a gathering with some other members of the team at Giants Stadium yesterday. The reunion celebration will include the merchandising of apparel and autographed memorabilia; a portion of the revenue generated will go to various charities.

title: Bank Merger Clears Hurdle
description: The Justice Department approved the $3.2 billion merger of the Corestates Financial Corporation and Meridian Bancorp today after the Pennsylvania banks agreed to sell 11 branch offices with $444 million in deposits.

title: Ambiguity' On Taiwan
description: With China test-firing missiles into the seas around Taiwan's main ports and American warships patrolling the Taiwan Straits in response, the United States remains deliberately vague about the depth of its commitment to defend Taiwan from attack.

title: F.B.I. Using Newspaper Ads To Seek Vietnam Informers
description: When Vu Duc Vuong, the director of a Southeast Asian refugee center here, first saw the advertisement in one the nation's leading Vietnamese-language newspapers last month, he thought it was a joke.

title: Son of Last Kaiser Meets Vienna Press : A Habsburg Defies Exile From Austria
description: In what might be described as an act of lese-republique, a Brussels businessman who was born an Austrian archduke challenged legal banishment from his native land by appearing at a press conference Monday in Vienna.

title: After 50 Years, G.I.'s and Russians Meet Again
description: Lieut. Col. Jeff Hammond, the commander of the 429th Field Artillery, First Armored Division, peered into the empty hatch of a Russian armored personnel carrier.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;St. John's Forces Mahoney To Leave
description: Brian Mahoney reluctantly walked away from St. John's University yesterday. He was asked to leave the job he once coveted for years, the one for which he waited patiently if anxiously in the spring of 1992 while a slow-moving search process eliminated more-established candidates.

title: Transit Authority Is Planning To Cut 800 More Token Clerks
description: The Transit Authority plans to cut 800 more token booth clerks from New York City subway stations, slashing their ranks by a third, over the next two years as it goes ahead with its electronic fare collection program, officials said yesterday.

title: Chess
description: Zsuzsa Polgar, at 26 the oldest of the three remarkable sisters from Budapest, has won the women's world championship from Xie Jun of China by a decisive 8 1/2-4 1/2 score. Her prize for the three-week match was $125,400.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in some editions of Business Day yesterday about overnight trading on Asian financial markets misstated yesterday's decline in Hong Kong's leading stock market index. The Hang Seng index closed down 820.34 points, or 7.3 percent, at 10,397.45.

title: The Mayor's Clumsy Visit
description: There is never a good time for the Mayor of New York City to inject himself into Middle East politics, but it would be hard to imagine a more sensitive moment than now. With the peacemaking effort between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization barely registering a pulse after four terrorist bombings, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani should not be grandstanding in Jerusalem.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Making a rare public appearance, MADAME CHIANG KAI-SHEK, the widow of the Chinese Nationalist leader, went to the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday for a preview of an exhibition of Chinese art treasures from the Neolithic period through the 18th century. The show, "Splendors of Imperial China: Treasures From the National Palace Museum, Taipei," opens to the public on March 19.

title: Sales of New Homes Jumped in January
description: Despite some havoc from the blizzard, new-home sales shot up 4.2 percent in January. It was the second straight gain as mortgage rates dipped to a two-year low.

title: NYC;2 Gestures, 2 Statements About Israel
description: FOR those who still hold the United Nations in high regard, this may not be the best time to arch an eyebrow over its behavior. The international anchor on Manhattan's East Side has enough troubles, what with the deadbeat known as the United States falling $1.5 billion in arrears and Patrick J. Buchanan feeding the fantasies of the camouflage set -- people convinced that they are about to be invaded by black helicopters under United Nations cover.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;007 Campaign Wins an Award
description: A joint promotional marketing campaign for the James Bond film "Goldeneye" and the BMW Z3 roadster took top honors last week at the 13th annual Reggie Awards ceremony, at which the best promotional marketing campaigns of 1995 were honored. The awards are sponsored by the Promotion Marketing Association of America.

title: Ross Hunter, Film Producer, Is Dead at 75
description: Ross Hunter, a movie producer devoted to preserving the romance and glamour of Hollywood in films like "Pillow Talk," "Magnificent Obsession," "Imitation of Life" and "Airport," died on Sunday at Century City Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: Patterns
description: Ins and Outs of the Tents

title: Prosecutor Says Clinton Helped Ex-Partner Get Improper Loan
description: As Governor of Arkansas, Bill Clinton helped secure a $300,000 business loan for a business partnerthat she instead put into her personal checking account, a Federal prosecutor argued today at the opening of the Whitewater trial here.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Dolphins Sign Barnett
description: The Miami Dolphins acquired a new target for DAN MARINO, signing the former Pro Bowl receiver FRED BARNETT to a five-year, $8.5 million contract. The Dolphins expect Barnett to replace receiver IRVING FRYAR, a free agent who is likely to play elsewhere in 1996.

title: Grace to Sell Dearborn Unit in Move to Lift Shareholder Value
description: Fulfilling a promise it made in September, W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Dearborn water treatment and process chemicals business to Betz Laboratories for $632 million in cash.

title: New Guidelines on English A Sketch, Not a Blueprint
description: There is no specific call for first-grade readers, phonics or Faulkner. No demand for sentence diagramming or Dante.

title: Trying to Fit Saab Into the G.M. Family;Hope and Frustration From Sweden
description: Five years ago, it took Saab Automobile A.B. more than four days to make a car.

title: Claude Welch, Medical Leader And a Renowned Surgeon, 89
description: Dr. Claude E. Welch, who enjoyed messing around with medicine so much as a 12-year-old drug-store clerk in small-town Nebraska that he went on to become one of the nation's leading big-city surgeons and medical statesmen, died on Saturday at Massachusetts General Hospital, his base during an acclaimed 40-year career.

title: Its Library Crippled, Danbury Rallies;Arson Shuts a Center of a Diverse City
description: The Danbury Public Library burned the night of Feb. 27, and the next day, cleanup workers were already tossing ruined books down a chute into a trash container. Marie Proverb and her children, driving by, had never seen books treated that way.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jaguars Pick Up Means
description: NATRONE MEANS, a former Pro Bowl running back who was dumped by the San Diego Chargers last month in a salary-cap move, was claimed off waivers yesterday by the Jacksonville Jaguars. By claiming the 23-year-old Means, the Jaguars have to assume the four-year, $7.3 million contract he signed last summer after an 11-day holdout. But Means will only count $1.6 million against the Jaguars' salary cap because the Chargers have to pay the pro-rated portion of his signing bonus.

title: Officer Charged With Raping His Daughter
description: A New York City police officer was charged last month with raping his 9-year-old daughter twice at his home on Long Island, officials said yesterday.

title: Joseph Braunstein, New York Musicologist, 104
description: Joseph Braunstein, a musicologist, teacher and the senior program annotator for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, died on Sunday in the book-lined Manhattan apartment that he described as his "monk's cell." He was 104.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Thomas Renegotiates
description: THURMAN THOMAS, who will be 30 in May, signed a three-year contract extension yesterday that will keep him in a Buffalo Bills' uniform at an age when most running backs are retired.

title: A Trip to Israel, a Message Back Home
description: On the second day of a trip to Israel, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani conducted something of a rolling press conference, visiting Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. He began the day by riding a Jerusalem bus line that had been bombed. Page B3.

title: Unjustified Shipping Subsidies
description: For a while it looked like the end of the line for maritime industry subsidies, a long-entrenched corporate welfare program that has come under intensified Congressional scrutiny. But the hardy U.S. shipping industry and its labor unions, which have handed out millions in campaign contributions, pushed the House to approve $1 billion in new subsidies over the next 10 years and have brought the Senate close to action on a bill to keep those wasteful subsidies coming. The Senate should not let it happen.

title: U.S. Bars Ex-East German Spymaster
description: The State Department said today it has denied a visa to Markus Wolf, who once ran Communist East Germany's foreign spy service, on the ground that he had in the past been involved in terrorist activities.

title: Girl to Get Benefits In Death of Father Before COnception
description: A child conceived through artificial insemination after her father's death will collect Social Security survivor benefits, her lawyer said today.

title: Science Search Winners Are Led by New Yorkers
description: Winners of the Westinghouse science contest seem to occupy a different sphere than their classmates. There is Bruce Mizrahi Haggerty, a Stuyvesant High School senior in Manhattan, who has already co-written eight academic journal articles on geology and works as a research geologist at New York University.

title: Burbank: A Cinderella City Where Fantasy Pays the Bills
description: Drive just outside the airport here on Thornton Street and look at an unmarked gray building where workers are busily tearing off the windowless walls, and one is face to face with how the economic pain brought by the end of the cold war is being transformed into Burbank's new promise.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Rams Release Miller
description: It has been three months since CHRIS MILLER sustained his fifth concussion in 14 months, and he's still not back to normal. Yesterday, the St. Louis Rams released him.

title: Polaroid to Sell Digital Camera
description: The Polaroid Corporation, long the king of instant photography, displayed a point-and-shoot digital camera today for real estate agents, advertising photographers and other professionals.

title: POLITICS: FUND RAISING;President Is Given Award, Then Raises Money for Party
description: President Clinton mixed peacemaking and politics on a quick trip through New York City last night, accepting an award from Irish-American leaders for his efforts to end the fighting in Northern Ireland before moving on to raise $1.8 million for Congressional Democrats at a lavish $5,000-a-plate dinner in midtown.

title: Diller Is Cleared to Take Control of Silver King
description: Correction Appended

title: By Design;Chic Alphabet Soup
description: Status is back. Louis Vuitton celebrated its 100th anniversary this year by having designers like Manolo Blahnik, Isaac Mizrahi, Helmut Lang and Vivienne Westwood use its famous "LV" logo for a special collection of bags. High-profile lines like Gucci, Prada, Chanel and Hermes with instantly recognizable logos are recording big increases in sales. But even less-expensive clothes and accessories are sporting big bold logos.

title: Unions Cultivate Capitol Hill, Fertile but Unplowed Ground
description: Over bottled beer and Buffalo wings at a popular Capitol Hill watering hole the other day, Eddie Vaden of teamsters Local 246 fielded questions about how the labor movement of Jimmy Hoffa could help organize a sizable share of nonunion workers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF XYLAN MORE THAN DOUBLE ON FIRST DAY
description: The shares of Xylan Inc. closed at more than twice the offering price on their first day of trading. Xylan, based in Calabasas, Calif., makes high-bandwidth switching systems that enhance the performance of computer networks. The company sold 4.2 million shares at $26 each to raise $109.2 million. The stock closed at $58.375 yesterday, as nearly 5.5 million shares were traded.

title: In U.S.-China Tension, a Mutual Blindness
description: To the Editor:

title: How Presidents Campaign
description: Bill Clinton has not been loafing while the Republicans go about choosing someone to run against him. He dipped into his campaign budget to make two recent visits to California, a big and politically important state, and on Monday he swooped down on New Jersey, another state that could be crucial come November. His ostensible purpose was to call attention to the dangers facing 10 million New Jersey children who live within four miles of toxic waste dumps and to announce some new initiatives for cleaning them up. The name of the political party that presumably stands in the way of a safer environment was never revealed. The names of the people who would throw him out of office -- Bob Dole, say, or Pat Buchanan -- never escaped his lips.

title: Subway Service Disrupted
description: Subway service on Manhattan IRT lines was disrupted last night for two hours when northbound trains were halted at 125th Street because of reports of sparks on the tracks in the Bronx, officials said.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Manhattan 'No Longer a Divided House'
description: One team. One heartbeat.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Investcorp Planning to Sell Its Remaining Stake in Gucci
description: Investcorp S.A. said today that it would sell its remaining 51 percent stake in Gucci Group to the public.

title: La Finta Giardiniera' By the Mannes Opera
description: Three performances of Mozart's comic opera "La Finta Giardiniera" are to be presented this month by the Mannes Opera at Riverside Church, Claremont Avenue at 122d Street in Morningside Heights.

title: A Touch of Vienna Off Central Park West
description: GEORGE AND JENIFER LANG'S Cafe des Artistes, 1 West 67th Street, now has a tiny sibling. The Parlor at Cafe des Artistes, across the vestibule from the main restaurant, is a snug coffee and drinks bar that seems plucked intact from a boulevard in Budapest or Vienna. What was once an office has been fitted with a handsome old zinc-and-mahogany bar, a newspaper rack and marble tables. Accents of brass and forest green enliven the dark paneled walls, which are hung with drawings by Howard Chandler Christy, who painted the murals in the cafe. The Parlor is open from 8 A.M. to midnight and serves coffees, pastries, sandwiches, tea, hors d'oeuvres, drinks, wine and desserts.

title: The Diet Wheel Again Spins To Protein
description: FRAN McCULLOUGH, a book editor in Manhattan who has lost 60 pounds in the last year, is relishing the response of people who haven't seen her for a while ("Is that really you, Fran?"). Friends of Janet Pope, a decorative artist in Baltimore, shake their heads in awe at her weight loss -- 56 pounds in 13 months -- accomplished, like Ms. McCullough's, by cutting down on carbohydrates and concentrating on protein.

title: Checkout Time for Balancing the Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: One Company Seen Settling Tobbaco Suit
description: Liggett & Myers, the nation's sixth-largest tobacco company, and lawyers representing smokers are expected to announce a proposed settlement today in the largest class-action lawsuit against the tobacco industry.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALLIANCE FOR TWIN LABORATORIES AND LEONARD GREEN
description: Twin Laboratories Inc. and Leonard Green & Partners L.P. have agreed to form a joint venture to acquire Twin Laboratories for about $225 million, the companies said yesterday. The joint venture will consist of the five Blechman brothers -- all vice presidents at Twin Laboratories and the sons of the founders, David and Jean Blechman -- and Leonard Green & Partners, a Los Angeles merchant banking concern. After the transaction, the Blechman brothers will hold a 45 percent stake in Twin Laboratories. Twin Laboratories, of Ronkonkoma, L.I., markets vitamins and mineral products.

title: America Online Gives Microsoft Favored Status On Internet
description: What a difference a day makes in cyberspace.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;WFMU in Fund-Raising Drive
description: A radio station on the campus of bankrupt Upsala College began a fund-raising campaign this week in the hope of avoiding eviction from its present quarters, the station manager said. WFMU (91.1 FM), is now in the only occupied building on the campus.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RETAIL PROPERTY TO LIQUIDATE AFTER SALE TO GLIMCHER
description: New York-based Retail Property Investors Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell its assets to Glimcher Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust in Columbus, Ohio, for $203 million. Retail Property, which owns 22 retail shopping centers, said its board had approved the sale, which was still subject to shareholder approval. Glimcher owns and manages 92 properties in 22 states.
