Retail Property said the company would be liquidated after the sale. Glimcher's shares fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $16.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Crew Warns Of Layoffs For Teachers
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew warned a City Council committee yesterday that the system may have to lay off teachers if it is forced to reduce its spending by $1 billion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Most G.M. Factories Close After Strike at Parts Plants A week-old strike at two G.M. parts-making plants has caused the closing of nearly three-quarters of the company's North American assembly plants, idling 83,000 workers. By now, 21 of G.M.'s 29 car and truck assembly plants have run out of brakes and sent their workers home. With those plants closed, 30 other G.M. parts factories have shut down.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;N.B.A. Suspends Rauf
description: Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf, the Denver Nuggets' leading scorer, who has cited religious beliefs for his refusal this season to stand during the playing of the national anthem, was suspended today without pay by the National Basketball Association.

title: In U.S.-China Tension, a Mutual Blindness
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The N.C.A.A. basketball tourney has graduated to the ranks of major sports-marketing events.
description: THE ardor of advertisers to affiliate themselves with the annual tournament of the National Collegiate Athletic Association is approaching levels that might even require a repunctuation, to March? Madness!

title: In U.S.-China Tension, a Mutual Blindness
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Ohio Strike Shuts G.M. Plant
description: A United Auto Workers strike at two General Motors Corporation brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, forced the shutdown of G.M.'s assembly line in Linden yesterday, putting 2,100 union members out of work for the duration of the walkout.

title: Stocks Drop in Japan
description: Japanese stock prices fell today, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues closing down 215.57 points, or 1 percent, at 19,734.70. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 153.98 points.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AFTER $2.5 BILLION INVESTMENT, MGM IS PUT UP FOR SALE
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. was put up for auction yesterday, with bids expected from around the world for the resuscitated entertainment company. MGM's owner, Credit Lyonnais, which invested about $2.5 billion in the company, hired Lazard Freres, the investment bankers, last November to study a sale. Published lists of potential bidders include Chargeurs S.A. of France, Polygram N.V. of the Netherlands, Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany, the Walt Disney Company, the General Electric Company and New Regency Productions. Bank and studio officials would not say what price MGM might fetch, but estimates ranged from $1.5 billion to $2 billion. Frank Mancuso, a onetime Paramount Pictures studio chief who transformed MGM into a box office contender over the last three years, also has an option to put together a bid. MGM took in $333 million last year on 15 releases, for a 6.3 percent share of the domestic box office.

title: Record Ozone Depletion Observed in North
description: The ozone layer was briefly depleted by a record 45 percent this winter over an area stretching from Greenland to western Siberia, the World Meteorological Organization said today.

title: TV NOTES;High Hopes for Aliens
description: Folks at Jim Henson Productions hope to have as much luck with their second new ABC show as they did last week with the premiere of "Muppets Tonight!" It won its time period, Friday evening at 8:30, in the Nielsen ratings among households, and even among adults aged 18 to 49. On Friday, Garth Brooks will be the Muppets' human guest star. At 9, following the Muppets, ABC will introduce "Aliens in the Family," also a Henson creation. The new shows temporarily bumped "Boy Meets World" and "Hangin' With Mr. Cooper" from Friday's "T.G.I.F." lineup, but both are expected to return in May. L. M.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;$1 Million Campaign Costs
description: For the first time, campaign costs for a single Assembly district exceeded $1 million last year, a nonprofit, nonpartisan public policy research institute said yesterday.

title: Denver Airport's 2 Deals Clouded by Rising Rates
description: The finances of Denver International Airport became even more complicated yesterday as rising interest rates threw a cloud of uncertainty over two deals -- including an unusual so-called Dutch auction -- aimed at lowering Denver's borrowing costs.

title: Downed Adirondack Trees Will Remain, Pataki Agrees
description: Capping an effort to balance firefighting needs with a mandate to keep the Adirondack preserves forever wild, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that millions of trees damaged when a windstorm leveled 430,000 acres of public wilderness last July would remain where they lie, allowing the forest to heal naturally.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: Two Roman Catholic Views Of Japan After the Bomb 'Two Cities' 30th Street Theater

title: After Enduring Sharp Skid, The Dow Ends Slightly Up
description: Blue-chip stocks ended slightly higher yesterday after recovering from a sharp selloff earlier in the session.

title: Why Some Light Drinkers at 20 May Still Be on Track to Alcoholism
description: THE college student who seldom drinks hardly fits the mold of a budding alcoholic, but a new study indicates that, depending on his genetic profile, his risk may be comparable to that of a classic party animal.

title: TV NOTES;Deja Vu at the Hospital
description: Don't look for a new episode of "E.R." on NBC tomorrow night, or next Thursday night, either.

title: Foreign Affairs;China's Nationalist Tide
description: We met in a restaurant on the edge of Beijing, a seedy place with warm Tsingtao beer and a fish tank full of giant frogs. My dinner companion was a thirtysomething veteran leader of the 1989 democracy uprising in Tiananmen Square, who'd done his jail time. He came to talk about changes in the human rights struggle in China, and I think his words are worth listening to at this key juncture in U.S.-China relations.

title: Report Cites Drugs and Police Role in Man's Death
description: A report released yesterday by the Medical Examiner's Office has concluded that a South Carolina man died from cocaine intoxication while in police custody in Brooklyn last December, but that injuries he suffered in a scuffle with officers also contributed to his death.

title: Seeking Return to Ways Of Patronage in Politics
description: It is no secret that the fabled Democratic machine in Chicago stole a vote or two for John F. Kennedy in the 1960 Presidential election. It is less well-known that Republicans in downstate Illinois were padding the vote for Richard M. Nixon.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Earnings Rise 16% At Prudential of Britain
description: The Prudential Corporation P.L.C., Britain's biggest life insurance company, said yesterday that its operating profit jumped 16 percent last year despite a difficult home market. It said 1995 operating profits increased to L804 million ($1.23 billion) from L693 million and the company raised its dividend by 9 percent, to 15.7 pence (24 cents).

title: James Watt Draws a Fine But Not Jail
description: Former Interior Secretary James G. Watt was spared a jail sentence today and instead was fined and ordered to perform 500 hours of community service for withholding documents from a grand jury investigating a Government housing scandal.

title: At the Nation's Table: Johnson, Ark.;From Down Home To Ozark Cuisine
description: When Miles James was dreaming up the menu for his year-old restaurant, James at the Mill, in Johnson, Ark., his wife, Courtney, told him one morning, "You were saying corn dog in your sleep." He took that to heart.

title: Backpack: An Inalienable Right?;Student and Her School Tangle Over Civil Liberties
description: On one side of the courtroom was a willfully defiant 14-year-old honor student, well versed in the civil disobedience of Thoreau and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and eager to start carrying her maroon backpack to classes again.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Traffic Is Tied Up for Miles After Ice Falls Onto Bridge
description: Warmed by springlike sunshine, ice broke off the towers and cables of the George Washington Bridge yesterday in chunks that smashed onto the roadway, forcing the authorities to close the upper level for more than four hours and starting monumental traffic jams on both sides of the Hudson River.

title: Ex-Soviet A-Bomb Fuel an Easy Target for Terrorists, U.S. Says
description: The republics of the former Soviet Union cannot account for a large share of the hundreds of tons of bomb-grade uranium and plutonium once listed in their stockpiles, creating a "primary national security concern for the United States," Government investigators are warning in a new report.

title: No Headline
description: These Tuesday night meetings are getting to be more and more fun."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Life Term for Slaying Of Jordan's Father
description: A jury in Lumberton, N.C., chose life in prison yesterday for a man convicted in the killing of MICHAEL JORDAN's father.

title: Rich Are Getting Richer, but Not the Very Rich
description: The rich appear to have gotten richer in the early years of this decade, according to Federal statistics issued today, but this time they did it at the expense of the super-rich.

title: Making a Home for Gay History and Awareness
description: There is a corner for almost everybody in the new San Francisco Public Library, nearing completion in the Civic Center area, but the most unusual one can be found on the third floor, where the James C. Hormel Gay and Lesbian Center is housed.

title: AT&T Unit Offering Would Be the Biggest
description: The AT&T Corporation plans to raise as much as $3.19 billion selling shares of its equipment business in the largest initial stock offering in United States history, according to regulatory filings.

title: HOCKEY;Devils' MacLean Set For Knee Surgery
description: John MacLean, the Devils' career scoring leader, will undergo arthroscopic surgery Wednesday on his right knee and will be sidelined 7 to 10 days.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Multinationals Raised '95 Investment in 3d World 13%
description: In a statistical snapshot that reflects some of the downsizing by business, the World Bank said yesterday that foreign corporations invested $90 billion building factories and equipment in developing countries last year, an increase of 13 percent over the level of 1994.

title: Embattled L.I. Incinerator To Go Way of Shoreham
description: When Glen Cove's $40 million incinerator and its towering smokestack were built in 1983, its technology was heralded as the solution to the problem of shrinking landfills on Long Island and in other densely populated areas.

title: Two British Airlines Settle a Dispute
description: British Airways P.L.C. said today that its archrival Virgin Atlantic Airways had agreed to settle its remaining legal dispute in Britain over allegations of dirty tricks.

title: Real Estate;Chicago wants to bring back the grease paint, and two deals are helping theater  restoration.
description: TWO real estate transactions have given new hope for the restoration of a theater center in downtown Chicago by two companies that are also active in Broadway restoration.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Do Not Point the Way: San Jose State Knows
description: Kentucky needs a scrimmage, and it might as well be San Jose State.

title: Film Price Hits $8.50, But There Are Ways To Save
description: The price goes up. The price goes down. Sony Theaters, the city's second-largest chain, has quietly raised the price of a ticket at its Manhattan theaters to $8.50 from $8, keeping New York securely in first place as the nation's most expensive city in which to see a movie.

title: For Irish, a Mix of Pride and Discomfort Over the I.R.A.
description: Plates were cleared from the linen tablecloths, rounds of coffee and drinks were ordered. It was time for the evening show at the Westchester Broadway Theater. It was time to sing about hunger strikes, oppressive British rule and the Irish Republican Army.

title: Governor Rowland's First Year
description: Gov. John Rowland has rightly focused attention on the problems of Connecticut's troubled cities. But he also promised to reduce spending that is vital to urban areas and to deliver a $200 million tax cut that will make it even harder in future years to assist the cities. The Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, which represents the state's cities and towns, has estimated that the Governor's proposed cuts in aid to municipalities add up to $65.4 million for 1996-97. The group has begged him to put off the tax cut. He should forget about it altogether.

title: Business Travel;Donald Trump and the Pritzkers are giving the Grand Hyatt a face lift.
description: IN 1980, Donald Trump helped initiate a decade of glitz when he sheathed the aging, brick-walled Commodore Hotel in glass and joined with the prosperous Pritzkers of Chicago, owners of the Hyatt chain, to give it a new name -- Grand Hyatt -- as well as new management.

title: Immediate Inspection of Rail Cars Is Sought
description: Federal safety inspectors urgently recommended today that all commuter rail cars be inspected immediately to make sure passengers can escape if there is a crash. The National Transportation Safety Board action followed a collision in Maryland on Feb. 16 that killed 11 people.

title: Heroin Indictments Link Drugs to Smuggling of Aliens
description: Six Chinese immigrants were indicted yesterday on charges of selling heroin, and offering discounts in return for forged passports to help them smuggle illegal immigrants into the United States.

title: Personal Health
description: TEST your antibiotics I.Q.:

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Forbes Says the Midwest Is Critical To His Effort
description: A disappointed Steve Forbes said tonight that if he did not make a "breakthrough" in the next round of Midwest primaries that he would end his candidacy for the Republican nomination.

title: BASEBALL;Cone Says His Fastball Is Popping and Hopping
description: David Cone has never been concerned about regaining his precise touch on pitches and getting his splendid right arm to perform productively. He chuckles at speculation that he has thrown too many pitches to be effective anymore and he reminds doubters that the Mets whispered about his supposedly overworked arm after trading him four years ago.

title: I.R.A. Official Begins Visit To U.S. With Modest Schedule
description: With memories of last month's Irish Republican Army bombs in London still fresh, Gerry Adams, leader of the I.R.A.'s political wing, Sinn Fein, arrived in New York City yesterday for a six-day visit in the United States and a schedule considerably more modest than he had for a historic trip here a year ago.

title: Food Notes
description: Saved by Soda Bread

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MEDPARTNERS/MULLIKIN INC., Birmingham, Ala., a physician services management company, agreed to acquire the privately owned CHS Management Inc., a health care organization that provides management services, for $47 million.

title: Bank Deal in Northwest
description: First Savings Bank of Washington Bancorp Inc. said today that it would acquire all the stock of Inland Empire Bank of Hermiston, Ore., for about $32.1 million in cash. Under terms of the agreement, shareholders of Inland Empire, which is closely held, will receive about $60.24 a share. Inland Empire had assets of about $159 million, deposits of $139 million, loans of $84 million and shareholders' equity of almost $18.5 million as of Dec. 31.

title: Out of the Spotlight, Intelligence Services Weigh an Alliance Against Terror
description: When the television lights go out after the summit meeting in Egypt on Wednesday, the real work will begin behind the scenes: an international effort to form a counter-terrorism alliance involving the espionage services of half a dozen nations.

title: Pulp Producer Cutting Output
description: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. said this week that it would reduce its pulp and lumber production for two weeks next month, citing higher pulp inventories and lower prices.

title: Plan to Block Censorship On Internet
description: The top on-line services companies and the National Consumers League announced yesterday that they would begin a campaign to educate the public about intellectual property rights, privacy and consumer protection on the Internet.

title: Hospital Leasing Plan Suffers a Big Setback
description: Mount Sinai Medical Center has withdrawn from the bidding to take over two city-owned hospitals in Queens, a decision that represents a significant blow to Mayor Giuliani's plans to dismantle the public hospital system.

title: C.I.A. Confirms Blunders During Economic Spying on France
description: Blunders by Central Intelligence Agency operatives trying to gather secret information on French trade negotiations and economic espionage led to an international embarrassment, a report by the agency's inspector general concluded today.

title: Saab Aircraft Order
description: Saab Aircraft said today that it had won a $350 million order for 50 regional airliners from Mesaba Airlines, which operates feeder flights for the Northwest Airlines Corporation. The airliners, 30 new Saab 340B Plus aircraft and 20 used Saab 340A planes, will replace Mesaba's entire fleet over the next three years, Saab Aircraft, a unit of Investor A.B. of Sweden, said. Mesaba, which is based in Minneapolis, operates as a link for Northwest Airlines in the United States and Canada, connecting to Northwest flights at Detroit and Minneapolis-St. Paul.

title: Senate Republicans Add Money For Education and Job Programs
description: Yielding to the White House and to their Democratic colleagues, Senate Republicans agreed today to increase spending by $2.7 billion on education and job-training programs as part of a 1996 budget package.

title: Toxins at the Pump
description: Carol Browner, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, thinks the American people shouldn't be guinea pigs. She's right.

title: Muslims Reclaim Old Homes
description: The streets of this Sarajevo suburb, which were the paths of bitter departure for Bosnian Serbs on Monday, were filled anew today with crowds of jubilant Muslims waving flags, hugging neighbors and chanting "Bosnia! Bosnia! Bosnia!" as they ripped down Serbian signs and emblems.

title: Vince Edwards, 67, the Doctor In the Hit TV Series 'Ben Casey'
description: Vince Edwards, who played a handsome, brooding neurosurgeon in the 1960's television series "Ben Casey," died on Monday at the University of California Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 67.

title: BASEBALL;Error-Prone Indians Compensate With Bats
description: The sun returned to spring training, Florida style, today, and Mike Hargrove, whose team lost two games to rain the previous day, was smiling again. "Everything's fine," the Cleveland manager said when asked about his camp, "except we're not catching the ball."

title: Du Pont Prosecutor Says He Won't Try For Death Penalty
description: Prosecutors said today that they would not pursue the death penalty in the murder case against John E. du Pont, who is accused of killing an Olympic wrestling champion in late January.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LYNNE MEADOW, the artistic director of the Manhattan Theater Club, and JOAN GANZ COONEY, a founder of the Children's Television Workshop, have both been showered with honors during their careers. But they never expected the awards bestowed on them yesterday.

title: Journal;Beyond the Birdcage
description: Who would have guessed that we live in a country where Robin Williams and Nathan Lane are a sexier box-office pair than Robert Redford and Michelle Pfeiffer? Not me or anyone in Hollywood. But that's a fact: "The Birdcage," a comedy celebrating a gay couple's 20-year bond, sold $18 million worth of tickets last weekend while "Up Close & Personal," which it knocked out of the No. 1 slot, had opened to a mere $11 million.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices in Sharp Decline As Fungus Disrupts Export Sales
description: Wheat prices plunged yesterday, after a rare fungus discovered in Arizona crops forced the Government to halt exports last week to 21 countries, some of them large wheat importers.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets End Another Game in Ice
description: Even on a night when Shawn Bradley rejected almost everything remotely in his vicinity, on an evening when Jayson Williams said he thought Charles Barkley was on cruise control, the Nets ran headlong into a familiar nemesis: themselves.

title: China Signaling U.S. That It Will Not Invade Taiwan
description: As the Chinese military began live ammunition exercises off Taiwan on Tuesday, mainland Chinese officials were sending unambiguous signals to the United States that China does not intend to invade or attack Taiwan, Chinese and Western officials say.

title: At the Nation's Table: Chicago;A Chef Returns And Lightens Up
description: Being a hands-on chef is a back-breaking, physically demanding job. So when Gabino Sotelino, 55, the chef and partner in Chicago's elegant Ambria restaurant, stepped out of the kitchen and into the front office five years ago, nobody was surprised. But he's back in the kitchen now, and he is definitely raising some eyebrows.

title: Protesters Fight a Plan For Washington's Home
description: If George Washington really cut down that cherry tree, this is where it happened, on the back edge of Ferry Farm, his boyhood home. It is also where he tossed a dollar across the Rappahannock River, or maybe it was a stone or maybe that never really happened, either.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: How Patronage Grew At Board of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Serb Leader Expected to Turn Over Key War Crimes Suspects
description: Senior American officials said today that they expected President Slobodan Milosevic to allow two Bosnian Serb soldiers to be transferred to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague soon, thus handing the prosecutors their potentially most explosive witnesses so far.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Rowland Threatens Layoffs of Court Workers
description: Once again playing hardball with state employees, Gov. John G. Rowland showed today what can happen to state workers who win raises that he opposes: they can lose their jobs.

title: Microsoft Gives Demonstrations of Its New Technologies
description: The Microsoft Corporation gave a series of technology demonstrations today that disclosed new details of how the company intends to leverage its dominance of personal computing software into a dominant role in the Internet market.

title: Mount Sinai Rejects Plan To Run Public Hospitals
description: In a surprising setback to the city's efforts to dismantle its public hospital system, Mount Sinai Medical Center has withdrawn from the bidding to take over Elmhurst Hospital Center and Queens Hospital Center, two of the three hospitals that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had offered for long-term lease.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cordiant Posts Loss for 1995
description: Cordiant P.L.C., which owns agencies including Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising and Bates Worldwide, said yesterday that it had lost $53.5 million in 1995, compared with a profit of $21 million in 1994, because of the turmoil related to the departure of former top executives and accounts as well as one-time charges.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: Advertising New York, the annual benefit event sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York, Advertising Women in New York and the American Advertising Federation, will for the first time present three "Best Corporate Citizens" awards. The 1996 event is scheduled for June 19 in Rockefeller Center. Girls Inc., New York, an education and advocacy organization, named Nike Inc., Beaverton, Ore., to receive a corporate image award for a campaign about young female athletes carrying the theme "If you let me play," which was created by Wieden & Kennedy, Portland, Ore.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Survival Odds 'Slim,' Fokker's Chairman Says
description: Ben van Schaik, chairman of Fokker N.V., said yesterday that chances for the plane maker's survival had become "extremely slim" because foreign suitors and Dutch banks and pension funds were not likely to help out. If no rescue plan can be worked out by Friday, then Fokker's major divisions will be declared bankrupt.

title: Forstmann Builds Buyout War Chest
description: Forstmann Little & Company, a private investment firm, said yesterday that it had raised $2.3 billion to create its largest buyout fund to date.

title: Sports of The Times;A Case For Fill-In Coaches
description: THE Knicks were in the soup, and management, part way through the season, decided to change coaches. After all, a number of players were disgruntled, and a few more were gruntled. Several preferred choices for coach weren't available at this time, so the Knicks reluctantly dipped into their own organization for what they termed an interim coach.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Hindemith as Firebrand And Wit of the Viola
description: An event called the International Hindemith Viola Festival may not exactly sound like a crowd-pleaser. But the idea behind it was intriguing and the last of the four festival concerts at the Miller Theater at Columbia University on Sunday afternoon attracted a large and enthusiastic audience.

title: SWIMMING;Swimmer, 28, Finds Niche In New Guard
description: Angel Martino grimaced when she learned that her age equaled the combined ages of the breast-stroke phenoms, Amanda Beard and Jilen Siroky, a pair of grizzled 14-year-olds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two tenors and a pop diva -- PLACIDO DOMINGO, JOSE CARRERAS and DIANA ROSS -- will help celebrate the 1,100th anniversary of the founding of Hungary by Arpad, a Magyar chieftain.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: KNICKS NOTEBOOK;Team Downsizing: Waive One, Sign One
description: Corporate downsizing being what it is, the Knicks gave the rotund center Victor Alexander the buyout package today while signing the journeyman forward Ronnie Grandison to a 10-day contract.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices In Retreat Once Again
description: Treasury prices ended lower yesterday as expectations that the Federal Reserve would not soon lower short-term interest rates continued to dog the market.

title: Settlement Reached in Police Shooting Suit
description: The family of a 16-year-old youth who was shot in the head and killed last March by a New York City police officer in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, has settled a Federal civil suit with the city for $400,000 but is still calling on the United States Attorney to file criminal charges against the officer.

title: The Wrong Answer to Terrorism
description: With the first anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing approaching next month, Congress and the White House are pressing to complete action on new antiterrorism legislation. In haste to demonstrate their resolve in an election year, President Clinton and lawmakers from both parties are ready to approve steps that would dangerously erode American liberties. Combating terrorism is vitally important, but it should not threaten long-established rights of privacy, free speech and due process.

title: Quaker Oats Wants to Shed 2 Frozen Food Lines
description: Abandoning more than a decade of modest effort to become a player in frozen foods, the Quaker Oats Company announced today that it was putting its Aunt Jemima frozen breakfast products and Celeste frozen pizza lines up for sale.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Virtuosic Mix of Refinement And Bursts of Anxiety Juliette Kang, violinist Carnegie Hall

title: POLITICS: THE ECONOMY;Buchanan, in Midwest, Vows to Protect American Markets
description: Patrick J. Buchanan said today that as President he would use tax and tariff policies to return "virtually the entire" United States steel market to domestic companies.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AN exchange between mother and daughter, heard while waiting for a bus outside the Morris Brothers store, Broadway and 84th Street.

title: Rwanda Seeks Ex-Officer From Cameroon
description: Rwanda asked Cameroon today to extradite a former Rwandan army colonel accused of helping plan the 1994 killings of at least half a million people.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Lamb With a Grand Salad on the Side
description: The leanest cut of lamb is from the leg. If your butcher won't give you a half pound of boneless lamb, buy the whole leg, boned, and freeze the rest in portions suitable for your family.

title: A Korean Family's Dream, A Community's Struggle
description: WHILE their high school friends spent most Saturdays and summer vacations lolling in bed, playing basketball or going to movies, Veronica Jung, now 21, and her sister Rose, 19, worked.

title: New Terrorism Bill Protects Civil Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Fashion;A Thundering Start for Paris Shows
description: Anyone looking for a signal that fall 1996 will be a strong Paris season had one every second with the thundering tribal beat at the show of Dirk Bikkembergs here on Monday night. With a thumping bass so loud and powerful it reset the heartbeat, the show began a round of collections that will last nine days, with 82 houses on the official schedule.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bayer Net Up 20%
description: The German drug and chemical maker Bayer A.G. reported yesterday that its profits rose 20 percent in 1995 and said it would increase its dividend 15 percent. The company said it had net income of 2.42 billion marks ($1.6 billion) for 1995, up from 2.01 billion marks in 1994. Sales rose 2.7 percent, to 44.6 billion marks ($29.58 billion) from 43.4 billion marks. Bayer said it would increase its annual dividend to 15 marks (9.9 cents) from 13 marks. (AP)

title: Gun Is Tied to 2 Killings
description: The gun used to kill the owner of the Second Avenue Deli in Manhattan last week was the same one used to kill the night manager of a Westchester County motel last fall, the police said yesterday.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Of Nixon and Kissinger: What Might Have Been
description: There's a briefly introspective moment in Russell Lees's entertaining "Nixon's Nixon," when Richard M. Nixon (Gerry Bammon) and Henry A. Kissinger (Steve Mellor) consider how far they've come from their humble origins. It's late on the night of Aug. 7, 1974. The place is the Lincoln Sitting Room in the White House and both men have had a lot to drink. Facing impeachment, the President of the United States is being urged by his Secretary of State to bite the bullet and resign. Nixon refuses to make a decision. Kissinger is worried about his own future.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Kentucky Won't Waltz to That National Title
description: Maybe the Kentucky Wildcats will be able to stand on a victory platform at the Meadowlands on the night of April 1, embrace each other and scream "I told you so" to all of us. Maybe their talent and style is capable of gaining the six most difficult victories in any college basketball player's life, the ones necessary to add a national championship banner to the top of Rupp Arena. Maybe the highly scrutinized shortcomings of the Wildcats are just that -- overemphasized imperfections that will ultimately make no difference.

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;DOLE CAPTURES ALL 7 STATES IN BIGGEST DAY OF PRIMARIES; GRIP ON NOMINATION IS SOLID
description: Senator Bob Dole overwhelmingly won primaries in seven states on Tuesday, including delegate-rich Florida and Texas, in a daunting display that virtually assured that he would be the Republican Presidential nominee.

title: POLITICS: THE FRONT-RUNNER;Dole, Dominant in Primaries, Faces New Battles in Capitol
description: Barring some completely unforeseen development, Senator Bob Dole, the Republican front-runner, faces a pair of prospects no one has ever faced before.

title: FILM REVIEW;ABC's of Self-Negation for Butlers
description: Since most movies portray people struggling to get ahead, it takes a certain kind of nerve to make a film about a man who attends a special school to study self-negation.

title: Opening Arguments End in Trial of Clinton Associates in Arkansas
description: Testimony began today in the trial of three former associates of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, the first jury trial to result from a two-year investigation of a real estate project that has touched on their personal and political finances in the 1980's.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRACOR TO ACQUIRE WESTMARK'S ASSETS IN STOCK DEAL
description: Tracor Inc., a maker of military electronic systems in Austin, Tex., agreed yesterday to acquire all of Westmark Systems Inc.'s assets for about 7.95 million Tracor shares. Assets of Westmark, a closely held company in Dallas, consist primarily of Tracor stock and warrants and some real estate. James B. Skaggs, Tracor's president, said the agreement allowed the company to simplify its capital structure and broaden ownership of its shares. The transaction value of about $126 million is based on a valuation of Tracor's stock at $15.80 a share, the company said. Tracor's shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $15, in Nasdaq trading. Upon closing of the deal, Westmark will liquidate by distributing the Tracor shares to its 29 shareholders.

title: Bosnia War Tribunal Isn't Out of Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking to Fix Damaged Image, Apple Hires Burson-Marsteller
description: Apple Computer Inc., still recovering from its public relations debacle during merger talks with Sun Microsystems Inc. and the ouster of its chief executive, said today that it had retained Burson-Marsteller to manage its worldwide public relations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Iranian elections misidentified a holiday to be celebrated there on March 20. It is the Persian new year, not the Islamic new year.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L. Won't Use Replay in 1996
description: Instant re play used from the 1986 through the 1991 seasons and creating as many problems as it did solutions -- is not likely to return for the 1996 National Football League season, but may be used on an experimental basis this fall, Paul Tagliabue, the league's commissioner, said at the league owners meeting here today.

title: Cardinal Scherer, 93, Brazil Conservative
description: Alfredo Vicente Cardinal Scherer, one of the leaders of the Roman Catholic Church's conservative wing in the 1960's and 70's, died on Saturday in the southern Brazilian city of Porto Alegre. He was 93.

title: Man Is Killed in Traffic Dispute
description: A Manhattan traffic dispute ended violently yesterday morning when one driver shot and killed a passenger in another vehicle on Lafayette Street in Greenwich Village as dozens of startled pedestrians and motorists ducked for cover, the police said.

title: 75% of G.M. Plants Are Idle As Strike Enters a 2d Week
description: A week-old strike at critical parts-making factories has led to the closing of nearly three-quarters of General Motors' assembly plants in North America, with some 83,000 G.M. workers idled today.

title: Ads Herald Amnesty Plan To Pay Taxes
description: New Jersey begins a $4 million advertising campaign this week urging anyone who owes the state back taxes to pay now without any penalty during a tax amnesty program that starts Friday and runs through June 1.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Southern Miss Coach Quits
description: The Southern Mississippi basketball coach, M. K. TURK, resigned yesterday after 20 seasons in which the Golden Eagles had 13 winning years and made 8 post-season appearances, winning the 1987 National Invitation Tournament.

title: POP REVIEW;An Underworld Fantasy Of Dark Sexual Themes
description: On his new album, "Shag Tobacco" (Island), the Irish singer Gavin Friday conjures up an underworld populated by transvestites, transsexuals, minors, prostitutes and one married couple. It is a place where sex is always dirty.

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Pitching Masters the Braves Again
description: Sure, it's only the exhibition season, but if spring training is a yardstick for the regular season, then the Mets are miles ahead of the defending World Series champions. For the second time in five days, the Mets shut out the Atlanta Braves and Greg Maddux, posting a 6-0 victory today before 4,556 fans at Thomas J. White Stadium.

title: TV NOTES;Letterman Makes a Choice
description: Staff members from "Late Show With David Letterman" were still in shock this week over Mr. Letterman's abrupt decision on Friday night to replace Robert Morton, the executive producer of the show since it started on CBS. Several staff members, who spoke only after being promised anonymity, said that Mr. Morton's contributions, which ranged from his access to stars and agents to his handling of the press, were never fully appreciated by Mr. Letterman.

title: Our Towns;When Politics Mars the Calm Of Suburbia
description: POLITICS is never gentle, not even in the seemingly tranquil, ever-so-polite suburbs. What has happened recently in this Westchester County community shows how brutal suburban politics can get.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Player Agents Sued by N.B.A.
description: The National Basketball Association took legal action yesterday against several player agents and lawyers, accusing them of trying to interfere with the new collective bargaining agreement.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Trade Deficit Fell in Late '95
description: The deficit in the nation's broadest measure of trade fell sharply in the fourth quarter of 1995 but was still the second highest on record for the full year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Virus or Bacteria? How You Can Tell
description: You most likely have a viral infection against which antibiotics are ineffective if you experience any or all the following symptoms for less than one week: tickly or scratchy throat, runny nose, sneezing, watery eyes, minor headache, minor aches and pains, tiredness or early fatigue.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the relationship between Saab Automobile A.B. and the General Motors Corporation misidentified a car. It was a Chevrolet Lumina, not a Chevrolet Corsica.

title: California To Get More In Quake Aid
description: More than two years after the Northridge earthquake jolted Southern California, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would pay $932 million to Los Angeles County to help rebuild or replace four local hospitals.

title: At the Nation's Table: Denver;A Streetcar Barn Turned Wine Bar
description: When Coors Field opened last year in Denver's popular lower downtown historical district, microbreweries popped up on every corner. But two 20-somethings saw a void in all the foam and decided to open a wine bar, Enoteca LoDo.

title: Mexican State Governor Tied to a Massacre of Peasants Quits
description: The powerful Governor of the state of Guerrero, Ruben Figueroa Alcocer, resigned today, bowing to pressures arising from the police massacre of 17 opposition peasants on a remote country road in the state last year.

title: BOXING;Team Tyson: It's Low Profile to No Profile
description: Mike Tyson's secret world continued today behind closed doors.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CONSECO TO BUY A COLORADO LIFE INSURER FOR STOCK
description: Conseco Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Life Partners Group Inc. for $600 million in stock. Conseco, an insurance holding company in Carmel, Ind., said it would pay $21 a share in stock for Life Partners, a life insurer in Englewood, Colo. The shares of Life Partners rose $4.25 yesterday, to $20, on the New York Stock Exchange; the shares of Conseco rose $3.125, to $66.125. Conseco will also assume $240 million of Life Partners' long-term debt. Stephen C. Hilbert, Conseco's chairman, also said the company was terminating Conseco Capital Partners II L.P., an acquisition partnership formed in 1993.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ON FIRST DAY, SHARES OF FORTE SOFTWARE SOAR 82%
description: The shares of Forte Software Inc., which sells software to manage financial transactions, closed 82 percent above the offering price on their first day of trading. Forte closed at $38.25 in Nasdaq trading of almost 3.3 million shares. Forte sold 2.1 million shares at $21 to raise $44 million. Forte's software enables companies to develop application software to manage financial transactions on client-server computer networks. Customers include British Telecommunications P.L.C., Eli Lilly & Company and the World Bank.

title: 1 in 8 Queens Students Attends Fewer Class Hours Than Required, aReport Finds
description: Because of overcrowding, nearly one in every eight public high school students in Queens -- 8,001 of 66,968 -- attends class for fewer hours daily than the minimum required by law, according to a report released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Rex Lee, Former Solicitor General, Dies at 61
description: Rex E. Lee, a staunchly independent conservative legal scholar who was Solicitor General in the first four years of the Reagan Administration and later became president of Brigham Young University, died on Monday at Utah Valley Hospital in Provo, his hometown. He was 61 and had been fighting various forms of cancer for 10 years.

title: A Familiar Name Above the Title
description: David Merrick, the old master of Broadway, sat in a wheelchair, his gloved hands resting on his cane. Disabled by a stroke that has robbed him of intelligible speech, he turned to his associate Natalie Lloyd and in a low mumble tried to tell her something that he wanted conveyed to the others in the room.

title: Bombings Set Nerves Of Israelis On Edge
description: About 9:45 this morning, a boom echoed across Jerusalem, jangling the nerves of residents shaken by two suicide bombings on consecutive Sundays in the past month.

title: Evarts A. Graham Journalist, 75
description: Evarts A. Graham, a former managing editor of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, died last Thursday at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis. He was 75 and lived in St. Louis.

title: TENNIS;Capriati Not Quite Ready Yet For Rubin
description: Jennifer Capriati, that famous face from the past, had her latest comeback bid ended tonight by a player who has come into her prime in the present.

title: Democrats Win A Skirmish On Whitewater
description: Senate Republicans tried and failed today to break a filibuster that Democrats have been staging to prevent a vote to extend the life of the special Whitewater committee.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: JAZZ
description: New Band's Driving Bass Heads for the Dance Floor Jimmy Bosch, trombonist S.O.B.'s

title: Travelers Chief Gets 44% Raise
description: Travelers Group Inc. paid its chairman and chief executive, Sanford I. Weill, $7.8 million in salary, bonus and restricted stock last year, a 44 percent jump from the previous year, according to Travelers' preliminary proxy statement, filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Bosnia War Tribunal Isn't Out of Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Kimana Tikondo Group Ranch Journal;Warily, the Masai Embrace the Animal Kingdom
description: There is no love lost between Marika Lonkoijoo, a 24-year-old Masai, and the elephants who ramble at night through his farm on the dusty range beneath Mount Kilimanjaro and feast on his tomatoes, onions and corn.

title: Vietnam Veterans Aren't Typically Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Trade Deficit Narrows 29% in Year
description: Germany's current account deficit narrowed 29 percent last year, to 24.8 billion marks ($16.73 billion), the Federal Statistics Office said yesterday. The current account is the broadest measure of trade, including services and some capital flows. The deficit was down from 34.7 billion marks the year before.

title: Wine Talk
description: EVERY year around this time, a consumer magazine called Wine and Spirits surveys restaurants to find out what is selling, and the findings have much to say about what's happening to wine in America.

title: TV NOTES;Yet Another 'Incident'
description: The clout of Steven Spielberg was made evident again this week when ABC decided at the last minute to "double pump" an episode of his series "High Incident" on Monday and Tuesday nights.

title: Gasoline Price Jumps
description: The average price of a gallon of gasoline jumped 2 cents nationwide in the last two weeks. The average pump price, including all grades and taxes, was 121.09 cents on Friday, according to the Lundberg Survey of 10,000 gas stations across the country. That was up 1.96 cents from the survey on Feb. 23.

title: Key Semiconductor Index Falls for 2d Month
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator fell for a second month in February, a trade organization reported late today.

title: Japan Votes for Clinton
description: When forecasting the Presidential election, the punditocracy endlessly debates Bob Dole's electability, the Buchanan insurrection and Bill Clinton's resurrection from political death. But the commentators have ignored an enormously important factor: Japan.

title: COMPANY REPORTS: Market Place;Ann Taylor Stores shows that robust sales can hurt profit margins.
description: WHETHER a retailer sells brooms or bras, it is dangerous to try to sell too many of them. Just ask Ann Taylor Stores.

title: Broken Rail Tied to Wreck
description: A break in the track may have caused the freight train derailment that set off a huge propane fire here, Ed Burkhardt, president of the Wisconsin Central Transportation Corporation, told The Oshkosh Northwestern on Monday.

title: In U.S.-China Tension, a Mutual Blindness
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Where Trauma Reigns and Speed Saves
description: When it comes to television programs about hospital emergency rooms these days, you can't always tell whether art is imitating life or the other way round. Using the tricks of the camera and editing room to heighten the excitement, "Trauma: Life and Death in the E.R." charts the highs and lows of a Saturday night in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. It's a frenetic hour of gunshot wounds, knife gashes and injuries from accidents on the street and in the bathtub.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;1,200 'Final Four' Volunteers
description: About 1,200 people have volunteered to help the Sports and Exposition Authority host the Final Four National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball games at the Meadowlands.

title: Meat Dishes, and Many Others, Taste Better After Browning
description: ASK any chef why meat is seared at the beginning of cooking and the reply will very likely be, "To seal in the juices." The ruder among them might add, "you idiot," because this is a culinary truism that has been repeated for hundreds of years.

title: INSIDE
description: A Stirring of Rebel Hearts

title: Factory Is Set to Process Dangerous Nuclear Waste
description: For the first time since the beginning of the atomic age, the United States has opened a factory to package the worst waste from nuclear weapons production in a form that is intended to be safe for the long term.

title: TV NOTES;Profitable Afternoons
description: Parents who allow afternoon television watching but do not allow "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers" or "The X-Men" usually have lively alternatives on public television. But this week and last, WNET/Channel 13 has left New York-area children bereft of their afternoon anti-superheroes, like Wishbone, the literary-minded dog; Carmen Sandiego, the globe-trotting sleuth, and Bill Nye, "the science guy."

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: A Host of Instant Changes In a Tale of Mutual Paranoia 'The Ends of the Earth' Theater Row Theater

title: MIDDLE EAST TALKS ARE EFFORT TO AID PERES AND ARAFAT
description: In one sense, the more than two dozen world leaders gathering at this Sinai resort on Wednesday to prop up the tottering Middle East peace effort will have succeeded just by showing up, according to some of the sponsors.

title: HOCKEY;Richter Set for Backup Duty
description: His timing is not quite all the way back, but his injured groin has withstood the demands of a full practice the last two days. So today, Mike Richter pronounced himself ready to return to the Ranger lineup in time for Wednesday night's game against the Florida Panthers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mayor, at Home, Lauds Israeli Resolve
description: Returning from a 35-hour trip to Israel yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani praised the fortitude of the Israeli people in the face of repeated terrorist bombings but stayed away from the most pressing issue raised by the attacks: whether the peace process would continue.

title: Pataki Aide Assails High Fees to Defend Poor in Death Cases
description: In a letter made public today, the Pataki administration denounced as exorbitant a proposed set of fees for court-appointed lawyers who represent defendants in death penalty cases, provoking a sharp debate over how much the state should pay to insure adequate defense of poor people facing capital punishment.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Lott Calls It a Career
description: Defensive back RONNIE LOTT, who played with four Super Bowl teams while with the San Francisco 49ers, announced his retirement yesterday.

title: Stigma Curtails Single Motherhood in Japan
description: This was a grandchild that Mika's parents did not want.

title: BASEBALL;Rizzuto to Come Back to Broadcast Booth
description: In his farewell address last summer, Phil Rizzuto insisted he had called his last game. But fans, Mickey Mantle's sons, George Steinbrenner and WPIX-TV/Channel 11 persuaded Rizzuto to return this year for 31 of the station's 50 games.

title: Albany Agrees To New Power For Chancellor
description: Legislative leaders reached agreement yesterday on a bill that would strengthen the hand of the New York City Schools Chancellor at the expense of the community school boards as he tries to root out corruption.

title: Sovietologists, Years After the Collapse, Cope With a New Reality
description: With breathtaking suddenness in 1991, the cadre of academicians popularly known as Kremlinologists -- pampered and privileged by years of Federal, foundation and academic patronage -- found themselves outmoded.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Procter & Gamble Reassigns Clearasil
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had shifted responsibilities for its Clearasil brand of acne medication and skincare products in North America and Europe to Tatham Euro RSCG in Chicago from D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $30 million.

title: Checkout Time for Balancing the Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Reversing Course, Judicial Panel Allows Television in Appeals Courts
description: Reopening a door they slammed shut only 18 months ago, the judges who make policy for the Federal courts voted today to let Federal appeals courts televise appellate arguments if they chose to do so.

title: Bosnia War Tribunal Isn't Out of Options
description: To the Editor:

title: King Wins Iditarod Race
description: Jeff King won his second Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race today, coasting into this historic Gold Rush community to the sounds of sirens and hundreds of cheering spectators.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Sort of Like Batman, With Uzis and Laptops
description: Using an elaborate decoy of a shootout and exploding cars, a special police squad using Uzis and laptop computers steals past elaborate building security and, while blowing up steel doors, begins wiping out the guards of a kingpin drug distributor. When the boss tries to escape, he takes a hostage. "I don't negotiate," snarls the leader of the police team, just before putting a bullet between the villain's eyes. And "Swift Justice" hasn't even got to its opening credits yet.

title: COMPANY NEWS;THOMAS P. POLLOCK, VICE CHAIRMAN AT MCA, RESIGNS
description: Thomas P. Pollock has resigned as vice chairman of MCA Inc., the company said yesterday. No reason was announced for the resignation. He was appointed vice chairman of MCA in July, after joining the company in September 1986 and serving as executive vice president of MCA and chairman of the motion picture group. He was also a member of the company's board. As chairman of the motion picture group, Mr. Pollock was credited with bringing creative talents to the studio. When the Seagram Company acquired 80 percent of MCA last year, Mr. Pollock became vice chairman, hoping to assume broader corporate responsibilities. But Edgar Bronfman Jr., chief executive of Seagram, has been assembling a new team, and Mr. Pollock chose to resign. He had been a partner in the law firm of Pollock Bloom & Dekom before joining MCA.

title: Review/Fashion;Now (Miyake) and Then (Dior)
description: Experienced designers should be the first to appreciate that nothing, least of all fashion, stays the same. Issey Miyake, in the collection he showed on Tuesday, faced down the fact that the fashion consumer is not the same person she was 27 years ago, when he started designing in Paris. By contrast, on the Dior runway it seemed as if time had stood still.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CONSOLIDATION AND 1,000 LAYOFFS BY ALLEGHENY POWER
description: Allegheny Power System Inc. said yesterday that it planned to dismiss 1,000 employees, or about 17 percent of its work force, to compete better in a deregulating electric power industry. The cuts will result in a pretax charge of $75 million to $100 million and will be carried out over the next two years. The power company has about 5,750 employees. New York-based Allegheny also said it would consolidate operating divisions at its three main subsidiaries, Monongahela Power, Potomac Edison and West Penn Power.

title: As American as Steak, Smoke and Lobbying
description: Hi," said Tom Smitherman, the manager of the Capital Grille, Washington's restaurant of the hour. "Welcome to decadence. Here, let me blow some cigar smoke in your face and pass you a martini." He was not kidding. The national reputation of this politically-incorrect-and-proud-of-it restaurant, whose rise has coincided with that of Newt Gingrich, has crowds beating down the doors.

title: When Lightning Struck in London And a Deluge of Asthma Followed
description: BOLTS of thunder and lightning struck. Wind gusts scattered grass pollen over a wide area. Many people immediately began wheezing and having difficulty breathing from asthmatic attacks. Emergency rooms were swamped with 10 times the usual number of asthmatics. For nearly half the victims, it was the first asthmatic attack in their lives. Thirty hours later, it had turned into the largest epidemic of asthma following a thunderstorm.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Report Faults Justice System
description: A severe breakdown in communication between the criminal justice and mental health systems enabled Conrad Jeffrey, a former mental patient, to win his freedom and murder a 7-year-old girl, according to a report commissioned by Robert N. Wilentz, Chief Justice of New Jersey, that was released yesterday.

title: Coca-Cola's Forecast Only Spurs Debate
description: The Coca-Cola Company served up business estimates and sales statistics today in an effort to woo 200 analysts who gathered at its headquarters here. But the company succeeded only in perpetuating a disagreement about the future appeal of its pricey shares.

title: The New Drug-Price Squeeze;H.M.O.'s Are Fighting Back in the Battle Over Costs
description: It took only a few weeks for Merck & Company, the nation's biggest drug maker, to note the damage after the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York told its 850,000 members that it would no longer pay for most of Merck's highly regarded but often expensive products.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Newark Permit Office Closed
description: The state Department of Community Affairs closed Newark's city permit office last week, saying the operation was in disarray. After Charles Bishop, a city engineer, was named provisional director yesterday, the department gave the city permission to resume issuing construction permits.

title: Corrections
description: A table with the Taking In the Sites column in Business Day on Monday about investment information on the World Wide Web misstated the electronic address for one finance-related offering, Research Magazine Online. It is: http://www.researchmag.com

title: Satellite Falls to Earth
description: A Chinese spy satellite falling from space disappeared harmlessly over the south Atlantic late Monday night.

title: Chemical Producers Weigh Ethylene Plant
description: The Eastman Chemical Company has joined the Lyondell Petrochemical Company, Union Carbide and the Quantum Chemical Company in studying whether to build an ethylene plant that could cost as much as $900 million.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia Chief Discards Plan for Revamping
description: The managing director of Alitalia S.p.A., Domenico Cempella, has scrapped his predecessor's reorganization plan for the unprofitable airline and says he will disclose his own plan in two months. "Alitalia lacks a restructuring plan that contains goals and methods that will guarantee growth and return to profitability," Mr. Cempella told unions Monday in his first meeting with them since his appointment Feb. 22.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Young Predators Caught in a Chaotic System
description: NO MATTER HOW LOUD I SHOUT A Year in the Life of Juvenile Court By Edward Humes 399 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HANSON UNIT AGREES TO A $1.59 BILLION SALE
description: Willamette Industries agreed yesterday to buy a sawmill and more than a million acres of timberland from a unit of Hanson P.L.C. for $1.59 billion. Willamette plans to sell nearly half the acreage for more than $600 million once the sale closes on May 15. Hanson, a British industrial conglomerate, recently announced plans to scale back its holdings. The assets involved in the transaction are the last of the sawmills and timberland owned by Hanson's Cavenham Forest Industries unit. Willamette, which is based in Portland, Ore., plans to sell 207,000 acres in Oregon and Washington to Crown Pacific Partners, also of Portland, for $205 million. Temple-Inland Inc., of Diboll, Tex., is set to acquire 230,000 acres in southwest Louisiana for $90 million. Willamette is also discussing the sale of another 104,000 acres in Oregon to the Hancock Timber Resource Group for $350 million.

title: James F. Nordstrom, 56; Led Clothing Retailer
description: James F. Nordstrom, a retired co-chairman of Nordstrom Inc. and a grandson of the department store company's founder, died on Tuesday at his home in Seattle. He was 56.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EATON BIDS FOR CAPCO AUTOMOTIVE AFTER TALKS STOP
description: The Eaton Corporation offered yesterday to acquire the Capco Automotive Products Corporation for $11 a share in cash, or a total of $121.7 million, after Eaton said merger talks between the two companies had broken down. Eaton also said it would nominate its own slate of candidates for election to Capco's board at that company's annual meeting on May 14. Eaton, which owns about 7.3 percent of Capco's stock, said that the companies had discussed a possible merger but that Capco's board had recently refused to continue the talks. Capco, based in South Bend, Ind., makes truck transmissions. Eaton, based in Cleveland, makes automotive equipment.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Lose Chambers But Gain Andreychuk
description: In a game marked by inspiring goaltending from both teams, the Devils and the Montreal Canadiens played to a 1-1 deadlock tonight at Continental Arena and revised a page from the New Jersey record book. It was the fifth consecutive overtime game for the defending Stanley Cup champions, matching a team record, and the tie extended their undefeated streak to nine games, which also tied a team record.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;DISNEY DROPS ANGEL PLANS
description: The Walt Disney Company abandoned plans yesterday to buy the California Angels after the company couldn't reach an agreement with Anaheim to renovate the team's ballpark.

title: Protect Judges From Politicians
description: We all know about places like China and Peru, where the courts are a Government-controlled sham. Americans justifiably feel that our legal system with its independent judiciary is superior. But recent events in New York show that not even our state's system is impervious to political pressure.

title: POLITICS: DEPARTURE;FORBES PLANNING ON DROPPING OUT OF THE CAMPAIGN
description: Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate who had challenged the Republican establishment on Capitol Hill with his call for a radical restructuring of the tax system, will drop out of the race for the Republican Presidential nomination today, his campaign manager said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIG SEVERANCE FOR FORMER BANKERS TRUST PRESIDENT
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation gave Eugene B. Shanks Jr. a lucrative severance package after he resigned as president in October, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Shanks had been considered the heir apparent to Charles S. Sanford Jr., the chairman and chief executive. But after lawsuits and losses stemming from the bank's sale of derivatives, the Bankers Trust board in October instead named Frank N. Newman, 53, a former top Treasury official, to succeed Mr. Sanford, who has stepped down as chief executive and plans to resign as chairman in April. In return for agreeing not to criticize the bank or lure away any of its employees for one year, Mr. Shanks will receive his full salary for a year and additional payments of more than $2 million. Mr. Shanks will also receive a bonus for 1995 comparable to the bonuses of other top managers. In addition, 31,000 shares of restricted stock, worth more than $2 million, will be vested with him immediately.

title: The Great Safire Disconnect
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Fascinating Fasciation

title: LIFE IN THE ROUGH: Rookies on the Golf Tour;Though a Star Is Born, Just Call Him Lumpy
description: A year ago this week, Tim Herron was just another baby face on the driving range on the Nike Tour, a struggling young player who was about to miss the cut in Monterrey, Mexico. He had four sponsors back home in Wayzata, Minn., a bank account that had very little margin for error and a big golf game that was better suited to the PGA Tour than the minor leagues.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Public-Relations Fee Income Rises
description: Fee income for the 50 largest public-relations agencies rose 12 percent in 1995 to nearly $1.3 billion, an annual survey shows.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: GPA Group in Move to Refinance Debt
description: GPA Group P.L.C., the Irish aircraft leasing company, announced yesterday that $4.05 billion of pass-through certificates had been sold in a major securitization and refinancing transaction to a syndicate of underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Edge Lower; 6.68% Yield
description: Treasury prices edged lower in nervous trading yesterday as market participants awaited reports on inflation due out today and tomorrow.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund misstated the source of one recent donation. The $51,000 contribution came from Evelyn Y. Davis and the Evelyn Y. Davis Foundation, not the estate of Evelyn Y. Davis.

title: Benefits Found In a New Drug To Fight Clots
description: Newly available blood-thinning medicines should allow many of the 400,000 Americans who suffer dangerous clots each year to be treated at home, rather than spend a week in the hospital, researchers say.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Taiwan Will Add To Stabilization Fund
description: Taiwan's Cabinet has tentatively lined up $150 billion (new Taiwan), or $5.4 billion (United States), to add to a stabilization fund to support stock prices if military tension with China persists after this month. The Cabinet persuaded a group of insurers, banks and other financial institutions last month to purchase up to $200 billion (new Taiwan) worth of shares if stocks fell amid rising military tension with China.

title: Girl Defying School Rule Against Backpacks Defends Her Position inCourt
description: Fourteen-year-old Elyse Meredith defended her defiance of her school's ban on backpacks today and argued that only those misusing them should be penalized.

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;C.E.O. Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke Power Sets Buyback
description: The Duke Power Company said this week that it planned to buy back up to $1 billion of its common stock in the next five years. Duke Power, a utility holding company in Charlotte, said it might buy back up to $200 million in 1996. Duke shares rose 75 cents today, to $48.50.

title: THE POP LIFE;Selling the Return of the Beatles, Part 2
description: Capitol Records put its Beatles marketing plan into full gear yesterday, with advertisements for "The Beatles Anthology, 2" on network television, movie screens, CNN programs shown in airports, video monitors in department stores, bus shelters and almost every other surface that is for lease.

title: Calendar: Chinese Artworks, Irish Heritage and Toy Trains
description: Chinese Arts Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street; (212) 879-5500.

title: SUMMIT IN EGYPT: THE PALESTINIANS;Israelis Ease Their Closing Of the West Bank and Gaza
description: Faced with a mounting outcry over the nine-day-old siege of Palestinian areas, Israel today allowed trucks to bring basic food into the Gaza Strip and reopened communication channels with Palestinian officials.

title: CLOSE TO HOME;A Poet's Tale: Other Houses, Other Lives
description: LIVING in other people's houses, with other people's things, has been the main domestic arrangement of my adulthood. It feels oddly natural, maybe because the first other-people's house any of us lodge in is that of our parents. We live with their taste before we know what taste is; we allow them to choose our clothes and dress us. Whatever they believe home is -- a faux Versailles, or a tumble-down trailer -- remains, for a while anyway, what we believe home should be.

title: Census Sees a Profound Ethnic Shift in U.S.
description: Fueled by immigration and higher birth rates among Hispanic women, the United States is undergoing a profound demographic shift, and by the middle of the next century only about half of the population will be non-Hispanic whites, the Census Bureau predicted today.

title: Denver Airport Completes Bond Auction
description: While it did not go exactly as planned, the Denver International Airport yesterday completed its Dutch auction -- a financing technique unusual in the municipal market that lowers the airport's borrowing costs.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;64 Teams Are Set to Begin The Great Endurance Test
description: When the games begin, 16 on Thursday and 16 on Friday, a simple factor will become more and more significant as the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament establishes a direction. One day short of five months since the start of practice, weary players will wonder and concerned coaches will worry -- how much gas is left in the tank?

title: CHRONICLE
description: By any measure, the soprano RENEE FLEMING has been having a banner season. She started last fall by singing Desdemona in Verdi's "Otello" on opening night at the Metropolitan Opera, then performed with one opera company after another here and in Europe. On March 1, she sang Donna Anna in "Don Giovanni" with Sir Georg Solti conducting at the reopening of the Palais Garnier in Paris following a $30 million renovation. In December, she signed an exclusive recording contract with the London/Decca label, the first American singer in 31 years to do so (Marilyn Horne was the last).

title: 16 Children Are Slain in Scotland As Gunman Storms Into a School
description: A man carrying four handguns stormed into a school here this morning and opened fire on a gym class filled with 5- and 6-year-olds, killing 16 children and a teacher, and reserving a final bullet to take his own life.

title: Avant-Gardist Comes Into Bloom
description: There are Octoberfest and wine tastings; the Cineplex and Sundance, flea markets and the Findlay galleries. There are the huge Paris shows, with catcalling photographers, pounding music and 1,200 people in the audience. And there is Rei Kawakubo's Comme des Garcons connoisseur show, staged on Tuesday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's warning that budget cutbacks could force teacher layoffs carried an incorrect byline. The article was written by Maria Newman, not Andy Newman.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Candidate for Congress
description: A fourth candidate has entered the race to fill Mr. Zimmer's seat. Mayor David Del Vecchio of Lambertville said yesterday that he would join a field that already includes Rush Holt of Hopewell, Carl Mayer of Princeton Township and Richard Walling of East Brunswick.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Enjoys A Splendid Spring Day
description: Watch Dwight Gooden unleash impressive fastballs that pop into the catcher's mitt. Watch Jimmy Key toss his splendid array of pitches that tantalize and fool hitters. Watch the starting rotation for the Yankees evolve. Watch Joe Torre chew on another pretzel and hope that his rotation remains crowded and remains a problem, an enviable problem.

title: Games Without Gloves Launching Tyson-Bruno
description: For 40 minutes, two seats at the head of the dais were empty. Neither Mike Tyson nor Frank Bruno wanted to be the first one to sit down. So hundreds of members of the international boxing media as well as a dozen fighters from Saturday night's undercard tried to keep busy.

title: Argentine Tax Chief Quits Amid Scandal
description: Hugo Gaggero, the head of Argentina's tax agency and an ally of Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo, resigned today.

title: Sweeping Changes Set for System of Meat and Poultry Inspection
description: The Department of Agriculture plans to announce sweeping changes in the way meat and poultry are inspected, but the new rules will not include mandatory testing by industry for the salmonella bacteria that kill more than 4,000 people a year and sicken as many as five million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;DuHaime Gains Endorsement
description: The dean of New Jersey's Congressional delegation, Marge Roukema, announced yesterday that she would endorse Richard A. DuHaime, a longtime ally, in his bid for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate. She said that her decision to support Mr. DuHaime, director of the Passaic County Freeholders, was not meant as a swipe at a fellow Congressman, Representative Richard A. Zimmer of Delaware Township.

title: BASKETBALL;A Puzzled Olajuwon Speaks Out on Citizenship
description: The National Basketball Association's most prominent Muslim player seemed puzzled yesterday by the stand taken by Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf regarding the conflict between religion and the national anthem.

title: TOBACCO'S BROKEN LINE: THE LAWYERS;The Scent of Legal Success May Only Increase Lawsuits
description: While the Liggett Group's proposed settlement would resolve some huge claims against the company, it would do nothing to resolve -- and might even provide new momentum for -- an onslaught of lawsuits against the tobacco industry.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A POISON PILL IS ADOPTED PRIOR TO A SPINOFF BY G.M.
description: Electronic Data Systems said yesterday that it had adopted a poison-pill takeover defense as the General Motors Corporation prepares to spin off the company. The strategy would make it prohibitively expensive for an unwanted suitor to buy E.D.S., as the company, which provides computer services, is known. E.D.S. said the plan was not adopted in response to any known takeover threat.

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Bats Continue Beating The Best
description: First Greg Maddux, now Hideo Nomo. If only it were September instead of March. Then the Mets could really make a big deal out of beating two of baseball's best pitchers on consecutive days.

title: Philadelphia Zoo Fire Is Tied to Heating Cable
description: The fire that left 23 primates dead of smoke inhalation at the Philadelphia Zoo last December was caused by an improperly installed heating cable in the roof of their quarters, not by questionable actions of guards that night, zoo officials said today.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Christ the King And Rice in Final
description: Christ the King (26-0), the defending champion, got 22 points from Lamar Odom and kept its undefeated season alive last night with a 68-46 victory over St. Francis Prep (20-8) in a Catholic High Schools Athletic Association semifinal at St. John's University in Queens.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY REPORTS;WOOLWORTH CORP. (Z,N)
description: The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it lost more than $100 million in its fiscal fourth quarter, mainly because of an accounting charge to write down the value of some assets.

title: A Lobbying Firm With D'Amato Ties
description: For a year now, Robert J. Malito has been considered the most sought-after lobbyist in the Capitol. And for months, legislators and colleagues who have admired or envied his prosperity have pointed to one reason: United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Stocks Mostly Higher Despite Drop in Dow
description: Although the Dow Jones industrial average eased yesterday, stock prices generally rose.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;A Piano Man of Influence
description: Few musicians in the history of jazz have radically changed its practice, its daily working vocabulary. The pianist McCoy Tyner, who is playing at the Blue Note through Sunday, conceived of a harmonic system as a member of the classic John Coltrane quartet that from its inception infiltrated virtually every corner of the modern jazz world. And his rhythmic sense, percussive and ponderous in the wrong hands, is a staple of improvisers 30 years later.

title: New York City Builds A Better Watchdog;Agency May Be a Model for Business
description: It is probably the last place on earth that blue-chip American corporations would turn for advice: a suite of second-floor offices in a low brick building near an elevated subway line in the South Bronx, the home of the inspector general of the New York City School Construction Authority.

title: School Parents Call Halt To Use of Book on AIDS
description: For four years, students taking health classes at Horace Greeley High School here have read Earvin (Magic) Johnson's 1992 book, "What You Can Do to Avoid AIDS," as part of the AIDS education curriculum.

title: Asia Looks to U.S. to Protect Trade Routes Around Taiwan
description: SINGAPORE  The newly growing U.S. naval presence in Asia is intended to demonstrate American determination to protect freedom of navigation as well as to discourage conflict between China and Taiwan.

title: Respectfully, 3 Composers Dare to Rewrite Ellington
description: If anything is sacrosanct in jazz, it is the work of Duke Ellington. His genius coincided with the rise and maturation of the recording industry, and he took full advantage of the possibilities of modern technology; his masterpieces are available for anybody who has a library card or a bit of spare cash for a CD. The works are fixed, and not just in the imagination.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOST CAPITAL CITIES SHAREHOLDERS PICK DISNEY STOCK
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that 82 percent of Capital Cities/ABC Inc.'s stockholders had chosen an all-stock payment in the recently completed merger between the two companies. Owners of 126.8 million of the 154.6 million shares of Capital Cities elected to receive their entire payments in Disney shares. But the number of Disney shares offered in the merger is limited, so those requesting all Disney stock will get a little more than one Disney share and $62 in cash in exchange for each share of Capital Cities that they owned. Holders of about 14 percent of the shares chose to get one Disney share plus $65 cash for each share. The other 4 percent of shareholders will receive $127 cash for each share.

title: The Great Safire Disconnect
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Film Series, l'Amour and Other Essentials
description: A beautiful teen-ager chatters with her girlfriend about Julia Roberts's salary and a sex survey in a magazine. She likes going to discos to meet rich men, who often boast about the brand names of things they own. She adores such talk but she herself lives more frugally, sharing an apartment with two young men, one of whom dreams of making big money selling blue jeans. The two young men like violent movies and game shows. They are often too busy watching television to notice their gorgeous roommate when she takes off her clothes.

title: A Bus Joke That Fell Flat
description: Bus service in New York City may be a joke, but someone doesn't think the joke is funny.

title: POLITICS: TEXAS;Teacher Stuns Democrats in a Senate Primary
description: A 46-year-old high school teacher who campaigned by crisscrossing Texas in his pickup truck captured first place on Tuesday in the Democratic primary for the Senate seat held by Phil Gramm.

title: TOBACCO'S BROKEN RANKS: THE OVERVIEW;Industry Split By Major Deal In Tobacco Suit
description: One of the nation's major tobacco companies broke ranks yesterday and agreed to settle a huge class-action lawsuit, exposing cracks in the powerful industry alliance that has battled antismoking cases for decades.

title: Liberties;Up Close and Personal
description: The Clintons are right, after all.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Afraid of Sharks, Rifles And the Passing of Time
description: DANCING AFTER HOURS By Andre Dubus 233 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hoesch-Krupp Has Big Earnings Jump
description: The German steel and engineering company Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp said yesterday that its earnings for 1995 jumped more than twelvefold, to 505 million marks ($340 million), from 40 million marks a year earlier. The company said it would pay a dividend of 5 marks ($3.36) a share, the first time since the company was formed in 1992 that it will pay a dividend.

title: Currents;Wallpaper to Wake Up a Room
description: FOR maximalists, there are two extravagantly designed wallpapers that offer enough lushness and ornament to make a plain room fancy.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reed Elsevier's Profit Surged 19% Last Year
