description: Reed Elsevier N.V.'s shift from print to electronic media helped to fuel a 19 percent profit gain last year, and the company says it wants to back that strategy with more than $1 billion in additional acquisitions.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : A 5-Year Test for Alcoholics
description: Recovering from alcoholism is similar to recovering from cancer: The subject must be symptom-free for five years to be out of danger of relapse, according to a study by George E. Vaillant of Harvard Medical School and Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Panel Weighs Genetics Bill
description: The State Senate Health Committee will take up a bill today that would prohibit health insurance companies from using information gathered from genetic tests as a basis for denying health insurance coverage.

title: Fed's Survey Finds Growth Is Moderate
description: The nation's economy grew modestly in the first two months of the year, with wages firmly in check despite an apparent spreading of labor-market tightness, a Federal Reserve survey found today.

title: Currents;A House on the Move
description: STEVEN MALLORY, a senior at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., not only studies architectural preservation, but also practices it -- on an 18th-century farmhouse that he bought for $3,000, dismantled, and plans to reassemble this spring on family property in Arlington, Vt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A familiar approach as Calvin Klein says that he, too, makes khakis.
description: CALVIN knows jeans. Calvin knows scents. Calvin knows underwear. But does Calvin know khakis?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Brain-Dead Baby's Heart Stops Despite Ventilator
description: Mariah Scoon, the brain-dead infant whose parents fought to keep her on a mechanical ventilator although she was pronounced legally dead last month, was disconnected from the machine yesterday after her heart stopped beating despite the artificial support.

title: Medaphis Plans Purchase
description: The Medaphis Corporation agreed today to acquire Rapid Systems Solutions Inc. for stock valued at about $42.6 million. The Atlanta-based Medaphis, which provides billing and accounts-receivable services to hospitals, said it would acquire Rapid Systems' capital stock in exchange for 1.14 million Medaphis shares. Rapid Systems, which is based in Columbia, Md., is a privately held computer-network concern. Last year Rapid Systems had revenue of $14.7 million, while Medaphis had revenue of $468 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Plans for 2d New Casino Hotel
description: Mirage Resorts of Las Vegas, which hopes to open a 2,000-room casino hotel in Atlantic City, is also seeking partners to develop a smaller casino hotel across the street, a spokesman said yesterday. Several companies have expressed interest in building the 1,000-room hotel, which would be located on a 14-acre marina district parcel that Mirage has owned since the early 1980's, said Alan Feldman, the Mirage spokesman. TERRY PRISTIN

title: THEATER REVIEW;Monologues of a One-Man Wedding Party
description: One of the six characters portrayed in "Brine County Wedding," a stupefying exercise in tedium, is a waiter at a restaurant called the Turkey Tepee. And that just about describes the whole show.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SEARS APPROVES BUYBACK OF UP TO 10 MILLION SHARES
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that its board had approved the repurchase of up to 10 million shares over the next two years. The shares are to be used for the company's stock-based incentive plans for employees, Sears said. As of yesterday, Sears, the retailer based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., had 392 million common shares outstanding.

title: Milken Inquiry By the S.E.C. Is Looking Into Hasbro Stake
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a substantial investment that Michael R. Milken, the former junk-bond king, and Lawrence J. Ellison, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Oracle Corporation, made in Hasbro Inc., the toy company, according to a Government official and associates of Mr. Milken.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Patriots Acquire Jefferson and Clay
description: The New England Patriots have made their first big moves of the off season, signing the free agents SHAWN JEFFERSON and WILLIE CLAY. Jefferson, 27, a speedy receiver who played for the San Diego Chargers, and Clay, 25, a safety from the Detroit Lions, agreed to terms on Tuesday.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Gasoline Move Higher On Report of Falling Inventories
description: Gasoline prices rose sharply yesterday after a report showed an unexpected drop in United States stockpiles.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GETTY PLANS TO SPIN OFF MARKETING OPERATIONS
description: The Getty Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it planned to spin off its petroleum marketing business. Getty, which is based in Jericho, L.I., said it had not determined the ratio at which it would distribute stock of the new company, to be named Getty Petroleum Marketing Inc., to shareholders. After the spinoff, Getty Petroleum will change its name to the Getty Realty Corporation. It will keep the company's real estate holdings, including service stations and supply terminals, and lease most of them back to the new company. Getty Petroleum expects shares of the new company to trade on the New York Stock Exchange, where Getty's shares rose $1.25, to $15, yesterday. Getty Realty will also retain a heating-oil business in central Pennsylvania and Maryland. Getty Petroleum Marketing will have the company's marketing operations and inventory and supply contracts.

title: A New Compuserve Service Plans to Appeal to Families
description: Compuserve Inc. disclosed plans yesterday for a proprietary service aimed at families and novice computer users.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BUFFETT GETS PERMISSION TO INCREASE HOLDINGS
description: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett has received permission to increase his holdings in the American Express Company to 17 percent, according to the company's proxy statement. Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Mr. Buffett's company, now owns a 10.2 percent stake, already the largest holding in American Express, the financial-services giant.

title: Is Pippin a Breakthrough or Outmoded on Arrival?
description: It seems a potent combination: Apple Computer Inc. and Bandai Company Ltd. developing a simplified home computer to combine the American company's innovative Macintosh technology with the Japanese toy maker's knack for fun. The Power PC meets the Power Rangers.

title: Seoul Frees Labor Unionist
description: South Korea has released on bail a labor union leader adopted as a "prisoner of conscience" by Amnesty International, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today. The union leader, Kwon Young-kil, head of the Korea Confederation of Trade Unions, was arrested in November.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swiss Bank Registers 30% Profit Increase
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation announced yesterday that it registered a 30 percent rise in net profit for 1995, helped by greater-than-expected cost savings from its acquisition of the British merchant bank S. G. Warburg. Swiss Bank said it had earned 1.053 billion Swiss francs ($875 million), up from 811 million Swiss francs a year earlier. The increase was in line with forecasts. It represented a reversal from 1994, when profit slid 41 percent.

title: The Met Plans Five New Productions for Its 1996-97 Season
description: The Metropolitan Opera is to present five new productions during its 1996-97 season, including its first staging of Benjamin Britten's "Midsummer Night's Dream." Also among the new offerings is Giordano's "Fedora," a work last seen at the Met in 1926, and Berg's "Wozzeck," which has had only one previous Met production. New stagings of Bizet's "Carmen" and Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin" round out the additions to the repertory.

title: Venture Plans Sega Arcades
description: The Japanese video-game giant Sega Enterprises, Dreamworks SKG and the MCA Inc. unit of the Seagram Company said today that they would form a joint venture to open more than 100 entertainment centers in the next four years. Financial details were not disclosed.

title: HORSE RACING;Florida Derby Is Looking For a Superstar to Emerge
description: Mike Smith, shooting for his third straight victory in the Florida Derby, this time aboard Unbridled's Song, puzzled over the list of nine colts entered in Saturday's race and their impact on the Kentucky Derby seven weeks later, and said, "Everybody's looking for a superstar."

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Lieutenant Governor Loses Her Police Escort
description: The rift between Gov. George E. Pataki and Lieut. Gov. Elizabeth McCaughey Ross widened this week when the chief of the Governor's security detail took away her state trooper escort after receiving complaints that she had used the troopers to chauffeur her on personal errands.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: POLITICS: LOOKING FORWARD;With Dole Cashing In, Both Sides Say All Bets Are Off for Fall
description: Senator Bob Dole's emergence as the likely Republican nominee has led both parties to re-evaluate just how much of an advantage, if any, President Clinton would have over him in November.

title: Jupp Calls for a Large European Army Capable of Acting Without U.S.
description: PARIS  Prime Minister Alain Juppe called Wednesday for the creation of a European army of up to 350,000 men capable of acting independently of Washington in a crisis but integrated within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Liggett Breaks Ranks, Settling Tobacco Suit The Liggett Group, the smallest of the nation's five major cigarette companies, broke industry ranks, agreeing to settle a huge class-action lawsuit. Lawyers representing millions of smokers agreed to drop the company from the suit in return for payments to a national quit-smoking campaign and Liggett's promise to withdraw from the fight against new tobacco regulations from the F.D.A.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Police Chief Fights for Gun
description: William R. Celester, the Newark Police Director placed on administrative leave in November after Federal agents raided his home and office, is fighting to keep his gun permit, his lawyer said yesterday. But the Essex County Prosecutor's office will go to court to force Mr. Celester to surrender the permit if he does not do so voluntarily, said an office spokesman.

title: TOBACCO'S BROKEN LINE: THE STRATEGIST;Tobacco Industry Split Might Benefit Financier
description: Bennett S. LeBow, a one-time computer scientist, has a reputation for clever financial dealings that sometimes raise eyebrows on Wall Street. But his deals have never seemed very important to the broader public.

title: ON BASKETBALL;A Kid Named Jones Gets to Live the Dream
description: Dontae Jones was hard pressed to hide the sound of wonder in his voice as he spoke by telephone from Starkville, Miss., on Monday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Council Members Face Fines
description: If the City Council does not adopt a budget by Tuesday, the State Department of Community Affairs will fine members personally $25 a day, Deborah DeSantis, deputy commissioner of the department, said yesterday.

title: POLITICS: THE DEBT;Gingrich and Dole Softening Their Line on Borrowing Limit
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole today softened the Republicans' hard line on legislation to extend the Government's borrowing authority, turning to a plan that both party conservatives and President Clinton would be most likely to accept.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Schroders Profit Flat
description: Schroders P.L.C., Britain's largest independent securities firm, said yesterday that its pretax profit was little changed in 1995 for a third year as gains from managing funds offset a decline in investment banking profit. Schroders said pretax profit was L197 million ($299.4 million), compared with L195.4 million in 1994. Analysts said the earnings were in line with their expectations, although they said they were concerned about the lack of growth in the investment banking business. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: About New York;Squeezed Out, But Resolved To Hang On
description: GUS EPPINGA and Jim Davis live at the Gramercy Hotel, which is not the kind of place where you find mints on the pillows at night. Lately it's where they woke up to find eviction notices on their doors.

title: SUMMIT IN EGYPT: THE OVERVIEW;World Leaders Join in a Condemnation of Terrorism
description: Invoking the solemn shared history of three religions, leaders of 27 nations, including a broad swath of the Arab world, joined today in a sweeping condemnation of the recent suicide bombings in Israel and vowed to cooperate in fighting terrorism and promoting peace throughout the Middle East.

title: SUMMIT IN EGYPT: THE SYMBOLISM;The Meeting's Message: Put Terrorists on Notice
description: Sometimes, symbolism itself is substance.

title: Giuliani Expects Bratton Deal For Book to Pass City Review
description: In an attempt to ease tensions with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton yesterday dutifully handed City Hall his $350,000 book contract for an ethics review as the Mayor had demanded.

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;New Ethical Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Push to Abortion Pill, a Second U.S. Group Will Test It
description: A New York group said yesterday that it had made its own copy of the French abortion pill, RU-486, and would begin testing to help speed the drug to market in the United States.

title: MARKET PLACE: TOBACCO'S BROKEN LINE;A Dealer's Boldest Play May Reshape the Game
description: For Bennett S. LeBow, the Niccolo Machiavelli of the foxy deal, yesterday's agreement to settle a giant class-action lawsuit against his Liggett Group tobacco company is being viewed as his masterpiece.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Abdul-Rauf Vows Not to Back Down From N.B.A.
description: One day after the National Basketball Association drew a firm line, Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf of the Denver Nuggets showed no signs of backing down from his refusal to stand during the national anthem based on his personal and religious beliefs.

title: PROPHETS & PROFESSORS: Essays on the Lives and Works of Modern Poets : BOOKS
description: PROPHETS & PROFESSORS:Essays on the Lives and Works of Modern Poets

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;Blacks and Insecurity
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;Good News: New Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Here Today, Here Tomorrow
description: IT'S not that 7-year-old Andrew Folken flik dislikes the carpenters that come to his house every morning at 7:30. He enjoys watching them play Ping-Pong with his older brother, Alexander, and they even look after him when the baby sitter has to leave early. But Andrew nonetheless hides the bowl of Cheerios on his lap under the table when the carpenters come into the kitchen.

title: TOBACCO'S BROKEN LINE;Philip Morris Chief Gets a Raise of 32%
description: The Philip Morris Companies raised the salary and bonus of its chairman and chief executive, Geoffrey C. Bible, by 32 percent last year.

title: Bill to Limit Immigration Faces a Setback in Senate
description: In a setback to those who want to cut legal immigration, the Senate Judiciary Committee appears ready to consider new restrictions on legal and illegal aliens in two separate bills, with illegal immigration to be considered first, rather than one overall measure.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Jones Enters Pro Basketball
description: ROY JONES JR., the International Boxing Federation supermiddleweight champion, has signed to play for the Jacksonville Barracudas of the United States Basketball League.

title: TENNIS;No. 1 Muster Stung by Upset
description: The French Open champion Thomas Muster, the No. 1-ranked player in the world this week, was provided with a swift ejection from his opening round match at the Newsweek Champions Cup tonight by a brash Romanian with a relatively humble ranking of 40th.

title: A Stretch for Stallone: A Role With No Muscles
description: Marriages in Hollywood are sometimes weird. And one of the weirder ones was announced today when Miramax Films, which has released such arty movies as "Il Postino," and "Restoration," said it was planning to make a drama with Sylvester Stallone.

title: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;Why Dixie Was Buchanan's Waterloo
description: After his victory in the New Hampshire primary last month, Patrick J. Buchanan's campaign rumbled southward, and it seemed to many that he was steaming toward fertile ground.

title: As a Sarajevo Suburb Changes Hands, Muslim Scavengers Reign
description: They knocked on the door and tried to kick it in, a constant swarm of suitors sizing up the homestead and furniture. They threatened and cajoled, unhindered by the international police monitors living next door or by the pleadings of the owner, a 65-year-old Bosnian Serb who gave his name only as Aco.

title: BOXING;Briggs Stays Focused On Learning Process
description: It was nighttime on Central Avenue in East Orange, N.J. A car with three young men was double-parked while one of the passengers flirted with a young woman on the street. A Land Cruiser, also with three fellows, came up behind the car and waited to get by.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Trade Clark To Toronto for Youth
description: The Islanders have had a dreadful season and are trying to rebuild. The Toronto Maple Leafs have had a disappointing season, but they should still make the Stanley Cup playoffs and are trying to improve their chances in the post-season.

title: Before the Murder, A Judicial Journey;An Abusive Union, a Testy Judge And a Chaotic System That Failed
description: Long before it erupted in murder and an extraordinary bid by a governor to oust a little-known judge, the domestic violence case against Benito Oliver was just another skirmish in a simmering feud between the Brooklyn District Attorney's office and Judge Lorin Duckman.

title: Soros Group Buys Stake in Gymboree
description: A group led by the financier George Soros has acquired a 5.4 percent stake in the Gymboree Corporation of Burlingame, Calif., an operator of play centers and children's clothing stores.

title: SUMMIT IN EGYPT: CLINTON;A FORCE OF 10,000 GUARDING CLINTON
description: Arriving in Jerusalem to show solidarity with Israelis, President Clinton also stepped into an epic security operation today -- and into some feisty politicking as well.

title: The Great Safire Disconnect
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;South Africa to Oust Defiant School Board
description: South African authorities said today that they would dissolve the governing body of a former whites-only school that is clinging to apartheid.

title: Suspended School Board Members Run Again
description: Members of two Bronx community school boards who were recently suspended for allegations of corruption will face little opposition in the May 7 elections, according to a list of official candidates filed yesterday with the city's Board of Elections.

title: U.S. Sending Envoys to Seek Peace in Armenian-Held Region
description: The Clinton Administration has begun an unusually high-level effort to settle the bitter war over Nagorno-Karabakh, a disputed enclave of ethnic Armenians in Azerbaijan, and to help make the region safe for oil development, American officials said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Jobless Rate
description: British unemployment rose by 6,800 in February, to 2.21 million, in the first monthly increase since August 1993, the Government said yesterday. Unemployment is at 7.9 percent, unchanged from January, the Central Statistical Office said. It said changes to the rules on receiving welfare had helped to raise February's figure by classifying certain categories of people as unemployed. The number of jobless has fallen by more than 750,000 since peaking in December 1992. (AP)

title: A Public Look at Private Gardens
description: GREAT private gardens are created in all sorts of places by all sorts of people. Those of historical interest are preserved with public or private financing: as national treasures, like Jefferson's gardens at Monticello, or as local gems, like Wave Hill in Riverdale.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;An Aptitude for the Lyrical
description: Bella Davidovich has always had an affinity for the music of Schumann and Chopin, and it was to those composers that she devoted her program on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall. There were no surprises or revelations: Miss Davidovich played, as always, with a reliably solid technique, an occasionally heavy hand in the bass, offset by an ability to make a melodic line sing, and a sensibility that suggests both the intimacy and extroversion of Schumann's and Chopin's music.

title: Adelphi Chief Tells Students His Trouble Is Not Theirs
description: The president of Adelphi University, under fire for his high salary and generous perquisites, told students at a forum today that he had no plans to resign and dismissed his legal problems as of no importance to them.

title: INSIDE
description: Republicans in Congress Back Down on Debt Limit

title: No Headline
description: He's too much of a realist. He looked at it pragmatically and made his decision."

title: As Albany Cuts Funds, Lobbies Spend More
description: Scrambling to save their piece of the shrinking state budget, corporations and interest groups spent $46.9 million to lobby state government in New York last year, a 17 percent increase over 1994 and the largest rise in nearly two decades, a state commission said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Liggett Breaks Ranks, Settling Tobacco Suit The Liggett Group, the smallest of the nation's five major cigarette companies, broke industry ranks, agreeing to settle a huge class-action lawsuit. Lawyers representing millions of smokers agreed to drop the company from the suit in return for payments to a national quit-smoking campaign and Liggett's promise to withdraw from the fight against new tobacco regulations from the F.D.A.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: No Headline
description: He's too much of a realist. He looked at it pragmatically and made his decision."

title: A Compromise On Restricting Liability Suits
description: House and Senate negotiators reached final agreement today on a compromise measure to limit lawsuits involving faulty products, setting up a critical vote in the Senate next week.

title: Economic Scene;Planning could help in upheavals like the arms industry cutback.
description: OUT of sight, out of mind? The virtual collapse of Southern California's mighty arms industry, with the largest regional job losses since the Great Depression, is no longer on the national radar screens. Unemployment in Los Angeles County has edged down to 8.6 percent today from 9.4 percent in 1994. Besides, downsizing is hardly a problem unique to Southern California or to military contractors: the drive for enhanced productivity is hitting every big business from banking to textiles to retailing.

title: Future Of Arts Agency Unclear
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee that appropriates money for the National Endowment for the Arts said today that he thought Congress would most likely give the endowment $99.5 million budget for the fiscal year 1996, the same amount it gave the agency last year, but that the endowment's future was still in doubt.

title: POLITICS: VOICES;Pub's Straw Poll Finds Politics a Low Priority
description: When he first ran for the Presidency four years ago, Patrick J. Buchanan was smart enough to stand a round at the bar of O'Malley's pub here in the 11th Ward heartland of city politics and offer his imaginings about the plight of the working class.

title: Moscow Journal;With the Walruses, B-r-r-raving Russia's Winter
description: A snowy crust covered the ground. Flags snapped in the breeze. A rare sunny sky was giving way to a flat, dismal gray.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: H.S. BASKETBALL;Yes, Columbus High's Time Has Come Again
description: Jerry Garfin, the principal at Columbus High School in the Bronx, has waited 36 years for another shot at a Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Broken Hearts Still Achy In a Country-Western Bar
description: On one side of Patrick Fahey's convincing saloon set for "The Corner Bar's My Lover Since You Ran Out on Me" stands a jukebox. From time to time, one of the half-dozen characters in William Hemmig's play gives it a good swift kick.

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;It Won't Last Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: Dam Break Floods Summer Resort Area
description: A dam holding back the a lake swelled by water from snow melting in unusually warm weather broke tonight, sending millions of gallons of water roaring over trailer homes, houses and cars near the summer vacation towns of Alton and Gilmanton.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Starks Is Given Green Light
description: If John Starks's career is defined by the amount of freedom he gets from a coach, then Jeff Van Gundy has become his passport to an exciting and familiar destination: John's World, where you can catch fire, grow ice cold and then recharge all in a span of 48 minutes.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;American Envoys' Killers Are Freed in Lebanon
description: An appeals court today freed two Lebanese men convicted of kidnapping and slaying two American diplomats and their driver in 1976, at the height of Lebanon's civil war.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Incinerator Ash Use Protested
description: Several citizens groups yesterday protested plans by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to use incinerator ash for paving roads.

title: Japan Sect's Role in Murder Case Emerges, Prompting Outcry
description: For years the Sakamoto family has stared out from photos and handbills, a happy young couple and their year-old child who vanished in 1989. This week a confession in court explaining how members of the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect killed the family has left Japan touched and saddened.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;An Issue Of Religion And Respect
description: IN this landmark year of Presidential and home-soil Olympic races, the global sports ambassadors of the National Basketball Association are wrapping themselves in red, white and blue. Their most popular and successful marketing campaign -- "I Love This Game" -- has been replaced by one with a more jingoistic edge.

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;A United Response
description: To the Editor:

title: Pension Insurance Fund Deficit Is at Its Lowest Level Since 1981
description: The deficit in the Government's single-employer pension insurance fund fell by $925 million last year to the lowest level since 1981, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation announced today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Wrigley Campaign Captures Award
description: A campaign for the Winterfresh brand of chewing gum marketed by the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company in Chicago has taken top honors at the Advertising Research Foundation's third annual David Ogilvy Award ceremony for excellence in research.

title: Marriott Adding Rooms
description: Marriott International Inc. plans to add 120,000 hotel rooms in the next four years, up from a previous target of 100,000, the chief financial officer, Michael Stein, said yesterday. Mr. Stein also said Marriott expected continued double-digit earnings growth in all of its businesses, with especially strong results from hotels.

title: The Great Safire Disconnect
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Rise in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 188.96 points, or nearly 1 percent, to stand at 19,923.66. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 215.57 points.

title: Tire Fire Undermines I-95 in Philadelphia
description: Part of Interstate 95, the East Coast's main north-south highway, was closed early today after a suspicious tire fire erupted beneath an overpass and left the roadway too weak to support traffic.

title: Nassau Sues To Halt Closing Of Rail Offices
description: The Nassau County Executive and other top county officials announced today that they had filed suit against the Long Island Rail Road to block the closing of 15 ticket offices and 2 stations in Nassau.

title: Brooklyn Shootout Kills Man and Injures Three
description: A wild shootout that erupted on a street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon left one man dead and three others injured, including a 14-year-old boy who was seriously hurt by the gunfire, the police said.

title: For G.M. Pickets, Coffee and Concern
description: After several days of golf and household chores, George Heeter, Jack Dyer and Bob Coulder showed up today at a General Motors brake factory here to take their turns carrying picket signs and to marvel at their ability to cripple the world's largest auto maker.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jets Trade Turner to Packers for Draft Pick
description: The Jets traded cornerback MARCUS TURNER to Green Bay yesterday for a conditional sixth-round pick in the 1997 draft. The condition is that Turner make the Packers squad for the 1996 season.

title: Panel Offers Sharp Criticism Of AIDS Research Projects
description: The Government's $1.4 billion AIDS research program is uncoordinated, lacks focus and needs a major overhaul to attract new scientific talent and spur novel and imaginative ideas, a Government-appointed panel said in a report issued yesterday.

title: How Arafat Uses Hamas
description: If the intifada convinced most Israelis that we cannot occupy the Palestinians, the recent wave of terrorist bombings has proved that we also cannot make peace with them.

title: Canada, Backed by Mexico, Protests to U.S. on Cuba Sanctions
description: In a sign of the growing tensions between the United States and its trading partners over stepped-up American sanctions against Cuba, Canada said today that it had lodged a trade protest with the Clinton Administration, and Mexico immediately asked to join Canadian-American discussions on the issue.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ARCHER-DANIELS IN JOINT VENTURE WITH RHONE-POULENC
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company said yesterday that it would form a joint venture with Rhone-Poulenc S.A.'s animal nutrition unit to market pre-mixes for animal feed. Pre-mixes are blends of amino acids, vitamins, medicinal additives and other elements. Archer-Daniels, the grain processor based in Decatur, Ill., will contribute pre-mix operations in the United States, Canada, China and Vietnam, and stakes in ventures in Mexico, Taiwan and Thailand. Rhone-Poulenc, the French drug and chemicals concern, will contribute pre-mix operations in France, Australia and Indonesia, as well as stakes in pre-mix companies in Italy and Japan.

title: Clothes You Gave Away Are a Hot Item in Africa
description: Martin Eshitemi had to bargain hard for his latest sartorial acquisition, haggling a good 15 minutes with the owner of a wooden stall overflowing with shirts. When it was over, the taxi-driver paid $1.50 for his prize: a used T-shirt with the N.F.L. logo on the sleeve and Budweiser emblazoned across the chest.

title: Censorship in the Balkans
description: Before the killing started in Bosnia, hateful nationalist propaganda from official Serbian media helped prepare the ground. That is why the current campaign by President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to harass and suppress independent broadcasters and newspapers warrants special attention and protest from abroad. Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, has also engaged in forms of media harassment. The Dayton agreement, which both Presidents signed, cannot produce a lasting peace in the former Yugoslavia unless independent voices have a chance to counter the sometimes inflammatory official media line.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unilever to Shift Management Structure
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products company, said yesterday that it was changing its management structure so that it could respond better to changes in markets and the economy. The company said it would create a seven-man executive committee, effective Sept. 1, that would become its main management body.

title: Kerouac's Daughter Rebuffed in Bid to Move Father's Burial Site
description: The daughter of the novelist Jack Kerouac has lost the first round in an effort to move her father's body from a cemetery in this former mill town and rebury him in New Hampshire.

title: Early-Release Pair Seized in 5 Slayings
description: Two prison inmates free under an early-release program were arrested on Tuesday in the slaying of three video store workers and an elderly couple who apparently stumbled onto the crime.

title: Arbitrator and Foes to Discuss Pact
description: For the first time since New York City teachers rejected a proposed five-year pact three months ago, representatives from the teachers' union, City Hall and the Board of Education are to sit down today with a state arbitrator to discuss their differences and the prospects of returning to the bargaining table.

title: Inquiry Criticizes Law Enforcement Gathering as Lewd and Racist
description: The Good Ol' Boys Roundup, an annual gathering of law enforcement officers in Tennessee, had degenerated over the years into a lewd, beer-soaked outing with a host of activities offensive to members of minorities and women, according to a report issued today by the Justice Department.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Falling Ice Again Forces Closing of Bridge's Upper Level
description: Chunks of ice fell onto the roadway of the George Washington Bridge again yesterday, forcing the closing of the upper deck for a few hours from midmorning to early afternoon.

title: Grass-Roots Fight Emerges on Hospital Plan
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani selected the first city-run hospitals to be put up for sale, he chose three that were considered the most marketable. Because they were in neighborhoods with medical alternatives, they were also considered the least likely to generate community opposition, or so his advisers told him.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CASINO DATA SHARES PLUMMET AFTER 6 EXECUTIVES LEAVE
description: The shares of Casino Data Systems plunged 24.4 percent yesterday after six executives who joined the company in December returned to their previous employer, International Game Technology. Casino Data, a casino technology company based in Las Vegas, Nev., that is trying to enter the gambling-machine business, hired away four International Game vice presidents and two division directors in December. Casino Data did not return a telephone call seeking comment. International Game, which is based in Reno, Nev., said the executives would seek a release of their employment agreements with Casino Data or a determination that those obligations could not be enforced. Casino Data shares dropped $3.75, to $11.625, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of International Game, which makes video games, slot machines and gaming monitoring systems, climbed 75 cents, to $14.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mohammed al-Ghazali, 78, An Egyptian Cleric and Scholar
description: Sheik Mohammed al-Ghazali, an Islamic cleric and scholar whose writings have influenced generations of Egyptians, died on Saturday while delivering a lecture in Riyadh, the Saudi Arabian capital. He was 78 and lived in Cairo. The cause of death was a heart attack, Egyptian newspapers said.

title: How Not to Write English
description: A curriculum guide for teaching English has just been released in a tongue barely recognizable as English. The original idea was a good one. Everyone wants to learn English, the lingua franca of airports and the Internet, of rock music and arcane scientific journals. Then why not recommend national standards for instruction so that, at the very least, American high school students can become more polished users of their own language?

title: Clinton Pledges to Seek Light-Rail Funds
description: The Clinton Administration pledged today to seek Congressional financing to build the first half of a light rail system that would run along the Hudson River from Ridgefield to the Bayonne Bridge.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CONRAIL IN DISCUSSIONS ON SALE OF RAIL LINES
description: Conrail Inc. said yesterday that it was in exclusive talks with two companies on the sale of its nearly 400 miles of rail lines in eastern Massachusetts and Connecticut. Financial terms were not disclosed. Conrail, which is based in Philadelphia, said the talks were with Railtex Inc. of San Antonio and the Providence & Worcester Railroad Company, based in Worcester, Mass. Railtex would get certain tracks in Connecticut and Massachusetts, as well as operating rights on other tracks. Providence & Worcester would get ownership of freight service in parts of Connecticut and limited trackage rights on Conrail routes between the Connecticut-New York State border and the borough of Queens, as well as some freight rights in Massachusetts.

title: HOCKEY;The Rangers Squander Three Leads
description: The Rangers led the Florida Panthers three times last night at Madison Square Garden, but not when it really counted. They had to settle for a 3-3 tie, which extended their streak without a victory at home to seven games (0-3-4). Their last three home games have ended in ties.

title: Krzysztof Kieslowski, Maker Of Enigmatic Films, Dies at 54
description: Krzysztof Kieslowski, the Polish film director who achieved international acclaim with his hauntingly enigmatic trilogy, "Three Colors," died yesterday in a hospital in Warsaw. He was 54.

title: POLITICS: THE ENVIRONMENT;Democrats Fight to Restore Curbed Programs
description: Senate Democrats sought today to restore environmental programs that have been curtailed during the long budget standoff, as the Clinton Administration vowed again to veto any spending bill that undercut its environmental priorities.

title: Thomson Deal Is Under Antitrust Review
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division has opened an investigation into the Thomson Corporation's $3.43 billion acquisition of the West Publishing Company, whose on-line legal research business is similar to that of one of Thomson's big divisions.

title: Jack Weprin, 65, Leader in Jewish Groups
description: Jack Weprin, a real estate lawyer who was prominent in New York Jewish organizations and a benefactor of many, died on Sunday at Kutscher's Country Club in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y. He was 65 and lived in Greenwich Village in Manhattan.

title: House Kills Sweeping Provisions In Counterterrorism Legislation
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to approve an amendment by the National Rifle Association that eliminated what both critics and supporters said were the central provisions of a broad counterterrorism bill.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Anglo American to Buy 5.9% Stake in Lonrho
description: The Anglo American Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 5.9 percent stake in Lonrho P.L.C. for L91 million ($138 million) from a company controlled by Lonrho's chief executive, Dieter Bock. Anglo American, a South African mining concern, also said it had acquired first rights of refusal to buy Mr. Bock's remaining 18.5 percent stake should he decide to sell. Mr. Bock said he intended to hold his remaining stock for the time being.

title: Bridge
description: One of the enduring unsolved theoretical mysteries of bridge is this: which opening lead should be chosen when the choice is between two suits each containing one honor?

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Settlement Is Reported On AIDS Virus in Japan
description: The Health and Welfare Ministry and five drug companies have agreed to a court-proposed settlement of suits brought by Japanese who contracted the AIDS virus from contaminated blood products, ministry officials said today.

title: AT HOME WITH: Michael Graves;How the Pearl Designed His Oyster
description: IN a land of brand names, Michael Graves is the Coca-Cola of American architecture.

title: The Great Safire Disconnect
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Republicans in Congress Back Down on Debt Limit

title: Progress on Courtroom Cameras
description: This week's narrow 14-to-12 vote by the Judicial Conference of the United States to give Federal appeals courts the option to televise appellate arguments marks a welcome turnaround. Just 18 months ago, in the glare of the O. J. Simpson murder case, the Federal courts' chief policy-making group voted to bar cameras from both appellate arguments and trials.

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;Who's Fine?
description: To the Editor:

title: John W. Duffy, 89, 'Mr. Ireland' on Parade Day
description: John W. Duffy, an Irish railroad man's son who made the transition from County Tyrone to County New York without any noticeable interruption of national allegiance, died at a hospice in Branford, Conn., on Sunday, six days before the annual St. Patrick's Day Parade, which had long stepped off to his command. He was 89.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L. Will Experiment With the Instant Replay
description: The National Football League will experiment with instant replay during some preseason and regular-season games, but the system will not be implemented on an official basis during the regular season, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said today at the owners' meeting.

title: Currents;40 Artists of Brooklyn
description: BASEBALL teams are scarce in Brooklyn, but artists are not. In a new show, "Design Brooklyn," at the nonprofit Rotunda Gallery, 33 Clinton Street (near Pierrepont Street), in Brooklyn Heights (718 875-4047), the works are by 40 artists who live and work in the borough. The show opens tomorrow and runs through April 27.

title: Corrections
description: A listing yesterday of the delegations attending the summit meeting in Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, misidentified the heads of the Qatari, Spanish and Yemeni delegations. The Qatari leader was Foreign Minister Hamad bin Jassem bin Jaber al-Thani, not the Emir, Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani; the Spanish leader was Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, not Jose Maria Aznar; and the Yemeni leader was Foreign Minister Abdul-Karim al-Iryani, not President Ali Abdullah Saleh.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the indictment of six Chinese immigrants on drug charges misstated the month in which the Golden Venture immigrant-smuggling ship ran aground off Queens in some editions. The shipwreck occurred in June 1993, not in March 1993.

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;Like the Third World
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?;What Capitalism Means
description: To the Editor:

title: European Topics : Heading for Majorca? Brush Up on Your Catalan
description: In Palma, Majorca, the newspaper Baleares will soon become the Diari de Balears, ending a 60-year Spanish-language history to publish instead in Catalan.

title: HOCKEY REPORT
description: Longest Game

title: Currents;Housewares Without Stairs
description: WHY have a two-story shop if customers make use of only one floor? "Only 50 percent of the customers went downstairs," said Peri Wolfman (inset right), an owner of Wolfman-Gold and Good Company, the SoHo housewares shop. When the store reopens tomorrow at a new location, 117 Mercer Street (Prince Street), it will still have 2,000 square feet -- but all at one level.

title: Microsoft Wins Piracy Lawsuit
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had been awarded $8.08 million in damages in a software piracy lawsuit it filed against Unitron Inc., a computer manufacturer in Taiwan.

title: Magic Johnson's Book Removed by School
description: School officials in Chappaqua have decided to stop using Earvin (Magic) Johnson's book "What You Can Do to Avoid AIDS" after a parents complained that its descriptions of sex were inappropriate for high school students. In addition, the school board is creating a panel to review health class materials.

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Buchanan Sees Light At End Of Drubbings
description: Patrick J. Buchanan's thoughts turned at times today from the drubbing he is taking in this Presidential contest to his prospects in the next one, in the year 2000.

title: Phillips and Anadarko Drill New Well Beneath Gulf's Salt
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company and the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that they had completed another successful well in the Gulf of Mexico, significantly increasing the prospect of tapping large reserves of oil and natural gas below layers of salt that cover large parts of the intensely developed existing fields.

title: SUMMIT IN EGYPT;Appeals Against Terrorism, Jointly and Individually, by Former Adversaries
description: Following is the statement issued yesterday by participants in the meeting at Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, as read by President Clinton, along with excerpts from statements by Mr. Clinton, Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, Yasir Arafat, President of the Palestinian Authority, and Prince Saud al-Faisal, Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia. Prince Saud's remarks were transcribed by The Associated Press; the statements by the others were transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service.

title: Essay;The Shaky Three
description: Three of the world leaders who gathered at Sharm el-Sheik in Egypt -- Shimon Peres, Boris Yeltsin and Bill Clinton -- are actively campaigning to remain in office. It is as if they were running mates on an international incumbency ticket, with each having an intense interest in helping the others win.

title: Genetic Engineering of Crops Can Spread Allergies, Study Shows
description: Researchers said today that they had the first solid evidence that proteins that can cause potentially serious allergic reactions could be transferred to crops through genetic engineering.

title: Sit-In Over Police Killings
description: Twelve people were arrested at the Brooklyn District Attorney's office yesterday after they staged a sit-in to protest the refusal of grand juries to indict police officers in separate killings last year.

title: Should Downsizing Lead to a New System?
description: To the Editor:

title: Training a Dog With Treats, Not Tricks
description: WE decided to get a dog for simple reasons -- as a playmate for our 5-year-old daughter, a running partner for me and a four-legged vacuum of whatever food our 7-month-old launches over the side of her highchair. But before we went to get our puppy last fall, I wondered how I would train her. So I searched the local library for books on the basics -- sit, down, stay, come and heel. And, please, no jumping up on people or begging at the table.

title: Events: Architecture Shows, Talks and an Antiques Sale
description: Building New York Rotunda of the Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House, foot of Broadway; (212) 683-0023, extension 15.

title: COMPANY REPORTS
description: TRINET CORPORATE REALTY TRUST, San Francisco, a real estate investment trust that acquires and manages office and industrial properties, has bought the headquarters complex of Federal Express Corp. in Memphis for $26 million.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;War Horses That Prance Like Colts
description: Abbado's 'Figaro'

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Sendups of Forbes, Clinton and Royalty
description: Dana Carvey did one hilarious new impression in his sketch comedy show on Tuesday night, but here's what it would take for that character to become a breakout hit: Steve Forbes would have to become President. Mr. Carvey's Forbes had a glassy, wide-eyed gaze, a plastered-on thin-lipped smile, and a naivete that made him fondle a sack of money and call for a comforting cup of cocoa. That kind of dead-on impression once made Mr. Carvey seem like George Bush's evil twin. But on the evidence of the first show, the Carvey series on ABC looks almost as lifeless as the Forbes campaign. The debut already looked tired and old.

title: Reviews/Fashion;Beautiful Flight or Dizzy Free Fall
description: It is experimental designers who most often provide the joy of fashion. An unusual cut that flatters the body like never before, an unexpected color combination that delights the spirit, a new coupling of two or three comfortingly familiar styles that look adventurous yet harmonious.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Jump to the Pros or Not? Colgate Star Sheds Light
description: High school seniors are turning professional, college freshmen are turning professional, but Adonal Foyle is staying at Colgate.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It will certainly be a trip down memory lane tomorrow for fans of ERIKA SLEZAK, who plays Victoria Carpenter on the soap opera "One Life to Live." At the close of the show, ABC will show a two-minute montage of the actress through her 25 years on it. Tonight, the network is giving her a party in its corporate offices, with producers and writers from past seasons.

title: New York City's Newest
description: New York City has heard warnings throughout its history about the burdens of its large population of immigrants. New estimates from the Census Bureau, showing migration patterns in and out of the city in the first half of the 1990's, may well reinforce fears that a rising flood of arrivals from foreign countries will increase the cost of schools and social services while the city's tax base keeps eroding. Examined more carefully, however, the patterns of immigration yield a strikingly more hopeful portrait. In fact, the influx of foreigners in the city is enhancing its economic vitality and rescuing whole neighborhoods from decline.

title: Stocks Advance on Hopes For Rising Company Profits
description: The stock market rose modestly yesterday as traders bet that an expanding economy would push corporate profits upward.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES M. LAROSSA, a criminal defense lawyer whose clients have included Anthony Scotto, Paul Castellano, Mario Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito, is about to face many of the judges who have heard his cases again. But in addition to listening to him, they are also likely to be applauding.

title: POLITICS;Clinton Chats With Press
description: The President spoke for an hour to reporters aboard Air Force One today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fokker Says Asian Bids Are Not Forthcoming
description: The struggling Dutch plane maker Fokker N.V. said yesterday that no suitor had come forth to rescue it despite the passing of a deadline for bids by two Asian aerospace rivals: Samsung Aerospace of South Korea or China's Aviation Industries. If both Asian companies fail to make bids, Fokker's aircraft manufacturing business, with up to 5,500 jobs, would almost certainly close, causing the biggest layoffs in Dutch corporate history.

title: Justice Dept. Seeks Fairness in Forfeiture Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: HOUSE RACE -- BATTLE FOR CONGRESS -- Illinois's FifthDistrict; Democrats Hone Swords in Chicago Election
description: The 4200 block of Ridgeway Avenue is a monument to the remnants of the storied Chicago Democratic Machine. Every single house, on each side of the street, displays a jauntily angled sign proclaiming "Blagojevich for Congress '96."

title: The C.I.A.'s Reason for Living
description: In an effort to strengthen the battered Central Intelligence Agency, a Presidential commission has recently recommended steps that would do just the opposite -- weaken it as an independent and objective interpreter of foreign events.

title: Rogers Has Arm Trouble Plus Trouble With Torre
description: Kenny Rogers's availability for the start of the regular season became unclear today when the Yankee left-hander reported enough stiffness in his pitching arm to be scratched from a start tonight against the Detroit Tigers.

title: The Dying Need Respect, Not Conferences;Gun Control and Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Lila Perlstein, Bridge Player, 70
description: Lila Perlstein of Roslyn Heights, L.I., a top bridge player, died yesterday in North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She was 70 and had cancer, said her son, Jay Perlstein of Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Have High Hopes for New Forward
description: There have not been too many players whom Lou Lamoriello picks up at the airport. But the president and general manager of the Devils did just that this afternoon with Dave Andreychuk, an indication that the team's latest acquisition is someone special.

title: Head of I.B.M. Has Better Year Than I.B.M.
description: In one of the most generous pay packages for a corporate executive last year, the chairman of I.B.M., Louis V. Gerstner Jr., received $4.8 million in salary and bonus, plus stock options and other incentive pay with a current value of more than $13 million, the company disclosed yesterday.

title: Real Estate;When a second broker takes over a listing, the first may still profit under new  rules in New York City.
description: WHEN a seller decides to switch real estate agencies, what happens when a customer who looked at the property with the first broker comes back to buy it from the second broker?

title: FILM REVIEW;What if Butch and Sundance Had Kissed?
description: The Celluloid Closet" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 13. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Miscellany
description: * The Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said that the number of magazine advertising pages in February fell 4.9 percent from February 1995, to 15,960. For the first two months of 1996, total ad pages fell 4.6 percent, to 28,750, from the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Country Life 1994. Miramax. $100.72. 107 minutes. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Officer Killed and Another Hurt In Carjacking Battle in the Bronx
description: Two police officers were shot last night, one fatally, in a gun battle that erupted after the officers tried to thwart a carjacking in the Fordham section of the Bronx. The wild gunfight also left four others wounded, including three bystanders.

title: NYC;Keeping a Plant In the Bronx Is Job No. 1
description: ASKING Jose Alvarez if he is worried about his future is a bit like asking if he is alive. Why waste the question, that's how obvious the answer is, he said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Merged Chase Bank Goes to McCann
description: The bank to be created March 31 by the merger of the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had named McCann-Erickson New York to handle the retail portion of its account, with billings estimated at more than $50 million. The merged bank also selected Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York to handle corporate advertising aimed at large businesses; those billings were not disclosed.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Woman Killed in Car Crash
description: A woman was killed yesterday afternoon when she drove onto a busy street in Newark's North Ward heading in the wrong direction and smashed into a New Jersey Transit bus, said Detective Daniel Collins, a police spokesman. The bus driver and five passengers were injured, none of them seriously, said Ken Miller, a spokesman for the transit company.

title: Japanese Suits on H.I.V.-Tainted Blood Settled
description: Five drug companies and Japan's Minister of Health and Welfare agreed today to a proposed settlement with hemophiliacs who were infected with the AIDS virus through contaminated blood-clotting products, setting the stage for the end of seven years of bitter litigation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;2 Pepsico Divisions Drop Out As Sponsors of Carvey Show
description: Reports of the demise of the ABC sketch comedy series starring Dana Carvey, which drew complaints over the contents of skits performed in the first episode on Tuesday, might have been premature. Though two of the three principal advertisers have withdrawn from the series, the third said yesterday that it would continue to participate.

title: Star-Spangled Coercion
description: By agreeing to stand in silent prayer during the national anthem, Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf of the Denver Nuggets has acted to end a confrontation with the National Basketball Association that threatened his team's playoff chances and his $11.2 million contract. His suspension for refusing to stand during the anthem because of his personal and religious beliefs has now been lifted. But in the process of coercing Mr. Abdul-Rauf to rethink his position, the clever patriots who run the N.B.A. have lost sight of what the pre-game ritual celebrates.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Davis's Knee Passes Test
description: The Knicks have been riding a wave of strong play in the last week, a streak that has grown because of their work on the court and in practice. Yesterday, it became clear that good fortune is also their ally.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Senators Resist Both Plans For TV Airwaves Auction
description: Distancing themselves from both the White House and Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, members of the Senate Budget Committee expressed deep reservations today about proposals to raise billions of dollars by auctioning off radio frequencies earmarked for digital television.

title: Medical Care Is Going to the Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: CHRONICLE
description: When CAROL CHANNING accepts a lifetime achievement tribute in Los Angeles on Monday, it will have a particularly poignant tinge.

title: Hawaii Doesn't Back Same-Sex Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home;Secrecy and Justice
description: The case before him, the judge said, "harks back to a dark era in American history when Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was a powerful political force in this nation, when promising careers in the public and private sectors were arbitrarily cut short based on innuendo, unsubstantiated allegations and irrational fears. . . ."

title: ROOTS OF TERROR: A special report.;Alms and Arms: Tactics in a Holy War
description: Hamas, the main force behind the suicide bombers who have thrown the shaky Middle East peace talks into crisis, is an organization with deep roots, a popular base that feeds on misery and resentment, an international support network, and a clear goal: to turn the nascent Palestine into an Islamic state.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: A Walk in the Clouds 1995. Fox $100.71. Laser disk, $39.98. 102 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.

title: Home Video
description: Having tentatively announced a September introduction for the digital video disk (DVD) -- a platter the size of an audio CD that will hold an entire movie -- hardware manufacturers and the movie industry are scrambling to solve problems, some of them formidable, that could delay the new product's arrival until next year. DVD requires a digital player that functions like a VCR (except that it doesn't record) and will cost about $500. Enticing consumers to purchase such an item requires a large amount of software -- in this case movies -- to use with the machine, and, in a replay of the chicken-or-egg scenario, the hardware and software should ideally be obtainable at the same time. Otherwise, the availability of too few films could result in the sale of too few players and undermine DVD before it gets established.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Exiles Lost Beyond Love
description: RICHARD DRESSER'S "Below the Belt," which opened last night at the John Houseman Theater, takes place in "a distant land" across an unnamed desert on an industrial compound that each day turns out 20,911 units of something never identified. We seem to be somewhere in the third world. In fact, we're in a dimly realized fourth world, a surreal territory in which corporate bureaucracy, thinking and deformation of language spell the absolute end of American civilization.

title: How the Irish Came, and Overcame
description: THE Irish are New York's ur-ethnic group. They were here first -- which is to say that they were the first to immigrate in real numbers and complicate the neat world the Dutch and the British had made for themselves -- and they were the first to struggle as a group with the issues of discrimination and assimilation that still define the immigrant experience today.

title: 25 and Under
description: I'm a Southerner, transplanted, who wants the comforts of my culture and food around me," said Alexander Smalls, co-owner and guiding force of Sweet Ophelia's, a new Southern bakery and cafe in SoHo. "It's a selfish indulgence."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hoechst Plans to Split Drug and Chemical Units
description: Hoechst A.G. of Germany plans to split its drug and chemical businesses to try to raise shareholder value, The Financial Times reported today. The company is considering options, including a spinoff of the pharmaceutical operations and partnerships with other drug makers. "I do not believe a pharmaceutical business such as ours can sit comfortably inside a chemicals company," the company's chief executive, Jurgen Dormann, told the newspaper.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIGICON DISCUSSING MERGER WITH A SMALLER COMPANY
description: Digicon Inc. said yesterday that it is in preliminary merger talks with a undisclosed smaller oilfield services company. As a result of the talks, Digicon, which provides seismic-data services to the petroleum industry, pushed back its planned offering of 3.7 million shares. In trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of Digicon rose 31.25 cents, to $8.125.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 24 about the decline in the value of the South African currency included a quotation from an investment adviser in Johannesburg that misidentified the first big American bank to stop making or renewing loans to private borrowers in South Africa in the 1980's. It was the Chase Manhattan Bank, not Citibank.

title: Prosecutors To Try Again To Sway Criticized Judge
description: In the face of scorching criticism, what will Judge Harold Baer Jr. do?

title: CHRONICLE
description: Singing Bess in "Porgy and Bess" is satisfaction enough for CYNTHIA CLAREY, the mezzo-soprano, who usually sings the smaller role of Serena in the Gershwin opera. But she said yesterday that she expects singing Bess in South Africa to be an incomparable experience.

title: ART REVIEW;Strolling Through Political Art's Past
description: A few years ago, the New York State Council on the Arts issued a call for exhibitions addressing the still underrecorded history of alternative movements in American contemporary art. Two shows that resulted are now on view in SoHo, at Exit Art/The First World and the Drawing Center.

title: Senate Panel Creates 2 Bills On Legal and Illegal Aliens
description: By a surprisingly wide margin, the Senate Judiciary Committee agreed today to consider new restrictions on legal and illegal aliens in two separate bills rather than one, imperiling large proposed cuts in legal immigration.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Wearied by Rebuilding, Kobe Aide Is a Suicide
description: The Deputy Mayor of Kobe, in charge of rebuilding the city after last year's earthquake, killed himself today, the police reported.

title: Art in Review
description: Louise Belcourt Annika Sundvik Gallery 26 Grand Street SoHo Through March 23

title: DANCE REVIEW;Irish Steps and Their Kin
description: RIVERDANCE: THE SHOW," a song and dance revue from Ireland that has had phenomenal success in Dublin and London over the last two years, has the right idea. A traditional culture can survive only as a living tradition, brought up to date.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Jets Get Graham to Catch O'Donnell's Passes
description: Last season, the Jets' offense struggled, partly because the wide-receiver corps suffered in quality and quantity. Yesterday, the Jets made a move to correct that by adding a quality unrestricted free-agent receiver in 27-year-old Jeff Graham to go along with their new quarterback and new offensive tackles.

title: Review/Fashion;Lacroix's Lush Mood Steals the Show
description: Bazar by Christian Lacroix and Christian Lacroix Jeans, its spinoff collection, together constitute one of the most inventive secondary lines. With their dense, funky prints, fearless juxtaposition of colors and rakish shapes, they are lush as well as streetwise.

title: Einstein Manuscript Up for Auction Shows Science Can Be Art
description: What turns a piece of paper into history is that it marks a seminal moment, a point in time when conventional thinking was challenged and forever changed. What makes it art is not only the peculiar beauty of its yellowed pages, faded ink or elegant script, but that it lives, infused with the spirit of the author's hand.

title: Transit Chief Warns of Cuts In Service
description: After months of assurances from transit officials that there would be no more cuts in subway and bus service until 2000 or beyond, the new president of the Transit Authority warned yesterday that he might have to cut service to balance the authority's budget.

title: For Children
description: Douglass Street Festival The Gowanus Arts Exchange 295 Douglass Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues Park Slope, Brooklyn (718) 596-5250 Recommended ages: 8 and up Tomorrow and Sunday

title: Review/Fashion;Another Sure Step At Helmut Lang
description: It's been said that editing yourself is like trying to tickle yourself.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Babe 1995. MCA/Universal. $22.98. Laser disk, $24.98. 92 minutes. Closed captioned. G. Release date: Friday.

title: Hawaii Doesn't Back Same-Sex Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF;Three Share The Lead At Bay Hill
description: When golf gets to this very highest of levels, success and failure often depend on attitude. A positive thought process can lead to low scores, a negative one to high scores and an indifferent one to a weekend off after missing the cut.

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Robert Wilson, theater director, has just finished reading "The Art of the South Pacific" by Anthony Meyer.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Trade for Kurri and McSorley
description: In a bold attempt to contend again for the Stanley Cup, the Rangers acquired experience, size, some skill and a lot of toughness last night in a multiplayer trade with the Los Angeles Kings.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Dispute Over Jail Leases
description: Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive, and a Democrat, complained to a Senate committee yesterday that the county has been forced to absorb $12 million in lease payments for state prisoners housed in county jails.

title: FILM REVIEW;Two Nuns and a Decision of Life or Death
description: The situation is painfully familiar. Military patrols in a small border town in a fragile Latin American democracy are making a brutal house-to-house search for a young rebel fugitive. When the hunted man steals into the austere home shared by two nuns, Sister Ana (Veronica Oddo) and Sister Ursula (Elba Escobar), they must make a potentially life-or-death decision whether to hide him or force him to leave.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EATON SUES AUTO PARTS MAKER OVER DEFENSE TACTICS
description: Stepping up a $121 million takeover bid for the Capco Automotive Products Corporation, the Eaton Corporation said yesterday that it was suing the auto parts maker in Federal court to drop its poison pill and other defense tactics. Capco said it had hired CS First Boston to review the bid and expected its board to meet late next week to consider the proposal. Eaton, which owns about 7.3 percent of Capco's stock, had offered on Wednesday to acquire all the remaining shares for about $11 a share in cash. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Capco surged $4.375, to $12.125, on speculation that Eaton might sweeten its bid for the truck transmissions manufacturer. Eaton was unchanged at $59.125.

title: 4 Are Charged With Dumping In I-95 Tire Fire
description: Four men have been arrested and charged with felonies and misdemeanors charging them with dumping tires that erupted in flames under an elevated section of Interstate 95 here on Wednesday, the police said today.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Actress, Mother and Con Artist, 1906
description: Good news: the Ridiculous Theatrical Company and Everett Quinton, its star, artistic director and playwright-in-residence, are back in business with "Call Me Sarah Bernhardt," a new play with music that opened last night at P.S. 122 in the East Village.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about companies seeking alternatives to layoffs misstated the name of a steel company. It is the Weirton Steel Corporation, not Weirton Steel & Wire.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STERILE CONCEPTS REJECTS ANOTHER OFFER FROM MAXXIM
description: Sterile Concepts Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected a second takeover bid from Maxxim Medical Inc., saying that it was in the best interest of the company to remain independent. Under its second offer, Maxxim would have paid $17.75 a share, or $128 million, for Sterile Concepts, a maker of custom surgical trays. Maxxim revised its bid earlier this week after Sterile Concepts rejected its first offer of $16 a share. Under both offers, Maxxim Medical would have assumed $29 million of Sterile Concepts debt. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of Sterile Concepts fell $1, to $16.625, and Maxxim fell 12.5 cents, to $18.875. Maxxim Medical makes medical products.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Closing Ranks Against Terror
description: There are times when the tangled, often violent affairs of nations give way to a moment of reflection and reconciliation. Such was the case on Wednesday when the leaders of countries once bitterly divided assembled in the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheik to stand together against terrorism and demonstrate their support for the endangered peace effort in the Middle East.

title: BASKETBALL;Playoff Hopes Fade As Nets Fall at Home
description: For the Nets, home is where the hurt is. They lost their fifth straight game at the Continental Arena tonight, 100-92, to the Washington Bullets and their chances of making the National Basketball Association playoffs continued to evaporate.

title: Steve Forbes Bows Out
description: Steve Forbes abandoned his self-financed quest for the Presidential nomination yesterday in a more generous spirit than he displayed during his abrasive primary campaign. He offered unreserved support to Bob Dole, the man he carpet-bombed with commercials portraying the majority leader as an unprincipled hack. Unlike Pat Buchanan's campaign, which is still in business, he did not make ideological demands, asking only that Mr. Dole fashion a party of "principles, ideas and issues" that "appeal to the better angels of our nature."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Officers to Patrol Trains
description: Twenty uniformed officers will be permanently assigned to patrol PATH trains, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. Every nighttime train will be patrolled, as will more than half of weekday trains and 90 percent of weekend trains, said Mark Hatfield, a spokesman for the authority.

title: The Dying Need Respect, Not Conferences
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Micron Posts Results Below Expectations
description: Stung by a steep drop in the price of memory chips, Micron Technology Inc. reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that were far below the estimates of Wall Street analysts.

title: Saks Planning Stock Offering And Growth In Outlet Stores
description: Saks Fifth Avenue, that icon of luxury goods and urban elegance, is looking to outlet stores in the suburbs for its future growth.

title: FILM REVIEW;Two Sisters' Beaus Are Just One Guy
description: Modesty has not forbidden Fernando Trueba, whose Academy Award-winning "Belle Epoque" invoked the work of Jean Renoir, from comparing his first American comedy to the films of Preston Sturges and Billy Wilder. Mr. Trueba, a former film critic in his native Spain, has modeled this leaden trifle on classic screwball farce, but changing times mean different personnel. And how.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Ire and Votes: U.S. Vents Its Rage at Cuba In Trade Law
description: The bill that President Clinton signed this week penalizing foreign companies doing business with Cuba illustrates two of the most controversial trends in American trade policy.

title: BASEBALL;The Mets Have Too Many in the Outfield
description: If there has been one unit that has performed well this spring from the best player to the unknown player, it has been the group of outfielders who came to camp with hardly a job or a roster spot open.

title: FILM REVIEW;Airline Terrorists Meet A Techie and a Toughy
description: Hope there's a good movie on this flight," a United States Special Forces commando says sardonically in "Executive Decision," Stuart Baird's "Die Hard in the Ozone" about a 747 in terrorist hands. This itself is a good, taut movie for red-meat action audiences, but it's not one you will be seeing on an airliner. Not ever.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;New Editor in Chief At Reader's Digest
description: Reader's Digest promoted its executive editor, Christopher P. Willcox, yesterday to editor in chief. He succeeds Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, who announced his resignation last month.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: SOUTHEAST;Shock Waves: Carril and Princeton Stun U.C.L.A.
description: For all the predecessors who had been disappointed in past months of March, and for the coach who can turn practices into torture, the students of Pete Carril painted his masterpiece tonight.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BTR Says Profit Rises, And Plans Consolidation
description: BTR P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose a higher-than-expected 6 percent in 1995 and announced details of a long-awaited strategy to refocus the business in fewer units with global reach. BTR, the diversified industrial company with Britain's biggest market capitalization, said profit rose in 1995 to a record L1.50 billion, or about $2.3 billion, from L1.41 billion in 1994.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Canadian Team Drafts Dead Man
description: For the second time in a year, a Canadian Football League team has drafted a dead player.

title: What's Up, Bugs? It's Mickey!;For Warner and Disney, a Friendly Rivalry on Fifth Ave.
description: If a grudge match could ever be arranged between Bugs Bunny and Mickey Mouse, there seems little doubt who would get a giant safe dropped on his head. Mickey is too nice for the rough stuff. Bugs, as he has always cheerfully admitted, is a stinker. Las Vegas odds-makers would have a field day.

title: In America;Torture by H.M.O.
description: From the New England Journal of Medicine comes the story of a North Carolina family that was devastated by the inflexible and thoroughly inhumane decisions of a national health maintenance organization.

title: The Dying Need Respect, Not Conferences
description: To the Editor:

title: Burger King in Japan
description: Burger King is broadening its presence in Japan. Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the conglomerate that owns Burger King, and Japan Tobacco Inc. said today that they would form a 50-50 joint venture to open 100 new Burger King restaurants in the Tokyo area by the end of the century.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST;Halfway to an Upset, San Jose State Runs Out of Magic
description: San Jose State thought it had a monumental upset brewing against Kentucky. Then the second half started.

title: Meningitis Epidemic Kills 4,500 in West Africa
description: A meningitis epidemic sweeping through western Africa has killed more than 4,500 people and shows no signs of abating, the World Health Organization said today.

title: Buyback Announcement Lifts Monsanto
description: The shares of the Monsanto Company rose today after the company announced plans for a share buyback and possible stock split, and for changes in its employee stock option program to focus it more strongly on performance.

title: Pataki Warns Of Further Cuts In State Budget
description: At the end of a last-ditch visit to Washington today in which he received no assurance of help from the Federal Government, Gov. George E. Pataki set the stage for cutting as much as $2 billion more from his already beleaguered budget.

title: New York City to Resume Contract Talks With Teachers
description: The Giuliani administration agreed yesterday to resume negotiations on a new contract with New York City's teachers union, but city officials warned that any new offer would fall short of the five-year pact the teachers rejected last December.

title: Hawaii Doesn't Back Same-Sex Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Panel Approves Helmet Rule
description: A State Senate committee approved a bill yesterday that would require rollerbladers, roller skaters and skateboarders under the age of 14 to wear helmets. About 7,000 children are expected to suffer head injuries this year while engaged in these activities, said the measure's sponsor, Senator John A. Girgenti, Democrat of Hawthorne.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Payton Is Suspended
description: Guard GARY PAYTON of the Seattle SuperSonics has been suspended for one game without pay and fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association for head-butting Orlando's JOE WOLF during Wednesday night's game. The incident occurred with 8 minutes 46 seconds remaining in the fourth quarter of the Sonics' 100-99 victory. Payton will miss tonight's game against Dallas. (AP)

title: Changes Planned For Globex System
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the Paris futures exchange and Reuters Holdings P.L.C. said today that they had reached an agreement to extend and make changes in the electronic commodities-trading system that they operate jointly.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Chechen Rebels Battle Russian Forces in Grozny
description: Russian planes and artillery pounded the village of Bamut in the hills of western Chechnya today, and clashes were also reported in Grozny between Russian forces and separatists armed grenade-launchers and small arms.

title: Art in Review
description: Catherine Opie Jay Gorney Modern Art 100 Greene Street, near Prince Street SoHo Through March 30

title: Dole Courts Democrats
description: Touring in the Midwest, Senator Dole outlined his case against President Clinton and urged Democrats who strayed to Ronald Reagan in the 1980's to vote again for a Republican Presidential candidate.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Revenues at Oracle Rise 41%, But Profits Disappoint Analysts
