description: The Oracle Corporation reported third-quarter earnings that fell just below Wall Street analysts' estimates despite a 41 percent rise in revenues.

title: A House Panel Supports a Bill On Health Care
description: With a bipartisan spirit rarely seen in Congress these days, a House subcommittee today approved legislation that would guarantee health insurance coverage for millions of Americans who change jobs or lose their jobs each year.

title: Sinn Fein President Will March in St. Patrick's Day Parade
description: Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, will march in the St. Patrick's Day parade on Saturday, the first time he has taken part in the nation's largest celebration of Irish heritage.

title: I.R.S Revamping Disputed
description: Republican lawmakers threatened today to cut nearly $1 billion from the Internal Revenue Service's budget next year unless the agency corrected shortcomings in its ambitious modernization effort.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAIN CAPITAL PLANS TO BUY NEW ENGLAND NUCLEAR
description: Continuing its plan to sell its four medical-products businesses, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said yesterday that it would sell its New England Nuclear unit to Bain Capital Inc. Financial terms were not disclosed. The sale of New England Nuclear means Du Pont has one more unit to sell: Sorvall Centrifuges, a supplier of centrifuges and accessories. New England Nuclear, of Boston, makes radio-labeled compounds used in animal research by drug companies and has annual sales of about $100 million. It employs about 500 people worldwide. Bain Capital is a private equity investment firm.

title: G.M. Strike Closes Plant In Tarrytown
description: Ripples from the distant General Motors strike in Ohio finally reached here today when the company shut down its gargantuan assembly plant looming over the Hudson River. But given the uncommon predicament of the 2,000 workers, the shutdown was as much insult as injury.

title: U.S. Offers Ideas to Reduce Violence on Job
description: The Labor Department today issued guidelines intended to reduce workplace violence, which except for traffic accidents is now the leading cause of death on the job.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: WOMEN;Tennessee Gets a Big Boost: Ailing Holdsclaw May Play
description: Tennessee received some welcome news heading into the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament. Despite a potentially bad knee injury, Chamique Holdsclaw, its best scorer and rebounder, may be ready for a first-round game tomorrow night.

title: Market Place;Kmart's President Is Seen As a Force That May Save the Company
description: WHEN Warren Flick, president of the Kmart Corporation, talks about the state of the company when he came on board, he is like an angry father who just returned home from a business trip to discover his teen-ager has trashed the house.

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday, "New York City's Newest," incorrectly stated that Puerto Ricans and native-born blacks are leaving the city in proportionately larger numbers than whites. The City Planning Department says that about 18 percent of the city's Puerto Ricans and of its native-born whites left the city between 1985 and 1990. In the same period, 12 percent of native-born blacks left.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LEXINGTON CORPORATE PROPERTIES INC., New York, the real estate investment trust, agreed to acquire the headquarters of Northwest Pipeline Corp. in Salt Lake City for $57.6 million.

title: Today's Man Gets Funds
description: Today's Man Inc. said this week that a United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware had approved a $20 million financing plan that would insure that the men's clothing retailer could keep a fresh flow of new clothes on its racks. The financing comes from CIT Group/Business Credit Inc. Today's Man, based in Moorestown, N.J., filed for Chapter 11 protection under the United States Bankruptcy Code in February after unsuccessful talks to restructure its credit line.

title: Car Passenger Killed In Failed Robbery
description: A passenger in a car in downtown Brooklyn was fatally shot yesterday by a man who was trying to steal the driver's jewelry, the police said.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: EAST;UMass Hammers Back And Wins
description: For Massachusetts, the top-seeded team in the East Regional and the team ranked No. 1 in the nation, the opening-round game against Central Florida, one of two teams in the tournament with a losing record, was not supposed to be a particularly painful experience.

title: HORSE RACING;Training for a Race by Avoiding Races
description: Can a horse win the Florida Derby after running only twice in four months? For that matter, can the same horse win the Kentucky Derby after running only three times in six months?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Across Nation, Scores of Workers Affected
description: The General Motors Corporation and its outside suppliers have laid off tens of thousands of automobile parts workers across North America as a nine-day-old brake-factory strike here continues to cripple the world's largest auto maker.

title: History's Country Home
description: STRETCHED out listlessly along the Delaware River in eastern Pennsylvania, its arcadian landscape dabbed with pre-Revolutionary houses, close but not too close to New York City, Bucks County has always held an attraction for those with an artistic bent.

title: BOXING;King Claims Hard Work Helped Regain the Power
description: Mike Tyson's gaudy and often vilified promoter, Don King -- even "crucified," in his words -- is on the eve of becoming the most important noncombatant in American boxing. Again.

title: Havana Journal;Cuba's Home Cooking Hooks Tourists
description: From outside, they look much like all the other houses in their neighborhoods, distinguished only by flashing Christmas lights or a bright sign out front. But step into the living room, and suddenly you are face to face with one of the few manifestations of capitalism open to the average Cuban: a private, family-run restaurant.

title: Plea Pact Held Near For Talk Show Host
description: The financial radio talk show host Irwin (Sonny) Bloch is apparently close to a plea agreement with the United States Attorney's Office in Manhattan to settle Federal criminal charges of tax fraud, perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: Blow for Blow: Israelis Demolish Bomb-Maker's Family Home
description: The house of the man held responsible for seven terrorist attacks in Israel was blasted to rubble today, the latest measure in Israel's attempt to deter Palestinian militants from carrying out suicide bombings.

title: Homestake Bulgaria Deal
description: The Homestake Mining Company has exercised an option to buy up to 34 percent more of a gold and copper operation in Bulgaria from Navan Resources P.L.C. for $48 million. Homestake acquired the option last year when it invested $24 million for a 10 percent stake in Navan, an Irish mining company with mineral interests in Europe. Homestake will initially pay up to $12 million to Navan Bulgarian Mining B.V., the Navan unit that holds a 68 percent interest in the operation.

title: Scottish School Killer Had Stormy Past
description: For years, local politicians said today, they had been trying to get someone to do something about Thomas Hamilton.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: TENNIS;Fighting Backache, Graf Wears Down Davenport
description: Pushed to the limits of her physical endurance, Steffi Graf stubbornly exceeded them last night, but she needed 2 hours 44 minutes to claw her way into the final of the State Farm Evert Cup.

title: ART REVIEW;Little-Seen Examples of a Painter's Graphic Gifts
description: Until the retrospective of Pierre Bonnard (1867-1947) arrives at the Museum of Modern Art in the summer of 1998, this modest yet thoroughly satisfying exhibition of nearly 60 drawings and watercolors at the Wildenstein gallery provides a firm reminder of his greatness. In a somewhat piecemeal fashion, it covers much of his long career, featuring little-seen works from his estate. In the process, it underscores Bonnard's graphic gifts, so often overshadowed by the radiant, tapestrylike paintings of his maturity, those paradisiacal landscapes and scenes of domestic calm depicted in opalescent, sometimes riotous colors.

title: A SHAREHOLDER PRESSES UNISYS TO BREAK UP
description: One of the biggest shareholders of the Unisys Corporation is calling for the computer maker to split into three public companies. The proposal, made by Greenway Partners L. P., an asset-management firm controlling more than seven million Unisys shares, appears in the company's annual proxy statement, filed earlier with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Unisys management, responding in the proxy, said it opposes the idea. The company had 171.4 million shares outstanding as of Dec. 31, meaning Greenway and its affiliates hold a 4.95 percent stake. In late January, Unisys reorganized into three distinct business units: information services, computer systems and customer services. It is those three units that Greenway Partners is picking as a target in its spinoff proposal.

title: Sports of The Times;Earl Boykins Has Arrived On the Scene
description: NOT many people knew Earl Boykins existed when they opened the revolving high-pressure doors to the domed stadium. With Connecticut and Duke and U.C.L.A. coming to town, who knew about a little man who wears Isiah Thomas's number and Isiah Thomas's killer smile?

title: BASKETBALL;Abdul-Rauf's Plan: Stand, Pray and Play
description: Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf reached a compromise with the National Basketball Association yesterday, apparently without compromising his personal beliefs. As a result, his two-day-old suspension for refusing on religious grounds to stand during the national anthem is over.

title: FILM REVIEW;Who's on Third? A Chimp?
description: One thing you can say for Ed, a chimpanzee whose baseball-playing expertise propels the Rockets, a minor-league team, to glory: his behavior is a lot more human than any of the other characters in this flimsy, laugh-free family comedy. Brought to the Rockets as a mascot, Ed ascends to third baseman once he has demonstrated his formidable fielding skills. In his first professional game, he wows the crowd by executing a spectacular triple play. Overnight, his hairy mug graces the cover of Sports Illustrated.

title: More Journalists Jailed, but Fewer Are Killed
description: Journalists were imprisoned in record numbers around the world last year, according to an annual survey released yesterday in Washington.

title: Art in Review
description: Valerie Jaudon Sidney Janis Gallery 110 West 57th Street Manhattan Through March 23

title: Mideast Peace Process Isolates the Fanatics
description: To the Editor:

title: Macromedia in Deal To Acquire Iband
description: Macromedia said this week that it was acquiring Iband Inc., a developer of Internet Website development tools in a stock deal valued at $32 million.

title: Now, Eat Your Artificial Flavors, Sonny!
description: A new study suggests that health-food enthusiasts may have it all wrong, and that artificial flavorings that have become a staple of junk foods -- from barbecue potato chips to caramel candy to cinnamon chewing gum -- may actually be good for people.

title: Slogan for Many Chinese: Make Money, Not War
description: War?" exclaimed the 45-year-old waitress standing in the doorway of a sidewalk cafe facing the southern gate of Tiananmen Square. "What on earth are you talking about?"

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Advertising;Selling the nonmusical Sondheim/Furth play is a tricky business.
description: STEPHEN SONDHEIM loves solving puzzles as much as he loves writing songs for musicals like "Follies" and "Into the Woods." Here is a puzzle that might confound even Mr. Sondheim: How do you sell a Sondheim show that is missing what his mentor, Oscar Hammerstein 2d, would call the sound of music?

title: Alfred P. Slaner, 77, Developer Of Supp-Hose Hosiery, Is Dead
description: Alfred P. Slaner, a well-connected corporate executive and philanthropist who made the best of both sides of his family tree, died yesterday at a nursing home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 77 and is recalled, among other things, as the man who developed Supp-Hose.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Boston U. Player Tells of Ordeal
description: TRAVIS ROY broke into tears yesterday as he described trying to get off the ice after crashing headlong into the boards in his first shift in his first game as a Boston University hockey player.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: WEST;Drexel Floors Memphis in Day's First Upset
description: Drexel grows them bigger than you think.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Who Exactly Is This Sexagenarian Sex Kitten?
description: LOVE, AGAIN By Doris Lessing 352 pages. HarperCollins. $24.

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Dole Appeals to 'Reagan Democrats'
description: The Republican field now all but clear, Senator Bob Dole turned his attention today to the general election in November, laying out a case against President Clinton and explicitly urging Democrats who strayed to Ronald Reagan in the 1980's to vote again for a Republican Presidential candidate.

title: POLITICS: BOWING OUT;Forbes Quits And Offers His Support To Dole
description: Steve Forbes formally folded his Presidential campaign, threw his support behind Senator Bob Dole and vowed today that he would remain on the public stage to promote the flat tax and other upbeat, supply-side ideas.

title: House Passes Narrow Counterterrorism Bill Unlike Senate's
description: The House of Representatives today approved a slimmed-down counterterrorism bill, forwarding it to an uncertain fate as Democrat and Republican leaders alike predicted it would be difficult to reconcile with a far broader measure that sailed through the Senate last year.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Bank Posts Rise Of 7.7% in 1995 Profit
description: Banque Nationale de Paris said yesterday that its profit rose 7.7 percent in 1995 as cost-cutting and reduced provisions for risky loans offset a fall in income from securities trading. The company, also known as BNP, posted profit of 1.78 billion francs, or about $356 million.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stock prices were higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 267.19 points, or 1.34 percent, at 20,190.85. On Thursday, the Nikkei advanced 188.96 points, or nearly 1 percent.

title: Stopgap Bill Wins Passage, Averting A Shutdown
description: Averting the third partial shutdown of the Government in less than six months, Congress tonight passed a one-week extension of a temporary spending measure, due to expire at midnight on Friday, that has kept nearly a third of Government agencies operating.

title: Traffic Jam Clogs AT&T's Information Highway
description: If you wanted to get on the information highway today via AT&T, you first had to drive along Route 202 to a jam-packed parking lot in this Central Jersey town.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TBC TO PURCHASE BIG O TIRES FOR $56 MILLION
description: The TBC Corporation reached a preliminary agreement yesterday to acquire Big O Tires Inc. for $16.50 a share, or about $56 million. Big O, a tire retailer, also said it had terminated its agreement to be acquired by Boti Holdings Inc., a management group, for the same $16.50-a-share price. The agreement with TBC, a marketer and distributor of automotive products, is subject to certain price reductions based on transaction costs and other expenses. Big O said that a material adjustment was unlikely as a result of the costs. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Big O rose $1.4375, to $15.25.

title: Credit-Card Delinquencies Rise; Price Report Shows No Inflation
description: The ranks of consumers who have fallen behind on credit-card payments edged up to match a 10-year high in the final quarter of 1995, a sign of growing household distress that some economists argue threatens to bring the five-year-old economic expansion to an end.

title: Executive Changes
description: BEAR, STEARNS & COS., New York, named Alan Mnuchin and Michael Yagemann to head its media and entertainment group. Mr. Mnuchin joins the firm as a senior managing director from Goldman, Sachs, while Mr. Yagemann, a senior managing director who has been with Bear, Stearns for six years, will relocate to New York from Los Angeles.

title: Art in Review
description: Rachel Harrison Arena Gallery 313 Clinton Street (near DeGraw Street) Brooklyn Heights Through March 31

title: A. C. Barger, Physiologist, Is Dead at 79
description: Dr. A. Clifford Barger, professor emeritus of physiology at the Harvard Medical School, who helped identify the bodily processes that can lead to congestive heart failure, died on Wednesday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 79.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Transfer of Commands Sought
description: Two Democratic New Jersey Congressmen, Frank Pallone Jr. of Long Branch and Robert Menendez of Bayonne urged their colleagues yesterday to order two operations at the Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne to be transferred 42 miles away to Fort Monmouth.

title: Supai Journal;Flooding Tests a Village's Endurance
description: Living in the maw of the Seventh Natural Wonder of the World for at least 600 years, the Havasupai people of the Grand Canyon have never had any great incentive to take up residence elsewhere.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: TV SPORTS;A Hot and Cold Team Tricky for CBS Bosses
description: You had to worry about George Raveling. As he called yesterday's first-round Kentucky-San Jose State men's tournament game, Raveling, the former Southern California coach, raved and shouted.

title: Art in Review
description: Andrew Masullo Andre Emmerich Gallery 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through March 30

title: Major and Minor Players in Place, Historic Whitewater TrialUnderwhelms Little Rock
description: One of the side trips of the Whitewater investigation is being played out in a Federal courtroom here as Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas and two former business partners of President Clinton stand trial on conspiracy and fraud charges growing out of a separate series of bank loans and real estate transactions a decade ago.

title: The Arts Go Back to School
description: There are millions of Americans who know what it is to have a public school art teacher treat them to slide shows, guide them through a few museums and show them the difference between, say, Cubism and Impressionism. They know about music teachers, too, who teach them to play instruments and give them their first hearings of Chopin and Brahms. Some even know what it is to have a dance teacher who tries to drum a few Martha Graham moves into their feet.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;True North Appoints 2 Top Executives
description: True North Communications in Chicago, which owns agencies including Foote, Cone & Belding, promoted two top executives yesterday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Report Assails School District
description: The Atlantic City school district spends three times more on administrative costs than other comparable districts in New Jersey and often hires people who are well-connected rather than qualified for the job, an interagency task force said in a report issued yesterday by State Treasurer Brian W. Clymer.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HILTON AND LADBROKE DISCUSSING ALLIANCE
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation and Britain's Ladbroke Group P.L.C., competing holders of the renowned Hilton name, have been talking about ways to work together. "We have had talks with Ladbroke regarding ways in which we can enhance the Hilton brand," said a Hilton spokesman, Marc Grossman. He said the discussions had increased since Stephen Bollenbach became Hilton's president and chief executive last month. Hilton gave up its right to use the name abroad when it spun off the international operations in 1964. Ladbroke acquired the company in 1987. Hilton's stock rose $1 yesterday, to $92.50.

title: State Rules Out Manslaughter In Lodi Chemical Plant Blast
description: New Jersey authorities today ruled out filing manslaughter charges against officials of the aging chemical plant that exploded in Lodi last April 21, killing five workers as they unloaded volatile chemicals from a vat.

title: FILM REVIEW;Adventures of an Englishman Fighting Fascists in Spain
description: Land and Freedom" was shown as part of the 1995 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 6. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, 63d Street and Broadway in Manhattan.

title: Hawaii Doesn't Back Same-Sex Marriage;Options to Loneliness
description: To the Editor:

title: Agent Orange May Be Tied To Birth Flaw
description: The exposure of Vietnam veterans to Agent Orange and other herbicides has been tentatively linked to an increased risk of spina bifida in their children, according to a report by the Institute of Medicine released today.

title: Custodial Helper Overtime Is Faulted by Comptroller
description: The Board of Education routinely paid some school custodial helpers for enough overtime to double or triple their salaries in 1994, for a total of $31 million, without ever questioning the payments, according to an audit released yesterday by City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi.

title: A DEAL IS REACHED ON LINE-ITEM VETO WITH DOLE'S HELP
description: Prodded by Senator Bob Dole, Congressional Republicans ended a nearly yearlong stalemate and agreed today on a version of the line-item veto for the President.

title: No Headline
description: Senator Dole said he wanted it done."

title: FILM REVIEW;Literally and Figuratively, Unclothing a Dreamboat
description: Heaven forbid that the centerfold models and beauty contestants who inflame our erotic fantasies turn out not to be who we imagine they are. If they are in fact impostors, what's left to believe in?

title: Two Sisters' Beaus Are Just One Guy
description: Modesty has not forbidden Fernando Trueba, whose Academy Award-winning "Belle Epoque" invoked the work of Jean Renoir, from comparing his first American comedy to the films of Preston Sturges and Billy Wilder. Mr. Trueba, a former film critic in his native Spain, has modeled this leaden trifle on classic screwball farce, but changing times mean different personnel. And how.

title: Iona Is Ousted From N.I.T.
description: Mark Bass scored 22 points and Dmitri Domani added 21 as St. Joseph's beat Iona, 82-78, tonight in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Man Charged With Killing Wife
description: On Wednesday night, the police said, Marco Luciano, 33, violated a court order of protection and went to his wife's apartment in Woodside, Queens, and in the course of an argument, fatally stabbed her.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KULICKE & SOFFA SHARES HIT BY EARNINGS ESTIMATES
description: The stock of Kulicke & Soffa Industries fell yesterday after the company, a maker of semiconductor assembly equipment, said that its second-quarter and year-end results would be below Wall Street's expectations. Kulicke said earnings for the third and fourth quarters were also expected to be significantly lower than the corresponding periods a year earlier. Kulicke expects earnings for the second quarter ending March 31 to be comparable to the 44 cents a share reported in the period a year ago. A First Call Inc. consensus estimate put earnings for the period at 66 cents a share. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Kulicke & Soffa fell $3, to $15.75.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FUQUA ENTERPRISES TO BUY LUMEX MEDICAL UNIT
description: Fuqua Enterprises Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Lumex medical products division of Lumex Inc. for $40.75 million in cash. Fuqua, based in Atlanta, said that the deal was part of its effort to become a major provider of medical products, a business it entered in November with the purchase of Basic American Medical Products. Separately, Lumex said the sale was part of its strategy announced in December to focus on its Cybex worldwide institutional fitness and rehabilitation business. Lumex, based in Bay Shore, L.I., markets a wide range of health care products. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of Fuqua rose 25 cents, to $23.875. On the American Stock Exchange, Lumex rose 62.5 cents, to $13.125.

title: With Record Speed, F.D.A. Approves a New AIDS Drug
description: Acting faster than ever before to allow the marketing of a drug, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the third in a new class of medications that attack the AIDS virus.

title: Restaurants
description: Most chefs don't mess with success. When they have a restaurant that pleases the public, they tend to let well enough alone.

title: CLINTON, IN ISRAEL, STRESSES SUPPORT FOR PEACE EFFORT
description: By turns politician, preacher and professor, President Clinton raced from the peak of Mount Herzl here to the heart of coastal Tel Aviv today to convince Israelis that the United States stood squarely behind them and their endangered peace.

title: TV WEEKEND;The Goddesses, the Femmes Fatales, the Dames
description: The subtitle of "The Good, the Bad and the Beautiful" is "Women in the Movies." Less obviously, the two-hour documentary, made in association with Women in Film, is also about women in television. Most of the production credits go to women, including Jacoba Atlas as executive producer and Kyra Thompson as senior producer and writer. And all of the commentary within the film comes from women. Much is made of the modern woman's quest for power. One impressive measure of her success is this splendid documentary.

title: On My Mind;Sharm el-Sheik Reality
description: It would take a heart of stone not to be moved with hope at the sight of the presidents, prime ministers and kings gathered at Sharm el-Sheik to denounce Hamas terrorism. Yes, and it would take a brain of mush not to see that the conference evaded major realities of fighting Hamas terrorism, and created a new one.

title: Senate Votes to Withhold Some Bosnia Aid Until Iranians Leave
description: The Senate has voted in favor of a measure sponsored by the majority leader, Bob Dole, to withhold $200 million in civilian aid to the Bosnian Government until Iranian military and intelligence personnel leave the country.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RICKEL HOME CENTERS PLANS TO CLOSE 13 MORE STORES
description: Rickel Home Centers Inc. said yesterday that it would close 13 stores by July, bringing the total number of closings to 26 stores since late 1995. After the closings, Rickel, a retailer of home improvement products, will operate 66 stores in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York and Delaware. Rickel filed for protection from creditors under bankruptcy law on Jan. 10. The company has been battered by competitors, particularly The Home Depot Inc. The store closings are subject to United States Bankruptcy Court approval.

title: Art in Review
description: John Lees Hirschl & Adler Modern 21 East 70th Street Manhattan Through March 23

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Real Contest This Time

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Republicans Agree on Plan For a Line-Item Veto Congressional Republicans agreed on a version of a line-item veto for the President that would shift much of the power of the purse from Congress to the White House. It would give the President the power to remove items from spending bills one by one, without vetoing or approving the measure as a whole.

title: Mother Charged With Killing 17-Month-Old Girl
description: A Bronx woman was charged with killing her 17-month-old daughter after the police went to the woman's apartment and found the child seriously injured and unconscious, investigators said yesterday.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Clockers 1995. MCA/Univarsal. $100.71. Laser disk, $39.98. 129 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BASF Plans to Buy A Japanese Drug Maker
description: The German chemical company BASF A.G. said yesterday that it planned to buy 51 percent of the Japanese drug company Hokuriku Seiyaku for 500 million marks, or about $340 million. The move would give BASF a foothold in Japan, the world's second-biggest drug market.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Little Change In Bond Prices
description: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, paring back earlier gains made after a Government report showed no mounting price pressures in the economy.

title: Diner's Journal
description: When the new Michelin ratings were released last week, Paris had lost a venerable three-star restaurant, Tour d'Argent, and gained a new one, Arpege.

title: A Former Gruntal Trader Is Found Guilty
description: A former trader at Gruntal & Company was convicted yesterday of paying kickbacks to a Keystone Group portfolio manager to win Keystone's junk-bond trading business.

title: Albany to Computerize Campaign Finance Records
description: After years of resistance, legislative leaders agreed today to put the state's campaign finance records on computer, doing away with an antiquated, paper-choked system that often made it hard for the public to learn who had given money to political candidates.

title: Noble Drilling To Buy Dutch Oil Explorer
description: The Noble Drilling Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Neddrill oil- and gas-exploration unit of the Royal Nedlloyd Group of the Netherlands for about $350 million. The deal would create one of the world's largest drilling contractors and oil-service companies.

title: New Federal Rule Helps Intensify Smoking Fight in States
description: Spurred by new Federal regulations requiring states to discourage teen-agers from smoking, tobacco companies and smoking opponents are battling fiercely over a wide range of proposed state laws affecting the marketing, sale and use of tobacco.

title: Einstein Manuscript Is Going, Going. . .
description: In 1912, Albert Einstein crossed out an L in his notes and made scientific history. Tomorrow, the 72-page manuscript in which he rendered - and revised - his particular theory of relativity is expected to bring between $4 million and $6 million in an auction at Sotheby's Article, page B1.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;McGwire Out 2 Weeks
description: MARK McGWIRE will have to stay off his right foot for two weeks after tearing connective tissue, a team doctor said yesterday. The Oakland Athletics' slugger, who hurt his foot Tuesday in an exhibition game, was examined by the team orthopedist JERRALD GOLDMAN. The foot will be re-examined in two weeks. Goldman said the injury was similar to one to the first baseman's left foot that forced McGwire to miss the final two months of the 1994 season. (AP)

title: Inside Art
description: A Merry Old Sale

title: POLITICS;Rostenkowski Wins on 4 Counts
description: A Federal judge threw out 4 of the 17 charges this week in the political corruption case against former Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois.

title: In Search of New Commodities;U.S. Futures Exchanges Try to Regain Lost Ground
description: When Wall Street swooned last Friday, worried investment managers sought cover here, where the nation's largest futures exchanges give them an opportunity to hedge their risks.

title: Chelsea Fire Snarls Traffic
description: A two-alarm fire in a commercial building in Chelsea snarled traffic on the West Side of Manhattan during the evening rush yesterday, the police said. No one was injured.

title: INSIDE
description: Smoking and the States

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A City Flattered by Imitation
description: To officials of Ocean City, there is something awfully familiar about the new slogan the state of Pennsylvania plans to use to promote tourism this summer: "Pennsylvania Memories Last a Lifetime."

title: Federal Judge Curbs Law On Sex-Offense Disclosure
description: A Federal District judge in Newark has temporarily barred all 21 prosecutors in New Jersey from notifying schools and other institutions of the whereabouts of convicted sex offenders who have served their sentences but are still considered dangerous.

title: Sit-In Is Stalling Budget Vote in Japan
description: If the popular image of Japanese politicians is of boring men in suits nodding soberly at stultifying speeches, a visit to Parliament these days is likely to open people's eyes.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACE LTD. IN ACCORD ON TAKEOVER OF BERMUDA CONCERN
description: Ace Ltd. reached a definitive agreement yesterday for its previously announced $600 million acquisition of the Tempest Reinsurance Company of Bermuda for common shares. Ace said the number of shares it would issue would be based on the average closing price of the shares for a defined period before the deal closed. If the average share price is $45 or more, Ace Ltd. will issue about 13.3 million shares. If the price is between $33 and $45, the number of shares will be calculated by dividing $600 million by the average share price. If the average share price is $33 or lower, Ace Ltd. will issue about 18.2 million shares.

title: Family Feud in Albany
description: What is it about governors and lieutenant governors in New York? Recent history is replete with their feuds and slights. Now the relationship between Lieut. Gov. Elizabeth McCaughey Ross and Gov. George Pataki has deteriorated so badly that Mr. Pataki is allowing her state trooper detail to be withdrawn. Ms. McCaughey Ross is not in any danger, the Governor's office says. But as a gesture, withdrawing the security escort lacks a certain subtlety. The way things are going, Ms. McCaughey Ross may show up in her office one day like Ingrid Bergman in "Gaslight" and find the door locked.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MEDAPHIS ADDING BSG FOR 7.5 MILLION SHARES
description: The Medaphis Corporation, the biggest medical business services company in the nation, agreed yesterday to acquire the BSG Corporation for about 7.5 million shares of stock. Medaphis stock soared after the deal was announced, rising $4.75, to $44, in Nasdaq trading. At that price the deal is worth $330 million. Medaphis, based in Atlanta, will also assume BSG stock options and stock rights representing an additional 2.66 million shares of Medaphis common stock, worth about $109 million. BSG provides a wide range of computer technology.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: SOUTHEAST;Temple's Defense Wraps Up Oklahoma
description: Oklahoma certainly missed its share of shots against Temple's bump-and-grind defense in the first half. The Sooners blew 17 of 27 floor shots in the half but left with hope; they trailed by only 30-24.

title: SHOOTOUT IN THE BRONX: THE OVERVIEW;3 Men Held in Killing of Officer, Bringing Calls for Death Penalty
description: Three Bronx men, all with long records for armed robbery and other crimes and all under the supervision of parole officers, have been arrested in the killing of the New York City police officer who died in a wild shooting spree along the Grand Concourse on Thursday night.

title: Crackdown on Marijuana Users Fits the Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudanese Vote, Sourly, as Islamic Fervor Chafes
description: Like many northern Sudanese, Siddiq Sidahmed Hassan considers himself a good Muslim. He favors traditional flowing Arab clothes, as white as pure faith, and prostrates himself to Mecca five times a day without fail.

title: Officer's Credibility Is Key For Judge Rehearing Case
description: After Carol Bayless, a suspected drug courier, took the witness stand yesterday, Judge Harold Baer Jr. turned to her and said, "Think of all this activity you and I have generated." Everyone laughed, but the truth of the judge's quip resonated in the standing-room-only courtroom.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALBANK FINANCIAL REJECTION OF BID LIFTS STOCK
description: The shares of the Albank Financial Corporation rose yesterday after the company rejected an offer from the Trustco Bank Corporation. The takeover bid, which could have been worth more than $467 million, was made on March 8. Trustco announced the offer late on Thursday. Albank's stock closed up $1.875, to $26.875, in Nasdaq trading after reaching $28.875, a new 52-week high. "The net bottom line is Albank is not for sale, and if Albank were for sale it would not be to Trustco," said Herbert Chorbajian, chairman of the Albany-based banking company. Trustco, based in Schenedctady, has 47 branches, all in the Albany area. Albank, with nearly $3.5 billion in assets, has 47 branches in New York, 9 in Massachusetts and 7 in Vermont.

title: Dale Harris, Arts Lecturer And Critic, 67
description: Dale Harris, a writer and lecturer on dance, music, art and literature, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;School Security Chief Arrested
description: Curly M. Ferguson, the chief of security for the Atlantic City school system, was arrested and charged in the theft of more than $100,000 from the Board of Education since he was hired two years ago, prosecutors said yesterday. Mr. Ferguson, 52, is charged with theft by deception and official misconduct for authorizing fraudulent payments to subordinates and accepting kickbacks, the Atlantic County Prosecutor, Jeffrey S. Blitz, said. Mr. Blitz would not say whether anyone else was involved in the theft.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: COMPANY NEWS;LIMITED COMPLETES TENDER OFFER FOR 85 MILLION SHARES
description: Limited Inc. said yesterday that it had completed its tender offer to buy back up to 85 million shares for a total of $1.61 billion. The $19-a-share buyback was intended to return cash to shareholders from the $680 million initial sale of stock in its Intimate Brands Inc. and the sale of its credit-card bank unit last year. Limited said the tender offer, which expired on March 6, was oversubscribed. It said about 185.9 million shares were tendered, including 428,525 shares held by odd-lot shareholders. Limited said it would purchase all shares tendered by odd-lot holders. The company operates Limited, Express, Structure and Abercrombie & Fitch stores.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;G.I. on Patrol in Bosnia Shot by Intruder at Camp
description: An American soldier was shot and wounded in the left shoulder today after challenging an intruder at a base in the American-monitored sector of northern Bosnia.

title: Clinton Plays Politics In Minority Contracts
description: To the Editor:

title: Charity Official Says He Embezzled
description: The former executive director of the American Parkinson Disease Association, which raises funds for research, pleaded guilty in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday to embezzling more than $1 million in contributions.

title: Toward Talks in Ireland
description: In the next two weeks politicians on both sides of the Irish Sea will be making crucial decisions for Ireland's future. John Major's British Government, in consultation with its Irish counterparts, will decide how to conduct elections for the participants in all-party talks on the future of Northern Ireland. The agenda and the timetable for the talks must be set. The ultimate goal should be to create an inclusive forum and to pull the Irish Republican Army back into civilized political dialogue.

title: POLITICS: OHIO -- AN AMERICAN PLACE -- Where Party Loyalty Reigns;Though G.O.P. Is Hot, It's Lukewarm for Dole
description: Patrick A. DeOrio, an insurance salesman, is at the heart of the Republican Party establishment here. He is a Republican state committeeman, a Republican member of the county Board of Elections, has been to the Republican Party's school on polling and has given up many of his nights to run phone banks out of local insurance offices on behalf of Republican candidates. Last year he was the Stark County Republican volunteer of the year.

title: New Jersey's Tax Cuts Have Worked
description: States around the country are cutting taxes, and no state has received more attention than New Jersey, where Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's income tax cuts have made her a rising Republican star. But because all states pass most of their revenues back to local governments, critics say that states' cuts will force local property taxes to rise -- leaving taxpayers no better off.

title: William Douglas, 42, a Choreographer
description: William Douglas, a modern dancer and choreographer, died on March 10 at a hospital in Montreal. He was 42 and lived in Montreal.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Asian Group Buys 20% of Brierley
description: Brierley Investments Ltd. of New Zealand gained its biggest shareholder since its founder, Ron Brierley, cut his holdings in the 1970's and 1980's. An Asian investment group bought a 20 percent stake for up to $680 million (New Zealand), or $468 million (United States). The group, Delham Investments, paid a premium for the stake. Delham consists of Hong Leong companies in Malaysia and Singapore, the Indonesia-based Salim Group, and the Sembawang Corporation and Haw Par Brothers International Ltd. of Singapore.

title: Proof Isn't Final on Foster Care's Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;World Trade Center for Sale?
description: Joseph V. Doria Jr., the Assembly minority leader, is signaling his support for selling off assets and functions of the Port Authority that are not directly linked to transportation or port services. Among the recommendations in a resolution introduced this week by Mr. Doria, a Bayonne Democrat, is the sale of the World Trade Center, Joe Donnelly, a spokesman for the Assembly Democrats, said yesterday. A spokesman for the Port Authority would not comment on the Doria resolution. JOE SHARKEY

title: TENNIS;Haarhuis, Ranked 68th, Defeats Sampras
description: Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi both missed a chance to grab the No. 1 ranking today when they failed to brave perfect desert conditions and bowed out in the quarterfinals of the Newsweek Champions Cup.

title: Crackdown on Marijuana Users Fits the Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hoechst Clarifies Report
description: Hoechst A.G. said yesterday that a report that it was planning to separate its chemical and drug businesses was an "overinterpretation" of comments made by the company's chairman on Thursday. Hoechst said an article in The Financial Times yesterday did not correctly reflect the comments by the chairman, Jurgen Dormann. The Financial Times said that Hoechst, Germany's largest chemical company, planned the separation in an attempt to give better value to shareholders. A Hoechst spokesman said that separating the chemicals and drugs businesses was one of many options. Reuters

title: Russian Parliament Denounces Soviet Union's Breakup
description: In its most direct challenge yet to the authority of President Boris N. Yeltsin, Parliament voted overwhelmingly today to denounce the 1991 accord that led to the dissolution of the Soviet Union.

title: 3 Young Dancers and How They Did It
description: Jason Jordan had something other than free ballet classes in mind when he showed up for auditions held by the New Ballet School eight years ago at P.S. 29 in Brooklyn. "Most of the guys did it to get out of school," Mr. Jordan, now 17 years old, admitted with a broad grin. Now he is a promising young professional dancer whose airborne jump and easy, innate sense of classicism may be seen in performances by the Feld Ballets/NY, which will be at the Joyce Theater through March 31.

title: Astronomers Say New Comet May Be Brightest in Decades
description: A newly discovered comet has appeared in the sky, and astronomers say it may become the brightest one in two decades.

title: State Trooper Accuses Newspaper in Syracuse of Libel
description: A former New York State Police lieutenant has sued The Syracuse Post-Standard for libel, saying the newspaper unfairly linked him to an evidence-tampering scandal involving troopers that he supervised.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Tuesday's Democratic primary in the Fifth Congressional District in Chicago misstated Dan Rostenkowski's length of service there in some editions. Mr. Rostenkowski was seeking a 19th term in 1994 when he was indicted on corruption charges and the Democratic stronghold fell into Republican hands that year.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Library Moves for Renovation
description: Remember hauling those cartons of books the last time you moved? Consider the staff and volunteers of the Montclair Library, which has to pack and move 160,000 books after it closes its doors tomorrow for a 14-month, $6.3 million renovation. 'We've got our roller skates on," said Caroline Fannin, who is coordinating the move. A smaller branch on Bellevue Avenue will remain open, and by mid-April the library will have a temporary base at the Y.W.C.A. on Glenridge Avenue.

title: Chief Executive Removed At Troubled Greystone
description: With charges of mismanagement mounting at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital over abuse of patients and lax security, the state removed George A. Waters Jr. from his post as the hospital's chief executive officer.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FEDERAL PAPER SHAREHOLDERS AGREE TO PAYYMENT PLAN
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that about 73 percent of the shareholders of the Federal Paper Board Company had had chosen a stock payment in the recently completed $2.7 billion merger between the two companies. International Paper, a paper and packaging products company, said owners of about 34.9 million of the 47.8 million shares of Federal Paper chose to receive International Paper stock. Those holders will get 1.013 International Paper shares and $16.68 in cash for each of their shares. Holders of about 11.28 million Federal Paper shares elected to receive cash and will get $55 in cash for each of their shares. Federal Paper shareholders who did not make a selection will also get $55 in cash.

title: Pataki's New Budget Proposal Puts Giuliani's Plans on Hold
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's new budget proposal threw New York City's budget into disarray yesterday, offering a tiny flicker of hope for new state aid but raising the far more likely possibility that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will receive less than he has said he needs to close the city's $2 billion shortfall.

title: Promus Bids for 28 Hotels
description: The Promus Hotel Corporation has made a cash offer of $147.4 million to purchase 28 Hampton Inn hotels primarily in the Southeast and Midwest. Of those hotels, which are owned by two hotel investment groups, 19 are managed by Promus. The offer was made to the partners in Growth Hotel Investors and Growth Hotel Investors II of Greenville, S.C., Promus said.

title: Jet Skis vs. Peace on Islands in Battle of San Juan County
description: Over the last decade, the drone of Jet Skis, Wave Runners and other high-powered wet bikes has come to virtually every waterway in the United States, bringing with it a conflict that may be the recreational equivalent of smoking versus nonsmoking in public spaces.

title: Keep Neighborhood Defender Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about a new type of computer floppy disk misstated the data capacity of the original 3 1/2-inch floppy used with the first Apple Macintosh. That disk had a capacity of 400 kilobytes -- not 720 kilobytes. Later versions had capacities of 720 kilobytes, 1,000 kilobytes, and, ultimately, 1,400 kilobytes -- or 1.4 megabytes.

title: 2 BUILDERS CHOSEN FOR SPEEDY TRAINS ON NORTHEAST RUN
description: Taking a decisive step in its ambitious plans to upgrade train service in the Northeast and give the airlines a run for their money, Amtrak today chose the contractors to build a $611 million fleet of "American Flyers" that would cut the time of train service between Washington and Boston by two hours.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bradley to Address Forum
description: Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat, who has decided not to seek re-election, will hold a forum at Rutgers University on Monday with citizens groups to examine ideas for changing the way American political campaigns are financed. "It couldn't get higher priority from him," Mr. Bradley's spokeswoman, Vicki Streitfeld, said. Among the groups scheduled to participate are the League of Women Voters, United We Stand America and the Council of Black Churches.

title: Crackdown on Marijuana Users Fits the Crime;Baghdad Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Established Designers Rise in London
description: LONDON  London fashion is all about the thrill of subversive trends and an exhilarating clash of future stars in the making. This season, however, despite the madcap antics of several budding Gallianos and Westwoods, the city's fashion pace is being set by a more sedate bunch of well-established designers who stand resolutely above the fray.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Confident, Playful Rhythms
description: Leon Parker has quietly built a reputation for being one of the finest jazz musicians of his generation. At Bradley's, where he'll be through tonight, the young drummer showed why. Mr. Parker has a natural way with music, and the way he articulates the passing of the time makes the music feel good. He's assured rhythmically, and playful, and he has developed a group concept.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Post Says Operating Profit Rose
description: Deutsche Post A.G., the state-owned postal service, which plans to sell shares in 1998, said yesterday that its operating profit rose 40 percent in 1995. "Despite a high volume of investment, we expect a further improvement in operating profit this year," Klaus Zumwinkel, chief executive of Deutsche Post, said yesterday. Deutsche Post still wants to buy a 40 percent stake in Postbank along with a group led by Deutsche Bank A.G. and Swiss Reinsurance, Mr. Zumwinkel said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BHC FINANCIAL'S ISSUES SLIDE ON INFORMAL NOTICE OF CUTS
description: The stock of BHC Financial Inc. tumbled almost 30 percent yesterday after the company said it had received "unofficial oral notice" that its largest client, Citicorp Investment Services Inc., planned to do its own securities processing. BHC Financial, based in Philadelphia, said it expected its agreement with Citicorp Investment to end early in the fourth quarter of 1996. The company also said another large undisclosed client had given informal notice of its intent to end its agreement in the third quarter of 1996.

title: Prices of Treasuries Retreat for a Fourth Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the fourth time this week as concerns grew over the faster pace of economic growth.

title: Major Visits Site of Killing Of Children In Scotland
description: As families of the 16 children slain here on Wednesday made funeral preparations, Prime Minister John Major and his chief political opponent, Tony Blair, arrived today to talk to parents, children, teachers and doctors, and to visit the school gymnasium where the killings took place.

title: About New York;In the Light, A Streetscape Comes to Life
description: RHODA ROSS wasted little time when she arrived in New York in 1967 eager to start her painting career. She went straight to the top.

title: Defendant in Clinic Shootings Portrayed as 'Terrorist' and 'Sick Man'
description: In closing arguments today, the prosecution urged jurors to focus closely on what John C. Salvi 3d did when he killed two women and wounded five other people at two abortion clinics and to keep him from "getting away with murder."

title: BASEBALL;A Shutout Streak Stays Intact
description: Statistically speaking, Paul Wilson can't pitch much better than he has this spring. Five shutout innings against the Baltimore Orioles tonight gave the Mets pitcher 14 scoreless innings for the spring, raising expectations that were already lofty.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about the life of the boxer Shannon Briggs misidentified the person Briggs called his stepfather, who was convicted of manslaughter and died in prison. The stepfather was Gene Priest, not Willis McDonald, who is Briggs's biological father.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;World Bank Moves to Cut Poorest Nations' Debts
description: The World Bank has offered to reinvest part of its $1.3 billion annual surplus in a new trust fund that would be set up to reduce the debts of the world's poorest nations.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;3 Ministers Are Linked To Graft in Colombia
description: Three ministers in the Cabinet of President Ernesto Samper were linked today by prosecutors to an investigation into the financing of Mr. Samper's 1994 campaign.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Snowball Tosser Cries Foul
description: He's become this Joey Buttafuoco-like villain," Robert Ballard Jr., a lawyer for Jeffrey Lange, the Giants Stadium snowball-tosser, said yesterday. But Mr. Lange, 26, now hopes to score from the Giants and the State Sports and Exposition Authority with a lawsuit seeking damages for being vilified after a Dec. 23 snowball-throwing melee by Giants fans.

title: John A. Berrill, Cartoonist, 72
description: John A. (Jack) Berrill, a cartoonist who produced the comic strip "Gil Thorp," died on Thursday at his home. He was 72.

title: Agreement Reached In Cable TV Deal
description: General Communications Inc. said today that it had reached agreements to acquire three Alaskan cable companies for $280.7 million in cash, common stock, a note and assumed debt.

title: BOXING;In Night of a Fallen Heavyweight, Briggs Sustains His First Defeat
description: This was supposed to be Shannon Briggs's night to prove that he belonged among the elite heavyweights. Instead, it was the night the previously unbeaten -- but untested -- Brooklyn fighter fell to earth. Hard.

title: Zimbabwe President's Last Rival Withdraws From Election
description: Zimbabwe's presidential election turned into a non-contest for President Robert Mugabe today when the last of his opponents withdrew from the race one day before voting was to begin.

title: Car Dealers Are Said to Pad Buyers' Costs
description: Car dealers in New York State overcharged at least 50,000 customers by about $1 million in registration and title fees in the last two years, Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco said yesterday.

title: Craig Logan, Jackson Interior Designer, 45
description: Craig Logan Jackson, an interior designer best known for the innovative D. F. Sanders & Company housewares stores in the 1980's, died on Thursday at Tisch Hospital of New York University Medical Center. He was 45 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, misstated his organization's connection to recent terrorist bombings in England. The Irish Republican Army -- not Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing -- has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

title: Testimony Differs Widely on Subway Shooting of Officer
description: Two transit police officers gave conflicting accounts yesterday of the shooting of an undercover colleague by an off-duty New York City police officer in a Manhattan subway station: One officer testified that Officer Desmond Robinson was lying on the platform when Officer Peter Del-Debbio shot him in the back; the other testified that he was not.

title: Retailers Push Own Labels
description: MILAN  After two decades on the defensive, as prisoners of big-name designers and their trademarks, clothing retailers are now attempting to recapture the high ground of consumer confidence. As usual, Italy's fashion industry has found a way to make money out of the change.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Taste of the Unexpected
description: Perhaps it was unintentional, perhaps not, but Mariss Jansons accomplished an unusual reversal of expectations in his concert with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. He made the Brahms Second Symphony sound fresher, more rhythmically vital and even more up to date than Bartok's Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;U.S.C. Names Bibby as Permanent Coach
description: HENRY BIBBY had the interim removed from his title yesterday, being named basketball coach at Southern California. Bibby was hired even though the Trojans did not win in nine games under him after CHARLIE PARKER was fired on Feb. 7.

title: In Heavy Smoking, Grim Portent for China
description: Rushing down a Beijing alleyway where a north wind was kicking up dust among the vegetable stands and cigarette vendors, Huang Jinhui, 25, paused to explain to a stranger why he smokes.

title: 'Liquid' Assets Lure Big Investors
description: PARIS  When Revlon executives made a public share offering earlier this month, they took to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with more than just the usual lure of money to be made.

title: Man Expected to Go to Prison for Helping Wife Kill Herself
description: A Manhattan man is expected to go to jail for helping his wife commit suicide, after he pleaded guilty yesterday to a reduced charge in the unusual case.

title: The Constitution on Death Row
description: WASHINGTON

title: INSIDE
description: For AT&T, Fewer Jobs to Cut

title: End Is Planned For Magazine
description: The Meredith Corporation said this week that it would suspend publication of Home Garden magazine with its May-June issue.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Core Units Are Closed By Fokker
description: Fokker N.V., the Dutch aviation pioneer, collapsed today, putting 5,600 people out of work in the biggest single wave of job cuts in the history of the Netherlands.

title: Review/Fashion;Was That Phantasm by Galliano a Dream?
description: There is a great morning-after scene in Donna Tartt's "Secret History" when the novel's eccentric collegiate characters awaken to deal with the aftereffects of recreating a hedonistic pagan ritual.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: An Indonesian Asset Is Also a Liability;Low Wages Woo Foreign Business, But the Price Is Worker Poverty
description: Many days Tongris Situmorang, in his blue baseball hat with a large X on the front, hangs around the gates of the enormous Nike sport shoe factory here, talking to friends leaving the assembly lines at the end of the work day.

title: Liggett Group Reaches Pact With 5 States
description: After stunning the tobacco industry on Wednesday by settling a class-action suit by the nation's smokers, the Liggett Group dropped the other shoe yesterday.

title: Observer;Hero Of the Air
description: I am not a good air traveler. I cry too easily. I cried when my flight from Boston to Washington's Dulles Airport was canceled last Friday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Abdul-Rauf Stands, but Jordan Delivers

title: Rig Count Drops by 26
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States dropped by 26 this week, to 693, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 667 rigs operating nationwide a year ago.

title: Industry Pace Rises Sharply; Inflation Low
description: Rebounding more sharply than expected, industrial output rose 1.2 percent in February, a gain three times as large as a decline in January that reflected the impact of a blizzard in the Northeast, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Man Is Convicted in a Killing
description: Richard Feaster, 24, was found guilty yesterday of killing a Deptford gas station attendant, Keith Donaghy, 30, during a robbery in 1993. The jury will reconvene on Wednesday to decide whether to sentence him to the death penalty. Mr. Feaster still faces trial on a charge of killing another Deptford gas station attendant, Ronald Pine, 55, three weeks after he shot Mr. Donaghy to death.

title: Company News
description: BRIGHTPOINT INC., Indianapolis, an independent wholesale distributor of cellular telephones and related products, signed a definitive agreement to acquire Allied Communications Inc. of Bensalem, Pa., a privately held distributor of wireless communications equipment, for $42 million in stock.

title: Buchanan's Salute to Abbie Hoffman
description: To the Editor:

title: Dynamic Duo
description: Even in Washington, where the revolving door between government service and lucrative lobbying whirs with breathtaking speed, Representative Bud Shuster's dealings with a lobbyist named Ann Eppard have attracted special notice. The Pennsylvania Republican is the chairman of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee. For more than 20 years, Ms. Eppard was his chief of staff.

title: Journal;The 'Too Jewish' Question
description: As the upwardly mobile mobbed Sotheby's last week to get their hands on the American consumer's ultimate porno -- the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis auction catalogue -- I was some blocks away on the Upper East Side contemplating Barbra Streisand's nose.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 'American Flyer' Trains Planned for Northeast Moving decisively to upgrade train service in the Northeast and challenge the airlines, Amtrak chose the contractors to build a $611 million fleet of "American Flyers" that will dramatically cut train travel time between Washington and Boston. The top speed of the new trains, the first of which is to be delivered in 1999, is 150 miles an hour -- 25 miles an hour faster than trains that now travel between New York and Washington, and 50 miles an hour faster than between New York and Boston.

title: Sports of The Times;A Tale Of Two Tysons
description: IF beauty is in the eye of the beholder, boxing is too. Mike Tyson is apparently two different people now -- the one that his co-managers, Rory Holloway and John Horne, see, and the other that his former trainer, Kevin Rooney, hasn't seen.

title: Crime in the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Harvard Upset Winner
description: A Harvard team that had lost the last nine games of the regular season upset Vermont, the first-place finisher in the Eastern College Athletic Conference, in a semifinal game of the ECAC tournament tonight.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HORIZON/CMS HEALTHCARE DISCLOSES INVESTIGATION
description: The Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation, an operator of nursing homes and rehabilitation hospitals, disclosed yesterday that Federal investigators were looking into $3.4 million in Medicare billings it may have improperly submitted. The Albuquerque, N.M.-based company admitted that it appeared that some of its billings to the Government did not follow Medicare rules. But it maintained the overbillings were a mistake and "do not represent a regular pattern or practice." Nonetheless, the investigation could eventually result in civil or criminal fines and sanctions that might hurt the company's finances, Horizon/CMS said.

title: SHOOTOUT IN THE BRONX: THE SUSPECTS;3 Young Men With Violent Records Dating to Their Teens
description: Ricardo Morales was 15 when he helped hold up a Bronx bodega, a stickup that left the owner dead. Angel Diaz's start in crime came almost as early -- he was 16 when he was sent to prison for holding up a jewelry store, 19 when he was paroled and 20 when he was sent back to prison for robbery and assault. Jesus Mendez had barely turned 18 when he began a 7-year sentence for armed robberies in the Bronx.

title: Crackdown on Marijuana Users Fits the Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST;Down by 12, Louisville Wins in Overtime
description: Entering the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, DeJuan Wheat's long-range jumper was off and his right middle knuckle was swollen and throbbing.

title: South Africa Journal;Sporting Life Thrives On Beer and Cigarettes
description: And you thought the D Train was tough.

title: Melting Planet
description: It has been as ugly in the Berkshires, two and a half hours north of New York City, as open, undisturbed country ever gets. One day the temperature reached 47 in the afternoon, with steady rain. The ground was frozen and still partly covered by snow, which had turned porous and grainy. A dense vapor clung to the tops of the snowbanks. Water ran in thin, scalloped rivulets across tarred roads. It streamed across the earth and pooled in every depression, where it stayed because it had nowhere to go. In every ditch, every hollow, a tea was steeping, a cold, sepia tea of last year's leaves in a basin of discolored ice. It was easy to find oneself staring into the tangled woods, wondering why exactly humans had never learned to hibernate and whether it was too late to think again.

title: Anti-Zionism Doesn't Equal Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Crackdown on Marijuana Users Fits the Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Republicans Wondering Which Dole Will Emerge
description: When Senator Bob Dole took the stage at a rally in Columbus, Ohio, on Thursday night, his voice was vigorous, his tone was sharp and he kept his target -- "Veto Bill," as he jubilantly labeled his opponent, the President -- in his sights for 20 lively and focused minutes.

title: Friars Pull Out N.I.T. Victory
description: Derrick Brown and God Shammgod scored 19 points each tonight, and Providence made 10 of its final 12 free throws in beating Fairfield, 91-79, in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Pataki Reveals Surprise Funds To Ease Budget
description: After threatening repeatedly in recent weeks to slash state programs if Washington failed to provide the aid he wanted, Gov. George E. Pataki made the surprise announcement today that he had found $1.4 billion in additional money that he said would enable him to balance his 1997 budget without making painful new spending cuts.

title: Murder Jury Starts Again
description: The jury weighing murder charges against Erik and Lyle Menendez began deliberations all over again today after the forewoman and a pregnant juror were dismissed for medical reasons.

title: Broad Reach of Whitewater Counsel's Inquiry Is Upheld
description: In an affirmation of the sweeping power of independent counsels, a Federal appeals court today concluded that the legal team investigating accusations of misconduct by Bill and Hillary Clinton did not overstep its authority by broadening the inquiry with an indictment of the current Governor of Arkansas.

title: An Out-of-the-Way City Turns Into an Art Capital For 10 Days EachMarch
description: Location, it's been said, is everything. But who would have thought that this tiny city near the borders with Belgium and Germany would prove the ideal location for the world's largest art fair?

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Add Championship Experience
description: Along with acquiring experience, size, skill and toughness, another reason for the Rangers' big trade with the Los Angeles Kings on Thursday night was the backgrounds of the players.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Fifth Avenue between 44th and 86th streets and 86th Street between Fifth and Third avenues will be closed from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. today for the Saint Patrick's Day parade. In addition, 44th to 46th streets from Park Avenue to the Avenue of the Americas will be closed starting at 8:30 AM.

title: Bomb Suspect Drove by Target
description: Terry L. Nichols has told investigators that he and Timothy J. McVeigh drove past the Federal Building in Oklahoma City on Easter Sunday last year, three days before it was ripped apart by a bomb, newly released court documents show.

title: Israel Asks for Advanced Gear In Anti-Terror Pact With U.S.
description: Israel is asking for advanced American equipment and access to raw intelligence to flesh out President Clinton's promise of an anti-terrorist pact, including ground stations to receive satellite data and better access to communications intercepts, officials said today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Study on Childhood Cancer
description: Federal and state health officials plan to meet in Washington next week to plan a joint study of higher-than-normal childhood cancer rates in Ocean County. Officials from the New Jersey Health Department and the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will meet Wednesday in the office of Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat from Englewood, to discuss the scope and cost of the study. The study will try to determine why cancer rates among children in some parts of Ocean County are higher than what would normally be expected, an aide to Mr. Torricelli said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about a performance of "Riverdance: The Show" at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night referred incorrectly to an instrument played by one of the musicians. Eileen Ivers played a blue electric violin, not a guitar.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Evil Fragments Made Whole
description: Danial Shapiro and Joanie Smith sent people rushing through realms of terror in the program their company, Shapiro and Smith Dance, presented on Wednesday night at Dance Theater Workshop. The two choreographers, who create works collaboratively, were in a somber mood in "What Dark/Falling Into Light," a premiere inspired by the experiences of Mr. Shapiro's great-grandparents, who survived the Holocaust.

title: A Performer Is Not a Teacher
description: After years of desperation and neglect, the arts education community in New York is ecstatic. The Annenberg Foundation has announced a grant of $12 million, which with matching funds would bring a $36 million, five-year arts program into the New York City public schools. But the plan that a consulting group, Artsvision, has developed for the grant money is misguided and should be reconsidered.

title: Weekly Record On Big Board
description: An eight-year-old record was broken this week, when more shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange than any other week in its history, surpassing the previous high set after the October 1987 stock market crash.

title: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL;Oshkosh Is the End of the Line for Violets
description: New York University ran into a buzz saw tonight in the semifinals of the women's Division III basketball tournament, losing to the University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh, 62-37.

title: POP REVIEW;Putting a Dark Spin on the Beatles' Memory
description: Oasis doesn't hide its debt to the Beatles. At the Theater (formerly the Paramount) on Wednesday night, the group ended its set with "I Am the Walrus." Noel Gallagher, the band's guitarist and songwriter, segued one of his own tunes into the Beatles' "Octopus's Garden," while the lyrics dropped phrases like "yellow submarine" and "wonderwall" (from a George Harrison album title). The music, too, skillfully recycled chord changes, guitar lines, drumbeats and even vocal inflections from the Beatles circa 1965-67. Liam Gallagher, Oasis's lead singer and Noel's brother, wore rimless glasses to play up a passing resemblance to John Lennon.

title: No Headline
description: Man must smoke. I know that smoking is not a good habit, that it's harmful to your health. But I have no choice. To carry on social relationships and to do business, I have to smoke."

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Building a Program on Bach
description: Peter Hurford, an English organist of great and varied accomplishment, used what he called "a scaffolding of Bach" to build his program on Wednesday evening at St. Bartholomew's Church. Bach being Bach, of course, it was almost inevitable that the scaffolding would remain the most majestic part of the edifice.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Princeton Finally Has a Good Answer
description: Not long after midnight, the Princeton Tigers were still in the national collegiate basketball tournament, and the most memorable back-door play in Pete Carril's 29 seasons at the school was still a fresh memory.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;VW Says '95 Profits More Than Doubled
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that its profits more than doubled in 1995 to 336 million marks ($228 million). But the results were weaker than industry analysts had forecast. Revenues climbed to 88.12 billion marks ($59.94 billion), from 80.04 billion marks a year earlier. Operating profit soared to 1.11 billion marks ($755 million), from 461 million marks the year before.

title: Bridge
description: It was 10 P.M. on Saturday in Philadelphia, and the fate of the 1996 Vanderbilt Knockout Teams hung in the balance. Zia Mahmood and his team held a small lead against Nick Nickell and his world champion squad. Zia's partner, Michael Rosenberg, had to face a difficult problem in playing the diagramed deal in three no-trump.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: EAST;Texas Tech Starts Fast, Then Needs To Hold On
description: Friends had warned Texas Tech Coach James Dickey that the first game of the national tournament is the toughest, particularly for higher-seeded teams. Before his players faced 14th-seeded Northern Illinois tonight, Dickey reminded them that Purdue had nearly lost to 16th-seeded Western Carolina the night before.

title: HOCKEY;Andreychuk Excels in First Devils Game
description: The Devils displayed a potent offense in their 5-0 victory tonight over the Tampa Bay Lightning at the Continental Arena, and Dave Andreychuk had a great deal to do with it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIRD SET ON ITS ACQUISITION BY CERTAINTEED
description: The Bird Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Certainteed Corporation, a subsidiary of Saint-Gobain S.A., in a transaction valued about $50 million. Bird, based in Norwood, Mass., and Certainteed, of Valley Forge, Pa., are producers of asphalt roofing shingles. Saint-Gobain, of France, is a glass and building-materials group. The deal values Bird's common shares at $7.50. The shares were up $1.25 yesterday, at $7.25, in Nasdaq trading. Bird, which was founded in 1795, has annual sales of about $50 million.

title: AT&T May Cut Fewer Jobs Than It Initially Estimated
description: Not three months after it stunned Main Street and delighted Wall Street by estimating that it would cut 40,000 jobs over two to three years, the AT&T Corporation is now predicting fewer reductions.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Samsung and HyundaiTeam Up for License
description: Samsung and Hyundai, South Korea's two largest conglomerates, said yesterday that they would jointly bid to win a Government license to enter the personal communications services business. The move is part of an alliance between the two in telecommunications before the opening of the Korean market to foreign companies in 1998.

title: New Rules on Air Traffic Control Would Let Pilots Choose Routes
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would adopt a radically different concept of air traffic control in which pilots would pick their routes, altitudes and speeds, and air traffic controllers would intervene only if flight plans conflicted.

title: SHOOTOUT IN THE BRONX: THE NEIGHBORHOOD;On Troubled Streets Where Officer Died, A Gun Battle in the Night Is No Surprise
description: In the bleak patch of the Bronx where Officer Kevin Gillespie was killed Thursday night, life is controlled in a harsh way by the drug trade.

title: Ray S. Cline, Chief C.I.A. Analyst, Is Dead at 77
description: Ray S. Cline, the Central Intelligence Agency's chief analyst during the Cuban missile crisis and in retirement a fierce defender of the agency, died today at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 77.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COOKSON GROUP ADDING ENGINEERED POLYMERS
description: Cookson Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had acquired the Engineered Polymers Corporation, a Minnesota-based maker of structural foam and molded plastic products, for $87 million. Cookson, a British industrial materials concern, said Engineered Polymers' products are similar to those produced by Cookson's Loudon Plastics, which recently reported strong growth in the same markets. Engineered Polymers' main products are plastic pallets used for shipping. The company had sales of $60 million for the year that ended on June 30, 1995.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;UConn's Moore Probably Out
description: Ricky Moore, Connecticut's freshman guard, will almost certainly miss his team's second-round game against Eastern Michigan on Saturday afternoon because of a shoulder injury.

title: Independent Counsel Given a Wide Reach
description: A Federal appeals court said yesterday that the independent counsel investigating business deals involving Bill and Hillary Clinton did not exceed his authority by exploring an area that led to the indictment of Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas.

title: China Says Maneuvers Will Last Through Taiwan's Elections
description: China announced tonight that it would carry on large-scale military exercises off Taiwan through the presidential elections there, ignoring Taiwan's calls to end belligerent acts and resume a dialogue.

title: Union Lays Out Demands in G.M. Strike
description: Strikers at a brake factory here want safer equipment, more training, more hiring and an end to moves by the General Motors Corporation to buy more parts from outside companies, local union officials here said shortly before the two sides agreed to stop discussing their differences in public.

title: Court Puts Down Rebellion Over Control of Federal Land
description: Dealing a major blow to dozens of counties that have passed ordinances asserting that the Federal Government does not in fact own the public lands that make up nearly half of the American West, a Federal judge in Nevada has ruled that such measures are illegal.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Senior Iranian Official Faces Arrest in Germany
description: In a highly unusual move that could bolster the American campaign to isolate Iran, a German judge has issued a warrant for the arrest of Iran's intelligence minister on murder charges. The minister, Ali Fallahiyan, is suspected of having ordered the 1992 killing of a Kurdish exile here.

title: Sports of The Times;Time Has Run Out For This Cinderella
description: THE Richmond Coliseum was buzzing with pre-game possibilities yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article and picture caption yesterday about an investigation involving New York City school custodians misidentified a custodial helper accused of fraud. He is Ronald Dingman, not Peter Dingman, Ronald's brother, who is also a custodial helper. In addition, another custodian's name was misspelled. His name is Matthew Donohue, not Donahue.

title: Viacom in Swap for New York FM Outlet
description: Viacom Inc. will become one of New York's largest radio station owners after it swaps its three Seattle stations for WAXQ-FM in New York in a transaction valued at $90 million.

title: Heart Risk Found for Short Men
description: Two new studies from Rhode Island and Germany have found that the shorter men are, the greater their risk of heart trouble and high blood pressure. But the findings did not apply to women.

title: BOXING;In Bruno, Tyson Finds Opponent Who Can Hit
description: The way Frank Bruno's daydreams play it out, he will attack Mike Tyson on Saturday night, cheered on by 2,500 roaring Brits in the MGM Grand crowd.
