Tyson will be flustered by this onslaught, the insecurity brought on by three years in prison will take its toll and his own dreams of revival will disappear into the desert night.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OFFICEMAX SETTLES LAWSUIT AGAINST ITS FORMER PARENT
description: Officemax Inc. said yesterday that it had settled its lawsuit against its former parent, the Kmart Corporation, and would not have to reimburse the discount retailer $3.7 million for a debt payment. Kmart contended that the amount was Officemax's share of a payment due the holder of Kmart's real estate bonds for a shopping center in Manchester, Conn., where Officemax is a tenant. But Officemax sued Kmart earlier this month, saying the company was obligated to repay the debt because it failed to maintain an investment grade rating on its senior debt and not as a result of any action by Officemax. Officemax, based in Shaker Heights, Ohio, said Kmart had agreed to reimburse it for attorneys' fees and expenses incurred in filing its lawsuit.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Titletown, N.Y.C.

title: Administration Calls for End To G.M. Strike
description: The Clinton Administration called on the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers today to settle a 10-day strike that has virtually shut down the North American operations of the world's largest auto maker. The call came hours after negotiations here appeared to show the first signs of progress.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Gauging the Power of Words To Unify a Spectrum of Styles
description: By reading the texts and leaving the music aside, "Voices of the Spirit," at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night, could be comprehended at a glance. This first of three events spoke to music that speaks to the spirit. The references were religious, often biblical, and represented, as the originator of the concerts, Dawn Upshaw, explained, "points of initiation" into the trials and the puzzles of spiritual life.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A 'Firebird' Abundant In Eerie Spectacle
description: Choreographers often love to take fresh looks at familiar balletic stories, and Francis Patrelle offered his own new interpretation of Stravinsky's "Firebird" on Thursday night when his company, Dances . . . Patrelle, performed at the Kaye Playhouse.

title: HORSE RACING;Patton Scores At Gulfstream
description: On the eve of the $500,000 Florida Derby, the East's major shootout for Kentucky Derby candidates, the old warrior Patton won for the first time in 14 months when he scored an upset victory today in the Gulfstream Park Breeders' Cup Sprint Championship at 22-1.

title: Amdahl Chief Executive Resigns; Predecessor Will Succeed Him
description: E. Joseph Zemke abruptly resigned today as president and chief executive of the Amdahl Corporation, citing personal reasons. Mr. Zemke's departure came as a surprise to industry analysts and company insiders alike.

title: Religion Journal;A New Book and a New Look at Jesus as the Corporate Manager Nonpareil
description: The theologian and physician Albert Schweitzer once observed that people who write about Jesus' life often wound up describing their own times at least as much as they did Christ's. No such effort "so reveals one's true self," Dr. Schweitzer wrote 90 years ago.

title: Mounting Legal Assault Against 'Megan's Law'
description: Since January, the paroled and indigent rapists and child molesters had been filing, one by one, into the offices of New Jersey's public defenders. They wanted legal help to block the state from revealing their names and addresses to schools, day care centers, women's shelters and, in some cases, neighbors.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WEST;Santa Clara Is Once More Giant-Killing
description: The Vancouver Grizzlies want him.

title: SHOOTOUT IN THE BRONX: THE OFFICER;Upbeat Presence In Downbeat Precincts
description: On Thursday night, Officer Kevin Gillespie of the New York Police Department's Street Crime Unit proved his love for his job one last time, chasing down carjacking suspects in one of the Bronx's most troubled neighborhoods and receiving a fatal bullet for his pains.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;MacTavish and Hawerchuk Swap Teams
description: In a deal involving centers over 30 years old, the Philadelphia Flyers traded CRAIG MacTAVISH, the league's only helmetless player, to the St. Louis Blues yesterday for DALE HAWERCHUK, one of the National Hockey League's leading career scorers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: In Eye of a Storm Over Gay Clergy;Despite Turmoil, Priest Is at Home in Suburban Parish
description: The hundreds of welcome pamphlets scattered throughout St. George's Episcopal Church proclaim that there will be no outcasts here. The people in the pews on this sunlit Sunday morning prove that.

title: Luxury Companies Focus on Service
description: PARIS  Economic stagnation and more demanding, ever-thriftier clients are forcing luxury retailers to find ways to improve their image and create customer loyalty. Almost unanimously, they are focusing on service.

title: POLITICS: ON CAPITOL HILL;Dole Is Cashing In a Chit For Supporting Gingrich
description: When Newt Gingrich needed him last year, Bob Dole gulped down whatever doubts he harbored about the Contract With America and dutifully signed on to the House Speaker's Republican revolution.

title: POLITICS: VOICES;'Our Party, Too,' Black Republicans Say
description: The Frederick Douglass Crusaders, a tiny group of black Republicans on the city's South Side, are still mourning what might have been: a black renaissance within the Grand Old Party born of a Presidential candidacy by Colin L. Powell.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Heineken Profits Rise
description: The Dutch brewer Heineken N.V. said yesterday that its profit rose slightly last year from 1994, when profit was swelled by a one-time gain from an asset sale. The company said it earned 664 million guilders (about $402 million) in 1995, up from 662 million guilders the year before. Sales rose 4.7 percent, to 10.44 billion guilders. Profit in 1994 was inflated by a one-time gain of 59 million guilders from the sale of the company's stake in Bols Benelux B.V. The company said exports rose significantly last year. AP

title: Private School or Public? One Family's Search
description: I am the happy mother of a sunny 5-year-old. My husband and I have watched her progress from a serene infant to a capable toddler. We found a good nursery school for her to attend, where she revealed affinities for watercolors, library books, her classmates and the computer. We saw her become a small person who loved the city, from the tire swing in her playground to the sculpture of Perseus and Medusa at the Met. The city appeared to love her back, from the Bengali hot-dog vendor who handed her free Chee-tos to the sanitation guys who chatted over their shoulders with her as they sent barrels of recyclables crashing into their trucks.

title: THE WORLD;Gunboat Diplomacy, '96 Model
description: ONLY hours after the orders went out from the White House last weekend, 81,000 tons of hardened gray steel began to shake to life in the Persian Gulf. The aircraft carrier Nimitz picked up speed, slicing through the briny waters of the gulf, its course set due east. President Clinton had ordered the Nimitz to join another carrier, the Independence, off Taiwan as a reminder to China that the United States intended to protect its Taiwanese friends.

title: George
description: To the Editor:

title: The World's Greatest Salesman
description: THE POLITICAL CAREER OF THE ITALIAN MEDIA MAGNATE SILVIO BERLUSCONI STARTED, appropriately enough, with a videocassette. On Jan. 26, 1994, Berlusconi addressed the Italian people on all three of his national television networks. Within two months, he turned Italy's political world upside down, created a new political party from scratch and won national elections that would make him Prime Minister.

title: THE DECAY OF CINEMA
description: I was dismayed to read that Sontag has joined the chorus of writers who prematurely write the obituary for cinema. A new generation of cinephiles are willing to look beyond Hollywood and Europe. From the epic human dramas of Zhang Yimou to the simple, poetic tales of Idrissa Ouedraogo, the latest "new wave" of cinema is coming from countries whose films were often ignored in the past, including China, Burkino Faso, Iran, Taiwan and Hong Kong.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/BMW Z3;Desire Under the Palmettos
description: ALL South Carolina needs now is a seat in the Bundestag. It already has its own Autobahn, a local stretch of Interstate 85 where 43 German companies make their home. The best restaurant in town is Gerhard's Cafe on Main Street, where many of the area's German nationals gather for conversation, doses of Jagermeister and plates of Rindsrouladen. In the din of the busy restaurant, the words "Ja" and "Ya'll" mingle into a kind of weird Bavarian-Bubba dialect.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: MORTAL WORLD Poems. By Deborah Pope. Louisiana State University, cloth, $17.95; paper, $9.95.

title: Grumman's Exit Is a Blow to Bethpage
description: NORTHROP GRUMMAN, the aerospace giant that once dominated the Long Island military industry, is trying to sell half its former 600-acre home in Bethpage.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;A Confident Dole Takes Aim Mostly at Clinton on Midwest Swing
description: A confident Senator Bob Dole began a final push today for the Midwestern votes on Tuesday that could bring him within a handful of delegates needed to clinch the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Furnishings Sized for the City Domain, the home furnishings store, has made a few adjustments to the Manhattan market: downsizing some pieces.

title: WEDDINGS;Margaret Chute and Daniel Jamous
description: Margaret Ellen Chute, a daughter of Jane and Mortimer Chute Jr. of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Daniel Jamous, a son of Kari and Haroun Jamous of Draveil, France. Jane Chittick, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the French Library and Cultural Center in Boston.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Garrell S. Mullaney;Consolidated Care for the Mentally Ill
description: GARRELL S. MULLANEY is the chief executive of Connecticut Valley Hospital in Middletown, which will by the end of this year become the state's sole remaining hospital for the mentally ill.

title: BOXING;This Fighter Is Making Fans of Her Skeptics
description: The promoter Don King represents more than a hundred professional boxers. One is a woman, Christy Martin, who was on her third Mike Tyson undercard last night at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Economics of Scarcity: Being First on the Block Has Its Price
description: DO you absolutely, positively have to have a BMW Z3 right away? No problem. Two were advertised in The Dallas Morning News last week -- for $50,000, roughly nearly $20,000 over the manufacturer's suggested retail price.

title: POSTINGS: 31-Story Building Going Up Next to St. Jean Baptiste on E.76th St.; Condo Rising Beside Church's Dome
description: A 31-story luxury condominium named The Siena is rising beside the 172-foot dome of the Italian Renaissance style St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church and Rectory on 76th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues.

title: Silence Spoken Here
description: FORGET about mastering a foreign language. We're too old, it's too hard and life is too short. And perhaps, after all, silence is the best language for travelers.

title: ANNE FRANK;'She Knew Who Her Enemies Were'
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel to Court-Martial 3 Soldiers in Attack
description: Three Israeli soldiers are to be court-martialed for letting a suicide bomber slip into Israel from the Gaza Strip, the army announced Friday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Cowboys vs. Chiefs in Mexico
description: The Dallas Cowboys and Kansas City Chiefs will meet in Monterrey, Mexico, on Aug. 5 as part of the American Bowl preseason series. In 1994, a Dallas-Houston game in Mexico City's Azteca Stadium drew 112,000; the stadium in Monterrey holds 45,000. The game, 27th in the American Bowl series since 1986, will be part of Monterrey's 400th anniversary celebration. ABC will televise it in the United States. (AP)

title: Descent Into SoHo
description: BRAIN FEVER By Valerie Sayers. 308 pp. New York: Doubleday. $23.95. THE kingdom of madness is a destination we never visit voluntarily, and such are its shifting borders and evanescent landmarks that those who make the journey are often not sure where they are headed or when they have arrived.

title: DINING OUT;Cheerful Service, Live Dance Music
description: DANCING'S back, hence the emergence of supper clubs. At one of them, the Savoy Supper Club in South Norwalk, a not-quite-cavernous dining room with ornate glass chandeliers is lined on two sides with banquettes. There is a stage at one end of the room, a pool table and lounge area with two couches at the opposite end. A dark dining room ceiling and subdued lighting add to a nightclub atmosphere.

title: Reliving the 70's, in Touch With the 90's (VH1's New SplitPersonality)
description: A year and a half ago, the decade-old music-video channel VH-1 gave itself a makeover, dropping the hyphen from its name and adopting the slogan "music first." Formerly a rest home for stand-up comedians and established soft-worck singers (Phil Collinsk, Michael Bolton, Whitney Houston), VH1 began promoting itself as a place to see up-and-coming new artists like Sheryl Crow, Melissa Etheridge and Counting Crows.

title: Park Officials Take Steps to Save Rainbow Trout From Disease
description: IN an effort to prevent Long Island waters from becoming infected with a disease that is deadly to rainbow trout, officials of the Connetquot River State Park have announced new regulations for fly fishermen who will begin the trout season in the park's waters on April 1.

title: ON POLITICS;Constituent Has a Gripe; Torricelli Has a Headache
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Englewood Democrat who is running for the Senate, has taken on the Central Intelligence Agency for its role in Guatemala, championed embargoes to weaken the Castro regime in Cuba and even overcome Newt Gingrich, who tried last year to toss him off the House Intelligence Committee.

title: YOUR HOME;Making A Sale Easier
description: EVER visit a used car lot? If so, you might have noticed that despite differences in price, mileage, model and mechanical condition, nearly all the cars on the lot had at least one thing in common: a new wax job.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: SCENE;The Party Begins: Will It End in Love or Food Fights?
description: AN annual mating ritual of New York singles is on. Dating is not the issue. At stake is finding housemates to share those steamy summer weekends in beach houses in the Hamptons and on Fire Island.

title: Giuliani Firmly Backed Palestine Peace Effort on Visit to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: March 10-16;Anthems, Islam and Basketball
description: For over 60 games, Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf, the Denver Nuggets star point guard, avoided standing while the national anthem played. Only when fans began asking on radio talk shows about his conduct did the 27-year-old player, who converted to Islam five years ago, declare that the nationalism implied in the song ran counter to his belief that "Islam is the only way."

title: Gay Novelist's Invisible Lives Are Fashioned Into Best Seller
description: WHEN E. Lynn Harris writes about the particular difficulties of being black and gay and the universal loneliness of the search for romantic love, he calls it "getting naked."

title: Walter Weir, 86, Longtime Leader In Advertising
description: Walter Weir, who shook off his early failures as a vaudeville tap dancer and saxophone player and became a leader in the world of advertising, died on March 2 at St. Mary Medical Center in Langhorne, Pa., a day after suffering a heart attack. He was 86.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: SOUTHEAST;Perfect at the End, Huskies Stay Alive
description: When the end was near for the Eastern Michigan Eagles, the standing ovation was just a consolation prize. For the longest time, the Eagles had managed to keep the Connecticut Huskies within their reach. An early burst had temporarily knocked the top-seeded team in the Southeast regional back on its heels. As the game neared the stretch run and Connecticut tried to take Eastern Michigan out, the Eagles would not go away.

title: DINING OUT;Garlic Crowns Italian Fare in Ossining
description: ONE can't help noticing a few sagging or stained chairs, a bit of frayed carpeting on the stairs and a couple of smudged menus, but, in general, through seven years of heavy use, Guida's has managed to keep most of its luster. In fact, the place proved brighter and better than we remembered, and the kitchen's offerings, although a few were too liberally salted, were more accomplished.

title: WEDDINGS;Caroline E. Kane, Stephen J. Levy
description: Caroline Eve Kane, a director of special projects at the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, is to be married this evening to Stephen Jeffrey Levy, a lawyer in Brooklyn. Rabbi Arthur Schneier is to perform the ceremony with the bride's uncle, Rabbi Joseph Klein, in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STUYVESANT SQUARE;Old Idea in New Age: Night School
description: The last school bell didn't always toll in mid-afternoon. At the turn of the century, thousands of students were educated at night schools, especially immigrants who had to work during the day. Today, with people from abroad once again flocking to the city and many students having trouble balancing jobs and studies, some educators say that night school is an idea whose time has come around. The city has two night schools, Manhattan Comprehensive Night and Day High School, on Second Avenue at 15th Street, which holds regular academic classes until 10:45 P.M. Monday through Thursday and on Sunday, and Brooklyn Comprehensive Night School, which shares space with Midwood High School.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: MASQUERADE By Gayle Lynds. Doubleday, $22.95.

title: Time Again to Celebrate the Sugar Moon at Muscoot Farm
description: MAPLE in the mists was palpable. Visitors, mostly young families, crowded into the old blacksmith shop as Farmer Joe Plummer, a ruddy-cheeked bona-fide rural resident, took them step by step through the process of making maple syrup.

title: Merle Eugene Curti, 98, Scholar Who Won Pulitzer for History
description: Merle Eugene Curti, a scholar of American history and a Pulitzer-Prize winning author, died March 9 at the Methodist Retirement Center in Madison, Wis. He was 98 and lived in Madison.

title: Putting Fabric Together, Putting Lives Back Together
description: WHILE government is talking about getting people off welfare by starting training programs, Sue Westphal is doing something about it.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WOMEN;UConn's Strength Withers Howard
description: Before last night's game, Coach Sanya Tyler and her players from Howard vowed they would not be intimidated when they met Connecticut, the defending national champion in women's basketball.

title: THE NATION;In This Race, It's the Center Against the Middle
description: AS the curtain falls on act one of the 1996 Presidential election, a question naturally arises: How did an angry, change-hungry electorate, whipsawed by broad economic forces and mistrustful of the very idea of a political establishment, end up with two utterly conventional career politicians as their parties' nominees?

title: The Pro Athletes With Synthetic Fur
description: WANNA earn $100,000 a year and become famous? All you have to do is dress up like a barnyard or jungle creature and shake your fanny in front of 20,000 people. Oh yeah, a few other things. You have to be able to dunk basketballs through flaming hoops, soar through space on thin steel wires and ski down endless flights of arena steps.

title: How Frances McDormand Got Into 'Minnesota Nice'
description: NOT ALL MOVIE COPS are nicotine-cured cynics with New York borough accents, or laconic, toothpick-chewing good old boys. Take Marge Gunderson, the police chief played by Frances McDormand in "Fargo," the new film written, produced, and directed by the brothers Joel and Ethan Coen.

title: Einstein Manuscript Fails to Sell at Auction
description: The earliest surviving manuscript in which Albert Einstein elaborated on his theory of relativity failed to meet a confidential minimum bid at auction yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 40 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the singer Cassandra Wilson's new album misstates its title. It is "New Moon Daughter," not "New Moon Rising."

title: ART;Individualist Bents In Juried Exhibition
description: Expo 15 B. J. Spoke Gallery, 299 Main Street, Huntington. Through Mar. 24. 549-5106.

title: A Basketball Game Viewed As Politics
description: On the surface, the basketball game between the two top teams in Stark County, Ohio, had nothing to do with politics. But on another level, McKinley High School versus Jackson High School may say more about what is at stake in politics than the latest primary results. McKinley, the Canton city high school, versus Jackson, the suburban township high school, is about two different ways of living, in Stark County and America.

title: New Releases
description: THE AFGHAN WHIGS: 'BLACK LOVE' Elektra

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Hillary Clinton to Visit Troops in Bosnia
description: To show support for the soldiers her husband sent to enforce the Balkan peace, Hillary Rodham Clinton plans to visit American troops in Bosnia later this month as well as with the families they left behind at bases in Germany and Italy.

title: March 10-16;Smoke or Blue Smoke?
description: Liggett Group, the nation's fifth-largest tobacco company, shattered the decades-old solidarity of the tobacco industry against lawsuits and regulation last week: it agreed to settlement terms in both a private class action lawsuit and lawsuits filed against the tobacco companies by five states.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN BEACH/SHEEPSHEAD BAY;Lundy's Leads a Street's Revival
description: The restaurant is one of glee-evoking legend, where families devoured pink chowders, nibbled on light biscuits and dined on lobster. And now when people enter the new Lundy's, they saunter across the clay-colored floor and often smile nostalgically as they witness the shucking at the clam bar, the soft lights on the golden pillars and the waiters resting large plates of food on the white-clothed tables.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Literary Lighthouse

title: Cross-Dressing for Success
description: LIEUTENANT NUN Memoir of a Basque Transvestite in the New World. By Catalina de Erauso. Translated by Michele Stepto and Gabriel Stepto. Foreword by Marjorie Garber. 80 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $16.95.

title: George F. Scheer, 78, an Author Of Works on Revolutionary War
description: George Fabian Scheer Jr., a chronicler of the Revolutionary War, died March 9 in Memorial Hospital at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. He was 78 and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: SOAPBOX;The Hulks That Hog the Marina
description: PERCHED on the shore of Riverside Park, the 79th Street Boat Basin was intended to be a jewel of New York. Instead it's turned out to be a concertina-wired fortress, home to several score relentless lobbyists and dozens of nonfunctioning vessels in various stages of disrepair.

title: Stop Gossiping
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE GARDEN;The Basis for Success
description: GARDENING is an endeavor that works from the ground up: success depends almost entirely on the quality of the soil.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Pressure Is On in Cincinnati
description: Cincinnati voters, mindful of the anguish suffered by Cleveland's sports fans, face a tough decision on Tuesday: Raise their sales tax to build new baseball and football stadiums or risk losing a team.

title: The Gladiators of Borough Park;Rivals Compete for Power in an Orthodox Arena
description: They could be brothers, almost.

title: THE CAPITALIST;A Boardroom of One's Own
description: A FEW WEEKS AGO, A NONPROFIT NEW York research group called Catalyst released the results of a survey of 461 female executives and 325 male chief executives who worked for large American companies. According to the survey, the typical female executive is 45 years old, white and married with children. She has worked for her company for 12 years and now earns $248,000 a year. She also feels slighted: about half of the women surveyed said they would have gone still further if they had not been stereotyped and excluded by the men around them. Their male bosses, on the other hand, felt that it was mainly a lack of experience that was holding female executives back.

title: Music Notes;Hamptons Music Festival Clarifies Identity
description: WHAT'S in a name? Maybe enough to turn a music festival that was moderately successful at the box office in its first season into a hit the second time.

title: When 'Made in Connecticut' Counted
description: IF any one piece of real estate in Connecticut best represents the history of the Industrial Revolution it would have to be a couple of acres on Capitol Avenue in Hartford near the state capitol. Starting in the mid-19th century, the factory buildings on the site were passed along from company to company. As one industry faded, or moved elsewhere, another came to take its place.

title: SIGNOFF;On Cable, on the Web, on the Plane
description: WHETHER you love Mark Bunting or hate Mark Bunting, you are certainly going to be seeing a lot more of Mark Bunting. The voluble computer pitchster is the relentlessly upbeat host of "The Computer Man," a weekly half-hour tour of cyberworld that has been appearing since January on the Learning Channel.

title: EUROPE '96: FESTIVALS;Lucerne's Lyrical Side
description: I DISCOVERED the Lucerne International Music Festival accidentally, on my first trip to Europe with my mother in 1958. During a midsummer visit in the quaint city, I saw an announcement for a recital at the Kunsthaus by a pianist named Arthur Rubinstein. I was just becoming acquainted with classical music, and I had never heard of him. I bought a ticket, and the beauty of his sound on that memorable evening still haunts me.

title: Inquiry in Officer's Death Focuses on Parole Process
description: As police officials continued investigating the gun battle that killed Officer Kevin Gillespie on Thursday night, several prosecutors and parole officials criticized yesterday what they called a loophole in the justice system that allowed one of his accused assailants to be on the street.

title: EARNING IT;The Boss Was a Giant: How to Fill the Shoes?
description: SAM WALTON, the charismatic founder of Wal-Mart, built a single discount store in Rogers, Ark., into a retail behemoth. Workers, whom he respectfully dubbed "associates," loved him for team-building practices like the daily cheer: "W-A-L M-A-R-T," punctuated with a Chubby Checker-like twist they call a "squiggly." Known for his masterful selling instincts, down-home manner and habit of turning up at stores to inspect the wares and inspire the troops, he became a legend inside and outside his company.

title: HOCKEY;Jonsson's Star Power Gives Isles Hope for a Bright Future
description: In his first game as an Islander, defenseman Kenny Jonsson assisted on a goal, masterfully played the point on the power play, killed penalties, broke up offensive rushes by the Pittsburgh Penguins, inadvertently broke a teammate's nose and left a locker room of players and coaches raving over his performance.

title: Body of Missing Student Is Found in River
description: A 20-year-old student from the State University College at Geneseo was found dead today in the Genesee River, five days after her disappearance, school officials said.

title: THE HERO'S LAST SIGH
description: Michiko Kakutani in her column on Salman Rushdie's heroism states that almost alone among prominent American writers I refused to go on ABC television to protest the Iranian Government's threat to murder him (Culture Zone: "The Hero's Last Sigh," Feb. 25).

title: China's Military Power
description: As China flexes its military power in the Taiwan Strait, the immediate concern is that Beijing has rashly concluded the threat of force is a legitimate way to pursue its political objectives with Taiwan. The longer-term and more serious worry is that these exercises may be the first sign that China intends to use its rapidly growing military power to intimidate its neighbors throughout Asia.

title: Neighbors Ask Town to Act Against Pt. Washington Businesses
description: TWO years ago, when Faith Wurzel bought a house in Willowdale Terrace, a quiet residential neighborhood of Port Washington, she paid little attention to a one-block industrial zone across the street.

title: Night Brings Terror and Arson to Sarajevo Suburb
description: They are out in the night, boozy young men with temper and purpose. They threaten with guns, knives and gasoline, beating old men in their homes and setting apartment buildings on fire.

title: Like Wachtler, We All Need to See Prison Life
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WEST;Georgia Exposes Purdue as a Paper Tiger No. 1
description: This is still better than the hospital.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: P.S.A.L.;Erasmus Beats Grady, And a Difficult Season
description: The boys of Erasmus Hall's basketball team thought they had done their part to bring their school -- threatened with closure because of academic deficiencies -- back to the fore in New York.

title: On Language;Of Mainstreams and Movements
description: THIS IS A RACE BETWEEN THE MAINSTREAM and the extreme," declared Senator Bob Dole, drawing the battle lines after his New Hampshire defeat by Pat Buchanan. That choice of words has reverberated through recent political history.

title: IN THE GARDEN;A Not-So-Secret Basis for Success: The Soil Itself
description: GARDENING is an endeavor that works from the ground up: success depends almost entirely on the quality of the soil.

title: Turmoil on Lower East Side Is Hardly Typical of Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVES;Lawless Friendship
description: We were sitting on a sea wall one summer afternoon, laughing about a future that we envisioned as countless days in porch rockers, reminiscing and complaining about our dentures, when suddenly she said, "I can't imagine growing old without you." I was touched, but also startled. Ruthie and I had spent our lives together, separated by 200 miles and often many months, but always able to pick up a conversation as if space and time had never interrupted it. Still, we were undemonstrative, unsentimental, closemouthed really. Even in silence, we could always hear what the other was saying. "I can't imagine growing old without you." It was the only instance in which one of us had articulated what both of us had always known: that the glue that bound us was as powerful as that which binds parent to child, husband to wife.

title: MUSIC;A Lifelong Love Affair With the Humble Banjo
description: THE banjo, that five-string sultan of twang, has been around.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;Consumed by Big Ideas in Small Packages
description: A FEW YEARS AGO, Cliff Petersen, an aerospace engineer, realized he had a problem: his vast collection of 19th-century patent models was controlling his life. Gone was his initial excitement over such miniature versions of inventions that ranged from the practical (a shingle-sawing machine and a fold-up rocker) to the absurd (a coffin with an exterior bell and a revolving chair with bellows below the seat to cool the sitter's face). What remained was his intense anxiety over how he would part with these objects.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Criticisms Aside, UConn Knows Where Its Strength Lies
description: How do you match perfection? When you win the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's championship with a 35-0 record and your star is voted player of the year and your coach is voted coach of the year, what do you do for an encore?

title: March 10-16;E Pluribus Unum, Circa 2050
description: They may not be candidates for the endangered species list -- yet. But the Census Bureau reports that non-Hispanic whites could lose their numerical dominance in America's population.

title: WEDDINGS;Madeline Mitchell And John Tretout
description: Madeline Claire Mitchell, a daughter of Bernice H. Mitchell of New York and the late Bernard Mitchell, was married yesterday to John Marcel Tretout, the son of Patricia and Marcel Tretout of New York. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Tewell performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: IN BRIEFS;Fair Lawn Council Wants Police Chief in Uniform
description: The apparel oft proclaims the man," Shakespeare wrote, and a majority of the Fair Lawn Borough Council agrees. Reasoning that Police Chief William Gormanns would be more recognizable, and therefore more effective at deterring crime, the mayor and the council voted 3 to 1 on Tuesday night to order the chief to wear his uniform at all times while on duty during daylight hours.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Spring Brings Tours to Virginia
description: The landscape and heritage of America's first colony will be on display this spring in tours of Virginia's homes and gardens.

title: N.H.L.'s Extra Points: Comebacks and Squandered Games;Unfair to Grunfeld
description: To the Sports Editor: William Rhoden's column on the Knicks' Ernie Grunfeld ("A New Fight or Plain Old Surrender," The Times, March 6) was both strident and unfortunate.

title: Season's Greetings;Spring (Yes, Spring) Arrives This Week. Here's How to Find It.
description: WANT to go out?" I asked Moose and Plover. It is a rhetorical question, anchored in our morning routine. The dogs always want to go out.

title: Downsizing: How It Feels to Be Fired
description: EARLIER this month, The New York Times published a series of articles called "The Downsizing of America" about the causes and consequences of layoffs.

title: Transactions
description: TRANSACTIONS

title: BOOKSHELF;The Influence Of the Wearers Of the Green
description: ON St. Patrick's Day, New Yorkers turn their attention again to a group that figures in much of the city's history. It is a day to reflect on the waxing and waning of Irish-Americans' influence and their links to the struggles of the old country. Here are excerpts from three books that explore those themes.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA;1,000 Times No! Bouley Booker Takes Last Call
description: Wedged into a 6-foot-by-2-foot windowless closet deep beneath Duane Street in TriBeCa, Mark Setlock fields calls from desperate souls from all over the world. "Please, you have to help me," pleads a woman from New Jersey, "my mother is dying of cancer."

description: Children can learn to eat better and exercise more at the same time they learn to read and write, a major new study involving nearly 100 elementary schools in four states has shown.

description: As Austria celebrates what it considers its 1,000th birthday this year, its considerably older capital offers a dazzling program of exhibitions, music and other cultural events.

title: Cost-Cutting Strategy
description: For many years, the General Motors Corporation has been giving in to strikes at critical parts factories while hiring almost no new workers, so that its work force has gradually aged and begun retiring.

title: Academic Myopia?
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Jennifer Bandier, W.J. Diggins 3d
description: Jennifer Lee Bandier, a daughter of Denise LeFrak and Martin Bandier, both of New York, was married last evening to William Joseph Diggins 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Diggins Jr. of Buffalo. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Plaza in New York.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Beat Sixers With No Apologies
description: As Philadelphia forward LaSalle Thompson walked off the court to take a seat on the bench last night, he looked to Coach John Lucas and said without hesitation, "We got a bunch of sorry players, Luke."

title: The Literature of Resistance
description: INVENTING IRELAND By Declan Kiberd. 719 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $35.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN BEACH/SHEEPSHEAD BAY;Beach Path Ends in Legal Bills
description: It has been a bad few years for those who live on Manhattan Beach.

title: POSTINGS: 'Civics Lessons: Recent New York Public Architecture';An Exhibition Honors Projects Done and Not Done
description: The budget for public buildings is slashed. Brilliant projects -- whether modest branch libraries or an elaborate police academy -- are stillborn on architects' drafting boards. Regional planners warn that if new capital projects are not undertaken soon, the city will lose its greatness. This is not a cautionary tale, it is reality, say the creators of "Civics Lessons: Recent New York Public Architecture," sponsored by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. The exhibit opened Friday at the United States Custom House on Bowling Green and is open daily from 10 to 5.

title: Editors' Note
description: The New York Times Book Review carried a review last Sunday of "Perfect Villains, Imperfect Heroes: Robert F. Kennedy's War Against Organized Crime," by Ronald Goldfarb, a lawyer who worked in the Justice Department under Attorney General Kennedy. The review, by Selwyn Raab, a reporter who covers organized crime for The Times, acknowledged that Mr. Goldfarb's book cites disclosures and views presented in "Mob Lawyer," a book Mr. Raab wrote in 1994 with Frank Ragano, a lawyer who had represented organized crime bosses.

title: Sunday March 17, 1996: REQUIEMS FOR PETS;Guilt Rides The Internet
description: What do you do when a good friend dies?" a grieving poet wonders in the Virtual Pet Cemetery, one of several memorial parks on the Internet for people who have lost pets. The answer, judging from many of the eulogies that are posted there from around the world, is that you express a fair amount of guilt.

title: State Has Big Role In Medical Research
description: CONNECTICUT has become one of the leading biomedical research centers in the country, according to a study by Connecticut United for Research Excellence, a consortium of state-based companies and researchers.

title: Aging Leaders of Detroit Mafia Are Among 17 Indicted by U.S.
description: A criminal epoch came to an end this week when the aging leaders of the Mafia in Detroit were arrested and indicted on Federal charges that they had carried out a campaign of terror for the last three decades by plotting murders, arsons and beatings.

title: Sports of The Times;Indiana Gives Its Heart To Game's Underdogs
description: THE ball caps were from Butler and Purdue and Indiana and Notre Dame and IUPUI and obscure little junior colleges, but the voices roared "Way to go, Princeton" and "We love you, Pete."

title: SPENDING IT;50 Cents Off! 2 for 1! But Get Them While You Can.
description: DAVID KAISER is a cognitive research psychologist who lives in the affluent Brentwood section of Los Angeles. He and his wife make a total of $70,000 a year and frequently spend long weekends in Santa Barbara.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Londoners Carry On Despite I.R.A. Bombings
description: BRITONS are exhibiting their renowned stiff upper lips in response to the Irish Republican Army's renewed bomb attacks here, determinedly carrying on with their daily routines in the belief that to do anything else would be giving in to terrorism.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Peter Price, Park Avenue Guerrilla
description: WITH his gently spreading midriff and expensive suits, Peter O. Price looks like an average 55-year-old television executive. But beneath his Hermes tie beats the heart of a revolutionary.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Broncos Add McMillan
description: The Denver Broncos have signed defensive back ERIK McMILLAN, the former Jet who is attempting a comeback after two years out of football.

title: Theodore Fetter Songwriter, 89
description: Theodore Henry Fetter, a songwriter and television producer, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: U.S. to Help Israel Build Border Fence
description: While Israel is seeking equipment from the United States to fight terrorism, only part is actually for the identification and interception of potential terrorists. The bulk is intended for a controversial project to build a high-tech barrier to separate Israel from the West Bank, which the Israelis have largely turned over to the Palestinians.

title: JERSEYANA;Where One of America's Sharpest Political Wits Found Refuge, and a Home
description: In 1872, Thomas Nast moved to Morristown from New York City. Legend has it that he moved here to elude the Tammany tiger, fearing revenge for having helped to expose Boss William Marcy Tweed's corruption ring. Nast, America's best-known caricaturist, was an expert at devising pointed symbols, and he had made the tiger a symbol of Tammany Hall.

title: MAKING IT WORK;The Last Picture Show
description: FOR many aficionados of Hong Kong action films, the last week of February was a time to exult. The most popular movie in America was a dubbed version of "Rumble in the Bronx," starring Jackie Chan, the comic daredevil who reigns as Asia's box office king. "Broken Arrow," a Hollywood movie made by John Woo, Hong Kong's gangster film auteur, was second. And a running weekend film festival called "Hong Kong Action at Midnight" continued to sell out at the artsy Angelika Film Center on Houston Street.

title: Not Out of Africa'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Birth of a Theatrical Comet
description: IT BURST on the scene seemingly out of nowhere, this pulsing musical with the beat and cadences of the East Village. Almost instantly, the glowing reviews started pouring in, and limousines began pulling up in front of the modest New York Theater Workshop, where the show opened last month. The show, of course, is "Rent," the acclaimed rock musical that was inspired by Puccini's "Boheme" and that is already bound for Broadway. "Rent" was quickly hailed as a rock opera for our time, a "Hair" for the 90's. Its reception has been made poignant by the fact that its creator, Jonathan Larson, died just before the opening, at the age of 35. The show really didn't arrive out of nowhere, though. It was born of one man's vision and determination. The story of how it came to be also serves as a reminder of the vibrant theatrical life that exists beyond Broadway and how that life nourishes Broadway. The making of "Rent" is a classic theatrical tale of luck, grit, ambition and, finally, applause. By Anthony Tommasini. Page 7. The cast is an ensemble, but each performer has a singular tale to tell. By Peter Marks. Page 7. What the world of classical music can learn from "Rent." By Bernard Holland. Page 31.

title: IMAGES AS ICONS;Scream Heard Round the World
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY VIEW;Tales Worth Telling Must Be Richly Human
description: EVENTS AND FACTS TURN INTO legends because things we know very well about life come up against things -- wonders and terrors -- we can hardly believe or grasp. What we know about is ourselves, and how the same traits show up time and again: grace or greed under pressure; ignorance and ambition hand in glove; genuinely good souls living under the same roof as people who would sell themselves and their children for a fistful of dollars.

title: ON HOCKEY;For Montreal, More Than a Change of Address
description: Slow, eerie music played through the speaker system as ghostly black-and-white photographs of hockey players were projected on the bright, white ice of the new arena.

title: Kidnapping of Ethnic Chinese Rises in Philippines
description: The kidnapper's speech impediment gave him away. As he negotiated with Jepson Dichaves over the amount of ransom for the businessman's two small sons, he kept stumbling over the word for cheapskate.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: CHARACTER ABOVE ALL Ten Presidents From FDR to George Bush. Edited by Robert A. Wilson. Simon & Schuster, $23.

title: Diploma Equals 2d Chance
description: AN alternative school system is helping thousands of people in the county begin new and useful lives. The widespread system, which is operated from youth shelters, correctional institutions, community centers and high schools, offers a second chance in the form of a high school equivalency diploma.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: SOUTHEAST;Carril's Reign Ends With a Grimace
description: The final elimination of Pete Carril's Princeton Tigers took place in 35-second intervals tonight. This time, the Tigers were faced with an opponent that wanted to be here, one with veteran leadership and a sense of purpose. There was no sick, distracted and vulnerable defending national champion to knock off, no matter how many times the Princeton band played the "Underdog" theme.

title: WEDDINGS;Edward B. Stead, Henrietta Wright
description: Henrietta Wright, a partner in Goldberg, Godles, Wiener & Wright, a Washington law firm, was married yesterday to Edward Benjamin Stead, the general counsel and a senior vice president of Apple Computer in Cupertino, Calif. The Rev. Daniel Holzer, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Queen of the Snows Church in Lake Tahoe, Calif.

title: MARKET WATCH;A Fight That's All Smoke and Mirrors
description: For those who treat politics as a spectator sport, Pat Buchanan's 1996 campaign has been a blessing, transforming a dull process into an exciting one. Bennett S. LeBow is doing the same thing for the tobacco industry.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL: UPDATE;McDonald's Drive-Through Returns to Drawing Board
description: A decision on whether to grant McDonald's a zoning variance to build a drive-through restaurant at the corner of Atlantic and Third Avenues was postponed last week after a city agency asked the fast-food chain to further revise its design.

title: Woodbury Barns Are Home to French Chic
description: CAROLE WINER had a foothold, a 12-year-old business called Country Loft Antiques in the historic district in Woodbury. But she also had a vision of an expanded environment that could become a destination for antiques buyers and browsers.

title: Correction
description: A chart accompanying an article in the Neighborhood Report on March 3 about the Regina Opera company in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, misstated the pay status of some of its performers. Singers are not paid; orchestra members receive $25 for each performance.

title: WEDDINGS;Alessandra Niceta, Clayton Rose
description: Alessandra Anna Niceta, a daughter of Hope and Dr. Piero O. Niceta of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Clayton John Rose, the son of Dr. Kathleen Campbell Rose of Washington and Dr. Richard Rose of Chicago. The Rev. James Chiosso performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York. The Rev. Karsten Nelson, who is a cousin of the bridegroom and a Lutheran pastor, assisted.

title: TENNIS;Graf Downs Martinez And Captures the Title
description: She danced in her hotel room to celebrate reaching this final after being hobbled with a touchy lower back in her touch-and-go semifinal, and today Steffi Graf danced off to Las Vegas, Nev., in a private Cessna jet to celebrate her first tournament victory of the year. Not surprisingly, to everyone but herself, this 96th career title was obtained at the first event she entered on the 1996 Corel WTA Tour.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Smiling Eyes
description: Color THE QUIET MAN (1952) green - emerald green as in Ireland, and the picturesque village where a great director surely must have a field day. John Ford's film is as Irish as Paddy's pig, with an indigenous-sounding cast that Ford must have hand-picked, down to the last Gaelic brogue. It's also a genial, richly entertaining romantic comedy, with John Wayne, Maureen O'Hara (above with Barry Fitzgerald) and Victor MacLaglen out front. Plot? The homecoming of an American boxer (Wayne) with a dark secret. The rowdy, climactic battle of Wayne and McLaglen, up hill and down dale to cheering locals, is a pip - SUNDAY at 3:05 P.M. on TNT.

title: PENTAGON WEIGHS ENDING OPPOSITION TO A BAN ON MINES
description: With the daily threat of land mines to American soldiers in Bosnia having brought the issue home, Gen. John Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has ordered a review of the military's longstanding opposition to banning the use of land mines, which kill or maim more than 20,000 people a year, mostly civilians.

title: ON THE MAP;Even Chemists Get the Blues at Hoboken Jam Night
description: Stand on the corner of Hudson Street and Hudson Place 'round midnight on a Monday, and you can see Hoboken's weary PATH riders wondering why wailing blues and a raucous crowd are spilling out of a bar at that hour.

title: EARNING IT;The Lear Jet, Downsized: Hop on the Corporate Bus
description: NOW that the frugal 90's have replaced the flashy 80's, it may be time to eschew the trappings of power transportation.

title: BENEFITS
description: 'The King and I' TUESDAY -- A benefit evening for Variety, the Children's Charity, and Forward Face, which provides financial and emotional support for children with facial disfigurements, will include dinner and tickets to the first preview performance of "The King and I." The 8 P.M. performance at the Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52d Street, will follow dinner at Palio, 151 West 51st Street, at 6. Tickets, $200, or $100 for the play alone, from (212) 684-5860.

title: IN BRIEFS;Archdiocese May Close Polish Parochial School
description: For years, Polish immigrant students have attended St. Stanislaus Kostka School in Garfield, receiving a solid Catholic education and strengthening their cultural bonds to their homeland. But this school year may be the last.

title: Downsizing: How It Feels to Be Fired
description: EARLIER this month, The New York Times published a series of articles called "The Downsizing of America" about the causes and consequences of layoffs.

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS;Margaret Tracey, Russell Kaiser
description: MARGARET TRACEY, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has tiny, delicate features and is so effervescent on stage that she looks like someone who lives on spring water and magic dust.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Moonlight Reveries
description: THE ATMOSPHERE suggests the American South in the wee, small hours of a humid summer night. The music is an unclassifiable hybrid of folk, jazz, pop, blues and country. Listening to Cassandra Wilson's astonishing new album "New Moon Rising" (Blue Note), one has the pleasure not only of stumbling into an intensely aromatic musical environment but also of hearing a gifted vocalist exult in her continuing self-discovery.

title: For Twins, a Shared Common Approach Before Paths Diverge
description: IN the beginning, there was one Anthony -- Carol -- and starting in the mid-1980's it seemed as if no group show in Connecticut could sail without her. Then came Elaine, her twin sister, materializing gradually like the Cheshire Cat and, since the early 90's, the two have been fixtures in Connecticut and Manhattan.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Dodgers and Rockies Head Right to Center In Left-of-Logic Shift
description: National League West teams seem to be up in arms about their outfielders. A year ago the Los Angeles Dodgers moved Raul Mondesi from right field to center, and now the Colorado Rockies have moved Larry Walker from right field to center. The moves have been somewhat controversial, because Mondesi and Walker have the best outfield arms in the league, and right field is where such weapons are located.

title: THEATHER;The Seven-Year Odyssey That Led to 'Rent'
description: Jonathan Larson's rock musical "Rent" was conceived seven years ago on a sticky summer night.

title: Julius A. Shaw, 72, a Champion Of Rights for Disabled People
description: Julius A. Shaw, who lost the use of his legs to polio when he was 8 weeks old and spent most of his adult life championing the rights of the disabled, died on March 6 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 72, and lived in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

title: Westchester Q&A: Bobbi K. Reitzes;For Mother of Diabetics, a Balancing Act
description: FOR Bobbi K. Reitzes, life today is very different from what it was 21 years ago when the first of her two diabetic children was born. Life for the Chappaqua resident no longer includes giving her children daily insulin injections, taking urine samples to test for blood sugar, keeping charts and living with constant stress and worry.

title: N.H.L.'s Extra Points: Comebacks and Squandered Games;All for Money
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN;Turf War as City Tries to Curb Sidewalk Chaos
description: It is a rainy Friday morning in Chinatown as commuters stream out of the Grand Street subway station, running the gantlet of fishmongers, fruit salesmen and vegetable dealers who spill out onto the sidewalk. Ling Ma, the owner of the Kong Kee market, presides over her half-dozen employees with a hawk's eye as they sell sugar cane, fried tofu and meticulously arranged mounds of fruit from stands at the corner of Grand Street and the Bowery.

title: For a Brother Who Died of AIDS
description: WHEN Meg Gordon Roe was first chosen to dance with George Ballanchine's New York City Ballet, she was only 10 years old.

title: Edwin Birger Olsen, Architect, Dies at 94
description: Edwin Birger Olsen, an architect whose assignments took him to the National Gallery of Art, the Smithsonian Institution and the Kennedy White House, died on Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 94 and lived in Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: Downsizing: How It Feels to Be Fired
description: EARLIER this month, The New York Times published a series of articles called "The Downsizing of America" about the causes and consequences of layoffs.

title: Russians Report Progress on Chechen Town
description: After three days of shelling a separatist Chechen stronghold, Russian troops were reported today to be "mopping up" the region, but an official said that fighting might continue around the town for days.

title: Serbia's Vojvodina Area Needs Protection, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: ART REVIEW;Looking Back at Losses Of Time and a Friend
description: ART displayed in the Hunterdon Art Center faces tough competition from a "ye olde" setting that includes whopping beams and a waterfall outside. But at the moment, the container takes second place to its contents, namely shows that are profound rather than picturesque.

title: A Library Fire Spurs Copycat Fears
description: OF all the public buildings in a city or town, the one that is usually held dearest is the library, whether it be a massive, ornate granite building on Fifth Avenue and 42d Street in Manhattan or a modest white clapboard Revolutionary-era structure in a small Connecticut community.

title: Tories Stake Out a Tough Stand Against a 'Monolithic' Europe
description: The Conservative Government staked out a tough position on European integration this week, promising that it would use an intergovernmental conference this month to beat back any attempt by the European Union to extend its powers into areas of national sovereignty.

title: HOME CLINIC;Now Is the Best Time to Remove Deposits in Chimney Flues
description: BURNING wood in the fireplace creates thick deposits of creosote in the flue. There are two important reasons for removing these deposits. Creosote and soot deposits are highly flammable and are the leading cause of chimney fires. Also they are acidic; if they are not removed they can attack the mortar and damage the masonry in the chimney.

title: World News Briefs;Girl Killed in Attack Blamed on Irish Group
description: A gunman fired into a Belfast house Friday night, killing a 9-year-old girl and and critically wounding a 19-year-old man in an attack thought to stem from a feud within Irish National Liberation Army.

title: Southern Discomfort
description: MOTHERS OF INVENTION Women of the Slaveholding South in the American Civil War. By Drew Gilpin Faust. Illustrated. 326 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $29.95.

title: THEATER;A Director Who Sees Himself in Many Characters
description: IN 1981, Tennessee Williams summoned Robert Falls to his home in Key West, Fla., to read him a script. The playwright had seen a production of his "Streetcar Named Desire" in Chicago directed by Mr. Falls, and had hooted with pleasure during the performance. "Oh, that Blanche!" Williams remarked slyly to Mr. Falls afterward. "She's going to talk her way out of that asylum in a week."

title: Sheik Gad al-Haq Dies at 78; Influential Egyptian Cleric
description: Sheik Gad al-Haq Ali Gad al-Haq, an influential voice of conservative Islam who headed Egypt's highest religious authority, died of a heart attack on Friday at his home in Cairo. He was 78.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;A Place Where the Rule Had Teeth
description: On Feb. 28, Jeffrey Tassiello became a rare casualty on the Upper East Side, a bar owner whose request for a liquor license was rejected by the State Liquor Authority in the face of loud and pointed neighborhood opposition.

title: SHELTER;Group-Home Saga: Money to Build, No Money to Operate
description: The voice on the phone sounds weary, and Fred Patterson admits he is not ready to wage another battle just yet. In 1994, the Old Bridge resident churned out newsletters and testified in hearings around the state to raise awareness about a $160 million bond referendum. The money was intended for the building and purchasing of group homes for 4,000 developmentally disabled people on a waiting list for housing, including Mr. Patterson's daughter, Kathy, who is severely retarded.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the size of the universe misstated the definition of a second in angular measurement. It is one-3,600th of a degree, not one-360th of a degree.

title: Unaware, Over There
description: So, how's your wife? Never ask a potential client that question in Riyadh; it will be seen as an invasion of privacy. And, in Beijing, make sure to face the restaurant door when treating clients to lunch; otherwise, they'll assume you're not paying. If you have a tale of a cultural blunder on a foreign business trip, send it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: WEDDINGS;Norma Drelich, Charles R. Kaplan
description: Norma Drelich, a daughter of Gloria Drelich of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Dr. David Drelich of Jersey City, was married last evening to Dr. Charles Ryan Kaplan, the son of Susan and Dr. Hyman Kaplan of Chattanooga, Tenn. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: March 10-16;Americans Spy on French
description: The Central Intelligence Agency spied not wisely and not too well when it sought to steal economic secrets from France, the agency's inspector general reported.

title: Sunday March 17, 1996: VOWEL TO THE RESCUE;Protection Racket
description: You may not believe, but that doesn't mean you can't prepare. And so the Schwa Corporation of Reno is equipping unbelievers with silly but haunting survival gear for the approaching invasion of extraterrestrials. There is the ubiquitous T-shirt and cap, of course, as well as a wallet-size Survival Card that advises the bearer to "give or do whatever they ask." Also, a paper Alien Impostor Mask to help you blend into the new crowd and even a set of 18 bumper stickers to disguise your car as a Schwa Corporate Vehicle that's sure to befuddle even a Maryland state cop decoy. Almost everything bears the stark, unsettling image of a saucer-eyed alien.

description: ANTHONY RAPP (portrays Mark Cohen, the video artist; modeled after Marcello in "La Boheme")

description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;From a Writer Who Shocks, Music That Charms
description: FOR FOUR DECADES, Paul Bowles was remembered primarily as the author of the 1949 novel "The Sheltering Sky." An American expatriate who fled to Morocco in the 1940's and hardly ever returned, Mr. Bowles found himself relegated to the margins of 20th-century letters.

title: 21st-Century Scribes: Monks Designing Web Pages
description: At Christ in the Desert, a Benedictine monastery tucked between stark mesas, 24 monks follow the routine of prayer and labor that has sustained their order for 1,500 years. They clean, chop wood, weave, carve icons, bake bread and design sites on the Internet's World Wide Web.

title: IN SCHOOL;Language Proposals Confound Officials
description: School officials are still slogging through the thick book of curriculum standards that the New Jersey Department of Education released last month. But at least one recommendation -- to teach foreign languages to every child starting in kindergarten -- has already created a ruckus.

description: AT 7:40 on a drizzly morning in Long Beach a beat-up white Saab pulled into a parking lot at Lindell Avenue and Broadway with three surfboards on the roof.

description: The sheer breadth of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's power has become immensely clear in recent days, through a matter that has nothing to do with tax cuts, presidential politics or the state budget.

description: On television this week our screen adaptations score on a global level. Welcome to China, the Himalayas, Brooklyn and New Orleans.

description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Travel Advisory column on March 3 about two exhibitions in Houston misstated the origin of "John Singleton Copley in America." It opened at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, not at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on page 47 of the Arts and Leisure section today misspells the first name of a pianist performing at the Kosciuszko Foundation this afternoon. He is Igor Kipnis.

title: HOCKEY;Sheppard Traded to Panthers
description: The Florida Panthers acquired right wing Ray Sheppard in a trade with the San Jose Sharks today, strengthening their offense for what will likely be the first playoff appearance in their history.

title: A Surge in Second Second-Chance Finance
description: THE neon signs promising "fast cash" flicker from dusty brick storefronts as they have for 50 years on this narrow stretch of Church Street known as Loan Alley.

description: Chardonnay Corey Creek, Southold, 1994. About $13.

title: Downsizing: How It Feels to Be Fired
