title: The Conflict Between A.M. and P.M. People
description: Being bogged down by laughter, I find it difficult to compose this protest directed against David Boucher's piece entitled "The Conflict Between A.M. and P.M. People," which appeared Feb. 25. I found the topic and its composition extremetly revealing and brilliantly dealt with. And being a P.M. person, who certainly suffers more than the A.M.ists, and even though Mr. Boucher has me roaring with uncontrollable laughter despite my horrible existence, I found his piece extremely pertinent.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Biggest Gainers So Far in 1996 Are Not the Most Aggressive
description: Many of the year's best performers on this list are funds in the growth-and-income category. These funds look not only for capital appreciation, but also for high dividends -- a relatively conservative approach that usually leads to blue-chip stocks. The average gain for the category is 4.67 percent so far this year and 30.27 percent for the one-year period. Among the big funds, Vanguard Windsor II leads the group for both periods.

title: TALKING MONEY WITH: ELI BROAD;Investment by Delegation: The Art of Knowing Who Knows
description: WHAT does a man with a fortune valued at well over $800 million do when the stock market drops 171 points in one day, causing panic on Wall Street and pandemonium in the press?

title: Residential Space In Lower Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORLD;Can African Democracy Survive Ethnic Voting
description: DURING 17 years in power, Mathieu Kerekou, this country's former Marxist dictator, is credited with having paved all of two and a half miles of road in his native north, an arid dustbowl whose status as Benin's forgotten hinterland was left unchanged even by its favorite son.

title: IN THE KITCHEN;A Change of Pace With Squid and Octopus
description: CALL it calamari if you will, but squid has achieved an acceptance that would have seemed impossible 15 or so years ago. And now octopus is on the way. Both are more commonly served in restaurants than at home. Some ethnic groups, notably Italians and Greeks, dote on them. And more home cooks should give them a try, now that fish markets often sell them cleaned.

title: WHAT HAPPENED TO FRED CUNY?
description: I really enjoyed the article about Fred Cuny, but I am disturbed that the mystery of his disappearance seems to be more important than what he accomplished in his life and what he stood for, which is to make a difference in people's lives and to have an impact on the world. We can't let that commitment die with him.

title: BOOKEND;Bernard Malamud: Behind the Poker Face
description: To watch Bernard Malamud play poker was to watch him write. For years we shared a poker game in Bennington, Vt. He divided his time between city and country -- spending winters in Manhattan, then returning to New England after the worst storms had passed. In the game there were faculty members from Bennington College, musicians, painters, sculptors; there was the local millionaire and the man who ran the gas station; we took turns playing host. Malamud would always call well in advance to plan for his turn; he'd say, always, "Count me in."

title: Sunday March 17, 1996: HIGHWAY ROBBERY;Half a Cop Car Is Better Than None at All
description: Lead-footing it down the interstate, you suddenly spot the cruiser parked ahead, perform a brake-pedal fandango and steal safely past, well within the speed limit. Faked them out again.

title: Roswell L. Gilpatric, Lawyer And Kennedy Aide, Dies at 89
description: Roswell L. Gilpatric, a New York lawyer who played a pivotal role in the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, when he was Deputy Secretary of Defense, died on Friday at his home in midtown Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Help for Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Senses Fragility in Realm's New Coin
description: Canadians are smacking it against concrete walls, hammering it, boiling it, burning it and freezing it. The idea is to see if their new $2 coin -- composed of a soft inner plug of bronze and hard outer disk of nickel -- falls apart.

title: WEDDINGS;Shera Spar, Douglas B. Dubitsky
description: Shera Tamar Spar, the daughter of Rabbi Elliott T. Spar of Smithtown, L.I., and the late Sondra Spar, was married last evening to Douglas Bruce Dubitsky, the son of Judith Nachamie of Sands Point, L.I., and Les Dubitsky of Sarasota, Fla. The bride's father performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Smithtown, where he is the senior rabbi.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: A Death in Fresno
description: IN MY FATHER'S NAME A Family, a Town, a Murder. By Mark Arax. 399 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Whittle at Roster, Paring Veterans and Youngsters
description: Trimming a roster to the final maximum is a manager's first important task of a young season. It means releasing some players he would rather keep and gambling that some players will, in the long run, perform better than others. Some choices are obvious. Some are gut feelings. Any of them can mean the difference in a game or a season.

title: THE DECAY OF CINEMA
description: Can Sontag really believe that between 1930 and 1955 "only in France were a large number of superb films produced"? Are we to conclude that the best work of Howard Hawks, Alfred Hitchcock, Nicholas Ray and Preston Sturges, to name only a few, doesn't make the cut? Jean-Luc Godard, for one, would disagree: he frankly reveres those classic American movies Sontag so pointedly neglects.

title: Crew's Big Test: Defending Board Suspensions
description: In a mahogany-paneled courtroom in the South Bronx, almost deserted but for the lawyers involved, a centerpiece of the five-month-old chancellorship of Dr. Rudy Crew is undergoing its first major test.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Before You Wish Upon a Star, Check the History Books
description: NOW and then, mutual funds have years that are simply breathtaking. Such was the case in 1995, when some diversified United States stock funds produced gains in the high double digits.

title: HORSE RACING;Sharp Unbridled's Song Retakes Favorite's Role
description: Unbridled's Song, who lost his last two races by the combined margin of less than one length, outran Editor's Note by nearly six lengths in the Florida Derby today and recaptured his ranking as the front-runner on the road to the Kentucky Derby.

title: Word for Word/Vaudeville;The Roar of the Greasepaint, The Smell of the Jokes
description: NOW George Burns is as dead as vaudeville.

title: QUICK BITE;An Alternative to Burgers and Brown Bags
description: There's no shortage of restaurants on Hoboken's main strip, Washington Street, and they offer everything from slushies to sesame noodles. But Kristin Spear still saw a niche for herself.

title: Quiet, Please
description: FREE TO ALL Carnegie Libraries & American Culture, 1890-1920. By Abigail A. Van Slyck. Illustrated. 276 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $47.50.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Amtrak Begins Charge For Changing Tickets
description: Amtrak has begun charging a fee for changing many of its tickets or for getting a refund. The fee is $20 a ticket, $10 for children.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Rodman Uses His Head, Jordan Uses His Skills
description: Thirty-seven points and 16 rebounds from Michael Jordan would summarize most Bulls games.

title: THE BLACKLIST;Not Only Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: On Thin Ice
description: INSIDE EDGE A Revealing Journey Into the Secret World of Figure Skating. By Christine Brennan. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $23.

title: Foils Are a Palpable Hit On the Birthday Circuit
description: IT'S almost 2 on a Sunday afternoon.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Honoring Jackie Robinson
description: The Cairo High School baseball field in Georgia has been renamed in honor of Jackie Robinson.

title: Historic Tours Focus on Women
description: MAIDEN nieces dependent on a distinguished uncle, ladies overseeing household servants on a 19th-century estate, young women playing the pianoforte: those could be the elements of a new Jane Austen film, but the scene is American, aspects of daily life at historic Sunnyside here.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Give Canadiens A Housewarming Gift
description: For the Canadiens, tonight's game was the first at Molson Center, which has replaced the Forum. For the Rangers, it was the debut of three new players, all veterans, obtained in a trade.

title: Audit Criticizes Spending at 3 SUNY Branches
description: Three branches of the State University of New York improperly deposited state money into accounts that the state does not oversee and spent some of it on unauthorized gifts and bonuses to staff members, the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, has charged in an audit.

title: WEDDINGS;Deborah Schondorf, Stuart Novick
description: Deborah Lynn Schondorf, a daughter of Phyllis and Jay Schondorf of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to Stuart Philip Novick, a son of Myrna and Marvin Novick of Commack, L.I. Rabbi Hillel Silverman performed the ceremony at Temple Sholom in Greenwich.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;No-Show Fees: Well, Yes and No
description: THE car rental companies sounded fierce for a while last year, asking Visa and American Express to design penalties for customers who reserve and then do not show up. But so far no one planning to rent a car in the United States is facing a wide system of penalties.

title: OFF THE RACK;Taking Promises of Profits With a Bigger Grain of Salt
description: BEFORE you put your money in companies whose promise is tied to some new product or developing technology, you'd better put up your defenses against securities fraud.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;Flaws Aside, 'Rent' Lives And Breathes
description: WHO HAS MUSICAL CULTURE AND WHO doesn't? A letter to the editors of this newspaper recently complained that young people don't. Its author used opera on the radio as a measuring stick. "I . . . remember walking from one end of the Yale campus to the other on a warm Saturday afternoon without missing a beat of the Metropolitan Opera broadcast through open dormitory windows," the offended correspondent writes. "Thirty years later, the same trip yields loud rock." A strong indictment, but of what?

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: AT HOME IN FRANCE Tales of an American and Her House Abroad. By Ann Barry. Ballantine, $20.

title: Help for Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Sports Mirrors Life;It's Not Just a Game: The City-Suburban Tensions of an Ohio County
description: On the surface, the basketball tournament game between the two top-seeded teams in Stark County, McKinley High School and Jackson High School, had nothing to do with politics. On the surface, it was just another classic matchup in this sports-crazy northeastern Ohio county, where 5,000 fans turn out for high school basketball games and 20,000 for high school football games.

title: N.H.L.'s Extra Points: Comebacks and Squandered Games
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FOOD;Baby Food
description: IN TERMS OF FASHION, PUDDINGS COME AND go; in terms of affection, they mostly stay. The affection stems mainly from early memories of comfort, which is where the disdain probably comes from as well. There is, you see, an innocence and a softness about pudding that can, depending upon the mood of the culture, be either endearing or fodder for pity. (Of the latter opinion, Ambrose Bierce denounced pudding as "detestable . . . a malevolent conspiracy of the hen, the cow and the cook.")

title: March 10-16;Mass Murder in Scotland
description: An unemployed loner with an enthusiasm for guns and young boys burst into a primary school in Dunblane, Scotland, Wednesday, killing 16 children, all under age 7, their teacher and wounding 12 other children before killing himself.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Private World
description: The faithful, moving screen version of Carson McCullers's play (and novel) THE MEMBER OF THE WEDDING (1952), has a major flaw: the camera. Close-up, the seams show: Julie Harris's expert but obvious technical finesse as a younger teen-ager, and the endless, intimate dialgoue she shares with a loving servant (Ethel Waters, above with Ms. Harris) and little boy (Brandon de DeWilde). The minor performers are luckier, in breathers. Fred Zinnemann's perceptive direction suits this touching fragment of adolescent yearning. It's a photographed play, devoid of dramatic structure to begin with, and hardly a movie at all. But you'll remember it - MONDAY at NOON on BRAVO.

title: Don't Mess With Our Cultural Patrimony!'
description: ON JAN. 20, SOMEONE suffering under the misapprehension that I was an employee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art hit me quite hard in the jaw. It was my last night in Taipei, and I'd gone with art-world friends for a late drink at an attractive bar near my hotel. On one side of us, some skinny young men with loosened neckties were using portable phones; on the other, two young women in chic Japanese eyeglasses giggled together. Nearby, a guy with jeans and a leather jacket was punctuating his Chinese sentences with snatches of California-style English. It was Saturday, around midnight, and we were drinking beer with salted prunes in it, as is done in Taipei. I was quietly describing my dinner that evening with Chang Lin-sheng, vice director of the National Palace Museum in Taipei; Maxwell Hearn, the Met's curator of Asian art; Shih Chou-chien, director of art history at Taiwan University, and others.

title: WEDDINGS;Mara Berkman And Dean Landis
description: Mara Ingrid Berkman, the daughter of Carol and Myles Berkman of Pittsburgh, was married last evening to Dean Ives Landis, a son of Elayne and Leonard Landis of New York. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the William Penn Hotel in Pittsburgh.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Restored Bells Ring a Muted Note
description: Perhaps the collective hearing of Yorkville is not what it used to be. Perhaps a four-year absence has made the ears grow fonder. Or perhaps the bells above a new concrete platform in the Church of the Holy Trinity at 316 East 88th Street really do sound, well, different.

title: Help for Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: BACKTALK;Old Isn't as Old as It Used to Be
description: When Rudy Galindo won the national title at the United States figure skating championships in January, he became one of the grand old men of the sport. At 26, Galindo is the oldest national champion in more than half a century.

title: WEDDINGS;Maria von Hartz, Jay Shapiro
description: Maria von Hartz, the daughter of Katherine and John von Hartz of New York, was married yesterday in Los Angeles to Jay Shapiro, a son of Rose Shapiro of Dominguez Hills, Calif., and Pete Shapiro of Los Angeles. The Rev. Gary Musgrove, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony at the Oviatt Penthouse.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-17

title: Flu May Limit Duncan's Play
description: Tim Duncan's stomach virus could restrict his minutes in Wake Forest's game against Texas on Sunday -- and possibly keep him on the bench altogether.

title: IN PERSON;On the Other Side of the Divide
description: ONE day last summer, Karin Abarbanel looked outside where a block party was taking place. Her Montclair neighbors were doing all the normal things that people do at block parties: laughing, talking, grilling meat. But to Ms. Abarbanel, the whole scene seemed anything but normal.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD MYSTERY: UPPER EAST SIDE;Fair-Weather Signals on the Islands
description: Promenade down Park Avenue on a sunny afternoon and the orange contraptions on the traffic islands between 84th and 86th Streets appear somewhat mysterious.

title: WEDDINGS;Lyn S. Jacobson, B.I. Klayman
description: Lyn Simone Jacobson, a daughter of Anita and Robert Jacobson Jr. of New York, was married last evening to Benjamin Ike Klayman, the son of Dorothy and Albert Klayman of Cincinnati. Rabbi Robert N. Levine performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: BASEBALL;Australian Hopes '96 Makes Him A Yankee
description: He's an Australian trying to become a Yank, and answers to the nickname Mate. Mark Hutton, a 6-foot-6-inch right-hander with a 95-mile-an-hour fastball, seems to have mastered everything about baseball except the part about avoiding injuries.

title: BOXING;Briggs's Career Hits a Detour
description: That big thud you may have heard Friday night was the sound of Shannon Briggs's carefully laid plans for becoming a heavyweight contender smashing against the canvas here.

title: STYLE;Green Alert
description: Consider green, a color more important than you think. There is the green associated with plaid pants on the golf course, British racing cars, guacamole, being sick before throwing up, dental floss and envy. Green is the only color that gets it own day. Some political analysts believe the Red Menace of Communism has been replaced by the Green Menace of Islamic fundamentalism. When I learned that green -- precisely, acid green, was au courant this fashion season, I asked people if they had any green opinions.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: PROSPECT PARK;A Creole Festival Sets Spirits Aloft
description: THE sights and sounds of a Haitian marketplace festival will transform the Prospect Park Picnic House Saturday and next Sunday.

title: A Transvaal Epic
description: THE SEED IS MINE The Life of Kas Maine, a South African Sharecropper, 1894-1985. By Charles van Onselen. Illustrated. 649 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $35.

title: Discovery of Graves in Bosnia Raises Hope of Tracing Killers
description: The discovery of a suspected mass grave in the mountains of western Bosnia is giving Government investigators -- as well as family members of the estimated 3,000 people still missing from this valley -- increased hope that the remains of most of the slain will be found and that it will be possible to build legal cases against those who directed massacres here.

title: CLASSICAL BRIEFS
description: BACH: VIOLIN CONCERTOS (4) Tafelmusik; Jeanne Lamon, violinist and conductor. Sony Classical SK 66265; CD.

title: THE BLACKLIST;Repeat of History?
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Notebook;Senator D'Amato's Popularity Problem
description: Alfonse D'Amato's 16-year career as New York's junior Senator has been an unremitting quest for the respect of his Washington peers. Its more mundane theme over the last half-decade has been an unremitting quest for a 50 percent voter approval rating. Lately, he would be happy to settle for 40.

title: FOOD;A Change of Pace With Squid and Octopus, Grilled or in Salad
description: CALL it calamari if you will, but squid has achieved an acceptance today that would have seemed impossible 15 or so years ago. And now octopus is on the way.

title: EUROPE '96: FESTIVALS;A Listener's Choice
description: Some of Europe's music festivals, like Three Choirs, Bayreuth and Salzburg, have almost become historic monuments. Others, like Verona, held in the city's ancient Roman Arena; Granada, held in the Alhambra, and Sanonlinna, in Finland's Olavinlinna Castle, utilize magnificent historic settings. Whatever the site, festivalgoers will find offerings for all tastes, from revivals of ancient works to world premieres.

title: On Multi-Cultural Education
description: The positive spin of your Feb. 11 article, "Multi-Cultural Education: Immersion Lesson for Students," disguises some very troubling aspects of this movement. For starters, solicitude for immigrant or minority students is nowhere near as new as the article implies. It was present during the last major wave of massive immigration in the early 20th century, while teaching various perspectives has a long tradition in American education.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;While Law Preaches Distance, Bars Keep Clustering
description: Throughout the city, neighborhood groups and noisy bars mix about as well as gin and Scotch. So residents who felt besieged by bars and clubs applauded a 1993 law that prohibits the opening of an establishment that serves liquor if there are three others within 500 feet -- unless the newcomer's presence is "in the public interest."

title: The Democratic Manifesto
description: WE'RE RIGHT, THEY'RE WRONG A Handbook for Spirited Progressives. By James Carville. 183 pp. New York: Random House and Simon & Schuster. Paper, $10.

title: Sunday March 17, 1996;A QUESTION FOR: Andrew Bergman
description: At 51, he is best known as a screenwriter and director, but he also has a Ph.D. in American history and is the author of a new play, "Working Title," at the American Jewish Theater.

title: RESTAURANTS;Steak and Sides
description: DRIVING to this beautiful town on the banks of the Navesink River is likely to distract you, for a moment, from the mission at hand, which is to find a really good steak.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Irish in Name Only
description: EVERY year around this time, Rick Smith, an executive of the Ireland Coffee Company, takes about 50 calls from various charities and civic organizations, asking his company to participate in a St. Patrick's Day parade or some other Irish event in South Jersey.

title: World News Briefs;Pope, Ill, Cuts Schedule And Delays Trip to Siena
description: Pope John Paul II, recovering from a digestive problem, has reduced his activities for the coming days and postponed a visit to Siena.

title: In the Region, Strengths Amid Softness
description: LIKE an automobile with one leaky valve, the New York metropolitan region's residential real estate market clattered through last year, losing some of its momentum from 1994.

title: Celtic Twilight
description: TALES FROM THE IRISH CLUB A Collection of Short Stories. By Lester Goran. 132 pp. Kent, Ohio: The Kent State University Press. Paper, $12.

title: A Double Standard In Health Coverage
description: TO most of its employees, the Gannett Company makes no excuses for economizing on health care. Those who want to pick their own doctors and hospitals instead of sticking with the cut-rate Communicare Choice network, a company brochure warns, face high deductibles, low payments and, potentially, thousands of dollars of added expense.

title: SOAPBOX;Calling Any Cop Named Patrick
description: THE annual St. Patrick's Day Parade along Kennedy Boulevard is such a tradition in Jersey City -- with its legions of bagpipers, shamrock-wearing priests, antique cars, Miss Colleen contestants and much else -- that you might suppose it had gone on forever. In fact, it dates back just three decades, and its beginnings were not what you might call respectable.

title: COPING;The Envelope, Please. . .: The College Try
description: THE only adolescent face on the bulletin board of Steven Singer, director of college counseling at the Horace Mann School, gazes clear-eyed from under the brim of a Marine cap.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: Nine, Novena By Osman Lins. Sun and Moon, paper, $12.95.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 6/ Hotel stocks have taken off this year, but it's the high-end chains that analysts expect to perform the best over the long-term. By Barry Rehfeld.

title: Sued by School Board, He Backs Suers
description: Your article ["School Board vs. Bond Opponents, Feb. 25] re the tribulations of those in Commack having the temerity to oppose the taxpayer-paid promotion of a school bond issue there rings a very loud bell here in Glen Cove. Take heart, however -- those of us in Glen Cove and Long Beach are, after 10 years of fighting the almighty public education political machine, still trying to get our long-promised voting rights for school budgets and bond issues, just as the other 127 school districts in Nassau-Sluffolk enjoy right now.

title: WEDDINGS;Melissa Gottesman, Michael Crowley
description: Dr. Melissa Eve Gottesman, a pediatric resident at Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx, was married yesterday to Michael Dawson Crowley, a lawyer. Msgr. Edward M. Connors performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: BASEBALL;The Great Debate Over Revenue Sharing
description: Amid accusations, suspicion and potential television chaos, baseball club owners will debate the critical issue of revenue sharing at their quarterly meetings in Phoenix starting Monday. With the start of the season only two weeks away, if the owners don't approve a proposed interim revenue-sharing plan, the most immediate ramification could be the inability of teams to televise their games locally.

title: Greet the Season By Planting a Tree Or Taking a Hike
description: Want to get in the spring spirit? Here is a sampling of scheduled events that should help.

title: Trickle Down;It's a Slow-Growth Economy, Stupid
description: SO much goes unsaid when Bob Dole calls for a balanced budget and less regulation to get the economy booming again. Or when Bill Clinton offers his formula of more public spending on job training and education to bring back the old prosperity. As the chief rivals for the Presidency, they are engaging in a rather traditional campaign debate -- one that assumes the American economy can go back to the high growth of another era.

title: Sex-Felon Rights And Notification Face Legal Snag
description: FEW laws have drawn so much attention as New York State's version of "Megan's Law," which requires sex offenders to register with police departments and allows the police to release some information about convicted sex offenders to their communities.

title: EUROPE '96: FESTIVALS;Music in Grand Irish Houses
description: EVERY June for the last 26 years, there has been a festival of music in great Irish houses, and although the concerts are open to the public, getting the word out has not been a top priority. We found out about it quite by accident -- eavesdropping in a restaurant. My husband, Wil, and I go to Ireland every couple of years, and the combination of music, architecture and gardens struck us as an opportunity to indulge our interest in all three. Aside from these attractions, there is the Irish countryside. Getting from A to B (never as the crow flies and occasionally stopped dead by a cattle fair in the middle of the village) is half the fun. The festival takes place over a period of two weeks, and consists of a series of concerts in grand houses and historic buildings. The venues vary from year to year -- a couple of the concerts are always in Dublin, the rest scattered about the country.

title: THE METHOD OF A NEO-NAZI MOGUL
description: I was gratified to see Stephan Talty's evenhanded discussion of the skinhead phenomenon ("The Method of a Neo-Nazi Mogul," Feb. 25). He correctly writes that the majority of American skinheads are not part of the white power movement. To elaborate further, there are groups of African-American and Asian skinheads who along with white nonracist skinheads have spurred the resurgence of ska music. Ska has a worldwide following but is rooted in the works of early Jamaican performers like Bob Marley, Desmond Dekker and Jimmy Cliff, hardly a forum for white power propaganda.

title: INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Trouble for movie theaters in Chinatown.

title: The People's Holocaust
description: One day in November 1942, at the height of the Germans' systematic slaughter of Polish Jewry, men serving in a battalion of about 500 reserve policemen learned that they would be undertaking yet another genocidal killing, this time of the Jews of Lukow.

title: WEDDINGS;Alexis Summer, Spencer J. Angel
description: Alexis Wynne Summer, the daughter of Renee F. Summer of New York and Robert Summer of Warren, Conn., was married last evening to Spencer Joshua Angel, the son of Rita and Joshua Angel of New York. Rabbi M. Asher Murciano officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Two Disney Resorts Apart From the Parks
description: Travelers can now stay at a Disney-operated resort even if they're not visiting Walt Disney World. Disney's Vero Beach Resort in Florida opened in January, and Disney's Hilton Head Island Resort in South Carolina opened March 1.

title: Christians Can Still Accept Evolution Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARKCHESTER;Depositors Cry Abandonment As Bank Shuts
description: For nearly 25 years, the Citibank branch on Metropolitan Avenue was the bank of choice for many of the 40,000 residents of the Parkchester condominium complex. Customers preferred it over smaller banks in the area because of the bank's reputation and because it was within walking distance. Older citizens liked being able to still rely on tellers for their transactions. The community's support made it one of the more profitable bank branches in the city, with annual deposits of $65 million.

title: After a Public Death, Baby Mariah Is Privately Buried
description: Covering her coffin with roses and releasing one white balloon into the cloudless sky, the parents of Mariah Rachel Scoon buried their daughter yesterday, four days after her heart stopped, ending their battle to keep her on a ventilator even though she had been declared brain dead.

title: CLASSIC MUSIC;A Composer Finds His Muses In the Here and Now: Performers
description: Elliott Carter says he composes for real performers and an imaginary audience. He tends to speak of his scores in terms of the character of the performers, not abstract sounds. Appropriately, therefore, two coming programs will present some of his most recent music played by an inner circle of Carter specialists who have actually influenced its sound and style.

title: Low Turnout in Zimbabwe
description: Voter turnout was low on the first day of Zimbabwe's one-man presidential election today despite efforts by President Robert Mugabe and his party to bring voters out. Mr. Mugabe, 72, is the sole candidate in the election today and Sunday, following the withdrawal of his two challengers. Even before Ndabaningi Sithole and Bishop Abel Muzorewa dropped out, many Zimbabweans saw the election as a mere formality for confirming Mr. Mugabe in power.

title: EVENING HOURS;With Flowers And Benefits In Bloom
description: Late winter celebrations around town to help scientific research, a college fund, children's hearing and growing things, all on March 7.

title: In the Region/Westchester;Brokers See a Continued Crest in Housing Sales
description: LAST WEEK, before 500 realtors at Houlihan/Lawrence's annual meeting, Donald Trump announced his intention to acquire the 144-acre Briar Hall Country Club in Briarcliff Manor where he wants to refurbish the golf course and build 144 town houses in clusters and a new clubhouse.

title: Jazz Trombonist: Stylist and Composer
description: Ray Anderson, a jazz trombonist, is not an easy man to reach -- at least not at his Long Island home.

title: A Taste of English Village Life
description: WHEN my mother and I pulled up to the home of Theo Dobbe and Ben Kok for dinner, a bright-blue Oklahoma flag was flying atop their cliffside house in the fishing village of East Looe, Cornwall.

title: Chapin School Is Indeed Part of Its Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF;A Late Bloomer Tries to Take a Trip Into the Mystic
description: For a sport governed by literal rules and inflexible numbers, golf is influenced by an inordinate amount of whimsy. Serendipity, mystical occurrences, unseen hands, they seem to materialize frequently in golf, more so than in any other sport.

title: Brodkey's Tales
description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats/York Avenue;2 Brothers, 1 Apartment
description: THEY are David and Ricky Nelson for the 90's: Two brothers in their 20's, one more clean-cut than the other, one hipper looking, with a ghost of a beard, sharing a $976-a-month two-bedroom rental on York Avenue.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN BEACH/SHEEPSHEAD BAY;Fear Changes Cabbies' Habits
description: Last month, a livery cabdriver was killed by a gunshot to the back of his head on a quiet street in Sheepshead Bay. It was a day after another driver was slain less than a mile away, his body found hung over the steering wheel and his money gone.

title: News Analysis;Death Penalty Raises Issue Of Obligation Of Prosecutor
description: The excruciating dilemma facing Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx District Attorney, was symbolically set in motion last March with the stroke of a gold Cross pen.

title: Our Towns;Trying to End A Sad Ritual Of College Life
description: OLD-TIMERS here sometimes marvel at how the social rituals of the State University College students never seem to change.

title: Man Accused of Killing Toddler in Foster Home
description: A Bronx man who told the police that his 2-year-old daughter had choked to death was charged with the toddler's murder Friday night after the Medical Examiner found that she had bruises to her heart and three fractured ribs, the police said yesterday.

title: THE BLACKLIST;Time for Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: EAST;Minutemen Are Tested For the First Time
description: The test by fire that Massachusetts had been waiting for came its way this afternoon from Stanford and the Cardinal's incendiary guard, Brevin Knight. The Cardinal took UMass to the threshold of elimination from the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament -- closing to within a point with under a minute to play -- during a second-round game of the East Regional at the Providence Civic Center.

title: Obsession
description: CHEKHOV'S PLAYS An Opening Into Eternity. By Richard Gilman. 261 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $30. RICHARD GILMAN'S book, as he acknowledges in his introduction, is rooted in an obsession. Traveling around Russia in the glasnost year 1989, he was "continually remembering Chekhov stories and plays, inspired by an incident, a face, a venue . . . or even by an object such as a samovar, which always makes me think of 'Uncle Vanya,' or an old clock, which brings to mind 'Three Sisters.' " Even upon his arrival at Sheremetevo Airport in Moscow -- a most unromantic place -- he saw some straggly birches and remembered Chekhov's phrase "dear, modest birches." But above all it was at Yalta, where the doctor-playwright spent the last years of his short life, that the visiting American felt happily overwhelmed. The annual meeting of the Chekhov Society was taking place; he was impressed by the sense he had of all being on intimate terms with their hero. Invited unexpectedly to speak, he gave a "rambling and disjointed" talk, which received "a generous round of applause." Following an interview on Crimean television, he saw his image in a newspaper, "bearded, gesturing, a Chekhov fanatic."

title: BOXING;Tyson Reclaims His First Championship Belt
description: There's nothing left to speculate about. Mike Tyson is back, and dangerous.

title: Mad, Grand Gestures
description: Emerald City Stories. By Jennifer Egan. 178 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $22.50.

title: Cajun Charm
description: Thirty years after moving to New Orleans from staid Charleston, Rosemary James still revels in the city's mildewed grandeur. The formalities typical of the South -- swags at the windows, a parlor full of coordinated Chippendale -- are distorted in a town where masquerade confronts the tropical swelter of the bayou. Faux finishes, saturated color and elaborate ornamentation are the essence of New Orleans style, to which James, an interior designer, has brought her own sense of exaggerated elegance, for a look she calls Swamp Palazzo. You can see it in her own period gem: a 19th-century town house in the French Quarter, once a plantation owner's pied-a-terre, with wrought-iron balconies overlooking a garden. (Her husband, Joseph deSalvo, runs a bookstore on the ground floor, where William Faulkner wrote his first novel, "Soldiers' Pay.") Ten-foot windows and wide-plank cypress floors belie the diminutive size of the building, which has four tiny rooms per floor crammed with Louis XVI, Directoire and Napoleonic campaign furniture -- all chosen for its small scale and, believe it or not, says James, its comfort. Her palette is a curious blend of down-to-earth and dreamily evocative colors. The parlor and the dining room are what she calls Empire green, a shade appropriate to the early 19th century and the only hue that she and her husband could agree on. James imagined the bedroom with its violet walls, tented bed and striped chairs as a private homage to the country boudoir of Empress Josephine. In James's studio, a daybed made of two antique headboards sits directly in front of double doors thrown open to a garden. Fortunately, Swamp Palazzo is a very forgiving style, indifferent to the effects of sun and age on moire draperies and taffeta slipcovers. Time only renders it all the more splendid.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 3 about the Czech and Slovak American Enterprise Fund misspelled the surname of a director who was voted off the board last December. He is Joseph S. Fichera, not Fischera.

title: Keeping to a Safe Topic With the Prince
description: THE list of rules was simple.

title: Streetscapes/Cars;When Streets Were Vehicles for Traffic, Not Parking
description: THE New-York Historical Society's "New York Then and Now: The Upper West Side" is quite different from the usual show of old photographs. Working with a collection from the early 20th century, the curator, Dale Neighbors, presents successive images of Central Park West, Broadway and West End Avenue -- not so much of their buildings, but of the streets themselves, with matching current-day pictures by the Society's photographer, Glenn Castellano.

title: A LA CARTE;Hamptons Enterprise Expands to Manhattan
description: WHEN a heralded Manhattan restaurant opens a branch in the Hamptons, most diners there already know its name and flock to it. But what happens when the process is reversed?

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: LIGHT FANTASTIC Adventures in Theatre. By John Lahr. Dial, $23.95.

title: A Foreign Ensemble And Some From Home
description: IT is always a pleasure when musicians from abroad make stops in Westchester, as the Ysaye Quartet of Paris is doing today at 3 P.M., bringing Ravel, Debussy and Faure to Purchase College. In addition, there is great pride in the fact that many artists have chosen to live in the county, some of whom -- like James Wayne of Tarrytown and Eliot Friedman of Chappaqua -- are also appearing today.

description: MAYBE IT'S NO "BONNIE and Clyde," but for a while this winter credentials seemed in order for "Normal Life," a small, independently produced film about a Chicago couple who rob banks.

description: To the Editor:

title: CLASS IS NO LONGER A FOUR-LETTER WORD
description: The class content of a Pat Buchanan rally is so thick you can smell it. It smells like motor oil. Or so it does this February afternoon on the floor of a transmission factory in Fort Dodge, Iowa, where the air tools hiss, the employees wear coveralls and Buchanan confers upon them the proud title "worker." He issues his usual condemnations of corporate greed and pokes fun at Steve Forbes, his impossibly rich rival, for cooking up his ideas with "the boys down at the yacht club." He even solicits Democratic votes by mocking his own party's plutocratic past. "You can join the party of greed for one evening!"

title: OUTDOORS;A Walk Between Seasons
description: I finally took my customary, long-awaited March walk through the woods. This will undoubtedly surprise those of you who can't imagine anything about March being "long-awaited," other than the end of it.

title: Downsizing: How It Feels to Be Fired
description: EARLIER this month, The New York Times published a series of articles called "The Downsizing of America" about the causes and consequences of layoffs.

title: Wash, Cut, Tease, But Above All, Sell
description: THE roomful of hair stylists, manicurists and salon owners was engrossed as a slide projection showed a rushing river. "Write this down," Erica Miller ordered the participants in the session she was leading at last week's 79th International Beauty Show in Manhattan. "Water will revitalize you."

title: Corrections
description: A review on Feb. 18 of "Robertson Davies: Man of Myth," a biography by Judith Skelton Grant, misstated the nationality of the theater director Tyrone Guthrie, who invited Davies to join the Old Vic in London in 1938. Though Guthrie later directed several seasons of the Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Ontario, he was born in England and was never a citizen of Canada.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN BEACH/SHEEPSHEAD BAY;Bureaucratic Static Jams a Park Traffic Reduction Program
description: City officials had hoped to unveil a simple, ecologically friendly pilot project before Earth Day next month: Bicyclists and joggers would have full command of the road that snakes through Prospect Park, which would be open to cars only during rush hour in the summer.

title: March 10-16;Trial in South Korean
description: Sixteen years after seizing power, two former South Korean presidents went on trial last week. Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo, who once ruled the country virtually by whim, are the victims of the country's evolution to a democracy that has no warm memories of repression, corruption and killings.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST;Neither Flu Nor Fouls Can Stop the Utes
description: Utah proved once again that it can win without its star forward, Keith Van Horn.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Feb. 18 about Snowdonia National Park in Wales misattributed a mountain guide recommendation. The Snowdonia National Park Authority recommends only guides at the Climber and Rambler organization; Gordon Hartshorn was suggested by the Wales Tourist Board.

description: UI: 'SIDELONG' Southern Records, Box 25529, Chicago, Ill. 60625

title: Foreign Affairs;Bending The Mountains
description: As cities go, Taipei and Beijing have little in common. But having just traveled between the two, I found the mood in each eerily similar. In both capitals there is a dangerous hot-house political atmosphere, in which Taiwanese and Chinese politicians and generals, talking to themselves, have pumped themselves up with illusions and paranoia about the intentions of the other side, so much so that it's scary. Both of these nations need a dose of reality -- a two-by-four right across the side of the head to be exact -- that probably only the U.S. can provide at this time.

title: Day of Sorrow And Anger At a Wake
description: Their white gloves, crisp dress blues and solemn bowed heads signaled that the police officers huddled on a sun-dappled sidewalk here had not been summoned on ordinary business.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a biographical note on Feb. 18 with a review by Claire Tomalin of "The Diaries of Sylvia Townsend Warner" referred incorrectly to the actress who is the subject of the reviewer's book "Mrs. Jordan's Profession." Dorothea Jordan (1761-1816), professionally known as Mrs. Jordan, was for some 20 years the mistress of Prince William, Duke of Clarence (later King William IV) -- not of William's father, George III.

title: WHAT HAPPENED TO FRED CUNY?
description: Thank you for your fine article on Fred Cuny ("What Happened to Fred Cuny?" by Scott Anderson, Feb. 25), whom I met briefly some years ago. I long admired his courageous and quiet work, and that of his group, to help the needy and the less fortunate throughout the world.

description: To the Editor: Your page one article on March 10 on the seemingly "moderate" proposals to revamp and destroy science education illustrated well the feeling of helplessness and isolation faced by schoolteachers daring to teach evolution. More often, the pressure is much more local and less liable to press coverage.

title: ART;For Twins, a Shared Common Approach Before Paths Diverge
description: IN the beginning, there was one Anthony Carol -- and starting in the mid-1980's it seemed as if no group show in Connecticut could sail without her. Then came Elaine, her twin sister, materializing gradually like the Cheshire Cat and, since the early 90's, the two have been fixtures in Connecticut and Manhattan.

title: WEDDINGS;Barbara Danko and Michael J. Jones
description: Barbara Danko and Michael J. Jones, both lawyers, were married yesterday in South Orange, N.J. Msgr. Harold P. Darcy performed the ceremony at the Chapel of the Immaculate Conception at Seton Hall University.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Emotions Were of Many Hues Under Parade's Banners of Green
description: The Celtic music echoing through the canyons of Fifth Avenue during yesterday's St. Patrick's Day parade seemed to sound every note of the human experience. The bagpipes wailed for a fallen policeman. The flutes sang of a hope for peace. And the drums banged out a beat of defiant, exuberant joy.

title: Sleepless in San Diego
description: THE HOLY BOOK OF THE BEARD By Duff Brenna. 323 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $24.95.

title: New Drug Czar Is Seeking Ways to Bolster His Hand
description: When Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey talks about an "unraveling of physical and spiritual well-being" in the United States Army, he refers not to wartime Vietnam, where he pulled two combat tours and was badly wounded, but to peacetime Germany during the 1970's, in a military garrison ravaged by drug and alcohol abuse.

title: TELEVISION;TV Turns to an Era of Self-Control
description: IT IS SEPTEMBER 1998, and in flickering family rooms around the country, viewers are tuning in for their first glimpse of the new television season. Situation comedies dominate the prime-time schedules of the six networks, but there is bold drama as well. "N.Y.P.D. Blue," in its sixth season on ABC, is more provocative than ever.

title: Turmoil on Lower East Side Is Hardly Typical of Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Nights of the Living Dead
description: ANGEL STRINGS By Gary Eberle. 315 pp. Minneapolis: Coffee House Press. Paper, $12.95. FOR me, magic is usually the kiss of death when it comes to fiction. As soon as the angels start appearing, I get up and take out the garbage, preferably with the offending book right on top. I don't like things that couldn't really happen, I don't like time travel, I don't like dreams that maybe really aren't dreams after all and I abhor most of all an author's implication that mystical, wonderful, spiritual things are going on all around us. It will come as no surprise that my least favorite movie is "Miracle on 34th Street," with "It's a Wonderful Life" nipping at its sappy little heels.

title: N.H.L.'s Extra Points: Comebacks and Squandered Games;No Fair Chase
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Clinton Promises to Veto Product Liability Bill
description: President Clinton said today that if Congress approved pending legislation to limit damage awards in lawsuits involving faulty products he would veto the measure because it did not provide enough protection for consumers.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Some Postcard Postscripts
description: SUPPORTERS of the flat tax claim that by doing away with scores of deductions, exemptions and credits, the flat tax will create a loophole-free, airtight system that is so simple even large corporations will report their taxes on postcard-size returns. In reality, the flat tax -- as detailed in the legislation introduced by Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader -- will create gaping loopholes that cannot be closed without a new set of complicated rules.

title: New Releases
description: WYNONNA: 'REVELATIONS' Curb/MCA

title: With Land Sale Edict, Yeltsin Opens Way to Longed-For Era
description: The wheels of democracy were moving about as fast as molasses at the monthly session of the Tula Land Reform Committee. There was a lot of talk about tractor repair and tax laws. There were farmers wondering about when to plant the spring grain, and whether the Government was going to give them any money to do it.

title: On Multi-Cultural Education
description: If one of the main objectives of multi-cultural education is to teach students respect for diversity, that's admirable. If, however, it seeks to possibly revise history by say teaching youngsters the Spanish version of the Spanish-American war, then it is entering some murky waters. Would your reporter, the Anti-Defamation League or the American Jewish Congress like to see World War II taught from a German perspective, or would veterans organizations like to see the war against Japan taught from a Japanese point of view? As an American, a Jew and a veteran of that conflict, I would take great exception to such a curriculum.

title: Liberties;Rocket Scientist
description: O.K., I admit it.

title: The District Attorney And Publicity
description: Your March 3 article ["Pirro Assailed Over News Breaks"] certainly pointed up the question of whether District Attorney Jeanine Pirro is overly aggressive in courting the media to the potential detriment of the rights of the accused in criminal cases.

title: TV Consumer Reporter Thrives on Adversity
description: IMAGINE inviting 15 guests toddlers to 12-year-olds -- to your basement playroom, giving them glops of chocolate sauce, mustard, grape jelly, Twinkies with cream, then announcing, "O.K., kids, food fight!"

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Housing Industry Sees a Repeat of Listless '95 Sales
description: Last fall Joseph Morrison, a computer programer for AT&T, and his wife, Elizabeth, a teacher, decided to move from their town house in Hillsborough to a $250,000, four-bedroom house at a subdivision being built in Montgomery Township.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Aruba Plans to Expand Its National Park
description: Eco-tourism is taking a step forward in Aruba, which recently announced plans to expand and improve access to a national park and to create an environmentally protected zone outside the park. The project will double Aruba's protected land, making it 20 square miles, about one-fourth of the 73-square mile island.

title: Editors' Note
description: The New York Times Book Review carried a review last Sunday of "Perfect Villains, Imperfect Heroes: Robert F. Kennedy's War Against Organized Crime," by Ronald Goldfarb, a lawyer who worked in the Justice Department under Attorney General Kennedy. The review, by Selwyn Raab, a reporter who covers organized crime for The Times, acknowledged that Mr. Goldfarb's book cites disclosures and views presented in "Mob Lawyer," a book Mr. Raab wrote in 1994 with Frank Ragano, a lawyer who had represented organized crime bosses.

title: World News Briefs;Peruvian Court Upholds American's Life Sentence
description: The Peruvian military's highest court has upheld the sentence of life in prison without parole for an American woman convicted of aiding leftist guerrillas.

title: CHATTER;Embracing a New Season
description: Spring officially begins on Wednesday. After one of the snowiest winters on record, how do you plan to celebrate?

title: ON THE STREET;Beyond Olive Drab
description: There's nothing new about fashion as a uniform. What's new is a young generation's wearing uniforms as a fashion statement. What has emerged on the street is a jacket with a satiny finish made of a nylon and rayon fabric developed for the Army in 1964 and now used for police uniforms. It's these $120 jackets, without the insignia or gold buttons, that are the rage among young people who are dressing in a minimalist, institutional and utilitarian style. Produced by Spiewak and featured in its catalogues, the jackets are available in black, dark brown, vibrant orange and silver. The look dramatizes fashion's swing from the highly decorative to the highly durable.

title: New Releases
description: DEDE SAINT-PRIX: 'CHOUVAL BWA SANS FRONTIERES' Declic

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;Hoist on Their Own Ad Campaigns
description: IN the world of advertising, guerrilla warfare has broken out.

title: Fight Roils Museum and Wealthy Neighbors
description: Inside, the atmosphere is quiet, studied and spectacular. For decades, the Barnes Foundation here on the Philadelphia Main Line has dazzled visitors for the extraordinary number of paintings by Renoir, Matisse, Cezanne and other masters, all displayed in the quirky, clustered manner that the founder, Dr. Albert C. Barnes, chose to promote his theories of art appreciation.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;Preserving The Relics Of the Fairs
description: The New York World's Fairs once heralded "the world of tomorrow" and "something for everyone." Now, slightly more than 30 years after the gates at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park closed on the 1964-65 extravaganza, the cash-strapped city can only watch as the theme park crumbles and millions of pieces of memorabilia are gobbled up by other museums, slip into the hands of private collectors or simply disappear.

title: IMAGES AS ICONS;Early Quotable
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;The Beatles Recycle Yesterday (Part 2 of 3)
description: Memo to beginning bands: Save everything. Every false start, every discarded arrangement, every bungled vocal. With luck, you can release them 30 years later and conquer the top 10 all over again. The only other requirement is that the first time around, you have to revolutionize popular music.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;A Storm Over a Dorm Plan
description: A $147 million building plan by Columbia University, intended to ease a shortage in student housing and replace aging structures, is running into opposition from preservation-minded neighbors. In recent well-attended meetings with neighborhood residents, Columbia presented its plan for five new buildings. Several others may be demolished to make way for the new, which will include a student center to replace Ferris Booth Hall, and a dormitory.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Deals and Discounts
description: TAHITI TOUR A seven-night package to Tahiti and Moorea is offered by New Frontiers at a price starting at $1,039 a person, double occupancy, including round-trip air fare from Los Angeles or Oakland. (Because Corsair, the charter airline used in the package, does not serve Tahiti from the East Coast, travelers from New York must buy tickets for a flight to California on another airline and make a connection.) The package includes two nights' hotel in Papeete, five in Moorea and ferry between Papeete and Moorea. It is available through December. Information: (800) 366-6387 or (212) 779-0600.

title: ART VIEW;Islands of Peace in a Life Awash in Sadness
description: The American visionary Ralph Albert Blakelock is known for softly Romantic paintings, made mostly in the 1880's and 90's, that depict moonlight glimmering through screens of leafy trees or hazy Indian encampments dwarfed by their natural settings. Blakelock, who was born in New York City in 1847 and died in 1919, is also known for a life of such suffering that it reads more like a soap-opera version of artistic sacrifice than the real thing, as a small exhibition at the Heckscher Museum here makes abundantly clear. Recognition had once seemed likely. A self-taught artist with exceptional gifts as a draftsman, Blakelock had seen his work exhibited at the National Academy of Design when he was only 20.

title: IMAGES AS ICONS;A Creative Call to Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday March 17, 1996: BY THE NUMBERS;Fortune Of Wheels
description: A set of wheels for $4,500 sounds reasonable enough -- provided there's a car attached. But four gold-plated wire wheels alone can cost that much, a fact that hasn't escaped notice of the bad guys.

title: Sports of The Times;Left Hooks Silence Bruno's Fans
description: IN the MGM Grand's arcade of restaurants, bars and shops, hundreds of British believers in the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion were waving Union Jacks, wearing Union Jack 'do rags, holding their drinks and singing.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Astros Looking to Las Vegas
description: The Houston Astros, whose spring-training lease in Florida expires this month, are considering Las Vegas, Nev., and three other sites, the owner, DRAYTON McLANE, said.

title: Q and A
description: Archeology in Europe

title: DANCE VIEW;Transformed Before Your Very Eyes
description: THE LOVELY ODETTE IS turned into a swan. A grotesque Nutcracker becomes a handsome prince. Choreographers love changing dancers into something other than what they initially appear to be.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/NoHo;Spacious Lofts, Cast Iron and Ultrachic
description: ANTIQUES stores have replaced crack vials on Bond Street, stylish restaurants are opening all over NoHo and loft prices continue to climb, making it a vibrant, viable neighborhood.

title: WEDDINGS;Ha Yun Kang, David S.H. Cho
description: Ha Yun Kang, a daughter of Consul General and Mrs. Shin Sung Kang of Honolulu and Seoul, South Korea, was married yesterday to David Sang Hyun Cho, the son of Hae Soon Kang Cho and Kyu Won Cho of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Hong Jung Shik, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Institute for Diplomacy and Security Studies in Seoul.

title: Commercial Property/Port Authority Bus Terminal;A Former Haven of Sleaze Is Now a Refuge of Retail
description: A FEW years ago, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey asked commuters what sorts of stores they would like to see at the 42d Street bus terminal. Most mentioned drugstores. That made sense -- except that for more than 40 years a Walgreen Drug Store had been operating in Center Court, the terminal's most heavily trafficked area.

title: MUSIC;A Recital With Scores From Thomas Jefferson
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON was not only a profound thinker and master statesman, but also a man who declared that music was his passion. He played the violin well and the cello tolerably, copied "fiddlers' tunes" into his notebooks, composed several string quartets, and maintained an extensive music library.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: I SURVIVED CARACAS TRAFFIC Stories From the Me Decades. By Richard Grayson. Avisson Press, 3007 Taliaferro Road, Greensboro, N.C. 27408, $21.

title: FILM VIEW;Hollywood Gets Raked Across the Stage
description: SHE WALKS ON STAGE IN A FRUMPY housedress, her hair in an old-fashioned French twist, wearing bright yellow rubber gloves for washing the dishes. "I live with my husband, my two children and my flawless Italian accent," says Toni DiBuono as Meryl Streep, "on my farm in Africa . . . er, er, Iowa!" Though Ms. DiBuono's wickedly on-target impersonations are one of the delights of the musical revue "Forbidden Hollywood," the scene probably wouldn't work without those rubber gloves. They offer the kind of grimy, unglamorous detail missing from "The Bridges of Madison County," sending up the film as the antiseptic fairy tale it is.

title: U.N., World Bank and I.M.F. Join $25 Billion Drive for Africa
description: With Africa falling deeper into debt and poverty, the United Nations has announced a joint program involving the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and its own agencies aimed at raising $25 billion over the next decade to spur development on the continent.

title: INSIDE
description: A Familiar Enemy

title: THE NIGHT;A Pressing O' the Flesh
description: IRISH eyes were all on President Clinton on Monday night as he walked into the grand ballroom of the Plaza to receive the Irish-American of the year award (a Waterford crystal dove on an American flag backdrop) at a dinner for 400 given by Irish America magazine.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Cornell's Trip to N.C.A.A. Comes Courtesy of ECAC
description: Cornell's season of small miracles continued tonight when it won the ECAC tournament championship here with a 2-1 victory over Harvard.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE

title: Special-Needs Children Face Education Cuts
description: CURRENT plans by Gov. George E. Pataki to cut funds for preschool special education programs by 20 percent has alarmed parents and educators. The proposals would also change the membership of the committees that determine which children should receive services, restrict eligibility for some services, including summer programs, and shift some of the cost to local school districts.

title: WEDDINGS;Lisa Considine And Alexis Kraft
description: Lisa Considine, a daughter of Drs. Maria and Daniel Considine of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to Alexis Kraft, a son of Madeline and Eric Kraft of East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. George Rassas performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Lake Forest.

title: Athletes Standing Up As They Did Before
description: Thanks to Mahmoud and Muffin, we've just enjoyed a quick trip back to the late 1960's-early 70's. Because so many of the racial, religious, sexual and political issues that flared in that hot, jittery and still unresolved period were smothered in the sports boom of the 80's, it sometimes seemed as though the brief era of athletes making principled stands didn't so much end as take a rain delay.

title: IN BRIEFS;The Changing Concert Scene: More Seats on the Way
description: As spring approaches, music-lovers begin thinking ahead to the summer concert season, but in New Jersey the sites keep changing. After losses like the Capitol Theater in Passaic, which closed in the 1980's and later burned, and the temporary Summerfest facility that the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority ran in a parking lot near Giants Stadium in 1992, the number of concert sites has begun to expand instead of shrink.

title: N.H.L.'s Extra Points: Comebacks and Squandered Games;Magic's Role
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DIARY
description: THE AUTO BUSINESS Strike Against G.M. Expands At stake is one of the fundamental issues in the auto industry: do companies have a right to shop for lower prices by buying parts from outside suppliers, putting many of their workers' jobs at risk? As befits such a fundamental issue, no easy solution is in sight. What started as a walkout by 3,000 members of the United Automobile Workers at two G.M. brake-assembly plants in Dayton, Ohio, has led to more than 47,000 layoffs and another 70,000 workers idled. Throughout the auto business, hundreds of suppliers began feeling the impact as G.M. shut two dozen assembly plants. G.M. says that to reduce costs it must turn to lower-paid nonunion workers. For the week, though, G.M. shares barely budged.

title: Times Readers Help the Neediest
description: In 1912, when The Times published its first stories about the city's 100 neediest cases, 117 readers responded with contributions of $3,630. Thus began a long chronicle of public-spirited generosity toward New Yorkers whose lives have spun out of control, whether through loss of work, drug addiction, physical abuse, mental illness or other unhappy circumstances.

title: In the Bloomingdale's Area, It's Not Just Retailing
description: THE word from Frank Pizzuro is that Diesel U.S.A. has scored a big hit with what he calls the very-forward, very-fast styles it offers at its new store on Lexington Avenue and 60th Street.

title: FUNDS WATCH;Crunching Numbers Beyond the Border
description: Fund managers who rely on quantitative analysis -- meaning that they use computers to analyze reams of data and come up with good stock prospects -- have had a mediocre record abroad.

title: House Buying Made Simple on the Web
description: AN American in Paris recently bought a house in Larchmont without leaving France. Similarly, a Texas family made an offer on a home in Wilton, Conn., without going there. Whether it's Paris, France or Paris, Tex., anyone with access to the Internet can now "see" thousands of homes, apartments, hotels and office buildings all over the world, and they are available for sale or rent on the ever-widening World Wide Web.

title: WEDDINGS;Richard Kahan, Katherine Lobell
description: Katherine Swenson Lobell, a civic volunteer, was married yesterday to Richard Alan Kahan, the urban developer and a former president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. Justice Ernst H. Rosenberger of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the couple's home in New York.

title: Not Out of Africa'
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Connecticut;Home Seekers Buying More, Especially in Fairfield
description: WEAKENING consumer confidence held back home sales and new construction in 1995, Connecticut real-estate professionals say, except in lower Fairfield County, which continued to attract a steady stream of affluent buyers. But the first two months of 1996 have produced a spurt of contracts that has raised industry expectations for a better, if not a banner, year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 8 in the Arts and Leisure section today carries an outdated reference to the opening of a revival of "Inherit the Wind" on Broadway. On Thursday, after the section was printed, the play, which is to star George C. Scott and Charles Durning, was postponed indefinitely because Mr. Scott was ill; it will not open tomorrow night.

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Rinzler, Mr. Buckingham
description: Jane Ruth Rinzler, the daughter of Dr. Carl Rinzler of New York and the late Carol Eisen Rinzler, was married last evening to Marcus W. Buckingham, a son of Mrs. Peter Boorman of London and Graeme Buckingham of Sarratt, England. The Rev. Mark Aitken, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York.

title: INVESTING IT;The Hotels With the Nicest Rooms Win
description: THE stock market has been volatile this year but don't blame the lodging industry. It has been one of the top-performing Dow Jones industrial groups for most of the year and recently passed the hot precious-metals and casino sectors to become No. 1.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Fidelity Realignment: Not Just New Faces
description: SHAREHOLDERS in two dozen Fidelity funds will probably see a significant shift in how their money is managed because of an overhaul in the equity funds division announced by Fidelity Investments last week.

title: DINING OUT;The Look of Spring in a Bistro Setting
description: SPRING came early to Bistro 99 in Atlantic Beach. Since it opened last October, diners have been eating amidst bouquets of flowers and plants, single blooms on every table and a room divider painted to resemble a garden wall complete with hand-stenciled foxgloves and ferns.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Widell Joins Colts Offense
description: The Indianapolis Colts got more help for their offensive line yesterday, signing DOUG WIDELL, the unrestricted free agent offensive guard.

title: Many States Fail to Fulfill Child Welfare
description: At least 21 states are under court supervision because they failed to take proper care of children who had been abused or neglected, and many of them have flouted their obligations even after promising in legal settlements to protect the constitutional rights of foster children, court records show.

title: Cuttings;Signs That Spring Is Just Around the Corner
description: My friend George, a history buff, just told me about the spring of 1816, which never came. It snowed in June on Long Island.

title: THEATER;Coward's Last Work, Superstar Al Pacino
description: FOR late-season reconstruction, the Long Wharf Theater steals the show. Consider a major cast replacement in the current production as well as three newly scheduled attractions to light the theater for two months beyond the closing of the season's last entry, "All in the Timing" by David Ives.

title: WEDDINGS;Lelia Wardwell, Edmund Mander
description: Lelia M. Wardwell, the daughter of Sarah and Allen Wardwell 2d of New York, was married yesterday to Edmund Mander, a son of Enid and Noel Mander of Earl Soham, England. The Rev. George Packard performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Epiphany in New York. The Rev. Henry A. Tilghman, an uncle of the bride and an Episcopal minister, assisted.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FRESH MEADOWS;Adult Theater Reborn as Indian Movie House
description: Joining a growing number of Indian movie theaters in the city, the former Mayfair Theater, a gay adult movie establishment on Fresh Meadow Lane, reopened this weekend as the Bombay Theater.

title: THE DECAY OF CINEMA
description: Susan Sontag sharply brings into focus the final melancholy frames of cinephilia ("The Decay of Cinema," Feb. 25). Those of us lucky enough to have fallen in love with cinema in the 60's and 70's have shed many tears at the loss of this once faithful, inspired and surprising lover.

title: UP AND COMING: Kcho;Art Is a Cuban's Vessel to Freedom
description: WHEN HE FIRST ARRIVED in New York from Havana in January, Kcho (whose original name was Alexis Leyva Machado) met a man who had emigrated from Cuba years before. "How did you get here?" the man asked. "Were you held in Guantanamo?"

title: IN THE KITCHEN;A Change of Pace: Squid and Octopus
description: CALL it calamari if you will, but squid has achieved an acceptance that would have seemed impossible 15 or so years ago. And now octopus is on the way.

title: March 10-16;F.B.I. and Vietnamese Spies
description: Can a spy be brought in from the cold by a newspaper ad?

title: Rebound Reported In Office Occupancy
description: THE view to the east from Oxford Health Plan's new offices here show Westchester's rolling hills blanketed in snow. The west side affords a panorama of downtown White Plains. "You've got the bucolic on one side, and you've got the urban on the other," said Steve Daniels, regional director of operations for Oxford. "Of all of our offices, this is the nicest in terms of work environment."

title: The Teacher Who Would Be President
description: TOMORROW the pundits will have to pause in their shifting assessments of Dole and Buchanan to consider the Schneller factor.Because shortly after 2 P.M., if all goes according to plan, Walter N. Schneller will be nominated for President here and will accept with a stirring, 800-word speech.

title: SHELTER;At Three Times the Population, This Town Will Still Be Tiny
description: In most towns, a dozen or so new apartments would be little more than a footnote to community history. But in this borough, a proposal to build 12 to 16 apartments on a 2.5-acre site represents a seismic change in the landscape, with the potential of tripling its population.

title: ARCHITECTURE;Rediscovering the Legacy of Brazil's Coffee Barons
description: BRAZIL'S ARCHITECTURAL identity has been defined by its Portuguese-influenced Baroque churches, Oscar Niemeyer's modernism and the high-rises that rim the beaches of Rio de Janeiro. But now the fazenda de cafe, or coffee plantation, once the seat of a powerful, slave-holding rural aristocracy and the source of Brazil's biggest export, is being rediscovered and newly appreciated as a significant part of the country's architectural legacy.

title: The Best Years of His Life
description: A TALENT FOR TROUBLE The Life of Hollywood's Most Acclaimed Director, William Wyler. By Jan Herman. Illustrated. 518 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $35.

title: Mass. Appeal
description: While the Music Lasts My Life in Politics. By William M. Bulger. Illustrated. 328 pp. Boston: A Richard Todd Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.

title: GARDENING;The Not-So-Secret Basis for Success
description: GARDENING is an endeavor that works from the ground up -- success depends almost entirely on the quality of the soil.

title: WEDDINGS;Anne M. Falvey, Daniel O'Connell
description: Anne Meade Falvey, a daughter of Marilyn and Paul Falvey of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel O'Connell, a son of Joanne and Edward O'Connell of Pittsburgh. The Rev. James Keenan, the president of St. Peter's Prep School in Jersey City, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: Sunday March 17, 1996: LOVE OF BLARNEY;Greener Pastures
description: Five's a bad omen, four's the good one and three's the crowd. No mind, it's a three-leaved plant that will color that crowd of Irish-Americans who parade their heritage today, decked out in shamrock bow ties, shamrock shirts, shamrock everything. All this for a sprig of wild clover?

title: The View From: White Plains;Tara Circle Keeps in Step With Its Educational Programs

description: NUSRAT FATEH ALI KHAN AND MICHAEL BROOK: 'NIGHT SONG' Caroline

Although the economic conditions of the Irish people have changed since then, the Christian Brothers still put their stamp of Irish practicality and sense of community on students at places like Iona College.

title: Running Short On Volunteers'
description: I read with interest the article, "Running Short on Volunteers" [Jan. 28].

If you gaze at it with narrowed eyes, and block out the sound of ambulance sirens and other passing traffic, you might sense the serenity of a century ago, when the house was part of a neighborhood called Nook Farm.

I just can't resist these European deals -- which explains what I was doing, polishing off a split of Bandita Rioja 1991 on an Iberia Airlines flight from New York to Madrid last month.

description: IN an effort to curb teen-agers' use of marijuana the police and schools in East Hampton are asking stores to stop selling rolling papers.

Bauer. In a dignified obituary on page 9 of the March 7 issue, the weekly Leader told its 6,500 readers only that Mr. Bauer, 48, "died suddenly" three days earlier.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Father and Son Locked in a Universal Struggle
description: IN the new play at the Crossroads Theater Company, five characters tidily personify a theme, a conflict and a resolution. The prerequisites for playmaking are in place. But where's the play?

title: A Little Money Going a Long Way Indeed
description: ELIZABETH ROBERTS, 7 years old, knows well what it's like to stay overnight at a hospital: "One day I woke up and I said, 'Mommy -- where are you?' I wanted to go home."

title: The Un-Nominated

If she does it again as the Academy Awards are handed out next Monday night, who can blame her? The Academy overlooked her scorching performance as a needy, no-talent singer, but it nominated Mare Winningham (a very worthy contender) for playing the composed and beloved country music star in the family. Leigh cannot have failed to get the message. She's a fearless actress and, in "Georgia," a great one. But America's sweetheart she's not.

description: An avalanche killed at least 32 people today in a village in northern Pakistan.

description: SINCE 1993, when the Board of Education began the citywide choice policy, parents in New York have had more freedom, at least in theory, about where they send their children to public school.

description: S,M,L,XL (Small, Medium, Large, Extra-Large). By Rem Koolhaas and Bruce Mau. Edited by Jennifer Sigler. Photographs by Hans Werlemann. 1,344 pp. New York: The Monacelli Press. $75.

title: INVESTING IT;Fidelity Tries Pitch To Masses
description: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS, already dominant in the $3 trillion mutual fund industry, is heading straight for Middle America.

title: March 10-16;Jump-Starting Mideast Peace Despite Political Roadblocks
description: It lasted barely four hours, but the "summit of the peacekmakers" in Egypt last week was extraordinary. Twenty-nine world leaders convened to condemn terrorism and pledge support for peace in the Middle East.

title: Charting Ups and Downs of Village Centers
description: PERHAPS the sad turnaround began when Gristede's supermarket left town. Now the empty storefront is like a gaping wound along a busy stretch of East Hartsdale Avenue here where commuters travel daily. By all accounts, businesses should be thriving in this picturesque hamlet, from the little stone train station at one end of the small commercial strip to the apartments and gracious homes on the other end.

title: March 10-16;Bombs for the Making
description: Whatever the legacy of the former Soviet Union, its leaders did the outside world one important favor: They kept tight rein on the radioactive material that terrorists and rogue governments covet in making nuclear weapons.

title: Fund for Women a Leader in Addressing Inequities
description: FOR a new organization helping immigrant women from Central America, $2,000 was enough to turn an idea into reality.

title: Behind Prison Walls, Poor Reading Skills Also Pose a Barrier
description: About two-thirds of prison inmates have such poor reading and arithmetic skills that they are unable to write a brief letter explaining a billing error or interpret a bar graph, according to a new study of literacy, education and training in the nation's prisons.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Rumpole Returns
description: First-rate comic writing is often more difficult to produce than the serious stuff, and real pros are few and far between. One of these is John Mortimer, an Englishman best known in this country for his mystery stories starring the comic and gallant barrister Horace Rumpole. Mr. Mortimer knows his territory, and his comments on the vagaries of the English legal system and the small value it places on common sense and moral standards are as sharp as ever in RUMPOLE AND THE ANGEL OF DEATH (Viking, $22.95), the 10th volume of stories in the series. In Rumpole, Mr. Mortimer has created a wonderfully durable and attractive character, henpecked as a husband but masterful with a jury, an honest man whose only cause is "preventing the conviction of the innocent." Rumpole's true home is the courtroom, but we are also made privy to life in the gloomy flat in Froxbury Mansions where he exists in pitiful thralldom to his wife, Hilda, otherwise known as She Who Must Be Obeyed. This moniker notwithstanding, the forbidding Hilda has occasional moments of decency, and Rumpole fans will be amused to find one story narrated by Hilda herself, in which she reveals surprisingly romantic yearnings as she contemplates an affair with a smarmy colleague of her husband's. In his happy ability to play a seemingly infinite number of diverting variations on the same theme, in the fluidity and panache of his prose, his combination of high intelligence and low foolery, John Mortimer is worthy of comparison to P. G. Wodehouse. "Rumpole and the Angel of Death," like all of the preceding Rumpole volumes, makes for ideally civilized light reading. Brooke Allen

title: Correction
description: A listing last Sunday in a schedule of events for Women's History Month was outdated and was published in error. The National Association of Women Artists Collection was exhibited at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers in 1995; it is not currently on exhibit.
