title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;A Portrait of an Angry Art Lover
description: For Sotheby's, the auction house now in full ballyhoo over the upcoming sale of hundreds of items from Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis's estate, Douglas Esposit is a fly in the bisque.

title: Long Island Q&A: Dr. Barbara Burkhard;Evaluating Parents and Their Children in Stressful Situations
description: IN 1993, Dr. Barbara Burkhard developed the Child Treatment Program in the mental health division of the North Suffolk Center, part of the County Health Services Department.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Doisneau's Paris
description: Near the end of ROBERT DOISNEAU: A Photographer's Life (Abbeville, $75), Peter Hamilton explains that his book was "supposed to be the 'definitive' monograph" about the French photographer, born in 1912, who spent his life documenting the sometimes lonely beauty, enduring romance and comic contrasts he found in Paris and its suburbs from the 1920's to the 80's. A sociologist, Mr. Hamilton was clearly able to understand that Doisneau's art was deeply rooted, reflecting both his pride of place and his humanism. A typical photograph from the 30's shows carefree boys watching a merry-go-round. A shot of a coal ration card against a snow-covered Paris Opera illustrates the hardships of the occupation. A photograph of unkempt children in an empty, cobblestoned Paris square speaks of France's dreary 50's; and new suburban concrete overpasses and modern apartment buildings show up in Doisneau's late pictures. Doisneau's death in 1994, before the book's completion, obviously came as a personal loss for the author. "Robert Doisneau: A Photographer's Life" is less exhaustive than it appears, for all its nearly 400 dense, oversized pages, with almost as many striking duotone and color reproductions, and the appendixes and interviews. For one thing, many of the book's pages could have been better used to show photographs and to provide details about projects only mentioned in passing, rather than to describe Doisneau's very static life (he inhabited the same suburban apartment from 1937 on and almost never traveled abroad). Most important, Mr. Hamilton eschews any real discussion of Doisneau's frequent use of models, actors and mises-en-scne in order to re-create scenes of daily life. His world-famous 1950 photograph "Baiser de l'H/tel de Ville," for instance, was far from being documentary; it was staged. Without an exploration of the practice of presenting as candid something that isn't, and of the ethical and photo-historical questions it raises, a monograph about Doisneau can't be definitive. Christine Schwartz Hartley

title: In Yonkers, the Cancer Fight Broadens
description: WHEN Joan Borgatti's doctor told her that he wanted to do a bone marrow transplant to treat her breast cancer, she thought she was going to die. After he explained the procedure to her, it made sense: who was a better candidate for the latest cancer treatment than a 30-year-old mother of two?

description: After two failed bids for the Presidency, Bob Dole is trying something different this time, with some success: he is listening to the people he hired to give him advice.

The Center for Hope comes alive at night, when, behind its cozy curtained windows, support groups meet to talk about the loss of a loved one or how to deal with a life-threatening illness. Some celebrate their survival. All join to cope.

description: A land mine killed a 14-year-old boy and seriously wounded his mother near Sarajevo, the capital, the newspaper Oslobodjenje reported today.

title: Patents;Changes in meat inspection rules prompt innovations to deal with contamination.
description: THE Federal meat inspection system is about to undergo its first major modernization in 90 years, with more stringent regulations to be announced in a few weeks. The long-anticipated changes have spurred a wide range of technological innovations among meat and poultry processors, which are searching for ways to reduce the incidence of salmonella and other bacterial contamination.

title: Hans-Joachim Bremermann, 69, Professor
description: Hans-Joachim Bremermann, a biomathematician who provided insight into the nature of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, died on Feb. 21 at Alta Bates Medical Center in Berkeley, Calif. He was 69 and lived in Berkeley.

title: NATO Forces Have to Watch As a Sarajevo District Burns
description: Grbavica, the final Serbian-held enclave in the Sarajevo area that will come under Muslim-Croat control, was rent by huge explosions tonight as fires swept through the district and gangs armed with cans of gasoline dodged NATO patrols in an effort to ignite high-rise apartment blocks. There was little that the NATO-led peacekeeping forces appeared able to do.

title: Exhibitions Celebrate a Times Centennial
description: Four of New York's most prominent cultural institutions will join together to produce a series of exhibitions in June to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the publisher Adolph S. Ochs's purchase of The New York Times. The unusual collaboration, which involves the New York Public Library, the Museum of Modern Art, the American Museum of Natural History and the Pierpont Morgan Library, celebrates the stewardship of Ochs, whose acquisition of the paper for $75,000 in August 1896 marked the beginning of the modern history of The Times.

title: Why Principals Defect
description: Strong, resourceful principals are indispensable to school reform, so it is alarming to find that some of New York City's best principals are being drawn in increasing numbers to the suburbs, where salaries are considerably higher, support services are abundant and budget cuts are less threatening.

title: Phone Plan Is Attracting Immigrants In New York
description: Danny Coronel, a bartender from Elmhurst, Queens, lost his telephone when a former friend used it for calls to Hong Kong -- $1,900 worth. Jose Ramos, a livery-cab driver, and his wife, Jackie, never had a phone, even though they moved to Washington Heights in Manhattan from the Dominican Republic more than two years ago. "We didn't have anything in our name in this country," Mr. Ramos said. "It was just too hard."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Tobacco Industry Inquiries Have Quietly Broadened The Justice Department has expanded an array of criminal and civil inquiries into the tobacco industry, lawyers say. While department officials had cautioned earlier that indictments were unlikely, the tobacco companies' aura of invincibility in court has been weakened by industry whistle-blowers, disclosures of internal company documents and an agreement by the Liggett Group to settle its part of a class-action suit against the major tobacco companies. [Page A1.] Progress in G.M. Talks After a weekend of negotiations, representatives of General Motors and the United Auto Workers seemed optimistic about settling a 12-day strike at two brake plants that has forced the closure of 24 assembly plants and idled tens of thousands of workers. [A10.]

title: MUSIC REVIEW;In a Flowery Garden, Mozartean Complexities
description: Almost everything about "La Finta Giardiniera" speaks to youth. Mozart was 18 when he wrote it. The libretto, of cloudy origin, offers toothless erotic peccadillo: bikini-beach romance transposed to an 18th-century garden.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Carlson's New Hire For Lauren Account
description: Neil Kraft, a creative executive in fashion and retail advertising, has joined Carlson & Partners in New York in the new position of senior vice president and creative director, working on the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation account.

title: U S West Rejected Time Warner Offer
description: Time Warner Inc. offered U S West Inc. an 80 percent stake in their jointly owned cable television systems in exchange for regaining complete control of a shared entertainment operation, an executive of U S West testified on Friday.

title: The Beltway Campaign
description: After wrapping up his latest primary victories last week, Senator Bob Dole said it was "time to go back to work" in Washington. Coming from a man who has been fighting hard in the campaign all year, that comment spoke volumes about the unfinished business facing the Republican Congress and President Clinton. The latest word is that Mr. Dole will push for perhaps dozens of ideologically driven bills on the budget, tax cuts, welfare reform and other issues, forcing the President to wield his veto pen.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Pitcher Burns Hands
description: Boston Red Sox pitcher VAUGHN ESHELMAN burned his hands early yesterday while trying to extinguish a fire in his hotel room in Fort Myers, Fla. The fire started when his wife, JULIE, was trying to warm a baby bottle for their 2 1/2-month old son, EVAN, with a candle. A wash cloth became ignited by the flame and when the fire spread, Eshelman tried to smother it with his hands, Red Sox officials said. He suffered second-degree burns. (AP)

title: Canadian Killed in Florida
description: A vacationing Canadian high school student was fatally shot here late Friday night, and a teen-ager wanted in the killing surrendered to the police today and was charged with murder.

title: Stuart Watson, 79; Led Wine Company
description: Stuart D. Watson, a former chairman and chief executive of Heublein Inc. who led the wine and spirits company during a period of great expansion, died on Tuesday in Venice Hospital in Florida. He was 79, and a resident of West Hartford, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Start Fast But Can't Keep Pace
description: The Islanders gave up a power-play goal and a short-handed goal, repeatedly blew defensive coverages and betrayed all their inexperience in a 5-1 loss to the Chicago Blackhawks today at the United Center.

title: Sports of The Times;Tyson Is a Champion Without a Marquee
description: HE'S the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion again, but Mike Tyson is a marquee fighter without a marquee fight.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Limousine Rider Is Wounded
description: A 35-year-old Newark man was shot in the shoulder yesterday by a man who carjacked the limousine he had been riding in, police said. The wounded man, Mohammed Hassan Sayed, remained in guarded condition last night at University Hospital, a nursing supervisor said.

title: Democrats Split on Line-Item-Veto Legislation
description: Senate Democrats on Friday sharply criticized a Republican agreement on a line-item veto proposal, a plan developed by Republican leaders in the expectation of support from President Clinton.

title: Corrections
description: An article and headline in some copies of Business Day on Tuesday about Barry Diller's deal to take control of Silver King Communciations reported the action of the Federal Communications Commission incompletely. The commission approved the deal but stayed its completion pending consideration of objections filed by the Urban Broadcasting Corporation, which asserts that Mr. Diller violated the Government's multiple-ownership rules. A brief report in the Diary column in Money and Business yesterday repeated the error.

title: Portrait of a Suicide Bomber: Devout, Apolitical and Angry
description: Just two days before he boarded a Jerusalem bus and ignited a satchel packed with TNT, blowing himself up and killing 25 passengers, Majdi Abu Warda spent an hour quietly arguing with his mother about going on a family picnic.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The small American agency for Intel is now inside a huge worldwide parent company, Euro RSCG.
description: THE high-tech marketer that urges computer users to insist on "Intel inside" has unexpectedly consolidated its advertising at a global giant, but in a twist will not leave its small American agency on the outside.

title: MEDIA: TELEVISION;The first devices to block TV programs with sex or violence ratings might be months away.
description: EMPOWERING parents -- that is supposed to be the reason the television industry has agreed to rate shows for sexual and violent content, and the reason Congress has required that sometime after 1998, TV sets must include a device to allow consumers to block shows with certain ratings.

title: Thomas Enders, Diplomat In Cold War, Is Dead at 64
description: Thomas O. Enders, a career diplomat who played a major role in the secret bombing of Cambodia during the Nixon Administration and guided the early Reagan Administration policy in Central America, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 64.

title: Essay;A Case for Polyandry
description: The institution of marriage has been put into play.

title: World News Briefs;African Leaders to Tape Refugee-Return Appeal
description: Presidents from Rwanda and surrounding countries have agreed to videotape promises of safety to refugees who return home.

title: Reviews/Fashion;From Gaultier, Sense of Humor With a Twist
description: My name is Amber Valetta," said the supermodel Amber Valetta, talking into a camera being beamed to a dozen cubed television screens suspended at the end of the runway of Jean-Paul Gaultier's show on Friday night. "Big cubes, small cubes, my head is a cube."

title: Yes, Writing English Is a Process. And It's Easy.
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Southeastern Conference Showing Power in Numbers
description: Their first-round victory, an inefficient, uninspiring survival against Virginia Commonwealth, inspired this observation about the Mississippi State Bulldogs: This is the team that beat Kentucky?

title: Text and Subtext
description: The National Council of Teachers of English has issued its long-awaited curriculum guidelines. The report, which the council developed with the International Reading Association, was immediately attacked for being too loose and brief, for containing "very vague and general statements," as Michael Cohn, a senior adviser to Education Secretary Richard W. Riley, said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Budget Hearing Scheduled
description: Seventy-three people, including representatives of various educational institutions, teachers, parents and students, are scheduled to testify Wednesday at Trenton State College, when the Senate and Assembly budget committees hold the second in a series of hearings on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed $16 billion budget. A third hearing will be the following Wednesday at the Atlantic City Convention Center.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST;Louisville Sends Villanova Home
description: Last year, they were knocked out by Old Dominion in the first round. This season, the Villanova Wildcats, led by the all-American Kerry Kittles, had greater expectations. But reaching the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament was not what they had in mind.

title: At 27, a Talk Star Sets Out To Transform Chinese TV
description: Yang Lan traveled from Shanghai to New York City to attend graduate school because, she said, her fans back home in China would not have left her alone to study. Oprah Winfrey could sympathize.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: State Regulators Coordinate Lloyd's Inquiry
description: State securities regulators have begun coordinating a fraud investigation of Lloyd's of London, the world's largest insurance market.

title: World News Briefs;Austrian Urges Repeal Of Anti-Hapsburg Law
description: After the Hapsburg heir to Austria's throne defied a law barring the former imperial family from the country, President Thomas Klestil said in an interview published today that the law was anachronistic and that the aging sons of the last Emperor posed no threat to the country.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: 2 Bodies Found in East Village Apartment
description: The bodies of a man and a woman who had been shot were found in an East Village apartment on Saturday afternoon after residents of the building complained about a persistent odor, the police said. The police said they did not know the victims' identities and had no suspects in the case. No weapon was found, they said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Q & A:/ Joseph S. Nye Jr. : Military's Muscle-Flexing In a Chinese Political Game
description: Joseph S. Nye Jr. was assistant U.S. secretary of defense for international security affairs until December. He is now the dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. He spoke about China and Taiwan with Brian Knowlton of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Federal Budget Impasse Hits Home With the Threat of Layoffs in School Districts
description: Teresa McAnaney and her colleagues at the Pleasant Valley Elementary School here have tended to view the budget stalemate in Washington as a distant drama that has mainly led to the periodic closing of the nation's parks and museums and a handful of Government agencies.

title: Behind the Scenes;My Way or the Highway
description: Recent legislation provided outlines for technical standards in the personal communications industry, but not all standards debates are solved so easily. Most often, as in the case of videocassettes, when the Betamax format lost out ot the VHS format, it is the market that eventually sets the standard.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Rodman Judgment Due
description: DENNIS RODMAN was expected to be suspended today for head-butting Referee TED BERNHARDT during the Chicago Bulls' game against the Nets at the Meadowlands Saturday.

title: As Payroll Shrinks, Government's Costs For Contracts Rise
description: Even as President Clinton and Congressional Republicans race to take credit for shrinking the Federal payroll, the Government's costs for outside, or contract, employees keep rising.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Injuries Mount for Reds
description: Cincinnati Reds outfielder ERIC ANTHONY suffered a mild to moderate shoulder separation and will have to rest for a week to 10 days. Manager RAY KNIGHT said Anthony might wind up on the disabled list. Anthony is the fourth Red injured this spring. (AP)

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The Art of Making Life Easier as It Nears an End
description: If you have tears, prepare to shed them tonight. "Letting Go: A Hospice Journey" accompanies hospice teams in California, Montana and New York City as they try to comfort the dying and their families and to search out some gains in the ultimate loss. It makes vivid the appeal of a movement that now serves hundreds of thousands of patients and is growing.

title: U.S. Merchant Marine Is Worth Saving
description: To the Editor:

title: Scottish Inquiry's Focus: Why Strict Gun Law Failed
description: As sermons, prayers and a one-minute silence across the nation today registered continuing grief and horror at the killing of 16 young children in a Scottish school last week, Britain confronted a troubling question: Why didn't the country's stringent gun laws prevent the massacre?

title: POLITICS: SUPPORTERS WITH A STAKE;Four Midwestern Governors Angle for an Offer From Dole
description: Even as they unite behind Senator Bob Dole before Tuesday's Big Ten primaries, four Midwest Republican Governors are tensely eyeing one another and a prize each would like to win: a place as Mr. Dole's running mate.

title: FEDERAL THRUST AGAINST TOBACCO GETS NEW VIGOR
description: The Justice Department, which began investigating the tobacco industry three years ago, has in recent months expanded the criminal and civil inquiries, making them the Clinton Administration's most aggressive prosecutorial effort against the makers of a single consumer product, Government and private lawyers following the issue say.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Harnisch Pleased, Despite Miscues
description: If it were a regular-season game, Pete Harnisch might have been miffed at the infield error that kept him from escaping an inning without damage. Instead, Jerry Browne's miscue in the sixth inning of today's B game against the Orioles offered the right-hander from Commack, L.I., an opportunity to see if his surgically repaired shoulder could make the baseball dance again.

title: Taking In the Sites;Arena for Hoop Dreams On the World Wide Web
description: The total couch-potato workout now takes one hand for the remote, and one for the mouse. Sports services on the World Wide Web are jostling to make you feel busy while you watch slim men sweat.

title: Museum Of TV And Radio Goes Bicoastal
description: Television has always been considered a stepchild of the entertainment business. But tonight it was given the Cinderella treatment -- and accorded full validation -- with the West Coast opening of the Museum of Television and Radio.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: SOUTHEAST;Cincinnati and Tech Offer Friday Preview
description: Cincinnati and Georgia Tech today selected different routes to the Southeast Region's final four. Both, however, will be there on Friday night at Rupp Arena in Lexington, Ky., two victories shy of a snappier prize -- a trip to the Meadowlands and to the tournament's elite of elite -- the Final Four.

title: What They're Reading
description: Dame Barbara Cartland, author of hundreds of romance books, is reading "Nelson" by Christopher Hibbert.

title: FIGURE SKATING;A Big Bundle of Nerves Quickly Melts on the Ice
description: As he awaited today's qualifying round of the world figure skating championships, Rudy Galindo became dizzy and felt as if he were going to faint. Always a nervous performer, this time he had contracted terminal stage fright.

title: Princeton's Literary Magnetism;It's Home to Likes of Morrison, Oates and Benchley
description: If someone were to write a memoir of the literary life that has flourished in this area in recent years, one chapter might cover the curious adventure of the distinguished poet and the Volvo repair man.

title: Officer Kills Himself At Manhattan Concert
description: An off-duty police officer killed himself during a St. Patrick's Day concert in midtown Manhattan, shooting himself once in the head as an Irish rock band was playing an encore, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of coming lectures in the Connecticut Weekly yesterday gave an incorrect date for a lecture by the author Grace Mirabella. It is March 26, not March 19.

title: Raja N. Khuri, 61, Educator in Beirut
description: Dr. Raja N. Khuri, a former acting president and dean of medicine at the American University in Beirut, died on Wednesday at his home in Greenville, N.C. He was 61.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Most Sinister Gathering Of Not-So-Usual Suspects
description: Almost everybody loves a good mystery play, even those people who read mystery novels only when nothing else is available: you're spending a weekend in the country, it's late, everybody else is asleep, you have a choice between a tattered copy of June Bride and a stack of Agatha Christie paperbacks. Christie wins. At any point you can turn to the back of the book, find out who did it and go to sleep, the mind as barren as a looted tomb.

title: In America;Sardine Sandwich
description: Hop aboard the New York transit elevator. Fares going up, services going down.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALICE QUINN, the poetry editor of The New Yorker, has found a new poet: BROOKE ASTOR, and she plans to publish three of Mrs. Astor's works.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: EAST;Texas Tech and Georgetown Roll
description: When Darvin Ham went after a rebound of a missed jump shot by his Texas Tech teammate Jason Sasser with just over 12 minutes left in the first half today, he did more than give literal meaning to crashing the boards.

title: GOLF;Second Unknown Rises to the Top on Tour
description: Paul Goydos won the Bay Hill Invitational today, proving in the process that the PGA Tour is the ultimate meritocracy and that -- when given the opportunity -- the 263d-ranked player in the world can take the measure of one of the hardest courses and one of the best fields in golf.

title: Digital TV, Dollars and Dissent;The Political Battle Grows Over the Use of New Broadcast Technology
description: There are a lot of disturbing programs on television these days. But lately some of the most ominous emanations from broadcast stations have taken the form of a lobbying campaign.

title: Killer's Lawyers Say Shots Were Meant Only to Disable Rabin
description: Making closing arguments in the trial of the confessed assassin of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, defense lawyers struggled today to save their client from a murder conviction, arguing to a skeptical bench that he had meant only to disable Mr. Rabin, and that a second gunman might have fired the fatal shots.

title: HOCKEY;Cornell and Providence Will Keep Playing
description: Cornell and Providence College enjoyed the spoils of their unexpected weekend success yesterday, when both were included in the 12-team National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I tournament. But the two surprise tournament winners -- both of which finished fourth in their respective leagues -- did not impress the N.C.A.A. selection committee: Each was seeded No. 6, or last, in its region.

title: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Razia Bhatti, 52, Who Headed Crusading Journal in Pakistan
description: Razia Bhatti, a Pakistani editor who championed social causes and campaigned against Government corruption, died on Tuesday at her home in Karachi. She was 52 and the founding editor of Newsline, Pakistan's most influential political monthly.

title: INSIDE
description: China Warns the U.S.

title: Doubts on Tying Job Loss To Laws on Environment
description: Environmental regulations have not been an important cause of job losses, a California State Senate report, due to be released on Monday, concludes.

title: Hope and Anxiety for Lovers of the Saab
description: To the Editor:

title: American Radio Deals
description: The American Radio Systems Corporation has agreed to acquire Marlin Broadcasting Inc. for about $66.5 million, including the assumption of debt. American will buy Boston-based Marlin's stations in Philadelphia, WFLN-FM, and Detroit, WQRS-FM, both of which carry classical music. In addition, Marlin's president, Howard Tanger, agreed to buy Marlin's classical station in Miami, WTMI-FM, for $18 million. American, also based in Boston, owns 15 FM and nine AM stations.

title: Man Found Guilty Of Killing Girlfriend
description: A former hotel worker has been convicted of stabbing his girlfriend to death in 1994 and leaving her remains near a suburban Albany bicycle path.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Book Publishers Worry About Threat of Internet
description: Officially, "Le Grand Secret" remains a literary state secret, a physician's tortured confessional disclosing the elaborate deception to hide the failing health of Francois Mitterrand and the vagaries of his prostate.

title: BOXING;Brutal. Reverent. Blissful. Tyson.
description: The only thing new about Mike Tyson, who once again wears a heavyweight crown, is the old hostility.

title: Corrections
description: A company logo in Business Day on Friday, with a brief report in the Company News column about the planned closing of 13 stores by Rickel Home Centers Inc., was published in error. The symbol was that of Home Depot Inc., which is a competitor of Rickel.

title: Comcast in Talks for 2 Philadelphia Teams
description: The Comcast Corporation confirmed Friday that it was negotiating a bid to buy Philadelphia's two indoor sports arenas and its professional basketball and hockey franchises.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Walter Weir, an advertising executive and professor, misstated the date of his death. It was March 9, not March 2.

title: No Press Cards for Spies
description: An old debate has been needlessly revived in a report on intelligence sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations. The report, prepared under the guidance of the project's director, Richard Haass, a former Government official, calls for reviewing "a number of legal and policy constraints" on clandestine operations dating to the 1970's. Those constraints chiefly concern the use of spies posing as reporters and the employment of bona fide reporters for intelligence missions. Both practices were all but banned then, and should be prohibited now.

title: Tennessee Is Focus of Debate On Adoptees' Birth Records
description: On the cattle farm where her adoptive parents brought her as an infant, and where she now lives with her own husband and 3-year-old son, Lucy Trenkle waits impatiently for July 1, when a new Tennessee law will help her uncover a secret that gnaws at her: the identity of her birth mother.

title: BASEBALL;3 Generations, 2 Families, 1 Calling: Ballplayer
description: Until 1992, three generations of the same family had never played major league baseball, or any other major professional team sport for that matter. Then Bret Boone joined his father, Bob, and his grandfather, Ray, as major leaguers. Now the Bells have joined the Boones.

title: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;Reports of the computer-assisted death of ham radio may be greatly exaggerated.
description: FEW people would ever feel an urgent need to answer the question, "What are the parasitic elements of a Yagi antenna?" or to identify all the causes of "splatter interference." Nor will many ponder "the maximum authorized bandwidth of RTTY, data or multiplexed emission using an unspecified digital code."

title: Japan Stocks Rise
description: Stocks rose here on hopes that exporters' earnings would improve after the dollar gained against the yen. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 148.20 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,339.05. On Friday, the Nikkei surged 267.19 points, or nearly 1.37 percent, to close at 20,190.85.

title: Russian Communist Aims for Broad Appeal
description: Carefully sidestepping his party's most divisive positions, Russia's Communist presidential candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, unveiled an election program today that is fashioned to appeal to a broad coalition of voters.

title: Injuries in Gay Bias Cases Drop But Number of Incidents Is Steady
description: Fewer homosexuals were injured in bias-related assaults in New York City last year than in 1994, according to a privately compiled report, but the overall number of incidents remained roughly the same.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Portrait of the I.R.A. In History and the Heart
description: REBEL HEARTS Journeys Within the I.R.A.'s Soul By Kevin Toolis 384 pages. St. Martin's Press. $25.95.

title: Reviews/Fashion;Leading the Way Back to the 1980's
description: Blessed are those designers who are open to inspiration from whatever cultural, social or political breezes whirl around them. With the right interpretation, the result is clothes with resonance today and value for students of history tomorrow.

title: Van Gordon Sauter: Back in TV (in a Small Way) and Still Making PeopleMad
description: Is Van Gordon Sauter a TV visionary? Or is he a destructive provocateur?

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Getting Arts Into Curriculum
description: The chairman of the State Assembly and Senate education committees plans to unveil a proposal today that is intended to integrate performing and visual arts into the general school curriculum.

title: Stock Tables Corrected
description: Because of a production error, the weekly New York Stock Exchange tables in Money and Business yesterday were outdated. The correct tables are printed today on pages D6 and D10-11.

title: Small Book From a Small Publisher Is a Big Hit
description: To create a nonfiction best seller, take a big publisher with money and marketing heft, the discounting muscle of the bookstore chains and a well-known author. Mix, and presto.

title: Sky Views of the Scorched Earth
description: Sometimes the truth can be seen only from the sky.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No matter where she goes, JOAN LUNDEN, who lost 50 pounds more than five years ago, is always asked the same question: How did she take off so much weight? "Everywhere I go, the doctor's office, the grocery store, the gas station, I get asked," she said the other day.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Lose Another To Their Florida Twin
description: When Martin Brodeur has scrutinized the Florida Panthers this season, it has been a little like looking in the mirror. As with the Devils, Florida is a strong defensive team with solid goaltending.

title: HORSE RACING;As Usual, Lukas Holds a Hot Derby Hand
description: They met on the road to the Kentucky Derby, standing at the owners' boxes outside the Turf Club at Gulfstream Park on the afternoon of the Florida Derby. It was a moment in racing history: Jimmy Jones, 89 years old, who with his father trained eight winners of the most important horse race in America, and D. Wayne Lukas, 60 years old, who has trained two winners of the Derby and has won the last five Triple Crown races. "Mr. Jones, it's good to see you, sir, how are you feeling?" Lukas asked with respect, extending his hand.

title: Kinko's Adds Internet Services to Its Copying Business
description: As a recent college graduate in the early 1970's, Paul Orfalea would spend evenings cruising the dorms of the University of California at Santa Barbara, hawking pens and spiral notebooks from an oversized knapsack. Each outing would bring about $40.

title: Topics of The Times
description: Pass the Pork Rinds

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Money Flows in Senate Race
description: United States Representatives Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood, and Dick Zimmer, of Delaware Township, the front-runner among the Republicans seeking to run against Mr. Torricelli next November for the United States Senate, are already performing well in one category. Reports by the Federal Election Commission show that Mr. Torricelli has amassed $2.2 million, the third-largest war chest of any of this year's Senate candidates, the A.P. reported yesterday. Mr. Zimmer was fifth at $1.75 million.

title: HOCKEY;Wings Clinch Division Title
description: The Detroit Red Wings clinched the Central Division title today, getting a goal and an assist from Igor Larionov to beat the Calgary Flames, 4-2.

title: Intel to Abandon Paragon Line of Supercomputers
description: The Intel Corporation has told customers of its Paragon supercomputer business that it will stop making the computers at the end of September and ship its last machines by the end of the year.

title: POLITICS: IN THE CROWD;In Michigan, Blue-Collar Support Is Drifting From G.O.P.
description: In a shot-and-beer tavern hazy with cigarette smoke, a couple of auto workers relaxed on bar stools after cashing paychecks fattened by overtime, and toasted a politician neither had supported four years ago.

title: China Warns U.S. to Keep Away From Taiwan Strait
description: At the outset of a climactic week of military and political struggle over Taiwan's future, China warned the United States today to keep its naval forces away from the Taiwan Strait.

title: 1996 Dance Awards
description: The recipients of the 1996 Dance Magazine Awards are Francia Russell and Kent Stowell, artistic directors of Pacific Northwest Ballet; the tap dancer Savion Glover, and Peter Boal, principal dancer with the New York City Ballet. The awards, given annually since 1954 for contributions to dance, are to be presented in a private ceremony on April 15 at the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium of the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. Information: (212) 245-9050.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;District Court Nominee Gains
description: The United States Senate Judiciary Committee last week approved the nomination of Joseph A. Greenaway, a lawyer with Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick, to serve in Federal District Court in New Jersey. Mr. Greenaway was with the Criminal Division of the United States Attorney's office in Newark from 1985 to 1990, coordinating all Federal narcotics cases in the state. If Mr. Greenaway is confirmed by the full Senate, he will serve in Newark, a spokesman for Senator Bill Bradley said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Judge Sues a Higher Court
description: A Hudson County Superior Court judge has sued the New Jersey Supreme Court, contending he was denied the right to defend himself on an ethics complaint, The Associated Press reported yesterday. In his lawsuit, filed in Federal Court in Newark, Judge Mac D. Hunter said he was not given a hearing before being privately reprimanded by the high court.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;UConn Women Have Reasons To Be Confident and Cautious
description: When you play in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournaments, there is no room for error, no looking past a supposedly overmatched opponent. One loss and you go home, as a top-seeded team (Purdue) learned Saturday in the second round of the men's tournament, as two teams seeded fifth (Purdue and Florida) and one seeded sixth (Oregon State) learned Friday and Saturday in the first round of the women's tournament.

title: No Headline
description: If we can't solve this problem, we may as well put flower boxes and parking lots along the waterfront."

title: BASEBALL;The Bat of Gerald Williams Not Talking Loudly Enough
description: Gerald Williams is quiet. Unbelievably quiet. When he is in a rare talkative mood, he utters a few sentences. Do not expect Williams to complain about his paucity of playing time. Do not expect him to grouse about anything.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WEST;For Arizona and Kansas, Several Scores to Settle
description: The Ben Davis Bowl will be on Friday.

title: U.S. and Russia Join in Supersonic Jet Study
description: In an unusual economic collaboration uniting former cold war adversaries, a leading manufacturer of Russian warplanes has joined forces with the American aerospace industry to carry out research for a possible supersonic passenger plane for the 21st century.

title: Don't Push Dole to Change His Stripes Now
description: To the Editor:

title: We Do Remember Example of the Elders
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Nissan Motor Co. (Australia) Pty., Melbourne, to Whybin TBWA, Melbourne, part of the TBWA International unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle the creative part of its consolidated Australian account, with billings estimated at $25 million. The account had been divided since August between Whybin TBWA and George Patterson Bates, Melbourne, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. The media portion will be handled by Auspace Media Pty., Melbourne, a joint venture of Whybin TBWA and Mitchell & Partners, Melbourne. TBWA International now handles Nissan accounts in 20 countries, including Britain, France, Germany and the United States.

title: Bridge
description: The bridge players of Long Island lost two of their most respected colleagues last week.

title: SHALLOW WATERS: A special report.;Curbs on Silt Disposal Threaten Port of New York as Ships Grow Larger
description: Rising shoals of mud threaten the economic engine that is New York Harbor, where 4,500 ships a year carry $60 billion worth of goods and generate tens of thousands of jobs.

title: Buffett's Report to Shareholders Holds Hint of Possible Successor
description: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett has suggested that a little-known executive at the Geico Corporation, a subsidiary of Mr. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. holding company, might take the helm if anything happened to him or his longtime partner, Charles T. Munger.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the weekly New York Stock Exchange tables in Money and Business yesterday were from the previous week. The correct tables are printed today beginning on page D6.

title: German Writer Sets Off Storm on Serbia
description: One of the most popular German-language writers of the postwar generation, Peter Handke, has stirred a sensation with a long essay defending Serbia against what he describes as a conspiracy of lazy and mendacious journalists who surf "from cliche to cliche."

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Glimpses of Sting, Man Inside the Lord of the Manor
description: Sting has a new album, "Mercury Falling," and the wheels of publicity have been grinding mightily. He has been making warm-up appearances before an official tour. The album has been reviewed and he has been interviewed extensively. And tonight Bravo, working with London Weekend Television, weighs in with "Sting: The South Bank Show."

title: Oxford Health To Split Stock
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said on Friday that its board had approved a 2-for-1 stock split and that it had filed to sell $200 million in common shares.

title: Executive Defends Downsizing
description: Robert J. Eaton, the chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, defended companies today against "the ongoing demonization of corporate America by some of our most prominent politicians and news organizations."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unitech's Shares Soar to All-Time High
description: Shares of Unitech P.L.C., a British electronics manufacturer, soared 34 percent yesterday to an all-time high after its larger rival, Siebe P.L.C., said it was in talks to buy the company. The purchase, estimated to be worth as much as L500 million ($760 million), would catapult Siebe, a manufacturer of industrial controls and other electrical equipment, into the No. 1 position in the fast-growing market for power supply converters.

title: Off Taiwan, U.S. Sailors Are Unworried
description: Lieut. Steven H. Cargill is one of the fighter pilots on alert, ready to be catapulted off the deck in an F/A-18 jet if China challenges the American flotilla. But Lieutenant Cargill is not looking very tense.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Residency Law Under Review
description: A Superior Court judge will hear arguments today by the Essex County Prosecutor and 11 public employee unions seeking to block enforcement of a dormant 1978 law that requires employees of Essex County to live within its borders. James W. Treffinger, the County Executive, has given more than 600 employees until June to move into the county or lose their jobs. Clifford J. Minor, the Essex County Prosecutor, has said that 40 percent of his work force would lose their jobs if the residency requirement were enforced.

title: The Orrin Hatch Land Grab
description: Members of Congress who care little for environmental stewardship have tried every legislative trick in the book to enrich commercial interests at the expense of America's public lands. That they have largely failed is a tribute to President Clinton's vetoes and the growing assertiveness of moderate Republicans who believe that their leaders have badly misplayed environmental issues. But the wrecking crew will not quit.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Tenor Puts Bel Canto on Display in Recital
description: The biography of the American tenor Paul Groves lists an impressive array of past achievements and future engagements: winner of the 1995 Richard Tucker Foundation Award; appearances at La Scala and the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Big Petroleum Concerns Said To Avoid a Gasoline Additive
description: The Environmental Defense Fund announced yesterday that some of the nation's largest petroleum companies have said that they have no plans to use a controversial additive that increases the octane in gasoline.

title: Too High for Buffett, Berkshire Stock Falls
description: The shares of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. tumbled $2,150 each, or 5.9 percent, yesterday as investors took to heart remarks by the company's billionaire chairman, Warren E. Buffett, that he would not buy the stock at current prices.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It may not be the 1960's, but last week there were two reminders of that era.

title: Sports of The Times;The Position That Makes Champions
description: ONE weekend into the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, choose the strongest image from the first 48 games: Princeton's perfectly executed backdoor play to eliminate defending champion U.C.L.A.? Wake Forest's resourcefulness, overcoming illness and injury to reach the Round of 16? The confidence of the Arkansas freshmen, too young to understand that they really shouldn't have done what they've done?

title: Regulators Renew Attack on Bad Brokers
description: In a tartly worded speech by the Securities and Exchange Commission's chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., and in a lengthy report by a number of oversight agencies, securities regulators announced yesterday a new effort to rid the securities industry of bad brokers.

title: Long Blue Line Mourns One of Its Own;Thousands Attend Funeral for Officer Slain in a Bronx Shootout
description: When Kevin Gillespie was just a child, his father moved out, leaving the boy's mother to raise him. By the time he was a teen-ager, he had grown wild and unruly, someone who drank and skipped school. At 16, he was sent by a family court judge to Lincoln Hall, a school for troubled and delinquent boys in Somers, N.Y.

title: G.M. Considers Executive to Manage Learning
description: Seeking to better harness the knowledge of its employees worldwide, the General Motors Corporation will likely appoint a senior-level chief learning officer to coordinate the spread of information around the company's vast holdings, a executive said in a speech late Sunday.

title: Patterns
description: Designer Joins Wolford

title: G.M. Strike May Be Worst Blow For the Midwest Since '93 Floods
description: Government and private economists said today that the 13-day-old strike at two General Motors brake factories here has delivered the worst blow to the Midwest economy since the floods of 1993.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 157.47 points, or nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 20,442.6. On Monday, the Nikkei rose 94.28 points, or nearly a half-percent.

title: POLITICS;In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPAQ CUTS PRICES OF NOTEBOOKS AS MUCH AS 28%
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation cut prices yesterday on its notebook computers as much as 28 percent and its fax modems as much as 34 percent. Compaq cut prices in the LTE family of portable computers, with prices starting at $2,999 for the LTE 5000 with a 75 megahertz Pentium chip, 8 megabytes of memory and a 510 megabyte hard drive. The machine previously cost $3,999. The LTE 5200, with a 120-megahertz processor, 8 megabytes of memory and a 1.35 gigabyte hard drive, was cut by $1,500, or 23 percent, to $4,999 from $6,499. Fax modems were also reduced. The Speedpaq 1192 Cellular-Ready fax/modem, which allows wireless connections, was cut to $149 from $199.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WESTCOTT COMMUNICATIONS EXPLORING SALE
description: Westcott Communications said yesterday that it was exploring a possible sale or merger that would improve its ability to sell its interactive training systems to larger clients. The company is a provider of multimedia educational and training services. Shares of Westcott rose $2.063 yesterday, to $17.063. But the company could sell for about $25 a share, or $490 million, said Joel Krasner, a securities analyst at Southcoast Capital. Mr. Krasner named AT&T and MCI Communications as potential buyers. Westcott said a sale or merger would enable it to expand its subscriber base for its interactive educational training systems more rapidly.

title: On My Mind;The Citizenship Of Belief
description: In the years I lived and worked abroad as a correspondent, I came to know men and women who seemed to me the best Americans I had ever met. Within them was the conviction that what America stood for was what they ached for -- the chance to achieve whatever lay within their talents and energy, in a free society. The phrase needed no definition.

title: Jerusalem Journal;Milk and Honey? No Dairy Allowed!
description: When his warriors proposed that David should become King of Israel, the Bible recounts, they threw a feast that lasted three days, with "meat, meal, cakes of figs, and bunches of raisins, and wine, and oil, and oxen, and sheep abundantly."

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Why Taiwan Scares China
description: In the debate over China's military exercises in the Taiwan Strait, few have discussed a fundamental reason for its actions: Taiwan's emerging democracy. China's main concern is not any movement toward independence but rather the effects of Taiwanese democracy on the island's foreign policy.

title: THE BABY TRAIL: A special report.;Adoptions in Paraguay: Mothers Cry Theft
description: Gladys Gomez's shoes are torn, her fingernails ragged and her blouse threadbare. But the picture she keeps in her pocket, of the daughter who disappeared almost three years ago, is still pristine, wrapped in plastic like a personal shrine.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Identities That Ignore Boundaries
description: The "Hispanic" category on census forms blurs dozens of national and regional origins and millions of individual choices about assimilation: what to keep, what to borrow, what to let go, what to learn. These two albums are statements of American identity, bilingual in their words and kaleidoscopic in their music, ignoring boundaries when inspiration strikes.

title: When Drug Kingpins Fall, Illicit Assets Buy a Cushion
description: The Federal drug smuggling and money laundering case against Claude L. Duboc was overwhelming.

title: Coma Victim Gives Birth
description: A woman who was raped while in a coma in a nursing home gave birth today, nine weeks prematurely, to a 2-pound, 11-ounce boy. The son was doing well and the mother appeared to be in good physical condition, hospital officials said.

title: POLITICS: THE CHALLENGE;Dole Campaigns in Midwest, Opening November Offensive
description: Looking to shape the political battlefield over which the Presidential election will be fought, Senator Bob Dole made his strongest challenge yet today for President Clinton to resume negotiations over a balanced budget, welfare changes and tax cuts.

title: Collapse of East Side Building Leaves 10 People Homeless
description: A four-story apartment building on the East Side of Manhattan partially collapsed yesterday afternoon, apparently the result of the recent demolition of the building next door. While no one was injured, the collapse left 10 people homeless, many of whom came home from work to learn that the building would be demolished, with their life's belongings falling victim to a wrecking crane.

title: Sometimes, Lobbyists Strive To Keep Public in the Dark
description: On a February morning two years ago, lobbyists from throughout the country gathered at the Colony Beach and Tennis Resort in Longboat Key, Fla., to share the secrets of their successful lobbying campaigns.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: GIANTS NOTEBOOK;Brown Can Take His Athletic Versatility to Another Court
description: If you want to understand why Giants management thinks so highly of Dave Brown and what he can become, just watch the quarterback play basketball. At a charity basketball game between Giants and Jets players to benefit the Boomer Esiason Heroes Foundation and the CJ Foundation for Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, an event that raised $150,000, Brown was a star.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.N. Talks With Iraq On Oil-Sale Impasse
description: A second round of talks between Iraq and the United Nations over a plan that would allow Baghdad to sell up to $2 million in oil over six months to pay for food and other urgent civilian needs ended today still stalemated over how to share the profits with Iraqi Kurds.

title: Q&A
description: Snow and Fog

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;7 Injured in Vehicle Accident
description: Two 14-year-old Elizabeth youths were comatose yesterday and five other people were hurt after one of the youths stole a parked Audi whose engine was running and then hit two other vehicles, the police said. The youth accused of stealing the car was not identified.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Through an Array of Poses, Both Humorous and Serious
description: The program presented by Jeanine Durning, Amos Pinhasi and Richard Siegal on Friday night at the Dia Center for the Arts was time spent in the pleasantly literate company of three good movers with interesting ideas and, best of all, a sense of humor.

title: Another Balanchine Disciple Tends the Master's Flame
description: I almost never go to the ballet," Suzanne Farrell said. She had just been asked her opinion of her old company, the New York City Ballet. But Ms. Farrell would not be drawn into a discussion of it, and who could blame her?

title: COMPANY NEWS;DISCLOSURE OF FRAUD INQUIRY HITS HORIZON/CMS STOCK
description: Shares of the Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation fell 14 percent yesterday on news the nursing home chain was being investigated for possible billing fraud by the Justice Department and the Department of Health and Human Services. The company had said late on Friday that the investigation involved about $3.4 million in Medicare and related co-insurance billings for services provided by facilities formerly operated by Greenery Rehabilitation Group Inc., a rehabilitation concern that Horizon acquired in early 1994. Horizon said it would record a charge of $5.1 million, or about 6 cents a share, for the quarter that ended Feb. 29. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of Horizon fell $2.375, to $13.875.

title: POP REVIEW;Giving the Fans What They Expect: Rowdiness
description: A big beat, a blues-rock guitar lick, a simple chorus and a leer: what more does rock need? Not much, if the band performing it is AC/DC. Formed in Sydney, Australia, in 1973 and a regular presence in the American Top 10 since 1979, AC/DC is a homage to perpetual adolescence; over two decades, it has barely changed its music, its message or its antics onstage. On Sunday night, at the Continental Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., fans showed up to enjoy a sure thing.

title: Chess
description: Hero worship of Paul Keres has not dimmed, although he has been dead for 21 years. He never won the world championship nor challenged for it, but his crisp, clean games and searing tactics excited chess players everywhere. And so did his dignified sportsmanship.

title: Sperm Counts: Some Experts See a Fall, Others Poor Data
description: DR. HARRY FISCH, who directs the male reproductive center at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, recently gave a talk to men in a support group for the infertile. How many, he said, think that sperm counts are declining worldwide? All raised their hands. And how many, he asked, think the decline is due to some toxin in the environment? Most thought that was true.

title: It's Time to Put Limits on Power of H.M.O.'s;For a Human Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;The Devils Are Feeling Playoff Pressure Build
description: In Jacques Lemaire's first two years as coach of the Devils, the players faithfully obeyed his demands without questioning his style. They trusted his instincts, and together they captured the first Stanley Cup for the franchise last season.

title: POLITICS: RACE FOR CONGRESS;Illinois Seat Is Battleground in War for Senate
description: For a dozen years, Illinois has been represented in the Senate by Democrats, even as Republicans have taken control of the Governor's mansion and the Legislature in this bellwether state in the country's industrial heartland.

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTY;Perot Is Officially Joining the Race for President, Until . . .
description: Here is the latest word on Ross Perot: he is officially running for President, but this does not mean he is really running for President. At least, not yet.

title: By Design;Colors That Bloom in Spring
description: The calendar says spring is imminent, which stirs dreams of balmy days. To get into the mood, there are clothes and accessories in warm-weather colors like lime, yellow and orange, and even cheerful citrus-fruit prints.

title: Israeli Press Lifts Cover Off Spy Chief
description: An Israeli newspaper today identified the newly designated head of Israel's overseas intelligence agency, the Mossad, challenging military censorship and breaching another wall of secrecy around the country's security services.

title: New Head For Poynter
description: James Naughton, the former executive editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, has been named president of the Poynter Institute for Media Studies in St. Petersburg, Fla., the institute announced yesterday.

title: Teen-Ager Gets Life In Michigan Slaying
description: A teen-ager who invited friends to a party to see the blanket-wrapped body of the dead man with whom she lived was sentenced to life in prison today for his murder.

title: Off China, Isle Waits Nervously
description: As China was set to mount a second wave of war games today barely 10 miles from this storm-swept granite islet, Wang Chien-hua gazed over the village's empty, puddled schoolyard. Only the sound of a lashing rain echoed into the cement-walled classrooms. That, and the roar of military trucks prowling the road outside.

title: Former Husker Is Convicted
description: Christian Peter, a former Nebraska nose tackle from Locust, N.J., was convicted today of disturbing the peace for grabbing a woman around the neck at a bar earlier this month.

title: Ornda to Buy Hospital
description: Ornda Healthcorp agreed today to acquire Cypress Fairbanks Medical Center, an acute-care hospital in Houston. Terms were not disclosed. The 149-bed Cypress Fairbanks and its related operations had about $56 million in revenue last year. Ornda, a hospital management company based in Nashville, had revenue of $1.84 billion in its 1995 fiscal year.

title: Review/Fashion;Off the Runway, On the Mark
description: There is a move afoot here to take fashion up close to the audiences, to dazzle them with the details that a runway presentation can erase.

title: TV SPORTS;So Close and Yet So Far: Didn't They See the Cut?
description: The front row must be an awful perch to watch boxing from. Blood, sweat and other whatnots spatter. You have to look up all the time. The only good part is not having to peer over Bert Randolph Sugar's fedora.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Suspension of Iraq-U.N. Talks Lifts Oil Prices to 4-Year Highs
description: Crude oil futures surged yesterday to their highest levels in more than four years after oil talks between Iraq and the United Nations were temporarily suspended and traders rushed to buy crude.

title: How Brain May Weigh the World With Simple Dopamine System
description: IN the ever increasing cascade of new information on brain chemistry and behavior, one substance seems to pop up whenever pleasure is involved. It is even called dopamine, a name that has no connection to the slang "dope" for drugs, but might just as well, considering that dopamine plays a critical role in the way animals and people respond to cocaine, amphetamines, heroin, alcohol and nicotine.

title: Olga Rudge, 101, Ezra Pound's Companion, Dies
description: Olga Rudge, the Ohio-born violinist who became companion, caretaker and champion of the brilliant but embattled poet Ezra Pound, died on Friday at the castle of their daughter near Merano in northern Italy. She was 101.

title: FIGURE SKATING;Ito Returns, a Little Bit Shaky, But Still Viewed as a Favorite
description: Four years after she apologized for winning a silver medal at the 1992 Winter Games, Midori Ito returned to international amateur skating today, her Olympic eligibility intact, if not her composure.

title: Stocks Surge As Dow Hits Another Peak
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surged nearly 100 points yesterday to an all-time high.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Hundreds of Cubans Seek to Emigrate to U.S.
description: Hundreds of Cubans gathered near the United States Interests Section in Havana today trying to hand in their applications for a new lottery for emigration to the United States.

title: The Mandelas in Divorce Court: He Tells of a Broken Marriage
description: President Nelson Mandela broke his long public silence about the disintegration of his 38-year marriage today, taking the stand on the opening day of his divorce trial to quietly describe his loneliness in the days after he was released from a 27-year imprisonment and went to live with his wife.

title: Market Place;Capital Gains Draw Tougher Clinton Stand
description: Capital gains taxes are back on the table in Washington, but the newest proposal is aimed at forcing wealthy investors to pay more to the Government, rather than allowing them to pay less.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton to Seek Tax Cuts, But Not on Capital Gains President Clinton, presenting his 1997 budget to Congress today, will call for $100 billion in tax cuts during the next five years -- notably a tax credit of as much as $500 for families with at least one young child, and a deduction of up to $10,000 for college tuition and other degree programs -- while making business bear the brunt of the cost of those breaks. [Page A1.]

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Silt Disposal Fund Proposed
description: Representative Robert D. Franks, Republican of New Providence, yesterday proposed legislation to allow money from the $600 million Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund to be used to help build disposal sites for contaminated silt in New Jersey and New York ports.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;In U S West Dispute, Time Warner Hints at Flexibility
description: Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner Inc., said today that he was willing to consider putting part of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., except its Cable News Network, into Time Warner's troubled partnership with U S West Inc.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Events column of The Home Section on Thursday about an antiques show at the Seventh Regiment Armory misstated the hours for this Wednesday. The show will be open from 4 to 9 P.M.

title: Officer's Death Renews Debate on Guns
description: Fifteen years ago, the New York City Police Department relaxed a policy that required off-duty officers to carry their weapons, hoping to prevent just the sort of shootings like the one that killed Officer Chris Gargan at a crowded Times Square rock concert on Saturday night.

title: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;A Campaign Calculator for the Budget
description: When President Clinton presents his $1.64 trillion budget for 1997 on Tuesday, it will be the opening initiative in a new phase of the Presidential race in which Pennsylvania Avenue supersedes the hustings.

title: Volcanic Fury Rocks Pacific Sea Floor Where Inner Earth Meets OuterEarth
description: IT is the heartbeat of the planet, a fundamental force of nature that continuously shapes the earth, concentrates gold and other rare metals, adjusts the sea's chemical balance, provides the main path by which the planet's interior oozes to the surface and may even be the place where life itself first arose eons ago. Yet because it occurs in the inky blackness of the deep sea, under the crushing weight of miles of sea water, it is mysterious and poorly known.

title: Wounded Officer Testifies In Subway Shooting Trial
description: Desmond Robinson said he never saw what hit him.

title: Executive Changes
description: FIRST UNITED CORP., Oakland, Md., a bank holding company, said Richard Stanton, its chairman, president and chief executive, would retire, effective June 1. William Grant, a vice president, will succeed Mr. Stanton as chairman and chief executive, while Robert Kurtz, a vice president, becomes president; Mr. Kurtz was also named chief operating officer.

title: Sports of The Times;Raging Bulls At the Mercy Of a Worm
description: THERE were no jolting news breaks when Bob Hill kicked off his shoes to watch the late sports on Saturday night. Tyson knocked out Bruno. Mississippi State flattened Princeton. Dennis Rodman head-butted the ref.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Southeast Semifinal Pits Teams With Speed
description: John Chaney, the Temple coach, peeked at the 16 teams left clawing for college basketball's supreme prize -- the national championship -- and realized that his team not only failed to reach the select group, but also finished short in another way.

title: Harold Courlander, 82, Author And Expert on World Folklore
description: Harold Courlander, a scholar, author and collector of folkloristic troves from Alabama to Africa and the Pacific, died on Friday. He was 82 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;From Verdi, an Attila More Hamlet Than Hun
description: It's hard to recognize the historic King of the Huns in Verdi's early opera "Attila." Verdi's Attila is seized by ambition, yet tormented by doubt; a man who conquers his Roman enemies, but yearns for their devotion. The fifth-century Hun warrior was nothing if not decisive.

title: WABC Radio Drops Dershowitz For Calling Another Host Racist
description: The radio station WABC-AM dropped Alan M. Dershowitz, the Harvard Law School professor and celebrity lawyer, from its roster of talk show hosts yesterday after he called the station's controversial host Bob Grant a racist.

title: Scientists Contradict Company on Nicotine
description: New evidence that tobacco companies regard cigarettes as nicotine delivery devices -- which they have long denied -- was made public yesterday by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Odysseus Elytis, 84, Poet and Nobel Laureate Who Celebrated GreekMyths and Landscape
description: Odysseus Elytis, a Nobel Prize-winning Greek poet celebrated for his lyrical and passionate evocations of his country's history, myths and rugged landscape, died yesterday at his home in Athens. He was 84.

title: Satellite on Wire To Plunge Tonight
description: THE satellite on a wire that broke free from the space shuttle Columbia more than three weeks ago is to plunge back into the Earth's atmosphere late tonight and is expected to burn up completely and not hit the ground, the United States Space Command said yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: In Long-Running Wolf-Moose Drama, Wolves Recover From Disaster
description: THIS winter was long, tough and tumultuous on Isle Royale National Park in Lake Superior, scene of the world's best studied predator-prey relationship, and the news is what wolf watchers were hoping to hear. A troubled wolf population has rebounded sharply and at the same time moose numbers have crashed in spectacular fashion.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Weapons Industry Turns to Latin America
description: Of the hundreds of billions of dollars spent each year on arms and weapons worldwide, Latin America has not been among the big buyers because of its weak economies and a United States policy that restricts the sale of high-technology military equipment.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers' Plans Hinge On How Richter Plays
description: Mike Richter's performance tonight will determine Neil Smith's behavior tomorrow morning. If the Ranger goalie is able to play a full game for the first time in almost three months, Smith will not have to make a deal for a goalie at the trading deadline.

title: At Least 150 Are Killed in Disco Fire in Manila
description: After a fierce fire spread through a disco packed with students early this morning, officials confirmed today that at least 150 people had been killed and said there may be as many as 50 more bodies still in the ruins.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lowe Acquires Health Agency
description: The Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies agreed yesterday to acquire William Douglas McAdams Inc. in New York, the sixth-largest agency specializing in health care advertising. Terms were not disclosed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;DDB Needham Unit Reorganizes
description: The DDB Needham Dallas Group, part of the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that it would reorganize by combining two units -- DDB Marketing Communications and the part of Tracy-Locke Advertising that works for the Pepsi-Cola Company -- into the TL Partnership, a stand-alone spinoff that will focus on promotional marketing.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Securities Firms Make Assignments
description: Two financial services companies have selected new agencies.

title: McCall Blocks Pataki Shift Of Jobs to G.O.P. Areas
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall today blocked Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to move nearly 5,000 state-financed jobs from the Democratic bastions of New York City and Albany to Republican areas upstate, saying it was so riddled with questionable fiscal maneuvers that it violated state law.

title: 2 Firms Ease Account Shifts
description: Prudential Securities and Paine Webber broke with tradition today and announced an agreement to allow clients to transfer their brokerage accounts between the two firms while retaining ownership of shares of in-house mutual funds.

title: EU Police 'Held Hostage' in Battle on Court's Reach
description: THE HAGUE  Alerted to a suspected drug shipment coming from Morocco last year, British Customs officials decided to turn to Europe's fledgling police agency, Europol, to get a jump on the traffickers.

title: INSIDE
description: 150 Dead in Manila Fire

title: Clothing Donations Go First to U.S. Poor, Not Africa Market;High-Protein Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Taxes and Election Fervor;A Silent Wave of Anti-Tax Emotion Holds Sway in Perry Township, Ohio
description: Denny Fulk, a precinct captain canvassing Citadel Avenue, rang the bell, and as soon as the door opened a crack, launched into his pitch. "Hi, I'm Denny Fulk, I'm one of your neighbors, I live over on Banyan and I'm on the committee to pass the Perry school levy," he began. "We have an important vote coming up on the 19th and I'd like to give you some literature. Any questions I can answer?"

title: Retail Complex in Harlem Takes a Big Step Forward
description: A long-stalled plan for a major retail complex on 125th Street in Harlem took a step forward yesterday when developers said they had received commitments from the Cineplex Odeon theater chain, Chemical Bank and a sports and recreation company to sign on as tenants.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MITEL TO ACQUIRE SWEDISH CIRCUIT MAKER ABB HAFO
description: The Mitel Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the integrated circuit maker ABB Hafo A.B. from Asea Brown Boveri, the Swedish-Swiss engineering company. Terms were not disclosed. Mitel, which is based in Kanata, Ontario, and makes telecommunications equipment, said the acquisition of the Sweden-based unit is expected to close later this month. ABB Hafo designs and makes integrated circuits and semiconductor components for the medical, industrial and space markets.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Apple Computer Inc.'s selection of a public relations firm misstated the company's relationship with the firm of Kekst & Company. Although Apple selected Burson-Marsteller to handle product-related announcements, Kekst continues to work with Apple on corporate matters.

title: City College Closing Black Studies Dept.
description: A year after winning its battle to remove Dr. Leonard Jeffries as chairman of the black studies department, the City College of New York said yesterday that it would eliminate the department and replace it with a more general black studies program.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LOCKHEED MARTIN EXTENDS OFFER TO BUY LORAL
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said yesterday that it had extended its $9.1 billion tender offer for all of the Loral Corporation's common shares outstanding through April 5. As of last Friday, 66.4 million shares had been tendered for $38 in cash and a share in a newly formed spinoff company each, according to the company, a military contractor. Earlier in the month, the European Commission extended its deadline to decide whether to clear the deal or start an in-depth investigation until March 27. Shares of Loral rose 50 cents yesterday, to $47.125, while shares of Lockheed Martin rose $1.625, to $77.625.

title: Missing Teacher Is Found Dead
description: The body of a 45-year-old teacher missing since Thursday was found Sunday in a desolate wooded area off the Garden State Parkway in Berkeley Township, the Ocean County Prosecutor said yesterday.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Digital Photos as Fuzzy Snapshots
description: WHAT is so strange as a digital bargain? The Epson PhotoPC is being trumpeted as a price breakthrough, the first color digital camera widely available for around $500. Just like its more expensive competitors, the PhotoPC offers all the photographic features you would expect from a $15 throwaway camera, with perhaps a tenth of the picture quality.

title: Battle Lines Drawn on Conservation Plans in Farm Bill
description: A fight between House and Senate negotiators over the conservation provisions of a proposed farm bill is threatening to derail the legislation, which many lawmakers have called the most significant environmental accomplishment of the 104th Congress.

title: Volatile Stock Market Is Good Sign, Not Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Finds Few Extremists, But Suggests Policies Be Stricter
description: A Pentagon investigation of racism in the Army has concluded that while racial hate groups have made few inroads in recruiting soldiers and their families, the military should consider reversing a policy that allows troops to join extremist organizations, officials said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: David M. Gordon, 51, a Leader Among Left-Wing Economists
description: David M. Gordon, a leader of leftist economic thought and a professor at the New School for Social Research in New York, died on Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 51 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Ghost Town Of Underwriting;Wall St. Firms Taking Flight From Municipal Finance
description: These are not happy days in municipal finance.

title: Gingrich and Dole Not Among the Many N.C.A.A. Seekers
description: The public may be clamoring for tickets to the N.C.A.A. Final Four basketball games on March 30 and April 1. But at least two top Washington Republicans are apparently not as anxious to see the games at the Continental Airlines Arena in the New Jersey Meadowlands.

title: Charles Keyes, 76, Parson in Appalachian Hills
description: Charles Keyes, the itinerant "parson of the hills," who spent his life delivering stem-winding sermons and dispensing Christmas joy to the mountain poor of five states, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Hickory, N.C. He was 76 and had been preaching since he was 5 years old.

title: Du Pont Joins Olin in Sale
description: The Olin Corporation and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that they had put their chlorine plant in Niagara Falls, N.Y., up for sale.

title: BASEBALL;Angels Unveil Lesson Plan
description: The youthful California Angels will find out this year whether they passed the course in baseball life they took last year, Pennant Race 101.

title: Oil Spills Off Texas Coast
description: A barge carrying about 714,000 gallons of oil broke open today outside the Houston Ship Channel, gushing a ribbon of oil at least five miles long into Galveston Bay.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Thursday, about the third annual David Ogilvy awards presented by the Advertising Research Foundation, misstated the headquarters of a winner, Smith & Company. Smith, which won for its work on the "Got milk?" campaign for the California Milk Processor Advisory Board, is based in Mill Valley, Calif., not Shelton, Conn.

title: Leslie Fay Plans to Spin Off Sassco to Creditors
description: The Leslie Fay Companies said yesterday that it had decided against selling its Sassco unit to a management group led by Sassco's president and founder, Arthur S. Levine. Instead, Leslie Fay intends to spin off the division to creditors.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Murder Suspect Is a Suicide
description: A man suspected of stabbing his girlfriend to death after she ended their five-month relationship hanged himself on Sunday, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Carl Anderson, 23, of Irvington, was found hanging from a tree in the backyard of a Roselle home, said Lieut. Vincent Gagliano of the Newark police. Last week, Mr. Anderson quarreled with Tia Hamilton, 21, a student from East Orange, and stabbed her 28 times, Lieutenant Gagliano said.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries' Prices Rise a Bit; Long-Bond Yield at 6.70%
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved moderately higher yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about social attitudes in Canton, Ohio, and two competing basketball teams there, misstated the year in which Gary Grant, now a player for the Knicks, led McKinley High School to the state championship. It was 1984, not 1987.

title: High Court to Revisit Issue of Curbing Abortion-Clinic Protests
description: With a Supreme Court ruling two years ago having failed to settle the debate over permissible limits on demonstrations at abortion clinics, the Justices agreed today to examine the issue again in a new case from upstate New York.

title: War Over Zoo: A Fantasy Land Vs. Interaction
description: The city wants to build a nice new children's zoo in Central Park, guided by the latest thinking in how to exhibit animals. An undisclosed donor has even been found to pay $4 million of the $6 million cost.

title: Partial McDonald's Victory in South Africa
description: The McDonald's Corporation has won part of its battle in South Africa to defend its name and trademarks from a local competitor, the company and lawyers said today.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Casts Doubts, Then Banishes Them
description: The doubts about Dwight Gooden's ability to regain his form returned in the first inning against the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, when he allowed three runs and four hits and needed 27 pitches -- as well as a line-drive double play -- to finally escape to the dugout.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;UConn Seniors Leave Home Winners
description: This was the final game at Gampel Pavilion, their home court, for Jennifer Rizzotti and Jamelle Elliott, the co-captains of the Connecticut women's basketball team. The two seniors left the adoring sellout crowd of 8,241 something to remember as they led the Huskies to an 88-68 victory over Michigan State tonight in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Trone Names A New Chief
description: Trone Advertising in Greensboro, N.C., said yesterday that it had hired James H. Feeney as president and chief executive, assuming those posts from Lee Trone, 53, who continues as chairman.
