Mr. Feeney, 57, had most recently been president at the Albert Frank Guenther Law International unit of AFGL International in New York; he also previously worked at New York agencies like Ally & Gargano.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CORT BUSINESS SERVICES CORP., agreed to acquire Evans Rents for $27 million. Both companies are furniture rental concerns.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRIDE PETROLEUM TO BUY ARGENTINA DRILLING CONTRACTOR
description: Shares of Pride Petroleum Services Inc. closed up 17 percent yesterday after the company said that it had agreed to acquire Argentina's largest drilling contractor for about $140 million. Pride will pay a combination of cash and notes for Quitral-Co. Saic, which operates 30 drilling and 78 workover rigs in Argentina and Venezuela. Shares of Pride rose $1.875, to $13.25.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rebuff for Insurance Industry
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday rejected a challenge by the insurance industry to a six-year-old law that imposed surcharges to pay off a huge debt run up by a state pool for high-risk drivers. In 1990, the insurance industry was forced to pay $1.4 billion in surcharges, to help pay off a $3.3 billion deficit. Without comment, the court rejected an argument by State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company that the surcharges kept the company from earning a fair rate of return, The Associated Press reported.

title: Goldman Has Threefold Rise In Pretax Profit
description: The partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company got the welcome news of an earnings turnaround yesterday afternoon, hearing that their business, buoyed by booming financial markets, earned pretax profit of $565 million in its fiscal first quarter ended Feb. 29.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the new head of the Government's campaign against drugs, misidentified a person pictured walking with the general. A spokesman for General McCaffrey said it was a reporter, not an aide to the general.

title: Chemicals That Mimic Hormones Spark Alarm and Debate
description: IN a warning supported by allies who include Robert Redford and Vice President Al Gore, some environmentalists are asserting that humans and wildlife are facing a new and serious threat from synthetic chemicals.

title: Budgetary Sleight of Hand in Albany
description: After promises from everyone that this year would be different, New York State is heading toward a new fiscal year in two weeks without a budget. If anything, Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature are playing a more ambitious game of fiscal maneuvering than Albany has seen in a long time, as all sides try to draw Washington into a contest over who should get the blame for the state's budget problems.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Animal Cruelty Bill Passes
description: The State Senate, in a unanimous vote, approved a bill inspired by the 1994 indictment of Frank Balun of Hillside, who was charged with animal cruelty for fatally beating a rat that invaded his garden. The legislation would exempt rats, mice or other pests from the cruelty laws. Similar legislation passed the State Senate last year but never reached the Assembly floor.

title: Training Site Is Disputed
description: National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue has summoned the Seahawks' president, Dave Behring, to New York on Friday regarding the team's off-season workouts in Anaheim, Calif.

title: POLITICS: THE WHITE HOUSE;PRESIDENT DRAFTS 1997 BUDGET PLAN OFFERING TAX CUTS
description: When he presents his election-year budget to Congress on Tuesday morning, President Clinton will call for roughly $100 billion in tax cuts over the next five years, fleshing out several of his proposals to benefit the middle class and to close a number of loopholes enjoyed by American business.

title: TCI to Buy Cable Holdings From Knight-Ridder
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the 50 percent share of a cable company that it jointly owns with Tele-Communications Inc., which is buying the stake and other Knight-Ridder cable holdings.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Panel Backs Longer Benefits
description: The State Senate Appropriations Committee yesterday voted to extend unemployment benefits from 26 weeks to 32 1/2 weeks to win support from labor leaders for a plan to solve the impasse on the financing of hospital care for uninsured New Jerseyans. The bill would allow the state to continue tapping into the unemployment insurance fund for so-called charity care for the next two years, but would cut financing from its 1995 level of $400 million to $275 million. Since the most recent charity-care financing plan expired on Dec. 31, the state has missed two $33 million payments to repay hospitals for treating the uninsured.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Rodman's Suspension Could Cost Bulls, Too
description: Issuing the third-stiffest penalty against a player for an on-court violation, the National Basketball Association suspended Dennis Rodman yesterday for six games without pay and fined him $20,000.

title: Austin Rocks, and the Music Business Pays Attention
description: Thirty-six music acts from New York, including stars like Joan Osborne and Iggy Pop and up-and-comers like Girls Against Boys and Thin Lizard Dawn, trekked here to perform at the 10th annual South by Southwest music festival and convention, which ran from Thursday through Sunday. Members of many other New York bands were here, too, not to play but to make connections and see other performers.

title: MCI and AT&T; Now Fight for Internet Customers
description: It's not quite Coke versus Pepsi, but MCI and AT&T; are turning the Internet into a tit-for-tat marketing battle, complete with catchy promotions and breathless claims of low, low prices.

title: Seles Sits Out 2d Tournament
description: Monica Seles withdrew from the Lipton Championships because of a shoulder injury, tournament officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: If the entire universe persuaded me to reconcile with the defendant, I would not. I am determined to get rid of this marriage. It exists only on paper."

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Scottish Town Buries First of the Children
description: The people of this Scottish town today buried 2 of the 16 children killed with their teacher last week in an attack by a gunman at the local primary school.

title: Warsaw Supports Jewish Museum Project
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: IN THE PARTY;An Abortion Foe's Higher Cause: Dole
description: Downtown, they were busy on Saturday morning dyeing the Chicago River emerald green -- a bit of St. Patrick's Day nonsense as traditional as the annual holiday march on Dearborn Street.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;The Duel of the News Magazines Begins
description: So, as advertised, "Dateline" went up against "60 Minutes" for the first time, the young shootist drawing against the old pro. Making a judgment on this sort of contest on the basis of a single encounter is like picking the winner in an N.C.A.A. matchup after the first couple of minutes on the court, but the event invites attention. Did Sunday night get a lot more interesting, as the NBC advertisement promised? Did people who did not watch "60 Minutes" have nothing to talk about around the water cooler on Monday, as the CBS ad threatened?

title: Too Many Engineers, Too Few Jobs
description: Is there such an acute shortage of skilled scientists and engineers that America's computer industry and research laboratories must recruit thousands of foreign workers yearly in order to compete globally?

title: Boeing Plans Higher Production Of Three Jetliners Next Year
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it would increase production of its 737, 747 and 757 jetliners next year, reflecting the continued rebound in demand for commercial aircraft.

title: Review/Fashion;A Chanel Line Speaks Volumes
description: The somewhat humorless house of Chanel, up in arms over photographs from its collections appearing on the Internet immediately after the shows, handed out fliers today with a warning on them to audience members. The edict said:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The country's biggest brewer renews its defense of that position.
description: ANHEUSER-BUSCH is seeking to regain momentum in the beer wars by undertaking several marketing initiatives.

title: BASEBALL;A Twinge in Pulsipher's Elbow Puts a Frown in Mets' Clubhouse
description: The upbeat atmosphere that has enveloped the Mets' camp this spring suddenly turned to fearful concern when Bill Pulsipher departed tonight's game with the Montreal Expos after two innings with a twinge in his left elbow.

title: Clothing Donations Go First to U.S. Poor, Not Africa Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Avoid Short View on Russian Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKEFELLER CENTER POSTS BIG QUARTERLY LOSS
description: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., which holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on New York landmark Rockefeller Center, said yesterday that it recorded a fourth-quarter loss of $28.8 million, or 75 cents a share, while the complex operated under bankruptcy court protection. A year earlier, the company had a loss of $1.4 million, or 3 cents a share. Rockefeller Center Properties' results have suffered since the owners of the center, two partnerships controlled by the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in May after years of losses. In September, the partnerships decided to turn the property over to Rockefeller Center Properties. As a result of the bankruptcy filing, the owners stopped making mortgage payments and Rockefeller Center Properties' revenue fell to $128,000 in the fourth quarter from $27.3 million a year earlier. Last fall, Rockefeller Center Properties agreed to a buyout offer by a Goldman, Sachs/Rockefeller team valued about $1.2 billion.

title: Observer;Forever Unwrinkled
description: Americans hadn't been interested in George Burns for years until it looked as if he might live forever. Then he became a celebrity, a celebrity being somebody whose chief talent is for turning up in People magazine.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks' Schedule Looks Like a Minefield
description: Riding a three-game winning streak, the Knicks practiced today and prepared for their toughest stretch of the regular season.

title: POLITICS: ON THE ROAD;Clinton Honors Troops' Service In Haiti Action
description: Presiding over a military parade ground whipped by a biting wind, President Clinton today celebrated the American troops who had served in Haiti, saying their mission had given the Haitian people "the breathing space they need to reclaim their democracy."

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.I.T.

title: PERIPHERALS;Exploring the Internet, With a Multilingual Interpreter Along
description: THE English language dominates the Internet, which after all started in the United States, although it is not the native language of most of the world. If you want to communicate with someone in, say, French, a fairly close cousin, you cannot put in the accent marks. If you want to read a World Wide Web page in, say, Russian, you cannot see its Cyrillic alphabet.

title: Panel Backs Retinitis Drug; Gilead Stock Recovers Some
description: Sometimes you have to stay to the end of the meeting.

title: Tuberculosis, Uncontrolled
description: Tuberculosis remains the world's most frustrating killer. Year after year it kills some three million people around the globe, even though effective treatments are known and the cost of applying them is relatively low. TB is the leading infectious killer of adults, the leading killer of AIDS victims and the leading infectious killer of women, causing more female deaths than all other causes of maternal mortality combined. If current trends continue, at least 30 million people will die of TB over the next 10 years.

title: MCI Reduces On-Line Stake
description: The MCI Communications Corporation is reducing its stake in an on-line venture with the News Corporation, and the Oracle Corporation will become one of the partners, MCI's chairman, Bert C. Roberts Jr., said today. MCI, which was an equal partner with the News Corporation, is cutting its stake to 15 percent. The stake that Oracle, a software publisher, is taking was not disclosed.

title: NYC;Help Wanted From Seniors At CUNY
description: WITH all the attention being given to corporate "downsizing" -- can't someone sponsor a contest to come up with a more appealing word? -- it might be useful to note that not every American company has hung out a sign telling job seekers to go away. That reminder was driven home in the sprawling Galleria of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where 90 employers set up booths the other day so that 5,000 seniors and recent graduates of the City University could drop by to explore their prospects for entry-level positions.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Trade Surplus Fell in February
description: Japan's surplus in merchandise trade fell for the eighth straight month in February, dropping 46 percent, to $6.13 billion, from the comparable month a year earlier as exports declined for the first time in three years, the Government said yesterday. Imports remained strong, rising 17 percent, to $27.9 billion, for the 36th straight month of expansion compared with levels a year earlier. Exports fell 3.3 percent, to $34.1 billion.

title: U.S. Seeks to Review More Disability Cases
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it wanted to step up a review checking whether people receiving Social Security disability benefits were still eligible.

title: Bosnia, a Nation Still Divided
description: Peace has already brought many benefits to the peoples of Bosnia, but it has not brought reconciliation and trust. The most disheartening example is Sarajevo, where an ethnically diverse population survived the war, but may not survive the coming of peace. If the pattern of ethnic intimidation and flight that has ravaged the Sarajevo suburbs in recent days extends throughout the country, the promise of a reunified Bosnia will be lost.

title: Clothing Donations Go First to U.S. Poor, Not Africa Market;Displaced Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Where's the Beef? On Top
description: New Yorkers lingering alongside the meat section of their local supermarkets may soon notice the disappearance of yet another only-in-New-York oddity: the clear-bottom plastic tray.

title: Bumping on Subway Leads to a Slashing
description: A woman enraged because a fellow subway rider failed to apologize after bumping into her slashed the commuter across the face with a boxcutter on a packed train in Queens, the police said.

title: Rene Clement, 82, Director Moved by the Ravages of War
description: Rene Clement, the French director of the Oscar-winning 1952 film "Forbidden Games" -- about a little girl orphaned by war -- and 14 other movies that reflected life by blending the approach of the documentarian with a touch of poetic elegance, died on Sunday in southern France, a day before his 83d birthday.

title: Childhood Friends Forge Brotherhood of Crime on Streets of the Bronx
description: When they came out of prison last year, the question was whether Angel Diaz, Jesus Mendez and Ricardo Morales would avoid the gang, the guns and the pull of the Bronx streets where they had made a vicious living together in the 1980's, robbing bodegas and jewelry stores and pistol-whipping people for wallets.

title: Fiery Farewell in Bosnian Land Transfer
description: A group of ragged Bosnian Serb police officers, their voices barely audible over a scratchy recording of the old anthem of the kingdom of Yugoslavia and the thunder of ammunition exploding nearby, lined up for a formal farewell to the neighborhood they will hand over to the Muslim-Croat federation on Tuesday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pearson's Pretax Profit Increases by 23%
description: The British media company Pearson P.L.C. reported yesterday that its pretax profit rose 23 percent in 1995, helped by a gain from the sale of its stake in the satellite television broadcaster British Sky Broadcasting Group P.L.C. Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, said its pretax profit was L365 million ($562 million), up from L298 million in 1994.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PENNY'S TO ADD STORES AND STRESS WOMEN'S APPAREL
description: The J. C. Penney Company will budget about $700 million in capital spending each of the next three years, open 100 new stores in 1996 and close 50 to 60 stores, a company executive said. Penney's also plans to modernize 500 stores, and place a new emphasis on women's apparel and accessories, said Wynn Watkins, vice president and director of investor relations. The company plans to open nine of its J. C. Penney Home Store outlets this year and 12 in 1997.

title: Man Guilty Of 2 Murders In Storming Abortion Sites
description: John C. Salvi 3d was convicted of murdering two receptionists at abortion clinics today and sentenced to two terms of life in prison without parole as a jury rejected his lawyers' claim that Mr. Salvi had acted under delusions brought on by paranoid schizophrenia.

title: A Wave of Manatee Deaths Puzzles Scientists
description: Marine scientists are racing to determine why about 30 manatees have died off southwestern Florida in less than two weeks.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF FLEMING FALL 10% ON DECISION IN FRAUD CASE
description: Shares of the Fleming Companies fell 10 percent after a jury ruled the grocery wholesaler must pay as much as $207.5 million in damages for overcharging David's Supermarkets Inc. Fleming shares fell $1.75, to $15.125. On Friday, a Cleburne, Tex., jury awarded David's as much as $150 million in punitive damages, finding Fleming and a former executive, James Stuard, liable for breach of contract, deceptive trade practices and fraud. David's, a closely held chain based in Grandview, Tex., has 23 stores. The company accused Fleming of breaching a contract to supply groceries at a certain percentage over cost, by misrepresenting Fleming's true costs. The jury granted David's three awards, one for each violation. David's must select one of the three, and the judge must approve the final damages.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ISOLYSER TO PURCHASE MICROTEK FOR $106.5 MILLION
description: The Isolyser Company agreed to acquire Microtek Medical Inc. for $106.5 million in a move that would increase its overseas sales of disposable medical supplies. Under the agreement, Isolyser will issue stock valued at $87.5 million, or $16.50 a share, and assume $19 million of debt. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Microtek rose $4.375, to $15.625. Shares of Isolyser rose 62.5 cents, to $17.50. Microtek makes disposable products like drapes and pouches for use in operating rooms. Isolyser also makes disposable products for health care uses. Fred Harlow, Isolyser's chief financial officer, said the acquisition gave the company, which has little international presence, a broader market for its disposable products.

title: It's Time to Put Limits on Power of H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Gretzky Rises To Occasion
description: Wayne Gretzky had a goal and an assist in his emotional return to the Forum tonight, a homecoming in which the crowd's sentiments were split between boos and cheers for the Great One. His Blues defeated the Kings, 3-1.

title: Irish Drug Concern to Buy Athena for $625 Million
description: The Elan Corporation, an Irish company specializing in drug delivery technology, said today that it would acquire Athena Neurosciences Inc. for stock valued at about $625 million.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Portrait of the Clintons, Cast in Dark Shadows
description: BLOOD SPORT The President and His Adversaries By James B. Stewart Illustrated. 479 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Anthropology Group Takes Activist Stand to Protect Cultures
description: AT the stroke of midnight on Nov. 10, 1983, the creation of a new national park in Sri Lanka made cultural orphans of the Wanniya-laeto, the last remnant of a people who appear to have lived on the island for 28,000 years. The final fringe of the forests in which they had been hunters and gatherers was put off limits for all hunting and gathering of food. A Wanniya-laeto who tried to stick to the old ways would be arrested as a poacher.

title: Good Junk Food or Pharmacologic Junk?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pact in Fedex Dispute
description: The Federal Express Corporation and the Air Line Pilots Association said today that that they had reached a tentative agreement on a new collective bargaining pact for the company's 3,000 pilots.

title: New Departure At First Boston
description: John Costas, head of United States fixed-income investing at CS First Boston, resigned from the firm yesterday, a spokeswoman said.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Olympics

title: Balkan Leaders Again Promise To Carry Out Accord on Bosnia
description: After eight hours of meetings today with Secretary of State Warren Christopher and a team of European diplomats, three top Balkan leaders agreed, once again but in more detail than before, to live up to their obligations under the Dayton accords.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On the same day, ROBERT CLARK, dean of the Harvard Law School, announced the establishment of the Morris Wasserstein Public Interest Law Professorship. The professorship is supported by a $2.3 million gift from the Wasserstein family, which includes MORRIS WASSERSTEIN, a businessman in Manhattan; his wife, LOLA, and their children: WENDY WASSERSTEIN, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright; GEORGETTE LEWIS, owner of the Wilburton Inn in Manchester, Vt.; SANDRA W. MEYER, a partner at Clark & Weinstock, a business-consulting firm in Manhattan, and BRUCE WASSERSTEIN, the chairman of Wasserstein Perella & Company, the investment banking firm in Manhattan.

title: Another Media Concern Dashes Into Professional Sports
description: In another case illustrating the growing attraction sports properties hold for large media corporations, the Comcast Corporation yesterday announced its purchase of two-thirds of a new venture to own the Philadelphia Flyers, the Philadelphia 76ers, the Corestates Spectrum, where both teams now play, and the new Corestates Center, into which they will move in August.

title: In Performance;DANCE
description: Eye-Catching Imagery And Surreal Stage Pictures 'Ballets With a Twist' Church of the Holy Trinity

title: Internet Courtroom Battle Gets Cyberspace Preview
description: It is the talk of cyberspace, so it was perhaps inevitable that a cyberspace talk show would be created to discuss a landmark legal confrontation taking place this week on free speech, pornography and the world's growing web of computer networks.

title: Chief Executive Quits Position At Blockbuster Entertainment
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that Steven Berrard, the chief executive of Blockbuster Entertainment, had resigned from the company.

title: Editorial Notebook;Russian Real Estate
description: Soviet leaders may have wrenched farmers from their ancestral ways and forced them into state farms, and industrialization may have drawn millions of people to the cities, but Russians still retain an almost mystical reverence for their land.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Suspension Over False Report
description: The partner of a Paterson housing police officer who fatally shot a man last month at a housing project has been suspended without pay for filing a false report, officials announced yesterday. The partner, Officer Richard DeJesus, who has not been charged with a crime, first told internal affairs investigators that he did not see the shooting.

title: No Headline
description: You haven't done anything yet. All you have to do is to let me go and take my car."

title: Theater in Review
description: Of a Mother and Daughter As Time Reverses Their Roles 'Bonds of Affection' Ubu Repertory Theater

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Tax Preparer Admits Evasion
description: The president of a tax preparation firm in Moorestown admitted yesterday in Federal Court that he neglected to file his own Federal tax return for 1991, when his income was $80,000, said Holly Kulka, an assistant United States attorney.

title: Christopher to Meet His Chinese Counterpart
description: As part of a series of meetings with top Chinese leaders to try to bring the United States-Chinese relationship back into equilibrium, Secretary of State Warren Christopher will meet the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, on April 21 in The Hague.

title: Exxon Gets China Rights
description: The Exxon Corporation said today that it had been granted exploration rights to two large blocks in northwestern China. The company said its Esso China Upstream Ltd. affiliate was the sole foreign oil company in these blocks, which are in the northwestern region of the Tarim Basin in the Xinjiang Uygur. Exxon said Esso was the largest acreage holder of any multinational oil company in China.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: The Bon Marche, Seattle, a division of Federated Department Stores, to McCann-Erickson Seattle, a unit of Interpublic Group, to handle the media part of its broadcast account, with billings estimated at $10 million. The media duties had been handled in-house; the creative part of the account will continue in-house. True Fitness Technology, O'Fallon, Mo., to TBWA Chiat/Day, St. Louis, a unit of Omnicom Group, to handle national advertising for the maker of exercise treadmills, previously handled by Kupper Parker Communications, St. Louis. The billings were estimated at $1 million to $3 million.

title: AT&T and I.B.M. Notes Alliance Is On Again
description: Just three weeks after abruptly canceling a joint service that was two years and millions of dollars in the making, AT&T and I.B.M.'s Lotus Development Corporation are expected to announce a revamped alliance today.

title: Ex-Intel Worker In Guilty Plea
description: A former Intel engineer pleaded guilty on Monday to stealing confidential information about computer chips produced by the Intel Corporation and sending it to a competitor.

title: About New York;Meltdown: The Equinox To the Rescue
description: PUFFY parkas and fuzzy flannels must go. So decreed Mo Stein, the owner of Frank's Sport Shop on Tremont Avenue in the Bronx, who has placed those items on sale. It's time for baseball, soccer and fishing, which in his business are surer harbingers of spring than sunshine or flowers.

title: POLITICS: THE PRIMARIES;Dole Continues to Roll Toward G.O.P. Nomination
description: Senator Bob Dole roared through the industrial Midwest Tuesday, piling up resounding primary victories in Illinois, Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin that left him just a handful of delegates short of sealing the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Wednesday, comparing changes in drug prices paid by health maintenance organizations and those paid by retailers, omitted an explanatory heading. The bar graphs represented changes in four categories -- heart medication, antibiotics, allergy relief and arthritis relief. The graphs did not depict changes for the specific drug brands -- Procardia XL, Zithromax, Claritin and Lodine -- illustrating the categories.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Times Mirror Chief Defends Cutting Costs
description: Mark H. Willes, the chief executive who has directed significant cuts at the Times Mirror Company, including the closing of New York Newsday, said last night that the moves were hardly unusual in American business.

title: COMPANY NEWS;XEIKON A.D.R.'S SURGE ON FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The American depository receipts of Xeikon N.V., a Belgian maker of digital printing systems, surged 34 percent yesterday in their first day of trading. The company, which is seeking to capture part of the short-run color printing market, sold 6.4 million A.D.R.'s at $15 each to raise $96 million. Yesterday, the shares closed at $20.125, in Nasdaq trading of almost 6.7 million shares. Each A.D.R. equals one common share. The short-run market, defined as print jobs consisting of no more than 5,000 copies, generally includes such materials as product catalogues and newsletters.

title: Who Gets the Best Seats, and How: The Rules of the Game
description: From back in Row Q of the New York State Theater, Leonard and Ellen Milberg yearn to recapture their old seats in Row G.

title: In Performance;POP
description: Message of Steadfastness Amid the Swaying Beat Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers The Academy

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Trying to Master the Master
description: As Maurizio Pollini headed into the home stretch of his Beethoven sonata survey at Carnegie Hall, Emanuel Ax took on the largest and most complicated Beethoven piano piece of all, the 33 Variations on a Waltz of Diabelli. These sometimes caustic, sometimes mystical commentaries on a trivial tune require a particular kind of mental virtuosity, an ability to produce hugely contrasted characterizations in very quick succession. On Sunday afternoon at Tully Hall, Mr. Ax showed himself to be one of very few pianists who have the technical and intellectual strength to grasp a nearly impossible score.

title: Police Volunteer Arrested
description: An off-duty auxiliary police officer was arrested early yesterday in the knife-point robbery of a delivery man in Manhattan, the police said.

title: HOCKEY;Richter Is Fit, But Not His Team
description: Mike Richter showed last night that he is again fit enough to play goalie for the Rangers. But other questions remain.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUDINESS;Spending Helps Japan's Economy Grow 3.6%, Beating Forecasts
description: Lifted by increased spending by consumers and the Government, Japan's economy expanded at a 3.6 percent annual rate in 1995's fourth quarter, the Economic Planning Agency said today. The growth exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: Stock Prices Lower, With Dow Falling 14.09
description: The stock market took a breather yesterday, with prices lower after Monday's record-setting performance.

title: Signet Banking Says It Might Have Been Loan-Scheme Victim
description: The Signet Banking Corporation said yesterday that it might be the victim of $81 million in fraudulent commercial loans, as F.B.I. agents arrested two people on charges of bank fraud in connection with the case.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Stumble, Scuffle, But Come Up Winners
description: The Nets were terrible tonight, but the Vancouver Grizzlies were worse.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Jazz's Dark Forces and the Artists Who Love Them
description: BUT BEAUTIFUL A Book About Jazz By Geoff Dyer 227 pages. North Point Press. $21.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Striking Out
description: The United Automobile Workers has drawn a line in the sand and struck at General Motors' two brake-production plants in Dayton. But G.M.'s hard-line decision to let the job action shut its entire manufacturing process, while negotiations drag on, demonstrates that if the U.A.W. decides to do nothing but strike, its efforts will be futile.

title: Bangladesh Premier Sworn In Amid Protests
description: The Prime Minister of Bangladesh, Khaleda Zia, was sworn in for her second term today, despite opposition protests against the elections that returned her to power.

title: TV Notes;A Problem Word
description: Is there a new chill of caution hovering over network television executive suites because of the recent passage of V-chip legislation by Congress and the industrywide agreement to begin rating programs for sexual or violent content?

title: Veterinarians Are Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida State Given A Slap on the Wrist
description: Florida State won another big one today, escaping serious National Collegiate Athletic Association penalties after a two-year investigation that began after a much-publicized shopping spree by Seminole football players.

title: Big Housing Project Is Raided by Troops
description: About 800 National Guard troops and police officers swarmed into Puerto Rico's largest housing project today, searching for illegal drugs and weapons and arresting residents.

title: Officer Sentenced for Lying Under Oath
description: A highly decorated police officer from the 34th Precinct in Washington Heights was sentenced in Federal Court yesterday to a year and a day in prison for lying under oath during a 1994 grand jury hearing.

title: Cellmark DNA Lab Sold
description: The Zeneca Group P.L.C. has sold its United States unit, Cellmark Diagnostics, to the closely held Lifecodes Corporation of Stamford, Conn., for an undisclosed sum. Cellmark Diagnostics, based in Germantown, Md., the largest private forensic DNA testing laboratory in the United States, analyzed DNA in the O.J. Simpson murder case.

title: March Lion Greets Spring With a Roar
description: A record-breaking winter wound down on a tumultuous note last night as high winds, heavy rains and coastal flooding left thousands of households and businesses without power throughout the New York region.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fire Damages Funeral Home
description: An early-morning fire yesterday damaged the 100-year-old building that housed the Wien & Wien Funeral Home in Jersey City. Rabbis in the area have offered their synagogues for funerals, said Barry Wien, president of the company, which has been run by his family for three generations. No one was injured in the blaze, and the cause is under investigation, Capt. Michael Pierro of the Jersey City Fire Department said.

title: Starts of Housing Surged 3% in February
description: Builders started work on new homes last month at the highest rate in more than a year as they prepared for a rush of buyers eager to lock in mortgage rates before the rates move higher.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Hoyas Know How To Get By On Talent
description: Georgetown proved last weekend that it can win despite poor free-throw shooting, repeated foul difficulties and an excess of turnovers. Its talent is that forgiving.

title: Passing the Cleaver at Oppenheimer's
description: HERE is an Upper West Side institution that apparently will endure. Harry Oppenheimer, 75, who has owned his butcher shop at 2606 Broadway (99th Street) since 1956, has sold the business to Robert Pence, a butcher and chef who is a graduate of the French Culinary Institute.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New Spring Water To Grey Advertising
description: The Great Brands of Europe unit of Danone Group in Greenwich, Conn., has expanded its relationship with Grey Advertising in New York by awarding the agency the account for a new product, Dannon Natural Spring Water. Though the billings were not disclosed, spending in large urban markets on an introductory campaign, which begins today with a distribution of free samples in Times Square, will be at a national rate of $15 million to $20 million.

title: Military Recruiting Ban On a Campus Is Upheld
description: Connecticut's highest court upheld a permanent ban on military recruiters at the University of Connecticut School of Law today, ruling that the Pentagon's policy on homosexuals violates the state's Gay Rights Law barring discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Michelin's Net Doubles Despite Drop in Revenue
description: Michelin, the French tire maker, said yesterday that it had more than doubled its profits in 1995, aided by higher operating earnings despite a downturn in revenue. The company's profits soared to 2.80 billion francs ($554.8 million), from 1.29 billion francs ($255.6 million) in 1994. The family-run company said its operating earnings rose to 5.70 billion francs ($1.13 billion), from 4.75 billion in 1994.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Get Physical: Oakley Is Ready to Return
description: Look. Down on the court. He's bumping bodies, knocking away passes headed into the low post, pulling down rebounds.

title: New York Plans to Stop Investing In Tobacco
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall announced today that he would stop investing state pension funds in tobacco stocks.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMERICA TO SELL ILLINOIS BANKING UNIT TO ABN AMRO
description: Comerica Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Illinois subsidiary, Comerica Bank-Illinois, to ABN Amro North America Inc. for about $190 million. Comerica Bank-Illinois has 25 branches and $1.4 billion in assets. ABN, a unit of ABN Amro Holding of the Netherlands, is the parent of the LaSalle National Corporation, a $16 billion holding company that operates LaSalle National Bank in Chicago. Comerica, a bank holding company in Detroit, also said it planned to buy back up to 15 million shares, or nearly 13 percent of its stock outstanding. Its shares rose $1 yesterday, to $39.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Panel Calls for Tougher Child Abuse Laws
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's Commission on Child Abuse called for changes in the state's child welfare system yesterday, including easing the removal of children from abusive households and making endangering the welfare of a child a felony.

title: Jackson Deal With a Prince
description: Michael Jackson, the American singer, and Prince Walid bin Talal, the Saudi investor, announced today that they had formed a venture, King Entertainment, to promote entertainment based on "family values."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Successor to Be Named
description: A successor to Assemblyman Monroe J. Lustbader, who died on Saturday, will be appointed during the first week in April by Republican officials from his district, John Renna, the chairman of the Essex County Republican Committee, said yesterday. Mr. Lustbader, Democrat of Millburn, had represented portions of Essex and Union counties since 1991. Although his term would have ended in 1997, his replacement will serve only until the end of the year, and the seat will be up for election in November, Mr. Renna said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 157.47 points, or nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 20,442.60. Financial markets here will be closed on Wednesday in observance of Vernal Equinox Day, a national holiday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Smith Pleads Guilty in Drug Case
description: In Orlando, Fla., SAMMIE SMITH, a former running back for the Miami Dolphins and Denver Broncos, pleaded guilty yesterday to two Federal charges of possession and distribution of cocaine and faces a minimum sentence of 20 years in prison.

title: One-Woman Shows
description: Pit Menousek Pinegar, Ayana Cahrr and Rebecca VerNooy are among the 30 female artists presenting their work in Womenkind VI, a festival of one-woman shows that runs from tonight to March 31 at One Dream Theater, 232 West Broadway, near Franklin Street, TriBeCa. Performances are at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday through Friday, 2 and 7:30 P.M. on Saturday and 2 P.M. Sunday. Tickets tonight for a benefit and post-performance reception are $25; $15 for other performances and $35 for a festival pass to all performances. Information: (212) 769-6814.

title: Negotiator Says U S West Was Told of Turner
description: An adviser to Time Warner Inc., Oded Aboodi, testified today that he told Richard D. McCormick, the chairman of U S West Inc., in 1993 that Time Warner was contemplating buying Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and that he asked whether U S West wanted to invest in the purchase.

title: If Wind Eases, Space Shuttle Will Revisit The Russians
description: For the third time in less than a year, the space shuttle Atlantis is set for launching toward a linkup with the Russian space station Mir, another rehearsal for the assembly and operation of an international space station later in the decade.

title: Judge Is Rebuked Over Conduct at a Trial
description: An appeals court panel yesterday rebuked a prominent Federal judge in Manhattan for his handling of a personal injury trial last year, saying that his treatment of one lawyer amounted to "antipathy that went beyond judicial skepticism."

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Division I Tournament

title: CHRONICLE
description: In "Somewhere in the City," a film starring SANDRA BERNHARD, EDWARD I. KOCH, the former Mayor of New York, plays himself -- which, he said, "is always easy."

title: Christopher, In Ukraine, Warns Russia
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher, in his third meeting in six weeks with President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine, lashed out at Russia's lower house of Parliament for adopting a nonbinding resolution last week declaring the dissolution of the Soviet Union illegal.

title: Persian New Year Table Helps Good Fight Evil
description: THIS morning at 3:03, when the sun crossed the equator, spring began. For Iranians, spring brings the New Year Festival. "The New Year represents the duality found in helping the god of light conquer the god of darkness," said Najmieh Batmanglij, who writes cookbooks on the cuisine of her native Iran.

title: Argyle to Buy 2 Stations
description: Argyle Television Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire two Arkansas television stations from Sigma Broadcasting Inc. for about $4.7 million in common stock, plus other considerations. The San Antonio-based Argyle, which now owns five TV stations, will also assume about $3.5 million of Sigma debt and will pay Sigma $3 million at closing for the transfer of real estate and for an agreement not to compete with the stations. The ABC-affiliated stations are KHBS in Fort Smith and KHOG in Fayetteville.

title: Real Estate;A new agency of New York City is moving into the International Design Center in  Long Island City.
description: THE City of New York has leased more than 200,000 square feet at the International Design Center in Long Island City, Queens, for a new agency, the Department of Design and Construction Services. The agency, responsible for most city-sponsored construction projects, has an option for an additional 113,000 square feet. The 17 1/2-year lease was valued at $40 million.

title: The Grammys Are Returning To New York
description: The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences will announce today that the Grammy Awards will return to New York next March after two years at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, a spokeswoman for the Grammys said yesterday. Past Grammy ceremonies in New York took place at the 6,000-seat Radio City Music Hall, but next year's event will be held at Madison Square Garden, which can accommodate 20,000 people, making the 1997 Grammy Awards ceremony the biggest ever.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENERAL PUBLIC TO CONSOLIDATE UNITS AND CUT JOBS
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation said yesterday that it would consolidate three of its operations into one management team in a cost-cutting move. The move will affect Jersey Central Power and Light, based in Morristown, N.J.; the GPU Service Corporation in Parsippany, N.J., and Metropolitan Edison and Pennsylvania Electric, which merged last year in Reading, Pa. The company's chairman, James R. Leva, said he expected a loss of 300 to 400 jobs. A spokesman said a large part of the cuts would be from management.

title: In Performance;POP
description: Tunes From the Carpathians, Moldavia and Transylvania Muzsikas Symphony Space

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Court Lets Workers Sue If Tricked of Benefits The Supreme Court ruled that workers whose employers trick them into giving up benefits can sue to have the coverage restored. The 6-to-3 decision gave new teeth to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.

title: In Performance;Classical Music
description: Beauty and Terror In a World of Shadows Guarneri Quartet Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Brazil Settles a Suit With Dart Family
description: Brazil has settled a lawsuit over $1.32 billion in foreign debt held by the Dart family, holdouts in a $49 billion debt swap between commercial bankers and Brazil in April 1994.

title: FUGURE SKAING;Harding Dusts Off Her Skates
description: Tonya Harding has begun skating four times a week and is searching for a way to resume a career that ended in the aftermath of the 1994 attack on Nancy Kerrigan.

title: What Einstein Wrote
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review
description: Where the Evil Is So Awful That the Awfulness Pales 'In the Land of Giants' The Intar Theater

title: BASEBALL;Key Is Superb, but Rogers Is Routed
description: Jimmy Key continued to amaze and Kenny Rogers continued to perplex tonight as both left-handers continued to make Manager Joe Torre's decisions about the Yankees' starting rotation arduous.

title: Senate Votes to Prevent Ouster Of H.I.V. Patients in Military
description: The Senate voted without debate today to overturn a month-old law that requires the mandatory discharge of members of the armed forces who test positive for the virus that causes AIDS.

title: BASEBALL;Thompson Rules Out Minors
description: Outfielder Ryan Thompson said today that he would ask the Mets for a release and consider playing in Japan if the club decided to send him to Class AAA Norfolk to start the season.

title: POLITICS: THE CHALLENGER;Looking Ahead to California Vote, Buchanan Lashes Out at Immigrants
description: Hopping from Michigan to California today, Patrick J. Buchanan turned his fire from threats posed by foreign companies to threats posed by foreigners, declaring that "this country is literally being overrun" by illegal immigrants.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Richardson Has No One in Stitches
description: After his Arkansas Razorbacks won their first game in the East Region last week, Coach Nolan Richardson began talking about how his 12th-seeded team really was not supposed to be in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: U.S. Faults Transit Agency Over Running of Signals
description: Transit Authority managers know so little about how subways are actually operated that they have not come up with a way to prevent train operators from driving through stop signals, top Federal safety investigators said today. Running signals is so common and so dangerous that it has been the cause of seven accidents injuring 115 people since July 1990, the investigators said.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Salmon and a Touch of Spring
description: At last, the first tentative signs of spring: buds on trees, daffodils pushing their way up, and best of all, asparagus, which makes a lovely creamy sauce to mix with pasta and serve with salmon.

title: Measuring the New Clinton
description: If voters were choosing between the Bill Clinton who ran for office in 1992 and the President who issued his budget plan for 1997 yesterday they would find enormous differences. That is not surprising, given that the political landscape has changed so sharply. As the Republicans have gained strength, the President has retreated from some of the core principles and programs he once embraced. One can complain that Mr. Clinton has made some regrettable concessions, but in a broad sense he had to retreat.

title: Germans Win Short Program
description: On a night of uninspired pairs skating, Mandy Wotzel and Ingo Steuer of Germany finished first in the short program, followed by Marina Eltsova and Andrei Bushkov of Russia and Yevgeniya Shishkova and Vadim Naumov of Russia.

title: Don't Punish All Palestinians for Acts of a Few
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;CAREMARK SETTLES WITH INSURERS FOR $65.6 MILLION
description: Caremark International Inc. will spend $65.6 million to settle disputes with insurers arising from a Government fraud investigation of kickbacks that the company, a health services concern, paid physicians for patient referrals. The settlement announced yesterday "resolves good-faith business disputes" stemming from the investigation and is not an admission of wrongdoing, said C. A. Lance Piccolo, Caremark's chairman and chief executive. The money will be deducted from Caremark's 1996 first-quarter profits. It is more than three times the $21.4 million Caremark earned in the first quarter of last year. Caremark, based in Northbrook, Ill., pleaded guilty last year to Federal fraud charges and agreed to pay $161 million in civil and criminal fines.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Survival Of the Nastiest;Manhattan Lab Draws Fame For TB Bacteria in Freezer
description: In a ninth-floor laboratory on the East Side of Manhattan, there is a white chest-style storage freezer that is home to some of the nastiest little Darwinian survivalists on the planet. Packed in plastic vials and suspended at 70 degrees below zero centigrade, this is New York City's own private hot zone: the lethal drug-resistant tuberculosis bacteria that flared in the city in the early 1990's came to rest here as the outbreak subsided.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHART HOUSE ENTERPRISES INC., Solana Beach, Calif., agreed to sell a 75 percent stake in its Islands restaurant operations to Islands Restaurants L.P., the owner and licenser of the Islands concept, for $23 million.

title: Don't Punish All Palestinians for Acts of a Few
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS;Estimates Vary on Dole's Delegate Count
description: Has Bob Dole secured the Republican Presidential nomination? As he sailed through another string of victories last night, there was disagreement about whether or not Mr. Dole had amassed the 996 delegates he needs to clinch the Republican nomination.

title: INSIDE
description: Blow to Affirmative Action

title: Slain Teacher Made a Tape Of Abductor
description: In the final minutes of her life, a New Jersey teacher secretly turned on a recorder that taped 24 minutes in which she pleaded in vain with her abductor to spare her life, the authorities said yesterday.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Strong Start, But Bonds Back Down
description: Bonds gave up an initial gain and were little changed yesterday as investors debated whether a jump in oil prices and signs of stronger economic growth would bring about an increase in inflation.

title: Passover Bakery Opens for a Sweet and Hectic Season
description: FOR most of the year, Schick's Bakery in Brooklyn is a beloved institution of the Borough Park Orthodox Jewish community and the source for justifiably renowned hallah, rugelach and other traditional Jewish breads, cakes, and cookies.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;$1 Million to Newark Schools
description: The Newark School District, under state control since last July, was awarded $1 million yesterday by a private foundation. The Prudential Foundation, an arm of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said the money would be used to start the Newark Fund for Excellence in Public Education.

title: Employees Can Sue Under Benefits Law, Supreme Court Says
description: Adding new teeth to the Federal law that protects employee pensions and other job-related benefits, the Supreme Court ruled today that workers whose employers trick them into giving up their benefits can sue to have the coverage restored.

title: Cause of Blindness in Glaucoma May Be Nerve Toxin, Not Fluids
description: THE blindness that results from glaucoma, long thought to be a result of too much fluid inside the eye, may be more the result of a neurotoxin, according to a new report that has intrigued, but not completely convinced, other scientists.

title: THE BALKAN PEACE: THE PENTAGON;Pentagon Report Predicts Bosnia Will Fragment Without Vast Aid
description: The Pentagon has offered its grimmest assessment of the prospects for peace in Bosnia to date, warning that without an enormous international aid program to rebuild its economy and political institutions, the country will probably fragment after the withdrawal of NATO peacekeeping troops late this year.

title: Instilling the Workout Ethic at Work
description: FOR much of his adult life, Sam Di blasi, a 54-year-old warehouse worker, has been lifting heavy loads. Last June, on Mutual of Omaha's corporate campus in downtown Omaha, he found himself inside a familiar stone warehouse dressed in sneakers, a T-shirt and sweat pants.

title: Excerpts From Pataki Death Penalty Letter
description: Following are excerpts from a letter from Gov. George E. Pataki to District Attorney Robert E. Johnson asking Mr. Johnson to affirm that he does not have a policy against seeking the death penalty.

title: Core Curriculum Vanishing In Top Colleges, Study Says
description: A study of undergraduate education since 1914 has found that the country's 50 best-known colleges and universities are no longer providing "broad and rigorous exposure to major areas of knowledge," once considered essential to a liberal-arts education.

title: Cooperating to Cut Bypass Deaths
description: Applying industrial management techniques to medicine, a group of surgeons saw the death rate among their heart-bypass patients fall by one-fourth after observing one another in the operating room and sharing their know-how.

title: Theater in Review
description: Taking On the Bureaucrats With Puppets and Polemics Bread and Puppet Theater Theater for the New City Political theater is alive and in stimulating shape in the East Village, where the Bread and Puppet Theater has set its sights on the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;AT&T's new campaign conjures up images from recent history.
description: REMEMBER Watergate? Those whose fading memories make it increasingly difficult to distinguish Woodward from Bernstein -- or were too young to grasp the significance of John Dean's oncological assessment of the Nixon Presidency -- can get a refresher course at this point in time from a series of sophisticated advertisements for the AT&T Corporation.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Residency Ruling Due Friday
description: A Superior Court judge said yesterday that he would issue a ruling on Friday on a challenge brought by the Essex County Prosecutor and 11 employee unions to an 18-year-old ordinance that requires county employees to live within its boundaries.

title: Senate Passes a Bill To Cover Spending In '96 Fiscal Year
description: The Senate yesterday passed a $166 billion spending bill that would cover the remaining six months of the fiscal year 1996 for some of the largest departments of the Government.

title: Philadelphia' Makers Settle Suit
description: The makers of the movie "Philadelphia" acknowledged yesterday that the film "was inspired in part" by the story of a New York lawyer who was dismissed after his employer discovered he had AIDS.

title: Melt Pounds With Cabbage Soup, a Diet From Nowhere Says
description: DIANA VAN BUREN, a restaurant manager in Manhattan, had never been on a diet. She said she didn't believe in them. She's not overweight but, like anyone else, could stand to lose 5 or 10 pounds.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Framers Never Intended Habeas Corpus as We Know It
description: To the Editor:

title: House Votes To Repay 7 Workers
description: The House passed a bill today to have the Government reimburse legal expenses of the seven employees dismissed from the White House travel office in May 1993.

title: TV Notes;Victorious '60 Minutes'
description: 60 Minutes" easily won its first confrontation with NBC's "Dateline" last Sunday night. For the hour, "60 Minutes" had a national rating of 15.6, while "Dateline" had a 9.4. (Each point represents 959,000 households.)

title: COMPANY NEWS;ANOTHER EXECUTIVE LEAVES CS FIRST BOSTON FOR RIVAL
description: An executive exodus from CS First Boston continued yesterday as the firm's top bank analyst, Thomas H. Hanley, resigned to join a rival, UBS Securities L.L.C. Mr. Hanley, 51, has been the No. 1 bank analyst for the last 12 years in surveys by Institutional Investor magazine. He is the second senior official to join UBS from CS First Boston in two days. John P. Costas, the firm's United States bond chief, left on Monday to become head of UBS's North American fixed-income unit. More than a dozen officials have left CS First Boston this year after bonus payments failed to meet many employees' expectations. Mr. Hanley was named a managing director and senior bank analyst at UBS, a unit of the Union Bank of Switzerland.

title: Yeltsin's Land Decree Is Illegal and Risky
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;CIRRUS LOGIC MOVES TO TRIM 13% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: The chip maker Cirrus Logic Inc. said yesterday it would cut about 455 jobs, or about 13 percent of its work force, and said it expected a substantial operating loss in the quarter that ends this month. Cirrus said the loss, caused by lower revenue, would be on top of restructuring charges. Cirrus, based in Fremont, Calif., also said it would sharpen its focus on new products that it believed would bring stronger revenue growth over the next 18 months. Cirrus shares fell $1.125 yesterday, to $18.625, in Nasdaq trading. Cirrus said the job cuts would involve regular and temporary employees in all of its operations.

title: A Collapse Raises New Safety Concerns About the Olympics
description: Two 10,000-pound steel beams, designed to support a temporary roof being constructed over the Olympic swimming and diving complex, collapsed on Monday night and fell 130 feet before crashing into a student athletic center on the Georgia Tech campus.

title: Clinton Calls For Tax Cuts In New Plan For Budget
description: President Clinton proposed a $1.64 trillion budget today embodying months-old proposals for middle-class tax cuts and slower growth in spending, and he sought to paint the Republican-controlled Congress as the impediment to balancing the Federal budget by 2002.

title: Lengthy Prison Sentences Given To 6 Who Beat a Boy to Death
description: Six young men who were convicted in the beating death of a 16-year-old on the steps of his church were given lengthy prison terms today. The victim's father vowed to seek vengeance in the afterlife.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PIECE GOODS BUYS A FABRIC AND CRAFT UNIT FROM CONAGRA
description: Conagra Inc. of Omaha said yesterday that it had sold Northwest Fabrics and Crafts to the Piece Goods Shops Company in a move to focus on its core food operations. Financial terms were not disclosed. Northwest Fabrics, of Charlotte, N.C., operates 84 fabric and craft stores under the names Northwest Fabrics and Crafts and Rainbow Bay Crafts. Annual sales are about $105 million. Piece Goods, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., operates 205 stores in the Eastern United States.

title: AT WORK WITH: Ann Harris;Still on the Stage (With Steak as a Co-Star)
description: WHEN Ann Harris was Ann Lee, co-starring on Broadway with Gertrude Lawrence in "Lady in the Dark" in the 1940's, her big line was about Victor Mature. "He's the most beautiful hunk of man you've ever seen!" she gasped nightly at the Alvin Theater.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Shots Are Fired at Home Of Russia's Bank Chief
description: Gunmen fired shots on Monday night into the apartment of the head of the Russia's Central Bank, the police said today. It was the first time in recent memory that such a high-ranking Government official has been threatened.

title: Management Faulted In Subway Accidents
description: Transit Authority managers know so little about how subways are actually operated that they have not come up with a way to prevent train operators from driving through stop signals, top Federal safety investigators said yesterday. Running signals is so common and so dangerous that the practice has caused seven accidents injuring 115 people since July 1990, the investigators said. The criticism followed a review of the February 1995 collision of two trains in which an operator ran through a red light, injuring 15 people.

title: Business Travel;USAir's terminal at La Guardia comes in second in a poll ranking airport concession programs.
description: WITH short runways, inadequate parking space and its location in the heart of a busy city, New York's La Guardia Airport wins few accolades from passengers or pilots. But the USAir terminal at La Guardia tied for second place with Portland, Ore., International Airport in a recent poll ranking airport concession programs. USAir's operation at Pittsburgh International finished first.

title: Indonesian Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: Negotiations to End Strike Against G.M. Falter
description: Progress faltered today in negotiations between General Motors and the United Automobile Workers to settle a two-week-old strike at brake factories here, and G.M. laid off more workers.

title: HOCKEY;With Islanders Going Nowhere, Some Players May Be Packing
description: The Islanders still have plenty of items on their long-term wish list, but only if some team makes a desperate plea will they be involved in any last-second deals before Wednesday's 3 P.M. trading deadline.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Big Talent for Trouble, Little for Screenwriting
description: You won't find it in Dante's "Inferno," but there is apparently a 10th circle of hell, wherein writhe those foolish enough to be Hollywood screenwriters.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MORRISON KNUDSEN TO TRIM STAKE IN McCONNELL DOWELL
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation said yesterday that it would sell about half its stake in the McConnell Dowell Corporation of Australia for $9.3 million to Paul Y-ITC Construction Holdings Ltd., a Hong Kong construction company. Morrison Knudsen, based in Boise, Idaho, has been short of cash since it discovered in early 1995 cost overruns on transit-car projects. Morrison Knudsen, which owns 43 percent of the ordinary shares of McConnell Dowell, said it would sell 8.27 million shares, retaining a stake of about 23 percent. McConnell Dowell makes pipelines for the construction industry.

title: Food Notes
description: Arborio With a U.S. Flavor

title: COMPANY NEWS;CATERPILLAR TO CLOSE PLANT IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Caterpillar Inc. said yesterday that it would close its Precision Barstock Products unit in York, Pa., because the plant was not competitive. Caterpillar said it would begin closing the plant in the next few weeks and would complete the shutdown in two or three years. All of the 1,100 employees will be affected. Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., said it recorded a reserve in 1991 for the cost of the closing, so the shutdown would not have a significant impact on its current results. The company said it had made contract offers to the United Automobile Workers that would have allowed the plant to stay open. Union members at the plant ended a 17-month strike in December, returning to work despite rejecting the company's proposal for a six-year contract.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;O'Donnell-Graham Duo Is a Reunion in Green
description: The quarterback who went to the Super Bowl telephoned one of the league's top wide receivers and told him, "The situation is great here."

title: Making the Shoe Fit, Perfectly;Companies Use Technology to Sell to a Market of One
description: When the Custom Foot shoe store opens its doors in Westport, Conn., for the first time tomorrow, it may be hard to judge how business is going: even shoppers making a purchase will be leaving empty-handed.

title: Agreement Reached in Oakland School Strike
description: After a bitter five-week strike that fractured their struggling city along racial lines, Oakland teachers have reached an agreement with the school board to return to work as soon as Wednesday in exchange for a new contract that gives them a substantial raise and smaller classes.

title: A Festival For Films That Defy Convention
description: There's a place for a film like "Home Brewer Serial Killer." It's not Cannes or Berlin or even Sundance. It's the New York Underground Film Festival, a relentlessly outrageous event, now in its third year, that provides safe haven for the kind of films that get made whether they need to or not. It embraces films, like "Baby Kebab" and "The Invincible Kung Fu Guy," that even the boldest independent distributors wouldn't handle with 10-foot tongs.

title: House Panel Approves Bill To Close an Insurance Gap
description: The House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill today that would guarantee access to health insurance for many people who switch jobs or lose their jobs, and Republican leaders said they hoped to take the measure to the House floor next week.

title: THE FINE PRINT: A close look at the immigration bill.;Change at the Border Could Pinch the Arts
description: By nearly all accounts, Karen Zacarias, a 26-year-old playwright from Mexico, seems destined for success.

title: Don't Punish All Palestinians for Acts of a Few
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Appeals Court Overturns Race-Based School Policy
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned the affirmative-action program at the University of Texas School of Law, paralyzing the university admissions process and possibly opening a broad new front in the battle over racial policies in higher education.

title: Officer Says He Shot in Fear in Subway
description: It was "a moment of fear" of being shot and killed, Officer Peter Del-Debbio testified yesterday, that caused him to empty his revolver at an undercover officer he mistook for a criminal.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Official Leaves Post In Colombia Drug Case
description: The Foreign Minister of Colombia stepped down today to confront charges that he helped President Ernesto Samper win the presidential election with money from the Cali drug cartel.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Renault Profit Off 41%; Car Unit Shows a Loss
description: Renault S.A., France's second-largest car maker, said yesterday that its profit fell 41 percent last year, hurt by a prolonged transport strike and a sluggish economy. Renault, whose biggest shareholder is the French Government, said net income fell to 2.14 billion French francs ($428 million) from 3.64 billion francs a year earlier. The company said its car division had an operating loss of 1.7 billion francs, in contrast to a profit of 289 million francs in 1994.

title: POLITICS: THE STRATEGY;Gingrich and Dole Aides Try New Unified Party Message
description: While Bob Dole is still going through the motions of a Presidential primary campaign, his campaign aides are already mapping out a coordinated, party-wide media strategy for the general election with the help of Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Starting With Columbus and Ending in Outer Space
description: Hearing a new opera is often like seeing a painting for the first time. In both cases, there is an irresistible temptation to look too closely at the details, to demand both subtlety and grand effect, and to instantly put the experience into the context of the broader canon. Usually, though, a work cannot really be seen until one steps back, stops worrying about the brush strokes and sees it with the perspective that distance affords. With a painting, one can have it both ways instantly, but in music perspective is a matter of time rather than space.

title: Fight Over Picking Up Tab For S.&L. Bailout Renewed
description: The savings-and-loan crisis may have passed, but the fight over who picks up the bill rages on.

title: TV Notes;Letterman, With Changes
description: David Letterman returns from vacation tonight with a new executive producer in charge of a show to be taped in the lobby, not on the stage, of the Ed Sullivan theater.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LLOYD'S INVESTORS WIN A NEGLIGENCE LAWSUIT
description: A group of 1,092 investors at Lloyd's of London won the main points yesterday in a negligence case against agents of the insurance market, dealing a blow to efforts by Lloyd's to settle litigation and refinance after five years of losses. The British High Court ruled that the underwriter for the Rose Thomson Young syndicate 255/258 in 1988 and 1989 acted incompetently in assessing and managing the insurance risk on these syndicates and that his incompetence was allowed by the syndicates' managing agents. The victory was the latest in a series of legal victories for Lloyd's investors. The Lloyd's market, suffering from five years of losses and facing lawsuits from 40 percent of its investors, has proposed a settlement of L2.8 billion, or $4.3 billion, and a debt relief package to end the litigation; Lloyd's investors have said that the sum must be increased to sway them from pursuing damages through the courts. Exact damages and an interim payment in yesterday's case are to be determined later.

title: Eating Well
description: DIET and fitness books have a new look: many now come with phone numbers offering products for sale that are supposed to help the dieter lose weight painlessly, whether it's by eating too few carbohydrates or too many, too little protein or too much, too little fat or too much.

title: Cigar Takes Track
description: A day after his 21-hour flight from Florida, Cigar started training today for next week's $4 million Dubai World Cup. The 6-year-old 1995 Horse of the Year spent about 15 minutes on the track with Tim Jones, assistant to trainer Bill Mott.

title: Framers Never Intended Habeas Corpus as We Know It
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review
description: A Comedy About Love And the Love of Money 'The Beggar of Borough Park' Jewish Theater of New York

title: Prosecutor in Bronx, Under Fire, Softens Stance Against Execution
description: Under pressure from politicians to seek the death penalty for the suspects in the killing of a police officer in last week, District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx indicated yesterday that his opposition to capital punishment is not absolute.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Philadelphia Signs Fryar
description: Irving Fryar, a three-time Pro Bowl player and a free-agent wide receiver, agreed today on a three-year contract with the Philadelphia Eagles. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Senate Increases Spending In the Other ('96) Budget
description: As President Clinton unveiled his budget for next year, the Senate today passed a $166 billion spending bill that would cover the remaining six months of the fiscal year 1996 for some of the largest departments and agencies of the Federal Government.

title: Woman Taped Pleas Preceding Her Death
description: In the final minutes of her life, a New Jersey teacher secretly turned on a recorder that taped 24 minutes in which she pleaded in vain with her abductor to spare her life, the authorities said yesterday.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;More Than A Drop Of Integrity
description: IF we needed any further evidence that golf is an oasis of integrity in a sports desert of mendacity, it came this past weekend. Last Saturday morning at the Bay Hill Invitational, Jeff Sluman disqualified himself from the tournament. He believed, but was not entirely sure, that he had violated a rule the day before by taking an improper drop.

title: Wine Talk
description: IN England's days of glory, there was the problem of second sons. What did one do with them after the oldest had inherited the estate? The army and the church were acceptable. Trade, never, unless it was the wine trade.

title: Residents Can Retrieve Items After Collapse
description: It was a long, tense wait, made more uncomfortable by a chilly rain, but residents left homeless by the collapse of a Manhattan apartment building finally had some good news yesterday afternoon: they would be allowed to re-enter the building to retrieve their portable belongings.

title: Journal;Follow The Money
description: Like the evil empire in its last gasp, Big Tobacco, America's foremost purveyor of last gasps, would finally seem to be tumbling down. Last week one cigarette manufacturer, Liggett, ended decades of industry solidarity by electing to settle anti-tobacco lawsuits rather than battle on to Armageddon. The Justice Department, abetted by a growing parade of industry whistleblowers, is in hot pursuit of criminal charges against tobacco executives who swore before Congress that they had no idea nicotine was addictive. Tobacco stocks, meanwhile, head south.

title: UAL in Lead As Airlines Enjoy a Boom
description: The United States airline industry, buoyed by higher fares and strong passenger traffic, is poised to show its first profit since 1979 for the first quarter of a year.

title: A High School Teacher Wins Over Showing R-Rated Movie
description: A judicial hearing officer has ruled that a local school district cannot dismiss a high school English teacher for showing the R-rated Bertolucci film "1900" to his 17- and 18-year-old students.

title: Estrogen Supplements for Women Could Help To Prevent Tooth Loss
description: Estrogen, a proven protector against bone loss, may also help women keep their teeth, a study suggests.

title: Executives From Taiwan Worry, but Stay in China
description: Like many Taiwan businessmen who live and work in this city, Chiang Yu-min likes to relax by leaving his steel factory at the outskirts of town to meet friends for a meal at Taipei City or one of the other hip, upscale restaurants that cater to "tai shang," as Taiwan businessmen are known in mainland China.

title: U.S. Home Computer Market Said to Slow
description: The United States market for home personal computers will see slower growth this year, Dataquest, a technology market research firm, said this week.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.I.T.

title: In Performance;Allan Kozinn
description: In a Rare Recital, Behrens Sings Strauss and Berg Hildegard Behrens, soprano, and Christoph Eschenbach, pianist Carnegie Hall

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Robbery Charges Dropped
description: Armed robbery charges against two Hudson County jail guards were dismissed yesterday after a jury said it was unable to reach a verdict. The guards, Marcus Walker and Theodore Lovely, both of Jersey City, were accused of breaking into a drug dealer's apartment in 1993, tying up the dealer and his girlfriend and stealing a safe containing cash and cocaine, said Edward DeFazio, first assistant prosecutor for Hudson County. While deadlocked on the robbery charges, the jury found the guards guilty of official misconduct for knowing that the man was a drug dealer and not arresting him.

title: Murder' to Close
description: Getting Away With Murder," a comedy-thriller by Stephen Sondheim and George Furth, is to close after the matinee on March 31 at the Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, Manhattan. The matinee of the play, directed by Jack O'Brien and starring John Rubinstein, Terrence Mann and Christine Ebersole, will be its 17th regular performance; it had 31 previews.

title: THE BALKAN PEACE: THE OUTLOOK;Bosnia's Checkerboard Partition: Instability More Likely
description: According to the Dayton peace agreement, the return of Sarajevo's largely Serbian suburbs to Government control was supposed to be an important step toward rebuilding a multi-ethnic country. But this morning, when the Bosnian police entered the last Serbian neighborhood designated to be transferred, their presence seemed instead to seal the lasting partition of Bosnia into three ethnic enclaves.

title: Valujet to Fly Into New York At a Discount
description: Discount airlines are beginning to elbow their way into La Guardia Airport in New York, long a bastion of the business traveler paying top-dollar fares.

title: Pataki Aide's Claim of Secrecy for Inaugural Funds Is Contradicted
description: As part of an effort to block the State Assembly's investigation of Gov. George E. Pataki's inaugural fund, a lawyer for the corporation that raised money for the event told a state court today that the names of the contributors would not be turned over to investigators because the donors had been promised secrecy.

title: Witness in the White House
description: President Clinton, a master at using the electronic media, is on the verge of making a videotaped appearance that could hurt his re-election effort.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Brenly to Join the Fox Network
description: BOB BRENLY, the former Giants catcher, will be a Fox Sports baseball analyst, joining TIM McCARVER and JEFF TORBORG. Brenly had called Cubs games on radio in 1990 and 1991, before rejoining the Giants as a coach. He will resign as the team's first-base coach at the end of spring training and be replaced by JIM DAVENPORT.

title: Naruto Journal;This Way to Peace of Mind: 750 Miles and 88 Stops
description: After 27 years working for a computer company in Tokyo, Michihiro Sakamoto found himself a victim of the quiet corporate cost-cutting that has been hitting Japan's older white-collar workers in this recession. At 52, he was induced to quit his job.

title: 3 Stowaways Found Dead in Ship's Hold
description: A cargo ship from Africa docked in Brooklyn yesterday carrying three dead stowaways -- all young men -- who were apparently poisoned when the crew fumigated the hold they were in to kill any insects in burlap bags of cacao beans, officials said.

title: Walter Sullivan, 78, Dies; Showed Science at Its Most Daring
description: Walter Sullivan, a science reporter and editor for The New York Times whose articles took him from pole to pole and ranged from the seabed to the shifting continents, and from the nuclear to the cosmic, died yesterday at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 78.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WOMEN;UConn Seniors Turn Things Up a Notch
description: For a week, Coach Geno Auriemma had been saying that his Connecticut team had to find a way to score when Kara Wolters, the 6-foot-7-inch all-America center, could not lead the way. One solution was for the other starters, notably Jen Rizzotti and Jamelle Elliott, to elevate their games.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;The Sitcom Recipe, Stirred Slightly
description: Sitcoms, sitcoms, everywhere, and not one to really cheer about. Some of the new ones, though, are reasonably pleasant and generally harmless. And these days, those are qualities not to be casually dismissed.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Receive Good Report On Pulsipher
description: A persistent wind blew throughout the Mets' exhibition game with the Cincinnati Reds today at Thomas J. White Stadium here. Most of it was weather related.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: BASEBALL;Raines, Injured Again, Could Miss Opener
description: Tim Raines lumbered through the clubhouse today with a blue splint on his left thumb and a blue look blanketing his face. Raines chipped a bone in the thumb during a slide into second base while attempting to break up a double play in Monday night's game with St. Louis, and now the Yankees are worried that he might not be ready to start the season.

title: Seinfeld' Is On. Pass the Junior Mints.
description: DR. DANNY CHU, a gastroenterologist who lives in Battery Park City, finds himself consistently eating certain foods during certain television shows. "During 'E.R.,' I eat Popsicles," he said. "The show has a lot of drama and it's so fast moving. Popsicles are cool, so they counteract what's going on."
