title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Rutgers-Camden Gets Rare Victory
description: Three weeks ago, WALTER K. GORDON called the situation "demoralizing" and a "lost cause." After the Rutgers-Camden men's basketball team lost its 108th straight game, the university provost announced that the school would eliminate the program. Yesterday, he changed his mind -- with a little help from his friends -- and reinstated the program.

title: Disco in Manila, for 35 People, Held 400
description: The Ozone Disco Pub in suburban Manila, the site of a fire that killed at least 150 people, had been approved for occupancy by no more than 35 people, officials said today. About 400 people were packed inside when the blaze started.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Until 1967, interracial marriages were illegal in 17 states -- and they might still be if not for RICHARD and MILDRED LOVING. Their love story and legal battle are the subject of "Mr. and Mrs. Loving," a made-for-television movie that had its premiere last night at the Kennedy Center in Washington.

title: Evacuees Go Home
description: Two weeks after they were evacuated, about 600 people were finally allowed to return on Monday to their homes outside a mile-radius of a train derailment site where propane has been leaking. But 1,700 people living within a mile of the wreck had to remain away.

title: POLITICS;Perot Says He'll Run for President if Asked
description: Ross Perot said today that he would run for President again and "give it everything I have" if members of his new Reform Party wanted him as their candidate.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article last Wednesday about American policy toward Taiwan referred imprecisely to the timing of the United States' cancellation of its mutual defense treaty with Taiwan. It occurred in 1979.

title: Personal Health
description: EACH winter more and more American families are plagued by recurrent strep throats that ping-pong among the children and their parents and do not quit until school finishes for the summer. Unlike the common cold, a far more familiar family plague during the school year, strep throat is much more than a pesky illness. It is debilitating, costly and dangerous.

title: I.B.M. Names New Manager Of Its PC Unit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation appointed Samuel J. Palmisano yesterday to lead the company's personal computer unit, a position that had been vacant since September.

title: Democrat Is Disputing President On Lawsuits
description: President Clinton telephoned as many as six senators today, imploring them to vote on Wednesday to defeat a measure that would limit the cash awards available to people who file lawsuits involving dangerous products.

title: Chemical Raises Dividend
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation increased its dividend 12 percent yesterday and will now pay 56 cents a share quarterly.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bayer to Cut 1,500 Jobs
description: The German chemical company Bayer A.G. will cut 1,500 jobs this year as part of its cost-cutting program, the company chairman said yesterday. The planned cuts represent about 1 percent of the worldwide work force. (AP)

title: To Rainbow Cuisine Via Warthog Pate
description: THE Delegates Dining Room at the United Nations is host to a culinary safari this month. Through March 29, chefs representing the South African Chefs Association are preparing menus of specialties like kudu medallions, ostrich pastrami, loin of springbok, warthog pate, Malay pickled fish and malva pudding.

title: H.M.O.'s Insure Access to Transplants
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs;Bangkok Bogs Down
description: They called it "the mother of all traffic jams." The place was Bangkok. The occasion was a four-day national holiday marking the start of the rainy season in Thailand last April. Richard Frankel, an environmental engineer in Bangkok, recalled the scene: "On Wednesday night we figured we would try to beat the traffic and get out of town. We planned to drive to Chiang Mai, 200 miles north, and spend the holiday there. So we packed up the car, fed everyone and took off from the house. Our plan was to drive on the expressway around Bangkok, continue out past the airport and then head north. We left the house at 10 P.M. The kids were asleep in the back seat, everything was perfect -- until we hit the expressway. The traffic was backed up bumper to bumper for 60 miles. By 10 the next morning, we had only reached the airport, just a few miles from our house. Some people abandoned their cars. We finally managed to turn around and spent the holiday at home."

title: Death and Discretion in New York
description: The murder of the New York City police officer Kevin Gillespie and the arrest of three suspects with a history of violent crime have brought front and center the issue of the state's new death penalty law and the limits of prosecutorial discretion.

title: Harvard Journal;A Tradition Is Pounded By Hammers and Nails
description: For Tweed Roosevelt, Class of '64, the Great Hall was Harvard.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;General Elections in India Are Set for April and May
description: India will hold general elections on four days starting in six weeks, election officials said today.

title: THE BALKAN PEACE: THE PROSECUTIONS;A Croat, a Muslim and a Serb Are Held in Balkan War-Crimes Cases
description: Authorities in Germany and Austria announced today that they had detained three men suspected of committing atrocities in the former Yugoslavia including, for the first time, a Bosnian Muslim said to have killed Bosnian Serb civilians.

title: Market Place;Tobacco stocks these days are not for the faint of heart.
description: BATTERED by days of bad news, tobacco stocks have plummeted in an otherwise buoyant bull market, and investors are wondering, hardly for the first time in the turbulent world of tobacco, whether to buy, sell or hold.

title: Frank Wigglesworth, 78, Writer And Performer of New Music
description: Frank Wigglesworth, a composer and teacher whose music was an important part of New York's new-music landscape in the 1950's, died yesterday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Marxist Leads In Benin Vote For President
description: The Marxist former military ruler of Benin appeared headed for a comeback today after the country's second multiparty presidential election, according to partial unofficial results.

title: Washington's Finances 'Are Much Worse,' a Panel Is Told
description: Just hours after students blocked traffic in the latest protest over proposed budget cuts in the District of Columbia, the chairman of the District's financial control board told a House subcommittee that the city's finances "are much worse" now than they were a year ago when the board was appointed by President Clinton.

title: South African Judge Gives Nelson Mandela a Divorce
description: Saying he could see no likelihood that President Nelson Mandela and his wife, Winnie, would ever be reconciled, a judge here granted Mr. Mandela's petition for a divorce today, ending a 38-year marriage that endured the persecution of apartheid only to founder after he was released from prison.

title: TV Notes;Look Who's Talking
description: With several morning talk-show hosts taking time off this week, some eye-catching substitutes were announced. It was not so surprising, perhaps, that Edie Magnus, a CBS News reporter, would fill in for Paula Zahn on "CBS This Morning," with Harry Smith, or that ABC's Barbara Walters would sub for Charles Gibson on "Good Morning America," which she did Monday and Tuesday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Cincinnati Voters Approve Tax
description: Cincinnati voters approved a half-cent sales tax increase yesterday to pay for two new stadiums in a $544 million project, but the battle to keep the Bengals and Reds in town is only half over.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Bank Profit Up
description: Credit Commercial de France, France's third-largest private retail bank, said yesterday that its profit rose 2.3 percent in 1995 because it reduced provisions on bad loans and improved risk management. Net income was 1.23 billion French francs ($246 million), compared with 1.20 billion francs in 1994. But gross operating profit fell 3.8 percent, to 2.51 billion francs. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAGNA BUYS MARLEY'S EUROPEAN AUTO PARTS OPERATIONS
description: Magna International Inc., a Canadian maker of automotive parts, said yesterday that it had acquired Marley P.L.C.'s European auto parts operations for about $73.6 million. The Marley Automotive Components Group makes instrument panels, door trim panels and other interior and exterior parts. The group, which has annual sales of about $202 million, owns six factories and has a stake in another. Magna, which is based in Markham, Ontario, said the acquisition would increase its annual sales in Europe to about $294.4 million. Marley is based in Kent, England.

title: Joining a School Board to Change ItCorrections
description: Edith Colon was born and raised in the South Bronx, attended its public schools and now has a daughter in seventh grade at Intermediate School 147. For years, she said, she has watched her neighborhood schools deteriorate and test scores plummet, and now she is mad.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Miller's Options May Lead to Garden
description: The Knicks need Reggie Miller more than Miller needs the Knicks.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EFFORT TO SELL AIDS PATIENTS' POLICIES IS BLOCKED AGAIN
description: A Federal judge has blocked an effort by Life Partners Inc. to resume sales to investors of bundled life-insurance policies taken out by people with AIDS. The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had obtained a new Federal court order after the company said it had revised its procedures to comply with an earlier order sought by the S.E.C. that blocked such sales. The company buys insurance policies from people with AIDS as "viatical settlements," combines them and resells them to investors. Last year the commission sued Life Partners, which is based in Waco, Tex., contending that the company was selling unregistered securities, had failed to register as a securities broker and was misleading investors. The judge, Royce C. Lamberth, said that the changes made by Life Partners were "artificial and technical." Life Partners has appealed the earlier orders.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Federal appeals court decision barring race as a factor in admissions at the University of Texas School of Law misstated the vote of one judge in some editions. Judge Harold R. DeMoss concurred in Judge Jerry E. Smith's decision; he did not dissent. Judge Jacques L. Wiener Jr. wrote a separate concurring opinion.

title: Einstein Manuscript Donated to Museum
description: The earliest surviving manuscript in which Albert Einstein laid out his theory of relativity, which did not find a buyer at an auction earlier this month, has been sold and will be donated to an Israeli museum, Sotheby's auction house said yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;KLM Merger Speculation
description: Shares in KLM Royal Dutch Airlines were up more than 3 percent yesterday in a falling market, as renewed merger speculation fueled interest in the stock. The shares were up 2 guilders at 59 on the Amsterdam stock exchange. Analysts attributed some of the rise to renewed talk by British Airways that it did not exclude European expansion. Analysts have long cited British Airways and KLM as compatible partners, though both have repeatedly denied that they are in talks. (Reuters)

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Make Minor Deal
description: The Islanders only made a minor deal yesterday on the trade deadline, swapping veteran checking centers with the Calgary Flames, and also picking up a draft pick.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Jamming on an Exuberant Spirit's Repertory of Joy
description: During his seven decades in jazz, Lionel Hampton has always made his music guarantee a good time. The musician who established the vibraphone in jazz with shimmering harmony and hard-swinging riffs, and who maintained his big band as a generator of uncomplicated joy, has lavished his musical expertise on entertainment. "Swing Into Spring: A Harlem Tribute to Lionel Hampton," on Tuesday night at the Apollo Theater, caught that exuberant spirit in an all-star concert.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Rate-Cut Hope Dims After Money Data
description: Germany's money supply grew at an annual rate of 12.6 percent in the first two months of the year, the Bundesbank said yesterday, reducing the chances for an interest-rate cut. Although Bundesbank officials had warned that money supply growth would be higher than in January, few expected such a sharp jump. Most had been expecting about 8.4 percent.

title: Of 'Old' and Euphemisms
description: To The Home Section:

title: Essay;The Nader Factor
description: Say what you like about Ralph Nader, he is an American authentic: iconoclastic, fearless, media-savvy, often wrongheaded, but -- as the man responsible for safety devices like air bags -- a public citizen who has saved thousands of lives.

title: Currents;A Mine Of Design
description: TO William Yeoward, a young award-winning English designer of home furnishings, "the best 18th-century designs look as simple, perfect and clean as anything modern."

title: Guns For Peace
description: The Dayton peace agreement ended the war in Bosnia, but it is only a small first step in securing a durable peace in the region. Economic redevelopment, the return of refugees and free and fair elections in Bosnia, combined with a movement in the region toward respect for law, are all critical to success. A new Pentagon report warns that more international aid must be forthcoming to speed rebuilding of the country and to lay the groundwork for economic and political stability. But equally important, the international community should support the United States in its pledge to provide the Bosnians with equipment and training to correct the military imbalances in the region.

title: Bank Official Saw Apparent Loan Fraud
description: A scheme that defrauded eight prominent international financial institutions out of hundreds of millions of dollars for more than two years might have continued but for the efforts of an executive at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, according to an affidavit submitted by an F.B.I. agent in charge of the case.

title: Celebrating Morton Gould With His Music
description: Correction Appended

title: Sports of The Times;There's Another Hue Of Bulls' Hair Dennis
description: DENNIS RODMAN complained that the penalty he received the other day for head-butting a referee was "too severe." The fine plus a six-game suspension added up to $203,000 and some change. Quite a whack, to be sure, especially with the price of hair dye going up as it is.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Posts Modest Advances Amid Uncertainty on Germany
description: The dollar was little changed against the mark and other major currencies yesterday because of conflicting signals over another cut in German interest rates.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Quality Bakers of America, Greenwich, Conn., to DeWitt Media, New York, for media planning and buying for the Sunbeam brand of baked goods, previously handled by Vitt Media International, New York. The creative part of the account, with billings estimated at $1 million to $2 million, continues in-house.

title: Giving Los Angeles an Airport Tower to Write Home About
description: IT'S a departure," Daniel Olivas, a project manager for the Federal Aviation Administration in Los Angeles, was saying the other day. He was not talking about one of the 1,100-or-so airplanes taking off daily from Los Angeles International Airport, but about the city's arresting, controversial $19 million air-traffic control tower, which will be officially dedicated tomorrow.

title: Internet Trading of a Stock Is Suspended
description: Amid questions from regulators, a small New York brewer said today that it was suspending an innovative trading system that allows its stockholders to buy and sell the company's shares on the Internet.

title: A Teacher Who Reached Out
description: In the end, Kathleen Weinstein died doing what she did best: continually trying to reach someone no matter how hard the task.

title: INSIDE
description: Prosecutor Defies Pataki

title: Let Brooklyn Port Welcome the Bigger Ships
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: CALIFORNIA;Dole on Verge of Victory, But Autumn Is Uncertain
description: For the first time in more than three frustrating decades, California Republicans are poised to play a decisive role in choosing a Presidential nominee. More or less.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NICOLAS CAGE and SUSAN SARANDON have won a new Oscar straw poll operated by Moviefone, Mr. Cage as best actor for "Leaving Las Vegas" and Ms. Sarandon as best actress for "Dead Man Walking." MEL GIBSON won as best director for "Braveheart," which also won as best picture.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACME-CLEVELAND REJECTS OFFER FROM DANAHER
description: The Acme-Cleveland Corporation, a maker of industrial tools, telecommunications equipment and other products, rejected the Danaher Corporation's unsolicited $173 million takeover bid yesterday and said that it would explore alternatives to it. Danaher, a maker of tools, industrial components and environmental control products that is based in Washington, made a tender offer of $27 a share early this month for all of Acme-Cleveland's outstanding common and preferred shares. Acme-Cleveland said the alternatives could include a merger, a purchase or sale of assets, the acquisition of securities, or changes in its capitalization or dividend policy. The shares of Acme-Cleveland, which is based in Cleveland, rose 50 cents yesterday, to $30.875.

title: Currents;When a School Gets A Mother's Help
description: SOME parents organize class camping trips or coach baseball. The architect Kathryn McGraw Berry, whose twins, Sam and Nicholas, are fourth graders at the Grace Church School, at 10th Street and Fourth Avenue, redesigned an art studio, left and above.

title: Currents;Freshening Up Laura Ashley
description: TOM FORD'S Gucci overhaul got headlines, but Basha Cohen, the new design director of Laura Ashley Home, is also performing a make over. The new look, young, fresh, bright -- in a word, undowdy -- is all over its 1996 catalogue. Whoever thought chartreuse and acid green would be Laura Ashley colors? Refreshing after cottage patterns are pillows embroidered with white daisies, left ($45). The catalogue is available for $4.95 from (800) 367-2000).

title: Journalists Aren't the Only Risky C.I.A. Cover
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties;Anything vs. Whatever
description: It is Wednesday, Sept. 25, 1996, the night of the first Taco Bell Presidential Debate. The candidates are at their podiums on stage at Washington University in St. Louis. The moderator, Ricki Lake, shakes hands with President Clinton and Bob Dole and gets the show rolling.

title: Run-Up in Oil Price Halts; April Contract Falls $1.28
description: Oil prices touched their highest levels in more than five years yesterday before falling sharply. Most analysts and traders said they expected that the recent surge in prices would end with spring's arrival, after one of the harshest winters on record.

title: Not Just a Weed Anymore
description: ONE of the world's oldest and most abundant resources is finally getting some respect. New technology is attempting to make a hero of bamboo, as an alternative to dwindling hardwoods.

title: A Chemical Bank Ex-Trader Arrested
description: A former trader for Chemical Bank, Victor Gomez, was arrested in London today on fraud charges related to $70 million in trading losses at the bank, Scotland Yard said. He faces the possibility of extradition to the United States.

title: Joining a School Board to Change ItCorrections
description: Edith Colon was born and raised in the South Bronx, attended its public schools and now has a daughter in seventh grade at Intermediate School 147. For years, she said, she has watched her neighborhood schools deteriorate and test scores plummet, and now she is mad.

title: Shuttle Launching Delay
description: The launching of the space shuttle Atlantis was postponed today for 24 hours because of stiff winds expected at the launch time.

title: On Writing English
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TITAN WHEEL MAKES OFFER FOR TROUBLED STEEL CONCERN
description: Titan Wheel International Inc. has offered to buy the McLouth Steel Products Corporation for $80 million. Morry Taylor, Titan's president and chief executive -- who withdrew recently from the race for the Republican Presidential nomination -- said yesterday that the bid was conditioned on replacing the managers of McLouth, a financially troubled, employee-owned steelmaker, with those of Titan. Also, the 1,250 hourly workers at McLouth who are represented by the United Steelworkers of America would have to reapply for their jobs. John Stoker, McLouth's chief financial officer, confirmed that an offer had been received. McLouth, which was founded in 1934 and which has been owned by its employees since 1988, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Sept. 29. McLouth employees own 87 percent of the company, which is based in Trenton, Mich. The stock of Titan, which is based in Quincy, Ill., was up $1, at $17.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HIGH COURT RULES RESULTS ARE VALID IN CENSUS OF 1990
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the validity of the 1990 census, ruling unanimously that the Federal Government had no constitutional obligation to adjust the results to correct an acknowledged undercount in big cities and among minorities.

title: In Detroit, Past Takes A Called Third Strike
description: Detroiters voted on Tuesday to use some of their taxes to build a ball park, leaving Detroit Tigers fans fearing that America's oldest baseball stadium -- and their childhood memories -- will be bulldozed.

title: Metro Matters;Looking Back At a Conflict On Gay Rights
description: THE time was 10 years ago, and New York City was in a hot, angry fever. People shouted and argued and prayed at City Hall. Lawmakers bickered and wept. Rabbis cited the Talmud, priests quoted from the Bible, Joseph Papp invoked Michelangelo, and Mayor Edward I. Koch -- sounding like an upside-down Chicken Little -- intoned: "The sky is not going to fall, the sky is not going to fall."

title: U.S., Waiving Ban, Will Send Arms to Pakistan
description: The Administration is to deliver $368 million worth of military hardware to Pakistan, overriding its own concerns that Pakistan's leaders are building nuclear weapons, members of Congress said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;Messier May Face Suspension
description: Mark Messier, the Ranger captain and leading goal scorer with 43, could be suspended for an incident during Tuesday night's game in which he hit Edmonton's Dave Roberts in the face with his stick.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. Approves Request By Taiwan to Buy Arms
description: The Administration approved Taiwan's request to buy Stinger air defense missiles and other weapons, a move officials said reflected a longstanding United States commitment to help Taiwan defend itself.

title: House Approves Ending Schooling of Illegal Aliens
description: After a testy partisan debate, the House today overwhelmingly approved a measure that would allow states to deny public education to illegal immigrant children.

title: Menendez Brothers Guilty Of Killing Their Parents
description: Erik and Lyle Menendez were convicted today of murdering their wealthy parents by shotgun blasts as they watched television in their Beverly Hills mansion in 1989.

title: It's Time for Openness in Adoption Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Events: Walking Tours For a Fine Spring Day
description: Spring 1996 is a day old, and there are walking tours to enjoy, while learning about history, architecture and New York folklore. Most of the groups listed in the following sampling offer walks regularly and will send a schedule on request.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Hockey

title: OLYMPICS;Nagano Backs Off on Olympic Promises
description: When the city of Nagano in central Japan was competing against Salt Lake City to win the right to be host for the 1998 Winter Olympics, it made a rash campaign promise.

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTY;G.O.P., Haunted by Perot, Hopes He Doesn't Mean It
description: Even as the specter of a resurgent Ross Perot is haunting Senator Bob Dole's ambitions for the White House, Republican officials said today that there was little they could do but hope that either Mr. Perot would not run as a third-party candidate or would not catch on with voters as he did in 1992.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Bermuda's new campaign tries to shed the resort's staid image.
description: BERMUDA will switch off its award-winning "Bermuda shorts" campaign today in favor of a kickier campaign designed to shed its staid image and attract younger, first-time visitors.

title: A Program to Revive Harlem
description: Harlem was once the center of life for the African-American middle class and a Mecca for artists, writers and musicians. But during the 1960's, middle-class flight and business closings left the district one of the most depressed in New York City. The city-funded effort that resurrected the South Bronx somehow passed Harlem by. Even so, recent years have seen a slow but steady influx of middle-class homeowners, drawn by affordable real estate and Harlem's proximity to both midtown and the suburbs.

title: A Treatment For a Cancer Risks Another
description: Girls who survive Hodgkin's disease face an exceptionally high risk of breast cancer later in life, a study has found.

title: Bridge
description: The beginner learns that if game is to be attempted it should be in no-trump unless an eight-card major fit is available. The intermediate player discovers that a weakness in one suit may indicate the need to play a minor-suit game, or a major-suit game with a seven-card fit.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Unilever Unit Picks Ammirati Puris
description: The Van den Bergh Foods Company unit of Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products giant, said yesterday that it had selected Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York to handle the account of its Ragu line of pasta sauces, which had been handled by J. Walter Thompson New York for the last eight years. Though the billings in recent years have ranged from $15 million to $20 million, they may be increased to $25 million to $30 million.

title: Nynex Proposes Cutting Board's Benefits
description: The board of the Nynex Corporation has proposed eliminating pensions for outside directors as of Aug. 1.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Product Liability Bill Clears Hurdle, Heads for Passage The Senate took an important step toward limiting damages available to people who were are hurt by faulty products. By a vote of 60 to 40, the minimum necessary, the Senate cut off debate on the bill. A dozen Democrats voted with the majority, in a repudiation of President Clinton, who has promised a veto.

title: Economic Scene;Private capital is king in the new order of world investment.
description: LOOKING for hard evidence that the world economy is becoming more seamless? Look no farther than the World Bank's report, released last week, on capital flows from rich countries to poor. In 1990, net flows were just over $100 billion, with less than half the money coming from private investors. Last year the number reached $230 billion, with 70 percent private.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Judge Rules Clinton Testimony Will Be Videotaped for Trial
description: A Federal judge in Arkansas ruled today that President Clinton would not have to travel to the state to testify at the Whitewater-related trial in Little Rock and could instead have his testimony videotaped in Washington and then played for the jury.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Jerry I. Reitman was named president and chief executive of International Data Response Corp., Chicago, which is being formed by a merger of S & P Data, Toronto, and Promark One, Phoenix. He was most recently executive vice president and director for integrated communications worldwide at the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago.

title: PATAKI IS SEEKING TO END REGULATION OF HOSPITAL RATES
description: Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a broad plan today intended to lower health care costs by lifting most of the rules that control the fees charged by hospitals.

title: Surprise Discovery in Blood: Hemoglobin Has Bigger Role
description: With almost the surprise that might greet discovery of a new bone in the human body, scientists have detected a major new task performed by hemoglobin, the blood's red pigment and transporter of gases.

title: Backers of Limits on Lawsuits Win a Victory in the Senate
description: After an intense legislative battle that had a strong whiff of Presidential politics, the Senate today voted to move ahead with a measure that would limit damages available to people who are hurt by faulty products.

title: Israeli Blockade Takes Toll In West Bank and Gaza
description: By about 5 this afternoon, after weeks of waiting, it looked as if Fatima Abu Jarad, a 4-year-old girl with leukemia, might finally get out of the Gaza Strip to an Israeli hospital for treatment.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Winnie Mandela Says She May Appeal Divorce
description: A day after a judge granted President Nelson Mandela a divorce, his ex-wife, Winnie Mandela, said today that she was considering an appeal to South Africa's highest court.

title: Russian Diplomacy Gets a Wily Spy and Survivor
description: A month after American-led forces defeated Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, Yevgeny M. Primakov, then a top adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, published a dashing account of his last-ditch efforts to broker a face-saving solution for Saddam Hussein in February 1991 and prevent the ground war.

title: The Pop Life
description: Grammy Tiffs

title: Moderate Rise in Retail Sales Seen as More Evidence of Growth
description: American shoppers pushed $201.1 billion across retail counters in February, a moderate eight-tenths of 1 percent monthly rise that economists called further evidence that the economy was expanding somewhat faster after skirting recession for much of the winter.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;March Wheat Contract Soars As Company Is Caught Short
description: The crosscurrents of short wheat supplies and futures speculation collided in spectacular fashion at the Chicago Board of Trade today as the expiring March wheat contract jumped more than $1 a bushel higher than the previous record set in 1974.

title: 48 Hours' Changes Format To More Than One Topic
description: Changes in the format of CBS's Thursday night news program "48 Hours" were announced yesterday. Although there was no announcement of personnel changes, speculation circulated within CBS News that Paula Zahn, a co-host of "CBS This Morning," would become a "48 Hours" correspondent when the network's low-rated morning news show is revamped later this spring.

title: It's Time for Openness in Adoption Records;No More Lies
description: To the Editor:

title: Monsanto Receives Gene Patent; Files Lawsuit Against 2 Rivals
description: Bolstering its claim to be the leader in agricultural biotechnology, the Monsanto Company said today that it had received a patent covering the synthetic genes that it and other companies have been inserting in plants to get them to produce their own insecticide.

title: U.N. Members Slow to Send Bosnia Police
description: Three months after it began sending international civilian police monitors and trainers to Bosnia, the United Nations has been able to field fewer than half the 1,721 officers it was asked to recruit because member countries are either not meeting their pledges or are sending unqualified candidates.

title: Stocks Again Off as Dow Falls 14.09
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday for the second straight session, led by a slump in technology issues.

title: The Anti-Consumer Act of 1996
description: The Senate is preparing to vote today on a pernicious piece of anti-consumer legislation masquerading as product liability "reform." The measure is little more than a bipartisan gift to manufacturers and trade associations that supplemented their lobbying and generous campaign contributions with misleading propaganda exaggerating the problem of high verdicts. The bill would arbitrarily cap the punitive damages that juries may award -- dangerously weakening the ability of the civil justice system to punish, and thereby deter, the reckless manufacture or sale of unsafe products.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;At Wake, Senior Balances Priorities
description: A typical day for Rusty LaRue does not begin like it does for his Wake Forest teammates. LaRue baby-sits from 7:30 until 11:30 A.M. before he goes to classes and labs and basketball practice. His son, Riley, is not quite 2 months old, so, of course, he does not yet call him daddy. LaRue's teammates do.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAXTER TO DISTRIBUTE DEVICE USED IN BYPASS SURGERY
description: The Baxter Healthcare Corporation has agreed to distribute exclusively a synthetic coronary artery graft made by Possis Medical Inc., Possis said yesterday. The shares of Possis, a maker of cardiovascular surgery products that is based in Minneapolis, rose $1.75, or 12 percent, to close at $16.25 yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Baxter Healthcare, a unit of Baxter International Inc., will make an initial cash payment to Possis, followed by further cash payments in the next three years to help pay for clinical trials. The amount of the payments was not disclosed. Possis said the device, called Perma-Flow Coronary Bypass Graft, was a synthetic tube used to bypass a blocked coronary artery during heart bypass surgery. Baxter Healthcare and Baxter International are based in Deerfield, Ill.

title: BASEBALL;Revenue Plan on the Agenda
description: Club owners are expected to approve a revenue-sharing plan on Thursday under which 13 high-revenue clubs will give money to 13 low-revenue clubs. In its final form, the plan will likely cost the contributing clubs less than that proposed under a plan that has been debated in recent weeks.

title: Money Is Channeled to Hamas By Way of a 'Shocked' Jordan
description: There are no Hamas offices in Jordan," Information Minister Marwan Muasher declared firmly. "Hamas simply does not exist here."

title: Trial by Fire for Bronx Prosecutor
description: The yawning maw of Yankee Stadium opens wide right outside the window of the sixth-floor offices of the Bronx District Attorney, Robert Thomas Johnson. In season, he can't avoid the roars, boos and hisses of thousands of fans just a block and a skip away.

title: Hamas and Bombings
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Opera Buys a Home Site
description: The Washington Opera announced tonight that it had purchased a landmark department store in downtown Washington for its future home. The opera, which has been in the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts for the last 25 years, paid $18 million for the building, which formerly housed the bankrupt Woodward & Lothrop department store.

title: SPORTS BUSINESS;N.B.A. Sues to Keep Scores in Its Court
description: Is a 28-20 Knicks lead over the Bulls a fact that exists in the public domain or a right controllable by the National Basketball Association? How tightly can the league restrict use of the information that Michael Jordan scored 28 points by game's end?

title: It's Time for Openness in Adoption Records;The Need to Know
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Anthony Gets Suspension
description: Vancouver's GREG ANTHONY was suspended for one game and fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for throwing a punch at New Jersey's SHAWN BRADLEY during a game. Anthony sat out last night's game at Atlanta.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;New Life For Pieces Of the Past
description: When the CD appeared, a decade and a half ago, everyone feared for the future of the past. How long, in the flurry of the here and now, would it take the new medium to to reissue all those aged treasures that had long and painfully accumulated on LP?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;A's to Open in Las Vegas
description: The Oakland Athletics, faced with a construction project at their stadium, will play their first six games of the regular season in Las Vegas, Nev., at the minor league Cashman Field, which seats 9,334, General Manager SANDY ALDERSON said yesterday in Phoenix. The Athletics will play the Toronto Blue Jays on April 1 and 3 and the Detroit Tigers April 4 through 7 before going on the road for eight games. They will play their true home opener in Oakland against the Chicago White Sox on April 19.

title: Clinton Meets With G.O.P.To Discuss Legislative Aims
description: In their first meeting since the Republican Presidential primaries began last month, President Clinton and his probable Republican rival this fall , Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, joined with other Congressional leaders today to map out legislative priorities.

title: Fiction Award Choices
description: The nominees for the 1996 PEN/ Faulkner Award for Fiction, a national award for American writers, were announced this week by the PEN/Faulkner Foundation, which administers the award. The five nominees are Madison Smartt Bell, for "All Souls' Rising"; Richard Ford, for "Independence Day"; William H. Gass, for "The Tunnel"; Claire Messud, for "When the World Was Steady," and A. J. Verdelle, for "The Good Negress." The winner of the award, to be announced in April, will receive $15,000, and the other nominess will each receive $5,000.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;South Korea Growth 9%
description: South Korea's gross domestic product grew 9 percent in 1995, helped by brisk exports and capital investments, the central bank said yesterday. The performance was the strongest since an increase of 9.1 percent in 1991, the Bank of Korea said. Exports of goods and services increased 24.1 percent. Exports of merchandise alone grew 25.3 percent with increased shipments of autos, semiconductors and machinery. Capital investment increased 15.9 percent. (AP)

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Surging Knicks Get to Bump Chests Like Old Days
description: A wild sequence late in last night's game revealed the fortunes of the Knicks and Pacers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;49ers Cover Bases By Signing Vardell
description: The San Francisco 49ers bought some insurance at running back yesterday, signing the former Stanford hero (TOUCHDOWN) TOMMY VARDELL to a two-year contract.

title: Investment by Netscape
description: Netscape Communications, maker of popular Internet-access software, has bought a stake in Voxware Inc., a developer of voice-processing software, Voxware said today. Terms of the investment were not disclosed.

title: BASEBALL;Rain Affects Perez's Outing
description: It was not raining and the tarpaulin was never placed on the field, but tonight's game between the Yankees and White Sox ended after Melido Perez secured the third out in the top of the sixth inning of Chicago's rain-shortened 3-2 victory. The Yankees explained the situation as "concern for the safety of the players."

title: Officers Said to Be Unhappy, Stressed-Out Scapegoats : A French Police Mystery:Suicides
description: PARIS  When constabulary's duty's to be done in France these days, the policeman's lot is not a happy one.

title: John Engler, Welfare Maverick
description: Gov. John Engler of Michigan is running hard to become Bob Dole's running mate, largely on his record of driving down welfare rolls. Mr. Engler's policies deserve credit, though a robust state economy did much of the work. But the intriguing part of this story is that the best parts of his welfare policy might make Mr. Dole mightily uncomfortable. They mirror President Clinton's welfare bill, which Mr. Dole and his Republican colleagues ridiculed out of existence.

title: Vote on Lawsuits Near
description: The Senate voted yesterday to move ahead with a measure that would limit damages available to people who are hurt by faulty products. The measure faces a promised veto by President Clinton.

title: U.S. Catholic Bishops Open Drive Against Doctor-Assisted Suicide
description: Opening a campaign against doctor-assisted suicide that could be as extensive as the one they have mounted against abortion, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops expressed alarm on Tuesday at a recent Federal court decision declaring that the terminally ill have a constitutional right to a doctor's help in ending their lives.

title: Chrysler Is Offering New Sales Incentives
description: The Chrysler Corporation began a new consumer incentive program this week, offering cash rebates of up to $4,000 or low-interest loans to buyers of select 1995 and 1996 models.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the funeral of Police Officer Kevin Gillespie misspelled part of the name of the Seaford, L.I., church where it took place. It is St. William the Abbot Catholic Church, not St. William the Abbott.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MANPOWER INC., Milwaukee, agreed to acquire Teamwork Sverige A.B., an employment service concern in Sweden, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUN COMMUNITIES TO BUY MANUFACTURED HOUSING GROUPS
description: Sun Communities Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 25 manufactured housing communities, mostly in Michigan and Florida, from Aspen Enterprises Ltd. for $226 million. Sun Communities, a real estate investment trust based in Farmington Hills, Mich., plans to raise funds for the transaction by issuing common stock, debt and partnership stakes. The funds will also be used to retire $64 million of debt and to convert the company's secured line of credit to an unsecured facility. Sun Communities stock was unchanged yesterday at $26.625, but the deal was announced after the close of trading.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Pipelines Hit Despite Law
description: After a natural-gas pipeline explosion in Edison two years ago forced more than 1,500 people to flee their homes, a law was enacted to require utility companies to mark the location of their pipes and to make contractors call a state-run telephone number before they dig.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about chemicals that mimic natural hormones misstated an affiliation of Dr. Bruce Ames of the University of California. He is a member of the Commission on Life Sciences of the National Academy of Sciences, which oversaw a recent report on pesticide residues in food; he was not a member of the panel that prepared the report.

title: COMPANY NEWS;$87 MILLION DEAL IS SET FOR TODAY'S BANCORP
description: Mercantile Bancorporation Inc., a bank holding company in St. Louis, said yesterday that it would acquire Today's Bancorp Inc. of Freeport, Ill., for $87.3 million in stock and cash. Today's Bancorp has about $518 million in assets and operates two banks, with 12 offices, in northwestern Illinois. Mercantile has assets of $18 billion and is based in St. Louis. It operates banks in Missouri, Iowa, Kansas, Illinois and Arkansas and provides brokerage services, asset-based lending, investment advisory services and credit life insurance. The shares of Today's Bancorp were up $2.875, at $29.625, in Nasdaq trading. Mercantile's stock was up 25 cents, at $45.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hewlett-Packard Narrows Review
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company has narrowed to 9 agencies from 24 a review of its account for computer peripherals like printers and scanners sold in the United States. The account, with billings estimated at $40 million to $45 million, has been handled for the last eight years by the San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNSPECIFIED AMOUNT OF STOCK TO BE BOUGHT BACK
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy back stock, but it did not specify an amount. The board of BellSouth, the regional phone company based in Atlanta, was leaving the amount to the discretion of management, said Al Schweitzer, a BellSouth spokesman. The company said it would buy back the shares on the open market. BellSouth has more than 994 million shares outstanding, and they closed at $39 yesterday, up 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: THEATER REVIEW;So Chipper, So Smiley, So Upbeat, but Why?
description: Should Willy Loman rise from his lonely grave in the next few weeks and visit the Circle Repertory Theater, he would surely recognize the character being played there by Frank Whaley.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the last gubernatorial election, the women's vote was very slim, and the way for women to participate in government is not just by studying government but by becoming actively involved, registering voters, working with candidates and running for office," ELINOR C. GUGGENHEIMER, 83, said yesterday.

title: Role of Openly Gay Episcopalians Causes a Rift in the Church
description: The son of a Presbyterian minister, Stephen P. Woodfin spent much of his life looking for a spiritual home where he would be welcome as a homosexual. Last year, he joined an Episcopal parish here and began the steps that will lead to his confirmation as a church member next month at the age of 46.

title: HOCKEY;Struggling Rangers Feel the Burn at Extra Practice
description: Normally, the Rangers would have had today off. But Tuesday night's defeat wasn't a normal defeat and the current slump isn't a normal slump.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Investigating Cancer Rates
description: Federal health officials and New Jersey lawmakers tentatively agreed yesterday to conduct two investigations into the causes of higher-than-usual cancer rates of children in Ocean County.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Of Homoerotic Elements in Mann's Work and Life
description: THOMAS MANN Eros and Literature By Anthony Heilbut Illustrated. 636 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $40.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Retail Sales Figures Send Treasuries Up
description: Treasury prices rose yesterday after a report on retail sales was weaker than expected.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOLLYWOOD PARK TO BUY BOOMTOWN, A CASINO CONCERN
description: Hollywood Park Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Boomtown Inc., a casino and riverboat owner based in Verdi, Nev., for $56.2 million in stock. Hollywood Park, an owner of greyhound and thoroughbred race tracks that is based in Inglewood, Calif., said it would exchange each share of Boomtown common stock for 0.625 share of Hollywood Park stock. Based on the closing price of Hollywood Park shares on Tuesday, the agreement values Boomtown's 9.23 million shares at $6.09 each. The shares of Boomtown dropped 50 cents yesterday, to $6.25. Hollywood Park stock rose 75 cents, to $10.125. The purchase will add Boomtown's four casinos to the four race tracks and one casino that Hollywood Park owns.

title: Ranchers Descend on Capitol to Gain U.S. Grazing Land
description: A few hundred extra pairs of cowboy boots are moseying around Capitol Hill this week, on the feet of ranchers who came East to lobby for passage of a grazing bill that would loosen restrictions on hundreds of millions of acres of federally owned ranch land.

title: Pope Says Church Is Not to Blame in Rwanda
description: Pope John Paul II said in a letter released today that the Roman Catholic Church could not be held responsible for the misdeeds of individual members during the genocide in Rwanda two years ago.

title: Wounded Officer's Account Is Disputed
description: A forensic expert testifying for the defense said yesterday that Officer Desmond Robinson had not been lying on a subway platform when he was shot four times in the back by a fellow officer who had mistaken him for a criminal.

title: VISITING DEATH ROW WITH: Sister Helen Prejean;Making Executions Personal
description: THE young man Sister Helen Prejean has come to visit this pre-spring morning has just learned the State of Louisiana has set a date to kill him.

title: POLITICS: THE BATTLE FOR CONGRESS;Illinois G.O.P. Picks Conservative for Senate Race
description: Seeking to take over the seat of Senator Paul Simon, a Democrat who is retiring this year, Illinois Republicans ignored the wishes of their party's leaders on Tuesday and chose State Representative Al Salvi to represent them on the November ballot.

title: Subway Graffiti Creeping Back To Haunt Riders;A Threatening Symbol Of the Bad Old Days
description: The plague of graffiti, once the international symbol of the subway system's and New York City's financial and spiritual collapse, is beginning to make a comeback on trains and in stations, a decade after a hard-fought campaign virtually eliminated it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CENTURA PLANS TO ACQUIRE BANK IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Centura Banks Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire First Community Bank, based in Gastonia, N.C., for about $28.7 million in stock. First Community has assets of $121 million and five branches. Centura, which is based in Rocky Mount, N.C., has assets of $5.5 billion and 153 offices. Centura's stock slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $34.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: House Panel O.K.'s Bill Assuring Health Care in Job Switches
description: In a unanimous vote, the House Commerce Committee today approved a bill intended to guarantee health insurance coverage for millions of Americans who switch jobs or lose jobs each year.

title: Sports of The Times;Hope, Faith To Determine Cup Chances
description: WITH the Stanley Cup playoffs only four weeks away, the Rangers are posing questions while the Devils are answering them.

title: Massacre in Croatia Described in Court
description: Prosecutors at a hearing of the international war crimes tribunal explained in detail today what they called the first episode of "ethnic cleansing" in the Balkan war, a 1991 "orgy of beatings" in Vukovar, Croatia, that left 261 Croats dead.

title: Insider-Trading Case Settled by Payment
description: A former Maryland Port Administration official has agreed to pay about $62,000 to settle insider-trading charges involving the takeover plans of a Baltimore bank, regulators said today.

title: Edwyn Silberling, 71, New York Prosecutor
description: Edwyn Silberling, a New York prosecutor in the 1950's who became a top organized-crime fighter in the Kennedy Administration, died on Tuesday at Huntington Hospital on Long Island. A Huntington resident, he was 71.

title: Universities Troubled by Decision Limiting Admission Preferences
description: A Federal appeals court decision that sharply limits the use of affirmative action at the University of Texas has shaken the nation's colleges and universities by threatening to dismantle admissions policies that give preferences to minorities.

title: Currents;Carving Gemstones Into Art Objects
description: WHEN Andreas von Zadora-Gerlof was a teen-ager living with his family in a fishing lodge in the Queen Charlotte Islands in the Canadian Pacific Northwest, his right hand was paralyzed in a hunting accident. His therapy included carving with a totem-pole master of the Haida Indian tribe. As the hand healed, an unusual career was born -- to the consternation of his family, who came from a long line of Swedish and Baltic soldier-barons.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK;Paradise Returns (With Heliport)
description: WHEN Louis Bacon bought Robins Island about two years ago, he didn't know he was protecting the endangered Eastern mud turtle. Nobody knew that a pond there, never sprayed for mosquitoes, was a safe home to the healthiest turtle population in the state.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Irvin Under Investigation
description: Dallas Cowboys wide receiver MICHAEL IRVIN remains under investigation after being in a motel room where a woman was arrested on drug charges, a prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Officials Dispute Federal Findings on Subway Safety
description: Transit officials took issue yesterday with a harsh assessment by Federal investigators that faulted top management for a subway crash in Brooklyn last year and said that while the system is generally safe, accidents are inevitable because the system is antiquated and heavily dependent on human performance.

title: NATO Urged to Keep Force In Bosnia After Pullout Date
description: As warnings mount that the fragile Bosnian peace could collapse without the presence of NATO peacekeepers, international civilian and military authorities here have begun to press for keeping at least a reduced NATO force in Bosnia beyond the currently scheduled departure at the end of this year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Acura Dealers Group Selects Landey
description: The Tri-State Acura Dealers Advertising Association said yesterday that it had selected Landey & Partners, Grounds Morris in New York to handle its account, with billings estimated at $4 million to $6 million. The Acura division of the American Honda Motor Company recently permitted local dealer associations to hire agencies separate from the national Acura agency, the Ketchum Advertising Los Angeles unit of Ketchum Communications.

title: Drifter Is Held In an Attempt At Abduction
description: A drifter with a lengthy arrest record was accused by Nassau County police today of trying to abduct a young girl from a playground in front of a Roosevelt, L.I., elementary school.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;15 Arrested in Heroin Raids
description: Federal, state and local authorities yesterday raided 13 locations in Jersey City and a Secaucus motel room, arresting 15 people and seizing more than 800 bags of heroin, officials said. Eleven of the defendants -- 10 Jersey City residents and one Brooklyn man -- were named in a Federal indictment unsealed in Newark yesterday, said Carmen Messano, the Hudson County Prosecutor.

title: BASEBALL;Key Recovery Warms Yanks' Spring
description: There was a fresh pink scar adorning the top of his left shoulder and a lonesome feeling invading his mind. This was last July, and not only was Jimmy Key's season over, but there was also doubt about whether he would ever throw a baseball precisely again.

title: HOCKEY;Devils' Stumbling Offense No Help for Playoff Hopes
description: What could be more inappropriate at this time of the season than for a team fighting for a playoff spot to score just a total of one goal in two consecutive games?

title: Once a Boomer . . .
description: To The Home Section:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Case of Green Card Bribes
description: DeAndre Rudolph, of Irvington, a former investigator for the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service, pleading guilty in Federal Court yesterday to accepting a $4,000 bribe in November for selling a detector the Government uses to determine if green card applications have been filled out properly.

title: Dharmsala Journal;Where the Dalai Lama Muses, the Sinful Intrudes
description: N. N. Nowroji has lived up here in the foothills of the Himalayas for most of his 81 years, and he thanks God, and China, for the Tibetans. It was 36 years ago this spring that the Dalai Lama and his entourage, who had fled Chinese troops suppressing an uprising in Tibet, arrived to set up their new homes here.

title: No Indictment in Fatal Use of Gun in Traffic Fight
description: In a test of Texas' new concealed weapons law, a grand jury today refused to indict a man who pulled out a concealed handgun and used it to fatally shoot an unarmed man who had attacked him after a minor traffic accident.

title: No Headline
description: The burden for peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina is on the shoulders of those folks that live here. If they don't want peace, there ain't gonna be peace. If they want peace, one year is more than enough to get them started."

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Travieso's Fall Off the Court Throws a Scare Into UMass
description: Massachusetts, the top-seeded team in the East Regional and the No. 1-ranked team in the nation, got a big scare this afternoon when Carmelo Travieso, its best shooting guard and 3-point specialist, took a tumble off a four-foot platform set up for interviews at the Georgia Dome and fell on metal supports, injuring his lower back.

title: U.S. Vulnerable to Terrorist Chemical Weapons
description: The United States is "very poorly" equipped to defend itself against a terrorist group armed with nuclear, biological or chemical weapons, the Director of Central Intelligence, John M. Deutch, testified today.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 284.93 points, or 1.39 percent, to 20,727.53. On Wednesday, the Tokyo Stock Exchange was closed in observance of the Vernal Equinox Day, a national holiday.

title: FIGURE SKATING;World Champion Falls And Drops to 7th Place
description: The world champion, Elvis Stojko of Canada, dressed as a checkered flag, and then proceeded to get lapped by the men's field today at the world figure-skating championships.

title: BOXING;Champions Slip Punches and Jabs After Dark
description: It may be so late on Saturday night that only the Damon Runyon characters will hang around to see Arturo Gatti fight.

title: Britain Ties Deadly Brain Disease to Cow Ailment
description: The British Government said today for the first time that there may be a link between what is known as mad-cow disease, a deadly neurological affliction of cattle here, and a similar fatal brain disease in humans.

title: For Governor and Prosecutor, a Running Argument Over the Law
description: March 7, 1995 -- New York became the 38th state to allow capital punishment when Gov. George E. Pataki signed a death penalty bill, fulfilling a campaign promise. That day, the Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, issued a statement giving his reservations. Here are excerpts:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an on-line discussion of free speech in cyberspace misstated the affiliation of Linda Ellerbee, who moderated it. She is president of Lucky Duck Productions Inc., which is in partnership with the Microsoft Corporation. She does not work for Microsoft.

title: Reinterpreting the Dazzle of India
description: AS Allegra Hicks strolled up Madison Avenue last Sunday on her way to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to examime textiles, she seemed oblivious to the stares of passers-by. Swathed in lilac cashmere and copper-colored harem pants, she stepped forth in Ali Baba shoes and exuded a defiant Italian beauty that made her appear fearless.

title: G.M. Strikers Fear Threat To Way of Life
description: The rest of the world knows the nation's largest auto maker as the General Motors Corporation, but residents of this quiet southeastern Ohio city have their own name: Generous Motors.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Lehman Brothers Says Earnings More Than Doubled in Quarter
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings more than doubled from a year ago, led by revenue gains in underwriting and trading as well as a decline in expenses.

title: The Long-Term Bite Of New Jersey Tax Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics Complaint Against Democratic Whip
description: A conservative organization filed an ethics complaint today against Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the House Democratic whip, accusing him of nepotism in connection with hiring and giving a raise to a woman whom he later married.

title: Jacquetta Hawkes, Archeologist, Is Dead at 85
description: Jacquetta Hawkes, archeologist and author, who was the widow of the playwright and novelist J. B. Priestley, died on Monday at Cheltenham General Hospital in London. She was 85, and lived in the Cotswolds town of Chipping Camden.

title: Balkan Broadcasts
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 5 about William J. Morgan, a psychologist who took his granddaughter to New Zealand to keep her from her father, misstated the legal situation of the girl and her mother. The girl, now 13, remains abroad with her mother, Elizabeth Morgan, who was given custody of her by a New Zealand family court provided that she remain in that country. The girl would need the New Zealand court's permission to leave the country and thus is not legally free to return to the United States.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;WPIX Signs Waldman
description: SUZYN WALDMAN, the WFAN radio reporter, was named a part-time Yankee announcer on WPIX-TV/Channel 11. By agreeing to call 13 road games, Waldman joins PHIL RIZZUTO, BOBBY MURCER and RICK CERONE..

title: Constitutional Change for Tax Measures Is Pushed
description: Republican leaders in the House called today for a Constitutional amendment to require two-thirds votes in both Houses for increasing Federal taxes and scheduled action on it for April 15, the deadline for filing personal income tax returns.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Turning Up The Warmth In a Serialist
description: Christoph von Dohnanyi is always finding new ways to trick people into enjoying the Second Viennese School. In a recent recording for London, he tempted consumers with the later symphonies of Mozart, concealing orchestral works of Webern at the end of each CD. At a Carnegie Hall concert on Monday night with the Cleveland Orchestra, Bruckner's Fifth Symphony was the lure, Schoenberg's Five Pieces for Orchestra the catch. The conductor presents these scores with such care and grace that audiences usually drop their natural resistance.

title: Prosecutor Resists Pataki Pressure on Death Penalty
description: Bridling at what he described as Gov. George E. Pataki's "heavy-handed" efforts to force him to seek the death penalty, District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx said yesterday that while he had not ruled out capital punishment in the case of a man accused of killing a police officer, he would not be pressured into making a decision.

title: It's Time for Openness in Adoption Records;Industry Lobbyist
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;One Year Later, a Memorial
description: It has been one year since a gunman killed four people and wounded a fifth at a post office in Montclair, and the township will hold a memorial service tonight at the Watchung School. Afterward, there will be a candlelight procession to the site of the former post office, which is now a retail store.

title: Police Say Secret Camera Caught Sergeant Stealing
description: A bookmaker suspected his employees might be stealing money, so he installed a hidden video camera at his East Harlem numbers business.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Abdul-Rauf Is Calm In Face of Controversy
description: It's been a struggle," Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf said. "But it's been a beautiful struggle. In what I did, I had no personal gain. I had no personal reasons, no selfish reasons for doing it. I knew that what I did wasn't wrong."

title: Assault Rifles Get Support Of G.O.P. In House
description: In a move that Democrats denounced as a bow to the gun lobby, Republican leaders in the House revived an effort today to repeal a two-year-old Federal ban on certain assault-style weapons.

title: Abduction Suspect Wanted a Car, but Would He Kill for It?
description: Michael LaSane's 17th birthday was coming, and he wanted a car.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: BASEBALL;An Umpire Sees Need For Stricter Discipline
description: Dennis Rodman wasn't the only person whose attention the National Basketball Association got when it fined and suspended the bad boy of the Chicago Bulls this week. Baseball umpires noticed, too.

title: Heinz Plans Acquisition
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that it had agreed to acquire a majority interest in Alimentos Pilar S.A., an Argentine pet food company. Terms were not disclosed. Alimentos Pilar, based in Buenos Aires, is Argentina's third-largest pet food producer, with annual sales of about $21 million. Heinz's chairman, Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, estimated the Argentine pet food market was growing at 15 percent a year.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Svenska Cellulosa Says Profits Soared Last Year
description: The big forest-products company Svenska Cellulosa A.B. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose more than fivefold in 1995 because it was able to increase prices and because units it bought earned more than expected. Pretax profit rose to a higher-than-expected 5.731 billion kronor ($868 million), from 1.060 billion kronor the previous year. The result includes 1.085 billion Swedish kronor from Papierwerke Waldhof-Aschaffenburg A.G. of Germany, in which the Swedish concern bought a 75 percent stake last year.

title: Trailer Court In a Time Warp
description: WHEN Ed Smith was a boy, in the 1950's, he and his parents camped when they traveled. They set up a tent, but the campgrounds they visited also had places for people with trailers. "I was fascinated by the life of the trailerists," he recalled. "They were the exclusive set. They socialized only with each other. We were the lowly tent dwellers. I yearned to know what went on inside those gleaming silver trailers. I dreamed of someday being able to camp in one."

title: Mets' Huskey Earns a Shot, But the Question Is Where?
description: Butch Huskey's bat has been so impressive for the Mets this spring that Manager Dallas Green is trying to figure out a way to keep him in the lineup when Rico Brogna is healthy enough to reclaim first base.

title: Fewer Russians on Kurils
description: Russia has cut the number of troops it has on the South Kuril Islands, a chain seized by Russia after World War II but still claimed by Japan, to about 3,500, Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov said today.

title: POLITICS: THE CHALLENGER;Buchanan Taking Aim At Dole On Free Trade
description: Pointing to Ross Perot's potential candidacy and his own strong showing in two Midwestern primaries, Patrick J. Buchanan said today that he hoped to shatter the Republican Party's historic commitment to free trade, suggesting he may bedevil Senator Bob Dole on that issue as much as on abortion.

title: Perry Watkins, 48, Gay Sergeant Won Court Battle With Army
description: Perry J. Watkins, an openly homosexual Army sergeant whose long battle to stay in the military led to a victory in 1990 before the Supreme Court, died on Sunday at his home in Tacoma, Wash. He was 48.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Bailout Is Planned For Banco do Brasil
description: Banco do Brasil S.A., Latin America's largest bank, said today that it lost $4.3 billion last year, an amount greater than its net worth. The Government immediately announced a rescue plan to increase the capital of the state-controlled bank by $8 billion.

title: Fund's Grants Focus On Man and Nature
description: To those who care about the natural world and man's positive imprints upon it, the slow disappearance of financing for historic preservation and environmental projects has been a little bit like a city street that suddenly loses a landmark.

title: A Conference on Black Literature Asks if the Good Times Will Stay
description: Normally, the wheels of cultural change turn slowly. That has not been the case with black writing in the United States. When Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn last held a conference on black writing, in 1992, the mood was somber. "Dismal" is the word used by Elizabeth Nunez, a professor of English at Medgar Evers and the organizer of this year's National Black Writers Conference.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Israeli Soldier Killed In Bombing in Lebanon
description: A suicide bomber from the Iranian-backed Party of God killed an Israeli soldier today when he blew himself up near an Israeli convoy in southern Lebanon, the Israeli Army said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Train Fatally Strikes Woman
description: A woman was killed by a New Jersey Transit train in the early morning darkness yesterday after she drove off a dead end and onto a railroad right-of-way and got stuck on the tracks just west of the Ramsey station, a transit spokesman said.

title: Calendar: Shows, Talks, Workshops
description: Clay and Glass American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street; (212) 956-3535.

title: Board of Education Approves District for Troubled Schools
description: The New York City Board of Education unanimously approved a plan last night to streamline the school system's bureaucracy and move the city's most troubled schools into a special new district under the direct control of the Chancellor.

title: Christopher Cautions the Russians on Isolation
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned Russian voters today that they face a choice in the June presidential elections between inclusion in the institutions of the West or self-isolation.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Plan to Limit Campaign Funds
description: In New Jersey, the law provides public financing for gubernatorial campaigns and imposes limits on candidates who accept the money. A coalition of political and citizen lobbying organizations would like to see public financing -- and spending limits -- extend to legislative campaigns. They plan to offer a series of proposals today that would include public financing of legislative campaigns and spending limits for candidates of $50,000 in legislative primary races and $100,000 in the general election.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New York Underground Film Festival misstated the given name of the director of "Farley Mowat Ate My Brother." He is Ken Hegan, not Tony.

title: Bamboo, Tamed, Bends to a Master's Touch
description: Bamboo is as prevalent as a weed here, its tenacious roots and furious growth the bane of the home gardener. So it may have seemed like bringing coals to Newcastle when two truckloads of the stuff -- 1,800 30-foot-long shafts in all -- were delivered to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts last week from a bamboo plantation in Augusta, Ga.

title: Executive Changes
description: BEHRMAN CAPITAL, New York, said that William Merrill Matthes had joined the firm as a partner.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Revenue and Hope Ebb At West Africa's Airline
description: All around this region, billboards for Air Afrique, French-speaking Africa's large multinational airline, proudly proclaim the carrier "the No. 1 Company in Black Africa." Catchy radio jingles promise travelers to do "more for you every day."

title: Hospitality Is Their Business;One Ethnic Group's Rooms-to-Riches Success Story
description: In the quarter-century that people of Indian ancestry have been emigrating to the United States in sizable numbers, they have carved out a steadily bigger share of the nation's hotel industry. Starting with no-name motels, they soon graduated to Days Inn, Econo Lodge, Rodeway and other economy franchises.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Home-Grown Chicory

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Dale Harris, a writer and lecturer on the arts and literature, referred incorrectly to his survivors. They indeed include immediate family members -- his sisters, Audrey Weber of Manhattan and Maureen Goldberg of Amagansett, L.I., and his brother, Jack Harris, of Stamford, Conn.

title: Procedure For Carew's Daughter
description: Michelle Carew, a daughter of the baseball Hall of Famer Rod Carew, is scheduled to undergo an umbilical cord blood transplant Friday to treat her leukemia, her doctor said today.

title: How Disney Products Cost Us and Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit Is Filed In Cellular Fraud
description: Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile has filed a Federal suit contending that two men swindled the company out of $130,965.

title: Dying of Resentment
description: The case of George Delury, the Manhattan editor who encouraged and facilitated the suicide of his wife, Myrna Lebov, explodes a myth. Chronically ill and dependent people who say they want help in committing suicide are not always acting out of free choice. The request can be a way of begging for support.

title: Digital Says It Won't Meet Forecasts, and a Sector Slumps
description: Blaming slow sales of its personal computers, the Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that this quarter's earnings would fall below analyst expectations. The news sent Digital's shares tumbling nearly 17 percent, dragging down other computer issues and, in turn, the broader market.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TAMMY FAYE BAKKER MESSNER'S second husband, ROE MESSNER, was sentenced to 27 months in Federal prison for bankruptcy fraud. After the sentencing in Wichita, Kan., Mr. Messner's lawyer revealed that Mrs. Messner was undergoing treatment for colon cancer.

title: Market Place;C-TEC plays 'Beat the Clock' with Clinton capital gains plan.
description: THE 1996 award for the most hastily assembled, but best-timed, news release may go to the C-TEC Corporation, a telephone and cable television company based in Princeton, N.J.

title: Universities Scramble to Weigh a Ruling's Impact
description: Administrators at the University of Texas, the institution at the center of a Federal appeals court ruling that barred the use of race-based affirmative-action admissions programs, said today that conforming to the ruling might ultimately cut the number of black and Hispanic students admitted to some of its campuses by half or more.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Patrolling Electronic Highways
description: There is something about the Internet that does not love communication. Experts or visionaries trying to explain what it portends find themselves resorting to metaphors -- superhighway, global public space -- that are far from crystal clear. Maybe it's just the newness of the thing or its still-unformed nature or the immensity and untidiness of the prospect of all that stuff being spewed endlessly, from everywhere to everywhere without any traffic director.

title: Mexicans Tire of Police Graft as Drug Lords Raise Stakes
description: Last week officers from an elite police anti-narcotics unit seized Rogelio Hernandez, 32, a motorcycle repairman, and drove him to the home of a cocaine trafficker, where they beat and threatened him as the trafficker demanded payment of a debt.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Business Digest on Wednesday, with a reference to an article about the departure of Steven Berrard as chief executive of Blockbuster Entertainment, was published in error. It showed George Dean Johnson Jr., a former Blockbuster executive, not Mr. Berrard.

title: When Fraud Truly Stings: Smaller Bank as Target
description: For a banker, what could be worse than discovering that you may have lent to a fraud?

title: William Sloane Jelin, Manufacturer, 44
description: William Sloane Jelin, a roofing-material maker who was a prominent Democratic Party fund-raiser, died on Wednesday at his home in Cape Elizabeth, Me. He was 44 and also lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday by Muhamed Sacirbey, the Bosnian Ambassador to the United Nations, used the term "Muslim-Croat Federation," which he finds unacceptable. The article should have referred to the "Bosnian Federation."

title: Market Place;Teamsters Hit a Nerve On Directors
description: Last week, the pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters named what it called the 23 least valuable directors in corporate America, citing poor attendance, conflicts of interest or service at companies whose chief executives were underperforming and overpaid in 1994.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Charity Care Measure Fails
description: Donald DiFrancesco, president of the State Senate, said yesterday that he did not have enough votes to win passage of the latest proposal to pay for hospital care for uninsured New Jerseyans. Under the plan, so-called charity care would have been reduced by $125, and the state would have continued to draw upon the unemployment insurance fund.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Moet Hennessy to Buy Celine Fashion House
description: VMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. will pay 2.7 billion French francs ($540 million) for the Celine fashion house and, separately, will raise its stake in Guerlain perfumes to 100 percent. The moves build on the luxury goods maker's strategy of expanding activities in high-margin luxury fashions and accessories. Celine is to be purchased within days, and LVMH Moet Hennessy will raise its take in Guerlain, the prestige perfume maker, to 100 percent from 58 percent before June.

title: Congressional Roundup;Limits on Liability Damages
description: The Senate today passed a bill limiting damages in lawsuits involving faulty products, but the 59-to-40 vote would not be enough to override President Clinton's promised veto.

title: Racial Tensions Intensifying At a Public School in Queens
description: After a white librarian at a Queens school was accused of using a racial epithet to refer to a fifth-grade student, further straining a difficult relationship between some white teachers and black parents, few imagined that life at the school, Public School 80, could get worse.

title: What School Reform?
description: In city after city across America, reformers are trying to change the way public schools are managed. Seattle has hired a former Army general as its superintendent. Milwaukee wants to let poor kids choose among public, private and parochial schools. Reformers in Boston are creating charter schools that are relieved of all but essential regulations.

title: RJR Nabisco Asks 'What If'
description: The head of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation has said the American tobacco industry would not rule out a deal to settle anti-

title: Bank Fraud Charges For Currency Trader
description: Victor Gomez, a former currency trader for the Chemical Banking Corporation, has been indicted on Federal charges related to the bank's loss of $70 million from unauthorized trading of the Mexican peso, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: 4 Archer-Daniels Executives To Leave Board for Outsiders
description: Four managers of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, the agricultural giant, will step down from its board of directors, the company announced yesterday.

title: FIGURE SKATING;Eldredge Wins Championship; Galindo Is 3d
description: Todd Eldredge, the son of a commercial fisherman, took one seasick ride on his father's boat as a boy and decided that if he were to make a living on the water the water would have to be frozen.

title: Bronx Chief Is Removed
description: Seeking to stem a three-month spree of shootings, murders and burglaries in the Bronx, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton yesterday removed Assistant Chief Rafael Pineiro, the Bronx borough commander, and transferred him to a desk job in Police Headquarters.
