title: Cowboys' Irvin Irks Prosecutors
description: The Dallas County District Attorney's office said today that it unsuccessfully tried to serve Dallas Cowboys receiver Michael Irvin with a subpoena in connection with a grand jury investigation into a drug arrest. But Irvin's lawyer said his client would "work with the D.A. in this case."

title: Law Tracking Sex Offenders Faces Setback
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday barred New York State from releasing the names and addresses of thousands of sex offenders who were convicted before Jan. 21, when a law allowing the practice took effect.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Ceballos Suspended
description: CEDRIC CEBALLOS, the Los Angeles Lakers' leading scorer, was suspended indefinitely by the team without pay yesterday, a day after he missed the team's charter flight to Seattle.

title: Scientists Find Antibody Aid In Cancer Fight
description: An antibody that unleashes natural killer cells and sends them out to destroy tumors may be a way to enlist the body's immune system in battling cancer, scientists report.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Senators Back Tobacco Suit
description: Two State Senators, Richard Codey, Democrat of West Orange, and Jack Sinagra, Republican of Edison, and the Medical Society of New Jersey called on Attorney General Deborah T. Poritz yesterday to join other states in a lawsuit against five major tobacco companies. The suit is seeking to recover the costs of Medicaid payments to people with cigarette-related illnesses. In New Jersey, that could amount to $20 million a year, a spokesman for the Medical Society estimated.

title: 25 and Under
description: Why does the Upper East Side have so many Italian restaurants? The answer isn't complicated: that's what the people want.

title: Candidate Is Seen For C.F.T.C. Post
description: The Clinton Administration said today that Brooksley Born, a Washington lawyer, was being considered to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, but added that a final decision had not been made.

title: Gene Study Finds Link to Type of Epilepsy in Surprising Place
description: Researchers say they have identified a gene responsible for a form of epilepsy, a finding that surprised scientists and pointed them in a new direction in efforts to understand other types of the disease.

title: Federal Agency Fines Company a Record $1.5 Million for Hiring Illegal Immigrants
description: Federal immigration authorities yesterday announced the largest fine ever levied against a company for hiring illegal immigrants -- $1.5 million against a Westchester cleaning business -- as part of a national effort to increase pressure on employers to comply with immigration laws.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANDREAS PAPANDREOU, the former Prime Minister of Greece, was discharged yesterday from the Onassis Cardiac Surgery Center in Athens, after a four-month stay, The Associated Press reported.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: EAST - Holding True to Form: 1-2 Punch Packs aWallop; Georgetown, UMass Prevail
description: In two distinctly different manners, Georgetown and Massachusetts reached the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's East Regional here at the Georgia Dome tonight. The Hoyas went through a ringer against third-seeded Texas Tech before downing the Red Raiders, 98-90, while the Minutemen waltzed to an easy 79-63 victory over 12th-seeded Arkansas.

title: Restaurants
description: Have you ever been bribed?

title: Softbank Plans to Buy a Web Advertising Service
description: Softbank, the Japanese company that has spent more than $3 billion in the last year on acquisitions, including its purchase of the computer magazine publisher Ziff-Davis, is expected to continue its buying spree next week when it announces an agreement to buy a stake in Interactive Marketing Inc., a seller of advertising space on the Internet's World Wide Web.

title: FILM REVIEW;Giving a Farewell Party With Death as a Guest
description: There is something inescapably ghoulish about a grown man who throws himself a pre-suicide party and raucously cavorts about the house singing a morbid revision of the old Lesley Gore hit "It's My Party."

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Young, Geeky and Suburban
description: REMEMBERING perfectly is the best revenge, as Todd Solondz demonstrates so beautifully in "Welcome to the Dollhouse," his mordantly hilarious suburban comedy about the torments endured by an awkward young girl. With a fine vengeance along with flashes of great, unexpected tenderness, Mr. Solondz lethally evokes every petty humiliation that his seventh-grade heroine can't wait to forget.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Play Displays a Growing City's Cultural Tensions
description: Alan Poindexter dropped his pants on stage in Charlotte for seven seconds Wednesday night, and nothing happened.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SAMSUNG HALVES OUTPUT OF 4-MEGABIT CHIPS
description: The Samsung Electronics Company, part of the Samsung Group of South Korea, said yesterday that it would cut monthly production of 4-megabit dynamic random access memory chips to four million chips from eight million, in an effort to stem declining prices. In the last six months, the price of 4-megabit chips has fallen sharply. The NEC Corporation and Hitachi Ltd. have also announced plans to cut production of 4-megabit D-RAM chips, switching to the more profitable 16-megabit chip. The moves by Samsung, the world's largest maker of memory chips, and the Japanese companies will reduce global output of the 4-megabit D-RAM to 31 million in the second half of 1996 from 50.5 million a month now, Samsung said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WORLD AIRWAYS MIGHT SELL STAKE TO EMPLOYEES
description: World Airways Inc. said yesterday that the airline and its parent, Worldcorp, were considering the sale of a large piece of the company to its employees. Worldcorp Inc. owns 59.3 percent of World Airways' outstanding stock. An additional 16.6 percent of World Airways is owned by MHS Berhad, a Malaysian investor. The company also said that it was exploring the possibility of a spinoff of its interest in World Airways or a sale to a third party. The stock of World Airways rose 62.5 cents, to $8.25, while Worldcorp rose 37.5 cents, to $9.75.

title: 3 Big Japanese Banks Expect Big Losses
description: Three big Japanese banks said today that they would suffer significant losses this year after writing off large portions of problem loans, including those to mortgage companies at the heart of a Government bailout plan.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: STANDOFF IN WESTCHESTER: THE VICTIM;An Officer Is Recalled As Easygoing And Polite
description: If he found a car in a no-parking lane, he would almost beg the owners to avoid the indignity of a ticket: "Could you please move your car?" He would ask, not command. He never simply barked, "Move! Now!"

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Childs Sparks Late Rally After Nets Lose Big Lead
description: The Nets blew an 18-point third-quarter lead so fast, Armon Gilliam did not even realize they had had one.

title: Fixed-Rate Mortgage Dips
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.81 percent this week, down from 7.83 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.6 percent, up from 5.55 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.32 percent this week, unchanged from a week earlier.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Saab May Still Bid For Parts of Fokker
description: The Saab Aircraft division of Saab, which is owned by Investor A.B. and the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that it was still interested in the bankrupt Dutch plane maker Fokker B.V. and was weighing a possible bid for parts of the company. "We are still interested, and we are working actively on our stance on a possible bid for parts of Fokker," a Saab spokesman, Anders Annerfalk, said.

title: Even if Economy Grows, Only a Few Will Gain;Profit Obsession
description: To the Editor:

title: TENSION IN TAIWAN: THE POLITICS;War Games Play Well for Taiwan's Leader
description: We hate China and we will fight to the death for Taiwan!"

title: On Stage, and Off
description: . . . A Doctor in the House?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;No Decision on Messier
description: MARK MESSIER, the Rangers' captain, remained in limbo for another day yesterday as the National Hockey League continued its review of his stick-related foul Tuesday night against Edmonton's DAVE ROBERTS.

title: TV WEEKEND;Sincere but Not Saintly, the Czarina's Mystic
description: Sympathy for the devil has rarely been carried to such a delirious extreme as it is in "Rasputin," an HBO movie with Alan Rickman exquisitely cast as the mystic who captured the minds of the doomed, imperial Romanovs. Shaggy-haired and laser-eyed, this Rasputin has manic energy, raw sexuality and extremely bad table manners. But defying the conventional view, he is decidedly not a charlatan. After a vision of the Virgin sends the peasant Rasputin to St. Petersburg, he alleviates the suffering of the Czar's hemophiliac son, and eventually carries the pain of all Russia within his tortured soul. This Rasputin is half Christ-figure.

title: 1.5 Million Penalty Over Illegal Immigrants
description: Federal authorities yesterday announced the largest fine ever levied against a company for hiring illegal immigrants -- $1.5 million against a Westchester County cleaning business -- as part of a national effort to increase pressure on employers to comply with immigration laws.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AST'S EARNINGS TO BE LOWER THAN EXPECTED
description: AST Research Inc., the maker of personal computers, said yesterday that its results would be lower than expected in the first quarter. AST said it had encountered less demand for its PC's as inventories have increased. The weak results for the first quarter are expected to follow a loss of $128.6 million and a drop in sales -- which is unusual in the PC industry -- in the fourth quarter of 1995. AST did not provide a specific estimate of its results for the first quarter.

title: Bad Law on Affirmative Action
description: For two decades the governing principle of affirmative action in higher education has been that race and ethnicity may be a factor, but only one factor, in choosing among applicants in pursuit of the legitimate purpose of a diverse student body. That was the judgment of the Supreme Court in the celebrated 1978 case of Allan Bakke, a white applicant who sued for entry to a California state medical school.

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks Dismantled by Jordan and Bulls
description: Michael Jordan had a mischievous smile on his face and one thought about the March 10 national television encounter between the Bulls and Knicks:

title: Congressional Roundup;Personal Plea on Gun Ban
description: A Long Island woman whose husband was killed by a gunman on a Long Island Rail Road train three years ago testified today at an impromptu hearing against a Republican measure to repeal a Federal law banning assault rifles.

title: Residents Try to Salvage Memories From the Rubble
description: Faith Lange returned to her shattered apartment in a collapsed East Side building yesterday morning to retrieve pieces of her life. She came out with little but school papers from third grade, a tiny chair she had as a 3-year-old, some special pictures.

title: In America;Playing to the Mob
description: The death penalty brings out the worst in politicians. With just the slightest whiff of an execution in the air, even the most mild-mannered officials can become agitated and recklessly aggressive, like respectable folks who suddenly have gotten all liquored up, and in their frantic howling for a killing we can hear the vestiges of the lynch mob.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Illinois Hires Kruger
description: LON KRUGER, who coached Florida to the Final Four in 1994, was hired yesterday as the coach at Illinois.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Militias Aim to Lure Elite Army Troops, U.S. Generals Fear
description: Senior Army commanders believe that members of the Special Operations Forces, the elite fighting units that include the Green Berets, have been selected for recruitment by extremist militias, the Army said in a report released today.

title: Tobacco Price Supports Aren't Affected
description: The farm legislation before Congress does not affect the separate system of price supports under which the Government protects tobacco growers against losses, providing access to loans and a guaranteed minimum price for their crops. In exchange, farmers agree to limit the amount of tobacco each grows.

title: Capital-Gains Tax Cut Would Create No Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Ontario Plant to Reopen
description: Allied Signal will reopen a hydrofluoric-acid production plant in Amherstburg, Ontario, that it idled in 1992, the company said today. A spokesman said the move, planned in November, was a response to the rising use of environmentally safer fluorocarbon products, as opposed to chlorofluorocarbons, by makers of refrigerators and air-conditioners. The Ontario plant is scheduled to begin full-scale operation in April 1997, with an annual production capacity of 52,000 tons. Allied Signal also produces hydrofluoric acid at a plant in Geismar, La.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an Israeli newspaper's identification of the new head of the Mossad secret service misidentified a book in which his predecessor's name was mentioned. It is "Friends in Deed," not "Friends in Need."

title: Home Video
description: Multifaceted 'Seven'

title: On My Mind;Buchanan and the Fish
description: So Patrick Buchanan will not be the Republican candidate for President this year. But he has become a steadily increasing political and moral liability to the Republican Party, to Americans who usually vote Republican and to Democrats thinking of doing so this November.

title: Even if Economy Grows, Only a Few Will Gain;Management's Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Survey Shows Slow Decline In Abortions
description: The number of abortions performed yearly in the United States is inching its way downward, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: A KILLING IN THE BRONX: THE OVERVIEW;GOVERNOR REMOVES BRONX PROSECUTOR FROM MURDER CASE
description: Gov. George E. Pataki removed District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx from the murder case against an ex-convict accused of killing a police officer yesterday because, Mr. Pataki said, he was convinced that the prosecutor would never seek the death penalty.

title: Art in Review
description: Beatriz Milhazes Edward Thorp Gallery 103 Prince Street SoHo Through April 13

title: Papandreou Leaves Hospital After 4 Months
description: Andreas Papandreou was discharged from the hospital today after a four-month stay during which he narrowly avoided death and had to resign as Prime Minister.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UUNET TECHNOLOGIES WITHDRAWS STOCK OFFERING
description: Uunet Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it was withdrawing its registration to offer 6.62 million shares of its common stock to the public. The company said it had terminated the offering because of the recent drop in its stock price. Uunet fell 50 cents, to $24.50, near the stock's 52-week low of $21.75. The provider of Internet-access services filed for the offering in February to raise money to acquire undersea and European land-based fiber optic cable capacity. The company said it would continue its plan to acquire fiber optic capacity.

title: FILM REVIEW;Finding a Career in Telephone Sex
description: Spike Lee's "Girl 6" doesn't reveal much about its title character, but it does make this clear: Mr. Lee adores her. He shows his fondness for this beautiful heroine (Theresa Randle) by surrounding her with every bit of fun and flattery in his considerable arsenal. Bold colors, a dance track of Prince songs, a parade of wild costumes, good-humored sexual teasing and warmly inviting cinematography by Malik Sayeed all contribute to this comedy's high-energy party mood.

title: Congressional Roundup;Temporary Spending Bill Extended by a Week
description: Negotiators from the House and Senate began work today on reconciling their widely differing spending bills to cover much of the Government for the remaining six months of the 1996 budget year.

title: CLINTON PRESSING JUDGE TO RELENT
description: The White House put a Federal judge on public notice today that if he did not reverse a widely criticized decision throwing out drug evidence, the President might ask for his resignation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;You can put a price on 'the most glamorous night of the year.'
description: ON no map does Madison Avenue run through Hollywood. But come Monday, when ABC broadcasts the 68th annual Academy Awards ceremony, advertisers and agencies will be as intrinsic a part of filmdom as avaricious agents and actors who insist, "What I really want to do is direct."

title: A KILLING IN THE BRONX: THE GOVERNOR;District Attorney Wouldn't Move, Pataki Aides Say, So He Was Moved
description: Aides to Gov. George E. Pataki talked to the Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, several times this week -- trying, they said, to avoid a public confrontation between the two men.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WESTINGHOUSE SAID TO BE PLANNING ASSET SALE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation plans to shed at least $300 million of nonmedia assets by the end of the year, which should push its stock higher and further its transformation into a media giant, analysts said yesterday. Westinghouse declined to comment. Analysts said Westinghouse management told them last week that the company would sell $300 million to $500 million in assets in the near term. The nonmedia units include Power Generation, Thermo King, Energy Systems, Government and Environmental Services, and the nonmilitary-related portion of Electronic Systems. Shares of Westinghouse fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $18.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Russians Fear Marxist Holds Secret Agenda
description: Last month Gennadi A. Zyuganov, presidential candidate and leader of the Communist Party, was the urbane, jolly statesman who impressed a worldly gathering in Switzerland with his talk of pluralism and business know-how.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Inside the Dragon of Mental Illness
description: WELCOME TO MY COUNTRY A Therapist's Memoir of Madness By Lauren Slater 199 pages. Random House. $22.

title: A Verdant Lawn As a Health Issue;Nassau Bill Would Require Notice Before Pesticide Spraying
description: For many Long Island homeowners, few things in life are treasured more than the beauty of their leafy shade trees and lush green lawns.

title: Sports of The Times;Waiting, Watching, Winning
description: WHAT constitutes a great college basketball game?

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fast Return to G.M. Unlikely
description: Even though General Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers Union reached a tentative agreement yesterday to end a strike at two brake-manufacturing plants in Dayton, Ohio, G.M. officials said it could take more than a week before idled workers in New Jersey return to work. [Page A1]

title: COMPANY NEWS;HEALTH MANAGEMENT PLANS TO REVISE EARNINGS
description: Health Management Inc. said it would revise its financial results for the first and second quarters of the 1996 fiscal year, and the fourth quarter of the 1995 fiscal year, after an internal review. In a statement, Health Management, of Ronkonkoma, L.I., said the revision was not yet complete, but it believes it will report a profit, before any one-time write-offs, for the first nine months of the current fiscal year. The company also said it believes each of the first three quarters of the 1996 fiscal year will be profitable before one-time write-offs. The provider of health management services warned last month that it might revise results after discovering accounting irregularities. The company's stock rose $1.875, or 65 percent, to $4.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Art in Review
description: Roni Horn Matthew Marks Gallery 522 West 22d Street Chelsea Through April 14

title: TV WEEKEND;Illicit Love in India for a Starchy British Family
description: In the resumes of the director Christopher Morahan and the writer Ken Taylor, no credit is more outstanding than the acclaimed mini-series "A Jewel in the Crown." Now, on a much less grand level, they return to India for the three-hour production of "The Peacock Spring," being shown on "Masterpiece Theater" in 90-minute segments this Sunday and next. The story is adapted from a novel of the same name by Rumer Godden ("Black Narcissus").

title: COMPANY REPORTS;ADOBE SYSTEMS INC.
description: Adobe Systems Inc. said yesterday that its earnings in its first quarter ended March 1 fell nearly 7 percent compared with the similar period a year earlier because of increased expenses for marketing and research and development.

title: Keep the Assault-Weapons Ban
description: For more than a year, Republican leaders in Congress have looked for the right moment to try to repeal the ban on assault-style weapons enacted in 1994. The law commands overwhelming public support, so there has not been an especially convenient time. Now the Republicans have abruptly scheduled a vote in the House today, without any hearings or votes by the Judiciary Committee or its relevant subcommittees, in the hope that supporters of the ban do not have time to rally their forces. The leadership's action is an outrageous attempt to placate the gun lobby and must be defeated.

title: Don't Let Publishers Stifle Internet Access
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUN AGREES TO BUY INTEGRATED MICRO PRODUCTS
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Integrated Micro Products P.L.C., a British supplier of computers for telecommunications companies, for $96.1 million. Sun said the purchase would enhance its product line. Integrated's "fault-tolerant" computers are designed to keep working without losing data, even during power outages. Sun, based in Mountain View, Calif., a maker of computer work stations, said Integrated Micro would operate as a new business unit within the systems division of Sun Microsystems. Sun's stock rose $1.75 yesterday, to $45.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Rise On Treasury Securities
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday on a report that showed regional manufacturing activity slowing slightly. The report served to revive hopes that the nation's central bank could yet lower interest rates.

title: Art in Review
description: Beat Streuli Janice Guy Gallery 29 King Street (near the Avenue of the Americas) South Village Through March 30

title: Diner's Journal
description: New York can use a few more fish places. Fortunately, it has one in the new AquaGrill in SoHo, which occupies the site of the former Three Degrees North. It's a pretty place. In the daytime, tulips droop gently in sunlight that streams through the windows and illuminates people eating rare tuna with avocado and arugula on freshly baked bread. In the evening, one end of the bar is covered with ice and three or four kinds of oysters and clams.

title: Capital-Gains Tax Cut Would Create No Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Raines Is Put on 15-Day D.L.
description: Tim Raines was placed on the 15-day disabled list today with a chip fracture of his left thumb, assuring the Yankees that their leadoff hitter and left fielder would miss opening day. Second baseman Pat Kelly is also expected to start the season on the disabled list.

title: A Schedule of Screenings
description: The New Directors/New Films series, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the department of film at the Museum of Modern Art, opens today and runs through April 7. Screenings are in the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1 at the museum, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan. Individual tickets are $8; $6 for museum or Film Society members; series tickets are $145; $110 for members. Information: (212) 875-5610; ticket availability: (212) 708-9500. Here is a schedule of the screenings. Sold-out shows are noted; occasionally, returned tickets are available at show time. Films that are scheduled for a commercial release in New York are noted. Today

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;More N.J. Trains Ran Lights
description: New Jersey Transit trains ran 18 red lights from 1991 through 1995, records released yesterday showed, more than Long Island Rail Road or Metro-North trains. Investigators suspected that a Feb. 9 collision in Jersey City, which killed two engineers and a passenger, may have been caused by one engineer passing a red signal, an offense he had been cited for twice.

title: STANDOFF IN WESTCHESTER: THE OVERVIEW;Officer Dies in Westchester Siege; Woman's Body Is Found in Home
description: A rifleman in a window killed one police officer and wounded a second as they answered a call for help at a Westchester County home yesterday, then held a cordon of rescuers and police sharpshooters at bay for hours with a barrage of gunfire that terrorized a quiet suburban street.

title: Don't Let Publishers Stifle Internet Access
description: To the Editor:

title: POP REVIEW;A Rocker's Digital Trip Down Memory Lane
description: Memory lane is a video screen in Graham Nash's "Lifesighs," a work-in-progress that had its world premiere on Wednesday night at the Walter Annenberg Center here.

title: FILM REVIEW;Where Gory Ends Wait For Drugged-Out Punks
description: Todd Verow's harshly repellent film adaptation of Dennis Cooper's novel "Frisk" may be the ne plus ultra of the experimental gay cinema known as queercore. This gruesome, boundary-pushing film, which opens today at the Quad Cinema, caused an uproar when it was shown last year at the San Francisco International Lesbian and Gay Film Festival. At a recent screening in Manhattan, its gory scenes of drugged-out punks being sodomized, strung up and murdered were enough to send a number of viewers scurrying to the exits.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Water Company Is Target of Bidding
description: Shares in Britain's South West Water surged yesterday after Severn Trent P.L.C., another regional water company, said it would seek clearance from Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission to make a cash bid for the company. The move followed an announcement by Wessex Water on March 7 that it intended to bid for South West Water. Wessex Water said it would not provide details of its offer until a regulatory review could be carried out.

title: No Headline
description: Fray Angelico Chavez, a multitalented Franciscan priest whose outpouring of poems, paintings, stories and historical writings celebrated and chronicled the early history of New Mexico, died on Monday at a nursing home in Santa Fe. He was 85.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Tennessee Williams In Deep Complexity
description: OF Tennessee Williams's great plays, "The Night of the Iguana" (1961) may be the most difficult to realize on the stage today, being the most easily misinterpreted with the help of hindsight. That's being demonstrated in the Roundabout Theater Company's handsome, wildly uneven revival, which, under the direction of Robert Falls, is risky to the point of wrongheadedness. The production opened last night at the Criterion Center Stage Right with a cast headed by William Petersen, Marsha Mason and, in her first Broadway appearance since "The Heiress," the stunning Cherry Jones.

title: Bids to Cut Legal Immigration Are Dropped From House Bill
description: The House agreed today to eliminate most provisions dealing with legal aliens from its immigration bill.

title: Atlanta Tickets Going on Sale
description: A total of 135,000 tickets for Olympic events previously announced as "sold out" -- including gymnastics, basketball and volleyball -- will go on sale by phone and on the Internet beginning at 9 A.M. Saturday, the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games said today.

title: Mr. Pataki Intervenes, Unwisely
description: Gov. George Pataki's decision to remove Bronx District Attorney Robert Johnson from prosecuting the murder of a New York City police officer, Kevin Gillespie, is an unfortunate intrusion on the discretionary authority of an elected D.A. The decision may also have created issues for the defendants to raise on appeal.

title: BASEBALL;Team Owners Approve Revenue-Sharing Plan
description: In what could be considered a do-over, baseball club owners overwhelmingly adopted a second new revenue-sharing plan today, hoping it could serve as a catalyst for a new collective-bargaining agreement with the players.

title: Vimrx Sets Sale of Stock
description: Vimrx Pharmaceuticals Inc., a biotechnology company, said today that a group of investors led by Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., would buy about $4.2 million of the company's stock. The investors will own about 10 percent, or 2.8 million, of Vimrx's shares and about 1.4 million warrants. Each warrant can be converted into one common share. In another development, Donald Drapkin, vice chairman of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, was elected chairman of Vimrx. Mr. Drapkin has been a member of Vimrx's board since December 1995.

title: A KILLING IN THE BRONX: THE STATUTE;Rarely Used Law Invoked From Misty Legal Realms
description: In removing the Bronx District Attorney from the prosecution of a potential death-penalty case, Gov. George E. Pataki is invoking a rarely used law to apply an untested one.

title: Neighbors of Man Accused of Huge Swindling of Banks Are Puzzled
description: If he did what the prosecutors say he did, what happened to the $323 million?

title: STANDOFF IN WESTCHESTER: THE SCENE;In Disbelief, Neighbors Coming Home at Dusk Find a Suburb Under Siege
description: People thought they were coming home tonight to the quintessentially suburban setting they were used to. Instead, they found a community torn apart by gunfire, and hours later some of them were still barred from their houses.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Minnesotans Split on Bill Requiring 'Living Wage'
description: In the hallways and tunnels of the Minnesota Capitol here, Mel Duncan spends his days lobbying for bills that he hopes will house the homeless, feed the hungry and ease the burden of workers who try to support their families on $4.25 an hour, the minimum wage.

title: Citicorp Will Invest in a Deal To Buy Masco Furniture Unit
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it would invest in a bid to buy the furniture business of the Masco Corporation, but it denied reports that it was the leading partner in the effort.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Radio Show Prank at Mosque Angers Muslims in Colorado
description: Three Denver disk jockeys may face dismissal from their jobs and charges of trespassing and harassment after barging into a mosque in a Denver suburb to blast "The Star-Spangled Banner" on a trumpet and a bugle as an on-air prank earlier this week.

title: A New Push For Financial Services Bill
description: Trying to jump-start the effort to deregulate the banking industry and at the same time deal with looming problems in the savings and loan industry, Republicans said today that they would push for a vote in the House next month on a sweeping financial services bill.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;4 Arrested in Robbery Attack
description: The police arrested four men yesterday in the robbery and beating of two workers at an auto repair shop. Kenny Long, 31, the owner of Hawk Auto Repair in Newark, and Demetrius Molette, an employee, were tied up with duct tape and pistol-whipped, said Detective Daniel Collins of the Newark police.

title: Maybe a House Is Just a Home;Skittish Prices Dull Real Estate's Investment Luster
description: In the 1980's, it was a gold mine. Now, the suburban brick colonial at 8304 Aqueduct Road here about 10 miles northwest of downtown Washington is just a house again.

title: TV SPORTS;Ratings Dunk: Jordan Plays and People Watch
description: When Michael Jordan negotiates his salary in the coming free-agent market, NBC and Turner Sports should kick in a few million dollars to help Jerry Reinsdorf, the Bulls' owner, or any other team that Jordan signs with.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Racial and Family Strife, Flavored by Marseilles
description: Every so often Karim Dridi's intoxicatingly sensuous film "Bye Bye" pauses long enough for the camera to drink in the voluptuous, fetid atmosphere of the Mediterranean port city of Marseilles. In the director's favorite shot, the movie's main character, Ismael (Sami Bouajila), visits the harbor to observe the steamships slipping silently in and out of port through a smoggy sunset. Such moments crystallize the feeling of wanderlust that permeates the film, lending it an aching romantic tug.

title: Opposition Mounts To Railroad Merger
description: The Union Pacific Corporation's proposed $5.4 billion acquisition of the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation is drawing opposition from shippers' groups that say it will hurt competition.

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTY;Some Voters See Need for Another Candidate
description: Paul Whittaker has put in more hours than he can count on behalf of Ross Perot and Mr. Perot's newly established Reform Party. He has circulated registration petitions, passed out Perot statements and tacked up enough posters to cover a football field.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Lyrical Nitrate 1990. Kino. $59.95. 50 minutes. No rating. Release date: April 11. Information: (800) 562-3330.

title: FILM REVIEW;Underdogs Don't Melt Under the Desert Sun
description: Hollywood films about teen-age competition are so desperate to convey the vicarious thrill of winning despite impossible odds that when one comes along that doesn't slavishly recycle every cliche of the genre, each refusal to conform is a little breath of fresh air. "Race the Sun" may belong to the cookie-cutter school of "Rocky"-style movies with a "teen beat." But its hapless high school losers who gain self-esteem by finishing a grueling 2,000-mile car race through the Australian desert are recognizable enough so that one doesn't feel like a manipulated fool rooting for them.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST - Holding True to Form: 1-2 Punch Packs aWallop; Kentucky Rolls; Wake Is Next
description: Somebody cut off that lane to the basket. Somebody strip that shooter before he tosses another 3-pointer. Somebody call off that shattering, trapping defense.

title: A KILLING IN THE BRONX;Excerpts From Messages by Governer and the District Attorney
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. George E. Pataki's news conference yesterday at which he announced he was removing District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx from a murder case because of Mr. Johnson's opposition to the death penalty:

title: FILM REVIEW;Forget the Cerebral. Just Kill Him.
description: Beneath the surface of "Diabolique," Henri-Georges Clouzot's elegantly perverse 1955 thriller about two women plotting the murder of their mutual lover, lie bottomless reserves of malice and kinky intrigue. The very sight of the victim's dainty wife and his tough, steely mistress, originally played by Vera Clouzot and Simone Signoret, is enough to suggest all manner of forbidden possibilities. Not least is that the women care more about each other than either ever cared about a man.

title: GENERAL MOTORS AND UNION AGREE TO END WALKOUT
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union agreed today to end the biggest auto industry shutdown in a generation, a 16-day strike at two brake factories here that virtually halted G.M.'s operations across North America and caused the layoff of hundreds of thousands of workers.

title: Even if Economy Grows, Only a Few Will Gain;Corporate Holy Cows
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The World Monuments Fund is to announce its List of 100 Most Endangered Sites at a news conference today in Manhattan.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;The Big Payback Was All but Inevitable
description: Scottie Pippen rushed back into Chicago's lineup last night, but it was hardly necessary.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Crumb 1994. Columbia Tri-Star. $99.11. Laser disk, $39.95. 119 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Carlow Charged In Fraud Case
description: The entrepreneur Michael P. Carlow, who once owned the D. L. Clark Company, the maker of Clark candy bars, was charged today with defrauding the PNC Bank Corporation of $31 million.

title: Even if Economy Grows, Only a Few Will Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;A Fiscal Conservative Is Elected to Lead Sweden
description: The Parliament today elected as Prime Minister a tough-minded technocrat who has pledged to rein in Sweden's indebted welfare system.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Faces 1968. Fox Lorber/Orion. $89.98. 87 minutes. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: BASEBALL;Green Says Harnisch Is Starting Spring Now
description: Pete Harnisch is trying to grasp the big picture as he continues his return from surgery on his right shoulder. It isn't that clear to the Mets' pitcher.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Brendel, Beethoven and Surprises
description: Alfred Brendel, who turned 65 in January, increasingly resembles a wiry, awkward, eccentric professor. His wispy white hair is always unkempt; his eyeglasses are always slipping to the tip of his nose. Despite decades of concertizing, the revered Austrian pianist still seems uncomfortable on a concert stage, bowing nervously, rushing to the wings as if to seek refuge from ovations.

title: TENSION IN TAIWAN: THE EXPATRIATES;Thousands Head Home For the Vote
description: Ming-Chau (Mitch) Yang said goodbye to his pregnant wife and 2-year-old daughter today to join millions of other Taiwanese by casting his vote in Taiwan's first direct presidential election.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Somalis Kidnap 5 Aides Of U.N., Then Free Them
description: Somali gunmen abducted five United Nations aid workers on Thursday, including the American head of the World Health Organization in Somalia, demanding money they said they were owed.

title: ART REVIEW;China's Self-Portrait: Power and Subtlety
description: THE exhibition "Splendors of Imperial China: Treasures From the National Palace Museum, Taipei," at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is almost what its publicity promised it would be: a huge, once-in-a-lifetime immersion in the art of a great civilization over much of its tumultuous history, and also a show of subtle but surpassing beauty.

title: Charms to Soothe the Savage Quark
description: To the Editor:

title: Election Set to Pick Delegates for Ulster Talks
description: The Northern Ireland peace effort lurched forward today when Prime Minister John Major of Britain announced a special election in the British province on May 30 to begin selecting representatives to full-fledged peace negotiations. Those talks are to open June 10.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Theremin: An Electronic Odyssey 1995. Orion. $96. 84 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Tenneco to Spin Off Newport News Shipbuilding
description: Tenneco Inc., one of the last big industrial conglomerates, said today that it would spin off its Newport News Shipbuilding unit and that it was also considering a sale or spinoff of its energy division.

title: Stock Market Closes Mixed, With Dow Falling by 28.54
description: The stock market closed mixed yesterday, reflecting investor concern over a deteriorating economy. Although the key market indicators all closed lower, there were more advances than declines on the major exchanges.

title: Bad Weather Is Blamed for Inventory Rise
description: Business inventories jumped in January, the Commerce Department said today, but analysts said the surge reflected special factors and not a weakening economy. They similarly dismissed an increase in jobless claims.

title: Sports of The Times;Colangelo, New Baseball Owner, Already Wants to Move the Series
description: THE worst sports idea of the year, so far, has just been proposed by Jerry Colangelo, the new owner of the future team in the new baseball state of Arizona.

title: FILM REVIEW;Rotten to the Core? Try a Little Fatherhood
description: Some movies begin on a note so sour that no amount of sweetness and light can erase that nasty first impression. The romantic comedy "Jack and Sarah" never fully recovers from its early scenes in which Jack (Richard E. Grant), an English yuppie lawyer, behaves like the most insufferable twit this side of Dudley Moore throwing one of his boozy tantrums.

title: S.E.C. Tightens a Rule on Money-Market Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved a rule today that seeks to tighten investor safeguards over money-market funds that invest in tax-exempt municipal securities.

title: Virginia Henderson, 98, Teacher of Nurses, Dies
description: Virginia Henderson, who took a temporary job caring for World War I wounded and ended up helping to elevate nursing into a respected independent profession as a renowned researcher, teacher and scholar, died on Tuesday at a hospice in Branford, Conn. Known as the mother of modern nursing, she was 98.

title: Art in Review
description: W. Eugene Smith Lowinsky Gallery 578 Broadway (near Prince Street) SoHo Through March 30

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: POLITICS: FINANCES;Dole's Campaign Nears Limit On Spending for the Primaries
description: Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign is on the verge of reaching spending limits for the primaries, according to the latest Federal filing, forcing his campaign to remove dozens of senior and junior staff members from its payroll and rely on advertising financed by the Republican Party to get him through the convention in San Diego in August.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions of Business Day on March 12, about a deal by Barry Diller to take control of Silver King Communications, reported the action of the Federal Communications Commission incompletely. The commission approved the deal but stayed its completion pending consideration of objections filed by the Urban Broadcasting Corporation. A brief report on Sunday in the Diary column of Money and Business repeated the error.

title: Art in Review
description: Jed Devine Bonni Benrubi Gallery 52 East 76th Street Manhattan Through April 13

title: The Spoken Word
description: "A CONVERSATION WITH SANDRA SUNRISING OSAWA," National Museum of the American Indian, Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House, 1 Bowling Green, lower Manhattan. Ms. Osawa will discuss her video about the jazz musician Jim Pepper, "Pepper's Pow Wow." Sunday at 2 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 825-6894.

title: Congressional Roundup;Grazing Legislation
description: The Senate narrowly approved legislation today that would overturn the Clinton Administration's rules for managing publicly owned grazing lands.

title: ART REVIEW;Made for Each Other in Paris: A Painter and an Actor
description: AT the very height of the French Revolution, there was a well-known actor called Baptiste Aine who dared to walk through Paris with his hair still powdered white, after the fashion of the ancien regime.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page in some editions on Wednesday,about a speech by the chief executive of the Times Mirror Company, Mark H. Willes, referred imprecisely to job cuts at the company. A thousand jobs have already been eliminated; the company is not planning to cut another 1,000.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Patrolman Held in Misconduct
description: A rookie patrolman has been charged with official misconduct for coaxing a woman into repeatedly having sex with him by telling her that she was the subject of a narcotics investigation and would risk losing her children if she did not do as he asked, the authorities said yesterday. The patrolman, Keith Sandull, of Howell Township, met the woman in November when he responded to a call, said John Kaye, the Monmouth County prosecutor.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Rutgers Tackle Signs
description: The Giants have signed the free agent offensive lineman KEN DAMMANN to a one-year deal worth the league minimum, $131,000. The 6-foot-5-inch, 285-pound Dammann (pronounced DAY-men) started three years at left tackle for Rutgers.

title: I.B.M., in Contract Maneuver, To Hire Many From AT&T
description: AT&T, eager to find new jobs for the tens of thousands of employees who will lose theirs as a result of the company's breakup into three independent companies, said yesterday that I.B.M. had agreed to hire as many as 3,000 AT&T workers -- in exchange for a multibillion-dollar contract.

title: POLITICS: VOICES;California Voters Seem Wary of Dole
description: Patricia Schnall, Eric Segura and Mark Ruckman all voted against Bill Clinton four years ago, offering their support instead to George Bush or Ross Perot. They are all Republicans or self-described independent voters who long ago gave up on the Democratic Party. They live in this teeming region east of Los Angeles, which these days is monitored closely for signs of shifts in both California's electoral dynamics and economic fortunes.

title: Art in Review
description: Gary Simmons Metro Pictures 150 Greene Street, at Houston Street SoHo Through April 13

title: Abroad at Home;Handcuffs on Learning
description: Universities around the world came to understand long ago that the quality of education improved if they had students with varying life experiences. That is why Oxford colleges sought working-class students. It is why Harvard, Yale and Princeton are far better universities today than when they were confined largely to privileged young white men.

title: Engineers Needn't Fear Worker Influx
description: To the Editor:

title: Claude Bourdet, 86, Leader of French Resistance and Leftist Editor
description: Claude Bourdet, a Resistance leader who emerged a starveling from the Nazi concentration camp at Buchenwald to become a leader of France's postwar non-Communist left, died yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 86.

title: POLITICS: THE FRONT-RUNNER;Dole Leads Republican Call To Rebuild Missile Defenses
description: Senator Bob Dole called today for the resurrection of plans to build a national missile defense system by 2003. The system would cost billions of dollars and would violate a treaty on anti-ballistic missiles between Washington and Moscow.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Japanese stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 26.61 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, at 20,700.92. On Thursday, the Nikkei gained 284.93 points, its fifth consecutive rise.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TARRAGON OIL TO MAKE BID FOR STRIKE ENERGY
description: Tarragon Oil and Gas said yesterday that it would begin a takeover bid for Strike Energy Inc. valued at $125 million (Canadian), or about $92 million (United States), which includes the assumption of debt. Tarragon, an oil exploration and production company based in Calgary, Alberta, plans to exchange one share for every 3.68 Strike shares. Based on Tarragon's current stock price, the offer values Strike, an oil and gas company, at about $3.40 (Canadian) a share. Strike's board said it would recommend that its shareholders tender their shares. Tarragon said shareholders who own a total of about 25 percent of Strike's shares had agreed to tender their stock. The offer is conditional on the tendering of at least two-thirds of Strike's shares.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: Starwood Buys a Hotel
description: The Starwood Lodging Trust and its affiliated Starwood Lodging Corporation agreed today to buy the 442-room Clarion Hotel at the San Francisco International Airport for $30 million. Starwood said it would assume management of the hotel after the scheduled April 15 closing date. The hotel will be sold by Shivani, a private investment group, Starwood said. Shares of Starwood Lodging Trust, a real estate investment trust, and the Starwood Lodging Corporation, a hotel management company, are paired and traded together.

title: POLITICS: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK -- THE AFTERMATH;For Dornan, 1996 Contest Is His Show
description: Emphatically rebuffed as Presidential timber, Representative Robert K. Dornan is taking comfort in his old Capitol routine of fervidly upbraiding the "activist homosexual lobby" and rudely equating the AIDS virus in the military with syphilis.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRANSAMERICA APPROVES STOCK BUYBACK PLAN
description: The board of the TransAmerica Corporation has approved the repurchase of as many as two million shares, or 3 percent of its common shares outstanding. Earlier this month, the insurance and financial services company, based in San Francisco, completed another buyback of two million shares. The repurchased shares might be used for option plans, or they might be retired. The company had about 67.7 million common shares outstanding on March 15. TransAmerica shares dropped $1.50 to close at $76.375, before the announcement.

title: FILM REVIEW;Unexpected Branches On a Quest for Roots
description: For a couple of minutes in the midst of David O. Russell's sneaky, sidesplitting "Flirting With Disaster," Mel Coplin (Ben Stiller) finds himself the brother of tawny blond volleyball-playing twins. This happy if impermanent accident is nothing unusual for Mr. Russell's wonderfully mad odyssey of a movie, in which a man sets out to find his biological parents and winds up meeting more weirdos than Alice found down the rabbit hole.

title: Ex-Hamas Group Forms Nonviolent Party With Arafat Backing
description: A group of Islamic militants formerly associated with Hamas announced today that they had formed a new political party that shares Hamas's broad ideology but rejects the use of violence.

title: Buenos Aires Journal;On Every Argentine Cellblock, Specter of AIDS
description: Far too sick to be housed with other prisoners, Carlos was recently transferred to Unit 21 of Munoz Hospital, a high-security ward that cares for federal inmates with AIDS.

title: TENSION IN TAIWAN: THE POLEMICS;China Denounces U.S. 'Interference' in Dispute With Taiwan
description: China lashed out at the United States today, accusing Congress and the White House of meddling in Taiwan, and warning that the People's Liberation Army would "bury" American naval forces now in the Pacific if they came too close to China's coastline.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;An Abstractionist on Canvas, a Fantasist on Film
description: These days it's no surprise when artists try their hands at different media, from painting to performance to feature films. But in an earlier time, when divisions among branches of art were strictly enforced by critics and audiences, artists were expected to stick to their chosen materials; photography, in particular, was relegated to a low position in the conventional hierarchies of art.

title: Mrs. Clinton Responds in Travel Office Inquiry
description: In her first public statements under oath about the dismissals at the White House travel office, Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she knew little about events leading up to the firings in May 1993 and that her recollection of specifics was blunted by the passage of time.

title: Art in Review
description: Vija Celmins 'Night Sky Paintings and Drawings' McKee Gallery 745 Fifth Avenue, at 58th Street Through April 5

title: Inside Art
description: Keeping the Focus on Asia

title: Ruth Chinitz Uris, New York Philanthropist
description: Ruth Chinitz Uris, a New York philanthropist and chairwoman of the Uris Brothers Foundation, died on Tuesday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 86.

title: Isles Undone By Hat Trick
description: Florida's newest player, Ray Sheppard, scored three goals tonight to power the Panthers to their third straight victory, 3-2, over the Islanders. The hat trick was the second this season for Sheppard and the eighth of his career.

title: FILM REVIEW;Paris Through the Eyes Of a Boy in a Loincloth
description: Whatever may have been funny -- possibly nothing -- about the popular French comedy now named "Little Indian, Big City," American audiences can watch it vanish before their eyes.

title: Market Place;Apartments Are Sold as Co-ops Again
description: Signs that the cooperative apartment market is slowly gaining strength are prompting a large real estate firm to reopen sales at its buildings on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report yesterday about the killing of an Israeli soldier in Lebanon misstated the location of an anti-terrorism summit meeting last week. It was in Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, not Cairo.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;City's Investment Distinction
description: The city of Summit has become the only municipality in the country to receive the highest investment rating from three bond-rating agencies, its chief financial officer, Ronald J. Angelo, said yesterday. Mr. Angelo said Fitch Investors Service, Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corporation have all rated the city AAA. "We have a high-residential real estate value and a vibrant downtown business district, and 98.8 percent of our residents and businesses pay their taxes on time," said Walter D. Long, the Mayor of Summit. TERRY PRISTIN

title: The Wrong Issue in Bosnia
description: American troops are only three months into their peacekeeping mission in Bosnia and Europeans are already urging them to stay beyond the December withdrawal date set by President Clinton. Much civilian reconstruction work will remain to be done after December if there is to be a lasting peace in Bosnia, but that was known from the start. It is far from clear at this point that an extended American military presence is warranted. Opening that issue now serves no useful purpose and could even invite further delay in already lagging civilian efforts to reinforce the peace.

title: German Neo-Nazi Said to Kill 5
description: A 27-year-old extreme rightist who claimed to have murdered five people over nine months -- one of them a woman wearing a badge that said "Nazis out" -- was arrested today, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 29 about leap years, quoting Dr. Alan Hilfer, who coined the term "Brigadoon syndrome" to describe the confusion of people born on the extra day, misstated the location of Maimonides Medical Center, where he is a senior psychologist. It is in Brooklyn, not the Bronx.

title: Two Exchanges Post Rises In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions for short sales were at record levels on the New York Stock Exchange in the most recent period; the American Stock Exchange also reported a large rise in short interest.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABRAXAS PETROLEUM CORP., San Antonio, sold its interests in two Texas oilfields to an investment partnership for $15.6 million in cash and a 25 percent equity stake in the partnership. An Abraxas unit will be the general partner, and an investment group affiliated with State Street Research Energy Inc. will be the limited partner.

title: No Headline
description: We cannot have different standards and different laws in different parts of this state. We cannot have the death penalty in New York State except the Bronx."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;McDonald's Deal in Italy
description: The Cremonini Group of Italy said yesterday that it intended to sell its chain of 80 Burghy fast-food restaurants to the McDonald's Corporation. No terms were disclosed. The 80 restaurants will be converted to the McDonald's brand name, more than tripling the chain's presence in Italy. As part of the deal, the IN.AL.CA. unit of Cremonini will become a meat supplier to McDonald's in Italy, Cremonini said. (AP)

title: 2 Key Fund Managers to Leave John Hancock Organization
description: Two of the nation's best-performing equity mutual fund managers are leaving the John Hancock Funds, in a demonstration of how, in a booming market, top managers can write their own tickets.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: WEST;A Talent for Coaching, A Gift for Loquacity
description: He is Dick Vitale with a bench pass.

title: 2 Decisions Reflect Bitter Conflict Surrounding University AffirmativeAction Policies
description: At roughly the same time that a Federal appeals court was finishing work on a crushing ruling against affirmative action at the University of Texas, a seven-year Federal investigation was concluding that the aggressive affirmative-action program at the University of California at Berkeley was legal and did not discriminate against white students.

title: Gay Marriage Doesn't Open Door to Polyandry
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: Music Weekend Children's Museum of Manhattan 212 West 83d Street (212) 721-1223 Recommended for all ages Tomorrow and Sunday

title: British Beef Banned in France and Belgium
description: The scare over the safety of British beef took an international turn today as France and Belgium suspended the importation of British beef and cattle and Germany said it would press for a Europe-wide ban.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRODERBUND REPORTS OPERATING EARNINGS LOSS
description: Broderbund Software Inc. said operating profits dropped in the latest quarter, but that a one-time payment caused a sharp jump in net income. The company also announced plans to buy back as many as two million of its 21 million shares outstanding. Its shares rose to $41 in after-hours trading, up from its Nasdaq close of $37.875 and from Wednesday's close of $39.50. The company earned $18.8 million, or 87 cents a share, in the second quarter ended Feb. 29, including $15.5 million associated with its failed attempt to buy the Learning Company. Excluding the gain, profits were $9.6 million or 45 cents a share.

title: Engineers Needn't Fear Worker Influx
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Led Aid for Bosnian Army Is in Jeopardy
description: The American-led effort to train and equip the Bosnian Army is in serious danger of foundering because of the failure to attract financial support from either Western allies or oil-producing Muslim countries. It has also been undercut by the continuing refusal of the Bosnian Government to expel Iranian and other foreign fighters, as called for in the Dayton peace accords.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Stackhouse Disciplined
description: JERRY STACKHOUSE, the Philadelphia 76ers' star, was suspended for two games and fined $7,500 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for a fight with JEFF HORNACEK of Utah in a game on Wednesday night. Stackhouse, who leads rookies in scoring with 19 points a game, will miss games at the Los Angeles Clippers tonight and Seattle tomorrow.

title: House-Senate Committee Agrees On Overhaul of Farm Programs
description: A House and Senate panel reached agreement today on a major overhaul of America's farm programs, ending New Deal policies that pay farmers for certain crops when market prices fall and replacing them with a system of flat payments that would gradually decline over seven years.

title: World Bank Blocks U.S. Builders' Bids
description: The World Bank said today that because the United States had fallen behind on contributions, American contractors would be prevented from bidding on about $2.1 billion worth of contracts financed by other nations.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Bosnia Aid in Jeopardy

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Decorated Iraqi General Defects to Jordan
description: A former chief of staff in the Iraqi Army who directed the armed forces during the final three years of the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war has defected to Jordan, Jordanian officials said today.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL;State Tournament Pits Best Against Best
description: The New York State Federation Tournament, which begins today in Glens Falls, is a showdown among the girls' and boys' champions of the state Public High School Athletic Association, the New York City Public School Athletic League, the Catholic High School Athletic Association and the Alliance of Independent Schools.

title: U.S. Deficit Rises in Month
description: The United States budget deficit widened 15.5 percent in February from a year earlier as spending picked up after the Government resumed full operations following a three-week partial shutdown.

title: NYC;Sell WNYC? Not So Fast, Some Say
description: AS the script originally went, they should have been playing taps by now for WNYC-TV. Give it a proper burial, bow heads, say a few kind words and then get on with life. That was the idea, and, for the Giuliani administration, it still is.

title: NCAA TOURNAMENT: SOUTHEAST;Confident Marbury: He Wears It Well
description: There was one constant in Stephon Marbury's first and perhaps only season as a college basketball player. Whether his assist-to-turnover ratio was bordering on embarrassing in late December or his outstanding play was leading the Yellow Jackets to a regional semifinal for the first time in four years, there was only one face to show the world.

title: POLITICS: IN CONGRESS;Vote Is Pressed on Election Spending Bill
description: House backers of a bipartisan bill that would impose strict limits on Congressional campaign spending began collecting signatures today to force the legislation to a vote despite the hostility of Republican leaders.

title: POLITICS;Alaska High Court Orders Open Primaries
description: The Alaska Supreme Court has ordered a return to open primaries, rejecting the separate Republican primary as unconstitutional.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Newsweek Adds Election Campaign
description: Newsweek magazine said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Mezzina/Brown Inc. in New York by awarding the agency an assignment to create a print, direct mail and interactive advertising and promotional campaign focusing on Newsweek's coverage of the 1996 Presidential election. Spending on the campaign, which carries the theme "Now you know," was not disclosed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: General Motors and Union Agree to End 16-Day Strike Negotiators for G.M. and the United Automobile Workers agreed to end the industry's biggest work stoppage in a generation. One person close to the talks said the accord called for some additional hiring at two brake factories, and would give G.M. some flexibility to farm out work to nonunion suppliers.

title: BASEBALL;Mattingly Won't Suit Up for Yanks in '96
description: The familiar voice that emanated from the speaker phone in a conference room at Legends Field today added a layer of intrigue around the mystery man who used to be the most renowned Yankee. Don Mattingly surfaced in this odd manner and declared that he will not play baseball in 1996 and would rather rejoin the Yankees if he ever plays again.

title: U.S. Displeasure With Beijing
description: Washington withdrew an invitation to China's Defense Minister and informally extended the freeze on new financing of American business deals in China. Page 5.

title: The Old Children's Zoo Did More Than Educate
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts Groups Can Collaborate With Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE LARRY KING SHOW;Perot Asserts 'Propaganda' on His '92 Bid
description: Ross Perot asserted tonight that he had been the victim of a propaganda campaign after the 1992 Presidential election to make it appear that his third-party candidacy had handed the White House to President Clinton. And he denied that a repeat run this year would derail Republican efforts to unseat Mr. Clinton.

title: Jane Oppenheimer Dies at 84; Expert on Embryos and Space
description: Dr. Jane Marion Oppenheimer, a biologist and science historian whose interests ranged from embryos to the physiological effects of weightlessness in space, died on Tuesday at her home in Philadelphia after a brief illness. She was 84.

title: City Tries to Do Budget While Wearing a Blindfold
description: New York City's annual trudge toward a balanced budget has never been tidy. But this year, thanks to the continuing budget stalemates in Washington and Albany, the city's financial outlook is more disordered than anyone can remember, raising the prospect of increasingly late payments to city vendors and a 1997 budget plan riddled with even more gimmicks and guesswork than usual.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about plans by Tenneco Inc. to spin off its Newport News Shipbuilding unit referred incorrectly to the company's earnings goal. The company has said it wants to increase earnings per share by an average annual rate of 15 percent; it does not expect to earn $15 a share.

title: Judge in Dow Implant Bankruptcy Ousts Lawyers on Panel
description: In a stunning blow to the lawyers handling breast-implant injury claims against the Dow Corning Corporation, the judge overseeing the company's bankruptcy proceedings has ordered that the lawyers negotiating on behalf of women with implants be replaced with a new negotiating committee, made up of the women themselves.

title: Louisiana Stands Alone on Drinking at 18
description: People who live here call it the "low, flat nothin.' " It is the stretch of country due east of the refineries that light up the night around Beaumont, and due west of the vast rice fields on the Louisiana line. Interstate 10 runs dead straight for miles and miles through here, a lost highway decorated, here and there, with a stark, white cross.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOARD VOTES TO MAINTAIN ITS FIRST-QUARTER DIVIDEND
description: The board of Pacific Telesis Group voted yesterday to maintain its first-quarter dividend, surprising some analysts who believed the company would not make enough money to keep the payout at current levels. The board voted to keep its first-quarter dividend at 54.5 cents a share, or $2.18 a year. The dividend will be paid on May 1 to shareholders of record April 19. All week, analysts had been predicting that the company would be the first Baby Bell to cut its dividend since 1984, the year the AT&T Corporation was broken up. Pacific Telesis has been lagging behind the other Bells in earnings growth. That has resulted in an 89 percent dividend payout ratio, which has been chewing up the company's net income.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHECKFREE IN ACCORD TO ACQUIRE SECURITY APL
description: The Checkfree Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Security APL Inc. for about $50 million in stock. Checkfree, of Columbus, Ohio, a provider of electronic payment services, said the acquisition would provide its bank and brokerage customers with real-time updates on the value of their investments. Security APL had 1995 revenue of $15 million, while Checkfree posted revenue of $49.3 million. Robert E. Bowers, Checkfree's chief financial officer, said the company would add about 2.6 million new shares to the 32.18 million already outstanding. Last month, Checkfree acquired Servantis Systems Inc., a provider of electronic banking services, for $169 million in cash and stock.

title: Arts Groups Can Collaborate With Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Astronaut Is Killed
description: The pilot who commanded one the last successful flights of the space shuttle Challenger died Friday when the small test plane he was flying crashed.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Mandela 'Physically Fit,' Surgeon General Says
description: The Surgeon General reported on President Nelson Mandela's health today, and found the 77-year-old President "physically fit for a man of his age and remarkably active as well as, of course, mentally astute."

title: How the House Voted on Repeal of the Ban on Assault Weapons
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 239 to 173 by which the House of Representatives today voted to repeal the two-year-old ban on assault-style firearms. A "yes" vote is a vote to repeal the ban. Voting yes were 183 Republicans and 56 Democrats. Voting no were 42 Republicans, 130 Democrats and 1 independent. X denotes those not voting.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Morris Out of Jail
description: Pittsburgh Steelers running back BAM MORRIS was released from jail yesterday in Rockwall, Tex., following his arrest on charges of marijuana possession.

title: In a Writer's Physical Loss, The Miracle of Creativity
description: In the luminous title story of "Dancing After Hours," Andre Dubus's new collection of short stories, the men and women in a neighborhood bar in a small Massachusetts town share a long evening of such closeness and mutual understanding that it approaches an epiphany. The catalyst for this communion is a quadriplegic who has survived his own tragedy with an extraordinary sense of who he is and what it takes to bring diverse people together.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;France Is Limiting American Carriers
description: France's civil aviation authority said today that it had told six United States airlines that it would cut their landing rights at French airports this summer in retaliation for American restrictions on the state-owned carrier Air France.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Poet Defends Explicit Lecture
description: As dozens of parents expressed outrage over an explicit AIDS lecture she presented Wednesday to Hillsborough High School students, the poet River Huston, who learned she was H.I.V.-positive after her husband died of AIDS in 1990, said yesterday that she had received about 100 supportive telephone calls, mostly from students. Ms. Huston, 35, of New Hope, Pa., acknowledged that her presentation was blunt, but said it was necessary to get students' attention. JOE SHARKEY

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Trying to Rescue a Beloved Relic of the Past
description: Christopher Munch, who explored the relationship between John Lennon and Brian Epstein so hauntingly in "The Hours and Times," has much more arcane subject matter in mind this time. "Color of a Brisk and Leaping Day" is Mr. Munch's dreamy, intense and finally elusive look at the Yosemite Valley Railroad and at a young man who vows to save it from oblivion.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Fanny Mendelssohn Was Audacious, Too
description: Scholars and performers seeking the history of female composers have often lamented the comparative paucity of high quality pre-20th-century works that have survived, and they have been forced to set up some wobbly pillars as mileposts. Fanny Mendelssohn Hensel, Felix's sister, was one of those mileposts, and for many years her attractive but not especially compelling chamber works and songs had to stand for a largely unpopulated 19th century.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: EAST;Minutemen And Hoyas: An Enticing Matchup
description: Massachusetts versus Georgetown is the kind of matchup that Minutemen Coach John Calipari loves. Two talented teams battling it out, each with star players capable of taking over a game, and two passionate coaches who emphasize tenacious defense as a catalyst for their offenses.

title: Time Warner Settlement Urged
description: Chancellor William Allen of the Delaware Chancery Court urged Time Warner Inc., and U S West Inc. today to settle their legal dispute before he rules on it in June.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 4 about Meyer Schapiro, art critic and historian, misidentified the settlement house in Brownsville, Brooklyn, where he attended an evening art class. It was the Hebrew Educational Society, not the Hebrew Settlement House.

title: Bond Buyers Snatch Up Disney Notes
description: The Walt Disney Company sold $2.6 billion in debt yesterday, the largest bond offering ever by a top-grade company.

title: Man Kills Ex-Wife And Then Himself
description: A Manhattan doorman shot and killed his former wife and fatally shot himself today after she refused to give him the keys to her sports car, the Nassau County police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE HOCKEY

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Angry Tyson Claiming He Is Underpaid
description: MIKE TYSON launched a surprising, expletive-filled tirade yesterday that contrasted with the often religious public persona he had maintained during the first months of his comeback.

title: G.I. Killed in Crash
description: An American soldier was killed and another injured today in a vehicle accident in Bosnia, American officials said. The names were withheld pending notification of relatives.

title: New York City's TB Rate Falls, but Still Leads Nation
description: Even as the number of new tuberculosis cases fell in New York City in 1995 for the third straight year, the city's infection rate is still the highest in the nation, partly because the highly infectious disease is continuing to spread among recent immigrants, city health officials said yesterday.

title: Arts Groups Can Collaborate With Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: FIGURE SKATING;For Kwan, Maturity Invites Success
description: When Michelle Kwan of Los Angeles finished fourth at the 1995 world championships, her coach, Frank Carroll, decided the judges had sent a message to the 14-year-old figure skater:

title: Jury Rules Against Hospital For Negligent Care of Baby
description: A jury has ordered the New York City hospitals agency to pay $23.3 million to a boy who suffers from brain damage and extensive paralysis because of complications after his birth in 1988.

title: Auto Club Purchases
description: The Automobile Club of Southern California is acquiring sister not-for-profit clubs in Texas, New Mexico and Hawaii. A spokeswoman, Layna Browdy, said the deal had been approved by the club's board and by the board of the national American Automobile Association, which has run the Texas, New Mexico and Hawaii groups recently. Ms. Browdy would not disclose takeover details. The deal would give the Southern California club, the largest A.A.A. affiliate, with 4.2 million current members, potential to expand its insurance, travel and auto finance businesses in markets where its penetration is far lower than in California.

title: Woman in Albany Has Sextuplets
description: A woman who had taken fertility drugs gave birth today to six babies. They were three months premature but healthy.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Connecticut's Season Comes to an Abrupt Ending
description: Throughout the long night, one that from the start took on the dangerous appearance of the final night of Connecticut's season, Jim Calhoun screamed in hope more than anger. This time, his words were more of a plea than a command.

title: Dean Foods Presses Operations Review
description: The Dean Foods Company, a diversified food processor and distributor, said today that it was continuing a strategic review of all operating units and planned to report on this in the current quarter.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Massimino Interviews
description: Nostalgic for his days as a college basketball coach, ROLLIE MASSIMINO spent today at Division II Gannon University in Erie, Pa., to interview for the job left vacant by a fellow Division I alumnus, BOB DUKIET.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;N.C. State Coach Quits
description: Coach LES ROBINSON, who restored academic integrity to the North Carolina State basketball program but lost 50 of 64 Atlantic Coast Conference games the past four seasons, resigned yesterday. Robinson, 53, had one year remaining on his contract. (AP)

title: Colombia's Beleaguered Chief Hints at Calling Early Election
description: President Ernesto Samper, who has spent much of his presidency fending off accusations that Cali drug dealers financed his campaign, opened the way today for his resignation by raising the prospect of early elections, perhaps before the end of the year.

title: Port Authority Is Trying To Cut Police Overtime
description: New York City police officers walking the beat on 42d Street, and Port Authority officers on duty inside the Port Authority Bus Terminal, are separated by more than just a swinging door. According to figures from both agencies, the Port Authority officers are paid an average of $65,000 -- about $20,000 a year more than their city counterparts.

title: An Election Plan for Northern Ireland
description: Irish Republicans and Unionists alike have denounced the British Government's plan for elections leading to all-party talks on Northern Ireland. The process is complicated and ungainly, obviously contrived to appease all sides. But a careful appraisal will show that no party stands to lose from signing on to the British proposal. The most important goal -- now attainable -- is to sit down together to start negotiating a future for Northern Ireland.

title: Stock Market Revives a Bit, With Dow Rising by 9.76
description: Stock prices advanced yesterday for the first time since Monday, after investors weighed the week's Government statistics and concluded that the economy was expanding moderately.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BWAY SIGNS AGREEMENT TO PURCHASE MILTON CAN
description: The BWAY Corporation of Atlanta signed an agreement yesterday to buy the privately held Milton Can Company. BWAY said Milton Can's shareholders would receive about $30 million in about equal portions of cash and BWAY stock, and BWAY would assume existing Milton Can debt. Milton Can, which has operations in New Jersey and Massachusetts, had sales of about $60 million last year, while BWAY had sales of about $250 million, it said. BWAY makes steel containers.

title: Unruly Bunch of Moderates;New Jersey Republicans Walk a Delicate Line
description: Representative Bob Franks of New Jersey considers himself a good Republican -- he used to be the party's state chairman -- but his smile soured and his tongue unlatched one recent morning when he discussed a rumor he had just heard: that the House Republican leadership wanted to kill the Federal assault weapons ban, popular in New Jersey, as part of the antiterrorism bill.

title: Undercover Agent Killed in Drug Operation
description: An F.B.I. agent trying to buy drugs in an undercover operation was fatally shot along with a suspect in the agent's car today, the authorities said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;AIDS Test for Suspect Upheld
description: A Somerset County Superior Court judge yesterday upheld a 1994 state law allowing rape victims to demand AIDS testing of accused attackers. The ruling involves Philip Riley, whose wife died of AIDS and who was charged with raping a female roommate in January. Judge Leonard N. Arnold said that the circumstances of the case were compelling enough to support the request for a blood test.

title: White House Snubs China Over Military Maneuvers
