description: The Administration signaled its displeasure with China on two fronts today, calling off a long-awaited visit to Washington by China's Defense Minister and informally extending the freeze on new financing of American business deals in China.

title: POLITICS: THE CONVENTION;Parallel Agonizing Over Immigration
description: Just as the Presidential primaries have often made the Republicans look like two opposing parties struggling within one body, this glittering seaside city on the Mexican border, where the Republicans will hold their convention in August, often feels like two deeply conflicting communities, one of anger, one of hope.

title: Taiwan Votes for President And Celebrates Democracy
description: After a nightlong celebration of their extraordinary march to democracy, millions of voters flooded more than 12,500 polling stations today to select their president for the first time by popular ballot.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Unruffled Amid Wild Rhythms Of Bartok
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center tends to keep the most ornery contemporary music off its main subscription series. But Tuesday night's concert at Alice Tully Hall began with a performance of Bartok's Sonata for Violin and Piano No. 2 that made this 1922 work sound as cutting-edge as anything written since.

title: Skating Rates With Viewers
description: ABC's telecast of the world figure skating championships from Edmonton, Alberta, on Thursday night drew a higher rating than CBS's broadcast of the regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament. The figure skating, which featured the men's finals competition won by the American Todd Eldredge, generated a 10.1 Nielsen rating during the 8-11 P.M. time period, compared with the 8.8 netted by CBS's games. NBC's prime-time lineup finished first in the evening's race, with a 17.3 rating.

title: Observer;The Market God
description: Why is it that people who praise "downsizing" for its salubrious effect on the economy are invariably people in no danger of being "downsized" themselves?

title: HOUSE APPROVES REPEALING OF BAN ON ASSAULT GUNS
description: After an abrupt two-day campaign, House Republicans voted today to repeal the 1994 ban on the manufacture of 19 semiautomatic weapons and high-capacity ammunition clips. The repeal passed by a comfortable margin of 239 to 173, but Democrats warned that the decision would haunt its supporters in November, even though the Senate was unlikely to act.

title: In Princeton, No Room for Illiterates
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Marriage, an Oxymoron
description: As study after study and victim after victim testify to the social devastation of the sexual revolution, easy divorce and out-of-wedlock motherhood, marriage is fashionable again. And parenthood has transformed many baby boomers into advocates of bourgeois norms.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EXIDE SAYS RUMORS OF F.B.I. INVESTIGATION ARE FALSE
description: The Exide Corporation said yesterday that rumors the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating the company were "totally false and without foundation." A spokesman for the company, a battery maker in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., said the rumor apparently started when the company's chief financial officer told several analysts yesterday about an F.B.I. investigation into an inventory loss at its plant in Greer, S.C. Exide's stock dropped $4.25, or 14 percent, to $26.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. When its stock started falling, the company learned that some on Wall Street misunderstood the situation and incorrectly thought Exide itself was being investigated, the spokesman said. In fact, he said, the company is the victim.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INDENET INC. , Los Angeles, agreed to buy Enterprise Systems Group Ltd., a privately held British media concern, for about $26 million in cash, stock and a promissory note.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VETERINARY CENTERS TO PURCHASE PET PRACTICE
description: Veterinary Centers of America Inc. said yesterday that it had a definitive agreement to buy Pet Practice Inc. in a deal worth more than $86 million, creating the nation's largest chain of veterinary hospitals. The deal would expand Veterinary Centers' operations to more than 150 veterinary hospitals in 19 states, with combined revenues of about $200 million. The stock of Veterinary Centers, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., gained $3.125, to $28.875, while Pet Practice rose 87.5 cents, to $9.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Orel Journal;Art Bares The Gulag; Russians Look Away
description: In a rickety basement artist's studio, Nikolai Getman, 78, keeps his public work, bland portraits of Siberian natives and flowery still lifes, on open display. Stacked along the top shelves lie dozens of canvases devoted to his secret life -- bleak, haunting oil paintings of life in Stalinist labor camps in Siberia, where Mr. Getman was sent in 1948 and where he spent eight years.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Freud, Jung and Sabina: Analysis of a Triangle
description: In the dawn of psychoanalysis, Sigmund Freud was always on the alert for new disciples, especially those who would expand acceptance of his controversial theories. One such early convert was the Swiss psychiatrist Carl Jung, who had had some success with "the talking cure" with a young patient named Sabina Spielrein, with whom Jung may or may not have had an affair but who certainly became intricately involved with both men.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to remove the Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, from a murder case misstated the position of the Erie County District Attorney, Kevin Dillon, in some editions. He did not support the decision.

title: Trenton and I.R.S. Settle State Pension Fund Issue
description: New Jersey officials announced today that they had reached an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service over the state's public pension system, averting the possibility of costly litigation and the need to put additional money into the pension fund.

title: Milk Sours the Farm Bill
description: A House-Senate conference committee has managed to tarnish the most important farm bill in years by inserting a last-minute provision for a New England milk cartel that would gouge consumers and violate the free-market concept that has made the 1996 farm bill worthwhile. The full House and Senate need to excise this noxious favor to the New England dairy lobby before approving the bill in voting set for next week.

title: Novels of Kobo Abe As Subjects of Film
description: Three films based on novels by the writer Kobo Abe, directed by Hiroshi Teshigahara and scored by Toru Takemitsu, are to be shown tomorrow at the Miller Theater, Broadway at 116th Street. The screenings will open a series devoted to the Japanese writer at Columbia University.

title: Sports of The Times;For Calhoun, One More Bad Memory
description: THERE was heartache this time, if no last-second heartbreak. You could see it in Jim Calhoun's eyes, hear it in his voice, even as it spun into earnest damage control.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN RADIO TO BUY HENRY BROADCASTING
description: The American Radio Systems Corporation, which is based in Boston, has agreed to acquire the Henry Broadcasting Company of San Francisco for about $115 million, which includes the assumption of debt. Both companies operate radio stations. American Radio said late on Thursday that it would exchange common stock valued at about $64 million and would also pay cash and assume debt. The closely held Henry Broadcasting owns and operates nine stations in Portland, Ore.; Sacramento, Calif.; Fresno, Calif., and in Omaha. American Radio owns or operates 15 FM and 9 AM stations in cities including Boston, Baltimore, Hartford and Austin, Tex.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Broken Hill Profit Was Off in 3d Quarter
description: Broken Hill Proprietary Company, Australia's largest publicly traded company, reported a third-quarter profit that was much lower than expected. The company said profit in the three months that ended on Feb. 29 dropped 31 percent, to 223 million Australian dollars ($173.2 million), against analysts' expectations of 350 million Australian dollars.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;120 Losing Bakery Jobs
description: About 120 workers at the Totowa bakery that makes Thomas's English Muffins will be out of work by the end of the year. "We are consolidating muffin production in the East," Tom DiPiazza, a spokesman for CPC International Inc., the bakery's owner, said yesterday. About 175 non-baking jobs will remain at the site, he said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Layoffs for Police Officers
description: The township sent layoff notices yesterday to 81 of its 154 police officers, effective May 10, and said that 16 firefighters would also be laid off. "It's going to be bad for the community to have a shortage of cops and firemen," said Councilman Anthony T. Blasi. "We're short of money."

title: Arts Groups Can Collaborate With Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: STANDOFF IN WESTCHESTER: THE GUNMAN;Spasm of Gunfire Brought a Man's Troubled Life to a Dismal End
description: With a prayer for forgiveness scrawled on the wall and his funeral clothes neatly laid out, a troubled young man with an arsenal of weapons was found dead in his Westchester County home at dawn yesterday, ending a terrifying, 14-hour siege in which he turned a quiet suburb into a battleground, murdered a police officer by ambush and then killed his grandmother, his dog and himself.

title: Pataki's Secrets
description: Shortly after taking office, Gov. George Pataki closed off the second floor of the State Capitol where he and his aides have their offices. The act frustrated a press corps and public used to wandering freely around the floor. Worse, it has become the symbol of an administration that shutters itself from view.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Guinness Stock Buyback
description: Guinness P.L.C. said yesterday that it was buying back 100 million common shares, or about 4.3 percent of its stock. The stock was up 5.5 pence at 466 on the London Stock Exchange. The Guinness chairman, Tony Greener, said the buyback was consistent with the company's policy of increasing returns to shareholders. The company increased its dividends 8 percent on Thursday. Guinness brands include Guinness Stout, Johnnie Walker and Bell's Scotch whisky and Gordon's gin. (AP)

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Chechen Casualties High
description: Russian aircraft and artillery pounded villages throughout Chechnya today, trying to stamp out rebel resistance, and casualties on both sides appeared to be high.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Cowboys Sign Thomas
description: The Dallas Cowboys announced yesterday the signing of the free-agent linebacker BRODERICK THOMAS, formerly of the Minnesota Vikings. The 6-foot-4-inch, 242-pound outside linebacker had 86 tackles last season for the Vikings, with 6 sacks. The 29-year-old will probably replace DIXON EDWARDS. (AP)

title: The General Motors Strike
description: Although the 18-day strike at two General Motors plants in Dayton, Ohio, ended Friday, the issues that provoked it will resurface this summer when the time comes for the United Automobile Workers to renegotiate its contracts with the Big Three auto makers. The practice of "outsourcing," which allows a manufacturer to buy component parts from outside contractors, is seen by the U.A.W. as a grave threat to its members. By buying from companies that pay lower wages, either in the United States or abroad, a manufacturer can save millions. G.M. makes more of its own parts than either Ford or Chrysler, but it believes that increased outsourcing is vital to its competitiveness.

title: Big Cocaine Cache Is Found Stashed in Airliner Cockpit
description: Illegal drugs have long been smuggled into the United States in the baggage carried by commercial airliners or in condoms swallowed by passengers. But this week, nearly 65 pounds of cocaine was discovered hidden inside the cockpit of an American Airlines jetliner traveling from Denver to Dallas.

title: HOCKEY;A Night That Brodeur Would Rather Forget
description: For Martin Brodeur, the goaltender who led the Devils to the Stanley Cup last season, this was a night to remember and forget.

title: Unexpectedly, the Clintons Are Skewered at a Dinner
description: When the Radio-Television Correspondents Association invited Don Imus, the WFAN radio morning man in New York, to be the after-dinner speaker at its annual gala on Thursday night in Washington, members knew how uninhibited his barbs could be. And how well informed; Mr. Imus is as well known for being obsessed with politics as for being a so-called shock jock.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Romania Bans Currency Deals by Foreign Banks
description: The Romanian central bank stripped two more large foreign banks of their licenses to trade currencies today, shocking foreign investors here and harming the Government's efforts to create an image of stable economic management.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about Senator Bob Dole's call to resurrect plans for a national missile defense system referred incorrectly to the history of such a system. None has ever been built.

title: POP REVIEW;Surviving and Soaring Over Life
description: Never teach your kids to play their first song in a minor key," Steve Earle said on Thursday night at Tramps. "It will mess them up for life."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: SHOWDOWN AT G.M. LEAVES BIG ISSUES STILL UNRESOLVED
description: Workers began returning to two General Motors brake factories this afternoon, ending their 17-day strike with local disputes resolved but not critical national issues between the company and the United Automobile Workers.

title: INSIDE
description: Crown Heights Reversal

title: STANDOFF IN WESTCHESTER: THE OFFICER;'Horrible Loss' of an Earnest Policeman
description: If somebody calls about a raccoon in his yard, the Eastchester Police Department is there. If someone calls with stomach pains, the department is there. If an elderly person falls out of bed and has trouble getting up, Eastchester police will be there ("two-minute response time," officers say proudly).

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WEST;Syracuse Hits the Shot; Arizona Doesn't
description: The mood swings could be life altering.

title: POLITICS: CAMPAIGN NOTEBOOK;Buchanan Bags 'Bobster' the Parrot Aide
description: The Bobster's disappearance is a mystery no more.

title: Economic Data Show Big Jump In Job Creation in New Jersey
description: New Jersey gained a significant number of new jobs last month, and the state's unemployment rate declined slightly, according to economic data released today.

title: Arts Groups Can Collaborate With Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: In Princeton, No Room for Illiterates
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE REVIEW;Nightmares Of Fanatics And Jungles
description: Federico Restrepo's Puppets and Drummers Dance Theater includes human beings as well as puppets. And many instruments, in addition to drums, were heard in the taped collage that accompanied "Aguirre, the Spiral of the Warrior," which the troupe from Bogota, Colombia, presented on Thursday night at La Mama.

title: DANCE REVIEW;From Bali, a Universe Where Upheaval Hides Beneath the Harmony
description: For many Westerners, Balinese music and dance are fluid, lyrical expressions of a harmonious universe. That impression owes something to the silvery beauty of the sound of the gamelan, the assemblage of instruments on which Balinese music is performed. But a close listening to this richly layered music reveals that dramatic changes of rhythm and texture play an important role in the scores. And that sense of vivid, sometimes comic upheaval was very much a part of a program by the Dancers and Musicians of Bali on Thursday night at Town Hall.

title: For 4 Whites Who Sued University, Race Is the Common Thread
description: One is now the manager of a Relax the Back store in suburban Dallas. Another returned to her accounting job, a third went back to a work as a financial analyst with the state insurance department of Texas. And the fourth actually did go to law school, but not at the University of Texas.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Europeans Let Britain Review Drug Concern Bid
description: The European Commission yesterday gave British authorities the power to review Gehe A.G.'s proposed acquisition of Lloyds Chemists P.L.C., raising the likelihood that the British drug wholesaler could remain independent. Britain's Department of Trade and Industry, which referred an earlier bid by Unichem P.L.C. to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission, said it was seeking to "properly assess the competition consequences of the merger." Gehe is a unit of Franz Haniel & Cie.

title: Partisan Judge-Bashing
description: President Clinton appears to have disowned a threat to seek the resignation of Federal Judge Harold Baer unless the judge reverses his controversial decision to suppress evidence in a pending drug case. The White House, in a clarification (read damage control), now says the matter should be resolved in the courts.

title: Safe and Unleaded
description: Watch out, New York. The New York City Council is considering a new law aimed at protecting children from lead poisoning that will likely hurt more than help. It would divert tens of millions of dollars from basic school maintenance and may well worsen the very problem it's intended to prevent.

title: In Italy, Corruption Scandal's Sweeping Spotlight Turns to Judiciary
description: In the old days, when corruption in Italy was an open secret everywhere but in the courts, Rome's judges and prosecutors were collectively known as the "gateway to the fog," a poetic way of describing a judicial black hole where touchy cases were sent to vanish.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SALEM SAYS IT WILL NO LONGER SEEK BIDS FOR THE COMPANY
description: The Salem Corporation, which manufactures equipment for use in the coal and metals industries, said yesterday that it would no longer seek bids for the company. The concern, based in Pittsburgh, said that it had terminated its contract with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation and that it had told the special negotiating committee and its counsel to cease activities. Salem said it had received no firm offers, though discussions with potential acquirers would continue. Salem also said inquiries from "financially responsible" bidders would be welcomed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Britain's Problem With Beef Is Good News to Argentines
description: With the ban against British beef spreading through Europe and to other parts of the world, Argentina was almost euphoric today over the prospect that its beef exports could rise sharply this year.

title: In Princeton, No Room for Illiterates
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Sues Mine Companies Over Pollution Across Idaho
description: The Justice Department filed suit today demanding that several big mining companies pay for environmental damage across a huge swath of Idaho where toxic wastes from mining and smelting have polluted lakes, streams, groundwater and wetlands over the course of a century.

title: STANDOFF IN WESTCHESTER: THE OVERVIEW;From a Bully in the Schoolyard To a Sniper in a Quiet Suburb
description: Even when he was young, his neighbors knew that Richard Sacchi Jr. was trouble, someone they had best stay away from.

title: Tribunal Files First Charges In War Crimes Against Serbs
description: The United Nations' criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia today issued its first indictments for crimes against Serbs, charging three Bosnian Muslims and a Bosnian Croat with murdering, torturing and raping Serbian prisoners at a detention camp in 1992.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Softbank Raises Stake in Yahoo!
description: The Softbank Corporation, a Japanese computer software distributor, will increase its investment in Yahoo! Inc., an Internet search engine company.

title: Attorney General's Team Takes Over Bonx Case
description: A team of prosecutors from Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco's office took control today of the grand jury investigation into the killing of a police officer in the Bronx, even as civil rights groups prepared to fight Gov. George E. Pataki's decision to remove District Attorney Robert T. Johnson from the case.

title: Journal;The Fat Book Thing
description: For those who love to hate them, Bill and Hillary Clinton are and always have been deceitful and hypocritical users, devoid of principles and class. Harsh charges, but even if true, do they amount to an indictable offense? So the press and public have been wondering for four years now -- back to March 8, 1992, when Jeff Gerth of The Times broke the Whitewater story. Whitewater, incredibly enough, has not only demonstrated longer staying power than Watergate, but it has now outlasted by several months America's involvement in World War II.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Peter Sellars Evokes an Operatic Bach
description: Curiosity reigned at the second of Dawn Upshaw's "Voices of the Spirit" concerts at the 92d Street Y, on Wednesday evening, as to how Peter Sellars would stage one of Bach's most introverted cantatas, "Mein Herze schwimmt im Blut" ("My Heart Swims in Blood," BWV 199). In the end the answer was simple: He made it stagey.

title: Beliefs
description: On Monday, a New York City police officer, Gary Lemite, stood in the pulpit of St. William the Abbot Roman Catholic Church in Seaford, L.I., and called on a prosecutor to seek the death penalty. "Do the right thing," he said directly to District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx, who was sitting in the front of the church.

title: Scottish Pupils, if Not Parents, Return With Good Spirits
description: The students of Dunblane Primary School returned to class today, their spirits seemingly undaunted by a gunman's rampage that ended in the deaths of 16 fellow pupils and a teacher 10 days ago.

title: Judges as Political Issues
description: The quadrennial judge-bashing season was proceeding nicely, as Republican Presidential challengers outdid one another in their professed eagerness to save the country from liberal judges, when the Clinton Administration suddenly did the unexpected. It stepped on the Republicans' lines.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WOMEN;Newcomer Is Trying to Crash Elite's Party
description: For Connecticut, it can be one more step toward winning its second straight national championship. For San Francisco, it is an opportunity to crash the elite level of women's basketball and prove that its upset victories over Florida and Duke last weekend were no flukes.

title: Who Benefits by New Jersey Income Tax Cut?
description: To the Editor:

title: Christopher, Visiting Russia, Hints at Support for Yeltsin
description: After a week of warning Russians that a vote for the Communists could isolate them from the rest of Europe, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, in Moscow today, tried to give a gentle boost to the re-election chances of President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;A Terrorist Betrayed by Love
description: When Chen Lin-Lang (Vicky Wei), the embittered protagonist of the Taiwanese film "Heartbreak Island," is first seen, she is serving the final days of a 10-year prison sentence for committing terrorist acts against the Government.

title: Long-Term Forecast for Taiwan Remains Upbeat
description: Marinus van Gessel, an American, has been here for 21 years, running a small but thriving import company, and business has never been better.

title: State Faults Agency's Inaction In Overseeing Foster Children
description: A state audit has concluded that New York City's child welfare agency has done practically nothing in recent years to improve its oversight of thousands of children in foster care, leading to inadequate treatment for children and to tens of millions of dollars in state-imposed penalties.

title: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;Echo of Gunshots Past as House Votes
description: This is Scott Phillips, my 17-year-old son," the mother suddenly said to a stranger, introducing her son as if he were still alive.

title: Suspect in '91 Crown Heights Death Faces Trial as an Adult
description: Reversing his earlier decision, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that Lemrick Nelson Jr., the man charged with violating the civil rights of a Hasidic scholar killed during the Crown Heights violence in 1991, is to be tried as an adult rather than a juvenile.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Union Warning at Rutgers
description: After months of threats that a delay in contract negotiations could lead to a job action, a new warning was issued yesterday by the American Association of University Professors, which represents 2,400 full-time and 1,700 part-time teachers at Rutgers University. The union's executive council said it voted to "prepare" for a one-day job action after it consults next week with three unions representing additional Rutgers employees.

title: Lower Bids Seen At Sale of Rights To Pollute Air
description: The price of permits for coal-fired utility plants to pollute the air is expected to dip to its lowest level yet when the Chicago Board of Trade announces on Tuesday the results of the annual auction it runs for the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: BASEBALL;Brogna May Be Ready For the Mets' Opener
description: Butch Huskey's switch to right field received another nudge today when the Mets' incumbent first baseman, Rico Brogna, received such an encouraging medical report that he might be available for the season opener in 10 days.

title: Who Benefits by New Jersey Income Tax Cut?
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Niagara Player Has Leukemia
description: Niagara point guard Ronnell Felton has been diagnosed with leukemia and is undergoing treatment in his home state of Virginia, Coach Jack Armstrong said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STOCK OF HILTON HOTELS SHOWS SHARP INCREASE
description: The stock of the Hilton Hotels Corporation shot up yesterday after Stephen F. Bollenbach, the chief executive, told The Wall Street Journal, that he did not intend to split Hilton into separate hotel and casino companies. Instead, he will concentrate on adding hotel rooms. Hilton shares were up $4.875, or 5 percent, at $97.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Bollenbach is a longtime hotel-casino executive who quit as Disney's finance chief to run Hilton last month. Before his appointment Hilton's shares were trading in the mid-$70's. Since then, they have traded as high as $99.625 on hopes that Mr. Bollenbach, the first outsider to run Hilton, will energize the company, which was long under family control.

title: British Beef Sales Plunge as Germany and Italy Join Import Ban
description: More countries imposed bans on British beef today as fears that it might be unsafe spread beyond Europe, while at home a widespread consumer boycott gathered force.

title: Shuttle Blasts Off, but Hydraulic Leak May Curtail Flight
description: With an explosion of daylight in the dark of night, the space shuttle Atlantis rocketed into orbit early today on a flight to link up with the Russian space station Mir, the third such mission in less than a year.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Rebound in Spirit But Fall Short in Points
description: There was no quit in the Nets tonight. Nor, as usual, were there enough points.

title: THEATER REVIEW;5 Puffs on a Semantic Exploding Cigar
description: An urgent warning to New York theatergoers: if you are planning to attend "No One Will Be Immune," the evening of short David Mamet plays at the Ensemble Studio Theater, do not -- repeat, do not -- schedule any activities involving conversation for at least two hours after the performance.

title: 11 - Year Sentence for Lawyer in Drug Case
description: An Upper West Side lawyer was sentenced to 11 years and 3 months in prison yesterday for taking part in what officials described as one of the largest money-laundering operations ever uncovered in New York City, a ring that hid tens of millions of dollars in drug profits for the Cali cocaine cartel.

title: BASEBALL;Cone Takes a Minor Detour
description: The cold metal bleachers along the first-base line at the Engelbert Complex were barren at 10 A.M. today, except for the dozen or so spectators who stumbled out of bed to watch David Cone pitch in a Class AAA exhibition game. Was this the proper setting for the highest-paid pitcher in baseball history? It was today.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST;Pass ... Pass ... Shoot Vs. Pass! Pass! Shoot!
description: Anthony Epps mulled it over, the idea of Kentucky having to tussle with Louisville for the Midwest Regional crown rather than with Wake Forest.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Where Fame Hasn't Had Its 15 Minutes
description: After "Natural Born Killers" and "To Die For," Hollywood may have come to a temporary halt in satirizing the lust for television celebrity. How much further could it go? Meanwhile, film makers from other countries have taken up the cause. But if Marcelo Pineyro's exuberantly romantic movie "Wild Horses" is any indication, the rest of the world is more than a decade behind American cinema in its attitude toward fame and media circuses. Outside the United States, total cynicism has yet to set in.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RESOURCE MORTGAGE TO SELL UNIT TO DOMINION CAPITAL
description: Resource Mortgage Capital Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its single-family mortgage operations to Dominion Capital Inc. for $67 million. Resource Mortgage, based in Glen Allen, Va., a real estate investment trust, said the operations were Saxon Mortgage Inc., which issues single-family mortgages, and Meritech Mortgage Services Inc., a mortgage-servicing concern. Dominion Capital is the financial services subsidiary of Dominion Resources Inc., a Richmond-based utility holding company.

title: It's a New Era On Jewish Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: Lufthansa in Accord With Air Canada
description: Lufthansa A.G. said today that it had an agreement with Air Canada to cooperate on international flights beginning June 15.

title: The New King of the Ski Moguls;Demand for Capital Forces Industry Into Consolidation
description: Leslie B. Otten began his ski career schussing the slopes of the Catskills aboard Army-surplus skis. Outfitted in galoshes and three layers of corduroy pants, he reveled in the thrill of the sport -- and in the special status he achieved among his second-grade classmates in Teaneck, N.J., when he showed up with a windburn on Monday morning.

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Dole Toe to Toe, but Side by Side, With Clinton
description: Trying to distinguish himself from President Clinton, Senator Bob Dole came to this dusty border town today and declared his support for a measure to allow states to deny public education to children who are illegal immigrants.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Loan Defaults at Schools
description: Trade schools with one-year programs have the highest rate of student loan defaults in New Jersey, the Federal Education Department said yesterday. For years, critics have said that some trade schools market heavily to poor and minority youths, but fail to place many graduates in jobs. The schools with the highest default rates for the 1993 fiscal year were: Drake College of Business, Elizabeth (51 percent); Empire Technical School, East Orange (40.5 percent); Natural Motion Institute of Hair Design, Jersey City (33.1 percent); Boardwalk and Marina Casino Dealers School of Atlantic City (33 percent); Capri Institute of Hair Design, Brick Township, and Concorde School of Hair Design, Ocean Township (both 32.3 percent).

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Water Tests Set in Toms River
description: Starting on Thursday, water from 17 public schools, 5 private schools and several municipal wells in the Toms River section of Dover Township will be tested for cancer-causing contaminants, the State Health Department said yesterday. The tests were prompted by an increased incidence of brain and central nervous system cancers among children in the area.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Hospital Groups Ready Suit
description: As millions of dollars in unpaid bills for charity care piled up, New Jersey hospital groups said yesterday that they intended to sue the state to force reimbursement, The Associated Press reported. For three months, hospitals have gone without payments for charity care as the Legislature and the Whitman administration argued over how to continue financing it. Details of the hospitals' suit will be announced Monday, said Gary Carter, president of the New Jersey Hospitals Association. The New Jersey Hospital Alliance, which represents 21 urban hospitals, will join in the suit, said its head, Sister Jane Brady.

title: Rice Advances to Final
description: In a game between New York City's Catholic and public high school champions, Rice of Manhattan, inspired by a full-court press in the third quarter, handed Erasmus Hall of Brooklyn a 92-74 defeat tonight in the Class A semifinals of the New York High School Federation tournament at the Civic Center.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in some editions of the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about the J. C. Penney Company's expansion plans misstated the timing. The company plans to open 100 stores and close 50 to 60 stores in the next three years, not in 1996 alone.

title: About New York;Heavy Fantasy In the 'Bronx' Of a New Film
description: NO stand-ins!" trumpet the ads for "Rumble in the Bronx," the Jackie Chan fist-and-foot-fest, which hovers in the Top 10 box office draws. Mr. Chan does his own stunts, which is impressive and dangerous. Yet in the movie's biggest stunt, he chickened out and used a stand-in.

title: A Civil Action' Wins Critics' Award
description: A Civil Action," Jonathan Harr's account of a legal battle between a group of Massachusetts families and two large corporations, was named the best nonfiction book of 1995 by the National Book Critics Circle.

title: Corrections
description: The Home Video column yesterday misstated the telephone number of Movies Unlimited, a mail order company in Philadelphia. It is (800) 523-0823.

title: In a Surprise, President of Moody's Rating Agency Resigns
description: In a surprise move, John A. Bohn Jr. yesterday announced his resignation as president of Moody's Investors Service Inc., one of the top credit rating agencies. Mr. Bohn will step down on April 1; no successor has been named.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Alitalia Is Near the Edge of a Fiscal Crisis
description: Alitalia needs a bailout this spring or risks not being able to pay salaries, according to Domenico Cempella, the executive appointed last month to save Italy's ailing national carrier.

title: Passion in the Autumn
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: The game's most dramatic world championship occurred in Bermuda in 1975. The Italian players included Giorgio Belladonna and Benito Garozzo, survivors from the great Blue Team, and Arturo Franco and Vito Pittala. With 26 deals left, the Italian victory streak seemed over: North America led by 56 imps.

title: Corrections
description: The heading of a report in the Company News column in some editions of Business Day yesterday, about the second-quarter results of Broderbund Software Inc., misstated the company's operating result. Operating earnings declined; the company did not report a loss in operating earnings.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Workers Return to G.M., But Issues Are Unresolved Workers began returning to two General Motors plants, ending their 17-day strike without resolving critical issues between the company and the United Automobile Workers union. While a few local disputes were resolved, the national issues are sure to come up again this summer when the U.A.W.'s three-year national contract expires.

title: Leslie T. Young, Legislator, 65
description: State Representative Leslie T. Young, who served in a district covering New Canaan and Wilton since 1984, died on Thursday. He was 65.

title: Whitewater Focus Shifts to Possible Perjury
description: The Whitewater independent counsel received formal legal authority today to investigate whether a former Presidential aide lied about Hillary Rodham Clinton's role in the White House travel office affair.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Achille Lauro Killer Recaptured in Spain
description: The Palestinian hijacker convicted in the 1985 murder of an American tourist aboard the Achille Lauro cruise ship was recaptured in southern Spain today, three weeks after he disappeared during a "good conduct" leave from an Italian prison.

title: Essex County's Residency Rule Faces Setback
description: A judge dealt a setback today to an attempt by the Essex County Executive to require employees of the county to live within its borders.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hong Kong Company Gets Sweetened Offer
description: South China Morning Post Ltd. raised its takeover offer yesterday for TVE Ltd. to fend off a rival bid. South China Morning Post, vying with Shaw Brothers (Hong Kong) Ltd. for control of TVE, a Hong Kong media company, increased its share offer and introduced a cash alternative for TVE shareholders.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST USA UNIT'S SHARES UP SHARPLY IN INITIAL TRADING
description: Shares of First USA Inc.'s payment-processing unit closed significantly above the offering price in their first trading day on expectations that the subsidiary will benefit from the soaring use of credit cards for everyday purchases. The sale of the stock of First USA Paymentech Inc. comes amid skyrocketing card use by Americans. Credit card debt rose 23 percent last year, to $416 billion, from $337 billion in 1994, the Federal Reserve estimates. First USA Paymentech is the nation's third-biggest payment processor. Shares of First USA Paymentech closed at $30.625 in trading of 4.8 million shares. First USA Inc., First USA Paymentech's parent, sold 5.1 million shares at $21 to raise $107 million. The sale represents a 16 percent stake.

title: No Headline
description: The evil that came to Dunblane last week is gone. This is a very important day for us because it marks the beginning of our recovery -- and I do mark my words, we will recover."

title: WEDDINGS;Rebecca Cohen, Andres Martin
description: Rebecca Anne Cohen, a daughter of Dr. Phyllis Cohen and Dr. Donald Cohen of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married there today to Dr. Andres Martin, the son of Marta Gutmann de Martin of Mexico City and the late Maximilliano Michel Martin. Rabbi Albert Feldman is to perform the ceremony at the B'nai Jacob Synagogue.

title: Random Objects of Desire
description: THE END OF ALICE By A. M. Homes. 270 pp. New York: Scribner. $22. WHAT can you say about a 19-year-old girl who likes to chew on fresh scabs from the knee of a 12-year-old boy? What can you say about a love story that begins in jail and ends in murder and stops off at various depraved stations along the way? Is the wish to defy the status quo -- pater le bourgeois -- a valid artistic urge and, if it is, under what circumstances? Is the value of shock more or less important in an age that professes to be unshockable?

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Diary column last Sunday about new Internet services misstated the name of the AT&T Corporation's service. It is Worldnet, not Networld.

title: SCIENCE;Gutting, Stuffing and Studying Since 1982
description: Liz Graham, humming a tune, sticks a finger up into her blue jay's skull, lets his soft skin drape around her hand like a cap and wiggles him like a puppet. Across the lab table, Leslie Johnson hastens to set the record straight. "We're not a bunch of weird people who wish Halloween went on all year," she says. "We are good people doing a public service."

title: Canadian Mounties Accused of Failing to Protect Their Man
description: In his scarlet tunic, blue breeches with a yellow stripe and wide-brimmed hat, the Mountie has long been a symbol of Canada. But these days, that figure of fortitude and rectitude who always gets his man is likely -- at least in the nation's irreverent press -- to wear the face of Mickey Mouse.

title: Taiwan's Democratic Election
description: Yesterday's presidential election in Taiwan was an affirmation of democracy, but not a declaration of independence. It is important that the leaders of Taiwan, China and the United States recognize that distinction in the weeks ahead as they weigh the election results and the future of Taiwan.

title: The Issue Is Respect;No Flaunting
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: March 17-24;Mad Cows Wreak Havoc
description: Great Britain now shares with Papua New Guinea the sad distinction of being the locus of an unusually cruel and fatal brain disease. In New Guinea the disease is called Kuru and is found among the Fore highlanders, who up until the early 1960's practiced a ritual form of cannibalism in which they consumed the remains of close relatives.

title: Little Progress in Mexico On Assassination Case
description: Two years after the assassination of a leading presidential candidate, Mexico's top justice official has made little headway toward solving the case and is facing questions about his competence and impartiality.

title: THEATER;Cancer, Medicine, Comedy
description: THE young woman notices a lump the size of a pebble in her breast. The doctor verifies the obvious: "You have a lump; why don't you stay off of caffeine and take vitamin E and, ah, come back in about a month."

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: DANCERS ON STAGE

title: Sunday March 24, 1996;A QUESTION FOR:
description: Projectionists spend more time in movie theaters than anyone else, but the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences never asks them about the Oscars -- or much else. So we did. Here's what four of them in New York had to say.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;His First Name Is Dontae'
description: The word from Dontae' Jones is that that little apostrophe after his first name on the Mississippi State roster is not a typographical error.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;In a Great Year for Snow, Skiers Look to Summer
description: A BANNER snow year is likely to enable skiers in search of sunshine and warm temperatures to carry their passion for spring skiing well into April this year, and in some cases even July and August.

title: From Necessity, New Forest Industry Rises
description: It was a charmless stand of scrubby black oak that Louie Myers strode into as dusk settled on Mad River Ridge the other day. But his eyes lit up. They began to dart. He scanned the wood like any animal-world forager, and he smiled.

title: Slick Manhole Covers Lurk In Crosswalks and Sidewalk
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING IT;Bre-X Has a Cinderella Story to Tell
description: THREE years ago Bre-X Minerals Ltd., then operating out of the basement of its president, David Walsh, paid $80,000 (Canadian) for mineral rights to 475,000 acres near Busang in northeast Borneo.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International3-17

title: SPENDING IT;The Price of Your Nonrefundable Ticket Just Fell? Don't Despair.
description: ON a harsh winter morning when your car was covered in snow and the local weatherman predicted six more inches the next day, you booked a spring trip to Florida. Giving two months' notice, you figured the advance airfare was a good deal and paid for a nonrefundable airline ticket.

title: March 17-24;The Census Counts, The Court Decides
description: More than halfway to the next census, the Supreme Court gave a constitutional seal of approval to the last one. The Justices ruled unanimously that the Bush Administration's refusal to use a statistical adjustment to correct an acknowledged undercount was a reasonable decision that did not -- as a Federal appeals court had suggested -- violate the principles of one person, one vote or the constitutional command of equal protection.

title: Unaware, Over There
description: In the late 70's, Procter & Gamble puzzled over its diaper's lukewarm success in Japan. Buy eyes in that country saw the problem clearly: Japanese parents change a baby's diaper twice as often as Americans do - about 14 times a day. That made the bulkiness of American-style diapers unnecessary, not to mention awkward when toting around lots of them. Do you have a tale of cross-cultural business goof? Send it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-Mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include a phone number. All submissions become become the property of The Times and may be republished in any meduim.

title: SPOTLIGHT;The Untouchables
description: Sunday blues? Not permitted - not with three Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers dance frolics on AMC, CAREFREE (1938) - at 6:30 P.M. - has a nifty batch of Irving Berlin songs, the beatiful "Change Partners" leading.And dig their slow-motion "Color Blind" glide across lily pads. Highlighting FOLLOW THE FLEET (1936) - at 8 P.M. - is the stunning "Let's Face the Music and Dance" (more Berlin). Ah, SWING TIME (1936)! - at 10 P.M. and again at 3:30 A.M. Many consider this their peak: the glowing Jerome Kern score, Astaire's dynamic "Bojangles" solo and the duo's rhapsodic footwork as dawn streaks a skyscraper club. Or is that heaven?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 25 with an article about skiing in the Northwest incorrectly described the area of Mount Bachelor, Ore., in which three skiers were shown. They were below the summit, not on it.

title: For Sherrill Milnes, Verdi's Perfect
description: IT is easy to picture the baritone Sherrill Milnes in costume. Swirling cloaks, plumed hats and swords that glint under stage lights seem made for his ruggedly handsome looks, longish hair and 6-foot-2 frame.

title: Politics and the Health Care Bill
description: Election-year politics has propelled health care back to the top of the Congressional agenda, but it is not clear whether politics will speed or hinder the passage of legislation to make health insurance more readily available to millions of Americans.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Consolidators: How Risky?
description: CONSOLIDATORS, companies that buy plane tickets in bulk from the airlines for resale to consumers, often at discounted prices, come in many shapes and sizes. They may be here today and gone tomorrow, with no more assets than a fax machine, a telephone and a customer's money, which they may use to buy a ticket from another consolidator at a slightly lower price. On the other hand, they may, like Council Travel, a company with 40 offices across the country, run a successful business reliably for decades.

title: Veterans of the 80's Return to the Wars
description: THEY were among the real estate industry's household names in the 80's, the ones on the buy or build side of almost every New York City deal. And then the recession came, and the old-time entrepreneurs -- dealmakers like Francis Greenburger, Dick Berry, Joe Newman, Larry Silverstein, Joe Bernstein, and his brother, Ralph -- seemed to simply stop doing deals here.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: MIDWEST;Kentucky's Machine Plows Its Way to the Final Four
description: The Kentucky Wildcats returned to a familiar position this afternoon, with their feet on the opponent's throat for 40 minutes and their team perched among the cream in college basketball.

title: Dreamland;Morning in America in Japan
description: WHEN this year's crop of American Presidential candidates dies and goes to heaven (an assumption some may question), pretty much the whole lot of them might end up here in Japan. It has just about everything they might want:

title: CHOICE TABLES;Where the Food Is New in Scotland
description: IN matters gastronomic, visitors to Scotland once were wise to stick to the certainties of breakfast -- mostly tea, toast and marmalade. No longer. The winds of change that have swept England have also reached north of the border. A new breed of Scottish restaurateur is prepared to treat Caledonia's larder -- its game, seafood, mushrooms and fruits -- with intelligence and restraint. Which is as it should be in Edinburgh, one of Europe's most elegant, intriguing and accessible cities.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Habitats/Garrison, N.Y.;There Was Room at the Inn -- and They Needed It
description: THEY have 6 marriages between them, and 9 children from 5 to 45 years old. They wanted a big house -- but maybe not as big as the one they got.

title: Child Welfare Will Suffer Under Block Grants
description: To the Editor:

title: A LA CARTE;Interested in Fine Dining? Search the Internet.
description: RESTAURANTS are rushing into cyberspace, and Long Island, especially the East End, is well represented on the Information Superhighway. More than 6,200 mostly fine-dining-type restaurants are already spinning around the Internet, according to Web Crawler, a search service that helps Internet users find web sites by subject matter.

title: It's Dick Vitale, Baby, The Voice That Makes March Mad
description: IF imitation is the sincerest form of flattery that must explain why Dick Vitale is blushing from head to toe. The world is full of Vitale knockoffs; no sportscaster has been parodied so much since Howard Cosell.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Two Masters in Search Of Their Old Mastery
description: THE PIANIST Herbie Hancock's "New Standard" and the saxophonist Sonny Rollins's "Sonny Rollins Plus 3," new albums by older masters, have a few things in common. Like so many recordings by established musicians these days, they both have an angle, and arguably a commercial one at that. They also share a heartbreaking sense of underachievement. It is as if two of jazz's great living improvisers -- Mr. Hancock is 55; Mr. Rollins, 65 -- either can't or won't find a context that lets them showcase their obvious gifts.

title: Foreign Affairs;Help Wanted: Deal Makers
description: In many ways the immediate Taiwan crisis ended two weeks ago. On March 8, the U.S. national security adviser, Anthony Lake, met privately with his Chinese counterpart, Liu Hua Qui, at Pamela Harriman's farm in Middleburg, Va. The conclusion of their daylong meeting was an "understanding" that went like this: The U.S. would use its influence to try to restrain Taiwan from any more far-reaching moves toward independence, and in return Beijing would not use military force to resolve its current dispute with Taipei.

title: Group Aiding Homeless To Get Concert Funds
description: SOCKS and underwear are not the usual entrance fees to chamber music concerts, but then next Sunday's musical to benefit Midnight Run, a nonprofit group that takes food and clothing to the homeless, is not the usual concert.

title: BASEBALL;For Boggs, a Coach for All Seasons
description: They have the same ruddy complexion, the same serious eyes, the same passion in their voices when they discuss hitting, and the same renowned baseball surname: Boggs. Ask Wade Boggs how he became one of the best hitters in history and he blurts out his father's name faster than his bat whooshes through the strike zone.

title: Word for Word/On Trial in Germany;We Weren't Following Orders, But the Currents of the Cold War
description: ONE of the most perplexing political questions of the late 20th century is how new democracies should punish deposed dictators and their associates. Victims cry for justice, but leaders of new regimes must decide to what extent it is possible, moral or prudent to pursue evildoers of the past.

title: Talbots Makes Debut On Litchfield Green
description: LAST WEEKEND, one of Litchfield's venerable brick buildings, part of the business district that faces the green, took a retail identity for the 21st century. Built in 1890, the "Beach Block" (as it is known in the archives) now sports a fresh coat of bright, white paint on its fluted pilasters, display windows full of tastefully dressed mannequins, planters filled with hardy red geraniums, a distinctive red door and signs bearing the logo "Talbots."

title: Something's Got to Give
description: All the way down the bank of radar scopes, the air traffic controllers have that savage, bug-eyed look, like men on the verge of drowning, as they watch the computer blips proliferate and speak in frantic bursts of techno-chatter to the pilots: "Continental 1528, turn right heading 280 immediately! Traffic at your 12 o'clock!" A tightly wound Tom Zaccheo, one of the control-room veterans, sinks his teeth into his cuticles and turns, glowering, to the controller by his side: "Hey, watch your goddamned planes -- you're in my airspace!" Two scopes away, the normally unflappable Jim Hunter, his right leg pumping like a pneumatic drill, sucks down coffee and squints as blips representing 747's with 200 passengers on board simply vanish from his radar screen. "If the F.A.A. doesn't fix this goddamned equipment," he fumes, retrieving the blips with his key pad, "it's only a matter of time before there's a catastrophe." And Joe Jorge, a new trainee, scrambling to keep his jets safely separated in the crowded sky, is actually panting down at the end as he orders pilots to turn, climb, descend, speed up, slow down and look out the cockpit window, captain!

title: A Successful Company Is Acquired. Will It Remain on L.I.?
description: EMPLOYEES at Fiber Options, Inc., first sensed something amiss last fall when strangers began parading through their Bohemia headquarters. Rumors began circulating in the executive suite and in the factory where fiber optic transmission systems undergo final assembly.

title: TAIWAN'S LEADER WINS ITS ELECTION AND A MANDATE
description: President Lee Teng-hui swept to an election victory today that exceeded all expectations and served as a forceful rebuke to mainland China. This island's voters gave Mr. Lee a strong mandate in their first democratic balloting for President.

title: INVESTING WITH;Mark G. Holowesko: Templeton Foreign Fund
description: SCANNING the globe for undervalued stocks often takes money managers to exotic locales. Mark G. Holowesko, an acclaimed manager of several Templeton foreign funds, is no exception.

title: Disaster Readiness: Primer for Companies
description: WHAT if? What if a hurricane hits? What if a terrorist strikes? What would such catastrophes do to your company? How can you better protect your company in the face of such disasters?

title: The Gentleman and the Jock
description: There is a spor for every man, no matter what his limitations. And there are the right clothes to wear for each, no matter how high- or low-tech that sport may be. For instance, something as basic as khakis and a polo shirt will do fine for pedaling around the neighborhood, but road racing demands something more streamlined - such as a skintight synthetic bodysuit and goggles. Here and on the following pages, an illustration of contrasting approaches to various sports - and sport styles.

title: Two Firefighters Injured in Blazes
description: A Jersey City firefighter was hospitalized in guarded condition yesterday, after he suffered heart problems and collapsed while putting out a fire in a three-story building.

title: Ideas & Trends;Can the Schools Stand or Deliver?
description: THE answer to all our national problems comes down to a single word: education," Lyndon B. Johnson said in promoting his vision of the Great Society in the 1960's.

title: F.Y.I.
description: But There's a Catch

title: POSTINGS: On a Street in North Bergen;New Jersey Neighbors: Firehouse, Playground
description: It looks like a piece of abstract modern art: A long, rectangular slab of light-gray split-face concrete block, with a large square on one side that has a window in its middle and that is, appropriately, fire-engine red. It is, in fact, the newest fire station in North Bergen, N.J.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: TRIAL BY FIRE By Nancy Taylor Rosenberg. Dutton, $22.95.

title: INVESTING IT;A Little-Known Strategy for Bond Buyers
description: KURT GUTFREUND, the president of a Chicago company that makes children's clothing, is like many other bond buyers. He doesn't like to take risks, and he puts a high priority on yield.

title: Appearances];The Seaweed Factor
description: SEAWEED IS ALGAE, A HUMBLE PLANT WITH NO TRUE root, stem or leaf. Plankton -- microscopic plant and animal life drifting in the water -- is humbler still. But in these herb-euphoric times, low on the food chain means high on virtue. Devotees graze not only on sea plants like hungry manatees, but also slather the stuff over their bodies. They comb cosmetics counters for thermal plankton creams and kelp cleansing gels. I am both attracted and repelled. The stories about the benefits of these plants are seductive, but seem too precisely tailored to hook into receptor sites of current assumptions, expectations and fears.

title: The Issue Is Respect;Respect, Part 2
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Range Rover 4.0 SE;The Changing of the Guard
description: I PAID too much for my first house, a tiny two-bedroom, one-bath bungalow that needed a lot of work, because of its prime location in a fashionable suburb. Two years later, a couple who saw more value in the address than I did gave me $10,000 above what I had paid.

title: Occupier of Synagogue Expresses a Deep Longing
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOLS;Across the State, Teachers Settle for a Slower Rise in Pay
description: New Jersey's teachers are among the best paid in the nation, with an average salary of $45,000. But in recent years, they have been settling for the smallest wage increases since 1968, when the state first allowed collective bargaining for teachers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Purdue Coach Dismissed
description: LIN DUNN, who led the Purdue women's basketball team to the Final Four in 1994 and to three Big Ten titles, was dismissed yesterday. "It has been determined that the long-term future of our women's basketball program will be best served under new leadership," said the athletic director, MORGAN BURKE, who said Dunn's contract would not be renewed.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Eurostar Adds a Stop An Hour From London
description: A new terminal at Ashford station in Kent, 56 miles from London, provides an additional stop for the Eurostar rail link from London to Paris and Brussels.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Can't Go Home Again? Tell These Frisky Strays
description: Flirting With Disaster Mary Tyler Moore, Ben Stiller, Patricia Arquette, George Segal, Tea Leoni, Lily Tomlin, Alan Alda Directed by David O. Russell R 92 minutes

title: How to Succeed in Britain Without Really Trying
description: MUGGERIDGE The Biography. By Richard Ingrams. Illustrated. 264 pp. San Francisco: HarperSanFrancisco. $27.50.

title: The Issue Is Respect;Respect, Part 3
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Retrieving a Lost World of Sensibility and Graciousness
description: IT IS NOT MERE CHANCE that a violin or violin case often appears in the paintings of Henri Matisse. Matisse, a master of color and design, studied the instrument assiduously until his 50th year and often compared the painter's art with the musician's. "Draw your large masses first," he told a student. "Look for their volume and fullness. You may embroider and make flourishes, but you must return to your theme, as in music." He liked to work with a small brush, seeking to fulfill what he called "the desire of the line."

title: Mali
description: To the Editor: I just returned from Bamako. I did not stay at the Hotel Sofitel, but at the Hotel Mande, three years old, which is on the Niger River 15 minutes from downtown.

title: When Little League Becomes Hardball
description: IT'S that time of year -- when baseball gloves are being lovingly massaged with oil, cleats pulled from the back of closets and pitching arms warmed up.

title: MUSIC;Taking Nothing Casually, Except a Contest
description: SHE went into the big one lightly, never expecting to win it. Now she says: "I didn't know it was so famous. I just thought to myself, 'I have the vocal music prepared, so I'll give it a shot'."

title: Lost and Found
description: ONE DAY LAST MAY, IN THE southern Rwandan town of Butare, a man named Albert saw his brother's 3-year-old son ride by in the back of a truck. Albert, who knew that his brother had been killed during Rwanda's genocide a year earlier, had assumed the child was also dead. When he saw the boy, he gave chase and in a matter of minutes took custody of his orphaned nephew. Albert considered the reunion miraculous. "He was a baby," he told me a few days later. "He followed one person. He followed another person. Nobody knew where he came from. It's pure chance that I was in Butare and he was in Butare and in that precise second I saw him -- and recognized him."

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: PICTURING THE WRECK By Dani Shapiro. Doubleday, $22.

title: Her Father's Cinderella
description: To the Editor:

title: Unneeded Services Inflate Home Health Care Cost
description: Twenty years after home health care was revolutionized as a way to provide cheaper, more personal help than in the scandal-ridden nursing homes, home-care costs themselves are ballooning out of control, many experts say.

title: OUT OF ORDER;Do You Have Time for a Private Vice?
description: HOBBY shops are part of the Long Island landscape. But the word "hobby" has a strangely old-fashioned ring. Hobbies, according to my dictionary, are "spare time" activities. Who has any spare time these days?

title: WEDDINGS;Barbara Newell, Ernest Kolowrat
description: Dr. Barbara Warne Newell, an educator and diplomat, was married on Monday to Ernest Kolowrat, a writer. Justice Leander J. Shaw Jr. of the Florida Supreme Court in Tallahassee performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Van Gundy Facing Decision Day on Starks-Davis Choice
description: Hubert Davis, enjoying the finest season of his young career, is preparing to return from injury. John Starks is healthy again, playing well and harnessing his emotions.

title: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
description: Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions, and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.

title: Death Shatters Officers More Used to Suburban Tasks
description: Just before 3 P.M. last Thursday, Officer Dominick Santoianni was holding a skunk at bay on a front lawn when Officer Michael Frey pulled up and asked if he needed help. Just then, Officer Frey's radio squawked -- something about a suspicious person at 17 Morgan Street.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;A Transfusion for Carew
description: MICHELLE CAREW, 18-year-old daughter of the Hall of Famer ROD CAREW, received a rare infusion of infant umbilical-cord blood on Friday to combat leukemia.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Can't Go Home Again? Tell These Frisky Strays
description: Race the Sun Halle Berry, James Belushi Directed by Charles T. Kanganis PG 105 minutes

title: In the Region/Long Island;Pine Barrens Landowners Say Rights Are Denied
description: ALL Joseph F. Gazza wants, he says, is a way to use property he owns in the Central Pine Barrens or a way of selling it at a fair price.

title: THEATER;A Long and Twisting Road Back to Broadway
description: THIS IS WHAT I CARRY with me." Donna McKechnie stands in a Manhattan sublet apartment surrounded by someone else's possessions, cradling a picture frame. In it is a photograph, taken 20 years ago, of her between Michael Bennett and Fred Astaire.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Reds Placed on Disabled List
description: The Cincinnati Reds put reliever JEFF BRANTLEY, pitcher JOSE RIJO and outfielders ERIC ANTHONY and THOMAS HOWARD on the disabled list yesterday.

title: Cherishing Dignity At Home
description: Were it not for Frances Lewis, Ruth Cooper would be passing her old age in a nursing home.

title: BOXING;A Split Decision Gains Title For Jones
description: Two years and four pounds later, two of the world's best small fighters -- Junior Jones and Orlando Canizales -- finally met last night at Madison Square Garden's Theater.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: SOME classics and near-classics of the 1930's and a later inside-Hollywood fable stand out on the week's movie menu. None - hooray! - are overshow, at least yet.

title: A Movie Tough Guy With a Heart of Gold
description: SOMEHOW OVER THE last six years, Kurt Russell, that good-looking journeyman actor, has become a highly paid action hero. In the current thriller "Executive Decision," he plays a security analyst who must save the East Coast from extermination.

title: HOCKEY;Vermont and Boston U. Reach N.C.A.A. Semifinals
description: Martin St. Louis, who came down from Quebec to play hockey for Vermont, tonight led the Catamounts closer to a national championship.

title: The New Look in Film Titles: Edgy Type That's on the Move
description: With the Academy Awards tomorrow night, the moviegoing public may be reminded once again of the relatively obscure members of the film making team: set designers, costumers, sound technicians and the like.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;A Get-Tough Message at California's Death Row
description: Senator Bob Dole toured California's death chamber at the state prison here today and said that as President he would push for laws to speed up executions of condemned prisoners.

title: Tih-Wu Wang, 84, Taiwan Publisher Of Periodicals
description: Tih-Wu Wang, a Taiwan-based publisher of economic and other periodicals, died on March 11 at Veterans General Hospital in Taipei. A Taipei resident, he was 84.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JAMAICA;F.D.A. Lab Goes Collegiate
description: For more than 30 years, the Food and Drug Administration has been conducting tests on consumer goods from a rundown warehouse in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, that freezes in the winter, boils in the summer and leaks when it rains.

title: Fighting Poverty Programs;Hartford Faces Vote to Bar New Nonprofit Services
description: While advocates for the poor say that more social-service programs mean more people turning their lives around, city leaders here have a different perspective: they say that more social service programs drain the economy, breed dependency and mean more poor people moving to Hartford, where one in four people is already on welfare.

title: TENNIS;Muster Loses Lipton Opener
description: Thomas Muster is now 0 for 3 in matches as the No. 1 player. He lost to Nicolas Pereira, 7-6 (7-4), 6-4, in his opening match at the Lipton Championships today.

title: Our Towns;When Deer And Suburbs Vie for Space
description: IN her backyard, Pat Frankemolle finds her thoughts turning to chicken wire, plastic tarpaulins and stockade fencing. "Cover," she said. "Lots of cover."

title: Back to the Future
description: HOLLYWOOD'S crystal ball has always been a little clouded. In fact, its often ludicrous films of the future have generally had more to say about the styles and attitudes of their own times than about the world of tomorrow. Although the utopian vision of the 1930's has more recently given way to pessimism, perhaps if the year 2000 is not as bad as expected, films will again have a brighter outlook.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a listing on Feb. 25 of tips for touring in Egypt described an Allen Drury novel incorrectly. The novel, "Come Nineveh, Come Tyre," concerns international politics; it is not about Egypt. Mr. Drury has written two novels about ancient Egypt, "A God Against the Gods" and "Return to Thebes."

title: Don't Condemn All Germans for the Holocaust;Foster Pluralism
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY;Quality of Life vs. Quality of Golf
description: IN the early 1990's, during a brief period when the old Spy magazine was actually amusing, a dispute arose on the Upper West Side of Manhattan over a golf driving range that had opened across the Hudson in Edgewater. At night, the range's bright floodlights were hampering the valued river views from high-rise apartments on Riverside Drive. While the aggrieved Manhattanites hired lawyers who wailed about property values and glare-induced stress syndromes, Spy came up with an ingenious solution:

title: FIGURE SKATING;Grace and Improvisation: Kwan Wins World Title
description: Lu Chen of China, the defending world champion, skates with a balletic grace, gliding over the ice like a leaf on water. After she received two marks of 6 for artistry tonight, all Michelle Kwan had to be was perfect herself.

title: EVENING HOURS;Fashion's Devotees, Under the Spell
description: Fall shows, Paris, March 12-19.

title: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
description: Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions, and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.

title: Sunday March 24, 1996: FALLING FOR LUCY;Look Before You Leap
description: I never thought for a second that Lucy would jump." Sarah Jessica Parker is speaking of her character in "If Lucy Fell," the new movie comedy in which two roommates (Parker and Eric Schaeffer) make a pact to leap off the Brooklyn Bridge if they haven't found true love by the time they turn 30. "Perhaps," the actress adds, noting the film's less-than-rave reviews, "it would have been best if Lucy had fallen."

title: Don't Condemn All Germans for the Holocaust;A Contradiction?
description: To the Editor:

title: March 17-24;Einstein Bid Rebuffed
description: After the earliest surviving Einstein manuscript on relativity failed to bring in the minimum $4 million bid at Sotheby's auction house in New York on March 16, the 72-page document, written in 1912, found a home in Israel. Sotheby's said the Jacob E. Safra Philanthropic Foundation bought the manuscript for an undisclosed sum and will give it to the Israel Museum in Jerusalem.

title: Justice Dept. Argued To Affirm Forfeiture
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Opera Has a Welcome Here
description: THE Westchester Hudson Opera Company's artistic director, Franco Gratale, a Westchester resident for 28 years and opera director for 35, formed his company last year with Charles Rosekrans, music director, who has worked with the likes of Beverly Sills and Anna Moffo, in the belief that opera has a place in the suburbs.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Can't Go Home Again? Tell These Frisky Strays
description: Ed Matt LeBlanc, Jack Warden, Jayne Brook, Doren Fein Directed by Bill Couturie PG 94 minutes

title: Few People But Teeming With Life
description: I WATCHED as my suitcases were hauled onto the already overloaded motorboat, dwarfed by the Panamanian ships and aging Chinese freighters in the harbor. I was in Koror, capital of the Republic of Palau, which gained its independence from the United States less than two years ago. This tiny Pacific island nation lies 800 miles southwest of Guam in the scattered expanse of Micronesia. Flying in earlier that morning through a battleship-gray sky, I hadn't been able to see the 350 or so islands that make up Palau, but the sun began to break through the clouds as I boarded the boat.

title: Cool Suits, Hot Jazz
description: THE sharp suit is back. And who better to wear these elegant styles than jazz musicians form Preservation Hall in New Orlean? After all, from Jelly Roll Morton and Cab Calloway, through Dizzy Gillespie and up through today's Nicholas Payton, jazz has always been known for its snappy dressers. Here, a group of band players from 24 to 87 show there are no age limits on style - especially as captured by the celebrated jazz photographer William Claxton.

title: EARNING IT;Virtual Recruiter: Software That Reads Resumes
description: THE next time you get hired or transferred, the person you may want to slap on the back or in the face may not be a person at all. That is because your fate was decided by a computer.

title: ART VIEW;A Fifth Avenue Showcase For What Opulence Buys
description: WHY ARE THEY beating down the doors to get a look at these things? Why, why, why?

title: Taiwan Can't Ignore Its Chinese Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: Dredging the Thames, Another View
description: The recent letter to the editor ("The Thames, the Sound and Toxic Dumping," March 10) by the fisheries biologist Michael Ludwig sadly contains enough mistakes and misleading statements so that I feel some effort must be made to present a more balanced picture.

title: Teachers, Teach Thyselves
description: THIS month the National Council of Teachers of English released "Standards for the English Language Arts," which outlined, in mind-numbing terms, what students from kindergarten to 12th grade should learn. Tucked in it was a glossary that defined obscure words, such as "listening" and "spelling." Below are excerpts. SARAH BOXER

title: When Children Simply Need Families
description: TODAY, in Connecticut, there are about 550 children looking for a good home. It doesn't have to be anything special -- just a bed, three square meals and a loving parent.

title: Also Inside
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 An investment banker and an influx of Soviet Jews give new importance to the Hebrew Free Burial Association.

title: POP VIEW;A Small World After All. But Is That Good?
description: WHEN DEEP FOREST'S "BOHEME" won this year's Grammy Award for world music, the purist in me groaned. With typical reflexes, the Grammy voters had chosen an album made in the exotic reaches of France, under the primitive conditions of a digital recording studio and steeped in the rarely noticed traditions of disco, house music and European rock. As the members of Deep Forest wrote in liner notes, "native melodies" were simply "raw material, an opportunity to mix, cross and blend." If this was world music, it was from a virtual world, where geography is warped by the click of a mouse. Call it small-world music.

title: SUNDAY VIEW;Diatribes? Homilies? It's Nixon
description: WHO SAID THAT THE AMERICAN passion for unseemly media rants and confessions began with Phil Donahue, Oprah Winfrey and the rest of the talk show enabler-hosts? I think it began about 40 years ago with the televising of the Army-McCarthy hearings and with Richard M. Nixon's Checkers speech. We spent the next quarter century watching him bring his gifts to a dazzling, monomaniacal pitch, both on television and tape: artfully crafted mea culpas, stream-of-consciousness diatribes, self-congratulation, self-flagellation, homilies, obscenities, bouts of aggression and subservience.

title: DANCE;Getting to the Heart of a Dance, With a Guide
description: IT IS OFTEN SAID THAT DANCE, unlike the other performing arts, with their written scores and scripts, has lived on through the passing down of choreography and interpretations from individual to individual and generation to generation. That tradition has become all the more vital nowadays as links to the past, especially the pioneering modern-dance choreographers, fade from the scene.

title: SIGNOFF;Why They Call It March Madness
description: HARDLY anyone recalls exactly when March Madness became synonymous with CBS Sports' broadcast of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's men's basketball tournament. CBS never trademarked the phrase because it belonged to the Illinois High School Sports Association. Still, the network has millked the motto for a decade, and spread the three weeks' worth of hoops enough to make the event as important to the network as "Murder, She Wrote" or "60 Minutes."

title: DRIVING;On the Highways: 8 Trouble Spots
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: Colleges' Improving Images Conceal a Host of Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: The Grunge American NovelA New York Times Magazine Profile
description: NERVOUSNESS AND DREAD frequently chase David Foster Wallace, and when they catch him, as they have now, he writhes and twitches and prattles at a breakneck clip, his incessant quips running the gamut from marvelous to mundane. ''Do you have my saliva?'' he asks a companion in his cab, reflecting on the way his jitters have drained all moisture from his mouth. ''Somebody took my saliva, because I don't have it.''

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Lindenhurst, L.I.;An Involved Village on Great South Bay
description: RESIDENTS of the Village of Lindenhurst, a South Shore Long Island community 70 minutes from Manhattan, believe in fighting to preserve their neighborhoods.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Barnes Foundation's dispute with its suburban Philadelphia neighborhood referred incompletely to a sexual harassment lawsuit against Richard H. Glanton, the foundation's director. The suit, which Mr. Glanton lost in 1993, was settled while on appeal, thus vacating the jury's finding.

title: The Issue Is Respect;And Elsewhere?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday The National Association of Realtors reports on sales of existing homes in February. In January, sales fell 4.1 percent.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Discarded Places
description: Since 1977, Camilo Jose Vergara, a native Chilean, has been training his camera on some of the poorest neighborhoods in several of this country's poorest cities. His photographs, with accompanying text, record an intriguing but often depressing landscape in THE NEW AMERICAN GHETTO (Rutgers University, $49.95). Mr. Vergara writes that he viewed his mission as documenting in pictures the "discarded and dangerous places" that are rarely traversed by people who do not live or work there. Returning again and again to the same street corner over a decade or more, he provides ample visual evidence of how a neighborhood and even specific buildings deteriorate over the years and disappear. Mr. Vergara's nine images of 178th Street and Vyse Avenue in the South Bronx, the first taken in June 1980, show an expansive brick apartment building in various states of decay.
