By January 1986, all that remains is a crumbling brick facade. In the final photograph, taken in October 1994, four or five new town houses have sprouted up, and two automobiles are parked out front on the street. "Two Bronxes are visible in these photographs: one that died too soon and one too flimsy to last," he writes. There are some signs of hope in his photo gallery: his camera has captured the new homes that have supplanted barren buildings, the tenacious presence of the church in even the most rundown communities and the arresting and colorful murals, many dedicated to black history and tradition, which belie the crime and grime that pervade Mr. Vergara's world. William K. Marimow

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 24, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: MOO By Jane Smiley. Fawcett Columbine, $12. This is campus farce with a difference. Set at a Midwestern agricultural college, the novel is less concerned with fights over tenure and multicultural curriculums than it is with a mining controversy and the fate of a huge pig. "A special pleasure of Jane Smiley's fiction comes from her knowledge and enjoyment of the physical world," Alison Lurie said here last year.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Ellen Matloff;The Secrets of Your Genes and What to Do
description: ELLEN MATLOFF took a job as a genetics counselor for the Yale Cancer Center six months ago, and quickly realized that she was at the beginning of an evolution.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: SOUTHEAST;UConn Left to Wonder How Season Went Sour
description: This exit was unlike any other that this generation of Connecticut Huskies had known. They were alone together in their dressing room Friday night, box lunches in their hands, deep into March but not nearly as deep as they had expected.

title: Moorea's Sumptuous Sands
description: WHEN it comes to travel, I have always had a knack for being in the wrong place at the wrong time. The eve ning before the 1989 San Francisco earthquake I was dining in an Italian restaurant downtown; my first trip to Paris coincided with a citywide transportation strike; on a visit to South Boston in 1979 I was bopped on the head with a 2-by-4 when the St. Patrick's Day parade turned ugly. And I still cringe on recalling that I had planned a nostalgic trip to Oklahoma City before the tragic bombing last fall -- where my old apartment was two blocks from the Federal Building.

title: When 'Ketchup' Is 'Tomato Achievement'
description: THE House passed the Immigration in the National Interest bill last week, while the Senate adopted the Common Sense Liability and Legal Reform bill. This week both expect to vote on the Contract With America Advancement bill.

title: Women in Communications Awards Writers
description: WHEN Women in Communications was founded in 1909, it was known as Theta Sigma Phi and was a small, Seattle-based group interested in promoting women's involvement in the newspaper and magazine professions. Now Women in Communications -- the name was changed in 1972 -- is a national organization for men as well as women who work not only in journalism but also in advertising, public relations, graphic design, publishing, photography and computer communications.

title: Significant Others;Much Will Hinge on 2 Close to the Candidates
description: A PRESIDENTIAL candidate's choice of a running mate can be a seminal event, of course, in advancing the career of the lucky politician who gets the nod. Five of the last 10 Presidents had served previously as Vice President, and in seven of the last eight elections, one or both of the major party Presidential nominees had served previously as Vice President. For the Vice Presidential nominee, it is a big step up.

title: Land on S. Carolina Island Is Sold to State, Averting Bridge Plan
description: The owners of part of a coastal island in South Carolina have sold the land to the state, abandoning a plan to build a bridge that might have resulted in the island's development as a resort.

title: TENNIS;Graf Finds Real World Full of Ups and Downs
description: Death, taxes and tennis: Steffi Graf, still the best but still besieged, couldn't be more certain that she won't escape any of them. But, old beyond her 26 years mentally and physically after a decade of pushing herself to prevail, it's tennis that continues to provide her best reason for getting up, albeit stiff and sore, each morning.

title: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins
description: WHITE-GLOVED waiters carried trays of hors d'oeuvres through the ballroom of the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan as an expectant crowd of investors awaited Paul G. Kahn, the man who had come to save their company.

title: MARKET WATCH;Oil Spurt: A Rally That Few Believe
description: There are times when virtually everyone knows something is true, and evidence to the contrary is dismissed as misleading, a temporary aberration that cannot be believed. Sometimes that conventional wisdom is right, but there are times when that evidence is pointing to a major change.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BAD DAY AT RIVERBEND Written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95. (Ages 3 to 8)

title: INVESTING IT;The ABC's of Taxable Gains
description: Last week, the Clinton Administration proposed that taxpayers be allowed to use only one method - average cost - to figure the capital gains or losses when they sell their stocks, mutual funds or other securities.

title: Life in the Lap Lane: New York Hotel Pools
description: FINDING swimming pools in the heart of Manhattan is a challenge, far greater than finding swimming pools just about anywhere else we have traveled.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: RESORT;Luxe in Cuba
description: Club Mediterranee has recently opened several luxurious resorts. Now it's going to build another one in a country where a classless society is the norm: Cuba. Club Med-Varadero, a 600-bed beachfront village, will be situated on the Varadero peninsula 80 miles east of Havana. It is scheduled to open in the 1996-97 winter season, and will feature scuba diving and deep sea fishing, as well as excursions to explore Cuba's natural beauty. American guests will be unable to go as long as the United States trade embargo with Cuba prevents Americans from spending dollars in Cuba.

title: WEDDINGS;Sarah Sternklar, Marvin Davis
description: Dr. Sarah Sternklar, a psychoanalyst in New York, is to be married today to Marvin Davis, a real estate investor in New York. Rabbi Meir Fund, a cousin of the bride, is to perform the ceremony at the Synagogue Space in New York.

title: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
description: Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions, and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/ In 1993, he was bankrupt. Today, David Walsh is worth $250 million. By Clyde H. Farnsworth.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: EAST;The Next Stop for UMass Is the Meadowlands
description: From the day that Massachusetts and Georgetown were made the No. 1 and No. 2-seeded teams in the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, most people believed that the Hoyas would be the boulder in the road as the Minutemen traveled to what they hoped would be their destiny: a national championship.

title: CULTURE ZONE;Designer Nihilism
description: IT WAS VALENTINE'S Day on Manhattan's Upper West Side, and the Sony Theaters at Lincoln Square were packed with couples holding hands and Mylar balloons. They were lining up in pairs to see the movie advertised as "the most celebrated love story of our time": "Leaving Las Vegas," a self-consciously depressing romance about a screenwriter named Ben who vows to drink himself to death and his girlfriend, Sera, a hooker who is beaten up and gang-raped. (Now there's a romance everyone at Lincoln Square can relate to!)

title: An Open Door to the World
description: WHEN I first heard about Servas, it sounded too good to be true. I was suspicious of an organization founded on trust -- on the implicit understanding that travelers wouldn't steal the silver, and hosts wouldn't wield axes in the night.

title: Charges Are Filed In Mosque Incident
description: Four radio station employees who engineered an on-air stunt involving barging into a mosque and blaring the national anthem have been charged with misdemeanors, but Muslim leaders say they want more serious penalties.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: WHITE RABBIT By Kate Phillips. Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Redeveloping the State's Industrially Polluted Sites
description: IN passing a new law that provides tax abatements to developers who clean up industrially polluted sites, the state has taken another step forward in spurring the redevelopment of such sites and, in the process, stoking the economy.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;A Don Faces Down a Blowhard
description: NO GOOD DEED GOES UNPUNISHED, cynics argue, and after a bizarre incident at his recent recital in the staid confines of St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan, the English organist Peter Hurford may be inclined to agree. As often happens at parish-sponsored events, the skimpy program booklet supplied no information about the music, which ranged from the familiar (Bach and more Bach) to the slightly obscure (works by Louis Daquin and John Stanley). So Mr. Hurford spoke to the audience before sitting down to play, as more and more musicians do nowadays.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;Youth Shelter Sold to House Chinese Scholars
description: Several years ago, the 11-story building with the porthole-shaped windows on Ninth Avenue and 17th Street housed and gave job training to hundreds of runaway youths who sought shelter with Covenant House. Soon, the building will be the first stop for visiting scholars from China, a Covenant House official said last week.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Beyond Words
description: Between the world wars, wordless picture novels were produced by visionary artists like Lynd Ward and Frans Masereel, both of whom were masters of the art of turning iconic images into acerbic narratives about human folly. After a period of decline, wordless novels have recently enjoyed a small revival as an offshoot of so-called graphic novels, which are themselves offshoots of comic books. Since the wordless novel relies so strongly on visual shorthand, it is often a difficult genre in which to express complex ideas and emotions. THE SILENT CITY (Kitchen Sink Press, paper, $24.95), Erez Yakin's story of the plight of individuals in an industrial totalitarian state, is by no means graphically simplistic; in fact, as Yevgeny Yevtushenko writes in his introduction, "Erez Yakin screams with the silence of his drawings." It is indeed remarkable that such powerfully and exquisitely rendered pictures -- reminiscent of George Grosz and Otto Dix's post-World War I antiwar prints -- were made in 1988, when the artist was just 18 years old. But it is no surprise that each image is more effective individually than as an element of a complete story. Mr. Yakin finds it difficult to keep his theme of totalitarian oppression from being a shrill echo of George Orwell's "Nineteen Eighty-four," replete with the common visual clichs of fascist brutality. Nevertheless, "The Silent City" is remarkable for its horrific portrayals of unbridled, demonic power, as well as for the difficult, oppressive darkness of its pictures, which makes them at times barely reproducible. "The Silent City" may not have pushed the limits of the wordless novel beyond what was accomplished in the 1930's, but it proves that Erez Yakin is a virtuoso image maker, a gifted artist at the beginning of what might well be a brilliant career. Steven Heller

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;The Roots of a Populist Who Would Be President
description: At Gonzaga High School, the Jesuit institution in Washington from which Patrick J. Buchanan graduated in 1956, the ideal of education was expressed in a Latin term, eloquentia perfecta, or perfect eloquence. It meant that students, instructed in written expression, in Ovid, Cicero, "The Gallic Wars" and in public speaking, were expected to attain rhetorical mastery as the fruit of their immersion in the liberal arts.

title: Taming the Wild Man Of Summer
description: SUMMER is fantasy season for men. They guys I know get completely caught up in their activities, leaving their real-world selves far behind. They're sailors on the high seas, or explorers conquering mountains. When the adventure is over and it's time to put on a suit, they find themselves in the grip of severe grooming dissonance. the wind-blown hair, the sunburned skin, the call used hands look out of sync with a coat and tie - sort of like Ben Gunn in Brooks Brothers. Luckily, there's a whole industry out there that recognizes the problem of taming the wild man of summer, and is ready with solutions.

title: IN BRIEF;Challenge for Newark Schools: This One Is Worth $3 Million
description: First the State Department of Education stepped in, aiming to solve deep-seated problems in Newark's public schools. Now Prudential Insurance, one of the city's largest employers, wants to lend a hand. Last week, the company announced it would donate $1.5 million to the school district through its philanthropic arm, the Prudential Foundation.

title: Hazards in Madrid
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the letter from the Seattle traveler ("Madrid Dangers," Feb. 18) who was accosted in Madrid and received no help.

title: IN BRIEF;Ripples Far and Wide From Whitman Tax Cut
description: It has been known for many months that Governor Whitman's influence has spread beyond New Jersey borders to other places interested in cutting taxes and shrinking government.

title: March 17-24;The Mandelas Divorce
description: In a packed South African courtroom last week, President Nelson Mandela described his private humiliation: not once since he was released in 1990 from a 27-year imprisonment had his wife, Winnie, entered his bedroom while he was awake. Soon, the 77-year-old president said, he began to suspect her of having an affair with a junior colleague.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: WOMEN ON DIVORCE A Bedside Companion. Edited by Penny Kaganoff and Susan Spano. Harcourt Brace, $22.

title: COVER STORY;Bob and Johnny Made It Look Easy
description: IT looks easy. Read a few jokes from the Teleprompter, introduce a few actors, and toss off an ad-lib or two after the winners give their acceptance speeches. But the fine art of playing host at the yearly Academy Awards ceremony seems to be beyond the reach of all but a few performers.

title: WEDDINGS;Megan Mulry, Jeffrey Huisinga
description: SEVERAL guests at the March 2 wedding of Megan Mulry and Jeffrey Huisinga suggested that the appropriate headline for them would be "Bookworms Wed."

title: Commercial Property/Southbridge, Mass.;Future Brightens for Depressed Massachusetts Town
description: MORE than a decade after its major employer took most of its operations and jobs elsewhere, this small community in south-central Massachusetts is still trying to work its way back to full recovery. With help from the Department of Defense, it is now taking a major step forward.

title: IN BRIEF;Doing What It Takes To Make People Smile
description: The Governor and the Legislature have come out in favor of smiles.

title: FILM VIEW;Oscar's Roster: A Mostly Motley Crew
description: ONLY DIE-HARD OPTIMISTS can look forward to tomorrow's Academy Awards ceremony (to be broadcast on ABC at 9 P.M.) as a big night for wild cards -- a chance to see someone go home a surprise winner for playing second fiddle to a pig (James Cromwell, best supporting actor) or painting Mel Gibson's face blue (best makeup). The more down-to-earth view is that Oscar's value as Hollywood's good-will ambassador is severely challenged this year.

title: March 17-24;It Takes a Scandal
description: In the race to define President Clinton's true moral mettle for the largest number of people, "Blood Sport," James B. Stewart's book about the Whitewater scandal and Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton involvement in it, has soared past "It Takes a Village," Mrs. Clinton's vision of a moral society. "Blood Sport" is No. 1 on the New York Times Bestseller List in the March 31 edition of the Book Review. And "It Takes a Village" has slid from second to sixth place.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Wallace Hurt For the Bullets
description: Rasheed Wallace, the Washington Bullets' top draft pick, is likely out for the season after fracturing his left thumb in Washington's 111-108 overtime loss to Orlando on Friday night.

title: Touches of Eden on A Pacific Isle
description: WE had just staggered to the summit of Malabar lookout at the north end of Australia's Lord Howe Island, 435 miles off the east coast of Australia. As a breeze off the South Pacific pushed lightly at our backs, we looked toward the two volcanic peaks at the opposite end of the scythe-shaped isle presiding over the serene turquoise waters of the lagoon. The coral reef was visible from here as a tortuous, foamy line between the sheltered basin and darker, rougher seas. Having hiked through plant life that was as exotic as it was profuse -- from thick thatches of Kentia palms to banyan trees with ostensibly as many trunks as branches -- we felt as if we'd been frolicking in an outsize, untended botanic garden.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;Street Fight: Unions Versus B.I.D.'s
description: When business improvement districts were born a decade ago, their supporters saw these self-taxing entities as vehicles for delivering basic services more efficiently -- and more cheaply -- than the city. Unencumbered by a unionized work force, many B.I.D.'s have been able to provide security and sanitation at a third of what it would cost the city. That is, until now.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Two Rieslings Bridgehampton Winery, 1994. About $11. Paumanok Vineyards, Aquebogue, 1994. Late harvest. About $15 (half bottle).

title: Conquistador
description: HERNANDO DE SOTO A Savage Quest in the Americas. By David Ewing Duncan. Illustrated. 570 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $40. IN 1536, Hernando de Soto returned from Latin America to a hero's welcome in Seville. The dashing 36-year-old conquistador had experienced a meteoric rise to fame. From the obscurity of an ambitious emigrant to the New World he had become the first European to journey into the Andes and come face to face with the great Atahualpa. The story of how he then audaciously entertained the dauntless Inca leader with a flamboyant display of Castilian horsemanship before leading his troops into the attack at Cajamarca, the Inca citadel, would be told again and again, first by messengers and chroniclers, then by historians, poets and novelists.

title: March 17-24;Round One of Bakke II
description: When a Federal appeals court struck down the affirmative action program used by the University of Texas School of Law, the university simply shut down its admissions offices. Now anxious college officials throughout the country are wondering what it means for them as well.

title: Child Care for Mothers at Work on Diplomas
description: FOUR-MONTH-OLD Terra was asleep in her teacher's arms, contentedly sucking a pacifier. Terra's group in the Elizabeth Celotto Child Care Center at Wilbur Cross High School in New Haven had just finished playing with squish bags, surgical gloves filled with rice or beans or popcorn kernels made by a teacher in the day care center, Dana Miller, and one of the toddlers she cares for. The bags introduce the young to a variety of textures, Ms. Miller explained.

title: Crime
description: Reginald Hill's deep, dark mystery THE WOOD BEYOND (Delacorte, $21.95) tells many stories, and they're all about death. Andy Dalziel, the shrewd head of the Mid-Yorkshire constabulary, puzzles over some old bones unearthed during an animal-rights march on a pharmaceutical laboratory. Sgt. Peter Pascoe, introspective and sensitive, gets caught up in an older mystery

title: Grand Designs
description: FROM LASCAUX TO BROOKLYN By Paul Rand. Illustrated. 187 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $50.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE;30-Year News Career Ending
description: Robert S. Trentlyon describes himself as just another casualty of downsizing by News Communications Inc., which bought The Westsider and The Chelsea-Clinton News from him in September 1994.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A Honolulu Hotel Is Transformed
description: The former Kahala Hilton Hotel in Honolulu, which has been closed since last February for a $75 million restoration, has reopened as the Kahala Mandarin Oriental, Hawaii. The 370-room hotel, which first opened in 1964, is the Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group's first property in Hawaii.

title: IN BRIEF;And You Thought You'd Seen the End of Winter?
description: Was the winter that ended at 3:03 A.M. on Wednesday the worst on record?

title: Digital Dressing, Or Software to Wear
description: SHOES that think? Ties that talk? A shirt that changes color? The long-predicted convergence of computing and communications is finally happening, thanks to the Internet. But the arrival of the talking computer is going to pale compared with that of the walking computer, as the very fabric of computing changes when the network is unplugged from the wall and wraps itself around us in smart clothing. World Wide Web, meet the Person Wide Web.

title: Col. R.F. Overmyer, Commander Of Shuttle Missions, Dies at 59
description: Col. Robert F. Overmyer, 59, who commanded one of the last successful flights of the space shuttle Challenger, died on Friday when a small plane he was testing went into a spin and crashed.

title: EARNING IT;When Physical Therapy Comes to the Workplace
description: PATRICK SHANNON was no match for the mountain while entertaining business clients on a ski trip to Utah last year. No sooner had Mr. Shannon, an actuary for the Cigna Corporation, angled onto the slope than he fell and rolled into a powdery ball. Scooped up by the safety patrol and rushed to a nearby hospital, he ended up with two torn ligaments and a fractured tibia in his right leg. It was his first, and perhaps last, attempt to ski.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CROSS-COUNTRY

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 25 about two documentaries on the Hollywood blacklist referred incorrectly to Christopher Koch, the producer of "Blacklist: Hollywood on Trial." He is not the son -- or any relative -- of Howard Koch, the writer who won an Academy Award as a writer of the screenplay for "Casablanca," and who died last year.

title: THE SENATOR CANNOT HELP BEING HIMSELF
description: In 9 out of 10 cases, I would have respect for a person who has, like me, worked his way through college or professional school and has worked hard to become a success in life. Then why don't I respect Senator Alfonse D'Amato? I almost did when I finished Philip Weiss's excellent article "The Senator Cannot Help Being Himself" (March 3).

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 19 about the forfeiture of suspects' assets in drug cases misstated the monetary yield of plea bargains in some editions. The Justice Department gets half a billion dollars a year from such forfeitures, but not all of those forfeitures are the result of plea agreements.

title: All for One, One for All? Let's Be Friendly Enemies
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviving the Look Of The Future
description: INSPIRED by recent advances in high-tech fabrics and a new appreciation of Mies van der Rohe's "less is more" credo, sportswear this spring is leaving behind the retro-inspired excesses of past seasons. (Remember 1970's leisure suits and plaid hip-hugger pants?) Still, it is a bit ironic that even these "modern" designs are firmly rooted in the past, from the experimental fashions of the Bauhaus and Russian Constructivists in the 1920's to the space-age fantasies of Pierre Cardin and Courreges in the 1960's.

title: FOOD;Fluent in French
description: DIANE FORLEY, THE CHEF AND OWNER of Verbena in Manhattan, is among the new generation of cooks who came of age, culinarily speaking, after the era of quiche and beef Wellington. Forley, 33, did her apprenticeship in the 1980's, when money and imagination flowed freely, when exuberance was high and when America grew completely enamored of food. The fluency she acquired in such an environment explains the ease and understatement of her cooking.

title: ART;Recalling a Pioneering Women's Gallery
description: "A Woman's Place: The Central Hall Gallery in the 1970's" The Museums at Stony Brook, 1208 Rte.25A, Stony Brook. To June 9. 751-0066.

title: INVESTING IT;Turmoil Over Painkillers, but Smooth Seas for Investors
description: SOMETIMES, the headlines blare lots of bad news about an industry or a company. But a closer look often shows that the impact on investors' wallets is likely to be muffled.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets' Reeves Is Veteran Of the Waiting Game
description: Not so long ago, Khalid Reeves was considered one of the premier young guards in the nation. His senior season at Arizona, he was considered one of the top three players in the Pacific-10 Conference. Some argued he was the best -- and that was a league that featured his teammate Damon Stoudamire and a precocious point guard at Cal by the name of Jason Kidd.

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRATS;The President and His Party Seem Closer After Past Battles
description: The relationship between President Clinton and his fellow Democrats in the House has, from time to time, read like a case study in "Can this marriage be saved?"

title: Phyllis Vineyard, A Consultant, 72
description: Phyllis Smith Vineyard, a corporate communications and customer service consultant who was also involved in health, family planning and social welfare, died of cancer on March 16 at her home in Blue Point, L.I. She was 72.

title: A Cleaner, Deeper Harbor
description: New York Harbor is in danger of shutting down. Thousands of tons of riverborne silt that accumulate naturally every year are choking its bays and tributaries and driving shippers to deeper ports in Nova Scotia, Maryland and Virginia. At risk are billions in annual revenues and 180,000 jobs that depend, directly or indirectly, on the Port of New York and New Jersey.

title: TELEVISION;What a Difference a Do Makes
description: I'M NOT CUTTING THE HAIR!" shrieks Michelle Pfeiffer, a novice television news hound with an unfortunate propensity for mall-girl tresses, to Robert Redford, a seasoned pro determined to haul her off for a makeover, in the recent tear-jerker "Up Close and Personal."

title: Sunday March 24, 1996: KNOW THYSELF!;Dynamic Duos
description: The Academy Awards triggered thoughts of sense and sensibility -- not expressly the Jane Austen novel or the Emma Thompson movie, but the character traits: the practicality of Elinor, the passion of Marianne. And soon, with the smart set ever ready for parlor games, those thoughts turned to complementary (for the most part) twosomes. Of course, one person's sense is another's sensibility.

title: Jackie: Going, Going, Gone
description: On April 23, an auctioneer at New York's Sotheby's will start the bidding on furniture, jewelry and odds and ends belonging to one of this century's most famous women. She was also one of its most private, a circumstance seemingly at odds with her family's putting up her lares and penates for public consumption. It is not.

title: Where There's Smoke, There's a Plan of Attack
description: THE New York City Fire Department, the largest in the world, is admired for its training and efficiency. Its dispatch systems, response networks and on-scene strategies are widely emulated.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;No Accounting for This Plan
description: IF a group of powerful corporate executives has its way, the current independent rule maker for accounting in this country will soon cease to exist.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Where Image Is Boswell and Flavoring Is Hazelnut
description: When Starbucks opened a branch on Broadway and 102d Street a little over a year ago, several Upper West Side writers protested the intrusion of the Seattle-based coffee bar chain. Now, they elbow one another for choice tables at what has become a hangout for the local literati, who are often fighting not only the old ennui but also cabin fever.

title: Filling in the Gaps Caused by a Street-Destroying Winter
description: On a recent misty afternoon, a half-dozen residents of Colby Court -- a small side street in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn -- gathered to watch workers fill in a web of cavernous potholes that had wrenched car wheels out of alignment, forced school-bus drivers to detour, and threatened to devour baby strollers.

title: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
description: Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions, and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.

title: Of Okapis And Giraffes
description: To the Editor:

title: EARNING IT;Life of a Cold Caller: Riding on a Smile and a Thick Skin
description: EVELYN WILEY'S desk is unadorned. No family pictures. No mementos or favorite sayings. The only thing distinguishing it is a small hand mirror perched on the keyboard of her computer.

title: The Issue Is Respect;Why Not Sit?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JUDO;Accepting the Hard Knocks Is Only a Part of a Grappling Passion
description: The young man in the brown belt whom she knew only as Lou jumped backward and touched the bridge of his nose. His fingers came away bloody. "I'm sorry, oh, I'm sorry," Celita Schutz said.

title: WEDDINGS;Paula A. Spiaggia, Peter G. Heist
description: Paula Ann Spiaggia, a daughter of Vincent Spiaggia of Mira Loma, Calif., and the late Margaret Hawksworth, was married yesterday to Peter Gregg Heist, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. C. Heist of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Greg Groh performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn.

title: Unity Cracking as American Nations Meet on an Economic Zone
description: Shaken by election campaigning in the United States that has indicated voter discontent over breaking down trade barriers, trade ministers from 34 North and South American nations meeting here this week decided they would begin discussing the structure of a Free Trade Area of the Americas next year.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;2,500 Light Bulbs Waiting for Sponsor
description: For 10 years, the huge Hitachi sign atop the Newsweek building just south of Columbus Circle told passers-by the time and the temperature "in Central Park." Before noon it also reported the day's weather, and after noon the forecast for the following day. But no more.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q. & A. column on Jan. 14 to a question about the Palio of Siena gave an incorrect date for the Feast of the Assumption. A reader's letter dated Feb. 27 pointed out that the feast day is Aug. 15, not 16. The horse races in Siena are, indeed, held on Aug. 16, as the answer said, as well as on July 2.

title: Cuttings;Not Just the Cow Pasture's Thorny Scourge
description: Several years ago, a neighboring farmer stopped to visit while I was working in the flower garden. He admired the irises and the baby's breath and then shook his head sadly at a lush, silvery-leaved planting at the back of the garden.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: NONE BUT THE DEAD AND DYING By Ellen Behrens. Baskerville, $20.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;Mutual Funds: The Musical
description: ALONG the byways of cyberspace, watch out for the intersection of Wall Street with Hollywood Boulevard and Madison Avenue!

title: ART/ARTIFACTS;The Nightly News In 12th-Century Garb
description: IN THE MIDDLE AGES, MURDERS, wars and heroic feats were often documented in brilliant color and gory detail on enameled objects displayed in the churches of Europe. In some ways, they were the medieval equivalent of the nightly news. Many people learned of the assassination of Thomas a Becket, for instance, through the illustrated panels on enameled boxes that held the saint's relics.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;An Outward-Gazing Eye That Explored The Inner Life
description: NO DOUBT EVERY WORK OF art embodies the impulse to self expression, but for most of recorded history that has not been art's primary goal. Since the days of the cave painters, art has been in the service of gods or spirits, religion, royalty, country, community and individual patrons. And, of course, ambition, and the need to earn a living. The idea of making art chiefly to express or to discover one's feelings was scarcely conceivable until the Romantics devised the myth of the bohemian artist, and it did not gather much momentum until the 20th century had digested the lessons of Freud.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Giving A Contrary, Trenchant Symphonist His Due
description: A CLASSICAL CD COLLECTOR has to clear a wide swath of shelf space to make room for a set of the symphonies of Beethoven, Mahler, Shostakovich or any other major symphonist. The three symphonies of Igor Stravinsky, on the other hand, fit comfortably on one disk. Yet these lean, distilled works, which total just over 70 minutes, are hardly less significant.

title: SQUATTER CHIC
description: In the nearly 15 years that I have been a firefighter in New York City, I have found nothing "chic" about squatters who illegally occupy abandoned buildings. Rolando Polit's space, which he partitioned with bolts of cloth and heats with a homemade stove, is a tragedy in the making.

title: Sports of The Times;Final Four Equals The Final Arena
description: SHE had heard the song before. The caller was a familiar sportscaster's good friend who desperately needed two Final Four tickets for his doctor. Now, with the telephone to her ear Friday afternoon, Carol Baran, the executive secretary in the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority offices, stared at the ceiling and closed her eyes.

title: The Most Polite Pit Bull in Local Politics
description: IT is difficult, but important, to describe the devastating finality with which Betty Cooper Wallerstein says goodbye.

title: BENEFITS
description: Latin Music Education

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Can't Go Home Again? Tell These Frisky Strays
description: Homeward Bound II: Lost in San Francisco Robert Hays, the voices of Michael J. Fox, Sally Field, Ralph Waite, Carla Gugino Directed by David Ellis G 103 minutes

title: Slavery Is an Issue Again
description: More than 130 years after the 13th Amendment officially ended slavery in the United States, an angry debate has broken out among blacks over the perceived acquiescence of the Government of Sudan in a black slave trade -- and about the support that Louis Farrakhan, head of the Nation of Islam, has voiced for the Sudanese Government.

title: From a Defeated Ex-Leader, a Warning
description: If there was a big loser in today's presidential election, it was Hau Pei-tsun.

title: Muddy Water
description: BLOOD SPORT The President and His Adversaries. By James B. Stewart. Illustrated. 479 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Bosnian Muslims Free 109 Prisoners
description: The Bosnian Government freed 109 prisoners of war from a jail in Tuzla late Saturday night in partial fulfilment of its obligations under the Dayton peace agreement, the International Committee of the Red Cross said.

title: On Language;Hissy Fits and Golden Oldies
description: THE PEOPLE UP there are having a hissy fit all over Washington," Pat Buchanan told "Face the Nation" on CBS. "They can't believe it -- 'The beast is coming.' "

title: The 79th Street Basin Has Plenty of 'Real Boaters'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Red Cross Takes a Second Look
description: AMONG those listening to Jeff Marinstein's presentation on disaster preparedness was Peter T. Cann of the Westchester chapter of the American Red Cross.

title: POSTINGS: 'Reviving Lower Manhattan';Uptown at Columbia, A Panel on Downtown
description: Its cavernous streets and skyscrapers -- both historic and glassily new -- are "the glory of the place," according to the architect Robert A. M. Stern, who will be presiding over a forum Friday to discuss the future of Lower Manhattan.

title: TORU TAKEMITSU;Like Grass
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Gail Moskowitz, Mitchell Novick
description: Dr. Gail Moskowitz, an immunohematologist, and Mitchell Perry Novick, a lawyer, are to be married today in Passaic, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Herman is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanuel.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS Tribute to a Jazz School That Started It All

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: WEST SIDE;Judging the Best at Singing to the Heavens
description: SCHOOL gospel choirs from around the country will compete on Friday and Saturday at the Martin Luther King Jr. High School Auditorium at Lincoln Center in an annual event that has expanded immensely over the years.

title: The Issue Is Respect;Lest We Forget
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: QUICK BITE;Where Turkey Is in Taste
description: The German-Tudor decor and coats-of-arms lining the dark walls suggest the kind of place that would serve steak and sauerkraut. But it takes only one bite of the specialties at Nick's Pizzeria & Family Restaurant for your tastebuds to be transported to Turkey.

title: Norman C. Keith, 83, a Founder And Director of 3 Oil Companies
description: Norman Clinton Keith, a Presbyterian minister's son who founded three oil companies and briefly served as acting president of Springfield College in Springfield, Mass., died on March 15 at his home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 83.

title: BACKTALK;Gibson Girls Become Basketball Women
description: Stella McCray, a Stanford University sophomore, was not used to playing basketball indoors. To her, running on the slippery wood floors was dangerous and sure to result in injuries.

title: In Balkan War, Many Parties Are Culpable
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Who Bought Boardwalk?

title: GOVERNMENT;For These Artists, State Grants Meant More Than Just Food on the Table
description: In the past, only a few of the 1,000 or so New Jersey artists who applied for fellowships from the State Council on the Arts each year were lucky enough and talented enough to be chosen for grants of $5,000, $7,000 or $12,000. Now, at least for the time being, there won't even be those lucky few. The council is suspending its fellowship program, which awarded grants to 64 artists in July, because of a cut in support from the National Endowment for the Arts, a reduction in the council's staff and an increase in its workload.

title: BEST SELLERS:
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: HOOP IS THICKER THAN WATER
description: It is ironic that Rick Barry's four sons have excelled in basketball despite the ambivalent feelings (if not outright resentment) they harbor toward their legendary father ("Hoop Is Thicker Than Water," by Bruce Schoenfeld, March 3).

title: The View From: Elmsford;Presto. It's Baseball Without a Park.
description: OPENING day is less than two weeks away, but for those who need a baseball fix sooner than that, there is now Designated Hitter. This simulation of honest-to-goodness baseball -- step up to the plate, hold a real bat, hit a real ball and then a computer takes over -- has been drawing fans of the great American game to Sportime U.S.A. since it was installed at the indoor recreation center here a few months ago. And, with spring training in full swing and baseball fever, as sportcasters like to call it, in the air, the crowds are getting bigger.

title: Businesses Should Be Loyal To Employees, Clinton Says
description: Harking back to the workplace reforms of the Progressive Era, President Clinton came to this old industrial state today to urge American companies to share success with their workers in the form of better benefits and training and announced that he would hold a conference in Washington to showcase good companies next month.

title: FILM;A Sisterhood On Camera and Off
description: FOR MORE THAN AN HOUR, Goldie Hawn, Diane Keaton and Bette Midler, brimming with wicked glee, clink Champagne flutes and drink lukewarm ginger ale in the cozily rich living room of an East Side town house.

title: NEW JERSEY & CO.;Jersey City (of All Places) Morphs Into a Cybermarket
description: Albert Blanco was elated when his company, Meta4 Digital Design, was selected last July as one of four finalists to redesign General Electric's site on the World Wide Web. But when General Electric officials said they wanted to visit the company's Jersey City offices, Mr. Blanco quickly became despondent.

title: Liberties;The Last Laugh
description: Don Imus knew something was awry when he made a raunchy joke about President Clinton and looked over to check his reaction.

title: Scientists Discover All Kinds of Friends
description: GOV. JOHN G. ROWLAND has been stung by beekeepers. And by farmers, horticultural-business owners, environmentalists, foresters, public health officials and householders who do their own landscaping.

title: Bias Is Seen in Removal Of Prosecutor From Case
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton and other civil-rights advocates urged the Federal Government today to prevent Gov. George E. Pataki from removing the Bronx District Attorney from the prosecution of a potential death penalty case, saying the removal violated Federal laws barring racial discrimination against voters.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Expos' Alou Extends Pact
description: Montreal Expos Manager FELIPE ALOU said yesterday that he would exercise his option to extend his contract through next season. "I assure you it has nothing to do with revenue sharing," said Alou. "I made the decision before camp opened. (AP)

title: THE BIRDCAGE';A Family Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION VIEW;Long Ago, When Burns Wasn't So Lovable
description: WHEN I WAS A BOY, I thought of the comedian George Burns, who died on March 9 at the age of 100, as a vaguely sinister figure. That's because the George Burns of my youth was not the huggably wise and wisecracking Jewish leprechaun he would become after "The Sunshine Boys" rejuvenated his career in 1975. The Burns of my youth was the straight man to his wife, Gracie Allen, on television's "George Burns and Gracie Allen Show" and a very different sort of fellow.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Landmarks Group Helps Temple Fight A Subway Eyesore
description: Dr. Alan Singer decided late last year that he could no longer stand "looking at our eyesore of a closed subway station entrance." He was talking about the southwest corner of 70th Street and Central Park West, next to Congregation Shearith Israel, where he is executive director. The entrance is at the south end of the station where B and C trains stop; the two remaining entrances are two blocks north, at 72d Street.

title: A Modern Medieval Castle
description: ANYONE brought up on fairy tales has a weakness for castles. When traveling around Britain, my husband, James, and I often make unlikely detours to visit one. Many are vacant shells or shattered heaps of stone, which as a romantic I find intriguing. Since James is a modernist architect, he is less interested in tramping over grassy ruins than in exploring extant buildings. When we discovered Castle Drogo, near Drewsteignton at the edge of Dartmoor in Devon, we found a castle we could both love. Hidden at the end of a long moorland drive and approached by a series of narrow, winding and high-hedged lanes, Castle Drogo is the last grand castle built in England. Completed after 20 years of construction -- the first stones were laid in 1911 and the Drewes began living there in 1927 -- it is a modern masterpiece designed by Edwin Lutyens (1869-1944), often considered England's greatest 20th-century architect.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WEST;For Kansas and Syracuse, Heroes Surface at Last Minute
description: One already sees a sports psychologist; the other sent Georgia searching for one.

title: Hearing Weighs New Plebiscite on Puerto Rico
description: Opening another chapter in the long and complex relationship between this island territory and the United States, a Republican Congressman led a hearing today on a bill he said could bring either sovereignty or statehood to Puerto Rico by 2010.

title: Ex-Wives' Tales
description: ASKING FOR LOVE And Other Stories. By Roxana Robinson. 275 pp. New York: Random House. $23.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;In Los Angeles, the Esthetic of Urban Grit
description: THE MET, THE MODERN, the Pompidou Center: art museums don't just display art. They portray art. They depict in three dimensions the position art occupies in a given place and time. Bergamot Station, a sprawling complex of commercial art galleries in Santa Monica, may well be the most accurate portrait of the art world in the 1990's. An ad hoc collection of ramshackle metal sheds once occupied by a company that made hot-water heaters, Bergamot Station is an ideal shelter for an art world stripped of the prosperity that covered it in the 1980's like a thick layer of goose fat.

title: JUDO;Circle of Support Extends Beyond the Mat
description: DONALD and BEATRIZ VALERA SCHUTZ Her parents, both from Houston, met as students at Rice and moved to suburban New Jersey. Her father, a Teledyne executive with a Ph.D. in geology, became a brown belt to stay in touch with his daughters' training. Once she began competing in national tournaments, he became her roadie. Her mother is Deputy Attorney General of New Jersey. NAGAYASU OGASAWARA Her only judo teacher, Ogasawara came to Westwood 29 years ago from Japan and slept in a back room of his dojo for the first four years. He married a local student, Christine. Their older daughter, Liliko, a 23-year-old student at San Jose State, is also on the Olympic team. It is not clear whether United States judo officials will give up a mat-side spot so that Ogasawara can coach Liliko and Schutz in Atlanta.

title: THE METHOD OF A NEO-NAZI MOGUL
description: Stephan Talty links George Burdi's Resistance Records to a recent hate crime because the accused murderer "had a copy of Resistance magazine in his rented room." Didn't we used to call this McCarthyism?

title: Child Welfare Will Suffer Under Block Grants
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation;You, Too, Can Balance the Federal Budget
description: ANYBODY can balance the Federal budget over seven years. I did it in a couple of hours.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Memories, Short and Long
description: Whaddya mean it was cut?" Sid Ascher growled at the telephone. "I've been a newspaper columnist for 50 years. A newspaper always cuts a column from the bottom. Anything important, you put at the top. You couldn't put them closer to the top?"

title: THE METHOD OF A NEO-NAZI MOGUL
description: Wait a minute. Are those anemic-looking youths in your photos going to be the foot soldiers in Burdi's Aryan army? Are those our Supermen? Which reminds me (as I try to wipe the incredulous grin from my face), if they possess such strength and wisdom, what are they doing keying cowardly hate messages on the Internet from the safe cocoon of home?

title: YOUR HOME;Access for Disabled In a Co-op
description: RONNI LYNN AROUGHETI, the president of Heron Ltd., a Manhattan property management company, thought there was little about co-op management that could surprise her. But when one of her clients received a discrimination complaint from the city's Commission on Human Rights, Mrs. Arougheti was caught off guard.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Wolters Being Recognized as a Star
description: On Thursday night, Kara Wolters and her Connecticut teammates watched the National Basketball Association game between the Bulls and the Knicks in Chicago. While the center of attraction on the court was Michael Jordan, the star in the stands was Wolters.

title: The Belle Curve
description: Statistically, it's a fact that every decade or so a bubble bursts on the scene.

title: Q and A
description: Perfume in France

title: THE METHOD OF A NEO-NAZI MOGUL
description: Your magazine is only helping mindless white cretins like this George Burdi character by giving them all the space you did in Stephan Talty's "Method of a Neo-Nazi Mogul" (Feb. 25). In a way, you almost encourage the curious to go looking for their Web sites and music.

title: Home for 'Head' By Lichtenstein
description: The beautiful "Modern Head" ["Lichtenstein 'Head' Upsets Southampton," Jan. 28] that had a brief showing in Agawam Park in Southampton has a home on the lawn of the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor. And I must say that when one drives through the gates and encounters this magnificent piece of sculpture it sets the sensual mood one experiences once inside the museum and grounds.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: LIVING THE DREAM My Life and Basketball. By Hakeem Olajuwon with Peter Knobler. Little, Brown, $22.95.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Manila Airport Judged Secure by F.A.A.
description: The Ninoy Aquino International Airport in Manila, which the Federal Aviation Administration last year said lacked proper safeguards for travelers, now meets the standards for effective security, the agency announced earlier this month.

title: Bull in a China Shop' Shakes City for the Better
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;24 Sri Lankan Soldiers Die in Attack by Rebels
description: Tamil Tiger rebels killed 24 Sri Lankan soldiers and wounded 14 in an attack on an army patrol near the eastern town of Batticaloa today, police officials said.

title: SOAPBOX;Driving From St. Petersburg
description: IT took a 4,800-mile trip to make me fully appreciate New Jersey. For most of my 35 years, it was simply my state, the place I hung my hat; I gave little thought to my status as a lifelong resident and a citizen. Then, on a recent visit to Russia, I met Vladimir.

title: Like, as in Grammar
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDENING;Starting Pest Control Before the Buds Break
description: TIMING, they say, is everything. And there is no time like the present to get the upper hand on scales, those hard-to-rout insects that hug stems and leaves under a self-made waxy protection.

title: Tarrytown Music Hall Thrives on Diversity
description: OVER one weekend last year, the Music Hall here shared its stage with a potpourri of music and sporting events. On Friday, there was an evening of Irish music; on Saturday, two folk-rockers performed, and on Sunday, the USA Bodybuilding Championships took over.

title: A Modest Strike;For the U.A.W., It's Not the Revolution
description: AT first glance, the basic relationship between labor and capital in the United States seemed to be changing last week.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: CONFESSIONS OF AN EX-DRAG QUEEN
description: I did some calculating based on your Sunday item "Confessions of an Ex-Drag Queen" (Feb. 25). Prior to kicking the habit (and based on a 16-hour smoking day), Melissa Bellinelli was firing up at a rate of 1 cigarette every 12 minutes, 5 cigarettes an hour, 4 packs a day, 28 packs a week, 112 packs a month, 1,354 packs a year.

title: Streetscapes/Gould Memorial Library;A Spectacular Interior Designed by Stanford White
description: FEW people know one of New York's most spectacular interiors, just as sumptuous as the New York Public Library and just as dazzling as the Chrysler Building. It's the 1899 Gould Memorial Library, at New York University's old uptown campus, on 180th Street between Sedgwick and University Avenues -- now Bronx Community College. The grand, domed reading room, designed by Stanford White, has long been idle, but now Bronx Community College is making progress in returning it to use.

title: La Jolla
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Daniel Sharfstein's article, "The Shimmering Jewel of La Jolla" (Jan. 21). As someone who has visited La Jolla at least annually for 20 years, I share his enthusiasm.

title: Police Won't Respond If Alarm Fee Is Not Paid
description: NEARLY 400 Suffolk County business owners have been advised that if they do not pay a burglar alarm licensing fee, the police will not respond if that alarm is activated. Eventually, as the police department works its way through the pile of scofflaws, another 5,500 violators will get the same letter.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about corporate medical benefits for executives and rank-and-file workers misstated the relationship of two executives in the Gannett Company, one of the companies cited. John J. Curley, the chief executive, is the brother of Thomas Curley, the publisher of USA Today, which is owned by Gannett.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;Global Thinker Keeps Neighborhood Safe for Radicals
description: From his law office across Avenue D from the Jacob Riis Houses and above the Bravo Supermarket, Stanley Cohen likes to think -- and act -- globally and locally.

title: POLITICS: CONGRESSIONAL MEMO;Fervor of Freshman Wanes As Re-Election Time Nears
description: For the 73 Republican freshmen in the House, many of them uncompromising anti-politicians who have said they would rather be right than representatives, an awful realization is dawning: Soon, they might actually have to choose between the two.

title: Guatemalans Covered Up Killing Of an American, U.S. Aides Say
description: Two Guatemalan Presidents, two Defense Ministers and high-ranking military officers paid by the Central Intelligence Agency helped cover up the facts of the killing of Michael DeVine, an American innkeeper in Guatemala, in 1990, United States officials have concluded.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;Hale House Stoop Stirs Flap
description: To many people, the name Hale House, the Harlem charity that cares for orphaned and abandoned infants, is beyond reproach. But at least some people who share the block with Hale House, on West 122d Street between Malcolm X and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevards, are not impressed with its neighborliness.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Jakarta
description: Jakarta makes no bones about its ambitions. A decade of frenetic construction has transformed Indonesia's capital into a glassy hub of commerce, with more skyscrapers under way. New night spots and designer shops seek to dissuade newly wealthy residents from spending overseas.

title: The Seeds of His Own Destruction
description: TROTSKY The Eternal Revolutionary. By Dmitri Volkogonov. Edited and translated by Harold Shukman. Illustrated. 524 pp. New York: The Free Press. $32.50.

title: Correction
description: A front-page cross reference last Sunday to an article about historic tours focusing on women misstated the century in which a female shipowner, Margaret Hardenbroeck Philipse, lived. It was the 17th century, not the 19th.

title: WEDDINGS;Beth Rosenberg, Joseph A. Herz
description: Beth Susan Rosenberg, the daughter of Audrey and Manuel Rosenberg of Boston, was married there last evening to Joseph Andrew Herz, the son of Leslie and Dr. Marvin Herz of Fairport, N.Y. Rabbi Elaine Zecher performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel.

title: Ancient Texts for a Modern Age
description: THE Haggadah, one of the world's most ancient books, holds a special place in Jewish culture. The text has been a centerpiece of Passover seders for generations of Jews, to be read aloud in explanation of such rites as Kaddish.

title: The Grunge American Novel
description: ERVOUSNESS AND DREAD frequently chase David Foster Wallace, and when they catch him, as they have now, he writhes and twitches and prattles at a breakneck clip, his incessant quips running the gamut from marvelous to mundane. "Do you have my saliva?" he asks a companion in his cab, reflecting on the way his jitters have drained all moisture from his mouth. "Somebody took my saliva, because I don't have it."

title: BASEBALL;Looking to San Francisco Voters To Send Message to Steinbrenner
description: There are two enormously appealing arguments for the proposed 42,000-seat baseball park at San Francisco's China Basin: one, a 335-foot home run down the right-field line will splash into the bay, and two, the $255 million park will be built entirely with private money. If voters clear the way by granting a zoning exemption on Tuesday, perhaps we can also consider the plan a message to New York: Let George Steinbrenner pay for his own sandbox.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Davis and Hitchcock Settle In With Seattle
description: Successful or not, Tino Martinez will be remembered as the player who replaced Don Mattingly. But include Russ Davis and Sterling Hitchcock in the future trivia question because they are the players who were traded for the player who will be remembered as the player who replaced Don Mattingly.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: BUT BEAUTIFUL A Book About Jazz. By Geoff Dyer. North Point /Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $21.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Refusing to Knuckle Under, in 1666 or Ever
description: ENTER Alceste, consummate critic, eternal outsider and alienated man nonpareil. Sustaining a terminal case of sincerity, he will not bend to "false and artificial intercourse" and "meaningless embraces." Might as well break with the whole human race, he reasons. So he does.

title: The Jew Who Fought to Stay German
description: ON A BLEAK DAY IN MAY 1942, a 61-year-old disenfranchised German Jew named Victor Klemperer, trapped in Nazi Germany, noted in his diary: "I continue to write. This is my heroics. I want to bear witness, precise witness, until the very end." He was a former professor of Romance languages at the Technical University of Dresden and had escaped deportation to the death camps in the east only because he was married to an "Aryan" woman. Gestapo agents, on a routine checkup, had just ransacked his room in one of the cramped "Jews' houses" on the outskirts of Dresden to which he and his wife had been confined after the confiscation of his house.

title: The Issue Is Respect
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MUSIC;Programs Highlight Women's Achievements
description: BEFORE Women's History Month becomes history, several programs are highlighting the accomplishments of female artists. Tuesday evening at 8, Ju-Ying Song makes her county debut at the Emelin Theater, playing works by Haydn, Schumann, Chopin, Debussy and Liszt. The young pianist was born in Taiwan, raised in Geneva and currently working on her doctorate at Juilliard, where among other honors, she was the 1996 recipient of the William Petschek Award. For reservations, call the box office at 698-0098.

title: DIARY
description: LABOR

title: Delay in Menendez Case
description: A judge on Friday reluctantly granted a two-day delay in the start of the sentencing hearing for Lyle and Erik Menendez after defense lawyers said they needed more time to bring in out-of-town witnesses to describe the brothers' troubled lives.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of the architect Rem Koolhaas on March 3 with an article about him and his new book, "S, M, L, XL," carried an incorrect credit. The photograph was by Lina Bertucci, not the Monacelli Press.

title: Barge Trips
description: To the Editor: I must take exception to your reference to the Queen of Holland (Q & A, Jan. 21) as a luxury ship. I had the misfortune of booking on a two-week Amsterdam-to-Vienna trip last July. The ship's food and service were poor. I left the ship in disgust four days early.

title: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
description: Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions, and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.

title: 5 Found Shot Dead In Burning House
description: A family of five was found shot to death inside their burning home on Friday, and investigators were uncertain whether the killer was an intruder or one of the family members.

title: Shuttle Atlantis Successfully Docks With Russian Space Station
description: The shuttle Atlantis linked up with Russia's space station 245 miles above Earth tonight, despite some earlier worry about a leak in a steering system that was found on Friday.

title: Dress Rehearsal For G.M. Closing
description: THREE decades and what seems like a lifetime ago, Otto Rivera, a lanky youth from the Bronx, drove to his first day of work here in a sporty, light blue 1963 Chevrolet Bel Aire. Since those first years working on the assembly line at General Motors, there have been promotions, a wife and family, a home in the suburbs and a series of newer model cars. Life was everything Mr. Rivera had hoped for, until his 47th birthday this year.

title: WEDDINGS;Adele T. Reilly, William R. Grant
description: Adele Teresa Reilly, a vice president at American Continental Properties, a real-estate investment concern in New York, was married yesterday to William Robert Grant, the chairman of Galen Associates, a venture-capital company in New York. The Rev. Donald Desmond performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: THEATER;Sculpturing a Play Into Existence
description: EARLIER THIS MONTH, more than two years after he had finished the first draft of "Seven Guitars," and in the middle of the play's pre-Broadway run in Los Angeles, the playwright August Wilson peremptorily cut five pages from the opening of the second act. This wasn't unusual. Plays often go through substantial adjustments on their way to opening night, and Mr. Wilson is probably more eagle-eyed, more persnickety, more of a tinkerer than most.

title: Death in Dublin
description: HOOD By Emma Donoghue. 309 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $23.

title: Islamic Rule Is Reaffirmed By Sudan Chief
description: Hundreds of Sudanese poured into the streets of Khartoum today to hear their newly elected President, Lieut. Gen. Omar al-Bashir, vow to keep the country ruled by "Islamic law and dignity," with no return to party politics.

title: Rising Stars
description: WHY is this pizza different from all other pizzas?

title: THE METHOD OF A NEO-NAZI MOGUL
description: Despite the depressing nature of your article on the young neo-Nazis, I was able to take away something positive from it all. Burdi's endorsement of a movie like "Pulp Fiction" indicates a failure on his part to stay true to his ideals of racial purity and blind racial hatred. Several major characters in the movie are played by African-American actors and there is even an interracial marriage.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CROSSWORD PUZZLERS

title: This Suffragist Didn't Stop At Equal Rights for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Can't Go Home Again? Tell These Frisky Strays
description: Executive Decision Kurt Russell, Steven Seagal, Halle Berry Directed by Stuart Baird R 132 minutes

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;Didgeridoo? They Hear You.
description: A first-time customer at the Music Inn could be forgiven for not feeling especially welcome. A chain sometimes stretches across the entrance, and the owner, Jerry Halpern, may stand at the door scowling. But once Mr. Halpern realizes that a visitor is truly interested not in "voodoo or something," but in the musical instruments from all corners of the world that cram his tiny store, he is an attentive, affable proprietor.

title: March 17-24;An Assault-Gun Offensive
description: One slogan of the House Republicans has been "promises made, promises kept," and on Friday they kept one to the National Rifle Association. The gun ownership group put the bulk of its $5.6 million in political spending behind Republicans in the 1994 election, and on Friday, with just two days' notice, the House voted 239 to 173 to repeal a two-year-old ban on 19 types of semi-automatic weapons and on high-capacity ammunition clips.

title: Don't Condemn All Germans for the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Decontrol At the End Of a J-51

title: Dead Soldier Is Identified
description: An American soldier who died Friday night after his truck ran off a temporary bridge while on a supply run was identified today as Pfc. Floyd E. Bright, 19, of Houston, United States Army officials said. They said he was a passenger in the truck, which was driven by Pvt. Joseph E. Dory, 22, of Edwards, Colo., who suffered a broken shoulder blade and bruises. Private Edwards was listed in good condition at a mobile Army surgical hospital at Camp Bedrock near the town of Donja Visca.

title: SOAPBOX;An Anchor Made of Brownstone
description: FOR 25 years I lived in high-rise Manhattan. The only way I could tell if it was raining was to look out the window to see if the cars were using their windshield wipers. That seems odd now.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Saberhagen Feeling Pain
description: BRET SABERHAGEN, who has been playing catch with the Colorado Rockies' trainer, DAVE CILLADI, every other day in Tucson, Ariz., since March 2, said Friday that he has started feeling pain in the back of his shoulder. "The good thing is there's no continual aches and pains when I'm sleeping or throwing playing catch," said Saberhagen, who was acquired from the Mets last July 31 and had arthroscopic surgery Oct. 24 to repair a torn shoulder ligament. "Only when I try to put something on it." (AP)

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;A Shadowy Future Looms For West 10th Street
description: Three months ago, David Ross fled the anonymous white-brick canyons of the Upper East Side and bought a studio in the far West Village. Mr. Ross, a 37-year-old artist, was drawn to the neighborhood of warehouses, garages and brownstones along the Hudson because of the smaller scale, the abundance of light and the 19th-century maritime architecture.

title: China Says Taiwan Election Shows That Voters Oppose Separation Fromthe Mainland
description: In a muted reaction to Lee Teng-hui's strong showing in Taiwan's presidential election on Saturday, China claimed a victory of its own today by interpreting the results as a sign that voters oppose the notion of separating Taiwan from mainland China.

title: Moonlighting
description: A PLACE TO FALL By Roger Director. 243 pp. New York: Villard. $22.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Reconfiguring the Michelin Firmament
description: The news of the 1996 Michelin guides was cause for celebration in some European kitchens, while in others, chefs may have felt like throwing in the towel. The famous judgments, issued country by country from December through March, were, as usual, full of heartbreak and surprise.

title: WEDDINGS;Kathryn Parlan, Austin Hearst
description: Kathryn Ellen Parlan, the daughter of Ellie Parlan of Bridgewater, N.J., and Stanley Parlan of Laguna Hills, Calif., was married on March 9 to Austin Hearst, a son of the late Austine McDonnell Hearst and William Randolph Hearst Jr. The Rev. Kelly Cannon, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's farm in San Simeon, Calif.

title: THE BIRDCAGE';Affirmation of Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Condemn All Germans for the Holocaust;No Blanket Indictment
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense Missile Fails in Its Second Test
description: An Army rocket being developed to defend against medium-range missiles failed to hit its target in a test on Friday, the Pentagon announced.

title: STYLE;'And the Outfit Is...'
description: Crossing and uncrossing my legs is not the only trick in my bag. And my breasts are not actresses. I mean, I turned in a performance. I've been nominated for an Academy Award. I plan to look subtle and dignified for this occasion. Go ahead, snicker. But what if God was one of us? Just a slob on the bus, or whatever. Think about it.

title: The View From: Fair Haven;Cheers for a Library Returning After Two Years on Hold
description: IT was 8:30 on a Tuesday morning, one of the first days of the February school vacation, and the little boy's face was pressed against the glass of the door at the Fair Haven Branch of the New Haven Public Library.

title: Clinton's Gunboat Diplomacy
description: As revelers made their way home through the streets of Taipei yesterday after celebrating Taiwan's first democratic presidential election, Beijing and Washington were no doubt sharing some sobering reflections.

title: HOME CLINIC;Hanging Pictures to Best Advantage
description: THERE are two reasons to hang pictures: the first is to complement the decor in a room; the second is to showcase a work of art. While it is possible to combine the two objectives -- by using a fine painting as the focal point of a design scheme, for example -- more often the artwork is wasted when decoration becomes the sole consideration.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Kings' McDaniel Injured
description: The Sacramento Kings rookie guard CLINT McDANIEL suffered a concussion yesterday during practice after he collided with a teammate as he went up for a layup. McDaniel was scheduled to undergo tests at the University of California, Davis Medical Center. A team statement said that he was listed in good condition. McDaniel, 24, suffered a concussion and was unconscious for about 15 minutes. (AP)

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;The Other Lauren
description: MAYBE it's because he doesn't want to be thought of as just another privileged son of a famous father. Or perhaps he's wary of being dismissed as another preppy hunk. Maybe it's a generational thing.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CENTRAL BROOKLYN;Divide and Conquer: Inner-City Children Getting Into Math
description: At twilight, when the rest of the children in the neighborhood are more likely watching television than crunching numbers, a dozen girls at the Mahalia Jackson School in Crown Heights pore over lessons in calculating means and medians. In another corner of the middle school, students are being trained in martial arts and dance. A few miles north, in Bushwick, a class of teen-agers, fresh from 90 minutes of soccer, review the principles of percentages.

title: The Mark of the Beast
description: GOOD NATURED The Origins of Right and Wrong in Humans and Other Animals. By Frans de Waal. Illustrated. 296 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $24.95.

title: WEDDINGS;Marci J. Hook, Mark E. Kamberg
description: Marci Jill Hook, the daughter of Elaine and Leonard Hook of Kew Gardens, Queens, was married last evening to Mark Eugene Kamberg, a son of Judith and Stephen Kamberg of Hollis Hills, Queens. Rabbi Isador Eisenberg performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: THE NIGHT;Of Blondes (Or Not) And Divas
description: DONATELLA VERSACE, the younger sister and creative partner of Gianni Versace, says she should have gone blond in the womb.

title: WEDDINGS;Paula Russo, David Woodman
description: Paula Russo, the daughter of Carol and Michael Russo of Wayne, N.J., is to be married today to David Richard Woodman, a son of Cherry Woodman and Dr. Richard Woodman of Redwood City, Calif. Msgr. James O'Rourke is to perform the ceremony at Our Lady of the Valley Church in Wayne.

title: World News Briefs;Former South Korea Aide Accused of Taking Bribes
description: South Korean Government prosecutors sought an arrest warrant for a former presidential aide today, in a move that may further damage the governing party before parliamentary elections next month.

title: A Sports Proposal for Pilgrim Site
description: FOR 20 years the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in West Brentwood has been the subject of many redevelopment proposals: a regional incinerator, a juvenile detention center and a state prison. Community opposition was instrumental in defeating those plans.

title: Gyula Kallai, 85, Former Premier Of Hungary
description: Gyula Kallai, a Hungarian intellectual who shared the vagaries of postwar Communism at the side of Janos Kadar, the party chief installed after the 1956 uprising, died on March 12 after a long illness, news dispatches from Budapest reported. He was 85.

title: Crackdown on Smoking Aims for the Wrong Target
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Coping column last Sunday, about the stress of the college admissions process, misspelled the given name of the director of college counseling at the Horace Mann School. He is Stephen Singer, not Steven.

title: Taming the Passover Plagues for Easy Consumption
description: Four times the Bible reminds parents that they must teach their children the story of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt. If a plastic frog and some rubber lice will help get the job done, Simon Jaffe is all for it.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSVILLE;Instead of School, a Youth Jail
description: Four blocks down the hill from Intermediate School 55 in Brownsville, construction crews are busy at work on a state-of-the-art installation that, starting this fall, will serve more than 100 teen-agers. The spacious $24 million building will have plenty of light and a quiet courtyard away from the bustle of the street.

title: Storming the Gates
description: EDOUARD MANET Rebel in a Frock Coat. By Beth Archer Brombert. Illustrated. 505 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $29.95.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: ACT OF BETRAYAL By Edna Buchanan. Hyperion, $21.95.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Loss Gives A Phenom An Outing As Fodder
description: Since reaching the big leagues after the All-Star Game break last season, right-hander Jason Isringhausen has been so consistently good that it's easy to forget he is still a young pitcher with growing pains to endure.

title: WEDDINGS;Linda M. Mollica, Andrew Lippman
description: Linda Margaret Mollica, a daughter of Mary Jean and Joseph Mollica of Princeton, N.J., was married last evening to Andrew Seth Lippman, a son of Arlene and Dr. Leonard Lippman of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. James R. Covington, a Unitarian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: INSIDE
description: Fearing the Wilson Factor

title: GOOD EATING;Multiple Choices Near the Theaters
description: CARMINE'S * (212) 221-3800; 200 West 44th Street; (c) American Express

title: March 17-24;Sane and Guilty
description: The insanity defense rarely succeeds. Proof came again in the trial of John C. Salvi 3d, who was accused of killing two receptionists and wounding five other people at two abortion clinics in Brookline in 1994. Mr. Salvi's lawyers acknowledged he had committed the shootings, the worst single act of violence at abortion clinics in the U.S. But they claimed Mr. Salvi's attacks had nothing to do with abortion. They argued that he was acting under schizophrenic delusions that he was saving the Roman Catholic church from a conspiracy by Freemasons, the Mafia and the Ku Klux Klan.

title: ROAD SHOWS;All the Vermeers In New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Over the Top
description: The T-shirt, that all-American classic, has acquired a new image and fit. Inspired by professional-sports tops, these color-blocked, form-fitting shirts have gone high-tech, with many in synthetic blends. They can be worn by men of all ages for everything from working out to volleyball -- and even, for those who have the energy, dancing at nightclubs.

title: You Can Quote Me
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times;Fewer Questions For Calipari
description: AT times, Massachusetts Coach John Calipari sounds like a salesman selling a product that is too good to be true. At other times he is like a radio evangelist. Always, he sounds like a coach.

title: DINING OUT;Hit or Miss in a Lovely Japanese Setting
description: IF restaurants were movies, Kyoto would be "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde." The first night at this Japanese newcomer in East Northport was Dr. Jekyll's turn. The restaurant captured the spirit of Japan and provided more than just another predictable meal at a suburban spot.

title: THE BIRDCAGE';Like True Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: The Grunge American Novel
description: NERVOUSNESS AND DREAD frequently chase David Foster Wallace, and when they catch him, as they have now, he writhes and twitches and prattles at a breakneck clip, his incessant quips running the gamut from marvelous to mundane. ''Do you have my saliva?'' he asks a companion in his cab, reflecting on the way his jitters have drained all moisture from his mouth. ''Somebody took my saliva, because I don't have it.''

title: Bright Comet Is Making Its Closest Approach to Earth Tonight
description: Comet Hyakutake, the brightest comet in 20 years, will reach its closest approach to Earth tonight, revealing itself to viewers with access to clear, dark skies and affording scores of observatories a rare opportunity to study some primeval ingredients of the solar system.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday with an article about the revitalization of Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, misstated the addresses of a restaurant and of a shopping plaza that is under construction.
