The restaurant, Lundy's, is at 1901 Emmons Avenue; the shopping center, Loehmann's Plaza, is at 2027-2063 Emmons Avenue.

title: Live Animal Use Spurs Protests
description: LIVE animal experiments that some doctors call essential and others say are useless are stirring protests at New York Medical College here.

title: ON THE STREET;Panache In Paris
description: It was an eclectic scene at the recent fashion shows in Paris, at least among the guests and the press. Like crocuses, some popped up in Easter egg-colored short Chanel jackets, like the one worn by Liz Tilberis, editor of Harper's Bazaar (left in photo). Anna Wintour, editor of Vogue (below left), wore a tulip-red bias-cut suit with a flared skirt. Color turned long striped jersey skirts brilliant.

title: SPENDING IT;Leaping Laptops! As Computers Shrink, Thefts Grow
description: SCOTT FRIEDMAN, a motivational speaker from Denver, and Evelyn Barish, a professor of English from New York City, have never met. But they have more in common than they know.

title: OUTDOORS;Fishers and Catchers, or the Trout Equivalent of 'Play Ball!'
description: For many, the April 1 opening of the trout season in New York State will be a symbolic farewell to an unusually assertive and tenacious winter.

title: An Officer on Every Subway Train: A Popular Promise That Disappeared
description: In 1990, New York City, battered by a record crime wave, demanded action, so its new Mayor, David N. Dinkins, proposed swelling the ranks of the police by almost 3,500 officers. But the price was steep: higher income and property taxes.

title: SKIING;Street Injured During Dash
description: Picabo Street, the star of the United States women's ski team, hit a gate during an exhibition race today and suffered head, neck and back injuries.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;Bookshelf
description: NEXT YEAR IN JERUSALEM: 3000 Years of Jewish Stories. Retold by Howard Schwartz. Illustrated by Neil Waldman. Viking. $16.99. (Ages 6 and up) A collection of folk tales, fairy tales, legends, even a vampire story, about the golden city is thoughtfully organized to include commentary about each tale, set in the margin of the page. Stylized watercolor illustrations.

title: Where Riverhead Went Wrong
description: I am very happy that someone has recognized the efforts that are under way to revitalize Riverhead and those that are devoting their time to this endeavor are finally getting some of the credit due them ["Riverhead Battling Steep Decline," March 3].

title: Polo Plan Incurs Neighbor's Wrath
description: AFTER a successful first season, the Bridgehampton Polo Club Inc. has asked the Southampton Town Board to issue another special events permit that will this year allow them to expand from four matches to six.

title: ART;The Sum of Circles and Rectangles Is Equal to the Building Blocks of Life
description: BACK to square one might describe "Infinite Measure," the lean, instructive exhibition currently at the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport. The show investigates geometry in nature and in the works of humankind, and it does so on attractive placards.

title: THE SENATOR CANNOT HELP BEING HIMSELF
description: Senator D'Amato may get more respect when he stops acting like a buffoon. Singing inane parodies of children's songs on the floor of the Senate and reveling in publicity about a high-profile fling with a gossip maven do not lend themselves to the Senator's pretensions of gravitas.

title: WEDDINGS;Hillary Cramer And Marc Blank
description: Hillary Dawn Cramer, a financial analyst at Capital Cities/ABC in Manhattan, was married last evening to Marc Adam Blank, who teaches the sixth grade at Public School 17 in the Bronx. Rabbi George Schlesinger officiated at Congregation B'nai Tikvah in North Brunswick, N.J.

title: SQUATTER CHIC
description: Squatter Chic" (photographs by Addison Thompson, text by Bruce Benderson, March 3) sent the perverse message that illegal and highly dangerous living conditions can provide a lesson in taste to less-hip city dwellers. The photos suggest a glowingly glamorous life style but fail to illuminate the unsanitary and physically dangerous reality of these apparent oases, in the midst of structurally rotting buildings.

title: IN THE GARDEN;Controlling Pests Before the Buds
description: TIMING, they say, is everything. And there is no time like the present to get the upper hand on scales, those hard-to-rout insects that hug stems and leaves under a self-made waxy protection.

title: In the Region/Connecticut;Design Review for a Seamless Community Fabric
description: TWO years ago Richard Chernevak, partner in the Madison development firm of Heflin Properties Ltd., submitted plans to the Litchfield Planning and Zoning Commission for a new CVS store, confident that the renderings he presented complemented the town's architecture and even the brick firehouse next door.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Philadelphia Feels Effects Of Inquiry
description: After another 60 criminal convictions were overturned by a Common Pleas Court judge this week as a result of a continuing investigation into police corruption here, the various agencies involved say the impact has only begun to be felt.

title: WEDDINGS;Marian C. Raab, M.T. Goldstein
description: Marian Carol Raab, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Selwyn Raab of New York, was married last evening to Matthew Todd Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Goldstein of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony at the City Midday Club in New York.

title: Minyan of Women' Consists of 10 Plays Of 10 Minutes Each
description: THE comedian Milton Berle, telling jokes, used to say to his television audience, "I've got a minyan of them." The Herbert Mark Newman Theater here has a minyan too, but it is light years away from Berle's material.

title: Westchester Q&A: Paul J. McCarthy;How Corporations Obtain a Bond Rating
description: WHEN a corporation or a government wants to issue bonds, it goes to a company like Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company. It is the job of the company to examine the would-be bond issuer, assess its credit worthiness and give the bonds a rating.

title: ART;Where Seating Is Part of the Collection
description: AS spectator sports go, art exhibitions can be as rough on the body as the mind, and I have always felt that galleries that provide chairs should be routinely encouraged, perhaps even subsidized. The Nardin Galleries here deserve that praise, together with a standing ovation for including in its current miscellany art that is comfy to sit in. To put it another way, the show called "Gallery Collection" consists of paintings and drawings as well as seating accommodation, which comes from the craftsmen of West Africa.

title: A Modern American Witch Hunt?
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING IT WORK;Lonely Are the Dead
description: RABBI SHMUEL PLAFKER stood over a plain pine coffin with the name Goldie Adler scrawled across its top. As he does on most days, the rabbi said his prayers to no one in particular.

title: To Fill Posts, F.A.A. Will Pay New York-Area Controllers More
description: The Federal Aviation Administration plans to announce in the next few days that it will pay air-traffic controllers in the New York area significantly more than those where there are fewer flights, officials involved in the planning say. The move is being made in an effort to end a chronic shortage of controllers in New York.

title: Ireland Boasted of a Drug Sting, but Joke Was on the Public
description: An elaborate sting operation intended to show that the Government is cracking down on marijuana smuggling into Ireland has turned into an embarrassing fiasco involving the police and customs services and a suspected drug dealer known as The Monk.

title: Opposition Slows Move Of Capital To Berlin
description: The German Government's move from Bonn to Berlin is being slowed by quiet but fierce resistance from reluctant civil servants, who are unhappy despite being granted a series of benefits that will cost hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: U.S. Gets a Break in Curbing Nigeria Business Fraud Schemes
description: A Nigerian man was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, to be followed by deportation, on Friday in what Federal investigators say is the first arrest and conviction related to international business fraud schemes emanating from the African nation.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS;A Bridge Too Far for Pupils
description: There is no bus ride to school for most of the young students who go to Middle School 142, only a trek under and over highway ramps along an unkempt footbridge that is strewn with water puddles, candy wrappers and crack vials.

title: Dr. Lauren, I Presume? Car Shoppers Go on Safari
description: WITH a nod to the tweedy life-style fantasies promulgated by Ralph Lauren, dealers for Land Rover North America are converting their auto showrooms into sport utility boutiques. There, amid hunting-lodge decor, would-be car buyers can get into a safari state of mind amid props like fishing waders, pith helmets and snowshoes.

title: News Analysis;Death Penalty Test
description: Early Friday morning, Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester County District Attorney, faced television cameras huddled on an Eastchester street where a police officer had been killed, and passionately reaffirmed her commitment to death penalty prosecutions. If the gunman, Richard Sacchi, had not committed suicide, Ms. Pirro would likely have been swift to consider him a candidate for capital punishment.

title: Visions and Revisions
description: William Appleman Williams The Tragedy of Empire. By Paul M. Buhle and Edward Rice-Maximin. 318 pp. New York: Routledge. Cloth, $65. Paper, $16.95.

title: Stolen Ticket
description: To the Editor: While I was visiting Los Angeles on vacation recently, my rental car was broken into and all my belongings were stolen. Included was my return ticket from Los Angeles to Portland, Ore.

title: And the So-So Winner Is . . .;Hey, What's Talent Got to Do With It?
description: CHARLIE CHAPLIN never won an Oscar. Neither did Greta Garbo, Alfred Hitchcock, Barbara Stanwyck or Cary Grant. Marilyn Monroe was never even nominated for one.

title: THE BIRDCAGE';No Feather Boas
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTAURANTS;Barn 'n' Brew
description: Interesting architecture, neat idea, great beer," a resident of this beautiful town said about the new microbrewery and restaurant in his area.

title: A Man's Best Friend
description: Men have always had a soft place in their hearts for sport jackets. No wonder. Since they were traditionally worn for casual country weekends at home or at the club, the associations were always the best. Now that dress codes are relaxed, and the sport jacket can go almost anywhere, it may lose some of that affection, but gain greater respect. No longer confined to bold plaids for the country, jackets come in subtle checks and small geometric patterns in understated colors -- just right for most offices, not only on Friday but every day of the week. And for dinner at the latest smart restaurant, there are plenty of dark, dressy sport coats that look great with a black polo or, if necessary, a white shirt and dark tie. Of course, while certain jackets are best in particular situations, accessories can still work wonders at changing a sport coat's personality.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Temporary LocationsAt Grand Central

title: Costa Rican Road
description: To the Editor: In "Inviting Lodgings, Luxuriant Land" (Feb. 18), Beth Brombert jokingly suggests that the purpose of Costa Rica's bumpy dirt roads is to keep trucks from passing as they do on the paved roads. I thought you might be interested in knowing a different reason not to pave the road to Monteverde.

title: The Three Tenors Juggernaut
description: THE IDEA WAS BIG, and fittingly it came from the big man himself, Luciano Pavarotti. It came to him at a big event, the 1994 sellout "Three Tenors" concert at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles, an extravaganza beamed to 1.3 billion television viewers worldwide, four years after the trio's smash debut in the ruins of ancient Rome, which generated the largest-selling classical recording of all time.

title: JONATHAN FIRE EATER
description: In "A Question for: Jonathan Fire Eater" (Sunday, March 3), I found it interesting and at the same time sad that five 20-somethings answer the question "Who are you guys?" by telling what their parents do for a living.

title: The World;The Idea of Europe Trips Over the Real Thing
description: AFTER two vicious wars, the peace and prosperity enjoyed by Western Europe in the second half of this century can be attributed in good part to a single act in the early 1950's, or at least to the idea behind it.

title: POLITICS: CALIFORNIA;Wilson Seen as a Weak Link for Dole
description: Gov. Pete Wilson of California, once touted as the golden boy of Republican Governors, now finds himself fending off criticism from party leaders around the country who are concerned that his unpopularity here could cost Senator Bob Dole this pivotal state in November.

title: Girl's Life;Math Homework, Lacrosse, Ballet, Nutter Butters: The Whirlwind Days of Meredith, Suburban 6th Grader
description: IT is perilously close to morning bus time and Meredith Phares is speeding up. She ducks out of the kitchen to snatch a homework paper from her father's printer, leaving a bowl of milk with soggy Rice Krispies for her mother to clear. She grabs her bulging black cardboard folder containing fall and winter sixth-grade schoolwork -- a description of Sanskrit as India's sacred language, two-line biographies of famous ancient Greeks, pages of fractions problems, the definition of chyme (partly digested food).

title: Criminal Case Is Ruled Out In Collapse
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office has concluded that it cannot file criminal charges against the owners of a Harlem apartment building that partially collapsed a year ago, killing three people.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Chase Manhattan Needs More Than a Vision for Its Vista Funds
description: IN the mutual fund business, banks are the also-rans. Throughout the 1980's and 90's, as longtime depositors have fled in search of higher returns, banks have taken only the most elementary steps toward building competitive fund groups.

title: Homecoming of Ethnic German Immigrants Sours
description: Emmi Schleicher arrived in Germany from her native Kazakstan six years ago and thought she had finally come home to the land her ancestors left over two centuries ago. Since then, she has learned a painful lesson.

title: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
description: Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions, and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.

title: Misunderstood as Ever
description: BEYOND THE FLOWER The Autobiography of a Feminist Artist. By Judy Chicago. Illustrated. 282 pp. New York: Viking. $27.95.

title: WORD & IMAGE;A Tawdry TV Pageant
description: IS THERE AN adolescent in America who did not know, weeks before its premiere, that "N.Y.P.D. Blue" -- yes, blue -- set out to stretch the boundaries of permissible sex on broadcast television? Is there any parent who doesn't know that "E.R." depicts anguished hospital scenes and gory medical procedures that might frighten a child? Does anyone need a ratings chart to discern the porno promise of a typical hour with Sally Jessy Raphael entitled "Mom, I'm a Teen Prostitute"?

title: Spicy Thai Fare, With a Little Bit of Laos
description: AHA," we thought, when we first heard about Moukratry Thai-Lao in Bridgeport, "maybe this is the beginning of a new trend, Laotian cooking."

title: First Closing Of Incinerator Renews Focus On Disposing Of Garbage
description: A DECISION by Glen Cove to dismantle its $10 million incinerator because it had become an economic and environmental albatross has raised anew questions about solid-waste disposal on Long Island.

title: Sports of The Times;Baseball Asks Fans For a Commitment
description: THE leapers are leaping and the skaters are skating, but in exactly seven days baseball is going to make a major demand: "We're back. Love us. We're here for you every day. We deserve attention."

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: INTIMACY AND TERROR Soviet Diaries of the 1930s. Edited by Veronique Garros, Natalia Korenevskaya and Thomas Lahusen. New Press, $27.50.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Jewish Museum to Show Early Chagall Works
description: Marc Chagall 1907-17," a survey of the artist's formative years, will open at the Jewish Museum in New York next Sunday. The exhibition examines the period during which Chagall developed his unique imagery and traces his life from Vitebsk, where he was born in 1887, to St. Petersburg, Paris and back to Vitebsk at the outbreak of World War I, ending with the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: Corporate Giving, Falling Behind as the Needs Grow
description: CONNECTICUT'S biggest money givers -- its businesses -- are having a hard time meeting demand. The state's largest corporations did give away millions of dollars in 1995, but the pot may be shrinking as the needs keep growing.

title: West Virginia Sheds Image and Opens for Business
description: Coal mining, poverty, old cars on concrete blocks, children running around barefoot: West Virginians know too well the outside world's perception of their state.

title: WEDDINGS;Jennifer Guthart, Alexander Powers
description: Jennifer Marla Guthart, a daughter of Margaret and Frank Guthart of Syosset, L.I., was married there last evening to Alexander Powers, the son of Phyllis and Edward Powers of Flint, Mich. Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein performed the ceremony at the North Shore Synagogue.

title: After Shocking Siege, The Grief Sets In
description: In phone calls, huddles with friends and family and at a wake for Officer Michael Frey of the Eastchester, N.Y., police, some of Officer Frey's colleagues began to grapple with the painful aftermath of the deadly siege that tore their town --and their department -- apart. Their accounts revealed many new details about how events unfolded that day in their Westchester suburb, where mundane matters like sick skunks and speeding tickets, predominate.

title: At UConn, How It Was With Harry at the Helm
description: HARRY HARTLEY is a pump-your-hand kind of guy. He walks around campus in a UConn sweatsuit, nor does he mind when a man in a pick-up truck dispenses with the formality usually offered a university president and shouts, "Hey Harry -- howsit goin'?"

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Feb. 4, about Puerto Angel, Mexico, referred incorrectly to the Buena Vista Hotel's telephone access. The hotel does, indeed, have a telephone; its number is (52.958) 43104, and the fax number is the same. A listing of lodgings with the column misstated the hotel's mailing address; it is APDO Postal 48, Puerto Angel, Oaxaca, Mexico 70902. This correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

title: FOOD;With Easter Comes Spring, and a Fillet of Lamb
description: EASTER is the time for genuine spring lamb, with its delicate flavor and tender flesh. In the recipe below, the bones from a saddle of lamb are roasted in the oven with vegetables and simmered in white wine and water to make a stock. The stock is reduced to a rich dark sauce, which is flavored with leaves of fresh tarragon. The fillet of lamb, only about three inches in diameter, is browned in a cast-iron skillet and briefly roasted in the oven.

title: MUSIC;In Recital, Bach, Beethoven and More Bach
description: SEVEN orchestras are performing this week, starting with two this afternoon at 4. The Greenwich Symphony concert will be at the high school, with the group's music director, David Gilbert, presiding over works by Bach and Beethoven.

title: Sunday March 24, 1996: POSTURING;Sitting Pretty
description: Office chairs can be hazardous to your health, inflicting, for instance, long-term damage to your spinal disks. So if "ergonomic" hasn't entered your vocabulary, sit up and take heed. "People have misconceptions as to what's ergonomic," says Richard Holbrook, an industrial designer in Pasadena, Calif., whose Ambi chair for Herman Miller recently won the American Product Excellence Award. "Ergonomics is fitting the object and task to the worker. Instead of the human body adapting, you get the environment to adapt."

title: An Audio Manufacturer Remembers Its Roots
description: THE HMG Digital Technologies Corporation of Hauppauge was what its founder calls "a textbook case of a company under pressure to economically justify staying on Long Island."

title: BELARUS TO JOIN RUSSIA IN A UNION
description: The leaders of Russia and Belarus agreed today to form a "union state" which, while it would not quite merge the Governments of the two Slavic nations, would nevertheless tie them to each other economically, politically and culturally.

title: Who Is This Masked Man?
description: A shape-shifter since his arrival in the White House, President Clinton avoids categorization in dress as in politics. His affinity for jogging shorts and leather jackets reflects his generation's love affair with fitness and comfort. As the baby boomers turn 50 and come to grips with their maturity, Mr. Clinton, as the chief boomer, can now comfortably wear the clothes of his father's generation, projecting gravitas in a three-peice suit, even when downing his favorite shake and fries.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
description: A History Lesson On Market Volatility

title: Correction
description: A front-page map last Sunday depicting changes in housing prices from 1994 to 1995 mislabeled a highway in Westchester County. It was Interstate 684, not 687.

title: THE SENATOR CANNOT HELP BEING HIMSELF
description: Weiss cannot resist the urge to besmear D'Amato with the taint of the underworld. However, he does so by way of surrogates, slyly pitting Italian-Americans against one another. John Zagame "grabs a dictionary to point out the Italian derivation of the word 'vendetta.' " An anonymous scion of Italy imagines D'Amato to be the quintessential "wise guy."

title: Foreigners Outdo U.S. Students On Harder Exams, Study Finds
description: High school students in other countries take more demanding science courses and do better on more rigorous tests than do college-bound students in the United States, a new international study has found.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE;Pier Plans Brewing on 54th St.
description: Today, Pier 94 on the Hudson River at the end of 54th Street is a gigantic city-owned truck garage. Two blocks south, a huge shed on Pier 52 sometimes houses exhibitors who spill over from packed trade shows at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: World News Briefs;French Court Puts End To Rwanda Torture Case
description: A French appeals court has put an end to an investigation into charges that an exiled Rwandan Roman Catholic priest was involved in the ethnic slayings in Rwanda in 1994, French news reports said today.

title: March 17-24;Menendez Brothers Convicted
description: A California jury last Wednesday convicted Lyle and Erik Menendez of murdering their parents, rejecting their claim that years of sexual and emotional abuse, not greed, had compelled them to commit the crime.

title: WEDDINGS;Brocha Heber and Joshua Metzger
description: Brocha Chana Heber, a daughter of Nechama and Rabbi Asher Heber of Brooklyn, was married on Wednesday to Rabbi Joshua Metzger, a son of Judy and Rabbi Alter Metzger, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Gershon Mendel Garelik performed the ceremony at the Roseland Ballroom in New York.

title: LIVES;Pregnancy, Unseated
description: I was quite taken aback the first time someone went out of his way to help me get a baby carriage through a shop door. A young man walking down Broadway noticed me struggling and detoured to hold the door.

title: BAR, NONE
description: I got goosebumps when I read, in Madison Smartt Bell's Lives essay, "Bar, None" (March 3), the line, "The first bar I ever entered in Manhattan was at the corner of Houston Street and the Bowery." My grandfather, Henry Davis, owned a bar at the corner of Houston Street and the Bowery. It was called Liberty Bar and Grill.

title: In Sarajevo Suburb, a New Border Stirs Tensions
description: The line separating Bosnia's former warring parties snakes through a drainage ditch and down the middle of a street, bisecting apartment buildings and houses with equal indifference.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THIS DAMN HOUSE! My Subcontract With America. By Margo Kaufman. Villard, $21.

title: HOOP IS THICKER THAN WATER
description: So Rick Barry gets, once again, the truculent, lousy-father treatment. Well, maybe, but I have a particular memory of him that is considerably more pleasant.

title: PETS;Open Spaces For City Dogs To Run Wild
description: PITY the poor pooch in New York. The sidewalks are filled with dog owners whose pets are tugging at the leash, yearning to roam free. But there are 13 dog runs in the city where canines can be legally unleashed to scamper at will. Here are the sites, with a brief review of each.

title: ON POLITICS;Listening Is One Thing, Seeing Is Another
description: Many of the lawmakers were only half listening to the testimony of Karen A. Spinner of the New Jersey Association on Correction. As Ms. Spinner expressed deep concern about the potential effect of proposed budget cuts on treatment programs for state prison inmates, two legislators were heavily engaged in conversation. Another, Assemblyman Joseph Saliga, a Democrat from Union County, never looked up while he busily tapped away on a laptop. It seemed that only Robert E. Littell, the chairman of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee, and a few others were listening intently to what Ms. Spinner had to say.

title: No Headline
description: Suddenly those freshman representatives in the House have discovered, 'Gee whiz, maybe we need another term to get our stuff done.' Ain't nothing like an election to put some pine in peoples' backs and practicality in their actions."

title: BASEBALL;Torre Unsure About Rogers
description: Joe Torre put Kenny Rogers's status in a precarious position today when the manager refused to say that the $20 million pitcher had a secure spot in the rotation. Rogers must produce some strong results when he opposes the Houston Astros on Sunday or he risks becoming a highly paid former starter.

title: INVESTING IT;Think That I.P.O. Looks Good? If It's Offered to Pay Debt. Look Twice.
description: INVESTORS buy initial public offerings because they want to get in on a venture's ground floor. As the company uses the offering's proceeds to build the business up, people hope that their returns will ride higher and higher, too.

title: Cosmic Shiver
description: I write this with trembling hands, because I haven't yet seen Comet Hyakutake -- the great spring comet that silently invaded our skies last week.

title: ON CAMPUS;A Master of Seduction Puts Hackensack on the Literary Map
description: The letters began in 1979, when Gene Barnett was teaching "Death of a Salesman" to his students at Fairleigh Dickinson University and seized on the idea of bringing Arthur Miller to campus. They continued through the 1980's, tasteful but persistent, as the professor beseeched the playwright to visit.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Enjoy Signs Of Hope Sandwiched Around a Blown Lead
description: This was the sort of game that a good team needs and sometimes gets when it is coming out of a slump. It was a wild and entertaining 5-4 victory for the Rangers over the Bruins this afternoon at Fleet Center. Truth be told, it might have been a decision that the New York visitors didn't really deserve.

title: HOCKEY;Overtime Victory Keeps Devils in Middle of Playoff Hunt
description: Overtime is the right time for the Devils. Eighteen times they have gone into the extra period this season, and 18 times they have emerged without a loss.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;UConn Women Reach Mideast Final
description: With one exception this season, a night of horror against Syracuse, the Connecticut women's basketball team has dispatched overmatched teams methodically and efficiently. It was not that simple tonight against San Francisco, which hardly seemed in awe of the defending national champion, but the Huskies eventually overwhelmed the Lady Dons, 72-47.

title: Hugh Kemp Clark, an Atomic Scientist, 90
description: Hugh Kemp Clark, a chemist and lawyer who had central roles in the development of atomic energy from the days of the Manhattan Project to the era of nuclear power plants, died on March 17 at his home in Kennedyville, Md. He was 90.

title: TELEVISION;ESPN2 Adjusts Course Without Dipping Below 200 M.P.H.
description: IT's 10:20 ON A WEDNESDAY NIGHT, and Julie Mariash is nervously waiting for a highlight tape. ESPN2's "N.H.L. 2Night" is going on in 20 seconds, and Ms. Mariash, the show's producer, wants to open with tape from a just-completed game between Tampa Bay and Toronto. Her audience, she explains, is composed of hockey fans who will want to know about this game first because its outcome will have a critical effect on the National Hockey League standings.

title: Timing Helped G.O.P. Win Farm-Bill Battle, but a Challenge Is Likely
description: For months, Democrats objected that a Republican-led overhaul of America's farm programs, ending New Deal crop subsidies to farmers and replacing them with gradually declining flat payments over seven years, would shred a valuable Government safety net.

title: WEDDINGS;Adrienne Paine, Douglas Johnston
description: Adrienne Middendorf Paine, a daughter of Judy and Dr. Lincoln Denton Paine of New Orleans, was married there yesterday to Douglas Ross Johnston, the son of Diane and William Howard Johnston of Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Donald R. Frampton officiated at St. Charles Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on March 10 about the opening of a Parade of Shoes store in the Bronx misstated the chain's size in the city. The new store, at 216 East 161st Street, is Parade of Shoes' 26th store in New York, not the first.

title: Coastal Geologist Questions Plan for Restoration of Barrier Beach
description: WHEN Federal and New York State officials reached final agreement recently on a $30 million project to restore the storm-battered western end of the Westhampton barrier island, property owners applauded.

title: Legislator's Departure in Sex Case Unsettles Christian Faction
description: Tom Garszczynski said he voted for the candidate because there was nothing not to like. He spoke of family values. He was a Christian conservative, yet "he didn't have a holier than thou attitude."

title: Candid Dialogue on Race Must Begin With Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: CHATTER;The Merits of Tax Amnesty
description: New Jersey is offering amnesty to people who have not paid their state taxes for several years. What do you think of this idea? Is it fair?

title: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
description: Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions, and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.

title: THEATER FINANCING;Post-War Survivors
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL;Robin Leads Rice to State Championship
description: Bevon Robin scored 16 of Rice High School's 38 first-half points and Chudney Gray added 16 as the Raiders defeated La Salle of Niagara Falls, 84-65, tonight in the New York High School Federation Class A final at the Glens Falls Civic Center.

title: Mali
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a trip to Mali, I was interested in "Under the Smoky Skies of Bamako" (Feb. 18). But while I agree that it is factual, I felt it was rather like the inchworm so busy measuring the marigold that it doesn't notice its beauty.

title: NOTICED;Read My Lipstick
description: WHEN she posed for a recent cover of Entertainment Weekly magazine, Julia Roberts had love on her mind -- and her midriff. Literally. To wit, the word "love" was prominently scrawled across the midsection of the star of "Pretty Woman."

title: And the Winner Is ... Stone in Valentino? Thompson in Armani?
description: THE annual Oscar telecast can be awfully low on highlights in its four-hour life span. One marginal joy for its millions of viewers is the dispensation of cold-blooded criticism on who looks good and who, more importantly, does not.

title: Los Angeles District Attorney Is Riding High Before Vote
description: Little more than six months ago, the Los Angeles County District Attorney, Gil Garcetti, seemed finished. His political obituaries were being written. After all, the man who came to office promising to win the big cases, appeared to have bungled the biggest one of all, the O. J. Simpson trial.

title: COPING;Claudine Calls Home and Sends Her Love
description: CLAUDINE called home.

title: Paper Threat
description: POP INTERNATIONALISM By Paul Krugman. 221 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $22.50.

title: The Whiz of Processing the Mail
description: IT may have been more than a quarter of a century in the making, but now everything is moving so quickly here that it is one big blur -- which is exactly the way things are meant to be at the United States Postal Service's 490,000-square-foot, state-of-the-art distribution center.

title: Jail Imposed for Fire That Killed Children
description: A woman who was in a bar drinking when a fire killed eight of the nine children she had left home alone was sentenced to nearly a year in jail on Thursday.

title: PERSPECTIVES;Housing Programs Strained as Cutbacks Take Hold
description: SINCE 1983 Denise Crowell and her two school-aged sons have lived in a two-bedroom apartment at 2665 Decatur Avenue in the Bronx. Her housing has not changed in 12 years, but her living conditions have vastly improved. And her rent has declined.

title: Of the Natural World and Indian Ways
description: SNOW was melting, mud was oozing and youngsters were playing in the Algonkian Village -- complete with wigwams -- outside the main building of the Institute for American Indian Studies in Washington. When E. Barrie Kavasch arrived to help the youngsters with their next activity, botanical drawing, it was clear that nobody wanted to go inside, for drawing or anything else, on such a fine afternoon.

title: DINING OUT;Flavorful Indian Cuisine in White Plains
description: STILL delightful after 22 years, the Bengal Tiger continues to grow and satisfy the county's taste for the seductive flavors of Indian cuisine, and the food here has never been better. Not content to rest on his restaurant's past success, Simpson Kalathara introduces new items with welcome regularity, and right now his comprehensive menu lists dishes representing almost every corner of India from the Himalayas to Cape Comorin.

title: ON THE MAP;In Oakland, a Refuge for Animals and a Message for Humans
description: The kittens are coming.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND;She Ain't Just a Hound Dog
description: THE winningest dog in America was taking a nap. Stretched across a blue-and-white down comforter lay a mass of flowing black hair.

title: Office-Supply Entrepreneur Dies at His Family Business
description: From his days as a preschooler until his murder on Friday, Howard Pilmar spent much of his life tending to his family's mid-Manhattan business, King Office Supply Company, at 14 East 33d Street.

title: WEDDINGS;Dr. Weinberg, Mr. Tenenbaum
description: Dr. Sydney Stahl Weinberg and Gerald Tenenbaum were married last evening in the York Room at Ramapo College of New Jersey in Mahwah. Rabbi Joseph Rudavsky performed the ceremony.

title: Elected Legislature In Hong Kong to End
description: A commmittee whose members were selected by China voted today to replace Hong Kong's democratically elected legislature with an appointed council after the Chinese take over the British colony next year.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Campbell Museum Closes
description: Citing declining attendance, the Campbell Museum, which opened in 1970 at the Campbell Soup plant in Camden, has closed its doors, officials said last week. The museum used to attract more than 60,000 visitors a year, but that number has dwindled to 20,000, a spokeswoman said.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;UMass Is a Lot Better Than It Might Appear
description: It happens all the time in schoolyards and in gyms. Guys get together to play a pickup game, and one group looks at the other and thinks: "We can take these guys. They don't have a game."

title: Nixon' Soundtrack Disk Puts a Face to the Music
description: Of the five original film scores nominated for an Oscar, John Williams's soundtrack for "Nixon" has a certain something extra.

title: The Oscars: A Scorecard
description: The 68th annual Academy Awards will be held tonight at 9 at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, and televised on ABC. Here are the nominees in the main categories:

title: Denver Is Proving Fertile Ground For Theme of Million Man March
description: After a 3-year-old boy was killed in a drive-by shooting in December, 100 black men fanned out through a black neighborhood here. They knocked on doors until leads resulted in three arrests several days later.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The writers STUDS TERKEL and HUNTER S. THOMPSON and former Senator GEORGE S. McGOVERN have one thing in common. They are among the 60 Americans who allowed themselves to be interviewed and filmed last year by two plucky 26-year-old film makers, SHAINEE GABEL and KRISTIN HAHN, for what will be both a book and a film about indigenous visionaries called "Anthem." Last month, the two film makers received a $225,000 book advance from Avon Books, according to their agent, JENNIFER RUDOLPH WALSH of the Virginia Barber Literary Agency in Manhattan.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;With a Classic Jumper, It Was Vintage Ewing All the Way for Knicks
description: The league's oldest coach, Dick Motta, and one of its youngest and brightest starting point guards, Jason Kidd, matched wits and assists today against the youngest coach and the oldest starting point guard.

title: ON BASEBALL;The Team That Loves to Be Hated
description: When the New York Yankees were functioning like a well-heeled Fortune 500 company, downsizing the rest of the American League's pennant hopes while minting money and championship rings at will, they were the most feared and hated team in baseball.

title: Clunbury Journal;'Mad Cow Disease' Threatens the Farming Life
description: John Croxton will not be going to market tomorrow.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Auction Against Pollution
description: Students at four schools in New Jersey helped raise money to buy air-pollution rights at an auction scheduled for today at the Chicago Board of Trade, according to a nonprofit environmental group.

title: Immigration -- Just the Facts
description: Congress is debating two bills, Patrick Buchanan used the issue to rev up his Presidential campaign, and a few polemicists have even called for a moratorium. Immigration may be hotly debated, but the facts and figures speak for themselves. Percentage of the United States population that white Americans think is Hispanic: 14.7. Percentage that is Hispanic: 9.5. Percentage that whites think is Asian: 10.8 Percentage that is Asian: 3.1. Percentage that white Americans think is black: 23.8. Percentage that is black: 11.8. Percentage that whites think is white: 49.9. Percentage that is white: 74.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Help for Substitute Parents
description: About 140,000 children in New Jersey are being raised by their grandparents and the number is growing, a spokeswoman for an elderly group says. Because of their age, their disabilities, or perhaps just their lack of knowledge, many of these substitute parents need help but do not know where to get it. Last week, the State Senate passed a bill that would establish pilot programs in five counties to help grandparents get assistance with financial, legal, educational and child-care problems.

title: Market Place;G.M. has begun telling analysts it can't offset lost production.
description: AS the General Motors Corporation struggles to reopen its assembly plants after a 17-day brake-factory strike, the bad news for the company, for its shareholders and for the American economy is that much of the lost weeks of production may never be made up. And that disrupts G.M.'s planning for the third quarter, when it will shut many plants as it prepares to introduce many new models, its most ambitious retooling in years.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Acer Inc., Taipei, Taiwan, to Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, to handle the branding assignment for the personal computer marketer, previously handled by Lai Venuti & Lai, Santa Clara, Calif. The billings are estimated at $7 million to $10 million. Riney was recently awarded the account of the Acer American subsidiary, the Acer America Corp., San Jose, Calif., with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: World News Briefs;Demonstrators in Belarus Oppose Tie With Russia
description: About 15,000 people, many waving red-and-white Belarussian flags, marched through downtown Minsk today to demand continued independence and protest Government moves to form a political, cultural and economic union with Russia.

title: FIGURE SKATING;After an Artistic Pep Talk, Kwan Paints a Masterpiece
description: The coach had found a quiet place in the Edmonton Coliseum, a cubbyhole reserved for the flower girls who retrieve bouquets tossed onto the ice. The scores for Lu Chen of China, the defending world figure-skating champion, were announced and the results were forbidding. Chen had received two perfect marks of 6 for artistry.

title: Gasoline Prices Jump
description: Prices at the nation's gasoline pumps jumped more than 3 cents a gallon as warm weather pushed up demand at a time of lagging international supply, an analyst said today. The average pump price, including all grades and taxes, was 124.39 cents a gallon Friday, according to the Lundberg Survey of 10,000 gas stations across the country. That was up 3.3 cents from the March 8 survey, Trilby Lundberg said. At self-serve pumps, where more than 95 percent of all gas is sold, the average per-gallon price was 117.92 cents for regular unleaded, 127.91 cents for mid-grade unleaded and 136.44 cents for premium unleaded.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;A 'Ring' About People, Not Places
description: There are 110 Canadians in my hotel, all here to worship at the feet of Wagner's "Ring of the Nibelung." For four nights spread over six days, 200 Germans, as many Australians and large contingents from Chile and Britain have struggled through windy downtown streets to join thousands of "Ring"-hungry Chicagoans at this orgy of the spirit inside the Lyric Opera.

title: Welcome to Donnybrook Park;In Long Island City, a Battle Brews Over a Recreational Space
description: With the exception of a patch of struggling grass, little is blossoming at Hunters Point Community Park in Long Island City, Queens. The playground, with its sandbox and one tiny slide, is usually empty; old people seldom sit on the oddly-shaped stainless steel benches.

title: Metro Matters;A Nostalgia For Death And Taxes
description: The year is 2000. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, having eliminated term limits, is looking ahead to his next campaign, and Gov. George E. Pataki, halfway through his second term, is planning ahead, too.

title: New Life for Grand Central
description: For two years, commuters have been staring at a strange, light green patch on the southeast corner of the great vaulted ceiling at Grand Central Terminal. This small corner forecasts good things to come: a cleaning of the whole magnificent star-scape that arches over the Grand Concourse, and a complete makeover for the dilapidated but still glorious landmark.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Surrounded by Gaiety, Disappointment in Love
description: There are moments in the New York City Opera production of "The Merry Widow," which was introduced last season and returned on Saturday night, when the central character in Lehar's enduring 1905 operetta is taken seriously. The soprano Jane Thorngren's portrayal of Hanna, the Widow Glawari of the title, is often touching -- a young woman, disappointed in love, who impulsively married an elderly banker and must now fend off the attentions of fortune hunters.

title: Ceiling Collapses in a Bronx Station House
description: Part of the ceiling and roof in a police station house in the Bronx collapsed yesterday, covering two rooms with plaster and debris but injuring no one, the police said.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Assigned Joe Hall, outfielder, and Kris Gresham, catcher, to their minor-league camp.

title: A Clash Over Course Work and Copyrights
description: Authors and publishers have opposed a ruling by a Federal appeals court that allows copy shops to produce customized anthologies designed by professors without seeking permission from or paying royalties to the holders of the copyrights involved.

title: Lawsuits Don't Deter Unsafe Products
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuits Don't Deter Unsafe Products
description: To the Editor:

title: In America;Come Stand With Us
description: Democracy," Marian Wright Edelman will tell you, "is not a spectator sport."

title: POLITICS: FOCUS ON JOBS;House Debate Hits Home on Jobs Program
description: The Job Training Partnership, a Federally financed program to retrain dislocated workers, is widely respected here by Republicans and Democrats, business, labor and educational leaders.

title: HOCKEY: NOTEBOOK;No Lemieux, No Problem. Penguins Rout Rangers.
description: Late in the second period last night, after Pittsburgh's lead reached 5-0, the electric scoreboards went dark at Madison Square Garden. This drew a sarcastic cheer from some Ranger fans, who were embarrassed at the progressive humiliation of their home boys.

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;The key issue for the Net is not the smut, it is the use of encryption.
description: THE current uproar over the Internet is about smut and what can be made public on the global computer network. But the next public-policy tangle will be about what we're allowed to keep secret.

title: Ceballos Puts His Skis Away
description: Cedric Ceballos returned to the Los Angeles Lakers today, offering an explanation but no details on why he spent four days in Arizona without notifying the team.

title: Avalanche Kills 2 Hikers
description: Searchers recovered the bodies of two men buried in an avalanche today on Mount Washington, the highest peak in the Northeast. The avalanche was in the Gulf of Slides, a popular hiking and skiing area southeast of the mountain's summit, which is 6,288 feet high.

title: Steep Hurdles To a Web Shortcut;Rapid-Access Computer Lines Are Stumbling Over High Prices
description: When Stewart Dickson moved to Delaware last year, he signed up with one of the Bell Atlantic Corporation's newest residential services: a digital phone line that would let him browse the Internet four times as fast as he could on ordinary phone lines. Mr. Dickson, a computer artist, promptly set up a colorful site on the Internet's World Wide Web to display his work.

title: DANCE REVIEW;The Sexily Slinky and the Bedraggled
description: The Second Avenue Dance Company/96 is made up of advanced undergraduate and graduate dance students at the New York University Tisch School of the Arts. But the group, which performed on Saturday night at the school's fifth-floor theater, had a thoroughly professional look. And the selection of choreographers was impressive.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;'Million Man March' Planned
description: Organizers of the New Jersey Million Man March say they expect about 10,000 blacks -- both men and women -- to march to the State House in May to warn political candidates that they should not take the black vote for granted, the A.P. reported yesterday.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stock prices were higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 214.52 points, or 1.04 percent, at 20,915.44. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 26.61, or 0.01 percent.

title: World News Briefs;3 Are Killed in Gunfight At Mosque in Kashmir
description: A furious gun battle between troops and separatist guerrillas in Kashmir's holiest shrine today killed at least three people and raised fears of a widespread public uprising.

title: Machine Tool Orders Fell 10% in February
description: Orders for American-made industrial tools fell in February, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said yesterday, suggesting that businesses are investing less in plant and equipment.

title: From One Serbian Militia Chief, A Trail of Plunder and Slaughter
description: For the thousands of Muslims who fled from this town in eastern Bosnia, and for the Serbs who remained, the war has bound this generation and the next to a Serbian militia leader named Milan Lukic.

title: POLITICS: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION;Dole Vows Opposition to Preference Programs
description: Bob Dole came to an Orange County shopping area here known as Little Saigon today and declared his opposition to affirmative action.

title: No Headline
description: There are so many abandoned children because there is no social policy by the Government for parents to keep their children. MARIE-THERESE STESSENS, head of a Doctors Without Borders effort to improve Romania's orphanages. [A6:1.]

title: Treasury Issues To Be Offered During Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned on Wednesday and Thursday.

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;An R.S.V.P for the Dole Victory Celebration Isn't Being Sent Back Yet
description: On Friday, Patrick J. Buchanan said he thought Senator Bob Dole was reaching out a hand to those who supported his fading candidacy. Then he spent the weekend snapping at it.

title: Measure Director's Value by Company Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Police Officers Hear Cardinal Firmly Oppose Death Penalty
description: In a delicately worded sermon that thrust him into the state's growing debate over the death penalty, John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, voiced his deep personal opposition to capital punishment yesterday, warning that it has tended to single out certain racial groups and offers a deceptively simple approach to wider problems.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some copies yesterday with an article about an agreement by Russia and Belarus to form a union reversed the identities of the countries' Presidents. The President of Russia is Boris N. Yeltsin; the President of Belarus is Aleksandr Lukashenko.

title: A Rebel Attack on Afghan Capital Kills 18
description: Rebel fighters shelled the shopping district in Kabul today, killing 18 civilians and wounding 14 others, witnesses and Government officials said.

title: Changing the Face of Publishing
description: The influence of the graphic designers Milton Glaser and Walter Bernard permeates the magazine world. Working separately at first and then in a formidable partnership, they have shaped and reshaped leading magazines and newspapers in the United States, Europe and Asia for more than 30 years.

title: Bartoli Reschedules
description: A Carnegie Hall duo recital of the mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli and the pianist Andras Schiff, scheduled for yesterday afternoon but postponed because of Ms. Bartoli's illness, has been rescheduled for Thursday at 8 P.M. The program of works by Beethoven, Schubert, Haydn and Rossini remains the same. Tickets for the Sunday concert will be honored on Thursday. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Lawsuits Don't Deter Unsafe Products
description: To the Editor:

title: J. D. Miller, Musician, 73, Dies; Wrote 'Honky-Tonk Angels'
description: J. D. Miller, whose song "It Wasn't God Who Made Honky-Tonk Angels" helped open the way to stardom for women in country music, died on Saturday at Lourdes Hospital of Lafayette, La. He was 73.

title: A Look at Europe's Future
description: The 1991 Treaty on European Union set out an ambitious plan for political, economic and monetary union by the end of this decade. With the decade more than half over, much of that agenda remains wishful. Europe's governance structures are unwieldy. Its quest for a common foreign and security policy stumbled badly in Bosnia. Only 3 of the European Union's 15 countries now meet the deficit target for the single currency.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Highway Projects Hastened
description: The Transportation Commissioner, Frank J. Wilson, plans to speed up 97 highway construction projects, the A.P. reported yesterday. The projects range from a $130 million extension of Route 21 from Passaic to Clifton to a $720,000 reconstruction of the Route 9 bridge over Main Street in Woodbridge, Mr. Wilson said.

title: HOCKEY;Now Here's Something Different: A Final Four Without Surprises
description: Colorado College and Michigan, the top-seeded teams at the West Regional, yesterday completed the field for the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament by winning quarterfinal games at East Lansing, Mich.

title: OLYMPICS;Johnson Is Granted Chance to Win 200 and 400
description: Michael Johnson got his wish and will now have an opportunity to make Olympic history.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Take A Victory Any Way It Comes
description: Don't tell Butch Beard his Nets were fortunate to pull out an 84-80 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks, which tied a franchise record for futility with 11 consecutive defeats.

title: Drug Kingpins Can't Trade Assets for Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A caption with a photograph yesterday of two boys on swings at the Jacob K. Javits Playground misstated its location. It is in upper Manhattan, not the Bronx.

title: Sun Sparkles, Temperatures Rise and Spirits Soar
description: Carefully, as if he could not believe that the moment he had been dreaming about for months had finally come, Otis tested the water. Too cold? Too muddy? No, just right. And so, with more of a graceful stretch than a dive, he plunged in and -- what else? -- dog-paddled across the lake in Central Park.

title: Media
description: BEAVIS and Butt-head probably couldn't find Sweden on a map. But to hear MTV tell it, the cable network's moronic duo are practically ambassadors for American popular culture abroad. The "Beavis & Butt-head" cartoon has spread the gospel of MTV to more than 260 million households in 70 countries.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Saturday about judicial decisions as political issues misstated in some editions the year in which the Willie Horton case was a campaign controversy. Mr. Horton, a convicted felon who raped a woman while on a prison furlough, became an issue in the 1988 Presidential campaign, not 1992.

title: History of Habeas Corpus Didn't Begin With the 20th Century
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE REVIEW;Keeping 3 Dancers Very Busy
description: Ton Simons may have been trying to show that less is more when he assembled the program that he presented on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Only three people performed during the entire evening; there were never more than two dancers onstage, and often there was only one.

title: Lou Rettino, Coach, Dies at 54; Led Teams to New Jersey Titles
description: Lou Rettino, one of the most successful high school football coaches in the country, died of stomach cancer Friday at his home in Westfield, N.J. He was 54.

title: Abusing the Debt Bill
description: The House Republican leadership has loaded up a bill to raise the Federal debt limit -- which Congress must pass if the Federal Government is to pay its bills -- with two offensive provisions.

title: CHINA IS OFFERING HIGH-LEVEL TALKS TO TAIWAN LEADER
description: In a gesture of conciliation to President Lee Teng-hui after his resounding election victory in Taiwan, China called today for a meeting between Mr. Lee and its own President, Jiang Zemin, and for opening direct air, shipping and mail links across the Taiwan Strait.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;And Now, The Real Tourney Begins
description: The Connecticut women's basketball team is halfway there.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Mason Hoists Favorite Victims For His Verbal Target Practice
description: Don't be fooled by the title of Jackie Mason's new show, "Love They Neighbor."

title: Giuliani Acknowledges That His Police Commissioner Is Job Hunting
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that William J. Bratton would step down as New York City's Police Commissioner as soon as he found the right job in the private sector.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Firefighter Still Hospitalized
description: The firefighter who had a heart attack and collapsed while fighting a blaze on Saturday at a Jersey City apartment building remained in critical condition yesterday, a nursing supervisor at Jersey City Medical Center said.

title: Abroad at Home;Sunlight And Shadow
description: California, land of the possible. So it used to be: the state where optimism was policy and the policy worked. Not today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;D.M.B.& B. Is Said To Fill Key Post
description: Dawn Hudson, a top executive at the New York office of DDB Needham Worldwide, is to be named managing director of the New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, said agency executives familiar with her plans and speaking on the condition of anonymity.

title: New Orleans Journal;Music Draws the Crowd; The Act Pays the Bills
description: Elliott Small can see fine, but he pretends to be a blind harmonica player who pretends to be able to see.

title: Taking In the Sites;Of Virtual Oscars and Film Fantasy
description: Alan Goodrich gagged when he heard the nominees for tonight's Oscar ceremony. So he did what any self-respecting 18-year-old would do these days: he posted The Academy Awards Protest Page on the World Wide Web.

title: Romanian 'Orphans': Prisoners of Their Cribs
description: Last month Aura Cretu gave birth to an underweight but healthy boy. She called him Victor, after her father, and then told the nurses that she could not afford to take him home and that he should be sent to an orphanage.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;Remembering Richard Nixon as a Mentor and a Model
description: They were two old loyalists of the Grand Old Party, both sons of poor, small-town America, self-made men who became partners in politics, shaped by deprivation and a shared resentment of those to whom life came easy.

title: Proposed Cuts to College Aid Protested as Hardship for Poor Students
description: The poor college student is romanticized in popular culture as a young person leading a sort of bohemian life style: wearing vintage clothing and living off campus, waiting tables or selling books between classes, struggling to remain in school and, eventually, reach the middle class.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Pepsi and Coke Plans For Special Drinks
description: Two lines of so-called New Age beverages are being overhauled as competition in the category intensifies.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about the growing number of parents who are seeking seats on community school boards misstated the location of Edith Colon, who is seeking a seat on the District 8 board in the Bronx. She was fifth from left, not second.

title: Louis Pataki, 83, Father of Governor
description: Louis Pataki, a former assistant postmaster in Peekskill, N.Y., who saw his son elected to the highest office in the state, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Hudson, N.Y., from complications following a heart attack. He was 83.

title: More Lyrics. More Lyricists. More Shows at the 92d Street Y.
description: To regulars, it's simply L.&L., as in light and lively, literate and linguistic, Lerner and Loewe or Lyrics and Lyricists. Although the name is not exactly accurate -- composers often get into the act -- the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Y is one of the longest running and most popular shows in New York. For 26 continuous years, it has been giving audiences a close-up look at the creativity of the American musical theater.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Swing-Era Orchestrations Handled With Assurance
description: So much is changing so rapidly in the institutional jazz world that Jazz at Lincoln Center's "Golden Pen," Saturday's concert of swing-era arrangements, sounded like a fairly normal programming ploy. Five years ago, the idea to display a series of often-brilliant arrangements might have seemed radical; it is now rare but accepted practice, and the pleasure gained is less from novelty and more from the sensuousness of the music itself.

title: Offerings of Equity Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Interactions: I'm O.K., My P.C.'s O.K.
description: It pays to treat computers politely. They can be jerks and bullies. But they can also be friends and teammates, and their praise is high praise indeed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- Advertising;Marketers of two on-line services start playing to the technology-challenged-but-curious.
description: TWO marketers of on-line services are adopting an advertising strategy meant to reassure computer users that high-tech does not necessarily mean high anxiety.

title: Nature Groups Say Foes Bear Friendly Names
description: Northwesterners for More Fish. The words conjure up visions of earth-shoed activists and leaping trout joined in battle against the greedy pillagers of the land.

title: The Downsizing Myth
description: The United States is not downsizing. It is upsizing. The economy is not growing as fast as some economists wish it would, but it is expanding.

title: The Black Writer Vis-a-Vis The World
description: A Raisin in the Sun" is not normally described as a Chinese classic. The author was a black American and so are the characters. But Keith Gilyard, an English professor at Syracuse University who served as moderator of a debate on black writing and the black experience at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn on Saturday, recalled a discussion with a Chinese student who assured him otherwise. The play, the student told Professor Gilyard, is really about the clash of values between the old and new China.

title: Ryder Says Strike Will Hurt
description: Ryder System Inc. says that it expects first-quarter earnings to fall short of Wall Street estimates, primarily because of the strike at the General Motors Corporation, its largest customer.

title: Benjamin Franklin Bills Ready to Become Hot Item
description: The Federal Reserve will release new $100 bills with off-center likenesses of Benjamin Franklin on Monday, and, based on past experience, most of them will soon be abroad.

title: Hamas Charities' Taint
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: SOUTHEAST;No Blues in the Delta Today: The Bulldogs Are Triumphant
description: The players in maroon and white tumbled to the floor of Rupp Arena one last time, forming a giddy pile after they had lifted Mississippi State's wondrous basketball season to heights the school has never known. You should resist the temptation to cast them as party crashers, even as they begin to contemplate the least expected trip anyone has made to the Final Four in several years. All Mississippi State has done is bulldog its way to a Southeast Regional championship, writing its own invitations and transforming the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament into its own party.

title: U.S. Woman Begins 5-Month Stay on Russian Space Station
description: Dr. Shannon Lucid became a member of Russia's space station Mir today, beginning her five-month stay with hugs, camera flashes and chocolate Easter bunnies.

title: Sports of The Times;It's a Kentucky Derby With Only One Entry
description: SATURDAY afternoon, and the downtown mall was dead.

title: Financial Crisis Is Gripping Smaller Cities of New York
description: This pretty, rusting city beside the Mohawk River is going broke. A few months ago, it used $3 million set aside for a new courthouse and other construction projects to pay bills. This month, it managed to pay its employees only because the state speeded up a chunk of aid.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;Harper Will Explore Free Agency Options
description: After he was through teaching a new Kidd some old tricks in front of his former team, Derek Harper surveyed his career today. This is what he saw: a 34-year-old point guard who will not have a contract at the end of the season.

title: Unexpectedly, Kohl Coalition Gets Lift From State Elections
description: Against the odds suggested by rising unemployment and economic slowdown, Chancellor Helmut Kohl won a major boost today from three state elections that were cast as clues to the midterm fortunes of his coalition, according to early projections.

title: BASEBALL;Fernandez Hurts Elbow; May Be Lost for Season
description: Tony Fernandez lunged across the dirt infield near second base to spear a ground ball, landed harshly on his right elbow and sensed there was a serious problem when he reached for the loose baseball and could not close his hand around it. Fernandez was right about the severity of the problem because the Yankees' infielder might miss the entire season after fracturing his elbow in the fourth inning today.

title: BOXING;A Show Of Smarts; A Brutish Battle
description: Despite itself, boxing survives. And even, once in a while, puts on such a fascinating show that the violence and blood seem acceptable.

title: Japan Court Ruling Favors U.S. Bases on Okinawa
description: A Japanese court today helped clear the way toward allowing the United States to continue using privately owned land in Okinawa for military bases, preventing a potential disruption to American operations there.

title: BASEBALL;Pulsipher and Ailing Elbow To Get Extra Time in Sun
description: When the Mets head north after their series with the Yankees in Tampa next weekend, Bill Pulsipher will not be going with them and Pete Harnisch probably won't, either.

title: Drug Kingpins Can't Trade Assets for Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. May Buy Fast Computer From Japan
description: A Japanese computer maker may be on the verge of achieving what had previously been unthinkable in this country: selling a supercomputer to a United States Government laboratory.

title: Burglar Injures Priest, 76, And Breaks Stained Glass
description: A burglar burst into a Franciscan monastery in the Cypress Hills section of Brooklyn early yesterday and when he found nothing to steal, he smashed stained-glass windows, hurled lamps, desks and picture frames and beat a 76-year-old priest bloody before fleeing empty-handed.

title: Bridge;A defensive performance that deserved an award.
description: If there had been an award for the best defensive play at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Philadelphia earlier this month, it would surely have gone to Bob Goldman of Highland Village, Tex., for his performance on the diagramed deal. He sat West, defending three no-trump, and his partner, Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., led a heart. When dummy played low he contributed the ten, forcing the ace.

title: Cambodia's Real Boss Rules From the No. 2 Post
description: In this hot and dusty village one recent morning, he was all smiles, embracing former enemies, handing out envelopes of money and sacks of rice, and telling an audience of soldiers, foreign diplomats and rebel defectors, "We are all brothers."

title: Safeguard Public TV
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: FACING THE ECONOMY;Recycled Ideas Echo Forbes and Buchanan
description: Steve Forbes might be out of the race and Patrick J. Buchanan relegated to the sidelines, but some of their economic ideas, reformulated or toned down, live on in the campaigns of Senator Bob Dole and President Clinton.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Record Year at the Tunnels
description: A record 112.5 million cars, trucks and motorcycles crossed the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and the George Washington Bridge last year, largely because of the unusually mild winter of 1994-1995, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Patents;The distilled essence of tobacco can coat more than your lungs. It also coats metal, and prevents rust.
description: RUST, it is estimated, costs Americans billions of dollars a year. It has to be scraped off machinery and prevented from clogging car engines. The Golden Gate Bridge must be continually repainted in a bright orange laced with anti-rust compounds.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Making Communication a Prerequisite for Sex
description: A WOMAN SCORNED Acquaintance Rape on Trial By Peggy Reeves Sanday 338 pages. Doubleday. $23.95.

title: Public Radio Being Pressed to Turn Its Success Into Independence
description: Deep in Appalachia, the residents of hardscrabble Pocahontas County, W. Va., (Pop. 9,000) do not think twice about where to tune their radio dials for country music, local news and helpful announcements about funerals, lost hunting dogs and school lunch menus.

title: Vaclav Nelhybel, 76, a Czech Composer
description: Vaclav Nelhybel, a composer born in Czechoslovakia who was a musical director of Radio Free Europe during the 1950's and composer in residence at the University of Scranton, died on Friday at a hospital here. He was 76 and lived in Fleetville, Pa.

title: Two Youths Fatally Shot In the Bronx
description: Two teen-agers were killed and a third was critically wounded early yesterday morning when an argument between two men in a Bronx apartment building erupted in gunfire, the police said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Plans Tuition Increase
description: Under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed budget, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey stands to lose $7.9 million in state aid. Consequently, administrators are proposing to raise tuition for New Jersey residents to $17,445 -- a 30 percent increase. Out-of-state residents would have to pay 50 percent more, or $26,167, if the trustees approve the plan, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: A 40% Jump in Cellular Phone Users
description: More than 9.6 million new customers started using a mobile phone in 1995, raising the total of Americans with cellular phones by 40 percent, to 33.8 million, the Cellular Telephone Industry Associations said today.

title: Killings of Stray Bison Have Montanans Angry
description: Two chocolate-brown bison calves, lying next to a busy highway, munched on carrots that someone had thrown them as Donna Lane drove by the other day. "They're orphans," she said of the year-old calves. "They shot the mother last week. They'll have to come back and shoot these."

title: Wade Nichols, 80, Magazine Publisher
description: Wade H. Nichols, former editor in chief of Good Housekeeping and editor in chief and publisher of Redbook, died at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx on March 15. He was 80 and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: The Smart Way to Ease Big Cities' Crush
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Bratton Is Job Hunting

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTIES;No Matter What Perot Says, He Talks Like a Candidate
description: With a broad attack on Democrats in the White House and Republicans in Congress, Ross Perot pledged yesterday to put a "united team" of his supporters into Government this November, asserting that it would bring an end to the political wrangling that has plagued Washington for much of the last two years.

title: World News Briefs;Iraqis Elect Parliament Pre-Approved by Hussein
description: Seeking to raise morale at home and improve its image abroad, Iraq today held its first parliamentary elections since 1989, but only candidates loyal to Saddam Hussein could run.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. to Face Struggle To Recoup Strike Losses As General Motors reopens its assembly plants after a 17-day brake-factory strike, the bad news for the company, its shareholders and the American economy is that the lost weeks of production may never be made up.

title: Kentucky's Sweeping Overhaul of Education Offers Lessons Both Positiveand Negative
description: At a time of incessant alarms about the need to revamp American education, one state has actually done it -- Kentucky, where a landmark court ruling six years ago produced the most comprehensive overhaul of public education the nation has ever seen.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: WEST;With a Splash of Orange, the Final Four Portrait Is Complete
description: Syracuse missed its exit.

title: Rig Count Rises by 32
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States rose by 32 last week, to 725, Baker Hughes Inc. said. There were 652 rigs operating nationwide a year ago. Of the rigs running last week, 422 were exploring for natural gas and 297 for oil; 6 rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count is the number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: History of Habeas Corpus Didn't Begin With the 20th Century
description: To the Editor:

title: Land Mines Should Be Banned
description: The fighting is over in Somalia. It is over in Cambodia, Iraq and Nicaragua. Yet in all these places, people -- many of them children -- continue to be killed and maimed by antipersonnel land mines, which retain their destructive power almost indefinitely. Now, with the lives of American soldiers threatened by thousands of mines in Bosnia, the Pentagon is belatedly rethinking its opposition to a complete ban on use of these weapons.

title: Haitians at Center of Montreal Election
description: Gilles Solomcariotte, a 40-year-old textile worker who emigrated from Haiti two years ago, is waiting for a bus on gritty Papineau Street, in a working-class district of northeast Montreal, the site of a fiercely contested election for a seat in the House of Commons.

title: Blue Cross Groups Seek Profit, And States Ask Share of Riches
description: Days after Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield received New York State approval to establish a for-profit subsidiary, legislative and consumer watchdog groups raised the issue of a lucrative payback to the public as part of the package.

title: 2 Companies Make Cable Modem Plan
description: The 3Com Corporation said that it had purchased an equity stake in closely held Com21 Inc. and that it would work with the company to develop cable modems.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: POP REVIEW;Emotional Confessions Of Sin and Redemption
description: Saturday was melodrama night at Tramps, with two songwriters who aren't afraid to be overwrought. Singing about lust and anxiety, addiction and salvation, Maria McKee and James Hall took on outsize personas, yelping and wailing and belting. They gave the kinds of performances that can seem hammy on recordings but keep an audience riveted.

title: Hillary Clinton's Thanks on Bosnia
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton sought today to build the morale of families of United States troops on peacekeeping duty in Bosnia as she opened an eight-day European good-will tour.

title: Essay;New Mandate of Heaven
description: Not far from the shores of a great power lies a large, populous island. Its people, living in freedom, face a momentous decision: to unite with the mainland, to declare independence, or to enjoy the benefits of association without separation. The great power exhibits its self-confidence by saying, in essence, "it's your call."

title: HOCKEY;Most Valuable Player? Depends on the Night
description: When the Rangers beat the Bruins on Saturday afternoon in Boston, Mark Messier played beautifully. He skated like a brisk spring breeze, scored two goals, assisted on two others and presented convincing evidence that he is the most valuable player in the National Hockey League.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Capt. JAMES LOVELL, the Apollo 13 commander, would rather not talk about that flight any more, he said recently in an interview from Washington. But he still wants Americans to explore space. On Friday, at a news conference in Washington, he announced the creation of Mission HOME (Harvesting Opportunities for Mother Earth), a nonprofit group intended to educate the American public about the benefits of space studies.

title: Hispaniola's 'Sugar-Cane Curtain' Is Starting to Come Down
description: With a new President in office in Port-au-Prince and another scheduled to be installed here this summer, Haiti and the Dominican Republic are suddenly moving to end decades of mutual hostility and suspicion that have helped make the Caribbean island they share a perennial tinderbox.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES FEDERAL RESERVE AS LAX MANAGER
description: In a rare independent examination of the Federal Reserve's operations, a Congressional report issued today criticized management by the secretive central bank of its own finances, suggesting that it could spend less and return billions of dollars to the Treasury.

title: Gasoline Prices Rise
description: Gasoline prices jumped more than 3 cents a gallon in the last two weeks as warm weather pushed up demand at a time of lagging international supply, according to the Lundberg Survey of gas stations across the country. The average pump price, including all grades and taxes, was $1.2439 a gallon last Friday. Compared with the survey of March 8, the price was up 3.3 cents, the largest price increase so far this year, the analyst Trilby Lundberg said.

title: Race Had No Role in Officer's Shooting, Prosecutor Says
