description: In his closing statement yesterday, a prosecutor said that race played no role in a white police officer's shooting of an undercover black transit officer who was mistaken for a criminal in a Manhattan subway station.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;Dole Vows Victory to Town That Has Never Failed Him
description: If there is a new Bob Dole, he is the man who returned to his home town today, not as a loser in a national campaign, as he has three times before, but as a winner.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Don't look for the president of New York University in Washington Square today. Look in Washington. Dr. L. JAY OLIVA is leading a platoon of some 30 students in a one-day academic assault on Capitol Hill.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Irvin Must Testify
description: The star Cowboys receiver MICHAEL IRVIN met with prosecutors in Dallas yesterday and was ordered to appear before a grand jury investigating a drug arrest, WFAA-TV reported. His attorney, KEVIN CLANCY, said the All-Pro wide receiver could appear as early as today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Ailing Breland Cancels
description: MARK BRELAND, a former welterweight champion from Brooklyn, will not be able to fight Friday night because of a stomach virus. Breland was to have fought FLOYD WILLIAMS of Mobile, Ala., at Nassau Community College in Uniondale, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about moderate Republicans in New Jersey's Congressional delegation misstated the vote of one representative, Christopher H. Smith, on a bill last November to increase premiums for Medicare. He voted against it.

title: POP REVIEW;Glimpses of Love, Loss and Upward Mobility
description: There was a sense of embarrassment at Radio City on Friday night for a show by the Mexican pop band Marco Antonio Solis y los Bukis. The band is one of the biggest draws in Mexico and Central America, and Radio City seemed half full. The group started out sluggishly, as if a bit chagrined. By halfway through the show, it had worked its way up to as much velocity as it could. The band, formed in the mid-1970's, is professional.

title: Home Resales Surge 6.5% In Rush to Beat Rising Rates
description: Fears of rising mortgage rates spurred a surprising increase in sales of existing homes last month despite severe winter weather, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Gems Stolen at Antiques Fair
description: A suitcase containing $94,000 worth of jewelry was stolen Sunday afternoon from a booth at the Atlantic City Convention Center, the police said yesterday. The victim, who was not identified for security reasons, had just finished packing the bag and had momentarily turned her back when the bag disappeared, said Sgt. Ernest Jubilee, a spokesman for the Atlantic City Police Department.

title: Panel Ruling Hurts Stock Of Genzyme
description: The shares of the Genzyme Corporation lost nearly 10 percent of their value yesterday after a scientific panel recommended that a new product be approved but that its use be limited to a narrower range than analysts had anticipated. The panel also expressed concerns about possible side effects.

title: Tucson H.M.O.'s May Offer Model for Medicare's Future
description: Partners for Seniors has expanded its pharmacy benefit!" a newspaper ad proclaims to Tucson's big retirement community. "Enjoy free health club benefits," promises Intergroup of Arizona. "Do you know," touts FHP Health Care, "how your health plan stacks up against FHP's? You tell us. $0 plan premium. $0 deductibles."

title: Q & A / Lorenzo Semple Jr.: The Oscars: A Look Behind the Scenes
description: Like the Hollywood movie industry, the Academy Awards have conquered a growing global audience  often at the cost of frustrations for foreign filmmakers. Lorenzo Semple Jr., a veteran screenwriter (his credits include "Three Days of the Condor" and "Papillon") and former governor of the American Academy of Motion Pictures, talked to Joseph Fitchett of the International Herald Tribune about the Oscar mystique.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officer Stabbed by Motorist
description: A Port Authority police officer was injured yesterday in an automobile crash just outside the Holland Tunnel and a second officer was stabbed when the police tried to subdue the driver who struck the first officer's car, officials said. Officer Larry McKevitt and Sgt. Mark Potepa were treated at Christ Hospital and released yesterday afternoon.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Steven Block;Molecular Biomechanic Is Tweaking Nature's Tiniest Motors
description: A DRAWING outside Dr. Steven Block's office at Princeton University shows a tug of war between a single DNA molecule and an enzyme that is trying to copy it. The DNA molecule is being held in place at one end, and the enzyme is pulling on the other.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Panel Approves Mandate Bill
description: The State Assembly Budget Committee yesterday approved a bill aimed at making sure lawmakers allocate the money to pay for programs that they impose on local governments and school boards, The Associated Press reported. The measure would create a Council on Local Mandates, which would decide whether a proposed law is an unfinanced mandate.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;The Latest Macintosh Operating System Revisions: Comet or Candle?
description: WAS it just a decade ago that we waited for the glorious arrival of Halley's Comet, only to see a little fuzzball smudging the night sky? Despite the disappointment of that event 10 years ago, some of us still venture out in the wee hours to catch a glimpse of potential greatness.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Discovering Her Father Through a Camera Lens
description: My dad died two years ago, and I don't know what to do with his ashes," says Nicole Betancourt at the very beginning of "Before You Go: A Daughter's Diary," which she produced and directed. The emotional essay is part of an HBO series called "Family Video Diaries," offered as recordings of personal crises that have changed lives forever. Apparently, if the networks can give us "America's Funniest Home Videos," pay cable can try "America's Most Serious Home Videos." Two sides of the same sales coin, so to speak.

title: Nebraska Bishop Threatens Excommunication for Dissenters
description: In a move that was aimed at quelling dissent within the Roman Catholic Church but has only fueled it, a Bishop in Nebraska has threatened to excommunicate those who are members of groups that disagree with church doctrine on the ordination of women and other matters.

title: Officer Is Wounded in Shooting in Elevator
description: A New York City police sergeant was seriously wounded last night during an apparent robbery, when two men cornered him inside an elevator in a housing project on the Lower East Side in Manhattan and shot him in the abdomen, the police said.

title: BASEBALL;Harnisch's Pitch to Stay With Mets Is Slammed
description: The Dodgers rocked the Mets' Pete Harnisch today, scoring six runs on seven hits over four innings. Four of the hits were home runs that, aided by a stiff wind, totaled about 1,600 feet. One blast by Raul Mondesi sailed high over the left-field fence headed for Jupiter, and we're not talking Florida.

title: Congress Votes to End Tea Tasting Board
description: Calling it an anachronism that should have been done away with decades ago, Congress has voted to take the Government out of the tea tasting business.

title: Agua Prieta Journal;Border Patrol vs. 'Illegals': Now, the Desert War
description: Raul Gutierrez had put in much of a day's work by the time he sat down for lunch in the Yolanda Cafe near the international border station here, so he ordered a T-bone steak.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Blazers Whip Sixers Arvydas Sabonis had 18 points and 15 rebounds in less than three quarters last night as the Portland Trail Blazers beat Philadelphia, 94-71, sending the reeling 76ers to their eighth straight loss.

title: Response by G.I.'s Mixed As Hillary Clinton Visits
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton charmed American troops at a U.S.O. show here, but it didn't hurt that the singer Sheryl Crow and the comedian Sinbad were also on the stage.

title: BASKETBALL;Revenge Can Be an Incentive for Kentucky
description: The imperfection was glaring only because there were so few blemishes. In other places, the length of the basketball season provides players and coaches with an opportunity to experiment, refine, nurture and grow. Here, even before December, the expectation is simple. You start with perfection and improve from there.

title: Nicotine Nasal Spray Aims to Halt Smoking
description: Smokers trying to break the habit are about to get new help: a nasal spray that gives them a shot of nicotine from a bottle instead of a cigarette.

title: Tibet Repression Worse, Rights Groups Charge
description: Somewhere in this hazy gray Chinese city, sequestered in a small home that is guarded 24 hours a day, a 6-year-old Tibetan boy is out of luck.

title: For Comet Watchers, One Night Isn't Enough
description: More than 100 people came to an otherwise deserted Staten Island park last night to see Comet Hyakutake, despite being told in advance that clouds would almost certainly make viewing impossible. Most waited for more than an hour, and left only after the moon was blanketed by clouds.

title: Softbank Enters Marketing Deal
description: The Softbank Corporation, the world's largest computer magazine publisher, agreed today to buy an equity stake in Interactive Marketing Inc., an on-line marketing and communications company.

title: BASKETBALL;Nee Is Leading Cornhuskers to Semifinals
description: Danny Nee has seen more than enough in nearly 40 years of basketball. Nothing, however, was quite so strange as what occurred this season.

title: Executive Changes
description: ALLIED DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES CORP., Detroit, named George Fishman, co-chairman, to the additional position of chief executive.

title: POLITICS: THE JUDICIARY;Senator Renews Attack on Clinton's Judges
description: Escalating an election-year fight over judicial appointees, the Republican chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee today criticized several of President Clinton's choices for the Federal bench as soft on criminals.

title: Mobil Says Cuts Are Not Over
description: The chairman and chief executive of the Mobil Corporation said today that the company's revamping is expected to be finished by the end of the year and should result in annual savings of $1.3 billion in 1997.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Chile Says Its Spraying Has Suppressed Medfly
description: Chile has declared victory over the Mediterranean fruit fly in a persistent, 30-year battle that included such tough tactics as spraying pesticides over heavily populated areas and confiscating all organic material entering the country.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Where can you find eminent pianists like ALFRED BRENDEL when they aren't giving concerts and recitals? On a busman's holiday, that's where.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Bartow Resigns
description: GENE BARTOW, who built the Alabama-Birmingham program from the ground up, resigned last night. The school president, J. CLAUDE BENNETT, made the announcement to surpised seniors at an awards dinner in Birmingham. Bartow's 34-year-old son and assistant, MURRY BARTOW, will take over.

title: Pataki Has the Right to Remove Prosecutor;Independent Judiciary
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Justices to Review Effort to Make English Official Language
description: Turning the constitutional spotlight on the growing number of state laws declaring English to be the official language, the Supreme Court today agreed to review an Arizona effort to require public employees to conduct government business only in English.

title: Out of Cash, Discovery Zone Petitions Court For Chapter 11
description: Discovery Zone, whose bouncing balls and slippery slides made it the nation's largest operator of children's indoor-recreation centers, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, ending its own long slide to insolvency.

title: By Design;A Jacket Ladylike or Hip
description: Call it a jacket or call it a coat. If it is knee length, cut on the straight-and-narrow, with buttons down the front, it is the favored topping shown by many designers for spring and again for fall, for a dress or pants.

title: Detroit Closes In On Best Record
description: Mike Vernon made 29 saves as the Detroit Red Wings beat Anaheim, 5-1, tonight to extend their unbeaten streak to 11 games.

title: Jewel in the Desert Plays Host to Richest Race Ever
description: Gambling is not permitted in this sheikdom on the shores of the Persian Gulf. But nearly everything else goes, including daily raffles of Lexus cars and one-kilogram blocks of gold and, soon, the world's richest horse race, a $4 million contest featuring Cigar, North America's Horse of the Year for 1995.

title: Findings Pose Challenge to Immunology's Central Tenet
description: FOR all mankind's existential agonizing over the nature of the self and the other, from the perspective of the immune system identity is strictly a biochemical affair. Interlopers are vigorously attacked and their molecular signatures are memorized so that next time they can be carded and stopped at the door. But when the immune system encounters the body's own cells, it recognizes them as friendly and waves them on by.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Dockers Begins Khaki Campaign
description: The Dockers division of Levi Strauss & Company has introduced a campaign carrying the theme "The mission," which promotes the Dockers line of khaki pants by encouraging workers to dress less formally on so-called casual days.

title: Time to Move On
description: The blame can be shared by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Police Commissioner William Bratton for letting their successful partnership deteriorate over the last several months. But now that the Mayor has confirmed that Mr. Bratton is looking for employment outside New York City's government, it is clear what the next step should be. Mr. Bratton's service as one of the most effective police commissioners in recent history is being undercut by his rivalry with City Hall and the growing perception that his attention is focused on looking for his next job. He and the Mayor need to work together to effect a smooth transition to a new commissioner.

title: Ex-Premier Revives Libel Suit in Singapore
description: The Former Prime Minister of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew, has revived a libel suit against an American educator to seek damages over a 1994 article that Mr. Lee says implied that there is corruption in Singapore.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Repairs Start on Tunnel Tube
description: A $53 million overhaul has begun on the center tube of the Lincoln Tunnel, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. Replacement of curbs, tiles, ducts, doors and a high-voltage cable will restore the tube to "good-as-new condition for 35 years or more," George J. Marlin, the authority's executive director, said. The repair work is expected to be completed in fall 1998, said Carmen Curci, a spokeswoman for the agency.

title: BASKETBALL;Things Are Looking Up: Oakley Is Back in Swing
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy will have more than his share of worries the last few weeks of the regular season, but one big concern will disappear on Tuesday night when the Knicks play the league's two-time defending champion Houston Rockets.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPUTER LEASING FIRM FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: A computer leasing firm that contends it was duped in a bank scam filed for bankruptcy court protection from its creditors yesterday. Nelco Ltd., based in Richmond, was tricked in a scheme by a former employee of the Philip Morris Companies to secure $323 million in loans from at least six banks, the F.B.I. charged last week. Nelco, a privately owned company, said it lost a substantial amount by arranging the leases of computer equipment that the loans were to finance. The banks then called in some of their loans, which forced Nelco to file for bankruptcy protection, said Richard A. Nelson, the chief executive.

title: POLITICS: ON THE BALLOT;California May Take Lead On Curbing of Lawsuits
description: When California voters go to the polls on Tuesday, they will not only pass judgment on prospective Presidential nominees but will also decide whether the nation's biggest state should take a lead in the bitter fight over how much to change the American civil justice system.

title: Big Gun Makes Hydrogen Into a Metal
description: USING a 60-foot-long gun, physicists at Lawrence Livermore Laboratory have created a metallic form of hydrogen. Their results, they believe, will compel planetary scientists to revise conventional notions about the inner structures and magnetic fields of Jupiter and similar giant planets.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SOFTWARE SPECTRUM PLANS TO BUY EGGHEAD DIVISION
description: Software Spectrum Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the corporate, government and education division of Egghead Inc. for $45 million. Software Spectrum said the purchase would increase its presence as a reseller of computer software to businesses and organizations. The acquisition would also roughly double the company's annual revenue to $767 million. The sale would allow Egghead, which operates 164 software stores, to focus on its core software retailing business. Egghead said it would retain the division's inventory and receivables, which it said it planned to liquidate.

title: Governors and Business Leaders Gather to Map Route to Elusive New Era of Education
description: Six years after the nation's governors met in Charlottesville, Va., to plot strategies for improving troubled schools, 44 governors and much of the nation's corporate leadership will begin a second national conference today, at a time of persistent worries that the "new era of education reform" President Bush hailed in 1989 remains elusive.

title: It's Politics, But Unusual
description: It was hard enough for members of Congress to make laws when they had to get them through the House, the Senate and the White House. These days they have to worry about the Electoral College, too.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Gentle humor and an office not in New York help agencies in magazine advertising awards.
description: THE notion that geography is destiny, at least on Madison Avenue, is getting a boost from the selection of the finalists in the annual awards competition for creative excellence in magazine advertising.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: TENNIS;Capriati Comeback Hits Sabatini's Speed Bump
description: She wore a blue skirt she bought herself at a local pro shop, she wore blue polish on her nails, and, to complete the color scheme, Jennifer Capriati wore a moderately blue expression this afternoon after being dismissed by Gabriela Sabatini, 6-1, 6-4, in the fourth round of the Lipton Championships.

title: Pataki Has the Right to Remove Prosecutor
description: To the Editor:

title: Woolly Adelgid, Meet the Ladybug
description: Japanese ladybugs have been called in to fight off a tiny pest that threatens to kill about 10 percent of Connecticut's trees.

title: Developer Named by Pataki To Head State Arts Council
description: Earle I. Mack, a real estate developer and a board member of the New York City Ballet, has been named chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday.

title: Britain Defends Beef As Europe Asks Ban
description: The European Union moved yesterday to ban British beef as unsafe, while the British Government stepped back from earlier warnings and said no further steps were needed to protect consumers from so-called mad cow disease.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Interest in Fokker Unit
description: The Swedish aircraft maintenance supplier FFV Aerotech, which is part of the Celsius Industries group, said yesterday that its Aviocomp subsidiary was prepared to bid for the maintenance division of the bankrupt Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. Aviocomp's managing director, Jan-Ingvar Johansson, said it could be two months or so before a bid was made. Fokker's maintenance division has about 900 employees. Fokker, which shut most of its operations on March 15, has been in a crisis since January when its majority owner, Daimler-Benz of Germany, cut off financial support for the company. (Reuters)

title: About New York;Puerto Ricans Get Freedom, Culturally
description: COMING of age in a city that has welcomed liberators-in-exile, a new republic declared its independence Friday night on the Upper West Side. Ambassadors (of the arts, goodwill and otherwise) packed its embassy, where they received passports and sang the national anthem.

title: Thousands Mourn a Slain Suburban Police Officer
description: Suburban towns have often been the scene of stately police funerals, with kilted bands of bagpipers, a line of familiar politicians and a somber column of blue as far as the eye can see. But almost always, the slain officer is someone who worked in the comparative mayhem of New York City.

title: HOCKEY;Fichaud's 'Dream Come True' Has a Disappointing Ending
description: Long before any other player left this afternoon's pre-game skate, Eric Fichaud grabbed his goalie sticks and headed for the dressing room, eager to look around the new Molson Center.

title: It's a New Season For the Economy;Some of Winter's Worries Linger But Growth Is on the Rebound
description: Beverly B. Miller, president of a company that manufactures packaging equipment, first noticed the change in late February. Calls to her sales force surged unexpectedly, and one large customer, Hallmark Cards Inc., increased its orders for the automated machinery that packages the cards and party favors it makes.

title: Astronauts Haul Supplies to Space Station
description: Working like skycaps high above Earth, American and Russian astronauts lugged 12-gallon sacks of water and other supplies today from the space shuttle Atlantis to the Russian space station Mir.

title: Offering by Fort Howard
description: The Fort Howard Corporation, a paper products maker, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 16 million common shares. The company, based in Green Bay, Wis., said it would sell the stock at the market price at the time of the offering.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICROS SHARES PLUMMET FOLLOWING EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The stock of Micros Systems Inc. lost more than half of its value yesterday after the company warned of disappointing earnings in the third quarter despite an expected rise in sales. The stock fell $25.75, to $25, in Nasdaq trading. Micros, which makes electronic terminals that perform cash register and data processing functions, said late on Friday that it expected third-quarter profits to lag behind the $2.2 million, or 28 cents a share, it earned in the corresponding period last year. Analysts had expected earnings of 40 cents a share for the quarter this year, according to a First Call survey.

title: COMPANY NEWS;S.E.C. CLEARS TRADES OF SPRING STREET STOCK ON INTERNET
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has cleared the way for a New York brewer to resume a pioneering Internet trading system for its stock. The Spring Street Brewing Company case is being viewed as a test of the S.E.C.'s flexibility in allowing companies to use new technology to tap financial markets. Last week, Spring Street said it was suspending its bulletin board stock trading system, named "Wit-Trade" after the company's Wit Beer, after S.E.C. lawyers expressed reservations. Wit-Trade, based on Spring Street's World Wide Web page (http://plaza.interport.net/witbeer/), lets buyers and sellers post prices and meet via electronic mail. After agreeing to a trade by contract, the parties send money and stock certificates to Spring Street to complete the trade. Andrew D. Klein, Spring Street's chief executive, said the S.E.C. sent a letter on Friday that "gives us essentially a green light to resume Wit-Trade with some modifications." The S.E.C. said Spring Street should have a bank or an escrow agent handle customer funds. It also asked the company to place warnings on its Web page so investors know the stock could be difficult to sell because it is not traded on a regular stock exchange.

title: Kelly Gets Treasury Post
description: Raymond W. Kelly, a former police commissioner of New York City, has been named by President Clinton as the head of enforcement at the Treasury Department.

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTIES;In California, Nader Nibbles At Margins Of the Race
description: In the past four weeks alone, Bill Clinton has traveled twice to California, promised to seek Congressional approval of more California-built C-17 cargo planes, agreed to complete one more B-2 bomber and announced a $400 million Federal loan for a Los Angeles rail-cargo artery.

title: Germans in Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: BankAmerica to Pay Severance in Mergers
description: The BankAmerica Corporation has adopted a plan that assures about 885 executives that they will receive severance payments if the company merges with another big bank.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Distilling the Wisdom Of the World's Religions
description: Much to the consternation of its more benighted detractors, public television keeps on justifying itself. For those who simply can't get giddy pondering the latest hairstyles on "Friends," the public system, however flawed, provides at least an occasional, and indispensable, oasis of substance. The latest example: "The Wisdom of Faith With Huston Smith," a five-part Bill Moyers special that begins tonight.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Doping Case Is Dropped
description: Reversing its policy, the International Amateur Athletic Federation decided yesterday in Cape Town to drop a doping case against the British 800-meter runner DIANE MODAHL.

title: CUNY Board Declares Crisis Over Aid Cuts
description: Facing their biggest budget problems since New York City's fiscal crisis in the mid-70's, the trustees of the City University of New York voted yesterday to declare a state of emergency that officials say is likely to lead to the elimination of more than 1,330 full-time faculty and staff positions.

title: The 1996 Oscar Winners
description: These are the winners of the 68th annual Academy Awards, given tonight at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion here by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences:

title: Benefits Fund Could Grow In the Market, Panel Advises
description: Members of a Federal advisory panel told Congress today that a portion of Social Security payroll taxes should be invested in the stock market, and several senators expressed cautious support for the idea.

title: Lola Beltran, Singer, Dies; Mexico's Adored 'Grande'
description: Lola Beltran, the soulful Mexican singer whose achingly emotional renditions of mariachi ballads made her known as Lola the Great to generations of Latin Americans, died on Sunday night in Mexico City. During a career that spanned five decades, she made a point of refusing to discuss her age, but she was believed to be in her mid-60's.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about campaign finance legislation misidentified the home state of Senator Russell D. Feingold, an author of the bill. He is from Wisconsin, not Maryland. The article also misidentified the organization headed by Joan Claybrook. She is president of Public Citizen, which supports the bill, not of Citizen Action.

title: BASKETBALL;UConn Secures Its Place In Finals
description: For a women's team that won the national championship last year and is within sight of another, Connecticut is still playing ugly basketball. And still winning.

title: New European Muses: Real Women
description: European designers had a new muse this season. It's difficult to imagine that after having used up wardrobes of so many Audrey Hepburns and Grace Kellys of the past there would be anyone left to mine. What pretentious reference could it be this time -- Ida Lupino? Isadora Duncan? Dawn Powell? Dorothy Dandridge? Elizabeth Barrett Browning? Uma, Oprah, Keanu?

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Home Lender Is Buying Insurer
description: The Halifax Building Society, the British home lender, agreed yesterday to purchase Clerical Medical Investment Group, a mutual insurance concern, in a deal worth L800 million ($1.2 billion). Halifax will pay L730 million into the central fund of Clerical Medical, while putting up another L70 million as capital for the thousands of policyholders who own Clerical Medical.

title: BASKETBALL;Like Last 13, Nets Fall to Spurs
description: Both the San Antonio Spurs and Sean Elliott kept going, and going and going tonight.

title: Staten Island Leadership Sues to Close Fresh Kills
description: For decades, residents of Staten Island have viewed the Fresh Kills landfill as a malodorous emblem of their relationship with the other four boroughs. But despite years of complaints, lawsuits and even a move to secede from the rest of New York City, Staten Islanders and their political leaders say the landfill is smellier than ever and offers conclusive proof that they are being treated as the city's forgotten borough.

title: Seeking Indigent-Care Plan, Hospitals Send Trenton Bill
description: Seeking to put pressure on the state to come up with a plan to pay for hospital care for the poor, the heads of several New Jersey hospitals today left a $96 million bill on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's desk and vowed to begin doing business with only those companies providing health insurance for their employees.

title: No Headline
description: We want to do what everyone else wants to do. Grow up and get married and have a family."

title: Albany Gives Crew Power to Unseat Boards
description: As expected, state legislators voted yesterday to give Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew the right to block winners of the May 7 school board elections from taking their seats in the districts whose members have been suspended for wrongdoing.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF C-CUBE TUMBLE AFTER I.B.M. CHIP INTRODUCTION
description: The stock of C-Cube Microsystems Inc. tumbled almost 22 percent yesterday after the International Business Machines Corporation introduced several chips for audio and video that investors feared would wrest business from C-Cube. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of C-Cube fell $12, to $42.75. I.B.M. displayed six chips yesterday for use in the next generation of professional digital video and audio equipment, multimedia personal computers and work stations, and digital set-top boxes. One analyst said I.B.M. would threaten C-Cube's business down the road, but not immediately because I.B.M.'s new chips were designed for use in personal computers, whereas C-Cube's products were aimed at consumer electronics products.

title: POLITICS: THE UNIONS;Labor Movement Endorses the President
description: The nation's labor movement has set aside its anger over President Clinton's trade policy and endorsed him today for re-election. Just 2 of the 78 unions in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. -- the teamsters and the longshoremen's union in San Francisco -- dissented, saying they wanted more time to consider their action.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Suicide, Mourning and a Different Sense of Reality
description: Hirokazu Kore-eda's exquisitely beautiful film "Maborosi" follows the spiritual odyssey of Yumiko (Makiko Esumi), a young Japanese woman recovering from her husband's inexplicable suicide. But that description doesn't begin to evoke the essence of a movie that is a pictorial tone poem of astonishing visual intensity and emotional depth. Watching the film, which has little dialogue and many lingering shots of the Japanese landscape, one has an uncanny sense of entering the consciousness of the main character and seeing through her eyes, all without really knowing her.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;On Regional Stages, Skepticism With Swagger
description: Leave it to John Malkovich to find existential emptiness in a Little Lord Fauntleroy wig. As the title character in "The Libertine," Stephen Jeffreys's drama of Restoration England, now at the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago, Mr. Malkovich plays broodingly with his crimped mane, evoking the hollow, glamorous hedonism of Julie Christie in "Darling." When this actor fingers his tresses, it's not split ends he's contemplating; it's the meaninglessness of life.

title: BASEBALL;Injury Has Yanks Offering Pitching
description: The Yankees, flush with pitching and shy of middle-infield depth, began an intense search today for a trade to alleviate a problem made suddenly critical Sunday by Tony Fernandez's probable season-ending elbow fracture.

title: Tensions Seen As Receding As China Ends War Games
description: China announced today that it has ended its third round of war games off the coast of Taiwan, held immediately before, during and after last Saturday's presidential election on Taiwan.

title: Right-to-Die Law Review
description: Washington State will ask the United States Supreme Court to review a recent appeals court decision that allowed physicians to assist the suicide of terminally ill patients, state officials said today.

title: A Paris Maison for Photography to Call Home
description: Thanks to Robert Doisneau's candid shots of this city's street life, Irving Penn's portraits of its artists and the host of other famous photographers who have worked here, Paris is probably more identified with photography than any other city in the world. Yet photographers have long complained that they do not enjoy proper recognition as artists.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIGICON AND VERITAS AGREE TO $72 MILLION MERGER
description: Digicon Inc., which acquires seismic data used to search for oil and natural gas, said it agreed yesterday to a stock-swap merger worth about $72 million with a Canadian competitor, Veritas Energy Services Inc. Under the agreement, the acquisition will be structured as a tax-free pooling of interests, in which each Veritas share will be exchanged for 0.80 Digicon share, or about $8.50 worth of Digicon stock.

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Focusing On Issues To Shape The Future
description: For a last campaign swing through two Western states today, Patrick J. Buchanan chartered an airplane to travel in style as he delivered another version of his list of demands on the Republican Party.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: New Format For Audio Is Under Review
description: Consumer electronics companies are preparing to introduce a new format for recorded music that will provide more vibrant and true-to-life sound than existing compact disks.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Advance in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose in light volume yesterday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting today. Economic fundamentals were unchanged and trading was confined to technical factors and short-covering by speculators.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball Major League Baseball ARIZONA DIAMONDBACKS -- Announced an affiliation agreement with the Nuevo Laredo Owls of the Mexican League. American League BOSTON RED SOX -- Claimed John Doherty, pitcher, off waivers from the Detroit Tigers. CALIFORNIA ANGELS -- Placed Steve Ontiveros and Bryan Harvey, pitchers, on the 15-day disabled list.

title: Stocks Up in Tokyo
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 99.33 points, or nearly half of 1 percent, to 21,014.77. On Monday, the Nikkei rose 214.52 points.

title: Board Offers Police Broad Power Over Safety in Schools
description: While continuing to rebuff Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's demand that the police take over school security, the Board of Education has offered the city's police force broad new responsibilities for recruiting, screening and training new safety officers and supervisors, a board safety official said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Lakers Give Ceballos A Cold Shoulder
description: If CEDRIC CEBALLOS expected his Los Angeles Lakers teammates to forgive his unexcused four-day Arizona vacation, forget it. Ceballos finally turned up Sunday, but the team did not toss out a welcome mat for him. His sudden disappearance last Wednesday has splintered a team fighting Houston for fourth place in the Western Conference.

title: Solv-Ex Stock Drops 67% After Report
description: The stock of the Solv-Ex Corporation, an oil company, plummeted 67 percent yesterday after the CNBC financial correspondent Dan Dorfman reported the negative findings of one study.

title: BASEBALL;First Pitch From Clinton
description: President Clinton will throw out the first pitch on Monday at the Baltimore Orioles' opening game against Kansas City, the White House has announced. Whether there will be a photo opportunity for Senator Bob Dole, the likely Republican Presidential candidate, remains a question. The Cleveland Indians have invited him to throw out the first ball against the Yankees.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Computer Sciences Buys 75% of Danish Concern
description: The Danish Government said yesterday that it had sold a 75 percent stake in its information-technology services company, Datacentralen A.S., to the Computer Sciences Corporation of El Segundo, Calif. A Danish official declined to disclose the amount paid but said the terms "were better than those offered by other bidders."

title: Survey Breaks Down Misuse of Alcohol
description: Five percent of the young adults responding to a new survey said they drove every time they consumed alcoholic beverages.

title: In Bosnia, Securing a Peaceful Future Now Depends on Roads, Refugeesand Elections
description: You want to see my graph of the future?" asks Carl Bildt, the former Prime Minister of Sweden who is in charge of carrying out all provisions of the peace agreement in Bosnia and Herzegovina except for the work of the 60,000 NATO peacekeepers who keep the belligerents apart.

title: Why Hand Russia Our Jet Technology?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Monterey County Travel and Tourism Alliance, Monterey, Calif., to Hoffman/Lewis, San Francisco, as the first agency of record. The billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Spy Versus Spy, Adventures on Line and Off
description: A CLASSIFIED alert, Chief, from your loyal Analyst Second Class: the Internet may indeed be crawling with would-be spies. Spycraft: The Great Game (Activision Inc., about $50), which comes on three CD-ROM's and demands up to 45 megabytes of hard disk space, also includes an optional link to the World Wide Web.

title: And the 1996 Oscar Winners Are . . .
description: Best Actor -- Nicolas Cage, "Leaving Las Vegas"

title: Insurer Names Head of Unit
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies promoted Jeffrey W. Greenberg yesterday to chairman and chief executive of its investment unit, nine months after he resigned as a potential successor to his father as chairman of the American International Group.

title: Here Come the Wild Cards
description: You have to feel for Bob Dole. Here he is, in his own words, "finally at the finish line," with only "an inch to go." Today's California primary should put him over the line. But who should pop up in his moment of triumph but Ross Perot, announcing that his new Reform Party will play a big role in the November elections and, further, that the party's Presidential candidate may well be none other than Ross Perot. Unless, of course, Lowell Weicker decides to seek the Reform Party's nomination for himself, which is what Time Magazine is speculating this week.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Shake-Up at Inchcape As Profits Plunge
description: Inchcape P.L.C., a leading British distributor of Toyota cars, replaced its chief executive yesterday and slashed its dividend in response to a 92 percent decline in profits last year. The company said its managing director, Philip Cushing, would immediately succeed the chief executive, Charles Mackay, who will serve as deputy chairman until he retires in June.

title: Bradley Leads Filibuster On Public-Lands Measure
description: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and his Democratic allies mounted a filibuster today against a Federal lands bill, saying that even though they favored provisions affecting their own states they would not accept proposals to open more of Utah to mining.

title: BASKETBALL;UMass Is Set to Unveil Damaging Evidence
description: Every basketball team that wants to be successful needs a player like Carmelo Travieso. You have heard of the Terminator. Meet the Demoralizer.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There was one sure bet that could be made last night as New York prepared to weigh in with its own round of Oscar parties: no pork on the menu. Not in the year of "Babe."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Pedroso Has Surgery
description: IVAN PEDROSO of Cuba, the world long jump champion, had surgery yesterday to repair a torn thigh muscle, and his doctor says there is a chance he will miss the Atlanta Olympics. Dr. RODRIGO ALVAREZ CAMBRAS, who operated on Pedroso, said in Havana that the operation was "successful," Prensa Latina, the Cuban news agency, said.

title: Birth Control Might Keep Mustangs From Outgrowing Range
description: EVEN in an age of endangered species, many animals are breeding prolifically, straining their environments and clashing with their human neighbors. One solution, now being tested on wild horses in the West, is birth control.

title: Angered by Klan Items, Man Drives Into Shop
description: When the Redneck Shop, with its merchandise of Ku Klux Klan symbols and garb, opened as "the World's Only K.K.K. Museum" in nearby Laurens earlier this month, residents wore black-and-white ribbons to symbolize racial unity, and more than 300 people joined in a protest of the glorification of bigotry.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTCORP JOINS IN BUYING 85% SIMMONS STAKE
description: Investcorp, the international investment company, and the management of the Simmons Company acquired nearly 85 percent of the concern, a bedding manufacturer, yesterday for $250 million. The investors said they had acquired the Atlanta-based Simmons, which had 1995 sales of $490 million, from affiliates of Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. The Simmons Employee Stock Ownership Plan will continue to own about 15 percent of the company, Investcorp said. Simmons employs 2,500 people in 18 plants. Investcorp's investments including Saks Fifth Avenue, Gucci and Circle K.

title: After Life of Notoriety and Pain, Son Tries to Solve His Mother'sMurder
description: He slept right through it, that terrible night more than 40 years ago when his mother, Marilyn Sheppard, was bludgeoned to death in her bedroom.

title: Stock Prices Finish Mixed In a Day of Listless Trading
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday in slow trading, with little in the way of economic news or internal dynamics to propel the market.

title: Cabdriver Is Killed in Queens Carjacking
description: A 44-year-old taxi driver from Senegal was shot and killed Sunday night in a carjacking outside his Queens home as he was preparing to park his car in his garage, the police said.

title: Chevron Unit In Canada Deal
description: The Chevron Corporation's Chevron Canada Resources unit said today that it had agreed to buy Norcen Energy Resources Ltd.'s interests in a number of Canadian east coast offshore properties. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Q&A
description: Air Supply

title: Russia Drops Big Tariff Increase, Clearing Way for an I.M.F. Loan
description: Russia has dropped a plan for a sharp across-the-board increase in import tariffs, clearing the way for a $10.2 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund, Western economists said tonight.

title: On My Mind;Dispatch From the Drug War
description: On the U.S. mainland, it is becoming politically unfashionable to call the war on drugs the war on drugs.

title: POLITICS;Perot Says the Time Is Here for a New Party
description: Brushing off Senator Bob Dole's appeal to stay out of the general election, Ross Perot said today that starting a major new party in the United States was "an idea whose time has come."

title: Plans for Market Near Auschwitz Dropped
description: A Polish trading company said today that it was abandoning plans for a supermarket near the former Nazi death camp at Auschwitz because of controversy surrounding the venture.

title: For Kindergartners, The Race Is On
description: Nancy Lorenz camped out overnight at Public School 129 in College Point, Queens for a shot yesterday at precious kindergarten openings for her twins. At home, she had left behind half-finished laundry and a hasty note to her husband.

title: Prosecutor Writes Note Of Regret To Judge Baer
description: After weeks in which a judge faced blistering criticism for tossing out evidence in a drug case, United States Attorney Mary Jo White sent a letter to the judge yesterday expressing regret that the case had become "a topic of political debate."

title: Ford Shifts Leadership at Lincoln-Mercury Unit
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that James G. O'Connor, executive director of export operations, had been selected to try to reverse the sagging sales of Lincoln and Mercury cars.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MEDTRONIC PLANS TO PURCHASE INSTENT FOR $200 MILLION
description: Medtronic Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Instent Inc., a maker of stents used in medical procedures, for about $200 million. Under the agreement, Medtronic will exchange 0.3833 of a share for each of the 10 million Instent shares, plus options outstanding. The purchase would expand Medtronic's line of stents, which are devices used to hold open passageways in the body that may have closed or become obstructed. Instent is based in Eden Prairie, Minn., and has operations in Tel Aviv. The company had 1995 revenue of about $2.4 million.

title: Star Television Venture Is Aimed at China
description: Star Television Ltd., the Asian satellite broadcaster owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, has formed a joint venture aimed at breaking into China's restricted cable television market, a Star Television spokesman said today.

title: How to Aid Care Givers and the Hopelessly Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAXXIM MEDICAL BIDS AGAIN FOR STERILE CONCEPTS
description: Maxxim Medical Inc. sweetened its hostile takeover bid yesterday for Sterile Concepts Holdings Inc. to $135 million, or $19 a share, after the medical products maker rejected two earlier bids. Maxxim first offered $16 a share for Sterile Concepts, based in Richmond, on Feb. 14. After that was rejected, Maxxim raised its offer to $17.75 on March 11. Maxxim's offer also includes the assumption of $29 million in debt. Maxxim said it would withdraw the offer if it was not accepted by the close of business on April 1. Shares of Maxxim fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $19.125, and Sterile Concepts' shares gained 50 cents, to $17.75.

title: Patterns
description: Inspired by 'Rent'

title: Whitewater Figure Is Given 28 Months
description: David Hale, the former municipal court judge and businessman who pleaded guilty to fraud and has been a central witness in the Whitewater inquiry, was sentenced today to 28 months in prison and ordered to make restitution of $2.4 million.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Pushing Beyond Grunge
description: The final nails are being hammered into the coffin of Seattle-style grunge rock. Here are three reasons: the Stone Temple Pilots, popular grunge imitators, have moved on to experiment with different styles; Babylon Zoo, the English pop stars, are taking grunge density out of context to merge it with futuristic dance music, and Christian groups like Jars of Clay are sanitizing grunge, playing a folksy variant. Soon, what was once grunge will have evolved into something completely different.

title: Best Seats in House
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Furloughs for Officers
description: The city of East Orange will temporarily lay off 97 of its 284 police officers for seven weeks, starting May 10, officials said yesterday. The furloughs are necessary to close a $500,000 budget deficit, Debra Chandler, a spokeswoman for Mayor Cardell Cooper, said.

title: ON HOCKEY;Messier Leads Charge At a Grueling Practice
description: After a meeting between the players and the coaches came a meeting among just the players. Next on the schedule yesterday at Rye, N.Y., was a long, demanding practice, with more than a few collisions, followed by wind sprints, up and down the ice, forward and backward, the length of the rink instead of its shorter width.

title: Waiting for a Black Heathcliff
description: African-Americans make up 12 percent of the population but 25 percent of the movie-going audience, according to the March 18 issue of People magazine. What have our billions of dollars bought us? "A lot more than they used to," say some. "Not enough," says Jesse Jackson, who organized a nationwide protest last night during the Academy Awards broadcast, calling attention to the "marginal role" of blacks in the film industry.

title: Observer;Pluto, Polo, Oh Woe!
description: A British scholar says Marco Polo never got to China. He may have made it to Constantinople, she says, but he probably invented the tale about the rest of the trip.

title: Curbing Central America's Generals
description: Since the cold war ended, the small countries of Central America have been trying to recover from an era of military dictatorship. Guatemala, home of Central America's most brutal military -- installed with the help of a C.I.A.-backed coup in 1954 -- is having the hardest time. A succession of presidents have tried, with small success, to bring the soldiers under control.

title: Chess
description: Dmitry Gurevich defeated everyone he faced earlier this month when he won the $5,000 first prize in the United States Masters Championship in Oak Brook, Ill. But despite his 7-0 score in the event, which was open to national masters and a sprinkling of invited juniors, the 39-year-old Chicago grandmaster did not overwhelm his strongest rivals so much as outfight them.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Oates Leaves as a Giant
description: Center BART OATES is retiring from professional football, but he is leaving as a Giant, not a San Francisco 49er. Oates, who played with the Giants from 1985-93, will hold a news conference today at Giants Stadium to make the announcement. He won two Super Bowl rings while with the Giants, then left for San Francisco.

title: Liechtenstein's Headstrong Prince Threatens Subjects  With Quitting
description: VADUZ, Liechtenstein  Having survived all of Europe's convulsions, including two World Wars, the principality of Liechtenstein is facing its first constitutional crisis of the century.

title: Francisco Villarreal, Defiant Mexico Mayor
description: Francisco Villarreal, a rebellious border city mayor who once went to jail for taking over an international bridge in defiance of the federal Government, died on Sunday. He was 65.

title: Market Place;Want a Cheap Buy? Try RJR Tobacco
description: What would you say about a stock that paid an annual dividend of 17 percent of the company's share price? What if someone told you the company had enough cash to raise that payout to 23 percent?

title: Panel Is Named for Tobacco Class Action
description: In a development that had been eagerly awaited on Wall Street, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans yesterday named three conservative judges to a panel that will decide whether a giant class-action suit against the nation's tobacco companies can continue.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;100 Texaco Stations Planned for Poland
description: Texaco Inc., the second-largest service station operator in the United States, said yesterday that it would expand its European network by investing $150 million to build 100 filling stations in Poland within six years. Texaco, based in White Plains, joins a rush by oil companies into Poland, where the economy is growing faster than anywhere else in Eastern Europe.

title: Substantial Drop' Is Expected In Quarterly Profit at Philips
description: Philips Electronics N.V. said today that it expected a "substantial drop" in its first-quarter profit because of low demand for its personal computers and weakness in consumer electronics.

title: Pataki Has the Right to Remove Prosecutor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Seizes 2 Leaders Of a Fugitive Group
description: Federal agents arrested two leaders of an anti-government group today whose members have been holed up in a remote area for more than a year, the authorities said.

title: War Games' Fallout: High Distrust of China
description: SINGAPORE  While China ended war games close to Taiwan on Monday, the repercussions in Asia of its military muscle-flexing are likely to last much longer and may have ensured that the United States and Japan will strengthen their security treaty, officials and analysts say.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Job Cuts in South Africa
description: Standard Bank of South Africa Ltd., the country's second-largest bank, said yesterday that it had offered voluntary severance packages to about 700 employees and might dismiss workers who do not accept. The offers primarily affect support staff but about 7 percent of those involved are managers. Workers who do not take early retirement or severance packages may be transferred, not necessarily at the same level, the company said. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Philippine Kidnappings
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the United Nations war crimes tribunal's newest indictments relating to the Balkans referred incorrectly to previous indictments by the tribunal. They involved allegations of war crimes in which the intended victims were Muslims and Croats, not Muslims alone.

title: Microsoft Says It Has a Million on Line
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that its Microsoft Network on-line service had one million subscribers after seven months of operations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Agency Shifts By 2 Companies
description: Two consumer marketers are changing agencies.

title: 7.9 Million Penny-Stock Repayment Ordered
description: A New Jersey securities executive was ordered to repay $7.9 million to hundreds of investors because they were not warned that his firm sold them risky penny stocks, regulators said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN FINANCIAL GROUP INC., Cincinnati, a property and casualty insurer, said the $63 million sale of its Buckeye Management Co. subsidiary would result in a pretax gain of about $35 million in the first quarter.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JAMES RIVER TO SELL INKS BUSINESS TO SUN CHEMICAL
description: The James River Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its inks business to the Sun Chemical Company, which is based in Fort Lee, N.J., and is a subsidiary of the Tokyo-based Dainippon Inks and Chemicals Inc. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. In December, James River said it intended to sell its CZ Inks division and its plastic packaging business to focus on its more profitable tissue-paper and consumer products business. Combined, the inks division and the plastic packaging business had about $540 million in 1995 sales, the company said. James River's CZ Ink's division employs 200 people at seven plants. James River said it would use proceeds from the sale to reduce its long-term debt.

title: Man Is Acquitted In Upstate Rape In Barroom in '91
description: A jury in upstate New York yesterday acquitted a man accused of a barroom rape in a case that stirred deep emotions about the treatment of sexual-abuse victims, small-town justice and what can happen when politics and the law intersect.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: How to Aid Care Givers and the Hopelessly Ill;Death of a Sister
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;In the Shadows of Hell and Hatred
description: In making "Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills," Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky discovered the kind of small-town nightmare that is a documentary film maker's dream. In this sad, lurid and darkly transfixing story, they locate all the elements of true crime reporting at its most bitterly revealing.

title: Pataki Has the Right to Remove Prosecutor
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Simpson Prosecutor's View of Life and the Trial
description: IN CONTEMPT By Christopher A. Darden, with Jess Walter Illustrated. ReganBooks/HarperCollins. 387 pages. $26.

title: 2 at Vulkan Charged With Paying Bribes
description: Two managers of the troubled German shipbuilder Bremer Vulkan Verbund A.G. have been charged with influence peddling, prosecutors said today.

title: Gibson Best Director for 'Braveheart,' Best Film
description: Braveheart," a tumultuous drama about the 13th-century Scottish uprising led by William Wallace, took two of the top Oscars at the 68th annual Academy Awards last night, including best picture. Mel Gibson, who directed and starred in the film, was named best director.

title: Pataki Has the Right to Remove Prosecutor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Top Appointments At 3 Agencies
description: Three agencies are making top-level appointments.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Agencies Named By Beer Company
description: The Gambrinus Company in San Antonio has named two agencies to handle its beer brands.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Travel Spending Increases
description: Spending on tourism in New Jer sey totaled $22.9 billion last year an increase of $3 billion since 1993 -- Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday.

title: Bridge and Tunnel Traffic Smooth as Tolls Rise
description: Traffic on major bridges and tunnels in New York City rolled relatively smoothly yesterday, even as a toll increase to $3.50 each way, from $3, took effect, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said.

title: Time Warner Plans to Sell Preferred Shares in Venture
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell $1 billion in preferred shares linked to its Time Warner Entertainment venture, using the proceeds to ease a burdensome debt load.

title: Another Departure at Kmart As Marketing Chief Resigns
description: In its latest housecleaning move, the Kmart Corporation announced yesterday that Kenneth W. Watson, vice president for marketing, would leave the company.

title: City Hall Memo;A Helpful Giuliani Is Drawing Bratton A Map to the Door
description: In a feat of political alchemy, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani spoke a few words Sunday afternoon and suddenly transformed William J. Bratton from the country's most celebrated police commissioner into a lame duck. The feat was all the more remarkable for being so obvious.

title: Artistry on Ice
description: The worlds of dance and sport can magically come together on the ice rink when top figure skaters compete, producing a fluid choreography of power and grace. That was the case in Edmonton, Alberta, on Saturday when Chen Lu of China and Michelle Kwan of the United States contested for the title at the world figure-skating championships. The marriage of athletics and art has rarely been more thrilling to watch as Kwan topped a near-perfect free-skating program by Chen to win her first world title at the age of 15.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 13 about plans for a new game reserve in Kenya misidentified one species found in the region. It is the African, or black, buffalo, that can be dangerous to humans, not the water buffalo, an Asian variety used as a draft animal.

title: Melville in Accord to Sell Toy Chain to Consolidated
description: The Melville Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Kay-Bee Toys chain, the nation's second-largest toy retailer, to the Consolidated Stores Corporation, for $315 million.

title: BASEBALL;Lack of Control Drives Dibble to Take Leave of Absence
description: A subdued Rob Dibble said today, "I came in quietly and I just want to go out quietly." But between his arrival in the major leagues in 1988 and his departure from baseball today, Dibble was like a meteorite that burned up everything in its path.

title: Problems Schools Can't Solve
description: One of my students wrote a short story in which he recounted how he watched as his father was shot and killed inside their apartment building. Another student was neglected so badly that at age 7 she lost all her hair from malnutrition; at 14, she still had to wear diapers to school. Yet another student was walking to the grocery store with her best friend when gang members started firing at one another; her best friend was killed. And just the other day, a 9-year-old boy in one of my classes wrote:

title: London Adamant as European Nations Ban British Beef
description: The European Union moved today to ban British beef as unsafe, even as the British Government was telling consumers at home that no further steps were necessary to protect them from exposure to so-called mad cow disease.

title: Sports of The Times;The Price Of Squashing Tomato Cans
description: With his boxing gloves on, Mike Tyson plods ahead in a straight line, but out of the ring he sometimes talks in circles.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cutbacks at Barclays
description: The British bank Barclays P.L.C. announced a plan yesterday to shed about 1,000 management and clerical jobs from its branches through a voluntary offer to employees. The company said a similar offer last year attracted more acceptances than Barclays had expected. The job cuts will be about offset by jobs created in an expansion of telephone banking, Barclays said. (AP)

title: Drinking Black Tea May Reduce Stroke Risk
description: Instead of tea and crumpets, people should try tea and apples, for they could reduce the risk of stroke, a new European study suggests.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gasoline Is Near 4-Year High As Peak Demand Approaches
description: Gasoline soared to its highest price in almost four years yesterday on concern that inventories are low at a period when refineries are usually gearing up for increased demand.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Lost Play Written by Shakespeare. Or Not.
description: In 1613, the King's Men, the theater company to which Shakespeare belonged, gave two performances of a play called "Cardenno." Forty years later, an entry in the Stationers' Register lists the planned publication of a play called "The History of Cardenio by Mr. Fletcher and Shakespeare." What happened to the play after that is anybody's guess.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed's Finances Criticized In Congressional Report A Congressional report criticized the Federal Reserve's management of its finances, suggesting the central bank could spend less and return billions of dollars to taxpayers.

title: Virtual Marriages for Same-Sex Couples
description: By the power vested in him by this bastion of liberal politics, Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. pronounced dozens of gay and lesbian couples virtual spouses today in the first such mass mock nuptials held by an American city.

title: Ada Louise Huxtable Receives Award
description: Ada Louise Huxtable, the architecture critic and historian, received the $24 Award from the Museum of the City of New York last night. The award, named for the value of goods offered by the Dutch to the American Indians for Manhattan Island, is presented to people who have made important contributions to improving the quality of life in New York City. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented the award at the museum.

title: Stock of Phamis Plummets 38%
description: The stock of Phamis Inc. plunged today, one day after it said its first-quarter profits would fall far short of analysts' estimates.

title: Sit-In at Japan's Legislature Ends
description: A day after losing an important by-election, Japanese opposition parties today ended a three-week sit-in that had blocked parliamentary debate on an unpopular bailout plan for bankrupt housing lenders.

title: TV SPORTS;Women on Court, but Few in Booth
description: Wanted: Women to call play-by-play for the N.C.A.A. women's tournament.

title: C.I.A. Panel Insisted on Central Agency Role
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Licensing Vocational Schools
description: The Assembly Education Committee approved a bill yesterday that would license vocational training schools and require them to offer students protection in the event of bankruptcy. The legislation was spurred by the bankruptcy of a chain of schools in northern New Jersey and New York City known as SCS Business and Technical Institute, said Jeff Whelan, a spokesman for the Assembly Democrats.

title: Defeat for Essex Executive On County Residency Law
description: The Essex County Executive all but conceded today that his attempt to require all county employees to live in the county had failed.

title: No Notice, No Spraying, Nassau Legislators Say
description: Enacting its first law, the new Nassau County Legislature voted overwhelmingly today to require contractors to send postcard notices to neighbors before spraying pesticides, paint or other airborne substances outdoors.

title: S.A.T. Ranks For the States Are Disputed
description: Challenging the use of state-by-state Scholastic Assessment Test rankings to justify spending cuts for schools, a new study says that some states are wrongly praised for educational gains while others are unjustly chided for mediocrity when their students are actually doing better than their peers nationwide.

title: A Small Town Now Hopes The Stigma Doesn't Stick
description: In the end, the Casablanca Restaurant itself may have best survived the night of Oct. 26, 1991, when the owner's son, the bartender and three other men undressed a woman who had passed out drunk after hours and had sex with her.

title: Fiscal Watchdog Bites Capital Master
description: He challenged residents to mow their lawns and clean their alleys, business leaders to create more jobs. He implored the District of Columbia Council to protect his summer jobs program, Congress to pass the District's 1996 appropriation bill.

title: THE BRATTON RESIGNATION: THE LEGACY;Bratton Hailed as Pioneer Of New Style of Policing
description: In his first days in office in January 1994, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton tossed a panhandler off a subway car, sacked his department's entire high command and promised to "take back the city block by block."

title: Sports of The Times;Browns' Victory Stirs Dodger Daydreams
description: MOST people already know that when Art Modell stuffed his football players into his gunnysack and left for Baltimore, he agreed not to take the hallowed name "Cleveland Browns" with him.

title: Five Goals And a Baby
description: Mario Lemieux had five goals and two assists to dominate his first game against Wayne Gretzky in more than three years and lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to an 8-4 victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Penne Dish With a Greek Accent
description: This penne recipe calls for a sauce of tomatoes, spinach and feta cheese, a typical Greek combination, often paired with shrimp. To retain the flavor and reduce the fat, mix yogurt with the feta to make a sauce.

title: The Twin Crises at CUNY
description: New York City and the nation have reaped enormous benefit from the City University of New York, a public system that has produced many distinguished scholars and allowed tens of thousands who might otherwise have been denied education to vault from poverty into the middle class and beyond. This week's decision by the university's board of trustees to declare a financial state of emergency reveals a system in budgetary crisis. Behind the vote, however, lies a crisis of confidence, with the faculty and some administrators questioning whether CUNY's Chancellor, Ann Reynolds, will give them a fair hearing before she acts on her plans for the university's future.

title: Reprisals Rekindle a Debate in Israel
description: When Israeli bulldozers rumbled up to Ribhi al-Sharif's house in East Jerusalem last week to tear it down, he didn't stay to watch.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Forget the Basics And Stumble Into Defeat
description: Do not leave the zone early. Clear the puck from the zone when killing a penalty. Do not let your goalie become the target in a shooting gallery. All so simple, so fundamental, and so lacking from the Islanders' repertory tonight at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;An insurer retires from 'real life' in favor of a new campaign about its many financial services.
description: JOHN HANCOCK, after a decade of offering what was described as "real answers" for "real life," will now tackle a real challenge: persuading consumers that they ought to sign their own John Hancocks to fewer credit-card receipts and more investment contracts.

title: U.S. Issues Rules for H.M.O.'s In an Effort to Protect Patients
description: The Federal Government today issued rules restricting the ability of health maintenance organizations to pay bonuses and other financial rewards to doctors as an inducement to limit the services provided to elderly patients and poor people under Medicare and Medicaid.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Rejected by Illinois, Coach Gets New Job
description: Jimmy Collins, passed over for the University of Illinois coaching job when Lou Henson retired, is the new basketball coach at Illinois-Chicago.

title: Catching the Image of Jazz as It Will Never Be Again
description: Forty years ago, the photographer Roy DeCarava dreamed up the idea for a book of jazz photographs he planned to call "The Sound I Saw." Today, he says, "I'm not happy with the things I hear."

title: On Russia's Campaign Trail, Communist Recasts the Past
description: Revising Soviet history as he goes, the Communist leader Gennadi A. Zyuganov made his first presidential campaign swing today, trying out his election pledge to preserve pluralism and private property on mostly Communist crowds in the distant provinces.

title: BASEBALL;Astros Try to Hang On in Houston
description: Major League Baseball proudly wore a mantle of stability this winter as it watched the National Football League struggle to control renegade franchises eager to abandon their communities in search of more luxury boxes and money.

title: BASEBALL;Battling The Crowd In Yanks' Rotation
description: When a pitcher throws well enough to come out on the positive end of a 12-4 game and still looks at the world grimly, chances are he is on the bubble.

title: THE BRATTON RESIGNATION: THE SUCCESSOR;New Commissioner Likely to Come From Inside, Aides Say
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may not have immediately announced a replacement for Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, but two or three of the candidates for the job stood directly behind him at yesterday's news conference at City Hall, senior mayoral aides said.

title: IN THE KITCHEN WITH: Catherine Malfitano;A Salome Who Knows the Value Of a Sharp Knife
description: SHE doesn't smoke or drink alcohol or coffee. She fast-walks and jogs, lifts weights at the gym and eats vegetarian. Oh, once or twice a week she'll strip and dance for her dirty-minded stepfather and order up a severed head on a plate.

title: Enron to Supply Jordan
description: Jordan has signed a letter of intent with the Enron Corporation to build a $300 million plant in Aqaba to supply Jordan as well as Israel with natural gas from Qatar in the year 2000, energy officials said today. They said the plant would handle up to 2.5 million metric tons annually of Qatari liquefied natural gas, with about two million tons expected to go to Israel, and the rest to Jordan and possibly to Palestinian areas.

title: Cellular Industry's Party Could End Soon
description: It is party time for the cellular telephone industry, and not just because the singer Wynonna Judd and the Eagles are performing at the industry's annual convention here.

title: Books for Easter and Passover Bakers
description: TWO new books offer Passover and Easter baking help. "Passover Desserts" by Penny W. Eisenberg (Macmillan, $24.95) explains the baking requirements for Passover, when no regular flour or leavening agents may be used. There are dozens of first-rate recipes, including Linzer-style cookies and a rich chocolate pecan cake. Margarine replaces butter in recipes that are pareve -- acceptable for all kosher meals -- but that is about the only compromise.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Business Travel;Hilton is expanding its program that allows guests to swap hotel points and airline miles.
description: THE Hilton Hotels frequent-guest program -- the only loyalty plan that allows travelers to exchange hotel points for airline miles and miles for points, and to transfer mileage from one airline program to another -- has become even more flexible, adding Trans World Airlines and Midwest Express to its roster of airline exchange partners.

title: HORSE RACING;In Dubai, Cigar Tries To Preserve His Streak
description: He missed his last start with a bruised right front foot. He will be running without the diuretic Lasix for the first time since November 1994. And he will be racing outside the United States for the first time in his career.

title: With Plenty of Jobs, Nebraska Goes to Lengths to Lure Skilled Labor
description: Laurianne Kobzeff squealed with delight as dollar bills and discount coupons swirled around her in the plexiglass booth known as the "Money Machine." Before her 14-second stint ended she had scooped up $32 as a job bonus, breaking two nails in the frenzy.

title: Oil and Technology Stocks Lead Modest Rise in Market
description: The stock market rose broadly yesterday, helped by a recovery in technology issues and a surge in oil shares.

title: TV Notes;Oscar Numbers Slip
description: As usual, the Oscar telecast on ABC on Monday night was the second-most-watched event on television this year, trailing only the Super Bowl; but it also trailed last year's Oscar show by a significant margin.

title: BASKETBALL;Bartow Is Succeeded By Son at U.A.B.
description: Murry Bartow was on the Alabama-Birmingham bench as a player back in the early 1980's when his father, Gene Bartow, coached the Blazers to national prominence after quitting U.C.L.A.

title: Two Winners Named For Bancroft Prizes
description: Two authors are to be named the 1996 winners of the Bancroft Prize, awarded annually by Columbia University for books about American history, biography and diplomacy, at a ceremony tonight.

title: Romeo' Tenor Leaves
description: Francisco Araiza, the tenor who was to sing the role of Romeo in the Metropolitan Opera's production of Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette," has withdrawn from the production and is to be replaced by Richard Leech when the production opens tonight. Neither the Met nor Mr. Araiza's manager at Columbia Artists Management would say why Mr. Araiza withdrew, other than that he had left the cast by mutual agreement. The cast also includes Ruth Ann Swenson as Juliette, Mark Oswald as Mercutio, Jane Bunnell as Stephano and Paul Plishka as Friar Laurent.

title: An Officer Who Shot a Colleague Is Convicted of Lesser of Charges
description: In a case that raised troubling questions about police procedures and race, a white New York City police officer who mistakenly shot a black undercover transit officer in a Manhattan subway station was convicted yesterday of second-degree assault.

title: Just How Dangerous Is 'Mad Cow' Disease?: Beef Crisis:Divergence on Risks Widens EU's Split
description: 'Mad cow' disease and its human equivalent, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, have spurred a dramatic divergence of views among scientists and veterinarians, leaving the consumer to wonder who, if anyone, is right.

title: Cheesecake's Charms To Enrich the Season
description: CAKES made of pure, fresh cheese belong to Passover, Easter and Orthodox Easter traditions. To Italians, Scandinavians, Russians and Greeks. And of course, to every assimilated New Yorker, many of whom feel that the cheesecake buck definitely starts and stops in New York.

title: Despite Acquittal, Woman Vows to Press On in Rape Trials
description: It poured the whole ride home from Canton to Syracuse Monday night, more than two hours of angry, windswept rain that rattled cars and turned the sky an eerie silver. Krista Absalon said she imagined that "God had opened up the heavens, and the angels were just circling around, crying."

title: In a U.N. Success Story, Guatemalan Abuses Fall
description: One afternoon not long ago, dozens of farm workers faced off against a platoon of military policemen in the cool coffee groves of this mountainside plantation in a tense labor dispute.

title: Texas to Press Issue Of Admission Policy
description: The Texas Attorney General, Dan Morales, said today that he would ask the United States Supreme Court to overturn a Federal court decision striking down an affirmative-action admissions program at the University of Texas Law School.

title: A Standoff in Which the Government Is Showing a Change in Tactics
description: Haunted by blunders in previous encounters with anti-government extremists, the F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, has begun a large-scale operation against a tax-resisters' group in Montana but is avoiding the military-style tactics that his agency employed in the past.

title: A Self-Styled Populist Plans a Run for Mayor
description: Sal F. Albanese represents one of New York City's most conservative neighborhoods, an area of Brooklyn that voted overwhelmingly for Rudolph W. Giuliani, George Bush and Ronald Reagan. Yet, a photo of Michael S. Dukakis hangs in his City Council office, and Mr. Albanese was one of David N. Dinkins's most enthusiastic supporters.

title: Mary Lavin, 83, Wove Tales of Irish Experience
description: Mary Lavin, whose short stories and novels about the conflicts in the hearts of her fellow Irish men and women transcended mere tales of life in Ireland, died on Monday at a nursing home here. She was 83.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: New Credo For Fitness: No Rest, No Gain
description: LISA KARNOPP of Bend, Ore., is training for the Olympic 5,000-meter run. A few weeks ago, she increased her weekly mileage and developed bursitis in her hip. Her reaction was to keep on training, pain and all. But her coach encouraged her to see a physical therapist and to rest for five days.

title: Wireless Bidder Drops His Push
description: John Dolan, who bid more than $900 million in the Federal Government's auction for new wireless communications licenses, dropped out of the competition yesterday, saying the bidding had gone too high.

title: Brazil Avoids Inquiry, but Not Doubt on Its Banks
