description: With an all-out campaign, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has averted a congressional investigation into the collapse of Banco Nacional, the fifth major Brazilian bank to require a Government bailout in the last year. In doing so, he calmed investors, who feared congressional scrutiny of the banking system and its major figures, but did little to quell doubts about the rules by which the banking industry here plays.

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTIES;Both Rival Camps Expect Perot to Be the Wild Card
description: After months of speculation that the Presidential ballot could be crowded with four or even five serious contenders, senior advisers to President Clinton and Bob Dole have concluded that only Ross Perot will succeed in mounting a viable national campaign. They are planning for a less muddled -- though equally contentious -- three-person contest this fall.

title: Smoking Restrictions Face Fight in Albany
description: With New York City's prohibition on smoking in most public places having been in effect for more than a year, the restaurant and tobacco industries have joined forces to try to override the ban, this time turning to Albany to press for a weaker law that would apply statewide.

title: Federal Judges Condemn Plan for a Line-Item Veto
description: The organization that represents Federal judges across the country today denounced a plan developed by Republican leaders of Congress that would allow the President to kill specific items in spending bills.

title: Old Problems Surface Between China and Taiwan
description: With the dust-up between China and Taiwan settling down, their officials began grappling in public today with the obstacles that remain before the two sides can even begin talking about delivering mail to each other, much less about a meeting between their leaders.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Post A Slight Increase on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market rose slightly in the most recent period, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday, still enough to reach the highest levels in 15 months.

title: U.S. Officials Confident That Mad Cow Disease of Britain Has NotOccurred Here
description: Federal officials are confident that the mad cow disease found in Britain has not occurred in the United States and that existing policies are adequate to protect the beef supply. A meeting of 70 animal and public health experts convened by the United States Department of Agriculture reviewed current policies last week and concluded without recommending any further safeguards.

title: David Packard, 83, Pioneer Of Silicon Valley, Is Dead
description: David Packard, who with his partner William Hewlett launched one of Silicon Valley's most innovative electronics companies from a Palo Alto garage with $538 in cash and a calling to "do something useful," died today at Stanford University Hospital. He was 83.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks rose strongly here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 315.21 points, or 1.5 percent, at 21,329.98. On Tuesday, the Nikkei gained 99.33 points, or nearly a half-percent.

title: How Safe Are Tylenol and Advil? Helping Patients Sort Out Risks
description: ATTACK advertising has migrated from politics to medicine with a recent spate of warring television and print advertisements involving the pain relievers Tylenol and Advil. And just as in politics, the result has been more heat than light.

title: Habeas Corpus Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Pleads Guilty in Theft of Duchess of York's Diamonds
description: A 20-year-old baggage handler at Kennedy International Airport pleaded guilty yesterday to one of the more brazen crimes in recent times: the theft of diamonds worth close to half a million dollars from the Duchess of York's luggage.

title: Ex-Officer Sentenced In a Drug-Ring Case
description: A retired New York City detective was sentenced today in Federal district court to life in prison plus 60 months for running a 30-person heroin and cocaine ring.

title: INSIDE
description: More Nixon Tapes Due

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Securities Hold Steady
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in thin trading yesterday, as the Federal Reserve held its monetary policy meeting without changing short-term interest rates.

title: Food Notes
description: Dean & DeLuca to Go National

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks' Anderson Arrested
description: Willie Anderson, the Knicks' reserve swingman, was arrested tonight before the team's game against the Rockets on a contempt of court charge for failing to appear six months ago in a child support case.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japanese Bank Losses
description: The fallout over Japan's debt crisis mounted yesterday, with 10 more big banks saying they would record pretax losses for the year ending on Sunday. Sakura Bank, Daiwa Bank, Asahi Bank and the Bank of Yokohama, along with six of the country's seven trust banks, will report losses because of a one-time disposal of delinquent loans. Many of the loans had been made to insolvent housing lenders. Two of those, Nippon Housing Loan and Dai-Ichi Housing Loan, announced plans yesterday to shut down. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Energy, Gallantry, Graphics And Glamour at the Oscars
description: The Academy Awards show got a new exclamation point (it was billed by ABC as a "Special Presentation!") and other excitable touches this year. The show began with worrisome hints that its new producer, Quincy Jones, would stop at nothing to make this staid ceremony more user-friendly, and might outdo even Hollywood in pandering to trashy popular tastes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;'Pepsi Stuff' Campaign Set
description: The Pepsi-Cola Company announced yesterday that it would introduce "Pepsi Stuff," which it called the largest promotional campaign in the company's history.

title: Foreign Affairs;The Double Anschluss
description: Serbs in Sarajevo burn their apartments rather than see them occupied by returning Muslim refugees . . . the Muslim Government refuses to break military links with Iran . . . the Croatian Government promotes the use of Croatian emblems, flags and even telephone dialing codes to absorb as much as possible of the half of Bosnia it's supposed to share with the Muslims . . . Haris Silajdzic, the Muslim former Prime Minister of Bosnia, who really believed in a multi-ethnic society, resigns in disgust . . . Those are just a few recent headlines from Bosnia, where, with each passing day, it becomes clearer that all the factions signed the Dayton peace accord in bad faith, and that Bosnia is heading for partition, not a reunified state.

title: Dole Blocks Vote on Raising Minimum Wage
description: After hours of arcane parliamentary stratagems interspersed with raw political attacks, Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, today blocked a Democratic effort to vote on raising the minimum wage.

title: TV Notes;Imus in the Spotlight
description: Perhaps the only person more delighted than Don Imus about the flash flood of publicity following his spicy speech at a Washington dinner last week was Mike Wallace of CBS.

title: Pakistan Shifting Stance On Hard-Line Afghans
description: After 18 months of covert military and financial backing for a guerrilla group that has imposed Muslim fundamentalist rule on more than half of Afghanistan, Pakistan appears to have shifted toward a policy that aims to bring an end to the civil war through mediation among all of Afghanistan's warring groups.

title: Separatist Guerrillas Leave Kashmir Shrine
description: About 17 separatist guerrillas ended a two-day occupation of Kashmir's holiest shrine tonight, leaving the buildings peacefully after an agreement with the Indian Government.

title: HOCKEY;Double Penalty Proves No Deterrent to Devils
description: The Tampa Bay Lightning had scored the tying goal in the third period and Devils Captain Scott Stevens was headed to the penalty box for four minutes for cross-checking and unsportsmanlike conduct.

title: Sports of the Times;When Good Never Seems Good Enough
description: JIM BOEHEIM sat behind a cluttered desk yesterday afternoon surveying a sunny office that, while spacious, was bursting at the seams with newsletters, photos, plaques and yearbooks.

title: Ability to Discover Tiny Breast Tumor Detection Creates a Dilemma
description: In 1992, more than 23,000 American women learned that they had tiny tumors in the milk ducts of their breasts that might, or might not, develop into invasive, life-threatening breast cancers. Almost half of them had breasts removed (mastectomies) to avoid any chance of cancer.

title: Personal Health;Bullying: who picks on whom, and why?
description: A SMALL group of young teen-age boys decided it was "fun" to turn a quiet classmate into a human plaything. They forced him to give them money, swallow weeds, drink milk mixed with detergent and allow himself to be led around on a leash.

title: THE BRATTON RESIGNATION: BEHIND THE SCENES;Squabbling Behind the Amicable Departure
description: To the end, they insisted there was no tension between them. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton stood together yesterday and smiled, praising one another as if hoisting pints of beer in a mutual toast.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: HORSE RACING;Race Broadcast Live on Ch. 71
description: Cable-television viewers in the New York metropolitan area can watch Cigar try to win his 14th consecutive race this morning in the Dubai World Cup, which will be carried live on Channel 71. New York City Offtrack betting shops, which have been taking win, place, show, exacta and triple wagers on the race since Monday, will continue to take bets until post time, 10 A.M. today, New York time. The race will be held at the Nad al-Sheba race track in the Persian Gulf emirate of Dubai, where post time is 7 P.M. today.

title: Taybeh Journal;A Niche Beer, Made, You Might Say, to Toast Peace
description: As niche beers go, Taybeh Beer faces hurdles unknown to other brewers.

title: THE BRATTON RESIGNATION: THE OVERVIEW;BRATTON QUITS POLICE POST; NEW YORK GAINS OVER CRIME FED A RIVALRY WITH GIULIANI
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton announced his resignation yesterday after 27 months in office, ending a tenure that saw a precipitous drop in New York City's crime rate and a consequent rivalry for the limelight with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that eventually led to the Commissioner's departure.

title: More Stores Add Menus to Shoppers' Choices
description: NEW YORKERS by and large have been deprived of the greatest attraction of mall life: the ever-present smell of food and the chance to shop and eat -- and shop and eat.

title: HORSE RACING;Out of the Saddle, Into the Training Hot Seat
description: The wide-bodied, bay-colored colt started pawing at the ground, then stamping his feet. "No, no, no, no, no," Angel Cordero Jr. yelled. "Stop it."

title: Wine Talk
description: TRADITION!" Tevye sang in "Fiddler on the Roof," and everyone's heart beat a little faster. Tradition. In a deracinated, normless world, it tells us where we have come from. And who we are. On April 4, when Passover begins, Jews everywhere who observe it will celebrate with kosher wine -- a tradition.

title: Scott Douglas, 70, a Dancer And Ballet Choreographer
description: Scott Douglas, a leading dancer with Ballet Theater in the 1950's and 60's and a choreographer and teacher, died on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70.

title: Marine Planes Grounded
description: The Marine Corps commandant ordered a 48-hour suspension of all non-essential flights by his service's aircraft while aviation procedures were reviewed, a spokesman said on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of George Burns on March 10 omitted a reference to the first of his two marriages. In the early 1920's, before he was married to Gracie Allen, he was briefly married to a dancer, Hannah Siegel.

title: News Analysis;For the Tories, a Prime Disaster
description: The crisis over British beef is turning out to be more than a body blow to an industry worth $6.5 billion. And it's more than a humiliating comedown for Britain's staple foodstuff, celebrated in the novels of Henry Fielding, that symbolized the country's power and supremacy beginning in the 18th century.

title: Sheriff Asks Tax Protesters to Surrender
description: A county sheriff appealed today to armed tax protesters, members of a group called the Freemen, to end a standoff at a remote ranch "without bloodshed."

title: The Master Builder of Malaysia;He Thrives With a Little Help From His Friends
description: It isn't often that across-the-board rejection by swaggering American and European investment banks warms a developer's heart. But Francis Yeoh Sock Ping acts as if it is the best thing that has ever happened.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Techno-Yuppies Who Live and Die by the Microchip
description: The characters in Hal Salwen's "Denise Calls Up" are all looking for love. And probably some of them would find it, if only they had the time. But they're busy doing nothing, techno-yuppie style: fiddling with laptops, juggling call waiting, chatting on car and cell phones, sending faxes instead of showing up in the flesh.

title: Real Estate;A state agency takes charge of the commercial redevelopment of a Massachusetts military base.
description: A NEWLY formed Massachusetts state agency is moving forward with its first major project, a $1.5 billion redevelopment of half of the Fort Devens Military Reservation, which spans four towns 35 miles northwest of Boston.

title: Journal;No Bravehearts Here
description: I don't believe that the bicoastal American show-biz and media elite are a bunch of pious and arrogant hypocrites. But if I did, I'd sure be having a ball right now watching two of that elite's most hallowed annual, star-filled rites -- Hollywood's Oscar show and Washington's Radio-Television Correspondents Association dinner -- expose the pretensions of their black-tie invitees.

title: Edmund S. Muskie, 81, Dies; Maine Senator and a Power on the National Scene
description: Edmund S. Muskie, the charming if often volatile Democrat from Maine who served as his state's Governor, as United States Senator and briefly as Secretary of State, died early today at the Georgetown University Medical Center. He would have been 82 on Thursday.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Mood Swings and Contrasts
description: The concert by the orchestra of the S.E.M. Ensemble on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall was an extended essay on the attractions of textural variety.

title: Colombia Chief Questioned on Drug Money
description: President Ernesto Samper of Colombia was questioned today before a Congressional committee that is investigating him on several charges related to illegal donations made to his 1994 presidential campaign.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Thursday about a bill to limit damages in liability suits involving faulty products reported that Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, provided the crucial 60th vote to halt debate. The article said Mr. Specter voted that way to help Senator Bob Dole, who wanted to advance the bill.

title: Body of Girl Is Discovered Near School
description: As soon as Curtisha M. Morning, a 17-year-old senior, disappeared from Riverhead High School nearly a month ago, her family, friends and schoolmates had been making emotional appeals for help in finding her.

title: TV Notes;A Sunday Shift
description: NBC, which has roiled the prime-time waters with aggressive scheduling moves in the last two seasons, shifting "Frasier" to Tuesday and "Mad About You" to Sunday, looks as if it is toying with another provocative shift for next fall.

title: Market Place;Mutual-fund assets exceed $3 trillion, and the end of cash inflows remains nowhere in sight.
description: THE money keeps flowing into mutual funds, which, a trade group reported yesterday, now have more than $3 trillion in assets. But the headlong rush into stock funds seems to be slowing, if only a bit.

title: Merger Expert Quits Salomon
description: Mark Davis, the co-head of mergers and acquisitions at Salomon Brothers Inc., has resigned to become head of mergers at the combined Chase Manhattan and Chemical Banking Corporations, officials at both said yesterday.

title: POLITICS: THE HOMETOWN;With Dole Rising, His Hometown Looks Ahead
description: For Bob Dole, it is a point of pride that he has not used his influence in Washington to bring home the bacon.

title: I.B.M. Set to Release Cheaper Software
description: In a bid to blunt the growing momentum of the Microsoft Corporation and improve its weak software business, the International Business Machines Corporation plans to introduce a series of aggressively priced new software packages today that run on corporate networks.

title: No Matter the Passover Menu, It's Got to Have Gefilte Fish
description: AT Campagna in the Flatiron district, the chef and owner, Mark Strausman, serves Italian-style seder dinners for Passover. But no matter what else is on the menu, there has to be gefilte fish.

title: At the Nation's Table: Taos, N.M.;New Trading Post: To See and to Eat
description: Steep blue mountains and chimerical storms have drawn creative people to Taos, N.M., for years. D. H. Lawrence, Georgia O'Keeffe and Ansel Adams used to frequent a central merchandise store in Taos called the Ranchos Trading Post.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;When Camby Smolders, UMass Heats Up and Then Sparks Fly
description: The fire inside Marcus Camby was smoldering long before Massachusetts Coach John Calipari came to ignite it during the warm-ups for the second half of the East Regional final against Georgetown last week. There were flashes in the first half, when Camby delivered a forearm to the chest of Jahidi White as the Hoyas' 300-pound center lumbered downcourt in transition.

title: Yeltsin Ends Visit to Norway With Accords on Pollution
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia ended a two-day visit to Norway today after meeting with King Haakon and the Prime Minister. Both sides reported some progress on trade and environmental cooperation.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Connecticut Is in Familiar Company AS a Season's Journey Nears Its End
description: With the rapid growth of women's basketball, you might think some upstart would crash into this week's Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: At the Nation's Table: Morristown, N.J.;Salvadoran-Italian Is the Message
description: On a bustling street in Morristown amid apartments, small shops and restaurants, a green neon sign shouts "Pupusas." Pradera's, the only Central American restaurant in town, specializes in the pupusa ($1), a grilled corn pancake stuffed with cheese or fried pork.

title: Chrysler Lawsuit Takes Aim at Class Actions
description: The Chrysler Corporation today took legal action against lawyers in Seattle and St. Louis who the company said had filed frivolous class-action lawsuits against the giant auto maker.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Manhattan Bagel Co., Eatontown, N.J., to DKB & Partners, Morristown, N.J., as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at more than $4 million.

title: Queens Group Calls City Deal Unauthorized
description: Adding a new twist to a controversy over the awarding of two city contracts, the chairman of a Queens social services organization that won the job to monitor welfare recipients said yesterday that the $43 million deal had been put together by an employee of the organization acting without the approval of the group's board of directors.

title: 10.2 Billion Loan To Russia Approved
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a $10.2 billion loan for Russia. The move is expected to be helpful to President Boris N. Yeltsin in the presidential election in June.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Defends Fed As Its Efficiency Is Assailed Alan Greenspan defended the Federal Reserve against criticism of the management of its finances by the General Accounting Office of Congress. At a hearing on his nomination to a third term as chairman, he called the Fed "an extraordinarily well-run organization." On a day that the Fed's policy committee decided to leave interest rates unchanged, Mr. Greenspan also gave a relatively upbeat if brief assessment of the economy, saying it was operating at a "reasonably good clip."

title: Quaker Plant for Atlanta
description: The Quaker Oats Company will spend about $50 million to build a new beverage plant and distribution center near Atlanta, the company said today. The Chicago-based food and beverage concern said the plant would produce Gatorade and Snapple teas and juice drinks and would employ about 150 people. The start of production is set for January 1997. The Atlanta plant will be the seventh company-owned beverage plant.

title: President Is Right to Testify on Videotape
description: To the Editor:

title: Jesuit Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosperity In New Chile Nourishes Drug Trade
description: For the last decade, Chile has served as the model for economic growth and stability in Latin America, after opening its doors to foreign investment and shifting from military dictatorship to democracy.

title: Simon Property To Acquire DeBartolo for $1.5 Billion
description: The Simon Property Group said yesterday that it would acquire the DeBartolo Realty Corporation for nearly $1.5 billion under an agreement that would solidify Simon's position as the largest developer and operator of shopping centers in the country.

title: Croatian War Crime Suspect Refuses to Cooperate
description: Despite a promise by the Croatian President to turn over a general indicted by the war crimes tribunal, the defendant's lawyer said today that he would not cooperate.

title: Americans Attached to Traditional Roles for Sexes, Poll Finds
description: Americans are more enamored of the traditional family structure, with a breadwinner father and a homemaker mother, than are people in many other countries, according to an International Gallup Poll of adults in 22 nations.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Drought Sends Wheat Prices Up; April Gold Climbs to $400.50
description: Wheat futures soared yesterday amid concern that a five-month drought affecting winter wheat fields was unlikely to ease soon.

title: A Kosher Feast Befitting Jerusalem's 3,000th Anniversary
description: JERUSALEM has always attracted travelers of every faith. In the ancient world Jewish pilgrims arrived during Passover with dried fruits and fresh green almonds, sheep and lambs slung over their shoulders. On March 18, Jerusalem played host to yet another pilgrimage when 13 of the greatest chefs came here to cook a 12-course kosher feast in honor of the city's 3,000th anniversary.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Six Get Awards For Aiding Diversity
description: Six Diversity Achievement Awards, honoring executives in advertising, marketing and the media for their work in fostering diversity, were presented Monday night by District 2 of the American Advertising Federation in New York.

title: HOCKEY;Richter to Start Tonight
description: Coach Colin Campbell put the Rangers through another rigorous practice today, and afterward announced that goalie Mike Richter would start Wednesday night against the Florida Panthers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Drug Trial Disappoints
description: Ciba-Geigy said yesterday that results of clinical trials of its new anti-thrombotic drug Revasc were below expectations and that it was considering whether to pursue use of the heart medication. Revasc is intended for treatment of acute coronary syndrome, which is life threatening to some patients. (Reuters)

title: Greenspan Calls the Fed 'Extraordinarily Well Run'
description: Responding to a Congressional report that was critical of the Federal Reserve's management of its finances, Alan Greenspan today defended his record as chairman of the central bank at a Senate hearing on his nomination to a third term, calling the Federal Reserve "an extraordinarily well-run organization."

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Short Takes
description: The sentinels in full dress uniforms at the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia now have their first woman, Sergeant Heather Lynn Johnsen, 23, of Roseville, California. The sentinels are drawn from the Army's oldest active unit, the Third Infantry Regiment, which dates to 1784 and is better known as the Old Guard. Although women were admitted to the Old Guard's Fife and Drum Corps in 1982, Sergeant Johnsen is the first woman to take part in the Old Guard's ceremonial duties.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Execution Stirs Protests In Bahrain
description: New fighting erupted today between protesters and the police after the execution of a dissident who was convicted of killing a police officer.

title: China's Patrimony
description: The Metropolitan Museum's "Splendors of Imperial China" is so wonderfully vibrant that one almost forgets the turmoil in today's China. This extraordinary collection, at the Metropolitan until May 19, is an invitation to banish politics from the mind and put art in its place.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Russia Cancels Bill Sale
description: Russia canceled a bill auction planned for today after Merrill Lynch withdrew from the sale and yields soared. The central bank chairman, Sergei Dubinin, called off the auction of 7.6 trillion rubles ($2.6 billion) of six-month bills. A delay in obtaining documentation prompted Merrill to delay purchases until next week, a Western banker said. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: TENNIS;Sampras Eliminates Martin And Adds to a No. 1 Cause
description: Pete Sampras can regain the No. 1 ranking by recapturing the Lipton Championships title on Sunday. That development would restore decorum to the men's tour, which has been maligned for allowing Thomas Muster, the French Open champion, a two-week vacation atop the ranking, despite four opening-round losses in five events.

title: The Birth Mother Who Found Me
description: In December 1992, I went home for Christmas. It was two weeks after my 31st birthday and the end of a difficult year. I had finally finished my second novel -- about a psychotherapist who long ago had given up a child for adoption and has decided that one of her patients is that child -- and I was left feeling a little lost, looking forward to spending some time with my family. The train from New York to Washington was crowded. People stood in the aisles; the luggage racks were bursting with large, ornately wrapped packages. The mood was festive.

title: BASEBALL;The Mets Put Huskey's Muscle in Right Field
description: Butch Huskey made his first start of the spring in right field today, and the best news from the Mets' perspective is that the shift to a new position did not affect Huskey's scorching bat.

title: The 1996 Oscar Winners
description: These are the winners of the 68th Academy Awards, given Monday night at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion here by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences:

title: At the Nation's Table: Carmel, Calif.;Developing a Taste For Olive Oil
description: Anyone who may have doubted that the food business is driven by people with passion has yet to meet Betty Pustarfi. On Fridays and Saturdays from noon to 5 P.M., Ms. Pustarfi, a former fancy-food-shop owner, can be found at the Bountiful Basket in Carmel, Calif., conducting a tasting of as many as 20 oils from six to eight countries.

title: Business Consultant To Study Broadway
description: In hopes of bringing more original work to Broadway, New York City and a group representing theater producers, landlords and unions have hired a management consultant to look at how Broadway operates and explore the creation of a foundation to finance new plays and musicals.

title: FILM REVIEW;Wall Streeter, Doting Father and Crack Addict
description: There's usually a briefcase in a movie scene depicting a drug deal, but the pitiable hero of Gary Winick's "Sweet Nothing" just shoves the contraband into his backpack. Similarly, the standard idea of a domestic quarrel often involves an angry exit. But when Angel (Michael Imperioli) is thrown out of his apartment by his desperately unhappy wife (Mira Sorvino), he just flops down on the doormat in the hallway.

title: Grand Central Project Echoes the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling Backs Banks' Sales Of Insurance
description: National banks won an important Supreme Court victory today with a unanimous ruling that the banks may sell insurance from branch offices in small towns, despite state laws to the contrary.

title: Wider Use Seen For Treatment Of Cholesterol
description: Millions of heart attack survivors with seemingly normal cholesterol levels should be put on cholesterol-lowering drugs to help them live longer, a new study concludes.

title: After Long Litigation, Agreement Is Near on Release of Tapes FromNixon White House
description: More than 3,000 hours of secretly recorded Nixon White House tapes, a hidden history locked in the National Archives for a generation, will soon begin to become public, according to people litigating over them.

title: A Fresh Look at Social Security
description: A Federal advisory panel unanimously recommended to Congress this week that Social Security payroll taxes be invested in stocks, reversing a 60-year policy of investing only in low-yield Government bonds. This radical idea met with surprising acceptance on Capitol Hill, testimony to how scared Congress is about the system's financial future.

title: Silenced Inmate Files Lawsuit Against N.P.R.
description: Mumia Abu-Jamal, a death-row inmate whose conviction for the 1981 killing of a Philadelphia police officer has drawn widespread protests, filed a lawsuit in Federal court here today accusing National Public Radio of violating his constitutional rights by censoring his radio commentaries from prison.

title: No Headline
description: An opportunity has presented itself that meets all of my needs, all of my conditions. I don't worry about a legacy eroding. The time is here. The time is here."

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Was Slaughter of Jews Embraced by Germans?
description: HITLER'S WILLING EXECUTIONERS Ordinary Germans and the Holocaust By Daniel Jonah Goldhagen Illustrated. 622 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Citigate Group Acquires Agencies
description: Citigate Group Ltd. in London said yesterday that it had bought the Albert Frank-Guenther Law advertising agency and the Torrance Group public relations agency from AFGL International Inc. in New York.

title: Education Summit Calls for Tough Standards To Be Set by States andLocal School Districts
description: In a gathering defined by calls for state and local action, 41 governors, 49 corporate leaders and 30 education experts met here today to develop strategies for tough, rigorous standards for the nation's schools.

title: Artificial Flood Created to Rejuvenate the Grand Canyon
description: Four huge arcs of foamy white Colorado River water shot out of a dam with a roar today as the Federal Government began a weeklong flood designed to turn back the clock on the Grand Canyon.

title: Broadway, Statue of Liberty and Fresh Kills?;World's Biggest Garbage Dump Hopes to Draw Tourists as Well as Gulls
description: Under the heading of sanitation lore, Steve Violetta tells of a researcher from Oklahoma who came to the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island to see how well the buried garbage was preserved. Something about the mounds of trash being transferred in the maw of a hydraulic crane from a river barge must have tripped Mr. Violetta's memory.

title: Margaret Rockefeller, 80, Backer Of Farm and Conservation Causes
description: Margaret Rockefeller, who worked on behalf of farmland conservation, the American Farmland Trust, the New York Botanical Garden and the New York Philharmonic, died yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 80 and the wife of David Rockefeller, former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Sticking Close to the Home Proves Ticket for Freshman
description: Tyrone Washington is 1 of 10 players on the Mississippi State team who is from this state. But he is unique.

title: New Money for Old, With Care
description: The Treasury has introduced a new $100 bill without withdrawing the old. This is a delicate long-term strategy aimed at stamping out counterfeiters without upsetting millions of foreigners who feel safer with dollars than with their own money.

title: Tobacco and Restaurant Lobbies Pressing in Albany to Weaken LocalRules
description: A year after New York City enacted one of nation's most restrictive limits on smoking in restaurants and other public places, the restaurant and tobacco industries have joined forces in Albany to push for a new, weaker statewide smoking law that would override the city's rule.

title: Calendar: An Orchid Show And Classes in Tree Care
description: Orchids of the World Winter Garden at the World Financial Center, along the Hudson River at Vesey Street (West Street); (212) 945-0505.

title: Plotting 'E.R.' Is a Last-Minute Operation
description: How do you tell 22 hours of stories about 7 characters in hourlong servings, interspersed with dense medical details, and manage to keep the largest audience in television clamoring for the next new episode?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Florida Hires Pitino Protege
description: BILLY DONOVAN looks a little like Kentucky Coach RICK PITINO, sounds just like him and talks the same brand of basketball. Florida can only hope that Donovan gets similar results.

title: ON THE SET WITH/The 'Seinfeld' Steinbrenner;The Head Yankee, Deconstructed
description: YANKEES fans may not always find George Steinbrenner a bundle of laughs, but a hefty slice of America does. For the last two years, a character in the guise of the Yankees' principal owner has emerged as one of the funnier aspects of "Seinfeld," the hit sitcom.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANDREW YOUNG, the former Mayor of Atlanta and Ambassador to the United Nations, who is a co-chairman of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, is off to South Africa, where he is to be married today to a longtime friend, CAROLYN WATSON, an Atlanta schoolteacher. Archbishop DESMOND TUTU is to officiate at the wedding.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Players Turn to Supreme Court
description: National Football League players asked the Supreme Court yesterday to let athletes file antitrust lawsuits against leagues that impose salaries after reaching a bargaining impasse with players' unions.

title: Bonn Cancels Planned Talks Between Bosnian Muslims and Croats
description: In a sign of deepening disarray that is threatening the Bosnian peace accords, the German Foreign Minister announced today that he was canceling a meeting intended to bring Bosnian Muslim and Croat leaders together to help strengthen their uneasy federation.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;149 Are Laid Off at Arsenal
description: Layoff notices went out yesterday to 149 engineers, scientists, clerks and machinists at Picatinny Arsenal as part of a $34 million budget cut by the United States Army. They will lose their jobs Aug. 3, said Peter J. Rowland, a spokesman for the military base. An additional 52 employees will be reassigned to lower-paying jobs. About 4,700 people work at the base, which is the second-largest employer in Morris County after AT&T.

title: California Radio Deal
description: The American Radio Systems Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire KSTE-AM in Rancho Cordova, Calif., from the Fuller-Jeffrey Broadcasting Companies for about $7.25 million. It is the third radio station the company is buying in the Sacramento, Calif., market. It already has an agreement to buy KYMX-FM and KCTC-AM.

title: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too;Recycling Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks in Sharp Retreat, With Dow Falling 43.72
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday, following a slump in the bond market. But technology issues bucked the selloff.

title: BASEBALL;A Wizard In Autumn
description: In spring training, where all the dreams of the old and the young seem possible, a cheery sun sparkled on this dreamy old ball field here, Al Lang Stadium. A Houston batter slapped a sharp ground ball up the middle in the second inning of a recent exhibition game against the St. Louis Cardinals. The shortstop took a few quick steps to his left and then dived for the ball, his body and arm stretched full length. The ball bounced past his glove and into center field.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Giants and Brown: No Deal Yet
description: The agent for the Giants' unrestricted free-agent quarterback, DAVE BROWN, said that even though he still expected Brown to sign with the Giants, it would probably not be any time soon.

title: Scottish Percussionist To Perform at Purchase
description: Evelyn Glennie, the Scottish percussionist, will give a solo concert at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y., on Sunday at 3 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about "Sweet Nothing," starring Mira Sorvino and Michael Imperioli, omitted the two final words of the last sentence. The sentence should have read, "Mr. Calderon, a familiar face usually relegated to character roles in tough-guy genre films, also rises to the challenge of a fuller, more down-to-earth role."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rehearing on Parole Ordered
description: The State Parole Board must reconsider a decision to extend a murderer's prison term for 10 years, a state appeals court ruled yesterday. William Tomaras, 37, who is serving a life sentence at the Southern State Correctional Facility for a 1975 fatal shooting, was denied parole in June 1994 because of what was described as his unruly behavior. The court said that 10 years was too long to wait for another parole hearing, The Associated Press reported.

title: No Headline
description: The punishment pales in my eyes in comparison with the crime, although I have no suggestion how to deepen this punishment. In my view, this murder is a violation of all the values of our people, from the Ten Commandments to the laws of the nation and the state."

title: The Path Is Cleared For Schulz-Moorer
description: A Federal judge in Newark yesterday overruled the International Boxing Federation by stripping Francois Botha of his heavyweight title, meaning that Michael Moorer will meet Axel Schulz for the vacant crown unless the judge's ruling is overturned on appeal.

title: Senate Democrats Force Withdrawal of Land Bill
description: Senate Democrats today turned back a Republican proposal to protect wilderness areas, maintaining that while two million acres of Federal land in Utah would be protected, millions more would be opened to mining and development in that state.

title: El Al President Plans to Resign
description: The president of El Al Israel Airlines announced his resignation this week over the Government's failure to privatize the national airline.

title: Massachusetts House Speaker Accepts Guilty Plea
description: The Speaker of the Massachusetts House agreed today to plead guilty to Federal tax evasion for filing false expenses and lying under oath about them.

title: Private Places, By Chance, By Design;Hideaways at Home
description: A New Yorker's life is in many ways a balancing act between the city's glorious energy and its bruising intrusions, a hunt to snatch a private moment in busy Manhattan -- or indeed at home. Here are places to find privacy in the city -- and ways to create a sanctuary at home. By NICOLAI OUROUSSOFF IT is a cautionary tale worthy of Edgar Allan Poe. Five years ago, Stewart Parr, a furniture dealer, moved into what many would consider the New York version of heaven -- a 3,500-square-foot loft on Vestry Street in Lower Manhattan. Its three windows, while small, had views clear to the Statue of Liberty.

title: New Custody Rules Complicate the Task of Judges
description: To a divorced parent with custody of the children -- usually the mother -- moving to a new area often promised a fresh start with a new spouse, a new job, or with old friends and family. But to the parent with visitation rights, usually the father, such a move augured a kind of parenting death by deprivation. And it was up to the judge to decide: should she stay or should she go?

title: COMPANY NEWS;SYNC RESEARCH SHARES RISE ON MARKETING AGREEMENT
description: The shares of Sync Research Inc. rose almost 29 percent yesterday after the company announced a deal under which the International Business Machines Corporation will market computer networking products made by Sync under the I.B.M. logo. Earlier in the day Sync, which is based in Irvine, Calif., said that it expected to report a loss for the first quarter. According to a survey of analysts by First Call Inc., the company had been expected to earn 4 cents a share in the quarter. The news of the expected loss briefly sent Sync's stock down to $12.25, a 52-week low. But by the end of the day, the stock had risen $3.75 to close at $16.75 a share in Nasdaq trading.

title: Fire Chief Appears to Lead List of Police Candidates
description: With Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's search for a new Police Commissioner beginning in earnest, the city's Fire Commissioner, Howard Safir, has emerged as a leading contender, while the departing Commissioner, William J. Bratton, has recommended his deputy, John F. Timoney, to replace him, police officials said yesterday.

title: Orders in Transportation Fell Sharply Last Month
description: The United States economy gained strength last month even though a midwinter lull in aircraft purchases caused factory orders to fall by the largest percentage in 10 months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Currents;The Beetle Will Ride Again, but Not Soon
description: BEATLES on pop charts, Marimekko on bed sheets, bare midriffs on runways. Is it any surprise that a team of designers in Simi Valley, Calif., is spending its hard days' nights on the revival of that other beetle -- the one made by Volkswagen? On March 5 at the Geneva Motor Show in Switzerland, Volkswagen rolled out the to-be-reintroduced Beetle, with its plump new silhouette (well, we've all got a bit thicker), symmetrical front to back. This time, the Volkswagen has air bags, four-wheel drive and a retractable Porsche Targa glass roof, Jetsons-ready. (A hardtop version will also be produced.) The Wolfsburg, Germany, company will say only that the new Beetle will be available "before the end of the century" and will not disclose its price, but the worldwide bug supply will come from a factory in Puebla, Mexico.

title: Journalists Approve Internet Reporters
description: In its first decision related to the Internet, the journalists' committee that oversees media operations in Congress voted today to provide credentials to reporters for qualified electronic publications.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;An Orchestra Quite at Home in the 20th Century
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic had to be somewhere on Monday evening, when the Academy Awards show occupied its permanent home, the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. Fortunately for New Yorkers not obsessed with Hollywood, the orchestra was at Avery Fisher Hall, playing a program of Stravinsky to close a three-concert stint at Lincoln Center.

title: Ailing Computer-Chip Workers Blame Chemicals, Not Chance
description: In 1988, Miriam Nicole Sanders, James Gibbons and Glenn Haight worked side by side on an I.B.M. production line here, making computer chips and happy to be earning $7 an hour.

title: Norman Williams, 80, an Expert On Planning and Zoning, Dies
description: Norman Williams, a retired urban planner and zoning expert who was chief of New York City's Master Planning Department in the 1950's, died on Sunday at his home in Woodstock, Vt. He was 80.

title: For Yellowstone Bison, a Humane Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: California Homes Are Selling Again
description: Beth Combee could hardly contain her excitement. After worrying about their jobs during the recent recession, she and her husband just received unexpected promotions and took a step she said they had only dreamed of during the years of economic uncertainty: they bought a handsome $104,000 house in a new development here known as May Ranch, 60 miles east of Los Angeles, in Riverside County.

title: Sports of the Times;Recalling Final Four's Garden Roots
description: IT is all taken for granted now in college basketball. Jump shots. Seven-footers. Black players. The wide foul lane. Race-horse fast breaks. The behind-the-back dribble. Teams throughout the nation with kids from high schools in the New York-New Jersey area. Kentucky.

title: Sports Agency Suggested to Handle Yankees
description: As the Yankees get ready to decide where to play when their Yankee Stadium lease expires in 2002, New York State is contemplating the creation of a sports authority that might give it an edge on its chief rival, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: Currents;Velvet Furniture Dyed Like Joseph's Coat
description: ZUZKA, a New York fashion and home-furnishings designer who grew up in Prague, Rome and Tel Aviv, is known for her exotic tie-dyed velvets done by hand. When used for upholstery, these resemble Joseph's coat of many colors.

title: Sports of the Times;Misery Has Company Among the Final Four
description: THERE is something wrong with a man who can't enjoy a free extended weekend in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: POLITICS: LEAVETAKING -- CAPITAL SKETCHBOOK;A Return to a Familiar Debate as a Lawmaker Prepares to Exit
description: All those days when I had so much trouble having kids kind of flash back in front of my face," Representative Patricia Schroeder said, anticipating the final abortion debate of her Congressional career with a mix of dread and relief.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Students to See Water Tests
description: Students from several science classes will be observers today when the State Health Department takes water samples from 23 Toms River schools. The water tests are part of a study examining the incidence of cancer in relation to Superfund toxic waste sites in the area.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Treasury Prices Fall On Strengthening Economy Treasury bond prices fell sharply on comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and a report on durable goods that both suggested that mounting economic growth could stave off further cuts in interest rates. Traders took the chance to sell, and the price of the 30-year bond dropped 1 8/32, to 91 8/32. Its yield rose to 6.68 percent, from 6.57 percent on Tuesday. [Page D20.]

title: Land Mines Saved My Life
description: Forty-four years ago this month, I was making my way down Hill 59 in Korea, not far from the ongoing peace negotiations at Panmunjom. But there was no peace on the hill. After a brisk firefight the previous night, my platoon had taken the hill from Chinese Communist forces. Despite my caution, I tripped on a wire. I heard a "thip" as it activated a mine, and I steeled myself for the explosion that would rip off my legs. Nothing happened. The mine had malfunctioned.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Hewlett-Packard Co., Palo Alto, Calif., to Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, London, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., as the first agency to handle the personal computer division's pan-European retail dealer support activities. In Spain, Saatchi & Saatchi will work with De Federico, Herrero & Ochoa, Madrid. The billings were estimated at more than $20 million. The appointment comes as Hewlett-Packard is reviewing its estimated $30 million core branding account in Europe, which is also handled by Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: ON GOLF;Rookies With a Midas Touch Are Suddenly All the Rave
description: There are no dynasties in golf anymore. The sport that for decades was dominated by a handful of giants is becoming the province of the hot hoi polloi, a band of talented youngsters that is crashing the gates armed with burgeoning confidence and a sort of cavalier disregard for the established stars.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Network to Lease Capacity
description: The New Jersey Network announced yesterday that it had struck a deal with Atlantic Microsystems Inc. that could bring in as much as $3.6 million in revenue for the state's public broadcasting system. Under the agreement, NJN will lease its excess microwave transmission capacity to Atlantic Microsystems, which operates wireless cable television systems in New York, Pennsylvania and Virginia.

title: Challenge for Judges In Custody Cases
description: Divorced parents seeking to move out of state confront judges in custody cases with a difficult decision, since granting the request often separates the remaining parent from the children.

title: Johannesburg Journal;Will Rugby Embrace, or Crush, a Dainty Flower?
description: A fan writes:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;3 Hijack Jet to Libya; 152 Passengers Freed
description: Three hijackers commandeered an Egyptian jetliner to Libya today, then surrendered peacefully to the Libyan military five hours later.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Don't believe everything you read about the Sheriff of Nottingham.

title: BASKETBALL;Marbury Gone, Reports Say
description: Stephon Marbury intends to leave Georgia Tech to enter the National Basketball Association draft, it was reported in Thursday's Atlanta Journal-Constitution, but a school official said no decision has been made.

title: Sensible Health Reform, for Now
description: The House is expected to vote today on two versions of health-care reform -- a sensible if limited Democratic bill and a harmful Republican version. The Democrats have also embraced a bipartisan bill now pending in the Senate that would make it easier for workers who lose their jobs to buy health coverage. That is of critical importance in this era of downsizing and job shifts. House Republicans have embraced these provisions but have added to their bill amendments that are not only bad health policy but could delay passage of any useful health-care reform this year.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Bangladesh Premier Says She'll Yield to Caretaker
description: Faced with growing strikes and street protests, Prime Minister Khaleda Zia gave in today to demands for new elections and asked President Abdur Rahman Biswas to form a caretaker Government.

title: Anheuser Beers to Carry Freshness Dates
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies will spend millions of dollars to try to persuade beer drinkers that its beers are the freshest available.

title: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too;Children Aren't Tie
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Orange's Stock Offering
description: Orange P.L.C., a British digital mobile telephone company, raised at least L624 million ($949 million) in an initial stock offering. On their first day of trading, the shares closed at 239.5 pence ($3.60), 17 percent higher than the sale price of 205 pence. A total of 21.4 million shares traded. The share sale, the biggest initial equity offering in Britain this year, valued the whole company at L2.5 billion ($3.75 billion). Orange sold 325 million shares globally. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Line-Item Lunacy
description: It's a scene from a paranoid thriller by Oliver Stone: A mercurial billionaire, elected President with 35 percent of the vote, holds America hostage to his minority agenda by vetoing item after item in the Federal budget, in open breach of the separation of powers doctrine enshrined in the Constitution. Impossible? Not anymore.

title: Libyan Troops Clash With Foes After Jailbreak
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has sent troops to northeastern Libya, apparently to stamp out unrest, diplomats and opposition groups said today.

title: Nationalism Checkmates Pawns, Too, in Bosnia
description: The American officer saw an example of the obstacles to reconciliation in Bosnia, and he figured the United States Army could help out.

title: An Education Conference With a Corporate Agenda
description: It was not the President who willed the conference into existence this time. The agenda of rigorous standards and better technology had all the sex appeal of cold oatmeal.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Noriega Fails In His Appeal For New Trial
description: A Federal judge today denied Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega a new trial, saying that new evidence suggesting that a crucial prosecution witness had been bribed was "troubling" but would not have affected the outcome of the case.

title: Space Walkers Attach Debris Catchers to Orbiting Laboratory
description: Two space-walking astronauts hung the orbital equivalent of flypaper on the Russian space station Mir today to collect cosmic grit.

title: COMPANY NEWS;THIOKOL PLANS TO BUY REMAINING STAKE IN HOWMET
description: The Thiokol Corporation said yesterday that it expected to buy the remaining 51 percent of the Howmet Corporation that it does not already own. The purchase price was not disclosed. Thiokol, a rocket and ammunition maker based in Ogden, Utah, and the Carlyle Group, an investment firm in Washington, D.C., bought Howmet in 1995 for $750 million, with Carlyle holding a 51 percent stake. Howmet makes precision castings for jet engines and industrial turbines. James R. Wilson, the chairman and chief executive of Thiokol, said at an aerospace conference in Arlington, Va., that after the company completed the acquisition, by 1999, its annual sales would rise to about $2.2 billion from an expected $900 million in the fiscal year ending in June.

title: To Giuliani, Rewards Of Control Exceed Risks
description: In late 1993, when Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani was interviewing candidates for police commissioner, he foretold a future moment after listening to a candidate named William J. Bratton make his pitch.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Viola to Play in Class AA
description: The former Cy Young award winner FRANK VIOLA, attempting to make the Toronto Blue Jays as a nonroster invitee, was assigned to Class AA Knoxville yesterday. Viola has agreed to the assignment.

title: F.T.C. Staff Opposes Sales by B.A.T.
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission recommended today that the five-member commission reject a plan by B.A.T. Industries to sell six discount cigarette brands to the Lorillard Tobacco Company, according to a report in a newsletter.

title: Officer Urges a Lenient Sentence For the Colleague Who Shot Him
description: Desmond Robinson said yesterday that he does not want a fellow police officer who was convicted on Tuesday of shooting him four times in the back to go to prison, adding that he plans to appeal for leniency at his sentencing.

title: Ritalin Maker Opens Drive To End Abuse
description: Responding to reports that schoolchildren are sniffing and injecting Ritalin to get high, the primary maker of the drug has begun a campaign to curb its abuse.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Pop-Rock Soul in a Traditional Body
description: The Bang on a Can All-Stars may have an impish name. But these six performers -- Maya Beiser (cello), Robert Black (bass), Lisa Moore (piano), Steven Schick (percussion), Mark Stewart (electric guitar), Evan Ziporyn (clarinets/saxophones) -- are excellent musicians who champion new music that doesn't fit into existing camps.

title: Equal Help for Schools
description: The unequal resources devoted to schools serving the poor and the affluent disgrace American public education. More than two decades ago the Supreme Court threw up its hands, saying that these disparities did not violate the Constitution. State courts in New Jersey and elsewhere have been more willing to demand steps aimed at greater equality. Their decisions have brought both progress and political turmoil in more than a dozen states. In New Jersey, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's struggle with education reform is the toughest test of her leadership since she took office two years ago.

title: Rabin's Killer Is Given a Life Sentence in Israel
description: Yigal Amir, the man who shattered Israel when he assassinated Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, was sentenced to life imprisonment today after having been found guilty of murder.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: STADIUMS;Replacing Candlestick Park
description: Given a mandate by voters on Tuesday, the San Francisco Giants turned their attention yesterday from campaigning for a ball park to building one.

title: Economic Scene;The rich are getting richer, etc., and it's likely to remain that way.
description: THE rich are getting richer, the poor, poorer and the middle class is barely hanging on. But not to worry: it's not nearly as bad as the numbers look.

title: Remember Snow? A Refresher Storm
description: Maybe it is too early to put away the snow shovels and galoshes after all. In a week that began with springlike warmth, the National Weather Service has issued a winter storm watch and a forecast of snow or sleet this afternoon and evening.

title: Federal Antitrust Inquiry Has Begun Against Moody's
description: The Justice Department has begun an investigation into the workings of the credit-rating industry that focuses on what some contend are anti-competitive practices by Moody's Investors Services Inc. in its ratings of some types of debt securities, people in the industry confirmed yesterday.

title: The Worlds in a Rock
description: The Chinese invented silk, gunpowder -- and the pet rock. Actually, they are scholar's rocks and they have been objects of connoisseurship since at least the Sung Dynasty (960-1279). They are still collected today.

title: CIRCUS REVIEW;Of Ambivalent Lions And a Flying Woman
description: The lavish spectacle running through April 28 at Madison Square Garden may be the 126th edition of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, but its spirit is the spirit of a circus reborn.

title: Rwanda Atrocity Inquiries Focus on Former Officer
description: Out of the blur of politically or ethnically motivated death squads that carried out genocidal massacres in Rwanda in 1994, one suspected mastermind is now appearing on the wanted lists of several countries, the Rwanda war crimes tribunal and a United Nations commission on illegal arms trafficking.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING SETTLES FEDERAL CHARGES
description: Automatic Data Processing Inc. has agreed to pay a $2.97 million civil penalty to settle Federal charges stemming from its acquisition of Auto Info Inc. in April 1995, the Government said yesterday. The Federal Trade Commission had contended that Automatic Data Processing failed to tell the commission that the acquisition might create an effective monopoly for information services to the automobile salvage industry. The F.T.C. said Automatic Data Processing, which is based in Roseland, N.J., had access to studies showing that the acquisition could hurt competition for salvage-yard computer systems, but failed to include them in the pre-merger review filing required by Federal law. The stock of Automatic Data Processing, which provides a variety of data services, fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $39.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bridge
description: For 60 years, the bridge players of New York City and Long Island have had dedicated service from Waldemar Von Zedtwitz, Edgar Kaplan, Sol Seidman and Ira Zippert. They have served successively as the representatives of the district on the American Contract Bridge League's board, helping determine policy for North America. Zippert retired last year, after a 12-year stint, and has been replaced by Al Levy of Stony Brook, L.I., the first Long Islander to hold the position.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Emissions-Test Delay Urged
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday that she planned to delay the start of a tougher auto emissions testing system until 1998.

title: Review/Fashion;Three Clear Signatures
description: AT a time when there is such a sameness in fashion that you can rarely name the designer without looking at the label, a few designers do manage to achieve a personal style. Count among them Norma Kamali, Isabel Toledo and Randy Kemper.

title: Right to Pollute Will Cost Less
description: It will cost electric utilities 48 percent less this year for the right to pollute than it did last year, based on the Environmental Protection Agency's fourth annual auction of pollution allowances at the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too;Where Is the Love?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chairman Says Goals Were Good
description: The assignments were formal and taken seriously, said John A. Catsimatidis, chairman of the Hellenic American Neighborhood Action Committee.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BASEBALL;Mets' New Pitching Ache Is Acevedo
description: Pete Harnisch, Bill Pulsipher and now Juan Acevedo. If things continue at this pace, the Mets may be starved for pitchers by opening day.

title: POLITICS: THE VICE PRESIDENCY;New Jersey Governor Quells Rumors Of Running
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, whose name has appeared on numerous short lists as a possible running mate for Senator Bob Dole, said today that she was definitely not interested in the Vice-Presidential nomination.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about the British Government's handling of an outbreak of a human brain ailment possibly related to so-called mad cow disease misstated a proposal for culling British dairy herds. The National Farmers Union plan for destroying older dairy cows would mean the slaughter of an estimated 14,000 to 15,000 cows a week, not in total.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Charles Taney, chief operating officer at the FCB New York unit of True North Communications, which consists of the FCB/Leber Katz Partners and FCB Direct agencies, was promoted to president, as expected. He assumes that title from J. Brendan Ryan, who had served as president and chief executive until being promoted to chairman and chief executive at Foote, Cone & Belding, New York.

title: POLITICS: THE PRIMARIES;With a Lock on Nomination Assured, Dole Takes a Campaign-Trail Detour
description: After a furious pace of contests over the last seven weeks, the 1996 Presidential primary season ended so fast that even the Republican victor groused about it.

title: More Words Of Teacher Are Found On Tape
description: In the final minutes of her life, a special education teacher who was abducted in a carjacking earlier this month managed secretly to record 24 minutes of her pleas to her attacker, then to turn the tape over and record 22 minutes more, the Ocean County Prosecutor said today.

title: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too;Middle-Class Value
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Said to Withhold War-Crime Data
description: Bosnia's representative at the United Nations accused the United States today of failing to turn over information on a notorious Serbian paramilitary leader known as Arkan, who has been linked to killings of Bosnian Muslims as late as last autumn.

title: For Yellowstone Bison, a Humane Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Virgin Founder May Start Anew
description: The flamboyant British entrepreneur Richard Branson is looking to re-enter the music business, three and half years after selling his Virgin Records label for $853 million.

title: Liberties;Baby-Talk Censure
description: It took 27 years of unwanted pouncing, yanking and smooching before Bob Packwood was bounced out of his job in Congress.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Capitalism's Future, Seismic If Not Apocalyptic
description: THE FUTURE OF CAPITALISM How Today's Economic Forces Shape Tomorrow's World By Lester C. Thurow 385 pages. William Morrow & Company. $25.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PENSKE MOTORSPORTS STOCK SURGES AFTER OFFERING
description: The stock of Penske Motorsports Inc. began trading yesterday and closed more than 32 percent above the price of its initial public offering. Penske, an owner of auto-racing tracks that is based in Detroit, sold 3.25 million shares on Tuesday at $24. The stock closed yesterday at $31.75 in Nasdaq trading of almost 3.9 million shares, meaning that some shares changed hands more than once. Penske Motorsports was organized in September 1995 as a holding company for Michigan International Speedway Inc., which operates a track in Brooklyn, Mich., and Pennsylvania International Raceway Inc., which operates a track in Nazareth, Pa.

title: Lobbying Ban Has Created A Sudden Hunger for Politics
description: With much of their lobbyist-financed lunch trade drying up because of new Congressional rules, two eating places on Capitol Hill are taking an unusual approach: they are trying to join a political party.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Blooming at Long Last

title: A Litton Division Is Raided In Federal Contract Inquiry
description: Federal investigators looking for contract and pricing information raided the offices of Litton Industries' guidance and control systems division today.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Rail Math: Ticket Machines Push Costs Up
description: When the Long Island Rail Road began installing ticket-vending machines in its stations in 1991, the goal was to save money. But railroad officials conceded today that costs actually went up.

title: Market Place;Stock prices aside, the smart money may be in PC servicing.
description: FOR manufacturers and retailers, the personal computer industry is a precarious, cutthroat business. All the profit, it seems, goes to Intel and Microsoft, which own the industry's crucial microchip and software technologies. So investors assign low price-earnings multiples to the shares of companies that make and sell personal computers, even in good times, and quickly head for the exit at the first sign of weakness.

title: Florida Tries to Ride Around Traffic
description: Faced with enormous traffic growth, Florida's Department of Transportation has promised $2.1 billion to ease congestion on the state's highways and runways with the fastest ride yet in the land of Disney -- a high-speed train like those that whisk passengers at 200 miles an hour in Japan and Europe.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Vermont

title: Clinton Urges State Action on Education
description: President Clinton urged the nation's governors today to enforce their push for rigorous classroom standards with state competency tests, saying there should be "no more social promotions, no more free passes" for students.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Heating Oil Hits 4-Year High Because of Drop in Inventories
description: Heating oil prices jumped to their highest levels in more than four years as refinery inventories fell following wintry weather that has lingered into spring.

title: Officers Confronting Officers: Old Rules Still in Place
description: In the tense days after a black undercover officer, Desmond Robinson, was shot in August 1994 by a white officer who mistook him for a criminal, the Police Department pledged to review its regulations to prevent such incidents.

title: Students Forage as Strike at Yale Closes Dining Halls on Campus
description: In what is almost as much a Yale tradition as "The Whiffenpoof Song" and secret societies, hundreds of university workers walked off their jobs today, closing the dining halls and flooding nearby restaurants with hungry students.

title: The Next Decision on China
description: As tensions over Taiwan ease after last week's presidential election there, President Clinton faces a difficult and important decision about China's secret sale of nuclear weapons technology to Pakistan.

title: Private Places, By Chance, By Design;Oases in the City
description: A New Yorker's life is in many ways a balancing act between the city's glorious energy and its bruising intrusions, a hunt to snatch a private moment in busy Manhattan -- or indeed at home. Here are places to find privacy in the city -- and ways to create a sanctuary at home. By NICOLAI OUROUSSOFF THERE is a view at the edge of Manhattan. From a single bench wedged between the roar of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at 51st Street and the murky East River, you can gaze over the water at a barren spit of land: The hollow shell of the abandoned Smallpox Hospital at Roosevelt Island's southern tip. It is a moment of surreal solitude.

title: Apple Expects It Will Lose $700 Million
description: Apple Computer said today that it expected to report a $700 million after-tax loss for its fiscal second quarter, a sign that the nation's third-largest personal computer maker is in even deeper financial trouble than had previously been recognized.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S.-Japan Pact Reached In Dispute Over Air Cargo
description: The United States and Japan said today that they had reached an agreement on air-cargo service, resolving one dispute that threatened to mar next month's summit meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto.

title: Keep Blue Cross Conversion in Public Eye;Reimburse Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Securities Show A Sharp Decline in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, after comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and a report on durable goods suggested that mounting econonic growth could stave off further cuts in interest rates.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Ralph Nader's Presidential candidacy misidentified the television program for which Bill Press, the former California Democratic chairman, is co-host. It is CNN's "Crossfire," not "Firing Line."

title: Cape Town Turns A Chic Corner
description: EVERYONE'S always known how terrific we are, but felt very guilty about it. Now that we're all reformed and black, they feel much better. Practically the whole of England -- lords and ladies galore -- has been out this summer. With the rand so low, you can get a wine farm for a song. The weather's good. And of course, nothing's really changed."

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Margaret Rockefeller, conservationist and philanthropist, misidentified the museum of which her husband, David Rockefeller, is chairman emeritus. It is the Museum of Modern Art, not the Metropolitan Museum.

title: Japanese Stocks Fall
description: Japanese stocks traded lower today. At the close of trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 34.16 points, or .16 percent, to 21,295.82. On Wednesday, the Nikkei gained 315.21 points.

title: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too;Overturned Racial Law
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Inco Bid Tops Falconbridge For Big Mine
description: Mining industry analysts said today that Inco Ltd.'s bid for the Voisey's Bay mine in Labrador might be just the beginning rather than the end of a battle with Falconbridge Ltd. over one of the richest mining discoveries in Canada in decades.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NORTHROP GRUMMAN TO DISMISS 2,100 WORKERS
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss 2,100 people from its military aircraft division in Southern California by the end of the year. Northrop Grumman, the military contractor, employs about 12,500 people in the region. It said declining work on its two major aircraft programs, the B-2 Stealth bomber and the F/A-18 attack fighter, made the cuts necessary. The planned reductions also arise from cost cuts on the version of the F/A-18 that is now in production. Northrop Grumman, which is based in Los Angeles, said that most of the cuts would be made by July 1.

title: Icy Chunks Shed by Comet Raise Hopes for Spectacular Show
description: As Comet Hyakutake streaked closer to the warming Sun, there were signs yesterday that one or more chunks may have broken loose from its snowball nucleus. Already the brightest comet in 20 years, Comet Hyakutake might become truly spectacular if its nucleus should disintegrate in the next few weeks.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;An Effort to Counter New York Cynicism
description: The employees of 30 agencies are taking part in volunteer activities and other pro bono work this week to counter what they consider a problem: New York City's reputation for cynicism.

title: 1980's Graft and 1990's Change;For Players in Scandal, Life Is Far From the Same
description: For Francis X. Smith, things are looking up. He recently regained his law license and is eager to resume a long-dormant career as a lawyer. For Michael Burnett, things are looking down. Convicted this month of masterminding a murder, he is expected to spend the rest of his days in prison.

title: Cougars and Lawyers Win in California Ballot Measures
description: While Senator Bob Dole's victory in Tuesday's California primary was a predictable political yawn, considerably less predictable was voters' wholesale rejection of three ballot propositions that, if passed, would have put California in the forefront of the much-disputed national movement to reduce court litigation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philips Will Raise Chip Production
description: Philips N.V. said yesterday that it planned to invest at least another 800 million guilders ($485 million) to increase its manufacturing capacity for semiconductor wafers. Philips said the new investment in its factory in Nijmegen, the Netherlands, the largest wafer plant in Europe, was in addition to 500 million guilders already invested there.

title: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too;Childless Marriages
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPUSA EXECUTIVES SAY SALES REMAIN STRONG
description: Officials of CompUSA Inc., which operates a chain of computer stores, said yesterday that they saw no evidence of a slowdown in sales of personal computers, despite recent speculation that one might occur this year. The company, which is based in Dallas, said its sales for the fiscal third quarter, which ended on Saturday, had jumped 29 percent, to $1 billion, from $776 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. CompUSA's directors also approved a 2-for-1 split of the common stock, which gained $3.125 to close at $53 on the New York Stock Exchange. The retailer said the split, in the form of a 100 percent common stock dividend, would be mailed April 22 to stockholders of record on April 8.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Farm-Family Values of Mid-40's Iowa
description: Phil Stong's folksy, homespun novel, "State Fair," is as impossible to brush off as lint. First filmed in 1933 with a cast headed by Will Rogers, it was remade in 1945 as a movie musical by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, a production that in turn was remade in 1962. "State Fair" still clings today, in large part because of the lilting score that includes such songs as "It Might as Well Be Spring," "That's for Me" and "Our State Fair." Be warned, however: If you allow any one of the melodies to penetrate your consciousness, you put yourself at risk. It will buzz around in the mind forever, or until a deep doze sets you free.

title: Liam O'Brien, 83, Screenwriter Who Found Hollywood Easy
description: Liam O'Brien, a one-time labor organizer who was such an immediate success when he tried his hand at writing that he went on to a long career as a Hollywood writer and television producer, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83.

title: Beneficiaries Sought in Pension Settlement
description: The Government began attempts this week to identify an estimated 40,000 workers believed eligible to share in about $100 million from pension plans terminated between 1976 and 1981.

title: Workers Bitter at Pay and Privatization Tie Up Bolivian Capital
description: Tens of thousands of state workers took to the streets of La Paz again today, chanting anti-Government slogans, hurling rocks at the police and blocking traffic. They were continuing a two-week-old strike demanding higher wages and protesting the Government's plan to sell off state-owned industries.

title: U.S. Imposes Strict Controls on Chemical Exports to Colombia
description: In a strategy intended to cripple the manufacture of Colombian cocaine, the United States is imposing stringent new controls on chemicals exported to Colombia by American companies that could be used to refine the illegal drug.

title: TENNIS;Boetsch Is Too Much For Red-Faced Courier
description: Even under the cover of his omnipresent slugger's cap, Jim Courier's face turned a spectrum of reds, all of them varying shades of frustration, this afternoon in his quarterfinal match at the Lipton Championships.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CAPCO AGREES TO TAKEOVER AFTER HIGHER BID BY EATON
description: The Eaton Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy the Capco Automotive Products Corporation after raising a bid to $12.50 a share, or more than $138 million. Eaton, a maker of auto parts, had previously offered $11 a share in an unsolicited proposal that valued Capco at $122 million. Capco, which is based in South Bend, Ind., makes manual transmissions and related parts. It urged its shareholders last week not to act on the previous bid until Capco's board responded. Capco's board has approved the latest bid, which will expire on April 15. Capco shares closed at $12.375 yesterday, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares of Eaton, which is based in Cleveland, were up 25 cents at $61.25.

title: BASKETBALL: N.I.T.;St. Joseph's Coach Martelli Fulfills a Lifelong Dream
description: Phil Martelli doesn't have a problem with being outspoken.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOARD APPROVES BUYBACK OF UP TO $600 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The board of Travelers Group Inc., the insurance and financial-services company, has approved the repurchase of as much as $600 million of the company's common shares for distribution in employee stock option and benefit plans. The stock closed yesterday at $65.25, down 25 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price, the acquisition would represent 2.9 percent of the stock outstanding.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Finally Dig Themselves Out of Deep Garden Rut
description: Just a few nights ago, Mike Richter's name was chanted as a plea. Last night, it was shouted in reverence by the sellout crowd at Madison Square Garden. And the Rangers, having gone through two days of grueling practices intended to purge the demons of a prolonged slump, snapped to attention with an inspired performance.

title: Europe Orders Ban on Exports Of British Beef
