description: Reacting to fears that a deadly disease may have entered the human food chain, the European Commission today imposed a ban on exports of British beef and a host of goods, ranging from medicine to cosmetics and candy, that have ingredients from beef byproducts.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Execution Voted in Shooting
description: A Gloucester County jury decided yesterday that a 24-year-old Woodbury Heights man should be executed for the October 1993 fatal shooting of a gas station attendant. The man, Richard Feaster, was convicted March 15 of killing Keith Donaghy with a sawed-off shotgun and robbing him of $190. The defense had put on several expert witnesses to show that Mr. Feaster was unable to control his impulses when he committed the crime, said Keith Warburton, an assistant prosecutor, "but the facts of the case show it was the result of intelligent planning."

title: Currents;Zany Etiquette In the Gravy
description: YOU get the feeling Jane Timberlake was told as a child to sit up straight one time too many. The San Francisco product designer is offering a tabletop collection called "Wild Mannered," consisting of napkins and chunky plates decorated with dozens of hopelessly demanding, but funny, etiquette dictums, which make you want to leave your elbows on the table or eat salad with the dinner fork. Dishes and linens are sold individually ($8 to $25) or in five-piece place settings ($100) at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (at 13th Street) or the Guggenheim Museum Store.

title: LeBow Says He Lost Money on RJR Deal
description: Bennett LeBow said yesterday that he and Carl C. Icahn had lost $40 million to $50 million on their investment in the stock of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: A heading above a picture yesterday with an article about efforts to make the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island a tourist attraction misattributed a quotation. As the article reported, it was Sanitation Commissioner John J. Doherty, not Assistant Commissioner Lucian Chalfen, who said: "Now I wouldn't tell the average visitor to New York to put it No. 1 on your list of things to visit. But maybe you think: 'I got a quiet day. I'm in New York. I'll go look at it.' "

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Legacies Of Passover And Easter
description: Composing today is an almost wholly secular enterprise, but in times past, when court chapels and church establishments were the principal employers of musicians, composers' outputs were driven by the demands of the church calendar. Even outside church and court, 18th- and 19th-century freelancers like Handel and Mendelssohn found a public eager to hear oratorios and other sacred works. Several recent releases look at the part of this legacy suited to the season of Passover and Easter.

title: INSIDE
description: Big Loss for Apple

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Morgan Stanley Reports Income Exceeding Wall St. Expectations
description: The Morgan Stanley Group Inc. reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose sharply, well exceeding Wall Street's expectations, led by gains in trading revenues and investment banking.

title: Latest Federal Shutdown Threat Lacks Crisis Atmosphere
description: Congress and the White House are locked in another budget battle, the temporary spending authority for much of the Government is dribbling toward expiration on Friday and threats of a Federal shutdown are again echoing up and down Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ONCURRENT COMPUTER CORP., Oceanport, N.J., agreed to buy a unit of Harris Computer Systems Corp. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in a transaction valued at about $21 million. The unit is engaged in "real time" computing, the solution of complex problems virtually simultaneously with the input of data, for uses like military simulations.

title: Drug Makers' Pricing Policies Are Raising More Objections
description: The prices that drug companies charge to community drugstores drew increasing scrutiny from all three branches of the Federal Government yesterday.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Facets of 70's Rock Revived by 3 Bands
description: Three new groups -- Cul de Sac, Trans Am and Six Finger Satellite -- looked back at European electronic rock from the 1970's on Sunday night at Brownie's and came up with three very different sounds.

title: Essay;Primary Reform Now
description: Those of us present at the creation of the modern political primary in 1952 remember the thrills of New Hampshire campaigning:

title: Disease Tests European Cooperation
description: As European countries prepare to gather in Italy on Friday for another effort to define their common future, the fiasco over mad cow disease and British beef exports has highlighted the sharp differences that remain among them.

title: Procter & Gamble Announces Price Cuts on Paper Products
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would reduce prices for its tissues, paper towels and bathroom tissues by at least 8 percent.

title: Longtime Ruler Overshadows Dominican Republic Election
description: This was supposed to be an election to mark the end of an era and usher in a new generation of leaders. But with a presidential vote looming here, the dominant figure of the campaign now in full swing turns out to be the same man who has governed this country for most of the past 35 years: Joaquin Balaguer.

title: Police Confirm Identity of Girl Found Slain
description: The Suffolk County police confirmed today that a body found Monday night behind Riverhead High School was Curtisha M. Morning, a 17-year-old senior who had been missing since Feb. 29.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sony, Getting Into PC's, Is Planning a Software Operating System
description: In what would be an audacious move for a Japanese company, the Sony Corporation is planning to develop a new software operating system, officials said today. Such operating systems, the fundamental software controlling computers and some other electronic machines, have been dominated by American companies.

title: Currents;Secrets of Image Makers
description: THERE will be plenty to do at "Behind the Screen," the core exhibition at the American Museum of the Moving Image, in Astoria, Queens. The futuristic 14,000-square-foot space, which cost $3 million to renovate, opens April 20. Future Walt Disneys can make animated shorts at worktables, above; fiddle with background music on a digital "soundtrack jukebox',' and practice "looping" dialogue on a library of film clips. The renovation was designed by Ali Hocek, a New York architect, in collaboration with a list of lighting, graphics and software designers that reads like a movie's credits. One exhibit simulates the split-second, mind-bending skill of a television control room team, with "real life" video from "Late Night with Conan O'Brien." Memorabilia demystify the movies -- the glittery chariot of "Ben Hur" looks cheesy, something from a high school homecoming parade. The museum is at 35th Avenue and 36th Street in Astoria. Information: (718) 784-0077.

title: 3 Die and 9 Are Injured as Blast Tears Through a Steel Factory
description: A thunderous explosion ripped through Beta Steel's plant today, killing three workers, injuring nine and shaking houses as far as 30 miles away.

title: No Sri Lankan 'Tribe'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Campaigns for mini-vans and pickups demonstrate that added doors are more than fifth wheels.
description: SOME of the nation's top advertising agencies have been scrambling to showcase the Motor City's hottest new feature: an extra door.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Shipbuilder To Give Up 3 Yards
description: The troubled shipbuilder Bremer Vulkan Verbund A.G. has agreed to give up its three eastern German shipyards, officials for Germany's privatization agency said yesterday. Vulkan, based in the western German city of Bremen, is accused of misdirecting aid earmarked for the eastern German shipyards that it bought after unification. Vulkan had long resisted suggestions that it should give up the eastern shipyards, but relented during weeks of talks with the privatization agency whose predecessor negotiated the initial sale.

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks Find Some Answers But Can't Win
description: They walked the ball upcourt, took David Robinson out of the game early and contested almost every 3-point line. The Knicks seemed to solve the league's most difficult puzzle tonight at the Alamodome.

title: Chicken Parts And Politics On Agenda At Sinai Talks
description: When President Clinton flew to Egypt two weeks ago, he met with some 30 world leaders to discuss Middle Eastern terrorism, and with the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, to talk about Bosnia, NATO, their re-election campaigns and bilateral annoyances -- including chicken parts.

title: Review/Fashion;Another Versace In the Limelight
description: THE New York collections began on Tuesday in the considerable shadow of the fashion statement made at the Academy Awards on the West Coast. It was a strange sort of role reversal for fashion, with supermodels shilling for the movies (wearing the work of the best-costume nominees), and stars shilling for Revlon, Harry Winston, Van Cleef & Arpels and whatever designer who had wooed them best. As the woman who couldn't be bought, Sharon Stone arrived as the actress she wants to be instead of the star clad in Valentino, touting her only label as the Gap.

title: Shin Kanmaru of Japan, 81, Kingmaker Toppled by Graft
description: Shin Kanemaru, the disgraced kingmaker who epitomized a corrupt back-room style of Japanese politics that many Japanese hope is now ending, died this morning at his home in Shiranecho, northwest of Tokyo. He was 81 and succumbed to a stroke stemming from diabetes, his family said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Irvin Finishes His Testimony
description: MICHAEL IRVIN, the Dallas Cowboys' star receiver, has concluded his testimony before a grand jury investigating an incident on March 4, when the police said they found him and three other people in a Dallas hotel room with two ounces of cocaine and three ounces of marijuana. Irvin was not arrested, and the grand jury, whose term expires Sunday night, must now consider what action to take.

title: Currents;Improving the Climate for Physical Therapy
description: PHYSICAL therapy can be as depressing as an injury, made worse by the grungy offices. An exception is the new office of Union Square Rehabilitation and Sports Medicine, 826 Broadway, above the Strand Bookstore. Dr. Jeffrey Gross asked the designers Kevin Roberts and Tim Haynes to design a playful, 7,500-square-foot space with the same inventive and hospitable esthetic as their home interiors. The designers chose aqua glass tiles to enclose a rooftop skylighted therapy pool, crisp white Saarinen chairs and sofas upholstered with black Naugahyde. "We took a cue from hip, upbeat gym design, rather than a 19th-century torture chamber," Mr. Haynes said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Not every wife puts her husband on a pedestal. So the first thing you ought to know about LYNN SYMS, the wife of the clothier SY SYMS ("An educated consumer is our best customer") is that she did.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: For Giuliani, a Split Spawned by Success
description: In sticking with William J. Bratton as Police Commissioner for 27 months, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had gambled that Mr. Bratton's value in reducing crime was worth his celebrity status, which often upstaged the Mayor. But Mr. Bratton finally fell victim to a powerful dynamic: Mr. Giuliani's desire for mayoral control, which ultimately outweighed the commissioner's attributes as a popular figure known for doing an outstanding job in reducing the city's crime rate.

title: U.S. and Europeans Differ on Follow-Up to Meeting on Terrorism
description: Differences between the United States and its European allies have emerged over the follow-up to the recent anti-terrorism summit meeting in Egypt, diplomats here say.

title: 2 Unions to Seek Board Representation at Kmart
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and another union said yesterday that they would ask shareholders of the Kmart Corporation to elect a new director as part of an effort to press the company to study a possible sale or merger.

title: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too;Unfair, Un-American
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;Cigar Hangs On in Desert Sand to Win 14th in Row
description: Cigar, the great American thoroughbred who traveled more than 6,000 miles to race here, held off a breathtaking stretch challenge tonight to win the $4 million Dubai World Cup by half a length and collect racing's richest prize.

title: Senate Approves Line-Item Veto for President
description: By an overwhelming majority, the Senate voted tonight to cede much of Congress's authority over Federal spending to the White House beginning next year.

title: Keep Blue Cross Conversion in Public Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Kingfisher Profit Gains
description: Kingfisher P.L.C. posted a 2 percent profit increase, before tax and a one-time gain, for its fiscal year ended on Feb. 3 as higher earnings at the company's core Woolworths stores offset slumping profit at its B&Q home-improvement chain. Pretax profit before items increased to L287.2 million ($476.9 million) last year from L281.5 million a year earlier. A combined profit increase of 16 percent at Kingfisher's Woolworths, Comet, Darty and Superdrug stores offset a decline at B&Q. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: S.E.C. Proposal Would Revamp Mutual Funds' Sales Policies
description: In a potentially sweeping overhaul of mutual fund regulation, the Securities and Exchange Commission later this year will propose major changes in the way mutual funds sell shares to investors and how they disclose the potential risks of the funds they are offering, a top S.E.C. official said today.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;New World Of Comedy In Black And White
description: While black artists and executives struggle for prominence in Hollywood, critics of the film industry often point to television as a medium where black performers are infinitely more appreciated. Superficially, that seems to be true. Yes, there are all those black sitcoms like "Living Single" and "Fresh Prince of Bel Air" (now in its final countdown), but their characters tend to be rigidly segregated from white society and most of their performers are curiously ignored when it comes time for Emmy Award nominations. Is it purely by chance that the one comic to emerge as a superstar from "In Living Color," Fox's former variety show dominated by black performers, was a white man named Jim Carrey?

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;In the End, Orangemen Are the Invisible Men
description: Of all the teams in the Final Four, Syracuse may feel the least amount of anxiety because national expectations are so low.

title: Accord on Longer Maternity Hospital Stays
description: New York State lawmakers agreed today to require insurers to pay for at least 48 hours of hospital care for mothers and newborns.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a memorial service at Carnegie Hall for the composer Morton Gould misidentified the conductor of members of the New York Choral Society in the Gould work "Quotations." It was Roger DeCormier, not John Daly Goodwin.

title: Justices Curb Federal Power To Subject States to Lawsuits
description: Escalating its profound and divisive debate over the relationship between the states and the Federal Government, the Supreme Court today bolstered state power by sharply curbing the authority of Congress to subject states to suits in Federal court.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: STADIUMS;Steps for Two Stadiums
description: Maryland's Board of Public Works voted yesterday to approve financing for a $200 million football stadium for the team moving to Baltimore from Cleveland, setting the stage for the issuance of $90 million in bonds next month.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;TCI Reports A Wider Loss In 4th Quarter
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss widened, reflecting higher operating expenses and the spinoff of its Liberty Media unit.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: NOTEBOOK;On the Count of 3, Roll Out the Floor!
description: The 215 separate 4-by-8 panels of hard-rock maple that arrived today at the Continental Arena on a flatbed truck from Michigan will get plenty of attention on Saturday and Monday. The panels make up the official Final Four floor.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;Trying to Make History of a Different Kind
description: As the Mississippi State basketball players practiced this week at the Humphrey Coliseum, they wore new sneakers. Spiffy black-and-white ones called Nike Air Up Tempos. Each pair was a small spoil for making the Final Four. New shoes and new, fresh smiles from the players all around.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pilkington to Revamp Its Glass Operations
description: Pilkington P.L.C. announced plans yesterday to restructure its glass-making operations worldwide and cut 1,900 jobs. The company cited weak European construction markets and the recent strike at North American plants of the General Motors Corporation. As a major G.M. supplier, the Pilkington unit LOF was forced to temporarily lay off 1,000 workers.

title: Columbia Gas Is Moving
description: Columbia Gas System Inc. said today that it would move its headquarters from Wilmington, Del., to northern Virginia and shift some workers from its pipeline subsidiary in Charleston, W.Va., as well. The moves are part of a reorganization aimed at streamlining operations as Columbia Gas and its pipeline unit, the Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation, emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The shift to temporary quarters in Reston, Va., will begin in August while a permanent site is sought, the company said. About 150 workers from Charleston will be transferred in late 1997.

title: Lear Hurt by G.M. Strike
description: The Lear Corporation said today that it expected its first-quarter earnings to be reduced by 10 cents a share by the 17-day strike at two General Motors Corporation brake-parts plants in Dayton, Ohio. In last year's quarter ended April 1, Lear earned $17 million, or 34 cents a share, on sales of $1.04 billion. Lear said that depending on G.M.'s production schedules, a partial recovery would be possible. Lear supplies car seats and other interior parts.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WESTINGHOUSE TO CLOSE FACTORY IN FLORIDA AND CUT JOBS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, based in Pittsburgh, said yesterday that it would close a turbine and generator assembly plant in Pensacola, Fla., by the end of 1998 and lay off most of the 650 workers there. The company said it was transferring production to other plants in an effort to increase efficiency in its business of providing power-generation equipment. A few of the workers in Pensacola may be offered transfers, said Mimi Limbach, a company spokeswoman.

title: Mayor Cancels 2 City Contracts With Service Agency in Queens
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday canceled two city contracts with a Queens social-service agency, citing concerns about how they were awarded and the fact that the nonprofit group that won the $43 million deal had recently hired a son of a lifelong friend of the Mayor's.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Less Privacy for Prostitution
description: The State Assembly will take up a bill today that would expand the definition of prostitution to include solicitation that occurs in private places, such as hotel rooms, as well as in public. The bill was introduced after the Atlantic City police vice squad said that the current law was inadequate, said Assemblyman Kenneth C. LeFevre, Republican of Linwood.

title: Primaries for Seats in Israeli Parliament Bring Some Surprises to BothMajor Parties
description: Israel's major political parties have chosen their slates for the May 29 elections, with both parties pushing former military men to the fore for a campaign that is likely to focus sharply on security issues.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EL PASO NATURAL GAS CUTTING MORE JOBS THAN EXPECTED
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company said yesterday that it was cutting 903 jobs, more than previously planned. The cuts amount to 38 percent of El Paso Natural Gas's work force of 2,400. The company said that 384 workers would be dismissed and that 519 had accepted early retirement or special severance packages. The company, a natural-gas producer and supplier based in El Paso, did not provide further information on the savings it expected from the cuts. The company had announced in January that it planned to eliminate up to 800 jobs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 17 about the likelihood that the Republican right will cause problems for Senator Bob Dole during the Presidential campaign misstated the Christian Coalition's position on his candidacy. The coalition, a conservative political organization, has not formally endorsed Mr. Dole; it says it will remain neutral during both the primary season and the fall campaign.

title: Shares of Northstar Tumble by 35%
description: Shares of Northstar Health Services Inc. plunged 35 percent yesterday after the company said on Tuesday that it had suspended its former chief financial officer, asked two directors to resign and set up an independent committee to investigate its accounting practices.

title: The Pop Life
description: Free Spirit's New Message

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Going With Duncan In 'Desperate' Infield Move
description: With Pat Kelly likely to go on the disabled list, Mariano Duncan will be the Yankees' opening-day second baseman unless there is a trade. That prospect leaves Joe Torre uneasy, mainly because with Duncan as a starter, there are limitations on the manager's ability to maneuver.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;7 French Trappist Monks Kidnapped in Algeria
description: Seven French Trappist monks were seized before dawn today from their monastery in northern Algeria by an armed group believed to be part of a Muslim insurgency, French officials said.

title: Will the User Snap Before the Lid Does?
description: THE trouble started on page 16, where it said to loosen something called the ball-cock nut.

title: Coke's Hometown Olympics;The Company Tries the Big Blitz on Its Own Turf
description: The ultimate marketer will soon put on its biggest show right in its own backyard.

title: First Boston Hires Economist
description: CS First Boston has rehired Neal M. Soss, naming him the firm's chief United States economist.

title: Society Can Accept Gay Marriages, Too;Not an Obstacle
description: To the Editor:

title: Anthony Ingrassia Service
description: A memorial service for Anthony Ingrassia, a playwright, director and producer, is to take place at 5 P.M. on Saturday at the Gershwin Hotel, 7 East 27th Street. Mr. Ingrassia, who was a member of the Ridiculous Theater Company, died in December at the age of 51. A number of performance artists and others are to take part in the service, which is open to the public.

title: POLITICS: ABORTION;HOUSE VOTES BAN ON A METHOD USED IN LATE ABORTIONS
description: After two hours of passionate debate, the House tonight gave final approval to a bill to outlaw a specific type of late-term abortion and sent the measure to President Clinton, who has said he intends to veto it.

title: Justices Apply Federal Law To State Political Conventions
description: A sharply divided Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Voting Rights Act of 1965 gives the Justice Department authority to review changes in the rules for state party nominating conventions that may make it more difficult for some voters to participate.

title: Anti-Tax Group Prowls; Neighbors Protest
description: In a classic tableau from Montana's Missouri Breaks country, a light snow eddied across dormant wheat fields today as honking Canada geese banked in a gray sky. But, in a jarring note, visitors to Richard Clark's farm were greeted by a carefully drawn hangman's noose.

title: Reviews/Fashion;The 70's Come Back, Perfected, at Tyler
description: Six months ago, when Prada and Gucci simultaneously began drawing from vintage looks of the 1970's, putting epaulet jackets and maxi proportions on their runways, Giorgio Armani had a great idea.

title: Albany Abandons Budget and Agrees on Stopgap Spending
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders today abandoned their effort to pass a state budget on time because of the budget impasse in Washington. They agreed instead to a stopgap spending measure that would freeze state spending at current levels for four weeks while also allowing a previously approved tax cut to take effect on Monday.

title: Officials Say Montana 'Freemen' Collected $1.8 Million in Scheme
description: To Montana's Freemen, the rural complex of machine sheds, wheat silos and ranch houses here is a new Federal Reserve Bank.

title: A. Harry Passow, 75, Dies; Studied Gifted Pupils
description: A. Harry Passow, one of the first educators to study the needs of intellectually gifted children and one of the first to see the problems of children living in urban poverty, died yesterday at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey. He was 75.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets Are Final Test for a Master Rebuilder
description: He helped revive once-proud franchises, from New England to the Giants to the Steelers. And now Ron Erhardt, at age 65, faces perhaps his most daunting challenge: the Jets.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Dallas Grand Jury Gets Extension
description: A Dallas judge yesterday extended by 30 days the term of a grand jury reviewing evidence from a motel drug bust at which the Dallas Cowboys star MICHAEL IRVIN and a former teammate, ALFREDO ROBERTS, were present.

title: Target Male Mustangs
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Lopez Retires From Ring
description: After a 16-year career that included winning three world championships, TONY LOPEZ says he is quitting boxing.

title: BASEBALL;As McGwire Heals, A's Will Look to Build With Youth
description: If you were a horse, it was suggested to the man on crutches, they would have shot you a long time ago. Mark McGwire laughed heartily.

title: COMPANY NEWS;APACHE AGREES TO ACQUIRE PHOENIX RESOURCE
description: Broadening its expansion into Egypt, the Apache Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Phoenix Resource Companies for $409 million in cash and stock. The Houston-based Apache said Phoenix has oil-drilling concessions in Egypt and two producing fields expected to generate $70 million next year. Apache will pay three-quarters of a share of Apache stock and $4 in cash for each of Phoenix's 16.1 million shares, or about $25.38 a share at Wednesday's closing price. Shares of Phoenix, based in Oklahoma City, jumped $4.125, or 21 percent, to $24 yesterday, on the American Stock Exchange, while Apache shares fell $1, to $27.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Art in Review
description: Jane Kaplowitz 'Death in Venice' Jason McCoy Inc. 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through April 13

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Toll Collectors Suspended
description: Three part-time toll collectors on the New Jersey Turnpike were suspended last weekend for wearing latex gloves on the job, and yesterday a spokesman for their union contended that managers were cracking down on minor infractions as part of a "reign of terror."

title: Reform Rabbis Vote to Back Gay Marriage
description: The Central Conference of American Rabbis, representing 1,750 rabbis of the liberal Reform movement, voted today to support civil marriage for lesbians and gay men and to oppose governmental efforts to bar such unions.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Flaw Is Found in Netscape
description: Researchers at Princeton University have uncovered a security flaw in the programming language used in the popular Netscape Internet browser system. Because of the flaw, a site could be rigged so that the personal Internet files of someone visiting that site could be deleted or made public, Edward Felten, an assistant professor of computer science, said yesterday. Sun Microsystems, the company that developed part of the Java software, where the flaw was found, has issued a warning to users. TERRY PRISTIN

title: COMPANY NEWS;BELOIT BUYS INGERSOLL-RAND'S IMPCO DIVISION
description: The Beloit Corporation, a unit of Harnischfeger Industries, said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the Ingersoll-Rand Company's Impco pulp-machinery division for about $125 million. Beloit, a manufacturer of paper-making equipment, said Impco's pulp- and fiber-processing lines would complement its products. Impco employs 725 at operations based in Nashua, N.H.; Sherbrooke, Quebec, and Linz, Austria. Harnischfeger, based in Brookfield, Wis., also makes mining and material-handling equipment.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Mythological Images of a Lost Samoa
description: Robert Louis Stevenson, who spent the last five years of his life in Samoa, described the colonial conflict over Samoa as "two bald men fighting over a comb." If the wall text at the exhibition "Picturing Paradise: Colonial Photography of Samoa, 1875 to 1925" can be believed, the colonial photographers of Samoa were more like blind men fighting over a mirror. Blinkered by their colonialist ways, they were able to see little more in the strange land they photographed than their own exotic fantasies.

title: Mutola May Benefit
description: When world track officials altered the Olympic schedule last weekend to help Michael Johnson in his attempt for a sprint double in Atlanta, they took away Maria Mutola's chance for a double of her own.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Of Romance and Friendship
description: Oh my God, how am I going to tell Amelia?" wails Laura (Anne Heche), only seconds after she decides to marry Frank (Todd Field). Laura and Amelia (Catherine Keener) have been best friends since girlhood, and each knows the other's every quirk. Since Amelia is most definitely single, the prospect of her friend's wedding means trouble. But it also guarantees Nicole Holofcener's first feature a mother lode of revealing little intimacies and nicely neurotic wit.

title: ART REVIEW;A Bazaar of Asian Wonders, High and Low
description: The arts of Asia are converging in New York in a big way. The blockbuster "Splendors of Imperial China" is packing in crowds at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Asian auctions are percolating at Sotheby's and Christie's. And a new Asian Art Fair, the latest brainchild of the organizers Brian and Anna Haughton, is filling the Seventh Regiment Armory for four days, starting tomorrow.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOME SAVINGS DEAL HELPS WELLS FARGO
description: Home Savings of America said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 61 First Interstate Bancorp branches for about $200 million, a deal that will allow Wells Fargo & Company to complete its takeover of First Interstate, an all-stock offer worth more than $13 billion. Home Savings, a unit of H. F. Ahmanson & Company and based in Irwindale, Calif., is the nation's largest savings and loan, with about $50.5 billion in assets at the beginning of the year. The acquisition of the branches would give it $500 million in consumer loans and $121 million in small-business loans. Home Savings said it would close as many as 27 of the 61 branches near its existing branches, and expected "modest" layoffs. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Ahmanson rose 25 cents, to $24.

title: Art in Review
description: Lani Maestro Art in General 79 Walker Street TriBeCa Through April 13

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Improved Outlook for Iraqi Sales Pushes Price of Oil 38~ Lower
description: Prices for crude oil fell yesterday amid revived concern Iraq and the United Nations would agree on a limited oil sale, which could mean about 600,000 barrels a day of new supply.

title: F.A.A. to Streamline Rules That Gave It Obsolescence
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, acknowledging that its procurement regulations are so cumbersome that new equipment is often obsolete by the time it is installed, said today that it would toss out almost all the old rules, beginning on Monday.

title: Nebraska Defies Crowd In N.I.T.
description: St. Joseph's had nearly everything on its side last night in the championship game of the 59th annual National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden: a tight game, a tempo to its liking, a Garden crowd of 12,464 fans, most of whom had trekked up from Philadelphia.

title: ART REVIEW;Unsettling Women of the Gilded Age
description: Even in homes where American painting of the late 19th century is a frequent topic, the name Thomas Wilmer Dewing probably isn't heard too frequently. Dewing was born in Boston in 1851, and at the age of 14 was apprenticed to a lithographer to support his widowed mother and siblings. Talented and ambitious, he went to Paris, studying at the Academie Julian. Upon settling in New York in 1880, he became one of the most sought-after painters of the Gilded Age, with some help from his friend and patron the architect Stanford White, who commissioned portraits and murals for himself and his clients and designed many of the handsome gilded frames still found on Dewing canvases.

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 111.03 points, or half of 1 percent, to 21,406.85. On Thursday, the Nikkei lost 34.16 points.

title: A New Chase Tries to Lead;Will the Merged Bank Be Greater Than Its Parts?
description: The last two decades make a humbling prelude to the rebirth of the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

title: U.S. Business Cutting Plans For Spending
description: American businesses plan to spend only slightly more this year than in 1995 on new buildings and equipment, marking a sharp slowdown in an important sector of the economy, a survey released today by the Commerce Department said.

title: FINAL FOUR: MEN'S PREVIEW;Following A Treasure Map And Title Dreams
description: Nobody arrives here by accident. No one just passes through. The Meadowlands, this weekend more than ever, will become a destination built upon obsession, professional lifetimes of planning, years of childhood fantasies and more money than ever seemed possible at an amateur sporting event.

title: Final Four '96
description: A preview of the men's and womwn's teams in college basketbaall's Final Four, with statistics and summaries of each team's strengths and weaknesses. SportsFriday, Page B19.

title: Delaware Court Issues Hoechst Case Ruling
description: The Delaware Supreme Court issued a ruling on Wednesday that could shift the cost of Hoechst A.G.'s $400 million share of a settlement to its insurers.

title: THE NEW POLICE COMMISSIONER;At News Conference, Safir Says Keeping Morale High Is Vital
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named Howard Safir Police Commissioner yesterday. Following are excerpts from a City Hall news conference with Mr. Safir after the announcement, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Distributor to Drop Some Dr Pepper/Cadbury Sodas
description: In what analysts called a blow to the company's expansion plans, Dr Pepper/Cadbury North America said yesterday that its United States distributor, Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., had decided to stop distributing several of its soda brands, including A & W Root Beer, Crush, Sunkist and Welch's.

title: Company Briefs
description: JOHN ALDEN FINANCIAL CORP., Miami, an insurance holding company, will sell two units: its asset-accumulation division and its credit life and disability business. The sale could fetch $275 million before taxes, analysts said.

title: Chronicle
description: Reflecting the transformation of the cold war into an old war, John Philip Sousa's pulse-stirring "Stars and Stripes Forever" was beamed aboard the Russian space station Mir yesterday as the day's wake-up call for its Russian-American crew.

title: FINAL FOUR: A LOOK BACK;Scandal, the Unwanted Scar of Triumph
description: It happened 46 years ago, on the cloudy night of March 28, 1950, and until this weekend, in fact, when the Final Four is played at the Meadowlands in New Jersey, it was the last time the N.C.A.A. championship was scheduled in the New York City area, as though, perhaps, to avoid any unsavory remembrances.

title: Drug Is Found to Shield Brain During Strokes
description: An experimental new drug powerfully protects stroke victims from catastrophic brain damage and may someday be given to virtually all such patients, researchers say.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DONNELLEY PLANS LAYOFFS AND EARNINGS CHARGE
description: The R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company said it plans to take a $411 million charge against first-quarter earnings and will close two plants, laying off as many as 950 people. Donnelley, the world's largest commercial printer for publications, also said that its first-quarter net income, excluding the charge, will be less than the 31 cents reported a year earlier. The company had been expected to earn 33 cents in the quarter, based on the average estimate of five analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. The two plants to be closed are in Casa Grande, Ariz., and Newton, N.C. The company also plans to spend $160 million for upgrades.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Persuasion 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $97.51. Laser disk, $34.95. 104 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.

title: Brinksmanship to Victory
description: After the Republican leadership threatened for six months to prevent the United States from borrowing billions of dollars more to keep the Government running, today's votes to raise the Federal debt ceiling were a strategic victory for Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. Mr. Rubin had warned for months that the Republicans were threatening the Government's credit rating.

title: David Copperfield' at a California Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: No Federal Handout
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in the News: THE NEW POLICE COMMISSIONER -- AT THE HEALM;No Spotlight Needed: Howard Safir
description: With his new Police Commissioner looming over his shoulder, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday read with relish the list of the celebrity criminals Howard Safir rounded up when he worked in the United States Marshals Service during the 1980's. But a moment later, he mentioned a more telling qualification possessed by Mr. Safir: The two men have been friends for two decades.

title: FINAL FOUR: SCOUTING;Tennessee
description: East Regional Champion Overall Record: 30-4 Ninth Final Four Appearance

title: Adventurous Asian Cuisine
description: CAN you name the restaurants that list these dishes on their menus? Raw shrimp on shiso with flying fish roe. Sour-spicy shimeji mushroom broth. Marinated hamachi. Red snapper with shiitake mushrooms, sugar snap peas and shrimp in ginger broth. Steamed cod in sake with black-bean sauce. Unagi and potato terrine with wasabi and yuzu. Dim sum for two. Shrimp tempura. Fried wontons. Thai seafood salad with ginger lemongrass vinaigrette. Lobster congee.

title: Shin Kanemaru, 81, Kingmaker In Japan Toppled by Corruption
description: Shin Kanemaru, the disgraced kingmaker who epitomized a corrupt back-room style of Japanese politics that many Japanese hope is now ending, died this morning at his home in Shiranecho, northwest of Tokyo. He was 81 and succumbed to a stroke stemming from diabetes, his family said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Former Coach Wants Job Back
description: A former Cleveland State coach who was fired six years ago wants his old job back. KEVIN MACKEY said Wednesday that he has contacted the university about the job and will file an application. He offered to sign an agreement to submit to regular drug and alcohol abuse testing.

title: In a Tense Johannesburg, Zulus Hold Peaceful Rally
description: The headline this morning read, "A Ring of Steel to Protect City." Thousands of police officers and soldiers patrolled the streets, the railroad stations and migrant workers' hostels. Sections of downtown were cordoned off with razor wire, and many businesses closed, their employees too frightened to be downtown when the Zulus marched.

title: Jeffries Protests Planned Closing Of College's Black Studies Dept.
description: Leonard Jeffries, the former chairman of the black studies department of City College, and Moyibi Amoda, its current chairman, protested in measured tones yesterday against the college's decision last week to close their department, but held out the possibility that they might take stronger action.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Home for the Holidays 1995. Polygram. $96.99. Laser disk, $34.95. 103 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Safer Way to Dredge New York Harbor
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: Where are we?" asks my friend. I look around at the former T-shirt shop that has become Downtown, owned by Giuseppe Cipriani (yes, he is the son of Arigo Cipriani), and say, "West Broadway and Broome." And then I look again and add, "I think."

title: Inside Art
description: A van Gogh Mystery

title: COMPANY NEWS;COORS ANTICIPATES STEEP QUARTERLY LOSS
description: The Adolph Coors Company said yesterday that it expected to report a steeper first-quarter loss because of unspecified problems. A year ago, Coors reported a loss of 2 cents a share for the first quarter, which it restated after shifting its fiscal year to conform to the calendar year. The company, in Golden, Colo., is expected to report first-quarter earnings about mid-April. Coors and other big American brewers have been struggling as specialty beers and imports gain market share in the sluggish industry. Shares of Coors fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $18.75, before the earnings forecast was made.

title: 1995 Was Good for Companies, And Great for a Lot of C.E.O.'s
description: A preliminary survey of the compensation of chief executives at a number of America's largest corporations indicates that executive pay may have risen last year at the fastest rate since the mid-1980's, when pay for performance became the guiding principle for rewarding corporate chiefs.

title: U.S. Studying Limited Penalties for Chinese Sale
description: Instead of issuing a blanket sanction against loans to companies doing business in China, American officials are drafting penalties against the Chinese company that sold $70,000 of ring magnets to Pakistan, a violation of an American law, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: For Children
description: 'The Peaceable Kingdom' Kosciuszko Foundation 15 East 65th Street, Manhattan (212) 734-2130 Recommended ages: 5 and up Tomorrow

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Office Depot Picks Thompson Chicago
description: Office Depot, the office-supply retail chain based in Delray Beach, Fla., said yesterday that it had selected the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson to handle its broadcast creative account, which had been handled by the Gold Coast Advertising Associates in Miami for the last eight years. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Del-Debbio Expresses Admiration for Officer He Shot
description: Peter Del-Debbio said yesterday that he found it "admirable" that the fellow police officer he was convicted of shooting plans to ask a judge to spare him from prison, even though the officer testified against Mr. Del-Debbio at his trial.

title: Lurching Toward States' Rights
description: A headstrong five-justice majority is driving the Supreme Court toward a revolutionary, indeed reactionary, interpretation of federalism, tilting the balance dangerously toward states' rights at the expense of Federal power.

title: U.S. Describes Plan to Ease Israeli Curbs on West Bank and Gaza
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced an emergency plan today to ease Israel's restrictions on Palestinians on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. His announcment came at the opening of a two-day conference of 27 nations on protecting Israel against terrorism.

title: BASEBALL;Met Sees Interleague Play Making Yanks Real Rivals
description: Lance Johnson has worn a Mets uniform for all of about seven weeks, but he's already sensing something special about the exhibition games with the Yankees on Friday and Saturday in Tampa.

title: TV WEEKEND;Sonny Crockett, but in San Francisco
description: Hit television series never die; their players just get reincarnated. So Michael Mann, the mastermind behind "Miami Vice," now directs big movies like "Heat" (good karma). Philip Michael Thomas, the actor who often seemed along for the ride on "Vice," turns up in television's wee hours promoting a psychic hot line (bad karma). And Don Johnson carries a huge whiff of his old character, Sonny Crockett, to his amiable new series, "Nash Bridges" (O.K. karma).

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a visit to Norway by the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, misidentified the King of Norway. He is King Harald, not Haakon.

title: Agency Facing Inquiry Loses More City Contracts
description: New York City officials yesterday canceled six more city contracts held by a Queens social service agency, a day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered two contracts worth $43 million jettisoned because of irregularities in their awarding.

title: A Safer Way to Dredge New York Harbor;Sea-Wall Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Dijon Journal;To Arms! Rebuilt Organ May Have German Accent
description: Burgundy, with its matchless wines and architectural monuments, is the last place you might expect the French to be on the defensive about their culture.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a Capitol Sketchbook article about Representative Patricia Schroeder's pending retirement from Congress misstated the nature of an appearance she made under the banner "Welcome Bob," in which she was described as joining colleagues in welcoming Senator Bob Dole back to Washington and urging him to work on the budget. The event was staged as satire.

title: Health Care Deal Seen
description: The nation's largest publicly traded hospital chain and a big Blue Cross insurer in the Midwest agreed yesterday to create a joint venture to provide managed health care services in northern Ohio, according to people with knowledge of the deal.

title: Cable and Wireless Holds Talks On Merger With British Telecom
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. and British Telecommunications P.L.C. said they were holding "exploratory discussions" on a possible merger that would create a global telecommunications powerhouse.

title: FINAL FOUR: SCOUTING;Georgia
description: Midwest Regional Champion Overall Record: 27-4 Fourth Final Four appearance

title: FINAL FOUR: SCOUTING;Massachusetts
description: East Regional Champion Overall Record: 35-1 First Final Four Appearance

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;A Kiss-Off To a Killer
description: Jose Maria Lara's comedy "Justino" offers a warning to employers everywhere: think twice before you pressure a loyal, longtime worker into accepting early retirement. Entrenched work habits die hard. And when certain skills practiced in the workplace find applications in other areas, the damage can be stupendous.

title: Israelis Sharing Pain in Oklahoma
description: Most of them were only 13 years old when a member of the Islamic militant group Hamas drove a car to their bus stop in Afula, Israel, just as school was letting out on April 6, 1994. A few moments later, the driver detonated a bomb that blew up a city bus, killed eight people and set the children on fire.

title: FILM REVIEW;Adults With Choices, And Sex Is the Big One
description: Carried Away" is a self-consciously high-minded film that confronts its grown-up characters with some ethical questions worth considering. How far should a doctor persist in prolonging the life of a terminal cancer patient? Should a board of education reject out of hand a dedicated and experienced rural school teacher because he doesn't have the proper credentials?

title: David Copperfield' at a California Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 26 about scientific findings on the aging of human brain cells misstated the given name of one of the "successful" elderly individuals profiled, an 89-year-old man who teaches philosophy at universities and writes books. He is Dr. Richard I. McKinney, not James. A letter from Dr. McKinney's family dated Feb. 28, pointing out the error was delayed in routing at The Times.

title: HOCKEY;As Devils Make a Point, Brodeur Hurts His Back
description: Who knows about injuries to Devils players? Some, out "day to day," stay away from week to week. Every so often, they retroactively announce a surgery.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Unrepentant, Defiant Blues For 7 Voices
description: A LITTLE more than a month before it officially ends, the Broadway season begins. That's the joyous sense of things with the arrival of August Wilson's big, invigorating if unruly new tragicomedy, "Seven Guitars," which opened last night at the Walter Kerr Theater.

title: GOLF;Leonard Rides Youth Wave To Tie Atop Leader Board
description: Lightning and thunder rolled across the TPC at Sawgrass in the first round of the Players Championship today, suspending play and stranding 69 golfers on the course. But before the unseasonable arrival of the foul weather, the wave that has been sweeping the game continued to flow across this former swamp.

title: Howard Wyeth, 51, A Rock Drummer
description: Howard Pyle Wyeth, a rock drummer and jazz pianist best known for working with Bob Dylan in the mid-1970's, died on Wednesday night at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nestle Reports Drop Of 10.2% in Net Profit
description: The Swiss food giant Nestle S.A. said its 1995 net profit declined 10.2 percent as the strong Swiss franc and higher coffee bean prices cut into earnings. The company reported net income of 2.92 billion francs ($2.45 billion), compared with 1994 income of 3.25 billion francs, which included a one-time gain of 306 million francs from the sale of cosmetics units. The fall was in line with analysts' expectations.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bills to Create Jobs Passed
description: Two bills intended to encourage companies to create new jobs in New Jersey were approved yesterday by the State Assembly and sent to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman for her signature.

title: Clinton Acts to Stem Public Housing Crime
description: President Clinton cleared the way today for a crackdown on crime that he said was intended to protect three million people who live in low-income apartments.

title: TENNIS;Ivanisevic Allows Chang Few Happy Returns
description: Here an ace, there an ace. Last night everything came up aces for Goran Ivanisevic, who has accumulated 620 this year. Moments after his expeditious 6-4, 6-3 elimination of fourth-seeded Michael Chang in their quarterfinal at the Lipton Championships, Ivanisevic vowed to set a record for aces that will "stand for another 200 years until the robots break it."

title: HOUSE APPROVES A BILL TO BROADEN HEALTH INSURANCE
description: The House tonight passed a bill to make health insurance more readily available to millions of Americans, but Republican hopes for bipartisan support crumbled as the White House assailed the measure and most House Democrats voted against it.

title: Art in Review
description: Dona Nelson 'Paradox Lake' Michael Klein 40 Wooster Street, near Grand Street SoHo Through April 6

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Devil in a Blue Dress 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $100.71. Laser disk, $34.95. 101 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MANVILLE TO PAY SPECIAL DIVIDEND AFTER SALE
description: The Manville Corporation said yesterday that it would pay a special dividend of $6 a share from the sale of its stake in the Riverwood International Corporation to a leveraged-buyout firm. Manville, a maker of building products, received $1.08 billion, or $20.25 a share, for its 83.3 percent stake in Riverwood, an Atlanta-based paper maker. The buyer was an investment group led by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, of New York. Manville said the special dividend, involving a total payout of $974 million, would be paid on April 12 to shareholders of record as of April 8. About $772 million of the dividend will be paid to the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust, which will use the proceeds to settle claims stemming from the asbestos business of Manville's predecessor, the Johns Manville Corporation. Also, Manville said its shareholders had approved the company's new name, the Schuller Corporation, which is expected to be effective today.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Brothers' Last Chance to Save Their Paradise
description: The calendar says March, but that's hard to believe. On the evidence of the amazing abundance of clever, adventurous American comedies that have arrived here during the last two weeks, it's looking like Christmas in July.

title: Cambodia Fighting
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Abdul-Rauf Sidelined by Sore Foot
description: MAHMOUD ABDUL-RAUF, whose refusal to stand for the national anthem brought a suspension as well as death threats, was placed on the injured list by the Denver Nuggets yesterday because of a sore left foot.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Show Decline For a 2d Day
description: The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for a second consecutive session, as market participants grew more pessimistic about the chances that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates again soon.

title: OPERA REVIEW;Meeting the Challenge of the Star-Crossed
description: Casting the leads in Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette" is a formidable challenge. Ideally, one wants a soprano with agile coloratura technique and vocal stamina, and a tenor whose voice has lyrical colorings yet heroic heft. With four extended love duets, the parts are draining. And then there is the matter of finding singers who look like Shakespeare's hormonal adolescents.

title: Advertisers Chase Young People in Cyberspace
description: Two fast-growing trends -- advertisers' use of computer sites reach consumers, and children's use of computers -- are combining to produce a new type of customer, the "cybertot," and a new concern for parents already worried about media influences on their children.

title: Accord to Buy L.I. Hotel
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Marriott Windwatch Hotel in Hauppauge, L.I., from the Colony Hill Associates, a private New York investment group, for $30 million.

title: Vatican Denounces Gay-Marriage Idea
description: The Vatican has appealed to voters not to support politicians who endorse same-sex marriages.

title: It's Money, Not Race, That Reigns in Hollywood
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEW POLICE COMMISSIONER: FINAL WORDS;Bratton, Leaving, Predicts Tension Will Stay
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton predicted yesterday that his successor, Howard Safir, would have his own share of trouble with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, saying that a certain amount of friction between the Police Department and City Hall was inevitable.

title: FINAL FOUR: SCOUTING;Stanford
description: West Regional Champion Overall Record: 29-2 Fifth Final Four appearance

title: News Analysis;Line-Item Veto: Less Than Meets The Eye
description: Representative Porter J. Goss, a Republican from Florida, called the line-item veto legislation that Congress sent to President Clinton today "a significant new weapon in our arsenal as we fight for a balanced budget."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- Advertising;Americans over 50 but under 65 may finally be getting some attention from Madison Avenue.
description: AMERICANS between the ages of 50 and 64 may finally be getting something their considerable spending power previously couldn't buy: a little respect from Madison Avenue.

title: FINAL FOUR: SCOUTING;Connectucut
description: Mideast Regional Champion Overall Record: 34-3 Thord Final Four Appearance

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Executives' Pay Gains Recall Booming 1980's The median salary and cash bonus of chief executives at dozens of the nation's largest corporations rose nearly 15 percent last year, a preliminary survey found, the fastest rate since the mid-1980's.

title: Evolution Measure Killed
description: The Tennessee Senate voted today to kill a bill that would have allowed school boards to dismiss teachers who tell students that evolution is fact. The bill, defeated 20 to 13, would have made the teaching of evolution as fact a form of insubordination.

title: Suit Says Schools Failed To Protect a Gay Student
description: The name-calling started when Jamie Nabozny was in the seventh grade and just beginning to understand that he was gay and how hard being yourself can be.

title: Slapp-Happy Companies
description: Corporate America complains that lawsuits are crippling productivity. Chrysler is seeking sanctions against lawyers who have filed unsuccessful class-action suits alleging that the company put faulty brakes in cars. A California referendum that would have capped fees for lawyers who represent injury victims was narrowly defeated on Tuesday. Under industry pressure, the Senate passed a tort reform bill limiting damages in lawsuits involving faulty products.

title: Fixed-Rate Mortgage Dips
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.69 percent this week, down from 7.81 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. It was the lowest since March 7, when rates averaged 7.38 percent. Rates had fallen to 6.94 percent on Feb. 15 -- a two-year low -- before rising to 7.83 percent on March 14.

title: Art in Review
description: Kathleen Schimert AC Project Room 15 Renwick Street, near Canal Street South Village Through April 13

title: Texas Joins Other States In Suing Tobacco Industry
description: Texas yesterday became the seventh state and the largest yet to sue the tobacco industry, seeking an end to advertising the state says is aimed at children, as well as more than $4 billion in compensation for Medicaid spending on tobacco-related illnesses since 1980.

title: ART REVIEW;When Chagall First Learned to Fly
description: YOU are excused if the name Marc Chagall makes you think first of Chagall Inc., purveyor of ethnic kitsch. During his later years, he did become a one-man industry, flooding the market with amiable, middlebrow confections. He died in 1985, at 98, in an almost all-encompassing nimbus of popular affection. But he had stopped being interesting long before that.

title: Yonkers Officer Suspended After He Is Charged in an Attack
description: A Yonkers police officer was suspended yesterday after he was charged with robbing and assaulting a 31-year-old black man near Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, in what the New York City police described as a possible bias attack.

title: COMPANY NEWS;C-TEC TO SELL SOME TELECOMMUNICATIONS ASSETS
description: The C-Tec Corporation, a telecommunications concern, agreed yesterday to sell some assets to a major shareholder, the RCN Corporation, for about $123 million. The assets to be sold include C-Tec International, which holds a 40 percent interest in Megacable, a cable television system operator in Mexico; Commonwealth Long Distance, a long-distance reseller, and the Residential Communications Network, a start-up that plans to provide telecommunications services. RCN owns 48.5 percent of C-Tec, which is based in Princeton, N.J. RCN is a unit of Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc. C-Tec is also planning to spin off its local telephone operations.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Clarifying Schumann
description: Andras Schiff played all Schumann at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night. Two hours of one distinctive and pervasive piano style, unrelieved by any other point of view, holds the threat of overkill. But in the right hands (and Mr. Schiff's are the right ones), sameness can become something better: call it reinforcement, or amplification. The more one heard on Wednesday, the clearer Schumann became. One saw the grace of the "Arabeske" and the flying fragments of the "Davidsbundlertanze" and "Symphonic Etudes" for what they are: microcosms of a great Romantic upheaval.

title: 750 Former I.B.M. Workers Sue I.R.S. for Taxing Severance Pay
description: A group of 750 former I.B.M. employees sued the Internal Revenue Service yesterday, contending that their severance payments should not have been taxed as wages.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's announcement that she was not interested in the Vice-Presidential nomination referred incorrectly to Senator Bob Dole's comments about potential running mates. Mr. Dole has not stated any preferences, and he has not named Gen. Colin L. Powell as his first choice.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER HAS A DROP IN PROFITS
description: Strawbridge & Clothier, a Philadelphia-based retailer, reported a sharp drop in fourth-quarter profits yesterday, and said it had received a takeover proposal from an undisclosed buyer. The company, which owns department stores, said the takeover bid could result in a tax-free distribution to shareholders valued at $20 a share, less than the company's recent trading price. The company's stock fell $1.875 yesterday, to $19.375, in Nasdaq trading. Strawbridge & Clothier's profits fell to $13.6 million, or $1.28 a share, in the quarter that ended on Feb. 3, from $20.3 million, or $1.93 a share, in the comparable quarter last year. Revenues slipped to $339.5 million from $347.4 million.

title: ON BASEBALL;Padres' Small Step South Reflects Game's Growing Interest in Mexico
description: When the Republicans gather in San Diego this summer to crown Bob Dole as their presidential candidate, they will also have to debate their stance on illegal immigration, including Patrick Buchanan's call for the building of a wall along the Mexican border.

title: Ousted Aide Gives Yeltsin His Support
description: Two months after he was abruptly forced out of office by President Boris N. Yeltsin, one of Russia's leading economic reformers has thrown his support behind the Russian leader.

title: It's Money, Not Race, That Reigns in Hollywood
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Casino Planning to Expand
description: The owners of the Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City said yesterday that they are developing plans for a $200 million addition, including as many as 700 hotel rooms and an expanded casino.

title: Stocks Are Little Changed, With Dow Gaining by 3.97
description: Stocks were little changed yesterday in quiet trading.

title: It's Money, Not Race, That Reigns in Hollywood
description: To the Editor:

title: Dutch Concern to Acquire Stop and Shop Chain
description: Royal Ahold N.V., the big Dutch grocery retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Stop and Shop Companies, the largest supermarket chain in New England, for $1.8 billion in cash.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED TECHNOLOGIES PLANS TO LAY OFF 1,200
description: The United Technologies Corporation's automotive-parts division said yesterday that it planned to close four plants and dismiss about 1,200 workers to reduce costs, because of increased competition. UT Automotive, based in Dearborn, Mich., supplies electrical and interior-trim parts for car and light-truck manufacturers. The plant closings, which were disclosed in The Wall Street Journal, are an effort to increase the company's operating profit margin and the layoffs represent about 10 percent of UT Automotive's United States work force, a UT Automotive spokesman, Michael Scholl, said. The plants to be closed are in Bennettsville and St. Matthews, S.C.; Morganfield, Ky., and Holland, Mich.

title: Minimum Pay Bill Falls Short in Senate
description: Republican desertions from Bob Dole's leadership today put a clear majority of the Senate behind increasing the minimum wage, but the House voted twice against considering the issue.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Love, Valour, Deja Vu

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Benn Will Fight Again
description: NIGEL BENN's retirement lasted 26 days. The British fighter grabbed the ring microphone to announce he was quitting after he lost his World Boxing Council supermiddleweight title to South Africa's THULANE (SUGAR BOY) MALINGA on March 2. He then dropped to one knee and proposed to his girlfriend, CAROLINE JONES.

title: FINAL FOUR: NOTEBOOK;Finals' Future Is Huge Arenas
description: Don't expect the Final Four to be held in a standard-size basketball arena anytime again soon. Even though he has no problem with the Continental Arena at the Meadowlands in New Jersey, the N.C.A.A. executive director, Cedric Dempsey, made it clear that domed stadiums are more likely to be selected in the future.

title: From Microsoft, Plans for a New Machine
description: The Microsoft Corporation, trying to maintain its dominance over computing standards, is about to mount a counterattack on the industry's quest for a $500 Internet computer.

title: FINAL FOUR: TV SPORTS;Aim Your Remote at the New Floor, an Old Vitale and a Map of Jersey
description: So you weren't one of the six fans who got tickets to the denouement of the college basketball season without being related to Governor Christine Todd Whitman, knowing the New Jersey Legislature or eloping with members of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: David Copperfield' at a California Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Colin S. Pittendrigh, 77, Biologist and Expert in Internal 'Clocks'
description: Colin S. Pittendrigh, one of the first scientists to perceive that "biological clocks" had a lot to do with the stress felt by jet travelers and the crankiness of night-shift workers, died on March 19 at his home in Bozeman, Mont. He was 77.

title: Market Place;Owners of preferred stock find a prize in the fine print in a merger.
description: TO some, it might look like a legal holdup. Others would call it a case of the squeaky wheel getting the bucks.

title: TCI Purchase of Viacom
description: Tele-Communications Inc. has disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its proposed $2.25 billion purchase of Viacom Inc.'s cable systems is "not yet probable." The companies are waiting for an Internal Revenue Service ruling on the sale. The deal's structure would allow Viacom to defer $500 million in capital gains taxes. A TCI spokeswoman said accounting rules prevent the company from declaring the purchase "probable" until it has a closing date.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 15 about Dr. A. Clifford Barger, emeritus professor of physiology at the Harvard Medical School, omitted the name of a survivor. She is his sister Cecille Barger Shure of Highland Park, Ill.

title: In Taiwan, a Mandate, but for What?
description: A week after this island's first presidential elections gave an overwhelming victory to President Lee Teng-hui, a new struggle has broken out over just what his mandate is: to pursue greater independence for Taiwan, or to reach accommodation with mainland China, perhaps as a prelude to eventual reunification.

title: About Real Estate;Renting Gains in North Manhattan
description: Lenders and building managers in the Inwood and Washington Heights sections of northern Manhattan say that because of the renewed rental market in the area and the growing willingness of banks to lend, apartment buildings are being rehabilitated at a pace not seen since the mid-1980's.

title: Cut in Math Program Is Reversed At the University of Rochester
description: The University of Rochester, which had planned to dismantle its graduate mathematics program as part of a larger move to cut costs, has reversed the decision after protests from scientists and educators around the country.

title: Grossman's To Close Stores
description: Grossman's Inc. said today that it would take a $40 million reorganization charge in the first quarter to close 60 of Grossman's stores and reduce its work force to 1,800 from 3,400.

title: THE NEW POLICE COMMISSIONER: THE OVERVIEW;Fire Commissioner To Take Over as Police Head
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed Fire Commissioner Howard Safir as the city's next police commissioner yesterday, consolidating his control over the nation's largest police department by turning to a trusted colleague with a long career in Federal law enforcement, although no experience in a municipal police force.

title: Inquiry Sees Nothing Unusual In Batch of Recalled Cigarettes
description: Federal health investigators said today that the eight billion cigarettes recalled by Philip Morris U.S.A. last year were no worse than any others and that the recall distracted attention from the real dangers of smoking.

title: Mobil Sued Over Tainted Water It Kept in Open Ponds at Plant
description: The Federal Government accused the Mobil Oil Corporation yesterday of having illegally stored contaminated water from its barge-cleaning operations in two large open-air waste ponds next to the Arthur Kill on Staten Island.

title: Sports of The Times;Before It Was the Final Four, Texas Western Made History
description: THEY didn't even call it the Final Four. That's one of the things Willie Worsley remembers from 1966. The N.C.A.A. did not have a copyright on the phrase, the newspapers seemed to have never heard of it, and Dick Vitale was not pneumatic-drilling it at us, baby.

title: Art in Review
description: Ray K. Metzker Laurence Miller Gallery 138 Spring Street SoHo Through April 13

title: FINAL FOUR: SCOUTING;Kentucky
description: Midwest Regional Champion Overall Record: 32-2 Eleventh Final Four Appearance

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;For Cigar's Entourage, 7,000 Miles to Reflect
description: With his bankroll standing at a record total of $7.6 million and his winning streak at 14 and counting, Cigar rested in Dubai yesterday before embarking on the return half of his 14,000-mile round trip to the Persian Gulf.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Legislator Charges Inaugural Money May Have Been Used Illegally
description: The chairman of an Assembly committee investigating the financing of Gov. George E. Pataki's inauguration said today that a preliminary inquiry has led the committee to conclude that as much as $700,000 more was raised than was spent on the inaugural. He charged that some excess money may have been illegally used to repay the Governor's campaign debts.

title: FINAL FOUR: SCOUTING;Mississippi St.
description: Southeast Regional Champion Overall Record: 26-7 First Final Four Appearance

title: INSIDE
description: Judges Defend Their Own

title: HOCKEY;Down the Stretch, Richter Is Raring to Go
description: The first baby steps were getting through a practice without pain, then through a game, then another, and now a third. Three games into comeback No. 2 from his seasonlong battle with groin injuries, Mike Richter looked like the man upon whom the Rangers will rely as the cornerstone for their drive to a second Stanley Cup in three years.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Profess No Concern After Gooden Gets Shelled
description: In his final start of spring training, Dwight Gooden, one of the projected cornerstones of the Yankees' pitching staff, continued to look more like a millstone today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Port Authority Crime Drops
description: Crime at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's airports, bus and marine terminals, PATH trains and the World Trade Center fell by an average of 6.4 percent in 1995, the sixth straight decrease, George J. Marlin, the agency's executive director, said yesterday.

title: FILM REVIEW;Brothers, Race and Reconciliation
description: In "A Family Thing," an earnest upbeat fable about the meaning of brotherhood in America, first-rate film acting infuses a contrived story with enough flesh, blood, wrinkles, warts and beads of sweat to make it intermittently surge to life.

title: No Headline
description: These executives are hard-working, driven guys, and if you give them $1 million instead of $10 million, they are still going to be very motivated." -- RICHARD FREEMAN, a labor economist, on chief executives' pay. [D8:1.]

title: Chronicle
description: Backstage at the St. James Theater on Broadway, right around the time "The King and I" opened on March 29, 1951, DOROTHY SARNOFF saw Yul Brynner pushing a wall very hard from a lunging position.

title: Wary Britons Turning Backs on Beef
description: No doubt it was a scene played out in countless grocery stores across Britain over the last week: An elderly man and his wife stood looking at the mountain of packaged beef in the Waitrose store on King's Road in Chelsea.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;49ers Sign Ex-Jet Johnson
description: JOHNNY JOHNSON, a onetime Pro Bowl running back who did not play last season after being cut by the Jets in a salary-cap move, was signed yesterday by the San Francisco 49ers in hopes he can revive the team's running game.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Tsongas Has Complication of Cancer Therapy
description: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts has developed a serious new complication of the therapy he received for cancer 10 years ago and was admitted to a Boston hospital yesterday, the hospital said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Canucks Replace Ley With Quinn
description: RICK LEY was fired yesterday as coach of the Vancouver Canucks with six games left in the regular season and replaced by the man who preceded him in the job, General Manager PAT QUINN.

title: Immigration Bill Advances in the Senate
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved legislation that would slightly increase the number of foreign-born relatives who can be brought into the country by American citizens and legal residents in the next decade. Most of the relatives would be wives and minor children.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Boston Market Unbundles Account
description: The Boston Market restaurant chain said yesterday that it had unbundled its account by naming three agencies to handle the creative part and another agency to handle the media planning and placement parts. The combined billings were estimated at $30 million. The J. Walter Thompson New York unit of the WPP Group had handled those parts until late last month, when that agency resigned from the account after only 10 months when Boston Market began talking to other agencies about added creative resources.

title: Power Agency Chief Resigns After Getting Plan Rolling
description: The leader of Gov. George E. Pataki's effort to dismantle the Long Island Lighting Company, James F. Gill, resigned today and is expected to be succeeded by Frank G. Zarb, a Wall Street executive who was Federal energy chief under President Gerald R. Ford.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Tax Cut Is Urged for Utilities
description: The Whitman administration yesterday proposed reducing the taxes paid by public utilities by 42 percent over five years. State Treasurer Brian W. Clymer and Herbert H. Tate Jr., chairman of the State Board of Public Utilities, said the change would reduce homeowners' energy tax bills by about 45 percent.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Strange Days 1995. Fox. $100.71. Laser disk, $49.98. 145 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Home-Loans Offer Is Rejected
description: A New Jersey consumer coalition that is seeking to block Fleet Financial Group's acquisition of NatWest Bank rejected a settlement offer yesterday that would have provided $475 million in home loans to low- and moderate-income people, a spokeswoman for the coalition said.

title: FINAL FOUR;States Put Aside Their Rivalry And Try a Little Cooperation
description: New York and New Jersey may raid each other for businesses, squabble over Port Authority resources, litigate over proprietorship of the Statue of Liberty and feud over the peculiar residency of the Jets and the Giants, two carpetbagging "New York" teams who play in East Rutherford.

title: Big Executive At Wal-Mart Taking Reins At Blockbuster
description: In an effort to revitalize its giant home-video business, Viacom is expected to name a top executive of Wal-Mart as chief executive of the Blockbuster Entertainment Group.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volkswagen Reports Doubling of Income
description: The German auto maker Volkswagen A.G. reported yesterday that its net income more than doubled in 1995 to 336 million marks, or about $227 million, as sales improved by 10 percent. Earnings per share rose to 22 marks, or about $14.80, up from 9.50 marks in 1994. Sales improved to 88 billion marks, or about $59 billion, in 1995. The earnings gain was mainly due to new valuations of fixed and current assets.

title: G.O.P. and Democrats Stoke Partisan Embers
description: His nomination now assured, Senator Bob Dole performed a quadrennial political ritual today, gathering friends and rivals to assault the opposition's candidate and remind his own party that he is now the candidate of all its members. Or is, as Mr. Dole put it, "a party animal."

title: FILM REVIEW;Bilko With a Sneaky 90's Glee
description: The Golden Age of television never got any more golden than Phil Silvers as Sgt. Ernie Bilko, pricelessly conning and weaseling his way through the Fort Baxter motor pool. Irreplaceable in his own day (and unthinkable as a movie star in this one), the bald, bespectacled, adorably dimpled Mr. Silvers has inspired a glossier heir. Steve Martin steps with surprising ease into a dangerously sacrosanct role.

title: HOCKEY;Michigan Will Face Colorado College
description: An overtime goal so messy that it was questioned by the losing coach produced a 4-3 victory for Colorado College over Vermont today in a long but compelling semifinal game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I hockey tournament.

title: FINAL FOUR: WOMEN'S PREVIEW;They're Defending Champions. And 34-3. And, Yes, Underdogs.
description: When you race through a basketball season with an unbeaten record (35-0) and a national championship, what do you do for an encore? Maybe win another national championship, as the Connecticut women will try to do here this weekend in the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Confession Shown at Slaying Trial
description: In a videotaped confession played yesterday at his murder trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, an escaped mental patient appeared casual and matter-of-fact as he told the police how he pushed a 63-year-old woman in front of a subway train to her death.

title: Merrill Lynch Quits Russian Treasury Bill Deal
