description: Merrill Lynch & Company has dropped out of a planned offering of $500 million of Russian treasury bills to foreign investors, a senior Russian central bank official said today.

title: It's Money, Not Race, That Reigns in Hollywood
description: To the Editor:

title: TV WEEKEND;How Much Is the Life of an Elephant Worth?
description: Just as you're settling into "Deadly Game," the latest report on the perennial cause of saving the African elephant, an unusual thing happens. Two hunters come along with the argument that by killing elephants, they are bettering the lives of Africa's humans.

title: Chemical Bank to Arrange $3.7 Billion Kmart Credit
description: The Kmart Corporation said today that Chemical Bank had agreed to provide $3.7 billion in credit, enabling the struggling retailer to clear its largest financial hurdle.

title: Easy for Companies To Hire Foreigners
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;PARKER & PARSLEY IS SELLING AUSTRALIAN ASSETS
description: The Parker & Parsley Petroleum Company said yesterday that it was selling its Australian oil and gas assets for about $240.3 million. Santos Ltd. said it had already bought most of the company's minority interests in various projects for about $155 million. Parker & Parsley, based in Midland, Tex., said it had an agreement with an unidentified buyer to sell the remaining asset, its 22.5 percent stake in a gas discovery in the Timor Sea, northwest of Australia.

title: U.S. Helicopter Sale to Turkey Hits Snag
description: When Turkey asked to buy 10 Cobra attack helicopters nearly a year ago, the request seemed certain to sail through the Pentagon, State Department and White House. The only objections came from human rights advocates, whose concerns are typically overridden in such cases.

title: New Jobless Claims Surge, but Strike is Cited
description: The number of new claims for jobless benefits surged by 43,000 last week to the highest level in nearly four years, lifted by applications from workers affected by the General Motors Corporation strike, which has been settled.

title: City Kills 6 Contracts With Queens Agency
description: New York City officials yesterday canceled six more city contracts held by a Queens social service agency, a day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered two contracts worth $43 million jettisoned because of irregularities in their awarding.

title: Dr. Warren Wetzel, Trauma Surgeon, 47
description: Dr. Warren Wetzel, a surgeon specializing in the treatment of snakebites and other physical traumas, died on Sunday at his home in the Bronx. He was 47.

title: Restaurants
description: You could get lost in Cafe Centro. The bustling brasserie feels as vast as New York, a crossroads sort of place where a person could disappear in the crowd.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;As Knicks Find Way, Mason Speaks Out
description: Some people say that Anthony Mason is only happy when he is unhappy and that love him or loathe him, Mason is Mason. Deal with it.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;International Herald Tribune Is Getting a New Top Editor
description: John Vinocur, the executive editor of The International Herald Tribune, said yesterday that he would step down from the post that he has held for 10 years.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Reviews/Fashion;Designing Clothes Women Actually Wear
description: Does the fact that elite designers are now doing clothes for real people mean everyone's copying Ellen Tracy?

title: NYC;A Potent Cure For the Terrors Of Rural Living
description: YOU may have to squint hard to find it, but there is a thin silver lining for New York City residents in a House vote the other day to make Uzis and AK-47's acceptable items for the home. The Congressional debate offers an opportunity to appreciate anew how much safer the city has become, whether thanks are owed to the departing Police Commissioner, the Mayor, plain luck or all of the above.

title: U.S. and China End Trade Negotiations
description: China and the United States ended three days of talks with little progress in a dispute over illegal third-country shipments of Chinese textiles, both sides said today.

title: Congress Sends President a Bill To End Farmers' Price Supports
description: Congress gave final approval early today to farm legislation that would end price-based subsidies and government planting controls that have been the basis of farm policy since the Depression.

title: Chronicle
description: Forget the winter that refuses to die.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: Corrections
description: A caption on Tuesday with a picture by The Associated Press showing the visit of Hillary Rodham Clinton to Bosnia omitted the identity of a man shown with her on a stage in Tuzla. He was Secretary of the Army Togo West.

title: Abroad at Home;Thumb on the Scales
description: In the American dream, law is the great equalizer. Rich and poor alike can seek their rights in court -- and obtain what the motto inscribed on the pediment of the Supreme Court building promises: Equal Justice Under Law.

title: Brazil to Auction Rail Concession
description: Brazil will auction a concession to run a stretch of its federal rail system on June 14 for a minimum price of 316.9 million reais ($323.4 million), officials said today.

title: Lithuania Grants Rights to Minorities
description: To the Editor:

title: FINAL FOUR: SCOUTING;SYRACUSE
description: West Regional Champion Overall Record: 28-8 Third Final Fout Appearance

title: Executive Changes
description: COMPUSERVE CORP., Columbus, Ohio, a unit of H& R Block Inc.,, named Steven P. Stanbrook to the new position of president of the on-line service's international operations. He was most recently president and chief executive of Sara Lee Bakery in Chicago, which is owned by Sara Lee Corp.

title: 25 and Under
description: Pao is not just a Portuguese restaurant, it's a cultural mission.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;In the Shadow of the Stalinist Terror
description: DUST AND ASHES By Anatoly Rybakov Translated by Antonina W. Bouis 473 pages. Little, Brown. $24.95.

title: Debt and Line-Item-Veto Bills Approved
description: In a compromise acceptable to both the White House and Republican conservatives, Congress today approved a package of legislation that would increase the Federal Government's borrowing authority to $5.5 trillion and would give the President expanded control over spending decisions.

title: In America;Madness as Usual
description: The police report of March 5, 1990, refers to the arrival of a "DOA," a male black, approximately 5 years old, at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital in the Bronx. When cops first saw the boy, he was lying face up on a table in the emergency room. His body, which weighed only 35 pounds, was covered with thick welts, severe lacerations and deep ugly bruises. His head and lips were battered and swollen, as if he'd been in a prizefight.

title: UNVEILED POWER: A special report.;Pakistani Leader Takes Tough New Tack
description: When Benazir Bhutto returned to power in Pakistan 30 months ago, she told friends that she had learned a lesson from her first, troubled stint as Prime Minister: Not to be swayed by critics who would like Pakistan, with its history of military coups and political violence, to be governed in the gentler traditions of Western democracies.

title: Agency Agrees to Help Close Budget Gap
description: The state's Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday agreed to give New York City $125 million to help close a gap in this year's budget, but only after extracting a promise from city officials that they would find ways to cut future budgets by an equal amount.

title: Home Video
description: Logistical Hurdles

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: The Mayor's New Police Commissioner
description: For those steeped in the proud and insular traditions of New York City's uniformed services, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's decision to appoint the Fire Commissioner as head of the Police Department must have seemed a little like naming an admiral to run West Point. But Fire Commissioner Howard Safir, who still has a business and family home in Maryland, is not actually aligned to either service. His career has mainly been in Federal law enforcement. He is above all else a trusted Giuliani loyalist whose friendship with the Mayor goes back more than 20 years.

title: FINAL FOUR: WOMEN;Rizzotti Named A.P. Player of Year
description: Jen Rizzotti, the 5-foot-5-inch point guard who led Connecticut into the Final Four this weekend, was named the women's college basketball Player of the Year today by The Associated Press.

title: On My Mind;The Making of an Anti
description: The dictatorship of the Communist Party is maintained by recourse to every form of violence."

title: BASEBALL;Puckett Having Vision Trouble
description: The Minnesota Twins slugger Kirby Puckett reported vision problems today and underwent tests, but it was too early to tell whether his problem was serious.

title: Anger Over Effort to Disinter An Infant of Mixed Race
description: Southern Baptist officials today denounced efforts by leaders of a small south Georgia church to disinter the body of a mixed-race baby who was buried last week in the church's all-white cemetery.

title: Judges Defend A Colleague From Attacks
description: In an extraordinary public statement by sitting judges, four leading members of the Federal appeals court in Manhattan defended another judge yesterday against criticism from President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, saying that political attacks on the judge's ruling in a drug case "threaten to weaken the constitutional structure of this nation."

title: Art in Review
description: Judith Joy Ross James Danziger Gallery 130 Prince Street SoHo Through April 6

title: Most Doctors With Violations Keep Their License
description: Of the more than 13,000 doctors in the United States who have been disciplined for serious incompetence or misconduct, most retain their licenses and continue to treat patients, according to a study by a Washington health group.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Till Death Do Them Part, Again
description: Happy endings can spring a leak; ever after can mean one week," Stephen Sondheim wrote in the mid-1960's. The lyrics, penned for the musical "Do I Hear a Waltz?," summed up a view of marriage that was becoming increasingly fashionable in the American theater. This was, after all, the era of Edward Albee's "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?," and August Strindberg had suddenly replaced James M. Barrie as the model for domestic portraiture.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Comet Hyakutake misidentified the instrument that received a radar signal bounced off the comet by the Goldstone Tracking Station in California. It was an antenna operated by Jet Propulsion Laboratory scientists at Goldstone, not the Very Large Array radiotelescope in New Mexico.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Operating Earnings Drop at Bertelsmann
description: Bertelsmann A.G., the German media giant, said yesterday that its operating earnings fell 16 percent in the first six months of its current fiscal year. Still, the company said it expected to report a profit for the full year, which ends on June 30.

title: An Endless Winter Takes Yet Another Curtain Call
description: Robins, crocuses and early-budding daffodils took a dusting across much of the region last night, as did millions of winter-battered psyches. Pete Flynn, head groundskeeper at Shea Stadium, said a little prayer.

title: Editorial Notebook;Are the Mad Cows Bad Cows?
description: Mad cow disease may destroy the British beef industry, topple the Government of John Major and slow the push toward European cooperation. But the most maddening thing about this waning animal epidemic is the great uncertainty about whether it poses a major or trivial threat to the health of those eating British beef.

title: G.O.P. Chairman, Train Conductor And 'Regular Guy';Blues-Playing Union Man Leads Party in Connecticut
description: Chris DePino concedes that he may not be the most typical Republican state chairman Connecticut has had: an Italian-American, Roman Catholic city-dweller who proudly shows off his union card from his job as a Metro-North train conductor.

title: INTERNATION BUSINESS;Alcatel Posts a $5.2 Billion Loss for 1995
description: Europe's largest manufacturer of telecommunications equipment, Alcatel Alsthom S.A. of France, announced yesterday that it had losses of $5.2 billion in 1995, a number that represents the largest one-year corporate deficit in French history.

title: ON AUTO RACING;Slow It Down to Count Indy's Cars
description: No one should believe the propaganda coming from either side in the Indy-car war. But when the Championship Auto Racing Teams car owners claim that their boycott of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway will make it difficult to cobble together a respectable lineup for the Indianapolis 500, you can overlook the folly of their plan to run a race the same day long enough to agree with them.

title: Raise Gasoline Tax. Wipe Out Deficit.
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;WATERS AGREES TO THE PURCHASE OF TA INSTRUMENTS
description: The Waters Corporation has agreed to buy TA Instruments Inc., a maker of analytical instruments, for $84 million. TA Instruments, of New Castle, Del., makes devices used by companies to test physical characteristics of polymers and related materials. The tests can be used in research and development to test properties like durability in plastic automobile bumpers. TA Instruments has been owned by a group led by management and Chase Capital Partners since 1990. Waters, a maker of liquid-based analytical instruments, has annual sales of about $333 million, while TA Instruments has sales of $47 million.

title: Is the House of Lords Next?;Britain Plans to Sell 60,000 Military Dwellings
description: In the continuing garage sale that has marked the British Government's exit from the business world over the last 15 years, the latest item up for grabs is a collection of some 60,000 rather ordinary houses and apartments scattered on and around military bases throughout England and Wales.

title: Syracuse Company Is Accused of Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has sued Bennett Funding Group Inc. of Syracuse, accusing it of running a Ponzi scheme by using money from later investors to pay back earlier investors.

title: Illegal Aliens Set Fire in Riot at Navy Brig
description: Illegal immigrants jailed in a Navy brig burned several mattresses today, panicking nearly 200 inmates and causing a disturbance that shut down the base.

title: Whitman Says Talk Of Running Hurt State
description: Almost every time Gov. Christine Todd Whitman left New Jersey in the last year, she confronted the Question.

title: Dow Loses 43.71 in Flurry Fueled by Program Trading
description: A flurry of computer-guided sell orders caused the Dow Jones industrial average to fall sharply in the final half-hour of trading yesterday, the last session of the first quarter. Other market indicators were mixed.

title: Leader of Fire Union To Head Department
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed the president of the city's firefighters' union, Thomas J. Von Essen, as fire commissioner yesterday. It was the first time a labor leader has ever moved into the Fire Department's top post.

title: State Comptroller Urges Albany To Reject M.T.A. Spending Plan
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall yesterday urged the New York State Legislature to reject the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's capital spending plan, charging that it relies too heavily on borrowed money and fiscal uncertainties, and could lead to less service and higher fares.

title: People Want to Fight Drugs. Do Our Leaders?;Eliminate the Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;MCDONALD'S SEEKING PERMISSON TO TRIPLE SHARES
description: The McDonald's Corporation will ask shareholders to allow the company to almost triple the number of its common shares, to 3.5 billion from 1.25 billion, preliminary proxy material shows. The fast-food giant said it was seeking the increase to have the flexibility to declare stock splits or stock dividends or to make acquisitions or financings. The company's proxy material notes that without an increase in authorized shares, McDonald's would be unable to make a 2-for-1 split. Since going public in 1965 McDonald's has split its common stock 11 times, most recently in 1988. McDonald's stock was down $1 a share yesterday, at $48.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FIGURE SKATING;Bankruptcy for Hamill
description: DOROTHY HAMILL, the women's figure-skating gold medalist in the 1976 Winter Games, has filed for bankruptcy after a series of financial setbacks. Hamill, 39, filed for Chapter 11 protection in United States Bankruptcy Court in Santa Ana, Calif., on Thursday, seeking to reorganize her finances, said her lawyer, CRAIG H. MILLET.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pechiney Returned To Profitability in 1995
description: The French aluminum and packaging giant Pechiney CIP said yesterday that it swung back to profit in 1995 and forecast more improvement this year, provided sales volume picked up in the second half. Pechiney reported a profit of 1.465 billion French francs, or $290 million, after a loss of 3.181 billion francs in 1994. The profit included 730 million francs from the sale of assets. The 1994 loss was after a one-time write-down of good will of 2.8 billion francs. Reuters

title: Keep Bank Ads True and Useful
description: Congressional Republicans are preparing to disfigure a valuable law that protects consumers from deceptive bank practices. The 1991 Truth in Savings Act requires banks to report yields on deposit accounts in ways that are not only accurate but also helpful for comparison shopping. Banks say the rules are complicated and costly. But rather than making reasonable changes, the House and Senate banking committees have eliminated core protections.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Easter music in Weekend yesterday omitted the times for two programs at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, Manhattan. On Wednesday, an all-Mozart program begins at 8 P.M.; on Easter Sunday, the afternoon service, with works by Byrd and Vaughan Williams, is at 5 P.M.

title: New York Can't Afford to Ignore Lead Paint
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Can't Afford to Ignore Lead Paint
description: To the Editor:

title: Aqueduct Loses Another Day
description: On the eve of New York's first prep race for the Kentucky Derby, the city got an old reminder of the cruelty of winter weather in the springtime yesterday when jockeys rode one race and then quit for the day because snowfall was making the track at Aqueduct too slippery.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EVEREN CAPITAL AGREES TO SELL ITS BETA SYSTEMS
description: The Everen Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Beta Systems Inc. unit to Thomson Financial Services for $63.5 million. Beta, based in Brookfield, Wis., is a securities processing and quotations service for brokers, banks and mutual funds. It will retain its name and continue to operate from Brookfield after the acquisition. Everen, a Chicago-based, employee-owned company, also owns Everen Securities Inc., formerly known as Kemper Securities Inc. The Toronto-based Thomson, which operates 38 financial information businesses, has annual sales of about $600 million. It is a subsidiary of the publisher and travel company. The Thomson Corporation has annual revenues of about $7 billion.

title: POP REVIEW;A Drummer's Subtleties
description: Drummers sometimes define themselves by the sound of their ride cymbal, and Joe Chambers, who is playing at Visiones through today, keeps his ringing with a big, open sound. Mr. Chambers is one of jazz's great living drummers, and one of the better composers to arrive during the 1960's.

title: News-Hungry Visitors Invade a Town
description: On Main Street, sleek satellite uplink trucks park next to battered pickups, some of which have a deer shot out of season thrown in the back.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Taiheiyo Bank of Japan to Be Liquidated
description: Four Japanese banks have agreed to liquidate the ailing Taiheiyo Bank and establish a new bank to take over its operations, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: Standoff With Militants Is High-Stakes Experiment
description: A five-day standoff between the F.B.I. and about two dozen armed anti-government militants in Montana has turned into a high-stakes experiment for Louis J. Freeh, the agency's Director, and for other law-enforcement institutions struggling to find a less-confrontational approach to potentially violent groups, experts say.

title: Mayoral Commission Offers Qualified Praise on Police Anti-CorruptionDrive
description: A mayoral commission praised "significant improvements" in the New York City Police Department's anti-corruption efforts yesterday but said there still were important deficiencies, including the lack of a mechanism to hold commanders accountable in fighting corruption.

title: No Headline
description: This is weird, really weird."

title: Citibank's Records Examined As Part of Mexican Inquiry
description: Federal law-enforcement agencies recently subpoenaed sheaves of records from Citibank's New York offices in an effort to assist Mexico with its investigation of Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of Mexico's former President, according to Government officials and bankers.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Navigation for the Directionally Challenged
description: President Clinton approved guidelines today that allow expanded commercial and civilian use of the Pentagon's satellite-navigation system, a move that will let pilots, motorists and others better pinpoint their location anywhere on earth.

title: About New York;A Jaded City Finds a Taste For Iowa Corn
description: IN honor of the premiere of "State Fair," horses, prize beef and ranch-bred critters were on display outside the Music Box Theater. Had the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical celebration of Iowa's summer ritual stirred some dormant rustic cravings among suave urbanites?

title: Product Liability Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: To venture into an obscure grand slam in the knowledge that the obvious small slam is likely to fail is a rare event, requiring a high level of bidding skill. But to do so after mentally projecting the play, aware that one lead will be killing but is unlikely to be forthcoming, may be unique.

title: Hartford Lawmaker Would Sell Stake in Lottery to Pension Fund
description: Connecticut's Speaker of the House, Thomas D. Ritter, proposed a twist today on Gov. John G. Rowland's plan to sell a $160 million stake in the Connecticut lottery to private investors: let the state sell it to itself.

title: Motor Wheel Plans to Merge With Hayes Wheels
description: The Motor Wheel Corporation agreed to buy Hayes Wheels International Inc. today for $560 million in cash and stock.

title: The Chief Exits to Applause
description: The ugliness with the Mayor notwithstanding, it wasn't a bad exit for the Irish immigrant with nearly three decades on the job, four stars to his credit and a suddenly uncertain future. John F. Timoney yesterday was on a stage, and there was a crowd of cops in front of him, standing and cheering.

title: Indonesian Fire Kills 78
description: Hospital officials said today that the death toll in a fire that swept a shopping center on Thursday had risen to 78.

title: On Cameras in Supreme Court, Souter Says, 'Over My Dead Body'
description: The subject was allowing cameras into the Supreme Court, and Justice David H. Souter minced no words.

title: Young Voters, Diverse and Disillusioned, Are Unpredictable in '96 Race
description: Their first memories of politics are of the Reagan era. They only glimpsed the end of the cold war. And they have no unifying experience like the anti-Vietnam movement of the 1960's.

title: Russia Agrees to Closer Links With Three Ex-Soviet Lands
description: In an effort to tap popular nostalgia for the former Soviet Union, President Boris N. Yeltsin signed an agreement today to forge closer ties with Kazakstan, Kyrgyzstan and Belarus.

title: Cannon Fodder
description: While much of the world shuns British cows, a Cambodian newspaper suggested today that the animals be shipped to Cambodia and allowed to roam free to detonate the millions of land mines littering the country.

title: Albert L. Kraus, 75, Financial Journalist
description: Albert L. Kraus, editor emeritus of The Journal of Commerce and a former editor and financial reporter at The New York Times, died yesterday at his home in Westfield, N.J., his wife, Patricia, said.

title: Company Briefs
description: MICROPOLIS CORP., Chatsworth, Calif., which makes high- performance disk drives used to record information, sold its disk-drive business to Singapore Technologies Industrial Corp. for $55 million.

title: No Longer Judicially Sacred, Grand Jury Is Under Review
description: District attorneys in the Bronx, upstate and suburban New York are quietly finding ways to sidestep the grand jury system, citing the cost and inconvenience of finding 23 people who will serve between one and six months to determine whether suspects should be charged with committing a felony.

title: FINAL FOUR: WOMEN;UConn's Title Dreams Ended By Semifinal Loss to Tennessee
description: Before the game, the Tennessee mascot held up two signs.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Price Posts Sharp Rise; No Signs of an Easing in Demand
description: Corn prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after an Agriculture Department report showed that strong demand for livestock feed and exports had left inventories worrisomely low.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Greystone Seeks Nurses
description: Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital, long criticized as overcrowded and understaffed, has begun interviewing job applicants to add 40 nurses and orderlies, John McKeegan, a spokesman for the State Department of Human Services, said yesterday. First crack at the jobs will go to current part-time workers and to applicants applying from another state hospital, Marlboro, where the number of patients is declining. Last month, state officials appointed a four-member team to run Grey stone after four male employees were arrested on charges of sexually assaulting female patients, and after a patient committed suicide while staff members slept. The hospital's chief executive, George A. Waters Jr., was dismissed earlier this month.

title: Europeans Pledge to Help Britain Fight Cow Disease
description: Seeking to defuse a dispute that threatened to drive Britain away from a united Europe, European leaders today promised Britain financial aid to combat mad cow disease and reclaim its export market in beef.

title: Bucharest Journal;Putting Best Face on Dictator's Folly
description: What to do with one of the world's biggest, gaudiest and ugliest buildings?

title: People Want to Fight Drugs. Do Our Leaders?
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Opposition Chief Making Comeback
description: After the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin in November, it seemed there was nothing Benjamin Netanyahu could say that Israelis cared to hear.

title: Jan. 31 Rate Cut Unanimous at Fed
description: Federal Reserve policy makers, confronted with signs of a slowing economy, were unanimous in lowering a key lending rate at their Jan. 31 meeting, minutes of the session disclosed today.

title: Samuel Schoenbaum, 69, Expert on Shakespeare
description: Samuel Schoenbaum, a scholar who helped stitch together a picture of Shakespeare's life by sifting records and documents gathering dust in Stratford-on-Avon and other English archives, died on Wednesday at George Washington Hospital in Washington. He was 69 and lived within walking distance of the Folger Shakespeare Library on Capitol Hill, where he drew his inspiration.

title: FINAL FOUR;A Game to Decide Who Is the Top Underdog
description: Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said he was happy to be here at the Final Four, preparing his team for the opening game Saturday against Mississippi State. He said he wasn't going to whine about anything. Then he produced his best smile to prove his point.

title: HOCKEY;Brodeur to Face Penguins
description: Martin Brodeur sat in the stands as his teammates skated through a 60-minute practice today. The Devils were glad to hear that there was no danger of their No. 1 goaltender missing Saturday afternoon's game here against the Penguins.

title: Bonds End the First Quarter on Upbeat Note
description: The bond market ended the first quarter yesterday on a positive note, as buyers emerged and prices rose.

title: Intelligence Experts Meet to Combat Mideast Terrorism
description: In a follow-up to the Middle East summit meeting at Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, political and intelligence experts from 29 countries and organizations, including Israel and the Palestinian Authority, met today at the State Department to draft specific recommendations to fight terrorism.

title: Religion Journal;An Effort to Restore Jewish Memory
description: If the Holocaust is understood as not just an attack on Europe's Jews but on their history as well, then Aaron Ziegelman's project is an effort to restore a portion of Jewish memory and reverse some of the Nazis' destruction.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Goddess and Goof United As the Perfect Soul Mates
description: Oh, why not just go on and say it? As the love goddess who fell to earth in the charming concert version of "One Touch of Venus," the latest offering from the Encores series at City Center, Melissa Errico is, in a word, divine.

title: FILM REVIEW;Angels on a Tough Mission From the Yard in the Sky
description: Contrary to its title, "All Dogs Go to Heaven 2," not every canine in the film ends up perched on a fluffy cloud, smiling beatifically, a halo floating over its head. Near the end of this sequel to the 1989 animated film, one of its scruffier doggie characters actually joins the scarlet-faced feline devil in the underworld. Maybe a better title would have been "All Dogs Go to Heaven but One."

title: How 3 Young Voters See the Election and the Choices
description: April Smith, 21 'Clinton Is the Lesser Of Two Evils'

title: Bill Goldsworthy, 51, Longtime N.H.L. Star, Dies
description: Bill Goldsworthy, an original member of the Minnesota North Stars and a five-time National Hockey League All-Star, died this morning of complications from AIDS. He was 51.

title: Review/Fashion;Praises to Sing Amid the Din
description: On the one hand, there's the music: loud and pulsating. On the other hand, there are the clothes: calm and quiet. There lies the dichotomy in many fashion shows, most notably the current fall collections: designers seem to think that raucous music will make perfectly nice clothes look exciting. But they can't fool the professionals in the audience, the fashion press and retailers who know what's exciting when they see it.

title: Aide Denies Pataki's Fund Was Misused
description: An aide to Gov. George E. Pataki said today that none of the money donated to cover the governor's inauguration and transition expenses was siphoned off to pay his campaign debts.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Plan No Early Trade
description: The Yankee hierarchy held a 45-minute meeting tonight and decided not to make a trade heading into Monday's regular-season opener at Cleveland.

title: Guilty Plea in Effort to Bomb I.R.S. Office
description: One of two men charged with trying to bomb the Internal Revenue Service building here has pleaded guilty to all three counts against him, including a count of using explosives in the commission of a crime, which means a mandatory 30 years in prison.

title: Mobil Denies Pollution Charges
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said yesterday that it would vigorously contest a lawsuit by the Federal Government accusing the corporation of having illegally stored contaminated waste water on Staten Island.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RALSTON PURINA TO SPIN OFF ANIMAL FEED UNIT
description: The Ralston Purina Company said yesterday that it planned to split its international animal feed business into a separate company, reflecting its desire to focus on selling pet food and Eveready batteries to consumers. Ralston sold its domestic animal feed business in 1986. The international segment had sales of $1.12 billion and earnings from operations of $45.2 million last year. The St. Louis-based Ralston said the spinoff might take up to a year to complete and was contingent upon a favorable tax ruling and final approval by Ralston's board. The transaction is meant to be tax free to current shareholders.

title: Mayor Forces Out Bratton's Aide After His Criticism
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered the First Deputy Police Commissioner, John F. Timoney, yesterday to leave the force immediately, after Mr. Timoney criticized the Mayor for his choice of Howard Safir as the new Police Commissioner.

title: President of Boston U. Quits To Become Its Chancellor
description: John R. Silber, the outspoken president of Boston University, announced yesterday that he would resign from the position he has held for more than a quarter of a century on May 31 and take a newly created post as chancellor of the university.

title: Journal;The Fetal Position
description: The moment the primary dust settled, the conventional wisdom did too: Bob Dole and Bill Clinton are both moderate, split-the-difference pragmatists (or is it opportunists?) who hardly differ on the issues. In the end, so this oft-repeated formulation goes, the country's choice will all boil down to character. Do we want the steady old guy with the heroic war record or the restless boomer who didn't serve? The candidate whose troubled first marriage ended in divorce or the one who patched his troubled marriage up?

title: HOCKEY: NOTEBOOK;Gopher Is Player of Year
description: Brian Bonin of Minnesota, a high-scoring forward as well as a high-scoring student, was today named the winner of the Hobey Baker Award, the prize that goes to college hockey's player of the year.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Hazzard Has Surgery
description: WALT HAZZARD, who coached and played at U.C.L.A. and spent 10 years in the National Basketball Association, underwent surgery yesterday at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center to replace a faulty heart valve. The 53-year-old former guard suffered a stroke last week.

title: The Ripoff Continues
description: Theft and featherbedding by public school custodians in New York City were supposed to be controlled by reforms imposed by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the State Legislature in recent years. But a report from a special investigator, Edward Stancik, shows that stronger action is needed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Toyota Sets A Buyback Of Its Stock
description: In a highly unusual move, the Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would spend up to $1 billion to buy back its own stock.

title: For $125 Million Cash, City Cedes Budget Control
description: In exchange for an immediate cash infusion of $125 million from the Municipal Assistance Corporation to close this year's budget gap, the Giuliani administration has accepted the corporation's demand to cut projected city spending by $125 million for each of the next four fiscal years, according to details of the agreement made public yesterday.

title: Bungling Privatization
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's plan to make New York City's Home Relief welfare program more cost-efficient started out swimmingly. The city social workers' union agreed to loosen work rules if the work stayed inside the Human Resources Administration. This is the sort of outcome the reinventing-government crowd likes best -- jobs are saved, costs go down. Then City Hall moved on to stage two -- the full privatization of two smaller programs within Home Relief, which provides benefits for 250,000 single adults. Everything fell apart.

title: Let Staten Island's Dump Go on Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Big Dutch Insurer Posts Record Earnings
description: Aegon N.V., the largest independent Dutch insurance company, said yesterday that it had record profits in 1995 and reiterated its commitment to grow through cautious acquisitions.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SOUTHERN NATIONAL TO ACQUIRE REGIONAL ACCEPTANCE
description: The Southern National Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Regional Acceptance Corporation, a provider of used-car loans, in a stock transaction valued at about $167 million. Southern National will exchange 0.3929 of a share for each share of Regional Acceptance, which would value Regional Acceptance at about $11 a share. Southern National, a banking company, will issue slightly more than six million shares in the transaction. Regional Acceptance, based in Greenville, N.C., has 27 branches in North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia.

title: INSIDE
description: Big Surge in Trade Deficit

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Gun Limits for Police Director
description: The city's embattled Police Director, William R. Celester, can continue to carry a concealed weapon, but only while on duty, a state judge ruled yesterday. Anthony J. Pope, Mr. Celester's lawyer, said the ruling might be appealed, since "the risk to his life is serious enough to warrant a 24-hour carry permit," The Associated Press reported. Mr. Celester has been on administrative leave since November, when Federal agents raided his home and office in an investigation of Newark city government. Mr. Celester is to return to work next week -- not running the Police Department, but supervising an effort to reduce violence in housing projects.

title: GOLF;The Unknown Leader Du Jour Is Tolles
description: It's a different day and it's a different name but it's the same story. Stop us if you've heard this before, but a relatively obscure golf professional who has not won on the PGA Tour is leading a field filled with the biggest names in golf. Well, at least it used to be filled with them, but more on that later.

title: Abbott Laboratories to Buy Medisense for $876 Million
description: Moving to extend its leadership in the medical diagnostics market, Abbott Laboratories said today that it had agreed to pay $45 a share, or $876 million, to acquire Medisense Inc., a leading maker of kits that allow diabetes patients to test their blood glucose levels.

title: Cow Disease Sparks Voluntary Rules on Feed
description: Reacting to the mad cow disease epidemic in Britain, the United States livestock industry and veterinary medical groups said last night that they will immediately establish a voluntary ban on the use of cattle and sheep parts in animal feed.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks' Confidence Keeps On Increasing
description: Since becoming the Knicks' head coach, Jeff Van Gundy has talked about playing strong defense and dominating games at home. Obviously, the Knicks have listened.

title: For Muslims In Bosnia: Harsh War, Harsh Peace
description: Azemina Besic grabbed the homemade shotgun from a village man with surprising agility for a 70-year-old woman.

title: Fat Flakes of Spring Snow Ring Up a Record
description: Floating down in flakes as big as silver dollars, snow cloaked the region once again yesterday, allowing Newark to join the company of cities with record snowfalls and setting yet another standard for New York.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Cecilia Bartoli and the Art of the Nuance
description: In terms of sheer vocal beauty, Cecilia Bartoli was not at her best Thursday night for her sold-out Carnegie Hall recital debut. There were occasional dry patches in her sustained singing and some tightness in the top notes, no doubt remnants of the cold that forced her to delay the recital from Sunday.

title: Final Four Is Not the Final Word on Scalping Experiment
description: From the dormitories of Syracuse University to the box office windows of wily New Jersey ticket brokers, a feverish case of avarice has taken hold of many of the fortunate few who were able to secure tickets to this weekend's N.C.A.A. Final Four basketball tournament.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Record-Setting Loss For Lowly Grizzlies
description: Vancouver set a new National Basketball Association record for futility with its 21st straight loss.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Noble and Self-Sacrificing, A Long-Distance Mother
description: If one were being facetious, Josephine Perera, the subject of Nilita Vachani's documentary film "When Mother Comes Home for Christmas," could be described as a Sri Lankan answer to Mildred Pierce. A widowed mother of three, who selflessly dedicates herself to making a better life for her ungrateful brood, Josephine is one of thousands of Sri Lankan women who have left their country to earn high salaries (by Sri Lankan standards) as domestics elsewhere.

title: Abortion Group to Advise Doctors On Drug Used to End Pregnancy
description: In a new effort to develop alternatives to surgical abortions, the nation's largest group of abortion providers is encouraging doctors around the country to explore the use of the drug methotrexate to end pregnancies.

title: Passionate Fans Invade From Four Directions
description: Hey, how do you know that this is the place where Dickie V. is going to be with the three-point, slam dunk contest?"

title: Bosnia Serbs Attack Muslim-Croat Police
description: Bosnia's uneasy peace was interrupted today when Bosnian Serbs fired on and threw hand grenades at Muslim-Croat Federation police officers along the new boundary separating the former warring factions, according to witnesses and films of the scene.

title: West Friendship Journal;True Believers Await a Call to Suit Up
description: What member of the Baltimore Colts marching band could ever forget that snowy Wednesday night 12 years ago when moving vans carried off the city's beloved National Football League team to Indianapolis?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the arrest of an off-duty Yonkers police officer on assault charges misidentified the employer of the victim, Ernest Champell. It is WNBC-TV, not NBC News.

title: Health Bill May Not Suit Clinton
description: What is it about the health insurance bill passed Thursday by the House that President Clinton so dislikes? And will Republicans alter or abandon those provisions to win his support for the bill, which offers new health insurance coverage to millions of Americans?

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;New Lloyd's Plan Backed by Britain
description: The British Government gave conditional authorization today to Lloyd's of London's proposals to transfer its old liabilities to a new reinsurance company known as Equitas.

title: The Beef That Built an Empire
description: The outbreak of mad cow disease has struck at the very heart of England's national identity. We British are not only what we eat, but what we believe we eat. And beef has always summoned up images of the red blood and muscle power that created Britannia, ruled the waves and put the fire in John Bull's belly.

title: New-Home Sales Drop 1.3% As Midwest Cold Hurts Buying
description: New-home sales slid nationally in February for the first time in four months, as unusually cold weather in the Midwest disrupted buying.

title: Electric Cars To Be Delayed In California
description: California air-quality officials voted today to water down substantially their requirement for electric vehicles in the next few years, giving a victory to the automobile and oil industries.

title: Union Head Named New York's New Fire Commissioner
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed the head of the city's firefighters' union, Thomas J. Von Essen, as the new Fire Commissioner yesterday, the first time a labor leader has ever moved into the Fire Department's top post.

title: In Cuba, A Musician As Outsider And Idol
description: Carlos Varela is one of Cuba's most popular singers and songwriters, yet it is almost impossible to find his records on sale in stores here. Many radio stations simply refuse to play his music, and he hardly ever appears on television. But when he walks down the street, Cubans of all ages stop him to talk about the meaning of his songs.

title: BASEBALL;Key Is Proving He's a Starter
description: Jimmy Key showed tonight that he is ready to open the regular season as a Yankees starting pitcher. Key, who had rotator-cuff surgery last July on his left shoulder, pronounced himself physically fine after allowing three runs and seven hits in six innings of a 7-3 victory over the Mets before 10,265 at Legends Field.

title: Pacific Gas Shares Fall 10% on Proposed Change
description: Shares of Pacific Gas and Electric fell sharply yesterday after the company, the largest publicly traded utility, proposed that it be allowed to speed up the depreciation of a nuclear plant and other power-generation assets.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BASF in Agreement To Build Chinese Plant
description: The German petrochemicals giant BASF A.G. signed a letter of intent yesterday to build a $4 billion plastics manufacturing complex in central China along the Yangtze River near Nanjing.

title: Turkish Kurd Rebel Threatens Suicide Bombings in Germany
description: The leader of Kurdish insurgents in southeastern Turkey threatened today to send suicide bombers to Germany in retaliation for its crackdown on Kurdish dissidents here.

title: Giuliani Aide Approved City Contract
description: A document recommending the awarding of two city contracts to a Queens social service agency was signed last summer by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's top aide.

title: Corrections
description: The Also of Note section of the Art in Review column in Weekend on March 22 misidentified the curator of a group show that closes today at the Sandra Gering Gallery in SoHo. It was organized by Robert Nickas, not John Miller.

title: Corrections
description: A sports caption on Thursday about the trophy presentation at the Dubai World Cup horse race misidentified the person awarding the trophy. He was Sheik Maktoum bin Rashid al-Maktoum, the prime minister of the United Arab Emirates, not Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, the Crown Prince of Dubai.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Parkway Bans Art Center Ads
description: Electronic signs along the Garden State Parkway can no longer be used to advertise concert acts and other commercial events at the Garden State Arts Center, the Federal Highway Administration said. Dennis Ingoglia, a State Highway Authority spokesman, acknowledged yesterday that the ads flashing on the highway signs promoted concert attendance, but he said that the ban would not affect negotiations to turn over management of the arena to a private partnership.

title: TENNIS;Sampras Foiled by Ivanisevic And Rain
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla, March 29

title: A Dangerous Delay in Montana
description: Federal authorities are to be commended for finally arresting four members of the armed Freemen group near Jordan, Mont. But the arrests of two of the group's leaders, LeRoy Schweitzer and Daniel Peterson, should have been made months, even years, ago.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Tokyo Delays Decision On Breakup of N.T.T.
description: Japan's coalition Government yesterday postponed for a year any decision on whether to break up the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. The postponement was included in an announcement of a package of measures aimed at deregulating the Japanese economy.

title: The Last Caudillo
description: Joaquin Balaguer was installed as President of the Dominican Republic with the help of an invasion by the United States Marines in 1965. Mr. Balaguer, now 89 and almost completely blind, has remained in power ever since, winning election after election amid claims of fraud.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Drug Concern Has 50% Rise in Net
description: Gehe A.G., a German company that is one of the world's biggest drug wholesalers, said yesterday that its 1995 profit surged more than 50 percent, to 211.5 million marks, or $142.7 million, largely because of its acquisition of AAH P.L.C.

title: Gingrich Gets A Mild Rebuke In Ethics Case
description: The House ethics committee gave Speaker Newt Gingrich the mildest of reprimands today for allowing a telecommunications investor to work as a volunteer adviser in his office.

title: HOCKEY;The Return of Verbeek Could Add Some Spring
description: He sped around the ice, cutting tight little circles, and then headed to the boards and threw a check, leading with his right shoulder. A few minutes later, after Ranger practice today at Rye Playland, someone asked Pat Verbeek if he was ready to go.

title: Big Bidder Quits Wireless Auction
description: Another big bidder dropped out of the Federal Government's superheated auction of wireless communication licenses today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Smoking Banned at Games
description: Peanuts and Cracker Jacks are still O.K., but smoking will be out at baseball games in Mt. Olive under an ordinance that takes effect April 22. Football games are also covered. Belleville, Cedar Grove and Clinton Township have also banned smoking in some recreational areas, said Regina Carlson, the executive director of New Jersey Group Against Smoking Pollution. In Sussex County, smoking is prohibited at all government-owned outdoor recreational areas. JOE SHARKEY

title: M.S. Suleiman, 77, Egypt's Ex-Premier
description: Mohammed Sidqi Suleiman, a former Prime Minister of Egypt who played an instrumental role in the building of the Aswan High Dam, died Thursday in Cairo. He was 77.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS FASTER APPROVAL OF CANCER DRUGS
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it would take steps to streamline the Food and Drug Administration's rules to speed cancer drugs to patients.

title: Stock and Bond Issues Surge During Quarter
description: Despite an uptick in interest rates that slowed new debt offerings in March, Wall Street enjoyed a healthy first quarter.

title: U.S. Is Adjusting Its Consumer Price Index
description: The Government said today that it was adjusting the Consumer Price Index to correct a fault in its measurements of inflation.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Brendel and Beethoven, Contd.
description: Alfred Brendel continued his romp through Beethoven with Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, playing the Second and Fourth Piano Concertos. It was a joy to see the veteran pianist and conductor each so thoroughly in his element, even if they were not always perfectly in tune -- or rather, in time -- with each other.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Struggling To Validate A Forbidden Marriage
description: Showtime's "Mr. and Mrs. Loving," made in association with Hallmark Entertainment, recalls the background of a Supreme Court decision that struck down miscegenation laws not only in Virginia, where the case had its roots, but also in 17 other states. The story gets a straightforward, no-frills treatment in this quietly affecting movie, which has its premiere on Sunday.

title: Race Bias Is Wrong, As Is Ignoring Merit
description: To the Editor:

title: FINAL FOUR: NOTEBOOK;Camby Is Named Player Of Year
description: Marcus Camby of Massachusetts took another step toward becoming the consensus national player of the year yesterday. He was awarded the Adolph Rupp Trophy by The Associated Press.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY NEWS;ISB FINANCIAL IS SET TO ACQUIRE JEFFERSON BANCORP
description: The ISB Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Jefferson Bancorp for $23 a share in cash, or about $51.2 million. Jefferson's stock last traded on Monday at $19.50 a share. After acquiring Jefferson Bancorp, based in Gretna, La., ISB Financial will be an $840 million banking company with 21 offices in eight parishes in southern Louisiana, including a new and significant presence in greater New Orleans. Jefferson Bancorp, which operates seven full-service offices in Jefferson and Orleans parishes in Louisiana, has total assets of $265.9 million and deposits of $229.1 million.

title: Review/Fashion;In a Time of Shadow, Two Sparklers
description: One theory about why the post-Gaultier generation lacks the creative brilliance Jean-Paul Gaultier taught fashion to expect is that the brightest and best young artists aren't drawn to fashion anymore. They make music videos or performance art or independent films or Web sites or zines.

title: Russia Says, 'Sorry'
description: The commander of Russian troops in Chechnya issued a rare apology today after the "unauthorized" bombing of a village that had signed a peace accord with Russia.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a decision by Reform rabbis to support civil marriage for lesbians and gay men misspelled the surname of a rabbi who spoke in favor of such unions. He is Yoel H. Kahn, not Kahin.

title: High Hopes for All. Great Expectations for Kentucky.
description: There is suddenly a symmetry to the University of Kentucky basketball season, as the four surviving teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament work to achieve the only suitable conclusion that followers of the Wildcats know.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PERKIN-ELMER PLANS CHARGE FOR A REVAMPING
description: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation said yesterday that it would take a restructuring charge of $62.3 million, or $1.44 a share, to cut 7 percent of its work force and reorganize its analytical instruments business into three units. The company, based in Norwalk, Conn., said in January that it would take a charge of $57 million to $65 million, or $1.30 to $1.50 a share. Yesterday it provided specific figures and said it would cut 390 jobs. The company, which makes analytical instruments and life science systems for the food, drug and environmental industries, expects to save more than $40 million a year in operating costs.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Palau Decides Geography Bee
description: The final question: In 1994, the island nation of Palau gained independence from this country. "What is the United States?" responded Seyi Fayanju, a seventh grader from Whitehorne Middle School in Verona, winning the "Jeopardy" style state championship of the National Geography Bee yesterday at Rutgers University. Winners of contests that were conducted yesterday in all 50 states will compete on May 28 and 29 in the national finals, sponsored by the National Geographic Society as part of its $85 million campaign to revitalize geography education.

title: BASEBALL;Minors Not an Option, Fuming Thompson Says
description: Sunday, high noon, is baseball's deadline for teams to cut their rosters to the maximum 25 players, and Ryan Thompson is preparing for a showdown.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EASTMAN CHEMICAL SEES LOWER-THAN-EXPECTED INCOME
description: Citing suppressed profit margins, the Eastman Chemical Company said yesterday that it expected its first-quarter earnings to fall below analysts' estimates. The company, a maker of chemicals, fibers and plastics, said its profitability had been hurt by lower selling prices, while raw material and energy costs had not fallen accordingly. The company did not say exactly what it will earn for the quarter ending March 31 but did say analysts' consensus earnings estimate of $1.64 a share was "aggressive." In the first quarter a year ago, Eastman earned $132 million, or $1.58 a share, on revenue of $1.2 billion.

title: Let Staten Island's Dump Go on Tour
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Proposes Kasich for G.O.P. Ticket
description: Nearly two-dozen House freshmen suggested today that Senator Bob Dole select Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio as the Vice Presidential nominee on the Republican Presidential ticket.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;20 Years for Bathtub Killing
description: Martin Hunter, 36, who drowned his wife in a bathtub during an argument in January 1995, was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison, the A.P. said. Mr. Hunter had pleaded guilty to aggravated manslaughter, saying he only intended to frighten his wife, Natalie, by holding her head under water.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Tokyo Stocks, Down So Long, Get Up Off the Mat
description: After a seemingly relentless decline that has blackened the economic atmosphere for years, the Tokyo stock market now seems to be on an intrepid climb, bolstering hopes that the sun may shine at last on investors here.

title: People Want to Fight Drugs. Do Our Leaders?
description: To the Editor:

title: Congressional Memo;Another Stopgap Plan Ends A Week of Accomplishment
description: Still unable after six months of haggling to agree on 1996 budgets for a host of Federal offices, including nine Cabinet departments, Congress gave up and went home today for a two-week vacation.

title: Crew Will Not Pursue School Uniform Rule
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he has no plans to follow President Clinton's advice and require students to wear uniforms, but he urged schoolchildren to "upgrade" their classroom wear and said more schools should adopt dress codes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: For-Profit Hospital Chain To Buy Blue Cross Business Columbia-HCA Healthcare agreed to buy the main business of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio for $299.5 million, in the first sale of a Blue Cross company to a for-profit hospital chain. The takeover could open the door for similar deals by a number of nonprofit Blue Cross plans that are struggling.

title: Big Hospital Chain Makes a Bid to Buy Blue Cross of Ohio
description: The nation's largest for-profit hospital chain agreed yesterday to buy the main business of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio, raising concerns among consumers, employers and providers of health care about the enormous influence that such a combination could exert.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN STANDARD TO LOWER EARNINGS ESTIMATE
description: The American Standard Companies said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would be below expectations because of weak European sales. The company, which makes air-conditioning units and bath fixtures, will also take a charge of about $200 million to reduce the value of some assets. Earnings will be "somewhat below" analysts' estimates but in line with earnings a year earlier, said Emmanuel Kampouris, company chairman, chief executive and president. The Piscataway, N.J., company reported profit from operations of $26 million, or 38 cents a share, in the first quarter a year ago, before a $30 million charge for a loss on debt retirement.

title: Observer;The Gone and the Eternal
description: After long absence from New York you notice things that full-time New Yorkers have quit seeing. Has it been widely observed, for instance, that the famously talky New York cabdriver is gone with the Trylon and Perisphere, the $1.50 second-balcony ticket for the best show on Broadway, Yankee Stadium crowds wearing fedoras and business suits, and old Delmonico's where men with diamond studs glittering on starched shirts may or may not have drunk champagne from Lillian Russell's slipper?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Modell Picks Ravens
description: ART MODELL named his National Football League team the Ravens yesterday, transforming the former Browns franchise from one revered by dog-mask wearing fans in Cleveland to one that draws on the literary bones of Edgar Allan Poe.

title: Sports of The Times;Pearl Gets Second Shot At Life
description: DWAYNE WASHINGTON'S voice sounded strong and upbeat. I told him, with a level of sincerity that probably surprised both of us, that it was good to hear he was O.K.

title: Setting Sail With Yoga;'Om' Helps Ease Stress of Base's Closing
description: It's tough working for the Coast Guard. You've got your oil spills, your death-defying rescues in choppy waters, your stray bottlenosed dolphins. There are boat people from Haiti and Cuba to intercept, not to mention drug dealers in cigarette boats.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-5

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Puckett Is Out
description: KIRBY PUCKETT's blurry vision is being caused by a partial blockage of a blood vessel in his right eye, and the 35-year-old Minnesota Twins outfielder will miss the season opener.

title: Turkish Army in New Battle In the Defense of Secularism
description: Last December, when a pro-Islamic party was surging ahead in pre-election opinion polls, the Turkish military summarily dismissed 50 officers on charges of propagating Islamic fundamentalism.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOARD BACKS REPURCHASE OF UP TO 10 MILLION SHARES
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 10 million common shares. Sprint has more than 400 million shares outstanding, including those held by France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom. Repurchased shares will be held as treasury stock and used primarily for employee benefit programs and other general corporate purposes, the company said. Sprint, based in Westwood, Kan., is the No. 3 United States long-distance company behind AT&T and MCI. Sprint and the French and German telecommunications companies earlier this year formed a joint venture called Global One.

title: Atlantis Crew Plans Early Return to Earth
description: After dropping off a crew member at Russia's space station for a five-month stay, the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis headed today for an early return to Earth on Saturday because of a leak in the steering system.

title: January Gap In U.S. Trade Grew Sharply
description: The nation's trade deficit widened sharply in January to nearly $10.3 billion, reversing its performance of late last year, when the Clinton Administration boasted that its policies contributed to a drastic improvement in American competitiveness, Commerce Department figures showed today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Paper Producers In Merger in Japan
description: The New Oji Paper Company, Japan's largest paper maker, will absorb the Honshu Paper Company in October to create the world's third- largest paper maker in a deal worth 280 billion yen, or $2.64 billion. Holders of Honshu shares will be able to turn in six of their shares for five Oji Paper shares.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Islander Is Suspended
description: Islanders defenseman BRENT SEVERYN has been suspended by the National Hockey League for tomorrow's game against the Rangers because he received his third game misconduct of the season Tuesday against the Capitals. Severyn was thrown out of the game for attacking MARK TINORDI after a jarring open-ice hit. To replace Severyn, the Islanders called up defenseman JASON STRUDWICK from Worcester of the American Hockey League.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Exploring the Depths Of Paranoia and Despair
description: From its opening scene, in which a young black couple find themselves stranded in the middle of nowhere when their car breaks down, Garret Williams's film "Spark" is seized with a sickening feeling of dread. Byron (Garvin Funches), who is driving his girlfriend, Nina (Melissa DeSousa), from Chicago to Los Angeles in his refurbished classic car, is a defensive macho hothead. When their vehicle is towed to a repair shop, the tension between Byron and the local rednecks escalates into a confrontation that ends with angry threats and drawn guns.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the line item veto overstated the cost to the Treasury of a Republican proposal that would increase the amount of money workers between ages 65 and 70 could earn without a reduction of their Social Security benefits. The proposal would cost $7.5 billion, not $70 billion, over seven years.

title: People Want to Fight Drugs. Do Our Leaders?
description: To the Editor:

title: GUIDE
description: MUSEUM BENEFIT

title: Marvin H. Albert, 73, an Author Of Mysteries and Biographies
description: Marvin H. Albert, the author of more than 100 westerns, mysteries, spy novels and works of history, died on March 24 in Menton, in the south of France. He was 73 and lived in Mont Segur-sur-Lauzon.

title: Tel Aviv
description: To the Editor: Our recent return from Israel sparked our interest in Ann Birstein's article. Visitors to Tel Aviv should not miss the Haaretz Museum, near the Diaspora Museum in Ramat Aviv. In addition to viewing the treasures, one can walk around the city's archeological site, Tel Qasile.

title: Kidnapped
description: CRIMINALS By Margot Livesey. 271 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: Black Rhythms, White Voices in Concert
description: IT'S been more than a decade now, but Mae Gibson-Brown remembers well the night her spirited gospel singing prompted a startling question. It was in October 1984 that Ms. Gibson-Brown and two of her children sang at a potluck dinner for parents at Wight Wood Elementary School in Branford, where Ms. Gibson-Brown is a teacher. Apparently, the performance had moved Sheila Dietz-Bonenberger, the mother of one of her students. "When we finished singing, Sheila came rushing up to me, her face flushed, and said, 'Mae, do you think it's possible for white people to learn to sing black gospel music?' " Ms. Gibson-Brown recalled recently. "In my head, I'm saying 'Why would they want to?' But I said, 'Yes, I think it is.' "

title: The French Connections
description: PAUL GAUGUIN A Life. By David Sweetman. Illustrated. 600 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $35.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: COP WITHOUT A BADGE The Extraordinary Undercover Life of Kevin Maher. By Charles Kipps. Carroll & Graf, $23.

title: Better Unread Than Read;Russia's Press Edits Out a Communist
description: THE Communist leader Gennadi A. Zyuganov has made some far-fetched claims on the stump. Last week, he suggested that Stalin respected the Russian Orthodox Church in his heart. He also said that 20 years ago the C.I.A. launched a plot to destroy the Soviet Union, and that the Russian mass media are conspiring against him.

title: Selling a One-Day Symbol;Pity the Pastor Who Runs Short of Palm Fronds
description: The symbol of Palm Sunday resonates with a power that theologians cannot fully explain. Palms are tangible yet fleetingly perishable and perhaps that's the key: Like Christ's last week of earthly life, they're green with promise and sharp-edged with the inevitability of fate.

title: POSTINGS: Developer Has a Plan for Medical and Apartment Complex;5.4-Acre Plot in Flushing Is Sold for $5 Million
description: A 5.4-acre parcel in the heart of Queens that has never had a brick laid upon it -- despite its neighboring concentration of garden apartments and private homes -- has been bought by a developer with visions of building a combined medical and apartment complex.

title: I.M.F. Rules Out Belarus Loans
description: The International Monetary Fund says it has given up any notion of resuming loans to Belarus in view of the poor state of the former Soviet republic's market reforms and economy.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Avoiding the New Fees For Smaller Accounts
description: INVESTORS irked by new fees on small mutual fund accounts may find that the pain isn't so bad if they shop around. Fund companies make a variety of exceptions -- for retirement accounts, for current customers and for accounts that fall below the new minimum requirements because of investment losses.

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW;Finally, 162 Games. And Now, Possibly, 62 Home Runs.
description: In the strike-shortened season of 1994, when the San Francisco Giants played 115 games instead of the usual 162, Matt Williams hit 43 home runs.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: HOTEL;Exercising in Your Room
description: Modest travelers who are tired of those hotel exercise rooms with the glass walls just off the lobby will be happy to know that the Ritz-Carlton in Aspen, Colo., allows guests to rent exercise cycles and stair-climbing machines in the privacy of their rooms.

title: Liberties;Raffish and Rowdy
description: We're no angels.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE LAST SANCTUARY By Craig Holden. Delacorte, $22.95.

title: A Change In Funds Affecting Disabled
description: BECAUSE of a change in the way the state and the county are financing programs for mentally retarded adults, 40 or so severely disabled people who have spent most of their lives in residential schools -- some out of state and others in the county -- will have to move to group residences close to their homes.

title: Temples Open Their Doors So No One Will Be Alone for the Seder
description: TWENTY-ONE years ago, Frieda Falk and several women she knew became concerned that the students at Adelphi and Hofstra would have no Passover seders to attend. The holiday fell mid-week during a regular school schedule, and there would not be enough time for students to travel home for the Passover holiday.

title: Tel Aviv
description: To the Editor: "Israel's Second City" was informative and gave a good sense of Tel Aviv's vibrant spirit. One additional remark: The name of the city, given in 1909, was taken from the Book of Ezekiel: "Then I came to them of the captivity at Tel Abib who dwelt on the River Chebar . . ." (3:15). The Biblical connection was important for the founders of the first Hebrew city.

title: ON LANGUAGE;The Coinage Game: Neologic Nellies
description: THOSE HARDHEARTED HANNAHS ARE going to cut Medicare," say the liberals.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;"Go" for Chapin
description: The dispute between the Chapin School and some neighbors was resolved last week when the five-member Board of Standards and Appeals voted unanimously to allow a $10 million, four-story addition to the private girls' school at East End Avenue and 84th Street. Some neighbors, including the writer Susan Cheever, had opposed the addition. Construction is set to begin at the end of May and to last 16 months. A.R.

title: Trust in God and Take Short Views'
description: AUDEN By Richard Davenport-Hines. Illustrated. 406 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $30.

title: Deafness, Context and a Charge of Harassment
description: To the Editor:

title: Avoiding the School Of Hard Knocks
description: To the Editor:

title: Tel Aviv
description: To the Editor: Ann Birstein is right that Tel Aviv is "unappreciated" by tourists -- and she is right again that there is much there to be appreciated. I have spent 15 summers teaching at Tel Aviv University, and have lived on Bialik Street, which Ms. Birstein justly singles out for its architecture.

title: In the Region/Long Island;Babylon Offers Accessory-Apartment Amnesty
description: IN an effort to bring more homeowners into compliance with a local ordinance permitting up-to-code accessory apartments, the Town of Babylon has offered a six-month amnesty to owners of unregistered, and therefore illegal, units.

title: WEDDINGS;Heather W. Kent, David L. Handel
description: Heather Wendy Kent, the daughter of Ellen and Dr. Donald Kent of Great Neck, L.I., is to be married today to Dr. David Lee Handel, the son of Fanny and Sheldon Handel of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

title: BOOKEND;Rehabilitating a Monster
description: Our restless culture propels itself as much by revivals as by new discoveries. This past season we benefited from the welcome return among us of Jane Austen and Vermeer. A few decades ago we rediscovered the beautifully written "Narrative" by Frederick Douglass, which provides a searing account of slavery from the inside. We can never again ignore it. Several centuries ago, the rediscovery of Greek and Latin classics helped usher in an era of humanistic and scientific exploration. We call it the Renaissance.

title: Blackboard;Life's Experience Bring a New Career
description: Life will come full circle for Shelly Tufts in May when she earns her master's degree as a nurse-midwife from Case Western University

title: Use of 'Native'
description: To the Editor: Regarding the letter from John Sherman ("Loaded Language," Letters to the Editor, Feb. 25) criticizing Marcia Burick's use of the word "native" in her article about Malawi, Mr. Sherman needs a better understanding of his native language as spoken and written in his native country.

title: For $66,000, 2 BR, 1 Bath, Gd Neighbors
description: ELLEN TELFEYAN is one of thousands of people who know the Mount Laurel experience firsthand. With her sons, Daniel, 13, and David, 11, she lives in a two-bedroom, one-bathroom apartment here -- one of 274 low- or moderate-income units in Society Hill, a neat, manicured development of 1,200 town houses of pale yellow and gray aluminum siding.

title: A Proposed Water Sale Stirs Opposition
description: WHY the anger? Why an alliance with New York City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi? At issue is water and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed sale of the New York City water system to the city's Water Board, a move that the Westchester Chamber of Commerce here opposes. The Chamber of Commerce has joined Mr. Hevesi in his legal fight against the sale.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: ENTER WHINING By Fran Drescher. Regan Books/HarperCollins, $22.

title: Modern Maturity
description: FOOTPRINTS By Shelby Hearon. 191 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: CHATTER;Adoptees' Roots and Records
description: The Legislature is considering a bill that would give adoptees access to their birth certificates, which are now sealed. Is this a good idea?

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Signs of the Medieval Times
description: TRADE signs, which identify businesses and services with three-dimensional figures, are often quirky and individualistic as well as attention grabbing. Descendants of the guild signs of medieval Europe, they still grace modern streets in the form of the barber's pole, the pharmacist's mortar and pestle and the pawnshop's three balls.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;Chinatown Rallies in School Race
description: The campaign start drew many of Chinatown's most prominent civic and business leaders to the 31 Division Dim Sum House. They listened to speeches, drank tea and worked on platters of dumplings, chow fun and Italian pastries. More than a half-dozen reporters and photographers from the Chinese-language press observed the event.

title: Just a Grave For a Baby, But Anguish For a Town
description: The integration of the Barnetts Creek Baptist Church cemetery is done. A mixed-race baby, the most recent burial here in the cemetery's serene patch of stained granite and plastic flowers, can rest peacefully now. So, finally, can her family.

title: WEDDINGS;Catherine Baxter, Andrew Eristoff
description: Catherine Elaine Baxter, a vice president in the private client services group at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Eristoff, the New York City Councilman.

title: THEATER;A Chorus Of Voices From a 'Dream'
description: MAGIC SPELLS, SPRITES, confused lovers, upended umbrellas . . . it must be the Royal Shakespeare Company's latest version of "A Midsummer Night's Dream." Opening tonight at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, under the direction of Adrian Noble, the company's artistic director, the production marks the troupe's first appearance on Broadway since it presented "Les Liaisons Dangereuses" nearly a decade ago.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on page 35 of the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about the world's 100 most-endangered monument sites misidentifies the painter of a mural in Mexico. He was Roberto Montenegro, not Diego Rivera.

title: Tel Aviv
description: To the Editor: Tel Aviv architecture "awful"? It's a pity Ann Birstein ("Israel's Second City," Feb. 18) didn't appreciate the strong echoes of Bauhaus brought to Tel Aviv by Jewish architects fleeing Germany in the 1930's. Because of pioneering modernists like Eric Mendelsohn, Joseph Neufeld and Carl Rubin, Tel Aviv has one of the world's largest concentrations of International style residential architecture.

title: Fugitive Arrested 25 Years After Officer's Slaying
description: A black radical charged in the widely publicized killing of a Philadelphia police officer 25 years ago was captured in a Chicago suburb by an officer looking for a pickpocket, police said. And the arresting officer said the man seemed almost relieved to be found.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Reno Air Is Selling Seats via Ticketmaster
description: Travelers can now call Ticketmaster to buy airline tickets for flights on Reno Air, the first airline to offer this option.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE CARDINALS With Meditations and Short Stories. By Bessie Head. Edited by M.J. Daymond. Heinemann, paper, $10.95.

title: March 24-30;The Formula, Please . . .
description: Hollywood, it seems, has learned not to ignore low-budget films when the acting shines, but the big splashy epic still has the central place in its heart.

title: Moves to End Affirmative Action Gain Support Nationwide
description: While race-based affirmative action programs at two of the nation's largest public universities, Texas and California, have been scuttled under an intense national spotlight, movements are quietly bubbling up in more than a dozen other states to curtail or end affirmative action in determining college admission and financial aid.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;Dissent As a Way Of Life
description: WHEN RUSSELL SHERMAN REACHES the climax of the first-movement development section in Beethoven's First Piano Sonata on a new recording, he quite properly fractures the theme, disrupts the regularity of the meter and seems to cast sonic fragments into space. Those seven measures, he suggests in the program booklet, are "sufficiently cryptic and probing" to recall the works of Beckett, Klee and the sculptor David Smith.

title: Where Sacred Music Soars on Easter
description: AS churchgoers prepare to open their ears to the glorious music that Easter has inspired over the centuries, a thought should be given to the men and women who make the music.

title: ART REVIEW;Unpainterly Painter; Transforming Sculptor
description: THE painter Lois Dodd and the sculptor Melvin Edwards are exhibiting at opposite ends of the Montclair Art Museum -- appropriately, for the two come from opposite ends of the art spectrum.

title: MARKET WATCH;When A Fine Can Mean Nothing
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers proudly announced last week that it had ordered Franklin N. Wolf, the erstwhile proprietor of F. N. Wolf & Company, a defunct penny stock firm, to repay $7.8 million the N.A.S.D. found had been wrongly taken from customers. And it fined him $250,000.

title: Leon Kronish, 79, Miami Beach Rabbi
description: Rabbi Leon Kronish, a prominent voice in Reform Judaism and an original leader and past national chairman of the State of Israel Bonds drives, died on March 23 at the University of Miami-Jackson Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 and lived in Miami Beach.
