title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE RAPTURE OF CANAAN By Sheri Reynolds. Putnam, $22.95.

title: SPENDING IT;American Express May Offer a Tax-Service Discount
description: THE American Express Company, out to lure new clients for its growing tax and business services unit, may add tax preparation next year to its list of perks provided to card holders. But the deal may come with strings attached.

title: The View From: New Milford;For Hoopsters Over 40 (Some Well Over)
description: SHORTLY after John O'Connor had sunk a soft one-hander from the left corner during a game at the Canterbury School Field House in New Milford, he threw up a shot from virtually the same spot. Only this one missed completely -- an "air ball" in the vernacular.

title: Rising Variety of Groups Vie for Attention at U.N. Rights Forum
description: Fearing that they are not being heard in Africa, two members of a dwindling tribe facing eviction from a Botswana game reserve went to Geneva this week to bring their case to a human rights forum that is opening its doors wider every year to petitioners from around the world.

title: Hello to an Old Friend: A Naturalist's Return
description: To the Editor:

title: Rachel and Her Children
description: THE COLOR OF WATER A Black Man's Tribute to His White Mother. By James McBride. 228 pp. New York: Riverhead Books. $22.95

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on March 10 about a Brooklyn Heights shoemaker, Yefim Slusker, who does work for the Metropolitan Opera, misidentified the opera for which Mr. Slusker made a 45-inch black belt for Placido Domingo. It was "Parsifal," not "Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg."

title: The Princess and a Plea: More Money
description: ON the day Lady Diana Spencer married into the House of Windsor in 1981, her good fortune appeared to be boundless. Hardly out of her teens, she decommissioned the world's foremost bachelor and signed on to produce the next heir of a monarchy whose wealth is conservatively estimated at more than $8 billion. Fifteen years later, her divorce nearly a fait accompli, the Princess of Wales faces a reversal of fortune.

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW;Johnson's Stature and Presence Catch Up With His Height
description: These are good times for Randy Johnson, a man at peace with his life, his career and even his height.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Two London Hotels Getting Renovations
description: Two landmark hotels in the heart of London -- the Stafford and the Ritz -- are being renovated.

title: DINING OUT;When Steak Is What the Party Wants
description: WE were puzzled by the photographs of basketball players inside the entrance of Bennett's Steak and Fish House in downtown Stamford. Our waiter explained that Bennett's is named for Bennett Salvatore, an N.B.A. referee who is a Stamford native and principal owner of the attractive new steakhouse.

title: EAT OR BE EATEN
description: I love my bread machine and use it at least once a week ("Eat or Be Eaten," by Michelle Huneven, March 10). It was given to me by an editor (cookbooks included) who got it from a literary agent who got it from a well-known conservative author.

title: POP VIEW;In Cuba, Music Eases The Pain
description: IN HAVANA, MUSIC IS EVERYWHERE, whispering to you from a distance, infecting your dreams. That Havana isn't in the news. The recent downing of two American civilian airplanes by the Cuban Air Force brought back a familiar image of Cuba. It is the Cuba of the Castro regime and 35 years of often clamorous hostility toward the United States. But beyond this official Cuba is another Cuba that is rarely mentioned, the Cuba of 10 million people struggling to endure hardship exacerbated by the American trade embargo. Music is one way Cubans ease the pain.

title: On the Track Of a Weekend House That's Affordable
description: THE town of Heath, Mass., is the kind of place where a Nathaniel Hawthorne short story might be filmed. In early spring, its village green appears bleak and pure, an assemblage of white clapboard mid-19th century buildings: a community hall that offers square dancing every other Saturday and a former church without a steeple that now houses the three selectmen, the town clerk, the library and the post office.

title: WEDDINGS;Justine L. Bloch, Kenneth Kohlberg
description: Justine Laura Bloch, a daughter of Lucienne and Dr. Claude Bloch of New York, was married last evening to Kenneth Ray Kohlberg, a son of Betty Kohlberg of Newton, Mass., and Ira Kohlberg of Alexandria, Va. Cantor Bruce Ruben performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Indian Chief Is Mascot No More
description: WHEN the Newtown High School marching band purchased new uniforms last school year -- the ones millions would see when the band marched in the Rose Bowl parade -- they made an important change: There was no logo of a proud Indian chief in the center of the jackets. It was definitely a sign of things to come.

title: World News Briefs;Taiwan Reportedly Plans Its Own Military Games
description: Taiwan is to hold a sea and air live-fire military exercise off Matsu Islands from April 7 to 10 and others later in the month, The Liberty Times newspaper said today.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;Tickets, Tow Trucks, Cat and Mouse
description: Afternoons on Atlantic Avenue have a gamelike air between Court Street and Boerum Place, with merchants peering out their storefront windows for tow trucks, customers dashing in and out of shops and delivery drivers looking both ways before making a drop-off.

title: EVENING HOURS;Fall Lines, Party Lines
description: Celebrating fashion collections and honoring 2 women.

title: Wide Net of 'Megan's Law' Snares the Very Young, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;Looking Straight Into the Eyes Of the Dying
description: UP TO THE 19TH CENTURY, IF you wanted to know the proper way to die, you could always find instructions at your bookstore. Ars moriendi tracts, on the art of dying, carried the Christian message about repentance, the afterlife, the struggle between the forces of heaven and hell for possession of the soul. The books were often illustrated, if only with a deathbed scene, making the art of dying possibly easier to comprehend than that of living.

title: Twelve Are Injured In Suspicious Blaze
description: Twelve people were injured last night, two seriously, when a fire of suspicious origin broke out in a six-story apartment building in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan.

title: WEDDINGS;Jonathan Klein and Jennifer Snell
description: Jennifer Lee Snell, an investigative reporter at WPLG-TV, the ABC affiliate station in Miami, was married last evening to Jonathan Charles Klein, the executive vice president of CBS News in New York. Rabbi Brent Goldstein performed the ceremony at the Delano Hotel in Miami Beach.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Hot Managers Getting the Star Treatment
description: WHILE no fund company will discuss how much it pays its star managers, the largest, highest-profile firms, like Fidelity, T. Rowe Price and Putnam, have the resources to pay top managers at least $1 million to $2 million a year, executive recruiters say.

title: Walls Are Built Without Thought Of Animals' Needs
description: ACROSS New England, old walls separate properties and buffer roads. Gracefully winding up and down hills, the gray stone piles run along the edges of fields, some now overgrown into woods. Most of the original walls were built by farmers taking one stone at a time from their land and laying it on top of another.

title: SIGNOFF;The Glory and Glamour of Dietrich
description: IN the rooms where AMC plots strategy, Tuesday is D-day. But don't look for Audie Murphy or a whole lot of kahki. This screen invasion arrives on legendary legs and waves of golden hair. The D stands for Dietrich, and Tuesday is AMC's Day of Dietrich.

title: WEDDINGS;Gail Pisano, Joseph R. Gromek
description: Gail Pisano, a senior vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, was married on Friday to Joseph Richard Gromek, the president and chief executive of Brooks Brothers. Both work in New York. Municipal Judge Buck Allen of the Town of Vail, Colo., officiated atop Vail Mountain.

title: Some Personalize Their Seder To Underscore Timely Events
description: AS Gloria Fischel greeted guests to her Passover seder last year in East Hills, she handed each one a map, a toy airplane, and a compass to go on a symbolic tour of the Holy Land.

title: Construction of $1 Million 'Main Line' Homes Surges
description: A SURGE in the construction of homes selling for $1 million or more is under way in the exclusive Main Line, about a dozen communities northwest of Philadelphia and within a 20-minute drive of downtown.

title: Behind the Siege in Montana, Bitter Trail of Broken Bonds
description: Two years ago, neighbors around here pitched in to save Casey Clark's life by donating equipment for a big farm auction. The farmers raised $125,000, and Mr. Clark's brain tumor operation was a success.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;City Hall Moves to Tame the Monster Street Fairs
description: The Giuliani administration has tended to view the city's approximately 400 large street fairs as traffic-clogging, quality-of-life hazards that run up police overtime and cost the city money, while enriching their sponsors. With fair season once again approaching, the administration says it intends to keep the Mayor's promise to impose restrictions on the monster festivals.

title: Blackboard;Cracking the Design World of Faberge
description: THOUSANDS OF people have been lining up at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York to view the legacy of the legendary jeweler Peter Carl Faberge, particularly many of the imperial Easter eggs specially commissioned by the last Russian czars. But the exhibition's reach extends further, to the aspirations of tomorrow's generation of designers.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;Take Me Out to the Snack Bar
description: IF history is any indication, tonight the whoosh of the first pitch thrown this baseball season will be accompanied by the sound of peanut shells crunching between fidgety fingers, the rip of Cracker Jack boxes and the chomping of thousands of hot dogs in stadiums across the land.

title: COVER STORY;How Love Came to Change the Law
description: In 1958, Mildred Jeter and Richard Loving were just another good-looking, happy young couple in love. They ahd grown up int he same small town and known each other all their lives, as had their families. When Mildred told her boyfriend that she was going to have a baby, Richard quickly announced his intention to do the right thing.

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW: NL WEST
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the east, the Mets are picked for third.

title: GARDENING;Running Wild: Plants That Know No Bounds
description: THE plant world is greening up again, with this springtime an especially deserved one after the long hard winter the region endured.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Thrifty Shoppers

title: DRIVING SMART;A Design for Safer Child Seats
description: A NEW means of attaching child-safety seats in cars could result in seats that are safer and easier to install.

title: INVESTING IT;Short-Sellers Are Lonely Hunters, but Is Their Bounty Near?
description: TRYING to profit from overvalued stocks has never been easy. But given the roaring bull market of recent years, the task has become onerous, and that has made a hard job even harder for short-sellers. These professionals hunt for sky-high equities and, by borrowing shares, sell them at the lofty price while later paying the lower price to which they expect the stock to tumble. They pocket the difference -- or pay it, if they guessed wrong.

title: No Headline
description: People talk a lot about how Chernobyl killed our country. That may be. But sometimes I think the fear is worse than the sickness."

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WOODSIDE;Resuscitating an Ambulance
description: It has been a rough year for the Woodside Volunteer Ambulance Corps. Back in June, it was shut down because of declining membership. Reorganized last fall, the corps was ready to reopen on Jan. 2 with a crew of 12 when a fire destroyed its headquarters at 60th Street and Woodside Avenue.

title: Blackboard;The Outlaw And the Treasurer
description: IT IS NOT known whether Joseph Lee Heywood took a fatal bullet in the face for successfully defending his college's money from a ruthless outlaw. But is is a sure thing that Carleton College, in Northfield, Minn., had some of its money in the town's First National Bank when Jesse James came to call.

title: POLITICS: TALK RADIO;It's Shocking, but Many Politicians Can't Resist the Chance to Have Such Big Audiences
description: Senator Bill Bradley arrived at KLOL in Houston last month bearing edible gifts -- doughnuts for the early-bird, drive-time disk jockeys scheduled to interview him about his new book.

title: C.A. Agemian, 86, Former Executive At Chase Manhattan
description: Charles A. Agemian, a former Chase Manhattan executive whose banking career covered two thirds of a century, died on Friday at a hospital in Neptune, N.J. He was 86 and a resident of Spring Lake.

title: Home Health Care Is Workable and Repairable
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF;Senate Bill Would Stiffen Domestic Violence Law
description: In February, a Brooklyn woman was killed by her boyfriend, whom a judge had released from jail even though he had been charged with beating the woman repeatedly, partly because New York state law classifies domestic violence as a misdemeanor unless broken bones or more serious injuries are involved. Now, attempts are being made to change a similar New Jersey law.

title: Adult Education;No Tests and You Can Hit Rewind
description: When Peter Saccio teaches Shakespeare's "Henry V" to undergraduates at Dartmouth College, they are shocked by the young king's guile and double- dealing. When Professor Saccio presents the same play to adults, Henry's slippery character causes hardly a stir.

title: A Last Party On the Way To the Guillotine
description: WHY, IT MUST BE Giordanomania. On Saturday evening, the Metropolitan Opera presents a new production of "Andrea Chenier," starring Luciano Pavarotti. Then, "Chenier" will open the Met's next season, which also includes the company's first staging of "Fedora" in 70 years. Shades of 1925-26, when the repertory included three operas by Umberto Giordano, the Italian composer: "Chenier," "Fedora" and "La Cena Delle Beffe."

title: POSTINGS: Former Precinct House in Bushwick Is Renovated;For Police Station, An Arresting Look
description: The old 83d Police Precinct Station House in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, vacant since 1984, has received a $5.7 million renovation and is no longer a burnt-out shell covered by layers of graffiti.

title: THE WORLD;Europe Isn't Divided In Its Joblessness
description: THE European Union is deep in crisis, perhaps the worst of the decade. It is not about beef, the problem that preoccupied leaders of its 15 nations Friday in Turin, where they had planned to kick off a conference on how to handle expected expansion, but about the one thing that truly unites them: unemployment.

title: IN BRIEF;Why Did the Books Cross Bloomfield Avenue?
description: EVENT A parade on Thursday morning that moved 30,000 volumes from the Montclair Public Library to the Montclair Y.W.C.A., which will serve as a temporary town library until August 1997 while the real library undergoes a $6.3 million expansion. ROUTE From the main library on South Fullerton Street, across Bloomfield Avenue and down Glen Ridge Avenue, about four-tenths of a mile.

title: MUSIC;Teachers At Work, Strings On Stage
description: THREE distinguished musicians are visiting Connecticut as mentors to their younger colleagues; the flutist Carol Wincenc is giving a recital and master class at Hartt School of Music, while Kurt Masur and Sherrill Milnes will be coaching instrumentalists and singers at Yale.

title: School for Disabled Fears a Shift
description: ON a recent Wednesday morning five students sat at a table in the kitchen of their high school, measuring ingredients for chewy oatmeal cookies.

title: GOOD EATING;Upper West Side's Flavors of Europe
description: CAFE DES ARTISTES*** (212) 877-3500; 1 West 67th Street; $$(c) all major credit cards

title: EAT OR BE EATEN
description: Remember Tab?" Yes, I remember Tab and I still drink it every day. It contains saccharin, which I prefer to aspartame, and it no longer has those much-maligned cyclamates.

title: Foreign Affairs;No Pain, No Gain, No Peace
description: I knew an Israeli colonel who had commanded Israeli troops in both south Lebanon and the West Bank, and I once asked him what was the difference between the two. Well, he said, on the West Bank, because of media and government scrutiny, "you have to explain every little move you make to 10 different people." But in south Lebanon, he said, you could do whatever you wanted. Or as he put it: "In south Lebanon, there is nothing between you and God Almighty. The only question you ask yourself when you are going to blow up someone's house is whether to use 50 kilos of dynamite or 25 kilos."

title: THEATER REVIEW;Brotherly Love: One Dead, Two at War
description: SOME plays endure; some vanish. "Buried Treasure" persists.

title: Kevorkian Going on Trial For 4th Time In Suicides
description: Less than a month after Dr. Jack Kevorkian was acquitted for a third time of violating Michigan's law banning assisted suicide, he goes on trial again, on Tuesday, in a case that the prosecution thinks it has a far better chance of winning.

title: HOCKEY;After 32 Years, Michigan Takes a Title
description: As wave after wave of Wolverine skaters came at him, perspiration poured from Ryan Bach's face.

title: OUTSIDER ART;The Balm Of Creativity
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD;Getting Sauced
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, CONDIMENTS WERE THE the essence of a place, a distillation of flavors that told the story of that land's cooking. But as the world grew smaller, condiments grew worldlier. Suddenly, mustard and ketchup have global identities.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FILMS FROM HONG KONG

title: Cher's His FM Mantra
description: NOT a creature was stirring at 5 A.M. on Friday, not even a stylist, when Ru Paul stepped out of his Greenwich Village apartment and into a hired car. Out of drag and looking plain as a homeboy, the drag diva was heading to Jersey City to be host of the morning "drive time" show at WKTU-FM, 103.5, a recently reincarnated station for disco and peppy pop. He hadn't slept at all the night before.

title: Mother and Her 2 Children Die in Huntington Fire
description: Sometime before 1 A.M. yesterday, R. Michael Lloyd left home to buy the makings of french toast for his wife and two children. When he returned, officials said, his ranch-style house in Huntington, L.I., was a charred frame and his family was dead inside.

title: The View From: Dover Plains;With Riders of the 6:33: A Train Like No Other
description: PHIL CELENTANO commutes to Manhattan every day not unusual except for the fact that he lives in the Berkshire Mountains of Massachusetts.

title: THE THEORY OF SUPERMARKETS
description: Hitt ought to have mentioned an unnerving development in consumer manipulation -- the "membership card." Supermarket customers with these cards no longer have to clip coupons; the checkout computer scans the card and takes every available discount. My local A.&P. keeps a running tab on how much I've saved and prints the information on my receipt.

title: Q and A
description: Copper Canyon

title: STYLE;Fashion Hotel
description: The first sign is the metal barricade that the police erect across from the entrance to hold back the camera-wielding groupies who camp out day and night, rain or shine. Next comes the caravan of florist trucks filled with bouquets of wildflowers and white lilies, which the bellmen dutifully place on all available surfaces in each of the pale pink suites.

title: Slouching Toward Mount Laurel
description: IT didn't matter that she was dying of cancer and couldn't walk without help, couldn't breathe without an oxygen tank. Ethel Lawrence insisted on going out on a hot and humid day in June 1994 for a last look at an empty field here that would someday, she hoped, be filled with housing for the poor.

title: Pay For a Stay At Weston Jail?
description: A TOILET, a cot, cold steel bars and an occasional sandwich are the only amenities a prisoner will find in one of Weston's two small holding cells.

title: New Releases
description: HORACE TAPSCOTT: 'AIEE! THE PHANTOM Arabesque

title: I.R. Brownstein, 65, Critic of the Judiciary
description: Irwin R. Brownstein, a Manhattan lawyer and former Brooklyn Democratic leader, state legislator and State Supreme Court Justice, died on March 24 in Miami Beach, while on a family visit. He was 65 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nevada Executes Man Who Killed 3 People
description: A man who killed his former wife, a bartender and a cook in 1984 was executed by injection early today, a few hours after deciding to forgo further appeals of his sentence.

title: Sports of The Times;Syracuse Makes Right Connection
description: GET me long distance, please, Syracuse is in the final. Jason Cipolla picked up the phone at the press table late in the game, to deliver this most improbable news.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;You Could Tell the 'Ism' by the Letterhead
description: IS THE LETTERHEAD endangered? Will the computer eliminate the need for paper correspondence and thereby do away with personal and corporate identities on stationery? Or will lettered banners be reborn in cyberspace?

title: Long Island Q&A: Edward J. Shubel;In the Forefront of High-Power Communications
description: PEOPLE should not be surprised when they receive a telephone call or fax from an airplane 30,000 feet over the ocean. Edward J. Shubel would not be.

title: THE GEOGRAPHY OF TASTE
description: Despite the diversity detailed in "The Geography of Taste," by Florence Fabricant (March 10), gustatory bicoastalism prevails in at least one area. The Best Foods mayonnaise "they treasure" on the West Coast and the Hellmann's prized in the East are one and the same, manufactured by Best Foods -- not so much a case of chacun a son gout as what's in a name?

title: French Bullfights
description: To the Editor: As animal protection organizations throughout the world struggle to end the barbaric spectacle of bullfighting, we at People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals are appalled to see The Times promote it in "Bullfights in France" (Q & A, Feb. 4).

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Blackboard;Turtle Turns Heads, Literally
description: Want to put your college on the map? It's simple. Just get a two-headed turtle. Thomas Nelson Community College in Hampton, Va., has 2,000 students, but not until it was given the freak reptile last semester was it featured in newspapers from Korea to Germany -- not to mention a science show on Canadian national television.

title: Gay, Getting Old, Getting By
description: THEIR romance began in classic New York style. The evening was dark and limp. The rain fell in a silver sheet and the subway train was nearly empty. Bill McDonald, home on leave and out for a good time, sat alone staring blankly out the window. The train stopped at the 65th Street station in Jackson Heights and a handsome man with a yellow handkerchief knotted around his neck boarded on the opposite side of the car.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercury Sable vs. Accord and Camry;Circling the Wagons
description: IF the top brass of the Ford Motor Company kept rejecting sketches of a new Ford Taurus in favor of something bold and different, they certainly got what they wanted. But did they kill the golden goose in the process of coaxing out the latest egg?

title: VIEWS;Survivors: The Lives and Troubled Times of a Newark Tenement
description: In the beginning I had no conscious reason for my interest in No. 322. Intuitively I felt drawn to the place, and it seemed important to photograph it and the people who lived here.

title: March 24-30;A Game of Chicken Ends
description: Remember America's imminent national default? The one that forced bond rating agencies around the world to put the United States on credit watch because Congress was refusing to raise the borrowing limit? Well, never mind. Quietly, almost sheepishly, the Republicans in Congress dropped their demand that President Clinton adopt their budget priorities in return for the needed $600 billion increase in the amount of bonds the Treasury can issue. Last week both houses overwhelmingly passed the increase, tying it to other legislation.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: FOUR adaptations - two from the stage and two the printed page - add spice to the mix on the week's film roster.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about developers who are returning to the real estate market misspelled the surname of the man who recently purchased Cityspire. He is Joseph Neumann, not Newman.

title: March 24-30;Abortion Politics With An Eye on November
description: Congress voted last week to outlaw one type of late-term abortion in the expectation that President Clinton will veto the ban. That would let Republicans use the veto against him in the elections.

title: March 24-30;Tensions Subside Off Taiwan
description: Just a week ago, talk of near-war with China -- stimulated by Chinese missile tests and live-fire exercises near the island -- dominated the windup to Taiwan's presidential election. But once the election was held, and Lee Teng-hui won his predicted convincing victory, the tensions almost immediately began to melt. Each side made a conciliatory statement, followed by indications it will take a tough bargaining stance in, or before, any future contacts. So while it was possible there had been movement toward each other, it was also possible that this was just a retreat from bellicosity.

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW: NL EAST
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the east, the Mets are picked for third.

title: Bulkhead Suits Are More Than Steel vs. Plastic
description: WHEN steel bulkheading was installed to protect Leonard Holzer's house in Water Mill in 1993, the house was in danger of falling into the ocean.

title: ART;Exhibitions Showcasing Multimedia Works
description: 24th Open Competition

title: Habitats/340 East 90th Street;21, and Just Out of College
description: WHETHER New York City was ever the assemblage of weird and wacky characters in those grand black-and-white films of the 30's and 40's -- all put there, it seemed, just to help a gal from the Midwest find her first job, her first apartment and, of course, Mr. Right -- is anybody's guess.

title: FINAL FOUR;The Connecticut Women Were Just a Player Short
description: Any poker player will tell you that two of a kind is good and one of a kind does little. In women's college basketball, Connecticut won the national championship last year because it had two of a kind in the low post -- 6-foot-4-inch Rebecca Lobo, who was the national Player of the Year, and 6-7 Kara Wolters.

title: FINAL FOUR;Kentucky Gets Ahead By Controlling Camby
description: Antoine Walker spent the night mixing his sports metaphors, playing center field in the Kentucky press, playing pulling guard in leading the Kentucky guards up the floor, running post patterns on the fast break and, most effectively, playing doubles with the Kentucky centers on Massachusetts's Marcus Camby.

title: Talking Head;Now, It's the Rhetorical Presidency
description: IT has been a year since President Clinton surprised most of his staff one Friday in Dallas by tossing aside a prepared speech text and delivering a different, more forceful address. There, before an assemblage of newspaper editors, he began spelling out what he would stand for, and what against, ending his long months of passivity and soul-searching in the wake of the Republican sweep of Congress.

title: SPENDING IT;Celebrity Foundations In Glare of the Spotlight
description: MICHAEL JORDAN is best known for his almost effortless command of the basketball court. But in the clubby sports world, he is also known as an astute businessman who controls vast sums of money with equal ease.

title: FINAL FOUR;Kentucky Holds Off Never-Say-Die UMass
description: They had very little experience with the business of losing, just one misstep through a winter the Massachusetts Minutemen could call their own. As they struggled tonight with an aroused group of Kentucky Wildcats, the Minutemen were true to themselves, right down to the very last final buzzer of their season.

title: TV RATINGS;How Violence Might Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Persistence Pays In Getting a Loan
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns;Crack Makes Its Spring Trip Up the Hudson
description: THE spring tourist season begins here after Easter, when people from New York City and thereabouts start coming up to make a day of the 36 antique stores along Warren Street. But the spring drug-dealing season, when youths commute the 120 miles from the city on Amtrak to sell pocketfuls of crack, has already arrived.

title: THEATER;About Women, About Pedestals
description: THE Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven and the Public Theater in Manhattan have joined forces to amplify the voice of Suzan-Lori Parks, but there's more.

title: NOTICED;A New Social Hive With 1940's Glamour
description: WHAT is it about dim 1940's night spots, with their upholstered leather booths and a clientele imbibing highballs and Salisbury steak?

title: New Releases
description: NEIL DIAMOND: 'TENNESSEE MOON' Columbia

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Sea Birds Again Doing Time on Alcatraz
description: Alcatraz Island has once again become a significant marine bird habitat. Last year, rangers spotted nearly 900 nesting pairs on the island, one of the highest counts since the National Park Service took over the 22-acre island in San Francisco Bay in 1972.

title: Excuse Me! You With the Red Thing on Your Head!
description: A business traveler may aspire to be a Citizen of the World, but sometimes he or she just comes across as the Ugly American. Have you -- or maybe a friend -- trampled on sacred local customs, grossly misread a foreigner's intentions or otherwise proved that when it comes to the global economy, you're still L'il Abner? Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;Monuments in Peril: a Top 100 Countdown
description: Correction Appended

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Twins Place Puckett On the Disabled List
description: KIRBY PUCKETT's blurry vision is being caused by a partial blockage of a blood vessel in his right eye, and the Minnesota outfielder will miss the season opener, the Twins said Friday after placing him on the 15-day disabled list.

title: Sold Out
description: We've got the information age all wrong. Someone who reads today's newspapers would conclude that the four most important aspects of the information age are cyberporn, Windows 95, Newt Gingrich and cyberporn. This is like saying that the most important signposts during the rise of industrial capitalism in America were mass-produced pornographic magazines, Warren Gamaliel Harding and the Veg-O-Matic.

title: New Releases
description: AUTECHRE: 'TRI REPETAE' Warp/Wax Trax!/TVT

title: Oil Companies May Have Underpaid Royalties to U.S., Group Says
description: Ten big oil companies may have short-changed the Federal Government by $856 million by understating the value of the oil they pumped from Federal lands and then paying smaller royalties on the reduced value from 1978 to 1993, according to a draft Interior Department report.

title: Political Science
description: LISE MEITNER A Life in Physics. By Ruth Lewin Sime. Illustrated. 526 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $34.95.

title: TENNIS;Graf Blazes Her Way Past Rubin for Fifth Lipton Title
description: Peerless on a cloudless Saturday, Steffi Graf unveiled a brief but brutal display of power tennis before a capacity crowd this afternoon at the Lipton Championships, where the temperature underfoot reached a sizzling 120 degrees.

title: M.S. Suleiman, 77, Egypt's Ex-Premier
description: Mohammed Sidqi Suleiman, a former Prime Minister of Egypt who played an instrumental role in the building of the Aswan High Dam, died on Thursday in Cairo. He was 77.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;On Trying to Name Famous Living Poets
description: TOMORROW, according to T. S. Eliot, begins the cruelest month. Its sweet showers shall pierce March's thirst (Chaucer), its days shall promise uncertain glory (Shakespeare) and it shall arrive as if it possessed sweet, small, clumsy feet (e.e. cummings).

title: POLITICS: THE FIRST VOICES;Polls Find Far Right Doesn't Define G.O.P. Vote
description: Despite warnings from conservatives that Senator Bob Dole risks losing crucial support from the Republican coalition if he moves toward the center, surveys show that the nearly 12 million people who voted in Republican primaries this year are not particularly far right on major social issues like abortion.

title: Westchester Q&A: Kathleen Friedman;Keeping the Deaf Emotionally Healthy
description: IN the movie "Mr. Holland's Opus," the main character has no problem relating to the high school children he teaches, but he can't -- or won't -- communicate with his deaf son.

title: MAKING IT WORK;It's March Madness, Baby. Sue Them.
description: MILLIONS of college basketball fans will be watching the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game on television tomorrow night, but they will not be the only ones experiencing March madness.

title: A Fairy-Tale German City
description: EVEN on a bitterly cold winter afternoon, the sunlight streaming into the hilltop cathedral of Quedlinburg warms its Romanesque sandstone with a golden glow. Deep in the church interior, real gold -- part of a thousand-year-old trove of medieval religious art -- lies in two small, softly lighted treasure chambers on either side of the upper choir.

title: Asian Immigrants Help Bolster U.S. Economy, New Report Says
description: From Cambodian doughnut-shop owners to Chinese electronics engineers, Asian immigrants do far more good than harm to the nation's economy, a new report says.

title: House G.O.P. Forms Environmental Group
description: House Republicans, mindful of criticism that the Republican Party is trying to gut 25 years of environmental laws, have formed a group to come up with an environmental program.

title: ON THE MAP;In Wayne, the Members of a Road Rally Club Start Their Engines
description: For many north Jersey motorists, mention of Wayne conjures horrific images of long waits at the Division of Motor Vehicles' regional penitence center on Route 23 north.

title: WEDDINGS;Jennifer Lewis, Bernard Yamron
description: Jennifer Ann Lewis, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Lewis Jr. of Rye Brook, N.Y., is to be married today to Bernard Benjamin Yamron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredrick N. Yamron of Anaheim, Calif. Rabbi Ronald B. B. Symons is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: March 24-30;Rabin's Killer Gets Life in Prison
description: In a life sentence meted out to Yitzhak Rabin's killer last week, and an official report on security lapses that led to the Prime Minister's assassination, Israelis were asked to contemplate the deepest roots of the trauma that transformed their country last November.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Who Owns The Dreyfus Affair?
description: IS IT, FINALLY, THE LIBRETTIST'S revenge? If it is true that no opera has ever endured solely on the strength of a libretto, it is equally true that librettists seldom get the attention or the respect they deserve.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday The Commerce Department reports on construction spending in February. In January, spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Living Helpless and in Hope;It's Not Easy Being 'Jose'
description: THERE are nearly 100 million Mexicans below the Rio Grande, but in the heat of an American election campaign they often are reduced to cliches.

title: Bridging a Gap With Storytelling
description: THE fourth graders sat in silent rows, politely listening to what might have seemed tales from another planet. Seated opposite them were five women and a man, all elderly witnesses to the world of long ago. The goal was spontaneous combustion between the two groups, a give-and-take with enough candor and amazement to melt the icy walls between the generations.

title: FINAL FOUR;Big East's Hopes Ride With Syracuse
description: If there was going to be a Big East team standing in line for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship, many people figured when the tournament was seeded three weeks ago that it would be Connecticut or Georgetown. Maybe even Villanova.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: SUNDAY VIEW;When Actor and Author Speak as One
description: TAKING TO HEART Willa Cather's description of an actor as a novelist who writes a book every night, I want to tell you about some of the fine stage writing I've come across recently.

title: Settlement in Girl's Death
description: The Rite Aid Pharmacy and a former pharmacist have agreed to pay $1.7 million to the family of an 8-year-old girl who died from a morphine overdose in 1994 after she was given the wrong painkiller while recovering from a tonsillectomy. The girl, Megan McClave, was given Roxanol instead of Demerol.

title: Blackboard;A College Class With a Kick
description: FOR STUDENTS at Franklin Pierce College in Rindge, N.H., there is one required course that brings them to their feet. It's contradancing. Often compared the square dancing, it came to America from France and Scotland in the 18th century. Contradancing is part of required course called "Experienceing the Arts" at the liberal arts college of about 1,100 students. "This area has been called the contradance capital of the world," said Lee Dunholter, the professor of theater arts who teaches the course. "So I think it's important for students who are going to spend four years in the area to take part in and understand what makes the art of contradancing so special."

title: Blackboard;Unconventional Mathematician is Making Brain Waves
description: Fred L. Bookstein, an unconventional mathematician at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, has used his skills in an arcane field to come up with a statistical approach to identify differences in the shapes of schizophrenics' brains, perhaps allowing treatment to begin een before the disease strikes.

title: Blackboard;Making Math Add Up for Girls
description: If Karen Karp has her way, girls will storm the barricades of arithmetic and move on to triumph in algebra, calculus and the numbered frontiers beyond. Her fight is to reverse the downward spiral in m athematics that so many girls experience between the ages of 10 and 13.

title: A LOOK BACK;Commissioners Past and Present
description: Howard Safir has never worked for a city police force, but he had extensive experience in Federal law enforcement and was known as a strong manager as New York City's Fire Commissioner. He began his career in 1965 as an undercover agent with the Federal Bureau of Narcotics, rose through the ranks of the Drug Enforcement Administration, then joined the United States Marshals Service. In 1984, he became the service's associate director of operations, a post he held until 1990, when he retired to found a security-consulting company. Mr. Safir, 54, is the 39th Police Commissioner since 1901, when the single-commissioner system replaced the old board of comissioners. The following is a list of commissioners since Patrick V. Murphy, who was considered the guiding force bhind the modern police department.

title: The Wild Boy of Nuremberg
description: LOST PRINCE The Unsolved Mystery of Kaspar Hauser. Translated and introduced by Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: The Free Press. $23. THERE are literally thousands of books and articles in German about Kaspar Hauser, the 19th-century German wild boy, and about everything that has anything to do with his case. There are poems by Verlaine and Trakl, a novel by Jakob Wassermann, a play by Peter Handke and an excellent movie made in 1974 by Werner Herzog. In far-off America, Herman Melville compared Billy Budd, the innocent, tongue-tied and doomed-victim sailor, to Kaspar. There are even books about the books and articles devoted to the case -- it remains a kind of cultural cause clbre. Now there is "Lost Prince," by Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson, who at least in part has made something of a career by calling attention to himself. Mr. Masson has produced an extremely eccentric volume on Kaspar Hauser. But since Kaspar's story is not widely known in English, a brief summary of its principal features may be useful at the outset.

title: WEDDINGS;Debra Feldman, Christopher Kiah
description: Debra Lynn Feldman, a daughter of Dianne L. Feldman of New Providence, N.J., and David P. Feldman of Warren, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Rowe Kiah, a son of Janet and David Kiah of Newton Centre, Mass. Msgr. William J. Capik officiated at the Church of St. James in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Cartoon Museum Heads South
description: The International Museum of Cartoon Art opened this month in new quarters in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Nowhere to Go
description: AGAINST GRAVITY By Lucy Ferriss. 303 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22. IN small towns, dissimilar people are compelled to know one another over time. Yearnings, antagonisms, subterfuges and alliances occur among residents who cannot later become strangers. For many, that is a fair price to pay for life in a place that is rooted and decipherable.

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS;Susan Harris, Glenn Gissler
description: WALKING into Susan Harris and Glenn Gissler's apartment for the first time, you might feel you were in Paris or San Francisco rather than Greenwich Village. Honeysuckle-yellow light pours through the wall of casement windows and into their large living room, a song by Natalie Merchant is playing, and right after the couple open the door, they offer to make cappuccino.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 3 about the Gore Mountain ski area in New York State misstated the location of Tannersville. It is 100 miles south of Bolton Landing, not nearby.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK;In Limbo: The Summer Job
description: Fourteen-year-old Elsie Perez's very first paycheck last summer wasn't for a lot of money, just $500 for seven 24-hour work weeks at a day camp in Sunset Park. But it was hers, enough to buy her own school clothes. Omar Sherwood's check was enough to buy gifts for his baby sisters and savor the pleasure of a measure of financial independence at 17. Aileen Quinones, 16, earned enough to buy Christmas presents for her little brother.

title: Sunday March 31, 1996;A QUESTION FOR: Lynda La Plante
description: She is the 50-year-old English creator of the Emmy-winning PBS series "Prime Suspect." Her first novel set in the United States, "Cold Shoulder," was just published by Random House.

title: F.Y.I.
description: History's Ticking

title: WEDDINGS;Molly Porterfield, Douglas Hanslip
description: Molly Anne Porterfield, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Edward Porterfield of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Douglas Glendon Hanslip, a son of E. Robert Hanslip of New Canaan and the late Suzanne French Hanslip. The Rev. Dr. John Boyle performed the ceremony at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago.

title: Amazing Anagrams
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes/The Candler Building;Amid 42d Street Renewal, a Facade in Disrepair
description: THROUGH all the hoopla of New York State's 42d Street Development Project, the gleaming terra-cotta Candler building has remained in private hands, looking slightly scruffier year by year, as if in anticipation of reaping a jackpot from surrounding rehabilitation.

title: The Arithmetic Of Beauty
description: IN Fuji Bank's fall ad campaign, a surpassingly elegant young man considers the relationship between a sunflower and a vase.

title: MUSIC;Works That Celebrate the Life of Anne Frank
description: A YEAR ago, Serenata -- the trio of Lisa Hansen, flutist, Wendy Kerner Lucas, harpist, and Maura Molloy, mezzo-soprano -- helped the Chaminade Club of Yonkers observe its centennial with a concert of music by its namesake composer. When Serenata returns to the club for performances on Tuesday at 1:45 P.M. at the Will Library, the ensemble will observe a more solemn anniversary: the 50 years since the death of Anne Frank. Besides Ravel's "Two Hebrew Melodies" and a set of Hebrew canons by Charles Lichter, the program includes "I Remember," which was commissioned by Serenata and had its premiere last month at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.

title: Sports of The Times;Wildcats Divide and Then Conquer the Minutemen's Inseparable Pair
description: EDGAR PADILLA, who'd had a trusty partner this entire season, was suddenly alone. Alone against the Kentucky press.

title: Classical Brief
description: PROKOFIEV: 'ROMEO AND JULIET' (EXCERPTS) San Francisco Symphony conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas. RCA Victor Red Seal 09026-68288-2; CD.

title: The Games That Children Play, From Jump Robe to Video
description: PLAY can be fun but it's also serious business, especially for children. It can reduce shyness and stress, breed friendships, strengthen cultural ties and enhance the art of communication. It can involve anything from toys and games to make-believe. And toys of the past can offer clues to the society that made and used them.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Who's Afraid of Jobs and Growth?
description: BOND and stock markets in shock! Dow plunges 171 points on stunning news of a big gain in jobs in February! Interest rates spike as unemployment drops to 5.5 percent! That was the report a few weeks ago.

title: WEDDINGS;Natalie Apprendi And Adam Levy
description: Natalie Eve Apprendi, the daughter of Sandra and Joseph Apprendi of Millville, N.J., was married last evening to Adam Benjamin Levy, the son of Barbara and Richard Levy of New York. Rabbi Solomon Acrish performed the ceremony at the Haig Point Country Club on Daufuskie Island, S.C.

title: New Takes on the Melting Pot
description: WHEN Judy Sulik moved to Bridgeport from the suburbs a few years ago she went exploring her new hometown and was amazed. Along with the expected Italian restaurants and Irish taverns she found a veritable United Nations of cuisines. Around every corner the native food of yet another ethnic group was being served.

title: Woman Dies in Explosion
description: A woman was killed today in an explosion and fire at a Rockland County gas station.

title: March 24-30;Dole's Big Moment
description: Talk about anti-climactic. Bob Dole passed the 996-delegate mark in the California primary last week to numerically clinch the Republican nomination for President. Yet the breakthrough was hardly noticed; ever since his triumph in South Carolina on March 2, the Senate majority leader had been rolling over his opponents so convincingly that no one had a chance to catch up, and everyone knew it. The next big events will be in August, when the Republicans hold their party convention in San Diego and the Democrats gather in Chicago. Tune in again then. RICHARD L. BERKE

title: Pilgrimages
description: THE NET OF DREAMS A Family's Search for a Rightful Place. By Julie Salamon. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: FILM VIEW;In the Authenticity Game, Only a Few Win
description: CITIZEN KANE," acclaimed by some as the greatest movie ever made, begins with a scene that looks remarkably fake. The Xanadu castle of Charles Foster Kane, looming behind a wrought-iron gate, is an obvious and not particularly striking example of matte painting. Orson Welles might have been able to come up with something more realistic, but he didn't want to; this short prologue has a purposefully dreamlike air, serving as a doleful adagio introduction to the fast-paced documentary segment that follows. Underneath the images, Bernard Herrmann's score quotes Rachmaninoff's "Isle of the Dead," a funereal tone poem inspired by Arnold Bocklin's once-famous painting of the same title. The whole sequence has the air of a grim storybook.

title: Future Meltdown
description: THE ENDS OF THE EARTH A Journey at the Dawn of the 21st Century. By Robert D. Kaplan. 476 pp. New York: Random House. $27.50.

title: JERSEY;The End of History, the Start of Tourism
description: DR. JOSEPH SALVATORE, the chairman of the State Historical Commission, felt a little awkward the other morning. He was standing alone beside a winding road with a picket sign that said: "Gov. Whitman: Don't Let the Commission Become History."

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: LEGENDS OF THE SAMURAI By Hiroaki Scato. Overlook, $29.95.

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW: AL CENTRAL
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the east, the Yankees are picked for second.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;Let's Leave Daughters In School
description: THE fourth annual Take Our Daughters to Work Day will be observed in just a few weeks, on Thursday, April 25. Started in 1993 by the Ms. Foundation for Women, it is meant to be an opportunity for girls between the ages of 9 and 15 to visit their parents or other adults at their places of business in order to observe what happens in the working world.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION: CHOOSING SIDES
description: PHAT X. CHIEM UNDERSTOOD well why many of his fellow Vietnamese-american students on the University of California's campus here opposed affirmative action.

title: The Beats of Edinburgh
description: LATE AFTERNOON AT ROBBIE'S, A PUB IN LEITH, A working-class district of Edinburgh, Scotland. Everyone is drinking Budweiser, of all things, by the pint. The air reeks of cigarettes and beer. Crowded around a corner table -- beneath cigarette ads, old-fashioned mirrors and two large-horned-animal skulls (probably Highland cattle) -- are Duncan McLean, Gordon Legge, Alan Warner and Paul Reekie, together with some blond-haired women and a young man with a shaved head and multi-pierced ears. McLean is holding forth on Scottish literature. At 31, he is one of the youngest of a group of Scottish writers who have smashed their way out of rave culture onto the British literary scene.

title: Disk Jockeys Will Apologize for Mosque Incident
description: Two local radio station disk jockeys who played "The Star Spangled Banner" on a trumpet and a bugle in a local mosque have agreed to make daily apologies for a week on their radio show and the station, KBPI, has said it will buy advertisements in the newspaper and on television to apologize for its employees' conduct.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;The Logic Of the 'Mad Cow' Scare
description: POLITICS and food intermingle. Ask any candidate who has followed the campaign ritual through New York City, eating his way caterpillar-like through the ethnic neighborhoods. The kosher hot dog, the Irish soda bread, the cannoli, the kielbasa. Food as tribal bonding: I eat what you eat; vote for me.

title: March 24-30;The Tough Get Going
description: Atop a crest of national admiration for New York City's reduction in crime, the city's Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton, suddenly resigned last week. Tensions between him and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had been building for more than a year, swirling around issues of control and credit for lowering crime to levels not seen since the 1960's. Even as Mr. Bratton was becoming a nationwide symbol of successful police work, City Hall officials had begun to feel that he was insufficiently deferential to the Mayor's authority. Meanwhile, Mr. Bratton and other police brass had chafed at what they believed was Mr. Giuliani's interference in police management.

title: Together Again
description: GERMANY UNIFIED AND EUROPE TRANSFORMED A Study in Statecraft. By Philip Zelikow and Condoleezza Rice. Illustrated. 493 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $35.

title: EAT OR BE EATEN
description: You list the pressure cooker as an invention that fizzled. As a matter of fact, I still enjoy using my mother's Presto, which dates from the 1940's. It cooks my weekly stew in less than 20 minutes. Some vigilance is required to watch the rings on the indicator rise as the steam builds, but this adds a bit of excitement to the chemistry of cooking.

title: Turning Out Thousands of Chocolate Bunnies and 'Creatures'
description: WITH Easter fast approaching, the night crew at Joseph's Chocolate Chalet has been in high gear, at work regularly until almost midnight, molding and adorning thousands of chocolate bunnies, ducks and other figures.

title: THE NATION;Minimum Wage, Maximum Debate
description: ALTHOUGH many Republicans are loath to admit it, there is an undeniable logic to Democratic proposals to raise the $4.25-an-hour minimum wage.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: FLUSHING;Munchies From Miss Potter
description: BEATRIX Potter wrote the tale of naughty Peter Rabbit and his siblings, Flopsy, Mopsy and Cottontail, in 1893, in an illustrated letter to her former governess's son, Noel Moore. Now, more than 100 years later, the story of how Peter burrows under the fence of Mr. McGregor's garden and munches on his delicious radishes and lettuce is still a favorite among children.

title: HOW WE EAT
description: Shopping at organic supermarkets, joining food co-ops, purchasing veggies and fruit (of an exotic nature) at local farmers' markets -- I don't know which to do first, but perhaps I'll do more of it after digesting your wonderful issue devoted to food.

title: HOW WE EAT
description: Congratulations on an outstanding issue, "How We Eat: An America Divided" (March 10). As with all your special issues, you have provided ample portions of that most vital category of nourishment: food for thought.

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW: AL EAST
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the east, the Yankees are picked for second.

title: A Journey From Melbourne Is a Pilgrimage for Justice
description: One day last week, Max and Fay Rosenbaum were driven past the corner of President Street and Brooklyn Avenue in Crown Heights where their son was fatally stabbed four and half years ago.

title: The Stealth Candidate
description: IF YOU LISTEN TO THE DEMOCRATS AND REPUBLICANS, THEY would have you believe that the 1996 Presidential race has already settled into a simple contest between Dole and Clinton. They ignore Ross Perot and his quest for a third party. Few Democrats and Republicans understand what his undertaking means for November. If they did, they would be worried.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Pope Urges Reforms in Labor and Welfare
description: Pope John Paul II, resuming his travels outside the Vatican today after an illness, strongly defended workers' rights and warned of the dangers of "easy welfare."

title: THE BIRDCAGE';Lesbian Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW WE EAT
description: Some of the pictures in your special issue reveal a perhaps unintended commentary. On page 38, a man and woman grab a quick dinner -- she sits on the floor, talking on a cordless phone. On page 39, a family prepares to have dinner -- one of the three wears headphones. On page 46, two men eat at McDonald's -- one is using a cellular phone.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: MISTER CHRISTIAN By William Kinsolving. Simon & Schuster, $23.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CRUISE SHIP;A Farewell Voyage
description: Holland America's flagship, the Rotterdam, which entered service in 1959, will make its final voyage Sept. 12 to 20, 1997, sailing from Vancouver, British Columbia, to Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The 38,645-ton ship, which has made 28 world cruises, will make its 29th and last round-the-world cruise from January through April next year. Most of the rest of the ship's final season will consist of seven-day Alaska cruises.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Braves Lose Jones
description: Third baseman CHIPPER JONES was placed on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to March 22, after arthroscopic surgery to remove a bone chip from his right knee, the Atlanta Braves said yesterday. Jones, 23, will be eligible to play April 6. Jones batted .265 with 23 home runs and 86 r.b.i. last year. (AP)

title: Backtalk;Who's on Verse?
description: On June 3, 1888, "Casey at the Bat" first appeared quietly on the pages of The San Francisco Examiner. Since that time, it has become one of America's best-known and best-loved poems. An even though mighty Casey's failure at the plate is initially tragic and surprising, it is, perhaps, a comforting metaphor for all of us in the Mudville masses.

title: Berlin Gets Overdue Bill For Uniting 2 Germanys
description: The financial cost of German unification finally struck Berlin this week, with the City Council approving the biggest budget cuts in half a century despite days of angry and sometimes violent street protests.

title: Unconventional Healer
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT;Finally, a Video Store for Harlem
ON POLITICS;Dreams of Washington Remain Dreams, For Now
description: Governor Whitman began the Tuesday morning telephone conversation with Bob Dole by offering congratulations on his victory in California, which clinched the Republican nomination. She asked when he planned to campaign in New Jersey for the June Presidential primary. Then she told him the real reason for her call.

title: In the Kingdom of Mourne
description: A TRADITIONAL Irish song sings of a Banbridge girl as "the star of the County Down," but the true attraction of this part of Northern Ireland, it has long seemed to me, is toward the county's southern end where -- in the words of another popular song -- "the Mountains of Mourne sweep down to the sea."

title: Choosing My Religion
description: NOT LONG AGO, I WAS HAVING SHABBOS dinner with three friends. I am still new to all this. As the candles were lighted and a song was sung, I stumbled along. We washed our hands, then said the blessing as we dried them. I did know that you weren't supposed to speak until the bread had been blessed, so I went back to the table.

title: HOME CLINIC;Some Easy Steps to Repairing Lamps
description: SIMPLE incandescent lamps consist of three basic electrical parts: the plug, the cord and the socket. When the lamp fails to work, one or more of these components is defective (assuming that the bulb is good and there is power to the outlet -- i.e., there are no tripped circuit breakers or blown fuses). Begin troubleshooting by examining each part, but first, unplug the lamp. A visual inspection may be reveal an obvious defect like a broken or a disconnected wire.

title: YOUR HOME;Diplomats And Their Immunity
description: THERE are few things landlords appreciate more than a tenant with a steady job, impeccable credentials and a prime minister or monarch as a credit reference. And there are few things that landlords appreciate less than a nonpaying tenant who is summons-proof, judgment-proof and not at all intimidated by an eviction notice tacked to the door.

title: The Thinnest Blue Line
description: RICHARD PENNINGTON LOOKS DOUR AS HE THREADS HIS way among the ponytails and little black dresses at Planet Hollywood in the French Quarter. The new Police Superintendent is wearing a splashy tie, and his double-breasted suit makes his broad shoulders appear even more imposing than usual. But he remains silent as his wife, Rene Webb, stops to mingle. Scanning the room through wire-rimmed glasses, Pennington seems aloof, distracted. It has been 18 months since he was brought in from Washington to clean up the New Orleans Police Department, which some have called the worst in America. Yet the chief continues to maintain a wary distance from strangers, still not sure whom to trust.

title: DIARY
description: BEEF British Exports Banned The European Commission banned the export of British beef and beef byproducts amid fears that a deadly brain disease could enter the human food chain from British cattle. The British Government called the ban unfair even as it made plans to slaughter at least some of Britain's 11 million head of cattle. BANKING Insurance Sales Upheld The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that banks may sell insurance from branch offices in small towns despite state laws to the contrary. The ruling will allow banks to sell insurance in 15 states, including Connecticut, Florida and New Jersey, that had barred such sales.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Memphis
description: Memphis reverberates with music during April and May, when the city rushes to honor the Southern tradition of big outdoor parties before the sultry summer takes hold.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Passports, Tax Still Backed Up
description: TRAVELERS are still feeling an impact from the Government shutdowns and snow days.

title: Giuliani Formally Appoints Correction Chief
description: In his third major appointment in as many days, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday named Michael P. Jacobson as the Commissioner of the city's Department of Correction.

title: The Shepaug's Waters: How Much Should Go to Whom?
description: IT doesn't matter which way the water of the Shepaug River is flowing, someone isn't happy about it. A 1921 agreement signed by both the City of Waterbury and the Town of Washington has surfaced, along with an escalating argument about how much of the Shepaug's water Waterbury is really entitled to, and how much should be left in the river.

title: Before the Revolution
description: The Secret of the Bulls By Jose Raul Bernardo. 299 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.

title: SOAPBOX;Strangers on a Train
description: I'VE been commuting between New Jersey and Manhattan for 12 years same time (7:54), same car (fourth from last) and, insofar as possible, same seat (second row, window). We commuters are creatures of habit, and we often sit next to the same person for years.

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW: NOTEBOOK;What Most Becomes an Heir to a Legend?
description: Tino Martinez, meet Doug DeCinces and Ray Knight.

title: Tracing Luther's Bold Footsteps
description: GO not to Wittenberg," Hamlet's mother urges him early in the Shakespeare play. The Danish prince bowed to his mother's wish and did not return to his studies at Wittenberg University, but this year, swarms of travelers will ignore her advice. They will make Wittenberg one of their main stops as they tour eastern Germany to visit the places where Martin Luther lived, worked and preached.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Missing Ingredients for Many 401(k)'s
description: PLENTY of investors have become believers in stock index funds, which aim to track a market instead of outperform it. But a key group remains outside the fold: 401(k) plan participants.

title: In the Region/Westchester;It's Spring, and Seeds Are Sown for Ice Rinks
description: NOW that the crocuses are up and spring is in the air it seems an odd time to be discussing ice skating. But ground will be broken next month for a twin rink complex open to the public in Elmsford, the first to be built in Westchester in 21 years.

title: News Analysis;A Plus for NATO in Bosnia
description: NATO's success so far in enforcing a military settlement of the war in Bosnia has restored the credibility and sense of purpose the alliance has been seeking since the end of the cold war, but the achievement rests on foundations as fragile as the peace here.

title: ON BASKETBALL;Syracuse Is Playing In a Zone of Its Own
description: FOR the last three weeks, Syracuse has been in that indescribable, indefinable area of performance called a zone.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Christian Rendeiro;Lessons in Citizenship From Portugal
description: CHRISTIAN RENDEIRO, 82, may well deserve the nickname "Mr. Hamden" more than any other individual. Twenty-six years ago he started the town's Goldenbells Festival, which has been celebrated under his leadership ever since and is taking place this year from April 14 to May 5. He was also the inspiration behind the town's carillon, which has chimed at Town Hall since 1986 (Hamden's bicentennial celebration).

title: COPING;For the Love of 'Lit' and the Drama of Life
description: Jim Perine chose "The Chosen" by Chaim Potok for his ninth-grade honors English class not only because it is a page-turner about cultural clashes, fathers and sons, religion, fate and teen-aged friendship that would have special resonance for the newly arrived Russians and Asians of Rego Park, but because he could get copies at discount. The $6.99 paperback was available through a book club for $3.50. Art is long but money's tight.

title: INSIDE
description: Your Home Diplomatic Immunity The first rule in dealing with diplomats is knowing which ones are protected by immunity from lawsuits. By Jay Romano 5

title: Albania to Call Elections
description: Albania's Parliament was dissolved on Friday so general elections can be held after four years of striving to transform the Stalinist country into a democracy, the Parliament Speaker, Pjeter Arbnori, said today.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Education Life/Section 4A

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: A Place to Eat, Drink and Smoke Cigars

title: Cuttings;When Malmaison Celebrated the Rose's Beauty
description: An English rosarian once told me with a twinkle in his eye, "I understand that her rose garden was designed in the pattern of the Union Jack." We were discussing the legendary rose garden at Malmaison, the home of Josephine Bonaparte. She lived there from 1799 until her death in 1814, first as the wife of Gen. Napoleon Bonaparte, then as his Empress, then as his former wife, after he divorced her in his quest for an heir.

title: Huck and Jim
description: To the Editor:

description: Beth Harriet Littmann, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil A. Littmann of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Darin Richard Laub, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Laub of Old Brookville, L.I. Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains.
