description: To the Editor:

title: Crackdown on Mob Seen as Mixed Blessing at Fish Market
description: In the dawn chill, workers bundled in leather jackets and sweaters grapple with ice-coated crates to keep seafood moving through the Fulton Fish Market, just as they have always done. But these days they labor in the charred hulk of a building, in cramped, makeshift quarters while major construction work goes on about them.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: WINTER TALES By George Mackay Brown. John Murray/Trafalgar Square, $25.95.

title: Bucking Tradition, Gardener Plants High-Yield Squares
description: I was always taught if you can't go over a mountain, you go around it; if you can't go around it, you tunnel through it; if you can't tunnel through it, you stay and make a gold mine out of that side," Mel Bartholomew of Setauket said.

title: Carolina Slacker
description: EDISTO REVISITED By Padgett Powell. 145 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $20.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about the construction of a juvenile detention center in Brownsville, Brooklyn, misstated the history of the site. Proposals have been made to build a school there but no school was ever scheduled to open.

title: Anne Ford Johnson, 76, Dies; Influenced Fashion and Arts
description: Anne McDonnell Ford Johnson, who served on the White House Fine Arts Committee during the Eisenhower and Kennedy administrations, helped restore Blair House in Washington and played an active role in social and charitable events in New York, died Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. She was 76.

title: Critics Say Coroner Puts His Morality Before the Facts
description: For a man whose job consists mostly of signing death certificates, it seems a bit out of place to find Dr. Dexter Amend cloistered behind a fortress of metal detectors and screeners in the once-sleepy office of Spokane County Coroner.

title: Croatian General Plans to Surrender To Hague Tribunal
description: The Croatian Government announced today that a Bosnian Croat general charged with involvement in the killing of hundreds of Muslim civilians would turn himself in to international prosecutors on Monday. The move was described by visiting American officials as an important step forward in bringing war criminals in the Balkan conflict to justice.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;'High Incident': The Naked Suburb
description: A POWER MOWER IS NOT usually an object of desire, much less an object invested with great emotional resonance. But at the end of the first installment of "High Incident," ABC's new cop drama on Monday nights at 9, a sentimental policeman named Lenny Gayer (Matt Craven) rode a power mower in memory of his dead partner. The partner, who had been planning to buy the mower that weekend, had been shot and killed days before, and Gayer's gesture of mourning and friendship was to get that mower and cut his partner's lawn.

title: Classical Briefs
description: 'CANZONI E DANZE' Piffaro. Archiv 445 883-2; CD.

title: DANCE;How a Choreographer Found His Dream Home
description: Serge Bennathan had a dream, even if he didn't realize it would one day lead his Toronto-based company, Dancemakers, to the corner of Eighth Avenue and 19th Street in Manhattan and the stage of the Joyce Theater.

title: Lilco Warns Rate Cuts Could Mean '97 Increases
description: UNDER pressure from the State Public Service Commission to propose immediate rate reductions, Lilco has warned that making any cuts now would mean higher rates as early as next year.

title: Stirrings
description: VTAL DUST Life as a Cosmic Imperative. By Christian de Duve. 362 pp. New York: Basic Books. Paper, $14. WHEN Charles Darwin wrote the "Origin of Species," he deliberately refused to speculate about the first beginnings of life, claiming he hardly knew enough to make any lasting contribution, and he held back from discussing what he really thought about the mental world of human beings, the highest point of the evolutionary process. Caution was necessary. Excited talk about spontaneous generation of insects occurring after electricity was run through overripe cheeses, and inflammatory, tub-thumping sermons on the miracle of divine creation, made the first stirrings of life on Earth the most perplexing and fascinating problem of the era. Similarly, to discuss the human mind as if its action were nothing more than the mechanical product of the brain might invite a storm of protest. Darwin therefore kept his evolutionary proposals inside strict self-imposed limits -- and was aghast when the hurricane that gathered raged around the very issues he studiously ignored. It is extraordinary how much more is now known about these mysterious beginnings and endings, the parts of the evolutionary panorama that Darwin left out. Over the last 30 years or so the whole emphasis of research has shifted toward opening up the world of the minute, the vibrant hidden frontiers of life. Christian de Duve's "Vital Dust," published in 1995 and now reissued in a welcome paperback format, provides an astonishingly full account of this new story about life, as lucid and engaging as the "Origin" itself. Here is the entire sweep of what is known about living matter.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;A Star Is Torn
description: No, INFAMOUS (Dutton, $23.95) isn't that manuscript -- the one Joan Collins's former Random House editors recently described to a Manhattan jury as uneditable piffle. "Infamous" is a later oeuvre, one that Rosemary Cheetham, a top English editor, proudly offered the same jury as proof that Miss Collins's writing could indeed be redeemed, albeit with extraordinary editorial effort. Having read "Infamous," I now know that Ms. Cheetham committed esthetic perjury, which carries the cruel and unusual sentence of having to read the unpublished Random House manuscript. Aloud. "Infamous" (on which Ms. Cheetham testified she spent an enormous amount of work) is moderately coherent, all right, but whatever sense of salacious fun Miss Collins may have brought to the manuscript has been lost. The writing just isn't cheesy enough. With metronome-like dutifulness, "Infamous" tracks the endless travails of Katherine Bennet, an actress popular for her role as a wealthy villainess on a nighttime television soap opera and an obvious stand-in for Miss Collins, who played Alexis Carrington Colby on "Dynasty." If Katherine Bennet is the poisonous Georgia Skeffington on the small screen, everywhere else she is a long-suffering victim -- generous, loving, faithful nad constantly betrayed. But who wants to read a "Gone With the Wind" as told by Melanie Hamilton? By the last 100 pages, it is clear that Ms. Cheetham's insistence that Miss Collins's work can be made readable is just flat-out wrong. The final episodes, in which Katherine realizes that her fabulous new husband is a full- blown psychopath, are so execrably written that they threaten to give popcorn fiction a bad name. Even the obligatory sex scenes are undercooked. JAN HOFFMAN

title: Counties Make Big Reductions In Home Relief
description: When Chris Scott applied for welfare last month, his case manager handed him a pamphlet that laid out strict guidelines he had to follow. It had a bland title, "Job Search Handbook," but to Mr. Scott it read like a manifesto for sharply curtailing public assistance -- a movement that is taking hold in counties across New York.

title: WEDDINGS;Julie Grayson and Jay Goldbaum
description: Julie Grayson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Grayson of Old Brookville, L.I., was married last evening to Jay Goldbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold K. Goldbaum of Manhattan. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated at Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I.

title: TECHNOLOGY VIEW;Better Bargains Than Ever, Far From the Basement
description: AS THE RAGE FOR home theater has pushed music reproduction out of the spotlight, music lovers have gained a paradoxical windfall. The demands of movie soundtracks, with their multichannel sound, have led to improved designs in receivers and generally helped turn hi-fi stereo into a better bargain than ever.

title: Bombing Suspects Transferred to Colorado
description: Timothy J. McVeigh and Terry L. Nichols, the two suspects in the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, were transferred today from Oklahoma to a Federal prison outside Denver, where their trial is to be held this year.

title: Schools, Principals and Image;On Lower East Side, Expertise at No Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Imperial Russia
description: The latest unwelcome detour in Russia's transition from Communism to democracy is serious talk in Moscow of reconstituting the Soviet Union or some variation of it. It is alarming to find this idea back in vogue so soon after the repressive Soviet empire was broken up. Responsible political leaders in Russia must strongly oppose the notion that the Kremlin might someday seek to reassert control over its neighbors.

title: Night Bloom
description: Lush, evening wear is the glory of the couture. And this spring's crop is no exception.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Watchung Power Center Proposed at Lockheed Site
description: FOR more than 30 years, the 85-acre Lockheed Electronics complex was a constant sight alongside Route 22 in the Somerset County Borough of Watchung. But in 1990 it closed, leaving behind a prime, albeit polluted, piece of property.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 17 about movies that are released directly on videocassette without being shown in theaters or on television included one title incorrectly. The film "Normal Life" is scheduled to have its initial release on HBO, not on cassette.

title: In Uganda, An Election Where Parties Are Silenced
description: Uganda's first presidential election officially got under way this week with plenty of hoopla, speeches, rallies and bunting, but without the one ingredient opposition politicians say would make it possible to unseat President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni: political parties.

title: Steinberg and State Reach Accord on Suit
description: THE state and Saul Steinberg, the financier and major contributor to George E. Pataki's gubernatorial campaign, reached a settlement this month on a suit over a steel bulkhead at the Steinberg house on Dune Road in Quogue Village.

title: FINAL FOUR: NOTEBOOK;Teammate's Decision Led Wallace to Stay
description: Syracuse forward John Wallace said if one of his teammates, guard Lazarus Sims, had not returned, he probably would not have made his well-publicized decision not to enter the National Basketball Association draft.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: AIRLINE;Coffee, Tea or Beer?
description: Beginning this month, Kiwi International Air Lines will serve a beer of the month on its flights, for $3 a bottle, the same as the regular brands. The featured brand for March is Corona (even though the airline doesn't fly to Mexico).

title: Agency Board Dismisses Man Over Scandal With Contract
description: The social service agency whose $43 million in city contracts was canceled last week by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has dismissed the administrator who won the contracts last year.

title: DINING OUT;Bonding, Italian Style
description: BIANCA JAGGER and Representative Robert G. Torricelli may have occasionally dined at Buongustaio, but the man sitting across from me is far more typical of the restaurant's clientele. Few people know either his name or his occupation, but he's well taken care of. No sooner does he enter than a glass of ice is set down on his table. (Buongustaio doesn't have a liquor license, and he likes to start his dinner with whisky, which he pours from his own metal flask.)

title: Theatrical Touches for Holiday Themes
description: FOR a church music director, Paul Epstein has what he considers rather radical ideas.

title: Abortion Politics
description: In a move that seems as much a matter of politics as principle, Congress has voted to outlaw a particular type of late-term abortion method and impose criminal penalties on doctors who use it. Last week's vote in the House sends the bill to President Clinton, who has threatened a veto. The fact that the abortion issue is always volatile in a Presidential election year should not prevent Mr. Clinton from carrying out his threat.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 The corporate basketball leagues: March Madness and plenty of elbows in this inside game.

title: New Releases
description: ROSANNE CASH: '10 SONG DEMO' Capitol

title: HOCKEY;Numbers Are Low, Appreciation Is High
description: The numbers are what first stand out, and what also make the questions necessary. Jari Kurri has scored 583 goals, seventh best in National Hockey League history, and his 1,338 career points are a record for any player born outside North America.

title: The Cover-Up
description: THE AMERASIA SPY CASE Prelude to McCarthyism. By Harvey Klehr and Ronald Radosh. Illustrated. 266 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $29.95.

title: IN PERSON;Weird. Seriously Weird.
description: Mark Sceurman is looking for Midgetville.

title: Blackboard;You're a Neanderthal! And That's a Compliment
description: An anthropology professor at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y., has brought political correctness to a whole new level: he teaches a course championing Neanderthals against stereotyping.

title: Marsha Wenk, 37, A.C.L.U. Official
description: Marsha Wenk, legal director of the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, which prevailed in cases involving school prayer and a law requiring community notification about the presence of paroled sex offenders, died at New York University Medical Center on March 23. She was 37 and lived in Bloomfield.

title: LIVES;My Inner Shrimp
description: For the rest of my days, I shall be a recovering short person. Even from my lofty perch of something over six feet (as if I don't know within a micron), I have the soul of a shrimp. I feel the pain of the diminutive, irrespective of whether they feel it themselves, because my visit to the planet of the teen-age midgets was harrowing, humiliating and extended. I even perceive my last-minute escape to have been flukish, somehow unearned -- as if the Commissioner of Growth Spurts had been an old classmate of my father.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Foot Dragging In Albany Puts Programs at Risk
description: TOMORROW may be the deadline for passing the state's budget, but that has come to mean little in Albany. This year, as has been the case for the past 12 in the state's capital, agreement on a spending plan for the coming fiscal year still appears a long way off.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;European Churches Address Tourism's Toll
description: ARE they churches? Are they museums? The question is increasingly vexing church officials across Europe, as the number of visitors to sacred buildings increases.

title: Q. & A.
description: Holding Off On Filing A Deed

title: Huck and Jim
description: To the Editor:

title: STREET SMARTS;Odyssey Nutriceutical: Prescription for Disaster
description: PLY some stockbrokers with a few drinks, and soon they'll spill the dirty secret: When it comes to suckers, Wall Street likes nobody better than doctors.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;The City That Poor Richard Could Afford
description: IT is necessary for me to be extremely frugal for some time," wrote a green young Benjamin Franklin in 1726 on his return to Philadelphia after a brief stay in London. Taking a note from him, I found a thrifty way to get to the City of Brotherly Love in mid-January. I did it not by walking across New Jersey (as Franklin once did) or by buying a $60 off-peak, round-trip ticket on Amtrak, but by taking a New Jersey Transit train from Pennsylvania Station in New York; in Trenton, I transferred to an R7 Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority train to Suburban Station, in the heart of Philadelphia's Center City. The trip took two and a half hours, an hour longer than Amtrak would have. But the connection was easy and the off-peak round-trip ticket cost just $24.

title: Upper-Class Twits Made Me Do It
description: ROGUE TRADER How I Brought Down Barings Bank and Shook the Financial World. By Nick Leeson with Edward Whitley. Illustrated. 273 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95

title: On Social Security, Proceed With Caution
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Bus Half Empty or Half Full?
description: The Upper East Side, with only one subway line, has traditionally depended on its buses. Yet bus ridership has been dropping and the Transit Authority has run some lines at a substantial loss for the last decade. Nearly every attempt to trim service, however, has been opposed by local politicians and neighborhood advocates.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;Blockbuster Blooms in a Longtime Video Wasteland
description: For years, Harlem residents have complained that their community suffers from a case of benign neglect when it comes to life's amenities. Until recently, basic conveniences like pizza delivery were unavailable to the area's predominantly black population. Videos were rented at a handful of mom and pop general stores -- with relatively small selections -- or bootlegged through an open-air market of street vendors.

title: Canceled Trip
description: To the Editor: We have had an extremely distressing experience with Jet Vacations, a company that sells travel packages.

title: Showgirls' Crawls Back As High Camp at Midnight
description: ONCE a pair of naughty Hollywood film makers, a writer and a director, blew $40 million on a peek at the world of Las Vegas lap dancers. They predicted that their gutsy drama would shake the movie rating system to its foundations. Instead, "Showgirls" merely prompted a yearning to bring back the "X," for execrable.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: WHEN THE AIR HITS YOUR BRAIN Tales of Neurosurgery. By Frank T. Vertosick Jr. Norton, $23.

title: BELIEVE IT OR NOT;The Garden State, From Alien Pea Pods to the Plague
description: Little-known facts and apocrypha from the pages of Weird New Jersey:

title: Out of the Rubble of Sarajevo, a Story of War and Survival
description: ON A BITTER COLD morning an old man slings a rope over a tree branch in one of this city's many cemeteries, ties a noose around his neck and hangs himself. As he sways, he mumbles the words of a famous Bosnian poem, asking himself what has become of his country, his language and his world.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Irvin's Status Is Still Unclear
description: The grand jury in Texas investigating an incident involving Michael Irvin, the Dallas Cowboys wide receiver, recessed on Friday night and left unanswered until at least tomorrow the question of whether it would indict Irvin on drug charges or take no action.

title: What Imus Deserved
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE/SOHO;Artist Duo's Death Mourned
description: For many Greenwich Village residents, the first sign that something was wrong came when the morning newspaper stopped arriving. Peter and Dolores Martinez had delivered papers throughout the Village for years and rarely missed a day. The job gave Mr. Martinez time to paint and sculpt, and when he had a show he would slip postcard announcements between the pages of The New York Times or The Daily News.

title: 4 Killed as Plane Hits Car
description: A light plane trying to make an emergency landing on a highway near Cape Cod smashed into a car today, killing four people.

title: CUBAN COMMUNISTS TAKE HARDER LINE
description: Warning of what it described as a campaign by the United States to "deceive, confuse and dismantle" the Cuban revolution, the Cuban Communist Party has called for strengthening ideological and economic orthodoxy and threatened "severe punishment" for those who failed to comply.

title: Schools, Principals and Image;Mayor's Budget Policies Scare Away Teachers, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools, Principals and Image;Alternative Art Space Alive and Well in Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: ART VIEW;Ambitious Miami Reaches For a Place in the Sun
description: FROM BEHIND ROSA AND Carlos de la Cruz's art-filled house on the bay in Key Biscayne, there's a sweeping view of the Miami skyline. The de la Cruzes left Cuba when Castro came to power, and they've become two of the more affluent and visible members of the vast Cuban emigre population that has transformed the city.

title: A LA CARTE;East End Enterprise Adds Another Restaurant
description: ROWDY Hall was a turn-of-the-century boardinghouse that attracted many of the first artists and writers who came to the Hamptons. Now it is the name of the newest restaurant in East Hampton, at 10 Main Street in the Parish Mews, around the corner from the cinema.

title: POLITICS: PEROT'S PARTY;Perot, Back on the Stump Again, Still Dances Around the Question
description: O.K., are you ready for this? Stand by!" said the man from Texas, hands on hips, rattling off statistics on the national debt. "Now hold on to your hat," he told an auditorium packed with college students, offering some figures on Federal tax rates today compared with 1930.

title: As Plant Closing Looms, an Enclave Splinters
description: In the mid-1980's, Mirta DeJesus and her two sisters traveled up from Puerto Rico to find work in this Catskills village's chief industry: a plant that processes 40,000 kosher chickens a day.

title: INVESTING IT;For Oxford Health, Vital Signs Are Fine
description: OXFORD HEALTH PLANS has been a big hit among patients and investors for years. In fact, the company has reached that point where success inspires suspicion: Is the prosperity justified? Can it be sustained?

title: EARNING IT;If It's Friday, This Might Be Your Flex-Time Day Off
description: ON Friday, nearly half of the 1,100 employees at Texaco's headquarters in Harrison, N.Y., did not show up for work.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Stung by Past, Knicks Play Magic for the Future
description: The last time the Knicks visited Orlando, they had a different coach and a demoralizing performance.

title: HOCKEY;The Devils' Best Won't Do Against Powerful Penguins
description: The Devils kept Mario Lemieux and Jaromir Jagr, the top two goal producers in the league, from scoring. They killed five penalties against the league's top team with the man advantage. But they could not stop Brad Lauer and Petr Nedved of the Penguins this afternoon at the Civic Arena.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Colt Faces Gun Charge
description: Colts linebacker QUENTIN CORYATT faces a felony charge of pointing a handgun at another motorist in Indianapolis. Pointing a firearm, a Class D felony, is punishable by up to three years in prison, BEVERLY PHILLIPS of the Marion County prosecutor's office said Friday.

title: County Seeking Volunteers On Day to Clean Up Parks
description: THE County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation will soon be in full swing for spring. To prepare for warm weather, the department seeks volunteers for its second annual Pitch In for Parks Day.

title: Sunday March 31, 1996: JIM CROW LOSSES;The Secret Game
description: Aubrey Stanley double-checked the laces on his sneakers and sneaked a look across the gym floor. The other team's center was a good three or four inches shorter than Big Dog, the center on Stanley's team, the Eagles. A good sign. Stanley and his teammates, dressed in their maroon jerseys, satin shorts, knee pads, striped wool socks and war-issue canvas high-tops, lined up for the tip-off.

title: ON THE STREET;Hungry Little Coat Accedes to an Encore
description: The "hungry little coat," cut close to the body, enjoyed a revival this past winter, and this is giving impetus to a renewed interest in the spring coat. Women of a new generation are wearing it like a dress or softening the man-tailored style with sweaters and lace skirts.

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Bohen, Mr. Morehouse
description: Shawn Jacqueline Bohen, a daughter of Halcyone H. Bohen of Washington and Frederick M. Bohen of New York, was married yesterday to Richard Morehouse, the son of Marget Sands of Washington and Frederic Morehouse of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Bill Wallace, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Lindsey Chapel of Emmanuel Church in Boston.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;An Ad Gets Muscled Out
description: After taking out an advertisement suggesting that Chinese take-out restaurants serve dogs and cats, Crunch Fitness, the growing gymnasium empire, apologized last week for its insensitivity to the Asian community.

title: THE GEOGRAPHY OF TASTE
description: Your paean to America's eating habits failed to mention the predilection among Middle Westerners for salads in which the only green ingredient is lime Jell-O or the Granny Smith apples in my mother-in-law's Snickers salad. That's right! Snickers salad -- a concoction of Granny Smith apples, Snickers bars and Cool Whip.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;'The Most Dangerous Game in Town'
description: IT takes a few of seconds to figure out the game of roulette. Put your money down, and if the ball lands on the number, the group of numbers, or the color you've bet on, you're paid accordingly.

title: CATCHING A MAN WITH ARROZ CON LECHE
description: In "Catching a Man With Arroz con Leche" (March 10), Julia Alvarez provided her recipe for rice pudding. More important, she acknowledged its effect on her life.

title: New Releases
description: GUIDED BY VOICES: 'UNDER THE BUSHES, UNDER THE STARS' Matador

title: THE BIRDCAGE';Exploitation All Around
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Rogers Goes to Bullpen; Thompson Is Demoted
description: The Yankees will begin the regular season with their new $20 million pitcher as a setup man in the bullpen, as New York's two baseball teams fine-tuned their rosters with the regular season rocketing into view.

title: WEDDINGS;Lisa Ann More, Anthony Bienstock
description: Lisa Ann More, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George More of Cincinnati, was married there yesterday at St. Paul Lutheran Church to Anthony Revell Gallinger Bienstock, a son of Anne Carpenter Bienstock of Wallkill, N.Y., and Peter Bienstock of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. David Lampman, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Paul Ruter, a Dutch Reformed minister, participated.

title: Adult Education;Shakespeare 101 for One
description: I always felt a nagging guilt about Shakespeare.

title: THEATER;A Blending, Delicacy and Gruffness
description: A CAMBODIAN woman writes to a homeless man who has been sent to a farm in rural New York, where he plants tomatoes, breathes "fresh organic air" and gives vent to his hostilities. "Maybe someday we can meet," the woman says, reading her words out loud.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: OLYMPICS;Torch Relay Begins
description: The symbolic flame of the 1996 Summer Games was sparked to life yesterday and began a 111-day journey to Atlanta, as HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON urged nations "to find peace and camaraderie through sport."

title: WEDDINGS;Alicia M. Alvarez, Emilio Jimenez
description: Alicia M. Alvarez and Emilio Jimenez, both lawyers in New York, were married yesterday in Dorado, P. R. Judge Rosario Villanueva of the Superior Court of Puerto Rico, in Bayamon, officiated at the Hyatt Cerromar Hotel.

title: THE NIGHT;Elevator Operator Wore Mink
description: THE elevator doors opened at the Pier 59 studios at the Chelsea Piers complex, and Calvin Klein gestured to the woman at his side. "Aren't you getting out?" he asked.

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW: AL WEST
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the east, the Yankees are picked for second.

title: Nondining AloftTo the Editor: Re "Airline Food Keeps Shrinking" (Practical Traveler, Jan. 14) and Virginia K. Henry's letter about American Airlines' Bistro service (Feb. 25). On an 8 A.M. American Airlines flight Feb. 8 from Hartford, Conn., to Austin, Tex., with a stopover in Chicago, there was neither food nor Bistro service.    Upon check-in at Hartford I was told there would be breakfast. Beverage service was available but no food, not even a pretzel, from Hartford to Chicago. The flight attendants suggested that I deplane in Chicago and purchase food for  the Austin leg. I decided to wait for a very late Mexican lunch in Austin.
description: Anyone with a medical condition should consider another airline or pack food. At the very least, we should be informed if on a flight of this length there will be no food service.

title: THE BIRDCAGE';The Message: Laugh
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BIRDCAGE';Accepting and Loving
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Indian Forces Destroy Kashmiri Muslim Shrine
description: Indian troops firing grenades and mortars today destroyed the headquarters of the separatist group that had occupied Kashmir's holiest mosque.

title: HOW WE EAT
description: You ignored the eating patterns of a growing portion of our population: those who are forced to rely on what's available in homeless shelters, soup kitchens and, too often, dumpsters behind restaurants and markets.

title: College and Money;Flexing Their Academic Muscles
description: LONG BEFORE HE SIGNED a letter of intent to play football at the University Alabama in Tuscaloosa, long before he signed a multiyear, mutli-million-dollar contract with the Kansas City Chiefs of the National Football League, Derrick Thomas had already committed to the first major deal of his life.

title: Lost in Toyland
description: STANDING on the top floor of the Toys "R" Us store in Santa Monica, Calif., far above the endless racks of Monopoly games, Barbie dolls and coloring books, Diane Summers Craig was very much alone.

title: TASTES LIKE CHICKEN
description: Molly O'Neill, you gotta be kidding ("Tastes Like Chicken," March 10)! Your recipe for stuffed chicken breast has 28 ingredients. Who's going to shop for green lentils and ginger and Serrano chili and jicama and cilantro and fresh basil and wild rice and porcini mushrooms? And where's the 1 ounce of turkey ham going to come from? Do you remember the first time you worked with phyllo dough? This recipe could become a nightmare.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;Food Plaza Is Troubled Giant
description: With more than 100 parking spaces, a 100,000-square-foot interior that dwarfed its competitors and the promise of Asian foods at wholesale prices, Korea Town Plaza, the Price Club of pan-Asian foods, seemed destined for success when it was opened in December 1994 by the Rhee brothers, Korean businessmen who owned four prospering supermarkets and wholesale establishments across the country.

title: Debacle on the High Seas
description: SHORTLY BEFORE FILMING BEGAN ON "Cutthroat Island," which quietly entered the record books as the biggest flop in Hollywood history after its release last December, a seemingly unrelated event set the pirate picture off on its race to self-destruction.

title: Right to Die;Life After Quinlan
description: TWENTY years ago today, the New Jersey Supreme Court issued its landmark 7-0 ruling in the case of Karen Ann Quinlan. The court found that the constitutional right of privacy was broad enough to encompass a person's decision to forgo life-sustaining medical treatment in certain circumstances. It also said Joseph Quinlan, her father, could make the decision on her behalf.

title: WHO IS THE BEST RESTAURATEUR IN AMERICA?
description: What might be added to Arthur Lubow's portrait of Drew Nieporent? Only a footnote on behalf of all who worked with him as part of the frenetic performance known as dinner at Tavern on the Green when he was a front-room manager. We who attended Drew's nightly training in the art of food service were treated with the same humor, warmth and grace that he bestowed upon his elite clientele. His management style created a loyal cadre of captains, waiters and busboys who followed Drew as he created new culinary fiefdoms. Even those of us who, years later, established careers outside the food-service industry still feel a Gump-like pride in our work with Drew, remembering the touch of class he engendered in us all.

title: WHO IS THE BEST RESTAURATEUR IN AMERICA?
description: Those of us who live there think of it as "the malling (mauling) of TriBeCa" ("Who Is the Best Restaurateur in America?" by Arthur Lubow, March 10). Long before Drew Nieporent came, we had our own local restaurants, which served the community quite well. (Riverrun Cafe, TriBeCa's first restaurant, opened in 1979 and still thrives today.) Nieporent and his Hollywood invasion have changed our neighborhood -- for the worse. Stretch limos spewing gas fumes line up, double park, clog our streets. No one I know who lives in TriBeCa eats at these restaurants. Instead, we suffer hordes from Jersey and the Upper East Side.

title: No Headline
description: IT IS TIME FOR SOME magic - under water, in outer space, at the circus, and in the hands of a master magician. Each of these programs takes some worthy, or at least serviceable, concept from the Gutenberg Age, or even television, and magically transforms it into something else.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Sunday March 31, 1996: BATTERS UP;Picked Off By Jet Lag
description: Major League Baseball clubs on the East Coast have a home-field advantage they don't even care about. According to an unheralded study that appeared after regular-season play last year, home teams playing teams that have just traveled eastward cross-country score 1.24 runs more than usual because their opponents are jet lagged. Big deal, you say. Except, as the authors point out, in 1991 and 1993, East Coast-West Coast races in the National League's Western division hinged on a single game, and in each case the East Coast team won.

title: FILM;Reaping a Robin Williams Whirlwind
description: THERE IS TROUBLE AT The Birdcage, a popular drag club in South Beach, Florida. Rehearsals for a new act are going badly. The surly, bubble-gum-chomping partner of Starina, the club's main draw, is giving her absolutely no support. Starina (Nathan Lane) turns to Armand Goldman, the gay proprietor and her companion of many years. Can nothing be done? Armand hurtles exasperatedly onto the stage.

title: BENEFITS
description: Donations From Dining TODAY -- More than 100 Manhattan restaurants will donate part of this evening's revenue to God's Love We Deliver, an organization that delivers meals to homebound people with AIDS. The restaurants include Elaine's, Indochine, Gramercy Tavern, Time Cafe and Republic. Information: (212) 294-8141.

title: Backtalk;For the Founding Father of Fantasy Baseball, a Reality Check
description: For years, I've been known as the guy who invented Rotisserie League Baseball," said the guy who invented Rotisserie League Baseball, Daniel Okrent. "I've loved the fame of it, but more and more, in pleasant social situations, people would come up to me and describe in numbing detail their team, and their last 50 trades.

title: State Police Settle Suite Over Retirement
description: Forty-eight former New York state troopers who were forced to retire at age 55 will share $1.2 million in back pay and benefits to settle an age-discrimination lawsuit, officials said.

title: Schools, Principals and Image;Defending Public Schools And Decrying Negativity
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;Charming Wine You Can Cut
description: It's not something most vintners would brag about. But for decades, the city's last kosher winery, Schapiro's on the Lower East Side, has used the slogan "wine you can almost cut with a knife" to advertise its Concord grape and Malaga wines.

title: DR. BROWN'S CEL-RAY TONIC
description: In the mid-1950's, Ethel Merman, who was starring in "Call Me Madam," called my office at the New York American Beverage Company (producers of Dr. Brown's) demanding to know where her blankety-blank "tonic" was ("Dr. Brown's Cel-Ray Tonic," by Bernard Cooper, March 10). I quickly sent a case to her.

title: MUSIC;Faure Finds a Champion at the Keyboard
description: GABRIEL FAURE dreamed of composing works for large orchestras. But with his busy life in Paris as organist, choirmaster and conservatory teacher (not to mention his thorny family relationships), he wrote only on summer vacations, and never did get around to it.

title: Home Health Care Is Workable and Repairable
description: To the Editor:

title: First Internet Wiretap Leads to a Suspect
description: Using evidence from the first court-ordered wiretap on a computer network, Federal officials have charged an Argentine student with hacking his way into United States military computers.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROL GARDENS;'Mayor' Who Refused to Run
description: Salvatore (Buddy) Scotto looks so much like Mayor Giuliani that strangers often mistake him for the Mayor. But Mr. Scotto seldom encounters strangers when strolling, driving, or just standing in his neighborhood. Many locals refer to Mr. Scotto as the Mayor of Carroll Gardens.

title: Minimum-Wage Debate Shows G.O.P. Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: Enrique Jorda, 84, Orchestra Director In San Francisco
description: Enrique Jorda, a Spanish-born American conductor who was music director of the San Francisco Symphony from 1954 to 1963, died on March 22 at his home in Brussels. He was 84.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the opening of a Talbots store on the Litchfield green quoted incompletely from Michel Robert, an opponent of the store. Contending that chain stores on the green benefited primarily tourists, not residents, Mr. Robert said, "Residents are not going to shop at Talbots every day or even once a week or once a month."

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW;Can These Yanks Lure Comparison Shoppers?
description: Are you looking for a sound investment for 1996? Gather your friends who live and die with the Yankees and convince them that this is a new team with a new outlook and that it would be ludicrous to make comparisons to last year. Offer them a modest sum to never mention 1995 with the shrewd provision that you can charge them a dollar every time they compare someone or something about those Yankees with these Yankees. You might collect enough singles to retire.

title: Nuclear Test-Ban Conference Falls Behind in Writing Treaty
description: An international disarmament conference meeting in Geneva to draft a treaty ending nuclear testing has fallen behind goals set by the Clinton Administration, which hoped to have the accord ready for signing this summer.

title: A Once-Defiant Polish Shipyard Is Now Sinking
description: Under the Communists, this city and its shipyard served as the fulcrum of opposition, the center of defiance. Now the city thrives, but the shipyard is on the verge of bankruptcy and stands, dispirited, as an emblem of decline.

title: CUNY, in Absorbing Budget Cuts, Doesn't Slight Liberal Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 3/ Odyssey Nutriceutical Sciences has no sales and no marketing staff. But no matter. It does have a weapon: doctors. By Kurt Eichenwald.

title: Schools, Principals and Image;Parents of Students Are Best Source on Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Life;A Lesson in Limbo
description: Paul Battles is a medievalist in his sixth year of doctoral studies at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Jennifer Marshall, a student of German literature, is in her fifth year at Yale. Both Ph.D. candidates are preparing to test the academic job market this December, at the annual meeting of the Modern Language Association, the premier job fair for their disciplines. Their days already have the variety and independence that represent much of what they prize in the academic life. They just never seem to end.

title: DINING OUT;Traditional and Innovative Portuguese
description: THERE is a pretty, new Portuguese face in Mineola. Atlantis is a modern, open, airy place warmed by hand-painted tile murals, brick-outlined archways, hanging copper pots and shining pale wood floors.

title: At Funds, They're Down But Not Out
description: MOST children are bright enough to wrinkle their noses when presented hand-me-downs. Why aren't mutual fund investors that smart?

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 31, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW;For Mets, the Future Is Now (or Soon)
description: In many respects, the Mets will be starting a new era as well as a new season when they face the St. Louis Cardinals tomorrow afternoon at Shea Stadium. Pumped up by a spring of growing optimism, it's hard to find anyone wrapped in orange and blue who doesn't believe that 1996 is just the first step in a long stretch of success for a franchise looking to revive its past glory.

title: On Social Security, Proceed With Caution
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING WITH: Edward C. Mitchell;Invesco Total Return Fund
description: EDWARD C. MITCHELL thrives on bad news.

title: Sunday March 31, 1996: TALES OUT OF SCHOOL;Let's Do Lunch Time
description: School lunches are usually about as appealing as wilted lettuce, but to hear David Price tell it, nothing could be finer than cafeteria food in Carolina. He is the Lunch Menu Man, who reads the bill of fare on telephone information lines and radio stations around the country, sounding like a Southern-fried Crazy Eddie as he rhapsodizes about broccoli-woccoli.

title: Mr. Starr's Conflicts
description: As a practical matter, the work of Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel investigating Whitewater, is too far along to start over. That means it is essential for Mr. Starr to take steps to clear up the conflicts of interest that are hanging over his investigation. Such steps are especially important since Mr. Starr has said he will make some public comment on his investigations before the election. The public has a lot riding on the quality of Mr. Starr's legal work, and he will fail in his public responsibility by clinging to the narrow reading of conflict-of-interest rules that has allowed him to split his time between his public duties and work at his law firm.

title: Datebook
description: SUMMER PROGRAMS

title: BEST SELLERS: March 31, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: ANTARCTIC NAVIGATION By Elizabeth Arthur. Ballantine, $14.

title: ART;Trees That Can Hold Up in Any Weather
description: IN the lobby gallery of the office building at 100 Pearl Street in Hartford, the exhibition "Trees" is just right as a harbinger of spring.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Rossini's Cinderella
description: Cecilia Bartoli's fairy godmother had been working overtime these days. With numerous credits including a Grammy Award and a sold-out Metropolitan Opera debut in February, th 29-year-old Italian mezzo-soprano's rise to stardom has had something of a fairy-tale quality to it. Now television viewers will get a chance to hear Ms. Bartoli in the title role in the Houston Grand Opera production of Rossini's comic opera LA CENERENTOLA on Great Performances, WEDNESDAY, at 9 P.M. on CHANNEL 13.

title: Sunday March 31, 1996: BRIGHT LIGHTS, BIG TOURIST TRAP;Mining the Strip
description: Nevada boasts a wide range of scenery, from the alpine beauty of Lake Tahoe to the seemingly endless sagebrush flats cut only by distant mountain ranges. So which gorgeous stretch of road has the state designated a scenic byway? (One hint: it has nothing to do with Area 51 or extraterrestrials.)

title: THE THEORY OF SUPERMARKETS
description: I read "The Theory of Supermarkets," by Jack Hitt (March 10), with amusement. As a city dweller accustomed to small stores and small aisles, I love walking into a Super Stop & Shop. Every summer I rent a car and visit friends in Massachusetts. Their home is 15 or 20 minutes from the nearest Super S&S, and I try to find reasons to go daily.

title: Yorkshire Terrors
description: Behind the Scenes at the Museum By Kate Atkinson. 333 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $22.95.

title: Word for Word/Ads Left, Ads Right;Hello, Classified? We're Targeting Phyllis Schlafly . . .
description: ALL you worrywarts wringing your hands over whether liberals and conservatives in this country will ever come together can just take a chill pill. They already share common ground in this respect: they are both the targets of advertisers hawking a variety of products and services, some of which are pretty schlocky. Hey, it could be something to build on.

title: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;C-Span Inventor Offers More Politics Up Close
description: Brian Lamb, a journalist whose meekness seems of biblical proportions as his television realm steadily multiplies, quietly opened a third front this week in his own revolution, the C-Span one that predates the Gingrich era.

title: Shuttle Delay Presents Crew With Problem
description: Bad weather today forced a one-day delay in the landing of the space shuttle Atlantis, but the crew almost had to make an emergency landing when there was a problem in opening the huge cargo-bay doors for the crucial cooling of shuttle equipment.

title: Deputy Commissioner Apologizes to Safir
description: A day after being ordered off the police force by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for criticizing the appointment of Howard Safir as the new Police Commissioner, John F. Timoney, the Department's First Deputy Commissioner, called Mr. Safir to apologize. The Mayor, meanwhile, said that he had no regrets about forcing Mr. Timoney out.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
description: Finding Bargains Against the Flow

title: ON CAMPUS;Union Effort by Part-Time College Teachers Bogs Down
description: A year has passed since part-time faculty members at eight state colleges took the first steps toward creating a union, but their quest for higher pay and job security could drag on indefinitely. Last month, an official in the State Attorney General's office set forth a series of reasons why the part-timers, or adjuncts, should not be allowed to bargain collectively.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-13

title: CUNY, in Absorbing Budget Cuts, Doesn't Slight Liberal Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: A VIEW FROM BERKELEY
description: When the debate over affirmative action in higher education started to simmer, the stance I took as Chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley seemed to surprise many people.

title: ROAD AND RAIL;Jilted by Toll-Weary Truckers, the Turnpike Goes A-Wooing
description: At least twice a week, Tom Chandler drives his 75-foot-long truck through New Jersey on Interstate 287, though it is not his road of choice. "Too rough," said Mr. Chandler, whose tractor-trailer is loaded sometimes with telephone books, sometimes with Chef Boyardee spaghetti. "It's hard on the tires, hard on the tie rods, hard on the shocks."

title: WEDDINGS;Claudia Califano, Charles Tortorici
description: Claudia M. Califano and Charles J. Tortorici, both assistant district attorneys in Brooklyn, were married yesterday. Msgr. James J. Dorney performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in New Brighton, S.I.

title: THE THEORY OF SUPERMARKETS
description: Hitt's article was on target, but he omitted mentioning the high price we pay for water on vegetables. At my supermarket, the greens are soaked periodically. How much do I pay for water on my heavily soaked escarole (at 99 cents a pound) and my waterlogged radicchio (at $3.99 a pound)? They don't charge that much for water in the Mojave Desert.

title: Schools, Principals and Image;Art School Defends Impact on Missing Girl
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MORALITY OF FAT
description: Molly O'Neill aptly points out that her "family members who have made dietary changes battle the same 10 pounds that [her] brother who eats pizza five nights a week and steak on the other two does" ("The Morality of Fat," March 10). Study after study has shown that our bodies naturally gravitate toward a set weight, and that diets don't work. When are Americans going to go back to just enjoying themselves and their food?

title: A Show of Artists' Pots
description: CACHEPOT CACHE or Lots of Pots, an event celebrating art and spring, will start tomorrow when terra cotta flowerpots, decorated by more than 50 Westchester artists, go on display at the Neiman Marcus store in The Westchester here.

title: World News Briefs;Bangladesh Gets A New Premier
description: A former Chief Justice was sworn in today as head of an interim Government to replace that of Prime Minister Begum Khaleda Zia, the state television reported.

title: THEATER;Germany Can't Forget a Legendary Director
description: WITHIN DAYS AFTER the revered playwright, poet, director and translator Heiner Muller died of throat cancer on Dec. 30, the question of who would succeed him as artistic director of the Berliner Ensemble, Germany's best-known theater, was being hotly debated. Behind-the-scenes lobbying was already intense by the time Muller was buried on Jan. 16 in the same cemetery where Bertolt Brecht lies.

title: Bypassed Police Official Offers Apology
description: A day after being ordered off the police force by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for criticizing the appointment of Howard Safir as the new Police Commissioner, First Deputy Police Commissioner John F. Timoney called Mr. Safir yesterday to apologize.

title: THE BIG CITY;Manhattan Projects
description: AFTER WRAPPING buildings, enveloping islands and fencing coastlines on four continents, Christo dreams of something even more outrageous. He would like to create his first piece of public art in his hometown -- which, unfortunately for his ambitions, is New York.

title: New Releases
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: 'CZECHING IN' Skoda, P.O. Box 1389, Wilmington, Del., 19899-1389

title: INSIDE
description: Kentucky Derails UMass And Will Face Syracuse

title: Home Health Care Is Workable and Repairable
description: To the Editor:

title: Party Boss's Formula: 2 Parts Fist, 1 Part Finesse
description: Sitting in his spacious office one recent morning, Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez reflected on his first days as the Bronx Democratic Party leader two years ago. The party, he recalled, worked out of a dark basement office. It was deep in debt and about to be evicted.

title: BASEBALL PREVIEW: NL CENTRAL
description: This preview was written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish. In the east, the Mets are picked for third.

title: DRIVING;Trouble Spots To Avoid
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Derby Run Is Doubtful For Winner of Gotham
description: Romano Gucci won the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct by half a length yesterday for his fourth victory in four career starts, but apparently his handlers won't capitalize on his laurels. He is considered more of a sprinter than a distance horse and doesn't figure to run in the Kentucky Derby.

title: IN BRIEF;Casinos Are Ready For Ben Franklin's New Look
description: The Federal Reserve Bank's release of a new, improved $100 bill on Monday did not catch Atlantic City's casinos off guard. Last month, the casinos held training sessions so that every employee -- cocktail waitresses, valet parking attendants, masseuses, dealers, change-makers and anyone else who might see, or dream of seeing, a C-note -- could identify the new currency.

title: March 24-30;A Long-Term Guest Settles In
description: Dr. Norman Thagard must have had a slow, and hungry, four months last year. When he lived on the Russian space station Mir as the first American to do so, his science equipment didn't arrive till the end of his stay. And, eating what he found in Mir's cupboard, he lost 17 pounds.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;Will New Law Put Brake On Sidewalk War?
description: Hellbent on speed, bicycle messengers in Manhattan have a reputation for being heedless of pedestrian-choked crosswalks, scattering hapless victims. But now that the fax and the computer modem have contributed to the decline of such messengers, many Manhattanites see a new menace: fast-food delivery cyclists, mainly for pizza joints and Chinese restaurants, barreling down sidewalks.

title: WEDDINGS;Ceri E. Hadda and Lloyd A. Gelwan
description: Ceri Elizabeth Hadda, a daughter of Annemarie Hadda of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Dr. George M. Hadda, was married last evening to Lloyd Arthur Gelwan, a son of the late Rebecca and Leo Gelwan. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel in New York.

title: March 24-30;Giving Patience a Chance
description: When Federal agents set out to make arrests at an armed encampment of tax resisters in Montana last week, they revived unpleasant memories of the deadly failures of Federal law enforcement at Waco, Tex., and Ruby Ridge, Idaho. But this time the Government is field-testing a non-confrontational approach, in a stand-off now nearly a week old.

title: A WASTED LAND -- A special report.;10 Years Later, Through Fear, Chernobyl Still Kills in Belarus
description: This has been a cheerless decade for 18-year-old Svetlana Lebenok. She never finished school because there are no longer any schools around here to finish. Her three older brothers spend their days tethered to a vodka bottle. Her parents live like invalids.

title: DINING OUT;For Italian Cuisine, Look to Larchmont
description: ALTHOUGH tables are much too closely spaced and those for four much too small and although the place is noisy and stuffy at peak moments, that is, much of the time, this renovated restaurant last occupied by La Cote D'Argent is more than worth knowing about.

title: Schools, Principals and Image;Diversity or Tokenism? Dissecting Family's Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUNG NEW JERSEY;Pass the Mackerel and Toss In Some Pasta: Grocery Clerks for a Good Cause
description: Coffee cans were flying through the air in one room, pieces of pasta in another. The coffee was headed in the right direction: into boxes of food destined for soup kitchens, homeless shelters and senior citizen centers. And the pasta -- well, it may be inevitable that a little food will fly when 180 eighth graders get together, even for a good cause.

title: Commercial Property/Subleases;Tenants Plucking Up Space Left by Downsizings
description: GROWTH in the availability of first-rate office space on a sublease basis has become a key feature of the office market in the metropolitan region, the result of corporate restructurings, acquisitions or consolidations. And brokers say that tenants are taking advantage of it.

title: Natalie Holland Philanthropist, 89
description: Natalie Holland, who supported a number of philanthropic and other institutions, died on Monday at her winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 89 and lived on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 25 about a journey along the Nile misstated the location of the Temple of Isis. A reader's letter dated Feb. 26 points out that it is on the island of Philae, not at Kom Ombo. The correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

title: ART;Sculptured Ceramic Dresses Animated by Invisible Bodies
description: ON view at the Hopper House Art Center in Nyack is a memorable blend of ceramic sculpture by Jackie Shatz, and constructions, by Tina Martin, and at the Allen Sheppard Gallery in Piermont is an equally memorable solo by the landscapist Peter Schroth. The bad news is that both shows close Thursday.

title: WEDDINGS;Alejandra Downey and S.T. Kagel Jr.
description: Alejandra Beatriz Downey, the daughter of Beatriz G. Downey of Southport, Conn., and the late Kevin Peter Downey Sr., was married yesterday to Stuart Todd Kagel Jr., the son of Anne Fowler of Columbia, S.C., and Mr. Kagel of Brooklyn. Msgr. Peter Cullen performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Queens Old-Timers Uneasy As Asian Influence Grows
description: Ethel Chen, considering a run for the New York City Council, sat in her office above the teeming Asian hub of Flushing, counting the Chous, Hsiehs and Lins on the voter rolls. Blocks away, Chun Soo Pyun, a potential candidate for the same seat, was tallying the Kims, Choys and Rhees.

title: March 24-30;Return of a Recording Artist
description: Nixon fans! Let down by Oliver Stone's historical drama? Take heart: Nixon's coming back, in glorious monaural.

title: The Common Denominator Is Dance, Ballet to Jazz
description: CAN I have a little attitude here?" asked the dance instructor, Leon Davis.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE/SOHO;Historically Inaccurate Trees
description: While a post-equinox snowstorm was brewing, tree-loving SoHo residents, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern and some local politicians gathered on Broome Street to celebrate the "Greening of SoHo," a plan calling for hundreds of trees on SoHo's streets. According to the plan, about 70 trees and shrubs will be planted in the ground in the coming months, courtesy of the Parks Department, and many hundreds more will grow in planters, financed and maintained privately.

title: Swiss Cow Disease on Rise
description: Four new cases of mad cow disease have been reported in Switzerland in March, pushing the number recorded this year to 20, the Swiss Federal Veterinary Office said today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page map on March 10 with an article about house sales in New York City misplaced the Queens community of Sunnyside. It is west, not southeast, of Woodside.

title: GOLD RUSH FOR COLLEGES IN ATLANTA
description: PREPARATIONS FOR the Summer Olympics here have represented a multifaceted bonanza for some of the city's many colleges. Everything from new athletic facilities and advanced technology to research projects and a sense of renewal have been the result. Many long-planned projects have been speeded up - sometimes by decades. But reaching the finish line has brought a few lessons in championship hurdle-jumping as some institutions scrambled to secure the public and private financing by needed. And, along the way, what has been good fro the Olympics and for the colleges has not always been seen as good for some touched by the changes.

title: TELEVISION;Been There, Seen That
description: AS YOU WATCH TELEVISION these days, you may feel more and more as if you're seeing double. Don't adjust your set, though. The fact is that in the middle of the regular television season you are seeing double, or even triple. Repeats, once mainly relegated to summer, are now sprinkled heavily in prime time from December through April. These days, when you tune in your favorite show, you may well find yourself saying: "Oh, no! This is the one about the cross-dresser!"

title: When Bomb Threats Are Close to Home
description: THE attack on the Federal Building in Oklahoma City and the bombing of the World Trade Center were hard-hitting messages to Americans that bomb attacks don't just happen in Beirut, London and Sarajevo. The Westchester County Bomb Squad never doubted it, because they have seen it happen in Larchmont, Eastchester and Yorktown Heights.

title: Germans Investigate Spying for Moscow
description: Prosecutors have begun an investigation of 50 Germans suspected of spying for the Soviet K.G.B. and its successor, the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service, Der Spiegel magazine said today.

title: A Picture Helps a Son to Play On
description: IT is there, in his locker, the big reason for the breakthrough season Otis Hill of White Plains has been having. That season is a big reason that unheralded Syracuse University has still been playing basketball deep into March.

title: THEATER;A Blend of Opposites: Delicacy and Gruffness
description: A CAMBODIAN woman writes to a homeless man who has been sent to a farm in rural New York, where he plants tomatoes, breathes "fresh organic air" and gives vent to his hostilities. "Maybe someday we can meet," the woman says, reading her words out loud.

title: Making Stiff Upper Lips Quiver
description: ON the corner of a tree-lined street in North London's Belsize Park is the spacious red-brick Victorian home of Susie Orbach. It's a family neighborhood; bicycles stand propped up in the entryway next to two pair of bright blue children's Wellingtons. Two flights up, off a small waiting area, is the consulting room, a large, white, cheery space that seems bathed in soft light even on a drizzly March day in London. A bunch of yellow daffodils stands on a table, not far from a coffeepot. Two black leather chairs sit across from each other; a couch lines the opposite wall.

title: WEDDINGS;Ilene H. Stern, David Goldson
description: Ilene Hope Stern, a daughter of Sandra Levin of Massapequa Park, L.I., and a stepdaughter of Herbert Levin, was married last evening to David Goldson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Goldson of Lakehurst, N.J. Rabbi Allen Lucas performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: EARNING IT;In a Family Business, the Beat Goes On
description: IT is no secret when the secret formula is in use in the melt room of the Avedis Zildjian cymbal factory here. Men scurry. A red light flashes. A blue overhead gate comes down to keep out the inquisitive.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Spoleto Festival U.S.A. Announces Its Program
description: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. plans to open its 20th-anniversary season on May 24 with the Ballet du Rhin's production of "La Fille Mal Gardee," an 18th-century work that was reconstructed by the Baroque dance expert Ivo Cramer and designed by the French film maker Dominique Delouche. The Charleston, S.C., festival, which runs to June 9, will feature 45 classical, dance, jazz, opera and theater programs, including a 20th-century music series and "Footprints in the Garden," a series focusing on world dance traditions.

title: FOOD;Asparagus Pairs Well With the Holidays
description: PASSOVER and Easter closely coincide this year, and asparagus, a perennial springtime treasure, suits both holidays.

title: Meeting Towns Halfway On Cellular Phone Sites
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Wendy Manshel, Michael Weinman
description: Wendy Ellen Manshel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Manshel of New Orleans, was married last evening to Michael Louis Weinman, the son of Zoe Van Wyck deRopp of New York and Irving Weinman of Key West, Fla. Rabbi David Goldstein performed the ceremony at the Hotel Inter-Continental in New Orleans.

title: Clinton Calls for Minimum Wage Increase
description: President Clinton renewed his call for an increase in the hourly minimum wage today, combining it with a modest bit of Congress-bashing.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Rabbits Redux
description: Alicia Ezpeleta has written that rare rabbit book for adults that does not feature the words "with brown gravy" anywhere. Instead, she has produced a delightful compendium of lagomorph lore, profusely illustrated with reproductions of artworks and artifacts culled from a vast array of world cultures -- from ancient Egyptian hieroglyphics to 20th-century American cartoon characters. "Rabbits have represented almost every emotion, ideal, foible and personality trait known to humanity," she writes in RABBITS EVERYWHERE (Abrams, $24.95), and she goes on to explore the rabbit's role as a symbol for such things as sexuality, fertility, purity, luck and cunning in various societies. The text not only touches on the best known of the literary long-ears -- the Easter Bunny, Peter Rabbit, the March Hare, Br'er Rabbit -- but delves into the lives of the less publicized as well, including the heroic hares of both Buddhist and African fables. Despite the rabbit's affectionate place in the hearts of many, Ms. Ezpeleta, an interior designer, reveals that a few cultures weren't very fond of them: the Vikings lumped them in the same category as sea monsters, and the ancient Celts assumed that rabbits purposely lived underground because of their affiliation with darker powers. The giant demon-bunny absconding with a young maiden carved into a portal of the Chartres Cathedral is a little unsettling compared with the familiar images of Bugs and Thumper, and the author even manages to link similar medieval notions of evil to the role of killer rabbit in the movie "Monty Python and the Holy Grail." Ms. Ezpeleta takes a grand hop through rabbit history, noting along the way that the same creatures used to represent immortality and rebirth in the old Chinese, Greek and Roman legends can be seen even today fulfilling the same role in television's Energizer Bunny commercials. J. D. BIERSDORFER

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: TIMES SQUARE A Week of Storytelling From the Global Village

title: Nun's Art Depicts Irish Famine
description: MOST of the pictures in the house here where Sister Anne Therese Dillen, an Ursuline nun, lives with three other nuns were painted by Sister Anne. The wall decorations include religious wood carvings, bright boat scenes, two portraits of the late composer-conductor Leonard Bernstein and some scenes of rural Ireland. But on a rare sunny day in early March, her concerns were about 31 other paintings. "Or is it 30?" she wondered out loud. She explained, "I haven't seen the exhibit for four years."

title: Blackboard;S.A.T. Studies in a Flash of Cards
description: Flashcards are tried and true means of instructing elementary school students. Now, a Los Angeles company is betting they will become a popular way to study for the Scholastic Assessment Test.

title: QUICK BITE;Sandwiches So Big They Bet You Can't Eat One
description: If you think the sandwiches at Manhattan's Carnegie Deli are large, then you probably haven't been to Harold's New York Deli in Parsippany. It is not for the timid, the fat-gram counters, the lower-your-cholestorol advocates, the dieters or the faint of heart.

title: GOLF;Tolles Survives Rain and Weather
description: It should have all been too much for Tommy Tolles. First, there was the rain, cascading from the dark skies. And there were the charges from the veteran players, sending shock waves all across The Players Championship at Sawgrass, electrifying rounds of 64 from Phil Mickelson and 65 from Ernie Els and 66 from Colin Montgomerie.

title: WEDDINGS;Suna Chang and Michael R. Potenza
description: Suna Chang, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Soo Ill Chang of Fresno, Calif., was married last evening to Michael Robb Potenza, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Potenza of Piscataway, N.J. The Rev. L. Denver Hart, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: WHAT I'VE LEARNED FROM TOAST
description: So much about toast, and not a word about that great toaster of the 1940's, the Toast-O-Lator ("What I've Learned From Toast," by Alan Burdick, March 10). A flip of the Bakelite switch called the motor to life. A slice of bread was inserted at one end onto a moving track. As it made its way down the gantlet, the toast-in-progress could be viewed through a porthole (to fine-tune its speed). Perfect toast dropped out the far end at a constant, assembly-line pace and consistency.

title: Quiz
description: Athletes from 197 nations around the globe will gather in Atlanta this summer to participate in the centennial of the modern Olympic Games. Test your knowledge of some of the people and events that have made Olympic history since 1896, when 13 nations competed for medals. To win a gold of your own, answer 16 correctly; a silver, 14; a bronze, 12. Good luck!

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;What Makes a Borough Bard?
description: The job requirements for Poet Laureate of the Borough of Brooklyn are fairly simple: you have to be a published poet recognized by your peers, and you have to have some connection to Kings County. Preferably, you call it home.

title: A Job-Training Bill Is Being Attacked by Conservatives
description: Legislation to streamline Federal job-training programs, praised by President Clinton and conservative Republicans as a vital step in an era of layoffs and downsizing, is bogged down in Congress and threatened by attacks from very conservative groups.

title: Crime and Punishment
description: GUILTY The Collapse of Criminal Justice. By Harold J. Rothwax. 238 pp. New York: Random House. $23.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Pound Ridge, N.Y.;Affluent, Rural and Very, Very Private
description: ZOE CALDWELL, the actress, and her husband, Robert Whitehead, the theatrical producer, built a saltbox house in Pound Ridge 26 years ago.

title: Schools, Principals and Image;Deafening Noise in Ears, She Sides With Cheever
description: To the Editor:
